column2: The Board of Health, finding some difficulty obtaining full reports of the prevailing disease from the physicians of the city, have determined to report the interments for each day. The public may rely implicitly on the published reports, as the Board will receive full returns from all the undertakers of the city.

NEW-YORK MEDICAL COLLEGE.--The Churchman heartily congratulates the friends of this institution on the accession of Dr. PARKER to the Professorship of Physiology and Pathology. The fact is thus announced in the New-Hampshire Statesman of the 20th inst:

Not that it is at all possible to satisfy everybody that the prevailing sentiment of the (Cubans is bitter discontent Not that we can make the fact a bit more perspicuous that when LOPEZ landed none rose up. unarmed and impotent as they were, to aid him.

A CELEBRATED STKPPING-STONE.-While workmen were engaged on Friday. in taking up the steppingstone in front of the mansion of the late CORNELIVS VAN VORST, in Wayl e-street, it was found, upon turning over the stepping stone, that it was the pedestal on which stood the equestrian statue of GORGE IIl , which formerly stood in Bowling Green, New-York.

We purpose in this article to contrast the promises made in the proclamation of GORSTSCHAKOFF to the inhabitants of the Principalities, with the manner in which those promises have been since fulfilled by the agents and generals of NICHOLAS. "We come among you," says that proclamation, "neither with the projects of conquest, nor with the intention to modify the institutions under which you live, or the political position which solemn treaties have guaranteed to you."

Broadway, cor. Reads-st Agricultural Warehouse. R. L. ALLEN, (Late A. B. Allen Co.) 189 191 Wate Archltects.

By the arrival at Salem yesterday of the bark Edward Koppich, we have Montevideo dates to July 11, and also later accounts from Buenos Avres. General PINTO, President of the Chamber of Representatives, and Provisional Governor of the Province, died at Buenos Ayres June 28, and was buried with great pomp on the 30th; the Foreign Ministers and Naval officers being present.

The City has been blessed with health through the week. The physicians who are old and rich enough to speak unhesitatingly, affirm that there is very little sickness prevalent. The story is less flattering as we descend to the youngest and most needy members of the profession.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. The comet now visible in the western sky, is the one whose discovery in Gottingen, in June last, was duly announced in the columns of the TIMES. It will continue to increase in brilliancy for about a week, and then, rapidly approaching the sun, be soon lost in his rays.

The reopening of two or three of the City Churches took place yesterday. Among them were Dr. CHEEVER'S, Broadway and Fifteenth-street; Mr. BURCHARD'S, in West Thirteenth-street; and the Green-street Methodist. We give sketches of the opening discourses. We are pleased to learn that there is a gradual improvement in the condition of Rev. Mr. BURCHARD.

Lieut. McGUIRE, of Washington has been appointed Mail Agent between New-York an California. Mr. WISE's visit to Washington is strictly private and professional, though his name is mentioned in connection with France. A Maine man has been appointed Charge to Bolivia, vice WOODBURY, declined.

NIBLO'S SALOON.---On Saturday evening this room was handsomely filled with an audience attracted by the announcement of a debut. The interest of such an event was enhanced by the circumstance of the debutante being a lady. Madame the Baroness JULIE DE BERG, a pupil of LIsTZ and THALBERG, was, in mere sound, an attractive announcement, and, consequently, with the other considerations, drew a brilliant audience.

The ceremony of breaking ground on the Black River and Utica Railroad took place yesterday, in this city. A large assemblage of people was present, notwithstanding the incessant rain in the morning; and the proceedings throughout were marked with the right spirit.

The Crystal Palace is certainly rich in modern effigies. If Madame TUSSAUD were alive, one promenade round the American Department would positively kill her with envy. Her celebrated collection of wax figures would sink into insignificance before the gorgeous array of allegorical and other groups, which in magnificent attire decorate this portion of the building.

The mails and telegraphic dispatches for several days furnish us with data by which we arrive at the fact, that the deaths in New-Orleans for the week ending Aug. 24, reached the enormous figure of eighteen hundred and fiftv-eight, or an average of 265 per day. Estimating the population reInaining in the city at 50,000, this makes about one death weekly out of every twenty even.

REPLY OF DR. FOOTE 10 MR. WEED. From the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser. In his quotation from my card, published in this paper last week, Mr. WEED finds it convenient to omit that I said " the motion to take a recess was warmly and successfully resisted " This, and this only, is proved by the long citation from the Philadelphia North Americatt. The scene was, as Mr. WEED says, violent and exciting.

Hundreds of persons visited the pier foot of Warren street on Saturday morning, to see the burned hull of the Cherokee. To prevent confusion, the gate at the pier was closed, and admittance given only to such as had business. At 3 o'clock in the morning, the flames were got under, and the stern had settled down with about 18 feet water in the hold; the forward part was not so far under water.

Portage forever! I am away at last, but could scarcely give it up. Portage must become a favorite place of Summer resort. Niagara, and Saratoga, and Cape May, and Schooley's Mountain, are all too humanized. At Portage, we have nature unadorned; " when unadorned, adorned the most." The lovers of the wonderful in art will flock thither to behold the bridge;

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: At 5 o'clock, A. M., we have just hoisted anchor, and are now on our way out of the harbor, for New-York. I send a list of officers: Commodore--JOHN THOS. NEWTON: Commander, James T Gerry Lieut. Win. W. Bleecker; Flag Lieut. Richard L.Love;

New-Orleans papers of Sunday last are received. The mortality of the week is reported at 1,534--of which 1,365 were from Yellow Fever. The total deaths by the fever, for three weeks, was 3.669. A deputation of citizens -from Baton Rouge had arrived to assist in nursing the patients.

Mr. Dix. it is now universally understood, has been laid on the Sub-Treasury shelf, and is to be left there; the President halving finally abandoned his original well-known intention to confer the French mission upon him. The President does not waver in the high opinion he has ever entertained for Sir. Dix, nor has his confidence in that gentleman's "nationality," and faithful adherence to the Baltimore Platform, been shaken in the least;

On Saturday evening a new phase of the House-Painters' movement was developed The Journeymen have, thus far had it all their own way; but the "Bosses" have finally taken their own stand--declaring that they will pay who more than fourteen shillings per day The Jourusymen, on the other hand, intimate their determination to stand out for the full rate of $2.

The weather continues between wind and rain, with the thermometer at 84[degrees]. Everything is dull, and news very scarce. The Fall trade commenced a few weeks earlier than usual this year, but the business has not been as large as was at first anticipated.

SIR: A leading article appears in the columns of Ichabod to-day, of such consummate bad taste, worse feeling, and superlative illogical stupidity, that, although I have been lately inclined to leave the offender to the tender mercies of the more legitimate invective to be found almost daily in your paper, I cannot resist the impulse of writing on the present occasion.

As the number of these vehicles is rapidly increasilng, in a short timeit will be quite is perilous for pedestrians to reach the boat as to cross Broadway at Fulton-street. All this can be avoided by a little regulatiol. As the Newark stages go out by Grand-strect, and

At the opening of the Court on Saturday morning, Judge WILLARD offered an order that at the hour of recess, the Court adjourn until Monday morning, at 11 o'clock, which was adopted. The examination of CHARLES COOK was then resumed by Mr. HASTINGS, on the part of the Managers-and concluded.

In detailing the incidents of a single day's experience at the House of Industry, it will be necessary entirely to omit the regular routine of religious exercises, work, school, meals, and all such incidents as are common to all days, and present only such as are occasional, or, in the very necessity of the case, can happen at no precise hour, and by no definite rule.

The American Party of the Eleventh Ward held an adjourned meeting in Manhattan Hall, Fourth-street, last evening, Mr. JOHN B. CONCKLIN in the Chair. The attendance was small, presenting, both in numbers and enthusiasm, a great contrast to the previous meeting. The Secretary read the minutes of last meeting, which were approved.

We have just examined, at the office of the Mexican Mail Company, a work recently published by General ALMONTE, Mexican Minister at Washington. The work is a duodecimo of 600 pages, in Spanish, and presents, in a condensed and tabular form, a vast deal of information respecting the Mexican Republic--more, perhaps, than can be obtained from any other source.

The following list of appointments, nearly all which I have previously announced, will be officially published in to-morrow's Union. ROBERT J. WALKER, of Mississippi, Commissioner to China; R. AUGUSTUS IRVING, Connecticut, Secretary of Legation to Russia; DAVID L. GREGO, Illinois, Commissioner to the Kingdom of Hawaii; PHILO WHITE, Wisconsin, Charge d'Affaires to Eucador;

The United States steamship Princeton arrived here on Saturday night, at 9 o'clock, after grounding twice in sight of the Light-house, while in charge of a branch pilot. She left the Gut of Canso on Saturday morning, about 6 AM. The day was beautiful, and the Princeton was making more miles understeam than ever before. About midday the alarm of fire was

OVERBOARD.--A man residing in Union-avenue, employed in a store in New-street, New-York. while returning home by the Peck-slip ferry, at a late hour on Saturday night, walked off of the boat into the slip, on the Williamsburg side, in consequence of the darkness of the bridge and slip. He was rescued with much difficulty, in a very exhausted condition The lights at present used on the bridge are totaly unfit to answer the purpose designed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The subject involved in the heading of this article, is an important one in many respects ; and as you have recently admitted communications touching the question, I would beg the favor of making a few suggestions bearing upon the matter.

At Rye, Westchester Uo , N. Y., suddenly, on the 29th inst, GEORGE M., twin-child of Alanson F. and Sarah M. Briggs, aged 2 years and 8 months. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral services, from the house of the parets, No 139 Henry-st, this day, (30th,) at 2 o'clock, P. M. On Monday morning, Aug 29, MARIA S. CAMPBELL, wife of Judge William W. Campbell. aged 38 years.

The U. S. Mail steamer Georgia, THOS. A. BUDD, Commander, arrived last evening. She brings no later dates from California than those received by the Northern Light. She brings the mails to Aug. 1. She left Aspinwall Aug. 19, at 10 P. M. Panama dates are to the 18th. There was nothing of interest transpiring on the Isthmus. The general health is better this Summer

The event of the season has come off. The immaculate JULLIE, wields his baton in Castle Garden. The monster Ophicleide, the monster drums, anti all the other delightful monstrosities of the monster concerts, are among us, and now on successive evenings we may listen to an aggregate of good music hitherto unknown to our amateurs.

The Atlantic's news had no effect on the Cotton market. Which has continued dull, and the better qualities are a shade lower, while the lever qualities have declined 1-16th to 1/2d. The sales of the week were 39,000 bales, of which 3 680 were to speculators. and 5.820 to exporiers The sales of Friday were 5,000 bales. the market showing some improvement at the close.

The weather is delightful, the thermometer at 2 o'clock, at the Bulletin office, being at 79[degrees]. By the Health Report I see we had four deaths by yellow fever last week. This is the first time the yellow fever has been officially reported, though it has been with us for some time. The city was never more healthy than at present, and all fears of being, visited with an epidemic have vanished.

It seems sometimes that even holidays have their desagremens. We saw a couple the other day, at the Palace, who had evidently come out to make a day of it. The male biped was clad in his go-tomeeting coat; a white waistcoat, washed into a painful state of cleanliness; tight shoes, and a new hat. His dame was equally magnificent.

Come one-come all, say I. Our "Vanity Fair" is somewhat crowded, it is true, but a few eligible stalls are still in reserve, and visitors will never be called to exclaim, with the Rev. Mr. Stiggins, against the " obduracy" of those who won't permit their " particular vaniqy to be sold in this establishment."

Great excitement was occasioned at the Cataract House yesterday, by the arrest by DeputyMarshal TYLER, of PATRICK SNEED, alias Joseph Watson, a colored waiter at that house, who is accused of being the murderer of JAMES E. JONES, of Savannah. on 6th July, 1819.
Ye wha direct the Exhibition, An' manage a' things wi precision, Mock na a simple bard's petition, Wha' pouch is bare, An' yet wad like to feast his vision On yon big "Fair."

LATEST FROM MEXICO--A dispatch dated New-Orleans, Aug. 26, says: The steamer Texas arrived here last night, with Vera Cruz dates to the 21st inst., City of Mexico to the 17th, and San Francisco, California, to the 1st. The Intelligence from the latter place was anticipated by the arrival of the Northern Light at NewYork.

ARREST OF A BOSTON THIEF.--A man named TIMOTHY LEARY, alias LE ROY, was arrested in a house in Flushing-avenue, a few days since, with others, on suspicion of passing' counterfeit money. Upon the arrest being made, he was identified as a person who, some two years' since, robbed a broker's office in Milk street, Boston, of upward of $2,000, which he accomplished by playing the grab game

John B. Swaze, a youth of about 18 years of age, and mail-carrier on the route from Indianapolis to Montezuma, has been arrested on a charge of robbing the mail. Letters which had been abstracted from the mail ten days previously were found in his possession. The accused was brought

By the arrival of the Europa at Halitax, we are in possession of one week's later news from Europe. The Eastern question, when the Elutrpa left, remained as per previous advices. No change had taken place since the announcement already received, that the Porte accepts, without modification, the note prepared hy the four Powers, and acceded to by the Czar.

The Royal Mail steamship Europa, Capt. SHANNON, from Liverpool on the 20th inst., arrived at her wharf here, at 9 1/2 o'clock this evening. She brings 206 passengers for Boston. The Collin's steamship Atlantic, from New-York on the 6th August, arrived out at Liverpool, at noon on Wednesday the 17th.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: The first cause for complaint occurred in the early part of July, when the train from Morristown was detained at the bridge across the Hackensack river, for over an hour, from the fact that we were furnished with a locomotive of the ' no go " order, which was unable to draw the train over the curve, just before you reach the bridge. Cause No.

Col. BENTON is indulging an unamiable spirit towards the Administration. A gentleman asked him if he often visited the White House. He replied, with Bentoman emphasis, "No, Sir; no, Sir; I never go this Buzzard's roost."

Our correspondent is a little late with his discovery of the Cornet, but his letter came by mail from Long Island, which will sufficiently account for the delay. It will be remembered that the Department pay some $6,000 a year for running a horse-express down to the East End, to bring such pleasant effusions as the following to hand some week or two after they are written.

EXCURSION OF TIIE CONTINENTAL GUARD.The excursion of the Continental Guard, of Jersey City, took place yesterday, and was entirely the largest, probably the most agreeable one of the season. The steamboat Hero, and the barge Mellon were chartered for their use. They went to St Ronan's Well. Their number was estimated at I 000 at least; and their net profits will not fall short of $250. Everything passed off agreeably, and without accident.

The Vigilance Committee, on Saturday last, arrested the Mayor of this city--Hon. CHARLES WILSON-for murder on the 9th of June last, duriug the GAVAZZI riot. He was held to bail in the sum of $8,000 to appear on the 14th October next to answer at the Criminal Court of Queen's Bench.

The harbor of Quebec is doubtless one the finest on the continent. There is ample room for many miles of wharves, and space to float an Immense quantity of timber, which is its great stagle. The whole British navy might ride here in safety, sheltered from northeasters by the Isle of Orleans; yet at a distance of seven hundred miles, river and gulf, from the open Atlantis.

Brevet-Captain HACHALIAH BROWN, First Lieutenant of the 3d Regiment of Artillery, died at Jefferson Barracks, Missouri, on the 23d, of bilious fever, in the thirty-first year of his age. He graduated at the Military Academy in 1842, and entered the service as a Brevet Second Lieutenant in the 4th Regiment of Artillery, in, which regiment he continued to serve until March, 1845, when he was transferred, by promotion, to the 3d Artillery.

Uncle Sam pays every year, for having his mails carried around from New-York to San Francisco and Oregon, something like six hundred and fifty thousand dollars, or about one-fourth as much as the whole inland mail transportation of the States and Territories.

FIRE AT SAG. HARBOR.-The loss by the burning of the LigoneC Oil-Cloth Factory, at Sag Harbor, Long Island, on the 21st, was not less than $3,000. The amount of insurance was $1,400. The property was owned by JAMES G LEONARD, Esq., and the estate by E. S. LATIIAM, deceased, of that village. Arrangements were just being made

THE TOMB OF MR. WEBSTER.--A marble black has been placed in front of Mr. WEBSTER'S Tomb, at Marshfield--similar to those which he erected in memory of his wife, son and daughters--which bears the following inscription: "DANIEL WEBSTER, Born Jan. 18, 1782, Died Oct 24, 1852 Lord, I believe; help thou my unbelief.

The sum of $5,000 has been contributed in this city in aid of the sufferers at New-Orleans, and transmitted to the Howard Association. Collections are still being made, and the sum will probably reach $8,000.

The projected Railroad through the streets of this city, for which some of our citizens have got a charter, is not very popular. At a hearing before the Mayor and Aldermen, on Thursday, some NewYorkers were examined in favor of it, and Mr. CHOATE spoke against it, on behalf of the oppugners, showing the informalities and crudities of the business, and the difficulties in the way of carrying...

There was, yesterday, considerable excitement produced in Cincinnati, by the trial, before Judge FLINN, of another Slave case. It seems that a gentleman from Mississippi having purchased three slaves in the State of Virginia, delivered them into the hands of an agent, to be removed to his plantation in Mississippi. The agent took passage on a steamboat at...

A terrible collision took place last night on the Schenectady and Saratoga Railroad, fourteen miles from this place. DANIEL OSTRANDER, fireman, was nearly killed. A gentleman from NewHampshire was badly injured, and others were more or less injured.

In the United States Circuit Court, before Judge NELSON, the argument in the case of HOWARD Co., of Buffalo, against FORBUSH Co., for violation of letters patent for KETCHUM'S mowing and reaping machine, has just been concluded. H.V. SOPER, of Batavia, solicitor; W.P.N. FITZGERALD, of Washington, GEORGE GIFFORD, of New-York, counsel for complainants; Messrs. ROGERS and BOWEN, of Buffalo, counsel for defendants.

Have you enough to do, good friend! Then do it, and be thankful that you have. We stand at the opening of an avenue through which people pour their wants upon the world, and we know something of what "wants" are. Some want money. And such can certainly get it, by paying for it. Some want land; that, money will always buy.
From the London papers received by the last steamer, we compile the following particulars of the existing state of the Russian Empire.

We have seen it!--the egg within an egg-- a sphere within a sphere--even as in this blessed Union each State is surrounded, enclosed, circumvented, and protected within another great State, of which it is a part. We saw it yesterday--to wit, an egg, the size of a small goose-egg--that is to say, about the length of your pocket pencil, about the thickness of your inkstand.

It will be recollected that, on Friday, the 18th inst., a brutal attack upon, and robbery of, a peddler took place on the road, some eight miles from Coxsackie. Efforts have since been constantly made to arrest the perpetrator, and we are glad to state that they have succeeded.

The following important circular, just issued by the Secretary of the Treasury, will be found of much interest and importance to superior officers of the Revenues, and to merchants and importers generally. It is a compendium of Tariff Law on several important points, and, so far, will be found a complete and revised guide to the transaction of Custom House business:

Did you ever look into one of those mysterious drawers, which ladies spend so much time in filling and arranging, and open and shut with so much importance; looking all the while as if they had just been appointed maid of honor to the Princess royal? This I was permitted to do not long ago, and I did not pay anything for the sight; but I believe I am one of the privileged ones.

ANOTHER SHOOTING AFFAIR.--A man named JOHN WARD was yesterday brought before Justice BLACKLEY, by officer CAIN, on a charge of shooting MICHAEL LEE. A complaint was also made against LEE for breaking the skull of Mrs. WARD with a shovel. The parties were both locked up for examination. The two persons under arrest occupy adjoining shanties at Red Hook Point.

A Parliamentary Commission has presented its return with regard to the condition of the Slave-Trade. So far as the Atlantic's waters are concerned, the evil is quite extirpated--Cuba constituting the single exception. To Cuba, therefore, the report devotes more than ordinary attention. To eradicate that sole plague-spot is the object of the...

The Boston Medical Journal entered upon its 49th volume, on the 3d of August. The Editor says that when he started it, he waited on every practitioner in Boston, soliciting subscriptions stating that it was to be published weekly. One subscriber only was procured in that city. All thought the old New-England Quarterly occupied all the ground.

FATAL ACCIDENT ON THE HARLEM RAILROAD.-- A fatal accident occurred on the Harlem Railroad on Monday evening. As the 9 o'clock up train was approaching the flag-station, at One Hundred and Fifteenthstreet, a man was discovered lying on the track, but was not discovered in season to reverse the engine, and the entire train passed over him, killing him instantly. The head was severed from the body, an arm cut off...
The total number of interments in this city, during the past week, were 1,628, of which 1,442 were from yellow fever.

The arrival of the Georgia put us in possession of our usual files from Australia. The papers are dated down to the 16th of May. The general news is not of much importance. The commercial intelligence is worthy of attention. By a return from the convict department, it appears that 1,721 convicts arrived in the colony of North South Wales, from the 30th of June, 1852, to the 31st of January, 1853.
The United States Mail steamship James Adger, Capt. JOHN DICKINSON, from New-York, arrived here at 3 o'clock this (Monday) afternoon.

It seems almost impossible to impress upon many persons having correspondence with Europe the regulations of our foreign postal system. They will not learn that, in certain cases, if they attempt to prepay their postage, and fail, by carelessness, to pay all that is due, their letters are necessarily charged with the full postage, and are not credited with the proportion actually offered...

The Boston Post is not an organ. It is not solemn enough to be a Church organ, and nobody ever outraged his own reputation by supposing or hinting that it could be a handorgan; a thing to be wound up, and a certain tune to be ground out of it. It is rather like some nobler instrument, on whose keys the fingers of its worthy and facetious editor run...

Yesterday was a day of excitement at Saratoga. The trotting-match between "Taconey" and "Flora Temple," and the Grand Ball at the United States, were the attractive features. The day was very fine. Although the sun shone bright as only an August sun can shine, the atmosphere was not oppressive, but softened around me like a serene dream.

Moran vs. Moran.--In re-application for Divorce, and the application for Martin Van Hovenburg, Attorney to the Wife, to show cause why he should not be stricken off the rolls for malpractice--The case was resumed at 12 o'clock yesterday morning.

The statement in a New-York paper that Secretary MARCY had replied to Lord JOHN'S recently published letter to CRAMPTON, relative to the refusal of the United States to become a party to the Tripartite Convention, guaranteeing Spanish possession of Cuba, is erroneous. The letter was not addressed to MARCY, therefore it neither required or admitted of an answer from him.

It is settled at last that England is to have a decimal coinage. A Parliamentary Committee has been persuaded to report in favor of the change, with so strong a recommendation that it be effected forthwith, that we may confidently look to the next session for the transmutation of the report into an act. It is no great wonder that the measure has not...

The market had been flat all the week, with prices irregular and tending slightly downward in the better qualities, while the common kinds of American had given way...

THE HOUSE-PAINTERS' STRIKE.--Another meeting of the employers was held last night, but the reporters for the press were not admitted. The prevailing impression, however, among the journeymen, was that they had not yielded anything. At the meeting of the latter, held as usual at Convention Hall, Mr. COWTON presided. The principal business of the evening consisted of ar rangements for the meeting at Metropolitan Hall to night.

The weather is delightful. Every agreeable person wears a smile--that is, with the exception of a number of corpulent policemen, who have been chasing other people's dogs all over the city. I understand they succeeded in capturing fifty-four to-day. If they were only so expert in catching rogues, what an honest and quiet city we should have, in the course of a year or two.

The demand for GOLD for shipment per Harbinger, was brisk up till Friday, when it ceased, and the price immediately fell from 76s. 9d. to 76s.

Our politicians, or at least the few active ones left, are now busy with the Conventions for nominating city and county officers. The Whigs have selected a good Assemblyaticket for the city proper, and instructed their representatives to vote for a consolidation of the city and districts under one Municipal Government.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: You will remember, undoubtedly, that a few years ago the remark went the round of the papers, that the 4th of March had been selected as the day for inaugurating the President of the United States, because it would never fall upon a Sunday at the commencement of the Presidential term.

The number of interments for the twenty four hours ending this morning was 148, including 124 who died of yellow fever. NEW-ORLEANS, Tuesday, Aug, 30. The number of interments during the twenty-four hours ending this morning was 139, of which 125 died of yellow fever.

The Whig County Convention met to-day, and nominated MOSES HAMPTON for District Judge; JAMES CAROTHERS for Senator; T. J. BIGHAM, JOHN J. MURE, JOHN E. PARKS, CHAS. NAYLOR and JOHN M. PORTER, for Assembly; E. P. JONES, Prosecuting Attorney.

SINGULAR ESCAPE OF PRISONERS FROM BLACKWELL'S ISLAND--We were yesterday informed by a gentleman residing on the shore of Long Island, opposite Blackwell's Island, that as he was dining about 12 o'clock, M., Monday last, he discovered twelve nude men leaving the water near his house, who immediately separated and ran off in different directions.

On Monday, Capt. GOODRICH, Superintendent on the Black River Canal, testified in regard to the Commissioner's visitation of his section. His testimony was very much like that of the previous witnesses. Gov. BOUCK was called, and testified as to the practice of letting work during his commissionership. He stated that in many instances, work had been let to persons other than the lowest bidder.

The Temperance Convention here to-day was an immense gathering. They met at 10 1/2 A M. Hon. WM. R. ALLEN, of Burlington, was chosen President. Speeches were made by Gen. CAREY, of Ohio, Mr. PENNEL COMBE, of Pennsylvania, P. T. BARNUM, and others. A series of resolutions were reported, debated at length, and adopted.

In my last, I advanced some of the general reasons, both geographical and commercial, which will make Ohio roads, in the aggregate, more profitable than those of any other State. I will now give a more special view of these works-their general direction, and the effect of their construction upon the finances of the State and nation.

Broadway is always jammed. The carriageway is hopeless-below St. Paul's, incurable. But the pavements-never were they half so crowded, so perplexing, so frequently impassable; and simply because something more than 25 per cent. of homeless sight seers, chiefly, is added to the ordinary population of the City.

At a meeting of the Employing Hollse-Painters of the Lity of New-York. at which over fifty firms were represented, and held at the residence of R. B. FOSDICK, Esq., G. G. SMITH was appointed Chairman, S. WOODWARD, Vice-Chairman, and THOMAS GUILLE and GEOA BARNEY were chosen Secretaries. A Committee was appointed to prepare a statement, explanatory of the difficulties existing at this time between the journeymen and the employers of the trade.

The mail schooner Eclipse arrived here to-day, with Havana dates of the 25th, and Key West 26th inst. From Havana there is no political news. SUGARS were unchanged, but somewhat firmer, and would doubtless advance should ships arrive. Shipping being very scarce, and freights quoted at ??4?? ton for Co?? and a market.

A terrible explosion of gunpowder occurred on the wharf at Wheeling on Monday. A keg fell from a dray, because ignited and communicated to the dray, exploding about twenty kegs. The dray man was instantly killed, and another man was seriously injured and blown into the river.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times : Having learned that an unfavorable impression was obtained by some people, from my article about the water-spirits in Dr. BEDERTHA'S establishment, I am inclined, in a more presy way, which will perhaps be more easily understood, to correct it. On the 10th inst., the Kalish correspondent of the Austrian Lloyds wrote that, although negotiations for peace were still going on at St. Petersburg, the War Department was as active as ever The troops in the camp of Powonski, near War saw, are much troubled with affections of the eyes. and the cholera has again begun to show itself in the capital of Russian Poland.

Galveston papers of the 19th, and Indianola papers of the 16th inst. have been received. The Indianola Bulletin says: Since our last we have had excessive rains and cold weather. We fear this may exert an unfavorable influence on cotton in its present state. By a gentleman who has just traveled through Wharton and Matagorda counties, we learn that the crops of sugar and cotton over there are remarkably fine.

Last night, a vast multitude of the different trades of the City assembled at Metropolitan Hall, for the pur pose of expressing their sympathy with, and giving their active support to the House-Painters, with the history of whose strike the public are now pretty familiar. The body of the room, where the Painters, whom the meeting most immediately concerned, were for the most part seated, was as full as the sitting-accommodation could possibly admit of.

The Democratic Convention of the Second Assembly District, Erie County, met, last evening, to elect Delegates to the Syracuse Convention. Upon organizing, it was evident the Anti-Administration party were in the ascendant, when the Deleeates in the interest of the Custom -House and Post Office seceded, and organized a separate Convention, in which great confusion prevailed, consequent on the attempt of a Custom-House delegate to read a protest against the action of the Convention.

The nations of the Old World are drifting from their moorings, and are once more at the mercy of the waves of time and circumstance. They can no longer find safe anchorage in the ancient roadstead. but labor heavily on the swell of their troubled seas.

The publishers are preparing for an early Fall trade. The long-continued and successful musical season, with the prospect of new attractions during the Autumn, seems to indicate an unusual demand for boudoir music. It is extremely gratifying to notice among the compositions lately published, a large admixture of American works. Their success will, we trust, incite other publishers to a similar enterprise.

The Whole World's Temperance Convention assembled at Metropolitan Hall, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. The house was fairly occupied--not to make a pun. There were probably a thousand persons present, and they were very attentive. The parquette was nearly all occupied, and the first circle received a thin sprinkling.

The early trains this morning brought a numerous body of delegates and others to the State Temperance Convention, and the country roads poured in their quota to the general gathering. In point of numbers, the Convention will prove highly encouraging to the Temperance cause; and speakers of eminent ability are here to give interest to the proceedings.

The dedication of a new Cemetery, for the use of all denominations, took place yesterday, near Flushing. It is located about two miles outside the town, and is pleasantly situated But little or no ornamental work has been done in the ground, although one tenant of the tomb even already rests there--a chill having been recently interred within its borders.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I must again trouble you with a communication, in reply to the address of the Employers in your morning edition. Their address commences with a little self-flattery, which of course would be excusable, but old adage that "Self-praise is no recommendation," and their acts and conduct bear too forcibly against them, to allow it a favorable reception.

Yesterday was a fast-day in the calendar of fillibusterism; for, on the 1st of September, 1820, Gen. NARCISO LOPEZ, the head of the Cuban revolutionary party, was done to death. Last year, or ex gratia, a Mass was said for the souls of the sufferers--such a mass as the homicide or highwayman enjoys by the canon of the Church.

The bark Eutaw, which sailed enc yesterday for Baltimore, returned to port this afternoon, with the crew in a state of mutiny. We th learn that, when off Cape Cod yesterday, the crew refused to obey orders. A parley ensued, when they attacked the Captain with an axe, breaking four of his ribs, and injuring him badly in the head.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: The statement of " Keep Cool," published this morning in reply to the communication which appeared yesterday, setting forth the miserable management of this road, may be satisfactory to the Directors, but cannot fail to excite the contempt of those who are almost daily passing over the route.

This subject has already been treated in the TIMES by our Washington Correspondent. It is, however, one of much interest to the public, and consequently we take the following from the Washington Union: In the mail to Great .Britain the single rate of postage is 24 cents, prepayment optional. On either a letter or packet of any weight the whole postage or none at all should he prepaid.

ANOTHER PRISONER ESCAPE.--Four prisoners, in a state of nudity, attempted to effect their escape from Blackwell's Island, by swimming the East River to Long Island. They were discovered by the keepers when half way across the river, who gave chase.

Our Democratic friends had a fine time yesterday, at BURT SCOTTS, on the occasion of the Convention of the Delegates representing the Second Assembly District of Erie County. As was anticipated, from previous movements in the ward meetings, a desperate fight was made by the Administration Appointment party, but it was soon discovered that they were too hopelessly in the minority to make even a show of resistance.

THE COURSE.--A match of great local interest came off yesterday afternoon over the Saratoga Course. Mr. SPRINGSTEAD'S horse Tom, and Mr. SPENCER'S Frank Pierce, trotted against each other in mile beats, best three in five, to sulky, for a stake of $500 and added purse.

OLR BULL enjoys in this country a considerable prestige. He is patriotic, charitable and popular. He bestows his superfluous means on worthy objects, and has earned for himself the reputation of an amiable and sterling man. He has supported this character on the present occasion by yielding his services, and thus organizing a beneficiary conert, for the relief of the New-Orleans sufferers.

New-Orleans papers of Thursday and Friday last are received. They generally express the belief that the fever had reached its height, and would stadily decline. The weather was favorable. Among the deaths we notice, LEVI G. PETERS, of New-York; JOHN T. REILIY, of Boston; SOPHI L. and EDWARD A. CLIFFORD, wife and son of Col. CLIFFORD, lae o Providence.

A couple of trotting matches took place yesterday, atUnion Course, Long Island. The charioteering ground in question is not a place of very general public resort on such occasions, as the charges of a dollar and half a dollar for admission to the only accessible points of view somewhat limits the attendance of spectators.

In the Colonial and Foreign Produce Markets we have had a steady business this week, without material change in prices. through in several instances the tendency is upward. The deliveries for export are increasing, while the home consumption continues. very large. Owing to the uncertain state of foreign politics great indisposition is shown to come under engagements; but MONEY.

The Maryland Whig State Convention met this morning. SAMUEL HAMILTON, of Talbot, was appointed President, with the usual number of Vice Presidents and Secretaries. A resolution was adopted to nominate a full ticket for State Officers. The Convention then took a recess for one hour. Tile Cholera has entirely left Cumberland.

The House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church assembled at Odd Fellows' Hall, Camden, N. J., at 10 o'clock this morning, to investigate the charges presented against Bishop DOANE, of the Diocese of New-Jersey. The House was called to order by the presiding Bishop, BROWNELL.

This Assembly resumed its sittings yesterday morning. A large number of both ladies and gentlemen were present in the lobby of the Hall. The Chairman having read the resolutions brought forward at the previous day's meeting, the Amphions sang a Temperance hymn, beginning with the words, ' Intemperance, like a raging flood."

The Newport season still continues, and unless it meets with some sudden drawback, (such for instance, as the coming on of a cold rain-storm) appears likely to reach the full period of its shortlived existence-September the 15th. As a "watering-place" (I don't mean a pun,) the island of Rhode Island must ever be a favorite. Were there no other inducement, the air alone would repay us for our sojourn.

SMALL POX AT HAMPTON, N. H.--There is considerable excitement at present in the usually quiet town of Hampton, N. H., caused by the appearance of the small pox in town. Last Spring a stranger visited the town, was taken sick with the small pox, and to prevent all danger of contagion, a house was erected at the north part of the town, and there he was nursed. A PRETTY ROW.--The politicians have not all the fun. The doctors come in for a share. Witness the following: The Commercial Hospital and Lunatic Asylum at Cincinnati is, it seems, under the control of the Medical College of Ohio, and the physicians who have no inside chance, have came to the conclusion that there is something wrong about it.

The Democrats of the Twenty-second Assembly District of Rennselaer held a consultation at Lansingburg to day. The Barnburners and Softs had four united towns out of seven. They organized the Bonvention, and appointed SAMUEL GOUGLASS. Barnburner, Delegate to the State Conventiont The Hunkers withdrew,and organized another Convention, and appointed CHARLES J. WILBER their Delegate.

In consequence of the breaking of part of the machinery on which the DAILY TIMES is worked, part of our edition yesterday morning was not printed and served until a late hour; and owing to the same cause, as we can only work three of the four cylinders of the press, there may be a similar delay this morning.

This grows to be a very worldly spot. The World's Fair reopened last night, and most happily opened, too. The World's Convention of Women has run its race here in these two latter days, and a very pleasant, jovial race it has been.

GOTTSCHALK'S Concert has been the theme of universal admiration. I secured a seat shortly after the opening of the doors, and it was well that I did so, for though the weather was far from favorable, the room filled rapidly; and when GOTTSCHALK appeared upon the stage, he was welcomed by the applause of the largest and most fashionable assemblage of the season.

New-Orleans papers of Saturday last are received. The fever was still declining, both in the number of cases and malignity. The weather continued favorable, and confidence in the abatement of the epidemic, was increasing daily. The Delta had lost three compositors, one pressman, and one reporter, by the fever;

LATER FROM SANTA FR.--We have letters and papers from Santa Fe, of the 30th. An unsuccessful attempt was made, in the early part of July, to organize the Democratic party in the Territory. On the Fourth of July, a ball was given at the Exchange, which broke up in a fight between the Mexicans and Americans, in which Mr. JOHN FINNEGAN was killed by a pistol shot.

The royal visit to Ireland will be far more private than accords with the tastes and interests of the Dublin folks. Neither levee nor drawing-room will be held during the stay of her Majesty; and even the visit to the Exhibition is to be managed as quietly as possible.

JAMES C. HALL, late Postmaster here and now President of the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad Company, was attached in the street this evening by Dr. AMES, a returned Californian, who discharged a pistol at him, the ball entering the abdomen, and lodging in the hack of Mr. HALL.

THE EPIDEMIC.--After repeated disappointment, in our hopes and calculations, in reference to the subsidence of the dreadful scourge, which has been, for the last fourteen weeks, depopulating our city, we can perform the grateful office of announcing to our friends abroad, that there is a very perceptible change for the better in our mortuary reports, as well as in the condition and number of the cases.

The Court of Bishops reassembled at Camden at 10 1/2 o'clock this morning. A large number of clergy and laymen are present. Besides the bishops in attendance yesterday, we notice the following: Bishop SMITH, of Kentucky; Bishop HOPKINS, of Vermont; Bishop DELANCY, of New-York; and Bishop GREENE, of Mississippi. The house is now nearly full.

GENTLEMEN: As an American, I sympathiss most deeply with the suffering which the epidemic now prevailing at the South has indicted upon the inhabitants of New-Orleans But they have yet another claim upon my regard.

We have papers from the city of Mexico to the 17th ult., and from Vera Cruz to the 21st. There is no news of importance. Judge CONKLIN is at Jalapa; but will leave on the next steamer from Vera Cruz. The two hundred men sent to Minatitlan to quell the outbreak had returned to Vera Cruz.

Who so bold as to say that New-York is a republican city? Who dares assert that our citizens are unshackled by a despot's will If there be any hardy enough to make the assertion, he lies. Let him whisper the treasonous slander, as he loves his safety, with bated breath, lest the mighty king who now reigns among us should gain cognizance of the falsehood, and execute an awful and speedy vengeance on the traitor.

The Bishops reassembled this morning at 10 o'clock. Rt. Rev. Bishop BROWNELL in the chair. There were present several clergymen and others from the diocese, whose names I mentioned yesterday. Rt. Rev. Bishop SMITH, of Kentucky, read the Litany, after which the room was cleated. In addition to those mentioned yesterday, Bishops SMITH, Ky; GREENE, Miss., and DE LANCEY, of West New-York, were present. making a total of twenty-five.

Our readers will remember that the peddler, HIRAM WILLIAMS, who was shot down and robbed on the 19th of August, in Greene County, had recognized a man named JOHN H. HENDRICKSON, and sworn that he was his assailant. While the judicial investigation was going on before Justice STEWART, Capt. DITCHETT and Constable BENNETT arrived there with WARREN WOOD, who was arrested in New-York City, a few days since.

It is rumored that Mr. GORDON, a Webster Whig, Postmaster of Boston, may soon have leave to retire. The Postmaster for St. Louis is not yet decided upon. Judge BOWLIN is pushing COLBURN, AntiBenton, vigorously. The Administration is anxious to please the Missouri Anties, but it dreads the wrath of Old Bullion.

By the arrival of the Crescent City we have received the New-Orleans Picayune to the 25th ult. As we have already gathered from our telegraphic dispatches, the deaths from yellow fever were on the decrease. The Board of Health had advertised for eleven physicians, at a salary of $200 per month.

The amount of coal transported over the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, for the week ending yesterday, was 43,561 tons--making the total amount this year 1,074,723 tons, against 1,176, 665 tons, for the same time last year. The amount of coal brought down by the Schuylkill Navigation Company, for the week ending yesterday, was 28,320 tons--making the whole amount this year 538, 828 tons, against 495,062 tons for the same time last year.

The Navy has been brought over. This is but a specimen of the political integrity of this people, exhibited, however, on rather a large scale. The fleet consisted of three steamers, and, I think, four sailing vessels. What makes this case a little more flagrant than usual in these countries is, that the principal commanders were foreigners.

Albany-1. Benjamin F. Sayre. 2. Hiram Perry. William Cassidy. 4. James McQuade. Cattarasgus--1. Robert H. Shankland. 2. Lemuel S. Jenks. Cayuga--3. Wm. F. Cooper. Chautauque-1. S. S. Whallon. 2. A. F. Allen. Chemung--1 George W. Mason. Chenango--1. Ira P. Barnes.

A meeting of Delegates from different Trade was held at Convention Hall, Woosterstreet, on Saturday evening, for the purpose of forming an association for the protection of the interests of those bodies, and developing generally theirpowers and resources. The idea, we believe,

The Austrian Government has protested against Captain INGRAHAM'S forcible rescue of KOSZTA, as a violation of the law of nations. It quotes VATTEL, the articles of the old Confederation and the Constitution of the United States, to prove that no subordinate officehas a right to declare war in the name or on behalf of the country to which he belongs ;

The U. S. Mail steamship Atlantic, Captain WEST, from Liverpool Wednesday, 24th, 1 P. M., arrived at this port on Saturday, at 5.30 P. M. The Asia arrived out on Sunday morning, 20th, at 5 o'clock. The Taurus was advertised to sail on the 24th, for this port. The U. S. corvette St. Louis sailed from Malta Aug. 4, to the eastward.
The following is the weekly return of Deaths in the City and County of New-York, for the week ending Saturday, Sept. 3 TOTAL NUMBER, 494--Men, 92; Women, 66; Boys, 196: Girls. 140.

The New-York Anti-Slavery Society held two meetings yesterday in Metropolitan Hall. The afternoon service commenced at 3 o'clock, and was attended by some fifteen hundred persons, including about a hundred colored persons.

The bark Cuba, Capt. HOWE, from Palermo, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, having on board, in irons, JOHN DUDLEY, one of the crew of the ship France, Capt. TEAL, charged with three others with making a murderous attack upon Capt. TEAL, on the 26th July last, on board said ship.

Before Jude THOMPSON. IMPORTANT TO BENEFIT SOCIETIES.--Elizabeth Theadore vs. Gottlieb Durst and P Miller.--This action was brought to recover fifty dollars allered to be sue the plaintiff from "Lafayette Lodge, No 3, of the Order of the Sons of Liberty:" of which lodge August ?? the husband of the plaintiff was a member at the time of his death, which occurred about six weeks ago, in this city.

The Crystal Palace Gas-Light Opening was effected on Friday evening, in presence of a delighted crowd. The machinery in the arcade was in full operation, and the picture-gallery was crowded with visitors The general impression was one of high gratification with the sights seen there, if not with the sounds heard from the laboring engines and whirling wheels. The Palace from without was a glorious spectacle ;-we have studied the

The grand instrumental concert of last even ing, (for the benefit of the sufferers by yellow fever in New-Orleans,) to which I referred in my epistle of yesterday, rather exceeded (so far as the crowd was concerned) my most sanguine expectations.

On the afternoon of the 2d inst., suddenly, of apoplexy, JANE WILSON, relict of the late Geo. Wilson, Esq., of this City, in her 72d year. The friends of the deceased, and also those of her sons, Harris, William H. and George Wilson, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No 186 West 30 ??, near 8th-av., this afternoon at 4 o'clock.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.-It is with unfeigned pleasure we direct attention to the entertainment provided by the MARETZEK Company this evening. The occasion is one of universal sympathy, and will, we are assured, be attended with gratifying results . Our philanthropic brethren of the Howard Association need all the assistance it is in our power to extend to them.

If it had occurred only once, we might...

The Atlantic's news gives us a clearer insight into the policy of England and her allies in regard to Turkey. The action of the British Government, with the comments of the London Times, copied in another column, sufficiently describe the treacherous plot of which Turkey is to be made the victim.

The New-York Vegetarian Society inaugurated a Vegetarian Vestival at Metropolitan Hall on Saturday evening. Some three hundred men and women sat down at table. The tables were set for double that number, but a dispersion was effected, and the paucity of numbers was more real than apparent. The display of vegetables was not tempting. The viands were poorly dressed, and...

In our issue of Saturday morning, the reports of the proceedings at the Woman's Temperance Convention, were necessarily curtailed. We append sketches of the remarks of Rev. John PIERPONT and Hon. JOHN P. HALE, as made at the evening session of the Convention on Friday:

The Court of Bishops met at 10 o'clock this morning. After prayer by Bishop OTRY, spectators were requested to retire. Bishop DOANE protested against the use of a small ante-chamber, adjoining the Court-room, by the counsel for the prosecution. He said it was giving them an advantage not possessed by his counsel and friends.

The U. S. Mail steamship Crescent City, Lieut. SCHENCK, U. S. N., Commander, arrived at this port on Saturday. She left New-Orleans at 8 A. M., on the 26th ult, and Havana at 12 M. on the 29th ult. The returns, at the sailing of the Crescent City from New-Orleans, showed a slight decrease in the number of deaths from yellow fever.
New-Orleans papers of Sunday last are received. We notice among the deaths from fever: SARAH R. OLMSTEAD, of Newburg, New-York; THOS. M. DICKINSON, of Boston ; and Mrs. D. APPLEGATE, of Philadelphia.

DOINGS IN THE CHURCHES YESTERDAY.--Yesterday was a busy day among the Churches. Several edifices were reopened after the Summer vacations, and the pastors delivered their discourses to large and attentive congregations. The Broadway Tahernacle Society we conted back their pastor, Rev. J. P. THOMPSON, who has just returned from his tour in Europe and the Holy Land.

We sympathise fully with the efforts that have been made lately towards preventing further encroachments upon our harbor, and wish them all success. A speedy relief from the evils already produced is, however, hardly to be expected, and we would, therefore, suggest that energetic measures be adopted towards freeing our harbor from some of its most dangerous natural obstructions, especially the sunken rocks. In so doing,

Harper's Magazine for September, with other interesting and instructive matter, contains a very beautiful article of two pages, entitled "Uncle Bernard's Story," which was originally published in the June number of Putnam's Monthly, for which it was written by Rev. Dr. BETHUNE.

Leaving out of view the question as to the policy and the duty of the United States to take part directly in the quarrels of European States, there can be no difference of opinion in regard to the magnitude and importance of our own interests in Europe and in the East. The state of affairs in Europe is, at this time, critical.

POLITICAL BRIBERY IN PHILADELPHIA.-POlitical bribery, if the telegraph tells a true tale, is not confined to England. Bribes are taken in Philadelphia. Not very large ones;--very small; too small to be considered respectable, even in Philadelphia. The last instance known was during a session of one of the conventions recently held there.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The article in your paper of Tuesday last, headed, "Incidents of a day at the Five Points House of Industry," has not been without its fruits of good. Two letters reached Mr. PEASE yesterday enclosing valuable contributions. From one of these letters, dated "Mount Carmel," Ct., I extract the following:

Since the melancholy occurrence (the shooting of HALL by Dr. AMES) there has been much excitement in the streets of our city, and, to speak plainly, the public sympathy is generally against the defendant, and frequently did we hear it stated, " it is a most villainous transaction," " a deliberate and malicious attempt at murder," and other equally strong expressions.

It will be recollected that Commodore NEWTON's death was published in most of the newspapers, which was erroneous, as he is still alive. He was, however, too ill to proceed in the Columbia (his flag-ship,) to San Juan de Nicaragua, with our Minister. Hon. SOLON BORLAND and suite. He therefore dispatched Commander PENDERGRAS??, with orders to proceed with our Minister to his place of destination, and the Commodore came north for his health.

The Court of Bishops met at 10 o'clock this morning. Bishop KEMPER conducted the religious services. The doors were closed, as on Saturday. Before adjourning on Saturday, Bishop MEADE, one of the presenting Bishops, said he had been impelled to the present action by a memorial signed by 130 citizens of New York, supposed to be members'of the Episcopal Church.

From information at this port, derived from Mr. DOTY, in the Missionary work at Amoy, we learn that the rebels have addressed a communication to the army in the north, proposing to join it, and that the immediate object of their movement is the capture of this province (Fuh Chau) which they design to present to the new Emperor.

SUB-MARINE BLASTING IN NEW-HAVEN HARBOR.-We learn, from a private source, that the operations against Middle Reck, in New-Haven Harbor, cannot be completed during the present season. This announcement will doubtless be Heard with regret by all who have interest in its removal. The difficulties with which Monsieur

The Democratic State Convention, when it convenes, will be well worth looking at-at a safe distance. Seventy-two Delegates have been elected, and among them are to be found all ancient and recent consistency of shells--from doughy softness to the hardness of an impenetrable brick.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times Your correspondent, "F. W. S.," in the TIMES of Monday, very reasonably finds fault with the notice of COLERIDGE, published in your paper of June 4. That article, to say the least, gave me much pain. I could not, and I do not believe, that the portraiture of the great poet and philosopher given there, is a true one.

The foreign advices received yesterday have unsettled the market for Breadstuffs, and prices of all descriptions have advanced. There has been a fair inquiry for FLOUR for shipment, and 1,000 bbls. fresh ground superfine sold at $5 871/2@ $6--an advance of 37 1/2c @50c ?? bol. over the closing rates of Saturday. There is fair demand for city consumption at $5 87 1/2 up to $6 50 for common and extra brands, according to quality.

Our Democratic European correspondent, in a letter which we publish this morning, pays his respects to the Washington Union. That paper, holding the position of an organ of the Administration, and claiming to represent the Democracy of the country, saw fit, a few weeks since, to assail our correspondent with more zeal than knowledge,

New Orleans papers of Monday and Tuesday last are received. They say that the fever is dying out for the want of material. Among the deaths were MILTON ARTHUR, a composior in the Crescent office, and CHARLES ADAMS of Philadelphia.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: "Civis, Jr.," had he known more of the lozenge boys, supposing his interest real, might, indeed, find abundant cause for sympathy; but, I venture to say, his benevolence would suggest some better employment than selling lozenges. Had he known more of them, he might readily have answered his own question," Are they a nuisance."

To-day the World's Temperance Convention begins its sessions in Metropolitan Hall. The proceedings will probably continue for three or four days. An interesting programme of exercises is furnished for the occasion. Among the speakers announced are NEAL Dow, Judge O'NEALL, lion. C. N. OLDS, JOHN CASSELL, Esq., of England; Rev. JOHN PIERPONT, Gen. S. F. CARY, Dr. LYMAN BEECHER and others.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the Freeman's Journal of Sept. 3, it is stated that the astronomers of the National Observatory have led the public into an error by declaring that the comet now leaving us is the same with that discovered by KLINKERFUES in June last; and, further, that this one is identical with the periodical comet known as BIELA's.

Last night GRISI and MARIO sang, according to the operatic announcement, "for the last time this season, their engagement being finished." The occasion was invested with peculiar interest, as the musical journals announced that it would be the last appearance in dramatic music of these income parable artists in England.

The total number of deaths reported yesterday was 133. of which 110 were from yellow fever. RICHARD HAGAN a well known citizen died on Thursday. Business was entirely suspended yesterday, in accordance with the proclamation of the Mayor. On Sunday morning. Rev. J. P. THOMPSON, Pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle, resumed his labors in his own pulpit, after his return from the Old World, where he has been sojourning for the past year, for the recovery of his health. His discourse was heard by a very large and attentive audience. Mr. THOMPSON took his text from 2d John, 12th verse: "Having many things to write to you,

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: I read with some interest the letter of Judge EDMONDS, published a few weeks since, containing a brief statement of his investigation and experience with the " rappers," table-movers," , and the facts, or "physical manifestations," which overcome his incredulity on the subject.

MR. LAW's FERRY.--The residents of Williamsburg will be gratified to learn that the work on the new ferry is going on promisingly. Two large floats and two bridges are nearly completed at the foot of South Eleventh-street. The ferry-slip will be filled in so that the water will be of sufficient depth to float the boats safely.

How much the cause of Temperance has been advanced by the recent Convention of Men, Women and Bloomers, whose garrulity has so largely exhausted our space and the public patience for the past few days, we shall not presume to calculate. We think it unfortunate, however, for the respectability of any cause that it should fall into such hands, and be urged by such proceedings as those of the past week.

General DIX's friends should make haste to sympathise with him. I state from undoubted authority, that Gen CASS has been handsomely offered the French Mission. His acceptance or nonaccept ance, to outsiders is unknown. We have frightful accounts of Death's doings at Mobile. Half the population are absent, and yet forty-three deaths occurred in 24 hours.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. I beg permission to say a few words in reference to what has fallen from the Washington Union, against my having found fault with Commodore STRINGHAM'S ostentatiously saluting Baron BRUCK, the Austrian Envoy, upon his arrival at Constantinople.

The September Session of the Common Council commenced yesterday afternoon. The proceedings in the Board of Aldermen were quite interesting. The Annual Report of the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department was received, and is given below. A number of petitions were presented in the Board of Aldermen and appropriately referred.

The Boston Post's article on allegiance and naturalization, is a topic of much remark here, because of its many striking points of argument, and its bold enunciation of novel yet manifestly just views. It is a mistake to suppose that Mr. CUSHING wrote it. Anybody who reads it with care, will not attribute it to his pen. It is wanting in the elegant finish of the Attorney-General's productions; and it betrays some blunders

The late American Minister, on retiring from Mexico under the recall of the new Administration, made a parting address to General SANTA ANNA which, under the circumstances, strikes us as rather a remarkable document. It is prepared with ability, and will be read in this country, as it was heard in that, with decided interest.

JULLIEN's CONCERT.-The attendance at Castle Garden during the past week has been of an extremely satisfactory character. The public has not failed to recognize the merit of Monsieur JULLIEN's entertainments. An audience largely exceeding those of the operatic season nightly assembles to listen to the unrivalled band of the popular conductor. Last night the American

Hon. J. WALKER'S resignation of the Chinese mission has been accepted. The cause of his resignation is believed to be a remonstrance of his relatives against going, as his health does not improve as rapidly as promised when he accepted the appointment. The appointment of a successor may be expected at an early day.

The World's Temperance Convention held its first session in Metropoli an Hall yesterday morning. The body of the Hall ws filled nearly to its full capacity, but there were only a few persons scattered through the galleries. On the platform we observed NEAL DOW, Judge ?? NEALL, JOHN CASSELLS. Of England, Rev. JOHN

The contest for the control of their coming Convention, among the " fierce democracie," grows desperate and excited. The " state of the odds " cannot be learned from the leading journals of the factions, because to play off their game of brag, and keep up the spirits of their partisans, each claims nearly every delegate elected as " sound.

We are within a few weeks of oar State Election; and although Both political parties have issued their calls for a Nominating Convention, it is evident that the interest felt in the matter on either side is quite different from that which has hitherto ushered in our annual autumnal contests.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Tmes : I would respectfully call your attention to a great and growing evil in this City, which is carried on with impunity, as if there was no such thing as a City ordinance to prevent it, or to protect persons doine a lawful business.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: No. 251 BROADWAY, Tuesday, Sept. 6, 1853. CATHARINE-STREET FERRY-HOUSE BURNT.--The Ferry-house and bridge of the Catharine street Ferry, on the Brooklyn side. were intally destroyed by fire, Monday evening. The trips of the boats were suspended, and, will not probably be resumed to-day. The building was of frame, some two hundred feet in length, and the center building two-stories in height.

Mr. OLIVER DYER, one of the Editors of the Musical World, publishes a letter in our columnns this morning, giving definite shape to the rumor mentioned by that paper a short time since, that Madame SONTAG had been told that $15.000 had been paid for editorial notices of her performances in the New-York press.

THE HEALTH OF THE CITY.--Our report of to-day, as well as those for several days past, show a most encouraging and promising decrease in the amount of morality. The decrease has been steady for more than a week, and will undoubtedly continue so until the subsidence of the epidemic--a period very near at hand, if the present very favorable weather continues.

The underground railroad " is a term which has come into very general use to designate the organized arrangements made in various sections of the country, to aid fugitives from Slavery in escaping to Canada. That such organizations exist and are extensively efficient, is well known.

To the Editor of the Ne- York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: The following extract of a letter from a correspondent in the western part of this State. will be perused with interest, although eg-otistical to the last degree. I may add that the consignment proved a foul one:

Our files of the Correo de Carraccas extend to the 6th of August. The earthquake of the 15th July, so destructive at Cumana, was felt very generally in the northern provinces At Barcelona, several hoises were destroyed, including a branch filled with troops. all of whom escaped uninjured. Nearly every building in the city suffered more or less seriously.

One hundred men have been thrown out of employment at Augusta, Me, by the burning of one of the mills at the west end of Augusta Dam. Before the devouring element was arrested, It had consumed two saw-mills, a spool factory, two planingmills, a grist-mill, a boarding-house, and an immense quantity of lumber, prepared for shipping. The loss of property is estimated at $140.000.

The Court of Bishops is assembled to dispose of the Third presentment made of the Bishop New-Jersey, by the three Bishops of Virginia, Maine and Ohio, which said presentment is identically the same as the first and second presentments made by the same three Bishops, with simply a different phraseology, and which were dismissed by the first Court of Bishops last year, as unfounded and unsustained.

This Court resumed its adjourned sitting yesterday morning, before Judge Beehe, when the following gentlemen were sworn upon the Grand Jury: Luther C. Carter, Foremen; Robert H. "Selim," named by J. WOODRUFF, and g. m. "Lady Vernon," named by D. PFIFER--mile beats, the brat three in five. in arness. Owing to the intense heat the trotting was

BOBY OF A YOUNG MAN FOUND IN A RAVINE NEAR TIVOLI FALLS--SUPPOSED MURDER.--The northern section of the city was thrown nto the greatest alarm, yesterday, by finding the body of a young man near the Tivoli Falls. When discovered by some young men, his body was completely covered with sand, leaves. A dreadful fracture was noticed on the back of his head sufficient to have caused his death.

The Evening Post indignantly disclaims having advised Mr. PUTNAM to commence a suit against the HARPERB, for having accidentally used a short story which was his legal property. Its article, it declares, "treated the matter jestingly throughout."

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I notice in the DAILY TIMES, of this date, account of a "Mysterious Well," discovered on Berges Hall, Brooklyn. The place where it was discovered was the of the Box Fort." a small fortification, who good service during the Battle of Long Island.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The extract from the London Times, on the death of Sir GEORGE COCKBURN, published in your paper of this 5th September, contains a paragraph accusing my ancestor, Commodore BARNEY, and the brave men under his command, of cowardice and of being filled with terror by the very presence of the British admiral in the Chesapeake Bay, in 1814.

The Temperance cause, the Temperance movement, the Temperance reform, or by whatever name it may be called, must now he regarded as a fixed fact in our modern history. It has taken a hold of the public mind, deeper than the most sanguine would once have ventured to predict It has gone beyond this: it has penetrated the public conscience. It has entered into our stock of public

A Correspondent in yesterday's TIMES gave the rapping spirits what Mr. Pecksniff would call an "Pligible opportunity" of doing some good in the world. Considering how little they have done hitherto, we think they ought not to neglect this chance.

The Suffolk County Teachers' Association has just closed a session of five sittings, at Greenport. On the first afternoon, (Thursday, Sept. 1,) a spirited discussion was held upon "the best method of teaching children to read," in which warm advocates were found for the different systems known as the "word method," "the old method," and " the phonetic method." The Geneva Gazette, states that recently a man named Walter Carey was found dead in the corner of a fence, on a railroad track, six miles west of Lockport. An inquest was held, and a verdict rendered that his death was caused by the heat. On the afternoon of the same day, Carey's friends procured his body from Coroner Atwood,

The Court of Bishops reassembled at 10 o'clock. Prayer was offered by Bishop POLK. Before the Court adjourned yesterday, after deciding not to admit the report of the Diocese Committee, Bishop BROWNELL, one of those who voted in the negative, as would appear, on the ground that he deemed it illegal to admit a third party, yet being willing to hear the Diocese, moved that the Court hear the Diocese through respondent.

Business in the Navy-Yard, at Charlestown, is brisk at present, and promises to continue so. On Monday one hundred mechanics and laborers were admitted into the yard, in addition to the num ber previously employed, and others will be admitted this week Orders have been received to put the sloop-of-war Dale in condition for sea. She is destined for the coast of Brazil.

The Natchez papers correct the report that the yellow fever has been declared an epidemic in that city. They say there is some yellow fever and some deaths from it, but that, as a general thing, it yields readily to medical treatment. The physicians here say that it is not stubborn but when the patient is prudent, and has kind nursing. the disease is not unmanageable.

We have been favored, from a reliable source, with a biographical sketch of Commander INGRAHAM, whose late gallant conduct in command of the St. Louis, in the harbor of Smyrna, has given him a world-wide reputation.

A gentleman, writing from France, tells a story concerning the obstinacy of his Satanic Majesty, when requested to evacuate the body of one of a set of fanatics, called Jewingians et Pious, who were praying and singing with vast zeal and unction in their chapel, in the village of Comerania, which is of some interest.

THE WINNEBAGOES AND THEIR NEW TRACT.The Winnebagoes are dissatisfied with the country allotted them on the South side of the Crow Wing river, and many of them have refused to locate there, so negotiations have been opened with them. Gov. GORMAN, of Minnesota, and Gen FLETCHER were the Commissioners of the United State to attend to the matter, and on the 3d of August they met the Indians at Watah Prairie.

We publish elsewhere in our columns, an interesting paper by Hon. THOMAS EWBANK, late Commissioner of Patents, presenting an entirely new idea in marine proptilsion, which will well repay attentive perusal by all who are interested in that subject.

Before Judge Betts, sitting in Admiralty. Yesterday being the first day of term, hi Honor sat to hear the usual return of process and motions. In re the Ship Angelique--This vessel having been sold, and the fund paid into Court, under an order made by Judge Ingersoll, quite a number of claimants have appeared to dispute the priority of the original libellants to be paid out of the fund.

To Hon. James C. Dobbin, Secretary of the Navy: SIR: I take occasion, from the recent breakage of the shafts of the U. S. Mail steamer Pacific, while on her passage across the Atlantic, respectfully to solicit your attention to some thoughts on paddle-wheels, forming, as these do, a chief element in the national steam marine.

Under the heading of a " National Reform Convention," a Call was issued some days ago, for a convocation in this City of all such persons as should be " in favor of a thorough reform in the administration of our City, State and General Governments." Persons so disposed accordingly met in Convention at the Mechanics' Institute, Bovery, at 9 o'clock yesterday
New-Orleans papers of Wednesday last are to hand. The statement regarding the exportation of the clothes of fever victims is generally ridiculed and denied by the press.

In the Circuit Court of the United States, Judge PITMAN, this morning, at Chambers, delivered the decision of the Court upon the motion for an injunction in the case of HORACE H. DAY against ISAAC HARTSHORN, DAVID HAYWARD and NATHANIEL HAYWARD, which was recently argued before him at Newport.

At New-York at last ! It be of a truth a world of a city, indeed. Soon after my arrival, I was standing on the Astor House steps, looking up Broadway-a wonderful street to be sure, and of a marvellous length-noticing the vast numbers that were thronging the sidewalks.

Long after 9 o'clock yesterday, the Tabernacle presented a desolate a, pearance not very encouraging to the Woman's lights Reformers. Scarcely a dJzen paople had assembled, who, spead through the large buillding, rather added to the loneliness. At the regular hour for meeting, about two hundred hid assembled.

The Public Stocks come in rather slowly. The Atlantic brought scarce an older for redemption of Loans held by foreign parties, notwithstanding the news of the enhanced premium offered by the Secretary had arrived out. Careful and reliable estimates show that of the 40,000,000 Loans of 1842, '46,'47 and '48, less than 5,250,000 are in foreign hands.

The Court of Bishops reassembled at the usual hour. Prayer was offered by Bishop ELLIOTT. The Court is not yet full, Bishops HAWKS, of Missouri, COBB, of Alabama, and WHITEHOUSE, of Illinois, being absent. The latter is detained by the meeting of his diocese.

Their Majesties left on Saturday for Dieppe, with all the accompaniments of state and magnificence that it was possible to squeeze into a railroad trip of a couple of hours' duration. Although St. Cloud is not upon the line to Dieppe, they, nevertheless, entered the imperial car at the gate of the Park, and left it at their place of destination. Our State election took place today, and we have the vote for Governor in about 20 towns, which show a Whig loss compared with last year. There is no election by the people, but GOV. FAIRBANKS, Whig, will have a large plurality. The resuit will depend on the Legislature, which is very close.

THE PEOPLE'S CONVENTION AT CLEVELAND.--The Cleveland Herald thus speaks of the ticket which was put in nomination at the People's Convention, held in that city on Saturday last: HORACE FOOTR, Esq., who is nominated for Judge of this Judicial Districtt, is a lawyer of distinguished ability, of unimpeachable integrity, and would do honor to any judicial position.
