M. B. Larsky, the Russian engineer, lately deceased, who had also acquired a reputation as a poet, and an archaeologist, made a discovery of the greatest importance in White Russia--a discovery brought to light when his papers were examined after his decease.
Nobody but Col. BENTON would ever have conceived the idea of making a State for the sake of building a railroad. But that is his attempt touching the proposed Territory of Nebraska.

The Charleston Mercury, one of the most rabid of the Pro-Slavery, State-Rights papers of the South, is out in favor of the appointment of Gen. Dix as Minister to France ! His support of VAN BURBN in 1848 is pronounced a small matter, which should not expose him to special hostility.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.-- patronage appears to be flowing strongly in this direction. It would be difficult to find one more deserving of it. Mr. WALLACK has commenced his season with excellent arrangements, and a company which cannot be surpassed.

CELEBRATION AT GROTON.-The town of Groton, Conn., on Tuesday, was alive with a mass of visitors, assembled to celebrate the anniversary of the massacre of Fort Griswold, which occurred Sept. 6, 1781. The ferry-boats, regular and extra, plying between New-London and Groton Heights. were crowded during the whole day, and thousands availed themselves of other means of access to the town, to listen to the speeches and join in the ceremonies.

The general features of the traffic in Dry Goods during the past week, have been essentially the same as those of the business of the preceding six days. Western, Southern, and local jobbers have purchased seasonable productions with avidity, and at firm prices. These articles are not overabundant, and owners of them manifest no anxiety: to realize.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: To prevent further mistakes in regard to my connection with the Chinese Company, which may have been induced by my silence, caused solely by a disposition on my part not to prevent their being the recipients of sympathy and assistance from the public, I respectfully solicit the privilge of stating, in your column is, the facts.

A MAN SHOT BY A SNAKR.-A letter in the Philadelphia Ledger states that, a few days ago, a man named LOUMAN, storekeeper in Siddonsburg York County, was out gunning, when he discovered a large snake, and in order quickly to socure it from running away, he placed the butt of his rifle, loaded with a ball at the time, upon the body of the snake, with his hand directly across the msazze.

The Westfield Standard tells about a spring of water in the town of Otis, Massachusetts, which if true, "beats all natur." The editor says that when a rod from it he was taken with the ague, and looking at his thermometer, found the mercury had fallen from 94 degrees to 70! On placing the instrument at the bottom of the spring, the mercury descended to36, or four degrees above the freezing point.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Time : We observed, in the TIMES of the 31st tilt., an anonymous communication in reply to our article on lightning-rods, and have since seen a part of that communication in another paper over the signature of the author, J. ENNIS.

COMMENCEMENT AT BROWN UNIVERSITY, PROVIDENCE, R I.-The Eighty fourth Commencement of Brown University was celebrated yesterday, at the First Baptist Meeting-house, Providence, where the exercises of the graduating class were performed, and degrees conferred. Afterwards, an oration was pronounced by Hon. B. F. THOMAs, of Worcester, before the Alumni.

GOLD IN MAINE-A friend of the Editor of the Boston Traveller has shown him a specimen of veritable gold dust taken from the newly discovered mine upon the Sandy River, in Maine. The locality, which is some twenty miles from Farmington, bears strong resemblances to gold regions in California, and it was through these resemblances that a returned miner from California made the discovery.

Yet the carrier charged me 25 cents for delivering the letter at my residence, No. 201 West Eighteenth-street, Is Postmaster FOWLER aware of this, or is it only an imposition of the carrier?

Another of the melancholy catastrophes, which we have been so frequently called upon to chronicle of late, occurred yesterday morning on board the steamer Bay State, Capt. BROWN, of the New-York and Fall River line, while on her passage from Fall River to this City.

We called yesterday to see the man who has been asleep for five years, and whose case was detailed in the TIMES some weeks since. We found him in what seemed like a sound sleep. He was lying in bed, his eyes nearly closed, his respiration rather slower than is usual, his breathing a little stertorous, pulse some seventy-five strokes in a minute, soft and weak.

On the6 o'clock express train from this city, on the Hartford and New-Haven Railroad, last evening, about a dozen Irishmen took passage. One drunken fellow persisted in standing upon the platform, after the conductor had repeatedly told him to go inside. With some difficulty he at length seated him.

IMPORTANT LEGAL DECISION.-The City Solicitor of New-Bedford has given a written opinion that the city in its corporate capacity cannot, either through a vote of the City Council or otherwise, make any agreement, promise or contract that shall be legally binding, to indemnify the officers who shall serve warrants in the seizure of liquors, against the damages they may sustain by being prosecuted therefore.

If ex-Governor POINDEXTER had died twenty years ago, it is probable his death would have attracted more attention than it does to day. His part in State as well as National politics was a co-spieuous one.

Yesterday morning, about 12 o'clock, a terrible affray occurred at a notorious dance-house. located at No. 308 Water-street, which created an alarming excitement in that section of the Fourth Ward. It appears a party of seamen met at this rendezvous. where abandoned characters of both sexes congregate at all hours of the night.

The total number of deaths reported for the twenty four hours ending this morning was 116--including 95 from yellow fever. Much fever prevails all along the river. To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your Philadelphia correspondent thinks me "an Abolitionist of the bitter school." As a piece of news, this is startling enough. Being myself an Alabamian, and having scarcely a relative north of Mason and Dixon's Line, I am surprised to find myself transformed into a "bitter" partisan of the opposite school.

The British and North American Mail steamship Asia, from Liverpool Saturday, Aug. 27, with 150 passengers, arrived at 10 o'clock last evening. The mails per Asia were in charge of Lieut. LEWIS, R. N., Admiralty Agent.

COMMERCE OF BOSTON TO AUSTRALIA -- The Boston Journal states, that within the year past there have been dispatched from that port for Australia one steamer, twenty-three ships, twenty-two barks. and three brigs, all first-class vessels.

From the Albany Eveing Journal If Whigs are impelled to review the past, it is that they may draw from the retrospect lessons for the future. The Campaign of 1852 left the Whig party overthrown and prostrate. In such a condition of utter political bankruptcy were we, that many gravely insisted we should never "resume," while others pronounced the party annihilated.

Everything was quiet when they left the Bay of St. Lawrence. The E. P. Howard has been absent two months, and the Henrietta over three months.

SUFFOLK COUNTY COURT.--The Circuit Court held by Judge STONG, has been in session in Riverhead, Suffolk County, this week. There were no criminal trials and no civil trials of much interest, The Grand Jury had a busy session.

Colonel FORNEY will commence the publication of a new Democratic journal in New-York, to be called the Press, about the 1st of 'October, with abundant capital and backing. The President thoroughly endorses this enterprise, and the Press will receive all the available public patronage. Col. FORNEY still intends to move again for the Clerkship of the House of Representatives.

The following paragraph, from the Albion of last week, has but just come to our notice: "Finally-and we offer the fact without note or comment-we are informed that the mysterious stranger on Nantucket Shoals was also seen from the deck of the Pacific, but Capt NYE did not think it requisite to reconnoitre him.

In accordance with resolutions passed by the " BARR General Committee," at a meeting held on Friday evening last, an election of delegates to the approaching Democratic Convontion, at Syracuse, was held between the hours of 5 and 7 o'clock Thursday evening. There was little opposition, and no disturbance in any of the Ward--the Hard-Shells having it at their own way for the time.

We have but few particulars to add to the account of the disaster to the Bay State. The narratives of eye-witnesses, published in the TIMES of yesterday, gave a complete account of the scenes at the time of the catastrophe. The Bay State was a staunch steamer, built seven years ago, expressly for the navigation of the Sound.

At the sitting of the Court, yesterday morning, the Eighteenth Ward rioters, who had been convicted on the previous Tuesday were placed at the bar. On the use the question being put, as to what they had to say why sentence should not be awarded against them,...

ILLNESS OF CARDINAL WISEMAN.--We deeply regret to have to inform our readers that the illustrious and revered Cardinal Archbishop of Westminster has been for the last week confined to his house at Walthamstow with a serious internal complaint, and that a good deal of anxiety itself about him.

At the meeting of the Board Friday evening, a quorum did not arrive until 5 1/2 P. M., when the roll was called, and the Board proceeded to business--RICHARD T. COMPTON, Esq., in the Chair Petitions Referred.--Of Cataract Engine Co. No. 25, for a new location. 0' Jeremiah Crowly and others, to have nuisance abated at the foot of Thirty third street, East River.
Cleared. Steamships Augusta, Lyon, Savannah, S L. Mitchell James Adger, Dickinson, Churleston, Spofford, Tileston Co.: Jamestown, Parish, Norfolk and Richmond, Ludlam Pleasants.'

According to the New-Hampshire "Transactions," some towns in the Granite State have received more money in exchange for apples than for any other article of produce. Ten barrels of Winter apples are held to be worth as much as a ton of the best hay; and some large stories are told of the yield of sundry newly-grafted but very old trees.

Though the kindness of Mr. ALEXANDER McWHINNEY, now a resident of Australia, for merly of Kingston, Jamaica, we yesterday received a file of the Melbourne Argus to June 10. Mr. McWHINNEY left Kingston about a year since, with his own family, and a large number of others, in a brig which he had chartered for the trip. The company comprised some fifty four adults and several children.

From the Dublin Tablet. A more signal exhibition of that great law which so often punishes unbelief by consigning the proud intellect to the most abject credulty has seldom been afforded than by ROBERT OWEN'S late letter to the Queen.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: May I say a few words through your columns, touching the Episcopal Court at Camden, and the efforts of Bishop DOANE to prevent matters proceeding to the issue of a trial?

It is really fortunate for the country that the fourth estate--that of the Press--exists. Uncle Sam would otherwise certainly fall victim to bad Government. Congress, if not grossly corrupt, as Colonel BENTON and Mr. VENABLE insist, is open to very shrewd suspicion of being occasionally neglectful and fallible. The executive, like HOMER, nods sometimes, and American interests suffer.

The most notable fact in regard to the Austrian treatment of the KOSZTA difficulty, is the coolness with which it dogmatizes upon questions of purely American law. The very first act was to pass upon the claim of the man to be considered as a citizen of this country; a question only determinable by American authorities.

HON. JACCB B. MOORE, late Postmaster of San Francisco, and long prominent as a political and historical writer, died, as has already been announced, at the residence of his brother, in Bellows Falls, Vermont, oh the 1st inst., aged about 5G years. Mr. MOORE was a native of New-Hamp shire, in which State he resided until 1840, when he removed to New-York, to edit the Daily Whig.

Reopening of City Churches. Several of the Churches in this City and Brooklyn were reopened yesterday, after undergoing their customary Summer renovations. Grace Church, Breadway, was opened with a discourse by the Rector Rev. THOMAS TAYLOR.

For the first time since the body met In June last, we have a consistent account of the doings of the Memphis Convention. It is given in Prof. DE Bow's Review, for September. It is scarcely necessary to say every resolution goes to the question, why more active measures are not taken for the development of Southern trade, and the direct exchange of Southern products with those of foreign countries:-the old topic.

General Cass, in a very recent letter to the President, most cordially assures him of his high personal regard, and declares that no President ever had so many difficulties to encounter as he has had; and his course has been judicious and ?? and that the writer will accept of no position under the Government but that of Senator. The President, he says, can rely upon his earnest and ?? support of his Administration.

It is not without pleasurable emotions that we take up a pen for the purpose of announcing the non-reappearance of that Comet,up to the present time of writing. But, reader, don't be too sanguine. Recollect its got all day to come in, and at the rate of 30,000 miles a minute it can get over a good deal of ground in twenty-four hours-more particularly as the road is said to be in excellent order.

In another part of this morning's paper will be found, as is usual on Monday, the list of burials for the week past, as reported to the City Inspector. Referring to that for particulars, we simply design to call attention to some points suggested on glancing over its items. The whole number of deaths was 531, being an increase of 37 over that of last Monday.

The New-York train, due here last evening, did not arrive until 4 o'clock this morning; having been thrown off the track near Beverley. The forward brakeman, named IREDELL, was instantly killed, and JOHN COESON, the engineer, considerable bruised.

OLE BULL.--This distinguished violinist has accepted the solicitation of his numerous ad mirers, and will give another concert at NIBLO's Saloon, to-morrow evening. We would advise our readers to procure tickets at an early hour. The last concert given by this gentleman was crowded to excess, and many hundred people were compelled to leave the doors. Every one should hear OLEBULL.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In perusing your paper of this morning, my attention for the first time was directed to the present occupancy of the Mercer-street Art-Union building. The remarks therein convey an impression equally injurious as the paragraph extracted from the Tribune.

On Saturday morning, Sept. 10, WILLIAM BARNES, Senr., aged 83 years and 26 days. His relatives and friecds are invited to attend the funeral, at 9 o'clock on Monday morning, from his late recidence, No. 154, Pobinsr. st. Funeral service will take place at St. Porl's Chapel. The remaine will be taken to Trinity Cemetory.

A great demonstration of the Sons of Term Temperance took place on Friday evening, at Metropolitan Hall, at 7 1/2 o'clock--Hon Judge O'NEALL, of South Carolina, M.W.P., presiding, assisted by the G. W. P.'s of the Grand Divisions. The platform was occupied by the officers of the various Divisions.

RANKING's half-yearly Abstract of the Medical Sciences, being a practical and analytical digest of the principal American, British and Continental medical works, published from January to July, of 1853, has appeared. If this were all of the contents of RANKING's Abstract, the work would be invaluable; but in addition we have a series of critical reports of the highest order on the progress of medicine and the collateral sciences, during the same period.

VERMONT STATE FAIR--The Exhibition all the Vermont Agricultured Society will be held on the 13th inst., and will continue during three days. The grounds are alreadly extensively laid out and fitted with great care to meet the wants of the Exhibition.

The National Intelligencer copies from the Philadelphia Inquirer a Washington letter, denying a statement I made with others, some weeks ago, of an interview which took place between Mr. MARCY and M. BODISCO one Sunday morning, relative to an article in the Union on the KOSZTA case. The correspondent presents no proof of my error.

The Parade of the American Protestant Association yesterday, despite the wet weather, was really hardsome. Several of the Lodges had hands of music with them, and displayed some pretty banners. The regalia of the members was very rich, resembling that of the Grand Lodge of I. O. of 0. F.

LAYING THE CORNER-STONE OF A CATHOLIC CHURCH.--The ceremony of laying the corger-store of St. Mary's Catholic Church, on the corner of Remsen and Leonard-streets, took place yesterday afernoon. In the absense of Archbishop HUCHES, who was said to be ill, Very Reverend JOHN LAUGHLIN, Vicar-General of the Dicease, officiated, assisted by JOSEPH N. PAGULT, Vicar General of the Nova Scotia Diocese, and Rev. P. McLAUGHLIN, Pastor of the Church.

We are standing on the "Gibraltar of America," three hundred and fifty feet above the level of the sea. Northward the districts of Montmorency, Quebec and Port Neuf extend from the river towards uninhabitable wilds, immense forests, cold, inaccessable and dreary, but fringed all along the river borders with villages and cultivated fields.

We have dates from Austin to the 20th ult. The election returns had come in very slow, and there were yet twenty-four counties to hear from. The following is the result for the office of Governor, as far as ascertained:

We publish, in another column, a brief extract from a Washington letter, copied from the Pennsylvania Inquirer. It will be seen that the writer disputes a statement made aome weeks ago by our special correspondent at Washington, detailing certain conduct of the Russian Minister, well calculated to excite popular disgust and rebuke.

The Charivari devotes a long article to Mr. SOULE, who is, at present, in Paris, apropos of an article in the Debats, condemnatory of that gentleman's torch-light and brass-band speech in New York. The writer says that the most extraordinary efforts are made by the Spanish editors to induce the Government not to receive Mr. SOULE.

The "break-up of the season is ?? complete, and London is now in its autumnal stage of desolation. Its streets are deserted by all its fashionables, and a large proporation of its prosperous classes, who have already gone to the country, to the bathing please, or to the Continent,--the letter, perhaps, for cheapness, since a ?? abroad admits of economy being ?? at home, by the temporary discharge of a ?? of superfluous servants.

The schooner Star-Lighll, Cipt. MCUoNELL, arrived at this port last night. from the Bay of St. Lawrence. This, it will be recollected, is the ves sel wvhich was seized by H. M. steamner Delasration, Cat.. CAMPBELL, August G. Capt. Mcfonrr.t, informs us that he was unjustly and wrongfully seized. He had that way been working down from the westward, and toward night had aclhored inshore. He, however, soon after observed the fleet,

Advices from Montevideo apprise us of a renewal of revolutionary symptoms among the people of the Banda Oriental. The victory of URQUIZA in 1852, was not, it seems, sufficiently decided to extinguish the old party rancor; and Gen. ORIBS, the ally of ROSAS, is again in the field, preparing to attack the capital, and restore the supremacy of the " Whites."

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Your paper of the 8th inst. contains a Card of Mr. WM. H. VAN WAGNER, denying my charge against him before the late New-Jersey Temperancc Convention, threatening to arraign me before a Court of Justice, and imputing malice as the motive of my action.

The first number of the Hoboken Gazette appeared on Saturday. The paper is a neatly printed folio, published weekly, owned and edited by Mr. THOS. W. WHITLEY. The course of the Editor is to be independent. In the Introductory, occurs the following passage: "It is not every one who crieth " Lord, Lord," but :he that death," An, in the true Man, the true Christian, and true Democrat."

The Postmaster General has advertised his readiness to receive proposals until the 31st proximo, for the carriage of the transmarine mails. To judge from tile list upon which he solicits bids, it might be supposed that the commerce of the country has reached its climax; that communication between the various points of the world is not to be developed infinitely beyond the present compass;

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR : Annexed we send you a list of donations since our last, amounting to $5,147. The amount has been remitted to the Association, for the benefit of the widows and orphans, made so by the epidemic. The fever is decreasing rapidly, and the Society advise us that they have all the funds necessary for the relief of the sick, thanks to a generous, charitable people.

FALSE REPORTS BY TELEGRAPH.--We understand that reports were received last evening at different points along the several lines of telegraph leading from this City, stating that the Nigara had arrived at Halifax, bringing intelligence of a great rise in breadstuffs in Europe, consequent upon the actual commencement of hostilities between Russia and Turkey.

DEMOCRATIC STATE CONVENTION AT SYRA CUSE--In consequence of a disarrangement of the telegraphic wires, the main portion of our dispatch from Syracuse failed last night. So far as received, we were informed that there was a vast assemblage of people there from all parts of the State, and from many States of the Union.

BY A MAN IN HIS HONEYMOON. I. Oh, ladies, will you hear a truth, Of late too seldom told to you:-- Nor deem--he begs it of your ruth--The writer over bold to you. For, by the pulses of his youth, He never yet was cold to you. And, therefore, 'tis in sober sooth, That he would now unfold to you What may,--apart from rhythmic flights,-- Be called, the sum of "Woman's Rights."

The active part taken by Mr. Joliffe, counsel in the late slave case before Judge Flinn, in the meeting on the Ist inst., at Masonic Hall. Cincinnati, where a large number of citizens had met preparatory to the impeachment of Judge Flinn before the Legislature, highly incensed the Judge ; and yesterday morning, at an early hour, he stationed himself, with Isaac Vanansdol and other friends, rear the corner of Fifth and Vine streets

I was forcibly reminded this morning that " cool weather" had set in, on going into the Merchants' Exchange, and finding anthracite fires burning in the grates. Last night a slight frost was perceptible on the meadows below the city.

The complimentary dinner (of which I telegraphed you yesterday) to Gen. PILLOW and Hon. FRED. P. STANTON, took place on Saturday evening at the United States Hotel. The affair originated with several Southern gentlemen, most of whom are Tennesseans, and who are for the present located in this city.

All the rumors of a rupture between Secretary MARCY and the President are false. MARCY has the entire confidence of President PIERCE, and the Cabinet is a unit. The Cabinethad a long session to-day, at which Foreign Affairs were discussed. Capt. INGRAMAM will certainly be sustained.

Yesterday afternoon two trotting matches came off on the Union and Centreville Courses, Long Island, each of which was attended by a large number of persons. At the Union Course the following blooded horses were entered for a purse and stake of $125, mile heats, best three in five, in harness:

The steamship Georgia reached here on Saturday evening, and was but slightly damaged She encountered the gale on Tuesday, 80 miles southwest of Cape Hatteras, and soon sprung a leak. The water extinguished the fires, but by the exertions of the passengers and crew at the pumps, the water was reduced, and steam again got up, The passengers generally have left here for Baltimore.
RELIEF FOR NEW ORLEANS.---The Committee recently appointed to raise money for the sufferers at New -Orleans, have made their report of collections as follows: First Ward--CHAS. A. WOOLSEY, $546;

The preparations for the Fair of the Kentucky Mechanic's Institute, are going on finely The Committee on Exhibitions have procured the second story of the Farmers' Tobacco Warehouse on Second-street, as the place for holding the Fair. This room is well-adapted to the purpose being one hundred and eighty-three feet long, and one hundred and twenty-four feet wide.

The city of Detroit and vicinity was visited by a severe frost on the night of the 28th of AugustCrops of potatoes, buckwheat, and corn were badly nipped, while pumpkins, sluashes, cucumbers, melons, sweet potatoes, and other tender plants are completely cut off, and look as black as if a fire had swept over them.

Among the novelties lately arrived at the Palace, are several contributions, from American mechanics, to the Machine Department. Among others, we noticed a very beautifully finished foot-lathe, for turning ivory and small work, constructed by CHARLES STUART, a body aged only fourteen years. This lathe, from its elegance of design and admirable finish, is quite a creditable production for so youthful a mechanic.

Suddenly, on Monday morning, Sept. 12, WILLIAM J. CLARKE. His remains will be conveyed to Greenwood Cemetery for interment, at 10 o'clock this morning, from the First Reformed Presbyterian Church, corner of Myrtle av. and Lawrence at Brooklyn. His friends are invited to attend. Carriages will be in waiting.

Complying with the invitation of a number of Union men, forwarded several weeks ago, Hon. ROBERT TOOMBS, addressed a large concourse of the citizens of Macon and the adjoining counties, at Oglethorpe, on Wednesday last. He arrived in the cars at 10 1/2 o'clock, and in less than an hour, was thundering to the masses at HORNE JELKS' Warehouse, where the rostrum and seats had been provided.

BOARD OF HEALTH.--The Board of Health yesterday refused to permit the ship John W. Minor to land a cargo of rags, cotton, and hides, at the Atlantic Dock. This vessel is from New-Orleans. The Health Officer stated that the cholera was, in October, 1825, introduced into this city by a trunk of clothing, belonging to a man named BAISLEY, who had died with cholera, being sent here from New-Orleans.

Officers DEHAVEN and KEIFER have for some time been aware that a notorious counterfeiter, the ringleader in that business in the West, was so journing in Covington, distributing forged notes and counterfeit money. Yesterday afternoon they went to Covington, to the Hammond House, foot of Greenup-street, where JONES at the time happened to be, though he boarded at the Franklin House.

Returns received by telegraph and otherwise render it certain that there is no choice of Governor by the people. It is also nearly certain that no distinct party will have a majority in the Legislature, and there is no great chan e from last year in the general result. Brunswick, Gorham, Freeport, Falmouth, Durham, Cape Elizabeth, Bath Hallowell, Gardiner, Pittson, Calais, Saco and Biddeford show a Whig gain.

THE WILKKSBARRE SLAVE CASE.--The Philadelphia Bulletin derives from one of the Deputy Marshals, who has returned from Wilkesbarre, the following version of the recent slave case of which we have already published another account:

A meeting of the Board was held last evening, Alderman STUETEVANT in the Chair. A variety of communications, from different parties, with respect to sewers and other unsavory matters, were read and duly disposed of. A petition of John D Lent, Foreman of Knickerboeker Hoss Co No. 2, to have the word "resigned" erased from Thomas H. Bunting's name on the Firemen's register, was referred to the Fire Department.

Mary Foley was placed at the bar on an indictment charging her with stealing a pocket book containing upwards of $50, the property of Edward O'Brien. It appeared from the statement of the prosecutor, that he went to a groggery in the elegant vicinity of the Five Points, and while there. Mary Foley came in and threw her arine round him, embracing him with great fondness.

The great Temperance Convention met in the large Hall of Tremont Temple, this evening, at 7 1/2 o'clock. Hon. ELISHA HUNTINGTON, of Lowell, in the Chair. A resolution was passed, declaring that this is a Convention of men, accordding to common usage. A good deal of opposition was made to the acceptance of this order, but no debate ensued.

Our city has been all astir to-day, celebrating the anniversary of the memorable victory of the American arms upon Lake Erie. This is the fortieth anniversary of that battle and triumph, and the events have been observed in a manner worthy of the occasion. The Governor and his staff were present, and several of the survivors of the action took part in the observance of the day.

The Commercial Bulletin, of the 5th inst., says: The weekly report ending yesterday, (Sunday) at 6 o'clock, A. M., shows a very decided and gratifying diminution. The number of interments for the week ending August 27, was, of yellow fever, 1,352; of other diseases, 176; total, 1,528. The interments for the week just ended are, of yellow fever, 767; of other diseases, 130; total, 897.

We have no mail beyond Mobile to-night. The fever was very bad in that city, and the proportion of deaths on the increase. Tuesday last was observed as a day of fasting and prayer, all business being suspended. The Daily Register had so many hands sick, that it was forced to suspend publication on Monday.

The Board of Local Inspectors of Steam Boilers, having completed their examination of witnesses in relation to the causes of the explosion on board the steamer New World in July last, and having also instituted care ful examinations of the boilers of that vessel, have made their report to the Collector of this port. The document is given in full below.

The Commercial Bulletin, of the 5th inst., says: The weekly report ending yesterday, (Sunday) at 6 o'clock, A. M., shows a very decided and gratifying diminution. The number of interments for the week ending August 27 was, of yellow fever, 1,352; of other diseases, 176; total, 1,528. The interment for the week just ended are, of yellow fever, 767; of other diseases, 130; total, 897.

Of the many curious, not to say funny things emitted from China, the rarest and finest is indubitably the current rebellion. It is so exceedingly odd to detect a specimen of that atrocious crime, which statesmen all about the globe can discuss complacently; divines exult over from the pulpit;

Smokers, do be careful where you throw your lighted cigars. The fire which consumed sundry stables and a dwelling house on Sunday night, and turned a large number of poor people, homeless into the streets, is supposed to have been started by a lighted cigar falling upon a hay-loft in one of the stables.

The Secretary of War returned to Washington on Friday from his excursion to New-England. During his short stop at Hartford, he was complimented by the citizens with an impromptu banquet, at which the Mayor of the city presided, and who welcomed the distinguished guest in an appropriate and cordial address. To this address Col. DAVIS made a brief reply.

The mail has just arrived from Utah, and, to save you space and trouble, I sum up its news. The Utah Indians, who have naturally been dissatisfied since their departure from their old residence and forced settlement in the Colorado Valley, have become thoroughly exasperated, and seem determined to carry on a predatory and murderous conflict with the Mormons.

The accident which occurred on the Camden and Amhoy Railroad, on Friday, resulted in nothing worse than the extermination of one man, the mutilation of another, and a moral. Which latter is, that there never will he security on railroads until a complete system of sentries is established along each line, similar to that upon the Hudson River Railroad:

Mr. WALLACK'S Theatre is retaining that current of success which, last season, swept him on to fortune. The house last night was well filled. to witness the representation of a new comedy entitled "The Mysterious Lady." With some very excellent points, this comedy, which is presented as new, but which smells of a firmer age, on the whole lacks sufficient vivacity to insure it a very long ran.

Accounts from Montevideo, July 25, represent the state of political affairs there on the brink of another revolution. There were two parties actively preparing to submit their rival claims to an arbitrament of arms--the "Reds" and the "Whites." The former are the present administration party; the latter are desirous of obtaining a share of power, and, to that end, failing in their powers of persuasion, appear determined to see what virtue there is in revolution.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: You have in an editorial article in your paper of the 8th inst, under the head of "The Episcopal Trial at Camden," alleged that the charges brought against Bishop DOANE "are venial." Will you be so good as to tell the public what those charges are? They are understood to be lying false swearing, obtaining money upon false pretences, intoxication;

TAXES IN KINGS COUNTY.--At the last meeting of the Board of Supervisors, the Committee on General Taxes reported the general taxes, necessary to be levied in the County of Kings, for the current year, as follows: 1. The State tax, by an ant of the Legislature of the State, passed July 21, 1853, requiring one mill on the dollar of the valuation of the real and personal property in said County.

We give, in another column, an abstract of a speech made at Oglethorpe, Ga., a few days since, by Hon. ROBERT TOOMBS, U. S. Senator from that State, in regard to the election for Governor now pending. The position of Mr. TOOMBS in regard to the political parties of the country, gives importance to his views.

The Secretary of State says he has nothing to do with the communication in the Union's furnishing extract, from DICKINSON's speech in '47, or the editorial comments accompanying it. The editorial introduction was not written by Mr. EAMES, as charged in a dispatch to the New-York Herald, but was written by Judge NICHOLSON, without consultation with Secretary MARCY, or any other persons.

We find the following in the Statesman, Columbia, Mo.: On Saturday last, HIRAM, a negro, belonging to Mr. YOUNG, of this country, was brought before Mr. GORDON, Justice of the Peace, and F. T. RUSSELL. Recorder of Columbia, on the charge of attempting the crime of rape upon a daughter of one of our most respectable citizens.

A fire broke out about 2 o'clock this morning, in the store of L. Y. GARDINER, in the village of Amsterdam, and property to the amount of $30.000 was destroyed. The following is a list of the principal sufferers: L. Y. Gardiner, loss $10,000--partially insured; J. Sandford, loss $5,000partly insured in the Howard and Hartford Companies;

It is not generally known, says the Charleston Courier. that in Barbadoes there is a mysterious vault, in which no one now dares to deposit the lead. It is in a churchyard near the sea-side. In 1807, the first coffin that was deposited in it was that of a Mr. GODDARD; in 1808, a Miss A. M. CHASE was played in it; and in 1812, Miss D CHASE.

Quiet, comfortable times the Whigs had yesterday. The stillest places in town were where the polls were open. In another column will be found the list of delegates to Syracuse, then and there elected. The ballots went into the boxes as noiselessly as snowflakes fall;

Five yachts started yesterday morning on a race to Marcus Hook and back, for a purse of $500. The race was a dull affair, there being no wind, and the distance was accomplished principally by drifting with the tide. The Bianca, a New-York boat, came in first this morning, 19 minutes ahead of the John S Keyser. The Flying Cloud, George L. Broom and D. L. Wilcox, were not in sight.

First impressions of New-Orleans... Curious variety in the population.. The free people of slight African Mood... Prostitution, 4c. I was awakened by the loud ringing of a hand-bell, and turning out of my berth, dressed by dim lamp-light.

The friends of Temperance in Massachusetts have decided that those, not males, who put themselves in trowsers and on platforms at public meetings. and who are otherwise anxious to perform these duties which nature has assigned to men alone, shall not trifle with, or injure a righteous cause.

On Sunday afternoon, says the Buffalo Commercial, as Mr. Berry, of this city, in company with a friend, was driving a spirited young horse attached to a light buggy, the animal became restive and took to kicking. When the dashboard was demolished, the occupants of the buggy jumped out and the horse ran.

Will the Washington Union throw enough light on the Fishery business, to teach us why the squadron is returning, in the midst of the season ? Simultaneous with the announcement of the fact, we learn of wholesale seizures of our fishing vessels; of others returning home with meagre cargoes; and of general loss and disaster.

SUPPOSED MURDER AT DUNKIREK.--The Dun-Kirk Journal relates a mysterious occurrence on the beach near that village, which, it is suspected, is in some way connected with burglary or some more serious crime. It was blowing quite a gale on the lake, when two men were discovered on the Each, in the act of starting or taking care of a fire.

It is stated by the Boston Travelter that two Boston officers fell into a trap of their own making, a few days since, by which operation one of them enjoyed a short imprisonment within stone walls. The Boston Association for detecting counterfeiters, dispatched two of their officers to Canada to purchase of a gang known to exist there, some counterfeit bills. for the purpose,

The Sam lizard is all alive--albeit, not inconveniently so. We have started within half an hour of embarkation, and the wild night, tumbling waves, and driving rain outside, only increase the zest with which folk apply themselves to enjoyment within. Merrily the music-sounds issue from the ladies' cabin--fiddle, flute, and guitar, are in full operation, even as are the nimble feet of the dancers, as cotillion follows cotillion.

A NEW BAPTIST CHURCH AT BOSTON.-On Monday, the corner-stone of a new church about to be erected on Somerset street, Boston, by the First Baptist Society, of which Rev. R. R. NEALr is pastor, was laid with appropriate ceremonies. Among those present were Mayor SEAVER, exMayor BlGLOW, Hon. ABBOTT LAWRENCE, the pastors of the Baptist churches, and also several pastors of other denominations.

The preliminary proceedings of the Convention were settled in caucuses last evening. The " Hards" fixed on IRA P. BARNES, Clerk of the Senate, from Chenango, for temporary Chairman. They are now again in caucus, and claim a majority of fairly elected delegates.

The Primary Elections for the choice of City Delegates to the Whig State Convention, to be held at Syracuse on the 5th of October next, took place yesterday, in the various Wares of the City. Everything passed off quietly, and without opposition, except in two or three wards. We give below a complete list of the Delegates and committees chosen in the several districts:

Smith, Mobile; John W. Weems, N. O.; William A. Grant, Ala....Prescott--J. W. Caldwell, Charleston; H. W. Heird, Baltimore; C. L. Kenner, Tex.; William T. Lowher, Phila.; Wm. P. Curtis, St. Louis;...

While we are reading with interest and much pleasure the letters of Superintendent BSALE, his friends in California are suffering great uneasiness because or his non-arrival. His delay in leaving the frontier, they were not aware of, nor of his several interruptions in reaching the branches of the Gre at Colorado of the West.

FREIGHT DEPOT OF THE BUFFALO AND NEWYORK CITY RAILROAD AT BUFFALO.-This huge building is gradually rising from its foundation-the stone work having been completed, and a commencement made with the brick. It covers about an acre and a third; its dimensions being: Length, 249 feet; breadth, 210 feet; height in centre, 35 feet: height in sides, 17 feet.

DR. I. P. GARVIN--Dear Sir: I have just received your favor of the 26th inst., stating that am represented by Whig presses and itinerant orators in Georgia as an Abolitionist, and I thank you for the opportunity you have afforded me of saying in reply: 1. That I am not and never have been an Abolitionist. in any sense of that term.

TheMissouriRiver, on Saturday week, succetded in cutting a new mouth, or debouch, into the Mississippi, across the point of land lying about half a mile above where it has run of late years. It now strikes the Mississippi in a direction which is likely to prevent the washing of the Illinois or eastern shore to any injurious extent.

A grand banquet in honor of C. E. DETMOLD, Esq., Engineer to the Crystal Palace Association, was given at the Astor House, last evening, by the contractors and mechanics engaged in the construction of the Palace.

Last evening, when the upward Boston train of cars reached Manchester, GEORGE: H. DODGE, Esq., President of the Manchester and Lawrence Railroad, left the car in which he had been riding, where his carpet bag, containing money and papers to the value of about $15,000, was hanging. Upon returning, it was missing, and has not yet been re. covered.

The loss by the fire, on Monday night; at the corner of Flushing-avenue and Adelphi-street, is much larger than at first supposed. Messrs DENIKE ELY'S loss amounts to about $4,000; five horses were destroyed, together with a quantity of laths, lime, cement, They were insured or $2,??50, as follows: $1,000 in the Hamilton Office, New-York, $750 in the Atlantic Office, Brooklyn and $800 in the Firemen's Insurance Company, Brooklyn. n.

Our additional returns of the election do not affect the results indicated last night. No Gov. ernor is chosen by the people, and neither of the prominent political parties have a majority in the Legislature. It will probably be some days before the exact result is known. Second Dispatch PORTLAND. Sept. 13-9 o'clock, P. M.

The State Temperance Convention reassembled this morning, at 10 o'clock, at which time there were about 500 people in the Hall. During the forenoon, the number Increased until the Hall was well hiled. Prayer was offered by Rev. Dr. DANNETT, of this city.

We have New-Orleans papers of Tuesday and Wednesday. The decided decrease of the fever was restoring animation in New-Orleans, and the boats had resumed their regular trips up the river. The Crescent, however, says the epidemic is only stayed for want of material, and the papers generally warn strangers from approaching the city.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Time: SIR: Having observed in Wednesday's issue of your valuable daily, an article with the above caption, I felt rather surprised to notice that the writer entirely omitted to mention the vast amount of injury and injustice done to the interests of the less fortunate class of inhabitants,

There is a rumor afloat here to-day, that Mr. CUSHING will go to France, and that Mr. DALLAS will assume the office of Attorney-General. The rumor, however, is not credited. It is also rumored that Messrs. GUTHRIE and DAVIS are about to retire; but that is certainly without foundation.

The Syracuse Convention evidently forgot all about the President's and his Cabinet's high hopes of them, yesterday. They had squalls and confusion extraordinary,-a regular blow-out, two Conventions, and such a lot of hired bullies up from New-York, that the Adamantines did not hesitate to say that they feared for their lives.

Why is it that a portion of the Democratic press is waging war on the President for his appointments to office? Have we fought the battle for offices or for principles ? If the former, then every man in the United States who voted for PIERCE, should he provided with one; if the latter, as the simpleminded mass honestly believe, then is such a war shameless in the extreme.

Receipts since our last: FLOUR 3,000 bbls.; WHEAT 25,000 bush; CORN 9,000 bush; OATS 11,000 bush.; BABLEY 2,000 bush; FLOUR has been in good steady demand for the East and home trade; sales 2,000 bbls. at $5 37@$6 50 for State, and $6 37@$6 6 ?? for common and mixed Western. The President, J. TROTTER, Esq., in the Chair. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. Petitions Referred--Of Alexander Young and others, for a rewar in Fourteenth street. Of Samuel Peck and others for the introduction of the Croton water in Thirty-eighth-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues.

POISONIG OF A FAMILY, AND ARREST OF THE FEMALE CRIMINAL.-- In the Police Court. yesterdayy afternoon, complaint was entered by officer UNDER WOOD against one "CATHARINE EVANS," SO called, an Italian woman, who has been serving in the capacity of cook in the family of Mr. JAMES PAINE, No. 132 Essex street, for the crime of administering arsenic, with the intent of taking life.

A RACE ON MOUNT WASHINGTON--A footrace against time was run on Mount Washington on Friday last. A gentleman bet with one of the proprietors of the Summit House, that he (the proprietor) could not run a mile in eight minutes, starting from the very top of Mount Washington. The bet was a gold watch.

BURRNING OF TIIE FEMALR INTITUTE AT MONTCOMERY, ALA-- It is a mutter of serious regret to announce the destruction by fire of the capacious and elegant buildings of the Metropolitan Female Institute of this city, on Friday morning. The fire originated in the servants' rooms, and soon enveloped the south wing, and from thence rapidly spread to the main edifice and other connecting structures.

The Court of Bishops have been all the morning deliberating in secret session on the motion to dismiss the presentment. Bishops WHITTINGHAM, HOPKINS and McCOSKEY, participated in the debate. Great eagerness is manifested to hear the result of the vote, which will probably be taken before the adjournment to-day.

Five boys, named Patrick Gallagher, Thomas Gallagher, William Donelly, Smith and Hanagan, were indicted for breaking and entering the housed of Mr. Hotehkiss, of Sixth-avenue, and stealing a quantity of fancy furniture, a guitar, a bottle of champagne and other property.

I sat in my cupola the other night, when. for several hours, there was on alarm of fire, and revolved many things in my mind. And there came back to my memory-reviewing the days of childhood-a knife with many blades, fifteen or sixteen, which, for a long series of months, worried my imagination with suggestions of its beauty and utility.

The statuary at the capitol has been opened to inspection, as far as a removal of the framing in which it was brought from Leghorn will admit. The outer enclosure remains. Until that is removed and the whole group thrown open, so as to be taken in at a single glance of the eye, a fair and final judgment cannot be pronounced.

The excitement and confilsion are on the increase. There is a delegation of about thirty fighting men, headed by IRVLNG, of Washington Market, here. The Adamantines charge that they are employed by Softs to intimidate, and hold possession of the building; and all sorts of manoeuvres are making by each side to head off their opponents.

The Portsmouth Globe contains the purser's statement of the recent accident to the steamship Georgia. The vessel was much damaged, her hurricane deck, state-rooms, bulk-heads, , being cut up for firewood, all her wood having been washed away. Many of the passengers lost all their baggage and money.
EVENING SCHOOLS.-The Free Public Evening Schools are to open on Monday evening next, at School House No 1, corner of Concerd and Adams-street, and at the new school-house in Warren-street.

An adjourned general meeting of the Trades of this City was held at Military Hall, Bowery, last evening. Mr. D. G COLTON occupied the chair. It having been suggested that the first business should be the resumption of their duties by the Committee on Credentials.

We have received dates from Galveston to the 28 inst , and Indianola to the 30th ult. The yellow fever has made its appearance in Galveston, as the following resolution, published by the Board of Health on the 28 inst., will show;

At the recent Democratic dinner, given in Washington, in honor of Gen. PILLOW and Hon. FRED. P. STANTON, the former gentleman delivered himself of certain political heresies in relation to Cuba, which demand the animadversion of every man who wishes to see the character of the American Government, and the character of the American Republic, continue, as heretofore, above suspicion and reproach.
BABIES ON THE ISTHMUS.--A gentleman who has lately "traveled over Jordan," on his way to the promised land of California, relates a queer incident that took place while he was crossing.

ANOTHER COUNTERFEITER ARRESTED- $1,000 IN SPURIOUS NOTES ON THE STATE BANK OF OHIO FOUND!-One day last week a man stopped at the Washington House, Covington, who registered his name as GEORGE KINGSLEY.

THE COURT.--The Hudson County Court of Over and Terminer, in session at Bargen Corners, was Occupied yesterday with the suit between Jersey City an the heirs of the COLES Estate. It will probably be before the Court throughout this day The suit is for a piece of ground bounded by North-First street on the north, Eni--street, on the east Eortherly by South-First street, and westerly by Jersev-avenue and Coles street.

The schooner Gazelle, from Belize, Honduras, has arrived here, bringing Mr. HEMPSTEAD, late American Consul at that port. Mr. H. reports that on July 12, a party of Spaniards attacked Limas. killed the policemen, and attempted the lives of the magistrates, the Collector, and the British Consul.

The advices received by the Franklin and Niagara this morning have had no effect upon BREAD-STUFFS Both buyers and sellers are holding off for the reception of their private circulars The receipts and stocks of FLOUR Continue extremely small, and there is a moderate export demand.

The U. S. M. steamship Franklin, Captain WOTTON, from Havre and Southampton, arrived yesterday morning at 6 o'clock. She made the passage in twelve days and eight hours. The Franklin brought over six hundred tons of French and Swiss goods and one hundred and sixty passengers.
THE PROJECTED COUNTY HOUSE.-A remonstrance against the erection of the projected County House on Vanderbelt-avenue is being circulated throughout the city for signatures.

In the Chemical Department of the Palace, a new oil. made from the seed of the cotton plant by WILBUR CO., New-Orleans, is worthy of attention. Past efforts to extract this oil have hitherto failed from two causes now obviated. First, from the difficulty of milling the seed; secondly, from the apparent impossibility of clarifying the oil.

ARREST OF MURDERERS.--We are pleased to learn that the murderers of poor old, inoffensive WM. COLEMAN, of Staunton, are most probably under arrest.

A NEGRO VETERAN.--Few persons have traveled in Texas who have not heard of THOMAS SAVOY, alias Black Tom, alias the Special Citizen Of Bexar Co. He was by trade a barber, but by inclination a soldier, and his history is intimately connected with the warlike part of that of Texas.

London Money Market .... SEPT 1. In consequence of the positive tone of the announcements regarding the final settlement of the Turkish dispute, the English funds opened this morning with a firm appearance. which was followed however. by a sudden and rather severe reaction.

THE MAINE LAW.-The squabble between NEAL Dow and JOHN NEAL. has brought out a good many statements respecting the operations of the Maine Law. Mr. NEAL'S assertions seem not to be supported by the facts in the case.
The Bank of England has raised the rate of interest on Commercial bills to 4 percent. There was nothing politically important stirring in England.

The following are the resolutions passed by the "Hard-Shells:" Resolved, That the platform of principal established by the Democra ic National Convention, at Baltimore in 1852, continues to receive our hearty concurrence and approbation as a whole, and in all Its parte, and we here by declare our adherence thereto, and reliance there-upon. as containing in letter and in spirit the true principles of Democracy.

At New-Orleans there is a most gratifying decrease in the virulence of the pestilence, and public confidence is beginning to be restored. The sums received from all parts of the country by the Howard Association, were very large, and were daily arriving.

Liverpool Cotton Market. Purchases for the trade during the week, although large, are yet less than the consumption, and holders having continued to supply the market very freely with all descriptions prices have favored buyers, although not sufficiently to alter quotations.

FATAL AFFRAY.--Yesterday afternoon, information was received by Coroner WILHELM that it was necessary to hold as inquest on the body of a man lying dead at the Bellevue Hospital. The Coroner proceeded to the institution, and, after making due inquiries, ascertained the deceased had died of injuries received from the hands of a man named JOHN RIMBACK.
