To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: "Once more upon the waters." We had heard of the wonders or the Sague nay a few faint and imperfect descriptions, and determined to see and judge for ourselves. Monday afternoon, therefore, found us on board a most unpromising-looking craft, described in the hand-bills as the well-known sea going steamer, Rounland Hill, with an UPPER DINING SALOON, splendidly furnished, with COMMODIOUS STATE-ROOMS, ,

A serious accident resulting in the death of one man, and a serious injury to four others, occurred on the Canal Railroad about 5 o'clock, on Monday evening. It seems that a party of Irishmen, on their way down the road in a hand car left the car standing upon the tract alone.

Mr. J. COCHRANE observed that he should like to hear Mr. GROVER's opinion of the ticket. Mr. M. GROVER said: Mr. PRESIDENT AND GENTLEMEN OF THE CONVENTION: My opinion of this ticket is called for. This is the fourth State Convention I have attended in Syracuse, and I think, including myself, we have got entirely the best ticket that was ever made here. [Laughter.]

TWO MEN KILLED AT TROY.-- We learn from the Troy Times. that a serious accident occurred at the new depot building in that city, on Thursday evening, by which two men lost their lives. As near as could be ascertained, two of the supports, each about 150 feet long, had been raised, and, as it was supposed, properly secured by iron rods and rope guys.

The Number of deaths reported during the 24 hours ending this morning was 54-including 47 from yellow fever. We have sad accounts from Lower Mississippi. The fever was raging dreadfully in the villages and plantations, and large numbers of negroes were dying.

New-Orleans mails of Friday contain details of the ravages of the vellow fever in that vicinity. At Thibodeaux there were twenty deaths in three days The detention of the mints was caused by damages to the railroads from late rains.

At Louisville a woman named Theresa Bowes was killed by a stab in the side, while walking the street. A man named Smith Peters, who was with her, received eight or nine cuts in the neck and back. Peters says the stabbing was done by two men whom he did not know. His story is doubted by some. The sister of the deceased says Peters had previously threatened to kill Thresea.

DREADFUL RAILROAD ACCIDENT. --The morning express train on the New-York Central Railroad, going West, while standing at the Onedia Depot, was run into by a freight train going in the same direction The passenger cars were badly sh-ttered, and Mr. BUCKLEY THATCHER, of Medway County, Ohio, was instantly killed.

In attempting a review of the scenes enacted here during the last two days by the Democracy, it is difficult to tell how or where to commence. Indeed, unless one is more intimately familiar with the secret history, objects and aims of the respective factions, than an independent outsider is expected to be, he will find it quite impossible to understand those scenes. But there are some things,

Gen. PILLOW, one of the leading politicians of Tennessee, made a speech at Washington a few days since, a report of which was published in the TIMES of Tuesday last,-in which he insisted that any attempt on the part of Spain to abolish Slavery in Cuba, would absolve the United stares from all their treaty obligations, and justify them in forcibly seizing and annexing the Island.

The town of Somerset, in Perry County, Ohio, hits recently been the scene of serious riot and bloodshed. The Sheriff of Perry County sent dispatches to Zanesville for military aid to quell the riot, and the City Guards and a company of volunteers, to the number of about seventy-five, repaired to the besieged town.

YELLOW FEVER AT MONTGOMERY, ALA-The Board of Health of Montgomery report that on the 12th August, two cases of yellow fever arrived in that city direct from New-Orleans. Since that day, 13 cases have occurred, nine of which came direct from New Orleans, Mobile and Pensacola The remaining four cases occurred in a family of Irish laborers. living near the river.

The murderer of Mr. and Mrs. COZZENS was arrested last night, in a barn in Sherburne, about a mile from COZZENS' house. He confessed to having called COZZENS out of his house, but denies that be murdered him.

MURDER IN A LUNATIC ASYLUM--CHRISTIAN GEINTNER, the German who was tried at Niagara, three years ago, for the most diabolical murder of his father, mother and two sisters, and who was by the Jury found guilty, and strongly recommended to mercy, has committed another in the Lunatic Asylum, Toronto, whither he had been sent under supposition of insanity.

MY DEAR SIR: I have this moment received your favor of the 10th, calling my attention to an article in the Washington Union, charging me, in substance, with having favored and advocated the WILMOT Proviso in the Senate of the United States, in 1847. and presenting partial extracts of a speech I then made to prove it.

On Friday, Sept 16 EDWARD DUNIGAN, aged 40 years. His friends and acquaintances and also those of his mother, and brother. James B Kinker are respectfully invited to attend his funeral. without further invitation from his mother's residence, No. 175 Henry st, tomorrow, (Saturday,) at 10 o' clock. A.M. or from St. Peter's Church, Barley st. at 11 o' clock, when the funeral ceremonies will have terminated.

On Friday last, at 1 o'clock, P. M, the youthful murderer, of whose trial and conviction I gave brief sketches, for the benefit of the readers of the TIMES, a few months since, suffered the extreme penalty of the law. Soon after his conviction, he made a full confession of his guilt, and professed, to his spiritual adviser, contrition for the enormous crime.

SALES OF STOCKS AT PHILADELPHIA--Friday--First Board--$500 Spring Garden 6s, '76 102; $600 City Railroad 6s. 64, 93; $4000 Suiqa hanna Canal, C4: $1,000 United States 6s. '56, 109 1/2; 100 Washington Railroad, 384; 300 Morris Canal. 17 1/4; 100 Schuylkill Navigation Preferred 31 1/4; 80 Chester Valley Railroad, 13 1/4; '2 Mechanics' Bank. 34 1/4.

We find in the Boston Journal the following particulars of the horrid murder committed on Wednesday night, in Sherourne, a quiet town, about a mile and a half from the village of South Framingham. Mass.

On Thursday night, Madame DE BERG'S Concert at Metrepolitan Hall was well and fashionably attended. The programme offered particular inducements to lovers of music, and created hopes which were perhaps but partially realized. Madame STEFFANONE was, we regret to say, so indisposed that it was impossible for her to appear as promised.

Thursday was prolific in Railroad accidents. The writer cf this paragraph encountered one on the road between Bennington, Vt., and Troy, remarkable for the very narrow but complete escape which it made from being serious.

There is nothing, perhaps, in connection with modern improvements which would so astonish our grandfathers, if those worthy old persons were to come to life again, as the changes for the better in the way of locomotion.

The Convention was called to order at 9 A. M., Prof. JEWETT in the chair. There were about twenty delegates present. S. HASTINGS GRANT, ESq., Secretary, read the minutes of Thursday's proceedings, which were adopted. Mr. CHARLES FOLSOM, Chairman of the Business Committee, reported the following order of business for the day:

Arrived, brig Mary Adeline. from Rio Jaeiro. Spoke, lat. 35. long 91.45, bark W. G. Lewis, from Rio ion Boston Also arrived, brig Alida, from New-York for San Juan, leaky, sails, and otherwise damaged ingales of 5th and 12th On 12th passed unknown wreck in the Gulf.

The first sod of the European and North American Railroad was turned yesterday, at this place, by Lady HEAD, assisted by the LieutenantGovernor, in the presence of about 25,000 persons. The grand procession of the Trades, Fire Companies, Masons, , accompanied by bands of music, was two miles long. Commodore SHUBRICK and suite were present.

MEETING OF LIQUOR-SKLLERS--RISE IN THE PRICE OF GROG-Puonant to a call published in the daily papers, a meeting was held at the Broadway Houses last evening composed of many of the restaurateurs and saloon proprietors of the city, for the purpose of advising in regard in the property of raising the price of "drinks" from 6 1/2 to 10 cents per "drink"

NARROW ESCAPE OF THE STEAMSHIP GEORGIA.-- A correspondent of the Baltimore Sun gives the following account of the New-York steamer Georgia, which made so narrow an escape from destruction last week, in a storm off Cape Hatteras, while on her way, with 450 passengers, to California:

The Russian Minister spent some time in the State Dpartment to-day. It was rumored that he communicated to Secretary MARCY the important fact that Russia approves of the course of Austria in the KOSZTA affair.

On the 15th inst, by Rev. Dr Moore, at St Andrew's church, Staten Island. His Excellency, VICTORLANO DE L. PAREDES to ANNE, daughter of the late Malcolm Mac Gregor Esq formerly British Consul to Panama. On Thursday 10th inst. at Fort Hamilton, L I., by Rev. Dr Sears, FRANCIS HOPKINS to REBECCA H., daughter of Wm S Sea's, Esq. at of this city.

The United States Mail steamship Washington, Captain E. M. FITCH. the arrival of which of COWES was reported on Saturday, August 27, had a narrow escape from accident and perhaps from destruction, while approaching the Needles o Friday, during the heavy gale which blew on that day.

By this conveyance I send you several numbers of the British Pasket, which I recommend to your perusal. You will note the strenuous efforts made by Mr. LATHAM, at the head of a Commission of English merchants, to convince the diplomatic agents of the flagrant injustice they were committing in recognizing URQUIZA'S blockade of this port-an injustice acting solely to the prejudice of foreign commerce.

The Court convened at 10 o'clock, the president, six judges and twenty-four Senators, answering to their names at the roll-call After reading of minutes, the President stated if there was no other business before the Court, he would proceed to take the final judgment of the Court upon the articles.

We continue receive communications concerning the charges against Bishop DOANE, and the proceedings that have been had in regard to them. As the controversy has now been closed. we trust, forever, we deem it wholly unprofitable to continue the public discussion of its merits.

City Morning. The following is the City Inspector's weekly statement of deaths in the City and County of New-York, for the week ending. Saturday, September 17: TOTAL NUMBER--447. Men, 91; women, 56; boys, 148; girls 152.

The Coroner's Jury have closed their investigations in the matter of the collision on the Central Railroad. They have agreed upon their verdict, but it is not drawn up in form. They have been in session two days. Their finding will contain a statement of the facts, as shown by the testimony, and the verdict is based on these facts.
Our readers will learn with interest that the incipent legal steps have been taken for carrying into effect this important measure, authorized by the recent law of the Legislature.

THIRD DAY. Soon after 9 o'clock, on Saturday, the Convention was called to order--Prof. JEWETT in the Chair. There were only a few members present. In the absence of Mr. GRANT, the Secretary, the reading of the minutes was dispensed with, and Mr. DANIEL GILMAN requested to act as Secretary pro tem

LOMBARDY.--Some Slight nominations have been made in the state of seige of Milan. An additional impost, on direct taxes had been decreed to cover the deficiency is the revenue of 1852 and 1853. The decree in signed by STRASOLDO. Austrian Lieutenant.

The verdict of the Coroner's Jury in the case of the accident on the Hudson River Railroad, will be found in another column. The occurrence is not charged upon any one in particular, though censure of the Company is implied, for lax regulations for such emergencies.

THE FIREMEN.--The firemen of Jersey City held a meeting Friday evening, at Franklin Hall, relative to their differences with the Board of Aldermen, which was more fully attended and enthusiastic than those previously held. Mr. JOHN SYLVESTER presided, and H. H. BAKER Was Secretary.

Liverpool Markets. LIVERPOOL, Tuesday, Sept. 6, 1853. Since the departure of the Niagara on Saturday last, out COTTON market has worn a dull and heavy aspect. The desire on the part of holders to make progress in sales with such a limited inquiry adding to the prevailing gloom, which necessarily gives the advantage in price in favor of buyers.

The trial of Rev. H. W. SMULLER, before the Ulster Classis, was closed yesterday morning. Two of the specifications were dismissed without trial. The third was tried, with the following verdict: "1. That the Classis cannot say that brother SMULLER was guilty of any adulterous intentions.

The Russian, Prussian and Austrian ministers have filed in the State Department a protest against the conduct of Capt. INGRAHAM. Russia and Prussia side with Austria against the United States. Secretary MARCY'S views of this momentous matter are matured, and will probably be submitted to the Cabinet meeting tomorrow.

We learn from a letter received in this City, that Rev. Mr. and Mrs. HARTWELL had just arrived at that port, to reinforce the American Board of C. T. Missions at that place. They had been at Amoy during the troubles.

OLE BULL'S Concert, on Thursday night, was very fully attended. NIBLO'S Saloon was crowded, and we are sorry to add it was terribly hot there. It should be remembered that cool air is rather refreshing than otherwise, and that on such beautiful nights it would be no sin to open a window. But, suffocating though it was, the audience bore it with becoming patience.

STORM AT CINCINNATI--BRIDGE WASHED AWAY--EXTENSIVE DAMAGE TO PRIVATE PROPERTY.--Yesterday morning a violent shower visited our city and the country adjacent, which by advices received at this office up to a late hour last night, has done immense damage to private property on the side of the bill, and the corn crops in the country.

VICTOR BIRDSETE died very suddenly at his residence in Pomeroy, last night, aged 71. He had resided in Pomeroy for forty six years, was twice elected to Congress; once to the State Senate; to the Constitutional Convention, in 1821, and frequently to the Assembly.

FIRE.--About 12 o'clock on Thursday night, a fire broke out in Messrs. McWAY SON's rope-walk situated in Fifth-street, between South Eighth and South Ninth-streets, about 250 feet of which, together with a three-story brick building, owned and occupied by the said firm, for the engine-boiler and a large quantity of machinery; a stable containing a quantity of feed and several sets of harness. and a light wagon, were entirely destroyed.

THE SHERDORN MURDER--ARREST OF THE MURDERER.--Yesterday afternoon, Coroecr ELIPHALET WHEELER. of Framingham, held an in quest on the body of REUBEN COZZENS, Who was murdered in Sherhorn, on Wednesday evening.

The U.S. Mail steamship Arctic, from Liverpool about 11 1/2 o'clock M. A. Wednesday, September 7, arrived here yesterday morning. The Africa arrived Sunday, 4th inst., at "Bell Buoy," off Liverpool, 4 o'clock, morning.

The Turin Gazette publishes the law authorizing the Sardinian Minister of Finance to carry out the Convention with the Transatlantic Company at Genoa, to establish steam communication between Sardinia and America.

The steamship Alabama, G B. SCHENCK, commander, reached this port on Saturday. She made the voyage from Savannah in 58 hours. She brings papers to the 14th inst. The Republican has this item of news: SUDDEN DEATH.--JOSEPH GEORGE, Esq., one of the most respectable citizens of Savannah, died suddenly at his house yesterday morning, of apoplexy.

Trial Trip of the Golden Age. The new Australian steamship Golden Age Lieut. D.D. PORTER, U.S.N., Commander, went down the bay on Saturday for a trial trip. A company of nearly six hundred guests was on board, nearly half of whom were ladies,--a novelty on such occasions, and a very praiseworthy innovation on established custom.

We tender citizens our sincere congratulations on the decreasing mortality of our City. The number of interments during the past week was 447,--which is 47 less than for any week of the past two months, and 84 less than last week. Note how the figures stand.

From France we have nothing more important than the fluctuating accounts of the grain markets. Numerous vessels had arrived at Marseilles, with wheat from Odessa. These advices were of 31st ult. The price of wheat had fallen considerably at Rouen and Lille, and likewise at Villeneuve, Astaffort, Marmande, and Moissac, in the Lot and Garonne.

CATHARINE KENNEDY.--No indictment was found against this girl, by the grand jury of Hudson County last week, on the charge of aiding in the robbing of the Hudson County Bank, and her sureties were discharged. No person was indicted for that crime.

Our information on the Eastern question is as vague as ever. In Britain the public appear to have decided that the subject either is settled, or will be settled without more ado, and therefore little or nothing is now said on the subject.

The new clipper ship Matchless, Captain PORTER, hence on the 6th instant, for San Francisco, and which returned yesterday, in distress, experienced a severe hurricane on the 8th, in lat. 39 29, ion. 59 45, which carried away all her three topmasts, and head of the foremast, and swept her decks of water-casks, provisions, and spars.

DARING BURGLARY AND RONBERY IN BROOME COUNTY.--On Saturday night last, the house of Dr. S. HUGGINS, of Sandford, Broome County, N.Y., about six miles from this village, was broken open by a gang of villains, disguised and painted black, one of them having the Anti-Rent disguise.

From the London News. The mail brings no news of any abatement of the terrible fever at New Orleans. The deaths are still told in hundreds. There is in existence, and in England, a pamphlet written by a physician to prove that New-Orleans is the most healthy city in the United States.

New-Orleans papers of the 11th inst., are received. The total number of deaths during the week ending on the 10th inst., was 576, including 421 by the yellow fever. The total number of deaths since the commencement of the epidemic, had been 7,700 by yellow fever, and by other diseases 2,400.

Matters are now in preparation in regard to the Agricultural and Mechanics' Fair in this State. The place of exhibition, which is within convenient distance of the depot, is the same occupied in this city for a similar purpose two years ago.

The undersigned members of the State Central Committee, just appointed by the Democratic State Convention, all of whom were present during the action and deliberations of that body, as members or witnesses of its proceedings, deem it their duty to call attention to a single fact, which marred the otherwise gratifying unanimity and harmony of that body, and to repel a calumnious and unfounded charge made against its members.

A dieastrous break occurred in the Erie Canal this morning, at 1 o'clock, which it will require, it is supposed, ten or twelve days to repair. The location of the break is near Bushnell's Basin, about ten miles east of this city. About twenty rods of the towpath are carried away, and the bottom of the canal is washed out to an average of six feet for a distance of ninety rods.

Dispatches from Odessa, August 19, state that business was brisk, and prices still looking up. Corn continued in demand for Italy and France, and there were large arrivals of grain from Ghourka. From Galatz. August 23, it was reported that 120 vessels, laden with corn, were at Salina, unable to get to sea; several having been detained four months for want of lighters, had their cargoes heated.

The Telegraph announces among other victims of the dreadful plague at New-Orleans, Mr. HARRY R. W. HILL, a well known merchant of that city. Mr. H. was considered acclimated to the fever, and probably remained at home in works of charity and good offices at this season of death and desolation, under what has proved to be a mistaken sense of security.

The Queen had terminated her visit to Ireland, and had gone to her residence at Balmoral, Scotland. Nothing of the least political import had occurred, but the principal members of the Cabinet remained in London, awaiting the development of the Turkish affair.

By the bark Peacock, at Salem, the Register has received advices from Montevideo to the 6th August. Captain UPTON was ashore when the contest occurred between the National Guards and the black troops of the line, and found the bullets flying too thick for comfort.

From Berlin, August 30, it was affirmed that, depending on its own resources alone, there was no apprehension of scarcity in Prussia, although he harvest had been but indifferent. A destructive fire had happened at Lubec.

From the Evening Post MIDDLET, WN, ORANGE CO . Sept. 16, 1853. The nominations of State officers made by the Democratic State Convention held at Syracuse on the 13th and 14th insts., are well received here, particularly that of WHEELER H. BRISTOL of this county, for State Engineer and Surveyor.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign ?? BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,). No. 112 Broadway, A.T. STEWART Co., (do.).. Broadway, cor. Reader. Agricultural Warehouse. R.L. ALLEN, (late A. B. Allen Co.) 189 191 Wate.

Coroner HILTON held an inquest at Bellevue Hospital on Friday afternoon, on the body of JOHN SCHAPP, who came to his death by reason of blows on the heat, inflicted with a hatchet in the hands of WILLIAM RIMBACH, on the 5th inst. The particulars of the case appeared in yesterday's TIMES.

We published some weeks since a report of proceedings in Court, involving the quarrels which have been for some years notorious between Hon. Mrs. NORTON celebrated as an Author, and her husband. A separation took place between them many years since: the rumored cause of which was undue intimacy between the lady and Lord MELROORNE.
The Southern correspondent of the DAILY TIMES, in his last letter from New-Orleans, hinted at a very important matter to us in New-York--the relation of vice in one class to extravagance in another.

ROAD SUNK.--A piece of road about ten rods in length, on the South-bridge Road, beyond the junction of the Providence, Norwich, and Western Railroads, in this city, sunk some six feet underwater on Friday night last.

We publish this morning the address of the un-terrified Democracy recently assembled at Syracuse. They tell a very straight story, and make out a very strong case in support of the regularity of their proceedings and nominations.

FATAL CASE OF SOMNAMBULISM.--Yesterday morning Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest at No. 164 Seventh avenue, on the body of HELEN McDONALD, who was killed by falling from the third-story window of the above house, while in a state of somnambulism.

The DAILY TIMES completed the second year of its existence on Saturday morning. For the first twelve months it was published on a sheet only half its present size, and sold at half its present price;--so that, in its present form, it is only one year old.

On Friday, Sept. 17, THOMAS O. HASLEHURaT, in the 26th year of his age. His friends, and those of his brothers, are invited to attend his funeral, from the resilence of his brother, Amity-at., Brooklyn. His remains will be taken to New York Mills for interment.

The following additional particulars of the accident on Me Central Railroad we find in the Utica Ga??tta of the 17th: The Express train which left here for Syracuse, at 2 o'clock this morning, while making its usual stop at Oneida, was run into about 3 o'clock by the freight train which left this city immediately after it.

For more than one reason, considerable interest attaches to the success of the steamer Golden Age, of whose trial-trip down the bay, on Saturday, we have given a full account in another part of this morning's paper.

The ceremony of laying the corner-stone of the COOPER Institute took place on Saturday morning, in the presence of the Mayor, the founder of the work, the architect, the workmen, and a small audience of the public.
Lieut. SCHWARTZ, commander of the brig Ussaro, who figured in the KOSZTA affair, is promoted to the rank of Captain, and put in command of the corvette Juno.

Calamities thicken on the Hudson River Railroad. On Saturday, two workmen on the road were killed near the same spot, and within a short time of each other, by a projecting bridge timber. The particulars of these additional catastrophes will be found below.

SICKLES and THURSTON, GREEN CO. vs. GEORGE H. CORLISS AND JOHN BARSTOW, of Providence. This was a motion for injunction to restrain the defendants from any further infringement of the patent granted to FREDERICK E. SICKLES, for the improvement known as " Sickles Cut-Off;"

EXCITEMENT AT CINCINNATI.-A novel excitement has just sprung up in Cincinnati. Some of the market people, both farmers and hucksters, have been arrested, fined, and imprisoned, under a city ordinance, for continuing the system of forestalling, by which the prices of domestic produce are greatly raised on the citizens.

ATTEMPT TO RELEASE KISSANE AND FINDLAY FROM JAIL.-An unsuccessful attempt was made on the 16th inst.. to release KISSANE and FINDLAY, in jail in Cincinnati, on a charge of forgery. The persons making the attempt were REUBEN KISSANE, a younger brother of the one in prison, and another lad named JOHN B. POLLOCK. They were, however, detected by the watchmen.

New-Orleans papers of Monday and Tuesday last are received. They contain the details of the Mexican news by the steamer Texas. Mr. GADSDEN on presenting his credentials to SANTA ANNA, expressed a desire that the United Slates should cultivate friendly relations with Mexico SANTA ANNA'S reply was eminently friendly.

The first Congregational Unitarian Society (Rev. Mr. BELLOWS, Pastor,) commenced public service on Sunday, in Academy Hall, No. 663 Broadway, where Divine Worship will be continued until the new church has been erected. There was a large attendance of members of the congregation, and several strangers. Rev. Mr.
TWO MEN KILLED ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD, NEAR FIFTY-SECOND-STREET.--Last night, two laborers, whose names we did not learn, were run over and instantly killed on the Hudson River Railroad.

At his residence, near Newburg, on Saturday evening, 17th inst., JOHN H. WALSH, in the 70th year of his age. In Brooklyn, on the morning of the 19th inst., Mrs. E. A, wife of F W Hotchkian and daughter of the late Rev Gustavus F.Davis, D D, of Hartford, Coan. Her funeral will be at the house of Mr. Chittenden, pierrepopt-st., on Tuesday at 3 o' clock P.M.

The following letter of thanks to Captain INGRAHAM, for protecting M. KOSZTA from Austrian violence, has been signed by a large number of Hungarian exiles resident in this City. It has been sent, in the original as well as in an English translation, to its destination by Capt. BOARDMAN: Captain Ingraham. U. S. N, commanding U S. sloop-ofwar St Louis;

LARGE FIRE IN LYNN.--A destructive fire occurred in Lynn about 1 o'clock this morning, by which the large block of stores, on the corner of Federal-street and Federal square, and the building adjoining were entirely consumed. The buildings were owned by JOSEPH MOULTON, Jr., and were valued at $3.500.

The following have been the receipts since Saturday" FLOUR, 13,000 bbls.; WHEAT, done: CORN 20,000 BUSHELS: OATS. 15 00 bushels. FLOUR has been dull under the Arctic's advices with sales of only 500 bbls. at $6@$6 1 1/2 for state and common mixed Western BARLEY, 34,00 bushels sold at 76c for two rowed, and 83c $84c. for four-rowed. OATS are dull and lower; sales at 46c.@1/2c.

This Court, Judge HAINES presiding, continued its session, during last week. On Friday night the Grand Jury, which has been in session for four days, came into Court with thirty-seven bills of indictment. There were nine indictments found for selling liquor-some of them for selling it on Sunday, and others for selling it without a license. There were others indicted for keeping disorderly houses.

The HealthOfficer reports G4 deaths during the last week ending Saturday last. Males 36; females28; adults 28; children 36. By consumption and dysentery, 8 each; marasmus 7; infant cholera, dropsy in the head, and old age, 3 each; typhoid fever, ?? fever, heart disease, whooping cough, inflammation of the bowels, inflammation of the liver, 2 each. There were 20 additional deaths, each from a separate disease.

For Beeves, at the WASHINGTON DROVE YARD, corner of Fourth-avenue and Thirty-fourth-street, and CHAMBERLAIN'S HUDSON RIVER BULL'S HEAD, foot of Robinson-street. For Cows and Calves, Sheep and Lambs; (and also for Calves,) at BROWNINGS, in Sixth-street, near Third-avenue, and also at CHAMBERLAIN'S.

The Moniteur published its second pregnant paragraph on Saturday. Like its predecessor, a fortnight ago, it consisted of three lines, and contained a world of meaning. The imbroglio had advanced a stage, and the Slltan had accepted the note of the Vienna Conference, " with sundry changes of reading without importance."

Our foreign advices state that Lieut. SCHWARTZ, who figured in the KOSZTA affair, has been promoted by the Austrian Government to the rank of Captain. We should like to know what for? We cannot recall any brilliant achievement which he performed on that occasion.

YELLOW FEVER AT BATON ROUGE.--The New-Orleans Commercial Bulletin has the following: The stampede in Baton Rouge, on the announcement that there had been three deaths from yellow fever, must have been terrific. People-at least all who could-closed their stores, dwellings, , in hot haste, and fled to the country, in every description of vehicle that was obtainable.

The "Hard-Shell" of the Democratic General Committee held a special meeting last evening, at their head-quarters, in the main room of the Stuyvesant Institute, on the second floor. THOMAS J. BARR, Esq., presided, and respecting their County Ratification Meeting, the following resolutions were adopted:

On Sunday morning, Rev. H. WILBURN, of Mobile, Alabama, delivered a very interesting and instructive sermon before a numerous and highly respectable congregation, at the Methodist Episcopal Church in Mulberry-street. The reverend gentleman took for his text the 13th verse of the 4th chapter of the Book of Proverbs:

The Annual Fair of the New-York State Agricultural Society commences to-day, at Saratoga, where the Fair of 1847 was held. The grounds selected for the Exhibition are situated on Lakeavenue, about a mile to the east of the village, on the farm of Madame JUMEL.

It is now said, with confidence, that JOHN Y. MASON, of Virginia, has been appointed for France, and ex-Senator ALLEN, of Ohio, for the China mission. Messrs. BURR, O'CONOR and O'SULLIVAN, are here. O'CONOR had an interview with the President to-day and offered, in view of the inharmonious condition of the party in New York, to return his commission.

We have files of the Eco del Comercio to the 8th inst. It is grieved to learn that, by the steamer Texas, recently arrived, the individuals disembarked have been attacked with yellow fever. The cholera had made it appearance in some towns of the State of Oaxaca, and had approached within five or six leagues of the capital.

A serious accident occurred yesterday on the Ramapo and Paterson Railroad. The 51/2 o'clock afternoon train left Jersey City, with three passenger-cars, for Paterson. The train was running at the rate of forty miles per hour, when, near the Boiling Springs, the engine and tender were thrown off the track.

The Board of Health report two yellow fever deaths during the past week in this city. The disease was brought here, it will be remembered, by the bark Mandarin, and still lingers about Southstreet wharf; and LATHAM'S lead-pipe factory, located there, has been closed in consequence of the dread entertained by the workmen.

The letter of Gen. CONCHA we have had the past week, and the general impression is that it is unworthy of the source from which it comes. CONCHA was beloved here for the simplicity and truthfulness of his character,

The Newark Club played a return-match yesterday, with the New-York Club at Hoboken. The weather or was delightful and the attendance large. New-York was victorious, scoring 117 the first innings, 126 second; while the Newark got only 42, leaving 202 for the Newark to get in their second innings. They gave up the game nobly.

The Italian Opera, at NIBLO'S Garden, opened last night with the well-known opera of "I Puritani." In spite of the risk of contradicting so eminent an authority as Mr. CORBYN, the proprietor of certain libretti sold at the door, and who attributes, in his books, this work to ZINGARELLI, an old and not very popular composer, we must, nevertheless, consider it as one of BELLINI's Latest works.

The two main driving-engines in the Machine Arcade are now in complete working order, and in a suitable condition for a critical judgment of their merits, compared with other stationary engines of the same power. We shall first speak of the " Henry Clay." manufactured by Messrs. CORLISS NIGHTINGALE, of Providence, R. I.

Lord PALMERSTON is employing his temporary release from his arduous duties at the Home Office, in a provincial tour. The other day he laid the foundation-stone of a new "Athenaeum," at Melbourne, in Derbyshire, where he possesses estates. The proprietors of the new Institute were peculiarly fortunate in securing his lordship to open it.

Before Hon. Judge Duer. In consequence of the order to show cause why the defendants should not be enjoined and restrained, pursuant to the demand of relief made by the plaintiffs in their complaint, the parties appeared before the Court yesterday morning. Mr. A. L. Jordan represented Mr. Hope; Mr. Anuthon appeared for the Sixth-avenue, and Mr. Willard for the Eighth avenue Railroad.

A most disgraceful scene was enacted in North Thirdstreet, between Second and Third-streets, on Sunday afternoon, between a party of some 300 or 400of the members and friends of engines Nos. I and 10.

Hon. VICTORY BIRDSEYR.--The Syracuse Journal, in announcing the death of lion. VICTORY BIRDSEYE, of Onondaga County, which occurred on Friday last, adds the following: He had been in apparently good health and spirits, and retired to bed as usual, without suspicion of ailment; but, not appealing in the morning, one of the family proceeded to his room and found him a corpse.

Our City have lately been edified by the procession and gymnastic performances of a German Society. So far as we know, the whole affair was orderly, and the two or three thousand young men in beards and moustaches acquitted themselves very creditably in leaping poles and drinking lager-bier at Harlem and Hoboken.

A collision occurred on the straight line between this city and Rochester, yesterday afternoon, between the State train and a gravel train, by which two men were killed. Their names have not been ascertained. The papers here attribute the fatal accident at Onaida to the circumstance that a competent engineer had been dismissed, and a fireman appointed in his place.

The bark John Winthrop arrived this morning from Constantinople. Reports, Sept. 9, experienced a severe hurricane from S. W. to N., which blew away some sails, amongst others the close-reefed maintopsail, and threw the bark on her beam-ends.
My way led me through one of the by-lanes of the great City in my evening walk, and as it was just at night-fall, I met at almost every step the laborer "hieing from his toil."

MURDER OF A RETURNED CALIFORNIAN.--A man on his return home from California to Jackson County, Illinois, a few days since, was met only a short distance away from his house by a neighbor, who, upon learning he had money, killed and robbed him.

The recent letter of Hon. JOHN A. Dix to a Georgia gentleman, designed to establish his adherence to the Baltimore Platform, does not give universal satisfaction. The following letter, written at an earlier date, is extensively reprinted as an offset to it:

From the Washington Union The New-York TIMES appears to be troubled about the movements of Commodore SHUBERICK on the fishing grounds, and especially appears to be in doubt about the sufficiency of his instructions.

The Oneida County Independent Democratic Convention has just concluded its deliberations. The Maine Law was endorsed, and the following nominations made: For Senator, EDWARD LOOMIS; District Attorney, THOMAS G. FROST; Superintendent of the Poor. ELLIS ELLIS ; Justice of the Session, JOHN P. STANFORD.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your report of the proceedings of the Classis of New-York, held on Monday of last week, it is stated that " Rev. Mr. CHAMBERS said he was informed, on good authority, that a suspended member of their Church had been permitted to preach in a church at Bushwick."

GEN. McKAY.--The Wilmington (N. C.) Commercial, of the 17th, announces the demise of Gen. McKAY, as follows: He was on his return from Edgecombe County where he had attended as a witness, and was taken ill on board the cars on Wednesday afternoon, and was obliged to stop at Goldsboro', where he expired about 8 o'clock, at Mrs. BORDEN'S hotel, in the 65th year of his age.

THE SICKNESS AT MOBILE.--We have been favored by a gentleman from Mobile, who is at present stopping in this city, with the perusal of his letters, received from a partner in business and brother, in the ill-fated city.

MAINE.--An Extra Session of the Legislature of Maine has been called by Gov. CROSBY, to meet at Augusta, on the 20th inst. The Commissioners chosen by the Legislature, with authority to purchase the Massachusetts lands, have concluded a contract for this purchase.
The arraignment of W. R. MORGAN and MATTHEW MORGAN, Jr., for assault on ISAAC S. HONE, took place this morning in Court.

New-Orleans. The official report of interments in New-Orleans, for the week ending September 11, is as follows: Yellow fever, 399; other diseases, 131 : total, 530 On the 11th there were 68 deaths, of which 48 were of yellow fever; on the 12th, 55 deaths, of which 40 were of yellow fever.

To the Editor, by the New-York Daily Times. In your article of Friday last, under the above title, you remind our citizens that this is the season for the annual payment, of the seventy-five cents military commutation fee.

The general Committee appointed to carry out the necessary arrangements for the Mass Meeting to be held at Metropolitan Hall on Thursday next, assembled last evening at the Shakespeare Hotel--M. GASPAR DE BETANCOURT presiding.

New Orleans papers of Wednesday are received. At Madisonville the fever was committing great ravages. Hon. JOHN Y. MASON'S house at Richmond, Va., was destroyed by fire on Monday last, together with a large amount of valuable furniture, books,

Their Majesties are still absent upon their incognito excursion. The enthusiasm, or starting, by which ever name you choose to call it, seems to continue. Jaunts at sea and little rides on the coast are found to benefit the Empress' health.
We commence, this morning, a very interesting History of the Revolution now in progress in the Chinese Empire, which we find in recent numbers of the London Times.

From the Washington Union. The leading article in the New-York TIMES of the 12th instant is devoted to the Russian Minister M DE, BODISCO, and the defence of him against certain allegations of unwarrantable interference with the freedom of the press by a correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer.

The visit of her Majesty to Dublin has occupied large space in the daily journals of the past week, and is not only more interesting, but is likely to prove of more importance than was at first anticipated. Though talked of as a "private" visit, it is now manifest that privacy is about the last attribute attached to it.
The CLINTON Statute was removed yesterday from its resting-place in front of the City Hall. It was about time for its withdrawal from the bad company it had fallen into.

John H. Jones, et al. vs The Schooner Hanover, and Wm. H. Tompkins et al vs. John H Jones et al -- There suits were brought to recover the damages consioned by a collision which took place in the night of January 18. 1850, between the some twenty miles from Amelia, off the coast of Virginia some twenty miles from Cape Henry, by which the Amelia, with her cargo, was surk.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: I observe with pain a disposition on the part of the New-York TIMES (as well as the New York Tribune,) to taunt the "Old-Line Democrats" in the late State Convention, with a want of courage, for not standing up to a fight with the New-York "Short-Boys." The Tribune does this editorially, to my utter surprise, but the TIMES more especially through its reporter.

The target excursion to Coney Island yesterday, of the above named Long Island Companies, was one of the most novel and interesting of the season. It was a trial of gunnery between the two Companies, and as such reflected much credit upon both.

Most good men desire to see a Pacific Railroad built, and speedily, if practicable. The if is pregnant with weighty considerations. The Federal Government may remove it, or private enterprise directed by men of real substance, not mere adventurers, financial or political, may do it ; with or without Government aid.

CRYSTAL PALACE.--We understand that the is sue of weekly tickets of admission to the Crystal Palace will be suspended after the present week. It is found that the plan is attended with serious inconveniences, and the Directors have accordingly determined not to authorize the issue of weekly admissions.

A TRAGEDY IN ARKANSAS.--The Little Rock Whig, of the 1st inst., says that JOHN G. PASCHAL., of Galley Rock, Pope County, and WM. O. WILSON, of Conway County, had a difficulty in making a settlement; the last seen of PASCHAL, alive was on his way to WILSON'S.
The City Government has just made a contract with somebody or other to lay down granite blocks in that part of Broadway where the PERRINE nuisance now exists.

The Journal of Commerce states that as soon as the appointment of Mr. WALKER as Minister to China was known in England the British Government immediately sent a special Embassy to China for the purpose of concluding a commercial treaty.

We have an acquaintance--a contented man. He has grumbled before now, but it was an unprofitable employment, and he gave it up. He occupies but part of a house, and congratulates his wife every day that she has so little sweeping to do.
MURDER.--A most outraeous murder was committed at the Tabernacle meeting house, in Cul-pepper County, Va., on Thursday, the 8th inst., by WILLIAM CURTIS upon FREDERICK BROWN.
The police have been aware, for months past, that a gang of counterfeiters have been at work at their infamous business for a long time, in and about Hamilton, in Butler county.

The rain is now falling rapidly and many of our streets are flooded with water. It is, however, a welcome visiter, and must be productive of much good. The heat, in the earlier part of the day, was quite oppressive.

LARGE WAREHOUSE OVERTURNED IN CANADA.--We learn from the Toronto Leader, that the vast building erected only this Spring on G. MURRAY JARVIS' wharf, in that city, and containing, it is said, 10,000 bushels of wheat, and 700 of corn, besides a large quantity of hay, is now lying overturned on the west side of the wharf, and half immersed in the water.

The Athenians always declined to send an ambassador to Sardis, alleging that the atmosphere of that Court was unwholesome for republicans. Equally unpropitious for American diplomats is the air of Buenos Ayres.

To the Editor by the New-York Daily Times: SIR: I was pleased to observe, during a brief visit to your City yesterday, that at least one hack-proprietor has availed himself of a suggestion which emanated from the TIMES a short period since.

A DESPERATE LEAP.--The St. Louis Republican says that one day last week, as one of the trains was leaving the Pacific Railroad depot, a horse was put in one of the cattle cars, and at once became so much frightened at the strangeness of his position as to become unmanageable.

The missing New-Orleans mail of the 8th, is received, but the regular mail has failed beyond Mobile. The Mobile Register of the 14th inst. Says : " There is no abatement of the sickness, but patients are increasing in number, both in the infirmaries and private practice.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN WEYMOUTH, MASS.--On Saturday night, a fire took place in the counting room of Messrs. LOUD RHINES, at Weymouth Landing, which extended to the lumber on the wharf, which was partially consumed.

"After great difficulty, arrangements have been made to establish the organ--the President, his friend, PIERCE BUTLER, and FORNEY'S friend, FORREST, the actor, and CALEB CUSHING'S old friend, PAUL R GEORGE, being the chief stockholders.

The dinner to Hon. J. M. BOTTS, of Virginia, took place at the City Hotel last evening, upwards of fifty persons being present. Hon. A. C. M. PENNINGTON presided, and in announcing the second toast, made a few remarks complimentary to Mr. BOTTS, stating that he comes from the State of Virginia, the Mother of Presidents and Statesmen, not the least among whom was our honored guest.

ESCAPE OF PRISONERS FROM THE MISSOURI PENITENTIARY -- TWO OF THE CONVICTS DROWNED -- Eight convicts, who went at work on the railroad near Jefferson City, taking advantage of an opportunity, lately made an effort to escape from their bondage.

Inquests were held yesterday upon the bodies of CHARLES TEXTER and ADOLPH CELLAEIUS, the two Germans who were killed on Monday night, on the Hudson River Railroad, near Fifty second street. A brief account of the accident was given in yesterday's TIMES. It appears that the unfortunate men were walking on the track when they were struck by the Albany passenger-train, due here at 10 o'clock.

On Tuesday morning Sept. 20, ELIZABETH GARDNEE SCHONTON, wife of Isaac W. Brinkerhoff The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral on Wednesday, the 21st it st., at 2 o'clock, P. M. from the residence of C. W. Brinkerhoff, No 287 Tenth-st. The remains will be taken to Greenwood.

The Hunker Address, adopted last week, and signed by the Hunkers, appeared in the Albany Argus yesterday. We quote a few passages: It stands at this moment precisely where it stood in 1847, when a faction in this State resisted and split off from the regular Democratic State nominations, because the Convention refused to recognize the WILMOT Proviso as an integral part of the Democratic creed.

DEAR SIR. As a faithful delegate from the free democracy of Boston, I had counted upon sharing the councils and encouragement of our State Convention at Fitchburg, this day; but the physician into whose hands I have fallen this week, admonishes me that I cannot make the necessary effort at this time without endangering the recovery of may health.
EARTHQUAKE ON THE GULF COAST.--About 5 o'clock, on Sunday afternoon, the shock of an earthquake was felt at several of the watering-places.

We have learnt from the last published accounts of the Chinese insurrection, that the rebels are masters of Nankin, and that the eyes of the victors are already straining northwards in the direction of the chief Imperial city.

The Times has been excluded from Spain by a royal decree published in the official Gazette. Our contemporary is justified in boasting of this exclusion as a tribute paid to his influence in the cause of truth. We have not seldom differed from our contemporary, in times long past, and in times recent; for journalists must differ, as well as men and parties, in a country where happily opinion is free to shape itself independently.

NIBLO'S GARDEN--"Norma" was reproduced here last evening, and attracted an excellent house. The performance went off with considerable cidat. Signor SALVI sang with much spirit, and almost too much vigor. Indeed, generally, we observed a tendency on all sides to vociferate more than the necessities of the piece demanded. In the chorus of Druid, otherwise excellent, this objection was still observable.

We publish this morning a letter from the correspondent who, from time to time, has kept us posted with the cruising and doings of the Eastern Squadron. If the reader will open a map of the Provinces, and trace the tracks made by the ships of the Squadron, he will not be disposed to quarrel with them for the little they have done.

The Union of this morning defends the Cabinet against General CLARK'S speech at Syracuse, and says: "Having uniformly and earnestly sustained the policy adopted by the President in the formation of his Cabinet, and the distribution of public patronage, as wise in its conception, and well calculated in its faithful execution to maintain the Union, and strengthen the party,

Mr. S. B. BRITTAN, who asserts, we believe, the spiritual nature of the rappings, table-movings, , about which so much noise has been made, writes to us denying that there was any " collusion " between him anti Dr. RICHMOND, in their recent controversy upn this subject. He gives sundry reasons in support of his assertion, which, however, is just as good without them as with them.

The New York City Guards have shown themselves worthy of noble guests. The "Crack Companies " of the two great cities enjoyed themselves last night. The New-York City Guard, in their arrangements for their guests' entertainment, appointed last evening for a grand dinner at the Irving House, which duly came off in a magnificent style, worthy of the citizen- soldiers who were feasted and those who gave the feast. It was truly a great time.

Mr. POWELL, the American artist, who has been resident in Paris for several years, at work upon the large picture ordered by Congress for the Rotunda of the Capitol, has just returned, bringing the picture with him. Its subject is, " DE SOTO discovering the Mississippi."

The visitor to the Palace will have doubtless noticed the Banners bearing the Arms of the different States of the Union, waving under the dome in the northern nave, between the two divisions of the United States department.

The Corner stone of the First Reformed Dutch Church will be laid this afternoon, at 5 o'clock. Rev. Dr DE WITT, of New York, Rev. Dr TAYLOR, of Bergen, and others, will participate in the ceremonies of the occasion. It will be a beautiful and costly edifice.

The National Intelligencer copies the TIMES dispatch about the protest of the Austrian, Russian, and Prussian Ministers. It says it is probably correct; and adds, that there is a rumor that the English and French Ministers have also protested.

A very melancholy accident occurred on Monday, on the line of the Albany and Rutland Railroad, four miles from Schaghticoke, by which four men were killed instantly, and one seriously injured. The men were engaged in digging out a culvert, in dn embankment under the track, which had become filled up with sand, and prevented the passage of water.

MAINE ELECTION.--The Portland Advertiscr contains the full returns of the votes cast in Maine at the recent election. The Advertiser says: "The results, in a party point of view, are such as to afford no particular party any great cause for exultation, except at the thorough and complete defeat of its opponents." Louisiana, in its physical character, in its history, and in the native stock of its population, is very different from any other part of our country. There is no State which shows so many marks of having been long lived in by a civilized people--in which there is so much that is antique and respectable with age, and yet none in which the flow of young, enterprising, active life is greater.

DESTRUCTION OF JUDGE JOHN Y. MASON'S HOUSE BY FIRE.--We learn from the Richmond Enquirer that the residence of Judge JOHN Y. MASON, in that city, was destroyed by fire on Monday night. On opening the door of the room in which the fire was discovered, the flames and smoke came rushing out and forbade entrance.

THE ACCIDENT AT THE RAILROAD CELEDRATION AT ST. JOHN'S.--The St. John's Morning News, gives the following account of the accident which occurred at the Ball succeeding the "breaking ground " ceremony: "About 1 o'clock the centre beam, supporting the orchestra gave way, when the whole fabric fell with a terrible crash, precipitating the Band upon the floor from a height of twenty feet. The consternation was terrible.

New-Orleans papers of Thursday last are received. Also, the missing mails of the 9th and 10th inst. The papers contain details of Texas news to the 9th inst. The ordering of troops to the Rio Grande frontier had occasioned much speculation in Texas.

The "City Fathers" sat again Wednesday, Sept. 21, Alderman COMPTON presiding. After the reading of certain applications about sewers, and their accompaniments, Alterman DOHERTY asked for the reading of the report of the Committee on the Street Commissioner, which we need hardly say has been published in the papers some time since.

The Royal Mail steamer Africa arrived at 8 o'clock last evening, having le't Liverpool at noon on Saturday the 10th inst. She brings news from all ?? of Europe three days later than had been previously received.
LATE FROM MEXICO.--Late advices from New Mexico vid New-Orleans, announce the arrival of the five companies of U. S. troops which left New-York under General GARLAND, at Santa Fe, in good health.

UNWHIPPED OF JUSTICE.--The person arrested sometime since at Hoboken, engaged with others in defrauding four Virginians out of about $500 by the ball safe game,"--the circumstances of which we published at the time-has escaped unwhipt of justice. He was confined in Hudson County Jail, as were also the witnesses, the persons defrauded.

At Yonkers, at the residence of her son-in-law, Anson Baldwin, on Thursday, Sept. 22 Mrs. ELIZABETH PALMER, relict of James Palmer, deceased, aged 86 years, 3 months and 22 days. The friends and relatives of the family are invited to attend her funeral, at the above place, on Saturday, Sept. 24, at 10 o'clock A. M.

The Democratic State convention for the nomination or a candidate for Governor, met today at 12 o'clock, in the large saloon of the Temperance Hall. After a temporary organization, and the appointment of a Committee on resolutions, the Convention adjourned to 2 P. M.

It appears that not long since Engine ComCompany No 44 made an attack upon the members of Engine Company No. 18, took their apparatus away from them, and inflicted severe injury upon several of the men.

The Democratic State Convention met here this forenoon. Hon. J. M. USHER, of Medford, was chosen President-the vote being, for USHER, 66; for Hon. J. S. C. KNOWLTON, of Worcester, editor of the Palladiam, 46; scattering. 2. USHER and KNOWLTON are both Coalition Democrats.

The Democratic State Convention met here this forenoon. Hon. J. M. USHER, of Medford, was chosen President-the vote being, for USHER, 66; for Hon. J. S. C. KNOWLTON, of Worcester, editor of the Palladiam, 46; scattering. 2. USHER and KNOWLTON are both Coalition Democrats.

Rev. Mr. CHAPIN last night delivered an eloquent address to the company assembled at the meeting of the Horticultural Society. After a few preliminary observa ions, he said: The fact that we are an intensely practical people is one which is matter either of reproach or of compliment, according to the critic's point of view.

SHOCKING TRAGEDY AT OBERLIN, OHIO.--On the 15th inst., a most revolting murder was committed about three miles east of Oberlin, Ohio. A man named FULLHAM, had slandered a Miss BARBER and another young lady. The brother of Miss BARBER, and a Mr. LOVELL, the lover of the other slandered girl, went to FULLHAM to talk the matter over.

Since the destruction of the liberty of the press, which was the first act of SANTA ANNA'S return to power, it has been almost impossible to obtain any reliable information concerning the political state of the country. Light is thrown upon the subject by an article in the TIMES of this morning, copied from the NewOrleans Picayune.

About 5 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in the extensive Delaine print works in this city. the main buildings, 300 feet long, and the L, 225 feet long, were entirely destroyed. The stock of Delaines, valued at $25,000, was also consumed.

The Africa brings three days' later intelligence, not of startling interest, but still important to commercial circles. Both Cotton and Breadstuffs had both been dull, though the latter improved somewhat at the latest dates. The money market was especially depressed,

JULLIEN'S CONCERT last evening was attended by a numerous-perhaps the moat numerous audience yet attracted to Castle Garden. The various pieces in the programme were performed with excellent taste, and elicited unbounded applause.

The Evening Post is greatly distressed at the publication of Mr. EVERETT'S letter to Lord JOHN RUSSELL. It pronounces Mr. EVERETT guilty of an egregious blunder, and thinks-his example, if followed. will be productive of the most lamentable results.

A stated meeting of the Board of Education was held Wednesday evening--E. C. BENEDICT. Esq. in the chair. Mead, Chairman, , inviting the Board to visit the Horticultural Exhibition at Niblo's Garden. Accepted From E. W. Griffin, relative to Pelton's Maps. T. Committee on Supplies.

The visit of the Boston City Guards to New-York is quite an event in the military annals of our City. Yesterday morning, at 9 o'clock, they were escorted by their liberal entertainers, the New-York City Guard, to the Crystal Palace.

Close upon the light-retiring steps of Pleasure's votaries comes the firm tread of husbandmen in the gay saloons of Saratoga; and the gayeties of a more than usually brilliant and scarcely yet concluded season are already succeeded by a grand Industrial Fete.

Brigham Young, the Mormon Governor of Utah, has been lecturing his people, and in the course of his lectures lays down the following, which it must be acknowledged is a little more than "an eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth." If you want to know what to do with a thief, that you may find stealing, I say kill him on the spot, and never suffer him to commit another iniquity.

From the New Orleans Picayune. From a gentleman who came passenger on the steamer Texas, from Vera Cruz, and who has excellent sources of information concerning the real state of political affairs in Mexico, we learn a number of interesting facts on the subject, which confirm what we published some weeks since.

The Dublin Tablet closes an article on the KOSZTA case with the following sentence: "If the American Government is desirous of more intimate relations with Europe, it has begun in a foolish way. The Continental Courts are more than alarmed.
At Washington, Dutchess Co., N.Y. on Thursday, Sept. 22 by Rev Homer Wheston, Mr JAMES EDWARD UNDERHILL, of Washigton, to Miss PHOEBE, daughter of Judge Titus, of the same place.

The Perjury Case. JEFFERSON POLICE COURT. Before Justice Stear: On Thursday, at 12 o'clock, the examination upon the charge of perjury, against Justice BOYD, of Astoria, Long Island, preferred by SAMUEL DEVRY Sr, was resumed before Judge STUART, at the Jefferson Police Court, and the following are the proceedings. EVIDENCE FOR THE DEFENCE.
The total number of deaths reported for the 24 hours ending this morning was 28, of which 11 were from yellow fever. At Mobile, on Thursday, the interments were 20, including 14 from the fever.

On Friday, the 23d inst, MARIE A. HUNTER, in the 3d year of her age. Her friends are respectfully invited to attend her funeral at the residence of C. C. Pratt, No 7 Amny??st, on Saturday, 24th inst., at 2 o'clock P. M., without further invitation.

MISSIONARY MEETING.--The Home Missionary Society of Williamburg intend holding a public meeting at the First Baptist Church, corner of South Fifth and Fifth-streets, to-morrow (Sunday) afternoon, for the purpose of placing the objects of the Society fairly before the public. Several addresses are to be delivered.
The weather to-day has been quite pleasant, though in the early part there were symptoms of a storm. The thermometer, at 2 P. M., stood at 72 degrees.

Among the Autumn sporting matters, on the Long Island Turf, there was an exciting trotting match at the Union Course Thursday, for a purse of $250, mile heats best three in five, in harness. The harses named were as follows: b. g. Pet. by HIRAM WOODRUFF; A. JONES named g. g. Vermont; $. McLOUGHLIN named Green Mountain Maid, and D. PIPPEN named g m. Lady Vernon.

The Intelligencer of this morning maintains the correctness of its statement regarding the action of France and England in the KOSZTA affair. The Union continues to assail the Hard-Shells. It also, after approving of the sentiments of Mr. EVERETT'S letter, intimates that no notice will be taken of Lord JOHN RUSSELL'S note by the Secretary of State, as it was addressed to Mr CRAMPTON, the British Minister, and not to the State Department.

This morning proved very favorable, and the Show-ground was again filled, at an early hour, by visitors. By 12 o'clock a large crowd had assembled in and around Speaker's Hall, to hear the Annual Address from Hon. WILLIAM C. RIVES, of Virginia.

INCENDIARY FIRE.--Last evening, about 7 o'clock, a fire broke out in a stable in the rear of Duffield-street, near Myrtle avenue, which was destroyed, an also was destroyed two small wooden buildings fronting on Duffield-street, on ground recently purchased by Dr. SWALM, and occupied by Mr GEORGE ABBOT as a slaughter-house, and Messrs J H. PRENTICE CO. as a hat-box factory.

The members of Good Intent Engine Company No 3. together with a bomber of friends and several invited gueses, started for Springfield. Mass on Thursday afternoon for the purpose of joining the Annual Parade of the Fire Department in that place, and contending for one of the silver trumpets which are to be awarded to the two machines that throw the highest stream.

FOR BRIDGEPORT--THROUGH IN FOUR HOURS -- FARE FIFTY CENTS--CONNECTING WITH THE HOUSATONIC, NAUGATUCK, AND NEW-HAVEN RAILROADS.--The steamer CATA-LINE. Capt. CHARLES WEEKS, will leave from Packing, East River every MONDAY, WEDNESDAY, and FRIDAY MORNING at 10 o'clock.

Decisions in Admiralty on Appeal. UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT. Before Chief-Justice Nelson. CONSTRUCTION OF CHARTER PARTY. William R. Beecher and others vs. George J. Bechtel and others--This libel was filed to recover compensation for the loss and damage sustained by the owners of the ship Buenovenio for the non fulfilment of a charter party entered into by the respondents.

According to the United States Census, the Methodists are the most numerous and most wealthy of all the sects. The Baptists, in point of numbers are the next, and the Presbyterians next in wealth, and very near the same as the Methodists.

The following correspondence in regard to this case, in addition to the letter already copied into the TIMES, we find in the London journals: LETTER FROM MR. NORTON. To the Editor of the London Times: SIR : I regret that I should be compelled again to trespass upon your space, and upon the attention of the public, but my own character and honor require me to do so. My letter of the 24th ult.

FERRY ARRANGEMENTS.--The trips of the boats on the Jersey City Ferry, during the day time, will here-after be more frequent than they have been. Three boats, instead of two, will run from the slips in use for the public, making their trips every ten minutes, from 6 o'clock in the morning until 7 o'clock in the evening.
We publish this morning full reports of the very interesting addresses delivered yesterday and the day before at the state Agricultural Fair at Saratoga, by Prof. WILSON and Hon. Wm. C. RIVES.

CHARGE OF FORGERY.--Yesterday morning, a complaint at was made before Judge STUART, at the Jefferson Police Court, by man named JOSIAH L DAM, against SAMUEL N. HASTINGS, wherein he charges him with passing forged checks.

LAYING OF THE CORNER STONE OF THE FIRST REFORMED DUTCH CHURCH --On Thursday, at 5 o'clock, P. M, the ceremony of laying the corner-stone of this new edifice, to be erected in Grand-street above Washington street, was witnessed be a large number of spectators.

The columns of the TIMES this morning contain a very full and complete record of the proceedings of the Ratification meeting held at Tammany Hall last night. It was a very large and moderately enthusiastic gathering. The action of the un-terrified section of the Democracy in Convention at Syracuse was thoroughly approved, and the course of the Bards was stigmatized as hostile to the Democratic National and State Administrations.

The Evening Post finds companionship in its woe, over the publication of Mr. EVERETT's letter to Lord JOHN RUSSELL, in a Philadelphia journal. Both these papers are shocked at Nr. EVERETT's atrocious trespass on antique usage, and his unstatesmanlike interference with the functions of the Government.

Prof. WILSON delivered his Address last evening, in the Baptist Church, on the Culture of Flax. It was was an exceedingly valuable and in structive discourse, and will, when published, do much to diffuse information upon this important subject.

UNION HALL, SARATOGA. Thursday, Sept 22, 1853. This morning the Fair ground was opened to the public. The day is remarkably fine, and thousands have arrived and still continue to flock in from every direction. The road leading from the village to thee Fair ground is thronged with vehicles and pedestrians, who are last filling the large space enclosed

The "Softs" of the Harmonious Democracy had their Ratification Meeting at Tammaay Hall last evening, to respond to the nominations at Syracuse The affair was tremendous in point of numbers, and slim in supply of speakers The early part of the performances was refreshingly harmonious; the latter was given to uproariousness and an ?? fashioned rumpus in the Wigwam.
We learn, from good authority, that the third volume of MACAULAY's History of England--which has been announced as just upon the eve of publication--cannot be ready before the Fall of 1854.

Commodore VANDERBILT'S steam-yacht North Star returned to this port yesterday, from her pleasure cruise in European waters She has stood the trip admirably. Scarcely a strain appears in her frame, and there is no breakage. If she were replenished with provisions and coal, she would, according to the testimony of her officers, be ready for sea again immediately.

BURNED TO DEATH--A man named MARTIN NOWLAN, an Irishman, 21 years of age, was burned to death in the fire at the corner of Marshall and Gold-streets, on Wednesday night. He was employed in the factory of Messrs. JOHNSONS, SANDFORD Co.

Arrangements have been mace for holding trotting matches over the Saratoga Course each afternoon during the week. On yesterday (Wednesday) afternoon, W. PEABODY's b in "Lady Jane," Mr. ABRAHAM's b. g. " Oblmos," and Mr. NODYSE's b. g" centreville," ran for a purse of $250.

Hon. WILLIAM C. RIVES, of Virginia, delivered the Address before the State Agricultural Society on the grounds to-day, at 1 o'clock. P. M. It was a highly interesting and instructive address, and I therefore forward you a full and accurate report of it.

The latest national statistics of crime are found in the abstract of the Seventh Census. From that it appears that the whole number of persons convicted of crime in the United States, for the year ending June, 1850, was about 27,000; of these, 13,000 were natives, (including colored prisoners,) and 14,000 foreign born.

THE CHILDREN--DISCOURSE OF REV. C. L. BRACE.--Yesterday morning a discourse was delivered by Rev. CHARLES L. BRACE, Secretary of the Children's Aid Society, to the children of the Thompson-street Mission Church. This Church has been established at No. 44 Thompson-street, for some five weeks, and is under the Superintendence of Rev. F. JAMES.

The September term of the Court of Appeals commences at the Capitol, in Albany on Tuesday, Sept. 27. There are 238 causes on the Calendar, the first forty of which will be found below: 1. Abraham Wing, respondent, against Elias Lasell, appellant, and others.

Washington Monuments are good, but why should they be thrust into everybody's face, every where? Why should little boys, who never have a surplus of peace for bread, and where fathers have not a sixpence to spend from Christmas to Fourth of July, be obliged to contribute when they have a holiday of their scanty change, or be sneered at by their schoolmates as stingy fellows?

On Sept. 15, at Vienna, Canada West, of bilious fever, JOHN CARLTON COMSTOCK, aged 34 years, of the firm of comstock Brother, of this City. His remains were taken of Giblertville, N. Y., for in terment. At Newburg, Sept. 16, Mrs. ANN JAKE FORSYTH, wife of John Formyth, Esq, aged 60 years.

The plague has abated at New-Orleans, simply for the want of fresh victims. The acclimated and unacclimated population who remained over Summer have been decimated by the fever. The victims from the latter must have averaged nearly or quite one in five from the 20th July to the 24th September, the latest date from which we have telegraphic advice.

APPROACHING CONVENTIONS OF THE EPISCOPAL CHURCH.--On Wednesday, (the day after to-morrow,) commences the Annual Diocesan Convention of the Protestsart Episcopal Church in the Diocese of New York. Following it, on the next Wednesday, Oct. 5, the Triennial General Convention of the same Church meets. Both will be held in this City-the former at St. John's, the latter at Trinity.

We observe that Broadway has been blockaded by persons engaged in taking up the PARRINE pavement, for the purpose of trying some new experiment upon that part of the street. We should like to know by what authority they are doing it. The ordinance granting permission has only passed one branch of the Common Council, and, of course, has never received the Mayor's signature.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In order rightly to understand the KOSZTA affair, and to correct a misapprehension as to our naturalization laws, which might be produced by the fifth resolution of the Metropolitan Hall meeting, it should he remembered that when a person declares his intention to become a citizen, he does not then and at the same time renounce his allegiance to all foreign Governments.

The Board of health, ill their weekly report of interments made last evening, state the number of deaths in the city and liberties to have been 201, of which 86 are adults and 115 children. The principal causes were 27 by consumption, 7 cholera infantum. 1O connvulsions, 11 dysentery. 11 marasmus, 6 typhoid fever, and 13 still-born.

The letters of Collector BRONSON and Attorney O'CONNOR have produced an immense excitement. The Cabinet convenes to-morrow, and of course these gentlemen, and other New-York subjects, will be discussed. The Cabinet, I repeat, is a " unit," and believe, as I have before expressed, the President will pursue a decided course.
Weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 17th day of September to the 34th day of September. 1853. TOTAL NUMBER, 448--Men, 95; women, 84; boys, 134; girls, 135.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: I have read, with much satisfaction, during the last six months, the different able articles which have appeared in the TIMES, on the subject of crime, its increase, its aliment, and its remedies. I have been particularly interested in reading your leader, " Crime and its Preventives," contained in the TIMES of the 30th August.

The New-Orleans Relief Committee acknowledge the receipt of $442 in addition to the sum already subscribed. Of this amount, $200 were from P. T. BARNUM, Esq. The Committee make the following statement:

The whole number of interments for the week ending at 6 o'clock, on the evening of Friday. 16th inst., amounted to 212, being a decrease of 29 from the report of the preceding week. We give below a synopsis of the mortality from the 1st of August of the 16th inst. inclusive.

Four hundred and forty burials last week--just one more than the week before, and at least one hundred and one more than it ought to be, or probably would be, if the laws of health were at all understood. or where understood, generally acted upon. True, this is in reality a reduction from the mortality of the preceding week.

To the Editors of the Charleston Courier: GENTLEMEN: My attention has been called to the following article, in your paper of the 6th inst.: "It is said that Gen. JAMES HAMILTON, of this State, has filed in the Treasury Department an opinion of FRANCIS B. CUTTING, adverse to the decision of the late Administration, relative to the distribution of the five millions of dollars reserved in the Treasury for the Texas bondholders.

Collector BRONSON and District Attorney O'CONOR, the leading office-holders under President PIERCE in this City, have declared their determination to support the Bolters' ticket nominated at Syracuse. Their letters, addressed to the Committee of the Ratification Meeting held at Tammany Hall on Friday night, and published in another column of this morning's TIMES, will be found worth reading.

Be ore Chief Justice Nelson. RECOUPMENT OF FREIGHT-TENDER Anders Dedecan vs. Francis Vose et al.--This is a libel to recover freight of the ship Brodrene for the coveyance of bundles of rail-rod iron from Newcastle-upon-Tyne to the port of New York. The bill of lading is dated May 15, 1650, and contains, at the foot of it, the exception, "not accountable for rust."

The Nicaragua Transit Company's steamship Northern Light, Capt. THOMAS MINER, from San Juan del Norte, connecting on the Pacific side with the Brother Jonathan, from San Francisco Sept. 1, arrived at this port on Saturday evening, with 655 passengers, an independent mail, and a large amount of treasure on freight and in the hands of passengers.

NAVAL INTELLIGENCE --The U. S. steamer Princeton, HENRY EAGLE, Commander, arrived at this Port yesterday, in 2 days and 17 hours from Portsmouth, N. H. The Princeton is one of the vessels which composed the Eastern Squadron, under Commodore SHUBRICK.

The semi-monthly steamers from California left San Francisco on the 1st of September, with $2,420,000 in Gold Dust on freight, and 1,200 passengers returning to the Atlantic States-many of them, of course, on visits of pleasure or business, and not to remain long at their old homes.

The present week will open with the musical novelty of a first appearance of an Italian prima donna, at the Niblo Opera-Signora MANZINI, represented to be young and pretty, and with a fresh soprano voice, which will make its first essay before an American audience in Lucia.

A meeting of the practical Printers of New York, called for the purpose of resolving upon the best mode of affording relief to their fellow-tradesmen suffering from the epidemic in New Orleans, was held at Tammany Hall on Saturday Light.

The State Fair closed this evening.. The anticipation of making it superior to other years, has failed, through adverse weather and disappointments, which threw back the general arrangements; but, as a whole, it went off well, and I think the expenses will not so far exceed the receipts as was feared.

Yesterday morning, intelligence of Dr. OSBORN'S death at the New-York Hospital was received at the Coroner's Office. It will be remembered that a few evenings ago Dr OSBORN, a medical gentleman residing in Monroe-street, between Market and Catherine streets,...

We trust that amidst the political divisions and agitations of the day, the important subject of City Reform will not escape the attention of our citizens. However men may differ upon State or National politics, there is no reason why all the friends of good City Government should not unite to secure it. In this matter all have one common interest.

NICOLAY, on Tuseday and Wednesday, the 11th and l2th of October, at 11 o'clock, A. M., on the ground. We have dates from Olympia to the 29th of August--fourteen days later. The only subject engrossing the attention of the people of this Territory is what is called the "Cascade Road," which offers a passage-way to the immigrants from the Atlantic States into the Terriritory.

DASTARDLY OUTRAGE AND ROBBERY.--A dastardly outrage was perpetrated on Saturday night last, at the North Fork toll-gate, on the Lexington Turnpike, upon the person of Mr. RICHARD MITCHELL. Some villain, in order to rob the toll-house, called Mr. M. out to open the gate, and, watching his opportunity, seized him by the throat, and jerked him on his face to the ground, where he choked him until he was insensible. He then en-

A letter from Capt. ROTCH, of the bark Jasper, of this port, reports her at Auckland on 9th Feb., ready for sea, with a full crew. She had 800 barrels of sperm oil, and had refitted for fourteen months.

The reputation of these Springs is a debtor to deer and buffalo. It was one of their favorite "licks." and as their judgements are held to be extra debateable, the good people of the country were naturally inquisitive to find out the causes of their annual visitations. They began to use the waters for sundry affections, especially cutaneous diseases, and their simple minds were not slow to reach the acme of wonderment.

The Hard-Shells, or Terrified Democracy, held their Grand Ratification Meeting in the Park last evening. The meeting wes a very large one--numbering probably not less than ten thousand persons. The enthusiasm was very considerable, and the speakers were vociferously cheered. An un oward accident, by the falling of the platform produced an adjournment: at a somewhat earlier hour than was expected.

The Cabinet had nearly a five-hour session to-day. Secretary MARCY's paper on the KOSZTa case was discussed, but its consideration was not concluded. It will not be published for several days yet. It is a very strong and decisive paper, calculated to completely to disarrange the nerves of Old Fogydom. The Cabinet is not likely materially to change Mr. MARCY'S points, although they will revise the mode of expression.
