The steamship Texas arrived here last night, with dates from Vera Cruz to the 22d, and city of Mexico 18th inst. General TORNELL, the Minister of War died at Tacubaya, on the 15th, of apoplexy. No successor had been appointed.

ACCIDENT ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD--On Sunday, a man named WILLIAM REED was run over on the Hudson River Railroad, near New-Hamburg, while lying on the track. The night express train came along rapidly, and before the engineer could check the speed, REED wan run over. He was shockingly ??

We beg to call the attention of those among our lady readers who have occasion for Laces, Silks, or other articles of female apparel, to the establishment of Mesdames RUTTKAI and MESZLENYI, sisters of Gov. KOSSUTH, at No. 761 Broadway.
The U.S. steamer Fulton, from Portsmouth, N.H., passed the breakwater this morning, bound for this city. The Putman Horse Guards of Newark, the Taylor Light Dragoons, and German Rifle ??

The Moniteur states in a note, that notwithstanding the absence of the Chief of the State, the Ministers have several times met in council, at the department of Justice. What sorry conclaves they must have been. I have heard of the performance of "Hamlet," without Hamlet, but never without the first gravedigger.
JOHN S. DYE was arrested this morning, charged with keeping an office for redeeming fraudalent bank-notes, being similar to the charge against WILLIAM McCAMMON.

NIELO's GARDEN,--An unusual event--like the first appearance of a new prima donna, was pretty certain of being attended with a corresponding effect on the attendance here last evening. The house was brilliantly attended. Considering that "Lucia" is not the most attractive of operas, we must necessarily attribute this to the interest excited in the debutante, Sign'a.

JUVENILE MISSIONARY MEETING.--The First Quarterly Meeting of the Youth's Missionary Society was held at the South Fifth street Methodist Church, yesterday afternoon. The attendance was large. Services were commenced with an appropriate prayer by the pastor of the church, Rev. F. W. BILL, after which addresses were made by Rev JNO. SCUDDER, of New-York, Rev. A. SAY, of Philadelphia, and Rev. Mr. BILL. There

Kingston dates to the 12th are received. The new Governor, Sir HENRY BARKLY, was hourly expected to arrive in the man-of war steamer Brisk. The newspapers say that as soon as he arrives his Secretary will proceed to New-York, to meet there Lady BARKLY, who is to visit America with Sir JOSHUA RowE, (Chief Justice,) and Lady RowE, before going to Jamaica.

The following is an extract of a letter from a gentleman attached to Gov. STEVEN'S Surveying Expedition: FORT UNION, Aug 6. 1853. We have had, the greater part of the way, three several lines of survey: First, the main party under command of Gov. STEVENS in person, passing in the immediate vicinity of the southern bend of Red River of the North, crossing the Cheyenne twice,

LONG ISLAND RAILROAD.--We understand that the Long Island Railroad Company have established a Mechanics' Train, and intend it as a permanent arrangement: It arrives at South Ferry at 6 1/2 o'clock A.M., and leaves at 7 P.M. This train at present runs as far as Jamaica, and will probably soon be extended further.

NEW-GRANADA.--The Peruvian Minister. Senor PAZ SOLDAN, had left Bogota, after having regulated the question pending between Peru and New Granada, the chief of which is a question of territory on the banks of the Amazon. There is good news from the gold mines in the neighborhood of Chondales, large lumps of gold have been received, and very fine specimen of quartz.

THE FIREMEN.--Nothing was done by the firemen at their meeting on Friday evening last, except that they decided to hold a final meeting on Friday evening next. The probability is, that the Aldermen will take such further action, at their meeting on Tuesday evening, as will settle the difficulty existing between them and the Fire Department. Yesterday JAMS M. MILLER, of Maiden-lane, New-York, held a public sale of high-bred Stock, on the form of JAMES BATHGATE Esq., one mile above Fordham, Westchester Co. There were about sixty head of prime Stock, principally from imported Durham and Devon breeds.

There is very little of interest stirring here at present,--the KOSZTA case, the Austrian Pronunciamento, and the war of the Shells in New-York, quite monopolizing public attention. The Executive Departments are all busily employed in getting up their back business and preparing for the approaching Session of Congress.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times : I need not tell you that our folks love the TIMES. Nor how we think the Spectator may lie on the shelf awhile now; for today is more inter. testing than yesterday. And as for style, we are not sure but the odds are with you, Sir; and as was said 6f SOUTHEY's poetry, if you write nonsense we shall read it cheerfully.

Axe-grinling is reduced to a science. It has its professors, and ambitious young literati study it as a profession. Once the newspaper was supposed to be public property. To be a reader of it entitled one to the use of its columns; to be a subscriber authorized one to edit it.

Among all sects of Protestant Christians great complaint is made of the scarcity of preachers. It is so general, pervading not one sect, but all, that much uneasiness has been experienced by the friends of morality and religion on this account.

ACCIDENT AT WHITEHALL, N. Y.-As the afternoon train from Rutland was entering the village of Whitehall, N. Y., on Saturday, a man named .JOAB SMITH, was struck by the locomotive, at the crossing on Williams street and so badly injured that he died at 11 o'clock the same evening. At the Coroner's inquest, held on Sunday, it was proved that he was in a wagon at the time, racing With some boys in another wagon.

It is a fortunate circumstance for the proprietors of our places of public amusement, that the City Hall is in bad odor with respectable folk. Were it otherwise, there is no knowing what amount of injury it might inflict on them. The entertainments provided by our respectable City Fathers have no parallel in the metropolis.

The Lutheran Synod continues in session in St. Matthew's Church, New-street. Last evening Rev. Mr. YINGLING, Of Lycoming, and Rev. Mr. EHRIIART, of Northumberland County, were ordained as ministers, on which occasion an appropriate discourse was preached by Rev. BEINJAMIN KURTZ, of Baltimore, accompanied by solemn religious exercises.

I. O. of O. F.--The members of KNICKER ?? LODGE. No. 22, I. O. of O. F., are hereby notified to at end the funeral of our late brother, S. MARTINO, at No. 70 Warren st., Brooklyn, this (Wednesday) morning, at 10 o'clock. The members' are earnestly requested to meet at the Lodge room, Odd Fellow's Hall. at 9 o'clock A. M. By order of the N G. THEODORE F. PRUDEN, Secretary.

On Monday night, in Common council, the following preamble and resolutions were presented and adopted. Ayes 10 ; nays, 2: Whereas. The Commissioners appointed by the City of wiliamsburg and the town of Brshwick. for the purpose of preparing a plan to he submitted to the people, at the coming election pursuant to an Act for the Consolidation of the Cities of Brooklyn and Willamaburg, and the Town of Bushwick, under one Municipal Government;

Signora MANZINI, of whose first appearance we spoke briefly in yesterday's paper, repeats the character of Lucia to-night. It would be eminently unfair thus early to speak decisively of Sign'a MANZINI's vocal abilities, or even to draw a critical conclusion concerning them. Extreme nervousness prevented the lady from doing full or even partial justice to herself Monday evening.

The Burlington (Vt ) Free Press says that Mr. BOGUE, Democrat, who at the late election was chosen Senator from Franklin County, by two majority, died at Fairfax, on Saturday evening. There is no provision in the Constitution by which the vacancy can be filled.

The United States Consul at Bahia, Brazil, has communicated to the Department the following report of deaths at Bahia: April 5.-At Maroim," Dr. Luis Augustus, Greenfiald, of Fittaburg, Pennsylvania-disease unknown. 11th.James Hewitt, Philadelphia. cook of the schooner W. W. Fulton, of Philadelphia-yellow fever. 27th--Chrles W. Friend, seaman of bark Mantpelier, of Gloucester, Mass -yellow fever.

New-Orleans papers of Wednesday last are received. They contain the details of the Texas news to the 16th inst. The fever was prevailing extensively and severely, not only in Galveston, but through the interior of the State.

THe County Union, (Jamaica, W. L,) tells of a most disgraceful fracas which occurred in the Parish Church of St. James lately. It seems that Hon. Mr. LAWSON and family, have left the Episcopal Church for the Scotch Kirk, but to make a reconversion as easy as possible, his pew, which wa the best in the church, has been kept vacant for now more than a year.

Hon. JoHN W. DAVIS has accepted the Governorship of Oregon. HIRAM POWERS, the sculptor, has been appoint. ed Commercial Agent of the United States at Florence. Four companies of the Eighth Infantry have been ordered to establish military posts opposite El Paso.

A picture-gallery is always an interesting lounging-place, as well from the intrinsic enjoyment to be derived from a survey of the paintings, as from the thousand incidental bits of character which one picks up in every place to which gazers are attracted. The gallery of the Louvre, in Paris, is one of the most amusing places to spend a day in that we ever frequented;
ADAM KIEFER and CHAS. HUTTAKER were arrested yesterday, for having entered the residence of JOHN HESTON, in Varet-street. near Graham avence, a few daye since,

The weather to-day has been delightful, the very type of Spring. There is but little news stirring, but such as it is, I send your readers. The Grand Jury, this afternoon, made their usual presentment. They have been in session 28 days, have acted on 455 bills, of which they have found 287 true bills, and ignored 168.

Writers of fiction wield weapons now-adays more potent than thes word of the middle-age Reformer. The propagandist, or Iconoclast of to-day, dreams no longer of proving the truth of his doctrines at the dagger's point, or breaking the false idols of the world with an armed hand.

All accounts agree that the fishing business of this year has been an unsuccessful one; nor is this because the British cruisers are too sharp upon our schooners,-our squadron officers insist that on this subject there is no ground for complaint,-but simply because the business is overdone.

Yesterday afternoon a trotting match came off at the Union Course, L. I. The day was fine, and among the virsitor cur reporter noticed many old patrons or the turf, who for several months past have abandoned the Courses on Long Island and elsew here. The attendance was not very large, but those who were present seemed to eujoy the amusement with entire satisfaction.

THE YELLOW FEVER AT VICKSBURG--MEETING FOR THE RELIEF OF THE ? SUFFERERS AT THE ASTOR HOUSE.--Yesterday afternoon a meaning of gentleman interested in the city of Vicksburg was held at the Astor Houses, for the purpose of devising some means by which subscriptions might be raised to relieve the necessities of the afflicted in that place.

An adjourned meeting of such delegates as have been hitherto elected by the various Trades of the City to replesent them in the Labolers' Convention, met last night at KESH'S Hotel, corner of Elizabeth and Grandstreets. Mr. DAVID G. CROLEY (silver knifemaker) occupied the Chair, and Mr. J. A. LAWRENCE (ship joiner) acted as Secretary pro term.

Districts without fixed Sees. but committed to the care of a bishop. The Province of Baltimore is composed of the Metropolitan See ot Bahimore and ts. seven Suffragan Sees,Philadelphia, Charleston, Pltteburg, Richmond, Wheeling Savannah, and Erie.

The Massachusetts Democrats have been preparing, in Convention, for the coming elections. They have divided, and gone to verbal buffets on the Free-Soil question. The friends of the coalition had their meeting at Woreester, yesterday, where they nominated Hon. H. W. BISHOP, of Lenox, for Governor, and LEVI A. DowLEY, a Icather metchant of this city, for Lieutenant;

On Monday afternoon, as one of the cars belonging to the 4.10 train of the Hudson River Railroad was rounding the curve at Thirty-first-streer, the horses knocked down a laboring man, who was crossing the track, and one wheel passed over both his legs, nearly severing them from the body.

The ceremony of inaugurating the new Rooms of the Young Men's Democratic Union Club took place Monday evening at the new Club Rooms, No. 765 Broadway, between Eighth and Nlnth-sts. JOHN COCHRANE, Esq., presided, Remarks were made by WRIGHT HAWKS, S. WALLACE CONE and others. Letters were received from Gov. SEYMOUR, Hon. JOHN A. Dix and SIDNEY WEBSTER, Esq.
A splendid sword and epaulatts will be presented to Capt. POLLARS, of the Continental Guard, this evening, at the Armory of that Company.

DEMOCRATIC YOUNG MEN'S NATIONAL CLUBPERMANENT ORGANIZATION.-A meeting of the Democratic Young Men's National Club was held in S uyvesant Institute last evening, for the purpose of completing a permanent organization. The Chair was taken by Mr. C. GODFREY GUNTHER. and Me srs. J. H ANTHON and W. C. CLOVER, acted as Secretaries.

SINGULAR SUICIDE.--HELEN WILSON, a young woman employed in the bindery department of teh Ohio State Journal office, Columbus, disappeared on Saturday night. leaving behind a letter enclosing ehr gold ear-rings, and stating that having been falsely accused of some improper conduct with a young man, she could not bear to live longer under such an imputation,.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--"Lucia" was repeated last evening to a very fair house. Signora CONSTANZIA MANZINI made her second appearance, and more than sustaining the favorable impression created on her debut. The lady was in better voice, and appeared to have more confidence in the appreciation of the audience.

BILL OF FARE.--The Detroit Tribune is responsible for the following bill of fare, which it attributes to a Niagara Falls hotel: SOLIDS.--First Course--Arm Chairs. Second Course--Heaps of Plates. Third Course--Silver Spoons and Plate Forks. Fourth Course--Wait as long as you please and get nothing.

He told me that up to the time the TIMES of your city was commenced, he had been a subscriber to the Trimnnr, but had always felt some repugnance to its isms S., when your neighbor sent out his paper. he maid to himself, "Here is something that is orthodox," and it was substituted for the Tribure.

Owing to the inclemency of the weather yesterday. the attendance of spectators to witness the troting matches at the Centreville Course, L. I, was very alim The first troting match announced, was between th ehourse, ch. m Miller's Damsel, entered by Mr. CAHL, and b.g. Lar.ce, by JOHN NODINE, for a "purse and match" of $450.

A meeting of the descendants of Elder Wilham Brewster, one of the May Flower Pilgrims, was held at Norwich, Ct., on the 13th inst., to take measures tocomplete a biography of their ancestors. In the course of the discussion it was stated that the eldest son of Eider Brewster, and the eldest son of Miles Standish, settled in the vicinity of Norwick on lands deeded to them by Uncas, the Morgan Chief.

Your correspondent is at his post again, after a fortnight's absence, refreshed by the brief recreation, and in good spirits to commence the interesting campaign which the approaching Congressional season promises.

The meeting of the Softs at Albany on Tuesday night, as appears from the report of the Atlas, which we publish this morning, was a very brilliant affair: At 6 1/2 the citizens commenced gathering at the Capitol. Guns were fired, and large brilliant bonfire blazed at the head of State-street.

The Seventieth Annual Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the Diocese of New-York commenced its sessions yesterday morning, at St. John's Chapel, Varick-street. The p:oceedings were opened by the usual religious services.

This Court commenced its September term at the Capitol in Albany this morning. All the Judge present. Several motions were heard. The following causes were struck from the Calendar under the Rules: Nos. 11, 18, 20, 23, 24, 25, 40, 45 and 71. No. 256, Chappel, appallant, agt Chappel, respondent, Submitted. George A. Starkweather counsel for appelant; Do Wit C. Bates counsel for respondent.

The mail-boat Osprey, arrived at Halifax from Bermuda, brings papers to the 13th inst. The yelow fever had appeared at St. George's, and already carried off numbers of the inhapitants. Up to the 9th inst. there had died one officer, (Lient. WOODFORD.) nine men, four women, and two children belonging to the 56th Regiment, and 106 others were sick.

SERIOUS AFFRAY IN LYNN.-Last evening, as PATRICK McGUIRE and his two brothers, one of them quite a lad, were walking through Franklinstreet, they met three other Irishmen, named JOHN SHERIDEN, JAMES CULLEN and PETER FISK. Words passed between the parties, and CULLEN drew a knife with which he inflicted two stabs upon PATRICK McGUIRE one taking effect in the abdomen and the other in the leg, above the knee.
The publication of Secretary MARCY's A document is not yet ordered. I learn that it is very simple in style ; devoid all boasting Fourth of July declaration.

A very profitable business is being carried on in working the silver-mines and smelting the ore in New-Mexico. The machinery used is very crude and primitive, and yet workmen have been able to extract sixteen dollars from a muleload of three hundred pounds of the ore, and smelting five such loads is an oridnary day's work.

A special meeting of Journeymen Tailors was helt last evening, at GARRICK;S Sixth Ward Hotel, corner of puane and Centre-stree's to hear to report of some members of the Protective Union, in the employ of Messrs. WYMAN Co, No. 256 Broadway, who, it is complained, employ some workmen at a lower price than the standard rate of wages.

The Massachusetts wig State Convention met at Fitchburg this morning, and the attendance is numerous from all sections of the State, many of the leading Whigs being present. Hon.ROBERT C. WINTHROP was cbosen President ofthe Convention. Letters were read from Governor CLIFFORD, and Lieut. Governor HUNTINGTON, deching a renominaton.

The tendency of European society to confer on one part the height of power and hapiness, and to reduce the other to the extreme of weakness and misery, finds a counterpart in the City of New York. In fact, almost every peculiarity of European cities with pity, exists here, and in such degree as to demand our most profound attention.

Trade is still very lively and healthy. The country orders continue to pour in freely, and, from their liberal nature, afford great encouragement to factors, who are kept as busy as possible in discharging the calls of their customers, and preserving their own supplies complete and attractive.

THE FAVER IN GALVESTON.--The Journal of the 15th says the city sexton has made the following report of the interments. Sept. 12, 18; Sept 13, 9; Sept. 14, 12--total. 39. The most of these cases wer taken previous to the present clear and pleasant weather. The South breeze which has prevailed for the last two or three days is considered quite favorable to the health of well persons.

Fifteen or twnety Indians assembled recently at Syracuse, to help settle a dispute between a couple of natives of the Onondaga nation. One of the Indians was charged with shooting a cow belongint to another Indian. They were all sober, and the result of their consultation was to impose a fine of fity dollars on the offender, for the owner of the cow.

EMBEZZLEMENT.--Yesterday morning, a young man named GEORGE PARSONS was arrested by Lieutenant FLANDREAU, of the Eighteenth District, charged with embezzlement, while employed as clerk in the store of Mr. WILKINSON, No 829 Broadway. Being suspected of purloining money from the drawer, the proprietor laid a plan to detect him.

The State Fair is exciting great interest, and is attended by thousands of our citizens and strangers. Twelve cars on the Ohio and Pennsylvania Railroad came in this evening, filled to suffocation; and the Eastern cars still bring large numbers.

In 1832. (says the Buptist Recorder,) Mr. and Mrs. ToDD were sent out as Missionaries of the Aaamerican Board to the Tamil people. Mrs. TODD died in 1835. at Deviapathan. Rer, Mr. TAYLOR, of the Madura Mission, being in that place in February last visted her grave, to see if the monument was in repair.

Among the deaths at New-Orleans on the 18th inst, was that of Madame ZULIME GARDETTE, the mother of Dr. GARDETTE, of New-Orleans, and of Mrs MYRA CLARK GAINES. She died at the residence of her son. Dr. GARDETTE, at the advanced age of seventy-eight years. The Delta of the 20th inst, has the following notice of this remarkable woman:

The Police of the Third District received intelligence Tuesday morning, that a prize-fight was about to come off in that District. A force was put on the lookout, and a about 5 o'clock the fithting men were discovered assembled near Peters' Bridge, on Govwanus creek.

GOLD IN MADRID, MAINK.--Mr. WILLIAM GOLDER, of this place, has just returned from a visit to the diggings in Madrid, on the Sandy River. He brings a very small sample of gold, in scales, which was washed from the earth. It was found on the main branch of Sandy River, about six miles from Phillips village.

We have received later intelligence from Texas, including Galveston dates to the 16th instant, and Indianola papers to the 13th. We see it stated in the Galveston Journal, of the 15th, that the steamship Louisiana, which was to have sailed on the previous Sunday evening for this port, was detained until the following evening from sickness among the passengers and crew, resulting in the death of one before she left.

HEAVY ROBBERY ON A STEAMBOAT.-A gentleman who was a passenger on the steamer Caroline from New-Orleans, on her upward trip to the Illinois River, says the St. Louis Republican, of the 12th, returned yesterday evening, bringing intelligence of a heavy robbery which had been committed on board of that boat not long before his departure

We have no mail south of Norfolk to-night. Rev. Mr. STARR, of the Methodist Church, died at Mobile, of yellow fever. General ALLISON, Speaker of the House of Representatives, has been sworn in as Governor of Florida-both the Governor and the President of the Senate having left the State.

The Great talent and novel charm of Miss BREMER'S writings. so unlike any previous experience of English or American readers and the earnest and wide-spread popularity which a suited the refrom, have led us to anticipate her work on America with a feeling akin to impetience.

EXTENSION OF CANAL-STREET.--The subject of extending Canal street, and widening Walker-steet, has been heard several times at the Special Term of the Supreme Court. The advocates of this City improvement claim the confirmation of the report of the Commissioners, on the ground that many persons who signed the remonstrance have since changed their minds, and are now desirous that the improvement should take place.

We gave yesterday a tail review of teh last work of DICKENS, just brought to its close as a serial, and published emplete by the HARPESS. Of course Bleak House will find thousands of readers inthis country, in its book form, where the periodical chapters, prolonged through nineteen or twenty months, were thrown aside until the whole work could be had together.

On Wednesday afternoon, Sept. 26, suddenly, DAVID DODGE, infant son of Samuel D. and Susan W. Wilson, aged 19 months. The friends of the family, and also members of Eastern Star Lodge, No 227, F. and A. M., are invited to attend the funeral from the residence of his father, No. 183 Division-st., on Thursday afternoon, at 2 P.M.

A neighbor of ours who loved the Fall fashions of the woods, anti would have liked nothing better than to have enjoyed them for some weeks longer has just returned to town because his wife preferred the fall fashions of Broadway. He affected the varying dyes of Automnal foligae: she porsed the hues of changeable silks and wandered to the new style of bonnets.

A considerable number of the citizens of the Eighth Ward, favorabe to the cruse of City Reform, assembled last Eight at MERRITT'S Hall. No. 185 Spring street, for the purpose of electing Ward officers.

The Irish are very annoying on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and the North Western. The jail at Clarksburg is full to overflowing. The Parkershurg News brings us the intelligence of an attack by an Irishman on some respectable ladies,

A Boston correspondent of the New-Orleans Picoyune says: " In a jaunt among my friends of the Boston press, I found them about the same as when my acquaintance with them first commenced, now some five years.

The Union, to-morrow, will publish HULSEMANN'S letter relative to the KOSZTA case, and MARCY'S reply. So far from England and France having united in the remonstrance against INGRAHAM'S conduct at Smyrna, France has actually indicated to Austria its disapprobation of the proceedings of her officers, admitting the circumstances to be correctly set forth in the Vienna Pronunciamento.

A special meeting of the Old Men,s Whig General Committee took place last evening, at the Sroadway House for the transaction of important business connected with the approaching election for City and State officers. There was a large attendance of members from the Several Wards; and owing to the absence of JAMES KELLEY, Exq., the regist Chariman, ZOPHAR MILLS, Esq, of the seventh Ward, presided.

The Pennsylvania Inquirer says: Dr. Henry S. Patterson, the distinguished Professor of Matera Medica and Therapeutics in the Medical Department of Pennsylvania College, has withdrawn from the active duties of that Chair, in consequence of enfeebled health, and has been transferred to the Emeritus Professonship.

RUTGERS COLLEGE--At a meeting of the Board of Trustees of this Institution, on the 27th inst., Prof. GEORGE H. COOK, of the Albany Academy, was unanimously elected Professor of Chemistry and Natural Science, in the place of the late Dr. LEWIS C. BECK.

Some worthy people, desiring to help their not over-well paid clergy, took an opportunity, at the close of the year, to go about to the tradesmen of the place, and to pay all the outstanding bills of the aforesaid reverend gentlemen, causing them to be sent home receipted.

The Norwich and New London Steamboat Co. against The Steamboat Bay State--Judge Nelson, after the proffs were road and the case opened, and without; an argument, said he had no doubt the case and might as well dispose of it

Although the British steamer over due at Halifax has not been board from we have four days later news by the Bremen steamer, touching at Southampton, which port she left on 14th September. The political accounts are somewhat threatening again.

IF The proceedings of the Episcopal Convention yesterday were of peculiar interest and importance. The long-vexed question of the admission of Colored Churches to the rightss of representation, was finally decided in favor of the parish (St. Philip's,) which has so long claimed the privilege.

From the Utica Morning Herald. The Albany Atlas is an able antagonist, and, though its bitterness too often weakens its force, its blows are generally well aimed and planted. Sometimes the Atlas over-estimates its power; it strikes higher than it can reach ; it assaults objects impregnable to even its most biting sarcasm. An instance in point. is its attack, of Monday last, upon GREEN C. BRONSON.

The United States Mail Steamship Washingnton, C. M. FITCH, Commander, arrived at this port ta 2 P. M. yesterday She left Bremen on the 9th and Southampton on the 14th of September, and brings a large and valuable cargo of German, French, and Continental merchandise, together with her usual full complement of passengers.

The first of a Course of Lectures on the " Wonders of Egypt," was delivered on Wednesday evening, by Rev. J. P. THOMPSON, Pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle. The Tabernacle was well filled by an attentive audience.

The Convention assembled in St. John's Chapel, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. There was a full attendance of Delegates, but very few in he galeries. Morning prayer was read by Rev. RICHARD COX, of New-York assisted in the lesons by Rev. Mr. BULL. The Ante-Communion service Bishop WAINWRIGHT.

PHONETIC CONVENTION.--A Convention of the friends of Phonography and Phonotypy took place at the Franklin Hall, in the Franklin House, in Albany, on Wednesday, the 28th inst. A respectalble number of delegates, from various portions of the State, were in attendance.

The President has been quite ill for several days. He has premonitory symptoms, chills and fever. He is, however, improving now, and his physician expresses the hope that quiet will entirely restore him by Monday.

The weather, to-day, has been cool, yet pleasant. Our city continues thronged with strangers, most of whom are from the South and Southwest. With now and then a case of yellow fever, in the "infected district," the health of Philadelphia is improving, and I doubt not but the bill of mortality, for the present week, will show a decided decrease.

About 10 o'clock or Thursday night, two men, named JACOB WILSON and AUSTIN RANEIN, found a young man, apparently a German immigrant, lying on the sidewalk in West-stret, near Hammersley. He was perfectly insensible, evidently from loss of blood resulting from a terrible gash in the throat, and a fracture of the shull.

MEETING OF CONSOLIDATION COMMISSIONERS.--A meeting of the Board of Consolidationt Commissioners was hold on Thursday afternoon at the County Jail The President, Mr. RALBFLRISCH, called the meeting to order, and stated that as he had been elected previous to the appearance of the seven Commissioners from Brooklyn, he would tender his resignation as President of the Board. On motion of Commissioner BERGEW, Mr. KALIDFLEISH was reflected President.

Last evening the Young Men's Democratic Union Club held their regular meeting at their rooms, No. 765 Broadway, JOHN COCKRAN, Esq, in the Chair. The following resolutions were offered by Mr. H. P. CARR, and adoptea:

The Hunkers held a monster ratification meeting here to-night. It was one of the largest gatherings ever witnessed in this city. JAMES D. WASSON presided, assisted by numerous Vice Presidents aud Secretaries. One hundred guns were fired at dark in honor of the Adamantine ticket, and innumerable bonfires were lighted up in the streets. The Hall of the Capitol was insufficient to contain the people assembled.

The mails from New-Mexico arrived at Independence three days since; but the telegraphic dispatches then received contained nothing of any interest or consequence. I received, however, today, some letters from friends in New-Mexico, which post me up relative to the progress of things in that quarter.

YELLOW FEVER AT NATCHIZ.--We are glad to perceive that the pestilence was abating at Natchez at last accounts. From a total of 18 deaths, of which 17 were caused by yellow fever, on the 7th instant, the mortality by the 18th had fallen to 4, of which only 2 were from yellow fever. On the 19th there were no deaths ; and on the 20th 4, of which 3 were from yellow fever.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--"La Favorita" was produced here last evening. Notwithstanding its frequent repetition, the attendance was satisfactory. We have little else to add. The performance was an equal one, and gave satisfaction. Signora STEFFANONE was in excellent voice, but sang very unvenly. Signor BENEVENTANO acted and sang with moderation, and was deserving of more applause than he received. SALVI maintained his position as a capital tenor and remarkably had actor--apparently to the entire satisfaction of himself.

There was a monster meeting of the Albany Adamantines at the Capitol, on Thursday night. JOHN S. NAFkW called them to order, and JAM.s D. WASSON was appointed Chairman, Addresses were delivered by Gso W. CLINTON, SAMUEL S. BOWNE, JA,. T BRADY, Senator VANDERDILT, JNO. C. MATiER, and RUFus W. PBCKHAM, which were enthusiastically received.

I have just seen, with sincere approval, and in accordance with my early and constant wish, the publication of the correspondence between the late L DAVIDSON LEGARE and JOHN DUNOVANT, Esq. It is known that, at the termination of that correspondence, and with full assert to Mr. LEGARE's position as defined by it I became his acting friend, and served him as such at the hostile meeting which ensued.

The TIMES published yesterday morning, in advance of all its City cotemporaries, the very important correspondence between Chevalier HULSEMANN and Secretary MAROY, in regard to the case of MARTIN KOSZTA. The country is under great obligation to the Austrian Government for keeping Mr HULSEMANN at Washington as its representative.

The Convention reassembled at 9 o'clock yesterday. There were but few present in the body of the Church or in the galleries, during morniug prayer, which was read by Rev. T. BABCOCK, of Cohoes, assisted in the lessons by Rev. Mr. CALDY, of West Troy. After morning prayer, several of the clerical and lay delegates arrived.

THE FIREMEN--INDIGNATION MEETING -- The firemen of Jersey City held another, and probobly a final meeting, at Franklin Hall, last evening, relative to the difference between the Department and the Common Council. At the meeting of the Common Council on Tuesday evening last, the wishes, or demands of the firemen were not complied with--Alderman MARINE only voting for them.

The Royal Mail steamship America, Capt LANG, from Liverpool at 10 A. A.M., on the 17th inst., arrived here at 9 1/2 o'clock this (Thursday) evening. She brings 126 passengers. The COLLINS steamer Baltic arrived out at Liverpool on the evening of the 14th inst.; was off Holyhead at 10 o'clock A. M., but detained off the Mersey for want of water.

THE BOSTON PUBLIC LIBRARY.--The Committee authorized by the City Council to purchase a site for the Public Library, yesterday concluded the purchase of the " Wheeler estate," and one of the estates adjoining on Boylston, near Tremontstreet, the same being a portion of the Apthorp estate. The price paid is about $70,000.

SUOCRKNG BARBAITY TO A SLAVE.--The Carrollton (La.) Star, of the 23d ult., has the following: " We grieve, for the honor of our town, to have to record an inhuman outrage practiced on the body of an old negro of this place. named JOINsoN, the slave of CIIARLES HINES, by HINES himself, which resulted in death.

An adjourned meeting of this body was held at their rooms, No. 460 Broadway, last night. CHARLES C. LEIGH Esq, in the Chair Reports from the various committees stated the results of the applications that had been made. It appeared therefrom that Mr. EDWARD KETCHAM had declined to be put in nomination for the office of District Attorney.

The extensive and valuable Herbarium, left by Hon. Stephen Elliot, of Charleston, S. C., has been presented by his daughter to the Cabinet of Natural History of the Charleston College. It is contained in book form, and comprises twenty three large folio volumes.

Accord ing to the Newburyport Herald, many of the fishermen join issue with the officers of the fishing squadron as to the state of affairs on the mackerel grounds. They complain that the provincial cruisers are very arbitrary in their treatment-far more so than the Tnglish officers. They say they are driven off the coast, when in circumstances of peril, and are refused a harbor in the worst of weather.

CHARLES LANMAN, formerly Mr. WEBSTER'S private Secretary, has resigned his position at the head of the Copy right Bureau in the Department of State. T DEVIN REILLY, the Irish patriot, Clerk in the General Land Office; HORATIO N. SEARS, of Lenox. Mass., mail route agent between Bridgeport and Pittsfield.

If a war cloud, though no larger than a man's hand, be discernible on any part of the World's horizon, the barometer on 'Changethat most sensitive instrument- immediately gives token of the storm. Stocks and the mercury fall together. Money, as if afraid of its life, runs for its dens, and dare not show itself, except to borrowers, and they of the best, on a moment's notice, till all is quiet again.

There has been little or no change to interrupt the dull monotony of our " Hurricane Season, since the last packet. The Tortola difficulties are in a fair way of settlement. Courts are now in session there trying the principal offenders in the riot The comet startled us, but was only visible fox a few evenings.

The Turkish question is again the most prominent and interesting feature of our European news. The intelligence brought by the America is three days later than by the Washiglton, and sounds more warlike. France and England were still crying peace, but the Turks were eager for war; and it was with the utmost difficulty that the Sultan could restrain them.

Last week, two sons of Warren Slover were taken from us, and now the rejoicing spirit of their mother, ELIZA ANN. has left us. The mortal part of her is to be removed from her father's house, D. Fanshaw's #day, to the Marble Cemetery in 2d-st., this afternoon, at 3 o' clock. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend.

NEW MODE OF SWINDLING.--A warrant was, Thursday afternoon, placed in officer MURPHY'S hands, for the arrest of a man calling himself THOMAS SURE for obtaining ten shillings in the following manner, from a winow woman named ELIZABETH DOXY, residing at No 175 North Eighth street.

Thursday afternoon it was anticipated that some great trotting would come off at the Union Course, Long Island, as four celebrated horses had been entered for a purse of $250, mile heats, best three in live, to skeleton wagons. There was quite a large attendance on the ground.

The steamer Osprey, which arrived at Halifax on the 26th inst., from St. Johns, N. F., reports that a number of fishing vessels, together with their crews, had been lost on the northern side of Newfoundland, during a terrible gale which occurred about the 15th.

A new work by TALVI is an event which cannot fail to attract considerable attention. TALVI, as most of our readers are aware, is a lady, a German by birth, the daughter of JACOBI, and the wife of Professor ROBINSON, of this City. Her first work, Heloise, brought her prominently before the public, but it was her second work, the erudite Literature of the Sclavic Nations, that gave her peculiar eminence.

The DAILY TIMES of the 13th inst. contained an article on " Ocean Mails," based on an erroneous, although very natural, understanding of an advertisement of the Post Office Department, inviting proposals to carry the mails in ocean steamers. Under the circumstances, it is not surprising that tile article contained much of error, Which I should have noticed before except for absence from my post.

To those who have much time for study, hearing lectures is a rather superficial way of gaining knowledge. It is imbibing thoughts quite too fast for digestion. It is making other people's rhetoric and ideas take the place of one's own worked. out thoughts.

FEDDERICK INGERSOLL, of Vernon, was this day appointed delegate to the Whig State Convention from the second district of Oaside. Mr. IN GERGOLL like the other delegates from Oneida, is for ROSCOR CONKLING for Attorney General.

A meeting of the Seventeenth Ward Total Abetinence Society was held in the Sixth-street Presbyterian tendance was rather limited, and the greater part of these present were ladies. The President, Mr. F. DUNCAN, occupied the Chair, and Mr. W. HITCHCOCK acted as Secretary.

COLONEL FERMONT'S ExPEDITION.--Rumors of the illness of this gentleman, and of his return to St. Louis, have been prevalent here for some days. They are partly true. He suffered an injury the day after leaving the Missouri frontier, and returned to St. Louis (three hundred miles) for medical advice.

S. N. Commander, arrived on Sunday morning from Mobile and Havana. She left the first named port on the 24th inst., and the latter on the 27th. The steamship Philadelphia, for New-York, sailed from Havana on the 26th of September, with one wheel, with the Havan a mails of the 15th.

At a special meeting of the Common Council this morning by the casting vote of Mayor McCARTHY, the use of the City Hall was given for the celebration of the Anniversary of the rescue of the slave JERRY.

There have been over 300 cases of yellow fever at this place, 59 of which have proved fatal. At Port Gibson, all but 17 adults of the place have teen attacked by the scourge, and 60 cases have proved fatal.

Better and better! Pleasant Autumn weather has reduced still lower the weekly list of deaths. The number of burials of the last week was 396, which is 52 less than in the preceding, 51 less than the week before that, and 235 less than for the week ending Sept. 10. Of course, there is a cause for it; it will comfort us to speak of the cause a little further on.

Thirty-three interments were reported today, of which fifteen were from yellow fever. At Mobile there were eleven interments, six of yellow fever. Cotton has been more depressed since the receipt of tbe Washington's news. The market for Flour is tending upwards; we quote at $6 25.

BEFORE HON. JUDGE MITCHELL. Yesterday being appointed for the hearing of this most important matter, the various parties, represented by their several counsel, appared before the Court. Mr. R. DILLON, the Corporation Counsel, presented a petition from the Common Council for the appointment of Commissioners under the act, with the usual affidavits annexed to such petition.

An important movement is going on among the Inventors who have articles on exhibition at the Crustal Palace. They seek to protect themselves by an organization for mutual benefit, and have commenced the formation of a "National Inventors' Union," the object of which are fully set forth in the resolutions given below. The last meeing of the body was held on Saturday.

CRICKET--A genaral play at Cricket will take place at Hoboken, today on SAMS'S Grounda. On the 17th instant, the Philadelphia Club invite the New-York Club to show their skill. We hear that a Cricket Club has been formed by the scholars of the Free Academy, with the cosent of their teachers, and that the St. George Club have kindly tendered them the use of their growed for the purpose of organization.

The Cholera has fallen upon England in earnest. It does not appear suddenly, nor in parts which had been well fortified by cleanliness or even by common attention to sanitary regulations. It bursts forth as it did in 1832, at the North, and works southward.

The following promotions in the Army have been announced: SRCOND DRAGOONS--First Lieutenant P. CALHOUN to be captain, vice ARNOLE, dead. Second Lieuteant CHARLES H. TYLER to be first lieutenant, vice CALROUN, promoted.

SERMON BY DR. VAN ARSDALE--DISCOURSE TO SUNDAY-SCHOOL TEACHERS.--Last evening a very large congregation attended, in the Dutch Reformed Church, corner of Bleecker and Amos-streets, tohear a discourse to Sabbath-School Teachers, by Re. Dr. VAN ARSDALE.

In the precent imperfect slate of our information respecting the intentions of Russia, we are reduced to conjectures in estimating the probable course of events, but we are at no loss for materials in ascertaining the position of affairs, or in definish the propoective contingen ciss of European policy.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I invoke your courtesy for space enough to correct one or two errors, embodied in the obituary ? of the late Mad. GARDETTS, copied into the DAILY TIMES of Thursday, from the New-Orleans Dalis.

The ship Pytha, 928 tons, Captain EUWARD DAVIS, of Liverpool, was totally destroyed by fire, when lying in the Old Calabar River, on the 7th of July. She left Liverpool in February last, with 300 casks of oil, 200 casks of powder, brass rods, rum, cloth of different descriptions, and other merchandise, forming a very valuable cargo.
Treatting Match at Unles Ceures. A spirited trotting match same off at the Unless Course, Thursday, for ?? the ?? ISAAC WOODRUFF ?? PILFER named b. g. Datch Cherley.

" The melancholy days have come, the saddest of the year," sadly sang our poet. The Post is melancholy; the Union is melancholy. The letters, so thoughtlessly written by Collector BRONSON and Attorney O'CONOR, sadden the hearts of their brethren, and make the White-House a Bleak-House.

A private telegraphic dispatch from Vienna, dated yesterday, has been received in parts to this effect. "The Russian Cabinet has definitely refused to accept the modifications demanded by the Porte. A new memorandum from Russia is expected."

The Transactions of the Eighth Annual Meeting of the Ohio State Medical society contain, besides the minutes, several interesting papers. Dr. L. M. LAWSON, of Cincinnati, contributes one on the nature and treatment of certain nervous affections, particularly Coma. Drs. MARIS and BRONSON contribute leaves from their note books.

SHIP BUILDING IN WILLIAMSBURG AND VIGINITY.--Mr. THOMAS STACK, formerly of the firm of Members. PERRINE., PATTERSON STACK, has recently laid the ?? of two vessels. One of them is for a bark of 350 lons, for Mr. M. FREEMAN Co., 115 feet long, 26 1/2 feet wide, and 12 feet deep. The other is a three-masted schooner for Mr. WHITEFIELD, 140 feet long, 30 feet whide, and 18 feet deep.

To the Printers of New-York: GENTLEMEN: The Finance Committee appointed at a meting of the Printers of this City, held at Tammany Hall on Saturday evening, Sept. 24, 1853, acknowledge the receipt of the following sums, which, after paying the small expenses necessarily incurred, will be forwarded to-day to their proper destination:

Suddenly at Orienta, on Sunday, Oct. 2 LOUISA youngest child of Josiahe P. and Mary C. Knapp, aged 10 months and 22 days. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Monday, Oct. 3, and 2 1/2 o'clock P.M. Cras leave the New-HAven Depot, Canal st, at 11 1/ o'clock. Carriages will be in attendance at Mamaroneck Depot.

RESCUED FROM DROWNING -- A man named JOHN LEWIS, of Bedford, Fell into the East River, near the Fulton Ferry, on Saturday night, and would have been drowned but for the timely arrival of officer BUCK, of the Second District Police, who rescued him in an insensible state.

The British steamer America arrived at Boston on Saturday, at 1 P. M. Her mails were received at the Post Office early yesterday morning. We add to car previous summary from Halifax the following telegraphic items, received at Liverpool on the eve of the steamer's departure.

The America's mails add nothing to our intelligence concerning the probabilities of war. The only fact known concerning the progress of affairs, is the one announced by telegraph that the Czar had positively rejected the note framed by the four mediating powers, as modified by the Turkish Sultan.

THE OCTOBER ELECTIONS.--Georgia holds her State election next Monday, when a Governor and Members of Congress are to be chosen....Maryland holds her State election next Wednesday, for Governor, Congress and Legislature, except two-thirds of the Senate......

Yesterday morning Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest at No. 620 Third-avenue, on the body of Mr. MINARD T. ADEE, who died on Saturday night in consequence of injuries received on Thursday evening, at the hands of JAMES BURNS.

The Superior Court was this morning crowded to excess by members of the legal profession, to listen to the address of the above named gentlemen, expressive of the high regard entertained by the New-York Bar, for the late lamented ex-Chief Justice SAMUEL JONES, and the deep regret at his decease.

To the Editor of the London Times: Absence from London, and a severe private sorrow have prevented my sooner noticing certain letters which have lately appeared in the public journals, in which my name has been most improperly introduced by Mr. NORTON, who has thought fit to publish his copy of case laid before me for my opinion in 1836, and a letter of mine to his solicitor, dated Jan. 9, 1837.
The Army Board, for the revision of the Army regulations, composed of Adjutant General COOPER, Col. SUMNER, and Major LEE, (Judge Advocate,) met to-day at the War Department.
Secretary MARCY, you are aware, has been in this city for several days. But probably you were not aware that Chevalier HULSEMANN arrived here yesterday morning. His arrival was known to but a few.
Children's Aid Society. NEW-YORK, Thursday, Sept. 29, 1853. We acknowledge, among other late donations, the following:
Trial trip of the clipper schr. E. T. Blodgett, modelled by FISH MORTON, of New-York, and owned by E. TILDEN, BLODGETT, Esq.

The Baltic's advices, though they embrace nothing decisive as to the issue of the Eastern question, throw light on two or three important points connected with it. We have in the first place the distinct statement, though not official, that the Sultan will not withdraw or change the terms of the note which the Czar has refused to accept.

GENERAL THEOLOGICAL SEMINARY--OPENING OF THE SESSION.--The annual session of the General Theological Seminary of the Protesiant Episcopal Church, corner of Ninth-avenue and Twenty-first-street, opened yesterday, at 9 A.M. Morning prayer was read by Rev. Mr. MAHAN, Dean of the Seminary, assisted by Rev. Dr. JOHNSON.

STATISTICS OF NEW-YORK. Births, Marriages, and Deaths in the City-August, 1853. The City Inspector's monthly Statement of the number of Births, Marriages, and Deaths in this City, for the month of August, has just been completed.

HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD.--FALL AR RANGEMENT--NEW-YORK TO AND FROM ALBANY AND TROY.--On and after MONDAY, Oct. 3, 1853, the Trains will run as follows: GOING NORTH.--Leave New-York from the office cor Chambers-st. and College-place, at 6 A. M., Express Train for Albany and Troy, connecting with Northern and Western Trains. Through in 4 hours from Chambers-st. FOR POUGHKEEPSIE.--Way Passenger Train, 7 A. M., stopping at all stations, and carrying the Way Mail from New-York to Poughkeepsie.

Sickness of the Viceroy--More Troops for the Sultan--Activity of the Grain Trade--Scarcity of Shipping--Prospects of the Crop. Alexandria dates are to Sept. 10. Matters were very quiet in Egypt. Owing to the critical position of affairs between Turkey and Russia, ABBAS PASHA will not go to the Coast of the Red Sea, as he had intended.

Barings' Circular. LONDON, Friday, Sept. 16, 1853. The Colonial and Foreign Produce markets have been flat this week; the complicated state of foreign politics, with renewed animation in the Corn trade, and the enhanced value of Money, have checked all disposition to purchase, except for actual wants; but the general firmness of holders has prevented any notable decline in value.
ANNUAL PARADE OF THE BROOKLYN FIRE DEPARTMENT.--The Third Annual Parade of the Fire Department took place yesterday, under the charge of ISRAEL. D. NELSON, Chief Engineer, as Marshal of the day.

"Agriculture 18 the most healthy, the most useful, and the most noble employment of man." It must be true, for WASHINGTON said it; but, humph! if he had not said it, what perfect nonsense it would have been ! Probably our people know, and who of them practice upon the absurd aphorism ?

Opening of the States-General--The King's Speech. The States-General of Holland were opened at the Hague, on Monday, 19th, by the King, who made the following speech: GENTLEMEN: Again, after a short recess, I see myself in the midst of you. With pleasure I address myself to the Representatives of a people who give me the most decided and cordial proofs of fidelity and attachment.

Our bill of mortality, during the past week, shows a list of 198 deaths, of which 100 were children. Seven fatal cases of yellow fever are reported, and six malignant and five scarlet. The malignant cases may be set down as yellow fever, beyond all doubt. There were nineteen deaths by consumption, and sixteen by dysentery. Among the whole, sixteen died in the Almshouse, and only six were colored persons.

"Remember the Sabbath day to keep it holy !" Such the commandment given to Christians, and in Christian cities nominally followed. Let us see how the law is interpreted. Let us see how the day is sanctified.

This afternoon six lads went out for a sail in a small boat on Niagara River, when, by some accident the boat capsized, and two of the boys, sons of Messrs. BURTON and CLINE, highly respectable citizens, were drowned.

Our Havana correspondence, which owing to interrupted mail communications reaches us in a lump, contains a great variety of interesting and important intelligence. It will be seen that while the Cuban authorities are preparing to repel the statements made in our correspondence and in the British Parliament concerning their complicity with the Slave trade, there has been a fresh cargo of six hundred negroes landed on the Cuban coast.
To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: From an article that appeared in your morning's paper, I am led to request you to publish the following statements:

The West India Mail steamer Orinoco had arrived at Southampton, with dates from San Juan, August 19 ; Jamaica, August 26; St. Thomas, Sept. 1. The advices are not important, and most of them are anticipated by direct arrivals here.
Royalty Usefully Employed--General News-Items--The Cholera in England--A Benevolent American Hotel-keeper vs. The London Times--Suicide of a Supposed American--The Crops in Ireland,

A letter published in Gloucester, and in this city, on Saturday, from Prince Edward's Island, stated that the fishing schooner Winged Racer, had been seized by a British armed vessel for refusing to leave a harbor of that Island when ordered.

On Monday morning, Get. 3, GEORGE W. SCHOTT, in the 26th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of his father, No. 9 West 28th-st., on Wednesday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, without further invitation. Suddenly, at Fairmount, Westchester Co., on Monday morning, GEORGE A., infant son of Samuel and Emeline Blood, aged 8 months.

No News of Importance--The Rumored Loan--Mr. Barringer--Activity in the Navy-Yard--Railroad Collision--Reappearance of the Grape Disense--The Corn Trade, There is no news worth reporting. Some talk was current respecting a loan, but it admitted that the Government would not attempt such a measure at present, unless under the strongest necessity.

The Hards are decidedly up to-day. They are in great glee, and rejoicing exceedingly. AUQUSTUS SCHELL is here. He has had an interview with the President, but what passed is not yet certainly known to outsiders. The Hards assert that the President peremptorily refuses to decapitate BRONSON and O'CONOR.

The Regalia of Hungary--The Approaching Conclave at Olmutz. The Hungarian Regalia are to be brought to Vienna, and lodged in the Treasury called the Schatz-kammer, which is a collection of curiosities belonging to the State.

The steamship Philadelphia left the city of New-Orleans on the 21st day of September, at 8 A. M.; arrived at the Balize at 7 P. M. and an chored; crossed the bar at 5 o'clock next morning and sailed for Havana, at which port she arrived on the morning of the 25th of same, making three days three hours sail therefrom.

Full Accounts of the Progress of the Insurrection. The Governor of Shanghae had organized a fleet at Canton, with which to attempt the recovery of the mouths of the Grand Canal. Latest advices say the attempt was made, but totally without success.

By the Overland Indian Mail, received in England, we learn that the United States Expedition sailed from Loochoo, on July 3, for Japan. The Commodore's fleet consisting of the steamers Susquehanna and Princetown, and ships Plymouth and Saratoga, to be followed by the Powhattan and Vandalia.

SERMON BY BISHOP McCROSKEY. Delivered in Bleecker-street Church. On Sunday evening, Bishop McCROSKEY, of Michigan, preached an able and instructive sermon, at the Episcopal Church corner of Bleecker and Morton-streets, a large and highly respectable congregation being in attendance.

Senor Calderon de la Barca. Mr. CALDARON DE LA BARCA was to reach Madrid, Sept. 17. The Minister of Marine was not to be appointed before his arrival. PARIS, Sept. 18. M. SOULE leaves Paris this evening on his way to Madrid. He stops for a day or two at Bordeaux, but then goes on without delay.
The U. S. Mail steamship Baltic, from Liverpool about 1 o'clock P. M., Wednesday, Sept. 21, arrived at this port at 7 o'clock, on Monday morning, Oct. 3.

The Salt Lake mail arrived at Independence on Wednesday last. Mr. J. M. BERN HISAL. Delegate to Congress, was among the passengers. The emigrants had all passed Salt Lake. The Indians had been very troublesome in Utah, killing many persons.

Among our " moving accidents" by fire, the most conspicuous has been a conflagation in the steamship-yard, last Saturday on the premises of SCOTT, RUSSELL Co., at Mill Wall, Poplar. This was no common conflagration, seeing that the property destored amounts to about 100,000.

LAW-COURTS.--A general term of the Supreme Court commenced on Monday. There will also be held a special term. The October term of the City Court, before Judge GREENWOOD, commenced on Monday. A jury was empanneled and discharged until Monday the 10th inst., to enable counsel to attend to business in the other county. This term will be devoted exclusively to civil business.

The Austrian Government, through Mr. HULSEMANN, its Charge d'Affaires, declares that its Consul " was, without doubt, perfectly justified, when in virtue of those treaties, which subject Austrian subjects in Turkey to Consular jurisdiction, he seized the person of KOSZTA within the pale of his jurisdiction."

BURLINGTON COLLEGE--MEETING OF ALUMINI--A meeting of the Alumni of Bulington College, Vermont, was held on the 29th ult., the day ofthe Annual Commencemnt. Twentyone members of the Association were present. Rev.

We are informed that a Company has been organized, and the stock subscribed, for constructing a submarine Telegraph between Liverpool and New-York via Galway, New-foundland and Nova Scotia, and for extending subterranean branches of it to every part of Europe.

Before Chief Justice Nelson. COLLISION ON THE NORTH RIVER. Walter Millard ond Uri Milts vs. James E. Craig, and others.--The libel was filed in this case by the owners of the steamboat against the owners of the scow, to recover damages for a collision that occurred on the North River on the 6th November, 1850, about 11 o'clock at night, opposite the Twin Brothers, a ledge of rocks a little below Cold Spring.

A meeting of the Young Men's National Democratic Club was held in their room, Stuyvesant Institute, last evening, to hear the report of the " Committee on Permanent Organization." Mr. C. GODFREY GUNTHER Was appointed Chairman, and Mr. J. H. ANTHON, Secretary.

JAMBS G. KING, Esq., Principal of the Banking House of JAMES G. KING SONS, Wall-street, New-York, died yesterday morning, at his residence, in Weehawken, on the Jersey shore, and in the 63d year of his age.

There was a full attendance of Aldermen at the opening of the October session, on Monday afternoonRICHARD. T. COMPTON, Esq., in the Chair. The minutes of the two last meetings in September were read and approved.

The President is in god health and buoyant spitits. He believes that the efforts maaking to disorganize the Democtatic party, and embarrass the administration, will signally fail. The rumored appointment of CUSHING, Commissioner to China, is believed to be unfounded.

The Delegates to the Whig State Convention are assembling, and talking over matters. The most prominent names for candidates appear to be LEAVENWORTH, for Secretary of State; SPALDING, of Buffalo, for Comptroller; JAMES M. Cook, for Treasurer.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foregin Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,) No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co..(do.). .Broadway, cor. Reade-st. Agricultural Warehouse. R. L. ALLEN, (late A. B. Allen Co.)189 191 Water.

The steamship Crescent City, J F. SCHENCK, U. S. N., commander, arrived at this port last evening, bringing the U. S. Mails, 501 passengers, and nearly $1,000,000 treasure from California and Australia--the first shipment of gold from the latter place, (amount $40,000,) per ADAMS Co's Express, by way of Callao and Panama.

Secretary DOBBIN, accompanied by Captain McGRUDER, left here this morning, to visit and Inspect the various Navy Yards throughout the Northern States. JEFFERSON DAVIS is appointed Acting Secretary of the Navy, during Mr. DoBBIN's absence.

We take from one of the Brooklyn papers the following able and convincing. article on the question of a supply of water, and the means by which it may be attained. The article is worthy of a more general reading, and we therefore quote it entire :

RICHARD RIKER, son of John L. Riker and Lavinia Riker, in the 20th year of his age. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from his father's residence at Bowery Bay, Newtown, L. I., on Wednesday, 5th inst., at 3 P. M. On Tuesday, Oct. 4, Miss FRANCIS GAENES, in the 23d year of her age.

A PAPER--By E. G. SQUIER, ESQ. The New-York Historical Society held the opening meeting of the season in University Chapel, last evening--Hon. LUTHER BRADISH in the Chair. There was a more than usually full attendance of members. The minutes of previous meetings were read by Mr. FIELD, the Secretary, and approved.
JUDSON, the Democratic candiate for Governor, is believed to be elected. He has majorities in the following counties: DeKalb, 200l Coweta, 150; Fayette, 150; Case, 70; Chatham, 147; Bibb, 100.
Mr McKAY's monster ship, the Great Republic, of 4,000 tons, was successfully launched this morning, in the presence of 30,000 people from all parts of the country.

New-Orleans papers of the 28th ultimo are received. They contain the Mexican advices of the 18th, stating the prevalence of a rumor of hostilities having commenced in Mesilla Valley earl) in September.

A violent gale is blowing on Lake Erie, and the sea is running so high as to prevent vessels going out. The schooner Stranger came in this morning, and reports seeing a vessel about 12 miles up, 2 miles from the Canada shore, with three men clinging to the masts, which alone were visible above the water,

A number of the inhabitants of Carmansville assembled in that village yesterday afternoon, to witness the ceremony of laying the corner-stone of a New Dutch Reformed Church, and to listen to an address from Rev. Dr. VERMILYE, of New-York.

Cards of invitation were issued some days since by Capt. REID, attached to the Brooklyn Navy Station, to a large circle of the friends anti acquaintances of his son in law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. GEORGE SANDERS, to join them in a morning ball on board the North Carolina, 74, United States receiving ship, previous to their departure for London.

The city is filled with delegates to the Whig State Convention. Aspirants for office and a host of outsiders are here, urging various nominations. Among the group I notice many of the leading me bers of the party, but not as many as usual. The delegates appear to be mostly young men ; at least two thirds of them attend the State Convention for the first time.
We publich exclusively in the TIMES of this morning, the official Report of the late conference at Brussels, between Lieut, MAURY and the accredited representatives of the Maritime Powers of Europe.

It is due to the Editors of the Washington Union to acknowledge their kind attention in getting out an extra containing the KOSZTA correspondence, and mailing it to the press of the country twelve hours in advance of their regular edition.

Before Judge Philips. ACTION FOR LIBEL AGAINST THE SUN NEWSPAPER. John F. Gerard and others vs. Moses S. Beach and Joseph W. Stagg.--This was an action brought against the defendant, Beach, as proprietor of the Sun newspaper, and the defendant Stagg, as the author of the alleged libel for having published in the said newspaper an advertisement detrimental to the character of the members of No. 12 Hose Company.

The Maritime Conference lately held at Brussels, by invitation of the Government of the United States, between Lieutenant M. F. MAURY and representatives from the Governments of Great Britain, Prussia, France, Norway, Sweden, Belgium, Denmark, Netherland and Portugal, has resuited in the establishment of a uniform system of Observations at sea.

In addition to the accounts from Peruvian papers published in yesterday morning's TIMES, concerning the trouble between the Peruvian authorities and the commander of the ship Defiance, we have received an extract from a private letter, dated at Callao, to parties in this City, which is more satisfactory then accounts from other sources

TRICTS.--The Board of Aldermen have recently re-districted the Wards as follows: FOURTH WARD.--First District--To be bounded by the centre of Sands, Fulton, Bridge and Concord-streets. Second District--To be bounded by the centre of Concord, Fulton, Johnson and Bridge-streets. Third District--To be bounded by the centre of Johnson, Fulton and Bridge-streets.

Bulloch County gives JOHNSON (Democrat) for Governor, 360; JENKINS, (Unionist) for Governor, 23; SEWARD (Democrat) for Congress, 336 BARLOW, (Unionist) for Congress, 36. In McIntosh JOHNSON'S majority is 60; Liberty, do., 70; JENKIN'S majority in Effingham, is 70; Bryan, 60 JOHNSON'S election is considered sure.

Our readers have been made familiar with the origin and progress of the movement to consolidate the cities of Brooklyn and Williamsburg, and the town of Bushwick, up to the present time. To-day, we publish the reports of Committees appointed by and from

The schr. Gordon, from Port-at-Prince Sept. 10, arrived at this port this morning reports that the fever which had for so long a time, ravaged the Island, had disappeared at Port-an-Prince, and the accounts from the other parts of the Island were favorable.

The Commissioners on Consolidation met, as per adjournment, yesterday morning, at 11 o'clock, in the County Jail, when the following Committees presented their reports as follows: On Division of Wards.--That in the proposed consolidated city, Bushwick shall be entitled to two wards, making the north road running through Bushwick the division of the two wards.

A MAN WITH TWENTY WIVAS.--A man calling himself Dr. WM. HUNTER, but whose real name is NATHANIEL J. BIRD, is in jail at Camden, N. J., on a charge of bigamy and various other charges. ELIZABETH HARRINGTON, a lady of Philadelphia, visited him in prison, and ascertained he was the man to whom she was married on June 9, last.

On Wednesday, Oct. 5, ALEXANDER C. WHEELOCK, son of Clark Wheelock. The friends of the family, and the members of the Atlantic Hose and Relief Company, No. 1, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his father's residence, No. 91 Washington-st.; Brooklyn, on Friday, 7th inst., at 10 o'clock A. M.

The Secretary of the Treasury has issued orders, requiring the clerks throughout the depart meant to be at their desks from 9 to 3 o'clock, until April 1, and prohibiting going out to take drinks, on penalty of removal from office .

We have been placed in possession of Jamaica papers to Aug. 27. In the Legistlateiv circules nothing important had transpired. During the month there had been considerable rain. The Deputy Collecting Constable, for the parish of Portland, was recently severely assaulted and heaten, while attempting to force, by levy, the paryment of taxes due by some of the inhabitants to the parish. the same time,

President COMPTON in the Chair. Petitions were received of Samuel H. Higginson, that the Corporation purchase some copies of his Map of New-York, as it was in 1767; of T. Ball, to furnish a copy of the statuette of Daniel Webster, to be placed in the Governor's Room.

Nicholas Mason, of Roxbury, Mass., for Improvement in Cooking Ranges. Henry McCarty, of Pittsburg, Pa., for Improvement in the manufacture of Sheet Iron.

The schooner lost yesterday was the Oneida, loaded with 8,000 bushels of wheat from Toledo, owned by Captain W. ALLEN, who was drowned. She was run down by some steamer, bound up, the night before last, between 9 and 10 o'clock, and went down in about 15 minutes.

THREE FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENTS.-On Saturday morning last, as we learn from the Springfield Republican, DANIEL FERRE, of Springfield, an engineer of the Western Railroad, forty years of age, was killed, at the Chester Factories, by being run over by a freight train, while engaged in carrying before his engine a long shackling iron to attach to the last car of another train.

By the clipper-ship Maria, Capt. LYTLE, arrived at this port yesterday, we have dates from Rio Janeiro to Aug. 19 and 20, inclusive, with files of the Diario do Rio Janciro, Jornal do Commercio, and Correio Mercantil.

In another part of this morning's TIMES will be found a very interesting and instructive letter to Senator BUTLER, of South Carolina, from WILLIAM HENRY TRESCOT, Esq., upon the Diplomatic system of the United States, and in review of Secretary MARCY'S circular of instructions to our foreign agents.

RAILWAY TRAIN ATTACKED BY A GANG OF IRISHMEN.-The night train for Cleveland from Columbus, on Saturday, had an Irishman on board who gave the conductor much trouble, and who was dealt with as in such cases has been "made and provided."

Dr. GEO. C. HOWARD, of Churchville, committed suicide on Wednesday morning last, by drowning. He is said to have been an amiable and highly respectable man, well known throughout the Western part of Rochester county. He had recently purchased a farm at Churchville,

The storm of yesterday continued throughout the night with much violence. About 2 o'clock this morning, a fire broke out at the Five Points, on Evans-street, and the flames being carried by the wind, rapidly spread north towards the Canal, and east towards Main-street.

A meeting of the members of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday in the Merchants' Bank building, and resolutions of respect to the memory of JAMES G. KINO, late President of the Board, were adopted. Mr. Stevens, one of the committee appointed yesterday, in presenting the annexed resolutions, made some very feeling remarks on the virtues of the deceased, whom he considered a true man:

Yesterday the Court of Sessions was crowded by a multitude of liquor dealers, who on previous occasions had pleaded guilty to the charges brought against them, and now came up to receive the judgment of the Court for their illegal and unrighteous traffic.

The Twelfth Annual Fair 'of the Queens County Agricultural Society opened yesterday, at Hempstead, L. I., with a display equal to its former exhibition in this part of the county, though inferior to the late Fair held at Flushing. SUMNER W. BENNETT, Esq., very liberally granted the use of a large field of twenty acres, half a mile south of the village, on the Oyster Bay turnpike-road.

Two or three hundred persons, whose names will be found in another column, were fined yesterday in the Court of Sessions from $10 to $50 for having been convicted of selling intoxicating liquor without a license. The Judge in passing sentence warned them

The correspondence of the French and German press furnishes sundry items of intelligence, which have interest for American resders. A Paris correspondence sttes that the Rasso Turkish question will not be the only one dicussed in the private ocnference at Olimz.

DEATH OF MR> S??AELATTEN, THE D??AUGHJT??MAN--The Lake Superior Journal, of the 17th ult. gives some particulars of the death of Mr. SCHLATTER, a draughtsman attached to the Geological Survey Expedition at Portage Lake, who was frozen to death last Winter in the woods.

DEAR SIR: The publication of the new instructions from the State Department to diplomatic functionaries, the usual interest taken in new appointments, and to do the graver portion of the community justice, the serious character of many questions of foreign policy seem to have aroused a more than common degree of attention towards the diplomatic system of the Government.

SIR: The Press of Canada has been much occupied within the last ten days in exposing a fraud which has been dextrously played off on the Corporation of Toronto, through the instrumentality of Mr. BOWES, its Mayor, and of Mr. HINCKS, Provincial Financial Minister.
