By our latest dates from Santa Fe, we learn that quite an animated canvass is going on in New-Mexico for a delegate to Congress. The candidates are Ex-Governor LANE and a Mexivan Priest, Don JOSE MANUEL GALLEGOS. Governor MERIWETHER, upon entering upon his duties as Governor of the Territory, delivered the following neat and appropriate Inaugural Address:

ANOTHER MURDER!--A SEDUCER SHOT BY HIS VIOTIM!--Considerable excitemnt was caused in a aportion of our city last evening, by the intelligence that a colored man named JOHN E. MURRAY, residign on George street, between Elm and Race, had been shot in hisown house, and had died shortly after.

NEW-ORLEANS AND THE FEVER--DON'T RETURN YET.--We copy the following from the Picayune of the 25th ult: The large number of old and familiar faces which have suddenly reappeared in our streets within the last two or three days is very observable.

The U. S. Deputy Marshals CROSSIN and JENKINS had warrants of arrest served upon them yesterday, on a charge of riot, and assault and battery upon BILL THOMAS, an alleged fugitive slave, at Wilkesbarre. On the oath of WM. C. GILDERSLEEVE, a resident of Wilkesbarre,

Early this morning there was a very heavy white frost visible, but as the day advanced the mercury went up, and the weather has been delightful. Our Coroner--and he is a bright one-has been some three or four weeks investigating a case of alleged poisoning in West Philadelphia, of a young married woman, named AMANDA T. JENKINS.

I believe I was the first to communicate to your readers the fact that the Colonial Ministry had decided on petitioning the Home Government for an alteration in their political constitution, by bringing about a union of all the British North American Provinces, with Quebec as the seat of the Federal Government.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--DONIZETTI'S "Elisir D'Amore" was produced here last evening, for the third appearance of the new Prima Donna, Signora MANZINI. The character of Adina depends not alone on vocalism, but on good acting.

The Convention met this morning, and was called to order by E. D. MORGAN. Gen. BENJAMIN BRUCE, of Madison, was appointed temporary Chairman. After thanking the Convention for the honor of the appointment, Gen. B. congratulated the delegates on the auspicious circumstances under which they assembled,

The Triennial General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States assembled in this City yesterday. The opening ceremonies took place at Trinity Church. The body is composed of the Bishops and the Clerical and Lay Delegates of the various Dioceses of the Union.
SAMUL MEDARY, of Ohio, Minister, and THOS. E. MASSEY, of Alabama, Secretary of Legation at the Court of Chili, are here. They expect to depart on their mission abourt the 30th, vid Panama.

Visit to a Louisiana Sugar Plantation Continued-The Cultivation of the Cane, and the Manufacture of Sugar. I shall describe in this number the cultivation of sugar cane in Louisiana, according to the method followed on the plantation to which I have introduced your readers ; but before doing so, I will give a few particulars with regard to the nature of the plant.

MURDER AT FORT HAMILTON.--On Tuesday evening, a brutal murder was committed at Fort Hamilton, by an Irishman named JOHN O'SULLIVAN, who beat and kicked his wife CATHARINE, so severely, that she died within an hour. It appears that O'SULLIVAN had visited this City for the purpose of making purchases of coal,

The American Board of Missions held its annual meeting in this city to-day. The annual report shows the receipts to have been, for the past wear, $310,000, and the expenditures $314,000. The report from the Prudential Committee shows the whole number of members, 187; the whole number of missionaries, 360; number of missions, 28: stations, 149.

SUFFOLK COUNTY POLITICS.--A correspondent writing from Riverhead, Suffolk County, yesterday, says that the Democracy of the First Assembly District, on the 4th, nominated HUBBARD GRIFFING, Esq., for Assembly. The County Conventions met on the evening of the same day. The Whigs nominated their ticket with great unanimity.

The Portland State of Maine learns through Mr. Latham, of the Atlantic and St. Lawrence Railroad, that when he left Gorham, N. H., on Wednesday morning at 6 o'clock, the ground was covered with snow--the mountains being covered with it, and wearing apparently, their Winter garb--and that it was still falling when he left.

About fifty members of the Academy of Medi cine had a pleasant reunion at their quarters in the small Chapel of the University, last evening. Dr. ISAAC WOOD presided, assisted by Drs. DETMOLD and BEALE. After calling the roll, reading the minutes of the preceding meeting, and calling the standing committees for report, Dr. DETMOLD exhibited a thumb which was torn from the hand of the late owner during the day.

From the Washington Union. Commodore SHUBRICK returned on Wednesday to this city from the command of the squadron, detailed in July for the protection of American fishermen on the eastern coast of the United States and British North America.

FIRE.--On Wednesday about 11 o'clock, a fire broke out in the three-story brick building corner of Ewen-street and Montrose-avenue, owned by JACOB ZIMMER, which together with the contents, was mostly destroyed.
A ?man is about to be issued to authorize the admission of the evidence of Christians in Courts of Law. This is the most important reform that has taken place, in many years, in the Ottoman Empire.

JUDICIAL CONVENTION.--The Whigs have nominated, as delegates to the Convention of the Second Judicial District, to be held at Poughkeepsie Tuesday next, from the First District-JOHN HESS; Second District--WM. CONOVER; Third District--J. K. Gilbert.

It is estimated that the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, which convenes this afternoon, will bring to the city over a thousand visitors from various parts of the Union. This is a large number, when we consider that most of them come from the Eastern States.

The Emperor will not go to War--State of the Revenue--Emperor's Visit to Boulogne--Marriage of fair American--Various Items. Whatever may be the issue of the present Turkish difficulty, it is the general belief in Paris that the Emperor will not go to War. He is said to have expressed himself to that effect very recently.

We regret to announce the death of Hon. ELIJAH PAINE, one of the Justices of the Superior Court. Judge PAINE reached the City on Wednesday afternoon from Poughkeepsie, and was conveyed to his residence in this City on a litter, being too weak to assist himself.

The Navy Department is advised of the arrival of the frigate St. Lawrence, the flag-sloop of Commodore DOLANY'S Pacific Squadron, at Sancelito, Bay of California, on the 30th August, on a cruise. All well Hon. JOHN W. DAVIS, the new Governor of Oregon, proposes to sail for his post, via the Isthmus, by the steamer of the 20th inst., from New-York.

From Constantinople, Sept. 8, it was stated that the greatest excitement still prevailed. A petition was in circulation, and had obtained a great number of signatures, calling upon the Ministers either to make war or to conclude an honorable peace.

An address was lately presented by the Town Council of Greenock to Lord JOHN RUSSELL, in the Mid Church, the Town Hall having been found too small for the numbers who were anxious to testify their admiration of the noble lord's public services and conduct.
A large, faint, nebulous comet, resembling a star-cluster, was discovered near the forward paw of the Great Bear, on the night of September 11, by Mr. C. BRUHUS, in Berlin.

CONSOLIDATION. Meeting of the Board of Consolidation Commissioners. REPORTS OF COMMITTEES ADOPTED. A meeting of the Board of Consolidation Commissioners was held yesterday, at the County Jail, as per adjournment, Present: Commissioners Kalbfieisch, (President,) Coles, Strong, Wyckoff, Linsky, Murphy, Brode, Hopkins, Sprague, Sloun, Morris, Bergen. Johnson--13.
Paris correspondence states that the Sultan issued a manifesto, on 4th inst., but owing to the excitement it produced its publication was stopped after but a few copies had been printed.

It may be recollected that the celebrated violinist PAGANINI died at Nice about fourteen years ago, and that the Bishop refused to allow his remains to be interred in consecrated ground because he had died without receiving the sacrament.

The Governor of Maine devotes most of his messages to the Legislature, which just convened in special session, to the contracts for the sale in Maine of the lands in that State owned by Massachusetts.
The steamship Arabia, from Livepool Saturday noon, September 24, arrived at this port yesterday morning.

The Whigs at Syracuse nominated a ticket evidently with the purpose of electing it. This design is revealed not less by the Character of the nominations than by the harmony and union that prevailed in the Convention.

A man named WAGGSTAFF, convicted at the Hudson County Court, New-Jersey, of obtaining money upon false pretences, from a man named JOHN HALL, has been sentenced to imprisonment for four months, and a fine of $360, beside costs to the amount of $200.

THE MURDER OF MURRAY AT CINCINNATI. --FURTHER PARTICULARS--The murder of the mulatto J. L MURRAY, at George-street, Cincinnati, has created great excitement, and much interest and even sympathy are felt for the murderess.

The Whig party held a mass meeting last night in Penn-square. It was not a very immense affair. The speakers were Messrs. REED, GILPIN, O'NEIL, MORRIS, FLANIGAN, and WEAVER, all candidates for office.

After a visit to the State Fair, or failure, at Saratoga, I have been straying over Northern New-York and the Lake Champlain portion of Vermont Among other places that I have visited, are the Slate Quarries at this place; and thinking a notice of them might be interesting to your readers, I have made a few notes of what I have seen.

Overthrow of the Ministry--The New Cabinet. A dispatch from Madrid, Sept. 19, announces the downfall of the Lersundi Ministry. M. SARTORIUS is named Minister of the Interior and President of the new Cabinet.

Those who, for the last two months, have been preaching peace, and proclaiming the certainty of a pacific adjustment of the Russo-Turkish dispute, must feel not a little mortified and perplexed at the present aspect of affairs.
St. Petersburg Markets--Russo-American Factory. Dates from St. Petersburg are to Sept. 14, when the state of Exchange was rather less unfavorable, the quotation on London being 39d. to 39 1/8d.

SECOND DAY. Some of the Bishops, with the Clerical and Lay deputies, assembled in St. John's Chapel at 9 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning. Morning Prayers were read by Right Rev. Bishop SMITH, of Kentucky, and the Lessons by Bishop KEMPER, of Wisconsin. The attendance was somewhat scanty. After prayers the Bishop proceeded to take their seats in their House.

The Woman's Rights Convention assembled here to-day. Mrs. FRANCES D. GAGE, of St. Louis, was elected Presidentess; MARTHA WRIGHT, of New York, CAROLINE and H B. BLACKWELL, of Ohio, Secretaries--with nine Vice Presidents of both sexes.

MILITARY. Third Annual Target Excursion of the Harper Guard. The Third Annual Target Excursion of the Harper Guard was briefly noticed in yesterday's paper. The Company marched from the Park to the pier at the foot of Thirtieth-street, North River, where they embarked on board a steamer, and proceeded to Stryker's Ray.

From the London Times, 22d. In another part of our impression will be found a dispatch from Count NESSELRODE to Baron MAYENDORTT, expressing some of the reasons alleged by the Czar for refusing to accede to the Turkish modifications. This document will not require much comment.
On Thursday, Oct. 6, at Mr. Hunter's corner of 52d. st. and Broadway, Miss JANE S. PARKS, aged 22 years, 9 months and 4 days.

A new HOUSE Printing Telegraph line is, we understand, to be built this Fall, from Troy to Montreal and Saratoga Springs, which, when completed, will make the fifth telegraph line leading from this City by different routes, to Montreal and Quebec.
The Convention of the Liberty party met at the Free Church, Canestota, at 11 o'clock yesterday. Rev. J. W. LOGUEN was chosen President, and Rev. ABRAHAM PRYNE Secretary.

SECOND DAY. There was a better attendance of visitors at the Qtrey as County Fair at Hempstead, yesterday, than had been anticipated, seeing that the appearance of a heavy rain storm on Wednesday evening had completely cleared the village of strangers.

IMPORTANT CASE. Charge of Compounding a Felony. JEFFERSON POLICE COURT. Before Justice McGrath. A few days ago, a gentleman named Michael Mulvey, who recently resided in the village of Rhinebeck, Dutchess County, came before Judge McGrath, at the Jefferson Police Court, and made affidavit against a Justice of the Peace in that county, charging him with compounding a felony.

It would seem that a season which has proved so fatal to our Southern cities ought not to be an uninstructive one. The yellow fever has raged now these twenty weeks at New-Orleans--one would suppose that unless its origin and causes are wrapped in the most inexplicable mystery, some close observed would succeed in dragging them to light, so that hereafter the plague may be stayed before it crosses the threshold.

The Arabia brings us confirmation of the worst features of the intelligence from Europe by the previous arrival. The difference between Russia and Turkey grows more and more complicated, and seems still more certain to end in hostilities.

Fourth Anniversary of the American Bible Union. New Translations of the Scriptures. The Fourth Anniversary of the American Bible Union was held yesterday morning, in the First Baptist Church, (Dr. CONE'S,) corner of Broome and Elizabeth-streets. The sessions continued during day and evening.

The Woman's Rights Convention had a stormy session to-day. Resolutions characterized by the usual ultraism were adopted. They claim the elective franchise, political station, and all kinds of hard work for women.

The Episconal Recorder of to-morrow will contain a disclaimer of the slander against Arch bishop HUGHES. It states that the article in question was inserted during the absence of the publishers and editor from the City--pronounces it untrue, expresses regret at its accidental publication, and tenders such amends as every honest and Christian man should be most cheerful and ready to make when unintentional injury has been done to the feelings of others.

GROUND FOR A CITY HALL.--The Committee on Public Grounds and Buildings reported, some weeks since, in favor of the purchase of a block of ground on Erie-street, on which hereafter to put a City Hall and other public buildings. At the last meeting of the Board, the Committee on Laws and Ordinances reported that, under the Charter, the Board could not legally increase the debt of the city sufficiently to allow of this transaction.

A RIOT AMONG LABORERS.--Yesterday afternoon an alarming disturbance took place among a gang of laborers, employed at some new buildings erecting on Murray-street, near Church-street. It appears the dispute commenced between workmen who were tearing down the old building at the corner of Church-street, and others who were engaged upon the new warehouse on the adjoining lot.

The American Bible Union reassembled yesterday morning in Dr. CONE'S (First Baptist) Church At 9 o'clock a few of the members met in the Lectureroom, and joined in prayer. At 10[1/4] Dr. CONE (President) called the meeting to order. Rev. Mr. FOSTER, of New-Hampshire, offered prayer. The Secretary read the minutes of the previous day. MISSIONARY ENTERPRISES IN CENTRAL AMERICA.

The Canal tolls for the 4th week of September were $105,297; and for the season, $2,230,484,--being an increase of $28,567 on the same period last year. On Friday last a boiler at the steam saw-mill of VANSITTART COTTLE, in the township of East Oxford, Canada, exploded, killing four men who were in the mill at the time.

FOR THE WEST AND SOUTH.--BALTIMORE AND OHIO, AND WASHINGTON BRANCH RAILROAD, for WHEELING, ZANESVILLE, CINCINNATI, LOUISVILLE, ST. LOUIS, great road was first opened for through travel in January Inst. The tunnels then unfinished are now completed. The entire road is in fine order, and presents one of the most pleasant and picturesque routos in the world.

SIXTI AND EIGHTH-AVENUR RAILROADS.--The embarge has been removed! "The track is clear. The Avenue Railroads can, at last, move peacefully to the end their tether. We need wait no longer for the tardy movements of builders or the obstacles of Mr. HOPE. Yesterday, the work of repairing the damage to the return track in Church-street was completed, and the cars of both Roads commenced running anew through College-place, Barclay and Church-streets.

The Convention reassembled yesterday morning in St. John's Church, Divine service was commenced at 9 o'clock, Rev. Dr. CREIGHTON, the President, reading the Morning Prayers, and Rev. Dr. PAGE, of Memphis, Tenn., the Lessons. The Convention then resumed the transaction of its business.

The unwomanlike women who constitute all the Women's Rights Conventions, were at Dayton on the 24th ult., resolving in dignantly about the insulting outrage put upon their sex at the Metropolitan Hall World's Convention, and resolving amiably about Hon. NEAL Dow, who did not stand up so very stoutly for Rev. ANTOINETTE's rights, after all.

The celebration at Tarrytown yesterday, of the completion of the monument to the Captors of Major ANDRE, was one of the largest, finest, and most gratifying demonstrations of the kind we have ever attended. An immense number of the inhabitants of the neighborhood, with large delegations of military and other associations from this City and elsewhere were present, and evinced the liveliest interest in the exercises and the occasion.

The proceedings and display, yesterday, at the dedication of the monument recently erected at Tarrytown, for the purpose of designating the spot where Major ANDRE was captured, in character and grandeur far exceeded the general expectation. Doubtless so interesting an event would have called together a goodly number under the most unfavorable condition of circumstances; but patriotism was not tried by storm and rain.

AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY.--At the last monthly meeting of the Board of Managers of the American Bible Society, nine new auxiliaries were recognized; of which two are in Ohio, two in Iowa, and in Illinois, North Carolina, Tennessee, Georgia, and Missouri, one each. Various letters were received from abroad.

Stamford was crowded yesterday with strangers from this and the neighboring counties, to witness the Cattle Show and ladies' riding match. The exhibition of cattle exceeded anything even before seen in the State. A single train of oxen from the West numbered one hundred and eigoty yoke, all very fine animals. 5,000 persons were on the ground at the time.

The Board of Missions held their second meeting in the Church of Ascension, corner of Fifth avenue and Tenth-street, at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Rt. Rev. Bishop MEADE, of Virginia, in the Chair. The Rt. Rev. President opened the proceedings with prayer, after which Rev. Wm. DENISON, Secretary, read several reports from the various Missions in China, Africa, , giving a detailed account of their working.

SERMONS BY BISHOPS OF THE EPISCOPAL CHURCH.--'The members of the Episcopal Church in the City, will have a fair opportunity to-morrow, to hear some of the most distinguished divines of that donomination. Archdeacon SINCLAIR, will preach in All Saints' Church, Henry-street, to-morrow afternoon, the service to commence at 3 1/2 o'clock. Bishop CHASE, of New-Hampshire, will preach in the same church in the evening.

The forty-fourth annual meeting of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, commenced in the First Presbyterian Church this afternoon, at 4 P.M. In the absence of the President, the Vice-President, Hon. Chief Justice WILLIAMS, took the Chair, and called on Rev. R. H.BISHOP to open the session with prayer.

SIMION GREENLEAF, formerly Professor of the Law School at Cambridge, died suddenly in that city last night, of apoplexy. He was 70 years of age. There was a severe blow here yesterday and last night. U. S. ship Brandywine broke from her moorings, near Cohasset Rocks, and the steamer R. B. Forbes has gone in pursuit of her

The American Board of Missions met again this morning. The Prudential Committee announced that the Sandwich Islands, having been Christianized, could no longer receive aid from the Board. The Foreign Missionaries then took leave of their brethren.

On Saturday, the COTTON market was quiet. MACKEREL are exceeding scarce, and there are few or none arriving. Small sales of FISH from store at $18, $16, and $10 barrel for the three numbers. In FRUIT there is nothing doing, owing to the want of stocks to operate in.

In no branch of the public service, probably, is reform so absolutely indispensable, as in the Navy of the United States. The present is an auspicious moment to inaugurate it, and to secure the increase of its force and efficiency required by our extending commerce, and rapid national growth.

U. S. CIRCUIT COURT. Before Judge Nelson. PRACTICE-JURISDICTION. Seba M. Bogart et al. vs The Steamboat John Jay.--The libel in this case was filed in the Court below to foreclose a mortgage given by the purchaser of the ship to secure the consideration money.

The Mail steamer George Law, Capt. JOHN McGOWAN, arrived at this port on Saturday morning. She left New-Orleans Sept. 30, for New York, via Havana, at which port she arrived early on the morning of the 3d inst., and having embarked the mails and passengers, sailed at noon of the same day for this port.

The following are the redemptions of the various Stocks of the United States during the week ending Saturday. Stocks redeemable in 1862, $42,000; in 1853, $23,500; in 1856, $23,700; in 1867, $298,850; in 1868, $118,000. Total for the week, $506,050; over $200,000 of this amount was received from Europe; nearly as much was received from abroad, the week previous.

MEETING OF THE "UNIVERSAL DEMOCRATIC ASSOCIATION."--A' meeting, called for the purpose of forming a General Democratic Association of all Nations among their representatives in America, assembled in the Shakspeare Hotel on Saturday last, at 8 P. M. A large number of French, German, Italian and Spanish gentlemen were present, and the best feeling prevailed. Dr. MARTINACHE was called to the Chair, and Mr. QUESNE appointed Recording Secretary.

On Saturday morning, Oct. 8, WILLIAM P. CHAPMAN, Currier, aged 38 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral this (Monday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock from the residence of his mother, Amy Chapman, No. 104 South 8th-st., Williamsburg. On Sunday evening, Oct. 9. ELIZABETH, relict of Benjamin Lockwood, deceased, aged 69 years.

The escape of JOHN MITCHELL and JOHN MARTIN, associates in exile with THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER, is a certainty. We have perused letters from Australia, to their particular friends in this City, which speak of the manner of their escape, but from fear that their safe arrival in this country would be jeopardized by a publication of particulars, we have been requested to refrain from giving them publicity for the present.

News from California in twenty-two days is quick enough until the route is shortened. The news that has reached us so summarily by way of the Nicaragua line, is not of very great importance; but it must be of interest, whether important or not, since it mirrors the history of a large country for a fortnight.

ACCIDENT ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD.--At 9 1/4 o'clock, on Saturday evening, a collision occurred on the Hudson River Railroad near Tivoli, between the 7 o'clock Express-train from Albany and a cattle-train. The Express-train left Albany at 7:15 P. M., but waited at Coxsuckle for twenty-five minutes, to meet the 4 o'clock Express-train from this City, and so was thrown behind time.

By the American bark Joseph Maxwell, dispatch from Rio de Janeiro, Aug. 25, with 2,116 bags coffee, and other merchandise consigned to COLEMAN, GARDNER Co., we have files of the Rio papers with a few days later details of news. Dispatch 25th, American bark Cora, for Baltimore, consignees, F. LEBRETON Co., with 3,469 bags coffee and merchandise.

President COMPTON in the Chair. Petitions were received from Wm. H. Delano and others, to be organized as a Hose Company in the Eighth Ward. Of Joseph H. Godwin and others for a sewer in Elizabeth-street. A communication was received from Mr. Isaac, Edwards, Collector of Assessments, nominating Julius Johnson as Deputy Collector, in place of Robert McGary. Nomination confirmed.

Our dates from China are no later than thee previously received. The news, however, is more vetuminous, and will be found interesting. In the China Mail of July 21, we find a correspondence between TAOUTAE and II. B. M.'s Consul, about trafficking with the rebels at Nanking, and furnishing them with the munitions of war.

NIBLO's GARDEN.--MOZART's inimitable " Don Giovanni" will be produced this evening. The caste is unusually strong, and includes the names of STEFFANONE, BERTUCCA, PATTI STRAKOSCH, Signors BENEVENTANO, ROVERE, VIETTI, GASPA RONI, and ROSI. We learn with considerable satisfaction that Signora STEFFANONE has completely recovered from her recent severe indisposition, and will most positively appear this evening in the character of Donna Anna.

PARADE OF THE FIRST BRIGADE.--The First brigade of the N. Y. State Militia. coruposed of the 13th, Col. ABEL SMITH, 14th. Col. JAMES C. SMITH, 70th, Col. P. S. CROOKE, and 73d Regiments, parable to-day, and proceed to East New York for drill, The Brigade will be reviewed by General WARD.

The ceremony of laying the corner-stone of a Jewish Educational Institute, in Greene-street, adjoining the Synagogue Buai Jesharun, took place on Friday. The Institute is intended as the beginning of a Hebrew College to be hereafter erected in this City. The religious services on the laying of the Corner-Stone were conducted by Rabbi RAPHALL.

The Convention assembled yesterday, quietly, with scarcely any traces of the storm of the day previous. The harmony of the assembly was soon again threatened by the introduction of a letter from Rev. T. W. HIGGINSON, of Rochester, asking the Convention to take up a collection for the purpose of raising a fund to print cheap tract on Woman's Rights. Mrs. BARKER and ABBY KELLY objected, denouncing the reverend gentleman as a heretic.

Our fast printed report was dated 13th inst., since when a fair amount of business has been done, which would, no doubt, have been of a larger extent, but for the scarcity of vessels. SUGARS--Have continued to be in demand for Cucuruchos, Browns and Yellows, with advance is price of 1/4 rl. for parcels less damp than those which are now-days offered for sale.

Secretary GUTHRIE is by no means disposed to permit the Administration to be warred upon by its own officials in this City. His letter to Collector BRONSON, which we published on Saturday, shows that the Hunker movement in this State will encounter the whole power of the National Administration, and that Collector BRONSON will probably be removed from office.

FOURTH DAY. The Convention reassembled at 9 o'clock on Saturday morning, in St. John's Chapel. Rev. Dr. HOWE, of Pa., Secretary of the House, read Morning Prayer. The Lessons were read by Rev. Mr. RANDALL, of Mass. During divine service there was a thin attendance; but soon after, several of the delegates arrived.

PHEENOLOGY.--To-moroow evening, (Tuesday,) at 7 1/2 o'clock, Mr. FOWLER will lecture in the Mechanics' Institute, corner of Bowery and Division-street, on the location, adaptation, excess, deficiency and right direction of Amativeness, Philoprogeathveness, Combativeness, Destructiveness, Vitativeness, Aliemntiveness, Acquisitiveness, Secretiveness, Cautionsness, Constructiveness, Ideality, Sublimity, Approbativeness, Self-Esteem and Firm-areas, with remarks on punishments, truthfulness, deception, and the Mental Philosophy of Phrenology.

The Women's Convention reassembled this morning, when Rev. ANTOINETTE BROWN replied to Mr. BARKER's speech of yesterday. She objected to the term of Mr. BARKER's remarks, because they gave ground for newspaper denunciation of the Convention, as an infidel movement. If she thought the Bible taught women's subjection, she would not believe it. But the Bible taught no such doctrine She then denounced Mr. BARKER, and all who followed his course, as heretics.

The Board of Missions of the Protestant Episco. pal Church held an adjourned fleeting in the Church of the-Atcension, corner of Tenth-street and Fifth-avenue. to hear addresses from Bishops and Ministers of the Church, and the Chinese convert, TONG, which time did not permit on the last evening. The Church was, if possible, more crowded than on the previous occasion.
There is considerable political excitement hero this evening. The Democrats are holding a large meeting in Independence,square.

ALDERMRN'S DOINGS--The Aldermen, becoming indignant at the bold stand of the Corporation Counsel in reference to the JONES' Wood Park case, last night adopted a resolution empowering the Mayor and Comptroller to employ other counsel to effect a stay of proceedings until application can be made to the next Legislature for the repeal of the Act.

A meeting of Cubans was held on Saturday evening, for the purpose of adopting measures for a testimonial of respect to' Hon. D.M Barringer, late American Minister to Spain. The proceedings were entirely in Spanish. Don Ygnacio Beles Parez presided; Senior Valiente acting as Secretary; Messrs. Betancourt, Sanchez, and John S. Thrasher were appointed a Committee to draft appropriate resolutions and reported the following, which were adopted:

The 9 o'clock train from New-York, on Saturday, ran off the track this sile of the Raritan River, doing some damage to the track and injuring the engineer and fireman slightly. A car-load of workmen was dispatched from Jersey City immediately after the accident, to assist the disabled train.

The following circular will be officially announced to-morrow: GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS, NO. 12.-To Collectors and other Officers of the Customs, concerning Allowancefor Discounts underAct 20th April, 1818, and 1st March, 1823.

DEDICATION OF ANTIOCH COLLEGE--The services for the dedication of Antioch College were I held on the 5th inst., at the College Buildings, Yel- o low Springs, Ohio. Some elegantly bound bibles, donated by churches and individuals to the College, were presented by Elder JOHN PHILLIPS, and received by Hon. HORACE MANN,

In our report published in the TIMES of Sat??rday, of the proceedings at Tarrytown on celebrating the completion of a Monument erected to commemorate the arrest of Major ANDRE, we were compelled by lack of space to omit many interesting details which we had intended to publish in connection with it.

Rev. J. P. THOMPSON resumed his Lectures upon " Egypt and its Wonders," at the Brodway Tabernacle, Friday night. The proper time to choose for a visit up the Nile, was from from the 1st December to 1st March.

The steamship Illinois, Lieut. H. J. HARTSTRINE, U. S. N., commanding, left Aspinwall at 11 1/2 o'clock on the evening of the 1st inst., and arrived at Quarrantine at 91/2 o'clock on the forenoon of the 9th.
The doctors of Cincinnati have brought their bickerings, and disgraceful personal assaults, to a stand, if not to a full stop. The bone of contention has been the Commercial Hospital.

The singular turn Which the KOSETA affair design has taken, is subject of not a little discussion. There is no question, anywhere, that KOSZTA is, ere this a free man again, and on his' way to the United States.

One of the most destructive fires that we have ever witnessed in Providence, broke out this morning about 6 o'clock, in ARNOLD'S block, on Main-street, a portion of which only was completed, and, together with a large and valuable stock of T. WIIITAKER SONS, Crockery-ware dealers, are totally destroyed.
" DON Giovanni," as usual, attracted a crowded audience last evening. The performance was an exceedingly effective one; more equal and satisfactory than on any previous representation.

In another part of this morning's TIMES will be found a full report of the speech of His Excellency Governor SEYMOUR, at Tarrytown, on Friday of last week. As none but the most meagre and incorrect sketches of it have hitherto been published, and as it seemed to us a production of marked value and interest, we have submitted our report to the Governor's revision.

The Twenty-sixth Annual Fair of the American Institute commenced yesterday at Castle Garden. Since Mons JULLIEN'S vacation of the building, the managers have been actively employed in distributing the space into appropriate sections.
New-Orleans papers of Tuesday last are received. They continue the lawful accounts of the ravages of the yellow fever in the interior of the State. Washington had been almost depopulated.

Alderman TWEED in the Chair. Petitions were received from N. P. Brady, remonstrating against granting bulkhead at foot of Desbrosses street to the New-Jersey Railroad Company for ferry purposes, petitioner claiming right to the northern half of said pier. Referred to Committee on Ferries.

We have received by the Illinois full files of Kingston papers to Sept. 28. There is very little news in them worth publishing. A General Ordination of priests and deacons was held on Sunday, the 25th Sept, at the Cathedral Church, Spanish-Town.

EXCITING SCENES AND HEAVY BETS MADE. The Adamantine County Convention met in the City Hall this P. M -the delegation being nearly full. SANDFORD C. PARKER was nominated for Senator; JAMES L. BAAG for District Attorney; SAMUEL MARSH, of Pompey, for Superintendent of the Poor.

On Monday morning, Oct. 10, HANNAH, relief of the late John G. Clinch, in the 82? year of here age. The friends of the family and of her sons, Joseph W. and Frederick Clinch, are invited to attend the funeral, this (Tuesday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, at the residence of her son, Joseph W. Clinch, No. 91 ?-st. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

Before Hon. Judges Edmonds, Edwards, Mitchell, Roosevelt and Morris. Cornelius B. De Baun and Samuel E. Thistle vs. The Mayor Aldermen and Commonalty of the City of New-York, Horace P. Russ, George W. Reid, and Bartholomew Purdy, Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies.

A large and interesting collection of ornamental window, glass is exhibited by Messrs. CoopER and BELCHER, Camptown, New-Jersey. It is entirely of American manufacture, and consists of eight windows of Grecian, Gothic and Elizabethan hear designs, combined with elaborate engine and fancy work.

The Star of this evening says there is fear of an armed collision between the Creek Indians and the United States Marshal of the Western District of Arkansas, in consequence of his having arrested Indians for introducing spirituous liquors into the Indian country, and who had been punished under the Indian law for the offence in the same cases.

Stamford was crowded on Thursday with strangers to see the ladies' riding-match. There were six competitors for the premium. Stamford is not in California, where bull-fights along the Mexican borders are tolerated. It is not in Texas, where the boys are said to gouge each other's eyes by way of warming themselves for more serious labors, or more exciting sports.

BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--At an adjourned meeting of the Board of Supervisors on Saturday, the following resolution was offered by Mr. Bergen, and adopted: Resolved, That the County Treasurer place to the credit of the Superintendents of the Poor $8,000, for the support of the poor, out of the taxes paid for the present year, to be paid when such taxes shall be collected.

The National Intelligencer is quite shocked at the possibility of the Turkish Sultan's regarding with any degree of favor, the overtures which KOSSUTH is said to have made for a return to the East.

We have received from our special Washington Correspondent a well drawn, an able and interesting opinion, given by AttorneyGeneral CUSHING recently in the extradition case of WM. CALDER, who, it will be remembered, was arrested some time since on the charge of forgery, committed in Great Britain, and whose extradition as a fugitive from British justice was asked by the Agent of that Government.

THE BIRD-TRACK SPECIIIENS OF DIXTER MARSH.--The late DEXTER MARSH'S Museum at Greenfield, Mass., to which we sometime since alluded, hopefully entreating the graduates of Amherst College to purchase for their Alma Mater, in order to make her still more worthy than she had been to be remembered as the great depository of the specimens of animal foot-prints in the red sandstone, has been sold, and the pieces brought more than they were appraised at.

How necessary is companionship to all living creatures. There is the horse, who has been neighing and whinnying all day in the absence of his companion, who shares with him all his labors; stands by him in the stable; eats from the same crib, and gambols with him in the field.

A very large Convention is being held in this town to-day, to further the project of aid from the State to build the Hoosac Tunnel, General WOOL arrived this morning and was received by the military. There are about 1,000 delegates present, and the scheme bids fair to be an element in the coming State election. Col.WHITE, of Lowell, is President of the Convention.

From the National Intelligencer. Our Paris correspondent states that M. KOSSUTH, from his retreat in England, has been making overtures to the Porte with a view to his return to the Turkish dominions during the present conjuncture. These overtures are said to have been coldly met by the Sultan.
The hurly-burly of political excitement is just now at its height in Massachusetts. The papers teem with political intelligence, and party strife, to the exclusion of other matters of interest.

MAJOR J. V. L. -OVERBAGH.-On Friday, Major J. V. L. OVERBAGH died at Saugerties, of an apoplectic fit. He had enjoyed uninterrupted health up to Thursday evening, when he attended a Lodge of Odd Fellows, and returned home apparently cheerful.

The afternoon session commenced by singing a hymn. Several committees were then appointed. Rev. Mr. TREAT read a report on " The Preservation of the American Indians." The point to substantiate is, that a portion of the Indians can be preserved.

CONDITIONS OF THE POOR.--The Tenth Annual Meeting of this Associations, was held on Monday, at the Brooklyn Institute, JOHN H. BROWER, Esq., in the Chair. The audience in attendance , though small, was composed of our most respectable citizens.

The Democratic Mass Meeting in Fancuit Hall, this evening, was fully attended, and the proceedings throughout were harmonious and spirited. Alderman FROST presided, Ex-Governor BOUTWELL was the principal speaker, and his remarks were chiefly upon the subject of the adoption of the proposed new Constitution, which he advocated with much force.

On Tuesday morning, Oct. 11, after a short illness, aged 29 years and 6 months, WILLIAM P., son of the late Wm. Elder. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 90 Elm-st., on Wednesday, at 3 o'clock P. M. On Tuesday, Oct. 11, MARTHA; daughter of John and Martha Phillips, aged 1 year, 11 months and 23 days.

FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--Peter Hendrickson, keeper of a livery-stable on Fulton-avenue, was instantly killed on the Long Island Railroad, about 6 o'clock last evening, near Baker's-corner, on Atlantic-street. He was riding a wagon on the track when the evening train was going out; the locomotive struck the wagon, and knocked him out upon the track, when the cars passed over him, crushing him in the most horrible manner.

From the Paris Charivari. There is now assembled at Smyrna a squadron of six Austrian vessels, which are making preparation to avenge the insult offered to the Imperial flag by the U. S. Marine, in the late KOSZTA affair. In the Adriatic, Austria is fitting up considerable naval armaments.

The man who left this City about one year ago, after having had the temerity to insmuate that the country was ruined out and out, would have been back again last evening had he not, by an unforseen event, lost his hat while endeavoring to reach the express train hound hitherward.

The school-teachers are in mutiny,-or rather they will be if the Board of Education pass a very obnoxious resolution which lies on its table to-day. Tomorrow they will turn over the TIMES with great interest to discover what action has been taken in the matter, for it really is a thing of consequence to them.

DEATH OF MRS. WEBSTER.--Mrs. CATHARINE WEBSTER, widow of the late Professor JOHN W: WEBSTER, of Harvard University, and halfsister to W. H. PRESCOTT, the historian, died, at her residence in Cambridge, on Monday. She had been sick but 36 hours, though her health has never been good since the fearful event which made her a Widow.
The primary meetings of the Whigs were held yesterday morning, and those of the Democratic Softs last evening. We have received from our reporters interminable lists of the successful parties:

NIBLO'S SALOON.--Madame SONTAG'S Concert last evening was attended by a brilliant audience. The Saloon was entirely crowded. The performances were of the most satisfactory character. Mad. SONTAG was in excellent voice; the cavatina from " Linda," 0 Luce di Questa, was given with greater delicacy and brilliancy than on the performance of the opera.

Before Judge Nelson. LIABILITY OF SHIP FOR SUPPLIES ORDERED BUT NOT ACCEPTED. Chandler L. Ingersoll, appellee, vs. The Bark Cabarga.--This libel was filed in the Court below, to recover the value of two of the ship's boats, made by the libellant, at his ship-yard in this port, upon the order of the master.

McCLINTOCK, Dem, is probably elected to the State Senate. The Whigs are much disheartened. It is doubtful if they have elected their Representatives. ALLEGHANY COUNTY.--FORSYTH runs ahead of the Democratic State ticket, and BRAWLEY behind. There has been much scratching. The Senate and Assembly are both doubtful.

BARNARAS BATES, formerly Assistant-Post master of New-York, and the advocate of cheap postage, died here this morning. The forgeries alluded to yesterday are said to be to the extent of $50,000 against J. W. MASON. doing business in Commercial-street.

We publish this morning a correspondence from Melbourne which is well worthy the reader's attention. Affairs in Australia seem to be ripening to the condition which THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER foretold in his first lecture delivered here after his escape.

DEMOCRATIC SENATIONAL NOMINATIONS.--The Hard-Shell Convention of the Third Senatorial District last evening nominated Alderman THOS. J. BARR. of the Sixth Ward, for State Senator. Alderman BARR received 16 votes, against 5 for Alderman MOORE, of the \First Ward, and 7 for R. D. LIVINGSTON, late Member of Assembly from the Fifth Ward.

AMERICAN RELIGIOUS BOOKS IN GREAT BRITAIN.--The English correspondent of the Christian Observer says the eminent Glasgow firm, of which WILLIAM COLLINS, a member of Free Church, lately deceased, was long the head, has reprinted some of the most valuable books I ever read.

The Allgemeine Zeitung, well known as the best informed paper of Germany, and regarded as a mirror of Austrian opinions under the present regime, in referring to the position of the French and English Ambassadors at Constantinople, concludes, from several symptoms, that the late complete union and good understanding no longer exists between the two great Western powers.

SIXTH DAY. There was a small attendance of Delegates during Divine Service in St. John's Chapel, yesterday morning. Prayer was read by Rev. Mr. PRATT, of Maina,; Rev. Dr. HALLAM, of Connecticut, read the lessons. At 10 o'clock the House was called to order by the President, Rev. Dr. CREIGHTON.

The Annual Exhibition of the Maryland Institute was opened last evening, in presence of a very large and brilliant audience. Hon. CALEB CUSHING, Attorney General of the United States, delivered the address, which was listened to with great interest and attention. I forward you a full report, revised for the columns of the TIMES by Mr. CUSHING himself.

We have Galveston dates to the 30th, and exchanges from the interior of a corresponding recent date. The Austin State Gazette of the 14th, says that the citizens of the town of Bastrop had voted down the retailing of spiritous liquors by the decisive vote cf 125 to 31.

SHOCKING FRATRICIDE IN SPRINGFIELD.--HORACE and GEORGE SANDS, (colored,) sons of a woman known as "Old Samanth," and living in that part of Springfield called " Hayti," were on a drunken spree Friday night, their mother being with them, when a quarrel began between her and GEORGE, in which she tried to wrest a gun from him.

The American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions closed its semi-annual meeting at Cincinnati on Friday. The proceedings, we gather from our telegraphic dispatches and from the letters of our special correspondent, have been quite as interesting as usual, and the various statements laid before the large concourse in attendance have excited a great deal of attention.

The mail from the States, in charge of Mr. BARR, arrived on the morning of the 13th, making the best time on record. Mr. H. F. MAYER arrived in the mail, from whom we learn, that at the 22d mile point, this side of Fort Kearney, they met Mr. DAVIS and party, consisting of sixteen men, one woman and a boy, returning from Califrornia.

MURDER AND RAPE AT JAMAICA, L I.--On Sunday evening last, a young girl by the name of CATHARINE QUIGLEY was murdered near the village of Jamaica, Queens Co. She was about 45 years of age, and had that afternoon gone to see some friends residing in the town of Flushing. After making her visit she left--a little before dark--for the purpose of returning to Jamaica.

The Whig State Convention for the nomination of a Candidate for Governor met at Temperance Hall, in the City of Trenton, at 12 o'clock M., yesterday. The Convention was called to order by Hon. A. O. ZABRISKIE, Chairman of the State Central Committee; and on his motion JOHN RUNK, Esq., of ??, was chosen temporary Chairman; and after appointing the usual Committees, to select permanent officers and report resolutions, rules, etc., adjourned till 2 o'clock.

The Fair is rapidly approaching completion. There is no lack of contributions, and in a day or two more there will be but little space unoccupied. It will remain a matter for the judges to determine whether the articles exhibited are equal to those of last year.

Before Chief Justice Nelson. St. John, Hurr Taylor vs John H. Prentiss, Jas. H. Prentiss, Wm. H. Ames, Henry Moulton, and Lonsing E. Hopkins.--This was a motion for Injunction to restrain the defendants from any further infringement of letters patent, granted to H. A. Wells, for making hat bodies, and assigned to the complainants.

The majority for GILPIN. Whig, for Mayor of this city, is 3,106. Three Consolidation candidates, WM. C. PATTERSON, Democrat, GEORGE H. HART, Whig, and M. W. BALDWIN, Whig, (not on the Consolidation ticket,) are elected to the Assembly. ELI K. PRICE, Consolidation, is elected to the Senate by nearly 1,000 majority.

REINTRRMBNT OF GINERAL BROCK.- We learn from the Canada papers that the ceremony of the reinterment of the remains of General BROCK, and the laying of the foundation stone for the new monument at Queenston, will take place on the 13th of October, the anniversary of his death.

We receive from a correspondent in Switzerland the following interesting communication: The first European countries that adapted the system of Penitentiaries, as it is practiced in the United States. obliging continual silence as a punishment for hard labor, were the Swiss Protestant Cantons.

PUTNAM'S ILLUSTRATED RECORD.--The Illustrated Record of the Great Exhibition, now in course of publication by G. P. PUTNAM Co., and edited by Prof. B. SILLIMAN. Jr., and others, comprises a very complete and interesting summary of the articles on exhibition at the Crystal Palace.

HEROIC CONDUCT.--JAMES MCGARTY, the man in charge of the blasting near the tunnel of the Short Line Railroad, in Ohio, performed a heroic deed, a few days since, in saving from a dreadful death a lady and little boy who were seen approaching the blasts at the moment an explosion was expected.

A Mass Ratification Meeting of the Whigs was held in Faneuil Hall this evening. Hon. ABBOT LAWRENCE presided. E. H. DERBY, of Boston, made a speech in opposition to the new Constitution. Hon EDWARD EVERETT spoke for two hours, principally in opposition to the new State Constitution.

A terrible explosion took place this morning at the Navy-Yard, of the boiler on the sectional dock, while hauling on the sloop-of-war Cyane. Pieces of the boiler were scattered in all directions, the safety Valve falling upon the deck of the steamer Fulton, a distance of 300 feet.

Whence come all the people who crowd the places of amusement; and are there are any left at hone ? Does Betty rock the cradle without any to keep her company through the long evening ? Are the parlors vacated-are the sitting-rooms deserted, the nursery-toys cast idly on the floor, and even the kitchen empty? Last evening, circumstances made us peripatetic.

In the DAILY TIMEs of the 6th we gave the firt prt of a Report of the Maritime Conference recently held at Brussels, by invitation of the Government of the United States, between Lieutenant MAURY and representatives from nearly all the Governments of Europe. We complete the Report to-day, by giving a summary of the discussions, and of the conclusions reached.

I have seen no account in the Eastern papers of one of the most remarkable public works in our country-the Great Tunnel under the Walnut Hills, Cincinnati. So little is known of tunneling on a large scale in this country, that I think an accurate description of this work, in its present state, will be. at least a novelty to your readers.

The Washington Union brought by this morning's mail announces that JOHN Y. MASON, of Virginia,is appointed Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States at the Court of France. The long hesitation of the President as to the bestowal of this office, is at length brought to an end, and his final decision, as is often the case when a decision is procrastinated through irresolution, is an unfortunate one.

On Tuesday it was announced that a trotting match, for a purse of $75, would come off on the Union Coutre, between the following well-known horses that had previously been entered, S. McLAUGHLIN named blue g. Blue Bird; J. NELSON named g. g. Dennis McCabe; J. BRIDGES named b. m. Lady of the Lake; H. WOODRUFF named br. m. Lady Collins; J. WHELPLEY named b. m. Lady Relief.

The excitement was intense during yesterday and last night, in all parts of the City, respecting the great prize fight for a wager of $2,000, between JAMES, or " Yankee " SULLIVAN and JOHN MORRISEY, that was known by certain sporting. gents, to have taken place in the interior of Putnam Co, N. Y., bordering on the States of Massachusetts and Vermont.

A SHIP LARGER THAN THE LARGEST.--The Newburyport Herald, referring to the launch of the Great Republic, says: "Mr MCKAY, we hear, will immediately commence the construction of a ship larger than this, which he is to build by contract.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.-This is a red letter day in the calendar of New-York theatricals. The dramatic version of Mr. DICKENs'8 " Bleak House" is to he produced. The programme will be found in another column.

The Union, of this morning, publishes a letter from Captain GIBSON, regretting the course of some New-York papers in denouncing Secretary MARCY for the inquiries he had made as to his (Captain G.'s) character for truthfulness, being conscious that the Secretary should make all the inquiries necessary to refute the accusations made against him.

The following, from the New-Orleans Bee of October 6, will be read with interest: We are indebted to a friend for the following interesting details contained in a letter addressed to him from the city of Mexico. The Government has discovered an extensive plot in the city of Puebla.

The Habeas Corpus case of Deputy Marshals JENKINs and CROSSIER, arrested last week on a charge of assault and battery on BILL THOMAS, a fugtive slave arrested by them at Wilkesbarre, was called up in the Circuit Court to-day.

ACCIDENT ON THE PECK SLIP FERRY--PROBABLE Loss OF LIFE.--Last evening, as the 6 o'clock Peckslip Ferry-boat Onalaska, from New-York, was entering her slip on the Williamsburg side, she came in contact with the bulk-head of the lower pier with such force as to precipitate several persons who were standing on the extreme end of the bow into the water.

SEVENTH DAY. Divine service was held in St. John's Chapel, at 9 o'clock. Morning Prayer was read by Rev. Dr. VINTON, of New-York; the Lessons for the day by his brother, Rev. Dr. VINTON, of Massachusetts. The House was called to order at 10 o'clock A. M.--the President, Rev. Dr. CREIGHTON, in the chair.

Neither General MORRIS of the Home Journal, nor Dr. BRNJAMIN BRANDRETH of the pills, got the Senatorial nomination from the Seventh District Softs in their late Convention, though at one time the former got up to eight totes, and the latter to ten.

MONUMENT TO COUNT PULASKI.--The cornerstone of a monument to Brigadier Count PULASKI, one of the officers of the Revolutionary Army, was laid yesterday, in Monterey-square, Savannah. The Volunteer Battalion of Savannah paraded in honor of the occasion, and an address was delivered by HENRY WILLIAMS, Esq.

At. Freehold , N. J., by Rev. B. D. Palmer, SAMUEL G. VAN NORDEN, of New-York City, to Miss ELIZABETH GIBERSON, of Williamsburg. At St. Paul's Church, Albany, on Tuesday evening, Oct. 11, by Rev. Dr. Kip. CUYLER VAN VECHTEN, to HANNAH R. HAMMOND, all of Albany.

Dr. TYNG delivered his second lecture on the "Progress of the Reformation in Ireland," to a large audience last evening Having detailed in the preceding lecture his experience of the Mission Movements in Dublin, he now proceeded to recount some of his observations in the western part of the Island, where Missionaries made the first effort in the cause of Protestant Reformation.

We don't like to appear intrusive, or to meddle needlessly with what is really none of our business. But we can't help hinting, in the gentlest manner and with the kindest intentions in the world, to our neighbor, the Herald, that since it abandoned its old position of political independence

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A residence of two years in Europe, where I have been, I think, no lazy looker-on, is recently terminated by a giad return to my own blest country. I loved it and republicanism before, enough, I thought; but I love it and its free Government now far more.
The Washington Star states that the editor of the Herald made application for the appointment as American Minister at Paris. We heard this story some weeks since, but doubted its truth.

The President has appointed JAMES H.W.LLIAMS, Of Maine, Consul to Sidney, Australia, and JAMES H YOUNG, of New-York, Commercial Agent at Curacoa. The Star of this evening intimates that JAMES GORDON BENNETT was an unsuccessful applicant for the French Mission.

A morning paper gives currency to an intimation that there is something wrong in the accounts of SIMEON DRAPER, Esq., with the Government. The following letter from the Treasury Department shows how utterly groundless are all such representations:...

WALLACK's THEATRE.--A dramatic version 0 Mr. DICKENS' "Bleak House" was produced at this establishment last evening. Since the announcement that Mr. WALLACK had this work in hand, there has been considerable excitement among theatre-going folks.

The Legislature met here to-day, at 10 A. M. There were two hundred and ten members present; and soon after they came together, they proceeded to ballot for Speaker. They had four balloting without success, as follows:

Before Hon. John W. Edmonds. In re William F. Walker vs. Jonathan M. Wainwright, Bishop, , , case came up before the Court on Saturday, on motion by the plaintiff's coun sel for the defendant to show cause why an injunction previously granted to restrain him from prosecuting a certain sentence pronounced on Rev. Mr. Walker, by pronouncing judgment of displacement from the ministry of the Church, , should not be made absolute.

The election in the City and County o Philadelphia is not yet known. The election of Police Marshal will be contested. I give your nu merous readers the following items: At 1 1/2 o'clock this morning, fire was discovered in the stable of Mr. NELSON, situated in the rear o his hotel and liquor store, at the corner of Broad and Callowell streets, Spring Garden.

The Fourth Annual State Fair of Ohio has just terminated at Dayton. The grounds consisted of thirty-six acres within the Corporation, and not more than five squares from the Court-House.

A correspondent, who knows the facts, writes to assure us that our account of the accident on the Hudson River Railroad, a day or two since, was exaggerated. He says that "the boiler did not burst, but a coupling rod broke, and the broken road forced a small hole into the boiler, through which the steam escaped, and burned the hands of the engineer. The engine was not an old one,

The three parties held caucuses fast evening, and nominated their candidates for Speaker of the House. The Whigs nominated G. W. GRUNDY, of Virgennes; the Democrats nominated W. H. H. BINGHAM; and the "Free" Democrats nominated HORATIO NEEDHAM, of Bristol.

For Particulars see our Advertising Columns. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Italian Opera.--I Puritani. METROPOLITAN HALL.--Jullien's Grand Concerts. ATHENEUM, Brooklyn.--Mad. Henriette Sontag's Grand Concert. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Shandy McGuire--Law for Ladies--Brian O'Linn.

EIGHTH DAY. The Convention reassembled at 10 A. M. yesterday. Morning prayer was read by Rev. Mr. CLAPP, of Vt.; the lessons by Rev. Mr. FORD, of Ga. Rev. Dr. CREIGHTON (President) called the House to order, when the Secretary (Rev. Dr. HOWE) read the minutes of previous day, which were approved.

The Seventh, Eighth and Ninth Regiments, of which the Third Brigade of the New-York State Militia is composed, spent the greater portion of yesterday. in getting through the annual Brigade Drill, on the forty acres of the grounds of East New-York allowed to be used by them for that purpose. At 8 o'clock, A. M.,

New-Orleans papers of Friday last are received. The Yellow Fever was still prevailing in various towns of Mississippi and Lousiana. Natchez is now free from the epidemic, and trade is reviving there. The fever had disappeared from Thibdeaux, but at Yazeo City it was still raging severely.

Among the unpleasant occurrences which we are at times called on to notice, none has given us greater pain, or called forth a more intense feeling of indignation from the general public, than the recent brutal exhibition at Boston Four Corners.

Three thousand bushels of corn have recently been sent from Guadaloupe River, Texas, to Pensacola, Florida, where it has been engaged at remunerating prices ....The citizens of Tarrant County are turning their attention to the cultivation of wheat.

Dr. BURQ, in the Stecle, theorizes on the virtues of copper as a preventive of cholera. He has shown that of 200,000 workmen engaged in copper mines, and in the various manufactories of copper, from the works in which it is rolled into sheets to the shops of coppersmiths, nearly all escaped, and in most cases all escaped from attacks of cholera, although the disease was laging in their immediate neighborhood with fatal violence.

Next to the berth of British Ambassador at Paris, I suppose that the post of correspondent to the London Times is most to he desired. Let me rehearse a few of the immunities and privileges of that individual. His salary is $5,000 a yoar. He has a handsome suite of rooms furnished and paid for by the paper.

Notwithstanding the meridian warmth of the recent fine weather, we have had some chilly evenings. Several of them have been cold enough for a fire, and we lately ordered one to be lighted. It was the first fire of the season. There was little incongruity, want of harmony in the association, and so forta.

On Thursday, Oct. 13, JOHN D. MONTROSS. The friends and acquaitances are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 71 Saffolk-st., on Saturday morning at 8 o'clock. On the morning of Oct 10, in this City, ANNA JOSEPHINE KENNEDY, in her 24th year. She was a nature of the County Sligo, Ireland.

We made a notice yesterday of the reception of Gov. SEYMOUR at the Rooms of the Young Men's Democratic Club, recently opened at No. 765 Broadway. We now give a report of the remarks made by the Governor upon the condition of political parties in this State :--as a good deal of importance will be attached to them throughout the country, we have submitted the report to the Governor's revision:

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : I was passing along Avenue D, about 6 1/2 o'clock on Tuesday evening, when I encountered a fire-company with a throng of boys little and big, on either side, nearly covering the sidewalks.

A meeting of the citizens of Jamaica and its vicinity was held on Wednesday evening, in the Military Hall of that village, to express the horror and indignation of the inhabitants, and to take measures to cooperate with the anthorities in their efforts to apprehend the author of the outrage.

To the Editor of the Union: In consequence of certain statements that appeared in the public press, that were calculated to convey the impression that the prosecution of my case of damu ges against the Dutch Government had been neglected or improperly attended to by my own Government,
The Canada at Halifax brings us news from Europe a week later. There is nothing decisive on the Eastern crisis, but the quarrel is evidently becoming more and more complicated.
The last steamer from California brings, us be melancholy intelligence of the death of one of be most accomplished officers of the Army, Brevet Lieut. Colonel JAMES L. MASON.
Yesterday evening the Committee appointed to select the design for the medal to be presented to Captain INGRAHAM, metal the private residence of H. H. MORANGE, Esq., Twelfth-street, at 8 o'clock.

There was some rare sport at the Union Course yesterday, in the way of trotting matches, between several celebrated horses. The day was fine, and quite a large concourse of persons were present to witness the contests.

It was our good fortune, last night, to drift into the Nintn-street School room, where is kept the Eleventh Ward Evening School. We entered first the Female Department, where we found a fine lot of young ladies, all busily engaged in writing.

J. H. YOUNG has to-day been commissioned as Consul at Curacoa. The Richmond Enquirer is out with a strong article, fully endorsing the policy of the Administration, to the great disappointment and chagrin of the malcontents here, who had counted on the support of that piper.
The Royal Mail steamship Canada, Captain STONE, from Liverpool on Saturday, October 1, about 10 o'clock A. M., arrived at this port at 4 o'clock this morning, bringing 138 through passengers.

Tallman and five others impleaded with Thomas Collyer, indicted for manslaughter, by the destruction of the Steamboat Henry Clay, on the 25th of July 1852.--This indictment as was stated in the TIMES, stands for on Tuesday next, and aumerous witnesses have been summoned for that day. To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : You know the writer as one prepared to appreciate your indignation, sometime since expressed, against the great delays in the transportation and delivery of the mails between this City and Burlington, Vt.

The TIMES of yesterday morning announced the death of TRISTAM BURGESS, of Rhode Island. So long a period has elapsed since his name figured among the actors on the stage of public life, that very few of our readers are probably aware of the prominence it once held and of the degree of public attention his speeches commanded.

All our political fermentations are going on here pretty briskly. Faneuil Hall has just been hearing both sides, and will doubtless decide the matter before Independence Day. The Democratic Ratification meeting took place within its walls, the evening before last, and the Whig meeting last evening. The first was well attended, but not inordinately enthusiastic. The people, I could see,

In Williamsburg, Oct. 6, by Rev. J. R. Stone, S. R. MARTIN, Esq., to Mics HANNAH HUST, all of this City. On Wednesday, Oct. 12, in St. Stephen's Church, by Rev. Richard Cox, A. WALSTEIN KING, to ISABELLA S., only daughter of Nehemiah Lounsbery. At Galesville. Washington Co., New-York, Oct. 12, by Rev. J. F. Mason, JOHN G. WHIPPLE to Miss LAURA A. KETCHAN, both of this City.
THE UNITED STATES IN EUROPE.-The Democratic refugees in London, who have been calculasting upon the chances of war, are said to he employing agents in arousing the populations of the East.

CITY IMPROVEMENTS.-The authorities have directed the following improvements to be made: Willoughby-avenue to be opened from Washington Park to Franklin-avenue; Hunter-street do., from Gates to Fulton- avenue; Clason-avenue do., from Flushing to Kent-avenue;

We have been favored with the following extract of a letter from the most distinguished American statesman now in Europe, to a personal friend in New-Jersey, which cannot fail to be read with interest.

The U. S. Mail steamship Humboldt arrived at this port last evening. She brings the large number of 216 passengers, and 400 tons of merchandise. She had a rough passage for the season, having experienced a successon of strong westerly gales and rough head seas.

NINTH DAY. The Convention reassembled in St. John's Chapel, at 10 A. M., yesterday. Morning prayer was read by Rev. Dr. ATKINSON, of Maryland, (Bishop elect to North Carolina ;) Rev. Dr. WATSON, of New-Jersey, read the lessons.

Important developments relative to a design of the Government of England to Africanize Cuba are leaking out. Some weeks ago information was received here that Lord HOWPEN, British Minister at Madrid, had succeeded in making, in June last, a treaty with Spain, by which English cruisers are permitted to land men to search the plantations of Cuba on which slaves are suspected to have been carried from slavers.

The Third Annual Parade of the New-York Fire Department took place yesterday. The day could not have been finer. Cool enough to be pleasant, and sunny enough to make everything cheerful, there was nothing left to wish for. The display of the Firemen was remarkably good.

A correspondent of the Presb. Herald, writing from North Carolina, announces the following churches as having been strengthened by accessions on profession of their faith, viz: Charlotte church, under the care of Rev. CYRUS JOHNSTON, E. D., forty members; Davidson College Church,

SHE WOULD AND SHE WOULD NOT.-A fewdays since, a Mr. C--- , a gentleman of appearance, and possessed of excellent address, repaired to a fashionable boarding house on Sixth-street, not far from Race, and secured a room. In a few days he became acquainted with a young, beautiful, and wealthy Miss,and soon became attached to her, and proposed marriage.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The Express of last evening warns all "unacclimated" residents of Mississippi, Florida, Louisiana, , not to return to those States until the frost shall have come.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: You will bear me witness that I am not in the habit of troubling you with contradictions of the title-tattle in relation to Police delinquencies, with which the papers daily abound. There is much, too much,

Our Special Telegraphic Correspondence from Washington brings intelligence of important movements of the English Government, in connection with Slavery in the Island of Cuba. It is stated that a treaty has been concluded with Spain, by which England is permitted to prosecute in Cuba a search for slaves that may have been landed.

Although the dates received by the Humboldt are no later than brought by the Canada, the news is more voluminous, and contains much interesting information not previously published. The position of the French and English Governments towards the Sultan is more apparent than before; and in this connection an article from the London Times, which we publish this morning, will be read with interest.

At No 5. Lewis-st., on the 14th inst., after four days sickness, BARBARA, only surviving daughter of John and Barburn Buckie, late of Glasgow, Scotland. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Saturday, 15th inst., at 2 o'clock P. M. At Currytown, on Sunday morning, Oct. 9, JOHN WIERS, in the 74th year of his age.

The steamship Canada reached her dock at East Boston at about 10 1/2 o'clock this evening We do not find any political news besides that telegraphed from Halifax. The Circular of JAMES McHENR, dated Liverpool, 30th, says: Flour has been in active request. and closes at the highest quotations. Wheat is 3d.

Mon LAW AND MURDER IN THE CHEROKEE NATION.-The Van Buren (Ark.) Intelligencer gives an account of the arrest, by a party of Cherokees, of two respectable citizens, ANDY ADAIR and G. W. ADAIR, Jr, on the pretext that they had been concerned in a late murder.

A TERRIBLE AFFRAY AMONG PUGILISTS-Yesterday afternoon, a terrible affray occurred in Broadway, between several noted pugilists, which created a great mob and excitement. It appears a number of the pugilists assembled at the " Gem " Hotel, near the Broadway Theatre, and became quite exasperated respecting the recent brutal fight at Boston Four Corners.

WHIG SENATORIAL CONVENTION-THIRD DIS TRICT.-At a meeting last night, at No. 27 James-street, General HALL, of the Fifth Ward, in the Chair, Mr. RICHARD S. WILLIAMS, of the Board ofTen Governors, was declared nominated for Senator on the third ballot; upon which the while of the First Ward, one from the Third, two from the Fourth, and one from the Fifth, what is technically called " bolted."

According to rumors in circulation, the first effect of the passage of the Dardanelles by the French and English fleets has been the closer alliance of Russia, Austria, and Prussia, and the discontinuance of the Vienna conference.

G. DISBROW, which was entirely consumed Loss, $1,000insured for $500. The fire was, without doubt,

TO THE PUBLIC. It is a common boast that in our free and plentyful land the alternative of want or crime is presented to none, except through their voluntary rejection of the paths of industry and virtue. If this were true, the victims of sloth and appetite, although they could not reproach us with their misery, would be no less the kindred of our common nature, and as such entitled to our pitying aid.

DARTMOUTH COLLEGE.-The Concord (N. H.) Congregational Journal states that sixty-four students have joined the different classes in Dartmouth College the present term. The number in the classes is as follows: Seniors 50, Juniors 60, Sophomores 76, Freshmen 54, Total, 240.

The following removals and appointments by the Canal Board are announced: JOHN CRUMMY, appointed Superintendent of Repairs of Section 1, Erie Canal, in place of SMITH A. WATERMAN, removed. ELISHA B. DOW, appointed Superintendent of Repairs, Section 2, Erie Canal, vice SIMEON SCHERMERHORN, removed.

DISPENSARY REPORT.--The monthly meeting of the Williamsburg Dispensary was held on Thursday, when the following report of the workings of that Institution for the month of September, was submitted by H. P. Hardcastle, the Apothecary. Number of patients treated, 382, as follows: As the Dispensary, 342, and at their homes, 40. Males, 131 ; females, 251.

The Board met yesterday, at 5 P. M., R. T. COMPTON, Esq., in the Chair, and a quorum present. A few petitions of no special importance were received and referred. EIGHTH-AVENUE RAILROAD. Alderman TIEMAN presented a petition from residents of that section of the City lying between Fifty-ninth and Eighty-sixth-streets, to compel the Eighth-avenue Railroad Company to run their cars to Seventy-second-street. Referred to Committee on Streets.

LAYING THE FOUNDATION-STONE OF THE BROCK MONUMENT--On the 13th inst., the foundationstone of the new monument to General BROCK was laid at Queenston by our Canadian neighbors. Among the thousands who were present, were a number of veterans who had fought with the General.

The Message of Gov. WM. B. CAMPBELL, to to the Senate and House of Representatives, was read before them on Saturday last. The Governor expresses great satisfaction in being able, so near the close of his official term, to congratulate them upon the general and unparalleled prosperity of the State, especially in all the material elements of improvement in the condition of the country.

Among the legacies left by the late Administration, under Mr. FILLMORE, to that inaugurated on the 4th of March last, was an unsettled claim of Mr. FRANCIS W. RICE, late Consul at Acapulco, for redress of the insults and injuries sustained by him at the hands of the local authorities at the port.

The returns indicate the defeat of the Temperance party. In the northern portion of the State the Maine law is carried, but the south gave a large majority against it. The decision of the majority is " free trade in intoxicating liquor." The impression is that the Whigs have not elected more than twelve out of all their candidates for the Legislature.

The Public Stocks redeemed last week amounted to five hundred and forty-nine thousand, seven hundred dollars. The President has issued a proclamation admitting Hanseatic City, Bremen, into the Extradition Treaty of June 16, 1852, with Prussia and other States of the Germanic Confederation.

The Softs held their Senatorial Conventions on Saturday night, and succeeded in nominating candidates for Senator in the Third and Sixth Districts. In the Fourth and Fifth Districts, there were no nominations.
The following is the City Inspector's weekly statement of deaths in the City and County of New-York, for the week ending Saturday, Oct. 15: Men, 95; Women, 75; Boys, 129; Girls, 114; Total, 413.

As the steamer Washington was towing two heavily laden scows down the river, about 10 o'clock, this morning, when opposite Dock street the scows suddenly filled, and sunk, carrying down eight out of ten men on board.

THIRD ASSEMBLY DISTRICT.--The Democratic Assembly Convention, for the Third Assembly District, nominated, on Friday, S. D. MORRIS as candidate for Assembly. Dr. JAS. H. HUTCHINGS was tendered the nomination, but declined. Second District--JAMES H. HOWE was nominated by the Democrats of the Second District, for the same office.

On Saturday, Oct. 15, at her residence, at Hempstead, L. I., after a short illness, Mrs. MARTHA WRIGHT, in the 65th year of her age. The friends of the deceased are invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, at 12 o'clock, on Monday, Oct. 17. the remains will be conveyed to Jamaica for interment.
THE FIREMEN'S RIOT AT PROVIDENCE.--The verdict of the Coroner's Jury in the recent case of the murdered fireman, at Providence, develops a most extraordinary state of things in that city.

MURDER CASES.--The jury in the case of WM. BAREER, on trial at Worcester for the murder of his wife, returned a verdict of guilty. The Transcript says that the prisoner heard the announcement of the verdict without any apparent emotion, pettishly remarking aloud, "I know I am not guilty."

NIBLO'S GARDEN.-VERDI'S Opera "I Lombardi" will be produced here this evening. The principal artistes of the establishment will assist at its performance.

The Atlantic brings intelligence of the death of FRANCOIS DOMINIQUE ARRGO, the distinguished French Astronomer, whose contributions to Science have classed him among the highest in the list of European savans.

The terrible affray between two prize-fighters. which occurred in Broadway last Friday, and the statement of which was published exclusively in the TIMES of the following morning, has been brought to the notice of the police authorities.

TENTH DAY. The Convention reassembled at 10 o'clock, A. M., on Saturday, in St. John's Chapel. Morning prayer was read by Rev. Dr. A. B. CROCKER, of Rhode Island.; Rev. THOS. F. SCOTT, of Georgia, read the Lessons. The House was called to order, Rev. Dr. CREIGHTON in the Chair.

Through the kindness of an ardent friend of the liberal cause in Ireland, we are enabled to lay Before our readers, this morning, a few interesting particulars of the escape of the patriot and exile, JOHN MITCHEL, from Australia.

To the American Public: The late JENNY M. LIND, now Madam OTTO GOLDSCHMIDT, resident at Dresden, as a sweet singer, has made herself of pleasant and precious memory to tens of thousands of our countrymen, and to millions in the whole world.

The Cholera in Europe marches rapidly along the same route it held five years ago. It beats the old alarm--it has announced its coming in its old familiar notes. But no where in Europe were they ready for it. Newcastle never was filthier than the day it came.

The U. S. Mail steamship Atlantic, from Liverpool Wednesday, Oct., 5, at 1 o'clock P. M., with 210 passengers, , reached this port yesterday at 12 M. The Asia arrived at Liverpool at 10 o'clock forenoon of Sunday, 2d. On 28th ult., lat. 50??.46, lon. 28??.26 passed the Arabia from New York.

New-Orleans papers of Sunday last are received. They say that old residents may safety return to the city, but strangers should keep away The Natchez Courier records fearful ravages of the fever at various points along tile river and in the interior.

We learn from good authority that GEORGE LAW, Esq., has effected a sale ofa very considerable portion of his muskets to the Turkish Govenment,- -to be used in the war with Russia. They have not yet been sent, but are to be Shipped in course of a few days.
The policy of Mr. PIERCE'S Secretary of State, (who guides the Government) has ended where every-body expected--in the hopeless dismemberment of the Democratic party.
