The Cortland County Whig Convention on Thursday nominated PERRIN H. McGRAW for Assembly, and L. H. DUELL, the present incumbent, for District-Attorney. The Temperance party is also expected to nominate. Senator WILLIAMS, of Tompkins, has been re-nominated.

VISIT OF THE BOSTON MILITARY.--The Boston Veteran Corps will visit Jersey City, New-York, and Newark this week. They will arrive by the morning boat at 7 o'clock on Tuesday, and land at the foot of Cortlandt-street.

The principle of the Sub-Treasury Act is at war with enlightened commerce. Its practical operation, therefore, mast be productive of occasional mischief, as well as continual annoyance to the merchant and public creditor.

Hon. WILLIAM L. MARCY, Secretary of State: SIR: A few days ago the Washington Union and the Boston Post simultaneously published a most unjust and libellous attack upon my private and public character. The authors say that they got their information from the Department of State.

In spite of the Baltimore platform, American intervention in European affairs has become a fixed fact. War is actually raging between a live American (militia) General and the reigning monarch of Printing Housesquare.

The Atlantic, which arrived yesterday at noon, brings important intelligence from Eastern Europe. It is reported that a grand council of the Sultan's advisers had been held at Constantinople; that they had agreed in recommending and in drawing up a declarntion of war against Russia; and that this declaration had been signed by the Sultan.

The Secretary of the Navy has returned, and resumed his duties this morning. It is said that the Cabinet have decided to appoint WILLIAM H. CRAWFORD Postmaster of Jefferson City, Mo., and that BENTON advocated his claims.

We are indebted to a gentleman resident in this City for the following extract from a private letter received per steamer Atlantic, containing additional and interesting particulars concerning the escape of JOHN MITCHEL.

No one who notes the progress made in the various branches of industry, can have failed to remark the constant improvements introduced into the manufacture of dolls. The first striking feature was, I believe, the insertion of visual organs, moved by an ingenious and invisible arrangement of wires.

Yesterday morning the river Delaware was the scene of a dreadful calamity, by which nine men, seven of whom were in the employ of the Camden and Amboy Railroad Company, were drowned, and two others narrowly escaped with their lives.
New-Orleans papers of Tuesday last are received. The steamship United States had arrived at that port, with Harvana dates to the 6th instant. The cholera was making sad ravages at Matanz is.

There was a large, intelligent, and fashionable audience gathered last evening in the lower lecture-room of the Fourteenth street Medical Col. lege to hear Dr. JOHN DRAPER'S introductory to the regular course of lectures which open to-day.

Rev. Dr. KALLEY, late Missionary in Madeira, delivered an interesting discourse in the Presbyterian Church, corner of Grand and Crosby-sts, Sunday evening. on the History of the Reformation in Maderia, the present state of the Island, and the condition of the Portuguese Refugees who have settled in Illinois.

The President has appointed FISHER AMES HILDRETH Postmaster at Lowell, Mass., vice THOMAS P. GOODHUE, deceased: Mrs. AMELIA S. MODERWELL at Columbia, Pa., vice A. P. MODERWELL, her husband, deceased; and WILLIAM H. CRAWFORD Postmaster of Jefferson City, Mo.

WOMEN'S CITY ALLIANCE.--An adjourned meeting was held at Dr. TRALL'S Institute, No. 15 Laight-street, yesterday afternoon. Mrs. MARY C. VAUGHAN presided, and SARAH E. BARLOW acted as Secretary. A large number of ladies were in attendance, who gave in their names as members.

ARREST OF LIQUOR-SELLERS.--On Saturday last warrants were served upon most of the hotel-keepers and liquor-sellers of the First Ward of Jersey City, charging them with selling liquor without a license. It is expected that they will appear before the Recorder this forenoon. It is stated to be the intention of the opponents of the traffic to take the Wards in turn, and complain of the liquor-sellers in them.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--VERDI, the best abused composer of the day, had another trial here last evening. To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The FOUCAULT excitement has had its day and passed on, giving way to other, mostly less scientific, amusements; and who now thinks of the rotation of the earth as he watches the swinging of the pendulum in his ormulu or papier mache?

The union of the two systems of Public Schools-those of the Public School Society, and the Ward Schools-has thrown upon the School officers, and especially upon the Board of Education, a great amount of additional labor and responsibility, and for a year or two to come, the Schools of the City will require the constant labors of experienced men in the Board of Education as well as in the local Boards.

The Collector of this port has replied to the letter from the Secretary of the Treasury which we published some days since, concerning his relations to the Democratic party. In order that the reply may be more clearly understood, we republish the Secretary's letter.

In our issue of Saturday we called attention to the disgraceful breach of the peace which occurred at Boston Four Corners on the preceding Thursday. Our comments, necessarily severe, were in good time.

The Moyamensing Hose Company returned from New-York this afternoon, and met with a most cordial reception on the part of their brother firemen of this city. They express themselves much pleased with the treatment received in New-York.

Elsewhere, this morning, we have enriched our columns with an address of Professor DRA PER of the City University, on the necessity of legalizing the dissection of the dead. The address was well calculated to arrest the attention of the public, and to impress its point upon such legislators as will read it.

Collector BRONSON has replied to Secretary GUTHRIE'S letter, rebuking him for the manner in which he has distributed the patronage of his office, and giving him explicit instructions as to what is expected from him hereafter, in this respect.

It may not be known to many of our readers that there is in this City an organization known as the " ClubMen of '48." Its members are those, and those alone, who were connected with some one of the Clubs formed in Ire' land, by the liberal party, during the agitation of 1848, which was partially deadened by the exile of MEAGHER, MITCHEL, O'BRIEN, and others.
ITHIMAN W. BEARD, of Massachusetts, has to-day been appointed Sub-Treasurer at Boston, vice DAVIS, declined. AMELIA S. INODERVILLE has been appointed Postmistress for Columbia, Pennsylvania.

A meeting of French, Belgian, and Swiss Wine-dealers, called together at the Shakspeare Hotel, on Saturday evening, 15th inst., was not as fully attended as had been expected, probably because JULLIEN'S Concert for the French Beneficial Society, occurring on the same evening, had attracted many of those who would otherwise had obeyed the call. However,

Yesterday afternoon a the trotting match of three mile heats came off at the Union Course, Long Island, for $1,660, between b. g. Pet and p. m. Boston Girl. The former was entered by HIRAM WOODRUFF, and the latter by JOHN NELSON, both of whom are experienced in the horse line. There was a good attendance of the lovers of Turf Sport.

THOMAS ATKINSON, D.D., of North Carlina, and Rev. Mr. DAVIS, D.D., of South Carolina, as Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Rev. J. O'DONNEL, a Catholic priest at Portland, an active Temperance man, and formerly a strong supporter of the Maine law, is out in a letter upon that question, in which he states that drunkenness, misery, and crime among his people have increased rather than diminished by means of this statute.

Mary Mason, a decent looking woman, was placed at the bar, on an indictment charging her with stealing jewelry and wearing apparel, to the value of $35--the property of a Mrs. Roland, of this City. The accused, who sat beside her husband in Court, was defended by Mr. Busteed.

The burning of the steamer Henry Clay, on the Hudson River, about one year ago, will not soon be forgotten, The sensation of horror which pervaded wherever the particulars of that dreadful occurrence were made known, will not soon die away. It finds a lasting chronicle in the many family circles narrowed, and in the many hearts made sorrowful by its sad results.

The newly elected City Council, and the several District Boards of Commissioners, have met, and fully organized for business. Mayor GILPIN was sworn into office this morning. At the Chinese Museum, this morning, the Franklin Institute Exhibition was opened. The display was excellent.

Collector BRONSON'S letter was received at the Treasury Department at 12 o'clock to day. The President and Secretary GUTHRIE perused it carefully. Its effects, however, have not transpired. Lient. DELE's Pacific Railroad surveying party was one hundred days from Westport, Mo., to Los Angelos, California. On Grand River they lost almost all their outfit by the upsetting of a canoe, and lost a month in New-Mexico in refiting.

CHOLERA AT SEA--TERRIBLE MORTALITY.--Captain MUEFORD, of the packet-ship Havre, arrived on Monday at this port, states that he sailed from Havre on Sept. 5, with 377 passengers. He experienced a constant succession of westerly gales, and had but three days' fair weather.

This, the first "National" Exhibition of Horses in the United States, gives, up to the present moment, ample promise of being highly successful. The entries already exceed two hundred, comprising the most celebrated horses in the Union, and some fine thorough-breds from the Canadas.

FIRST DAY. The People of the Unite! States against Thomas Collyer, John F. Tallman, John German, Edward Hubbard, James L. Jessup, James Elmendorf and Charles Merritt. This long pending case has at last come in a palpable shape before the public, and probably in the course of the next fortnight the arguments and evidence will have been concluded, and the verdict rendered by the Jury.

The ship Western Empire, from Liverpool Aug. 24 for New-York, put into Quarantine this morning short of water. She has 650 passengers. Sept. 9, lat 47, lon 31. in a hurricane from S. E. to N. N. E, LOST fore and main topgallant masts, mizzen topmasts, and sails attached.

Rich times the doctors are enjoying just now. It is the season for the opening of the regular medical courses of Lectures in the Colleges, which always elicits through the "introductories " the most readable medical master of the whole year.

FROM THE BAY.--A letter from a Gloucester captain, dated at Cascumpec, P. E. I, Sept. 30. has the following: We are now lying in Cascumpec harbor, after having experienced a heavy gale of wind,--the heaviest that has been known for a number of years. There are twelve vessels ashore here. We have not heard from other places, but expect the damage and destruction must be great.

The cars containing the Eastern Mail, due here this morning, and LIVINGSTON FARGO's Express packages, were destroyed by fire this morning, between Cleveland and Columbus it was ignited by sparks from the locomotive. The mail was entirely lost, but part of the Express packages were saved.

Letters from Santa Fe announce that F. X. AUBREY reached there on the 14th ult. He crossed the Sierra Nevada at Tegon Pass on the 12th of July, and struck the Riodel Norte at Liberatta, and reports the ?? as having to obstructions for either a railroad or for wagons. He found gold at the crossing of the Colorado and other places, also silver and copper are in great abundance.

From the Freeman's Journal At last accounts Commodore PERRY and Squadron had sailed from the Leo-Choo Islands, the southern most group of the Japan Empire. Private letters from one of the officers of his Flag-ship give some interesting particulars not published in the Journals.
The first ballot for Governor, in Joint ballot, of the Vermont Legislature, has just been declared. It stood as follows: FAIRBANKS, Whig, 100; ROBINSON, Democrat, 97, and BRAINARD, Free-Soil, 38.
The following appointments are officially announced: ROBERT M. MCLANE, of Maryland, as Commissioner to China; and LEVI K. BOWEN, of Maryland, to Bordeaux.

DARING ATTEMPT AT HIGHWAY ROBBERY AT BOSTON, AND SINGULAR ARREST OF THE VILLAIN.--Early yesterday morning, as bank watch man ZACCHEUS HOLMES was passing through Green street, he fancied he heard a step behind him.

Leipsic Fair-Telegraphs and Passports. Liepsic Michaelmas Fair, just over, was declared to have been highly productive and advantageous to dealers of all kinds, except to jewelers an gros. Leather and woolen cloths had been carried off at an advance upon Easter prices, and large orders had been given from the United States and Italy.
BOSTON VETERAN ASSOCIATION.--The Veterans visited Newark yesterday, accompanied by a number of ladies and invited guests, and Capt. POLLARD and several members of the Continental Guard.

DEAR COCHRANE: I have your note in allusion to my position as a candidate before the Nominating Convention, in which you apprise me that while it was freely and fully admitted that my ability, integrity and judgment were beyond dispute, and that my judicial reputation was unimpaired, the prejudice against my spiritualism, alone, was noticed as a reason for declining to nominate me.

Prussia's Position in the Eastern Question. A Vienna letter, of 1st inst., in the Kolner Zeitung, states that the Prussian Ambassador in Constantinople has received peremptory instructions to second the representations of the Austrian Internuncio respecting the adoption of the Vienna Note.

At Milwaukie, during Sunday night, five alarms of fire were sounded--three of them false, supposed to be got up to weary the firemen; but the other two arose from conflagrations, the last of which occurred at a warehouse on Higby's pier, which was filled with flour, beef, and merchandise, almost all of which was destroyed.

The medical men and students had a good time again last night. The theatre of the New-York Medical College was crowded with persons who went up to hear, and having heard, went away gratified with Dr. CARNOCHAN'S address on Medicine and its connections, and incidentally, on the true policy of specialties, and the functions of the physician.

The Fair is now in excellent order. Not- withstanding the reasonable apprehensions of the public, the display is more than an average one. Excepting in the galleries, all the space that could be required is occupied.
TEMPERANCE CANDIDATE.--The Temperance people of Williamsburg have resolved to support Mr. JOHN G. BERGEN, the Whig nominee for Assemblyman, from the Third Assembly District.

AMUSEMENTS THIS EVENING, For particulars see our Advertising Columns. METROPOLITAN HALL.--Jullien's Grand Concerts. NIBLO'S SALOON.--Madame Coutag's Concert for the Benefit of the Children of Seamen. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Bleak House-Morning Call.

All day long, under our windows the din and turmoil of the working population of our City is painfully audible. Carts rattle, carpenters hammer, and Irish bricklayers shout. Little boys, with piles of daily papers under their arms, vociferously earn their diurnal half-dollar.

NIBLO'S SALOON.--A grand entertainment comes off to-night at this establishment. It is for the benefit of the Home for the Destitute Children of Seamen. Madames SONTAG, COSTINI, JULIA DE BERG, assisted by Signor BADIALI, ROCCO and PAUL JULLIEN, will give their valuable services.

DEATH OF THE SLAVE JERRY.--A letter from Mr. EDWARD WHEELER, formerly a resident of this city, (says the Syracuse Standard, of the 17th instant,) but at present residing in Kingston, C. W., informs us that JERRY died in Kingston on Saturday, the 10th inst.
The Boston Light Infantry arrived home this evening. They were received by the Light Guard, and both Companies sat down to a sumptuous dinner in Faneuil Hall.

The steamship Black Warrior has arrived at Mobile, with Havana dates to the 16th inst. The yellow fever still preveiled at Mobile; there were five or six deaths daily. The first cargo ever received at this port arrived to-day in the bark Salem, from the Chincha Islands.

No Change Contemplated in the Ministry--Increase in the Rate of Discount--French Fleet Ordered to Constantinople--Decree Relating to Breadstuffs--Funeral of Ara-go-Transatlantic Shipping Companies--Anecdote of the Emperor--The Wine Crop. The Bank of France has varied its rate of discount to 4 per cent.

An alarming fire has been prevailing of late in the woods and swamps, and has now reached within a mile of this city. 10,000 acres of swamp have been completely burnt over, destroying all houses, barns, fences, , in its course.

FROM OUR SPECIAL REPORTER. SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Wednesday, Oct. 19--7 P. M. The opening of the National Horse Exhibition has been attended with unquestionable success. At the hour appointed this morning, there were three hundred horses on the ground, all first-class, and numbering among them some of the finest animals in the United States.

COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS.-TUESDAY. Before His Honor the Recorder. MANSLAUGHTER IN THE FOURTH DEGREE. Wm Mulhollan, alias Billy Bottles, a young man, was placed at the bar on an judictment charging him with causing the death of an infant child belonging to Mary Ann Stevens.

INCENDIARY FIRES--ARREST OF THE SUPPOSED GUILTY PARTY.-Between 12 and 1 o'clock on Tuesday night, the store of HENRY MEYERS, on the corner of Henry and Luqueer-streets, was discovered to be on fire by the Police of the Third District.

Mr. Soule-Ministers to the United States and Mexico. Mr. SOULE arrived at Madrid on the 29th ult. The Government, it was said, had resolved to receive him as the Envoy of a friendly Power, and to await his acts.

WASHINGTON PARK.--At a regular meeting of the Common Council, held Monday evening, the following resolution was adopted by unanimous consent. Resolved, That a new warrant for one hundred and twenty days be issued to the Collector of Taxes, for the collection of unpaid assessments for Washington Park grades.

Judge EDMONDS, in a frank and manly letter, withdraws his name as candidate for reelection, on the ground that his opinions concerning Spiritualism, which ?e cannot change and will not conceal, are obnoxious to a large portion of the public.
The Barnburners, at their County Convention, nominated Dr. F. C. BRUNCK, for Senator, and B. H. AUSTIN, for Attorney General. The Whigs of this city have nominated JAMES C. HARRISON for Mayor.

A BOSTON SLAVE UNWILLING TO BE FREED. --Yesterday, on the representations of sundry persons, that a colored female, a slave, was living with a family from the South at a house at the North End, and was restrained of her liberty.

AMERICAN INSTITUTE ANNIVERSARY ADDRESS. Hon. WM. H. SEWARD will deliver the Anniversary Address before the American Institute, at the Broadway Tabernacle, this evening, at 71/2 o'clock.
The cotton mill here has suspended operations, in consequence of the hands striking against working eleven hours per day. The operatives have been parading with bands of music.

We have received files of Sidney and other papers, which, however, are not to as late a date as previous advices. Nevertheless, the following is not without interest to those acquainted with the object of Mr. P. J. SMITH'S visit to Australia.

It is understood that a Cabinet Council will assemble to-day, for the purpose of taking into consideration the critical point to which, after long and indecisive negotiations, the Turkish question has at length been brought.

At Darien, Conn., Oct. 5, SARAH ANTONETT, aged 4 years, 5 months and 24 days. Also, on the 15th, ROBERT BRUCK, aged 1 year, 8 months and 2 days, children of Henry B. and Hester Wallace. On Monday, Oct. 18, at the residence of R. D. Cantillen, Ny?ck, Rockland County, Miss JANE ALLEN LEE.

The St. John New-Brunswicker, of the 18th, has a report that a federal union of the British North American Colonies is contemplated, and that measures for completing the union will be submitted to the several colonies at no very distant day.

Another commercial enterprise of much promise has just been organized here under Government approbation-a joint stock company for the purpose of opening periodical steam communication with the ports of the East.

The People of the United States against Thomas Collyer, John F. Tallman, John Germain, Edward Hubbard, James L. Jessup, James Elmendorf and Charles Merritt. The Court assembled yesterday morning at 11 A. M.

We deem it a matter of congratulations that the highly important and arduous mission to China has, since the much regretted inability of Hon. ROBERT J. WALKER to undertake its duties, been confided to Hon. ROBT. M. McLANE, of Maryland.

I learn to-night that an important order, to carry into effect the British scheme for the Cuban apprenticeship system and emancipation, has been in the hands of Captain General CANEDO for some time, but that fearing it would produce disastrous excitement, he took the responsibility of withhold. ing it, except from a few wealthy planters, to, whom it was communicated confidentially.

Four more trials were had this morning on joint ballot for Governor--the last was as follows: FAIRBANKS, Whig, 103; ROBINSON, Dem, 100; BRAINARD, Free soil, 37. Further ballotings will be had to morrow.

A STEAMBOAT TRAGEDY--A MAN SHOT BY A WOMAN.-A tragedy occurred on the 9th innst., on hoard the New St. Paul, on the Missouri, near Cap-au-Gris, on the downward passage of the boat to St. Louis. Among the deck passengers were Mrs. LYDIA MIILER and her hushand. They had been married only three weeks, and were on their way from a visit to Minnnesota.

Verily this great City is a fearful place. We are called upon almost daily to record burglaries, robberies, arsons, assassinations, and murders;--so familiar is the general eye to paragraphs reciting horrible deeds, that they fail to excite more than a momentary attention.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: An articule appeared in the NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES of the 7th of October, headed "Important Case--Charge of Compounding a Felony," containing a statement of certain facts which, apparently to the satisfaction of the writer, were conclusive as to the guilt of the parties charged.

METROPOLITAN HALL.-Jullien's Grand Concerts. NIBLO'S GARDEN.-Italian Opera.-I Lombardi. BROADWAY THEATRE.-Dick the Newsboy-Paddy Carey-In and Out of Place-Barney the Baron. WALLACK'S THEATRE.-Bleak House-Two Can Play at that Game. NATIONAL THEATRE.-Uncle Tom's Cabin.

In another part of this morning's paper, will be found several affidavits, made by persons resident in Syracuse, who testify, in the most direct terms, to attempts on the part of the Hard-Shells, to hire bullies at the Syracuse Convention, to resist alleged attempts on the part of their opponents to overawe the Convention by similar means.

Yesterday was quite a gala day in turf amusement on the Union Course and Centreville Course, Long Island, on the occasion of numerous bona fide trotting matches coming off, for purses and stakes varying from two to five hundred dollars. The weather being unusually pleasant for this season of the year, and the entering of several celebrated horses being previously announced, a large concourse of people were present from New-York, Philadelphia, and elsewhere.

We fear we did that once enterprising newspaper, the Herald, some little injustice the other day in the " serious remonstrance " we ventured to make against its allowing itself to be beaten, so regularly and signally, in important intelligence, by the DAILY TIMES.

The Democrats and Free-Soilers of Essex County, met in separate Convention to day at Ipswich, agreed to coalesee on a ticket, and nominated three Democrats and two Free Soilers as their candidates for the Senate.

At Brooklyn, Wednesday, Oct. 19, by Rev. Dr. Neale, of Boston, HENRY C. YALE, to AMELIA, only daughter o? T. B. White, Esq., Brooklyn. At New-Haven. on the 19th inst., by Rev. Mr. Pitkin, E. DYER VINTON, Esq.. of Providence, R. I., to ALICE G., only daughter of Alfred P. Edmonds, Esq., of this City.
The Whig County Convention nominated JAMES MUNROE for Senator; CHARLES ANDREWS for District Attorney; JARED H. PARKER, Superintendent of the Poor, and LEVI WELLS, for Justice.

The second day of the Exhibition has opened, i possible, under a more auspicious sun than shone forth yesterday. The sky was without a cloud, the air delightfully clear and genial. At an early hour the Exhibition Ground presented a lively scene. Several thousand peo ple had congregated on the stands and round the course by 9 o'clock.

The Yellow Fever at the South. New Orleans Board of Health has declared yellow fever no longer an apidemic in that city. Mobile, on the 12th and 13th, there were 15 deaths, ?? were of yellow fever. Galveston, outof a population of 4,000, there have about 1,600 cases of yellow fever, and 400 deaths, physicians, and six out of eight Catholic priests, had Judge WATROUS and Judge WHEELER were ?? from severe attacks.

Rev. J. P. THOMPSON delivered the fourth and list of his Lectures on Egypt in the Tabernacle, last evening. He said first, that he was sorry to appear before his audience without the pictures promised, and without the drawing of the Sphinx. These pictures have been carefully prepared, and sent to the map-makers to be mounted, but they were taken from there, probably mistake.

We have papers and correspondence from the City of Mexico to the 3d inst. The British mail steamship Avon left on the evening of the 5th inst, without having shipped her freight list of specie and cochineal. A northern was blowing and prevented its being put on board; and at her appointed time she was compelled to leave without it.

The Anniversary Address before the American Institute was delivered last evening at the Tabernacle by HON. WILLIAM H. SEWARD, before one of the largest audiences we have ever seen collected in this City. The hour fixed was 71/2 o'clock, but long before that time the spacious building was crowded to its utmost capacity, and thousands gathered upon the sidewalk unable to obtain admission.

The trial of the case of "The People of the United States against Thomas Collyer, John F. Tallman, John German, Edward Hubbard, James L. Jessup, James Elmendorf, and Charles Merritt," was resumed yesterday morning at 10 o'clock.

The brothers JONES, ZELOTUS W. BURT, and WM. H. NORTHUP were placed upon trial for the murder of NEIL DOUGHERRTY, during the firemen's rows of the 10th inst., this morning, in the Court of Magistrates, before Judge MANCHESTER. If I except the trial of AVERY, perhaps no criminal trial in this State has created so much excitement as was exhibited this morning.
The Convention reassembled yesterday morning. at 9 A. M. Morning prayer was read by Rev. Dr. CREIGHTON, President, assisted by Rev. Mr. RANVALL, Assistant Secretary, Rev. Dr. CREIGHTON in the Chair.

In another part of this morning's TIMES will be found an article from the Washington Union, fully confirming the important intelligence published exclusively in the TIMES, two or three days since, concerning British movements in regard to Slavery in the Island of Cuba.

New-Orleans papers of Wednesday and Thursday last are received. Galveston dates of the 7th inst. report the epidemic on the decline. Dates from Vera Cruz to the 8th inst. had reached New-Orleans. A decree reestablishing the Jesuits in Mexico is published.

Governor SEWARD addressed one of the largest audiences last evening, we have ever seen assembled in New-York. The Tabernaclewas crowded to its utmost capacity, long before the hour of meeting, and thousands came who were unable to obtain admission. Gov. SEWARD was suffering under a severe cold, and it was with great difficulty that he went through the physical labor of pronouncfing the Address.

WHIG CITY CONVENTION.-This Conventio was hold last evening at the City Hotel. Alderman A B BAYLIS was elected Chairman, and JOHN LOMAS and A J. S. DEGRAW Secretaries. The following nomination. were made: For Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies--John M Perry.

PAINFUL ACCIDENT TO REV. DR. GRISWOLD.--A frightful accident occurred at the hose of Rev. Dr. GRISWOLD, No. 22 West Twenty-third-street. last evening, about 5 1/2 o'clock. Dr. GRISWOLD, who has been suffering several months from consumption, came to the City from his Summer residence last Saturday, to superintend the preparation of his house for the reception of his family.

THE EDITOR OF THE NEW-YORK HERALD AND THE FRENCH MISSION--The Herald half denies that Mr. BENNETT was an applicant for the Mission to Paris. Mr. B. is too wily a gentleman to have "filed papers" asking for any place under the Government. Yet he was by no means too modest to permit those connected with him to talk him up industriously, first for the Austrian Chargeslup. and afterwards for the Mission to Paris.

ANTI MAINE LIQUOR LAW.-The German Committees formed in the different Wards of our City, during the past fortnight helo a general meeting yesterday eveing, at Washington Hall, in Elizabeth-street, to mate arrange nts for calling a mass meeting of all citizens opposed to the passage of a prohibitory law.

The ship Sagadahock on board of which 70 deaths from cholera have been reported, is below this city. The Mayor and Aldermen held a special meeting this morning, and passed an order for the Committee on Internal Health to take such measures that the danger from its approach may be averted from the city.

Collector BRONSON's removal has certainly been determined on. Fact-fixed fact. The President will not tolerate insubordination. It is surmised that Judge NICHOLSON is preparing an elaborate answer to BRONSON's letter.

Several days since we published an extended statement of the history, mode of operations, results and general character of the effort which has been for some time in progress at the Five Points, under charge of Mr. PRASH, to purify that degraded Iocality, and offer to its wretched denizens a chance to reform.

A meeting was held here last evening, composed of prominent business men, without distinction of party. They adopted an address to the electors of the State, and proposed a State ticket made up from the Whig, Hunker, and Barnburner tickets.

Those (and they are legion.) who are in terested in the improvement of that noble animal, the horse, cannot but have read with pleasure the full reports we have furnished of the proceedings of the first National Exhibition of Horses, at Springfield, in the State of Massachusetts.

SIXTH DISTRICT-SOFT'S SENATORIAL CONVENTION. The Soft's Senatorial Convention of the Sixth District, comprising the Eleventh, Twelfth. Fifteenth, Sixteenth, Eighteenth, Nineteenth, Twentieth, Twentyfirst and Twenty-second Wards, met again last evening, at the Union House, corner of Twenty second-street and Third-avenue, but as far as we could learn, no business of any importance was transacted.

The Eastern synod of the German Reformed Church assembled again to-day, and proceeded to the consideration of a paper handed in the previous evening by Rer. Dr. KREMER, containing certain charges made by Rev. Dr. ZACHARIUS against Rev. Dr. S R: FISHER, editor of the German Reformed Messenger.

Morning prayer was read by Rev. Mr. JONES, of Tennessee, assisted by Rev. Mr. TALBOT, of Indiana. The Minutes were read by the Secretary. Rev. Dr. STEVENS explained that the reason why the Committee on Providing for the Widows and Orphans of Deceased Bishops,

Their Majesties left St. Cloud, with the usual flourish, last Thursday, for the Northern Departments. The first day's journey revealed no new or striking fact, unless it he the existence of a lady of honor of whom we had not heard before, Madame LEZAY MAGNESIA, and a singular proceeding on the part of the engine.

NATIONAL CLUB.-A meeting of this body wu held last night, at the Stuyvesant Institute. Mr. C. GODFREY GUNTHER in the Chair. The Committee of Vice-Presidents reported, as the result of a matter which had been referred to their consideration, that they had appointed Mr. GUNTHER, Mr. NATHANIEL JARVIS, Jr., and Mr. P. N. GLOVER, as Presiding Vice-Presidents.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Mr. PETER SQUIRES' very gentlemanly reply to my communication of the 14th would have escaped my notice but for the kindness of a friend in directing my attention to it. Mr. SQUIRES is doubtless honest in what be affirms.

The bark Benjamin Adams. From Syria, arrived at this port, brings a Jerusalem plow and other articles from the Holy Land, for the Crystal Palace at New-York. The ship Sagadahock lost only 55 passengers by cholera.

A collision occurred on the Railroad Bridge at Coatsville this morning, between a freight train going down. and a passenger train coming up. Both engines were disabled, and two men named WILLIAMS and DAVIS, on the freight train, were killed, and another, name unknown, severely injured.
To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: There was a brief announcement this morning of the death of Brevet Brigadier-General CHILDS, at Tampa, Florida, of yellow fever, on the 8th instant.
NIBLO'S SALOON.-We regret to learn that Signora STEFFANONE is again suffering from indisposition. Lust evening the opera of "Lucia " had to be substituted for that of " Norma "-the one announced.

This morning the managers of the Exhibition gratified the desire generally expressed for a grand procession of all the horses entered, numbering over four hundred. The weather continued beautifully fine, and by 9 o'clock the stands were crowded with spectators.

There was a circle round the moon on Thursday night, anti of course a rainy day for Friday. But the men most fold of fat cattle and large fowls, are they who don't mind a light shower or an inch or two of mud. To reach the ground we stepped into a Third-avenue car, and skated up in a few minutes.

There were buried, last week, twenty per sons more than the week preceding. Yet bowel complaints are decreasing,--a very pleasant fact in view of any possible arrival of the Cholera from Europe,--and the cases of fever are not increased. The increase of fatal cases of consumption was 28, of convulsions 7, and of dropsies in the head, 6.

About 2 o'clock on Sunday morning, as two young men, named M. C. MORSE and ROBERT DONOVAN were proceeding to their boarding-house, No. 35 Degraw-street, at the corner of Degraw and Van Brunt-streets, they met four men, named NEIL, McCUE, FRANCIS McGOVERN, WILLIAM MATHER and MICHAEL McWIGGIN, when some words passed between the two parties, the result of which was a fight.

The following letter, written quite recently by the Whig candidate for Governor in New Jersey, has just been published:-- WEST CREEK, Sept. 24, 1853. DEAR SIR.--Yours of the 19th is before me, and suffer me to say, it is a time with me when I should be careful. Everything I say is criticised.

The Hydropathic Quarterly Review is a neatly printed, prettily illustrated duodecimo of 192 pages, published by FOWLERS WELLS, of which the first number has just appeared--terms two doldars a year. The wood-cut on the first page of the cover is a very handsome symbol of the way this water practice treats the world.

AMERICAN DRAMAS AND ENGLISH CRITICISM.--The London Athenaum of the 24th ult. contains a critique on the recent performance of BOKER's play of "The Betrothal," at Drury-lane, with Mr. GUSTAVUS BROOKE in the principal character. The judgment of the critic is not favorable. "The plot," he says, "is exceedingly meagre and most inefficiently developed.

There was a good deal of curiosity manifested to hear the introductory at the New-York Medical College, of Prof. E. H. PARKER. the new occupant of the chair of Physiology and Pathology. In consequence, the lecture room was thronged at an early-hour, and a critical congregation of City Physicians and Medical Students listened with profound attention from first to last.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A few days since I noticed in your paper remarks tending to demonstrate the exemption of workers in Copper from Cholera. Having employed the sulphate of copper freely in cholera cases in Germany, in London, and in this country, with marked success, I am induced to trouble you in confirmation with my rationale of its modus operandi.

Besides the appointment of Mr. REDFIELD in place of Collector BRONSON, removed, it is stated that JOHN J. Cisco has been appointed Assistant Treasurer in place of Mr. Dix, resigned, and that J. ROMEYN BRODHEAD, Esq., is made Naval Officer in place of Mr. REDFIELD, promoted.

DR. ALBOTT'S EYPTIAN ANTIQUITIES.--The most interesting exhibition now on view in this City is undoubtedly the Gallery of Egyptian Antiquities, at the Stuyvesant Institute. No. 659 Broadway. Except the huge collections in the Royal Museums of Europe, there is nothing compared with this splendid result of individual effort.

M. FINNIN ROGIER, the Belgian Envoy, had an audience yesterday of the Emperor, in order to acquaint him with the marriage of the Duke of Brabant. With all respect for Court forms and recognized international traditions, this announcement borders on the grotesque. The marriage in question took place a month ago, and everybody in France was sufficiently informed of it.

ALD. STURTEVANT IN THE CHAIR. Resolutions.--By Ald SMITH.--Whereas, It appears by the bids lately made at the office of the Commissioner of Streets and Lamps, that the persons making said bids think that the streets can be cleaned at a saving of some considerable amount to the City;

Morning prayer was read by the Rev. Mr. CRANE, of Maine, assisted by Rev. Mr. WATSON, of North Carolina. The Secretary read the minutes of Friday's proceedings, which were approved. The Reports of the various Committees, resolutions, , were called for by the President.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In this morning's paper, I am reported as having spoken, last evening, against the Canon allowing of the restoration of deposed clergymen. I have never uttered a word against restoration.

The Steamer United States, Capt. LUCAS, arrvied at this port on Saturday afternoon, having left New-Orleans on the 12th, and Havana on the 15th. We are indebted to the purser for memoranda. The United States passed bark Zidon, latitude 26[degree] 01', longitude 79 [degree] 41', October 16.

Our neighbor of the Tribune, it strikes us, is getting ahead rather rapidly on the subject of Woman's Rights. He devotas a column, in his Saturday's issue, to a very energetic and some what impassioned discussion of the subject of Polygamy among the Mormons,--especially of the comments of the English press upon that particular feature of what they treat as a natural development of Republican institutions.

The Sunbury and Erie Railroad subscription, on the part Philadelphia, is the chief topic of conversation among our citizens. It is admitted by every candid, intelligent man. that the construction of this Road is the greatest enterprise projected in Pennsylvania--the greatest to the State. and the greatest to Philadelphia city and County.

Dull times here at present. The definte settlement of the New-York case disposes of the entire staple of gossip. The President distinctly claims the responsibility, and all attempts to divide him and his Cabinet have failed.

From the National Intelligencer. Our Paris correspondent, in his last letter, says : "I have just received a letter from Berlin, which states that our new Minister at that Court has arrived, and that his diplomatic spirit and ability are likely to be speedily tested by a case bearing in some particulars a close re semblance to the unfortunate KOSZTA affair, which is embroiling us again with Austria.

HON. ICHABOD BARTLETT, OF NEW-HAMPSHIRE.--We have heretofore noticed, under our telegraphic head, the death of this distinguished citizen--who died at his residence in Portsmouth on Wednesday, the 19th inst., aged 67 years. He was born in Salisbury, N. H, in 1786. His father, JOSEPH BARTLETT, was the first justice of the peace and first physician in the town.

FIREMEN'S ELECTION.--An election for a Chief Engineer and an Assistant Engineer for the Fire Department of Jersey City has been ordered by H. READ, Assistant Engineer, who did not resign. This electron is to take place on Monday evening, Aug. 31, from 7 until 10 o'clock P. M., to fill vacancies occasioned by the late resignations.

Unless our neighbor of the Herald has concluded to accept the offer of $100,000 for his paper, and start anew in some smaller city, he would do well to take our advice, turn out the political partisans who have at present entire charge of its columns, and make a serious effort to regain the character it once possessed for enterprise in obtaining news.

Some few months ago, the City was about to lease the privilege of maintaining a ferry between the foot of Wall-street and Brooklyn. There had been a great deal of grumbling, in certain quarters, because similar privileges bad been given away for a mere song.

ANNUAL REPORT OF THE COMPTROLLER.--The annexed is an abstract of Comptroller KENNEY'S Annual Report of the receipts and disbursements of the City of Williamsburg for the year ending August 31, 1853: Whole amount received on City Accounts, $279,992 53.Loans, $223,218.

In Brooklyn, Sunday morning, Oct. 23d, after a few days' illness, Mrs. EUPHEMIA, relict of John M Cooper, in the 73d year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, on Tuesday, (25th i st., at 2 1/2 o'clock, from the residence of her son-in-law, D. M. Lyons, No. 144 Dem.,st., without further invitation.

HON. JOHN DELAFIELD died suddenly at his residence, at Geneva, in this State, on Saturday, 22d inst. He was born in New York, in 1786, and graduated at Columbia College. On leaving college he was, for a time, engaged as clerk in the counting-house of a firm largely connected with the East India trade.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Considering the very inclement state of the weather, the attendance last evening was good. "Ernani," the solitary opera of VERDI which appears to retain the stage, always attracts an admiring audience.

Our special telegraphic correspondence from Washington this morning, concerning the English scheme for the Africanization of Cuba, is of even more than ordinary interest. The truth of previous communications on the same subject, and from the same source, has been doubted by some of our "hop-and-goeasy " cotemporaries with their usual caution.

DESTRUCTION OF THE FORTH HAMILTON HOUSE.--We mentioned briefly, yesterday morning, the destruction of the Fort Hamilton House by fire on Sunday night. It is supposed that the fire was occasioned by some sparks from the chimney, alghting on the roof. Before the fire was observed, it has spread to such an extent that all idea of saving the building was abandoned.

Oct. 24, by Rev. H. F. Pease. Mr. JOSEPH FOX. of New-York, to Miss EMILY A. FLETCHER, of Williamsburg, L. I. On Wednesday, Oct. 19, at Baptist Parsonage, in Bustleton, Pa., by Rev. Wm. Hutchinson, Hon. CHARLES HUGHES, of Washington County, N. Y., to ANNA E. HUTCHINSON, of the former place.

The first of a promised series of Lectures on "The Catholic History of America," was delivered in the Broadway Tabernacle last evening, by Mr. THOMAS D'ARCY McGEE. The suspect of the lecture was "Columbus and the Discoveries."

Having published the correspondence published by the friends of Mr. LEGARE, who fell in the recent duel with Mr. DUNOVANT, we also give place to the following card published by the latter. It will be read with painful interest, as showing by what needless and absurd punctilio a valuable life was lost and a large circle of friends plunged into the deepest affliction.

The late correspondence between Secretary GUTHRIE and Collector BRONSON has attracted to the policy of the Administration in regard to appointments so much of the public attention, that we should be derelict in our duty to the Democratic party if we failed to present the real points at issue between those distinguished functionaries in their true light.

GRAND LARCENY--A COURAGEOUS WOMAN--A man named John Robinson was brought before Justice Blachley, at the Third District Station-house, on Saturday, by Officers Blachick and Cullen, of the Third District, on a warrant charging him with grand larceny.

From the Boston Daily Advertiser. Hon. EDMUND BURKE, of New-Hampshire, who has been driven into a state of violent antagonism with the friends of the Administration in NewHampshire, has voluntarily revealed, sooner thin might have been anticipated, the secret movements by which the mysterious nomination was accomplished, in a manner apparently without a cause.

The Rochester Democrat of the 24th announces the death of the " Sleeping Man," CORNELIUS VROOMAN, who " died at his brother's residence, in Clarkson, on Monday, the 17th inst. While on exhibition in New-York, he was taken sick, which seemed to induce a wakeful state for a short period, and then a stupid condition, with intervals of wakefulness, until he was brought home on the 14th.

On Monday, Oct. 24, after a short and severe illness, MARY ELIZABETH, youngest daughter of Timothy B. and Mary Elizabeth Ross, aged 2 years and 3 months. The friends of the family, and also of Robert Roberts, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral on Wednesday, Oct. 25, at 12 M, from. No. 36 North Moore-street.

FOUND DEAD.-A young man, 35 years of age, named David Sackett, formerly a clerk in Mr. Armstrong's clothing store, in Grand street, was found dead in Mr. Inglass stable, corner of Grand and Sixth-streets, between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. An inquest was held, when the Coroner's Jury rendered a verdict of death from convulsions, aggravated by intemperance. Decreased was a native of Virginia.

The State Election takes place a fortnight from to-day-that being the "Tuesday next succeeding the first Monday in November." The canvass excites comparatively little interest, and the vote promises to be light.

Additional and positive confirmation has been received here of the perfection of the scheme to Africanize Cuba, according to the terms of the secret treaty between Spain, England, and France. The Union also says: " We have received additional and stronger evidence from Havana, which places the matter, in our mind, beyond any reasonable doubt.

We publish in another column, from the Washington Union, an extended exposition of the reasons which have prompted the President to remove Collector BRONSON. The article bears the stamp of authority, and is undoubtedly, in its views and sentiments, if not in its language, strictly official.

As tile pruning-knife has come into fashionable use with our new Administration, it may he well for our President, now that his hand is in, to set a good example in the matter of Congressional Messages. There is certainly room for reform. Grievances are not nuisanees, but still they are hard to bear if they take the shape of public literature.

THE LICENE BUSINESS.--The trials of Messrs. RAE, FRAZEE, WANNER and WILSON, hotel-keepers of the First Ward, Jersey City, on the charge of selling liquor without a license, were set down for yesterday before Recorder CUTTER. Mr. HENRY STEELE made the complaints against these parties.

The intense interest which the American people have shown in the gallant conduct of Capt. INGRAHAM, and the general satisfaction with which the able State paper of Secretary MARCY has been received, are quite sufficient to indicate that our National Mind is advancing beyond the narrow limits of domestic politics, and concerning itself with the more reserved questions of Statesmanship.

SIXTH DAY. The People of the United States against Thomas Collyer, John F. Tallman, John Germain, Edward Hubbard, James L. Jessup, James Elmendorf and Charles Merritt. Pursuant to adjournment, the Court assembled yesterday morning at 12 o'clock.

The weather has been of the most unpleasant character, suspending nearly all out door business transactions. COTTON remains unchanged, and so with BARK and PROVISIONS. The FLOUR market is very quiet-3,000 bbls. good brands, part Brandywine, sold for shipment at $6 50 ?? bbl, but he demand is limited, and both buyers and sellers are mostly indifferent about operating until after the receipt of later European advices.

THE WORKS OF WILLIAM H SEWARD. Elited by GEORGE E. BAKER ?? vols. New-York, REDFIELD; London, Low Co. In these three bulks volumes we have a collection of the writings and speeches of one of the most distinguished living politicians of the United States.

RAILROAD IN WARREN-STREET.--A communication has been submitted to the Common Council of Jersey City, by the New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company, stating that they propose to lay a track in Warren-street, diverging from their present road near Warren-street, and running through it, easterly, to the northerly side of the present depot of the Paterson Railroad.

The constant recurrence of accidents at our various ferries seems to demand some kind of investigation. Scarcely a day passes that we have not to record one or more of these events. Men, women and children are constantly getting in the water, and too often are not rescued until the vital spark is extinct.

It struck pleasantly on many ears when lately we heard that the great ideas of Brotherhood, Equality, and religious responsibility in Uncle Tom's Cabin were preached to the Bowery boys from the stage.

We continue to present a very full report of the interesting trial now in process in the United States District Court, of the officers and owners of the steamboat Henry Clay, the loss of which, last year, on the Hudson River, carrived d auguish to so many hearts, and created so profound a sensation throughout the country.

The PRESIDENT in the Chair. The following was the business transacted: A petition from Mrs. A. W. Leslie to have the nuisance caused by the overflow of water from the house of Engine Company No. 19, in Green-street, abated, was referred to the Fire Department Committee. Petition of members of Engine Company No. 49, for a new enginehouse, Referred to the Fire Department Committee.

SIXTEENTH DAY. The Convention reassembled, pursuant to adjournment, at 11 o'clock yesterday morning. There was a larger attendance than usual, during Divine service. Morning prayer, to the creed, was rest by Rev. Dr. HIGBEE, of New-York; the rest by Rev. Mr. COXE, of Conn.
From the Washington Union. The remarks made on this subject by us, some days ago, have attracted much notice and provoked some criticism.

Mr. GUTHRIA's last letter, and the recent change in the Collectorship of your port, show distinctly that you were correctly informed relative to the temper and attitude of the President. What has become of all those positive statements that General PIERCE had at last discovered the rocks on which he was splitting, and was determined to throw them out of his path? The statement was true, but not in the sense intended.

YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN Association.--The announcement that this Society would be inaugurated by a discourse from Rev. Dr. STORES, in Dr. BETHUNE'S Church, filled that building last evening with an intelligent audience.

The statement that the arbitration in BELCHER BROTHERS' concentrated molasses case has been decided in their favor, is positively erroneous. The Board of General Appraisers decided distinctly that the article is sugar, and fixed the dutiable value considerably above that invoiced by the importers, but not so high as claimed at New-Orleans.

TRAGEDY IN LOUISVILLE.--The Louisville papers have an account of a deliberate attempt of a lig?? hand to kill his wife, himself, and his child. The Journ?? of the 20th says: Last evening, JAMES FENN, a hatt by trade, and who has heretofore always burne a go?? character, attempted to kill his wife by shooting her.

Triennial Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church. SEVENTEENTH DAY. The Convention reassembled at 9 o'clock, yesterday.

The Hard-Shell organ has found an endorser for one of its reports. A. Mr. GILSON, one of the witnesses in the Henry Clay case, whose testimony, as given in Court, we reported verbatim on Monday morning, publishes the following card in yesterday's Herald: Endorsement of the Herald's Report.
The steamship Isabel, Capt. ROLLINS, arrived here last night, bringing Havana and Key West dates of the 22d inst. We have no political news of importance. KEY WEST SHIPPING INTELLIGENCE.
PARK BENJAMIN'S - LECTURE--Last evening PARK BENJAMIN delivered his lecture on Americanisms, at the old Reformed Dutch Church, in Grand-street, near Washington.

The Hard-Shell Committee, it strikes us, are managing the Herald badly. If they gos in the way they have begun, the concern will prove a bad speculation for them. We do not know whether Hon. D. B. TAYLOR or Hon. MINER C. STOREY has been installed editor in chief; but it is very evident that the incumbent, whoever he may be, lacks experience.
Nominations of the "Free Democracy"- The WIlkesbarre Slave Case. A meeting of the Free Democratic League was held at their room, Stuyvesant Institute, last evening.

The Story a Thousand Times Told, yet Always New. "Oh! will you not let me rest here one night? I have not where to lay my head." If you will go with me up town, dear leader, I will point you to an elegant mansion, in which once dwelt a family reared in all the luxury which wealth can purchase and indulgence lavish.

From the National Intelligencer. Messrs. GALES SEATON: The eminently beneficent system of Russia governing the extension of her dominions is not properly understood and appreciated in the United States.

The steam-boiler in SCHROEDER'S Print Works, in Smithfield, burst about 8 o'clock this morning, with a terrible explosion, instantly killing two operatives, and wounding the engineer and several other persons, probably fatally.

The following changes in the Revenue Marine Service are announced: 2d Lieut. A. L. HYDE promoted to 1st Lieut., vice GEORGE HAYES, dismissed. 3d Lieut, JOSEPH D. USHER to be 2d Lieut., vice HYDE promoted.

The steamship Texas has arrived below this port from Vera Cruz, bringing California dates of Sept. 90. She reports the departure from San Francisco of the steamer Pacific for San Juan del Sud. With 460 passengers, and $1,500,000 gold--and the steamer Panama, for Panama, with $1,100,000 in gold.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Allow me to correct an error into which the TIMES has been led, in common with some other City papers, as to the action of the Synod of New-York and New-Jersey. The resolution on Slavery, which appears in this morning's paper, was not adopted by the Synod, but was indefinitely postponed by a very large majority.
In New-Brunswick, N J., on Monday, Oct. 17, by Rev. Mr. Woodbridge. WARREN HARDENBURGH, Esq., Attorney at Law, to CORNELIA VAN RENSELEAR, daughter of the late Anthony Rutgers.

The TIMES surely apprehends the wide moral difference between the cases of bigamy under our laws, (where the bigamist can only accomplish his purpose through a gross fraud,) and the Mormon polity on that subject.

By telegraph to WELLS, FARGO Co., from Norfolk, we learned at an early hour last evening that the steamer Northern Light had put in there in distress. Subsequently have received the following from our regular Agent: NORFOLK, Tuesday, Oct. 25.

HORRIBLE MURDER.--An Irishman committed most horrible murder in Dupage County, upon the line the Chicago, St. Charles, and Mississippi Air Line Rail road, on the 21st inst. Two brothers named TOLE, had been employed on the road, had received their pay the morning, amounting to over $60.

TABERNACLE.--Those old established favorites, the HUTCHINSONS, attracted a large audience last evening. The programme was a popular one, and contained some features new to a metropolitan audience. Among the latter, we may mention the song of "Topsy"--a musical illustration of that peculiar character in Mrs. STOWE'S work.
SIR: Your letter 0f the 2Oth ult., arrived here during my absence, and ill-health has combined with constant occupation, thus far, to delay my reply.

Hon. HENRY P. HEDGES has declined the nomination of the Whigs of the First District of Suffolk county, for Assembly. In consequence, a convention, to sit at Riverhead, October 28th, has been called to nominate a candidate in his room. The Democratic candidate for the same District is HUBBARD GRIFFING, Esq., of Riverhead.
The Democrats and Free-Soilers, of Norfolk County, met in separate Conventions at Dedham to-day and formed a coalition, and nominated two Democrats and one Free Soiler for Senators.

THE FIRE IN THE WOODS OF MICHIGAN.--The Detroit Advertiser of Friday says the fire in the woods continued to burn with much fury; but the most dangerous fires are at some distance from the city in the towns of Livonia and Greenfield, and in that direction.

The announcement of a great trotting match to come off at the Union Course, for a purse of $4,000, between a celebrated sorrel gelding and the brown stallion "Cardinal," brought out a large concourse of people from this City and elsewhere, to witness the sport.

There are breakers ahead, if half you tell us of Europe is true. Wars and rumors of war--scarcity of bread--approaching cholera! Verily, the skies look lowering--not so much, indeed, for this favored land, as for those poor people in Europe.

The weather has been qul'e cool to-day, with but little business transpiring. The news from Europe is looked for with much anxiety, and until its arrival there will be nothing of moment done in business circles.

INCENDIARISM.--During the past few weeks, in cendiary fires have been quite frequent in this city. Last night, about 10 o'clock, the large livery stable of CONK LIN CARL, at the foot o Fulton-street, was set on fire in the bay-loft; but, fortunately, was discovered in time to save the building But small damage was done.

Judge EDMONDS has written the following private note, denying that he has ever been influenced by spirits in his official action, or that he has ever consulted them in regard to it: DEAR SIR: In a brief interview that I had with our friend Mr. PARTRIDGE a few moments since, he informed me that you had been told that my book showed that I had consulted spirits as to my decisions,

DEMOCRATIC NOMINATIONS.--The Democrats of the several Wards made the following nominations Monday evening, for Aldermen: 1st Word--George A. Sweeney; 2d do., James M. Neeley; 3d do., Wm. Hunter, Jr.; 4th do., No nomination; 5th do., F. G. Quevedo; 8th do., Thomas Mulligan; 7th do., Stephen C. Jackson; 8th do., No nomination; 9th do., Wm. H. Campbell; 10th do., Michael S. Gibbons; 11th do., Charles Hooper.

NEW-YORK MEDICAL COLLEGE. Prof. Doremus' Introductory. Creation--The Mosaic and the Chemical Account. Unpropitions heavens! what a night! dark, dirty, wet! We looked to see a dozen or two very persevering students, half a dozen patronizing doctors, and a postponement of the Lecture until the weather should be decent.

There was a horrible tale conveyed in the single line which announced in the TIMES of yesterday, that the ship Washington arrived from Liverpool at Quarantine with 952 passengers, of which 73 bad died, and 18 others were sick.
There was a white frost in this city and county last night, also at Mobile. The thermometer here at sunrise was down to 40 degrees.

The upper floor of the New-York Mills, in Rochestor, gave way on Friday morning last, carrying with it the floors below and about 6,000 bushels of wheat, 2,500 bushels of feed and a quantity of flour, which were precipitated into the river below.

The car on which the late mail was burned was a common freight car, open only at the sides. When it was found to be on fire--it being in the night, and the train in rapid motion--there was no means of communicating the fact to the conductor or the engineer, except by the cry of "fire;" and the noise of the cars and machinery, in this case, rendered that mode ineffectual.
It is quite fashionable in England, Just now, to speak of Quarantine regulations as relics of a barbarous age,--useless inconveniences,--often intolerable nuisances.

AN INVITATION TO NEW-ORLEANS.--The weather has again become cool and delightful, and we take occasion to reassure our absent citizens, and also strangers, that there is not the least danger in coming to the city.
The steamship Crescent City arrived here yesterday, with Havana dates to the 19th inst. The arrival out of the new Captain General was daily looked for with considerable interest.
On Sunday night, Oct. 23, at Copalse Iron Works, in this State, of apoplexy, LEMUEL POMEROY, in the Slat year of his age.

Inside of a stage-coach, and the night very wet--six passengers to be jolted into one another three smoking and three being smoked--curtains down, and spirits too--not much chance to sleep, and rather less to be awake--combined to make us feel, on our road from Newbern to Abingdon, that we must all do something uncommon for each other's happiness.
ARRIVAL or THE MAKION.--The U. S. Mail steamship Marion, Capt. FOSTER, 58 hours from Charleston, arrived at this port yesterday.

Mr. Murray's cross-examination by Mr. Wheaton was commenced yesterday morning. Q.--Had you ever any experience in the management of steamboats ? A.-No, Sir.
The Mayor last night sent into the Common Council a message giving his reasons for not approving the ordinance increasing the pay of policemen.

The Royal Mail steamship Niagara, Capt. LEITCH, from Liverpool on Saturday, the 15th inst., arrived here at 1 o'clock this (Thursday) morning. The Collins steamship Arctic, from New-York on lst inst., arrived out on Wednesday morning, the 12th.

We showed in our last article on this subject, that there is an excess of officers in the Navy as now constituted, and presented some of the evils resulting from such excess. The inquiry how this excess can be disposed of, is an important one to the country and to the service.

IMPORTANT TESTIMONY. At 10 o'clock yesterday morning, at the City Hall, Coroner BALL commenced an investigation into the causes of the late fatal affray at the corner of Van Brunt and Degraw-streets, which resulted in the death of CORNELIUS McCUE.

EIGHTEENTH DAY. The House reassembled at 9 o'clock. Morning Prayer was said by Rev. Dr. MEADE, assisted by Rev. Dr. VAN INGEN. The resolution sent down from the House of Bishops, ordering the Secretary to prepare an index of all the Journals of the Convention, came up for discussion, and after a short debate was adopted, with the following amendenent: "If the funds of the Convention be sufficient to defray such expense."

JOHN DUFFY, of New-York, has been appointed Consul to Galway, Ireland, and ALOIS D. GALL, of Indiana, Consul to Antwerp. The State Department has received information from the United States Consul at Hong Kong of the deaths of the following American seamen: JOHN McDONALD, April 10-residence unknown; SAMUEL WHEELER, July 16-rebidence unknown;
The bark Harward, from Newport, Wales bound to this port with railroad iron, went ashore on the 22d on Watchaprigne Shoals, and the vessel sunk to her deck in sand. The crew were safe.

SCENE IN A COURT IN MAIN.--At the Supreme Court in Alfred, Maine, last week, WILLIAM E. HASKELL, who was convicted on two indictments for storebreaking, being asked by Judge HOWARD if he had anything to say, made some hypocritical remarks calculated to propitiate the Judge, and received sentences of two years in the State prison on each indictment.

In Brooklyn, on Wednesday, morning, Oct. 19, in South Congregational Church, by Rev. W. H. Manh , JOHN M. TOMPKINS, of that city, to Miss FIDELIA MERRITT, of South Brookfield, Mass. On Thursday, Oct. 20, by Rev. Henry J. Fox, SIDNEY SMITH. to Miss HARRIET A. PECK, both of Brooklyn.
The Union is in danger again. The Herald has discovered that the National Theatre is in league with Senator SEWARD and other incendiaries for the destruction of our beloved Confederacy.

AFFLICTING DISPENSATION.--A family in this vicinity have recently been bereaved under circumstances of a very peculiar and distressing character. On Wednesday, the 12th instant, Dr. LOTHROF, of the Brattle-street Church, married the daughter of one of our well-known citizens to a young merchant of this city.

Mr. Benjamin Bagnal, of Milwaukee, was arrested some time ago on a charge of alleged depreditions committed on the Government lands of Michigan. On Friday evening last, he was again arrested in Milwaukee, by the United States Marshal. Ableman,

The loss by the fire here on Saturday night amounted to $125,000. It is covered by insurance in local and foreign offices. The press and public are quite indignant at Judge McLEAN'S order forbidding the publication of the Martha Washington trial during its progress.

The Southern Mail is through from Mobile. Two New-Orleans mails are now due. The yellow fever is still prevailing at Galveston, Houston, and other places in Texas. The movement among the United States troops on the Texan frontier continued The Indians were taking advantage of the removal. and recommencing their predatory incursions.

The steamer Northern Light had not arrived at this port at 3 o'clock this morning We received files of California papers from ADAMS Co, BEAFORD Co., WELLS. FARGO Co.'s Express Agents, and also from Mr ST. JOHN, at an early hour lust evening, for which we are under obligations. They left the Northern Light at Norfolk, and came on by land conveyance.

On Wednesday, Oct. 26, SUSAN M., wife of Robert B. Coleman, in the 46th year of her age. The funeral will take place on Friday, 28th inst., at 2 o'clock, P. M., from the Astor House. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend without further invitation. Her remains will be deposited in Greenwood Cemetery.

From the Albany Argus. The telegraphic announcement of the removal of Collector BRONSON reached as at such an hour on Sunday evening as to preclude comment; certainly such comment as such an act of discipline, under such pretexts and circumstances, called for.

Mr. BREED, the Agent appointed to collect subseriptions for making certain im provements in the buildings of the Institution, as well as to enable the Trustees to found other Professorships, and pay more liberal salaries to the Professors.

A COURIGEOUS WOMAN-On Thursday, at Salmon Falls, a young man, who had disguised himself so as to be taken for an aged beggar, entered the house of a Mr. DUDLEY, of that place, the family being all out except Mrs DUDLEY and her child.

The Twenty-sixth Annual Fair of the American Institute closed last evening. The Exhibition has occupied a shorter time than usual. The Premiums awarded were very numerous. Gen. CHANDLER made a few remarks before the reading of the lists was commenced. He alluded to the general character of the Fair, and bespoke for the Exhibition the consideration of the public.

The news from California, which we publish this morning, will he read with very general interest. There have been no extraordinary occurrences since the previous advices-but the cheerful character of the intelligence from the mines, and the general prosperity of the country, are gratifying.

The Northern Light, Capt. THOMAS MINER, from San, Juan del Norte, vid Norfolk, arrived at this port yesterday morning, with 718 passengers, and $1,500,800 in specie. The Northern Light, Capt. MIINER, left NewYork Oct. 5, at 3:30 P. M., and arrived at San Juan on Saturday, Oct. 15, at 4 o'clock, P. M., having stopped at Kingston. Jamaica, for coals.

PORTRAITS FROM DAGUERREOTYPES.-Happening, a few days since, to be at the studio of Mr. RANSOM, in the University building, on Washington-square, he showed us a mode, invented by himself, of painting portraits from Daguerreotypes, which cannot fail to produce very important results in portrait painting. It is purely mechanical,

On Thursday, Oct. 27, EUGENE BOGART, aged 50 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from his late residence, No. 29 West 32d-st., on Saturday next, at 2 o'clock, P. M., precisely, without further notice.

We have received Jamaica papers to the 12th inst. We learn from the Morning Journal that Sir HENRY BARKLEY arrived at Jamaica on the 4th inst., and was inaugurated on the 6th as Governor of the Island. Sir HENRY succeeds Sir CHARLES GREY in that important office. The ceremony of inauguration took place at Spanish Town.

We have dates from Caracas to Sept 10, inclusive. The latest advices received at the office of the Correo de Caracas, were from New-York, July 27; Havana, Aug. 9, and Liverpool, Aug. 16. Business was comparatively brisk, with fair prices for all imported articles.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: In the last two numbers of the TIMES, reference is made by your Washington correspondent to the case of Messrs. BELCHER BROTHER in their controversy with the United States Government. As Mr. BELCHER has left this City, we, as friends and correspondents of the house. feel compelled and authorized to reply to those remarks.

We publish this morning a report of a peculiar case in the Surrogate's Court, which involves about $250,000. It is to test the legality of a will executed by the late ABRAHAM G. THOMPSON, which bequeaths a large amount of property to religious institutions, while the testator had near relatives living, on whom he bestowed but a comparatively small sum.

OLIVER WINDELL HOLMES commences, this evening, a course of six lectures before the Mercantile Library Association, at Hope Chapel, on the English Poets of the Nineteenth Century. A more attractive announcement has not bees made for years.

We published, yesterday. Mayor WESTERVELT'S veto of the resolution to increase the salaries of Policemen. Vetoes are popular now-a-days; and the Mavor has shown so thorough a determination to exert all his official power to cheek the outrageous robberies of the Common Council, that the public is disposed, without inquiry, to approve of whatever he may do in the way of saving the public money. We have files of the Kingston Morning Journal to 13th inst. The news is not of special importance. Sir HENRY BARKLY has arrived, and the Legislature was to meet on the 18th inst. This circumstance had some effect on commercial affairs, as a speedy reimposition of the tariff is anticipated.

The General Labor Convention held its regular weekly meeting in the Fourteenth Ward Hotel last evening,--Mr. EDWARD MORRIS in the Chair. Owing to the storm, there was a small attendance. After reading and approving the minutes of previous meeting, the first business in order was the report of Committee on "Address to Working Men," who report the following:

We publish, this morning, the details of the European news received per the Niagara at Halifax. The prominent features of the intelligence do not vary materially from those published in yesterday morning's TIMES; but as it is more volominous, a better opinion may be had of the present condition of things in Europe.

Our dispatches from Honolulu are to the 27th of August. The Committee appointed to consider the petition for the removal of the Ministers, JUDD and ARMSTRONG, reported on the 15th of August adversely to the petition. The popular feeling, particularly among the foreigners, who are almost unanimous, appear to run high against the Missionaries.

The trial of MICHAEL McCoy and JAMES DUFFY, charged with the murder of CATHARINE QUICLEY, in the village of Jamaica, L. L., on the 9th of the present mouth, was terminated yesterday. The investigation was held before Justices ABRAHAM D. and JOHN S. SNEDIKER, in the Court room over POLLARD'S Hotel, Jamaica.

We have a word of advice for parents who have Children at School. Your little ones are dear to you,--about as dear, perhaps, as the apple of your eye. Their success at school is near your heart. Of course, you will do nothing to interfere with it. You are anxious to help them along,...

NINTH DAY. The People of the United States against Thomas Collyer, John F. Tallman, John Germain, Edward Hubbard, James L. Jessup, James Elmendorf and Charles Merritt. Mr. GEORGE P. EDWARDS' examination was resumed this morning.

The fire last night in the Howard block on Westminister-street broke out about 11 o'clock, and has been most disastrous in its results. The Howard block was composed of ten buildings, and was the finest in the State. It was entirely destroyed.

The important Will case of ABRAHAM G. THOMPSON, deceased, of this City, is now udergoing a new investigation before the Sarrogate. The case has excited much attention among the religious community, in consequence of the effort making by the heirs of Mr. THOMPSON to set aside the Will on the ground that Mr. T. was not of sane mind at the time the instrument was executed.

SECOND DAY. The Coroner's investigation in regard to the late affray in Degraw-street was continued until a late hour at night, when the following additional testimony was taken, and the case was adjourned over to Monday next, at 10 A. M.

WHIG NOMINATIONS.-The Hudson County Convention met at NEWKIRK'S Hotel, at Bergen Five Corners, Wednesday afternoon, at 3 P.M., and nominated ISAAC W. SCUDDER, of Jersey City, for Senator ; JASPER GARRETSON, of South Bergen, for Sheriff; and JAMES S. HUTTON, as Coroner for Jersey City. The name of D S.

DEMOCRATIC NOMINATIONS.--The Hudson County Democratic Convention met at Bergen Five Corners on Thursday evening, for the purpose of nominating their county ticket. The Convention met in mass at BEATTY'S Hotel, but adjourned to the Court House.

From the Albany Evening Journal. If the Cubans choose to do what they will with their own, what affair is it of ours? If there is a plan afoot for Emancipation in Cuba, and one likely to be just and effective, then those engaged in it deserve the thanks of the Christian World.

We yesterday gave the proceedings at Jamaica in reference to the men accused of the murder of CATHARINE QUIGLEY, the case which has created so much excitement on Long Island. Another investigation in regard to the same affair was had yesterday in Flushing.

Meeting of the Free Democratic League. A regular meeting of the Free Democratic League was held last evening, at its rooms in Stuyvesant Institute--JOHN JAY, Esq., in the Chair. Mr. WM. S. KINO officiated as Secretary.

The defence in this exciting case was opened yesterday. We give a full report of the speech of the counsel for the defendants, as it gives a very full and connected statement of the points which they will seek to establish.

The Softs held their County Ratification Meeting last night at Tammany Hall. The room was pretty full, but not by any means inconveniently crowded. Among the banners displayed in the room, which were not at all numerous, was one belonging to the "First Ward Unterrified Democracy," setting forth the pronunciamento "PIERCE, SEYMOUR, MARCY and GUTHRIE will be sustained by the people."

Several very good trotting matches were announced to come off yesterday, at the Union and Centreville Courses, Long Island, which would probably have been well attended but for the inclemency of the weather. Among the list on the programme were the names of the celebrated stock, Lady Suffolk and Fanny, for $400, mile heats, best three in five, in harness.

The steamship Ohio brings us no later dates from California. The news from the Isthmus, from South America, and particularly from Australia, is of more than ordinary interest. The extracts which we publish from the Australian papers of August 18, show that the people there are ripe for revolution, and that the former predictious of our correspondent there are about to be realized.

Aid to Yale College. We gave in yesterday's TIMES a brief sketch of the proceedings of the Alumni of Yale College, at Dr CHEEVER'S Church, on Wednesday evening. The statement of the Agent of the College, Rev. Mr. BREED, presented same facts of interest. The following is a sketch of his remarks:

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--This evening AUDER'S grand opera, in five acts, of "Massaniello," will be performed for the second time. This beautiful and popular opera was produced on Thursday evening in magnificent style. The scenery, costumes, groupings, and all the adjuncts were prepared for the occasion, and gave, we are told, general satisfaction.
Lieutenants STELLWAGEN, PARKE and HUGHES, and Passed. Midshipman RENSHAW, have been detached from the Coast Survey steamer Bibb, and ordered to the Coast Survey Office, Washington.

Edward Robinson against William Wilkinson.--This is a motion to set aside the judgment in this action, upon the ground that the defendant was not served with the summons. In support of the motion, the defendant swears' that he was never served with process, or notice or intimation of any proceedings against him, until he was called upon by the Sheriff, with an execution against his property.

DEMOCRATIC NOMINATIONS.--It is generally understood that EDMOND DRIGGS has received the nomination for Mayor o Williamsburg. CALEB PINCK and DANIEL RIELLY have been nominated for Aldermen in the Second Ward, and HENRY J. HOGOLTT and JOHN C. KELLEY for Aldermen in the First Ward.

The schooner John Oliver, from Turk's Island, arrived at this port, reports the schooner Manhattan, from Baltimore for Kingston, was lost on Caicas Reef on the 1st inst. The mate and six men were loft at Turk's Island.

Mr. McMAHON, said: Before opening, the case, I beg leave to submit to your Honor one or two authorities, and one or two propositions of law in answer to the cases which have been cited very frequently by the prosecution.

The Sentinel publishes a letter from Judge BRONSON, defending himself from the charge made against him by Secretary DAVIS, that he had been an advocate of Free-Soilism, and had advanced Free-Soil sentiments in a letter addressed to a VAN BUREN meeting in 1848.
