The steamer Ohio arrived at this port last evening. Her dates from California have been anticipated by the Northern Light. She, however, brings dates from Aspinwall and Panama, to the 15th inst.; and also) later and important intelligence from the South. The news from Australia will be found of much interest.

On Thursday, 27th inst., CATHARINE JONES HARDON daughter of the late Richard Harison, Esq. The relatives and friends of the family are requested to attend the funeral services, in Trinity Church, on Saturday afternoon, at 3 1/2 o'clock.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your paper of Oct. 7, you have certain observations on "Public Scourges; their Origin and Preventives," in which you maintain that quarantine is only a prevention against diseases of foreign origin, when the city quarantined abounds in filth and putrescence; that is the penalty for defective street and health police,--and would be a use less burden and expense to a cleanly and well regulated town.

If any one doubts that this is a remarkably busy world, he will find his doubts resolved by glancing over the columns of the TIMES. From every corner of the earth important and interesting news pours in upon us in a perfect flood.

From the Washington Sentinel. Hon JEFFERSON DAVIS recently published two letters in the Washington Sentinel relating to New-York matters, in one of which he spoke of me as " having been a very few years ago the advocate of Free Soilism," and referred to a letter which I wrote in July, 1818, to a VAN BUREN or Free Soil meeting in this city.

The appointment of ALOIS D. GALL, of Indiana, Consul for Antwerp; and of JOHN DUFFY, of New-York, Consul for Galway, Ireland, are officially announced. The Union's leader on British designs in Cuba is a scathing and brilliant article.

At the Democratic Convention of Plymouth County yesterday, it was Resolved, That the removal of the Collector of New York, when he attempted to disregard the principles the union of the ?? Party, deserves, and will receive the support of all true friends of Democratic principles.

The screw schooner Isabel, sent out by Lady FRANKLIN, many months since, by the way of the ?? of Magollan, has arrived at Vaiparaiso, where, we are sorry to learn, a disagreement among the officers has led to an abandonment of the whole expedition. To the Editor of the New--York Daily Times: SIR: I am again compelled to trespass on your Food nature, by asking, through your columns, another and final response to the attacks of "Rev. B. LOCKWOOD," whose second communication appeared is the the TIMES of Saturday last.

The weather has been dull to-day, but a bitter feeling exists in business circles, in consequence of the news from Europe. Cotton is firmer, but the sales limited. In Flour, some 2,000 barrels were disposed of, at $0 50$6 87 1/2 for common and extra brands. For city consumption the demand is good. Very little has been done in Rye Flour or Corn Meal.

From the Evening Post. We understand that Mr. O'CONOR has written a letter to the President, complaining that the glory of martyrdom which has been awarded to Brother BRONSON, had been denies to him; that like the two women grinding at the mall one has been taken and the other left.

The Albany Argus speaks of the removal of Judge BRONSON as being approved by the TIMES, which it characterizes as a "Whig journal in the interest of the Administration." The Argus is professedly a party paper,--one of the ablest and most influential in the country;--and, like the journals devoted mainly to party interests, it sees and judges everything from a party point of view.

Our neighbor of the Herald has taken a new twist. Finding the organship of the Hard-Shell party neither as profitable nor as honorable as he expected, and his friends not being as prompt as was expected in raising the $100,000 needed to start him in business in Boston or Philadelphia, he has concluded to go into a new line of literature.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: GEORGE MILLER, Esq, of this village, was today nominated by the Whig First District Convention for Assembly--H. P. HEDGES, Esq., you know, having declined. MILLER is a man of first rate ability, a lawyer of as much influence as any man in the County--his character and reputation are enviable.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your paper of this morning, under the head " Cholera at Quarantine," I find noticed the arrival of the packet ship Washington, with 952 passengers on board, and also that she has had no less than 73 deaths, besides several cases sent to Qu rantine Hospital.

The newspaper pulse of this country frequently gives throbs of special significance. One who keeps his fingers on this great indicator, will be doomed to some unpleasant sensations; but take it altogether, the moral and social sentiment of the Press argues a fair average of sound health and vigor.

The Southern mail of this evening brought New-Orleans papers of Monday last, but they contain no news of interest. A telegraphic despatch from Nashville, yesterday, announces the election of JOHN BELL, as U. S. Senator, Mr. BELL received 51 votes.

Yesterday morning quite an excitement was created in the City respecting an alarming railway accident on the Hudson River road, at the Yonkers station, some twenty miles distant from New-York, from the fact of a heavy passenger train being thrown off the track.

One of the most destructive conflagrations that has occurred within the City limits during the past year, took place early yesterday morning, in the block of handsome freestone stores known as "Fowler's Buildings," at the corner of Fulton and Nassau-streets.

The consecration of three Catholic Bishops took place in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. The ceremonies were of a most imposing character, and continued from II A. M to 4 o'clock in the afterseon. At 9 1/2 A. M, the doors were opened, and in a short time every available seat was occupied. Until the procession had entered, the main aisle was kept clear, but soon afterwards both main and side aisles were crowded.

You will perceive by the accompanying papers, which I send, that quite a change has been effected in the Government of our Island. Cont. V. OxROLM has been dismissed from his office, and retires on a pension of two thousand dollars a year. His dismission was recommended by Gov. HANSEN two years ago, when the home Government was taking measures to reduce the expenses of its Colonial possessions in the West Indies.

We have received, by the Arctic, in private letters and in foreign papers, highly interesting accounts of the progress and proceedings of the Japan Exhibition, which will he found in another part of this inorning's TIMES.

?? yesterday morning, an alarm of fire was sounded for the Second Fire District, and the fact was soon made known that another fire had broke out in the warehouses at the Atlantic Docks, to which place the Fire Department and police force promptly repaired, and through their exertions the fire was comparatively confined to small limits.

CITY MISSIONARY AND TRACT SOCIETY.-On Friday, the Jersey City Tract Society had a full mceting at the First Preshyterian Church, which held until a late hour, at which the Tract Society was so reorganized as to form a Tract and Missionary Society. Rev. Mr. IMBRIE presided, and Dr. J. J. TOULIN was Secretary.

The following is the City Inspector's weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 22d day of October to the 29th of October, 1853: Men, 75; women, 62; boys, 130; girls, 136. Total, 397.

STEAM-TUG AJAX.-Captain CHURCHILL, of the schooner Kossuth, from Newburyport, arrived on Saturday, reports, on Monday morning, Oct 21, between 9 and 10 o'clock, two miles east of Pollock Reef Light-boat, spoke steam-tug Ajax, from Now-YOk for Boston. It was blowing very heavy at the time from E. N. E. to S. E., with a very heavy cross sea. She appeared to be very deep in the water,

The bark Octavia, which arrived at Holmes' Hole on the 27th inst., from Matanzas, had on board Capt. HADLEY and the crew of the schooner Independence, of Boston, front Nuevitas, bound to New-York, which vessel was totally dismasted on the 19th October, in the Gulf, and abandoned on the 21st.

By the arrival of the Mcrlin at this port from Bermuda, we learn that business is looking up at St. Thomas. The health of the Island is very good-never was more so-weather very hot and close. The steamer Medway, at St. Thomas, left Navy Bay Oct. 9 for Carthagena.

On Friday evening, Oct. 28, ISAAC L. PECK, in the 39th year of his age. At Jersey City, on Saturday, Oct. 29, JOHN KELLOG GOODMAN, Esq.. in the 78th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are requested to attend his funeral, at the Church of St. Matthew, Jersey City, on Tuesday, Nov. 1, at 2 1/2 o'clock P. M., without further notice.

The U. S. Mail steamship Arctic, Captain LUCK, from Liverpool Wednesday, Oct. 19, 11 o'clock, A. M, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, with 220 passengers aud a valuable cargo of foreign goods. Among her passengers are Hen. D. D. BARNARD, of Albany, late Minister to Berlin, Hon. STEPHEN A DOUGLAS, of Illinois, and the Commissioners from Egypt to the New-York Exhibition.

We have at last official confirmation of the rumor, announced some days since,that the Sultan had declared war against Russia. The document has reached us, and will be found in another part of this morning's TIMES.

On Friday under the auspices of the Mercantile Library Association, the Lectures of the Winter Season of 1853-4 may fairly be said to have commenced in this City. The place was Hope Chapel, the lecturer was Dr. OLIVER WENDELL HOLMES, and the subject-the first of a series of Lectures on the English Poets of the Nineteenth Century-was, " WORDSWORTH."

A business meeting of the Free Democracy was held last night in their room in the Stuyvesant Institute. Mr. JOHN JAY presided, and WM. S. KING, Jr., acted as Secretary. Mr. JAY presented an ancient record of proceedings taken between the years 1785 and 1797, which was commenced on the 25th July, 1785, at the Inn of JOHN SIMONS, for manumission of slaves.

The following changes have been ordered among the marine officers of the Navy: Major Harris, transferred from the command of the Guard at Philadelphia Navy-Yard to that of the New-York Yard; Major Edelin from Head-quarters the Marine Barracks in this city, to the command of the Guard at Norfolk; Major Dulang from the command of the Guard at New-York to that of Boston;...

A very large and enthusiastic meeting of the friends of City Reform was held last evening, at Metropolitan Hall. The movement which was inaugurated in the same place in March last, has since gone actively forward, and the gathering of last night was a further exhibition of the determination of our citizens to establish a thorough reform in the municipal affairs of the City.

NIBLO'S SALOON.--Mr. MARETZEK is entitled to the thanks of the musical public for his last production. "Masanielle," as an opera, is a novelty; as a spectacle, a creditable indication of the ambitious spirit of the management. If Mr MARETZEK fails to elicit the general support of the public.

We conclude to-day the arguments in the Thompson Will case, the first part of which was given in the TIMES of Friday last. This is, in many of its aspects, one of the most important cases that have ever engaged the attention of our Courts of Law.

On Monday, Oct. 31, of paralysis, SAMUEL CORTLANDT LIVINGSTON, aged 71 years, I month and 8 days. The friends of the family, also the members of the John-street M. E. Church. are invited to attend his funeral, Tuesday, Nov. 2, at 2 o'clock from the residence of his son-in law, Wm. H. Warner, No. 169 Amos-st. The remains will be taken to Greenwood.

Attorney-General CUSHING has written a letter to Mr. FROTHINGHAM, of Massachusetts, in regard to the Coalition, which has been submitted to the President and Cabinet, and unanimously approved hy them. It is Adamantine, out and out and completely demolishes the puerile assertion that the Administration is Free-Soil in its tendencies.

Judge EDMONDS complains, in a letter evincing a good deal of feeling, that in the refusal of his party to nominate him for reelection, is involved a denial of his right to that free en joyment of religious opinion which we claim as our birthright; and he expresses surprise that this invasion of an important principle has called forth no public rebuke.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: An article, which appeared in your paper a day or two ago is calculated to mislead the public mind with respect to the proposition presented to the Board of Education by the Normal School Committee, and it is proper to say a few words in explanation, that those interested may be rightly informed upon the subject.

The 4 o'clock express train from New--York on Monday evening, when near Barrytown, was stopped by the breaking of the forward wheels of the locomotive. The train was at the time on one of the causeways crossing the indentations of the river, with water on both sides, and just where the train was, the banks on each side were about 8 feet high.

From the Journal of Commerce. Letters have been received from England, announcing the arrival of the American Arctic Expedition, under command of Dr. E. V. KANE, U. S. N., at Upernavick, in Greenland, and their departure from thence for the head waters of Smith's Sound.

CITIZENS: I have not been able to accept any of your invitations, but I have not been neglectful of your interests in the great subjects which absorb your attention, as the public press has fully shown. I have been able from this place to shed light over the Union on the question both of the Road, and of Nebraska, which must have its effect upon all candid and disinterested minds.
Colonel BENTON, in a late letter to the people of Missouri, which we publish this morning, reenforces his previous argument in favor of what is designated the central route for the Pacific Railway.

Miss BRAMER'S narvete has led her to introduce into her amusing but credulous volumes, ancedetes which will excite no little surprise in the minds of those who know anything about the subjects of them.

STEAMERS BURNT AND SNAGGED.--Three steamers were burnt at St. Louis on the 18th inst. While the hands of the steamer Montank were burning pitch, immediately in the rear of her boilers, for the purpose of cementing her decks, the kettle containing the pitch burst, and the contents spread over the deck, which, coming in contact with the fire was soon enveloped in flames.

In the deaths of J. B. BLACHE and Mr EDWARD GOTTSCHALK, which were announced yesterday, New-Orleans loses two of her oldest and best-known citizens. Both husbands and fathers, both active business man, and men o intelligence, and courteous, agreeable manners, they had each a wide circle of acquaintances and friends among those old residents who are really, though some-what retired and unnoticed, the population of our city.

A large meeting of the German Democrats of this City was held last evening at Tammany Hall. The gathering was con??ed to the section known as "Softs." The Administration was cordially endorsed. The sentiments of the President and Secretary of State produced especial tokens of regard from the parties having the demonstration in charge.

THE DEGRAW-STREET AFFRAY. Investigation Before Coroner Ball. The investigation before Coroner BALL in reference to the late affray in Degraw-street was continued yesterday.

BROADWAY THEATRE -- it is a bold experiment to produce a play of the ancient school, and a still bolder one for a debutante to confine her powers in such a limited area. FLETCHER'S "Elder Brother" is a play essentially; " stagey." The plot is improbable ; the incidents unnatural ; the languages inflated--although sometimes epigrammatic.

MY DEAR SIR: I have carefully deliberated on your remarks in the, interview between us, in which you observed that you trusted that your nomination had not interfered with any disposition on the part of the Convention to nominate me, and expressed you willingness to withdraw in my favor if the Convention were inclined to nominate me in you stead, and your conviction that in that event I could be elected.

ATTEMPTED MURDER OF A WIFE AND CHILD.--In Kingston, N. H., on Monday afternoon, a man named JONATHAN TIBBETTS, a resident of that town, while intoxicated, cruelly maltrented his wife and infant child.

SUPREME COURT CHAMBERS. Before Judge Edwards. Mary Westerhagen by her next friend, Herman C. Van Post, to Edward M. A. Rudolph, Baron Westerrhagen, otherwise called Edward Weston.--This case, which was somewhat peculiar in its features, came up on application to annual a marriage.

We see, with pleasure, that our recently published articles on Naval Reform have attracted attention in the ?ight quarters, and are likely to create the interest in this subject which its importance at the present moment especially demands.

The following appointments are officially announced: JOHN B. MELCHIORS, of New-York, Consul for the Grand Duchy of Hesse-Darmstadt, the Elector ate of Hesse-Cassel, and the Duchy of Nassau. EDWARD BALTZEL, Buchanan, Md., Consul for Rochelle, France.

The National Democrats of Essex County met at Salem this morning, selected a Senatorial ticket, and passed resolutions endorsing the Baltimore platform, the President's inaugural, and that they await with patience the act of his Cabinet, which shall show that it means to carry out in good faith the wishes and intentions of those National Democrats who nominated and elected General PIERCE.

Government this morning received voluminous dispatches frim Commodore PERRY, giving a detailed account of his visit to Japan. The contents have not yet been made public. Advices have also been received of the favorable reception of Messrs. BELMONT and DANIELS by the Governments to which they were respectively accredited.

The bark Marmion, arrived at this port from Glasgow, reports that on Sunday last, at Cape Cod, west by south 10 miles, saw part of a wheel-box and oil-can, and other parts of a wreck belonging to a steamer--no doubt part of the wreck of the steam-lug Ajax, of New-York, already reported.

We published yesterday the proceedings had in a meeting of a Special Committee of the Board of Aldermen, upon the proposition to extend Beekman-street across the Park, and lease the lower end of the Park as a depot for City Railroads. Alderman STURTEVANT was warmly in favor of the movement, which was quite as warmly opposed by other parties.
The steamship Texas sailed to-day for Vera Cruz. CHARLESTON, Tuesday, Nov. 1. The U. S. Mail steamship Marion, Capt. WILLIAM FOSTER, from New-York, arrived at 5 o'clock this (Tuesday) morning.

Charges Against the Chief Engineer. The Committee of the Board of Assistant Alder men appointed to investigate charges preferred against the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, ALFRED CAR SON, Esq., met in the Chamber of the Board of Assistant Aldermen, at 3 1/2 P. M. o'clock yesterday. There were present Messrs. WM.. McCONKEY and J. D. PARKER, members of the Committee. Assistant Alderman TAIT was absent.

The mail as late as due is through from New Orleans. The papers contain the details of the Mexican news received from Vera Cruz up to the 21st ult. The battle between the Yucatan Revolutionists and the Mexican troops continued eight days. A reimnant of the Revolutionists had fled to the mountains.

An official notification appears in our columns this morning, of the intention of the Directors to keep the Crystal Palace open through the Winter, and to make it a permanent receptacle for such products of industry and art as exhibitors may choose to submit to public inspection.

At a meeting of the Democratic and Free. Soil Conventions of Middlesex County, held at Concord, yesterday, a coalition was formed, each party nominating three Senators, to be supported by both. A resolution was passed, declaring that insubordination and dictation on the part of a public officer, to the head of the Nation, is treason to Demoeracy, and that the course of the President in removing Collector BRONSON met the approbation of the Convention.

A fire broke out this morning on Main, between Third and Fourth-streets, consuming the grocery more of Mr. BUSTARD, and realty damaging BOST'S tobacco factory and HOUSE's Telegraph office. Loss not yet aecertained.

ANOTHER TRIUMPH OF RICH'S SAFE!--$30,000 WORTH OF WATCHES AND JEWELRY, NOT INSURED, PRESERVED IN RICH'S SAFE:-The following letter from Messrs. SALISBURY ARROWSMITH needs no comment; it shows that the confidence placed in our Safes is never misplaced: NEW-YORK, Nov. 1, 1853.

The new brig Scovill, owned by E. J. BEMIS, of f Buffalo, was lost during the late storm on Lake Huron, while on her first trip down from Lake Michigan. She was insured, with the cargo of Wheat and Flour for $15,000, partly in the Sun and Mercantile Offices of New-York. The crew managed to reach the Canada shore on the mainmast--vessel total loss.

The Festival of the Sons of New-Hampshire in this City, to-day, was a note worthy affair. A procession, nearly 2,000 strong, of specimens of the Granite State formed at the State House and marched to the Hall of the Fitchburg Depot, which had been fitted up in a magnificent manner. Nearly 1,700 persons were seated at the tables, Hon. M. P. WILDER presiding.

A short time since, a class of people known as "bar-keepers" discovered, or pretended to discover, that they were not realizing sufficient profits from the sale of certain liquors. Selling, as they almost universally do, doctored brandy, and heightening its intrinsic poison by chemical additions, they based their movement on the assertion that it was impossible for them to sell pure brandy, and live by its sale, at the rate six cents a glass.

Thirty-six deaths less last week than the week before-that is matter of encouragement and thanksgiving. Death probably threw as many darts as usual, but they may rankle for weeks or months before their victims are entered in the permits for burial by the City Inspector and his clerks.

The regular monthly meeting of this Board was held On Tuesday afternoon at the City Hall, CYRUS P. SMITH, Esq., President, in the Chair, and a quorum of members present. The minutes of the previous meeting were read and approved. A hook, called Grimshaw's Pictorial United States, was presented to the Board for their consideration by Mr. Dillingham, and referred to the School- Book Committee.

SICKNESS IN HOUSTON.-The sickness in Houston is not abating. There were seven interments on Monday, the same number on Tuesday and five deaths on Tuesday night. Mr. SCHRIMP, who has been dangerously sick, is now recovering; also Rev Mr. PETWAY and Mrs. PETWAy. Rev. Mr. CAMERON, editor of the Banner, is sick, but not dangerously. Mr. REMINGTON, known to the public by several patented inventions,

We have Galveston papers of the 19th October, and Houston of the 21st. There were a few recent deaths by yellow fever at Galveston, although business had resumed its usual activity. At Houston there were 37 deaths by lever for the week ending Oct. 19. AN INTERESTING FACT.-One of the Missionaries of tile New-York City Tract Society having supplied the crew of a vessel going to Hayti, not only with tracts, but also with some religious papers and books, the men upon their arrival there made them into a parcel, and were taking them on shore, when they were stopped by a Custom-House officer.

In continuing the ramble mentioned in my last, we passed a cluster of cabins, made of timber, brick and noggin, much like the cottages of the French peasantry. They were occupied by French habitans or acadiens. These people are poor, unintelligent and indolent; cheerful and amiable.

Messrs. W. HALL SON, NO. 239 Broadway, have favored us with following new compositions: Passed away to Heaven--Ballad by W. VINCENT WALLACE. A beautiful composition-plaintive and simple. The Dawn of Day-Serenade arranged by WM. DRESSLER. This is an arrangement from JULLIEN'S Prima Donna Waltz-the solo so widely popularized by Kenio's performance.

Another attempt was made this morning to burn down another fire company's house-that of the Resolutioa Hose, in Cherry-street, above Fifth. The early discover prevented its entire destruction. Where these things are to end, no one can tell. In the Criminal Court, to-day, sixteen lads, ranging from 12 to 16 years, were arraigned for running with fire, companies. In the Tenth, Eleventh and Seventeenth Wards of Baltimore, the majority for LIGON, Democrat, for Governor, is 329--a Whig gain since last year of 204. WALSH, Independent, for Congress, gains in the same Wards 370. It is reported that WETHERED, Whig, for Congress' gains largely in Baltimore County.

NIBLO'S SALOON.-- The third performance of "Masaniello" attracted an overflowing house. Mr. MARETZEK has now struck the right vein, and if he will but exercise his own correct judgment, there is nothing to prevent the ensuing season being prosperous to a proverb. We have seldom seen NIBLO'S Theatre present so handsome an appearance as it did last night.

DEATH OF JOHN K. GOODMAN.-The funeral of the late JOHN K. GOODMAN, who died on Saturday last, was attended on Tuesday. He was born in Hadley, Mass., in 1776, and died at the age of 77. He came to Jersey City in 1802, when there were but three families living within the limits of Jersey City-then known as Paulus Hook-and those families lived in one house.

The cargo of the brig Martha Washington, from Malaga, was offered at auction to-day. Casks of blue mark Sun RAISINS brought $11 50@$11 75; boxes of Bunch Muscatels, $3 20@$3 22 1/4; halves do., $1 70@ $1 75; quarters 85c @90c. Boxes Layers brought from $3@$3 87. Only a portion of the cargo was sold.

Thirteen hundred thousand dollars will probably be disbursed from the New-York SubTreasury to-morrow, and nearly nine hundred thousand in payment of United States Stocks bought by the Treasury Department; the balance in ordinary business. It is estimated that over a million of stocks will be received and cancelled at the Treasury Department this week.

Two meetings were held in Metropolitan Hall yesterday, under the direction of the young men of the M. E. Church, pursuant to the following notice: A Missionary demonstration will be given at Metropolitan Hall, on the afternoon and evening of Wednesday, November 2, under the direction of the Young Men of the M. E Church in this City.

The trial of the officers and owners of the steamboat Henry City. charged with having caused the deaths of the persons killed by her taking fire was concluded yesterday,-and a verdict of not guilty was returned by the Jury, after an absence of less than half an hour. 'The charge of Judge I?GERSOLL, which was clear and able, together with the closing remarks of counsel. will be found in our columns this morning.

SAD AND FATAL MISTAKE-A MAN KILLED BY A HUNTER.-On the 25th ult., two young men were hunting in the woods of Sparta Township, Crawford County, Pa., when their attention was attracted by the sight of a moving object, about thirty rods distant, which they supposed to be a deer. One of them drew his rifle, but it twice missed fire.

We learn from good authority that our neighbor, the editor of the Herald, is about to commence a suit for libel against the DAILY TIMES: and that he has kept sundry legal gentlemen hard at work for several days in preparing the documents. In what the alleged offence consists we are not aware, nor do we know whether he' complains of damages to his character or circulation.

From the London Examiner. Among the telegraphic dispatches of yesterday morning (Friday) is one from Smyrna, announcing that the Hungarian KOSZTA left on the 23d ult. for the United States, with the consent of the Austrian Government. Another telegraphic dispatch, bringing the latest news from the United States, tells us that the Ministers of England and France arl said to have declared verbally to

The Free-Soilers had a gathering at Fanenil Hall last night, at which the letter of CALED CUSHING, ill opposition to the coalition, was attacked with great ferocity. The Times declares that the speech of the President of the Norfolk County Democratic Convention was incorrectly reported; that he did not declare that the President favored the coalition.

There is nothing of special interest stirring today, that could possibly please your readers, except the fact that boys are no longer to be permitted to run with, or after, fire apparatuses. This was decreed by Judges of the Court of Sessions this morning. One of our public school-houses took fire this afternoon in South took, through some gross negligence. Fortunately, the children had just left the place. Damage, slight.

Our War Literature increases. There is no end to the words that describe stirring times. We have an abundance of panoramas, presenting the great cities, the great rivers, the great waterfalls; and we have a profusion of books, that tell the stories of great captains and great armies.

One of the most important questions that American citizens are now called upon to consider is, How shall the masses who are flocking to our shores from the Old World be reached by Christian influences, so that their coming shall he for the good and not the injury of our institutions?

The national picture painted by W. H. POWgLL, of " The Discovery of the Mississippi," is still on exhibition at the rooms of the Academy of Design. This pictures as undertaken by order of Congress. It is intended to occupy vacant space in the Rotunda of the Capi ol at Washington. There are seven companion pictures, all illustrating events in American history. The Adamantine Democracy assembled in large force at Metropolitan Hall, last evening, pursuant to the following call: NATIONAL DEMOCRACY--GRAND DEMOCRATIC DEMONSTRATION--Clinton and the Speedy Enlargement of the Canals.--Democratic Republican Electors of the City and State of New York, friendly to the usages of the parts, and in favor of regular nominations, are invited to attend a Mass Meeting,...

New-Orleans papers of Friday last are received. Mexican advices state that General GADSDEN is getting along smoothly with SANTA ANNA. It hid been agreed that neither American nor Mexican troops shall occupy Mesilla Valley while negotiations are pending. Good feeling is represented to prevail towards the United States Government.

A special meeting of the City Reform General Committee was held evening at the University, for the purpose of taking action in relation to Ward Nominations. The Fourteenth Ward Reform Nominations were disposed of after considerable trouble, and a good ticket was recommended for the suffrages of the citizens in that district.

You will have heard of the death of FRANCOIS ARAGO. If you have not received any notice of his life, the following brief sketch will be in time. He was the son of a teller in the Mint of Perpignan, and was born in 1786. In 1802 he was at the Polytechnic School, and voted " No" upon the question of making BONAPARTE Consul for lifean action requiring no little moral courage.

At Yonkers, on Wednesday, Nov. 2, P. W. PADDOCK in he 56th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Friday, Nov. 4, at 2 o'clock P. M., at St. John's Church. At Westchester, Nov. 2,1853. WALTER, son of Henry and Janet Stoddart, aged 13 months.

I was glad to be told that somebody in your office protested against it, though you published it afterwards, and videlicet, notwithstanding, as I believe is the legal phrase in circumstances of that kind.

GADSDEN, our Minister, is getting along smoothly with this Government. It is agreed that neither American nor Mexican troops shall occupy the disputed territory in the Mesilla Valley, while negotiations are pending.

The Elecion is generally conceded to the Democrats. The Democratic State ticket is elected, but the Whigs have undoubtedly carried hith branches of the Legislature-thus securing the State Treasurer and U. S. Senator. The Whigs gain 4 Senators and 10 Delegates. The Congressmen Elect are JOHN K FRANKLIN, Whig; JACOB SHARER, Dem.; JOSHUA VANSANT, Dem.; HENRY MAY, Dtm.; W. T. HAMILTON, Dem.; A. R. SOLLERS, Whig.

Russell Sturges and Nicholas McCarty vs. The Ship Kate, her apparel and cargo.--Kirke Furniss, Clainants.--The libel alleges that the ship was worth $30,000, and her cargo $15,000, and demands salvage for bring her in from sea, to one-half the value of ship and cargo

The Free Soil and Democratic Conventions of Worcester County met at Worcester to day, and some curiosity was felt as to the influence of the CUSHING letter on the Democrats. A dispatch from Worcester says that a coalition was formed with entire unanimity and great enthusiasm. The following ticket was nominated: ISAAC DAVIS. J. W. MANSUR, ELISHA MURDOCK, AURIN BUGBEE, and JOSEPH WHITMAN.

In addition to the information contained in the Havana correspondence of the DAILY TIMES, and the official statements made at Washington, concerning the scheme now on foot for the Africanization of Cuba, we have received fresh and conclusive evidence of its reality, in a document recently published in London, which has just come into our hands.

COUNTY TEMPERANCE SOCIETY.--It is contemplated by the friends of Temperance in Hudson County, N. J., to form a County Temperance Society; and a committee consisting of Dr. Condit, Rev. Mr. Ayres, and Mr. Taylor, of Jersey City: and Rev. Mr. Thomas, of South Bergen, were appointed to consider the expediency of forming such a society. It has also been determined to hold Temperance meetings regularly, in Jersey City,

I learn to-day that $806,000 of the Stocks included in my dispatch of yesterday, is part of the old Holland debt of the corporate cities of this district, assumed by Congress in 1836. The money goes through MATTHEW MORGAN. Esq , of New York, to Amsterdam. Only $24,000 of this corporate debt now remains. $120,000 of Stocks were received at the Treasury Department to-day.

"D. O. MORTON, Esq.-Sir: Feeling that

The future of Texas was never more hopeful than at present. An abundant crop of all the products of the country has been realized, and all the supplies of the farmers are commanding remunerating prices. With the exception of a few places on and near the sea coast, which have been visited by yellow fever, the health of the State has been, as usual, quite good.

To the citizens of the Eighteenth Ward: On the 31st of October I, for the first time, saw my name in nomination for School Commissioner by the City Reform Committee of your Ward. I have never met with that Committee, nor was I consulted in relation to my name being put in nomination. I have not been notified by the Committee that I was nominated, or asked whether I would accept the nomination.

Owing to the vast number of candidates, the counting of the votes proceeds very slowly, and the returns of the city are not more than half in. LIGNON, Democrat, for Governor, will have over 3,000 majority in the city, but the balance of the State ticket Swill not be so large. In the Third District, VANSANT (Dem.,) beats PRESTON 99 for Congress,-with the County to hear from.

The exciting anti all-absorbing examination of the firemen charged with the murder of DOUGHERTY concluded to-day, in the decision of Judge MANCHESTER, before whom the case was brought in the Court of Magistrates. The evidence was finished on Wednesday afternoon, and the intervening time has been occupied by the counsel for the defence and prosecution.

THE LATE RAILROAD ACCIDENT.-The investigation relative to the death of PETER HENDRICKSON, who was killed on the Long Island Railroad a few days since, has been concluded. The Coroner's Jury have rendered a verdict that no blame can be attached to the Company or employes.

At a late hour last night, the City Hall bell sounded an alarm of fire for the Eighth District, which was found to be on board of the beautiful steam ferry-boat James Rumsey, lying at the foot of Barclay-street, North River. This vessel has for three or four years past been regularly plying between this City and Hoboken, for which route she was expressly built by Messrs. STEVENS, the Owners of the ferry.

FATAL ACCIDENT ON THE HARLEM RAILROAD.--Coroner HILTON held an inquest yesterday at Bellevue Hospital, upon the body of a man named TIMOTHY KEEFR, who died at that Institution yesterday, from the effects of injuries received on Monday night by being run over by a train of cars on the Harlem Railroad. It appears from the evidence, that on Monday night the deceased attended a political meeting in Sixty-second-street,

M. MAILLEFEET'S operations in HellGate have lately been brought to a close for this season, and this gentleman is now on a professional tour to the South. A considerable number of heavy charges have been fired this year upon " Pot Rock," and we are informed that the last survey shows a most satisfactory progress of this interesting and highly important work.

The meeting of the Democratic Hards, last night, at Metropolitan Hall, was a large and enthusiastic gathering. The spacious building was well filled, several speeches were made by gentlemen of distinction in the political world, and the proceedings were very spirited.

DEAR SIR: After a passage lengthened by three weeks of clams and head winds, we are to day about 100 miles S. S. W. from Callao. We left Port Phillip Heads, July 15. I left Boston the 18th of February last, arrived in Melbourne May 20, and remained there till July 3--a little over two months.

It was a suit brought by a colored mean for his freedom, and the Jury gave a verdict in his favor. We give the facts of the case.

When one mentions the French school of Painting, through what a bewildering variety of styles does one's wander! of a surety the French are as fickle in their pursuit of Art, as they are in their chase after Liberty. Paris has been as many total Art-revolutions, as governmental ones, which is saying a great deal.

Certain of the London press state most emphatically that at the conference at Warsaw the other say, between the Emperors of Russia and Austria, and the King of Prussia, NICHOLAS offered to Prussia an additional slice of Poland on condition of siding with him on the Turkish affair.

A Presbyterian Church has been organized in Bridgeport. Conn., with eighty two members. It is connected with the Presbytery of New-York. (Old School) Rev Dr. HEWIT was installed as poster over it. On the same occasion, Oct. 31, Dr SPRING, Dr. ?? Dr. SPENCER, Rev. Mr. WELLS, of Williamsburg, and Rev. J. E. ROCKWELL, took part in the exercises A lot for a church edifice has been given,

Our State Legislature met on Monday, and adjourned to-day, after short but apirited session. By a strict party vote, the bill authorizing the call for a State Convention to revive the Constitution became a law. The vote in the House was 36 Ayes to 21 Noes, and in the Senate the bill depended upon the casting vote of the Governor.

After tossing upon a rough sea, through a night overcast with clouds, we reached this city, so cherished by the people of South Carolina. But little shipping meets the eye; at least the masts seem few and slender to one accustomed to fling a glance along the wharves of New York.

GORTSCHAKOFF is very far from popular with the Russian army in the Principalities. The Russians Commissariat is said to be wretchedly managed, whilst the Turks have abundance of everything. OMAR is busily employed in organizing corps of ponteniers, but may not attempt to cross the river, for some time to come. A contract for 6,000 horses had been made in Persia, for the Turks.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. "But the gentlemen were wrong in their whole broad view of this British West India trade question. JACKSON took the WASHINGTON ground, and they were both right. LEMON PIES.--A lady tells the Agriculturist how to make four lemon pies. Grate the peels of four lemons, and squeeze the juice into the crated peel. Then take nine eggs, leaving out half of the whites, one pound of loaf (or white) sugar, half a pound of butter, one pint of cream (or of milk,) and four tablespoonfuls of rose-water, and beat them well together, and add the lemon.

WALLACK'S THEATRE--Mr. BOURICAULT'S new comedy was produced here last evening. Since its production on the London boards it has undergone considerable revision, and, we may add, improvement. It may be assumed as a postulate that all modern five-act comedies would derive improvement by undergoing a similar operation.

DEATH OF AN OLD TEACHER.--Three weeks ago, says the Boston Transcript of Monday, we published an account of the presentation of a silver pitcher and sal ver to Dr. NATHANIEL S. PRENTISS, formerly master of a Grammar School in Roxbury, by a number of his old pupils. We are now called upon to record his death, which event took place at West Cambridge on Saturday last. Dr. PRENTISS was 87 years of age.

EXECUTION OF A MURDERER.--THOS. BOARD, convicted of the murder of the PARKER family, was executed at Richmond, Va, on the 1st inst. When the trap was knocked from under him the rope broke. and the unfortunate man fell heavily to the ground. Much excitement followed.

Its contents comprise one article entitled "The situation," which we give entire, as it touches particularly upon the scheme to Africanize Cuba that has lately arrested the attention of our Government and Press:

HEINE.--HENRY HRINE, the German poet, has for many years past been struck with paralysis. His limbs, his body, his features, even to his very eyelids, are lame, and to all purposes like those of a dead man. Indeed, it may be said that life only lingers on the brain anil tongue--the man is a mere corpse--the poet alone survives. An exile from his country for many long years

The returns so far are meagre, but indicate a decided triumph of the Whig and Reform tickets for Municipal officers. In the Second Ward, AMOE J. WILLIAMSON (Whig and Reform) is elected over DODGE (Hard) by 35 majority.

ADDRESSES BY REV. DRS. TYNG AND ADAMS. The Tenth Annual Meeting of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor was held yesterday evening in the Chapel of the University, Washington-Square--JAMES BROWN, Esq., presiding. About 150 persons were present. The proceedings were commenced with prayer by Dr. DE WITT.

MESSRS GALES SEATON--Gentlemen: I send you a letter just received from Fort Massachusetts, in the Valley of San Luis, head of the Rio Grande del Norte, which came to me as unexpectedly as if it had fallen from the clouds, and could not have been more acceptable if it had been from any other put on the globe.

My friends, dear readers, are the "first people in the City," and so, of course, we "attend the first Church." You know better than I can tell you. what it is that constitutes the "first people" and the "first Church " The building itself is a mass of free stone, granite and marble, put to gether in much a way as to cost as much as possible.

DEATH FROM BURNS.--The Corner yesterday held an inquest on the body of Ann McArdle, about 20 years of age, residing in North Tenth near First-street, who died the evening previous in consequence of burns received by her clothes taking fire while in the act of removing a kettle from the stove.

SUDDEN DEATH IN THE CARS.--This morning, Mr. J. E. TESCHEMAKER died in the Medford train of cars, while on his way to this city. He was seen to falter soon alter the cars left Medford, and died almost instantaneously, it is supposed of disease of the heart, as he was subject to attacks of that disorder, which was probably brought on in the present case by his burrying to reach the train.

THE NEW CAPITOL AT NASHVILLE, TENN.--The editor of the Charleston Advocate, in a letter from Nashville, Tenn., thus speaks of the new building now erecting by the State in that city. The Capitol, one of the most magnificent buildings in the world is now nearly completed. It is built of solid limestone, quarried near the hill on which it stands, and covers exactly an acre of ground.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I cut the following from your weekly issue of June 25: THIS HOT WEATHER.--This is really hot weather. How others bear it, we don't know--we find it beyond bearing.
The Star of the West has arrived, and details of the California news of fifteen days later (which was given in outline telegraphically on Monday, from New-Orleans,) are received.

Yesterday morning, Coroner GAMBLE held an investigation at the New York Hospital, concerning the recent stabbing affair in South-street, near Dover, which resulted in the death of a young man named DENNIS COLLINS, who was wounded in the ab omen by a dirk in the hands of a sailor, named THOMAS MURPHY.

"UNCLE TOM AT BARNUM'S."--The grand moving panoramic scene, of the Mississippi river, in the "Uncle Tom" at Barnum's Museum, should immortalize the artist. The audience seems to sail down the river, on the steamboat, while the shore, its people, its houses, , glide away.

Protest of Dr. Harriot K. Hunt--No. 2. Our readers can hardly have forgotten Dr. HARRIOT K. HUNT, of Boston. Mass., the lady who created something of a sensation in the Tabernacle, in this City, during the Woman's Rights mania. Well, she gave the tax-gatherer fits last year, and now she is into him again with renewed vigor. She is a real, genuine, strong-minded woman.

In San Francisco, Sept. 30, Mr. Eli Myers, aged 40 Years. In San Francisco, Oct. 3, Ellen, daughter of Mr. John Nightingale, aged 14 months. In San Francisco, Oct. 1. Joseph, son of Mr. Edmund Wainwright, aged 8 years.
PASSAIC COUNTY.--Price's (Dem.) majority for Congress is 134. For Assembly, Philip Rafferty, Dem., Charles H. May, Whig and Temperance. and John J. Larue, Dem., are elected.

To the Editor the New-York Daily Times: The following "General Order" appeared in the Washington Union of the 23d October. GENERAL ORDER. Navy DEPARTMENT, Oct. 17, 1853. No application for a revocation or modification of enters from any officer of the navy ordered to report for duty at any place or station will be considered or replied to by the Department, until such officer, if able to travel, has reported in obedience to such order.'
The Installation of Right Rev. Dr. LAUGHLIN, the newly consecrated Bishop of Brooklyn, took place yesterday, in St. James' Cathedral, Jay-street.

THE ACT FOR THE PREVENTION OF CONTAGIOUS AND EPIDEMIC DISEASES.--The act of Parliament under which the order in Council respecting the cholera was issued, passed on the 4th of September, 1848. It is entitled "An Act to Renew and Amend an Act of the 10th year of Her present Majesty, for the more speedy removal of certain nuisances and the prevention of contagious and epidemic diseases."

The English Darlen Canal Company, organized in London last year, with a capital of $75,000,000, or 15,000,000 sterling, under the auspices of Sir CHARLES FOX, HENDERSON Co.; have sent an agent, Dr BLACK, to Washington, to solicit our Government to send an engineer to the Isthmus, to verify their reports and estimates, for the satisfaction of the American people, whose good wishes they are anxious to secure for this grand undertaking.

The complete triumph of the Reform ticket in our City election, is of good omen. It shows clearly that the people may be relied upon to redress public wrongs, in spite of party bonds, and all the corrupt influences which interested villainy can bring to bear upon them.

The returns from the interior come in slowly--owing, doubtless, to the multiplicity of candidates. The telegraph, however, worked badly all day yesterday, and consider ably delayed the receipt of intelligence.
By the mail of this evening, we have received New-Orleans papers of Wednesday and Thursday last. The ship New-York, from New-York, made the run to Charleston in 55 hours.

The recent rupture between the President and a portion of the Democracy of New-York has other lessons than those directly connected with the relations of party elements. New that the election is over, it may be well for us to indulge in a little newspaper moralizing upon the philosophy and history of party organizations.

THE ADMINISTRATION AND THE SPEAKERSHIP. Perceiving in a Washington letter, in the Baltimore Sun, an intimation that the Administration are about to have their candidate for the Speakership, we may as well say again that all such stories are without foundation.

Turkish return began with SALIM III. In 1789--an eventful European year. This Sultan especially endeavored to change the system of the Turkish armies, which the adverse formers of his war with Russia had prosed to be so interior to their enemies.

THE ELECTION --The following are the names of the persons elected on the City and Ward tickets: Mayor, Wm. Wall, Whig; Street Commissioner, L. A. Coles. Whig; Collector, Fordyce Sylvester, Dem.; Counsel, John Dean, Dem.; City Clerk, Wm. G. Bishop, Dem.; Treasurer, Minor H. Keith, Dem.; Comptroler, J. W. Burden, Dem.; Cells Keeper, A. N. Doxay, Whig ; Justice of the Pause, Jacub L. Fenn, Whig.

DEATH OF P. S. WARFIELD.--The New-Orleans Picayane announces the death of PERRY S. WARFIELD, Esq.. of the New Orleans Bar. He committed suicide on the 30th ult., at the Maison de Sante, in that city, whi?? laboring under inseaity. He was 34 years of a infant ?? was highly esteemed in New-Orleans.

No question is of more importance to the people of the South, and indeed of the whole Union, than the destiny of the Island of Cuba. It has been rapidly increasing in interest for several years, and looms largely in the future as the most momentous and perhaps perilous that can arise. Every intelligent mind feels that it is indisaolubly connected with the fortunes and fate of our country.

I have reason to believe that now that the election is over, extensive changes will be made in the New-York Custom-House. Whigs in office will be generally removed; and any Hard who may be found to have voted for COOLEY will be summarily beleaded.

Later from Rio de Janeiro-Debates in the Chamber of Deputies--General Intelligence. We have dates from Rio to September 22, inclusive. The health of the city was much improved.

Nov. 9.--Charles R. Reed vs. Robert L. Tayler.--This is an action for seaman's wages, brought against defendant for service rendered on board the ship Harkaway, on her voyage from the port of San Francisco to Cullao and the Chincha Islands, for guano, and to return to Hampton Roads for orders.

The arrival within the last fortnight, both from foreign and Eastern ports, have been very heavy, and at the present moment our market is completely glutted with every specise of merchandise. scarcely one single article of which will leave a margin of profit to the shipper.

From the Washington Union. We commented at home length on yesterday upon the position at present occupied by the National Intelligencer on the question so intimately connected with the future destiny of Cuba. It is refreshing to turn from the anti-American views of that journal to those of the New York TIMES, which are characterized by that singleness of American patriotism which will meet a cordial response in the popular heart.

The canvass for Speaker or the House of Representatives has already commenced at Washington. The Washington Star states that the President and his Cabinet will take no part in the contest, nor seek to influence its decision in any way.
Our neighbor, the Herald, is getting dissatisfied with his political alliances. He wants a new party created and lays down the platform for its organization.

BURIAL OF PROFESSOR BUTLER, MURDERED BY MATT. F. WARD -- The funeral of WILLIAM H. G. BUTLER took place yesterday morning. The impressive services were performed by his personal friend and warm admirer, Rev. Mr. HEYWOOD, of the Unitarian Church, who portrayed his many virtues with fidelity, and referred very briefly, but with powerful effect, to the circumstances attending his most melancholy death.
No man can doubt that there has been a marked change during the present year in the public feeling of this country towards England.

The steamship Star of the West, Capt. E L. TINALEPAUGH, arrived about midnight, front San Juan evening of Slet ult., with 600 passengers, and $1,299,644 in gold, on freight, and $480,000 in heads of passengers, to CHAS. MORGAN. She ..rings San Francisco dates from Sierra Nevada to 6 P. M. Oct. 16.

The common mechanics of our City or in rather a tight place. Mayor WESTERVELT, it Will be remembered, says $600 a year is more than the "best of them" earn. If that is what they average, as a class, very tight squeezing it must be for them to get along.

NIBLO'S SALOON.-Mrs. BOSTWICK's second Concert last evening was attended by a good audience. For some reason unexplained the programme was entirely changed. Three of the artists specified in the list did not appear at all; while the remainder operated with a beautiful indifference to the public expectation.

I have not written for some weeks, because nothing of any interest has been received here by myself or others from the country westward. This morning, however, I am in receipt of letters from the Upper Missouri and Pembina, in the Selkirk Settlement.

PANTHER, OR COUGAR, SHOT AT LEE.--On Tuesday last, as Mr. WILLIAM P. CHAPMAN was hunting for foxes near Lee Hill, in this county, his dog went on it track which brought the gunner in view of an animal of large size, in a tree.

" UNCLE TOM " AT BARNUM'S.-It is indeed a treat to witness so grand and so useful a work as that of Mrs. STOWE. brought out and popularized in the saperb style, and with such exquisite scenery, as we find at BARNUM's Museum.
New-Orleans papers of Friday last are received. The story of 6,000 Mexicans marching on El Paso is considered very doubtful, as that number of men could not be mustered in that region so quickly.

In a late number of the London Leader there is an exceedingly interesting' and able letter from the United States. It is mainly devoted to the New-Jersey Fourierites, but includes in general criticisms on our society.

By the arrival of the United States Mail steamship Franklin, JAS. A. WOTTON, Commander, we have received our usual files of Journals, together with correspondence of four days later date from London, Paris, Havre, Liverpool, and Southampton, than brought by the Africa.

One of the numerous murder cases that fill the docket of the Criminal Courts was decided yesterday by the acquittal of the prisoner, CHARLES THOMAS, who was put upon his trial for the murder of MICHAEL LAWLER, in May last.
Two Exciting Trotting Matches at Union Course, Long Island--The $6,6000 Trotting and Pacing Match--A Hundred Miles to be Trotted in Nine Hours for Several Thousand Dollars.

The "Independent Opposition Line's" steamer America, D. C. MITCHELL commanding, from Aspinwall, N. G., with 250 passengers, to E. MILLS, arrived at this port at an early hour this morning. The America left Aspinwall on Tuesday, Nov. 1, at 12 o'clock, and arrived at Kingston, Ja., after a run of 53 hours.

It is understood that Secretary GUTHRIE is in favor of the reduction of the duty on Iron of all kinds to 25 per cent. ad valorem. It is said that he will also recommend that Salt, Dye Stuffs, Mahogany, and other furniture woods, raw Silks, crude Drugs and Fruits, be put on the free list.

Nothing is talked of to-day but the manifesto of the Emperor of Russia, of which, however, no authentic particulars are known. Nevertheless, certain expressions a alleged to be contained in it are repeated in so many quarters that it is not easy to reject the reports on the subject as wholly devoid of foundation.

PROPOSALS FOR CITY RAILROADS.-The special Committee on Railroads met on Wednesday evening, at the City Hall, to examine proposals for city railroads. Present, of the Committee, Aldermen DAYTON GRAHAM, WILSON, HINMAN and REMSEN. Fifteen proposals were presented by the City Clerk to the Committee, of which we annex a brief outline.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : I like your expression, '' credulous volumes." It is gentle and brotherly, and perhaps describes better the character of this new book than the stronger epithets we and your other correspondents may use.

Some devotee of statistics has recently computed that Southerners have spent $5,000,000, the past Summer, in Northern travel. Whether this estimate is approximately correct or not, we have no means of ascertaining.

I hereby appoint Thursday, the 24th inst., as a day of Thanksgiving, for the people of the State of New York. I recommend its suitable observance by such religious assemblages and forms of worship, as our citizens may severally deem appropriate; so that we may, as a Commonwealth, with united hearts, humbly and gratefully render thanks to our Father in Heaven for His benefits, and earnestly implore the continuance of his favor.

The steamship George Law, JOHN MCGOWAN, Esq., commanding, left Aspinwall at 101/2 o'clock on the evening of the 31st ultimo, and arrived at Quarantine at 71/2 o'clock yesterday. She beings the California mails of Oct. 16, which were anticipated by the Star of the West, 465 passengers, and $672,821 in tressure on freight.

To the Editor of the Daily News: SIR: The period has now arrived, to which I stated, in a letter published two mouths ago, the negotiations would be prolonged. My statement was made with perfect assurance-an assurance justified by the result.

The CORN Market at Mark-lane, on the 24th wlt., was only moderately supplied with English WHEAT, and the improvenient noticed in the previous Friday's market was fully sustained. The factors commenced by asking a very considerable advance upon the prices of the 17th wlt,, and eventually a clearance was effected at a rise of 2s, to 3s. quarter on the rates of that day.

We gave yesterday the leading features of the intelligence received at San Francisco from the Sandwich Islands, by the brig Boston. The San Francisco Herald states that the appointment of Hon. E. H. ALLEN, in place of Dr. JUDD, is considered a great advance towards the annexation of the Islands to the United States, as Mr. Allen is the avowed champion of annexation.

The late Agricultural Fair and Cattle Show, held at Richmond, Va., was attended with unusual interest. The closing address was delivered by Ex-President TYLER, and presents so graphic and pleasing a picture of Virginia prospects, that we copy it entire: GENTLEMEN OF THE AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY: On me has devolved the task of uttering to you the valedictory address of the Executive Committee on this interesting occasion.

SUPREME COURT-OVER AND TERMINER. Before Judge Edwards. Charles Thomas, a stout built young man aged 21 years, and a native of the Kingdom of Hanover, was at to the bar charged with the murder of Michael Lawler on the 24th of May last, at a grocery store in Madison. street, by stabbing him with a knife.

Their Excellencies are obviously not in working humor since the election. Alderman STURTEVANT,

Gen. LEAVANWORTH, the Whig candidate for Secretary of State, seems to have survived the assaults made upon him by a brace of Wall-street papers, on the false charge of having aided to break up a Law and Order meeting in Syracuse.

Front the San Francisco Herald. Having been induced to try my luck in Australia by reading the bright and glowing reports given of its mineral riches, and being once again in California, I will give the result of my Australian experience and observations.

THE McDONOGH ESTATE.--The New-Orleans Picayune of Wednesday last says that the executors of JOHN MCDONOGH have filed in Court their third annual account of this large estate. As much of the property consists of wild lands, which are as yet unproductive, the receipts of the estate are much smaller than is generally supposed.

The news by the America at Halifax is interesting. There are reports of engagements on the Danube between the Russians and the Turks, but there is no reliable news of anything beyond slight skirmishes. It is rumored that further efforts will be made to reopen negotiations, but there is nothing authentic on this point.

THE NEW MOTOR--THE ERICSSON ENGINE.--It will be recollected that the caloric ship Ericsson returned from her trip to Washington about seven months ago, and that immediately thereafter essential modifications and improvements in the plan of the engine were determined upon.

It is quite probable that Secretary GUTHRIE, in his desire to simplify the Custom-House business, as well as to reduce the revenues of the country, will recommend the division of duties into two classes only, instead of three, as I suggested recently.

We had the pleasure yesterday evening of meeting of Mr. THEODORE WITHROP, of New York, direct from Puget's Sound, via Salt Lake and Independence, where he arrived, with the United States mail, on the 29th ult., looking as hearty and fresh as mountain men usually do.

The late news from the Sandwich Islands is very interesting, foreshadowing what we may expect in that quarter. The Islands, whose population is gradually dying out, are gravitating toward the United States, and will eventually be peopled with our race.

The Freeman's Journal expresses its cordinal approbation of the State Superintendent's recent decision on the right of teachers to compel the children of Catholics to read the Bible in our Common Schools, and adds: We believe that education, left to voluntary action, would be better taken care of than by State interference.

A meeting of the inhabitants of the Tower Ham letu, London, Captain MAYNE TEID presiding, was held to sympathize with Turkey. Mr. COBDEN, on the 25th, addressed the Mechanics' Institute at Barnsley, proposing as a model for imitation, the educational operations of the United States.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Last evening we had "I Puritani." The cast was the same as on its first production; the attendance scarcely so good, but more than an average one. Of the performance we may be brief. Signor BIENEVENTANO sang with remarkable finish and excellence.

A telegraphic dispatch published in the Paris Maniteux, dated Bucharest, 25th October, states that two Russian steamers with eight gunboats forced the passage of the Danube of the 23d, and encountered a brisk fire from the Turkish fort of Isaktchi, between Reni and Ismail.
Very general interest has been excited by the announcement, lately received in England, that the fact of the Northwest Passage, from the Atlantic to the Pacific Oceans, has been established.

Dr. JOHN DREW, one of the Council of the British Meteorological Society, has been commissioned by Dr. SCHONBEINto introduce to English observers his simple method of ascertaining the amount of ozone in the atmosphere. That gentleman's ozonometer is in general use throughout Germany, and he is naturally anxious that corresponding observations should be taken in this country.

In the Fifteenth Ward, although the Reform Charter ticket is elected by a plurality of over seven hundred, E. C. BENEDICT and Dr. BEADLE, are reelected Commissioners, and R. L. KENNEDY, Trustee of Common Schools, by a majority of not far from one hundred and fifty.

IMPORTANT INVESTIGATION. Selzure of Gunpowder on Board a Barge In the East River. BEFORE HIS HONOR MAYOR WESTVELT. On Saturday last, Fire Warden Crossin seized 788 quarter, and 32 halt kegs of gunpowder, on hoard the, barge Easton, lyling at Pier No. 4, East River, fort of Broad street. TO THE PUBLIC--"UNCLE TOM'S CABIN."--The following communication appears to be so calm, just and lucid a criticism upon a subject of popular interest, that we feel no hesitation in placing it before the public: NEW YORK, Thursday, Nov. 10. 1853.

ILLEGAL VOTING.--Officer HIGGINS, of the Chief's office, and deputy Sheriff HULTZ, on Thursday arrested MICHAEL CLARK, for voting illegally on Tuesday last. The accused voted five different times in the Second, Fifth, and Eleventh Wards. He was committed to answer.

The extreme probability of war in the East may render the following details upon OMER PASHA, the Sultan's best general, slight as they are acceptable. OMER PASHA is an Austrian by birth, being a native of Croatia, where he was born in 1801.

The following are the official dispatches of Capt. McCLURE, of the British ship Investigator, which has succeeded in discovering the Northwest passage, to the British Admiralty. We shall continue their publication as rapidly as possible until their completion:
The Royal Mail steamship America, Captain LANG, From Liverpool on Saturday, Oct. 29, arrived at this port, en route for Boston, between 9 and 10 o'clock this forenoon, She brings 126 passengers.
With the progress of the Chinese rebellion a doubt also makes progress, as to what may be the effect of that movement on the ethics of the empire commercial as well as religious.

I cannot learn that the Government has received any official advices relative to the recent developments in the Sandwich Islands, but there is a growing opinion here that the question of annexation will soon be forced upon us. The Minister to China's instructions are completed.

Projects of Uhurch Extension have lately engrossed much attention from the Christian community. During the year, four of our largest religious bodies have devised plans for the purpose, and are busy in executing them. To-morrow, that upon which the General Assembly of the New School Presbyterians have fallen, is to be presented in all the churches in their connection.

There was a large attendance at Union Course, L. I., Yesterday, to witness the match for $6,000. ten miles out, between Mr. H. WOODRUFF'S e.g. PRINCE, (trotter,) and Mr. GEO. SPICER's g. g. Hero, (pacer.) A good deal of interest was manifested, though there seamed to be little doubt as to the result.

Brooklyn, Williamsburg, and Bushwick, have given a very large majority in favor of Consolidation. They have done well. The union which will now he consummated in 1855, has long been desired by those most interested in their prosperity; and has not, of late, been opposed by many, other than those whose individual speculations and interests caused them to view the general good through the medium of personal advantage.

Public Recognition of the West Twenty-third-street Baptist church. The formula of publicly recognizing the religious association known as the West Twenty-third-street Baptist Church, was performed in Knickerbroker Hall (where this Church now worships) last evening. The interesting occasion brought together a large number of those interested, both lay and clerical.

The position of affairs is unchanged. It is now reported that the Czar will rather back out of the Principalities than fight there. This is surmised to be the purport of the reply sent by Russia to the request by France and England to evacuate the Principalities.

The Moniteur publishes an important editorial, indicating that the French Government will be firm in its support of Turkey. Disturbances had occurred in some of the provincial Corn markets. Commercial circulars attribute the continuous rise in Wheat to the greater demand for seed this season.

VAN NAME, all of Staten Island. On Thursday, Nov. 10, at Calvary Church, by Rev. Charles Tomes, EDWARD BURCKHARDT, to MARY ELIZABETH, daughter of Francis Tomes. Esq., all of this City.

Gen. PIERCE seems to have fallen into the position of his predecessor, Mr. POLK, and to be laboring with the same difficulties. Both were elected by a kind of sudden accord between different fractions of the Democratic party, none hoping to carry their own candidate, and all therefore waiving their peculiar desires for the sake of a common compromise.
FIREMEN'S PARADE-To-day the annual parade of the Williamsburg Fire Department takes place. The procession will move from the corner of Eighth and South Sixth streets, at 1 o'clock P. M.

At Brooklyn, on Saturday, Nov. 12, of consumption, ROBERT-WENDELL TRUILL, youngest son of the late Capt. J. O. Truili, aged 25 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral on Monday,

We have received dates from Utah Territory to the 1st of October. The Deseret News of that date contains an address by BRIOHAM YOUNG, giving his peculiar views on the variety of sentiments held by the inhabitants of this earth, including the Latter-Day Saints. JOHN M. HERNHISEL was elected delegate to Congress, on the first Monday in August last.

The third Lecture of this popular course was delivered on Friday night, at Hope Chapel, to a crowded audience. There were not seats for all who attended, and chairs anal stools had to be sought for out of the building, and distributed about the aisles. Many persons stood, notwithstanding all efforts at accommodation, and there were listeners stowed away behind the organ.

The yellow fever has made its appearance at the mouth of the Brazos. A railroad convention met at Mount Enterprise, in Rusk County, on the 10th ult., the delegates in attendance being from Rusk and a few neighboring counties. The object of the convention was to secure the speedy construction of a railroad through this State on the parallel of 32??, to constitute a portion of the Pacific road.

It is deemed not improbable that Mr. SEV-RANCE, the United States Commissioner to the Sandwich Islands, has already negotiated a ticaly of annexation to the United States. My letters, published last Spring, it will he remembered, indicated that his instructions left him full discretion in the premises.

A female, aged 20 years, was brought under the influence of chloroform lately, with intention of using the " actual cautery" on her, at St. Bartholomew's Hospital. The drug was administered by Dr. BLACK, but scarcely had the operation commenced, when the pulse grew faint.

The installation of Rev. THEO. L. CUYLER, the newly appointed pastor of the Reformed Dutch Church, in Market-street, took place last night, in the presence of a numerous congregation. The service was opened by Rev. Dr HUTTON, who, after singing, prayer, and the reading of a psalm, preached a sermon from the text--"We have this treasure in earthen vessels, that the excellency of the power may be of God and not of us."

Public feeling is much excited to-day, by the Russian manifesto, which Government will not allow to appear in our journals. Some violent passages from it were yesterday quoted on 'Change, and produced great consternation among speculators.

Twelve months ago, during a conversation be tween several sporting gentlemen, a match was made of $3000 to $1000, that no horse in the Northern part of the United States, could be produced within one year, that could trot one hundred miles in sine hours.

As there have been various rumors respecting the election of District Attorney for the City and County of New-York, we have obtained the following official vote from the County Clerk's Office, which, it will be observed, gives NATHANIEL BOWNITCH BLUNT, our present able and talented public presenter, a majority of three hundred and thirty eight, instead of 80, as was first announced.

ARREST OF AN ALLEGED ACCOMPLICE IN THE SHBRBORN MURDER.-A man by the name of NOYES MANN, formerly a near neighbor of Mr. REUBEN COZZENS, of Sherborn, (whose brutal murder in September last will be remembered) was arrested last evening at the Long Pond Hntel, in Natick, by Deputy Sheriff BANNISTER, on suspicion of being an accomplice in the murder, for which CHAPMAN is now in custody.

THE CHEROKEE NATION.--MESSAGE OF THE PRINCIPAL CHIEF--The Fayetteville Independent Published the annual Message of JOHN ROSS, the Principal chief of the Cherokee Nation, to the National Council. He says that the year which has elapsed has been one of manifold blessing,; the seasons have been propitious to the tillers of the soil, and the footsteps of pestilence and famine have been for removed from their borders. Hea al.

BURGLARY.-House No. 107 Henry-street was entered a few nights since by thieves, and robbed of about $140 worth of silver ware and jewelry. James W. Stone, arrested some months since for dealing rather freely with the property of livery stable keepers, has been discharged upon his own rocognizance--the complainant, Mr. Hendrickson. having died.
The elections in this State have gone in favor of the Administration candidates by a large majority. The delegation in Congress will all be of the same politics, from present appearances.

The steamship Isabel arrived here early this morning, from Havana and Key West, bringing dates from both places of the 8th inst. There is some political excitement in the Island. The revolutionary paper, Voxdel Purbla, had been again published.

SUICIDE OF A FORGER IN PORTLAND.--We learn that Mr. ARNOLD WENTWORTII, of Green, Me., Was brought to Portland on Tuesday, charged with forging several Pension certificates, and was taken before the United States Commissioner on Wednesday. He waived an examination, and was bound over in the sum of $5,000 to appear at court yesterday. In default of bail he was committed to jail.

Among the novelties of the day, Theology turns out two newly developed Societies, having their location in this City, and preparing to diffuse their light throughout the Union The first of these is the "Southern Aid Society"--an organization intended to promote the spirit of Home Missionary effort; a field hitherto occupied by the American Home Missionary Society, but now enlarged so as to embrace the entire area of the Southern States.

FIRE-A stable belonging to the Misses WILSON, in the rear of their residence in Bergen, near the Railroad, was destroyed by fire on Thursday evening. It was valued at about $300. Noinsurance. Its contents, to the value of about $100, were also destroyed. It was probably set on fire.

Hon. CHARLES SUMNER is addressing an immense assemblage of Free-Soilers, this evening, at Faneuil Hall, in favor of the proposed new Constitution Several hundred ladies are in attendance, and nearly fill the galleries.

The Cleveland Plaindealer says the rifled mail-bag, found in a wheat-car in that city, a few days ago, has been forwarded by the Assistant Postmaster to Indianapolis. It was the through mail from New-York to Indianapolis, and the presumption is that it was picked up from the platform at Galion, and made way with by the thief, It was thrown from the train on to this platform about 12 o'clock at night.

On Monday morning, Nov. 14, 1853, ELIZA M., wife of William A. Darling, in the 35th year of her age. The friends of the family, and those of her father, Gen. Daniel Lee, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, on Wednesday. 16th inst, at 2 o'clock P. M., from her late residence, No. 231 West 19th st., without further invitation. Her remains will be taken to Trinity Cemetery.

HEAVY ROBBERY OF GOLD DUST.--Thirty boxes, presented to contain gold dust, were recently shipped from San Francisco for this City, via Panama, consigned to the American Exchange Bank. Upon arrival here they were forwarded to the Mint for coinage, where it was ascertained that two of the boxes were filled with bullets and shot an adroit robbery having been effected, probably while the boxes were in transitu.

From Vienna we have rumors of contemplated risings at Milan and elsewhere in misgoverned italy. As these reports are Austrian in their origin, and are evidently intended to do mischief. we refrain from transcribing the vague statements that are made in the " Austrian" papers.

Letters by the Overland Mail convey intelligence of the lamentable wreck of a British ship supposed to be the Lady Euclyn, and a fearful sacrifice of life. she was a line vessel, recently built, 748 tons burden, commanded by Captain M'LELLAN, and was the property of Messrs. HERRINGS, of Liverpool.

Right Rev. Dr. PONSONBY, Lord Bishop of Derry and Raphose, died on the 28th, at his palace, Derry, in his 83d year. His successors not known. Lord CLONCURRY is dead, aged 81. He is succeeded in his title and estates by his eldest son, Hon EDWARD LAWLESS.

The first note of war which fell so ominously on the cars of Europe, has been as rapidly exchanged for a note of peace. The last three days have brought reports from the Danube, announcing successively an engagement and an armistice,--the "commencement of hostilities," and the conclusion of a trace.
The U. S. Mail steamship Baltic, which left Liverpool at about 10 A. M., on Wednesday, Nov. 2, arrived at this port at noon yesterday, with 174 passengers and a full cargo.

The Baltic steamer, from Liverpool, November 2, arrived early in the forenoon. Her mails were delivered several hours in advance of those brought to Boston by the America and not received here until after business hours. The market accounts, though, in some respects, not so favorable for American interests as the previous advices, produced a good effect on Wall-street.

Our telegraphic dispatches yesterday conArmed the intelligence we had previously published, of renewed disturbances and arrests in the Island of Cuba. Until the Isabel's mails shall have been received, we cannot, of course, be in possession of all the details.

The storm throughout this State was very severe yesterday. The railroad track east of here was washed away, in consequence of which the train from Boston, with the America's mails and passengers, was detailed. The nature, extent, and whereabouts of the damage, are not vit known here.

The ship Stornoway, Capt. HENRY L. HART, which arrived at this port yesterday, has beaten the American ship Challenge on the voyage from China to England. The Stornoway left Whampoa on the 14th of July, and Macao on the 15th of July. The American ship Challenge sailed from Whampoa for London on the 13th of July, and has not yet arrived.

The most terrible freshet that ever occurred in the Naugatuck River, visited our valley last evening. We had a heavy storm of rain on Saturday night and Sunday morning, hot no more thin we have experienced in this part of Valley many times without causing a flood, and what has caused such a rise in the river we are unable to say.

"UNCLE TOM" AT BARNUM'S.--All fair and non-?? critics admit that Mr. CONWAY's version of "Uncle Tom," performed at Barnum's Museum, is one of the most beautifully adapted to dramatic peculiarities and dramatic effects that genius could possibly orginate. It is full of lively incidents, and overflowing with life, spirit, genuine pathes, and irresistible humor. The scenery is the best, most varied, and perfect ever witnessed upon the stage.
