On Thursday, Nov. 17, SARAH JEANETTE, daughter of J. M. and M. M. Browning, aged 2 years, 9 months and 2 days. The friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral on Friday, at 3 o'clock, at the residence of her father, No. 53 Laight-st. Her remains will be removed on Saturday morning to Hudson for interment.

TURKS ISLAND.--A bark belonging to Messrs. HUGHES TODD, which arrived on Monday last, at Salt Cay, from Bonaire and Curacoa, reports no salt at either of those islands. The Captain states that is reported at Curacoa and other islands, that the ponds are inundated, and that not a bushel of salt is to be obtained at these islands.

The columns of the TIMES this morning present the complete particulars of disastrous conflagrations which occurred in this City early yesterday morning, The destruction of the Empire Iron Works, at the foot of Twenty-Fourth-street, on the East River, and the burning of an entire block of factories

Two terrible conflagrations, attended by immense losses of property, occurred in this City at a very early hour yesterday morning. We have seldom been called upon to record a calamity which has plunged so many persons into ruin and distress, without actual loss of life, as has been the case in these instances.

In the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets we have to report a continuance of the dullness that has been so long their prevailing characteristic, buyers becoming daily more reserved; while in many instances more disposition has been shown to realize, and lower prices have been accepted. We have no material change to notice in the MONEY market, nor in the state of Foreign politics;

A force of Russians was dispatched to the assistance of the town, when an engagement ensued, and after considerable slaughter on both sides the Turks retreated.

The People vs. Louis De Corn, indicted for the Murder of Eugene Melville.-In this case, the Jury agreed upon their verdict at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. At 51/2 o'clock messengers were dispatched to summon the Court and Counsel, and at 6 P. M. the Jury came into Court and answered to their names in the usual manner.

From the Albany Evening Journal. The resolution providing for an amendment of the Constitution so as to secure an early completion of the public works, must be ratified by the incoming Legislature. This will be done, undoubtedly, during the first week of the session. Afterward, a law must be passed, submitting the proposed amendments to the people, "in such manner and at such time as the Legislature shall prescribe ;

A day or two since we copied from a Memphis paper a statement to the effect that there had been an affray on the steamboat Dresden, near Helena, Arkansas, in which two were killed and three others wounded, An esteemed friend, who was a passenger on the Dresden at the time of the occurrence of the affair, arrived here on Saturday afternoon on the Pike, and furnished us full particulars of it.

WOMAN SHOT IN TROY.--While tile Whig torch-light procession was passing through the principal street of West Troy, opposite the planing-mill of Messrs. ROUSSEAU EASTON, a night watchman, named JAMES TEMPENNNY, in their employ, who was standing in the second stone doorway of the building, discharged a revolver, loaded with slugs, in the direction of the procession. The ball struck a house opposite, doing no damage.

In pursuance of a notice published in the daily papers, the friends and opponents of the project of allowing the Harlem Railroad Company to lay a rail-track in Crosby, Elm, and' Bleecker-streets, assembled at 4 P. M. yesterday in the library-room of the City Hall. The Committee on Streets of the Board of Assistant Aldermen were in attendance, consisting of Messrs. WHEELAN, ROGERS, and MCCONKEY.

To the Editor of the N. Y. Daily Times : The readers of your paper have seen with surprise the account of a recent match against time which was trotted last Saturday upon Long Island. The fact is astonishing--100 miles in 8 hours, 55 minutes and 53 seconds. The sporting world will not soon grow weary of talking of it.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I hope the influence of your Journal will be exerted to give notoriety to the flagrant attempt of the Police Department to evade the force of public opinion. The public have demanded that the Police should have a distinctive uniform, and the Department after a long delay, promised to make the reform. And whit is the result?

Hon. LINN BOYD is here, and aspires to the Speakership again. He will be a formidable candidate. JAMES ADAMS, of Massachusetts, Consul to Singapore. has resigned. VOLNEY E. HOWARD has resigned the Government Law Agency, for the California Land Commission.

FOURTH DAY. The fourth day's session of the Board of County Canvassers was held yesterday, at the City Hall. At the opening, the Chair was occupied by Supervisor CORNELL, of the Seventeenth Ward, but before adjourning he was relieved, at times, by Supervisor DOHERTY, of the Nineteenth Ward, and Supervisor WARD, of the Fifteenth Ward.

A hundred guns on the Uommon have sounded the knell of the New Constitution, sym bolizing its end--in smoke. Boston and the counties have rejected it by a majority (as appears just now) of about 5,000. In the matter of the State election, WASHBURN has got about 10,000 votes 1ess than the Democratic trio. BISHOP, WILSON and WALES, put together, and over 24,000 more thin the highest, BISHOP.

A SHORT VOYAGE AROUND THE GLOBE.--The iron screw steamer. Argo, recently arrived at Southampton, Eng., has been round the globe in 128 days. She was 64 days on her passage from Southampton to Melbourne, via the Cape Cood Hope, and occupied the same length of time in returning, via Cape Horn. She is completely ship rigged, and has an auxiliary steam power of 300 horse. to be used in adverse winds and calms.

The judicial investigation respecting a charge of arson, pending against a tea dealer in the Eighth, avenue, who is accused of setting fire to his own store, was commenced yesterday, before Mayor WESTERVELT. The first witness on behalf of the prosecution, who was in the employ of the defendant as clerk, was called.

About four months ago, JOSEPH PRICE absconded from the service of his employer, Mr. JONES, a silk-merchant in Raven row, Spital fields, taking with him a large sum in gold and notes. The thief contrived to elude every attempt that was made to effect his capture; but a suspicion being entertained that he hall gone to America, information was despatched to the Chief of the NewYork Police.

After an unaccountable pause of three quarters of an hour, the firemen present began to display symptoms of impatience.

On the morning of Nov. 18, CHARLES LEMUEL, only child of William 11. and Francis A. Tupper, aged 1 year, 1 month, and 7 days. The funeral will take place on Sunday morning, at 9 o'clock, from the residence of his parents, No. 253 7th-st. The friends of the family are invited to attend without further invitation.

BARNUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.--Two Performances daily.--Uncle Tom's Cabin in the evening. ACADEMY OF DESIGN, No. 663 Broadway.--Powell's National Painting of the Discovery of the Mississippi.

A remarkable fact in Natural History is developed by Professor AGASSIZ, in the November number of Silliman's Journal--viz.: the existence of fish producing lining young. Mr. A. C. JACKSON, a gentleman attached to the Navy. Yard Commission on the California coast, while fishing in San Salita Bay, caught with the hook and line a fish of the perch family containing several young, properly developed and lively.

By the courtesy of Mr. DE Bow, Superintenident of the Seventh Census, I am enabled to present to your readers some interesting facts from his work, now in press, which I believe have not heretofore been given to the public.

SCHOOl-HOUSE ON FIRE.--There was an alarm of fire yesterday afternoon, about 4 1/2 o'clock, occasioned by the taking fire, near the register of the furnace, of the floor in one of the lower rooms of the school-house in Market street. The fire did but little damage. There was a very dense smoke, however, which rendered the excitement among the children greater than it otherwise would have been.

DEAR SIR: I have received your communication requesting my opinion upon the resolution of the Common Council reducing the rest of the Wall-street Ferry, and have the honor to report: The lease for that Ferry was granted on the 10th day of June, 1852, for ten years, at the annual rent of $20,000 per annum, to commence 15 month from that date, subject to the power of the Common Council to regulate the.

CHURCH ERECTION.--The floods that so plentifully poured upon the seaboard last Sunday, prevented the Presbyterian Churches in our vicinity from taking up the intended contributions for the $100,000 fund. We understand that the cause will be presented in these Churches to-morrow. The delay will probably be of service.

Refore His Honor Mayor Westervel:. The investigation of the seizure of Gunpowder on board the barge Easton, lying at the foot of Pier No. 4, East River, was resumed before His Honor the Mayor, at 1 P. M.

CONFOLIDATION--THE OFFICIAL VOTE.--The Board of Commissioners of Consolidation met at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, in the old County Court-room, County Jail. The Chairman announced that he had received the full returns of votes cast in the different districts, for Consolidation, at the election on the 8th inst, Commissioner SLOAN moved that a Special Committee of three be appointed to examine the returns and report immediately--Carried.

Sloppy, drizzling weather brought a smaller audience than usual to Hope Chapel last night. The subject of Dr. HOLMES' lecture was KEATS. We thought the lecturer was not so happy as on former occasions. The Coruscation's of his wit was less brilliant and we were not struck by anything original in his remarks. He commenced by saying that there were two spring tides in the lives of men who lived out their full time.

ANNIVERSARY OF THE BIBLE SOCIETY.-The Hudson County Bible Society will hold its first Anniversary on Wednesday, the 30th inst., in Jersey City. In the afternoon of that day, there will be a public meeting of the Society. In the evening ihe anniversary exercises will take place, including the reading of the report of the Managers, and the delivery of Addresses.

YOUNG MEN'S NATIONAL DEMOCRATIC CLUB--ADDRESS TO THE NATIONAL DEMOCRACY.--A regular meeting of the Young g Men's National Democratic Club was held last evening at its Rooms in Stuyvesant Institute. The only important business transacted was the reception and adoption of an Address to the National Democracy, which we have not room to publish. The Address allades to the results of the recent election,

Though not possesing the numerical power and strength which distinguishes many of the sects commonly designated as " Evangelical," the Unitarian denomination in the United States occupies a position in respect to the learning and elevated moral character of its Ministers, and the intelligence, wealth, enterprise, and personal worth of those connected with it, which is hardly excelled, if, indeed, it be equalled, by that of any other reli?? organization in the country.

DEAR BROTHER: It is now a twelve month since I grasped your hand and gazed for the last time (perhaps) upon the faces of my friends; and when I think how numerous and varied have been the scones through which I have passed, and how very long it has been since I have enjoyed with any one whom I could regard with respect

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: I found, on looking at the TIMES, of the 17th November, that my name was mentioned as a candidate for the office of Commissioner of Jurors. I am not a candidate, and was very much surprised to see it so renorted. as it was without my consent or knowledge.

The arrangements recently made by the Postmaster General for carrying the mail twice a day between Mobile and Montgomery, on the great Southern Mail route, will, it is hoped, put an end ere long to the vexatious failures at that point. The country through which this route passes is very poor--too poor, indeed, to support a population sufficient to keep the road in repair. The contractors agree to repair the roads, bridge the streams,

We have already called public attention to what, as at present advised, we must consider the extraordinary proceedings of Mayor WASTERVELT in regard to the resolution, of the Common Council reducing the rent of the Wall-street Ferry from $20,000 to $5,000 per annum ;-and we propose to repeat our references to the subject until some explanation of it is tendered to the public.

We understand that Mr. MARCOLETTA, the Nicaraguan Minister, was presented yesterday, and duly recognized. He made some extemporaneous remarks on the occasion, to which the President responded in appropriate terms, extending a cordial welcome. The State Department are advised of Gov. VROOM's arrival at Berlin un ler favorable auspices, though he had not been formally presented, owing to the absence of the ling.

HORRIBLE MURDER OF A SLAVE--HIDEOUS CRUELTY.--THOMAS MOTLEY has been convicted at Alterborough, S. C., for the murder of a runaway slave. It was proved on the trial that the monster first shot and then whipped the slave; after which he put him in a vice and tortured him.

In one of the Continental papers we have from Helsingfors (Russia) an account of an electro-magnetic machine for the capture of whales. It is exhibited at the establishment of Mr. JULIN, an apothecary at Abo. It was invented by the celebrated Dr. JACOBI, of St. Petersburg.

We have received additional tables of the Census of 1850, the study of which has a good deal interested us. From one of them which exhibits the relative rank of the States, and their increase and decrease, we educe some curious facts. New-York is shown to take the first rank in population, as she has done since the Census of 1820.

SERIOUS ACCIDENT ON THE CINCINNATI, COLUMBUS, AND CLEVELAND RAILROAD.--Amelancholy accident happened to a construction train yesterday on the Cincinnati, Columbus, and Cleveland Railroad. It was one of those mishaps which human foresight cannot protect against.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Will you tell me what is the use of the Post Office? On Sunday, the 13th, a letter was mailed for me at Dobbs' Ferry, and I got it this morning, Thursday, the 17th, informing me of an important appointment for this day, at some distance. Of course it is too late.

THE NEWTOWN INCENDIARY FIRE--ARREST OF FOUR YOUNG MEN.--On Wednesday evening last the barn of SMITH ADAMS, of Newtonville, was set on fire and totally destroyed. Before this fire was put out, a wooden building to JAMES M. COOK, but a short, distance off, was set on fire and totally destroyed.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--There will be no operatic performance this evening. The preparations for the production of " The Prophete," impel the manager to sus pend further entertainments until Wednesday, when it will be produced. Unless the rumors which have reached us are unfounded, there can be but little doubt that this chef d'oeuvre of MYERBEER will prove as triumphant and profitable here as in the old country.

A large number of workmen were employed during Saturday afternoon and Sunday in widening the truck, putting down the switches, and making other preparations at the Paterson depot and the Bergen cut, which enabled the first through train on this wide track to leave the Jersey City Depot for Dunkirk last evening.

At Paris the sack of flour (157 kilogrammes.) which used to sell for 50 francs now costs 98, while Government quotes it at only 95. It is still rapidly rising. The rye, the almost exclusive food of the Breton peasantry, has rotted in the field, owing to the heavy rains of the early days of October.

The indications of the meeting of Congress, a fortnight hence, are quite manifest. The President and heads of Departments, with their clerks, are busy early and late, preparing their messages and reports; the guardians of the Capitol, hotel keepers, and landladies, are painting and furnishing their apartments anew; and the beau monde, and citizens generally, are preparing for this annual relief to the monotony of Washington Life.

The mission of Gen. D'HILLIERS with a staff of officers, whose presence at Constantinople would, under any other circumstance, of itself alone be sufficient cause of apprehension and offence to Russia, has produced wide-spread sensation an indicative of a warlike intention on the part of LOUIS NAPOLEON, who is, moreover, on the point of replacing his present minister at the Court of St. Petersburg by another military man, Gen. CANROBERT.

The new Christian Reformation in Turkey is one of the most important as well as interesting movements of our times; yet I have no where seen an account of it in the American press. To have originated a religious republicanism in the midst of Asiatic Turkey, you will admit, Mr. TIMES, to be a most honorable testimony, not only to the religious zeal, but to the powerful influence of America.

The financial question is still the all-absorbing subject that occupies the Sultan's Ministers, and the appointment of SAFATY PACHA seems to convey the idea that the desire of the Divan is to adopt important measures relative to financial matters at once, and to bring itself in closer contact with Europe, from which it had unluckily broken off ever since the Loan affair.

SINGULAR SOLUTION OF A MYSTERY.--Thirteen years since, in the vicinity of pittsburg, a man, who was involved in one difficult , suddenly disappeared, and the citizens supposing that he had drowned himself, dragged the river to find his body.

A meeting of the Fourth Presbytery of New-York was held in the Fourth-avenue Presbyterian Church, on Saturday afternoon, to take into consideration, for a sec ond time, a letter addressed to it from the Winchester Presbytery, of Virginia, on the subject of Slavery agitation. The attendance was small.

THE SPEECHES OF KOSSUTH.--"KOSSUTH'S speeches," says the London Athenaeum, "seem to us unique. To say that there is nothing like them in our literature, is little-we know of nothing like them in any literature. They unite two worlds. When they deal with facts, logic, figures, they are as clear, solid, businesslike, as an exposition by an English Chancellor of-the Exchequer should be, or the message of an American President.

Teniat, who was injured by being run over by defendant's cars.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: There are yet in existence, and scattered through the length and breath of our country, many of those who were active participants during the last war. Then they were in the morning of life, fresh with the vigor of youth, and ready when the summons came to take up arms, and bravely defend the cause which they had espoused--the cause of liberty.

Return towards the North--Life on a large Plantation--Treatment of Negroes--Shooting Slaves--Conversation with an Overseer--Flogging a Slave for shirking work. SPECIAL CORRESPONDENCE OF THE N. Y. DAILY TIMES. After a voyage up Red River, and a week spent in some of the cotton plantations of that district, I proceeded to Vicksburg, with the intention of visiting Central Mississippi and the Yazoo cotton region.

About one-fourth of our native-born Citizens leave the States of their birth, and settle in other portions of the Union. Virginia has seat out 335,000; South Carolina, 163,000; North Carolina, 261,000. Among the Northern States, Vermont and Connecticut have contributed the largest share of their population to colonize other sections.

The Board of Police Commissioners sat at 2 o'clock on Saturday. Present-His Honor Mayor WESTERVELT and lion. Judge BEEBE. The charge against BARNARD MCFARLANE, police officer of the Sixth District, for violent conduct, was called up and dismissed, the parties net appearing. The case had been left over several weeks, and each time the parties failed to appear.

FUNERAL OF MR. ATHERTON.--The remains of lion. CHARLES G. ATHERTON, of Nashua, N. H., lite U.S. Senator, were yesterday afternoon consigned to their final resting place. During the ceremonial the places of business throughout the city were closed, and the streets bore the impress of mourning.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: From an article on subjects of Naval interest, in the TIMES of the 17th, we find paraded a list of our Steam Marine, with as much pomp and circumstance as if, indeed, the display of the names of these seven steamers were enough

The Murder record was lessened on Saturday, by the conviction of HOARE, for the murder of his mistress, and the sentence of DE CORN to the State Prison. The statement put in by DE CORN is given, in full, in our paper this morning, and will be read with a painful interest.

DR. DOREMUS' SECOND LECTURE. The same audience as before, with enough in addiction to all the Chemical Lecture-Room of the New-York Medical College, greated the appearance of Professor ?? at precisely 7 1/2 o'clock on Saturday evening. He commenced by recapitulating the arguments and ?? of the first lecture. Chemistry teaches that the world has not always been in its present condition.

INDIAN CLAIM TO NORTHERN VERMONT.--There is now in attendance upon the Legislature of Vermont, in session at Montpelier, a deputation of Iroquois Indians, to press a claim to a considerable portion of the State. The Springfield Republican says the claim is no new affair. It was presented first in 1786, and has been renewed at frequent intervals since.

PROCLAMATION.--Mayor LAMBERT has issued his proclamation, Requesting the good citizens of Brooklyn to observe Thursday, the 24th inst., as a day of thanksgiving and prayer, in accordance with the request of the Governor of the State.

Hoare, for murder of Susan McAnanny, and the sentence of Louis De Corn, convicted of manslaughter in the third degree. At the silting of the Court-- Mr. Smith addressed the Jury in behalf of the prisoner Hoars, at considerable length.

The "Journal des Debats," of Paris, reasonably distrusting the mass of contradictory correspondence which flows into Western Europe from the East, has sent M. XAVIER RAYMOND, one of its ablest collaborateurs, to Constantinople for the express purpose of ferreting out the plain truth in regard to the state of things at the Ottoman Court and Capital.

FEMALE STEVEDORES.--On the banks of the Miami Canal may daily be seen females of German de- . scent engaged in unloading and loading boats. They are said to be able to do almost as much work as common laborers, and they receive nearly the same wages.

SERIOUS ACCIDENT ON THE CLEVELAND AND TOLEDO RAILROAD.--Yesterday a freight train for the West upon this road met with a serious accident nar Oberlin, the result, as nearly as we can learn, of carelessness upon the part of the engineer. The train consisted of the engine and one locomotive, which was being carried over the road, and of thirteen cars.

HOME FOR THE FRIENDLESS.--Our readers wil see, in another part of our paper, a notice of the donation visit to the Home of the Friendless, on Thanksgiving Day; and we hope it will not be forgotten by " those whom the Lord hath prospered." Every Institution of this kind is a saving to the City, in snatching victims from the prisons and alms-houses, besides doing a noble work of Christian benevolence and moral elevation.

Alderman Sturtevant in the Chair Mr. MOORE presented a petition from the students of the Free Academy, asking that a portion of Hamilton-Equare may be set aside for their use as a cricketground, until such time as the said park may be graded and laid out for public resort.

FROM SOUTH FLORIDA.--By the Jacksonville News, of the 5th instant, we learn that the yellow favor was on the increase at Tampa. Fifteen of the garrison had died from its effects, and the disorder had broken out among the citizens. Capt. CASEY, the United States Indian Agent, had arrived with authority to offer the Indians larger sums of money then were offered by General BLAKE, to induce them to emigrate;

The Annual meeting of the New-York Bible Society, auxiliary to the American Bible Society, was held yesterday evening in the Church of the Puritans, (REV. DR. CHEEVER'S) Union-square, at 7 1/2 o'clock. In the absence of H. K. BULL, ESQ , the President of the society, the Chair was occupied by E. M. KINGSLEY, ??., Vice President. The audience was slim.

Yesterday afternoon, the sporting amusement of the Turf was rather dull at the Union Course, Long Island, which was in consequence of the inclemency of the weather. The trotting matches announced to come off on this track, were as follows: Nov. 2., at 1 1/2 o'clock P. M., a match for $400, mile beats, best 2 in 5, in harness; WM. WHEELAN named b. g. Emigrant. HIRAM WOODRUFF named s. g. Congo.

A Parliamentary paper recently published, relative to the Australian colonies, contains an in teresting notice of the emigration that has already taken place from the maritime provinces of China, and of the capabilities and tastes which would fit the Chinese for settling in our tropical possessions.

At length the Ohio River is rising slowly, and has become navigable for large steamers above and below Louisville. The falls, or rapids, however, are still an almost impassible barrier. Today, the first steamers, of a very light draught, passed over the falls; but many more, that have been waiting here a long time for a rise, are still detained-- this being only a rise of about three feet.

A telegraphic dispatch dated Bath, Nov. says: "The ship Mains, FREEMAN, from Liverpool 21, for Bath, went ashore on Saturday morning, on Island Bar, during a heavy gale and for. She now on her broadside, and nothing can be done to save any portion of her cargo, as a heavy sea in running. If the ship holes together, and wind changes to northwest, a part of the cargo may be saved."

We are unable even yet. to present complete official returns of the recent election. In the table below, the vote for Secretary of State is, we believe, full and correct. The others are from reliable sources and are doubtless accurate. They are not, however, complete.

On Monday morning, Nov. 21. JANE, wife of David Morrison in the 48th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend he funeral, from her late residence, No. 428 Broome-st, on Wednesday, 23d inst., at 1 1/2 o'clock without for invitation. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

Yesterday was All Saints' Day-La Fete des Morts--and it became every one's duty. and especially a correspondent's, to visit Pere La Chaise. Having spent three hours in that City of the Dead, under a warm Indian Summer's sun, and having noticed sundry things worth telling, let me briefly detail the appearance of the cemetery on the Holiday of the Dead.

The investigation of the seizure of gunpowder made on board the barge Easton, on the evening of November 5, was resumed before His Honor Mayor WESTERVELT at 9 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning. Mr. DODGE, who appeared on behalf of the owners of the barge, addressed His Honor.

Hon HARVEY M. WATERSON, of Tennessee, has returned to his former posstion of assistant editor of the Union. A meeting of the Inventors' Protective Union was held at the Pantheon. No. 343 Broadway, yesterday afternoon. The meeting was called to order by HAMMOND HONE Esq., of Cincinnati, who suggested in consequence of the absence of the President, an adjournment till evening to No. 13 Crystal Palace.

LIBERTY FIRE ENGINE COMPANY No. 1.--ANNUAL BALL AND PRESENTATION.--This Fire Company held its fourteenth Annual Ball at the Hudson House, last night. It was largely attended by the gay and fashionable, and passed off in remarkably good style. ADKINS'S Cotillon Band was in attendance, and discoursed the music. Dancing commenced at 9 o'clock.

On Monday Nov. 14, the Biennial Session of the Alabama Legislature commenced. No sooner had the Senate organized, than Senator KELLY offered a " bill to exempt certain property from execution." Said hill provides, that in addition to property now secure from levy and execution, "one hundred bushels of corn" shall be intact from official hands.

FIRE--This morning, between 3 and 4 o'clock, a fire broke out in the building (known as the old Methodist Church,) on the corner of Union and Methodist streets, occupied by Messrs. T. M. J. H. ALLYN, as a piano manufactury, and by the Sons of Temperance as a Division Room. The building was burned to the ground with its contents.

SHARP PRACTICE.--The Cleveland Herald thus undertakes to explain how the verdict of "not guilty" was obtained in the case of the men recently tried in the United Circuit Court at Columbus for defrauding insurance companies by the burning of the steamboat Martha Washington: The defence brought on about three hundred witnesses, and made an imposing display in administering the oath to this array.

WARD THE MURDERER.--A letter from Louisville to one of the Cincinnati papers states that the WARD murder case continues to be much talked about in the former city. many idle tales being originated in reference to it. On Friday evening it was reported that MATT WARD had escaped by dressing in the clothes of his wife, and passing the guards with his sister, unsuspected.

FOUR CHILDREN BURNED TO DEATH.--On Friday night, the 4th inst., three houses, situated at the west end of the village of Paris, in this Country, were burned to the ground; and, melancholy to relate, four children of Mrs. MORROW--two boys and two girls--perished in the flames.

The National Intelligencer of Monday discuses with a good deal of solemnity the results of the New-York Election, and attaches to it a degree of importance which, under present circumstances, we are not a little surprised at. The pith of the Intelligencer's deductions is contained in the following extract:

HOWELL COBB'S defeat in the Caucus at Milledgeville is the leading topic of conversation. COBB, with the aid of the Whigs, will beat MACDONALD for Governor eighteen thousand votes. MACDONALD wanted a Judgeship in the gift of COBB, which the latter declined bestowing. Now MAC beats HOWELL badly notwithstanding. HOWELL abandoned Union-saving, and warmly supported JOHNSON for Governor.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : SIR : As one of the " Jurors " for examining a class of the articles on exhibition at the Crystal Palace, I wish to call your attention to a scandalous article in a Sunday paper, upon the selection of Jurors for the above specific duties.

The coming session of Congress promises to be one of the most acrimonious. corrupt and discreditable the country has lately seen. The Democratic party has a strong majority in both branches;--but it is not a compact, unanimous or well-disciplined party, and disappointments in the distribution of patronage will overbear all attachment to the party name and all loyalty to party behests.

Is there no name for it? Why have we no statement as to the nature of this strange mortality at sea, we have so often had occasion to remark of late? Is it cholera, ship fever, or what? Or do they only die without any specific cause? Ship-owners miss it that they do not tell us.

Our readers were informed, on the arrival of the late intelligence from California, that the steamer Arrow, on the eve of departure from San Francisco for Guyamas, was seized by General HITCHCOCK on charge of having violated the laws of the United States. The Echo du Pacifique, a French paper published in California, approves the seizure, which was very generally censured by the California press.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It is the privilege of great men--those men who shape the destinies of the world, and leave a name conspicuous for praise or execration--to place their impress upon all things which they touch. The places where such men have triumphed, suffered, or even for a time resided, are imbued with an interest which no lapse of time can do away with.

We extract the following from the Vigie de Duppe. in relation to the projected establishment of a line of transatlantre steamers, in ply between French and American parts: "The public are aware of the application made to the French Government by Mr. P. LEFERVRE, for the purpose of securing the free introduction into France of vessels built in foreign countries.

We have files of papers from Rio de Janeiro, to Sept. 25, inclusive. The latest dates at Rio were, Foreign---New-York, Aug. 15; Baltimore, Aug 12; New-Orleans, Aug. 9; California, July 16; Liverpool, Aug 25; Lisbon, Aug. 30; Havre, Aug. 22; Hamburg, Aug. 19. South American and Interior--Buenos Ayres, Sept. 2; Montevideo, Sept. 4; Val. paraiso, June 30; Pernambuco, Sept. 16, and Bahia, Sept. 20.

The subscription of $10,000,000 by Mr. ROBT. J WALKER, astonished everybody in Mississippi, to whom his pecuniary character was well known. Astonished is not the word. Astounded won't do. Dumfounded will not answer. There's not a word in any dictionary of the English language that will convey a just idea of the sensations ??eated by the announcement.

From the Cincinnati Columbia. We have deferred, for some time, an article upon the grape interests of our State and West generally. We wish we could do the subject greater justice than the limits of an editorial column give us opportunity; for the grape culture, the grape and wine interests of our community are fraught with very considerable importance now, and must, eventually, become a great and absorbing feature of the State's property.

The Courrier des Etats Unis, in publishing the following letter, which is also given in the Paris Constitutionnel, remarks that, apart from the important rectification of facts which it contains, it gives the measure of credit to be attached to the statements of the Herald: PARIS, Wednesday, Oct. 26, 1853.

1. 'Tis pleasant when our friends are rich To meet them day by day; Or good, or ill,--no matter which, Provided they can pay. But is there one--you answer not--Who would, or could avouch Esteem for one who hadn't got A dollar in his pouch ?

In another column will be found the protest of a large number of the property owners and residents along the line of the proposed Ninth-avenue Railroad, against its construction. The resolutions authorizing this road passed the Common Council over ten months ago, and were vetoed by the Mayor on the 12th of January last.

Yesterday was a white day in the annals of the Deaf and Dumb in New-York. It was likewise a cloudy day, and fears of a storm were entertained, but the apprehensions were happily quite unfounded, so that the ceremony of laying the Corner-stone of the new Institution for the Deaf and Dumb of the State passed off not only without interruption, but with extraordinary eclat.

A CHINESE MONTHLY.--Until within a short time, the only papers issued in China and printed in the Chinese language, have been the Pekin Gazette, (a mere mouthpiece of the Emperor.) and the Quarterly Red Book. Lately at Hong-Kong, a Chinese Monthly has been issued, styled the United Pearls, gathered from Far and Near.

From the translations we have occasionally given from its columns, our readers are probably aware that Charivari, the Punch of the French Capital, conceals, under its suit of motley, the strongest liberal sympathies, and is really at this moment the ablest political journal of Paris Under its mirthful disguise, it succeeds in publishing articles which would at once cause its suppression were they given in sober seriousness.

On Thursday, Nov. 22, ELIZA PARKER, wife of John N Briggs. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, on Thursday, 24th inat., at 1 o'clock P. M., from the residence of her mother-in law, No. 41 Jav st. At West Springfield, Mass, on the 22d inst. Mrs. MARY, Widow of the late Hon. Samuel Lathrop. aged 74.

The Director of the Rutland and Durington Railroad have assigned the property of the Road to the Trustees of the Second Mortgage Bonds, for the benefit of all concerned, being unwilling to pay the present high rates of interest for money, to meet their floating debt on 6 percent. Bonds falling due. The ast of the Murkerel fishermen arrived at Gloucester yesterday. The season has been the most unprofitable for many years.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--The necessity for additional rehersals, in order to insure the perfect realization of MEYERBEER'S music, will prevent the production of the "Prophete" until Friday next On that evening, this magnificent work will assuredly he placed before the public. Rehearsals are occurring twice a day, and no exertion or expense is being spared by MARETZEK to insure the success of MEYERBEER'S masterpiece.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Time: In your paper of Nov. 19, in which appears the first of a series of articles professing to give the "Chronicles of the Religious Sects in the United States," occurs the following statement: "Strange to say, the first Unitarian Church and Society in the United States originated in King's Chapel, one of the most ancient, wealthy and respectable Episcopal Churches then existing in the United States.

A meeting of this body was held last night at the rooms of the Society, No. 213 Broadway. The INGRAHAM Committee first sat, HENRY H. MORANGE, Esq., presiding, when the Treasurer reported that a sufficient sum of money was now in hand to justify the Committee in giving directions for the execution of the Medal and M. Cas-ulli.

The Journal of Commerce calls public attention to several points in our City legislation, which ought to be acted upon at once by the Common Council. It seems that the bids for sweeping the streets were opened on Sept. 17, and reported to the Common Council by Mr. ARCULARIUS, on Oct 25, more than a month afterwards.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The person who writes and signs himself an "unregarded private sufferer," in your paper of the 21st inst., should put his name to the article he writes against Post-Office: matters, and also make correct statements.

The last steamer brought out the specimen-number of a new semi-weekly paper, which is to appear regularly at Payerne, in Switzerland, from November 15. It is entitled the Progress--a Journal of the Revolution--and announces that it will be edited by "Democrats of all nationalities." Its principles are embodied in the following sentences: "Progress flows from the conquests obtained and confirmed by the revolution.

TO THE BANEVOIENT.--A young colored man, named JAMES B. ONEY, at present in the employ of JOHN F. SEYMOUR Co., No. 68 Pearl-street, some ten or twelve years ago succeeded in purchasing his freedom, by diligence, economy, and integrity. He left an only sister with her five children still in slavery, and he is very anxious to purchase their freedom also.

Last evening, between 7 and 8 o'clock, afire broke out in the fourth story of WM. G. WEST'S extensive letter envelope manufactory, at No. 67 Pine-street. The discovery of the fire was made by private watchman GELHARTZ. residing in the rear part of the Knickerbocker Insurance building, in Wall-street, directly behind the factory. The U.S. steamer Fulton sailed this a afternoon for Norfolk. The Manager if the House of Refuge have awarded a premium of $100 to E. C. HALE, of Worcester, Mass, for the best essay of juvenile delinquency, and a prize of $50 to Rev. T. V. MOORE, Presbyterian clergyman of Richmond, Va.

Before Hon. John W Nelson. Yesterday morning, Deputy Marshal DE ANGELIS brought up in custody a well-dressed, gentlemanly young man, 22 years of age, named ALEXANDER HEILBORN, who had been arrested on a warrant granted by Commissioner NELSON, under the act of Congress passed to give legal effect to the ASHBURTON Treaty.

Let us to day he thankful. Do not our hearts dictate it? The Governor r certainly has done so, in a most commendably brief proclamation. Then, reader, having shaven, taken a light breakfast, and talked over all pleasantly suggestive matters in such style and temper as will secure a smiling countenance for every member of your household, go up to church at eleven.

The investigation of the alleged forgery by VAN AERNUM and others upon Hamilton Exchange Bank, Canada West, (suspended for some days to allow of Mr. SAWIN to procure Witnesses from Buffalo,) was resumed before Justice STUART, in Jefferson Market Police Court, at 1 1/2 o'clock yesterday.

MY DEAR REILLY: I have now passed nearly five years in captivity to the English enemyfour years, eleven months, and fourteen days; for my days have gone by heavily, and I had time to count them. ,If ?? endure it any longer, I fear the iron will enter into my soul and corrode-I fear the virtue, that is to say, the pluck will have gone out of me.

Mr. BOURCICAULT'S COMEDY.--We have had but few occasions of visiting Mr. BURTON'S establishment lately. The entertainments usually provided there are not of a character to reader our grief very poignant at this circumstance Mr. BURTON has stopped aside from his usual course in producing the "Fox Hunt; or, the Adventures of Don Quixote the Second." and hence we are called on again to speak of the Chambers-street place of amusement.

Before Judge Betts. COLLISION--DUTY OF STEAMERS. Joseph Fish and others vs. the Steamship Black Warrior--The New-York and Alabama Steamship Company, Claimants.--The schooner Sarah Emma and the steamship came in collision in the evening of November 16, 1852. near Burnegat, and the schooner being sunk by the collision.

LECTURE BY REV. DR. BETHUNE. The first of the course of nine Lectures was delivered Tuesday evening at the Brooklyn Athenaeum, by Rev. Dr. BETHUNE, upon Lectures and Lecturers. There was a very respectable audience in attendance. The speaker, after a few prefatory remarks, said: The work Lecture is often strangely warped from its original meaning.

The steamship Empire City reached her dock this afternoon. Her dates from Havana are to the 10th ? but there is no news of importance. The ship Blanche, arrived here from Liverpool, with 400 emigrants, reports ten deaths from cholera during the passage

The "Hard" section of the Democracy of New-York held a grand congratulatory meeting at Metropolitan Hall, last evening. The house was packed with an audience who were very enthusiastic, and the proceedings passed off in excellent harmony and order. During the afternoon, salutes were fired, and the Democracy rejoiced beforehand.

The steamboat train on the Fall River Road, which left this city yesterday afternoon, was brought to a stand still between Stoughton and North Bridgewater at 6 o'clock last evening, by the breaking of a wheel of the second-class car. Mr. THOMAS J. CLAFFLIN, conductor of the train, immediately seized the usual signal lantern and went back to stop the special train from South Braintree to South Bridgewater, which was following behind.

We are gratified to learn that great improvements have just been made in telegraphic facilities between this City and Halifax, by which communications, which heretofore have been rewritten at four or five different points, are now sent direct, with but a single repetition. The new plan enables the lines to transmit messages in less than one quarter the time heretofore required, and also lessens, in a very material degree, the liability to make errors.

BY SUBMARINE TELEGRAPH. Five Russian officers had arrived at Constantinople as prisoners of war. Admirals DUNDAS and HAMELON are at Constantinople, and the fleets are anchored in the Bosphorus. There is a rumor that Bucharest has been stormed, This is, perhaps, premature.

Rev Dr. POTTS preached an able sermon to his large congregation, in the Presbyterian Church, on University place, in which he dwelt mainly on the duties to which Christian should be simulated by the recurrence of a day of public Thanksgiving, and by the Peculiar circumstance of the Society in which they live.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Permit me the use of your columns, in behalf of this organization, as it is one possessing some novel features, and will attract considerable attention.

Recently the readers of the TIMES were in formed "that the Austrian Government have revived the system of intolerance against the Jewish subjects." In fact, however, there was no need of a revival of the system of intolerance, because the Austrian Government have at all times been cruel and malicious against the unfortunate Jewish inhabitants.

The latest official accounts received is Paris from the theatre of war on the Danube state that the Turks crossed the river on the 27th and 28th ult. to the number of 12,000 men ; but of their subsequent operations there is no mention, and we must await further advices before we can accept the statement in the German papers, that they had been repulsed by the Russians.

UNION OF THE MONTGOMERY AND EMMET GUARD--The Montgomery Guard, (Captain MURPHY.) and Emmet Guard, (Captain McGRATH,) celebrated their union as one Company, by a parade and dinner, at the Eagle Drill Rooms, corner of Christy and Delancy-streets, last evening.

We regret to state, on the authority of direct information from Jackson, Mississippi, that the recent popular vote of the State in dicates a settled purpose not to provide for the repudiated Bonds of the State, passed to European and other creditors, on the establishment of the Union Bank in 1838-9.
FESTIVAL OF EXPRESS COMPANIES. A Grand Turn-out--Banquet at the Astor House. Yesterday was a gala day with the gentlemen connected with the Express Companies of the City.

Lieut. SAXTON, with a detachment of dragoons, accompanied by Mr. CUTHBERTSON, an old Indian trader, and Mr. TERIS, one of our merchants, arrived in this city from the Upper Missouri, They bring later accounts from Gov. STEVENS. Lieut. SAXTON was dispatched from the Pacific coast with provisions and supplies for Governor STEVENS. He has made deposits at several points west of the Rocky Mountains.

There could not have been a finer day for Thanksgiving than the one that came to hand yester-morning. The fog cleared up about 8 o'clock: the weather was mild, the air balmy. A little later there came a drop of a shower-just enough to make the ladies wonder what bonnet they should wear--then a clear sky and a cool fresh breeze. It was just the kind of day for the occasion.

A very excellent practical Thanksgiving Discourse was delivered by Rev. Dr. ADAMS, Pastor of the Madison-square Presbyterian Church, in the temporary place of worship occupied by that Society in Hope Chapel. The subject was the "Fewness, Simplicity and Commonness of the Objects essential to the Highest Measure of Pleasure, Contentment and Comfort."

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your correspondent from Cincinnati has certainly opened a very interesting subject in his letter on Christianity in Turkey, and one, as he truly remarks, on which the American Press has been quite silent--for which reason it is doubly important that, when the subject is opened, it should he brought before the public without either theological or political bias, and in an enlarged and general view.

BAPTIST SUNDAY SCHOOL MISSIONARY ANNIVERSARY.--The Fifteenth Anniversary of the New-York Baptist Sunday-School Missionary Association was celebrated last evening in the Baptist Church in Stanton-street, near the Bowery. The exercises were interesting.

We are happy to say that the pleasant festivities, which are the general accomplishments of the day of National Thanksgiving in the wide world abroad, also found their way yesterday to the juvenile community who flourish under the care of the Board of Ten Governors in Randall's Island. The kind generosity of some gentlemen made glad the hearts of the little ones, who are making their early pilgrimage in that wind-swept Patmos of ours.

The Hungarians are not the only people who feel the iron hand of the Austrian Government. The Jews have again been subjected to a system of religious intolerance and cruel and malicious persecution, even worse than others with which their race have so long been familiar, on the other side of the Atlantic.

The steamer Calcutta has arrived, after a run of 113 house from Alexandria. The India mail had arrived at Alexandria, with dates from Calcutta, Oct. 3; Bombay, Oct. 14; Burmah, Sept. 17; and Hong Kong, Sept. 27.

One of the most interesting statistical documents to be found, and full of instructive information, is the Tabular Returns of the Assessors, now before the State Board of Equalization, at Columbus. Taken in connection with the Auditor's Report of last year, it presents a complete view of the wealth and revenues of Ohio, both in aggregate and detail.

The Thirty-second Anniversary of the Hebrew Benovolent Society was celebrated on Wednesday evening by a Dinner at the Chinese Assembly Rooms, in Broadway. Three hundred and fifty gentlemen sat down at table Two raised tables occupied the extremities of the saloon, and three others were arranged longitudinally.

ACCIDENT ON THE ERIE ROAD.--The express passenger train which left Dunkirk on Tuesday night on the arrival of the Cincinnati and Toledo trains from the West, broke down ten miles west of Binghamton on Wednesday morning, about 7 1/2 o'clock. The train was thrown off the track by running over a cow.

Austria is keeping strict watch on the movements of Servia, and is concentrating a force on that frontier, but otherwise remains neutral. The Servias Government, meantime, has ordered its population to arm, and has in formed the Perte that neither Austria nor Russia will be permitted to occupy Servia.

The western papers will have already informed you of the election of a delegate to Washington by the people of Nebraska.' There are "sectional" interests in a new territory, of course, as well as elsewhere, and the delegate elect, H. D. JOHNSON, Esq., belongs to the northern section of Nebraskan politics.

It seems to be universally conceded that the Diplomatic System of the United States requires revision :--and the important features which characterize our intercourse with European powers just at present, commend the subject with unwonted force to public attention.

THANKSGIVING DAY IN BROOKLYN.--Yesterday was very generally observed by all classes in the city. In fact some commenced festivities the night before--balls were given at WILSON'S Assembly Room, and at Montague and Gothic Halls.
The natural curiosity of the public respecting the Turhi??k war is likely to be disappointed by frequent intervals of suspense, contradictory communications and uncertain intelligencs.

All things considered, the Children's Festival at the Five Points yesterday, was perhaps the most pleasing celebration of Thanksgiving Day in the City of New-York. The appearance of many hundred children around tables laden with all that childhood longs for or age can desire, is on any occasion, and under the most favorable circumstances, a most gratifying spectacle.

The British fleet, at Sp??thead, is ordered to be ready for Sea on the 11th, but their destination is not stated. The Lord Mayor's Banquet took place, as usual, on the 9th, and was attended by all the Cabinet and Forei?? a Ministers, including Mr. BUCHANAN. Mr. B.'s speech was merely complimentary to a successful issue.

The Overland India Mail has been telegraphed with news of vital importance, if true, viz.: The Czar has formed an alliance with Dost Mohomet to proclaim war against the British in India, if Britain persists in supporting Turkey. A large Russian force is to invade Hekharr, and a Persian army is collecting in the Valley of S??oltania to cooperate with Russia against Turkey.

By the arrival of the United States Mail steam ship Washington, E. M. FITCH, commander, we have received files of journals, together with our usual correspondence, of four days' later date from all parts of Europe than received by the Arabia from Liverpool. The Washington left Bremen on the 4th, and Southampton on the 9th. She brings a large and valuable cargo and 200 passengers.
The ceremony of laying the Corner-stone of a new Jewish Hospital in this City was performed yesterday, in accordance with the ritual of the Hebrew faith.

Thanksgiving was very generally observed here, business being suspended. No papers were issued here this morning. New-Orleans papers of Thursday and Friday last are received, but contain no news of interest.

It was the purpose of Commodore CON, as we stated at the time, to reply to the charges which were rumored some weeks ago, to the effect that he had dishonorably surrendered the fleet under his command, then blockading Buenos Ayres, to the enemy.

The President has nearly recovered his health, and will he able to be out to-day. The Message is nearly completed, and will be sent in advance to distant newspapers, all rumors to the contrary notwithstanding.

BREAKING UP A RAFT IN THE GEORGIAN BAY, WITH NINETEEN MEN ON IT. Last Monday night Mr. COATSWORTH, of Toronto, and 18 of his men, had a narrow and almost miraculous escape from destruction by a breaking up of a raft on which they were floating on the Georgian Bay.

COTTON--Our market has. within the last few days, assumed more firmness, and Middling qualities have been sold to-day at a trifling advance in the currency per Arabia. The sales of the week from up 45,000 sales, of which speculators tool 9,000, and exporters 3,000.

The Santa Fe mail has arrived, but brings no news of importance. Major AUBREY left Santa Fe on Oct. 15, for California. He is going to try a new route. Laut. WHIPPLE'S exploring party had reached Albuquerque.

The Alumnus of Amherst College, who was graduated here twenty, or even ten years ago, am'd much that is unchanged and unchangeable, finds, on revisiting his Alma, many things not a little altered and improved.

On Monday last the Herald stated that the Merchants' Bank had suffered from recent defalcations to the amount of $200,000;--the Metropolitan Bank to the amount of $180, 000;--the Bank of Commerce to the amount of $80,000; and the American Exchange Bank to the amount of $60,000.

THE CHARLOTTESVILLE TROUBLES-On the 22d inst., a number of students of the University surrounded the Delevan House, in which were gathered, on a social occasion, some sixty Sops of Temperance, including Prof MINOR. Rev Messrs. AUGUST and BROADDUS, and others, and demanded that one of the number in the house should be given up to their revenge.

The reformers of the early part of the eighteenth century were first called Methodists at Oxford, England--the appellation being originally applied to a certain number of young collegians, who had formed a Society to meet together in the afternoons, to read the Greek Testament, and other books of a religious character, to the end of mutual instruction and improvement.

Since the recent heavy robbery perpetrated at the Bank of the State of New-York, in Wall-street, of a package of its own notes, amounting to $37,810, the authorities of this City have been on the alert to forret out the criminals.

The President attended Thanksgiving service this morning, although he looks far from well. Notwithstanding his indisposition during the last few days, he has been much engaged in the preparation of his Message, which is now rapidly approaching completion.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--St leogin be have 10 record the production of an opera which, in point of novelty and superiority may be said to place the company of Mr. MARETZEK on a par with the modern range of music. Since the original production of this wonderful work, there has been but one opinion of its ments.

Honorable JOHN HULL, of New-Jersey, died at his late residence in Freehold, Monmouth County. New Jersey, on Tuesday morning, November the 8th, 1853, one of the oldest and most respected citizens of the County and State.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : SIR: An article appears in the DAILY TIMES of this morning, in which you state that my comedy, entitled "The Fox Hunt and the Adventures of Don Quixote the Second," is a translation or adaptation of a French comedy called "Sullivan."

J. B. BARCOCKS, merchant, of St. Andrews, N. B., who was injured by the collision, on the Fall River Rail road on Monday night, died yesterday morning. The failure of OTIS H. WEED, lee dealer, is reported.

The people of certain localities in Pennsylvania would secure advantages of trade which any sensible and impartial mind, looking to the relative position of New-York and Philadelphia, must concede, do not, and cannot of right belong to them.

Dr. HOLMES delivered his fifth lecture at Hope Chapel last night It was a fine, frosty, starlight night, and a large gathering was the result of the inviting weather and the lecturer's popularity We say popularity, advisedly, because Dr. HOLMES is a good surface-lecturer, and is therefore sure to be popular.

LECTURE BY HON. JOHN. E. HALE. The first of a series of lectures, to he delivered at the Brooklyn institute on Thursday evening of each week, was delivered that evening, by Hon. JOHN P. HALE, to a crowded house.

A paper of a Northern Department gives a very absurd account of a visit paid by their Majesties to the Fortress of Ham, where LOUIS NA POLEON spent six years in durance vile. As they crossed the drawbridge. says this journal, the features of the Emperor appeared much changed.

It bas been a matter of no great astonishment to a portion of our community, that General J. WATSON WEBB should have written such a communication as he did to the Times, because his well-known hankering for notoriety explained all this: but that he should have presumed to represent the feelings of his countrymen, or any considerable portion of them, when he held such language as he did, is somewhat amazing.

The emigrant vessels from Liverpool continue to cast forth from their decks into the sea, the emigrant dead by fifties and by hundreds. Yesterday, two vessels arrived at this port, showing, one a death list of one hundred, and the other thirty-three; and almost every vessel arriving here from England fails to land the number of passengers taken on board.

NEW MUSIC--JUST PUBLISHED.--"Katy-Did Sung" By Thomas Baker. "Didst ever ask the insect tattler what Key really did to make such a ??ir in the world, and gave occasion for its everlasting song of Katy-Did? "No." "Well, we have, and here is the answer."

On Thursday evening, a painful accident occur red in Broadway, near the corner of Chambers-street, which resulted in a loss of life. A young lady, named Miss CATHARINE DAWTON, residing with her parents at No. 120 Anthony-street was crossing Broadway, when she was knocked down and run over by an Express wagon.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : In your paper of the 17th inst., I read with pleasure an article on the Steam Marine of the United States. There was an error, however, instating their armaments, which allow me to correct.

The war news produced great sensation with the Administration. The President and Cabinet are intensely interested. The Union gave an Extra to the public containing the news, and says, editorially, what the Administration feel: "A general Continental war would seem to be inevitable.

GENTLEMAN: Your letter of the 17th inst., inviting me to attend a congratulatory mass meeting of the Natural Democracy of the City of New York to be held at Metropolitan Hall, on the 23d inst., has this moment come to hand. I regret that circumstances, which it is unnecessary to mention render it impossible for me to accept your invitation.

THE EXLOSION ON BOARD THE STEAMER ROBERT MARTIN.--The Charleston Courier, of the 23d, has the following in reference to the explosion on board the steamer Robert Martin: I Capt. COATES informs us that the Robert Martin present, as complete a scene of ruin as he ever saw; even the an ?? chains, and a heavy iron capstan, which was on desk, were blown on the neighboring bank.
The steamships Texas, from Vera Cruz, and Pampero, from San Juan Nicaragua, have arrived at this port.

The money recently abstracted from the Bank of the State of New-York, in Wall-street, was recovered on Saturday, minus the amount discovered a few days ago in the possession of two men in Toledo, Ohio, and an other sum amounting to $5,000 or $6,000, which has probably been expended by the robbers.

The Moravian Missions. Yesterday morning, Rev. D. BIGLER preached a sermon at the Church on the corner of Mott and Houston-streets, in aid of the Moravian Missions. There was a fair attendance, and a considerable amount was contributed for Missionary purposes.
The Canada's mails, from Boston, with our London files, enable us to give, this morning, a very comprehensive view of the relative position and operations of the hostile forces on the Danube.

SYDNEY GOLD CIRCULAR. Since the sailing of the Argo business is the gold market has not been of any amount. The price of Gold has an upward tendency, and ??3 18s. 6??, for Port Philip and Ovens has been given and New South Wales ??3 16s. 6d.; of the latter very little offering.

The Union of this morning has a lengthy article denouncing the Third party leaders. It says: "If political renegades and traitors were to be judged by their professions, they would all be sainted as models of patriotism."

From the Boston Journal. The New-York TIMES publishes letters from the presidents or cashiers of four banks in New-York, in which defalcations to large amounts are alleged to have taken place, denying that there is the slighest foundation for the statement. The report, it will be recollected, originated with the New York Herald, and the TIMES charges that it was fabricated.

The first of the Sunday evening course of sermons before the Young Men's Christian Association was delivered last evening in the Baptist Church in Second-avenue, between Tenth and Eleventh-streets, by Rev. Dr. FULLER, of Baltimore.

The Mail steamship Isabel, Capt. ROLLIN, arrived here at 11 o'clock last night, having been detained by head winds. She left Havana on the morning of the 22d inst, and Key West on the evening of the same day.

PHILHARMONIC SOCIETY--A promising indication of the progress of art in this country, in found in the continued prosperity of this most excellent society. The patronage which is now bestowed on each Concert by the general public, has justified the Directors in removing from their old quarters to the more spacious and elegant Saloon of Metropolitan Hall.

JUSTICE OF THE COURTS.--On Wednesday last, in the Court of Sessions Judge BEBEE sentenced to the State Prison for ten years a young man named LEVI WEEKS, who had been convisted of the crime of highway robbery. On Saturday last, in the Court of Over and Terminer, LOUIS DE CORN, "a respectable French man," was sentenced to the State Prison for two years and ten months, for murdering EUGENE MELVILLE.

The heavy robbery of nearly $38.000 in bankbills of the denominations of fives, tens, twenties, fafties, hundreds, $500 and $1,000, from the Bank of the State of New-York, in Wall-street, some three or four weeks ago, has created considerable excitement in this City, and also in other parts of the United States, where the information was sent by telegraph.

FORNEY'S main opponent will be HORATIO N. HARRIS, of Mississippi. FORNEY is terribly assailed, but will undoubtedly triumph. The officers of the House of Representatives is the engrossing topic of conversation.

STEAMER ROBERT MARTIN BLOWN UP.--By a letter received by Mr. DOUGLAS VESBITT yesterday, which was brought by the steamer General Clinch, from Georgetown, we learn that information a had reached that place that the steamer Robert Martin, Captain C. C. WHITE, from his city from Cheraw, had burst her boilers at Port's Ferry, on the Pee Deo, on Saturday morning last, billing it is said, about ten persons, and wounding several others.

Advices from Rome state that the exciting news from the banks of the Danube has created great excitement among the young soldiers of the French army of occupation, and also among the oldest veterans in the service, and that numerous applications have been transmitted to the compatent authorities for permission to witness the operations of the Turkish army.
Father GAVAZZI on Friday evening delivered his last lecture in Brooklyn, at the Athenacum, before a large audience. His subject was the "Pilgrim Fathers of America and their Present Descendants."

The records of the terrible and unprecedented marine mortality do not at all fall off. The papers seem agreed to speak of it as cholera, and probably it is that, but it is very little we know of the matter, considering the ravages that have been made.

SWINDLING YOUNG MEN FROM UP COUNTRY--ARREST OF A WRITING-MASTER.--Two young men named JOHN H. BURNS and CYRUS KING, appeared before Judge STAURT, at the Jefferson Police Court, on Saturday, and preferred a charge against a man named ISAAC R. GOWARD, who has, for several years, been in the habit of advertising for clerks, book-keepers, , , offering salaries from $600 to $1,200.

MISSISSIPPI ELECTION.--The regularly nominated Democratic ticket succeeded throughout in the State of Mississippi, at the elections on the 7th and 8th inst. J. J. McRAE is elected Governor by a large majorit--five thousand to seven thousand.
The steamer Massachusetts yesterday towed into Holmes Hole, a schooner from Rockland, Mo., dismasted in the gale of Thursday.
Rev. P. F. JONES, who has just graduated from Madison College, entered on his duties as pastor of the Baptist Church, corner of Lexington-avenue and Thirtieth-street, yesterday.

"UNCLE TOM's CABIN" AT THE NATIONAL THEATRE--This dramatic version from Mrs. HARRIET BEECHER STOWE'S celebrated work, being the most faithful, has caused it to have a run at the National unprecedented in the anuals of history.

HORRID MURDER:--We learn that on last Saturday a widow woman named MARY SIMONS, residing on the North side, was committed to jail, charged with the murder of her daughter, an interesting child of 12 years, who was found 'sa' in her house Saturday morning. It appeared in evidence before the Coroner's jury, that she was a woman addieted to int mperance, and cruel to her children.

Another meeting of the Committee in reference t0 the proposed Extension of the Harlem Railroad track in this City, was held in the Chamber?? the Board of Assistant Aldarmen, on Saturday afternoon A large number of persons interested in the project were present.

The total of burials within the City last week was 375. That is 34 more than the proceding week, and one more than the week before that. There is nothing in the report demanding special attention, except the item which informs us that during the past seven days there have been twenty-two deaths within our City from small-pox.

H. GLOVER, W. C. GRAY, JAMES PATRICK, THOMAS E. BODINE, EDWARD WESTON, JOHN W. COTTREY, HARVEY SPUNGSTEEN, JOHN WOODWARD, THOMAS CONNELL, GABRIEL TURK, and GEORGE TAPHAR.

Among the most important Items in the President's Message will be the recommendation of a large appropriation for at once finishing, arming, and equipping the forts on the islands of Key West and Tortugas on the Gulf of Mexico.

THE ROWDIES AGAIN--On Saturday evening, Mr. MICHAEL McNAMEE, keeper of a hotel at the corner of Prospect and Main-streets, on returning from Jamaica, called with a friend at a porter-house on Fulton-avenue.
The ship Bavaria, Capt. BAILEY. 960.tons, from Melbourne August 30, and off Port Philip Sept. 1, arrived at this port at an early hour Saturday forenoon, Nov. 26.

The whaling ship Citizen, of New-Bedford, had been lost in the Arctic Ocean. A portion of the crew were saved after having undergone terrible sufferings. Arrivals at San Francisco--Oct. 19, Reindeer, from New-York ; Susquehanna, from Richmond.

DEDICATION OF A NEW METHODIST EPISCOPAL CHURCH.--The dedication of the Reding Mission Mathedist Episcopal Church in Seventeenth-street, between First and Second-avenues, took place yesterday in the presence of a numerous congregation.
From the Buffalo Commercial Advertiser. The execution of this young man for the murder of Mr. BROWN, of Alden, took place in the court-yard of the jail this morning.
We give the details to-day of the trial of sundry persons charged with conspiring to assassinate LOUIS NAPOLRON. It is a curious affair--well worth reading.

DECISIONS. David S. Mills vs John B. Thursby.--This was was a motion to dissolve injunction. The Judge said : I think that the affidavit of the Sheriff shows that a valid levy was made upon the personal property of the defendant before his death, and before the return day of the execution ; but I am not prepared to say that there was sufficient levy upon the real estate.

The steamship United States, from Aspinwall, has arrived at this port, bringing California dates to the 1st inst. The steamship Illinois left Aspinwall for New-York on the 19th inst., with $1,000,000 in gold dust, and 150 passengers.

The trial of the conspiracies of the Hippodrome and the Opera Comique begins this day. I have collected a few details on the subject. A former writer in La Presse, M. JULES ALIX, inventor, among other things.

The Attorney General, Thomas E. Davis, and others, vs. the Mayor, , of New-York, Jacob sharpe and others.--This cause has been fully heard upon the pleadings and proofs, and as the complaint has been amendad by the introduction of the Attorney General as a prosecuting party, I am enabled, and shall now proceed.

His Excellency, Monsignor BEDINI, Apostolic Nuncie, assisted by Rev. Dr. CUMMINGS and a number of clergymen, performed the ceremony of laying the cornerstone of the Church of the Annunciation, yesterday afternoon, at Manhattanville, corner of Bloomingdale Road and One Hundred and Thirty-first-street.

On Saturday morning, 26th inst., of apoplexy, JOHN WOOD, aged 75 years. His relatives friends, and acquaintainies, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence; 31st.st., near 3d-av., on Monday, 28th inst., at 11 o'clock A. M., without further invitation.

Yesterday morning, Coroner O'DONNELL held an inquest on the body of a young man named PATRICK McMULLEN, who was killed by falling from a gang-plank of the steamship Baltic, lying at the foot of Canal-street. North River.

The particulars of the late defalcation in Troy, of which so much has been said and hinted in the papers, are thus given in a private letter, written from that city a few days since: FOSTER BOSWORTH, the Democratic (soft) Mayor of this city though a young man of some thirty years of age, has for many yeas been engaged very extensively in the grocery business here, both retail and wholesale.

At out one year and a half after the Declation of American Independence, Capt. Cook made known these Islands to the commercial world. HUMBOLDT claims that they were discovered in 1542, by a Spaniard, but whether this is true or not, Capt. Cook enjoys the honor of introducing them to the attention of mankind.

The most impudent thing of the age is a book on America by ALFRED BUNN. After his experience of two or three months here, his desperate failures in an attempt at lecturing, and his brilliant adventures in the lowest purlieus of the City, where-of our police records contain full particulars, one would have predicted that he would have mentioned the United States as rarely as possible after his return.

A THEATRICAL MYSTERY.--A great excitement was crested in the theartical circles on Saturday, in consequence of the sudden disappearance of one of the most beautiful and popular actresses connected with WALLACK'S establishment.

At Ithaca, on Tuesday, Nov. 22 after a linger illness, in the 66th year of her age, CATHARINE, wife of John Corley, formerly of this City. On Saturday, Nov. 26, at Plainfield, N. J. WILLIAM ALLEN, in the 64th year of his age.

New-Orleans papers of Monday last are received. They contain Galveston dates to the 17th, announcing the organization of the Legislature, and the delivery of Gov. BELL'S message, which is largely devoted to the subject of the Pacific Railroad.

The steamship Illinois arrived at this port last evening, with dates from the Isthmus to the 19th; California to November 1st; the same as previously received per telegraph, a, d later news from the South Pacific.

The mining news of the fortnight has been interesting, but there are few items of sufficient importance to attract attention abroad. In ourlast Summary, we noticed the convention held in the begining of last mouth at Sacramento, by delegates from different Water Companies of the State.

FIRE DEPARTMENT. Charges Against the Chief Engineer. The investigation of charges preferred against Alfred Carson, Esq., Chief Engineer, was resumed at 31/2 P. M. yesterday, before Assistant Aldermen Barker and McConkey.

Last evening Rev. Dr. CHEEVER preached a most able and interesting sermon at the Church of the Puritans, in Fifteenth-street, on the subject of the introduction of the Bible into our public schools without restriction. The Rev. Gentleman took for his text, 2d Deut. xxix, 29.
We publish this morning the Comptroller's Estimates of City Expenditures for the year 1854. The document was laid before the Board of Assistant Aldermen on Tuesday evening.

The steamer United States arrived here on Monday, the 15th. The steamer Medway, of the R. M. S. Packet Co., from Cathagena and St. Thomas, arrived at this port on the morning of the 16th. She brought a considerable force for the Panama Railroad Co.

The following gentlemen are understood to be aspirants for the lucrative position of Printers to Con grews: 1. ROBERT ARMSTRONG, Of the Union, who may be regarded as the Administration candidate. 2. BEVERLY 'TUCKER, of the Sentinel, who will be sustained by the Adamantise wing of the party.
A dispatch from the Breakwater states that the, brig Delhi from Porto Rico, with sugar and molasses for New-York, struck on the Breakwater last night, and was abandoned by the Captain and crew.

In our advertising columns will be found a notice of the target excursion last week of the "Stuyvesant 0ld Pear Tree Guards," a company made up of residents, in the vicinity of the famous old Stuyvesant Pear Tree.

NEW MISSION SCHOOL FOR CHILDREN.-A new Mission School has recently been established on Union street, near Hamilton-avenue Ferry,-to gather in, if possible, some of the many ignorant, idle, and vicious children, who haunt that section of the city.

FROM THE BAHAMA ISLANDS--Files of Nassau N. P. journals, to the 26th of October, have been received. We are informed that the authorities have arranged that the Government schooner shall leave the harbor of Nassau for the out Islands, on the 11th of every month.
FITZPATRICK and CLAY, the new Alabama Senators, are strong Southern Rights men, though friends of the Administration. Gen. ARMSTRONG'S election as Public Printer is considered certain.
About eighty years since, a merchant of Aberdeen left a large fund, the income of which was to he set apart as prizes for Treatises on the Evidences of the Divine Existence.

Navigation is closed here. The anchor ice with the surface ice making an obstruction of several feet in thickness. There are from 60 to 80 vessels with full cargoes enclosed in the ice, beside the steamers Daniel Webster, Boston, and Eastern State.

The following Report of Comptroller FLAGG comprises the Estimates for City Expenditures, in full, for the year 1854. The document was presented in the Board of Assistant Aldermen, on Tuesday evening last, and was then laid upon the table and ordered to be printed.

We are in receipt of papers from Valparaiso to the 15th, and of private advices from various points on the coast. Very little business was doing at Valparaiso, and the market was still glutied, and freight about as at our last advices.

The Courier Enquirer keeps its foreign correspondents pretty vigorously occuped in recording the thunders of applause which have greeted General WEBB'S letter to the London Times.

PROPOSED CONSOLIDATION OF THE "PRINTERS COOPERATIVE UNION" AND "TYPOGRAPHICAL UNION." --The Printers' Cooperative Union held their regular monthly meeting last evening, at No. 68 East Broadway, -DAVID E COOKE in the Chair.

This anxiously looked-for event came off Tuesday night with great eclat, at Musical Hall, on Bush-street. The spacious hall was appropriately decorated.. The important Property Question between the two branches of the Methodist Church, we are happy to learn, is about to be amicably adjusted in this City.

WIDENING 0F THE BOWERY. Adjourned Meeting of the Committee. The Committee appointed to consider the proposed plan for the widening of the Bowery. met in the chamber of the Board of Aldermen yesterday. The Chair man was absent, but Aldermen WARD and FRANCIS Were present.
