The Land Commission has been very active during the fortnight, and have decided fifteen cases. They have decided nineteen cases in all, of which ten, containing 99,000 acres, have been confirmed, and nine, containing 261,000 acres, have been rejected.

Two questions have absorbed the entire attention of the politicians, viz.: the removal of the Capital, and the election of a U. S. Senator. The attempt to remove the Capital is occasioned by a desire to favor Sacramento City, the proposed capital, and by the desire of some of the members to enjoy more luxurious fare than a to be had at Benicia.

EDITOR OF THE SAN FRANCISCO HERALD: Yesterday, a Sonorian, named BERNARDO DANIEL, was arrested by the Sheriff, and taken before a Jastice of the Peace, upon suspicion of having had a hand in the murder of two pedlers, near San Juan Bapista, same weeks since.

The Buffalo Commercial pertinently calls attention to the remarkable fact that war has actually broken out between Russia and Turkey, in spite of the assurances of one or two of our City journals that such a result was actually impossible Gen.

The Honor Mayor WESTERVELT yesterday delivered In decision in the case of the gunpowder severe on board the barge Easton. The Mayor decides that the gunpowder cannot be legally res??red to the claimants.

In my last letters I have impressed upon you that the question of Cuba is misunderstood in the United States. Too much importance has been placed upon the idea, that the inordinate pride of old Spain would be an almost insuperable objection to the acquisition of that much over rated Island.

Business is very brisk at Tahiti, which place is rapidly rising in importance. The natives on the Island of Raiatea are engaged in a civil war, and have had several battles lately. The French steamer Phogue has gone to the Island of Huahine with the expectation of having a fight with the natives
FRESH OUTBREAK OF THE YELLOW FEVER.- The yellow fever has broken out afresh, with greater violence than even, at Newport, Fla., and the citizen, were dying from the place at last accounts.
The intelligence from California received per steamer Illinois, and published in this morning's TIMES, is various, interesting, and in many respects important.

In the Jones Wood Park.--This case came up, pursuant to notice from the Corporation Counsel, Mr. Dilep, who appeared, in accordance with the act of the Legislature, to move for the appointment of Commissioners to carry out the provisions of the act for making a Public Park.

Since the sailing of the steamer of October 15, a larger amount of business has been done than during the previous fortnight, but not enough to constitute an actual activity in trade Rates of many classes of merchandize, indeed, have declined even from their former standard.

Mrs. Ex-President TYLER some months since wrote a vigorous and masculine letter to the Duchess of SUTHERLAND, repelling the notion that Slavery, as it exists in our Southern States, deserves the hostility of the Christian world, and especially insisting that Englishmen have no right to complain of its features and incidents.

The St. Louis Republican gives the following particulars of the death of THADDEUS D. WARREN, a resident of that city: "It happened at Keokuk on Wednesday last under circumstances of a most distressing character Major WARREN. in company with Mr. WILSON, of that city. on last Wednesday started. to take a buggy ride.

THE REGATTA--FIRST PAY . The elements yesterday were singular propitious and seemed to conspire in working together to afted as a lovely day for the commencement of our boat racing sports. The day was one of the balmest and miltest we have set had throughout he bright visitation of the Indian summer with which we have for some time been favored.

SUPREME COURT.-The November term of the Circuit Court, Special Term, commenced yesterday, before Judge Brown. The whole of yesterday was occupied in hearing motions. There are 345 cases on the calendar for this term, which will be called to-day.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A report has been in circulation for somedays past that we have made an additional purchase of Broadway proper viz.: the Broadway Theatre, and the buildings adjoining, to Anthony-street.

COMMON COUNCIL PROCEEDINGS. Board of Assistant Aldermen--Nov. 29. The President in the Chair. An arrival from Charlottetown, P. E. I., reports that a new bark built there, which sailed about twelve days ago for Liverpool, was wrecked when only three days out on the voyage to Liverpool. She was fully insured in New-York. Name not given. CHARLESTON, Tuesday, Nov. 29.

JOHN MITCHEL was born in the City of Loudonderry, in the year 1816, and is consequently now about 38 years of age. His father was originally a Minister of a Trinitarian congregation in that City, but owing to a slight accident, if it might be so termed, changed his religious views and adopted Unitarianism.

The Revolution of 1830--Anniversary Celebration--Eloquent Speeches of Messrs. Felix Foresti, Kornis, Morange and others. In pursuance of a notice published for some days past in the City papers, the Polish Democratic Society assembled last evening at No. 337 Broame-street, in the rooms of the Irving Literary Society, to celebrate the Twenty-third Anniversary of the Polish Revolution of Nov. 19, 1830.
Last evening the Royal Geographical Society held its first meeting for the session of 1853-54, at the rooms of the Horticultural Society, No. 21 Regent-street.

Association for the Relief of Respectable Aged Indigent Females. The Association for the Relief of Respectable Aged Indigent Females held its 40th Anniversary, at noon Yesterday, at the Asylum in Twentieth-street, between Second and Third-avenues.

The event looked for so eagerly by our Irish fellow citizens of this City and vicinity, took place yesterday. JOHN MITCHEL, the Irish "felon" of '48 arrived in this City in the steamship Prometheus, at 1 3/4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
The British Lion Peaceably Disposed-- Par-Hamentary Rumors--General News, but little stirring. It continued to be generally circulated that Parliament will be called together at an early date.
Home politics are altogether quiet. The trial of the Opera Comique conspirators against the Emperor's life still goes on.
The weather continues warm, but boisterous. The wind is blowing hard from the South. In Chicago and Cleveland the weather is mi'd, and vessels are running freely. SYRACUSE, Tuesday, Nov. 29.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--The third performance of the Prophete" comes off to-night. As we anticipated, the production of this opera has been attended with the greatest success. On Monday night the house was crowded to excess; indeed, several hundred people were disappointed in obtaining sears.

Liverpool Markets. Per Atlantic.] LIVERPOOL, Nov. 15, 1853. Since the sailing of the Canada on the 11th inst., our COTTON market has been exceedingly quiet, not with standing the advices per Asia, since to hand, partially confirm the previous reports of a killing frost in the Cotton growing regions.

Howe.--This was a in ??tion to set aside the order for the street of the defendant on the ground that the Court had no jurisdiction in the matter. The Court ordered a reargement of the matter before the General Term.

The War in the East is proceeding steadily towards its full development. The Turks have encountered the Russians certainly in one pitched battle, and probably in two, and have come off victorious.
Nor again this morning are we without our usual announcement of deaths at sea. Elsewhere in our columns, under its usual head, may be found the melancholy record.

On the 8th inst. a cargo of "Royal Africans," as those unfortunate wretches who have been kidnapped from their native shores are called, were landed a short distance to the eastward of Cardenas. The circumstance has been made known to the English Consul General, who addressed a letter to the Captain General on the subject.

PUBLIC INSTITUTIONS. Excursion to Black well's Island, by Monsignor Bedini and the Ten Governors. At a late meeting of the Board of Governors, EDWARD C. WEST, President, SIMEON DRAPER, and P. McLAUGHLIN, Esqs., were appointed a Committee to invite His Excellency, Monsignor BEDINI, His Grace A rebbishop HUGMES, and others, to visit the Penitentiary and Charitable Institutions on Blackwell's Island.

Our friends in Mississippi are rejoicing over the Democratic victory obtained in that State. The Piomph is complete and overwhelming to the opponents of the Administration. The Governor, Congressmen, and a large majority of the Legislature, are thorough Democrats and zealous supporters of the National Administration.

The President to-day appointed W. W. WHIT MAN Editor of the Troy Budget, as Postmaster at Troy, vice FOSTER BOSWORTH, resigned. Besides Colonel FORNBY, who leads off, Judges YOUNG and STURGES are talked of for Clerk of the House. YOUNG was formerly Clerk.

Attica, N. Y., is under embargo. One man has had small-pox and twenty others varioloid, and in consequence a Board of Health has been organized, and very stringent measures adopted to stop a further spread of the disease.

The Legislature of South Carolina assembled at Columbus yesterday, and the Governor delivered his Message to day. He states that the funded debt on the 1st October was $1,870,986, and the assets $5,175,542. He recommends a subscription of $750,000 to the Blue Ridge Railroad; the establishment of a Board of Education; and the appointment of Commissioners of Public Instruction.

The following special dispatch reached our correspondent at Liverpool just before the departure of the Atlantic: VIENNA, Monday.-- GORTSCHANOFF set out on the 8th inst. for Olten??, to chastise the Turks, having with him 24,000 troops, mostly infantry, and on the 11th came up with the Turks, who had come out to meet him.

The U. S. Mail steamship Atlantic, from Liverpool, about 10 A. M. Wednesday, 16th inst., arrived at this port at 4 o'clock yesterday morning. The Asia arrived out Sunday forenoon, 13th, at 9 3/4 o'clock.

Yesterday evening, at 7 o'clock, the following additional particulars of the battle which took place on the 5th, at ??, were forwarded by electric telegraph: "BUCHAREST--Fourteen superior officers were killed. The Turks remained masters of the field. The Russians retreated towards Bucharest."

Rev. Mr. GILES delivered his second course of lectures at the Brooklyn Institute, on Tuesday evening, to a large audience. The lecturer remarked: LADIES AND GENTLEMEN: O'CONNELL used to say of of himself, that he was the "best abused man in Europe," and the should also have said that he was the best abuser in Europe.

Sir. JOHN GRAHAM, in a speech at a public meeting in England, gave the following detailed account of the manner in which Lieut, BELLOT lost his life: "It is my duty, I think, shorty to describe to you the concluding scene of his life. Capt. INGLEFIELD had left the ship himself determined to brave the greatest danger. endeavoring to open a communication with Sir E. BELCHER, by a journey over the ice in fact.

Last evening we had the pleasure of attending a third performance of the "Prophet." Our first impresssions were confirmed. It is without doubt the finest opera ever produced in New-York, both musically and scenically. It is gratifying to observe the readiness with which our musical community recognizes its merits.

Ex. Governor SEWARD, accompanied by his son, paid a visit last night to the Mechanics' Institute. He was received by the Actuary of the Society, JAMES HENRY, Jr. Esp., who conducted him over the library, and to the different class-rooms, in all of which the distinguished visitor took considerable interest.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your correspondent 'Viator's" communication concerning the Eastern Churches, contains some very rate perversions of history, and most remarkable sentiments even for a churchman. The merest tyro in Ecclesiology knows very well that it is the Gician or Eastern Church which prevails in Russia.

We copy, in another column, the latest letter of the New-York Correspondent of the London Times, which consists wholly of a vehtment attack upon the Administration, and another upon the Crystal Palace. There is nothing especially noticeable in either, and there is undoubtedly some truth in both.

REARREST OF "YANKEE SULLIVAN."--This celebrated personage is again in the hands of the Sheriff of Weschester Country, who claims to take Yankee as a Prisoner for violating his parole of honor, not to fight or engage in a fight again, given to the Governor of the State, who therefore pardoned Yankee, and released him from the State Prison a few years since, where he was under sentence for the affair of LILLY and McCOY.

From the Charleston (S. C.) Mercury. "The South has gained nothing but a loss by his law. It was a stupid blunder on the part of Southern statesmen. The value of the slave lost is eaten up if capture follows, while hatred to the institution abroad and opposition to it at home , and increased by his hard features and barbarous enforcement of them."

The bark Sultana, with KOSZTA on board, will arrive here about 2 o'clock, this afternoon. The matter creates no sensation. A special Committee, consisting of Sargent O'Neill, Capt. Thomas Case, and D. W. O'Brien, leave here this afternoon for New-York, to invite MITCHEL to visit Boston. The Committee represent "Old Ireland," "Young Ireland," and Military Ireland.

PRNOBSCOT RIVER CLOSED BY ICE.--We learn by telegraph from Bangor, that the steamboats Boston, Daniel Webster, Eastern State, with about sixty said of other vessels, are frozen in at that place, and that the Penobscot is completely closed by ice.

CITY RAILROADS.--At the last meeting of the Common Council, a petition was presented from H. N. Conklin and George L. Bennett, asking permission to lay a rail track on Fulton street and avenue to Benford. Alderman freely moved that the prayer of petitioners be granted. ong discussion ensued,

We give elsewhere, this morning, an instructive and interesting paper on Naval Reform, the especial object of which is to show the propriety and necessity for a settled, positive, legalized code of Naval Regulations, similar in their character and purpose to the code of regulations in the Army.

From the officers, the Whig gathered the following particulars in relation to the fire and the lose:

We had quite a Railway Jubilee here this morning. Our Legislature meets day after to-morrow, and the town is greatly thronged by members, both regular and lobby, as well as by hosts of stran gers. According to appointment, Gen. RUSK addressed the whole of them convened in one vast concourse, on the great topic-the Pacific Railway.

The St. Andrew's Society celebrated its One Hundred and Thirteenth Anniversary, last evening, by a grand banquet at Metropolitan Hall. In the afternoon a business meeting was held in one of the parlors, the proceedings being, as usual private. Some new members were received.

On Tuesday evening, Nov. 29, ELIPHA B., wife of George H. Petrie. The friends of the family, and those of her father, M. B. Allerton, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from No. 84 12th st, this (Thursday) afternoon, at 1/2 o'clock. The remains will be taken to Greenwood Cemetery.

I write from the commercial capital of that porsion of our State which we denominate as "East Tennessee"--that section lying east of the Cumberland Mountain, and which has furnished no title excitement amount the capitalists of the Union, on the subject of copper mines.

The Salt Lake Mail has arrived at Independence, bringing intelligence of the massacre of Captain GUNNISON and part of his exploring party. An Express reached Governor YOUNG on the 31st Oct., from Captain MORRIS giving an account of the massacre, which was committed by a party of Indians on Sevier River.

At the string of the Court yesterday morning, the above prisoners were placed at the Bar to take their trial for having killed the deceased, William stafford, at French's Hotel, on the 14th of May last, by knocking him down. Stamping on him, and striking him on the head with a tumbler while on the ground.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Among the various public abuses with which this great City is afflicted, the impositions of hack drivers are not the least annoying. The extorlions of these men seem to be quietly submit d to as a necessary evil. Because they are trifling in amount, the victim grumbles and pays rather than be subjected to insult, or lose valuable time in seeking uncertain and unsatisfactory redress.

THE BANK ROBBERY REWARD.--Yesterday afternoon Mayor WESTERVELT handed the check for 4,270, over to Police officer KEEFE, that being tho reward given by the Bank of the State of New-York, for the recent arrest of CHAUNCEY JOHNSON, and recovery of the $32,365. The officer was accompanied to the Bank

WOLVES--The wolves of Maine seem to be numerous and remarkably ??, the present season. A correspondent of the Machias Union says that the accommodation stage and passengers from Rockland were a few days since driven back from the woods near Indian River, and detained over night by a large detachment of wolves.

Since the commencement of hostilities on the Danube, every day has brought an installment of news, mole or less important, and let it be added, more or less contradictory. For the details, I refer you to the various accounts given in the papers, leaving you to decide as to what seems to be most trustworthy. Corrected bulletins have yet to arrive,

The great transatlantic guardians of International Law can hardly start a quarrel with us in the case of the Sandwich Islands. Diplomacy may dispense with VATTEL and labored epistles. There has been no filibusterism-no Intervention-no bribes offered to his Majesty of the Pacific group of Islands.

As usual just before the meeting of Congress, there is an almost perfect lull in Washington developments and speculations. The Administration, at such a time, gives all its attention to preparation for the session.

MAGAZINE DAY.-There were no HARPERS or PUTNAMS in the early time, when Magazine Day was anticipated by us with as much interest as quarter day by a landlord. There was the Knickerbocker,-the only survivor of that golden time. Glorious Old Knick! PEABODY had just started him, and HOFFMAN dipped his pen in the best ink that was then manufactured to keep him well a-going. And he has gone.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your paper of this morning contains a short police of the deaths on shipboard, sand to be by cholera, and as information upon this subject seems to be scarce. I propose to give you some facts which may at least awaken public attention.

I learn that the Secretary of the Treasury will immediately renew, for one month, the offer of July and August last, for the purchase of United States Stocks, which expires to-day. The balance in the Treasury on the 28th instant, was twentyfour millions four hundred and sixty-one thousand three hundred and fifty-six dollars and sixty-five cents.

The Court of Common Pleas opened its session in the upper chamber of the State House at 9 A. M. to-day. Judge STAPLE's charge to the Grand Jury was an able and a learned one. His Honor reviewed the Criminal Code of this State, going back to the days of the Old Colony for examples and illustrations.

Violent gale swept over Lake Erie last night, commencing about 8 o'clock. The steamer Mayflower did not leave her dock. We hear of no accidents to the shipping as yet, but a good number of boats are out, for this season of the year.

Mr. PUTNAM, in a letter in another column, urges upon public attention the wretched condition of our Cab and Hackney Coach system. His statements and remonstrances are entitled to consideration. The subject is important and the evil complained of one of the most serious that afflict our City.

The Democratic members hold their causus on Saturday night, to nominate officers for the House. Tae following are the principal candidates: For Speaker Messrs. Boyd, Disney, Orr, Olds, Richardson, Phelps, For Clerk-Messr? Forney, Sturgis, Young and Harris, For Door-keeper--Messrs. McKnew, the present incirn bent, Johnson, of La., German, of Md., and Allen, formerly Assistant Door-keepers, and Berret, of Md. For Postmaster--Mr. Johnson, the present incumbent.

DEATH OF ANSON G. PHELPS, ESQ.--We regret to announce the death of ANSON G. PHELPS, Esq., an old anti highly respected citizen. Mr. PHELPS died yesterday morning at his residence in this City, at the advanced age of 73 years.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: While looking over a map of South America a day or two since, examining its resources, commerce, and elements of trade, I was forcibly struck by the somewhat startling fact,-startling to an American merchant,-that the greater part of its foreign as well as internal trade is-carried on and actually monopolized by English companies and capital.

To the Congregation of St. Louis' Church: Listen, dearly beloved, to the voice of your Bishop; assuredly you will then also listen to the voice of the Eternal Bishop of your souls, who has said to His ministers: "He that hears you hears me ; and he that despises you despises me." Your divine pastor speaker to you through his human shadow, whom he has here "appointed a Bishop to rule the Church of God."

The situation of Turkey at the present time is so peculiar that all intelligence from that quarter is eagerly sought for. The following extract of a letter from a highly respectable gentleman residing in Constantinople, to a friend in this country, though no containing the latest news, will, it is believed, interest the American public.

ARRIVAL OF KOSZTA -- MARTIN KOSZTA, the Hunarian, whose capture by Austrian official at Smyrna, and subsequent rescue by the intervention of the Commander INGRAHAM, of the St. Louis, from the Austrian bring Hussan], are familiar to our read is, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, in the bark Sultana, after a passage of 45 days.

The November returns of the doings of this Society, show the following results or the present month: Tracts distributed to criminals, in hospitals and at the Navy Yard. 2,450: Tracts distributed among sailors, 4,463; Tracts distributed in the city generally, 10,738; making a total of 96,645 distributed during the month of November.

RAILROAD ACCIDENT--The New York and Eric train which left Jersey City at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, was detained by an accident which occurred when it had proceeded about two miles. The switch was wrong and the locomotive was thrown off the track completely, doing some damage to the road.

BRUTUAL MURDER AT NIAGARA FALLS.--The Lockport Courier is informed that a most horrible murder was committed rear the Suspension Bridge on Sunday evening. It seems that a man named THOMAS COSTELLO, was charged with stealing some money from a woman, and a man living near the bridge, whose name we have not learned, took he part of the woman.

EMIGRATION TO FLORIDA--The Charleston Mercury says that for many years past the tendency of an active protein of the population of South Carolins has been to "plant itself upon the virgin fields of Florida" The establishment of a line of steam Is, communicating directly with the heart of each State, has simula and this tendency in an extraordinary degree.

MARINE DISASTERS.--The gale Wednesday night and Thursday morning was severe in the Lakes. ?? of vessls on Lake Michigan state that the fury of the wind and roughtnes of the sea has seldom been equalled. The brig Coroline spring a leak off Sheboygan. and was forced back to Chicago.

ESCAPE OF CONVICTS FROM THE STATE PRISON.--On Tuesday night four convicts, named GEORGE W. GOODCOURAGE, JOHN WILLIAMS, EDWIN S JONES, and BERNARD CAMPBELL, made their escape from the State Prison, at Charlestown. They escaped through the hospital department, which is undergoing repairs.

By the schooner Golden Eagle we have dates from NASSAU, N. P., to the 23d instant. A hurricane had been experienced there during the three days preceding the 23d. The salvage on the goods saved from the ship Henry has been settled by the Chamber of Commerce at 15 per cent. The salvers receive $42,750.

We give place in this paper to a calm and ingeniously prepared defence of the people of the borough of Erie, Pennsylvania, on the present Railroad difficulties in that vicinity. It is from a source entitled to a fair hearing, though we much doubt whether it will be found conclusive in argument, or sound in its mode of reasoning, whether tested by law or good morals. Mr. MORTIMES STRONG, Agent for the American Bible Society in a letter to the Galveston News, gives a glowing account of the prospects of Western and Middle Texas, through which he has recently traveled.

LECTURE BY REV. J S INSKIP. The first of a series of Lectures in the Madison -- street Methodist Episcopal Church, was given on Tuesday opening by Rev J. S. INSKIP. The subject was, Modern Spiritualism, or the Rapping's Exposed The audience was numerous and respectable , and appeared to derive much pleasure from the evening's entertainment.

Two railroad accidents happened last evening on the Erie Road. The trial which left Jersey City at 5 P. M ran off the track when two miles out, detaining the Philadelphia train due here at 9 until ??o'clock. The Erie train due at Jersey City at 71 o'clock met with an accident at Hohekus Creek, 26 miles from Jersey City.

The bark Brothers is chartered as the store ship for the Japan Squadron. She lies at the Yard. Com BOORMAN has just sent fifty-five seamen to the Boston Navy-Yard, for the sloop-of-war Germantown. About the same number of men were drafted for the frigate Columbia, now lying in the North River, near Castle Garden.

Rev. Messrs. HERRICK and PIERCE, with their wives, and Miss SMITH, Missinaries of the American Board, sailed Wednesday afternoon, on board the brig P. Soule, Captals BROWN, for the Gaboon River, Western Africa, where they are to joint the Gaboon Mission.

CRIME IN COLUMBUS--We learn from the Columbus Journal that SARAH WILLIAM, the wife of Z. WILLIAMS, lately deceased, has been arrested and charged with having caused the death of her husband by using poison. For several years they had not lived on friendly terms, and he had frequently charged her with infidelity.

If a man has steady business and is receiving wages, it is a duty to lay up something out of it. When one is learning a trade it is different, but after he has got his trade or profession-has fairly started, and has plenty of work, it is a great shame if he does not "get ahead" in his money affairs.

We publish this morning an opinion of Judge NELSON, recently delivered in the United States Circuit Court, granting an injunction in favor of GOODYEAR and the New England Car Spring Company against ANSON G. PHELPS and others--a decision of importance and interest.

The Prize Fight between BRODLEY of Movamensing, and SLOAN of Baltimore, came off at 2 o'clock this after noon in Montgomery County, north of the Tunnel on the Reading Railroad. They fought 11 rounds, occupying only 17 minutes, when SLOAN was declared vanquished, not coming up to time.

BELLOT, a Lieutenant of the French Marine, has just fallen a victim to his noble dovotion to the cause of humanity, which had impelled him, for the second tune, to visit the North Pole, in search of Sir JOHN FRANKLIN whose fate, like that of LAPRYROUSE, at the close of the last century, excites universed sympathy.

Each day but adds to the fervor of the enthusiasm created by the arrived of JOHN MITCHEL in this country. Since the moment of his landing here he has been besieged by crowds--representatives of civil and military organization, and private individuals--anxious toto testify their sympathy for the cause for which he suffered, and their joy at his escape from bondage.

MAIL-BAG ROBBED.--By telegraph communication in ?? the Postmaster of Seueca Falls to the Postmaster of this city, we learn that mail-bags sent to seneca Falls, from Albany and Troy, by way express train, last evening were rubbed this morning. The contents were all taken.--Albany Atlas, Nov. 30.

We hear of a new project for a Pictorial Weekly paper, to take the place of tne Illustrated News. which has just been discontinued. BARNUM's scheme failed for want of proper editing. Money is not the only thing essential to the success of a newspaper, though without it, of course, nothing can he done in these days of sharp competition.

The Union publishes an official notice from the Secretary of the Treasury, extending the tim, for the purchase of United States Stocks to the 1st of January next. In addition to the usual assignment, the holder must distinctly assign his interest on the same now made us at the Treasury, or transmit the semi-annual coupons, as the case may be.

The conclusive and triumphant response of the American Government to the demands of Austries for redresa in the KOSZTA affair, has been just received, and is the more satisfactory, because the successive Cabinets at Washington have rarely shown, of late years, an efficient zeal for the protection of the rights and previleges of America in foreign lands.

The city is filling up rapidly. The Democratic Caucus promises to be very full. The prospect is that Mr. FORNEY will be nominated for Clerk, almost by acclamation. Although there is much bitterness against the Administration among a few extreme men, it is evidently largely in the majority in Congress.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: This is emisently a national picture, for it is painted by an American artist; and it illustrates one of the important features of the progress of civilization, exploration, and discovery in the Western world. A good deal of misapprehension exists in regard to what constitutes a national painting, or work of art.

We published yesterday the official announcement of the fact that the controversy between the Methodist Episcopal Church and the Methodist Episcopal Church South, in regard to the property of the Book Concern in New-York, had been amicably adjusted, by the acceptance of a proposition made by the Southern Commissioners.

BROOKLYN SOCIETY FOR RELIEF OF RESPECTABLE AGED AND INDIGENT FEMALES.--The third anniversary of this Society was celebrated on Thursday evening at the Athenaum, corner of Atlantic and Clinton-streets. The exercises commenced with a prayer by Rev. Dr. LANSING.

We published on the 1st inst. a communication from a highly respectable and responsible source, concerning the wretched accommodations and revolting treatment of emigrants on board a packet ship, the name of which, by a very provoking inadvertence, was given as the New World.

New-Orleans papers of Saturday last are received. They contain Vera Cruz dates to the 22d ult., and City of Mexico of the 17th. The Mexican papers are filled with details of horrible outrages committed by the Indians on the frontiers.

PROMPT AND EXPEDITIOUS.--Yesterday, a party, composed of an elderly gentleman and lady, of a lovely young lady and her brother, were seen to get into a splendid carriage, from the door of the Verandah Hotel, on St. Charles-street, at 3 o'clock, when everybody else was at dinner, and drive to Christ Church, on Canal-street.

ROBT. F. SHAW, Jr., son of the late Hon. ROBT. G. SHAW, and a respected merchant, died at his residence in Summer street, last night.

Further particulars of the blow up of the propeller Independence at Sault St. Maire, have reached us in letters from passengers. The explosion was caused by the neglect to let off steam during a stoppage for the purpose of completing the raising of the anchor.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As rumors have lately been circulated, that the line for a proposed railroad, surveyed under my direction, from Hoboken through the interior of this State to Syracuse and Canandaigua, had been abandoned as impracticable,--I desire to correct this erroneous impression, by briefly stating the facts as they are.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: The only way to avoid the impositions of the hack drivers in this City, is to avoid the back drivers themselves.

CITY TEMPERANCE ALLIANCE.--The Annual Meeting of the City Temperance Alliance was hold list evening. The Report presented a number of interesting facts. The receipts of the year have been $4,550, and the expenditures the same.

Dr. OLIVER WENDELL HOLMES closed last night his series of six lectures on the English Poets of the Nineteenth Century. They have been attractive and popular, and have been regularly attended by large audiences of cultivated persons.

We are in possession of Vera Cruz dates to the 22d. The news is not important. We subjoin items of interest: Awful accounts of the depredations of the Indians in frontier States reach the Capital by every mail. The savages are carrying on a sanguinary war against the unfortunate inhabitants in the North of Mexico, and the General Government, it seems, is unable to render them any help.

ANOTHER RAILROAD DETENTION.--On Friday morning, the 6 o'clock New-York and Erie train was delayed at the western termination of the Bergen Cut. A switch, which is seldom used, was put into requisition on the previous evening, when the locomotive was off the track, and it was left wrong, so that yesterday morning the locomotive was thrown off the truck, and a delay of over three hours occurred.

On Friday evening the Boston Association had their first Annual Dinner in the Manhattan Hotel. Because the Anglo-American Republic has no transmarine possessions--no dependencies at the antipodes--it is very commonly, but very erroneously, concluded that she has no colonies. In the European sense, she certainly has none; but, in another and a better sense, she is the greatest and most successful colonizer that has ever existed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: I observe, in your paper of yesterday, a communication from "Inca, Jr.," on English power in South America. It would be well, Sir, if the causes which lead to this superiority were discussed, and the remedies pointed out. Our people might then take the necessary steps to secure a share of the increasing commerce of the important region.

The Census Documents are just about issuing from the printer's hands, at a distance of three years from the time they were, or should have been, delivered to Congress! Why this delay? Because the Government has undertaken to do officially what nothing but science and learning, individually developed, can do.

From the Washington Union. The Union of the Democracy. It is a truism which all recognize, that when the Democracy are united they are invincible. But it is no less a truism, that it is only when defeat has impressed or party with the importance of union that its value is fully appreciated.

Cotton market firm at unchanged prices. Sales of the week 6,000 bales; stock on hand 42,000. Wheat and Corn quiet and without change in quotations. Money Market. The British Mail steamer Europa, which left Liverpool about 11 o'clock on the forenoon of Saturday, the 19th ult., arrived here yesterday morning about 9 o'clock. The U.S. Mail steamer Hermann had not been telegraphed at Southampton.

COMMON COUNCIL - Board of Aldermen had no quorum last night. The Board of Assistants met, and passed the ordinance making the election of Chief Engineer triennial, and the resolution for the erection of a new Fireman's Hall. JOHN T. TOWERS, Superintendent of the Public Printing, yesterday notified the President that he could no longer discharge the duties,-his commission having expired. It is understood that A. G. SEAMAN will be appointed in his place. The total amount of drafts registered at the Treasury, for the week ending Dec. 3, was $767,134 70.

JULLIESN'S CONCERT.--The maestro for the million is again the City. After a highly successful tour in the neighboring cities, M. JULLIEN purposes giving us another series of his delightful entertainments. In reality the present season commenced on Monday, but as that evening was strictly a private and confidential one, 9 (being devoted to the jubilant sons of Albion,) we can only speak of the season as commencing last night.

Judge EDMONDS did not appear before the Historical Society last night with his paper on Central America. The reason why is not stated; a very satisfactory one it was, of course. We simply call attention to it as a remarkable thing in the history of this Society, that any such disappointment should have occurred.

A very interesting memorial was yesterday adopted by the Chamber of Commerce, praying Congress to take some measures to relieve the Baltic Commerce of the United States from the heavy exactions now levied upon it by Denmark. All merchant vessels

The U.S. M. steamer Empire City, H. WINDLE, Commander, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She left New-Orleans at 9 A. M., of the 26th ult., but, owing to detention, was unable to cross the bar till the morning of the 27th. The Empire City arrived in Havana early on the morning of the 30th, and sailed, with the mails and passengers, for this port, at 8 A.M., of the 1st inst.

A large fire occurred in this place yesterday, about noon, in the manufactory of Messrs. W. B. DOUGLASS, who are widely known as manufacturers of various kinds of cast iron and chain pumps, hydraulic rams, garden engines The fire occurred in some low wooden buildings, in which the manufacture of the chain pumps was carried on, which were entirely consumed, with everything in them that was considerable.

The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday, in the Merchants' Bank. Wall street. There was a more than usually good attendance of members--C. PERRITT, Esq., in the Chair. The minutes of previous meetings were read and approved.

The case of Fry vs. Bennett was continued Yesterday, and a report of the proceedings had will be found in another column. The public probably recollect the steady and malicious assaults of the Herald upon the Italian Opera, under Mr. FRY's management, which laid the foundation for this suit.

Mr. GIDDINGS administered the oath to Speaker Boyd. Senator PETTIT asked GIDDINGS, to-day, if he swore Boyd strong. GIDDINGS replied, "Yes; I swore him in well, and on the higher law. The joint resolutions of Mr. DEAN, thanking Captain INGRAHAM and rendering him a sword, finds favor inside and outside of the House.

HALIFAX, Tuesday, Dec. 6. The U. S. Mail Steamship Humboldt, Capt. LINES, from Havre and Cowes on the 23d ultime, bound for New-York, in attempting to make this port for a supply of coal, went ashore this morning, about twelve miles from this city, and is a total wreck.

American enterprise will meet encourage, ment, and American honor find safety, in the Annual Report of the Secretary of the Navy, published complete in this morning's TIMES Its arguments are forcible; its illustrations are apt and clear, and its recommendations will, we believe, receive the approval of a majority of the people, and command the early attention of Congress.

Mr. BOURCICAULT'S Lecture last evening was attended by a very fair audience, and listened to with decided interest. It was a graphic sketch of Society in Europe, interspersed with humorous illustrations from characters of the present day.

On Monday, Dec 5, ARAMINTA M., wife of Col. Adams, aged 24 years. The friends of the family, and those of her father, Lebbeus Chapman, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, without further notice, this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from his late residence, No. 145 Franklin St.

On this number 255 are of the highest class, the Postmasters of which are appointed by the President.

The New-Orleans mail of Wednesday last, is received. A runaway negro at Natchez. stabbed a white man to the heart who attempted to arrest him, and afterwards jumped among the machinery of a mill, and was crashed to death. The Maryland Coal trade last week, amounted to 14.300 tons.

BOARD OF ASSISTANTS--The Board of Assistant Aldermen referred a resolution ordering the Corporation Counsel to take legal measures for opening Elm-street from its present terminus south to Chambers-street. Reports were adopted in favor of concurring with the other Board in the report and resolution for rebuilding of Catherine Market; in favor of concurring to pay THEODORE HUNT $6,526 14, for extra work on the new Court-House in the Park and on Essex Market.

The Cubard steamer Canada, Captain STONE, sailed at noon to-day, with 82 passengers for Liverpool and 24 for Halifax, and $740.500 in specie, principal American gold coin and ingots. $50,000 of it is for Halifax. The schooner King Fisher, arrived this morning from Fayal, Nov. 16, reports the bark Medford, from Nantes for New-York, put in Nov. 15, short of water.

Governor JOHNSON, of Virginia, transmitted his Message to the Legislature of that State on the 5th. The new Constitution, he says, has worked well, and bids fair to fulfil the expectation of the people. The amount of the State debt is $18,041,775. The aggregate estimated value of the property of the people of the State is over six hundred million of dollars.

Report of the Secretary of War. We have received from our Washington correspondent a copy of the Report of the Secretary of War. Its length, however, and the crowded state of our columns, render it impossible for us to present it in full this morning. We give, therefore, a full outline of its most important statements and recommendations.

Dr. SOLGER delivered the second of his course of lectures on Russia and Turkey, last evening, in the the Chapel of the University, to a considerable and intelligent audience. His subject was somewhat comprehensive, embracing a view of the internal condition of Tur0key, the Strength of her military and naval forces, the administration of her laws and finances, her religious regulations, and her social customs.

Congress did nothing yesterday but elect Chaplains and a Printer. Gen. ARMSTRONG, proprietor of the Union, was chosen Printer, receiving 125 votes out of 216 cast BEVERLEY TUCKER, the candidate of the Hards, received but 20. This vote probably indicates better than any other taken, as yet, the strength of the Administration in the House.

THE CLAIRVOYANCE CONSPIRACY--A HABEAO CORPUS ISSUED.--The exciting case of conspiracy by which one of our wealthy and most respected citizens, named JOHN R. STUYVESANT, was defrauded out of a house and lot in Sixteenth street, valued at $8,000 or $10,000, has been kept rather quiet since the arrest of Dr. JOHN K. SEYMOUR.

They have their fast days, and, their feast days; their seasons of charity and occasions of good cheer; and the public is supposed to be ass ignorant of the very existence of the Order, is the first settlers of New-Amsterdam were oblivious, of its own future greatness.

You will hear something of the results of the first visit of Commodore PERRY to Japan, by the last mail, and, I suspect see a good deal of ignorant criticism on what he has done: some will scold the Commodore for waiting for an answer; others for not going ashore; others for not going to Yedo; and some for coming away from there.

There will be incidentally a recommunitive of the ship channel route of Dr. BLACK, the Secretary of the Navy having given permission for one or more of the officers of the Cyone to assist.

The Senate commenced business at 25 minutes past 12 o'clock. Messrs DIXOS, WALKER, and COOPER attended. The Chair presented the Annual Report of the Secretary of the Treasury. The usual number was ordered to be printed.

The moral sentiments of the Express have been shocked. One of the recognized chiffomers of that concern called upon the Secretary of the Navy for a copy of his Report in advance of its being printed, and was told that he could have it if he would pay the cost of copying it--about 420.

The steamship Daniel Webster, from San Juan, Nicaragua, with California dates to Nov. 16, 150 passengers, and $400.000 on freight is below. She reports the steamship Star of the West left San Juan on the 1st inst., for New-York, with 400 passengers and $1,465,000 on freight. The steamship El Dorado, from Aspinwall, is also below.

A meeting of the officers of the uniformed companies at New-York, Brooklyn, Williamsburg, and Jersey City, Dict. at Military Hall, in the Bowery, last evening, to make arrangements for the demonstration in honor of JOHN MITCHEL. Col. FER?S, of the Ninth Regiment, presented, and Capt. BUTLER acted as Secretary.

The Railroad Company commenced opening the gauge at the State Line this morning, and the cannon has just been fired to call out the citizens to tear down the bridges, SECOND DISPATCH. ERIE, Wednesday, Dec. 7--12 M. The excitement is increasing. A mob of about seven hundred rowdies in at the bridge, tearing up the track, and cutting down the bridge.

THIRD DAY. Pursuant to adjournment, the Court met yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. EVIDENCE FOR THE DEFENCE. The first witness called on the part of Mr. Bennett was Benjamin Galbraith, who, having been sworn, was examined by Mr. Sandford as follows: A.--Are you acquainted with Benedetti and Truffi Benedetti? A.--1 am. Q.--Where are they at the present time? A.-They are both in Europe.

The revision of the Customs Duties is the subject of first interest in the annual Report of Mr. GUTHERIE. His plan of revision is briefly and very clearly set forth. It is not complex in the detail, though by what difficulties it is likely to be surrounded in practical execution, the public will best judge after the publication of the list of free articles, and the schedule of ordinary and extraordinary duties.

"UNCLE TOM" AND "HOT CORN."--The children of the Five Points House of Industry, under the charge of Rev. Mr. PEASE, visit BARNUM'S Museum this afternoon. The new moral drama of "Hot Corn" is to be played there this afternoon. This evening the famous version of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," that has occasioned so much eulogy, and is witnessed always by such extraordinary crowds of people, will be repeated.

When Mr. FLORENCE nominated TUSTIN for Chaplain of the House, Mr. BAYLEY asked to what denomination the Chaplin of the Senate belonged. FLORENCE replied, "To the Methodists." BAYLEY then said that there were two sects called Methodists. FLORENCE rejoined that the Chaplain of the Senate was a National Methodist.

At Plainfield, N. J., on Nov. 28, by Rev. Wm. Whittaker, LEWIS E. CLARK, of New-York, to ANNIE E., daughter of Cornelius Boice, of the former place. At St. John's Church. Stamford, Conn., on Wednesday, Dec. 7, by Rev. Dr. Todd, Capt. HENRY WINDLE, of Tarrytown, N. Y, to JANE DE FORREST, daughter of Hon. Chas. Hawley, of the former place.

Valuable Donations--The Library Building. The regular monthly meeting of the New-York Historical Society was held last evening at the Corner city-- Hon LUTCHER BRADISH in the Chair. Mr. MOORE announced the receipt of several additional donations during the month preceding, and also the names of the donors.

Yesterday morning, Coroner HILTON proceeded to the City Hospital, and empanneled a Jary to investigate the foul murder of young man, named PATRICK CLARKE, during in affray in Centre-street, on the night of the 29th November. The first witness called Was THOMAS McQUADE--The was one of the party that were in the row when the deceased and JAMES WIER were wounded.

Congress has organized. The dread day is past; and all the hopes and predictions of those who prophesied the triumph of faction have proved idle as the wind. King Caucus still reigns: and the cohesion of "the Democracy" is not destroy ed. The Administration is strong--much stronge' even than is best friends had hoped--stronger than many of its predecessors at the termination of their first conflicts with the disappointed spoils-hunters.

THE ACCIDENTAL SHOOHING CASE.--The case of accidental shooting that occurred last Sunday evening on board of the schooner Meteor, lying at pier No 10, East River, resulted in the death of the unfortunate young man, John W. Fox; and yesterday, Coroner Hilton investigated the melancholy affair. It appears, the deceased was second mate of the above Vessel, and Mr Lambert first mate of the craft.

THE CANARSIE RIOT. Trint of the Parties Implicated in the Rio at Canarsie. At the Court of Oyer, and Terminer held in Brooklyn on Wednesday, Judge BROWN presiding sixteen persons appeared to answer an?dictment for a riot at Canarsie, in Kings Co., on the 5th of July.

The iron duties are to be further reduced in 1855. Runner fixes the 29th of January as the date of the Celebration by the Archbishop of Paris, who will, in the meantime, be made a Cardinal. The Prefect of the Seine presents a report of finances, showing a deficit of three-quarters of a million of francs in the year. The recommends an increase of window-taxes and trade-patents to meet it.
Another Cabinet Council was held on Wednesday. A Turkish sympathy meeting, attended by 3,000 persons, had taken place at Glasgow. KOSSUTH sent a long letter, expressing his views.

Last night the citizens of Harbour Creek, east of Erie, held a meeting and received to remove the break of the Railroad running on the public highway, consequently about 1 1/2 miles of the track late be removed by 2 o'clock this afternoon.

Liverpool Cotton Markets. The dull state of the Manchester trade, and dis??nished consumption, prevented the accounts of frosts from producing much effect. The market was, however, firm all the week, with daily sales of 6,000 to 7,000 bales. The low or inferior qualities of American were in more request at dearer rates, but the prices of other qualities were uncharged.

On Thursday, Dec. 8, JAMES ALEXANDER, youngest son of David and Jane Lamb, The friend and relatives of the family, and members of Hancock Chapter. O. U. A., also the members of the Ninth Ware Police, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, which will take place from the residence of his parents, No 13 7th-av., on Friday, Dec. 9, at 1 o'clock. His remains will be take in to Greenwood for interment.

SIR: From the accompanying Report of the Commissioner of the General Land Office, it will be seen that the surveys of the public and?? have been ??eadily prosecuted, and large bodies of new lands during the past year brought into market ; that the wants of the emigrant have been fully met, and choice selections offered to the hardy pioneer.

The welcome to JOHN MITCHEL by the people of Brooklyn yesterday, demonstrated that advantages other than strength are derived from union. The inclinations of the countrymen of Mr. MITCHEL, resident here, have led them to propose ovations by individual civic societies and single military companies--each anxious to have the most immediate and prominent connection with any demonstration designed for his honor.
The child died, as well as the Queen of Portugal FERDINAND had been sworn as Repeat for his son PEDRO V. The Regent continues the old Ministry.

The steamship Niagara brings to Halifax three days later accounts from Europe than the advices by the Humboldt. They are highly important, in a political sense, in reporting a cessation of active hostilities on the Danube, owing to the floods in the river and its tributaries, and the voluntary withdrawal of part of the Turkish forces.

Mr. JONES, of Iowa, with a view of giving time for the formation of Committees, moved that when the Senate adjourned, it be till Monday. Agreed to. Mr HUNTER called attention to the death of Vice President KING--pronounced an eloquent eulogy, and offered the customary resolutions of respect.

Constantinople letters of the 10th show that the operations at Oltenitza were a feigned attack intended to deceive GOETSCHAKOFF as to OMAR'S real intentions. The plan succeeded, and OMAR is combining his troops to attack the division of General LUDEES in Bessarabia, and the Ottoman force in the Black Sea is to cooperate with the land forces in that attack.

SUPERIOR COURT-FIRST PART. Before Hon. Chief Justice Oakley. FOURTH DAY. EVIDENCE FOR THE DEFENCE. The Court assembled yesterday morning at 10 A M. It was more crowded than on any of the preceding days.

The following is an extract from a letter to a friend in Madison County: NEW-YORK, Nov. 29, 1853. The disease in my head continues una??ted. My New York physicians (how justly I do not know) believe it is a consequence of the surgical operation to which I submitted just Winter That skillful operation relieved me entirely of a painful disease; but it is, perhaps a worse one which has come upon me.

THE CLAIRVOYANCE CONSPIRACY. Death of Mr. John R. Stayvesant. Yesterday morning was the time fixed for the investigation of the charges preferred by Mr. JOHN R. STUYVESANT against Dr JOHN K. SEYMOUR and wife. Judge OSBORNE was in attendance to receive the testimony The case, however, was delayed until 11 o'clock by the non-arrival of the complainant.

Speaker BOYD is counselling with his friends about forming Committees. The task is a difficult one, because there are so many new members. Mr. Phelps,, Breckenridge, or George Jones, will probably by Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means.

HALIFAX, N.S., Thursday, Dec. 8. The Royal Mail Steamship Niagara, from Liverpool about 2 o'clock. P. M., on Saturday, the 26th Ultimo, arrived here a little before 11 o'clock last night.

The steamer Marion, of the Charleston line, left yesterday morning for Halifax, with steam pumps and all necessary wrecking apparatus to assist the steamer Humboldt. The last accounts state that 120 cases of merchandise have been get out, and also the cabin furniture.

Secretary CUSHING delivered a glowing eulogy on the life and character of Hon. WILLIAM R. KING, late Vice President, in the Supreme Court to-day, and moved an adjournment. J. H. YOUNG, Consul at Currcoa, has been ordered by telegraph to Washington.

It seems clear from the testimony adduced that there was such a conspiracy. One of the prisoners testified that a plot had been formed for the purpose, and that the arrangement had been made

The New-Orleans papers of Saturday last are received. They contain Galveston dates to the 29th ultimo. The South Western Texas Railroad Conventions had provided for the exploration of the El Paso route.

The foreign representatives present in Washington, with their ladies, paid their respects to the President and his lady yesterday, which was the first reception Mrs. PIERCE has participated In. It is understood that the customary public receptions will be resumed at the White House next week.

CORONER'S IRQUEST. Yesterday morning. Coroner O'DONNELL held an inquest at No. 129 Second-avenue, on the body of Mr. JOHN R. STUYVESANT, whose sudden death from Asiatic Cholera we noticed yesterday. Mr. STUYVESANT's age was 56. He was a native of this City.

JOHN MITCHEL--THE NEW PAPER--A deptstation from the "Mitchel Club" of this city waited on Mr. MITCHEL, at his residence yesterday evening, and presented him with an address of welcome. The address is printed in gold bronze on green satin, and is very neatly and appropriately decorated.

This has been rather a dull day in Congress. The eulogies on the late Vice-President KINO were appropriate and eloquent. Mr. EVERETT and Mr. CLAYTON, especially, were listened to with deep interest; but I suppose your Congressional reporter has furnished their remarks. In the House of Representatives, theme honors to the memory of the illustrious dead were marked

From the Albany Evening Journal. The Utica and Schenectady Railroad has been, for several years, subject to more or less of depredation and obstruction in the vicinity of "Tribes Hill." Much time and money has been spent in efforts to defect the offenders, and the difficulty in doing so has caused great solicitude.

The Academy of Medicine, finding their usual room occupied, turned into the Chancellor's spacious quarters at the New-York University on Wednesday evening. The attendance was very large, the number of arm-chairs nearly, though not quite, as large. Dr. ISAAC WOOD occupied the Chair.

THE WHIPPED SLAVE CATCHER--The slavecatcher who was whipped by a ports of fugitives at Windsor, C. W., was named PAYNE. He was from Kenturky, where he owns a large plantation, and two or three hundred slaves. Three of his slaves were living near Windsor. He endeavored to induce them to pss over to Detroit with him, under the promise that he would there furnish. them with "free papers " For the purpose

Philadelphia and Newark papers assure us that Asiatic cholera is quite prevalent in this City. From the former city we heard the announcement some fortnight since, and at once took special pains to inquire how far it was true. The results are that we hear of five or seven cases of well-marked cholera

A meeting of the Women's City Temperanoe Alliance was held at No. 15 Laight-street on Tuesday. There were about twenty ladies present. At 3 o'clock P. M., the meeting was called to order by Mrs. T. S. MARTIN, President of the Society.

HORRID ACCIDENT.--At the Print Works this morning, two men were badly injuried, and eight others made a narrow escape. Twenty-five feet from the ground there was an arch roof, of brick laid in cement, over one part of the old Print Works, and they were seated upon it hammering it off, as it was hard as a rock. They had broken off a great quantity in safety.

Neither carrier pigeon, nor mounted Tartar, nor electric wire nor steam machine has brought us anything new since my last, from the seat of war. Our impressions upon the subject may be reduced to the following brevities, which may be easily committed to memory.

The War Department received advices to day from Captain MORRIS confirmatory of the previous accounts of the massacre of the GUNNISON party. The Star says that MORRIS found the bodies so mutilated by wolves that they could not remove or even bury them.

ESCAPE OF THE ICE-BOUND STEAMERS.--The ?? Mercury says that the passage of the steamers Daniel Webster, Boston, and Eastern State, down the Penobecot, after their escape from the ?? at Bangor, was marked by various jubilant demonstrations.

We learn that the Humboldt bas been kept insured up to about two months since, when the amount paid upon the several policies had reached $100,000, and it was deemed beat to allow each stockholder to insure his own interest or not at his pleasure. Thus, with the exeeption of about $60,000 insured to cover an obligation, the regular policies had expired and were not renewed.

THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.--The annual meeting else of the representatives of the Fire Department, for the lion of a board of officers, was held Thursday evenings at Firemen's Hall. The President, ANTHONY F. CAMPBELL, occupied the Chair, and WM. A. WALKER acted as Secretary. The election resulted as follows:

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: The Pleasantest holidays of the year are near at hand -- the annual season of festivities and gifts -- when love, and friendship, and gratitude, and generosity find a material expression. Our shops are full of tempting articles.

JONAS CHICKERING, the well known piano-forte manufacturer, died suddenly last night of apoplexy. N. CUNNINGHAM Co., merchants, Nos. 27 and 28 India Wharf failed yesterday afternoon for a large amount --reported at $150,000.

The accident of Thursday night on the NewYork and Erie Railroad, some particulars of which were given in the TIMES of yesterday, proves to be a serious affair. The injured brakeman, THOMAS FEATHERSTON, died yesterday morning at the City Hospital.

On Wednesday, Dec. 7, THOMAS G. MOWER, M.D, surgeon U. S. Army. The relatives and friends of the family, the officers of the Army and Navy, and the medical profession, are invited to attend his funeral, without further invitation. on Saturday, the 10th inst., at 1 P. M., from St. John's Church.

Before Judge Betts. In re William A. Smith, a citizen of the State of Virginia, Alexander P. Green, of the State of Tennesses, Charles B. Parsons, of Kentucky, and others, vs. George Lane, and others, of New-York.--Mr. Lord appeared, and moved that the degree of the Commissioners in this case, which had been agreed upon by them, and the set, tlement based thereon, should be now entered on the minutes of the Court.

CANNEL COAL IN WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA.--The discovery of this valuable mineral in our neighborhood in immense quantities has been rendered certain by recent explorations. Mr. JOSEPH BURKET, the fortunate individual on whose property the treasury has been found, has already drifted nearly 100 feet into the hill, and the prospect opened is promising indeed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I observe in your paper of yesterday a communication from " Inca, Jr.," and one from " Excelsior," on English power in South America. I should be pleased if both those gentlemen would get up a set of questions on the trade, manners and customs, and modes of trading; what description of goods, English, American or French, are the best goods for that market;

The newspapers in Boston are in a dreadful state of excitement over the fact that the Post got the start of them all in publishing the President's Message. Their columns are filled, morning and evening, with ponderous speculations as to the way In which this result was brought about, and with the most terrific denunciations of the unknown parties who were accessory to it.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.-On Wednesday evening we attended a sixth performance of the " Prophet." It was announced as the " last night," and attractedd an overflowing house. From parquette to the curious little side balconies was one mass of human beings. There was not single seat unoccupied, and many, who had wrongly calculated the contingencies of the occasion, had to pay the penalty by standing all the evening.

We have news from Fort Laramie to the 16th ult. The Cheyennes confirm very nearly the statement of their loss in the engagement with the Pawnees and other tribes, viz: seventeen Cheyennes, five Arrapahees, two Kiowas, and one hundred and seventy horses killed. They are now in tears and sorrow, and have sent out against the Pawnees a large was party of their tribe and Sioux.

LATER FROM BERMUDA AND ST. THOMAS.-By; the arrival of the British mail steamer Merlin we have dates from Bermuda to Nov. 30, and from St. Thomas to Nov. 16, announcing the disappearance of fever and the arrival of the new Colonial Governor ELLIOTT at the former place.

OR Saturday, Dec. 10, at Brooklyn, HARRUET LUCRETIA, aged 30 years, wife of Edward M. Duncan, and daughter of the ate William Russell. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, from No 227 West 27th-st., New-York, to-day, Monday. at 12 o'clock

The weather is warm and calm. The steamer Sultana leaves for Cleveland to-night, crowded with passengers. The Louisiana came in today. There was some excitement on the dock in consequence of a charge of murder against some of her deck hands, who are suspected of ?? and throwing overboard the second mate of the steamer Buckeye State, who was on board.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Another five-act comedy is to be produced here this evening. The activity of our New-York managers will become a proverb. During the past two weeks, three original Comodies have been produced. As an indication of enterprise and proper feeling, this fact is gratifying and significant. We trust will be no lack of public support.

The destruction of the immense publishing establishment of Messrs. HARPER BROTHERS, will probably be felt by a greater number of persons, and over a larger extent of country, than any similar disaster which has ever befallen any single business concern.
SANFORD'S Ethiopian Opera House, on Twelfth-street, below Chesnut, was damaged by fire last night. DANIEL TOLL, the brakeman on the Pennsylvania

As Hon DRIESBACH was performing his feats with the trained animals in the cage in the rear of the exhibition-room, the tiger spring at him, knocking him down, and fastening its teeth and claws upon DRIESBACH's breast and limbs. By the Salt Lake mail the following letter has been received from Mr. HOMANs, Astronomer and Civil Engineer of Capt. GUNNISON'S Surveying and Exploring Party: CAMP NEAR FILLMORE CITY, UTAH TERRITORY, Oct. 28, 1853. After having arrived thus far in safety, and been eminently successful in the accomplishment of the objects of our expedition, a most afflicting dispensation has cast a deep gloom over our party. Capt. GUNNISON, Messer.

ROAD-It is evident that the entire responsibility of the collision which occurred on the New-York and Erie Railroad, between Bergen Cut and the Hackensack River, on Thursday night last, rests upon those who were in change of the emigrant train--which should have remained at or near the junction of the Roads, instead of proceeding, until the Express train had passed.

The Cunard steamship Niagara arrived at her wharf about 111/2 o'clock last night, bringing in all, (including her own and the Humboldt's,) about 250 passengers. All the mails were forwarded for the South by the early train this morning.

The Railroad Company last night completed laying the track, and repairing the bridges up to the city limits, and the train was run over from the State line to within a tile of the ??. In the night the rioters at Harbor Creek again tore up the track, destroyed the culvert bridge, and plowed up part of the grade of the road.

The revenue cutter Hamilton left the ?? Dock here on Wednesday for a cruise, having on board THOMAS E. ?? of St. Marys, Ga., the captain; CAMILLUS SAUNDERS, son of Gen. ROMULUS SAUNDERS, first ?? -tenant; E. C. HINES, second lieutenant, and a crew of twelve men. It blew a hurricane last night.

The Union denies the imputation that the President, his Private Secretary, or any member of the Cabinet, furnished the Message in advance, and says newspapers which published it in advance, must have obtained copies by stealth, bribery, or some other indirection.

Yesterday evening, the residents of the easterly portion of our City-embracing the Seventh, Eleventh. and Thirteenth Wards-were thrown into quite a state of excitement, in consequence of a serious riot being anticipated respecting the arrest of a person who, for several Sunday, has been in the habit of preaching on the wharves, in ship-yards, and other obscure places along the East and North Rivers. The files of California papers brought by the steamships El Dorado and Daniel Webster contain little of particular interest to the generality of readers. As is usual late in the Fall, business was quite brisk, but prices were still low in consequence of the large stock of every description of goods on hand.
Halifax papers of the 8th are received. Rear Admiral ARTHUR FANSHAWE has been appointed to succeed SIR GEORE SEYMOUR as British Naval Commander on the North American and West Indian stations.

By the bark Springbok, from Cape Town, Cape of Good Hope, Oct. 25, arrised here to-day, we have CapeTown Papers to that date, which state that the country continued in a quiet state, -- only a few isolated murders occuring. The authorities were busily enagaged in allotting the for eited lands of the unfortunate Kaffirs to Dutch and English settlers. A portion of the English troops at the Cape are to go to India.

Aldermen FRANCIS presented a petition from 203 citizens living on the line, to have the Bowery opened to Franklin-square; also Pearl-street from Franklin square to Battery. Referred to the Committee on Streets. An invitation to the Aldermen to attend the Eleventh Annual Ball of the Mazeppas Engine Company No 48, on Wednesday, 18th inst., at the Chinese Assembly Rooms, was read and unanimously accepted.

Speaker BOYD has prepared a list of Comnittees in the House, and reappointed all the Chairmen of the last Congress, who are in this, including Mr. GEO HOUSTON on Ways and Means, Much dissatisfaction is expressed in consequence, The Senate Committers are also agreed upon.

The House of Representatives yesterday laid on the table, by the decisive vote of 128 to 72, a resolution offered by Mr. WENTWORTH, of Illinois, declaring the power and duty of Congress to build a Railroad to the Pacific.

Rows.--At a disturbance in Court-street on Sunday night, a man named ROBERT NEWELL was knocked down, and severely injured by falling upon the curb stone. An affray occurred in Court-street, near Dean, a few nights since, during which JAMES O'NEIL was severely stabbed in the abdomen and other places.
If there are any aldermen who are in danger of starvation from being thrown out of employment January 1st, 1851, we advise them to apply for admission to the Bar.

N??ne of the deck-hands of the steamer Louisiana, charged with the robbery and murder of E. ANDERSON, were arrested here on Saturday, and committed to jail. ANDERSON was ma??e of the steamer Buckeye State, resided at Cleveland, and bore a good character for sob??ety.

The Report of the Secretary of the Treasury appears to have given an unusual degree of satisfaction to the press of both parties. His Tariff proposition too clearly recognizes the principle of protection, to make his report very obnoxious to the Whigs, while the enlargement of the Free List, even upon this principle, has made it generally, if not universally, acceptable to the Democratic party.

SUNDAY ROWDYISM.--The Police of the Third Warden Sunday arrested a gang of rowdies for fighting the public street. Yesterday they were brought before Justice BOSWELL, who fined four of the party, belonging in New-York, and sentenced the fifth, named WINDELL KOOSTZ, to 60 days' imprisonment in the Peni??ary.

The HALPERS have opened a business office at No 65 Beekman-street, corner of Gold, in the building occupied as a type-foundry by JOHN T. WHITE. Their safe was taken there yesterday, and their account books, policies of Insurance, , , found to be perfectly safe.

Formerly when a steamer from Chagres or San Francisco arrived, the newspapers very properly headed the column with "News from California"; now we look through that opening for light from both sides of the Pacific.

The election of BEVERLY TUCKER to-day, Printer to the Senate, was totally unexpected by outsiders, and even by BEVERLY TUCKER himself. The whole matter was agreed upon in caucus, but kept a profound secret.

RESIGNED FIREMEN'S TARGET EXCURSION.--A Target Company is organizing, under the name of "More-house Guards." in honor of the late Chief Engineer. They will go to Hoboken on the 30th inst, for the purpose of shooting; and, afterwards, partake of a dinner It is probable that the Company will number over eighty persons.

Oregon enjoys peace and plenty. Internally and externally--absolutely and relatively. She has little to fear, and much to hope. The harvest has been abundant, and were it not for the great immigration which has rolled in upon us, there would be a surplus of all sorts of agricultural products.

" Uncle Tom's Cabin, as presented at the National Theatre, and "Little Katy, the Hot Corn Girl," as also performed at the National Theatre, we would cheerfully recommend as being the best and most truthful dramatizations to be witnessed in the City.

THE FIRE DEPARTMENT--ELECTION OF OFFICERS.--Over two hundred delegates from the several Tire Companies assembled in Firemen's Hall last evening. After the usual business they proceeded to elect officers for the ensuing year.

The Street Committee met in the Chamber of the Board of Assistants, at 2 o'clock P. M. yesterday, to hear parties in relation to the proposition for extending the Bowery to Franklin-square, and widening Pearl-street to the Battery.

If, as is rumored, Speaker BOYD has really determined to reappoint all the Chairmen of the Committees of the House of last year, so far as those gentlemen have been returned to the present Congress, he displays much less of tact and discretion than we should expect of one deemed worthy so responsible a position as that he occupies.

RICHARD T. COMPTON, Esq., in the Chair. Alderman BARR presented a petition from Michael Taggart, asking for compensation for a horse, killed by backing off pier No. 30, East River. Referred. REBUILDING A MARKET.

The investigation concerning the forged bank drafts that were cashed in Canada last Summer, is now drawing to a close. The following additional proceedings transpired yesterday, before Judge Stewart, at the Jefferson Police Court.

From the Washington Union. PUBLIC PRINTER TO THE SENATE. By reference to the proceedings in the Senate on yesterday, it will be seen that BEVERLY TUCKER, Esq., the proprietor of the Washington Sentincl, was elected Printer to the Senate. Mr TUCKER received 26 votes, and Gen. ARMSTRONG 17.

The MORGAN brothers were released from the City Jail yesterday, at 11 o'clock, A. M., and proceeded at once to the Aquicneck House, where they took up their quarters until this morning, when they left for New York. Their sojourn in Newport will cause them to be remembered by the people of this vicinity for a long time to course.

The investigation of this case was resumed yesterday afternoon in the chamber of the Board of Assistant Aldermen. B. B. Purdy, sworn, said: I am Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies. (Specifications shown for Engines Nos. 42, 46, 45, 15 and 26.)

Cancus Meeting of the Aldermen Elect. THE NEXT PRESIDENT OF THE BOARD. Last evening a caucus meeting of the new Aldermen was held in the Library-rooms of the City Hall. All the members elect were present except these from the First, Fifth, Sixth and Eighth Wards. NATHAN C. ELY, Esq., of the Seventeenth Ward, was called to the Chair, and Alderman MOTT, of the Twenty-first Ward, was chosen as Secretary.

CITY RAILROADS--The Specia1 Committee on Railroads, appointed by the Common Council, have, after a consideration of two months, "arrived at the conclusion that they would be doing injustice if they should adopt any other principle than that of giving contracts except at the lowest price, and in the offer of adequate security that the Railroads should be perfectly completed and conducted."

A regular session of the Suffolk County Teachers' Association was held at Riverhead last week. It commenced Thursday afternoon by the consideration of various Reports, one of which on Arithmetic received much attention. THOMPSON'S Practical (revised) was eventually adopted as the standard.

TWO MORE CHAPTERS IN THE KISSANE CASE -- The unfortunate KISSANE may well think that midfortunes "come in battalions" J. B. CLARKE, a lawyer from New Brighton, and the man who had the side court at the Hotel, for the examination of witnesses during the progress of the famous Martha Washington case, has brought suit against KISSANE for his services.

Yesterday forenoon Coroner GAMBLE held an inquisition at the City Hospital, on the body of Mrs. ELIZABETH H. DEIDERICK, who died of injuries received on the evening of the 8th mat., by the collision on the New-York and Erie Railroad. The deceased was about 30 years of age, and was the mother of two little children that were with her when the accident occurred.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--SALVI's benefit attracted a good attendance last evening. "Masaniello" was given for the last time, and quite as satisfactorily as on previous occasions. There will be but two more performances--one on Friday, and the last on Monday. The "Prephete" will be repeated on both occasions. There is no performance tonight.

New-Orleans papers of Wednesday are to hand. They contain further Texas news. Governor BELL had resigned his office, and the duties had devolved on Lieut. Gov. HENDERSON. General JONES had returned from the frontiers and reported the Indians all quiet.

THE RUSS PAVVEMEMT. Law on the Award of Contracts. SUPERIOR COURT--GENERAL TERM. Before Judge Hoffman. Horace P. Russ and Geo. W. Reid agt. The Mayor, , of the City of New-York, Bartholomew B. Purdy, Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies, and John Cooke and George Caplin.

The Senate commenced at 12 1/2 o'clock. Mr. HUNTER, from the Finance Committee, to which was referred the communication of the Secretary of the Treasury, respecting the manner of paying Senators, reported a bill to regulate the disbursement of the coutingent fund of the Senate.

The weather is still unusually warm and pleasant. The steamer Mayflower leaves to-night for Detroit, touching at Cleveland. SYRACUSE, Tuesday, Dec. 13. The weather is clearing up this afternoon, and becoming pleasant and mild. Boats are still running.

The times in Texas are good--finances in a sound condition, an overwhelming crop realized, remunerating prices obtained. Our Legislature is in session. Bills have already been introduced favor of setting apart a liberal sum for common school education, and making a generous donation of the public domain to secure the Pacific Railroad through our State.

The steamship Isabel has arrived here bringing Havana dates to the morning of the 8th, and Key West to the same evening. General CANEDO Was to return to Spain in about a week. Consul CLAYTON had been duly received.

A meeting of the Civic and Trades Societies of this City was held in Montgomery Hall, No. 76 Prince Street, last evening to take action in reference to their invitation to JOHN MITCHEL, to a public profession by them. Mr. WILLIAM CARROLL acted as Chairman, and Mr. JOHN McGRATH as Secretary.

We find the following in the Spirit of the Taxes, touching the shipment of Trotting stock for California: Mr P. HUNT, whose livery and sale stables at San Francisco, known as "Tattersalls," are so popular, sailed from this port on Monday last in the steamship Illinois.

On Monday, Dec. 12, JOSEPHINE, daughter of William and Margaret Tucker, aged 3 years 5 months and 14 days. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Wednesday, the 14th inst., at 10 o'clock A. M., from the residence of her father, No. 28 Macdougal-st.
