New ENGLAND SOCIETY.--The annual meeting of this Society was held on Saturday evening, at the Mansion House--CHANDLER STARR, the President, in the Chair. On motion, they proceeded to the election of officers- previous to which, the present President declined a reflection.

Our City is, as your readers are doubtless aware, one of the favored cities of the Great West. We are at the head of Lake Erie, at the outlet of the Wabash and Erie Canal, and the Miami Canal --the business of which is very heavy, and constantly increasing.

The Secretary of the Navy complains of the blunders in the New-York copies of his report, and attributes them to the telegraph. No copy of his report was sent by telegraph, as I am informed at the telegraph office. The blunders were made in his own office and by his own paid clerks who sold the Message.

Father GAVAZZI has been with us for the past week, preaching earnestly against Romanism, religious and political. He is a very eloquent man, and, for an Italian, argues very well. But he for gets the hemisphere. He involuntarily shows how much behied our policy of government is the mind of Italy.

Rev. J. S. INSKIP last evening delivered another of his Course of Lectures in the Madison street M. E. Church. His subject was "Woman's Rights." The lecturer held that the late discussions had done good, in so far as they directed public attention to the radical errors in Woman's education,--a subject which has been too much neglected.
STARTLING DEVELOPMENTS--A WIFE OF THREE HUSBANDS--One of the most extraordinary cases that it ever befell 'Squire PARSONS to investigate, came under his notice this morning.
Nothing was done by the House of Representatives yesterday but to lay on the table two or three additional resolutions in favor of a Pacific Railroad.

The last of a series of lectures by RABBY RAPHALL, on the Sacred Poetry of the Hebrews, was delivered on Monday evening in the lecture room of the Broadway Tabernacle. The attendance was not very large, but evidently drawn from the most intellectual and intelligent class of our citizens.

The following statement has been made by the party that left San Francisco in October for the invasion of Sonora: HEAD-QUARTERS OF THE REPUBLIC OF LOWER CALIFORNIA, Nov. 7, 1853. On the morning of the 17th of October we sailed with the first Independence Battalion for Lower California. The command consisting of forty five men, our voyage was a prosperous one to Cape St. Lucas.
Government Changes--The Indians inclined for Peace on the Brazos Frontier--Mexican Outrages. We have received Galveston papers to the 2d instant, and our exchanges from the interior as late as due.

HEAVY ROBBERY.--Sir GEORGE GORE, an English gentleman whose arrival here was noticed on Tuesday last, was robbed on his trip down from Chicago, of a portmanteau, containing a draft for a thousand pounds, or $5,000, a signet ring, near $300 in gold, and some jewelry of value.

Several ships have arrived at this port from Liverpool within the past week, crowded with passengers, on board which no mortality has occurred. But they are not a whit cleaner, so far as we can learn, than were those which lost a fifth or an eighth of all their human freight in the passage.

"UNCLE TOM's CABIN.--The correct and faithful version of this wonderful drama can only be witnessed at the National Theatre, where it has been played every night, and every Wednesday and Saturday, since the 18th of last July.

Seventeenth Anniversary of the Colored Orphan Asylum. The Seventeenth Anniversary of the Colored Orphan Asylum was celebrated last evening at Hope Chapel. The number of children present was 213, including boys and girls. The body of the room and the galleries were occupied by the audience.
An unfortunate difficulty occurred this morning between Secretary GUTHRIE and Senator GWIN, at the Treasury Department. The Secretary is charged with treating the Senator very rudely.

Present-The Recorder. Cornelius White, a colored man, indicted for an assault and battery with intent to kill George H. Combs, on the 23d of November, pleaded guilty to the assault. He was remanded for sentence.

EFFECTS OF INTEMPERANCE--Coronor O'Donnell yesterday held an inquest in the City Prison, on the body of Joseph Mercum, who died there on Saturday night, he having been found ying on the walk, corner of Broadway and Chambers street, by officer Jackson, to a beastly state of intoxication, and by him conveyed to the Police Court.

We publish elsewhere, for the edification of the curious, the articles of agreement under which the Manhattan Railroad Company is organized. It will be noted that everything is nice and formal to the last degree. There is no room for demurrer or amendment. The facts required by the General Act are all clearly set forth. We have the names, residences, and size of interest of each and every party.

This Anniversary was held in Cincinnati on Dec 4, 5, and 6. Missionary services were provided for all the churches on Sunday morning, the 4th. The prayer meeting, Monday afternoon, under the direction of Bishop JANES, was a season not to be forgotten. The Bishop suggested to each brother be called upon, the special subject of supplication in his prayer; and all the people followed in the devotions with heartfelt amen.

The second of Mr. DION BOURCICAULT'S "Winter Evenings" was given by that gentleman on Tuesday night, at Hope Chapel, to a crowded and applauding audience. The entertainment was nearly two hours in duration, but the audience, far from being wearied, were attentive and delighted to its close. The discourse of Mr. BOURCICAULT was pleasantly illustrated by several well-executed paintings of scenes of especial interest in the history of the drama.

MYSTERIOUS MURDER IN MISSOURI--The New Madrid Times of the 28th ult., had an account of the murder of a man named ABNER CHOATE, in Lucas Bend, about fifteen rules below the mouth of the Ohio, in Missouri. CHOATE is said to be from Kentucky. A man named HICKS was arrested for the murder, but on examination was discharged.

The first part of it describes Ward's Island, its refuges and hospitals, nurseries, school-rooms and chapel. The order, decorum and propriety apparent there to all visitors, are much commended. DEATH IN THE STATE PRISON.--BRADBURY FURGUSON, who shot his wife in the year 1840, at Exeter. N. H. died in prison, last month, aged 52. His murdered wife, ELIZA J. FROTHINGHAM, was a native of Ports mouth.

Our private correspondence with the bor; ough of Erie is rapidly increasing. Our table groans under the weight of letters, professing great respect for the TIMES, but deploring its blindness as to the real character of the Railroad riots at that place.

The New Orleans mail of Monday is received. The papers contain details of the Mexican news up to the 8th instant. The only item of interest is the statement that the plan of Guadalajura, relative to the prolongation of SANTA ANNA'S powers, have been recorded by the capital, and other important cities.

Great misrepresentations and many falsehoods, relative to the Railroad troubles at Erie, having been industriously circulated and widely scattered abroad, the Mayor and Couacils of the city have deemed it a duty which they owe, as well to themselves as to an intelligent public, to submit a brief statement of affairs-confidently believing, that when the truth is laid before the public, their conduct will meet with its hearty approval.

THE RELATION OF MASTER AND SiRVANT.In the case of Skipp vs. The Eastern County Rail. Road Corpany, lately tried in England, a novel point was presented. The plaintiff was the guard of a freight train coming from London. It became the plaintiff's duty at Lea-Bridge Station to attach to the train 42 trucks, which were there in readiness for the purpose.

At a special meeting of the Common Council this evening, a communication was received from FOSTER BoSWoRTH, saying that he would have moved to West Troy before the meeting of the next Board, and, therefore, begged to resign the office of Mayor.

THE ERICSSON--The problem as to the success of the ?? on approaches a solution. The engine is now so nearly completed, that a trial trip will probably be made next Tuesday or Wednesday, and Mr. ERICSSON is in the best Spirits--Such as confidence f success inspires.

The lot of the Eniigrant, at the best. is bard. Poverty chases him from his native land. Disease meets him on ship-hoard, and temptation to vice consort with him in the filthy steerage. Arrived here-penniless, homeless, and ignorant which way to turn,temptation whispers perpetually that the wages of sin are better than none, and the home of the vicious better than no shelter.

A bloody not took place among the laborers on the Illinous Central Railroad, at Lasalle, yesterday, growing out of a reduction of their wages. About 2 o'clock an alteration arose between ALBERT STORY, a contractor, and a party of Irishmen, during which one of the latter was shot dead.

MAN STABBED.--At Great Falls, N. H., night before last, a man named MOSES PLASE was danger and stabbed in the longs, under the following circumstances He had hired a team of a stable-keeper of the place named E. LOCKE, and had some words about the paymen of the bill.

At Amherst, Mass., on Thursday, Dec. 8, Rev. STEPHEN S. NELSON, aged 81 years. He was graduated at Brown University in 1794, and was settled over the Baptist Church, in Hartford, Conn., in 1798. He removed to Sing Sing, N. Y., in 1801, where, in addition to his duties as Pastor of the Baptist Church in that village, he was Principal of the Mount Pleasant Academy for thirteen years.
The amount of United Sates Stock redeemed at the Treasury, during the week ending to-day, was $669700. Among the recent arrivals are Gen. Wool .ex-Senator BERRIEN, and AUGUSTUS SCHELL. .

The Herald is devoting itself to training a jury for a new trial of the libel suit in which it has been so effectually floored. Its appeals to the public on its own behalf would be affecting, if their object were a little less apparent. It puts on airs of injured innocence,

GALE ON LAKE PONTCHARTRAIN. -- The high winds that prevailed yesterday have done considerable damage on the lake. We learn the steamer Lan caster was driven ashore, and there persons that were a board of her are reported as having been drowned.

Buried with music !" what an inducement to shufIle off this mortal coil. " Buried with music ! what an invitation to fit one's-self for interment, to hang. drown, choke, butcher the fail body.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--To night will positively be the last of the Opera Season. It is devoted to Mr. MARETZEK'S benefit, and will assuredly be a bumper. The whole of AUBER'S delightful opera of "Massaniello" will be given. and also the fourth act of the "Prophet." The latter, it will be remembered, is the most effective in the opera.

A FORGER ARRESTED--THREE FORGED CHECKS RECOVERED--CONFESSION OF THE FORGER.--Yesterday evening, about 6 o'clock, a well-dressed individual went into the clothing establishment of BARWISE KING, on Main, near Fourth-street, and purchased a pair of pantaloons, and then was measured for purchased a pair of then presented a check on the City Bank for $28 60, pay able to WILLIAM HUBBARD, (which name he claimed to bear.) and drawn by WILLIAM GLENN SONS.

CAUSES DECIDED AT THE GENERAL TERM OF THE SUPREME COURT, Albany, December, 1853. President--Justices PARKER, HARRIS, WRIGHT and WATSON. Judgment at Circuit affirmed.--Abner C. Robertson vs. John C. Woodin and al Order at Special Term affirmed, with $10 costs.--Barner Becker vs. John B. Matthews at al.

The grand Banquet in honor of JOHN MITCHELL, the Irish Patriot, took place last evening at the Broadway Theatre. The building was fitted up for the occasion, by covering the parqucite with a substantial flooring, upon which the tables were set. The boxes were reserved for the ladies, to whom two sea's were allotted for each ticket issued.

THE OFFICERS AND CREW OF THE CUTTER HAMILTON.--We learn from Capt. PEASE of the U. S. revenue cutter Jefferson Davis, who returned yesterday from Krawah Island, that he had made an examination of the coast ten miles further than it had been previously explored, and that two more bodies had been washed ashore since Sunday, making six in all.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your paper of this morning you give a note of Skipp vs. The Eastern County Railroad, lately tried in England, as presenting a novel point, namely: That a principal is not liable to one of his employees for injury sustained from tile acts or neglect of a fellow-workman in the course of the same employment.

GREAT SALE OF BOOKS.--Collectors of rare and curious books will be gratified by attending the auction rooms of GEORGE W. LORD Co., No. 356 Broadway, every evening during this week. The collection of books to be disposed of includes some rare and costly works.

On Monday, Dec. 19 Mrs. MARY LORD, wife of Samuel Lord. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully requested to attend her funeral, on Wednesday, at 11 o'clock A. M., from her late residence, No. 223 West 221 st.

THE FIRST SNOW.--The first snow-storm of the season commenced at 11 o'clock last evening, and continued during the night. The snow fell rapidly and thickly, and by 2 o'clock reached an average depth of three inches.
As much has been said about the office of Commissioner of Jurors, recently become va cant by the resignation of Mr WALKER, it may not be uninteresting to state how this office became established.

We learn from Captain LITON, of the truth Argentine, arrived at Salem from Buenos Ayres, that much discontent and dissatisfaction prevailed throughout the proviners. The Federal party, who compose the majority, are decidedly opposed to the present Government of Buenos Ayres, and another revolution was predicted in the course of a few months.
Mr. CLAY presented the credentials of Mr. FITZPATRICK. Senator from Alabama, in the place of W. R KING, resigned. Mr. FITZPATRICK appeared and was sworn.

LOVE AND SUICIDE--ATTEMPTED MURDER OF AN ACTRESS--Several weeks ago, under the above caption, we gave a circumstantial account of an attempt made on the life of Madame ELLENORE FOUGET, wife of Charles sage, by one ICLES BUTTFORD, who wounded the lady by a pistol shot and afterwards blew out his own trains.

EVERT EVERTSON.--The following is the testimony given before Judge HAYES by this brave California boy of fourteen years: in relation to the recent attack upon his mothers's house. Few men would have exhibited more coolness and determined courage; and when it is recollected that he was awakened from sleep in a dark night, his heroic self-possession excites our admiration!

Much disparaging comment, coming in had taste from Senator NORRIS, was embraced in the funeral ceremonies for the late Hon. CHARLES G. ATHERTON, to-day. He cast a fling at Hon. WILLIAM H. SEWARD about the " Higher Law."
Commander STERRETT has been detatched from the Naval Asylum at Philadelphia, from the 1st of January, and ordered to the Decatur; Commander LARPNER is ordered to the Asylum in his stead.

The brig William Price has arrived at this port with Rio Janciro dates to Oct. 30. She brings eight of the crew of the last, ship Roman, who report that the Captain set fire to the vessel before abandoning her.
The Committee have decided that none of the Poems sent in for the LATHAM $500 prize, are worth consideration, and decline awarding the prize to any.

Numerous petitions were presented. Mr. SHIELDS gave notice of a joint resolution, authorizing the President to convey the rank of Lieut. General by Brevet for equipment services. Mr. SEWARD presented the remonstrance of the citizens of Rochester against any international copyright law.

Citizen Attacked by Rufflans the Eighth Ward-Police Officer Shot at. A case of attempted highway robbery was brought before Judge STUART yesterday at the Jefferson Police Court. The crime was perpetrated under circumstances of an aggravated character.

A third trial to elect municipal officers yesterday resulted in the choice of ENOCH BARTLETT, Democrat, for Mayor, and a Democratic majority in the City Council at Lawrence. The Mayor and Alderman of this city have refused to license the $12,000 gift cincert, largely advertised by A. A. DAVIS to take place in our Music Hall.

The steamship Black Warrior arrived at Mobile on Saturday, with Havana dates to the 15th inst. She brings no news of importance.

The anticipated orders for the Naval Expedition to the Gulf of California, in search of the Fillibusteros, went out in the Aspinwall steamer to-day. They were telegraphed from here.

FROM BUENOS AYRES AND MONTEVIDEO.--The fine bark Argentine. Capt. GEORGE UPTON, arrived at this port on Saturday forenoon, from Buenes Ayres, 17th and Montevideo 22d October. We learn from Capt. UPTON that the city of Buenos Ayres was quiet when the A left, but much discontent and great disaffection were said to prevail throughout the Provinces.

Mayor WESTERVELT has vetoed the Broad way Railroad Bill on the ground that the privilege which it grants is a franchise, and should, according to the requirements of the new Charter, have been sold at public auction.

We are requested to call attention to a change of time from Thursday, as published in one or two papers, to Wednesday evening, of the dedication services of the new meeting-house belonging to the New England Church, Williamsburg. The corrected notice appears on our first page.

Yesterday was a busy day in Congress, though but little was done. We have Austin papers of the 3d inst., San Antonio of the 1st, Galveston of the 6th and 9th, and a number of other Texas papers. Captain SKILLIMAN, accompanied by Col. MANSFIELD, Inspector General of the United States Army, arrived at San Antonio on the 27th ult., from El Paso.

We have no mail to-night South of Wilmington, N. C. The Virginia Senate refused to pass the bill admitting small notes into circulation. The Maryland Coal trade last week, amounted to 13,000 tons.
The weather is very cold, and the canal and river are freezing up. But few boats are moving on the lake. DETROIT, Tuesday, Dec. 20.

The President, in his recent Message to Congress, in that paragraph referring to the North eastern fisheries, holds the following language: "With the view to remove all difficulties on the subject, to extend the rights of our fishermen beyond the limits fixed by the Convention of 1818, and to regulate trade between the United States and the British North American Provinces, a negotiation has been opened with a fair prospect of a favorable result."

On the 15th December a terrible excitement occurred at La Salle, Illinois. For same says it would I appear that the men working on the Plin to Central Railroad had been very much excited; on the 15th the cutbreak began.

An adjourned meeting of the Board of Consolidation Commissioners was held yesterday afternoon--President KALDFLEISCH in the Chair, and all the members of the Commission answered to their names. Commissioner STRONG announced, with appropriate remarks, the death of Mr. LEWIS, Sergeant-at-Arms, which occurred Saturday night last, suddenly, of inflammation of the bowels.

Several warehouses at Shreveport, La., containing from 7,000 to 8,000 bales of cotton, have been destroyed by fire. Two arrivals from Brazos, at this port, bring over $100,000 in spicie. A large and enthusiastic MITOHEL meeting was hold here on Saturday.

The announcement in the Senate to-day, of of Mr. ATHERTON's death, was marked by an exhibition of bad taste, such as I never witnessed before on any similar occasion. One certainly does not expect funeral ceremonies to afford the opportunity for political discussions; and the dictates of refinement alone should certainly be sufficient to exclude there from every slightest trace of party bickerings and vulgar flings at political opponents.

The building in the rear of No. 101 Chestnut street, belonging to Messrs. SWAIN, ABELL SIMMONS, proprietors of the Ledger, was totally destroyed by fire about 5 o'clock this morning. The fire commenced is the basement, occupied as a kitchen for the refectory in the front building.

The Convention for the election of a Commissioner of Jurors met on Monday. On motion, Chief Justice OAKLEY took the Chair, and DAVID T. VALENTINE Was appointed Secretary.

The New-Orleans mails of Tuesday and Wednesday last, as late as due are received. The brig General Pierce, with 160 emigrants for Liberia, mailed from Savannah on Sunday.

The Express, a few days since, published a long letter signed by MARTIN KOSZTA, and addressed to the President of the United States, purporting to have been received by telegraph from Washington. This unwonted display of enterprise on the part of the Express naturally excited attention, and drew from a correspondent the inquiry how they managed to get the document in advance.

We want to make a happy time for the poor little children in our industrial schools on Christmas Eve. These little girls have a hard lot, you know, most of the year. They are hungry and cold very often. They have no shoes or stockings or hoods for cold weather.

The arrival of the steamship Texas, which left Vera Cruz on the morning of the 8th inst., enables us to lay before our readers some interesting items of news from the Mexican Republic, with which we are furnished by a friend, who was a passenger.

We direct attention to a communication from Mr. MARETZEK, published elsewhere in to. day's paper. It is manly, plain-spoken, and, as regards Mr. MARETZEK entirely satisfactory. So far as the public is concerned, it remains for Mr. SALVI to explain his extraordinary conduct.

WOMAN: HER RIGHTS AND HER WRONGS. Not a crowded but a well filled house--not a stormy but a very intelligent and appreciative company greeted Mr. DION BOURCICAULT last night, upon the third of his Winter Evenings.

The weather here is clear and very cold. The steamer Isaac Newton arrived at an early hour this morning, having met with formidable obstructions in the way of ice, from Bristol to this city. She will leave early to-day for New-York.
DEATHS.-The Health Officer reports 86 deaths for the week ending last Saturday: 53 females; 33 males. Of these deaths 13 were from consumption, and 11 stillborn.

The Telegraph announces another dreadful outburst of violence at the borough of Erie, Pennsylvania, of which the Railroad property West of the borough is the latest victim.

Elsewhere, we publish a communication from Signor LIRENZO SALVI. It would have had more force had it been the first, instead of the second, to meet the public eye. As it is, it presents some points which may be lightly touched on.

Diabolical Outrage--Conviction of the Assatlant. Geo. Eno, alias Geo. Wilson, was put upon his trial at the Kings County Sessions, in Brooklyn, yesterday, upon an indictment for an assault with intent to commit a rape, on Hannah Maria Watson, on the 1st of June last.

We published, some time ago, the decision of the Secretary of State on a oomplaint against a school teacher in Washington County, for attempting to compel a child of Catholic parents to road the Ner Testament against their wish.
We are glad to perceive that Congress is disposed to take steps for the immediate increase of our Navy, in accordance with the recommendations of the Secretary of that Department.

Another outrage on the American flag!--another insult to an American Consul! So the first accounts made it; and those whose strength lies in their indignation, and in resenting insults, made all preparations to show why Uncle Sam ought to fly around, get into a passion, and put poor Peru through.
The Piedmont, Genoa and Turkey Railway was opened on the 6th inst. At Rome, twenty young men had been arrested on a charge of belonging to a London Secret Society.
Yesterday was the Two Hundred and Thirty-third Anniversary of the Landing of the Pilgrims, and was duly celebrated by the New England Societies of this City and Brooklyn.

THE COURTS--Hudson County Circuit Court, and Court of Oyer and Terminer--Chief Justice Haines presiding, assisted by Justices Griffith, Hill, Kidney, and Thomas. The December term of these Courts opened on Tuesday morning. The Grand Jury was called and sworn as follows:

On motion of Alderman BARD, Alderman STURTEVANT was voted to the Chair, and the Clerk proceeded to cell the roll, but the announcement was deferred until the Sergeant-at Arms had brought up a stray Alderman from the lobby, when a quorum was declared present.

In the United States Supreme Court, to-day, Messrs. JEREMIAH CLEMENS, of Alabama, and W.C. JOHNSON, of New-York, were admitted to the bar. In the case No. 33, CHOUTEAU vs MOLONEY, argument was continued by Messrs. WILSON and SMITH for defendant. The President has nominated, and the Senate to day confirmed Mr. P.J. STEER, of Rhode Island, as Consul at Dundee, Scotland, vice DEWOLF, deceased.

M. JULLIEN takes a benefit to-night at Metropolitan Hall. The programme is unusually attractive. Among the novelties we notice a Grand Fantasia and Selection from M. JULLIEN'S Opera, entitled, "The Destruction of Pompeii," performed one entire season at Covent Garden with great success.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: It has always been my principle as an artist to avoid bringing green-room quarrels before the public; and it is, therefore, with great reluctance that I find myself obliged to make statement about matter which happen behind the scenes.

The French Minister at Vienna was instructed to demand from the Austrian Government an explanation as to the alleged part of the Emperor of Austria in the recent Persian arrangements. The explanation is said to have been satisfactory.
GENTLEMEN: Your letter of the 10th, inviting me to attend and "address a mass meeting of the National Union Democrats," at the Chinese Museum, Philadephia, on the 19th inst., has been received.

There is no political news of Importance. The ship Edward Everett arrived in the Downs, from Baltimore, resened the master, two mates, and two seamen, of the brig Hyperion, bound to Jamaica, after they had been 57 hours on a part of the wreck--the Hyperion having sunk with eight men.

We are now in possession of all the facts relating to the arrest of Mr. PARSONS for street-preaching, and are able to divest the care of the false issues that had been raised about it, and to examine it in the light of truth.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Absence from the City, for a few days, has prevente I my reading the veto of Mayor WESTERVELT, and your admirable remarks upon it, until this moring. I am sure that I only represent the common sentiment upon, the subject, in condemning the extraordinary and unexpected weakness of that document, and in praising the vigorous ensure beatowed upon it in your columns.

FIRE DEPARTMENT.--At an election held Wednesday, GEORGE WILLIAMS, member of Engine Company No. 7, was elected an Assistant Engineer of the Brooklyn Fire Department. There were several candidates to the field, and the contest was spirited.

It was a wet day yesterday, till night, and then it was cold and sharp till midnight Soppy-looking gentlemen perumbulated the streets, very like Shatghai chickens well drenched. Blue nosed children begged for pennies, after nightfall, and elderly men hurried homewards, longing for the grate-fire and the cup of warm tea. LECTURE.--On Thursday evening, the second lecture of the People's Course was delivered by WM. OLAND BOURNE, at the Presbyterian Church, corner of South Third and Fifth-streets. The subject--"The Aims and Motives o Life "-was given by request of a Literary Society of young men belonging to the Church, and by whom the Course was got up. The audience was numerous and attentive.

A man was found dead at an early hour on Thursday morning living near the ferry landing on the Hudson River, in Greenbush. He was well dressed and of gentlemanly appearance. The Atlas says: Near him was found a single-barrelled pistol, which had been discharged of a lead. It was a new pistol and apparently had never been used. The ball had penetrated the right temple.

In the Supreme Court, GEORGE MILLER, of New York, and WILLIAM R. SAPP, of Ohio, were admitted to the Bar. In Case No. 8, the United States US. McDonough's Executors, Judge CATRON delivered the opinion reversing the decree below.

The trial of the Ninth Ward Rioters was concluded yesterday by the conviction of the prisoners, with the single exception of KELLY, the policeman. Twelve men were indicted for participation in the attack upon on omnibus-driver, who broke through the line of procession of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, at Abingdon-square, on the Fourth of July last. JOSEPH MURPHY, who murdered his wife at Fall River by forcing sulphuric acid down her threat, on the 9th of April last, has been tried, and convicted before the Supreme Court, and sentenced to be executed after one year's imprisonment.

The U. S. Mail steamship Hermann, E. HIGGINS, U. S. N., commander, arrived yesterday morning at 4 o'clock, from Bremen and Southampton. The Hermann bings 140 passengers and upwards of 600 tons of freight. She has experienced variable winds and weather.

The Santa Fe Mail has arrived at Independence. Advice from Chihuahna to the 2d Nov., state that business was extremely dull there, and it was thought that all the foreign merchants would soon leave for California, and the trade going into the hands of the Mexicans.

By the last census reports, it appears that there are nearly one million of persons in the United States over twenty-one years of age, who cannot read and write. More than one half of these are in the fourteen Slave States.

A TERRIBLE ACCIDENT.--The Cleveland Plain Dealer relates that on Friday afternoon, about 4 o'clock a most horrible accident occurred on the truck of the C. C. and C. Road, at the foot of Vineyard-street. The man hurt was named SCOTT, and he was employed as a station hand.

On Sunday, Dec. 25, of consumption, FREDERICK H. JOHNSON, in the 36th yea of his age. His relatives and friends, also the officers and members of Independence Lodge I. O. of O. F. are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 4 4th-st, on Tuesday morning, at 10 o'clock. His remains will be taken to Newark, N. J., for interment.

PASSING COUNTERIFEIT MONEY.--On Saturday last, a young colored man, known in New-York as "Ned Forrest." alias Elijah Bowzer, was arrested by Officer MINER. on a charge of being an accomplice, with two others, in passing a counterfeit $5 bill, of the Hamilton Bank, of Seitnate, R. I, on Mr. Fox, No. 42 Grand-street. The accused had in his possession an overcoat.

Between 1 and 2 o'clock on Sunday morning, a terrible stabbing affray occurred at the southwest corner of Canal and Hudson-streets, directly opposite STEWART'S porter-house. A short time previous to the occurrence, an Italian, who is unknown, entered the house with a companion, carrying a trunk between them.

PUBLIC DINNER TO GEN. WOOL -- A large number of our citizens have joined in an invitation to Gen. WOOL to accept of the compliment of a public dinner before his departure to California, and Gen. W. has accepted, and named the 31st inst. as the day.

There were buried in this City last week one hundred and thirty-three persons more than during the seven days preceding. Of these there were 31 children more under one year, 29 more between one and two years, and 41 more between two and five years than the preceding week.
Our dates from Honolulu are to Nov. 5. During the week ending Nov. 5, there were 184 new cases of small-pox in Oahu reported and 101 deaths. There is no small-pox in Honolulu.

MITCHEL DEMONSTRATION. -- The American theatre, on Pondas street, was densely crowded last evening with a highly respectable and audience, assembled for the purpose of congratulating JOHN MITCHEL on his escape from imprisonment and exite, to make arrangements for his reception in this city on his contemplated visit, and to Isten to the wrongs intlicted on Ireland.
Christmas will be generally observed here tomorrow. The Custom-House, Banks, and all the public offices, and the publication of the newspapers will be suspended. BALTIMORE, Sunday, Dec. 25.

Our readers will glance over the news brought by the Northern Light to discover, first of all if there is anything from that mushroom "New Republic" which one WM. WALKER and his forty-five stripe-worthy comrades farcically declared at La Paz on the 3d day of November last.

HORRID MURDER IN CLAY VILLAGE, KY.--On Saturday last a shocking murder was perpetrated at Clay village, in which a young man of respectable connections, beloved and respected by his friends and acquaintances, was hurried into eternity.
The Union of this morning denies that Collector REDFIELD has removed any of Judge BRONSON's appointers, and says a son of the latter has been con?? as Cashier.

The steamer America reached Boston at 2 o'clock on Saturday afternoon. We gave a synopsis of her news in the TIMES of Friday morning, received by Telegraph from Halifax. Her mails reached this City at an early hour yesterday morning.

A correspondent a Stockton paper writing from Columbia, ?? date of Nov. 14, says: Our ?? has again ?? the scene of an extraordinary excitement For a period ha??, a fend his existed between several persons living at the Saw mill Flats, and ?? residing at P?? Crossing.
At the very time when the merits of the CLAYTON-BULWER Treaty are about to be discussed again, circumstances are developing likely to give a practical proof of its value to the United States.

We are still without the answer of the State Department to Mr. CASS' resolution, calling for correspondence between the United States and the Government of Great Britain, relative to the CLAYTON and BULWER Treaty.

THE RIGHTS OF WOMEN.--Mrs. EMMA R. COE lectured on Friday at the Tabernacle on "The Rights of Women." She spoke quite effectively concern the various disabilities to which woman is exposed, and admitted that her sex enjoyed in America many privileges denied to them in Europe.

CHRISTMAS DAY AT DARNUMS MUSEUM.--the greatest place in New-York on Christmas Day is Barnum's Museum Performances nearly every hour during the day and evening. Entertainments of the most amusing kind, to suit all fancies.

THE GALE.-- Considerable damage was done by the gale of wind which prevailed Friday high in different parts of the city. A sleep at the foot of Advertisement was sunk by coming in contact with the pier.
At sea, on board of ship F. P. Sage, Nov. 14, George W. Cullin, of West Troy, N. Y. At Galloway's Ranch, Sierra County, Nov. 12, Catharine Alpine, formerly of New-York, aged about 18 years.

We have papers from Kingston (Jamaica) to Dec. 12 The House of Assembly had passed a bill to prevent depredation on coffee, pimento, and ginger. All parties must obtain Government licenses to purchase the articles.
The steamer St. Nicholas, which arrived to-day from the Breakwater, reports that an unknown schooner, bound in, was driven ashore Friday night on the shoal inside of Cape May. All hands perished.

Good, old-fashioned CHRISTMAS is here,--Christmas, which fills out the lank and hungry, and replenishes well-set tables, and fills the children's money-pouches and toy-boxes,--Christmas, which produces a spontaneous out-growth of evergreens, decks the Churches and the Theatres with swinging branches,--Christmas, that makes everybody glad, and nobody sorrowful.

The Supreme Court this morning rendered its decision c??ting the application of the Franklin Canal Company for a special injunction to restrain the authorities of Erie from tearing up the rails of said Company in the city of Erie.

To THE IRISHMEN OF NEW-YORK: My Friends: I am pleased to find that Mr. PARSONS, the street-teacher, met no interruption from any of you on last Sunday. I am gratified to think that the letter which I took the liberty to address to you was received favorably by you--that you agreed, in the main, with its contents--AND THAT YOU KEPT AWAY FROM DANGER.

From the Albany Argus. As we predicted, the summons for warfare has gone out, and the Free-Soil Administration presses are already teeming everywhere with de??tions of that "ignorant and insolent foreigner," JOHN MITCHEL.

If Austria has distinctly pledged herself to act with England and France in their efforts to adjust the differences between Russia and Turkey, a most important step has been secured towards preventing that war from becoming general and involving the whole continent in its issues.

This great Earth will be a very contracted patch of ground when the railroads are all finished and the steamboat lines in operation. Home-folks will be able to travel over it without taking more than a small carpet-bag, and the tribe of professed travelers will die out utterly.
The attractions for this evening are varied and of a superior order. The principal theatres have original pieces for the occasion, all conzenial and appropriate. We refer to them separately.

AMUSEMENTS THIS EVENING, For Particulars see our Advertising Columns. METROPOLITAN HALL.--Jullien's Grand Oratorio. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Cataract of the Ganges. WALLACK's THEATRE.--Game of Life--Old Time and New Time.
MEETING OF THE VETERANS OF 1812.--The Veteran Corps of 1812 held's special meeting at the Hotel, on Friday evening. Col. RAYMOND occupied the Chair, and Adjutant DALLEY acted as Secretary.

News arrived in San Francisco on the 16th ult., ever the Ramsey route, in sixteen days from New-Orleans. PATRICK BROWN and JOHN CASTELLO were both killed in San Francisco on the 29th ult., by the falling of a wall.

Hon. ROBERT OWEN, Jr., died at his residence in Randolph, on Wednesday morning, the 14th inst. His disease was consumption. He was born in Clarendon, Orleans County, N.Y., on the 17th day of July, 1820, but he became a resident of Conewango, in this county, in 1898.
Fires -- At 1 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in a large building at the corner of Avenue C and Fourth-street, known as "Tinkham H??ll," occupied by Mr O. PERRY.
The following is a statement of the condition of the Public Stocks on the 24th December:

The term (five years) for which Vancouver's Island was granted to the Hudson's Bay Company being about to expire, a majority of the white settlers have pa?? the British Parliament to take the Island under its special management, instead of giving the reins of government into the hands of a Hudson's Bay factor, as here??.

I have ever avoided newspaper quarrels, as I think the public of New-York, as well as at all the other cities at which I gave opera, can easily testify. Whatever annoyances or troubles have from time to time occurred between myself and the artists in my employ, have been kept away from public gaze, and my friends outside the great room have not been bored with them.

CRUEL TREATMENT OF INDIANS.--In the Shasta Courier of Saturday last, we find the following: A Mr. PIERCE, a packer, missed some of his animals one morning, a week or two since, on the Trinity, and after searching ineffectually for some time, returned to his camp.

Gov. WINSTON, of Alabama, was inaugurated at Montgomery on Tuesday last. The procession was the larges?? ever witnessed there. The Inaugural Address is plain, flat footed, old-fashioned Democratic document.

The Mail steamship Isabeila, with Havana and Key West ?? of the 22d., instant, arrived at this p?? this morning. The new Governor General of Cuba has signified his determination to do all in his power to prevent the landing of slaves, and also to capture slavers approaching the Island, but says he can take an acting after the slaves have been placed upon the estate of their owner

JOHN MITCHEL'S VISIT TO BOSTON.--It is now a fixed fact that our illustrious and trusted leader will visit this city. He has written to the Secretary of the Reception Committee naming Wednesday, 28th inst., as the day.

The weather here is clear and cold, and navigation is entirely suspended. DETROIT, Saturday, Dec. 24-7 P. M. The weather up to 2 o'clock to-day, was very cold, but it is growing warmer now. CHICAGO, Saturday, Dec. 24--7 1/4 P. M.

Our dates are to November 6, two weeks later. Gov. STEVENS, now on his way across the Plains, in charge of an exploring party to Puget's Sound, had been heard from, and was expected in Olympia on the 16th November.

We are not disappointed in the hope expressed in our last paper, that Pennsylvania would vindicate, through her Courts, the honor of the Commonwealth and outraged Law and Order, in the affair at Erie.

The Indianapolis Journal, of the 22d, has the following account of the explosion of the Zachary Taylor: The steamer Zachary Taylor, a freight-boat, running from Aurora to Cincinnati, had a flue collapsed on Wednesday morning just before daylight, at a point on the river about half-way between Cincinnati and Lawrenceburg.

Algeria promises to be of immense service to France in more ways than one. It has proved its capacity in the production of cotton, grain, silk, oil and wine, and now comes forward with a very creditable show of tobacco.

Private letters from Paris state that the news of the disaster to the Turkish fleet was received with the profoundest astonishment and grief. The Emperor is stated to have been overwhelmed by the intelligence.
We have received news from Constantinople, by Vienna, down to the 3d inst. The news of the disaster of Sinope is officially confirmed, and had just reached the Porte.

CAUGHT--We noticed two likely young aegromen, shipped on board the Telegraph yesterday, from the Covington wharf, for Louisville. They were carefully handcuffed, separately and jointly, and showed other evidence of having been roughly handled.
Though attention has recently been directed to this interesting portion of the world, yet comparatively little is positively known of it by the great majority of our mercantile and political classes.

Our city is the scene of a terrible excitement, caused by a threatened demonstration by an organized body of Germans against Bishop BEDINI, who is now the guest of Archbishop TURBELL, and officiated in the Cathedral yesterday morning.
We learn from England that Mrs. AMELIA OPIE, the popular author of numerous works of fiction, died at Norwich, the city of her birth, on the 2d instant, at the age of eighty-five.

Since our last article upon this subject, the whole of the mammoth establishment of the Messrs. HARPERS has fallen a prey to the flames. Of their immense stock, comparatively a few volumes--some 2,000 or 3,000--were saved, while the volumes destroyed were numerable by hundreds of thousands.

DREADFUL AFFAIR.--The Wabash Gazette gives the particulars of the murder of two Indians, named COTO MUNGO and JACK BONDAY, by NATHAN KIMBALL. These Indians in company with another were on a spree, when they encountered KIMBALL, who shot COTO-MUNGO, killing him instantly.

At about 1 o'clock this morning, a fire broke out in the "Novelty Bakery" establishment of TREADWELL Sons, No. 242 Front-street. The Fire Companies promptly responded to the alarm; but their efforts to save the building were unavailing; it was completely destroyed, together with the greater portion of its contents, consisting of a large amount of flour.
THE GREAT LIBRARY TO BE OPENED.--After long delays, many promises, and sundry hopes deferred, the opening of the Astor Library is at last actually announced.

Liverpool Markets. LIVERPOOL, Tuesday, Dec. 13, 1853. PROVISIONS--The stocks of old Bacon are clearing up at irregular prices, and a downward tendency is evident. An arrival of New Beef has quite paralysed the demand for Old--it is impossible to force sales even at a considerable decline. Pork is neglected.

Five or six officers in our Custom-House have received notice from Collector PEASLEE to vacate on the 1st of January, to make room for new appointments. One inch of snow fell here to-day, between 10 and 3 o'clock, followed by indications of rain.

In this City, as in many other places, the physicians have been discoursing lately of the propriety of revising their fee-bills. In several places they have increased their charges all around ; for what their fathers charged one dollar they propose to charge two.
To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Rev. H. W. BEECHER, in his speech at the New-England Dinner, has so spoiled a good story of Rev. Dr. ASEL BACKUS, that I feel quite disposed to correct it.
The steamer Pacific arrived at this port yesterday with later accounts from Europe, which give an unexpected and critical turn to the Eastern War.

A REMARKABLE SCENE.--Died in Strong Maine, of the malignant "throat distemper." which baffled all she skill of physicians, on the 26th of November, THOMAS HENRY, aged 9 years; on the 26th, ABBY JOSEPHINE, aged 6 years; on the 27th. NANCY, aged ?? years; and in five minutes afterward, JANE, aged 14 years, all children of Mr. THOMAS KENNEDY. During the scene a little infant daughter was added to the family.
Secretary DOBBIN has called attention in his Annual Report on the Navy Department to this valuable Institution. His suggestions are sound and practical.
John Hays, while mad with rum on Saturday night, deliberately knocked down a lady who was in company with a gentleman, while walking through Grand-street at the intersection of Tenth-street.
The little ones turned out of bed with a merry shout while the morning star was still singing and the big bass of the risen Sun had not drowned out its feeble voice.
The trial of HUGH DRUM for the murder of his mother is April last, commenced in Waukesha, Wisconsin, on Friday last. The evidence of the guilt of the prisoner is very conclusive.

A Country Prize Fight. The vicinity of our village was yesterday morning the scene of a disgraceful fight between two men of the names of DILDO and PETERS. There were but, a few who knew anything of the affair, and the fight came off in the woods north of the village, near the Railroad, at 9 o'clock precisely.

SAFETY OF CAPT. J. H. PERKINS, OFFICERS AND CREW.--It will be remembered that a few weeks age, some seamen, belonging to bark Hyperion, of Boston, were picked up, and carried to Cardenas, who reported tat the left the Hyperion I a sinking condition, and that Capt. PERKINS, his two officers and one seaman remained on board.

BOUND FOR PITTSBURG.--On Friday night of last week, when the Cincinnati train for Cleveland was near Iberia, a man, suffering under an attack of determine tremens, was discovered naked in the ladies' car, be having stripped off all his clothing.
Christmas at the House of Refuge. The juventies in the House of Refuge, East Twenty-third street, were, yesterday, checked by some of those "good things" that Christmas brings to all.

Park Benjamin's Poem. MONEY AND LOVE. The lecture room of the Mechanics' Society, No. 479 Broadway, was filled Friday night by a highly intelligent audience in anticipation of hearing a lecture of Mr. CHAS. L. BRACE, on The Danube.

DOUBLE MURDER.--The Memphis Eagle gives an are apt of a murder which was perpetrated to the lower part of Crittenden County, Arkansas, about two weeks since, under the following circumstances: An alteration had taken place between some wood-shoppers there, three of whom armed themselves with double bandied guns, and proceeded to the camp of three others.

METROPOLITAN HALL.--HANDEL'S oratorio of the "Messiah" was given last night by the New-York Sacred Hermonic Society. The attraction was of no ordinary character and the attendance consequently of the largest.

BRADY'S DAGUERREOTYPES - His famous pictures are too well known to our citizens to require comment. The daguerreotypes from his establishment have invariably commanded the highest prizes whenever offered for competition.

Yesterday morning Coroner WILHELM held an inquest on the body of ANTOINE JEROME, who was killed on the New-Jersey Railroad, near Newark bridge. The only important evidence taken was that of the engineer: Henry Hummell, sworn, said: I live in Rahway, N. J.:

TREATMENT OF EMIGRANTS.--A case was brought before the Commissioners of Emigration on Saturday, which goes far to show that the statement made by the Philadelphia Deputation on the Emigrant System of New-York is correct.

ESCAPE OF A SNAKE FROM A MAN'S MOUTH. --An extraordinary circumstance occurred a few days age to JONATHAN SMITH, gunnet's mate, who was pad off at Portsmouth, on the 6th of May last, from her Majesty's ship Hastings, 72 guns, on her return to England from the East Indies.

THE ATTEMPT TO KIDNAP AN IRISH GIRL FOR HER SUSPECTED PROTESTANTISM--We have already held the story of the infamous attack male on a ?? Irish on han girl in Che-sen, by two of her own relations and of the trial of the assaulting parties, the fine inflicted on one of them, and her appeal from the judgment.
According to the Baltimore American, the product of the Oyster Trade of the city is equal to or greater than the product of all the wheat and cord raised in the State of Maryland.
Yesterday morning a fire broke out in the grocery store of McDONNELL McCLUMPHA, which destroyed the block owned by REID TOLL, and two buildings owned by S. B. BORST and A. J. MALLORY.
The independent battalion, Rynders Grenadiers, Major G. B. HALL, held their third annual parade and dinner, yesterday. The Battalion mustered nearly two hundred, all wearing the tall hear skin cap.

The United States mail steamer Pacific, from Liverpool, Wednesday morning, Dec. 14, arrived at this port yesterday noon. The Cunard steamer Arabia arrived at 7 1/2 o'clock, on Sunday morning, the 11th.
At Brooklyn, Dec. 26, 1853, ALEXANDER EARLE, eldest son of Alexander M. and Sarah B. Earle, aged 9 years 9 months and 19 days Funeral services at 3 1/2 o'clock P M., on Tuesday, Dec. 27.
The great pedestrian, CANADA, is no more. The Great Spirit has taken him to himself, and are this his fathers have welcomed him to the fair hunting grounds.

SERIOUS RIOT--SEVERAL PERSONS INJURED--A serious not took place on Sunday evening, in First-street, between North Eighth and Tenth-streets. It originated in an old feud between two parties known as the "Cashes" and "Gillans," between the leaders of which a difficulty arose in the early part of the evening.

DEATH OF MR. LEMUEL STEELE. --This much esteemed and worthy citizen died at his residence in this city on Monday evening, the 26th inst., in the 67th year of his age. He was one of our oldest and most successful merchants, and during a long, active and useful life, had been selected by his fellow-citizens to fill many places of trust and responsibility.

From the Albany Evening Journal We are called upon to perform a painful duty in announcing the sudden death of ANTHONY TEN EYCK, Esq, clerk to the Attorney General of this State, and son of the late CONRAD A . TEN EYCK. This sudden death was caused by an accident, which occurred about 9'o clock last night, on the Troy Road It appears that be was going towards Troy in a one horse wagon,

The third of the course of Anti-Slavery Lectures at the Tahernacle on Tuesday evening was delivered by the Rev. THOMAS K. BEECHER, of Williamsburgh. He spoke nearly as follows:- It is a beautiful feature of the course of lectures, of which the present is unexpectedly made the third, that, while the lecturers are in perfect accord as to results, they are in equally perfect discord as to means and instrumental steps.

Before Judge Woodruff. Application was made yesterday by Edward C. West, President of the Governors of the Alms-House, for an order to arrest Mr. P?? proprietor of the Seven Mile Mura, and Mr. Joges, proprietor of the Pantescope of California. The application was granted, and Messrs. Perham were taken into custody and held to bail--?? first in the sum of $50,000, and the second in the sum of $10,000.

A Winter Evening is like an orange fully ripe. It is partitioned into from three to six hours, according to our habits, each of which is distinct in its offices, and, like the quarters" of that favorite fruit, can be peeled out without draining a drop from the others.

A live Yankee in the middle of Europe at this day, is about as disgustful an object to trans-Atlantic tyrants as can he conceived. He is regarded with about as much enjoyment as the "gentleman " would be who should insist on smoking his cigar in the magizine-room when the powder is served out.

The Star says the California Steamship Company positively refused to delay the departure of their last steamer one day, in order to allow Government to sent cut important dispatches relative to California Fullibusters.

The examination of JOHN W. Fox, Teller of the Mechanics' and Traders' Bank, Jersey City, concerning the money discovered in his fire-cap, was commenced yesterday at 10 o'clock A. M., before Recorder CUTLER. ISSAC W. SCUDDER, Esq., Attorney for the Bank, appeared on behalf of the prosecution, and CORTLANDT PARKER, Esq., Newark, and DAVID GOULD, Esq, Jersey City, for the defendant.

Snow is falling here so thick that objects at a short distance are invisible. It is now a foot deep on a level, and much drifted. The 8 o'clock mail train for New - York started,?? Two engines, but made very slow progress. Nothing has yet been heard of the steamboat train due this morning.

JULLEIN, was in a ?? prevented by the very inclement state of the weather. The attendance was wretched small. M. JULLIEN has been advised to repeat the programme, and advised correctly, we think.

We understand that Judge DUER yesterday granted a rule to show cause why an injunction should not issue against the Common Council's granting its assent to the application of the Manhattan Railroad Company to construct a Railroad in Broadway.

The Newgate Calendar tells us of criminals who thought it sufficient glory to end their career by picking the Sheriff's pocket on the scaffold. The Common Council seems determined to emulate them in this high ambition.

Judge PHEIPS, who was appointed by Governor FAIRBANKS, of Vermont, to fill the vacancy in the Senate, caused by the death of Senator UPHAM, took his seat in the Senate to-day. Previous to taking his seat, he had a conversation with President ATCHISON, who told him that neither he nor the Secretary claimed any right to omit his name in calling the Ayes and Nays. .
We would commend to all gold citizens to get up early now-a-days, and, if possible, read the morning paper through. Otherwise, they surely will never know the improvements going on around them.
J. Ross BROWNE, Esq., the well-known author and traveler, left Washington on Tuesday last for an extended and interesting tour, undertaken mainly as the Correspondent of the NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES.

MEETING OF THE BOARD OF EDUCATION.--The Board of Education held their regular weekly meeting on Wednesday evening, E. C. BENEDICT, President, in the Chair. An application of the school officers of the Ninth Ward for an appropriation of $280 for erecting an iron railing in from of Public School No 3 was read and referred to the Committee on Buildings and Repairs.

There was mary a dull attic and basement sad cellar through the Fourth Ward, lighter and happier Saturday evening for the efforts of our kind friends. Punctually at 12 1/2 o'clock Saturday noon, the children of the Industrial School gathered in the Mariners' Chapel, together with the regular Sunday School.

My lecture upon the "Peoples of the Danube" was regularly postponed, at the desire of the Committee, because Mr. BENJAMIN could not conveniently lecture at any other period of the Course.

A correspondent of the Post charged that Mr. A. procured an appropriation in Congress by fraudulent means--the appropriation relating to the Armory, we believe.

MURDER OF A WIFE. --On Saturday last, an Irish woman named MARY ANN NORTON was found dead in the house of her husband, CHARLES NORTON in North Brighton. It appears that the body of the woman was found at the foot of a pair of stairs. About one-half of the right our was missing, and there were also braises on different parts of the head and body.

Dr. NOTT, the President of Union College, paid in the Trustees of that Institution yesterday upwards of $660.000. The weather here is very cold. Thermometer at S A.M. only 12[degree] above zero. At the evening session of the Classical Teachers' Convention, yesterday, Prof. BURBANK presented a report on the positions and importance of academies, which was laid on the table in order to hear the a idress of Prof. TAYLOR

The old year is going out very mildly with us. We have had no snow as yet, and all we have snow and slush we can hardly say 'us Winter fairly. Last evening Mr. ELIHU BURRITT addressed a large meeting at Funeud Hall, on the theme of cheap ocean postage.

It was pretty good sleighing yesterday morning. The snow that tell on Monday not only covered the cobble-stones and pavements, but the thick stratum of dirt, too, that coats them, and tucked in nicely the great heaps of garbage and ashes that obstruct voyaging in certain parts.

We observe that some of the Ohio papers are urging measures of retaliation upon Pennsylvania for the outrageous conduct of the people of Erie. Such suggestions, though natural under the circumstances, are prompted by resentment rather than judgment. They will only lead to a prolongation of the difficulty.

The following vessels are ashore in the Bay: Brig Choctaw from GalvestJl. on Point Alderton, with her maste cut away: hrig Water Witch, from Savannah, on Long Beach; brig Monte Christo, from' St. Mary's, on Peddick's Island!; : hoooer Orlando, from Philadelphia, near Nantasket. They all went ashore at high water.No livet lst.

The Cunard steamer Africa arrived at this port at 11 o'clock yesterday forenoon. She brings accounts from Liverpool to Saturday, December 17, and London to the evening of December 16. The market advices are favorable.

Some few days since there arrived in this city Monsignor the Rev. CAJETAN BEDINI, Archbishop of The bes and Apostolic Nuncio of the Pope to Brazil, accompanied by a private Secretary, Rev. Mr. VIRTUE, who took up his quarters at the residence of Archbishop PURCELL, on Eighth-street, adjoining the Cathedral. On Sunday morning and evening addresses in Italian were made by him to an immense assemblage, which were transiated by the Archbishop.

" Good JOHN MITCHEL," as one of the Preston delegates the other day descrised him, is no longer, even as an Irishman or a convict, a unit in the British population. He has transferred his person, his allegiance, and ?? to the soil of America, and, by preference, to the State of Call others.

The immediate result of the destruction of the Turkish squadron at Smope, when the intelligence of that event reached Constantinople, seems to have been that the Ambassadors were called upon to take decided measures, and that they did accordingly dispatch two steamers of each nation, with joint instructions, into the Black Sea.

PARIS, Friday Evening, Dec. 16.--It is currently reported that the allied fleets have been ordered into the Black Sea. BY TELEGRAPH FROM LONDON TO LIVERPOOL. LONDON, Saturday Morning.-The Turkish Embassy has received advices of the Sinope engagement.

From the London Times. The tardy resolution adopted by the Adtairalty with regard to the late Sir JOHN FRANKLIN and his associates in adventure and misfortune oan scarely have taken oven the most determined Arctie diettante by surprise.

SYNOD OF MISSISSIPPI.--The Mississippi Synod of the Presbyterian Church, comprising the States of Louisiana and Mississippi, assembled in the City of Jack son on Wednesday, the 14th December, pursuant to a call of the last Moderator, Rev. W. A SCOTT, D D., of New-Orleans.

In the Board of Assistants, last night, the project for a Railroad through Broadway came up in a new shape. Instead of reenacting the hill granting the privilege to the Manhattan Company, in spite of the Mayor's veto, a bill was introduced providing that the privilege of constructing the road, according to certain specific provisions, shall be sold at public auction, in accordance with the requirements of the new Charter.

Although no official confirmation of the Declaration of War by Persia against Turkey has been received, the intelligence is considered quite probably. The English press, although admitting that the circumstance complicates the position of affairs, do not consider it of supreme importance. Persia, they say, although small in military strength has, it is true, the advantage of a geographical position that counterbalances the deficiency.

The resolution offered by Senator FISH to raise a Select Committee to inquire into and report upon the cause of the great illness and mortality on emigrant vessels, and what legislation, if any, may be needed, was, some three weeks since, adopted.

The weather is very cold. Thermometer five degrees below zero. Three inches of snow fell last night, CLEVELAND, Friday, Dec. 30-11:50 A.M. This is the coldest day we have had this season. The wind blows a gale. We have but little news.

The General Government, viewing this as a special case, has adopted most liberal measures to meet the exigencies of it. Previous to the withdrawal of any articles

We have received the following important telegraphic dispatch: "VIENNA, Thursday Morning.--The Russian General ANDRONIKOFF has totally defeated the Turks in a battle at Akalsik, on the boarders of Turkish Armenia. The Turks left 4,000 slain on the field. The Turks left 4,000 slain on the field.

Letters from Mexico, of December 17, have been received at the Courier office. Our Minister, Mr. GADSDEN, was making favorable progress towards an amicable arrangement of the disturbing questions between the two countries. The extravagant habits of the nation, together with the exhausted treasury, are said to be the principal obstacles to the immediate adjustment of the difficulties.

We give elsewhere full details-of the recent disturbances at Cincinnati in connection with the visit of Archbishop BXDINI, the Papal Nuncio. It seems that a German paper, the organ of a society of German infidels and socialists, published a most violent and inflammatory article, (which will he found in another column,) assailing BEDINI in the coarsest terms of vulgar vituperation, and distinctly urging a popular demonstration of violence against him.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate the Reportof the Superintendent of the Coast Survey, with a statement of persoms empl.)yed in his office. Ordered to be printed. Numerous petitions were presented. It was ordered that when the Senatle adjllrn, it be till Tuesday.
On Thursday morning,, Dec. 29, at Rossville, States Island, MARY JOSEPHINE, only child of Dr. Charles A. and Elizabeth S. Dosinberre, aged 6 months and 13 days.
Gen. SAM HOUSTON arrived here this morning in good health. A snow storm cammenced during the sight and contin ued until 10 o'clock this morning. It is now three iachesdeep.

The judicial investigation respecting the alleged forgery of $5,000 drafts, and passage of them in Canada West, pending against, D. W. Van Aernam, P. W. Saw in, John W. Abell, and J. L White, was concluded on Thursday before Justice Stuart, at the Jefferson Police Court.

Noah Brown appeared at the Kings County Sessions yesterday, to answer an indictment charging him with having obtained goods an false pretences from Maria Hewer in the month of October. The defendant was apparently about 26 years of age, law in stature, and of a visage somewhat spiculated and sanguine in its expression.

BOARD OF EDUCATION -- RESIGNATION OF THE SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC SCHOOLS.--A special meeting of this Board was held on Thursday, to take under consideration various matters upon with immediate action was necessary. The first introduced was the considering in the annual report each department of the public schools as a separate district, making in all some 44 districts.

The British Minister at Teheran has broken off diplomatic relations with Persia. The following bulletin was posted on the Bourse at ODESSA on the 5th December; "The Russian fleet, under the NACHIMOFF, has met in the Black Sea a Turkish and Egyptian fleet, comp sed of 13 ships--two-deckers, friga'es, corvettes, together with two steamers of 500-horsepower, and two others of 500-horse power.

We ask the attention of all friends of law and order to the following fect which has come to our knowledge this morning. By a dispatch we learn that Mayer KING last night received directions from the Governor of Pennsylvania to call out the militia and quell the riot. The Governor is expected to arrive at Erie to day from Pittsburg, by the way of Cleveland.

Our State legislature is to meet on Tuesday next. The Whigs have an overwhelming majority in both of its branches. If the organization should be effected as usual, upon a political basis, no doubt exists as to the result.

The following effusion, written by a midshipman on board one of the ships of Admiral DUNDAS's squadron, is quite popular throughout the fleet, and has found its way into the papers. It shows at heart what the sailors think of the figure they cut.

Different persons enjoy different fashions of New-Year's presents, while none are so illy educated that they cannot enjoy one of some sort or other. Now, for the poor family whom you know to be deserving, who are willing to work and do work with all their might, for mighty little money too, there is a present of the most elegant sort which they will appreciate.

Conspiracy Discovered--Effect of the Turkish News in paris--A New Loan--Cotton Spinning--State of Trade. The home news is without political significance. It appears that some fear of conspiracy against the Emperor's life did exist--at least in the imagination of the Police,--to present his appearing at the recent lasuguration of the new street, the Boulevard de Strasburg. To what extent discovery of this alleged conspiracy has been made the public are not in for aed.

Panslavism is again causing some uneasiness at Vienna, and the agents of the Government in the south impart of the Austrian monarchs are called upon to exercise redotloied vigilance. At Agram, in Croatia LOUIS GAJ, exist of a piper, has been arrested and brought to Vienna Servia, it is feared, may make use of her panclavisie sympathis.

The Railroad troubles at Erie are still continued. Outrages of the most flagrant character are perpetrated daily upon travelers who seek to pass through the borough, and now, the Courts of the United States have been distinctly and forcibly resisted in their attempt to secure private rights against the outrages perpetrated under the forms of law.

The Africa arrived yesterday, bringing intelligence of considerable interest from Europe. Lord PALMERSTON'S withdrawal from the Ministry is the most important event reported:--it seems quite certain, however, that he does net go out upon any difference as to the foreign policy of the Government, but be cause he cannot assent to the measure of Parliamentary reform which the Ministry has decided to bring forward at the next session.

For some time the Austrian papers, in imitation of the Augsburg Gasette, gave the public to understand that a Quadrople Aliance had been concluded between the Four Powers, but the recent displomatic negotiations are now reduced to their just dimensions, and all paries agree in saying that nothing more has been effected than that a collective note has been forwarded to Constantinople, in which the Porte is urged to treat directly with the Russian Cabinet.

The portmonnaie manufactory of L. E. WEBB, at Meriden, was totally destroyed by fire last night. About one-half of the stock in the building was saved in good condition; the remainder was either burned or badly damaged. Loss estimated at $5,000 or $6,000. It is covered by insurance.

On Saturday the men arrested for relaying the track and fined $30 each by the Erie Dogberry, were brought before Judge (GALBEAITH upon habeas corpus, and discharged. The Judge availed himself of the occasion to speak to the crowd assembled of the outriges committed by the Erie mon and authorities, denouncing their action in most unmeasured and scathing terms.

On Saturday morning, Dec. 31, at 10 o'clock, of disease of the heart, JOSEPH A. RHODES, aged 41 years 7 months and 2 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 113 South 2d-st., Williamsburg, on Tuesday, Jan. 3, at 1 o'clock P. M. without further invitation. On Saturday, Dec. 31, CHRISTIANA CHIRISTY, relict of Andrew Christy, in the 79th year of her age.

Mr. MITCHEL'S Lecture at Boston, which will be found in another part of this morning's TIMES, is a most admirable and timely discussion of the position and duties of European refugees of America. It is brief, condensed and exceedingly practical.

McMurray and Hilton, New-York vs. Oscar W. Sturtevant, and all the Aldermen and Assistants--Judgment affirmed unanimously by the Court of Appeals. This is the celebrated contempt case, and most assuredly fixes that matter a fine of $250 each, and 15 days in Eldridgestreet.

New-York City--What has been Done in 1853. The records of a mighty Metropolis furnish abundant material for the labors of the journalist. The events which transpire from one year's end to another, properly combined, would fill a respectable volume.
