About twenty-five hundred persons assembled at the Music Hall last evening, to listen to the lecture of JOHN MITCHEL, the Irish patriot refugee, who has taken up his abode on American soil to become an American citizen. Mr. MITCH EL was introduced to the audience by WILLIAM END, Esq., in a few spirited remarks.

The bark Maryland, from Baltimore, is ashore inside the Glades, with five feet of water in her hold, and foremast cut away. Schooner Mary E. Pierce, from Wilmington, N. C., is high up on Scituate beach, but may be got off after discharging. A ship, name unknown, is ashore on the Cliff. Assistance has gone to her.

Railroad communication is becoming open. The steamboat train, via Stonington, arrived this afternoon: The train which left Portland on Friday morning also arrived this afternoon. The sky is overcast to-night, and there are indications of more snow. Many of our streets are still impassable from the drifts.

COMMON COUNCIL.--The last meeting of the present Board of Aldermen was held on Friday evening. A Committee reported on the application of the Ferry Company for lease of, pier at the foot of Fulton-street, reported in favor of the same. A question arose as to the price to he paid by the Company; some members deeming $500 sufficient, and others $5,000. The report was finally laid upon the table. The following resolution was adopted:

The Board of Education met on Friday evening, at the building cor of Grand and Elm-Street--Mr. Benedic, President of the Board, in the Chair. This was the last meeting of the old Board, previous to the new organization.. After reading the minutes of the last meeting, the annual reports of the Standing and Executive Committees were taken up.

It is well to note the probabilities of the settlement of this lawless and disgraceful affair, under Pennsylvania influences and by Pennsylvania legislation. The Courts of the State have partially done their duty, but their paper mandates are powerless before the mob.

The Broadway Railroad scheme did fall through, after all. The new project passed by the Board of Assistants on Friday night, and which was skillfully framed so as to obviate the objections of the Mayor, did not commend itself to the Aldermen, and they accordingly laid it on the table.

When Mr. Potiphar gets in his half-yearly bill from Mr. STEWART, in which Mrs. Potiphar's extravagances are duly chronicled, and beholds therein several items which run as follows: To one brocaded silk dress.........$150.--he wonders, no doubt, why silk should be so dear, and why Mrs. P. wants so many dresses.

The President gives the customary New Year's reception to the million on Monday, between 12 and 2 o'clock. The usual reception on Tuesday will be consequently omitted. The GARDINER trial progresses slowly. The witnesses Meyer, Evans, Davis, Barry, Boubleday, Partridge, Mackie, Cochran, P. G. Johnson, Arrangois, Aguilar, Niles, and Angns, have been examined by the prosecution, and repeated their former testimony.

The European journals received by the Africa not only confirm the account of the total defeat and destruction of the Turkish fleet at Sinope, but also announce to us that, in Asia, the mercenaries of NICHOLAS have recently obtained a great victory at Akalsik, a town near the confines of Georgia and Armenia.

Immediately after the announcement of the appointment of Gen. WOOL to the command of the Pacific Department, the citizens of Troy, anxious to testify their approbation of the high regard which they entertained toward him as a citizen and a soldier, issued a notice, which was published in the most prominent journals of the United States, that they would invite him to a banquet previous to his departure.

The European journals received by the Africa not only confirm the account of the total defeat and destruction of the Turkish fleet at Sinope, but also announce to us that, in Asia, the mercenaries of NICHOLAS have recently obtained a great victory at Akalsik, a town near the confines of Georgia and Armenia.

Very suddenly, on Sunday evening, Jan. 1, Mrs. ELIZA DOREMUS, widow of the late Jacob I Doremus, in the 56th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence. No. 189 East 23d-st., on Wednesday, Jan. 4, at 1 o'clock P.M., without further invitation.

The Secretary of the Treasury gives official notice that he will redeem, up to the 1st of June next, $7,000,000 of United States Stocks on the following terms: 1. The par value or amount specified in each certificate. 2. A premium on the Stock of the Loan authorized by the Act of July, 1846, redeemable November 12, 1856; of 6 percent.

We continue to receive accounts of marine disasters in the late gale, and it is feared that further accounts, to come from Cape Cod, will show a large loss of life. The schooner Lovell, from Philadelphia for Boston, is a total wreck, and three seamen perished. The schooner Nancy Crosby, from New-York, is ashore at Brewster.
TO THE SENATE AND ASSEMBLY: You are assembled for the purpose of framing such laws as are demanded by the interests of the people of the State of New-York.

On account of the severity of the weather, there was but a limited attendance of the members of the Mechanics Institute on Friday evening, to listen to the lecture of ERASTUS BROOKS, Esq., upon the subject of the Press. The speaker stated, at the commencement of his re marks, that the greatest conservator of all a? was the art of Printing. What would the world be without the world of letters?

It is well to note the probabilities of the settlement of this lawless and disgraceful affair, under Pennsylvania influences and by Pennsylvania legislation. The Courts of the State have partially done their duty, but their paper mandates are powerless before the mob.

About twenty-five hundred persons assembled at the Music Hall last evening, to listen to the lecture of JOHN MITCHEL, the Irish patriot refugee, who has taken up his abode on American soil to become an American citizen. Mr. MITCHEL was introduced to the audience by WILLIAM END, Esq., in a few spirited remarks.

The Broadway Railroad scheme did fall through, after all. The new project passed by the Board of Assistants on Friday night, and which was skillfully framed so as to obviate the objections of the Mayor, did not commend itself to the Aldermen, and they accordingly laid it on the table.

The Governor has appointed Friday the 28th of April next, for the execution of JAMES CLOUGH, convicted of the murder of GIDEON MANCHESTER in Taunton about a year since. The Steam, Saw Mill, Machine Shop, and Iron Foundry owned by HERRY SYMONDS, at Burlington, Vt., was yesterday morning destroyed by fire, together with an adjoining dwelling-house.

FIRE--On Thursday night about 8 o'clock, a fire broke out in a stable in Sixth street near Grand, which was entirely destroyed. It also communicated to a frame building adjoining occupied by Mr. J. C. MARSH, as a dwelling and brush manufactory, which was considerably damaged.

COMMON COUNCIL.--The Gas Question.--An adjourned meeting of the Common Council was held on Friday evening, Alderman COMSTOCK is the Chair. The special Committee appointed at the last meeting, in reference to the gas question, reported that the gas used in Williamsburg had been analyzed by Mr. Chilton, of New-York, who ascertained that its specific gravity is 480, which is vastly inferior to that of New-York or Brooklyn.

Mr. MITCHEL's Lecture at Boston, which will be found in another part of this morning's TIMES, is a most admirable and timely discussion of the position and duties of European refugees of America. It is brief, condensed and exceedingly practical.

Messrs. GEYER and BUTLER appeared and took their seats to-day. Mr. SEWARD rose to a question of privilege. He said that Senators must have seen, during last week, a gentle man occupying a seat in the Senate Chamber as Senator from Vermont.

State of New-York, St.--STATEMENT of the Whole Number of votes given for JUDGES OF THE COURT OF APPEALS, at the General Election, held in the said State on the eighth day of November, in the year 1853, where in the several Counties in which the said votes were given are distinguished:

COMMON COUNCIL.--The last meeting of the present Board of Aldermen was held on Friday evening. A Committee reported on the application of the Ferry Company for lease of pier at the foot of Fulton-street, re ported in favor of the same. A question arose as to the price to be paid by the Company; some members deeming $500 sufficient, and others $5,000. The report was finally laid upon the table.

On Monday, at 12 o'clock, noon, the new Common Council was organized for the year. In the Board of Aldermen, Alderman VOORHIS, of the Ninth Ward, was elected Chairman pro tem, and Alderman ELY, of the Seventeenth Ward, was elected permanent President, receiving 15 votes, and Alderman MOTT, (Twenty first Ward.) 7.

When Mr. Potiphar gets in his half-yearly bill from Mr. STEWART, in which Mrs. Potiphar's extravagances are duly chronicled, and beholds therein several items which run as follows: To one brocaded silk dress.........$150,--he wonders, no doubt, why silk should be so dear, and why Mrs. P. wants so many dresses.

COLLISION ON THE HARLEM RAILROAD.--A collision accurred last evening on the Harlem Railroad, which was fortunately unattended by serious consequences. The down-rain due at Morrisana at 6 P. M., arrived a few minutes behind time, and after receiving several passengers at that station, delayed some two minutes longer, so that it was overtaken by the next down-train, the engine of which ran half-way through the last passenger car of the forward train.

On Saturday morning, Dec. 31, at 10 O'clock, of disease of the heart, JOSEPH A. RHODES, aged 41 years 7 months and 2 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 113 South 2d-st, Williamsburg, on Tuesday. Jan. 3, at 1 o'clock P. M.. without further invitation. On Saturday, Dec. 31, CHRISTIANA CHRISTY, relict of Andrew Christy, in the 79th year of her age.

The records of a mighty Metropolis furnish abundant material for the labors of the journalist. The events which transpire from one year's end to another, properly combined, would fill a respectable volume. They would be at best, how ever, but a barren mass of figures, which nobody but statisticians could bear to see, much less to read;
The last day of the year just closed relieved our City from the domination of a Common Council universally despised as unprincipled, corrupt and audacious to the last degree.

Immediately after the announcement of the appointment of Gen. WOOL to the command of the Pacific Department, the citizens of Troy, anxious to testify their approbation of the high regard which they entertained toward him as a citizen and a soldier, issued a notice, which was published in the most prominent journals of the United States, that they would invite him to a banquet previous to his departure.

The Legislatiue Caucusses were held last evening, The Whig members of the House met in the Assembly Chambers, T. C. PETERS of Genesee in the Chair. As soon as the Caucus was organized, a vote was taken for Speaker, with the following result: ROBERT H. PRUYN, 40; D. C. LITTLE JOHN, Oswego, 33; Blanks, 2. On motion, Mr. PRUYN was declared unanimously nominated.

In this City. on Monday morning, Jan, 2, Mr. ROBERT B 'ESSEISTYN, formerly of Hudson, to Miss SARAH E., daughter of Hamilton Jayne. Long Island and Hudson papers please copy. At Port Jervis, N. Y., Jan. 1, by Rev. Martin Herr, ABRAHAM S. BURDETT, M. D., to RACHEL, daughter of Henry Burdett, of Fort Lee, N. J.

Dr. NOTT, President of Union College at Schenectady, N. Y., has paid $600,000 of his indebted ness to that institution.--Boston Post. This is an entire mistake--due, doubt less, to an error in a telegraphic dispatch from Albany. Dr. NOTT has not been "indebted" to Union College in any amount.

Very suddenly, on Sunday evening, Jan. 1, Mrs: ELIZA DOREMUS, widow of the late Jacob I. Doremus, in the 56th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No 189 East 23d-st., on Wednesday, Jan. 4, at 1 o'clock P. M., without further invitat on.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Speed the Plow--Curiosities of Literature. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Cataract of the Ganges--The Rendezvous. NATIONAL THEATRE.--Uncle Tom's Cabin. BARKUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.--Two Performances.

We hear by telegraph from Halifax, of the wreck of the ship Stoffordshire, of Boston, on her way from Liverpool, and of the loss of her Captain, RICHARDSON, and about one hundred and eighty passengers, mostly Irish emigrants. She struck upon a rock and almost instantly went down.

BRUTAL MURDER BY IRISHMEN.--A most brutal murder was committed in the town of Manchester, at the grocery of RICHARD WHITEHEAD, about 8 o'clock on Monday evening, upon the person of ALEXANDER BRADLEY. It seems that on Monday evening between 7 and 8 o' clock while a large crowd were in the grocery drinking and making merry, four Irishmen, named PAT'K. CROGAN, CORNELIUS CRERY.--DWYER, and--DRISKER, entered the grocery, and purchasing cigars, retired.

Last evening, the United States Marshal made a descent upon the exemplary citizens of Harbor Creek. The spies, however, had watched him closely, and were there before him. When he reached there, the habitations of all for whom he was in search were closed. He could not get in, and if he had, it is not at all probable he would have found them.

METROPOLITAN HALL.--M. JULLIEN gave his final entertainment here last night. The attendance was unusually good, particularly in the reserved seats, where the ladies were presented with copies of M. JULLIEN'S New Year's Album.

FIRE.--On Thursday night, about 8 o'clock, a fire broke out in a stable in Sixth-street, near Graud, which was entirely destroyed. It also communicated to a frame building adjoining occupied by Mr. J. C. MARSH, as a dwelling and brush manufactory, which was considerably damaged. The premises were owned by Mr. F. ENGLEHAVPT, whose loss in about $500; insured. Mr. MARSH'S loss in stock and furniture $400; not insured.

ARRIVAL OF THE BLACK WARRIOR.--The steamer Black Warrior, JAMES D. BULLOCH, Esq, commander, arrived at this port on Monday morning at 11 o'clock. The Black Warrior left Havana on the evening of the 27th. She brings 14 passengers, and a large quantity of cotton on freight. There was nothing of interest transpiring at Havana. The weather was delightful, and the health of the Island remarkably good.

Governor SEYMOUR'S Message is a failure. He has made it too long by a third--by discussing irrelevant topics, and by continuing to write after he had said all he knew. His introductory column, rehearsing and glorifying the history of the State, is in had taste, and wholly needless. History will take due care of her reputation; and Executive documents ought not to trespass on her domain.

DEATH OF REV. LEWIS WELD.--We regret to learn, through the Hartford Courant, of the death of Rev. LEWIS WELD, Principal of the American Asylum for the Deaf and Dumb at Hartford, Conn. Mr. WELD was an earnest and efficient worker in the cause of Deaf Mute education, and the members of the venerable Institution lately under his care sustain a heavy loss in his decease.

The Legislatiue Caucuses were held last evening. The Whig members of the House met in the Assembly Chambers, T. C. PETERS of Genesee in the Chair. As soon as the Caucus was organized, a vote was taken for Speaker, with the following result: ROBERT H. PRUYN, 40; D. C. LITTLEJOHN Oswego, 33; Blanks, 2. On motion, Mr. PRUYN was declared unanimously nominated.

THE EPIDEMIC OF 1853--The Brandon (Miss.) Republican contains the following statistics in relation to the ravages of the yellow lever in that region, the past Summer and Automn: "In Vicksburg and vicinity, the number of deaths were 390, in a population of 3,500; in Yazoo City, 122, in a population of 300 or 400; in Lake Providence.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It would the gratifying to have Mr. MITCHEL reply to the following question: "In case of war between Great at Britain on the one side and Russia and Austria on the other, would you think yourself justified taking the opportunity (as American citizens or otherwise) of arming yourself against the former?"

We publish this morning a letter from a special correspondent, dated from near the scene of the Erie mob. He gives the latest movement of the Federal Marshal at Harbor Creek, and alludes to another effort to be made by the Railroad Company to reclaim their property at Harbor Creek. This letter is dated on Monday night.

A large number of persons assembled in the Chamber of the Board of Aldermen on Monday, to witness the ceremony of swearing in the "Reform" members. At 12 o'clock, the Clerk, Mr. D. T. VALENINE, called over the roll. As each member answered, he stood forward in the centre of the room, and took the oath of office from his Honor the Mayor, in the following order:

People will naturally inquire, before the Winter gales are over, what is likely to be the action of Congress with reference to River and Harbor Improvements. The President's inferential recommendation, that power be given to States to levy tonnage duties for the purpose of raising a fund to make these improvements, will not result in any favorable action.

The steamship United States, from Aspinwall on the 27th ult., has arrived at this port, bringing the California mails, passengers and treasure of the 8th December, together with those transferred from the lost steamer Winfield Scott.

RECAPTURE OF AN ESCAPED BANK ROBBER.--In November, 1852, JOHN RAND was tried at Norfolk for robiting the Farmer's Branch Bank, Portsmouth, Va., of about $60,000, and was convicted and sentenced to ten years in the State Prison, but while in the jail as Norfolk awaiting a decision on exceptions which had been filed, he managed to effect his escape.

Mayor WESTERVELT has given us a capital Message. It is plain and practical--marked by a high regard for the interests of the City, and by a clear understanding of the measures by which alone those interests can be advanced. It will be found at length in another part, of this morning's TIMES.

Both branches of Congress were especially busy yesterday. In the SENATE a mass of documents was received from the President, consisting of correspondence between the British and American Governments, concerning the CLAYTON and BULWER Treaty on the subject of Central America.

Messrs. GEYER and BUTLER appeared and took their seats to-day. Mr. SEWARD rose to a question of privilege. He said that Senators must have seen, during last week, a gentle man occupying a seat in the Senate Chamber as Senator from Vermont.

ADMIRAL DACRES.--The death of this distinguished English officer ii recently announced in the English papers. He commanded the Guerriere in her memorable encounter with the Constitution, where the brave HULL, then a young man, so gallantly defended the flag, of his Country.

PRESENTATION.--The officers attached to the different Courts of Kings County have made a New Year's present to Edward Burroughs, Esq., the Deputy Clerk of said Courts, of a splendid silver tobacco box an a gold pen and pencil, as tokens of their esteem for him.

THE FIVE POINTS OPERA--By general request from parties who delighted themselves in witnessing the representation of the "Five Points Opera," that performance will be repeated this evening at the Broadway Tabernacle. "The "original Maggie," of Hot Cora notoriety, will again be present, and sing "The Harp that once through Tara's Halls."
A violent gale prevailed here on the 22d and morning of the 23d, sinking and destroying a number of vessels at their wharves in the harbor. The loss is computed at about $20,000.

We certainly have never seen in the City of New-York so much semi-genteel rowdyism and dissipation as was exhibited on last Monday. Droves of young men seemed to swarm in every part of the City, rushing into and out of houses where they were making their New Year's calls, half intoxicated, reckless in their conduct and demeanor, universally profane and conducting in a manner not only disgraceful to themselves, but reflecting discredit upon the City.

The Governor has appointed Friday, the 28th of April next, for the erecution of JAMES CLOUGH, convicted of the murder of GIDEON MANCHESTER in Taunton about a year since. The Steam Saw Mill, Machine Shop, and Iron Foundry owned by HEARY SYMONDS, at Burlington, Vt., was yesterday morning destroyed by fire, together with an adjoining dwelling-house.

The clipper ship Staffordshire, Captain RICHARDSON, of and for Boston, from Liverpool, struck on Blond Rock, south of Cape Sable, about 1 o'clock on Friday morning, the 30th ult., and almost immediately went down; carrying with her about one hundred and eighty persons.

The Herald is quite indignant at the TIMES for having reported the Troy dinner to General WOOL. Its only object in saying anything about him was thereby to assail and annoy the Administration which sends him to California; and it doesn't understand what business the TIMES has to meddle with the affair at all.

The Royal Mail Steamship Canada, Capt. STONE, from Liverpool on Saturday, Dec. 24, arrived at this port at 9 o'clock this morning, en route for Boston. She brings 60 through passengers. The Collins steamship Baltic, Capt. COMSTOCK, from New-York, Dec. 10, arrived off Liverpool on the evening of Thursday, Dec. 22, but did not enter her dock until the following morning.

FROM ST. DOMINGO CITY.--By the brig Renville, BARTLETT, master, from St. Domingo City, Dec. 9, we learn that a few days previous to his sailing, a French man-of-war steamer was off the barbor, and had seat in a boat demanding an indemnity of 20,000 francs from the Government for refusing to allow the French emigrants to land. Conversation is naturally turned upon Central American affairs again, in anticipation of the debate which it is well understood will occur in the Senate after the answer to Cass' resolution shall be' sent in; and, as might be expected, some of the points likely to be presented in that debate are developing in conversational circles.

From the Boston Atlas of Yesterday. The packet ship Stoffordshire, Capt. JOSIAH RICHARDSON, which sailed from Liverpool Dec. 9, for Boston, is reported, by a telegraphic despatch from Halifax, N. S., to have struck the Blond Rock, south of Seal Island, on Friday morning.

COMMON COUNCIL.--An adjourned meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held at 11 o'clock. A. M. on Monday. After approving the minutes of the two previous meetings, and the passing of several resolutions, the Board adjourned sine die. The oath of office was administered to the new members by the Clerk.
Cleared. Steamships--Nashville, Perry, Charleston, Spofford, Tileston Co.; Delaware, Clark, Philadelphia, C. B. Sanford. Ship--Rio Grande, Perry, Havre, R. P. Back Co.

The new Board of Aldermen assembled on Mon day evening, at 7 o'clock, in compliance with the requirements of the Charter, and proceeded to organize by the election of Alderman DAYTON, of the Eleventh Ward, Chairman pro tem. The roll was then called, when the following members answered to their names: First Ward

On Wednesday morning, Jan. 4, MARY, wife of Joshua Thurston, aged 69 years. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral from her late residence, No. 28 Wyckoff-st., South Brooklyn, at 2 o'clock, P. M , on Friday, the 6th instant.

Now that the holidays are over, Congress seems inclined to work with a will. In both branches, debates of considerable interest, and still greater length, are likely to occur. The first question which will probably engage special attention, in the Senate, is that relating to the Clayton-Bulwer Treaty, concerning the British protectorate in Central America.

A FALSE CHARGE ABANDONED,--We mentioned a day or two since that sworn statements had been laid before the Mayor of Williamsburg, which led to the arrest of Mr. S. K. HOGGETT, on a charge of aiding the circulation of counterfeit notes on the Holl ster Bank, and that he had been bound over in the sum of $2,000 to appear for an examination on Tuesday last.

Liverpool Markets....FRIDAY EVENING. COTTON--The advices from New-York, per Baltic, which were made known at an early hour this morning, produced a better feeling in the Cotton market, and at the close prices were very firm. The sales of the week foot up about 45,000 bales, of which Speculators took 9,750 bales, priscipally Surals, and exporters 2,750 bales.

I commence this communication with two revolvers in my pockets, and a fearful-looking Arkansas-tooth-pick on the table before me. I brought one with me. But was soon assured by a friend that was not long enough to cope with those of Erie. He had six, and insisted upon my taking three of them.

The intelligence by the Canada, received by Telegraph from Halifax, is of considerable interest. No important changes have taken place in the aspect of the Eastern question. Threngs of "eminent members of an arduous profession" in the vestibales. A flock of inoffensive looking men, seeking the fate of " honest, intelligent and high-minded jurymen," under the invisible but irresis ihlc impuls of the behests of law. Mr. DOUGLAS, from the Committee on Territories, reported back the bill providing a Territorial Government for Nebraska, with a substitute for the bill. Mr. SEWARD'S resolution relating to the question whether Mr. PHELPS is entitled to his seat in the Senate was taken up.

The Tribune protests vehemently against extending over our whole State " the operation of the vicious and anti-Republican principles embodied in our City's Free Academy." This is a refreshing novelty in the radicalism of the day.

It will be remembered that last week we published account of the mysterious disappearance of this gentleman from New-Bedford, Mass. The excitement in that place in consequence has been intense Many supposed he had been murdered, and a reward of three hundred dollars was offered by the Town Council for the recovery of his body, or fifty dollars for reliable information that he was in the land of the living.

The Board met at 5 o'clock, pursuant to adjournment, and was called to order by Mr. WILD, the temporary President. The Clerk proceeded to call the roll, and thirty-three members responded. The minutes of Tues day's meeting were read and approved.

The Five Points Opera was repeated last evening at the Broadway Tabernacle, before a crowded house. The performances of two or three hundred children, aided by the voices of "Wild Maggio" and Miss BRAINERD, were well rendered and excellently received.

DEATH OF MR. WILLIAM GIBBS.--Die at Lexington, Dec 23, 1853, Mr. WILLIAM GIBBS, in year of his age. He was a native of Salem, where he lived till about the year 1832, when he removed to Lexington. He was much devoted to gotraloicaland historical researches. Partieslarly in reference to the first settlers of New England. He made considerable col-

The members of the Assembly in favor of the enactment of a law prohibiting the sale of intoxicating liquors, held a caucus in the Assembly Chamber this evening. There were about ninety members in attendance. Judge BURNET, of Essex, presided.

Before Judge Belts. AMENDMENTS TO PLEADINGS -- STIPULATION. Nathariel L. McCready against The steamship Brother Jonathan.--The libel in this case originally was be the owners a vassol lost by collision with the steam ship, for her loss, and also for the loss of the libellanis' cargo on board.

On Wednesday, Jan. 4, by Rev. A. R Vanneat. Mr. THOMAS W TIMPSON, of Baltimore, to Miss SARAH J., daughter of James T Moulton. of this City. On Monday morning, Jan. 2, by Rev. A. S Francis, Mr. ROBERT B ESSELSTYN, formerly of Hadron, to Miss SARAH E., daughter of Hamilton Jayne.

TAYLOR'S INTERNATIONAL HOTEL was opened last evening. The entire six stories of the building were brilliantly illuminated, and made a fine appearance. The christening was performed by the members of the City Press, a large number of whom were present at an elegant supper given by Mr. TAYLOR, in honor of the event.

We have sent a Special Correspondent for the TIMES to the seat of war in the northwest corner of Pennsylvania. The incidents which are occurring there, the principles involved, and the interests threatened by the proceedings of the Erie rioters, are of so much public importance, as in our view to justify this effort to obtain reliable information concerning their progress and results.

Mr. CUTTING'S move proves a decided failure. The Hards are discouraged if not discomfited. Only three Democrats front New-York stood up to CUTTING. A Special Committee of nine has been raised on the Pacific Railroad matter.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Some of the county papers have stated that Mr. ALLEN, the sheriff, during his presence in Erie, encouraged the people there in their unlawful proceeding. Such a wantoh and false statement deserves the severest condemnation,

The Senate commenced business at 25 minutes pat 12 o'clock. It was ordered that when the Senate adjourns it be till Monday. Mr. FOOT gave notice of the bill providing for the construction of a railroad from the Mississippi to the Pacific coast. He said his bill would be a practical measure and differing from the other projects heretofore submitted to Congress.

Liverpool Cotton Market. Throughout the woek the market was steady but without activity. There was a fair demand from the trade for American, and from speculators chiefly for Surat. The market was still well supplied with American, particularly of inferior qualities. The Behie's advices gave rather more tone to the market. The week's sales amounted to 45 460 bales, including 9, 740 on speculation, and 2,790 for export. No imports during the week.

We have files and advices from Havana to Dec. 30, inclusive. The latest dates at that port were from New-Orleans Dec. 26; Valpariso, Sept. 16 ; Madrid, Nov. 25. There was not much change in the health of the Island, although the number of fatal cases of fever appeared to be diminishbing.

While I write, our town is much excited under the fear that the cholera has broken out on the estate HULL, on the north side of the Island. On Friday last information was brought to the Police office, that five persons had died suddenly on that estate, and that others were sick. Steps were immediately taken by sending out three physicians to ascertain the nature of the disease. These

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Do you not think, that while ample justice has been done to those of the late Common Council who deliberately, and indeed professionally, sold themselves to dishonor, the few who did their duty have enjoyed something less than the credit properly due them! Even the TIMES, always so ready to mete out applause and reproach where they are merited, has been, I think, remiss in this instance.

Our City Councilmen are making a very discreditable commencement of their Legislative career. They have balloted forty or fifty times, and spent two days and some thousands of dollars in a perfectly ridiculous contest concerning the particular person who shall preside over their deliberations. We

NAVAL INTELLIGENCE.--The schooner N. H. Gambrill, Lieut. DE CAMP, Commander, arrived at this port yesterday in 53 days from Loando, South Africa, after having experienced a succession of violent gales, which stove bulwarks and done other damage. The N. H. G. hails from Baltimore--is a slaver and prize to the U. S. Frigate Constitution, Commodore ISAAC MAYO, and was captured on the 3d November, off Congo River, and placed in charge of Lieut. DE CAMP,

The war news from the East of Europe, received by the Canada, and published in yesterday's TIMES, is, upon the whole, in favor of the Turks. The Russians were repulsed at Kalafat, the strongly fortified position on the Danube, taken recently by OMER PACHA, and 4,000 are reported to have been killed in that engagement. William C. Moss and Richard T. Donovan appeared before a Jury at the Kings County Sessions, yesterday, to answer to an indictment charging the manslaughter (in the fourth degree) of Cornelias MeCue, on the 22d October. Both the defendants are small in person,--Moss apparently about 25 years of age, and Donavan many years younger.

THEODORE EISFELD'S CLASSICAL CONCERTS.--These choice sources are resumed this evening at DONWORTH'S Academy opposite Eleventh-street. The programms consists entirely of gonis, rendered by Mr. EISFELD'S usual quartette performers, assisted by Mesdames WALLACE and BOUCELL. The present Concert is the second of the fourth series.

The loss of the Winfield Scott and the necessity of dispatching another steamer to sup ply her place, is the means of furnishing us direct with the detailed news seven days later from California, with later also from Oregon, the Pacific Coast of South America, and from Australia. There is nothing startling in any of it, for which it is all the better.

Thomas, Dec 19, on board the Columbia, Flat-ship of the home squadron. For the object pressed I offer it for publication. Yours, c., H. R. WORTHINGTON, No. 28 Broadway.

There was another meeting of the friends of a Prohibitory Law held in the Assembly Chamber last evening. No vote was taken, but there can be no doubt that the question will be submitted to the people, and probably at the same time as the amendments to the Constitution. To obvi-

Suddenly, Dec. 5, at the house of Mr Wm. Maxwell, Washington. Brooklyn, (near Fulton.) Miss HESSY ROGERS, late of Belfast, Ireland, aged 69 years. Her friends, and those of the farely, are respectfully invited to attend the funeral without further invitation, from her late residence, on Saturday morning next, at 12 o'clock.

LOUIS XI--AN ORIGINAL PLAY IN FIVE ACTS. On Wednesday evening, at Hope Capel, Mr. BOURCICAULT concluded his "Winter Evenings" in this City. Notwithstanding the sloppiness of the streets consequent upon the thaw, quite a good audience for numbers, and an excellent audience for education and intellect, were assembled. The occasion was an interesting one.

FOUND DEAD.--A HUSBAND CENSURED.--Coroner HANDFORD held an inquest on Wednesday at No. 335 Grand street, on the body of Mrs. MARY MILLER, 29 years of age. who was found dead on Tuesday afternoon at her residence in Union avenue, near North Second-street.

The Board was called to order by HORATIO N WILD, the temporary President. The roll was called by the Secretary, and fifty-one members answered to their names. Mr. CLIFTON moved that the reading of the minutes be dispensed with, which was carried. On motion, the Board then proceeded to ballot for President of the Board for the ensuing year.

Before Judge Morris. Ruck against Major.--This is an action brought upon three bills of exchange. The complaint alleges that the bills were made in London, by the plaintiffs, and that the defendants accepted then; but that at maturity defendants failed to meet them. The defendants put in separate answers, denying any knowledge sufficient to form a belief as to whether the bills were drawn as charged.

The Herald's story about a treaty with Mexico having been received here, is utterly unfounded. It is either made out of whole cloth, or is a decided sell. You have been correctly advised relative to the progress of Mexican negotiations, and will continue to be. The story excites much merriment here.

MEETING OF THE VETERANS OF 1812.--A meeting of the Veterans of 1812 was held in the Star Hotel, Lispenard-street, on Wednesday even--Colonel RAYMOND in the Chair; Adjutant DALLY acting as Secretary; The Chairman stated that Mr. JACKSON, Superintendent of the New-Jersey Railroad has agreed to convey the members of the Corps to Philadelphia and back for $2 each.

A late number of Household Words contains two articles on American matters: one being devoted to "Air Maps and Lieut. MAURY;" and the other to the "Old settlers in Tennessee." A score of articles on our private or public affairs might probably be found in Late English Magazines and Reviews. The West-

It is time that the princely income from this office should be brought down to something like a reasonable standard. This mat

Organization of the Hards and Softs for 1834. The two wings of the Democracy--the terrified and the unterrified--commenced their yearly organization last evening. The "Hards" met at Stuyvesant, and the "Softs" at Tammany. The "Hards" assembled at 8 o'clock, and on motion of a Nineteenth Ward Delegate, JEREMIAH TOWLE, Esq., of the Nineteenth Ward, was called to the ?? and ANTHONY T. GALLAGHER, (Seventh Ward,) and JOHN W. BOYCE, (Twentieth Ward,) were chosen as Secretaries.

We are indebted to the purser of the Empire City, H.J. BULLAY, Esq., for the following account of the accident to that steamer and her probable loss: U.S. Mail steamer Empire City, Capt. H. WINDLE, left New-Orleans at 8 A.M. of the 26th ult. for New-York via Havana, and arrived off the Moro Castle early on the evening of the 28th, but was unable to enter the harbor until next morning.

We learn, says the Boston Journal of last evening, that the owners of the Staffordshire are included to doubt the reported loss of that ship, for the following reasons: First--Because she was not likely to be in the neighborhood of Seal Island in twenty days from Liverpool, at this season of the year.

The Times' correspondent states the Moniteur will soon contain a note to the effect that the entry of the fleets into the Black Sea is not with a hostile intention, but to maintain the armistice which it is hoped will be enforced between Russia and Turkey. The Morning Chronicle's Paris Correspondent writes that France and England are now fully agreed upon taking the most efficient mensures to coerce Russia.

To the Editors of the Home Journal : I have not forgotten m promise, made early last Summer, to send you an account of the Astor Library, when it should be a thing in case and not one in future. Such a thing it has at last become, and I lose no time in fulfilling my promise. Should my communication be accepted, please give it an early insertion in the Home Journal ;

The U. S. Mail steamship Illinois arrived at this port yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. She left Aspinwall with the passengers, mail and specie from the wrecked steamer Winfield Scott, brought from the wreck to Panama by steamer California, leaving San Francisco on the 7th of December, thus bringing seven days' later intelligence of a very interesting character.

In this City, on Monday, Jan. 2, 1854, by Rev. Thomas Marfarlan, LEWIS K. OSBORN, of Upper Morrisania, to CATHARINE F GOODENOUGH, daughter of Samuel Goodenough, Esq., of Riceville, N. J. On Wednesday, Dec. 28, at the Reformed Dutch Church. Lafay ette-place, by Rev. John Kaox, D. D, LEWIS W. MAIRES, to Miss SARAH J. BRADY, both of this City.

The ship Albus, in which I am a passenger, arrived here from Callao, Oct. 3. We found here a fleet of nearly 260 sail, all but three or four English and American. I shall send you a list of arrivals and departures for the last month with this.

Suddenly, Jan. 5, Mr. RICHARD H. RICHARDS, aged 60 years. The relatives and friends of the family, also the members of Lafayette Tent No. 5, I. O. of R., are respectfully invite 1 to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 168 Broome-st., on Saturday, 7th inst, at 2 P. M. His remains will be interred in Greenwood.

From "The Citizen," of To-day. Once more rosy morning dawns upon the earth. The "Peace and Order" established in Europe at the point of five million bayonets, begins to grow nervous. The nightmare of five years loosing its clutch upon the breast of the nations; and we see daylight, and hear the cheerful cock crew.

PISTOLS AND BOWIE KNIVES AGAIN.--A most disastrous fight took place in the bar-room of the Farmers' Hotel, in Covington, on Tuesday night last. Mr. HIRAM KLEAT, a respectable citizens of Kenton County, while under the influence of liquor, indulged in some abusive epithets against foreigners, several of whom were sitting in the bar-room at the lime.

Yesterday was the day on which the confidence of the leaders of the rioters in the integrity of their cause was tried and found wanting. Not one of them dared to have for Pittsburg in accordance with the notice of the United States Marshal to appear before the United States Court and show cause why a warrant for contempt should not issue against them.

Senior NAVARRO is engaged in the very useful task of compiling for publication all the decrees that have been issued by SANTA ANNA since the 20th of April last. The Orden considers this work on "Mexican Legislation" as one of same importance.

Young Men's Democratic National Club. The Young Men's Democratic National Club held a meeting in Stuyvesant Institute last evening--C. GODFREY GUNTHER in the Chair. The Chair announced the receipt of a communication from the Tammany Society, or Columbian Order, addressed to "JAMES T. BRADY, Esq., as President of the Young Men's Democratic Nation Club,"

Between fifteen hundred and I two thousand people assembled last evening at the Tabersacle to hear the address previously announced to be delivered by ELIH BURRITT, upon the subject of "Ocean Penny Postage." Mayor WESTERVELT, who had been designated I preside at the meeting, introduced the distinguished an learned speaker to the audience.

Mr. MURRAY from the Committee on Printing, reported a resolution, which was adopted, providing for printing for the use of members 10,000 copies of the reports of Expiorations of the River Amazon and its tributaries, and with the accompanying maps and plates.

Having this moment "crossed the isthmus" to this mob-struck borough, allow me a laconic epistle to your valuable journal. The time occupied in crossing from Harbor Creek to this point, is about one hour, by sleighs,(and most excellent sleighing,) at the Company's expense.

The monthly return of the City Inspector, showing the number of Births, Marriages, and Deaths in the City for the month of November, 1853, should have appeared some days age. The results are interesting. The births during the month were 1,698, or 80 less than in October : the deaths are 287 less ; and the marriages 46 less.

Last night Mr. MITCHEL, introduced by the Mayor, addressed a crowded audience at the Music Hall, and received a right vehement greeting. The place never echoed such loud plaudits since Mr. MEAGHER was there before. Mrs. MITCHEL also appeared at the meeting, accompanied by her friends, and was a warmly welcomed.

The steamship Canada reached her dock at East Boston about noon to-day. Her mails for New-York and the South go forward by the afternoon train. LIVERPOOL, Dec. 24.--The Emperor of Russia has sent an autograph letter to Prince MENSCHIKOFF, a follow:

PHYSICIANS IN MASSACHUSETTS.--Massachusetts, says the Boston Medical Journal, abounds with medical men. There are fourteen counties in the State; and taking the population as shown by the last census, and the number of physicians as given in the last State Register, the proportion in each county is found to be aslolows.
FROM HONDURAS.--A letter from Comayagun, Horduras, dated Sept. 25, 1853, published in the Orden, of Mexico, of the 17th inst., complains much of the prevalence of robberies.

It would be difficult to mention a more delightful evening than that passed at DODWORTH'S rooms last night, on the occasion of the fourth of the Classical Quartette Soirees. The programme consissed of but five pieces, but they were of the best. Mr. EISFELDT has brought these quartette parties to a state of great perfection.
Some time during the last year.--it was about a week last Thursday,--the Long Island Railroad train went through to Greenport, and only last night came back again.
The Common Council, last evening, passed an ordinance but scribing two millions of dollars to the Sunbury and Erie Railroad. A select Council meets to-morrow evening to act upon the ordinance.

The Union denies, by authority, the truth of the statements in the Herald concerning the conclusion of a treaty by Mr. GADSDEN with the Government of Mexico. It says: " We deem it proper to state that there is not a word of truth in the statement--that it is a fabrication out and out, and may be regarded as a fair specimen of most of the news which appears in that quarter."
Who loves all excellence of kind, May group, but not compare, the two, Since they are diverse types of mind, And each to self and culture true.

In the Senate to day, Mr. MUNROE gave notice of a bill amending the act relative to officers of the Legislature. Mr. FIELD gave notice of a bill authorizing the Canal Commissioners to let by contract the work for keeping in repair the sections on the enlarged Erie, Canal.

JEFFERSON was unquestionably one of the greatest men of his age-an age of intellectual giants. Whatever may be thought of many of his religious, philosophical, and political ideas, be was always in the front rank, in opinion as well as in action, and he asserted and vindicated what you thought with a pertinacity and a felicity of style and force of reason, which made him the heartiast friends and more inveterate enemies.

It is long and important. According to it, the total amount of the revenue applicable to disbursemen's is $3.459,181, while the year's disbursemen's were 52,696,118. The State taxes for 1853 embrace the School Tax, which accounts for the great apperent increase in general taxation, and the statement, as exhibited in the message, shows that State taxes have not increased in prepartion to local taxes.

In this moulting season of our policy and administration of our laws, both new and old, the orders conveying the intelligence of the Government for our guidance, are scrutinized with much care and interest by those who yet retain some apprehensionas to the consequences of so much power being vested in the will of one man.

Arrived bark Elk, Capt. HAMMOND, of, and 16 days from Boston for Philadelphia with loss of foresail and yard, having experienced heavy weather. On the 2d inst., lat. 39? 43', long. .53[Degrees] 56', fell in with schooner Osccola, Capt. BAKER, of Yarmouth, a total wreck, and took off Captain and crew.

A bill to repeal the acts providing for laying out the Central and Jones Parks, in your City, was introduced this morning, and read twice by its title. On motion, it was referred to a Special Committee, consisting of the Delegation from the City of New-York, and, I think they will report in favor of the repeal.

Before Judge Betts. DEPREDATIONS ON UNITED STATES TIMBER LANDS--CONSTRUCTION OF STATUTE OF 1831--EVIDENCE. The United States against The Schooner Cherokee, Reuhen Candy and others. Claimants.--This is a libel of information, demanding the forfeiture of the schooner for removing timber from the public lands in Florida, contrary to the prohibitions of the act of Congress of March 2, 1831. (4 Statutes at Large, 472, ??1 and 2.)

In another part of this morning's TIMES will be found an exceedingly interesting letter from the Chincha Islands. It gives very full and valuable details of the character of these Islands; of the deposits upon them, and of the mode in which the guano is procured for exportation.

For Particulars see our Advertising Columns. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--John Bull--Curiosities of Literature. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Cataract of the Ganges-The Two Buzzards. NATIONAL THEATRE.--Uncle Tom's Cabin.

There is some little curiosity to know what fabrication the Herald will venture upon next. It began with the wholesale falsehood about defalcations in our City Banks, which was very promptly exploded.

The telegraph from Albany announced a few days since that Dr. NOTT had paid to Union College $600.000. This is represented in some quarters as the discharge of a debt, while in others it is claimed as a donation.

A PARAGRAPH FOR BOYS.-- At Portland the other day a by who had often played truan, and bad been threatened by his parents with a severe punishment if the did so a gain, in an unlucky hour repeated the offence.

The land is filled with mourning. The disasters at sea with which the papers have been crowded, and under which the telegraphic wires have staggered, for the past 'fortnight, are fraught with more miseries than at first appear.

RUNAWAY AND MURDER--The Landerdale Republican gives an account of a negro was ran away in Alabama, taking with has a double barrelled shot gun. Before proceeding for he called at a neighbor's and informed him that has master was hunting, had got out of amountnition, and had sent him to borrow some.

The Italian crusader, GAVAZZI, lectured last night at Metropolitan Hall, to a very large and highly respectable audience. His subject was Italy in 18-18-40, and her struggles for Liberty and Independence.

The American Medical Monthly is the name of a new medical journal, which has this month made its appearance. It has the imprint of GEO. P. PUTNAM Co, and is edited by Dr. EDWARD H. PARKER, and conducted by Drs. HORACE GREEN, DAVIS, FORDYCE BARKER, DORKMOS, CARNOCRAN, PEASLEE, and the Editor.

Railroad matters are quiet at present, but rumors are afloat that some of the prominent" six footers" desire to compromise, on the withdrawal of all suits against them. This creates excitement among the more violent. The Sheriff has discharged his deputies, but the night watch is still kept on duty.

As I have many reasons for believing that there exists a misapprehension concerning the sentiment of Pittsburg in reference to the late riotous proceedings in Erie I have deemed it advisable, as I am jealous of our city's fame, to give you a fair and honest statement of how we regard them.

Texas is now in a highly prosperous condition. The Cotton crop of the State has been a full one,-especially have the cotton and sugar planters succeeded admirably. A much larger amount of sugar has been made, than over before--the quality of the article is good.

COURT OF APPEALS--Jan. 3.--No. 3 Luther Wright, 26, 30, 95, 119, 141, 155, 168, 233, struck off. Headrick, son case reserved for the 17th inst. No. 69 till 20th. JAN. 4.--Argued, Nos. 4, 5, 8. No. 3, Luther Wright, respondent, against Zinn Hooker, appellant--not concluded. If P Hunt for appellant; C. F. Coinstock for respondent.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Having recently had the misfortune to stop long enough at the seat of the present infamous Railroad War at Erie, Penn., to learn something of its merits, it may not be improper to give you a few of the leading features of its progress and character.

Storms at sea contend with fires on land to make the new year memorable with melancholy events. Our coasts are strewn with wrecks, and the hulks of vessels that rode proudly on the waves shortly since are driven before the wind or cast about at the sea's pleasure.

The Democratic State Convention met at Columbus to-day, and nominated S. F. Norris of Clermont, for Judge of the Supreme Court; and A. P. MILLER for member of the Board of Public Works. Resolutions to support the General Government, and readopting the resolutions that the Ohio Democrats organize and adopt as their political creed the Baltimore Platform or 1852, were adopted, by 197 to 27;

The republication of Mr. STACAULAY'S speeches by Messrs. LONGMAN, has given the right honorable gentleman an opportunity of denouncing in good set terms the unauthorized edition of another publisher, Mr. VIETELLY, Mr. MACAULAY has not much of the milk of human kindness about him, as many a sharp review and bitter essay may testify.

The Special Correspondent of the TIMES has sent us a full report of the proceedings in the United States Circuit Court at Pittsburg, in the case of the railroad riots at Erie, which will be found in another part of this morning's paper.
BROADWAY THEATRE.--Cataract of the Ganges--Domestic Economy. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Old Time and New Time--Game of Life--Who Speaks First? NATIONAL THEATRE.--Uncle Tom's Cabin.

At 6 o'clock, this morning a fire broke out in the Custom House Building, in Washington street, and at 8 o'clock the entire edifice was in rains. Besides the offices of the Customs, the building contained the Post Office, Reading Room, Atlantic Bank, the United States Court ??, the ?? of the Society of Natural History, J. S. BAILEY's bookstore, and offices used for other purposes.

From the Erie Weekly Gazette. There is general quiet just new on the gange question. The recent ??break in Harbor Creak seems to have satisfied the railroad men that they cannot accomplish their purposes by force, and the, have consequently, to all appearances, abandoned the attempt to relay the track.

A London correspondent refers to the re cent duels of SOULE, father and son, in Spain, in the following terms: You have perhaps been informed through a different channel of the duel which has taken place at Madrid, between the Marquis de TURGOT, the French Ambassador, and Mr. SOULE, the American Minister to the Spanish Court.

A bill introduced in the Assembly on Friday, by Mr. PETERS, read twice by its title and referred to the Committee on Banks, if passed by the Legislature, will give a large addition to the School Fund of the State, and do much for the support of Common Schools.

About 3 o'clock this morning, we were suddenly apprised of the arrival of the George Law, and close on her heels, of the Star of the West. They have had a long race, and came in head and head past Quarantine. To Pursers MITCHELL and B. S. HOPKINS we are indebted for the personal delivery of packages.

The probable fate of this man should be a warning to all fillibusters. He is a man of much talent evidently, and of a thorough education, having graduated in medicine both here and in Paris, and afterwards passed through a course of legal study.

To Correspondents. An??mous Communications will receive no attention. All articles professing to state facts. must be accompanied by the Author's name, not for publication but as a guarantee of the truth of the statements made.

The following are the Treasury purchases of Stock last week: Loan of 1842, twelve thousand five hundred dollars; loan of 1813 one thousand nine hundred dollars; loan of 1846 forty-four thousand three hundred dollars; loan of 1847 twenty eight thousand dollars; loan of 1848 seventeen thousand dollars; Texas Indemnity one hundred and thirteen thousand and seven hundred.

The Great Western Railroad will be completed in one week from to-day, and will be opened for travel on the Monday following. The thermometer in this city this morning, stood at five degrees below zero.

A CURIOSITY.--We were shown yesterday, by Mr. FINN, Deputy City Clerk, a medal, found about a week since by Mr. RICHARD H. TUTTLE, contractor, formerly of this city, while examining a cellar at ??, Dutchess County.

City Mortality. The following is the weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 31st day of December, 1853, to the 7th day of January, 1854: Men, 94; Women, 66; Boys, 171; Girls, 150; Total, 481.

From the Troy Daily Times. Some two or three days since we published a statement to the effect that Messrs. TYLER, of Albany, and CHURCH, of Angelica, had purchased a large portion of the manor in the County of Albany, and that Mr. CHURCH had also purchased a large portion of the manor in Rensselaer County.

The Mayor, in his Message, stated that the Commissioners of Estimate and Assessment for the Jones Wood Park, had already been appointed by the Supreme Court. This is not the case, as appears from the decision of Judge ROOSEVELT, rendered upon the application for their appointment, and given in another column.

SEMI-ANNUAL REPORT OF THE WATER COMMISSIONERS.--The Board of Water Commissioners of Jersey City have made their semi annual report to the Common Council. They give a statement of the expenditures of the Board, thus far in its operation, together with the estimate of the Chief Engineer as to the amount yet to be expended to complete the work.

THE REPORTED MEXICAN TREATY.--It is seldom that we deem it necessary to notice the fabrications which constitute the staple of the intelligence sent from Washington to the New-York Herald by some of its correspondents. But occasionally we feel forced to inter pose lest imposition may be practiced.

Four hundred and eighty-one persons were buried in this City last week. The number is one less than the week preceding, and about the expected average for the season. Consumption killed 63 of them. Of course by this word "consumption" is meant almost all sorts of diseases upon which a cough attends, which the physician fails to cure.

At Morrisania, on Saturday, Jan. 7, FRANCIS MARION, eldest son of Benjamin and Maria P. Devoy. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to at tend his funeral, from the residence of his grandfather, John M. Devoy, No. 54 Suffolk-st., on Monday, the 9th inst., at 1 1/2 o'clock P. M.

We are again compelled to record a most disastrous conflagration in our City. Metropolitan Hall and the Lafarge Hotel were burned to the ground on Saturday night, and property to the amount of over a million of dollars was destroyed.

To the Honorable City Council of the City of Cincinnati: GENTLEMEN: Your resolution of the 29th ult., requesting the Mayor to give such information to the City Council as may be in his possession with regard to the arrest of sunery persons, upon the evening of the 25th, is now before me, and the information asked for will be most cheerfully given.

The beginning of the year brings a recurrence of the lamentable disasters by fire. METROPOLITAN HALL and the LAFARGE HOTEL are in ruins. Heavy losses fall upon the owners, lessees, and insurance offices, and a large aggregate is added to the last quarter's catalogue of destruction.

In the matter of the proposed Park between the Third-avenue and the East River.--The Counsel of the Corporation, against the Corporation's wishes and express order, moves this Court to appoint certain Commissioners, five in number, named by him, to estimate the compensation to all the parties interested in the plot of ground between Sixty sixth and Seventy fifth-streets.

The two KIRKPATRICKS, Dr. SHERWIN, and JOHN K. JACK, have been arrested and taken to Pittsburg. This proceeding has completely cowed the rioters, and former prominent leaders are assenting themselves from the scene of operations.

I was not wrong in assuring you that justice would he dope to the traveling public, the railroad company and the citizens of Erie. By the report of the trial here to day, in the U. S. Circuit Court in and for the Western District of Pennsylvania, which I send, you will see that the Court has re solved to sustain its dignity and protect the traveling public from harm or inconvenience.

Yesterday afternoon, Mr. BENJAMIN MUDGE of Lynn, while walking on the track of the Eastern Rail road, near Ipswich was run over by the train, dragged several rods, and so much injured that it will be necessary to amputate both legs.

One hundred and fifty guests sat down to the hasquet, this evening, including several Members of Congress, WILLIAM SELDEN presided, assisted by sixteen Vice Presidents and four Secretaries. As a preliminary proceeding, the President read a series of resolutions, declaratory of Democratic principles, endorsing the Administration, , which were adopted with acclamation.

The news by successive steamers from the East of Europe is singularly vague and unsatisfactory. Instead of meeting expectations previously excited, it constantly raises new hopes doomed in turn to be disappointed.

The Deputy Marshal arrived at Erie yesterday afternoon, contrary to general expectation. Telegraphic dispatches had been received, giving the action of the United States Circuit Court, at Pittsburg, on Thursday last, but they did not anticipate the arrival of the Marshal until to-day. For the purpose of surprising them, the Deputy proceeded from Pittsburg by special express, and arrived on Friday afternoon.

On Saturday evening. Jan. 7, suddenly, Mr. CHARLES HOLLISTER, at his residence, No. 78 West 21st-st, in the 43d year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral, without further invitation at Calvary Church. at 1 o'clock, this (Tuesday) afternoon. His remains will be taken to Trinity Cemetery.

Eighteen out of the nineteen vacancies in the Senate were filled to-day by the Whig candidates. One vacancy in Berkshire was not filled. The Senate now stands: 29 Whigs, 8 Coalition, and 1 Democrat. A Governor and Lieut. Governor will be elected to-morrow by the Legislature.

MEETING OF THE CONSOLIDATION COMMISSION ERS.--A meeting of the Commissioners was held yesterday afternoon at the City Hall in Williamsburg. The President, Mr. KLABFLEISSH, in the chair. The Report of the Committee on the Fire Department and Excise Commissioners was taken up. The plan of the Fire Department, with several amendments, is the same as that of Brooklyn.

The chief event of the past fortnight has been the centract made by this Government, with the agent of a British Company, for establishing a line of propeller steamers from England to this port, touching at Rio Janeiro, via the Straits of Magellan. The Government promises sixty thousand dollars per annum for ten years. The Company are to make monthly voyages.

Within the last ten or fifteen years, the Government of The United States, with praise worthy liberality, has through its military and naval officers, made large contributions to the general stock of knowledge concerning foreign countries.

BROADWAY THEATRE--A capital little comedietta was produced here last night. It is called "Domes tic Economy," and is, of course, imported from the "other side." MALK LEMON, the editor of Punch, is the author. We say "imported, of course," because original writing appears to be something that the Broadway management can get on without. Everything else is tried but that.

The unblushing Impudence with which the Herald sticks to its fabrication about a treaty with Mexico is equalled only by the falsity of, and the utter want of foundation for the story. I understand that the correspondent upon whose authority the publication was made, went so far as to boast, privately, that he had seen the treaty itself.

The Academy of Medicine met on Monday evening, at its usual quarters, in annual meeting. Dr. ISAAC WOOD presid-d, assisted by Vice-Presidents DETMOLD, BEADLE, and F. C. STEWART The records of the last meeting were read by Dr. PURDY, the Secretary, and new officers were ballatted for, with the following results : Dr JAMES M. SMITH, President;

In St. James' Church, Batavia, Jan. 5, by Rev. Dr. Bolles, Rev. WM OSCAR JARVIS, Rector of Christ Church. Duanesburg, and ELLEN, daughter of the late Maj David B Douglass L.L D At Buffalo, Jan 2, at St John's Church, by Rev. Dr. Schuyler, M. D .R. FLEEMAN, of this City, to Miss MA THBA S. SPARKS, daughter of Captain A. Spurks, of Buffalo

We are glad to perceive that the recent disastrons fires in our City have had the effect of directing general attention to the absolute necessity of a reform in our style of building. Nothing can excuse the reckless ness which has hitherto prevailed on this subject.

Yesterday forenoon, between 11 and 12 o'clock, a Deputy Sheriff named ENOCH FOLSOM proceeded to the house of HEZEKIAH THISTLE, alias LOVETT, No. 113 1/2 Chambers street, to assist Deputy Sheriff VULTE execute the process of a fore closure mortgage against the goods and chattels of said THISTLE.

The walls of Old TAMMANY never, perhaps, saw gathered together within their spacious preeinets a more numerous and elegant assemblage of "the beauty and the chivalry " of New-York, than the company who graced its saloons last Right.

An attache of the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad Company left at the TIMES office on Thursday last, their annual report, directing its insertion in the place usually occupied by advertisements of that description. It was so published and a hill made out at our regular rates.

We give a condensed statement of several into resting decisions rendered at the last General Term of our Supreme Court, obtained through the politeness of Mr. Dusenbury, the very obliging clerk of the General Term. REPRESENTATIONS OF PARTNERSHIP.

Within a day or two announcement has been made of the affliction by paralysis of three of our distinguished citizens,--Mr. ED WIN CROSSWELL, Secretary of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, and better known from his long connection with the Albany Argus, Mr. DANIEL S. MILLER, of the firm of LEE, DATER MILLER, and Mr. WILLIAM M. HALSTED, an old and very estimable merchant.

A call having been previously issued to the surviving Veterans of the War of 1812, to meet in Convention at Independence Hall, in Philadelphia, January 9, it was responded to by over a thousand delegates, who appeared at 12 o'clock within the walls of that edifice, sacred in the eyes of Americans, from its associations connected with the early history of our Republic.

The Chair laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of War, showing the expenditures of this Department during 1853. Referred. Mr. CHASE presented the proceedings of a public meeting held in Cincinnati, in relation to the interruption of the mails at Erie, Pennsylvania. Referred to the Post-Office Committee.

Five of the overdue mails from New-Orleans are to hand, bringing dates to Monday last. The ship Kennchee arrived at New-Orleans from Danish Island, St. Thomas, with 219 passengers, who had been landed at St. Thomas from the ships Atlas and Claiborne, from Havre, disabled at sea.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: An article appeared in the Herald this morning commenting upon the negligence of the Government in not sending aid to the steamer San Fruncisco, or rather for only having seat one small revenue cutter. Whereas the following are the facts:

ACCIDENT ON THE CENTRAL RAILROAD.- About 9 o'clock Sunday morning, as we learn from the Argus, part of one of the freight trains coming east on the Central Road, became detached a mile or two west of Spraker's Station.

The people of California are greatly ex cited about the various projects that have been formed for the dismemberment of Mexico. The news of President WALKER's young Republic has but just burst upon them, and all the ardent fillibusters of the State are in a fever to be off to share in planting Republics, and harvesting the scrip to show the possession of public plunder.

Steamship-Black Warrior, Bullock, Livingston; Crock er Co. Ships--Issac Allerton, Sears, New-Orleans, Wm. Nelson Co.; S F. Austin. Clark, Galveston, J. Brower Mary Talarre (new.) Crockett. Havre, J. T. White Co.; Admiral, Bliff-n, Havre. M Livingston.

From the Cincinnati Gazette. Mayor SNELDAKER, in an official communication to Council, published in the morning papers, uses in self vindication the following language: "And yet, on the trial of the case, the City Attorney, for reasons best known to himself--HASAUREK, the editor of the Hochwachter, being an trial at the time--failed to prove the declarations of the parties previously made, and which would be admitted in every court of law to show their intent.

Two recent articles in Blackwood's Magacine, on the "Narcoties we indu'ge in." have attracted more than ordinary attention. Tobacco, hops, opinro, hemp, , are brought under skillful review, and their various physiological and psychological effects considered.

A dispatch, received by General JESSUP tonight, announces the recent sudden death, in California, of his son-in-law, Licut. JAMES BLAIR, son of FRANCIS P. BLAIR. The supper of the Jackson Democratic Association to-night was well attended and spirited.

The Speaker of the House has completed his appointment of Committees, and will announce them to the House to-morrow morning. The following are the most important: Judiciary--Burnett, Mallory, Baker, Benediet, Gibbs, G. Miller and Clark. Railroads--Peters, Cumming, Searing, Randall, and one more yet to be chosen.

MORTALITY.--The health Officer reports 86 deaths during the week ending Saturday last. Of those, there were 36 males and 50 females, Adults, 27; children, 59. There were 8 deaths by consumption, 5 by croup, 8 of levers, and 3 by small-pox.

Senators HALSEY and BARNARD appeared, and were sworn in. The State Engineer's report was received. Mr. WHITNEY gave notice of a bill relative to the New-York Chamber of Commerce. Mr. BROOKS gave notice of a bill for the punishment of assaults with dangerous weapons. Mr. BRADFORD gave notice of a bill for the improvement of medical science.

Between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the City was visited by another destructive conflagration, by which $25,000 worth of property was destroyed. The flames broke out in the large manufactory of cabinetware, piano-fortes, and other articles of mechanism in that line, situated in the rear, westerly of the French Protestant Church of Rev. Mr. VERREN, in Franklin-street, on the corner of Church street.

Meeting of Sympathy with the Sufferers. The ruins of Metropolitan Hall and the Lafarge Hotel attracted troops of gazers yesterday. The blackened remains of the noble buildings stand as a monument of the destruation that has wrapped no many persons in disaster during the past two or three months.

The Universal Democratic Republican Society held its regular semi-monthly meeting in the Stuyvesant Institute, last evening. Mr. McMULLEN was called to the Chair. COl. FORBES, Secretary to the Society, read a communication from Hon. JOHN P. HALE on International Law.

DEATH OF LUCETT, THE AUTHOR, AT THE SOCIETY ISLANDS.--Died, at his residence in Papeete, Tahiti, Society Islands, on the 29th September, 1853, EDWARD LUCETT, Esq, aged 38 years. The deceased was a native of Eating, Middlesex, England, and had removed to this island in the year 1841, where, in connection with GEORGE COLLIE, Esq, he continued to be extensively engages in commercial business.

The U. S. Mail steamship James Adger, J. DEKINSON, master, arrived at this port last night at 11 o'clock, in 56 hours from Charleston. On Monday, at 8 A M., 25 miles southwest of Cape Lookout Shouls, the J. A. exchanged signals with the U. S. Mall steamship Marion, from New-York to Charleston

Yesterday forenoon between 10 and 11 o'clock, considerable excitement was created in the vicinity of Broadway and Grand-street, consequent upon finding the corpse of Dr. WM. R. T. LUTENER lying in his office on the second floor of the American Hall, No. 458 Broad way, with a faightful pistol shot wound in the back of his head. The details of the affair are fully given

FROM JAVA.--By the Corning, which arrived on the 14th, 90 days from Batavia, we have new: from Java to Sept. 14th. The general news was very meagre. The slock of coffee. sugar and rice, some of the principal exports, were small at Batavia, and several of the vessels which had gone thither for freight, had left to load at other places.

The new Board of Councilmen makes an inauspicious commencement of the work of Reform in the City Administration. A Board consisting of sixty members will, without a vigorous effort against the natural tendency, degenerate into a noisy debating club.

The GARDNER DEAN mystery remains unsolved. During the past week ?? of our citizens, Messrs. JOSIAH S. BONNEY and FRANKLIN JENNEY, have been engaged in an investigation of the circumstamces attending the alleged "anduction." and have traveled with Mr. DEAN over a portion of the " Jordan" by which he reached Albany.

THE BROADWAY CONFLAGRATION.--Since the conflagration of Metropolitan Hall and the Lafagre Hotel. Captain Dicks, of the Fifteenth Ward Police, and others, have been engaged in endeavoring to trace the parties who are supposed to have fired the Hall.

The Governor issued a proclamation yesterday, convening the General Assembly for Thursday, the 9th of February. The subjects to be submitted are the districting the State into Senatorial and Representative Districts to prevent Eastern manufacturers and jobbers from selling their stocks by samplers;

There was a meeting of the New-York delegation held this evening to consider the proposition to repeal the bill to establish the Jones Park. A majority was found to be in favor of the repeal, but in accordance will a request of the minority, they decided to postpone action until the friends of the Park could be heard before the Committee.

HARD TIMES ON PARNASSUS.--Some time ago, one Mr. LATHAM, a gentleman living in Washington, having more money than he knew what to do with or being moved by pure one of divine poesy, organized a grand Pegasian scrub race, with a sweep stake of $500 to the winning man. In other words, he proposed to pay that sum to the happy author of the best National Ode.

COLD WEATHER IN LOUISIANA.--The Nachitochos Chronicle, of the 24th ult., has the following items: " On Tuesday we were visited with a snow storm, which continued for five or six hours, clothing everything in the meanwhile, with which it came in contact, with the livery of Winter.

From the Malone Palladium. On Thursday morning of last week, a man calling himself ADRAM DALEY, presented himself at the Bank of Malone, and requested Mr WHEELER, the Cashier, to cash a draft drawn by the Mercautile Bank of Plattsburg, on the Union Bank of Tray, and purporting to be for the sum of $800 Mr. WHEELER not being satisfied with the account be gave of himself, refused to cash the draft, and DALEY left.

MARINE SOCIETY--ANNUAL MEETING--The Marine Society held its annual meeting in the United States Hotel, on Monday evening. The meeting was called to order by the President, Captain CHAS. H MARSHALL. The Secretary, Captain H. RUSSELL, read the minutes of the last meeting. On motion, Captain WYMAN was requested to act as Assistant Secretary.

SOCIAL ENJOYMENTS.--The Editor of the StockDon Journal has received six invitations to attend Christmas Balls; he thereupon thus discourse h: "Two years ago, there were but few ladies here, and faney flxings were not in demand To day, a merchant displays his prints and muslins, kids and gatters, scars, collars and corsets, with as much expectation as he rolled ever a barrel of pickled pork in the almost forgotten past.

The Special Committee on the Pacific Railroad held their first meeting to-day. After a free conference, they came to the conclusion that they could harmonize their views and report a satisfactory bill.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I was sorry to see in the highly interesting letter of the Librarian of the Astor Library, that a man of such general knowledge and high achievements as Mr. COGSWh LL, cannot avoid the opportunity of sneering at the emphenious Dutch, of which he has collected one hundred d and fifty six volumes, out of respect to the old Kuckerbockers.

As we shall have but one steamer departing this week for the United States, I shall devote my present lester to foreign affairs, and commence by saying a word or two in relation to Spain, where the Minister of the United States and his ??on--two noble hears well worthy of each other-have just honotably vindicated their feelings--the on against the Duke of ALBA; the father against the French Ambassador.
