The steamship Yankee Blade arrived yesterday morning from Aspinwall, with the passengers of the Uncle Sam, from San Francisco. We are indebted to the Yankee Blade's Purser S. L. VAUGHT Esq., for early memoranda and papers from California and Kingston.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--A pleasant little affair was produced here last evening, called " A Pretty Piece of Business." It affords some good situations, for two well opposed characters-an exceedingly bashful and an exceedingly impudout man. The former by Mr. WALCOT, was a good piece of acting, as everything this gentleman undertakes is sure to be.

Before Hon Judge Ingresoll. The People of the United States against Theodore A. Rossi. EVIDENCE FOR THE PROSECUTION. The trial of Theodore A Rossi, charged with having in May, stolen various valuable articles from certain letters. the property of the United States, was commenced this morning at 11 o' clock.

Died at New-York, on the 7th of December, 1853, after a painful illness of many months, which he bore with the fortitude of a Christian and the patience of a philosopher, THOMAS C. MOWER, M. D., Senior Surgeon of the United States Army.

The Philadelphia North American complains, with great vehemence, of the injustice committed by those who assume that Philadelphia has in any degree stimulated or favored the recent Railroad riots in Erie.

ATTEMPT TO ESCAPE--A DESPERADO.--A young man, who gave his name as JOHN WILLIAMS, convicted of the charge of picking the pocket of Mrs. KEY, of Ohio, at the ferry, in September last, at the late term of the Hudson County Court of Oyer and Terminer, made a desperate attempt to break out of the Hudson County fail, at Bergen Five Corners.

Bishop BURGESS, of Maine, has written a letter on the Maine Law, concluding as follows: "I would avoid everything like an intrusion of an opiuion respecting the practicability or wisdom of such a measure elsewhere. I never appeared here as its public advocate, and I am not blind to such arguments as may be urged against legislation which, though it is peculiarly humane in its operation upon persons, is so sweeping with reference to things.

There is a good deal of commotion in England just now concerning the alleged interference of Prince ALBERT in political affairs. The English people have always been extremely sensitive to anything like an undue personal influence, in the conduct of the Government.

In anticipation of a melancholy message from the House, Mr. CASS moved that the subject of the Contral American affairs be postponed till to-morrow. Agreed. Mr. FISH presented the proceedings of the Grand Jury of New York, praying that a building may be provided for the detention of witnesses in cases before the United States Courts.

The Legislature of New-Jersey met to-day. No organization has yet been perfected. Col WILLIAM C. ALEXANDER. of Merger, is the most prominent candidate for President of the Senate, and will doubtless be elected.

ALLEGED MURDER ON BOARD OF THE BRITISH VESSEL ANGLO-SAXON.--As neither the United States Court her out State Courts could examine into the matter of an alleged murder of a passenger named DAVID MURPHY, charged upon ALEXANDER CAMERON, Second mate of the Anglo-Suzon, the British Consul. ANTHONY BARCLAY, Esq , aided by the counsel for the Consulate, Mr. CHARLES EDWARDS, thoroughly scrutanized the affair, by examining passengers and others.

THE STAFFORDSHIRE.--The ship North America, Gapt. GORHAM. one of TRAIN CO 'S line of packets, which left Liverpool eight days previous to the Stafford shire, has arrived at this port. It appears from an extract from the log, that the North America experienced a gale from the south-east, with snow, sleet, and severe squalls on the day on which the Staffe Ashire struck,(Friday, at 10 A. M, shore time.)

A block of wooden buildings on Woodward-avenue, occupied by Messrs. AMBERG Co., clothiers, T. H. ARMSTRONG. hatter; GEO DAVIS, grocer and liquor dealer; T W. LEWIS, ditto; SMITH TILLEY, boot and shoe store, and a paint shop, together with a dwelling on Larned-street, owned and occupied by P. TILLER, were destroyed by fire about 2 o'clock this morning.

The ship Alban, from Bristol for Norfolk, went as here in eleven feet of water, near Cape Henry, in the snow storm on Saturday night. The schnoner Shannos, from Boston for Richmond, has put in here with the loss of jib-boom, boat.

We have already spoken of the references made by Governor MANNING, of South Carolina, in his recent Message, to the subject of Education. Since the appearance of that document a very admirable letter to the Governor, on the general topic, has been published from the pen of Rev. Dr. THORNWELL. It is worthy of attention even beyond the limits of the State for which it was mainly intended.

The Message of Governor LOWE to the Legislalature of Maryland was presented on Saturday. The attention of the Legislature is called to the present criminal laws, and the necessity of their modification or or change in some important respects printed out.

Lecture by Rev. Henry Ward Beecher. The first of a course of lectures, to be delivered semi-monthly, before the Brooklyn Sabbath School Union, was delivered at the Plymouth Church on Sunday evening last, by Rev HENRY WARD BEECHER.

The trade in Dry Goods is, as formerly observed, still quite inactive. Factors are generally well supplied, and fully prepared to meet the early calls of their customers. Yet, the latter appear reluctant to move boldly at present, and for this reason we have but few novel transactions in this branch of business to record.
Among our City Items, this morning, will be found the particulars of a case of accidental poisoning by the mistake of a druggist, in giving to a customer a different medicine from the one prescribed.

There is a class of books devoted to the exposition of business, and designed to furnish men with practical rules for success, that is attracting considerable attention.

MECHANICS' INSTITUTE.--The members of the Mechanics' Institute held a meeting Tuesday afternoon, in the Institute, corner of Bowery and Division-street, and chose the following gentlemen as officers of the Society for the ensuing year:

THE CLAYTON-BULWER TREATY. Mr. SEWARD presented two petitions, when Mr. BRIGHT moved that all prior orders be postponed, which was agreed to, and the Senate proceeded to consider the motion to refer the correspondence relating to the CLAYTON and BULWER treaty.
SINKING FUND.--The semi-annual report of the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund presents as follows: Cash Receipts and Payments since last Report.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: On perusing the columns of your valuable daily publication on the 21st instant, my attention was drawn to what was termed a recipe for making super-posphate of lime.

Organization of the New Board. The new Board of Education, chosen at the last Charter Election, held their first meeting in their Chamber, corner of Grand and Elm-streets, last evening. Nearly all the members were present.

After the adjournment of the Convention, in the afternoon, the Delegates repaired to the restaurant of Mr. WILLIAM W. DUGAN, where a collation had been prepared for them, and after partaking of it, the Delegates from the New-York Veteran Corps marched through the principal streets, under the escort of the National Guards of Philadelphia, and the whole was preceded by the Pennsylvania Cornet Band.

The music publishers are unusually active this year. Their liberality is of the most unwonted character. Not content with issuing any quantity of good music, they have conceived a new idea of giving it away By depositing a tri??ing sum with Messrs. WATERS, JOLLIE or SCHUBERTH, you are privileged to ransack their stores and take away anything you like.

The New-Hampshire Annual Register, of which the thirty-third number for 1854 has been received, turns our attention to some facts as to the condition of the Granite State. Fist of all, they do not have to train in that State.

The Legislature of New-Jersey organized today. Col. ALEXANDER, of Mercer, was elected President of the Senate. A. R. THROCHMORTON, of Hudson, was elected Secretary; STACY B. REED, Of Burlington, Assistant; F. D. MULFORD, of Camden, Engrossing Clerk; and WM. B. SANNO, of Hunterdon, Sergeant-at Arms.

Sonora is that other State of Mexico over Which all fillibusterdom stands hovering. The good people--no, not so much the good as the fast people of our country, which is rich enough in gems already,--sees poor Mexico with this gem lying loose on her shelf, and they are very busy, all at once, "hefting" it, calculating its value, and reckoning what it would fetch.
The lecture before the New-York Anti-Slavery society was delivered on Tuesday evening by JOHN JAY, Heq., of this City. His subject was The First Abolition Society.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The resolution offered in the House of Representatives at Washington, proposing a vote of thanks and a sword to Capt. INGRAHAM, in approbation of his conduct in reference to the release of KOSZTA, the Hungarian, from Austrian restraint, has induced the writer of this article to present a view of the question, which he conceives shows that such resolution should not be adopted.

TRAVELER!--LOOK TO YOUR INTEREST, SAFETY AND COMFORT.--CANANDAIGUA AND NIAGARA FALLS RAILROAD.--This road, connecting with the "Canandaigua and Elmira" and "New York and Erie" Railroads, forms the most direct and expeditious route between New-York City and Niagara Falls, and being on the broad or air foot gauge, the cars are more commodious and comfortable than on any other line of travel. In fact.

The Watchman charged with Arson. INVESTIGATION BEFORE JUSTICE STUART. The watchman charged with seting fire to Metropolitan Hall was yesterday examined before Justice STUART, at Jefferson Police Court. The particulars of the arrest of the accused, whose name is JAMES NUGENT, were given in yesterday's paper.

The wealthy and educated, and especially the fashionable people of all civilized countries, are now so nearly alike in their ordinary manners and customs, that the observations of a passing traveler upon them, must commonly be of much too superficial a character to warrant him in deducing from them, with confidence, any important conclusions.

SEWAGE MANURE.--The value of sewage manure is insisted on, and illustrated by TUFNELL'S report to the Committee of Council on Education. The land attached to the North Surrey School was marked for its extraordinary fertility, owing to its irrigation by the liquid manure, distributed by means of a force-pump and hose.

From the Liberia Herald. The communication with England is monthly by mail steamers. The quantity of palm oil produced this season is unexpectedly large. The prospects of trade are good. PRINCE BOYER, of Tradetown, had met President RoBERTS on a foreign vessel at Tradetown, and promised to obey the Liberal laws give speedy evidence of the sincerity of his regret for past injuries.

We regret exceedingly that the resolution requesting our Senators in Congress to urge the purchase of Mount Vernon should have been killed in our Senate by an ill-timed at tempt to connect it with the question of Slavery.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As the TIMES is the sheet for the curious and inquiring, the following may be acceptable to its readers, and of some importance to those who wish to combine every advantage in obtaining a strong light in churches, halls and other large rooms.
In the United States Circuit Court to-day, before Justice IRWIN, in the matter of the Erie and Northeast Railroad Company versus the City of Erie and others, in Chancery.

The recent exploits of Colonel WALKER, together with the various subsequent accounts from California, have given fresh interest to the condition of affairs, as they are supposed to exist, on our Mexican border.

It is understood that the nominations of Collectors sent to the Senate to-day, included all that had been made during the recess. Collector REDFIELD will be confirmed to-morrow probably, by a unanimous Democratic vote. The nomination of District Judge GILES, of Maryland, was confirmed.
ASHES--Are in brisk demand, and advancing in price. The day's transactions reach 300 bbls. Pearls at $6@$6 12 1/2; and 100 bbls Pots at $5 56 1/4@$5 62 1/2 ?? 100 lbs.

Inquest on the Body. Coroner GAMBLE empanneled a Jury in the American Hall, at noon yesterday, to inquire into the cause of death of Dr. LUTENER, found murdered in his office on Tuesday morning. The body of deceased lay in a coffin, in the inner office. He was a fine man, aged 31 years, with regular, handsome features.

THE RIGHTS OF EMIGRANT PASSENGERS.--The English Court of Queen's Bench has been lately occupied by an action against the Australian Royal Mail Steam Navigation Company, the result of which has determined that of eleven other similar suits against that Company, which were pending in the same Court.

EDWIN J. BROWN, Esq., in the Chair. On motion, the regular order of business was suspended to receive the report of the Committee on Rules and Orders. The Report was accepted, and nearly the whole session was consumed in a debate of the several rules proposed. Of course it had no general interest. After some amendments the rules were adopted.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. By the arrival of the steamship Mexico, Captain THOMPSON, we have received dates from Galveston to the 30th ult. The schooner Sea Drift arrived yesterday in five days from Brazos Santiago, with a number of passengers. The news by this arrival is not so important, as nothing of interest has transpired on the Mexican frontier since the proclamation of the Empire of SANTA ANNA.
Two states of Mexico are to-day commanding extraordinary attention from the world. They are the States of Lower California and Sonora.

On Sunday last, Jan. 8, SUSANNAH, the wife of John L. Wendell. The friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, on Thursday. the 12th inst., at 3 1/4 o'clock, at the Church of the Holy Communion, 6th av., corner of 20th-st.

In the United States Senate yesterday Gen. CASE made a very long speech in vindication of his previous statements concerning the negotiation, under Gen. TAYLOR, of the treaty with Great Britain, concerning the political interests of the latter in Central America.

ANNIVERSARY OF THE BIRTHDAY OF FRANKLIN.--A meeting of the Committee of Arrangements of the New-York Typographical Society was held last evening?? at the Printers' Free Library, N?? 3 Chambers-street, to perfect arrangements for the celebration of the Anniversary of the Birthday of BENJAMIN FRANKLIN, on Tuesday, the 17th inst., by a banquet.

There was a tile this morning between Senators and the Lieutenant Governor, on a question of order. It will be recollected that a day or two since Senator DICKINSON, in submitting a resolution of inquiry relative to the sale of State lands, took occasion to charge certain persons with having robbed the School Funds by purchasing these lands at a price far below their actual value.

The CHAIR presented a communication from the Secretary of War, transmitting the report of the officers appointed to select a site for a Western Military Asylum. Mr. BUTLER said that to quorum of the Judiciary Committee was in the city. He moved that an additional number be appointed until the regular members appear. Agreed to.

From the Citizen of this locck. From official statistics of the emigration to this port during the past year, which we publish in another or part of the Citizen, it will be seen that the total number of emigran's is 284,630 showing a diminition in the returns of last year of 14,865.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I read your remarks in Tuesday's TIMES, on the Causes of Paralysis, with much interest. Undoubtedly long continued mental application is a predisposing cause, but this disease sometimes attacks the young and robust.
Petitions in favor of the Maine law were presented. Mr. BROOKS introduced a bill providing for the founda-?? of a new judicial district in New-York City.

The strike among the miners in the Comberland region counting. They demand an advance of five cents to top till the canal opens, and then ten cents additional, making fifty cents a ton. The Coal trade of last week was only 7,100 tops.

The Commissioners of Emigration promptly deny the truth of a report which has circulated considerably, and at last found its way into one of our cotemporaries, to the effect that they were in the habit of sending up newly arrived emigrants from infected ships by the Third-avenue Railroad for embarkation to Ward's Island.

The Baltic, which was detained at Liverpool a day and a half by low tides, and at the Hook fourteen hours, by a fog. arrived last evening. She brings no startling intelligence, but her news is interesting. Lord PALMERSTON has concluded to retain office.

Collector RELFIELD has forwarded to the Department a report giving the particulars of the unsuccessful cruise of the cuter Washington, and says he has directed the commander of the cutter to repair and put to sea again, with the least possible delay.

The case of THEODORE A. ROSSI, the Post-Office clerk, charged with opening letters and abstracting moneys therefrom, is still on. The testimony was closed yesterday, and the summing up was commenced on behalf of the prisoner.

Liverpool Cotton Market. The Canada, from Liverpool Saturday afternoon, the 24th, having taken out the report of that day's market, and Monday the 26th having been observed a close holiday, we have in reality but one day's business to report ; and that without any change in tone or price.

We learn from private sources that the troubles in Erie have been compromised, and that the Railroad Company will be permitted to lay down their track at Erie and Harbor Creek without further molestation. It is announced that trains will renew their regular trips, and that goods can now be send forward to the West as usual. We cannot vouch for the accuracy of this report.

On Wednesday, Jan. 11, SARAH JANE, wife of Joseph B, Albertson, aged 19 years 8 month and 22 days. Her friends are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, which will take place from her late residence No. 1 Dominicks, on Friday, Jun. 13, at l o'clock, P.M.

We had one of the most severe storms of the season last evening, accompanied with lightning. The water in the river has risen about six feet, and is still rising. The Mohawk and Schoharie Creeks were very high this moraing, but the ice had not broken up at 6 o'clock, although it was thought it could not hold much longer. SECOND DISPATCH.
The Recorder in the Chair. A Quorum answered to their names, and the minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. On motion, the Mayor was appointed Chairman for the year 1853.

A residence of three years in California, (1847 to 1850) and a subsequent absence of nearly four years, have prepared the writer to appreciate thoroughly the extraordinary changes and rapid growth of the new State, and may render some oc-casional sketches not uninteresting to the public.

BOARD OF EDUCATION.--An adjourned meeting of the Board of Education was held in the Common Council Chamber on Thursday evening. G. L. DEMAREST acted as Chairman, pro tem. The following named gentlemen were elected Commissioners to fill vacancies: 1st Ward--Messrs. SYLVESTHER and BROACH.

Mr. DRUM asked leave to offer a resolution, instructing the Committee on Naval Affairs to inquire into the expediency of authorizing by law the Secretary of the Navy to keep three public vessels--one at New York, another at Boston, and a third at Norfolk, to be prepared for prompt dispatch in case of maratime disasters.

MEETING OF THE TEACHERS' ASSOCIATION--RESOLUTIONS ON THE DEATH Mr. McNALLY.--In obedience to a call, the Teachers' Association of this City held a meeting in the Hall of the Board of Education, corner of Grand and Elor streets, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of testifying thier regret at the decease of Mr. FRANCIS McNALLY, late Principal of Ward School No. 41.

The British Ship Three Bells, of Glasgow, Capt, CREIGHTON, from Glasgow to this port, arrived yesterday at 4 1/2 P.M., with merchandise and passengers, after a passage of 45 days.

Major HOBBIE, the Assistant Postmaster General, it is said, now lies in a dying condition. M. BEDINI, the Pope's Nuncio, visited Washington yesterday, for the purpose of taking leave of the President, before departing from the United States.

DOINGS AT THE NAVY-YARD.--Business is very dull at the Brooklyn Navy-Yard. The United States steamer Princeton is finishing her repairs at the Naval Dry Dock. Yesterday afternoon workmen were cutting off the corners of the flages of her propeller, in order to male them round.

On Thursday. Jan. 12, AMANDA C., daughter of Dr. Wm. J.J. and Eliza Johnson, in the 18th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attent her funeral this afternoon, (Saturday,) at 3 o'clock, P. M., from the residence of her parents, No. 84 4th-st.

NATHAN C. ELY, Esq. in the Chair. Immediately after the roll was called, on Thursday evening, the President announced the following STANDING COMMITTEES FOR THE EN?? YEAR, Almshouse Department--Aldermen Christy, Chauncey, and Killy.

FOURTH DAY. Before Hon Judge Ingersoll. The People of the United States against Theodore A. Rossi.--The Court met yesterday morning at 11 o' clock. Mr. B.F. Dunning said: If the Court please, Gentlemen of the Jury--I rise to address you with feelings somewhat different from these, doubtless, on the part of the counsel for the defence.

THE PHILHARMONIC SOCIETY give an entertainment this evening at the Tabernacle. The programme includes several classic compositions, not often heard in our concert-rooms, rendered by the admirable artistes of the Philharmonic orcheitra.

On the second pahe of this morning's TIMES will be found a full report of the petition of the four prisoners confined in prison at Pittsburg, for contempt of Court, asking for a rehearing--with the arguments of counsel.

No event of the year has created deeper sympathy or more profoundly stirred the public heart, than the wreck of the steamship San Francisco, and the great loss of life by which it was attended. The general conviction, we believe, is that the disaster was due partly to her construction and partly to her loading.

The steamship Texas has arrived at this port from Vera Cruz, bringing dates from the city of Mexico to the 5th inst. Mr. GADSDEN our Minister to Mexico, came passenger in the Texas, having concluded an important treaty with the Mexican Government.

EXTRA SESSION OF ILLINOIS LEGISLATURE CALLED.--Governor MATTESON, of Illinois, has called an Extra Session of the Legislature, to meet on the 9th of February, 1854, and attend to a long chapter of subjects among the most important of which are To district the State into Senatorial and Representative Districts.

We published in successive editions of the DAILY TIMES on Saturday, very full details of the sad disaster to the San Francisco. During the day our reporters visited the ship Three Bells, and called also upon several of the officers and others who were rescued by her from the wreck, and obtained from them very full particulars of all the incidents of this dreadful catastrophe. On Saturday evening the ship Lucy Thompson, Capt.

The schooner Joseph James, of Bangor, came into the Hook about 8 1/2 o'clock this morning. She is about twelve rods from the beach, and it is impossible to get a word on board. She has no prospect of getting off this tide.

The following list of Business firms are among the last and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,} No. 113 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co, (do.). Broadway, cor. Reade-st.

Mr. CASS certainly did not add laurels to his brow to day by his speech on the Central American treaty. Whoever reads it must see that, so far as it assails Mr. CLAYTON's conduct, it is but a reiteration of what he said last Spring, and to which the ex-Secretary made a conclusire answer.

Before His Honor Judge Ingersoil. The Court met on Saturday morning at 10 1/4 o'clock, end, after a delay of a few minutes, the Jury were brought in. On the Jury entering the Court, the learned Judge asked them in they had agreed upon their verdict. The Foreman said that there was nut the slightest prospect of their coming to a decision.

The Railroad Company have had men employed during the entire day, repairing the track, and they have not been resisted by the rioters, al though they have hovered over them like crows from morning until night.

In the Assembly, Mr. CONKLING introduced his bill providing for the election of a Commissioner to investigate the origin of fires in the City of New-York. The Commissioner is to be elected at the first election that shall occur after the passage of the act, and thereafter once in three years.

The statement that Mr. GADSDEN is on his way with the long-expected treaty is generally credited here. If true, it certainly disproves the Herald's fabrication. Parties in the SLOO interest are greatly incensed. They will present claims against Mexico for damages.

ALBION FEMALE COLLEGIATE INSTITUTE, MICHIGAN, BURNT.--A correspondent of the Detroit Free Press, Mr. W. H. COLLINS, of Detroit, says that the fire was discovered about 6 o'clock in the morning, while the young ladies were at breakfast in the adjacent building. The fire probably originated in the attic, from a chimney, as it broke out near the central chimney, on the south side of the building.

The steamship Isabel arrived at this port yesterday from Havana, with dates of the 8th Jan. Her news is very meagre. The new Governor General, PEZUELA, had refused to deliver over to the American Consul the American seamen imprisoned at Havana.

The Coroner and Jury reassembled, at the Broad way House, at 9 o'clock on Saturday morning; but owing to the non-arrival of the officers with Mr. and Mrs. Hays, did net get to business until after 10 o'clock There was a large attendance of persons during the day, an increasing interest being manifested in this mysterious case.

NAVAL INTEILIGENCE--CHOLERA AT ST. THOMAS.--The U. S. storeship Relief, A. B. FAIRFAX, Lieut. Commanding, arrived at this port yesterday front Rio Janeiro and ten days from St. Thomas. The U. S frigate Savannah was at Rio Janeiro. The U. S. frigate Columbia was at St. Thomas, bound to the Windward Island.

Rev E. C. WINES, for several years Pastor over the Presbyterian Church at East Hampton, has resigned his charge in that village, and accepted the Professorship of languages is Washington College, at Wash-ton, Pa., to which he has now removed.

The following is a letter from the British Minister, Mr. CRAMPTON, to Mr. CLAYTON. It will be seen that it is a settler as against Mr. CASS' argument that Great Britain will claim, under the Treaty, that British Honduras is in Central America. It will be noticed that it confirms my statement, made some time ago, that the present American Administration concurs with Mr. CLAYTON in his construction of the Treaty.

More notices--more bills--more resolutions relating to railroads. In the Assembly comes notice of the early introduction of a bill imposing a toll upon all freight carried over the New-York and Harlem and Hudson River Railroads-in the Senate the introduction of a bill regulating and directing the manner of levying taxes upon Railroad property, and the passage by a unanimous vote of the following resolution of inquiry.

From the cards of these two ladies, which we have already published, we are inclined to think that our Swedish visitor has involved herself in a serious embarrassment, by attempting to excuse a trilling matter.

City Mortality. The following. is the weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 7th to the 14th day of January, 1854: Men, 173; Women, 83; Boys, 150; Girls, 138; Total, 483.

Memphis papers report that the steamer General Bem, bound from this city to Arkansas River, struck a snag in the Mississippi River, at Grand Cut Off, and was torn to atoms in five minutes. She sank to her hurricane deck, when the whole cabin floated off, leaving the hull, with fifteen deck passengers, below the surface of the water, all of whom perished.

The petition of JOEL HAYWOOD, contesting the eligibility of RODMAN M. PRICE to the office of Governor of the State, was called up in the Senate to-day. Resolutions were introduced by Mr. CONGAR providing for the meeting of the two Houses to proceed to try the same.

The Committee appointed by the St Albans Lodge to prepare an obituary notice of our late lamented brother, DANIEL MARTINDALE, Esq, beg leave to submit the following: JOHN McVEA AMES PERKINS, G. W. CATLETT. Died, in Jackson, La., Nov. 1, of the prevailing, epidemic, (yellow fever,) DANIEL MARTINDALE, Esq., in the 26th year of his age.

SUPREME COURT--GENERAL TERM. THE CITY SUPERINTENDENT OF COMMON SCHOOLS HAS POWER TO ANNUL A TEACHER'S LICENSE. The People against The Board of Education.-- This was a motion for a mandamus, and presented the simple question whether the City Superintendent of Common Schools in this City has power to annul a license granted to a teacher.

The American ship Severn, WAIT, master, left New-York on the 17th October, bound for California. She encountered severe gales and heavy seas for many days, lost many of her sails and stove in two of her port holes.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I trust you will not fail into the vulgar error of attributing the loss of the San Francisco wholly to the gale. The evil lies further back--in the construction of the vessel. Two fatal errors were committed: First--She had not sufficient beam Forty-one feet greatest breadth is barely beam enough for a vessel of twelve hundred tons.

The Europa's intelligence does not materially change the aspect of affairs in the east of Europe. The Paris Moniteur of the 30th of December, announces that the last news received from Constantinople affirms that the Divan perfectly agreed with the Ambassadors of France, England, Austria and Prussia, in regard to the terms upon which the Porte might honorably concur in the reestablishment of peace.

Mr. PEARCE offered a resolution directing the Committee on Naval Affairs to inquire into the expediency of making some suitable acknowledgment by the United States to the officers and crews of the British ship Three Bells, and the American vessels Kilby and Antanctic.

The late violations of the Revenue laws--by persons engaged rather extensively in smuggling--which were first brought to light by the TIMES, have aroused the Custom-House officials from the highest to the lowest to greater watchfulness, and vessels arriving in port unaware of these facts, fall an easy prey to their vigilance in their awakened condition. A rather extensive haul was made yesterday, and others are expected.

On Sunday, Jan. 15, Mrs. ELIZABETH WATKINS, widow of the late Joseph Watkins, in the 92d year of her age. Her relatives and friends, and the friends of the family, are respectlully Invited to at end her funeral, this after noon, (Tuesday,) at 1 o'clock, P. M., from the residence of her daughter, Mrs. Robb, No. 285 Springest.

The examination of witnesses in the case of JAMES NUGENT, charged with having fired Metropolitan Hall, on the night of Saturday the 7th instant, was resumed, yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock, before Justice STUART, in the Jefferson Police Court.

Upon the first page of this morning's TIMES will be found a very curious and interesting diagram, illustrating in a very graphic and striking manner, the relative progress in population of the several States and Territories of the American Union during the last sixty years.

Four mails were received to-night from New-Orleans, three from Savannah, and two from Charleston. Placards were posted about New-Orleans on the 9th, in English, French, Spanish, and German, announcing the intention of M BRDINI to visit that city, and calling on the citizens to treat him as a wild beast.

I have received a reliable letter from Mr. JACKSON, of Mississippi, stating that A. G. BROWN has been nominated in caucus by two majority,--and the Union Democrats being ruled out. On the 7th instant, the election came off.

The Committee on Judiciary in the Senate had a meeting to day, and reported this afternoon in a lengthy document that the question of RODMAN M. PRICE'S eligibility to the office of Governor of New Jersey was cognizable only by the Supreme Court of the State. Mr. CONGAR, from Essex, one of the Committee, dissented in a few remarks. The report was adopted.

SUPREME COURT--GENERAL TERM. The People ??x rel. William B. Reynolds vs. Azariah C. Flagg, Comptroller of the City of New-York, and The Same excel, Russ Reed vs. Tae Same.- OPINION OF ROBERT J. MORRIS, JUSTICE, In each of these cases a motion is made for a mandamus against A. C. Flagg.

In both Houses of Congress, yesterday, as will be seen by our report of the proceedings, the main topic discussed was the disaster to the San Francisco, and the public honors due to those noble-hearted seamen who risked their own vessels and lives in the endeavor to relieve the sufferers.

EXECUTION OF A MURDERER.--On Friday, the day appointed for the execution of ANDREW, H. TRAYER and HENRY T. WILSON, in Staunton, for the murder of WM. COLMAN on the 11th of August last, the penalty of death was inflected on TRAYER. The sentence was not carried into effect in the case of WILSON, he having obtained a respite of 30 days from the Governor.

PROVISIONS--A fair demand is experienced for new Bacon, at about 45s.; old is very dull. Beef and Pork are quiet. Cheese scarce. 50s. has been accepted for some large bbls. of Lard on the spot, and to arrive. Tallow has advanced to 60s. In Seets or Bark no transactions.

JULLIEN announces his concert for Wednesday evening at Niblo's Garden. In consequence of the lamentable destruction of Metropolitan Hall, together with the properties that had been prepared for the Bal Pare, JULLIEN has been compelled to postpone that event. Relying on the support of the public, M. JULLIEN has obtained the use of NIBLO'S Theatre, and will give one Concert prior to his departure for the South.

Private letters received by the Europa from Gov. KOSSUTH, state that he was induced to postpone his departure for Constantinople, which had been positively fixed for the 23d of December, by the necessity of some further preparations.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Having been absent from the City for several days, I was not aware until resterday of a statement published in the Sun of Saturday week, over the signature of D H. UNDERHILL, in reference to the loss of the Winfield Scott, severely censuring the conduct of Captain BLUNT, imputing to him carelessness and negligence.

The Cunard Mail steamship Europa, which sailed from Liverpool on Saturday. Dec. 31, arrived at this port at 8 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning. The U. S. Mail steamship Baltic, which should have sailed from the Mersey early on Wednesday morning, the 28th ult., was delayed by want of water or at the dock-gates, till 8 o'clock on Thursday night, Dec. 29, and was thus enabled to bring papers of that date.

On Sunday evening, Jan. 15, by Rev. F. S. Howe, Mr. R. EUGENE DIBBLE, of this City, to Miss FRANCES MARIA HUNT, of Massachusetts In Oxford, N. O, on Thursday evening, Jan. 12, by Rev. Mr. Hines, T. BROWN VENABLE, Esq., to DELIA M., eldest daughter of Russell Kingsbury, Esq., of that place.

Erie. the lawless--Erie, the entailer of loss and suffering upon all classes of society--Erie, the fright of babes, the dread of mothers, and the cursed of fathers--Erie, the despised of all honest, order-loving, law-abiding men--Erie, the shunned of merchants, and the disgrace of Pennsylvania--Erie, the universally denounced--poor, miserable, blighted Erie. has turned over (it could not fall) from the unenviable position it has held for several weeks.

The bark Mognolia, at this port, reports, 8th inst., George's Shoal southwest fifty miles, fell in with the hull of a vessel burning, south-southwest five miles. Stood for it, but a thick snow storm coming on, did not find her. Judged her to he a bark of about three hundred tons. Nothing was left standing but the mizz?nmast the head of which was painted black.

Major and Brevet Lieutenant-Colonel JOHN, MARSHALL WASHINGTON, of the United States Army, who was swept from the deck of the San Francisco soon after her troubles commenced, was one of the most useful, as he had made himself one of the most distinguished artillery officers belonging to the service.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: I observe in your paper of to-day a statement signed "JAMES LORIMER GRAHAM, Jr.," in which he says; "Lieut, MURRAY promptly offered his services; but as it was the duty of Lieut. FREMONT, the Quartermaster of the Regiment, he was obliged, at the solicitations of the officers, to go on board."

FIRES.--About 2 o'clock, on Saturday morning, a fire broke out in the second story of Mr. WAITE'S Machine Shop, in First, near Second-street, which was nearly destroyed, with nearly all the contents. The first floor was occupied by Mr. HENRY WAITE, as a Machine shop, whose loss amounts to about $2,300--no insurance. The second story was occupied by Mr. T. E. SHULTZ, as a percussion cap manufactory.

Our diplomatic system needs thorough and prompt revision. Our growing importance, our rapidly extending foreign relations, and the revolutionary state of European affairs, require that the diplomatic service of this country should be brought to its highest efficiency. Our ministers must be better paid,--

From the Washington Union. In another column will be found the detailed account of the recent renconcres between two American citizens in defence of a lany, wife of the one, and mother of the other, and the host who committed the insult, and the young nobleman who offered it.

About 10 o'clock this morning nearly a hundred women assembled at the State-street Bridge, and commenced tearing it down. They were armed with axes and saws, and one hundred feet of the Directors of the Northeast Railroad, was shamefully abused by the women who pelted him with rotten eggs, and tore his clothes off his back.

MIKE WALSH opened the grand conchological ball in Congress, by a characteristic tirade against the Administration and the Soft-Shells of the State of New-York. Mr. SMITH, of Alabama--the SMITH who distinguished himself some two years since by voting solitary and alone in favor of his own proposition to arrest Gov. KOSSUTH as an incendiary--rushed to the rescue, and damaged the Administration a good deal more essentially than MIXE'S epithets bad done.

CONSULAR APPOINTMENTS--RECOGNITIONS BY THE PRESIDENT.--The President has officially recognized CHARLES FRANSCOIS FREDERIC, Marquis de Monthelon, as Consul of the Emperor of the French at New York. C. MOSTON STEWART has also been recognized by the President as Consul of Buenos Ayres for the Port Baltimore.

NATIONAL POPULAR EDUCATION.--The Seventh annual meeting of the Board of National Popular Education was held in the Centre Church. Hartford, Conn., on the 4th of Jan, when the annual report of the Corresponding Secretary and General Agent was read, and addresses were made by Rev. Dr. ??? of the Methodist Church. Rev Mr. Btadie of the Congregational Church Rev Mr. Murdeck of the Baptist Church, and the Corresponding Secretary.

Dates from Galveston to the 6th of December have been received at New-Orleans. The news is not important. The steamer Magyar, plying between Galveston and Mobile, was wrecked, with no loss of life. The steamer Jack Hays struck on a snag in going up Trinity River.

The trains from New-York and Buffalo, on excursion over the Great Western Railroad, arrived here about 6 o'clock, having been detained on the road in consequence of the large numbers in the cars. Thousands of people are here from the country and from the Chicago, about 1,000 in the train for the East. The town is illuminated, and a banquet takes place at 7 o'clock

We find in the Utica Herald the following notice of a lecture recently delivery there by J C. DEVEREUX, Esq., of this City ;--Upon the Mediaval Ages: He took the Catholic point of view, and depicted the period from the fifth to the eleventh centuries--not a "dark ages."--but as ages of faith.

It will be seen by our correspondence in another column that the disgraceful outrages at Eric have been renewed. Yesterday the women of Eric,--or what is more probable, men disguised in women's clothes,--destroyed two of the railroad bridges, which have recently been rebuilt under the orders of the United States Court.

This report is moderate in length, occupying only 42 pages of the Legislative document, octavo, plain, and direct. The year spoken of ends with the 1st of July, 1853. The total number of districts reported is 11,684--144 more than last year.

Since the arrest of the United States Marshal and his Deputies, there has been no violent demonstration in the borough of Erie. There has been an unusual quiet-with the exception of a few threats to tear up what the Marshal had pat down, there has been no outward evidence of the real condition of things in Erie. To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times : SIR : I was very sorry to see your Albany correspondent disposed to caricature and make light of the social meeting of the friends of the Maine Law, on Friday evening last, at the Capital. I happened to be present at that meeting, and can assure you it was quite different from what he is pleased to represent.

This is JULLIEN'S night. Niblo's Garden will, without doubt, present an animated appearance. It is the only occasion on which JULLIEN'S splendid orchestra can be heard for some months. In addition to this, public sympathy is enlisted for the maestro in consequence of the heavy loss he sustained at Metropolitan Hall.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your remarks on this subject were certainly called for. Few are aware of the extent of this evil in our City. Forty-three deaths from this cause were reported in last week's bill of mortality; but how many cases of disease occurred are not known. Along the the First-avenue, and the avenues east of- that, cases are very numerous.

Before Judge Roosevelt. Daniel S. Bellows vs. As a Partridge and Thomas Fessenden.--This is a case arising on an assignment creating preferences for the benefit of creditors--a species of instrument which, although tolerated, is not favored by the law. Still, if confirmed to the solo purpose of giving a preference of one creditor over another, these instruments are valid, or at least they are not on that ground void.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Absence from the City has alone prevented one from sooner noticing a statement which appeared in several morning papers on Saturday, in reference to the sickness on board the San Francis-co after the wreck.

DESTRUCTIVE CONFLAGRATION IN PORTLAND, ME.--On Custom ??--formerly called the Exchange Building--is in ruins. The most distractive and disastrous fire that has ?? our ?? for many years, occurred between the hours of five and nine of Sunday morning, Jan. 6, camplerly destraving our noble Custom-House, and a vast amount of public and private properly.

The one hundred and forty-eighth anniversary of the day that gave birth to the patriot philosopher and printer, BENJAMIN FRANKLIN, was celebrated last evening by a grand ball and sopper, given at the assembly Rooms under direction of the New York Typographical Society. A Committee of twenty gentlemen (JAMES NARINE, Chairman,) took charge of the arrangements, which were carried out admirably.

EMPLOYMENT OF THE LABORING POOR. Alderman CHAUNCEY presented a lengthy memorial from Win. Smith Brown and others, in relation to the employment of a portion of our laboring population--idle and unemployed, are suggesting the manufacture of shoes and books by "teams," or a subdivision of parts as combined with the use of machinery.

There is a great deal of public indignation against the Captain of the Portland brig Napoleon for his dastardly desertion of the San Francisco. It may be well to republish the following, which is the report of the interview between the two vessels, made by Mr. McCARTY, chief mate of the Napoleon, on her arrival.

The steamship Black Warrior, from New-York for Mobile, via Havana, arrived at this port, yesterday, having put in to repair some slight derangement of her machinery. She reports having experienced very heavy weather in the southward of Cape Halteras The repairs to her machinery will be completed so that she will sail for Havana on Wednesday or Thursday.

By private advices received here, we learn that the regular Committee of the great BENTON meeting at St. Louis on the 8th of January, declined to report a resolution approving the present Administration. A resolution approving of the KOSZTA matter was passed, but one endorsing, in general terms, the Administration, offered by SAMUEL HOLMES, Esq., was thrown out, and all mention of it is excluded from the official account of the proceedings of the meeting.

To-day, at 12 o'clock, RODMAN M. PRICE, Governor elect of New-Jersey; was duly inaugurated and indueted it office. After the onthe of office were administered, the Governor delivered his inaugural address, in which he advocated a still more liberal provision for the education of every child in the State Special enactment. he suggests, should be avoided, labor and high wages should. be encouraged ;

The Message of Governor PEASE, of Texas, appears in the Galveston papers. The Pacific Railroad bill is commended, and the policy is advocated of appropriating lands in a liberal spirit, in favor of various State roads.

Mr. BROOKS'S resolution, instructing our members in Congress to procure for the State of New-York an equal share of the public domain for educational and other purposes in the event of the general Government donating those lands among the several States, was adopted.

Mr. REDFIELD'S nomination was reported in Executive Session to day. A single Whig's objection, because of Mr.SEWARD'S absence, prevented a vote. There were no indications of opposition. A number of additional unimportant nominations were sent in.

A frightful accident occurred here to-day. on the line of the New-Jersey Central Railroad. As the 12 o'clock M. through train from Easton, was leaving the station, a passenger, Mr. JOSIAH SAWDER, who left the ears for some refreshments, in his haste to get on board, full between two cars--the front wheels of the rear car passing over his right arm, managed it shockingly.

The Senate this morning requested the Secretary of State and the Comptroller to report the names of all Fire Insurance Companies which have filed in their respective effices declaration and copy of proposed charter, the capital stock of each and their respective places of business. ss.

At his residence, in East Chester, on the 16th inst., WEST F. CONCKLEN, fourth son of the large Jones W. Concklin, of the City, in the 28th year of his age. The friends of the family, and those of his brothers, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, without further invitation, from his late residence, on Wednesday, 18th inst. at 2 o'clock.

Mr. ALDEN, the chief mate of the Stafferdshire. arrived in this city to day. His account of the disaster is substantially as before stated. In a gale on the 28th December, the ship was almost stripped--the foremast alone standing. On the 29th, at 8 P. M., a hurricane from the W. N W. came on. By the captain's orders, the ship's course was kept northward until 12 o'clock.

Cholera at sea again begins to be reported to us by the dozen cases and the score. There is no dange that discussions of the subject will be untimely for yet a long while. On another page will be found a letter from the Surgeon of the San Francisco, correcting some erroneous statements that had been made as to the remote mortailty from this disease on board that in?? steamer.

Fifty-five minutes-only eleven-twelfths of an hour-was all the time that the Representatives in Assembly convened, this day devoted to the consideration of public affairs. In that brief period had been recapitulated all that was done on Saturday last-had been reported all that was ready for action, and notice given of all that it was at present proposed to do.

FROM ST. JOHN, N. B.--We have received paper from St. John to the 10th inst., A frightful tragedy occurred at Sydney, C. B. on the 30th ult. ARCHIBALI OTTO DODOR. Esq., Harris er at Low 27 years of age was shot dead in the store of Mr. BURCHELL, by NICHOLAS HENRY MARTIN, Esq., J. P., and late Postmaster at Sydney.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times : In looking over your valuable sheet this morning, I saw an article headed the "Causes of the wrack of the San Francisco," in which the writer attributes the loss of that steamer to her not having sufficient beam. The S. F. was 41 feet beam.

Several Executive communications were sent in. Mr. COOPER presented a remonstrance of the citizens of Philadelphia, against the establishment of a Mint in New-York. Mr DOUGLAS gave notice that on Monday next he would move to take up the Nebraska Bill.

From the Charleston Mercury. The last Murfreesborough Gazette says: "Yesterday, several negroes, belonging to the estates of DAVID GATLING and WILLIAM H. SEARS, were hired out, publicly. in this place, for the ensuing year, at prices ranging from $110 to $114. One negro man brought $130. These prices were given for ordinary field hanus."

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: We have from time to time given to the patriots and exiles of other lands, public entertainments. Sincerely believing that he who saves one human life, is greater than he who destroys thousands, I propose to the citizens of New-York an enjoyment which I feel assured they will remember for years, with pleasure and satisfaction.

The President is about to issue the following Proclamation: "Whereas, information has been received by me, that an unlawful expedition has been fitted out in the State of California, with a view to invade Mexico--a nation maintaining friendly relations with the United States--and that other expeditions are organizing within the United States, for the same unlawful purpose.

We did not arrive as early from the East as we expected. We reached here, twelve cars full, at 6 o'clock. The entire business part of the city was illuminated, can non were-firing, and great enthusiasm prevailed. Two thousand people were at the dinner The room was most splendidly decorated, and bands discoursed eloqnent music. The Mayor of Detroit presided.

Pennsylvania is just now considerably exercised on the subject of the Philadelphia Mint and the duties upon Railroad Iron, in connection with the law-defying affair on her Lake Shore border. It appears to be under stood at Harrisburg that some formidable movement is contemplated at Washington against Pennsylvania interests.

THE CASE OF THE SKIDDY.--In another column we give a report of the trial of a suit brought against the master and owner of the steamboat Francis Skiddy for detaining passengers on board who had bought Catskill tickets, instead of landing them at that place. The occasion of this was, it is said, not a race, but an endeavor to pass the Alide, and in the warmth of the endeavor the Catskill passengers were forgotten.

FIFTH DAY--CONCLUDED. Yesterday morning, at 11 o'clock, Justice STUART gave his opinion in the Arson case, which has been attracting public attention for some days past The Court-room was crowded with anxious spectators; the counsel for the defendant and a numerous corps of reporters were present, and impa??tently awaiting the further developement of the investigation.

Lecture of Rev. Henry ward Beecher. Nearly 3,000 of our citizens assembled on Tuesday evening, at the Tabernacle, to listen to the lecture of Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, it being the sixth of the regular course announced to be given under the auspices of the Anti-Slavery Society of this City.

In commenting on Monday morning upon the narratives given in the TIMES of the circumstances of the sad disaster which befel the San Francisco, we expressed the opinion that her wreck was mainly due to two facts, --first, that she was provided with guards, and second, that she was loaded "by the head."

We take pleasure in announcing the passage through the Senate, by a unan mous vote, of the bill submitting the Constitutional Canal Amendments to the people. The hill directs a Special Election to be held on the third Wednesday of February.

The officers of the Third Regiment of Artillery, as well as those associated with them in their late perilous position on the San Francisco, desire to express the high sense they entertain of the gallant conduct and gentlemanly bearing of Captain WATKINS, the commander of that ill fated ship. Ever kind, firm and energetic, he lef. no human means untried to save his ship and passengers.

Like a prisoner through the iron bars of his dungeon, I commit these lines to the dubious winds of chance, in the hope that they may be picked up by some good friend who will afterwards use them with discretion and judgment, and by this means give some information to the world concerning the state to which we are reduced, and the manifold sufferings under which we are hourly afflicted.

THOS. ATKINSON, D. D., Bishop of North Carolina. Subject: "The Age of CHARLES II" The lecturer commented by saying it would seem that in national as well as individual greatness there could not be universality of ??ent.

In the charters of the Sixth and Eighth avenue Railroads, there is a clause prohibiting the Companies from dividing more than ten per cent. among the Stockholders, and another authorizing the City Government to take possession of the roads at pleasure, on paying their cost and ten per cent. in addition thereto.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--Notwithstanding the, snow storm last evening, JULLIEN'S concert was crowded. it is scarcely probable that there ever were so many people congregated within NIBLO'S. The parquette, boxes, lobbies, stage, and passages, were one solid mass of human beings. The house presented a curious appearance, the parquette being boarded over and brought on a level with the stage.

ALLEGED FORGERY--Yesterday morning a resident of Brooklyn, named Heavy Stonehouse, was brought before Judge Bogart, at the Halls of Justice, by officer Camphell. It appears from the affidavit of Mr. Wm. Prim rose, that he sold out a saloon in Laurens-street to the defendant for $150, and took the following note for payment: $140. NEW-YORK, Sept. 6, 1858.

On Monday night the Board of Alder men unanimously passed Alderman MOTT'S resolution in favor of the passage of the bill, introduced into the State Senate by Mr. WHITNEY, to prevent the taxation and allowance of costs and charges to the Counsel to the Corporation for his services in opening and widening streets, avenues, and public parks.

In another part of this morning's TIMES will be found a letter from Pesth, exhibiting the character and influence of the Government. which Austria, since the close of the Hugarian struggle for Independence, has extended over that unhappy country. We hear but little of the domestic condition of Hungary under the new rule that is established over it.

DEATH FROM A RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--On Tues day morning, at 6 o'clock, an accident occurred at the Jersey City Depot of the New-Jersey Railroad, by which a German named THEODORE LELUFF, who resided at No. 375 Broome-street, lost his life. He, together with three friends, had attended a hall at Newark, and were reth??ing any the early train.

Oct. 11, the American ship Columbian, BURKE, muster, left Liverpool bound for Hampton Roads, with a cargo of salt. A succession of violent gales for eight or nine days carried away spars, and split and carried away several sails. The heavy seas caused her to labor hard and to leak so fast, that when she arrived at St. Thomas,(Oct. 27), she was making two feet of water an hour.

Before Judge Duer Smith against McCalingh.--This action was brought against one of the defendants as part owner, and the other as mas ?? the steamboat Francis Skiddy. It view out of an alleged race between the Skiddy and the Alide, on the North River, in July, 1852; about which, as our readers will remember. since decision arose at the time, the connection with the Henry Clay disaster, which occurred immediately afterward.

Mr. FISH presented petitions from New-York, in favor of a line of steamers between Brooklyn and Germany. Also, a petition from Inspectors of Customs in New-York, for increased compensation. Mr. COOPER presented the proceedings of a public meeting in Philadelphia in favor of Cheap Ocean Postage. The bill for the relief of LEWIS B. WILLIS was passed.

HIGH-HANDED OUTRAGE--The trial of E. A. READ and others, charged with selling liquor, contrary to law, commenced in Greenfield yesterday, before Gen. ASA HOWLAND, (J. P.) Mr. HOWLAND is one of our best citizens, (writes a Greenfield correspondent,) and resides in Conway, in this County The trial continued through the day, and the Court adjourned till this morning at 9 o'clock.

MORE PEABODY LIBERALITY.--GEORGE PEA BODY, of London, has recently performed another characteristic act, in presenting to his native town of Danvers $200 a year, during his life, for distribution in annual prizes of merit among the pupils of the Peabody and Holton High Schools of that town. The receipt of this offer was made the occasion of a very pleasant gathering of these two schools, on Wednesday last, at South Danvers.

Internal Condition of the French Empire. Extract of a Private Letter from an American Gentleman, Dated PARTS, Sunday, Dec. 26, 1853. The Emperor held his first general reception for foreigners on the 15th ; there were fifteen Americans present, and I am happy to say that one of our fair countrywomen carried off the palm of beauty--Miss -- , of New York.

CONSOLIDATION -- In the charter proposed for the consolidated city, the Commissioners have inserted a clause appropriating $1,500 to the Fire Department Fund. Another provision added provides that $1,000 shall be appropriated annually to the Dispensaries of this city and Williamsburg, to be divided in the proportion of the taxable property in the several districts.

THOMAS H. PERKINS, of Boston, is dead. He died Wednesday morning, and was 89 years, old Colonel PERKINS was the last of those who had a personal remembrance of the Boston massa??re, which preceded the Revolution.

When the law first went into operation in this State it was rigidly enforced in this city ; Rearly all the rum shops were closed, and if any sold, they did it stealthily. NATHAN C. ELY, Esq. in the Chair, DAYS OF MEETING. Alderman WOODWARD offered the following: Resolved, That the meetings of this Board commence on the first Monday of each month, and thereafter on Monday, Wednesday and Friday of each week until further ordered. Alderman CHAUNCEY moved to amend, by making it twice a week--on Monday and Thursday.

The steamship Canada, Capt. STONE, sailed at noon to day, with 68 passengers for Liverpool, and 18 for Halifax. She takes $231,000 in specie. The lost ship Tam O'Shanter, from Calcutta, was owned by Mr. SOULE of New Haven, and was commanded by his nephew. The amount of insurance is not yet ascertained.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: There are misstatements contained in the article in your paper of the 16th, which I cannot permit to pass unnoticed in justice to my fellow passengers on board the bark Kilby. It is stated that in a counsil held in the cabin, the superior officers on board sanctioned a proposition that we should desert the steamer, and make our way to the nearest port.

The rain falls equally upon the broadcloth of the just and the unjust--destroying the gloss on both; and during the Summer time, the sun shines as brightly upon the wicked as upon the righteous-giving a bronzed aspect to the countenances of all who receive its unobstructed rays,-so with equal disregard of merit, the Sabbath comes to Erie as it cometh to localities where Christianity doth more abound.

Mr. ALDEN, the first mate of the ill fated ship Staffordshire, reached this city by railroad last evening, having traveled the entire distance from Barrington to Waterville by stage--most of the way through snow lifts, and exposed to great suffering by the cold. One of his feet and one hand were frost bitten Mr. ALDEN has furnished the following authentic statement of the loss of this splendid ship.

BEFORE JUSTICE OSBORN. The judicial investigation pending before Justice OSBORN, respecting the shooting of a colored man named EDWARD MATTHEWS, a short time since, in Church street, was resumed at 3 P. M. yesterday. In the mean time, PATRICK MATTHEWS, charged with the offence, has been kept in the custody of Captain CARPENTER, who effected the arrest, and was present, with his counsel, ABRAHAM RUSSELL, Esq.

Numerous petitions have been presented, asking the passage of a general law for the incorporation of navigation companies. The principle of enacting laws under which associations may be formed for the prosecution of business, has been found to much lessen the duties of the Legislature, and in accordance with public sentiment, so there is little doubt that the prayer of the patittoners will be granted.

The annual Report of the Sixth avenue Railroad Company, presented at the annual meeting of the Stockholders on Monday last, exhibits a very promising condition of affairs in the management of that road. City Railroads are evidently prosperous Concerns. The Six b-avenue line is now in uniform operation from Forty fourth-street to Barelay, with a branch up ??eal-street to Broadway. The track is used in common by the Sixth

THE NEW-BOSTON TRAGEDY.--We yesterday stated that HENRY N SARGENT shot, in cold blood, a young lady named SERVILLA JONES, at New-Boston, N. H., on Friday last. I appears that he was violently enamored of the girl, which was not reciprocated. This so "worked up" his feelings that he became partially in sane. This had been evident for several days, as was also the cause.

This place has to-day been the scene of another railroad accident, which, as usual, seems to be the result of carelessness. As the first mail train East, from New-York, on the New-York and New-Haven Road, was approaching the depot in Westport, it was suddenly thrown from the track, and the engine and tender precipitated fifteen or twenty feet down an almost perpendicular bank.

The Macon Telegraph records the death in that city, on the morning at athe Sub inst., Co. O. H. THROP, in the 47th year of his age. Col THROOP was a native of New-York, but has resided in Macon for the last three years. Judge FRIERSON, formerly of Tuacaloose, Ala., died recently at Victoria. Texas.

The conquest of Lower California by Captain WALKER'S band of marauders engaged attention in the Senate yesterday. Senator GWIN attempted to transfer the responsibility of these discreditable proceedings from the people of California to the shoulders of the Government.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: When the papers first informed us of the supposed loss of the steamer San Francisco, with more than six hundred souls on board, including some of the finest officers of our army and their families, what a disgrace to our Navy was the answer of Secretary DOBBIN: "I have no ships fit to go in search of her."

The State is advertising for claims, or rather the State Prison Inspectors are soliciting all those having bills against the Institutions under their charge to present the same for audit, and prospective payment, if they are found correct. The reports of the agents profess to state the financial condition of the Prisons, but it appears no reliance can be placed upon their representations.
