Numerous petitions were presented for relief Also a petition requesting the Legislature to provide for furnishing suitable medals to the rescuers of the passengers of the San Francisco. Notice was given of a bill to prevent the plea of usury in certain cases.

We alluded yesterday to certain signs of a troubled spirit among the politicians and press of Pennsylvania, in regard to the effect of the Erie affair. The State has long been a sturdy beggar at the National Capitol. She has trained her leading men to claim undeserved favors and peculiar privileges from Congress, as a prescriptive right.

The opposition to Senator DOUGLAS' Nebraska bill is gathering strength and consistency every hour. It is so clearly regardless of Northern sentiment, and so bare-faced a bill for Southern votes that it must disgust a large portion even of those who are supposed to be especially benefited by it.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In a recent number of your paper there was an article calling public attention to the resources of this locality, whichtmay awaken some of our enterprising merchants (who are not already surfeited with business) to the importance of immediately establishing commercial intercourse therewith.

I never knew thee; but I feel A debt of gratitude to all Who drew the wrong-avenging steel When rang the tyrant's trumpet call; And, scorning threat and kingly frown, The scabbard, in their wrath, threw down. My life-blood, with redoubled force, Runs bubbling in its crimson course, And nameless raptures thrill my frame Such men, my countrymen, to name.

EXAMINATION AND DISCHARGE OF THE GERMAN CONVICTS.--Three German convicts, under arrest on suspicion of having stolen a quantity of goods from the house of C. STOVEKEN. in Jersey City, on the 8th inst., were examined before Recorder CUTTER, on Wednesday, and discharged for want of sufficient evidence. A woman, residing in New-York, testified that the accused were in her house at the time the robbery was committed.

An adjourned meeting of the sympathizers with the sufferers by the destruction of the Lafarge Hotel in Broadway, was held last evening at the Metropolitan Ho tel. At a late hour. the meeting was called to order, Capt. FERRIS in the Chair. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved.

There has been but little said or done in Erie during the past twenty-four hours that would be of any interest to your readers. Since the arrest of the Marshal, they seem to have concluded that after so great a work it was meet that they should rest awhile.

The Colonization cause is onward. Last night the Society held its Anniversary in Mr. BUTLER's Episcopal Church. Mr. LATROBE, its President, was in the Chair, and made an able address. He was followed by Judge WAYNE, of the Supreme Court, in a noble, eloquent and convincing argument in favor of the General Government aiding the plan of African Colonization.

In a country where everything finds its level, there are not many projects that can be pronounced utterly impracticacle. There is nothing politically impossible in an arbitration clause--nothing, physically, in a railway to Calcutta nor, as far as we know, in an electric cable from Galway to New-York. But there now lies before us the account of a scheme which does seem wholly beyond the range of British possibilities.

Five years since, when the question of constructing a Railroad from our frontiers to the Pacific coast was first suggested, with the exception of some few local interests likely to be injuriously affected by it, there was but one opinion in regard to its necessity, either immediate or ultimate.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your paper of the 28th of December, I find a letter from Louisville, Ky., in which the writer makes several errors--unintentional, no doubt--which I hope you will permit me to correct. The first was entirely unintentional, because at the time the letter was written the Pork business had not commenced in Louisville.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: This is unquestionably a "fast age." Young America is most emphatically progressive. Coming down town the other day in the Amity street stage, we observed a bright looking little fellow, enveloped in a black, shaggy little overcoat, enter the stage, and, after a few moments had elapsed, he took from his pocket several documents, which, with a particularly business-like air, he proceeded to examine.

Board of Education. The Board of Education held its regular weekly meeting on Wednesday afternoon--E. C. BENEDICT, Esq, in the Chair. The first business in order was the election of the Committees of the Board. Messrs. Stuart and Fell were appointed tellers. The following was the result:

Our Minister in China has managed to place the United States in an unpleasant posion in connection with the rebellion now going on in the Chinese Empire. We published, some ten days since, the correspondence between the American officials and the American merchants at the city of Shanghai, in regard to the payment of duties at the Chinese Custom-House at that port.

DEAN STEERT INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL.--This school has been in operation about one year, and new has under its influences 76 little girls, mostly from the most wretched class of society. Through the benevolence of a few individuals, in furnishing materials, the managers, with the assistance of a few friends, have made more than one hundred dresses, besides other garments for the scholars.

From the returns of the "General Board of Health," as published in the late London papers, we pick out some instructive facts. The cholera has been checked in England, though there has been no day lately in which the disease has not occurred in different parts of the country. In Scotland it still exists with unabated violence.

LECTURES.--On Wednesday evening the third lecture of the New England course, was delivered in the Northeast Congregational Church, in South Ninth street, by WENDELL PHILLIPS. Subject-The, Lost Arts. Notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather, the discourse was listened to by a respectable audience.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Permit me to call your attention to an enterprise, the beneficial operation of which has become manifest by a trial of nearly two weeks. I allude to the free dinner for the poor people, which is given by Mr. LINDERMUELLER, No. 118 Chat ham-street, every day during three hours, to everyone who asks it.

WALLAOK'S THEATRE.--The best written and best acted piece of the season was produced here on Thursday evening. It is called the " Bachelor of Arts," and is from the London boards. The comedy is in three arts, and has but two scenes--two thirds of the play proceeding in the same interior. This is the first instance in our memory where the principal and consecutive parts of a comedy occur in this fashion.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: I wish to know, through the medium of your paper, if there is any law, since the abolition of the Inspection Law, to compel Flour-dealers to deliver full weight--196 pounds per barrel to their customers.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Permit me to occupy a space in your paper to correct an error in what seems to be " public opinion," in relation to the order of disembarkation from the wreck of the San Francisco. My office and duties gave me an opportunity of knowing all the facts and circumstances in relation to the transfer of the troops from the steamer to the Kilby.

The party who left Mexico on 5th inst. with GADSDEN are now at the North. GADSDEN took Charleston in his way. HARGOUS, and (by this time) RAMSEY, of the Ramsey route, are in New York. The main features of the treaty are well understood. The Mesilla purchase will cost twenty millions dollars.

Once within our memory it was quito fashionable to talk of peace,--even of universal heace. It was when the clarion of war had not been heard within our borders for thirty years. Then only the old folks wore stirred when they beard the sound of drum and fife, being moved by the memories they summoned, and the very young ones, to hom such things came like illustrations of the books they had rend.

We have recently seen, in some of the Eastern papers, a notice of the death of Mr. JOHN KELLOGG, Esq., of Cornwall, Litchfield County, Conn, at the age of 70 years. Mr. KELLOGG was the only surviving son of lion. JUDAS KELLOGG, who having at an early ago graduated with distinguished honors, at Yale College,

To the Honorable the Court of General Sessions: The Grand Inquest in and for the City and County of New-York, in concluding their labors for this term cannot refrain from presenting to the consideration of the Court a few usages and practices that in their judgement are highly prejudicial to the administration of justice, and averse to the good order of society.

Our English papers contain numerous accounts of fresh outrages perpetrated upon foreigners by the Italian States. A Mr. BAGUIO, a British Ionian, who has long carried on business at Naples, recently visited Paris and London, On his return he landed at Leghorn, intending to go thence to Naples; but the Neapolitan Consul refused to vise his passport.

Board met pursuant to adjournment. The mines of the last meeting were read and approved. PARTITIONS. Of Hose Company No. 01 for a new carriage, Refered, of the residents of Harlem, for a hose carriage, with 16 legths of hose. Referred. Of Dr Fanshaw and others, have Eighteith-street opened from Fifth avenue to the Last River. Referred. .

Two mammoth steamers are building in Buffalo, to run in connection with the Michigan Central Railroad route on the opening of navigation. They are estimated to cost $500,110 each, and are to be named the Plymouth and Western World. They will be under command of Capts. Geo. E. Willoughby and O. C. Stannard.
GENTLEMEN--I regret much that my health prevents my uniting with you in this mode of commemorating the birth-day of our illustrious and beloved friend. The commemoration has my warmest approval.

We have two treaties with Mexico. The first, Judge CONKLING'S, guarantees the Stoo right of way over the Tehuantepec route. The second, Mr. GADSDEN's, secures to the United States thirty-nine million acres of land, and the right for another road; and abolishes the 11th Article of the treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, which required the United States to protect Mexico against the Indians.

We see it stated that some of the enterprising people of Brooklyn are talking of the propriety and necessity of a University in their pleasant city. We are very glad to see it because there is certainly a pressing need for more Universities.
WARREN WOOD, the murderer of WILLIAMS, the peddler, was hung in the jail-yard to-day, at 12 o'clock. He made a long address, in which he charged some of the witnesses with perjury.

The trial of CHARLES HOPKINS, WESLEY BROWN, and JOHN NAGLE, charged with confederating in a general plan to rob divers persons, was resumed yesterday at the Kings County Sessions. The interest innanufested by a crowded court in the proceedings at the opening seemed not to have abaied to the close.

The denoument] of this sorry drama, which history will call the second of December, seems to be nearer than might be supposed. At least, it is generally is it to be on here. Every day, every hour, intensifies and precipitates the crisis. Every one is in expectation of great events. Meanwhile, commerce, and labor and industry are in suspense. The Empire is like a dying man.

Some of our neighbors are dreadfully shocked because the TIMES published the President's proclamation against the fillibusters of Lower California in advance of them They are gradually getting used to this sort of thing, however.

On Thursday evening, 19th inst., at the residence of Dr, Bern W. Budd, by Rev. Thomas Gallaudet, JOHN C, HUNTER, purser of the U.S Navy, to SOPHIA, daughter of the late Rev. Thomas H. Gallaudet, LL.D., of Hartford, Conn.
WASHINGTON, Friday, Jan 20.

A memorial from the Mechanics' Institute was presented, calling for the appointment of JAMES RENWICX as one of the Harbor Commissioners of Syracuse. A favorable report was made on the bill for the incorporation of Companies to navigate the Lakes, Rivers and Canals.

Yesterday morning, the Judges of the Supreme and Superior Courts came down at tile usual hour, to hold the Special Term and Chambers of those Courts, but, in consequence of the fire, were unable to proceed to business, and adjourned until today, In the meantime, temporary accommodations for the Courts and Public Offices hive been prepared.

Violence reigns again in Erie. The long bridge over the street nearest the depot was deatroyed this morning by a mob composed of German women and men dressed In women's apparel. The scene, though scarcely more disgraceful, was the most picturesque of any I have seen since my soiourn in this villainous borough. During last eve.

The Religious journals share to the full extent in the steady and rapid improvement which characterizes the newspaper Press of this country. There is a great deal of complaint in all quarters of the short-comings of the Press,--of its inadequacy to the proper lischarge of its high duties, and especially of Its lack of the ability which its functions reluire.

MORTALITY IN BALTIMORE IN 1853.--The Annual Report of the Board of Health of the City of Baltimore has just appeared. The total number of deaths in the city during the year 1853, was 5,150; males 2,705, female 2,445, Frge colored persons 673, slaves 135. Among the principal diseases were the following; Applexy, 64; Asthama, o ; Bronchitis, 20; Cholera Infantum.

In reply to a resolution passed in the Senate, the Hudson River Railroad Company makes the following report. "That no agreement has been entered into between the Hudson River and Karlem Railroad Companies for maintaining any certain or specific rate of fare or freight.

Dr. SMITH was inaugurated Mayor or boston on Monday. On the occasion he made a good speech. He went in for good salaries to officers, and strict accounts. Public property, he says, is too high in the city. He advises to offer it on good terms to purchasers, taking one per cent, of the purchase money down, and mortgages on the improved properly as security for the balance.

The denomination or community known as the Society of United Believers, or Shakers,--So called from a devotional exercise in which shaking or dancing, or both, are practiced,--had its origin in England, about the middle of the eighteenth century; under the load of two seceding Quakers of the name of WARDLEY,

The Dissection bill has passed the Senate and been sent down to the House. As hereoforo the thing has had much better fate in the House than in the Senate, its friends are justified in their hopes that it will eventually pass both branches and become law. And why should it not pass!

The House went into Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union on the President's Message. Mr. SMITH, of Va., having obtained the floor, yielded it to Mr. CUTTING, who commenced his reply to Mr. HUGHES.
To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Meeting accidentally with a copy of your paper, dated 16th, I noticed an article entitled "Cholera at Sea,"

On the 20th inst., WILLIAM R., only son of Edwin R. Yale, aged 25 years. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, at 1 o'clock, this day, from No. 8 Reachest., New-York, His remains will be taken to Greenwood.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your readers may be interested to learn, through your excellent paper, that the New York State Temperance Alliance held its annual meeting in this city yesterday, and that unyielding determination was manifested, on the part of delegates in attendance from various countries of the State, to leave nothing undone in the

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I believe your paper contained the Report of the Secretary of War in advance of every other paper in this City, and as we of the Artillery desire to say a few words upon that report, we respectfully ask a space in your columns.

Brussels is a much more important point on the political map of Europe than is generally supposed. It is important, from its having a censtitutional life in the midst of absolute and despotio States; and it is also important, from its having a King with such family connections as those of LEOPOLD.

We are again surrounded by a mob, and work of destroying the railroad bridges that were recently rebuilt under the direction of the United States Marshal, has been again commenced by a number of the leading (ladient) of the city.

A numerous and respectable audience assembled in the Mechanics Society Lecture RoomThursday evening, to hour Mr. BAYARD TAYLOR speak on "the Arabe" among whom he has safetly nojurned. His discourse was one of the most outertaining that has been delivered during the season many portions eliciting warm plaudits.

NATHAN O. ELY, Esq., in the Chair. Alderman Howard asked to be execused in consequence of illness, caused by attending the fire at the Now City Hall, Excused. Alderman DNAXB presented a petition from Garret H. Stryher and others, for an oldinance to compel the Hidson River Railroad Company to discontinue the use of steam below Fifty-ninth-street, Referred.

The United States Circuit Court was in session to-day, for the trial of Mayor ALFRED KING and M. B. LOWRIE for contempt of the order of the said Court, in interfering and endeavoring to prevent the arrest by Marshal SPROUL, of KILPATRICK, KIRKPATRICK, SHERMAN and JACKS. (now in our County Jail,) on the 6th of January.

Mr. J. A. SOOVILLE, who acted as the private Secretary of Mr. CALHOUN for some months previous to his death, has published a letter embodying some interesting memoranda concerning his opinions on the relations between the North and South, and this forebedings, which towards the close of his life, amounted almost to monomania, of a speedy dissolution of the Union.

DEATH OF CAPTAIN PARTRIDGE.--A letter to the Manchester Mirror, dated Hanover, N. H., Jan. 17, announces the death of Captain ALDEN PARTRIDGE, the well-known military instructor. He died at his residence in Norwich, Vt., that morning, after an illness of a few hours.

Our harbor and town have been rather enlivened for a week or so past by the appearance of the United States frigate Columbia the sloop-of war Albany, and the steamer Fulton--a part of the Home Squadron under command of Commodore JOHN T. NEWTON, whose flag ship is the Columbia.

The telegraph has announced that the citizens of Boston and Baltimore have started subscriptions for the benefit of the Captains of the rescuing vessels is the San Francisco affair. The Boston papers give the following names of subscribers whose donations are already received:

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: In your paper of Thursday morning there are some statements in relation to the steamer San Francisco, made, probably, under misapprehension of the facts of the case, and without full know ledge of the action of the various parts of a steam engine.
Our Havana Correspondence by the Crescent City, which arrived on Saturday, contains some very interesting items of intelligence from that port.
WOODEN AWNINGS.--An adjourned meeting of storekeepers and others interested in the enforcement of the ordinance prohibiting the erection of wooden awnings, was held on Friday evening at the Odeon.

The following intelligence relative to the three American seamen confined in the Royal jail here was not made public until after the steamship Isabel had got under way, on her last departure for Charleston.

We see it stated that Capt. MCCERREN, of the Defiance, is at Washington seeking redress of Peru through our Government, for the outrages and injuries sustained by him at the hands of the Peruvian officials at the Chincbas Islands some months since.
We publish, this morning, another letter from our Special Correspondent, in regard to the progress of mob-outrage at the borough of Erie.

The mob last night hung in effigy Mr. J. H. WALKER, Director of the Erie and Northeast Railroad, accompanying the act with shouts and yells like infuriated fiends. The mad and drunken excitement knows no bounds.
We publish in another part of this morning's TIMES some interesting reminiscences of the late Mr. CALHOUN, from Mr. SCOVILLE, who was his Private Secretary during the last few months of his life.
Senator GWIN pronounces the President's proclamation too late to be of any service in preventing the evil at which it is directed. Some of his remarks upon this point are worthy of special attention:

THE LOO CHOO ISLANDS AND JAPAN. On Friday evening, BAYARD TAYLOR delivered a lecture on the above subject at Hope Chapel, in the presence of a large and highly respectable audience, comprising many of the members of the Mercantile Library Association, under whose auspices the lecturer had been employed.

About 4 o'clock this morning a fire was discovered in one of the stores under the Blossom Hotel, and so rapid was the progress of the flames that the whole block of buildings from St. Paul's street east to Crystal Palaco block is in one mass of ruins.

From the Portland Advertiser. MESSRS. EDITORS: Having seen statements in the Boston Daily Times, which are entirely unfounded, and having been repeatedly called upon to deny them, if false, I take the opportunity so to do.

HOMICIDE IN MILLEDGEVILLE.-On the 11th inst., WM. A. RALSTON, a resident of Macon, Ga., was killed in Milledgeville, by ARCHIBALD HONT, of Albany.

Dr. SOLGER's third lecture was delivered on riday evening, January 20. Its topics were Government and Revolution in France, Austria, and Prussia. Robert Blum's Secret History of Louis Napoleon's Coup d'Etat, etc.

The burials last week numbered 529--more by 46 than the week preceding. There have been 7 more of that convenient-to shield-ignorance disease entitled atrophy, 8 more of bronchitis, 6 more of diarrhoea, 11 more of dropsies, 4 more of eryaipclas, 4 more typhug, 6 more of whooping-cough, 7 more of measles, 5 more of palay, 3 more of small-pox, and 4 more stillborn, than on the second week of January.

A New Phase--Legal Proceedings against the "Hards" and "Softs"--The Tammany Hall Proprietors vs. The Democratic General Committee of 1852. The excitement of City Politics has been revived within the past few days, by legal proceedings instituted in the Superior Court against the Democratic General Committee of 1852, by JOSEPH W. HOWARD and CHAS.

PUMPING OUT BOSTON HARBOR.--Frequenters of our wharves are well aware that a class of vessels often lie at Long Wharf known as fishing-smacks. These smacks hail, in most cases from Cape Ann, and supply our market with fresh fish.

By the Crescent City we have files of Havana papers up to January 15, inclusive. They are full of servile compliment to the new Dictator of Mexico, who is extolled to the skies for his wisdom, heroism and piety.
By the last steamer I was unable to give matters that were at that time of some interest here, but which have passed the period for report as news.

From the New-Orleans Crescent. The papers from Vera Cruz we have received by the Texas are from the 5th to 9th, and as these embody the latest news, which is of great interest, we will take them up at once, the more especially as they supply dates from the city itself which we have not received, though we may yet get them.
To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I think you do right in giving place to written expressions of opinion respecting the concurring causes of the terrible disaster on board the San Francisco.
You may rely upon it that Mr. DEAN'S declaration of standing upon the Compromise of '50, in relation to Nebraska, Cuba, and Sonora, was well considered and authoratively stated.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your account of the destruction of the old Almshouse in the Park, on Thursday evening, you call it the "New City Hall." You may be correct, but as I have heard a variety of names given to the old edifice, I would like to be entirely satisfied on the point.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: I read in your paper of the 20th, an article headed "Free Dinner for the Poor," and signed "Be nevolence," in which the writer seems to imply that unless there should be an increase of contributions, the number of recipients will have to be very much limited.
We have some very curious and instructive revelations in the Herald and Express, as to the manner in which those high-toned and immaculate journals are edited.
BROOKLYN CITY.

The Crescent City is due here this morning from New-Orleans, but has not yet arrived. The Black Warrior, always punctual, is expected this afternoon with New-York mails, and they are anxiously looked for, as we received no letters by the Crescent City.

Mortality in Brooklyn in 1853. The Health Officer of Brooklyn has presented to the Common Council of that City his Annual Report of Deaths for the year 1853. We condense the principal statements of the report.

Our neighbor, the Tribune, is especially severe upon the administration for permitting piratical expeditions to leave the port of San Francisco, and still more savage upon Senator GWIN, for suggesting that there ought to be a vessel of war there to stop them.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: M. MAILLEVERT'S operations towards opening a channel through our Falls continue to attract the attention of the large sections of country interested in this improvement.

HEAVY ROBBERY IN ALBANY--SIX THOUSAND DOLLARS WORTH OF SILKS, SATINS AND VELVETS STOLEN.--The dry goods store of Messrs. GEORGE WHITE Co., on the corner of Broadway and Steuben-streets, Albany was entered on Thursday and robbed of silks, satins and velvets in the value of five of six thousand dollars.
It is with reluctance that I acknowledge a fervent desire to neglect my duty, by retiring from this sin abounding borough.

The British ship Sir Charles Napier, from Liver pool for Savannah, is ashere twenty miles south of Tybee. The weather is favorable, and she is likely to be got off. Her cargo consists of salt, and two hundred tons of railroad iron.

A very old customer is the hog. He was coeval with the mastodon, the dinotherium and the huge red deer; but those gentry have perished from the face of the earth, in spite of their great names, while the hog yet rootles and snoozes alternately in pen provided for him--is nursed and delicately regarded in his life, and in his death loved hugely.

Special Report. UNITED STATES VS. ALFRED KING AND M. B. LOWRY OF ERIE. The defence was this morning continued; the following witnesses were called: Dr. O. II. IRISH testified that STERETT, the man who threatened to raise one hundred and fifty men before morning to resist the Marshal, was an habitual drunkard, and that he was under the care of a committee of Court as a lunatic from that cause.

THE LAFARGE HOUSE SUFFERERS.--The final meeting of the friends of Messrs. WRIGHT, LARIERS Co., lessees of the late Lafarge Hotel, will be held this evening at Metropolitan Hotel. The amount to be sub scribed for the erection of a new Hotel, under the terms of an agreement drawn for the purpose, is $150,000, and as much more as can be obtained.

The Senate has passed a resolution expelling a colored reporter named DAY, by a vote of 17 to 10. The Erie resolutions were taken up, and a protracted debate ensued. A substitute of a milder tone, was offered.

The Nuncio to the Most Rev. Archbishop of Cincinnati: DEAR ARCHBISHOP: I need not tell you how deeply I have been affected by the truly affectionate welcome with, which I was greeted by your good Catholics, and particularly the institutions for the education of the youth.
In the Senate yesterday, there was a very interesting debate started by Senator CASS, in regard to the outrages offered to Archbishop BEDINI, at Cincinnati and other cities.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have read with great surprise in your paper of this date a communication signed "A Jerseyman," who takes the liberty of poking sticks at poor Pennsylvania in the matter of the Erie war. Now, what in the name of Crystal Palaces ought a Jerseyman to say on this question?

Among the pleasant phases of Winter life in the Metropolis are the "Receptions" at the residences of the President and his Secretaries. Men of all parties and creeds meet in social harmony; and it is here that politicians find their narrow, hitter road prejudices melting away in the glowing atmosphere of the Metropolitan drawing rooms.

DELINQUENT CONTRACTORS.--The failure of contractors to comply with the terms of their contracts, has been a matter of much annoyance. Although the con tractors give bonds for the faithful performance of their agreement, and are liable to a forfeiture of so much per diem i? not completed, yet they manage to avoid the penalty, and proceed in arranging matters to suit their own convenience, to the great detriment of the City.

On Tuesday morning last, says the Caddo, Louisiana, Gazette of the 7th instant, soon after the market people had mostly dispersed, a meeting took place on Texas-street between Mr. JOHN R. STANIK and Mr. THOS.S MCCONNELL, both citizens of this place.

FELLOW-CITIZENS: As Senators and Representatives in the Congress of the United States, it is our duty to warn our constituencies whenever imminent danger menaces the Freedom of our Institutions or the Permanency of our Union. Such danger, as we firmly believe, now impends, and we earnestly solicit your prompt attention to it.

A THIN HOUSE. There were but eighteen members in attendance this morning. Petitions, numerously signed, were introduced for a prohibitory Liquor law; also for the repeal of the law exempting the property of ministers from taxation. A bill was introduced authorizing Savings Banks to deposit their surplus funds in Trust Companies.

The steamers are making long Winter passages. The Niagara was sixteen days reaching Halifax on her inward voyage to Boston. Her news, not very decided in political affairs, but important commercially, was telegraphed yesterday to this City, and the summary of our Liverpool Agent will be found on another page.

Is it lawful for private citizens to organize themselves into a company and collect fire-arms, and deposit them in any building they may happen to own.

From the Washington Union. In an article which appeared in the New-York Herald, on the 19th instant, the editor makes what he terms "surprising discourses of General PIERCE's Free Soal correspondence and opinions."

Jan. 21, CATHARINE A., widow of Archibald McVickar, and daughter of the late Brockhoist Livingston. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, from Transfiguration Church. East 29 host., on Wednesday, 25th inst., at noon Her remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment. On Sunday evening, Jan. 22, Mr. JOHN VAN BUSKIAK, in the 54th year of his age.

The excursion party from the New York side to the Opening Ceremonies of the Great Western Road of Canada, have returned to their respective homes. The Canada arrangements were far from complete, or in all cases, comfortable.

Mr. JORDAN says that he once heard TROS. CAMPBELL narrate how that, when traveling in Scotland, he had been stopped at a small country in by the weather, and after dinner indulged himself with the toothpick, to while away the idle after hour. Enter Chamber moid: Sir, if ye please are ye dune with the toothpick?--Why do you ask? I suppose I may pick away as long as like.

MISSION SCHOOL.--The Mission School, under the superintendence of Rev Mr. WEST, on Union-street, near Hamilton-avenue, South Brooklyn, is rapidly increasing in interest and usefulness There are at the present time some sixty children who attend--a large portion of whom are girls. The majority of these children are from the very lowest station of society.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. SIR: The communication which I had the honor to send to you, under the above head, and which you inserted in your edition of the 20th inst., has elicited a letter by "A Lady," to which I trust you will allow me to respond in some brief remarks.

President PIERCK, in his late Message, after exulting in the profound repose which had followed the enactment of the Compromise Bills of 1850, gives the country the solemn assurance, that "this repose shall suffer no shock during his official term if he has the power to avert it."

The burning of the New City Hall affords the Government an excellent opportunity for providing a suitable building in this City for the accommodation of the United States Courts. Hitherto they have been dependent upon the City for the rooms they required, and no special provision has been made for the security of the valuable papers, documents, , connected with the immense business of the Federal Courts in this District.

WATER FOR HOBOKEN--UNION OF THE CITIES PROPOSED.--The subject of supplying Hoboken with water from the Jersey City Water Works, came up for discussion before the Jersey City Common Council, at its meeting on Friday evening, at the office of the Water Commissioners, at the Lyceum. A portion of the Water Commissioners and delegates from Hoboken were present.

Yesterday we had the opportunity of examining some specimens of gold brought in by Major STEEN, of the United States Dragons, from the vicinity of the Copper Mines in New-Mexico, in the neighborhood of Fort Webster where he has been stationed. The specimen is from surface washings, but sufficient to show that the precious metal exists there, and subsequent washings will, doubtless, prove its existence in larger quantities.

A telegraphic dispatch from Independence Missouri, states that the Santa Fe mail arrived at than place on Saturday last, having been 20 days on the road. Business at Santa Fe was very dull. Hon. HUGH SMITH had recovered from his wounds. KIT CARSON, FLETCHER, and others had just arrived at Santa Fe, from California. They left Los Angelos on Oct. 25, and report fine weather.

Arrived ship Java, HERON, 113 days from Tahiti via St. Thomas, Jan. 9. Touched at St. Thomas, Jan. 6, bark Barclay, TRIPP. of Westport, with 400 barrels of sperm oil. Arrived at St. Thomas, Jan. 5. ship Herman, SKINNER, of Baltimore, from Callao, in a sinking c??l1ition, having ten feet of water in her hold.

The Committee of Arrangements deserve great credit for the excellent manner in which the affair was conducted. On the second page of this morning's TIMES will be found an Address, which has just been issued at Washington, to the People of the United States, on the subject of the bill just introduced by Senator DOUGLAS permitting the establishment of Slavery in Nebraska, and repealing the Missouri Compromise.

Mr. PETTIT moved that the Committee on Private Land Claims be allowed a Clerk. Agreed to. Mr. DOUGLAS asked leave to make a report from the Committee on Territories. He said the attention of the Committee had been directed to the fact that the southern boundary of Nebraska, as laid down in the bill heretofore reported, which was 36[degrees] 30', would divide the Cherokoe Country.

We published some days since a letter from a correspondent of the TIMES at the Chincha Islands, revealing facts concerning the introduction of Chinese Coolies and the disposal of them to Peruvian task-masters, by English traders, which ought to command the attention of the British public.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--A Comic Drama, in three acts, was produced here last evening, called "The Hope of the Family." It is from the prolific pen of J STIRLING COYNE, a gentleman who has much to answer for in the dramatic way. The play depends entirely on the acting. What plot there is in it, is threadbare.

The British brig Belle, Capt. MEAGHER, arrived at this port yesterday morning, and was towed to the city in the afternoon by the tag boat Rescue. The following are all the names we could obtain of the crew and passengers of the Staffordshire, numbering 41, who came in the Belle: Passengers--Patrick O'Brien, John Terney, John Barnett, Michael Falley, Donald Delancey, Mary Jane Managan.

The Editors of Ohio held a Convention, shortly since, at Cincinnati. They did not seem to have any special object in convening, except to reproduce a certain good time that had occurred to them some weeks before, on a railroad excursion. But they eat to repletion, and drank past the line where wit and wisdom merge together, and made sundry good speeches.

Mensing, Havana and a market, Hennings, Muller Gusling; Vandalia, Richardson, New Orleans, Ralph Post

Mr. MECHI, the celebrated Agriculturist, in his Balance Sheet, read before the Society of A?s, makes some very important statements. He attributes the improvement of his lands to irrigation. The difference between the present and former Balance Sheets, lies in the live stock accounts.

In the Assembly, there, was hard work to obtain a quorum at the hour for meeting, 3 o'clock; but 65 members having at last answered to their names, the business of the session was proceeded with. Mr. D. P. WOOD, of Onondaga, introduded a series of resolutions in relation to the territory of Nebraska, and instructing our Representatives and Senators to oppose the further extension of slave territory.

M. BODISCO, THE RUSSIAN MINISTER.--This gentleman, whose death has been expected for same time past, expired shortly after 12 o'clock on Sunday night, at his official residence at Washington. He was about 70 or 75 years of age, and had been 15 years in this country. He was born in Wallachia, of a poor but aristocratic family, and about fifty years ago entered the public service of Russia.

Messrs. HOLLINSHEAD, TETLEY Co., report that notwithstanding the interruption to business by the snow storm, the demand during the week way steady for all classes of American, the market continuing bare of middling equalities owing to contrary winds. The quotations were firm and unchanged. Inferior qualities met with rather less attention. Total sales of the week, 29,890 bales, including 21,000 American.

Want is mingling its sinister menaces in Europe, with the concert of clamors which are protesting in every direction against the oppressions and injustice of the Governments. In France the press is by no means ignorant of the terrible condition to which the country is reduced, but it dares not, it cannot make the proper disclosures.

The mob has triumphed again. I informed you in my letter of this morning that about three hundred of the Erie rioters proceeded to Girard, with music and banners, to control a meeting called there, for the purpose of opposing county subscriptions to the Sunbury and Erie or other Railroads.

Messrs. SHERWIN, JACKS, KIRKPATRICK, and KILPATRICK, who were imprisoned on the 9th inst., for contempt, have to. day been discharged by Judge IRWIN on their own recognizances for $5.000 each, to make their appearance on the second Monday of May, to answer for the offence, and meanwhile to observe the injunction. The Erians address a mass meeting here this evening. PITTSBURG, Saturday, Jan. 21.

FIRE.--On Saturday morning a barn belonging to Mr. George Troutman, in Bushwick, on the Cypress Hills Ptank. Road, was destroyed by fire--supposed to have been the work of an incendiary. Loss $400. POLICY OFFICES.--On Saturday morning a posse of the Second Ward Police made a descent on two policy offices in North Second street.

THE NEW-YORK CITY TRACT SOCIETY--The Board of Managers of the New-York City Tract Society held their regular monthly meeting in the Bible House last evening, A. R. WETMORE Esq., presided. The meeting having been opened with the usual religious exercises, the missionaries for the different societies made their monthly reports, all which were of a very gratifying nature, as showing the success attending the efforts of the Society.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: The article in the TIMES of the 20th instant, signed B., is framed in the reckless way that characteiizes this whole movement in favor of sacrilege. There has been no communications "signed by Mr. ROBERT HYSLOP and others," and the communication on in the Courier, to which the article in question refers, was not signed by Mr. HYSLOP,

The steamer Northern Light arrived yesterday, with fifteen days' later news from California, which will be found in another part of this morning's TIMES. The arrival of two steamers from San Diego had conveyed to the Californians tidings of the safety of the Fillibusters at Ensenada and rekin?? the ardor of the whole people for such employment.

THE BRUSSELS CONFERENCE.--Wehavebeen have been favored with a copy of a letter received in this City from a distinguished foreign Naval officer, a memher of the late Brussels Conference, giving high credit to Lieut. MAURY and the United States for the design of a grand International Union, for purposes of Scientific research. The following is an extract:

MUSICAL.--We direct attention to the programme of a Concert announced for this evening, and to ba held at the Tabernacle. It is more that ordinarily interesting, and will, we imagine, attract a large audience. It is for the benefit of the free Church of the Holy Martyrs-Rev. JAMES MILLETT, rector. Considering the importance of the object, we are confident the Concert will be well atteuded. The programmed will be found in our advertising columas.

The steamship Northern Light, H. CHURCHILL, Commander, from San Juau del Norte, arrived yesterday morning at 9 o'clock, with 313 passengers, and $850,000 on freight to C. MORGAN. To Messrs. BERFORD Co., WELLS, FARGO CO., ADAMS Co., and ?? LORD, we are indebted for early papers and memoranda.

JUDAH TOURO'S will is dated the 6th inst. It appoints four Executors, giving $10,000 to three of them, and making the fourth, R. D. SHEPPERD. residuary legatee. Nearly $450,000 is bequeathed to different public institutions and for charitable purposes, including the following: $80,000 for the establishment of an Almshouse in New-Orleans; $5,000 to the Hebrew Congregation in Boston;

It is not to be presumed that the vital statistics furnished by any of the States, under their laws requiring the Registration of Births, Deaths and Marriages, are entirely accurate; but, allowing for all that, they begin already to present views of the growth and condition of society which could not otherwise be oblained.

HARPER'S MAGAZINE FOR JANUARY.-The January number of this magazine was issued yesterday. It looks much the same as usual. with the exception of the illustrations, which are omitted altogether. The literary contents are as varied and interesting as ever. The enterprise of the HARPERS was never more conspicuous than in the progress which they have made since the recent calamitous fire.

Several petitions were presented for a prohibitory Liquor Law. The bill authorizing Savings Banks to deposit their surplus funds in Trust Companies, was reported favorably upon, as also the bill to facilitate trials for larceny, burglary, Mr. CROSBY made a minority report on the proposed prohibitory Liquor law. Notice was given of a bill to designate a State paper. The annual report of the Trustees of the Northern Dispensary, New-York, was presented.

But there is another view of it which must not be passed by, and which presents a question, the solution of which calls for the earnest attention of the Representatives of the South, and in which they must be prepared to act in connection with the ratification of the Treaty. It provides for a cession to the United States of a tract of country equal in extent to the State of Georgia.

The semi annual Ineeting of the American Temperanee Union was held on Monday evening at the Broadway Tabernacle, WILLIAM E. DODGE, Eeq , Chairman of the Executive Committee, presiding. The North Carolina Bind, conducted by Mr. M. P. TORGSI, was present, and executed various airs with exquiile taste.

REBUILDING OF THE LA FARGE HOUSE.--The Committee appointed to receive subscriptions for $150,000 stock, and make arrangements for establishing Messrs. WRIGHT, LANIERS CO in a new hotel, held a final public meeting at Metropolitan Hotel last evening. Capt. THOS. T. FERRIS occupied the Chair, and Mr. W. H. DRAPER acted as Secretary.

We received yesterday, from a private source, generally well informed concerning the movements of foreign Courts, an interesting item of intelligence illustrating the preparations on foot for the Eastern war. It is stated that the English Cabinet recently proposed to the French Government that if she would dispatch two corps of troops against Russia-the one to land in Finland,

The Mail train from Augusta, near Lowry's Turn Out, ran off the track this morning. Three cars were smashed, and Rev. Mr. BAIRD, Editor of the Southern Presbyterian, and a brakeman, were badly injured. The cars arrived here at 61/2 o'clock this evening.

Dr. JUNKIN had ascended the pulpit and opened the service, and few of the congregation, therefore, knew of the murder till the close of the sermon. As many of the cadets had entered the church, one after another heard it and left, causing a great deal of confusion. The congregation know what something had happened, but most persons kept their seats.

Last evening Miss STONE delivered a lecture at the Broadway Tabernacle on the subject of Slavery, in the presence of a very large audience. She was attired in her Bloomer costume, and on presenting* herself was greeted with loud applause. Miss STONE commenced by observing that during her lifetime she had witnessed much suffering and sorrow, but it never approximated to the intense afiliction and unmitigated pain which fell to the lot of the slave.

Warren Wood, the murderer of the peddler, Williams, was executed yesterday, according to sentenced. The circumstances attending his execution were briefly these: Before the hour of 10, persons began to assemble in front of the jail, and invited spectator began to appear.

Among the many extra-constitutional measures of Federal Legislation was the Missouri Compromise. It may be admitted that it was un constitutional. The question turned not so much on that point as on the high question of political expediency.

In the Court of Appeals, to-morrow morning, the call will commence with No. 79--the reserved causes the same as yesterday. No. 93 is to be argued, and ten call will reach 91. In Senate, Mr. CLARKSON F. CROSBY, of the Select Committee, to whom was referred so much of the Governor's Message as related to the sale of intoxicatm drinks, made a minority report.

A public meeting of the Union of Literary and Debating Societies of the City of New-York, recently formed, is to be hold this evening at Hope Chapel. This meeting is designed as the initial step towards an extended organization of similar societies throughout the country, for the purpose of increasing

Numerous private petitions were presented. The Bill granting a pension to the widow of General JACOB BROWN was taken up and passed. THE NEBRASKA BILL. Mr. DOUGLAS moved that the Senate proceed to the consideration of the Nebraska bill. Mr. NORRIS hoped that the bill would not be taken up until the Senators had had an opportunity of reading it.

The news by the Niagara, received by telegraph from Halifax, and published in yesterday's ToiEs, confirms our predictions concerning the policy of NAPOLSON III. We have repeatedly expressed the belief-based upon his character and position, that under all his professions of peace lurked a wish for war ;-

In the Executive Session-of the Senate today, the International Copyright Treaty was repolted from Committee on Foreign Relations, without any recommendations, but with an amendment providing that the protection afforded to foreign authors, shall apply only to their books reprinted in this country.

The good citizens of Erie have added robbery to their schedule of committed crimes. They were Destruetiolnists-they are now Thieves. Since the demonstration at Meadville, by which they forced an appearance of favor toward the riotcrs of Erie, they have had but little calculated to keep alive the excitement necessary to render

For the last twenty-four hours this village has been in such a state of excitement as I have never before witnessed. About 6 1/2 o'clock yesterday (Sunday) evening, young Mr. BLACKBURN, a cadet of the V. M. Institute, was killed by Mr. CHRISTIAN, a law student.

The Dissection Bill is taking its usual course and meeting Its usual fate. Three Winters ago it passed the House almost unanimously at both the regular and extra sessions, and stuck in the Senate for several reasons; the main one, in our judgment, being simply because one of the parties whom the bill makes responsible for the decent use of the bodies granted for dissection,

MEETING OF THE TEN GOVERNORS.-The Board of Ten Governors held their regular weekly meeting in the Rotunda, last evening-SIMEON DRAPER, President, in the Chair. The sessionn was a short one, and but little business was transacted. The following resolution, offeredd by Gov. SMITH, was adopted:

This has been the coldest day of the season in this locality. At sunrise the thermometer was at zero-- at noon 4[degrees] above--and at sunset down to zero again. In towns a few miles from Boston, the thermometer was at 10[degrees] and 12[degrees] below zero this morning.

NEW DAILY PAPER.--The Jersey City Union, heretofore published tri-weekly by A. R SPEER, has been purchased by S P. HULL, of the Merristown Jerseyman, and transformed into the Jersey City Daily Union, edited by S. P. HULL and WM. T. RODGERS, Jr The first number of the Daily made a creditable appearance on Tuesday.

Several petitions were presented this morning, mostly in favor of a more stringent liquor law. A memorial was presented, asking for the incorporation of the American Geographical Society of New-York. The Secretary of State reports that no lands, under water, near New York City, have been granted to any individual or incorporation.

It is a subject of surprise that the mere costume of Madam SOULE should have caused so much bad blood at the Spanish Court. The lady is admitted to be exemplary and distinguished for amiability and refinement.

The Independent publishes the following interesting letter from THOMAS CARLYLE, received from a correspondent in Iowa. It was written to a young lawyer friend in 1847, while a resident of Tennessee, and in reply to inquiries in respect to a course of study: "CHELSEA, London, May 17, 1817.

EPIDEMIC IS NEW-ORLEANS.-- The President, Secretary and Treasurer of the II ward Association of New-Orleans, and the Finance Committee, have issued a judge report of their stewardships during the late terrible epidemic in that city.

The first Annual Message of Governor HEBERT to the Legislature of the State has been delivered at Baton Rouge. He first of the epidemic. He says that the sanitary condition of New Orleans is not a local but a State interest. This will be more conspicuously with the increase of the railroad communications now in progress between the city and the country.

BURTON'S THEATRE.--A wretched travestie of Mr. CURTIS' "Potiphar Papers," is being performed here under the name of "Our Best Society." It is utterly beneath criticism. The dramatist has performed his office cruelly, and the actors contribute their separate and collective mites towards a melancholy result.

An International Copyright Convention has been effected between England and the free Hansestac town of Hamburg. By this treaty all works of literature and art published in either country are placed under the protection of the existing laws in each, on equal terms. Translations also share in this protection to a limited extent.

We have heard from a reliable source an anecdote connected with the recent negotiations of Mr. GADSDEN in Mexico, which eminently illustrates the ambition for new territory which our people seldom fail, when opportunity offers, to indulge.

Mr. MITCHEL, in the Citizen, thus briefly expresses his opinion on the subject of "Fillibusterism" in general: We entirely disapprove of the Sonora expeditions, which are simple piracy. we entirely approve of the expeditions to Cuba, under LOPEZ. Why we make the distinction, we shall tell you next week, when we mean to examine the whole question of fillibusterism and the "expansivity of the Republic."

In theory, happy is the man who, though his business is in town, has his family and his home in some of the green and beautiful villages that surround the dusty, dirty, confused and wicked City. He lets himself down as in submarine armor, into the whirlpool for a few hours of the day, then goes up to sun himself and enjoy his findings for the remainder.

EXPOSING DISEASED MEATS FOR SALE.--Yesterday WM WILSON was arraigned before Justice DANIEL K. SMITH on a charge of exposing diseased meat for sale. The first witness called was JOHN M. LOER, who testified:

Dr. SOLGER'S fourth lecture was delivered on Tuesday evening, at Hope Chapel, to a larger audience than usual. It topics embraced--The policy of the great European powers, France, Austria and Prussia, in Germany and Italy, and the influence of England and Russia upon the political condition of the European People.

An Extensive Lottery Swindling Establishment Broken Up--Important Arrest and Seizure of the Implements-Letters Containing Money Stopped at the Post-Office. Before Justice WELSH. Through the indefatigable exertions of Justice WELSH and officer DE BEND.R, one of the attaches of the Essex Police Court, a very extensive lottery establishment in this City has been broken up, and the violators of the law taken prisoners.

From the Boston Commonwealth. In the Commonwealth of Dec 20, we gave an account of two persons, GEORGE Cox, of Middleboro', aged 46 years, and a little girl of 7 years, SUSAN R. THOMPSON, of Halifax, having been bitten by a dog supposed to be rabid. Both of the persons, as we stated, were taken to the Masschusetts General Hospital.

APPLETON'S EDITION OF THE BRITISH POETS. Edited by GEORGE GILFILLAN. Vols. 1 to 4. New York : D. APPLETON Co. There are none of the larger publications that we can hail with such sincere pleasure as this magnificent issue of the British Poets.

The British Mail steamship Niagara, from Liverpool via Halifax, arrived at her wharf at East Boston at about 10 o'clock this forenoon. She was quite covered with ice, and bore evidence of an unusually rough passage. On the arrival of the steamer off Long Wharf, the Custom House officers were on the alert, and no person was permitted to go on board of her.

The Freeman's Journal speaks of a "flagitious suggestion make in the columns of the Journal of Commerce, and also of the DAILY TIMES, as to the origin of the fire at Metropolitan Hall." We presume that the allusion is to the rumor that the Hall was set on fire in revenge for its having been used by GAVAZZI for the delivery of his lectures.

I have just read, in the TIMES of the 17th inst., your article on the "Year of Shipwrecks," with the list of losses. That you may complete the subject, and present to your readers a general view of the number and nature of the losses which occur in navigation, I will furnish you the statistics of shipwrecks and their causes, for the year ending 30th of June, 1851.

On Tuesday morning, Jan. 24, of consumption, LAVINIA P., wife of Henry A. Ransford, aged 18 years and 7 months. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, this (Thursday) afternoon, at 1 1/2 o'clock, from her late residence.

LOWRY and Mayor KING have escaped incarceration in Alleghany County Jail, for the present. You are doubtless aware that they were tried only on a charge of contempt, by resisting the Deputy Marshal while arresting and conveying Gen KILPATRICK, and three others, to prison.

The steamship Isabel has arrived here with dates from Havana and Key west to the 22d inst. From Havana we have no political news of importance and the markets were unchanged. The ship Hudson, reported ashore on Orange Keys, was not found by the searching vessels.

The excitement consequent upon the removal of bodies from the Methodist Burial Ground, at the corner of Second-avenue and First-street, has in nowise abated, but seems rather to be on the increase. Another meeting of those persons who feel indignant at the action of the Trustees, in their attempt to remove the bodies of their Fiends, was held in Hermitage Hall, last evening.

GAS MEETING.--On Tuesday evening a meeting of gas consumers was held at the Odeon, when the Committee appointed at the last meeting reported that they had tested the quality of the gas at present supplied to the public, and found it to be of a specific gravity of 401, while their agreement says it shall be 800.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The observations made by me touching the construction of the San Francisco, in your paper of the 17th inst, were based upon a statement made by you on the 14th, from which it appeared that the ill-fated steamer was 41 feet beam, and three thousand tons burden.

Southerners often represent the condition of their slaves to be so happy and desirable that we might wonder that they do not sometimes take measures to he made slaves themselves, or at least occasionally offer their children for sale to the highest bidder.

To Rev Henry Ward Beecher: REVEREND SIR: YOU will be surprised to see a letter addressed to you by one whom you supposed to be dead. In your Anti-Slavery Lecture, as reported in the Tribune, I find that you announced my decease to a large congregation; and, with Christian meekness, repressed the loud hisses of your hearers in consideration of the respect due to the deceased.

The snow storm in England, of the 3d, 4th and 5th of January, was almost beyond precedent. Writing of London, the Morning Chronicle says: "It is currently stated that any longer continuance of the present inclement weather will entail the alarming probability of a failure in the supply of gas for the metropolis.

MAN BURNED TO DEATH.--The Manchester Mirror states that a house in Centre Harbor, N.H, was burned on Friday night last, and that the owner. Jeus THOMPSON, a well known lawyer, perished in the flames. Mr. THOMPSON possessed a large and very valuable library, which he tried it first to save, but could not.

THE CASE OF JAMES L. HOARE--Yesterday morning Sheriff ORSER returned from Albany, having received the definite answer of the Governor in the case of this unfortunate man, who is conde__ed to be executed on Friday for murder.

The Eastern War has come home to all our stove-evens and our tables. The nondescript who "boards around," and eats by a bill of fare, with the price annexed, may get as yet just as thick a slice of bread for a sixpence, but the gregarious men whom "He hath set in families," see in their diminished loaves how war gnaws off the crust and consumes the substance of our supplies.

Dr. SAMUEL D. HEAP, United States Consul. died at Tunis, Barbary, Oct 2, 1859. He was born in 1781, in Carlisle, Pa. In 1804 he was appointed Surgeon to the United States Navy, and joined the fleet under Commodore PREBLE, then engaged in hostilities against Tripoli.

The United States Circuit Court was in session this morning, Judge IRWIN on the Bench. Colonel McCANDLESS presented the following petition from the prisoners: "The petition of IRA W. SHERWIN, JOHN JACKS, ARCHIBALD KIRKPATRICK, and JOHN KILPATRICK, "Respectfully represents, That they are now in the jail of Alleghany County on a conviction for a contempt of this Court.

Terrible Snow-Storm--Railroads Blockaded--London Streets Impassable--Policemen Frozen to Death--Numerous Shipwrecks. The Niagara's mails reached us at a late hour this morning. We have only time to make the following selections.

In the Maryland Legislature, resolutions returning thanks to Capt. WATKINS, Major WYSE, Lieuts WINDER and WISE, have been adopted, and the Senators and Representatives in Congress requested to use their influence to procure the passage of a law grating assistance to the widows and families of the officers and soldiers who perished.

Real estate in this City is experiencing a decided advance in value. After a few months of quiet, in which few transactions have taken place, the fever of speculation seems to have revived. Property is held at high rates.

This evening a meeting was held at the Court House, on the occasion of the release from prison of Messrs. KILPATRICK, KIRKPATRICK, SHERWIN, and JACKS, to express the sympathy of the audience with the citizens of Erie. Mayor VOLZ was unanimously called to the Chair.

We have received the Sixteenth Annual Report of the Boston Fire Department, and glean from it many interesting items of information. During the year ending Sept. 1, there were 205 alarms--36 more than the preceding year--and 172 fires. The amount of loss by fire was $515,167, on which there was $295,056 insurance.

The Colonization Journal furnishes some statistics with regard to the colored population of New-York City, which must prove painfully interesting to all reflecting people. The late census showed that while all other classes of our population in all parts of the country were increasing at an enormous ratio, the colored were decreasing. In the State of New-York in 1840 there were 50,000; in 1850 but 47,000.

The fourth lecture before the Williamsburg New England Society was delivered on Wednesday evening, by Rev. T. W HIGGINSON, of Worcester, Mass., on " The Old Puritan Clergyman." The lecturer began by remarking that it is easier for our imaginations to traverse distances of space, than of time.

The Assembly were in session last evening--the first night-work of the session. Mr. BARROW, from the Committee of the New-York delegation, made a minority report against the repeal of the bill establishing the Jones Park. He accompanied his report with a resolution that both that and the report presented by Mr. CONKLING, and all papers relating to the subject, be referred back to the Special Committee of the New-York delegation.
