THE MICHIGAN UNIVERSITY.--The Michigan papers, in lack of any prodigious fire to talk about since the burning of the Detroit church and the Albion Seminary, are exercising themselves in discussing the merits of Chancellor TAPPAN and the State University.

No news has been received in confirmation of the report so generally circulated yesterday, of the death of Mr. SOULE, Sen. It may, therefore, be taken for granted that there was no ground for the rumor, although it was so confidently believed yesterday that I thought it necessary to mention it.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: While communicating your own views on public questions to your readers, good policy will suggest that you permit, to a limited extent, your readers to communicate with each other through your columns.

Yesterday afternoon a meeting of this Board was held at the County Jail. Supervisor BERGEN presented a communication from JAMES M. SEABURY, County Treasurer, accompanied by draft of a proposed act relative to Treasurer's fees. with the request that the Clerk be directed to forward the same to the Legislature under the sanction of the Board. The act reads as follows:

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have read a statement in a letter from New-York, published in our City papers, from which it seems that there are large numbers of women in New-York who are greatly in need of employment.

The New-York Democratic 'Delegation held a meeting last night, and decided to oppose the Nebraska Bill. The Softs, to a man, voted to oppose it, and several Hards also. The Ohio Delegation also held a meeting this afternoon, and, it is rumored, their decision Was unanimous against the Nebraska Bill.

MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE.--Much excitement is prodneed in the town of Fallsburg, N. Y., by the following circumstances: ANDREW CLEMENTS, a tanner at the Sheldrake Pond, left home on Monday, the 2d of January, for New-York, by the way of Newburg, intending to return in two or three days His family antiously awaited his return up to Thursday last, when his wife and brother started in search of him.

In pursuance of a Call issued some weeks since, the friends of RELIGIOUS LIBERTY assembled at the Broadway Tabernacle last evening, under the auspices of the American and Foreign Christian Union, for the purpose of expressing their sense of the propriety of protecting American citizens in foreign lands, in the full enjoyment of their rights of conscience and of worship.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I remember seeing in the Paris Constitutionnel, soon after the coup d'etat of December, an article signed by GRANIER DE CASSAGNAC, in which WASHINGTON was styled a selfish, unpatriotic, cowardly dwarf. Similar epithets have been applied by similar men to the noblest men of all ages. The parties which thus seek notoriety by verfying the good, frequently resort for the same purpose, to eulogy of the vile.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : I noticed some days since an editorial in your paper, in which you expressed doubts as to the proper strength of the engines of the San Francisco. The opinion expressed by you was based on the report of one her passengers, which appeared with your editorial.

FATAL ACCIDENT.--CORONER'S INQUEST.--About 7 o'clock on Tuesday evening. Mr. Walter B Townsend, of the firm of Townsend Co., druggists, No. 236 Pearl-street, N. Y , in attempting to step from the Peck-slip ferry boat before she was properly secured, slipped between the bridge and the boat, striking his breast on the float, and fell into the water.

On Tuesday, Jan 24, 1854, at Calvary Church, by Rev. Wm. Berrian, D. D., Rector of Trinity Parish, THOMAS POTTER WRIGHT, to Miss LOUISA ROWLAND HIGGINS, all of this City. Savannah and Macon, Ga., papers please copr. Jan. 24, in this City, by Rev. D. L. Marks, Mr. WILLIAM T. PATTERSON, of this City, to Miss EMILY CLEMENT, of Rockland Lake.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--A good audience attended here last evening to extend a welcome "hand" to Captain CREIGHTON, on the occasion of his visit, One of the private boxes of the Theatre was tastefully decoraied with the stars and stripes; after a while, Captain CREIGHTON made his appearance, accompanied by a deputation of more than the box could hold.

In this City, Jan. 25, Mr. JOHN FORBES, aged 66 years. Mr. F. was one among the oldest Printers of this City, having served an apprenticeship with the publishers of the Commercial Advertiser. Webster (Noah) Hopkins. Prior to the War of 1812, Mr. F. was a devoted and enthusiastic member of the old Federal school, but during the war he volunteered his services to repel the enemy.

The contemplated coup ?ctat at Madrid, to which I have already alluded by telegraph, must be regarded as a movement of great interest and likely to produce results of much importance. Of the truth of the story there is little doubt. Indeed, if I mistake not, our Government is fully informed relative to the whole affair.

Mr. REDFIELD was confirmed to-day, after two and a half hours debate, by 35 to 8. The negatives were Messrs. Badger, Benjamin, Bell, Dixon, ,Dawson, Toombs, Jones, and Thompson of Ky. Messers. SEWARD and FISH spoke in favor of the nomination. All the Senators with Free-Soil tendencies voted Aye.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The trials of ordinary Policemen are soon disposed of and decisions speedily rendered; why should it take months to render decisions in the cases of Police Captains tried for gross violation of duty?

STEAM FIRE ENGINES.--The Philadelphia North American of Monday morning says: "We learn from good authority that a joint committee of the City Councils have accepted a proposal made by Mr. Harrison, an eminent and wealthy engineer and machinist of this city, to construct, upon a plan of his own, as ea?rn fire-engine which shall answer the purpose designed at least as well, if not better, than the engine now in use in Cincinnati.

A small but social company of the countrymen and admirers of Scotland's favorite bard assembled to honor his memory, on Wednesday evening, in the Caledonian Hotel, Staten Island. The supper room was tastefully decorated with evergreens; and, out from wreaths of mountam pine, the jovial countenance of " Rab," and cheerful smile of his Highland MARY beamed upon the feast.

A few years since the boys in the streets, who always very accurately represent the sentiments of their elders, were everywhere singing a song, of which the burden was a request, with the reasons annexed, that one Mr. Daniel Tucker should get out of the way. Tucker seems to have been a man who, though aged, was not venerable.

Fall of the Roof of an Iron Building. LOSS OF LIFE-SEVERAL PERSONS INJURED. A terrible accident occurred near the village of Fordham, Westchester County, between 8 and 9 o'clock yesterday morning, resulting in the loss of one life, and serious, if not fatal, injuries to seven or eight persons.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the various accounts of the loss of the San Francisco--and I have read them all--I see no mention made of any effort to keep the ship's head to the sea ; on the contrary, after the foremast went, it seems an attempt was made to cut the mizzen-mast away.

The meeting at the Tabernacle last night, to secure some greater degree of religious freedom to American citizens residing abroad than they now enjoy, was large, respectable, and highly interesting. Its proceeding, including speeches, resolutions, and letters from distinguished gentlemen who had been invited, will be found at length in another part of this morning's TIMES.

Visit to the Cell of the Condemned last Night--Extraordinary Nerve and Cheerfainess of the Culprit--Interview with his two Sons. The unfortunate criminal, JAMES L. HOARE, who stands convicted and under sentence of death, for the murder of SUSAN MCANNY, several months ago, will suffer the extreme penalty of the law this foreneon, between the hours of 9 and 10 o'clock.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: On several recent occasions, the Herald has attributed to me some knowledge of a letter allege? by that paper to have been written by Gen PIERCE to : Committee in this City, in 1848, sympathizing with the principles and candidates presented by the Buffalo Convention.

We started out a wintry afternoon, lately, to see some of our scholars in the Industrial School" of the Fourth Ward. A number of little ragged girls, disdaining to enter, were clustered about the door of the School. As they caught a glimpse of some one coming out, the cry of " Lie low'! lie low!" passed among them, and they were off, capering about in the snow-storm like so many little witches.

Several memorials were presented by the New York Senators for speedy action in reference to the encroachments on the harbor of New-York. A memorial was presented asking the appointment of DANIEL DODGE as one of the Commissioners for fixing the boundary line of the City of New-York. A select Committee, to whom was referred the subject, reported against making the office of Canal Auditor elective, but in favor of increasing the salary to $2,500.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,) No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co. (do.).. Broadway, cor. Roado-st. Agricultural Warehouse. R. L. ALLEN, (late A. B. Allen Co.)189 191 Water.
By a royal decree of November 9, the rates of postage to be paid upon newspapers and other periodicals coming to, or going from this Island, are as follows:

SMALL-POX.--The South Carolina papers out of Charleston, assert that small pox is common in that city, and are making considerable fuss about it; whereat, the Standard assures them that it is perfectly true, and moreover, that by searching for it, it can generally be found in Charleston.

All the legislative forms on the proposed amendments to the Constitution of the State of New-York to provide for the speedy enlargement of the Erie Canal, have been completed. The bill for a special vote of the people on the amendments has been signed by the Governor, and the third Wednesday, being the FIFTEENTH DAY OF FEBRUARY, fixed for the election.

BABY SHOW.--The baby show is not a jest, as many of our readers may suppose. The Augusta papers say that three premiums will be really offered at the next State Fair for the three finest babies which shall be presented. In order that such of our infantile patrons as are disposed to enter the lists may know the terms of competition and award, we annex the premium list as follows:

Mr. SEBASTIAN presented the credentials of Mr. A. G. BROWN, a Senator from Mississippi, for six years from the 4th of March last, and he was sworn in. All the Senators are now present, excepting Mr. RUSK. The CHAIR laid before the Senate a communication from the Secretary of the Interior asking for an appropriation of fifty thousand dollars, to pay debts incurred by the Mexican Boundary Commission.

The telegraph between here and Erie is down. but we learn from a party just arrived from Erie, that a meeting was held the night before at Fairview, 15 miles west of Erie, at which reverel Erie rowdies attanded, and endeavored to excite the citizens to a breach of law. The United States Marshal is now superintending the repairs at Erie and its vicinity.

The Washington Union declares that "the introduction of Judge DOUGLAS's territorial bill-has aroused the spirit of agitation where ever fanaticism exists." It might have added that it will extend that agitation into quarters which it has not penetrated hitherto, and create a fanaticism on the subject, from which the friends of the country had fondly hoped it might he forever exempt.

A Memorial was presented from the Institution of the Deaf and Dumb in New-York City, asking for an increased appropriation. A Memorial was sent up from the Grand Temperance Division of Western New York, asking for the passage of a Liquor Law, and remonstrating against the submission of the question to the people.

Our best publishers are emulous of the fame of ALDUS and BASKERVILLE. Witness the Boston edition of the British poets, published by LITTELL BROWN, rivals of the London Aldine edition of PICKERING, but actually surpassing, in typographical beauty, that famous but unfinished series. Witness some of PUTNAM'S recent publications,--his ADDISON, for instance.

Provisions.--There is an improved demand for new Bacon, and imports are taken ex ship at full rates; old Bacon neglected. Beef is more wanted, but without improvement in value. Pork very dull. Cheese continues source. Lard is dearer and in demand. Tallow has advanced 1s.@2s. In Seeds or Birk there has been no business. BREASTUFFS--Have daily advanced in value, under an active speculative and consumptive demand, and moderate stocks.
AN INDIA ON LYIGG.--The Cattaraugus Whig states a suit was recently brought before a magistrate in the village of Randolph, and during its progress an Indian was brought forward to testify.

James L. Hoare hung for the Murder of his Mistress, Susan McAnanny--Remarkable Firmness of the Culprit-His Refusal to Speak under the Gallows--Letters front the Convict to the Sheriff; Warden and his Counsel,

THE BROADWAY CONFLAGRATION--SITE FOR THE NEW HOTEL--The Committee appointed to select a site for Messrs WRIGHT, LANIERS Co.'s new Hotel, and to confer with Mr. LAFARGE with regard to his claims upon that firm, met again last evening, pursuant to adjournment, at the hall of the City Guard, who have manifested a very commendable interest in and liberality toward the en erprise from its commencement.

The letter of Pope Plus IX., accrediting Archbishop BEDINI to this country, was sent, with other documents, into the Senate yesterday. His mission, it seems, was mainly to proffer to the President assurances of the Pope's distinguished consideration. The Pontiff, it will be noted, solicits the President to extend the shield of his protection over the Catholics.

CONSOLIDATION.--The Commissioners held a meeting at the City Hall yesterday, and discussed the report relative to the Police Department, and finally laid it upon the table, and adjourned to Feb. 6. DOINGS AT THE NAVY-YARD.--There are only between five and six hundred men employed at the Navy-Yard at the present time, and business continues doll.

The Atlantic brings news of the entrance of the allied fleet into the Black Sea, and the text of the French circular Rote, which will be found at length in another column. The first of these facts, though long expected, has created a profound sensation throughout Europe.

Hon. Judge EDMONDS delivered a lecture, on Thurs lay evening, before the members of the Mechanics' Institute, corner of Bowery and Division st. His subject was "Constitutions and Institutions-their Influence upon the Destiny of Man." He commenced by remarking that our Constitutions were written, but our Institutions, many of them, were unwritten; but they entered into and influenced our daily wants.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate a message the President, with the correspondence relating to M. BEDINIS mission. Mr. CASS took Occasion to repel certain insinuations by the New-York Express touching his remarks on this subject.

On Friday morning, Jan. 27, GEORGE W. TAGGART, of the firm of Taggart Gray. His friends, and the friends of the family, are invited to attend the funeral, at the Church of the Restoration, corner of Monroe place and Clark st., Brooklyn, on Sunday afternoon, at 2 o'clock. On Friday, Jan. 27, 1854, FANNY, only daughter of Hiram S. and Catharine Disbrow, aged 16 months.

A dispatch from New-Orleans announces the arrival there, on the 25th inst. of the steamship United States, from Aspinwall with the California mails, passengers and specie of the 1st last, The mail steamer Ohio, for New-York, was at Aspinwall when the United States left. The Congress of New Grenada. had levied a tax of 10 per cent. on the estimated profits of all vessels arriving at and departing from Aspinwall.

The Queen gave birth to a daughter, at Madrid, Jan. 5. As mentioned in our French intelligence, the Marquis of TURGOT, the French Ambassador, who fought with Mr. SOULE. Sen., has been raised to the dignity of Grand Officer of the Legion of Honor.

MEETING OF WELSH CITIZENS AT THE ME CHANICS' INSTITUTE.--In Obedience to the call, "Oes y byd ir ia ith gymraeg," a meeting of Welshmen was held at the mechanics' Institute on the 25th inst, to take measures for celebrating St. David's Day on the 1st of March next. MORGAN MORGANS, Esq., presided. It is intended to combine the celebration of the Cambrian Eisteddfod with the establishment of a Wallaychfa.

It is beginning to be felt among us, that even the American power of labor has its limits. The truth is gradually being realized, that the human constitution is not made of steel and oak-fibre. There is a salutary, though tardy impression gaining ground, that sixteen hours' labor out of the twenty-four, and a hot brain through the night, are not quite the conditions of health, even in our unequaled country.

The papers at hand by the arrival contain nothing relative to home politics. They say no more of Prince ALBERT'S alleged interference with the machinery of Government. On the subject of Eastern affairs we have nothing different from what has appeared for many weeks past--mere speculations and discussions on the probable course that matters will take, but with no new facts in the case.

We have received from a Special Correspondent at Paris a very interesting letter on the political movements of the day. We can at present, however, only make room for the following interesting extract, which confirms our previous intelligence on the same subject: PARTS, Thursday, Jan. 5, 1851. Austria has thrown off her mask, and all Europe, by this time, perfectly comprehends what is to be expected from her.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your remarks this morning, under the head of "Special Canal Election," you omitted one very prominent fact, which had a most important bearing on the receipts and Canal revenues the past year, viz.: the numerous breaks on the Ca??al, and the time lost in transit during the repairs of the same.

The Monitour announces that the Prince DE CHIMAy had an audience of the Emperor on Sunday, 8 h inst, for the purpose of delivering a message from King LEOPOLD, of Belgium. It is surmised that this note covers some new expedient to seive the cause of the Czar, under pretext of advacing the cause of peace. As regards preparing for war, the French Government is acting with energy.

The statement that the New-York Democrats have held a meeting and agreed to oppose the Nebraska bill is erroneous. But it is quite clear to-day that the delegation will be against it. Senators HOUSTON, RUSK, and BELL will oppose it. The nomination of EDWARD BUCHANAN, of Maryland, as Consul to La Rochelle, in France, has been conformed.

EAST RIVER OBSTRUCTED WITH ICE.--ACCIDENTS.--The East River, during Saturday night and yesterday morning, was much obstructed by floating ice, making navigation somewhat dangerous. The bark Grape Shot, of New Haven, while lying at anchor off the foot of Main street, on Saturday night, had two holes made in her bows under water line, by the action of the ice, and commenced filling rapidly.

We intimated last week that whenever the control of the gauge of the Western Road at Erie was assumed by the Legislature, in ac cordance with the behests of the mob, the Eastern Company might be suffered to repair the break and restore the bridges on theirline .

The frequent recurrence of destructive fires in our City is exciting profound anxiety in the public mind. The TIMES of this morning records no less than seven which have occurred since our last issue. Not a week has elapsed for months, during which we have been free from this dreadful scourge.

The excitement on the Nebraska question is increasing and spreading. Mr. BADGER openly declares that he cannot vote for it, because the faith of the South is plighted to the Missouri Compromise. An effort will be made to-morrow to postpone the Nebraska Bill still further.

By two of the seven fires which have raged in the City since the last issue of our paper, at least one hundred families have been rendered homeless. Homeless ! what cold chills run through the body on reading the word. Wind howling through leafless trees on the Battery and around the corners of houses; but no thick wall on the windward side of it.

The Common Council held a special meeting on Thursday evening, to confer with he Commissioners of Bushwick, upon the proposed plan of converting the Bushwick Creek either into a sewer or canal. This will affect the grades of numerous streets in both Williams burg and Bushwick, which are drained by it, as also the surrounding meadows. A canal will require a filling in of about four feet, while a sewer will take eight.

There is much excitement in this City, in anticipation of the passage of the City Consolidation Bill by the House tomorrow. The bill is to be hastened through, in order to prevent the different districts from adding to the debt which is hereafter to be consolidated, by making subscriptions to the various railroad, purchasing parks, etc.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The steamer George Law left for Aspinwall Dec. 20. The San Francisco left the same port only two days later, and there, therefore, could only have been some 500 miles distance between them.

In this City, Jan. 29, STEPHEN H. CRANE, aged 41 years. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Tuesday, at 2 o'clock P. M., from his late residence, No. 686 Washington-st., without further invitation. His remains will be taken to Greenwood Cemetery for interment.

The United States mail steamship Ohio, Capt. Fox, from Aspinwall Jan. 18, arrived at this port yesterday morning, brings the mails from San Francisco to Jan. 1., (the California news anticipated by the Northern Light from Nicaragua,) 300 passengers, and $976,000 in gold dust on freight. By this opportunity we have later South American dates, and Australian accounts to Nov. 2.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--SHERIDAN KNOWLES' famous comedy of the "Love Chase," is to be produced here to night, for the first appearance of Mrs. HOEY, (late Mrs RUSSELL, of BURTON'S Theatre,) who takes the leading character--Constance. New scenery has been prepared for the occasion, and appropriate costumes. The cast includes THOMPSON, DYOTT, LESTER, VINCENT and others.

A fire occurred last night on the premises of J. T. NOYE, which were entirely destroyed Loss about $10,000. A fireman, named HENRY F. JACKSON, fell from the third story through a seattle, and was instantly killed.

The following list of Business Firms are among the best and most reliable in the City of New-York. American and Foreign Silks. BOWEN McNAMEE, (Importers,) No. 112 Broadway. A. T. STEWART Co. (do.).. Broadway, cor. Reade-st. Agricultural Warehouse. R. L. ALLEN, (late A. B. Allen Co.)l89 191 Water.

A meeting is to be held at the Tabernacle this evening, to protest against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise. "It will be noticed that this movement is not an Anti-Slavery movement in any respect. The call comes from parties who have been distinguished hitherto for the warmth of their hostility to the agitation of the Slavery question.

From the New-Bedford Mercury. We have before mentioned in our columns the tragedy at New Boston, N. H, a week or more since. We learn further interesting particulars from the Manchester Mirror. The parties were HENRY N. SARGENT, 28 years old, and Miss SERVILLA JONES, 17 years old, with whom he was ardently in love, without his love-being reciprocated.

At 1 o'clock this morning, a fire broke out in the large and costly block on Main street, known as Flagg's Buildings, which was entirely destroyed. The lower story was occupied by W. H. Hudson, clothing dealer; C. A. Whiton, dry-goods dealer; Martin Stow, dry goods, and Clark Sandford, dry and fancy goods. The stocks of all these occupants were mostly removed, with but little damage. All fully insured.

We are glad to quote from a truly American letter, received by a friend in. the City from our Minister in Switzerland, THEODORE S. FAY. It is written with reference to some anonymous insinuations in the press with reference to Mr. F.'s political views. We commend it to our most dainty and conservative diplomats in general:

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The person signing himself "Grex," who in a couple of columns of Saturday's TIMES, assails one of the Judges of the Supreme Court, has made so many misstatements in what he has written, and has omitted so much which ought to have been stated, that it is due to Justice that the truth should be made known.

Dr. SOLGER delivers the last lecture of his Course on European Politics this evening, at Hope Chapel. We believe all who have heard these lectures concur in pronouncing them exceedingly instructive and interesting.
At 1 o'clock this morning, a difficulty occurred at the Newcastle Piers, between Captain PETERSON, of schooner David Smith, and Capt. BEAVER, of Baltimore brig Sea Foam, from Rio Janeiro.

The House was in session last evening, the special order being the bill for the suppression of Internperance. Previous to passing to the consideration of the bill, a resolution was adopted directing the payment ? the witnesses who had been in attendance, but not sworn before the Committee on the case of the contested seat of Mr; CLARK.

"Never," said GUIZOT, "were such great events originated by such puny men;" and, really, it would be difficult to characterize the present state of Europe more correctly in as few words. The conduct of the European diplomacy, especially of the two great Western powers who were entrusted with the honor of liberal ideas and the championship of modern civilization, has been most pitifully ridiculous.

Another of those dreadful occurrences which we are so constantly called upon to record, took place on Saturday afternoon last, in the village of Ravenswood, L. I. The ballcartridge manufactory of Mr. ERASMUS FRENCH, situated about three-quarters of a mile from the village of Astoria, in the lower part of Ravenswood, suddenly exploded with an awful crash at 1 1/2 o'clock on Saturday afternoon.
Mr. BROOKS presented a memorial relative to the taxation of insurance companies. Mr. SHERRILL introduced a bill for the discontinuance of the Harlem River bridge.

EXTENSIVE ROBBERIES--0n Friday morning an important arrest of a hotel robber was effected by Officer KEEFE, one of the Chief's Aids. The officer was passing through Leonard street, and when on the corner of Church-street he observed an individual hastening down the street on the same side of the way, snugly wrapped up in a large cloak.

FATAL ACCIDENT.--On Wednesday night, the occupants of a brick building in George-street, near Fleet, were alarmed by a noise of something falling heavily on the sidewalk: and, on searen being made, it was found that Dr. MOSCHE, a druggist, whose store was on the first floor of the building, had fallen from the window of his room in the second story.

As your readers are already aware, the Legislature of Pennsylvania have annulled the charter of the Franklin Canal Company, and the signature of Governor BIGLER is now only requisite to make that act the law of the State.

On Saturday. Jan 28, alter a short illness, JOHN BRUNDAGE, in the 49th year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, in Lorrimer?? st., first door from the corner of North 2d. st., Williamsburg, on Tuesday, the 31st. at 1 o'clock P. M.
New-Orleans papers of Monday and Tuesday 'last are received, They contain Galveston dates to the 20th inst. The District Attorney had entered a nolle prosegui in the Fillibuster case.

I have to-day received information by a gentleman from " Sagua la Grande," that a brig recently ashore in that vicinity, and represented as being loaded with salt, was found on examination to have no salt on board, but with sixty or seventy casks of water, and the berth-decks of a slaver--the negroes having been previously landed and disposed of.

The Jury in the case of the Ravenswood explosion, met at Coroner BOYD'S residence, in St. George's place, Astoria, at 9 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, and after further consulting for sometime, rendered the following verdict at 11 1/2 o'clock.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: The season is now exceedingly severe for the poor and the houseless, and the high price of provisions is combining to produce still more suffering through the lowest classes.

We have received a very excellent letter from the editor of the Firemen's Journal, on the causes of the recent destructive fires in our City, and on the complaints which have been made in various quarters of misconduct on the part of members of the Fire Department.
A large and influential meeting of citizens opposed to any violation of the Act of Congress known as the Missouri Compromise, was held last evening, in the Broadway Tabernacle.

MAN KILLED AT THE SUSPENSION BRIDGE, NIAGARA FALLS,--On Friday evening last, as the night train of the Great Western Road was about starting from the Suspension Bridge, near Niagara Falls, one of the railway police and the check-man got into a scuffle, which resulted in the death of the former.

The following letters were written in reply to invitations to attend the meetings held at the Tabernacle last evening to protest against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise: Letter from Win. H. Seward. WASHINGTON, Saturday, Jan. 28, 1851. GENTLEMEN: The invitation to a meeting to be held in the City of New York, to protest against any repeal or violation of the Missouri Compromise, with which you have honored me, has been received.

The Coroner's Jury, in the case of the Ravenswood Explosion, have brought in their verdict upon the fifteen bodies that were killed thereby. They found that a lamp fed by alcohol was used for heating grease in the same room where there were between 400 and 500 pounds of gunpowder at the same time; and they did not hesitate to say that the explosion was caused by carelessness in the use of the lamp.

The galleries were crowded to excess at an early hour. The Chair laid before the Senate several Executive communications. Mr. ALLEN presented the resolutions of the Rhode Island Legislature instructing its Senators to oppose and resist any repeal of the Missouri Compromise. Laid on the table and ordered to be printed.

The weather here during Saturday night, yesterday and last night was colder than it has been since 1839, this morning, however, it has somewhat moderated, the thermometer having risen to four decrees above zero. In Dover, N. H., this morning, the thermometer was 12 degrees below zero. PORTLAND, Sunday, Jan. 20.

Several rumors having been afloat since the death of Mr. O'DONOHUE, to the effect that he had been neglected by the persons with whom he resided, and though having plenty of means no medical attendant was called in during his illness; and further charging certain parties with malfeasance of his funds--Dr. BALL, Coroner of the County, had his remains exhumed, and held an Inquest yesterday in the City Hall, Brooklyn.

The excitement in the Senate to-day was very great. Senator DOUGLAS' speech is conceded to have been the ablest that could be made on his side of the question, although vulgarly abusive of Senators CHASE and SUMNER, whose replies were delivered with great power.

It is curious that everywhere, from so near the Poles as men can find a building lot that will not slide when the weight of an ice but is erected on it, down to where the fatty tissues of the body are always in a fluid state, men habitually demand hot drinks.

LECTURES ON THE EAST.--Rev. JAMES P. THOMPSON will deliver the first of a course of lectures on topics relative to his travels in the East, this evening, at the Brooklyn Athenaeum, corner of Atlantic and Clinton-streets. The course is to be given under the auspices of the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association.

The Hayward India Rubber Works, at Colchester, Conn., consisting of five buildings, were destroyed by fire on Saturday night. One of the overseers, named 'GEORGE STARK, aged 31, perished in the flames. Five hundred hands have been thrown out of employment by this calamity.

A very large portion of our space this morning is occupied by the report of the meeting held at the Tabernacle last evening, to protest against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise. The meeting was very large, and composed of the most respectable, intelligent and influential portion of our people.

Before Justice Roosevelt. Mary H. Bolton vs. Louisa Lynch.--The decision of this case turn, mainly on the interpretation to be given to the Will of the late Dominick Lynch the elder, who died possessed of a large estate, principally land, some time in the year 1825.

DEDICATION.--On Sunday morning the First Methodist Episcopal Church, corner of South Third street and Union avenue, erected under the auspices of the Ladies' Home Mission, was dedicated to the worship of God by Bishop JANES.
The present Winter in England has been remarkable for two circumstances--the Thermometer and Prince ALBERT have both fallen below zero. There is no knowing what maybe the result of these phenomena.
Rumors of fresh successes by the Turkish Army in Wallachia have alarmed Vienna to-day. It is commonly believed that the Government is in possession of intelligence most unfavorable to Russia.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. By the arrival of the steamship Perseverance, Capt. LAWLESS, we have received dates from Galves on to the 20th inst. The Journal, of the 19th has the following items: The wreck of the steamer Jack Hays, as she lied in Trinity River, was sold at auction in this city on Tuesday last. Capt. ROACH became toe purchaser at $1,500.

INQUISITION CONTINUED--THE VERDICT.--The investigation concerning the death of PATRICK O'DONOHUE, the Irish Exile, was resumed yesterday morning in the City Hall, Brooklyn, by Coroner BALL. But few persons were present.

Another remonstrance was presented against the renewal of the Charter of the Harlem Bridge Company. Notice was given of a bill for the taxation of non-residents, doing business in New-York City, to be taxed the same as residents of the State.

SINKING OF A SLOOP-LOAD OF PORK.--The floating ice in the North River badly crushed and sunk the sloop Market, Captain SMITH, lying at the end of the pier at the foot of York-street, Jersey City, on Sunday morning at 1 o'clock.

Before Judge Clerke. In the matter of the Habeas Corpus to inquire into the imprisonment of Oscar W. Sturtevant.--Yesterday morning, a large crowd of the profession attended the Chambers to hear the decision of his Honor in this case.

To-day is Quarter-day, always a very serious occasion. But besides the usual solemnities attending its approach, the nervousness on its arrival, and the leanness when it is passed, this quarter-day of all the year is most fraught with important consequences.

The British and North American mail steamer Asia, from Liverpool at 9 o'clock on Saturday morning, 14!h January, arrived Tuesday, 31st, at 11 A. M. The news by this arrival is full of interest. For details we refer to the following summary:

A long session of the Assembly last evening was occupied in the consideration of the bill for the suppression of Intemperance. Many amendments to the first section were offered--some in good faith, and from a desire to improve the bill; others out of jest, and for the purpose of ridiculing the proposed enactment. nnumer-

Congress has just passed a bill, authorizing the U. S. Government to provide suitable rooms for the accommodation of the Federal Courts in this City. This step was rendered necessary by the burning of the New City Hall. Whether the provision referred to is designed to be temporary or permanent were not aware. ourse, however, percna-

The foreign intelligence brought by the Asia, of which a full digest will be found in the columns of the TIMES of this morning, is unusually interesting. OMER PACHA, the Turkish General, has gained another signal victory over the Russians, on the Danube, in the vicinity of Kalafat,--first assailing and taking the strong fortress of Citale, and then repulsing, in an open engagement, a large force of Russians sent to its relief.

On Monday, Jan. 30, ROBERT MILTON, eldest child of Lindley and Mary Underhill, aged 5 years 9 months and 15 days. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from the residence of his grandmother, Mrs. Juliet H. Mitchill, No. 272 Madison st., this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, without further invitation.

The prominent men of Pennsylvania from the Governor down, who have sympathized with the Erie outrages, appear to have over looked the consideration of public and corporate credit, in their anxiety for party capital and certain local, though very temporary advantages of trade. de the State, this is

FIRE IN THE CATHEDHAL AT LOUISVILLE.--The Alarm of fire, about 1 o'clock yesterday, caused great consternation by the report which spread through the alty that the new cathedral was on fire. Thousands rushed at once to the scene of disaeter, to save that magnificent structure from falling a proy to the flanes.

We have papers from the city of Mexico to the 7th inst., three days later. The Universal has an article on the subject of indemnity for damages sustained at the hands of the Indians on the frontier, in which it announces that there has been established in the capital, under the auspices of the Supreme Government, and agency destined to facilitate the most adequate means of attaining that object.

Arrests Yesterday-Goods Seized on board the "Asia"--Smuggled Goods by the "Alps" condemned. Yesterday on the arrival of the British Mail steamship Asia, two well dressed gentlemanly men were arrested on the prevalent charge of smuggling. They gave their names as JOHN JOHANSSESON and Dr. JOHN DOWLING, the latter being the physician of the ship.

The man, SILVERSTEIN, implicated in the recent burglaries in this city, was arrested this afternoon in the Hudson River Railroad Depot, by officer HAGARDORN. Sometimes since the store of WM. From the Cincinnati Columbian. We are indebted to M. STEVENS, First Assistant Sergent-at Arms of the Ohio Senate, for a list of the members of the Ohio Legislature, with a statement of their ages, occupations, etc.

We have received files of Rio Janeiro papers to Saturday, Dec. 10, inclusive. They contain no South American news of much importance, but are filled with European intelligence. The impending Russian war excites deep interest among all classes, but more particularly agitates the commercial men, to whom it opens no very flattering prospect.

After a rapid thaw we have new mild open weather, and all impediments to river navigation are removed. In the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets rather an extensive business has been done during the week, with large speculations in Baltic Produce; while BREADSTUFFS have again advanced considerably.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate the report of the War Department, relative to the expenditures for the improvement of rivers in Arkansas. Mr. PEARCE presented a petition from Customs Inspectors, of Baltimore, for increased pay.

Nearly the entire day was passed in an endeavor on the part of Senator DOUGLAS to get the Nebraska hill before the Senate for further consideration, and to have it continued from day to day until disposed of. In this he was not gratified. en-

Two or three days since a select corps of our City Police made a descent upon the little boys and girls who were engaged in clearing the crossings from mud, and who asked a penny for their labor from the gentlemen and ladies who were thus enabled to cross dry-shod, and marched a score or two of them into the Police Court. NEERS OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.--The election for the above officers took place on Monday evening. The election for Chief Engineer was to fill the vacancy occasioned by the recent death of BENJAMIN DUBOIS. The fire Department consists of sixteen Companies--all of whom declined to take part in the election, with the exception of Engine Companies No. 1, No. 5, and No. 8, and Hook and Ladder Company No. 1.

DEAR SIR : The Governor has gone to Erie with the view to allay all further difficulties, but whether he will prove successful remains to be seen. Many Democratic members thought it would have been more proper in him to remain at home, and so thought other sensible persons. en the Gauge Law question comes up it
The Senate, in Executive Session to-day, confirmed all the nominations before it that had been reported. They were chiefly collectors of customs. There were some few appraisers and land officers.

COMMON COUNCIL.--PRICES OF GAS IN THE CITY.-A regular meeting of this body was held on Monday evening. The President, Alderman BAKER, in the Chair. A communication Was received from Mayor WALL, in which he vetoed the resolution passed by the Board at the previous meeting, suspending the operation of the City Ordinance in relation to street awnings, The veto was sustained.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: I have noticed several articles in the TIMES reflecting not only on the character but the efficiency of the New-York Firemen. A few weeks since you condemned the careless manner in which buildings are erected in this City. Your remarks upon the subject of buildings deserve especial attention from the public.

The Deputy Marshal, from New-York, has arrived at Norfolk, having in his custody a fugitive slave. who was taken from vessel below New-York. The Maryland House of Representatives his passed to a third reacting the bill authorizing the city of Baltimore to loan $5,000,000 to the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company. The bill had previously pissed the Senate.

Three hours of debate, voting, striking out and inserting, last evening, told considerably in the progress of the bill for the suppression of Intemperance--the-fifth of the sections having been duly considered and passed upon. There was more earnest discussion last evening than upon any previous occasion, and less disposition manifested to offer and debate involous amendments.

FIFTH LECTURE. DR. SOLGER delivered his fifth lecture on Friday night last, at Hope Chapel. A very considerable and highly intelligent audience were present, The chief subject of the lecture was " The Eastern Question and the prospects of Europe, in case of a general European war, with particular reference to the position of Italy, Hungary, Poland, and Germany."

Houses of Refuge are not a modern improvement. When Moses stood in the plains of Moab hard by Jericho, it was ordered that among the gifts to the Levites should be certain cities of refuge, where any one that should slay a man unawares might flee and be safe.

NORTON's Literary Gazette is now published on the 1st and 15th of each month, instead of monthly, as before. The Gazette is devoted to the literary news of the day, furnishes complete lists of American and European publications, with the proceedings of literary societies, information concerning the growth of libraries at home and abroad, and accounts of the great trade-sales.

The return of Hon. N B. MORSE, ex Judge of the Supreme Court, to the practice of his profession, was celebrated by his legal brethren of the Kings County Bar, who gave a grand supper in his honor on Tuesday evening at the Mansion House, Hieks street, Brooklyn.

IMPORTANT ARREST OF COUNTERFEITERS.- Yesterday morning the Sheriff and his officers, with a posse accompanying, made a descent upon a canal boat lying at the dock near the foot of Well-st., and arrested ALEXANDER HARRINGTON and a man named PUTNAM, Capt CLARK, and a woman who had been living with the latter.

A memorial was presented for an appropriation to the Eye and Ear Infirmary. A report was made in favor of the separation of the office of Superintendent of Common Schools, from that of Secretary of State. BILLS PASSED.

The San Francisco Committee have made their awards. They have given to Captains LOWE, STOUFFER, and the admirable CRIGHTON, $1,000 each; to the officers of each of the three rescuing ships, $800; to the crews of those ships, $2,600; and to Captain WATKINS and his officers, to Captain PENDLETON, and Lieutenant MURRAY, $1,050-$9,050 in all.

The Street-Committee of the Board of Councilmen met at 3 o'clock-yesterday, pursuant to a resolution offered by Councilman KENNEDY, instructing them "to inquire into and report on the propriety of widening Weststreet to the width of 150 feet." There were only a few owners of property on the line present, and no person appeared to understand what was the project sought to be attained by Widen'ng the street.

At Flushing, L L., Feb. 1, EZRA FAIRCHILD, Principal of the Flushing Institute, in the 55 h year of his ago. His remains will be taken to Plainfield, N. J., for interment, on Friday, 3d inst., from Jersey City, by oars, at 12 M. Relatives and friends are hereby invited to attend. On Wednesday morning, Feb. 1, FREDERICK S, only child of R. S. and Mary Middleton, aged 1 year 1 month and 1 day.

The Parliament House and adjoining buildings, at Quebec, were entirely destroyed by fire about 2 o'clock this morning. The flames were not discovered until they had gained too much headway to be got under, notwithstanding that a sentinel was on duty near the spot.

The Cabinet had a four hours' session again to-day, during which the GADSDEN Treaty was the subject under consideration. It is rumored that the Cabinet is still undetermined whether to send the treaty to the Senate or not.

The Committee of Distribution of the San Francisco Rescuers' Fund met to day, and decided on the following disposal of the fund: To Capt. CRIGHTON, $2,000 ; to Capt. Low, of the bark Kilby, and Capt. STOUFFER, of the Antarctic, $1,600 each; to Capt. PENDLETON, of the Lucy Thompson, $250; Capt. MATHEWS, of the steamer City of New York, $500; and service of plate; to Lieut.

The bark Tally Ho, from Cape Town, Cape of Good Hope, Dec. 6, arrived here this morning. Left in port bark Kirkland, from New York, for Ascension Bay, four days. The banks Rienzi and Southerner, from Boston for Australia, had arrived with their Captains sick Bark Martha Anna, for Baltimore, sailed from Saldanba Bay, Dec. 3.

A resolution directing the Committee on Judiciary to inquire into the expediency of amending the rules of the Senate so as to remove the injunction of secrecy upon final action on nominations, and retain secrecy upon all debates on nominations, gave rise to some discussion in the Senate yesterday.

We publish on another page of this morning's TIMES, the details of the news from Santa Fe. Besides a most interesting account of a not uncommon. display of Mexican knavery which resulted in the death of an Indian Chief, there is a thrilling narrative of the sufferings of Mrs. JANE A. WILSON, during her captivity among the Camanche Indians.
A Jury was empanneled by Coroner HILTON, yesterday, to hold an inquest upon the body of JOHN SMITH, one of the victims of the Ravenswood explosion, who died at the Hospital on Monday last.

We took a pilot at 7 o'clock--about an hour and a half ago--and have just made the Highlands. We got soundings in 17 fathoms last Friday, to the northward and westward of Cape Hatteras, having crossed the Gulf Str. am that afternoon.

A journalist, like every one whose duties require him to watch the movements of the day and the developments of character, must see many things discreditable to human nature,. and discouraging to those who labor for its improvement.

Mr. SUMNER presented a petition from Lancaster County, Pa, praying that Congress would prevent the introduction of slavery into territory, now free, and lying North of 36[degrees] 30??. Laid on the table.

If we are to judge from the manner in which they have commenced their operations, the advocates of the Nebraska hill are determined to force it through Congress as rapidly and with as little debate as possible. Mr. DOUGLAS opened the campaign with a display of violence and bad manners seldom witnessed in the Senate, since Gov. FOOTE of Mississippi ceased to be a member of it.

The Santa Fe mail reached here to day, and an abstract of all I could glean from correspondence, , was sent you by telegraph. In addition to what I said respecting Maj. GREINER's operations, the prospect seems very good for the company to realize handsomely.

The Legislature of this Territory met on Wednesday last, and was organized without delay. S. BALDWIN OLMSTEAD is President of the Council, and NATHAN C. D. TAYLOR Speaker of the House. Today the annual Message of Governor GORMAN was read by him in the Hall of the House of Representatives, in the presence of both braaohes, and a large assemblage of citizens.

REED, for the under of Mr. WILLIAM FURLONG n the 22d of March, 1852, was commenced yesterday afternoon, before Justice STUART, at the Jefferson Market Police Court. Much misapprehension exists of the Mission at the Five Points belonging to the "New-York Ladies' Home Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church," and the Industrial Home under the superintendence of Rev. L. M. PEASE. A deal has bean said and written tending to mislead. An article in the Evening Post of the 15th November last, by the Publishing Committee of the Ladies' Home Missionary Society, needed correction.

On Tuesday, JAMES MARVAN was arraigned at the New Jersey Council Court, held at Bergen, for the murder of his wife ELIZABETH, on the 18th September last, in Harrison township Hudson County. The Judges on the bench were Chief Justice HAYNES, and Justices GRIFFITH, THOMAS and KIDNEY. Exhibitions of Poultry have become fashionable Late English papers record the great success of the Metropolitan Poultry Show recently held in London Tw Exhibitions of a similar character will take place in this City and Albany, during the present month. Two Societies are in existence, having the same object, and both established within the past year.

THE EXTRADITION CASE.--An application was made yesterday to his Honor Judge INGERSOLI, for a habeas corpus in behalf of ALEXANDER HELBRONN, claimed under the Ashburton Treaty. The petition set forth, among other things, that a habeas corpus had been issued out of the Supreme Court of the State to bring HELBRONN before one of the Judges of that Court, and that on the return of that writ, HELBRONN had been ordered to be discharged.

ARREST OF A BIGAMIST.--On Tuesday, Lewis Chandler, of Hoboken, arrested the day previous on a charge of bigamy, by Deputy Sheriff Pollard, was examined before Recorder Cutter. It appears that in 1848 he was married to a very respectable woman in Bergen, and has since been living with her in Hoboken.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--The "Love Chase" was performed here last night for the second time this season. The house was again crowded to excess. Mrs. HOEY sustained the character of constance with much force and prettiness; her acting in the fourth act, where. Wildrake announces his intended nuptials, was superior to what he had last season under the coquette-dispeasation of Miss KERNE. Mrs. HOEY is an acquisition to Mr. WALLACKE powerful establishment.

Yesterday afternoon, a rumor was in circulational that BEDINI had arrived in this City, and had been seen in the company of several clerical gentlemen, repairing to the new Catholic Church on Third-avenue, between Twenty-eighth and Twenty ninth streets. There is cause to doubt this report. By an article which we publish below from a Boston paper, it will be seen that there was a popular demonstration against him there on Tuesday night.

There is much bitterness now existing between the friends of General CASS and those of Senator DOUGLAS, in relation to the Nebraska bill. General CASS considers the measure ill-advised, but notwithstanding this opinion, there is no doubt that he will vote for it, after he has made a speech reaffirming the doctrines of the NICHOLSON letter, and arguing that the Missouri Compromise is unconstitutional. Mr. SEWARD presented resolutions to the Legislature of New York, calling the attention of Congress to the alarming mortality on board of emigrant vessels, and asking for appropriate legislation on the subject. Mr. EVERETT presented the Memorial of the widow of AUDUBON, praying this Congress would purchase the original drawings by her husband of the Birds of America.

A very numerous audience was present on Tuesday evening to listen to the lecture of HORACE GREELEY, Esq, the same being one of the regular course announced to be given under the auspices of the New-York Anti slavery Society.

Mr. BEECHER said that the motto, not the text, to his discourse was to be found in the last sentence of the fourth verse of the twelfth chapter of the Prophesy of Daniel--which reads "Many shall run to and fro, and knowledge shall be increased."

Previous to taking up the bill for the suppression of Intemperance, last evening, it was resolved to discontinue the holding of evening sessions, and to meet here after at 3i o'clock in the afternoon, at which time the Temperance bill should be the special order.

JOHN L. BARKER and CHARLES BONEY were arrested last night in the Howard Theatre, having in their possession a number of checks, varying in amount from $900 to $80, on New-York banks, suspected of being forgeries. Four of the checks were on the Bank of New-York--signed by WOODRUFF ROBINSON.

You address a very long letter to me, in the Citizen of Jan. 28, 1854, in defence of yourself and of American slavery. That you select me from among all who reporbated your apostacy from the gospel of human liberty. arises, I presume, from reasons of convenience to your rather than of compliment to me.

The Committee of the Board of Councilmen, on Lands and Places, to whom was referred that portion of the Mayor's Message, and other papers relating to the Central Park, held an adjourned meeting at 4 P. M., yesterday--Councilman MATTHEW in the Chair. There was a full attendance of persons interested.

It is stated that the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company of this City, held an insurance policy for $80,000 on the Great Republic. The aggregate insurance on that vessel was $260,000. The companies being in the habit of dividing their individual risks among several parties, will not suffer very serious losses by marine insurances, however heavy.

The Legislature, at the invitation of Easton and Philadelphia merchants, will make an excursion to-morrow over the Belvidere Delaware Railroad to Easton. The Road has just been opened. A great time is expected. The Air Line bill will be put upon the second reading on Tuesday next.

We find the following in yesterday's Evening Post: "The Trustees of Columbia College have been charged with a disposition to inquire into the religious views of a candidate for the Professorship of Chemistry, and Natural and Experimental Philosophy.

MEETING OF THE PRIVATE COACHMEN'S SOCIETY--PRESENTATION.--The Private C achmen's Protective Union Society held their monthly meeting in Constitution Hall, Broadway, last evening. The minutes of the last meeting having been read and approved, several applications for membership were received and acted on after which a report was read showing the Society to be in a highly flourishing condition.

From the Philadelphia Bulletin of last Evening. Captains CRIGHTON and Low, of the ship Three Bells and the bark Kilby, arrived in this city yesterday afternoon from New-York, and put up at the Girard House. This morning they, in company with several gentlemen, visited the different objects of interest in the city.
The Arabia, now in her thirteenth day out, has not yet made here appearance. The Niagara arrived here, from Boston, about 11 o'clock, and will depart again, for Liverpool, almost immediately.

THE U. S. MARSHAL'S OFFICE.--In consequence of the great inconvenience the Judges, their clerks, the counsel and suitors in the United States Courts are suffering from the want of room and other appliances to conduct the business devolving upon them, owing to the recent fire, the United States Marshal yesterday proceeded to Washington, to have personal conference with the Secretary of State on the subject.

MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE-MURDER FEARED.--It is feared that Mr. H. C LAWRENCE, the agent of an Insurance Company, has been foully dealt with. He left his office on Monday evening to make a deposit in one of the banks of this city, and has not since been heard of.

On Wednesday, Feb. 1, in the 53rd year of her age, PHEBE, wife of Benjamin Quackenbush. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Sunday next, at 1 o'clock, from the Third Universalist Church, corner of Bleecker and Downing sts. The remains will be taken to Greenwood.

A favorable report was made on the bill for the transfer of all bank papers and records to the Banking department. MR. ROBERTSON introduced his bill ceding jurisdiction to the United States over certain lands in the Hudson River, for light houses and other purposes.

What a delightful thing it is to hive a First of February! Two genial Spring days have opened the hearts of New-Yorkers, and have actually made men amiable on that worst of all times, known as " Quarter Day." Pleasant looking elderly gentlemen, who have not yet aspired to the comforts and dignity of house owners, are content to hand over sundry cool hundreds for the privilege of being house-occupiers.

The Cincinnati Gazette of Monday contains the following : A delicate and romantic interest is connected with the habeas corpus case now being examine in the Pronate Court before Judge Warren. The parties are connected with the Society of Friends, and are of families of the highest respectability both here and in Philadelphia.

FROZEN TO DEATH.--We learn by a gentleman from the country, that on Sunday night last, two farmers, returning with teams loaded with lumber from Ripon, were frozen to death on Green Lake Prairie, about 50 rods from a house. The teams were in a snow drift, and the men were both dead and stiff.

SAMUEL DUNSHEE, one of our oldest citizens, departed this life last Sabbath. Left an orphan at an early age, by his integrity of character and untiring industry he has acquired for himself a good name among the best of men. Unostentatious and generous hearted.

Last Saturday, the work of rebuilding the Railroad bridges crossing French and State-streets in this city, was completed under this direction of Marshal FROST. On Monday the track was relaid in Harbor Creek, and that bridge rebuilt. o-day

Our Washington correspondent sends us intelligence of a good deal of interest in regard to the position of our Government to wards the Sandwich Islands. The delay of the Administration in acting upon the advances towards a closer connection with the United States by the Sandwich Island authorities, has excited a good deal of surprise.

The Imperialist officers are gathering in this vicinity an immense crowd of the reckless, desperate .class of Chinese from all quarters, including a most select company of Canton Coast Pi rates, to the number of some thousands. Over these men the Mandarins seem to have hardly any control.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Please allow me, Sir, to correct your report of my evidence in the recent trial of JAMES MARIN at Bergen. I stated distinctly that Mrs. M.'s death was occasioned by a rupture of the spleen, extending diagonally for about 4 inches across its concave surface near the lower end;

The Annual Report of the Massachusetts Prison Inspectors has been published. They have been improving the Prison during the year, at a cost of $8,000, and also added to the grounds the MURDOCK estate, at the price of $25,000 for its purchase. They say $18,000 more could be spend to advantage before making the Prison any too good for the purposes required of it.

The Temperance bill was perfect up to and including the fourteenth section. The Constitutional objections raised to the eleventh section were surmounted to the satisfaction of the Committee of the Whole, and as is hoped, in such a manner as to save it in the Coures--but I think it weakened the choices of the bill upon the third reading.

WOMAN MURDERED IN TOLEDO.--Two women of had repute, temporarily living at a house of ill-fame near the distillery of BOWE KRANS, came down town yesterday forenoon, and became int-xica ed in a saloon in the upper part of the city. Their names, as given in the examinations, are BIDDY FURY, the murderess, a native of Cincinnati, and CATHARINE GILNER, the murdered women, who said she belonged to Cleveland.

MUDDY STREETS.--The fine weather of Thursday caused quite an impediment to pedestrianism along some of our unpaved streets, by producing a rather copious supply of mind, consequent upon the thawing of a clayey soil: - nothing similar, however, to the abominable filth which is allowed to accumulate in the thoroughfares of New-York.

To the Editor of the Transcript. A sense of the duty and the love which I owe to my native city of Boston, deciles me to overcome the repugnance which I feel, both from natural character and reflection, to obtrude myself, by an extra official act, upon the public. notice.

The search for the remains of the victims of the Explosion at Ravenswood has been continued daily since the occurrence. Numerous scraps of bodies have been discovered in the vicinity of the scene of the disaster. On Thursday, the relatives end friends of the sufferers instituted a final search, and succeeded in finding a number of remnants or bodies, Sufficient, in all, to fill a smallkeg. These remains were decently interred. of

AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY.--The regular meeting of the Board of Managers was held on the 3d inst., at the Bible House. Hon. LUTHER BRADISH presided. Seven new auxiliaries were recognized; two in Texas, three in Missouri, and in North Carolina and Indians, one each. Communications were received from different parts of the country, especially Oregon, California. Florida, Tennessee and Kentucky.

JAMES C. DERBY who has heretofore been of the publishing firms of DERBY MILLER, in Auburn, and DERBY, ORTON MULLIGAN, in Buffalo, has sold out his interest in both these establishments, and intends to open a publishing house in Park place, in this City.

We learn, with pleasure, that our friend Mr. PAUL ARPIN, a gentleman who became very widely and favorably known in this country by his able editorial management of the Courrier des Etats Unis, proposes to deliver a course of lectures on the poets, historians, novelists, philosophers and critics of France.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: In supposing PIUS IX. ignorant of our Constitution, you are, I think, in error. The President is Commander-in-chief of the Army, and through the Secretary of War has a real power as such.

On Friday morning, Feb. 3, after a lingering illness, NATHAN H. JACKSON, of the late firm of W. N. Jackson Sons, in the 48th year of his age. His friends and relatives are invited to attend his funeral, without further notice, on Sunday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from his late Residence. No. 215 Clin on-st.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. I have perused with a great deal of pleasure, two leading editorial articles that have recently appeared in your valuable journal, upon the proposed repeal of the Missouri Compromise.

THE ICE BRIDGE AT NIAGARA.--We learn from a visitor that an ice bridge is thrown across the river just below the American Fall, and at the foot of the Ferry staircase. It is formed of cakes of ice, heaped up together in every possible shape, and rises some twenty feet above the water. It is already used as a highway for foot passengers between the States and Canada.

CLASSICAL QUARTETTE SOIREE.--The third concert of the fourth season of these and little musical parties, was held last night at DODWORTH's rooms, next to Grace Church. The attendence was, as usual, of the best. It is not easy to find a more select audience, or one that more evidently enjoys itself than that which usually attends these suirees.

CHARLES and JAMES FARRELL, (father and son,) arrested on a charge of setting fire to a dwelling owned by CHARLES FARRELL, located on Tillary-street. near the Navy Yard, on the night of the 25th of January last, were yesterday brought before Justice Smith for examination. ALEXANDER MCCUE, Esq., appeared for the accused.

Will not landlords, unless there is some special objection, have the kindness to state the amount- demanded for rent when they advertise their " Houses to Let!" It would save house-hunters days of time, and miles of traveling, as well as protect themselves from scores of unprofitable calls daily.

To-night Erie is all agog. Gov. BIGLER came in the Western 7 o'clock train. Thirteen guns announced his arrival. The Military and Fire Companies and a crowd of citizens assembled at the Break, where the cars stopped in the mud, to receive him.

MEETING OF THE VETERAN CORPS.--The regular monthly meeting of the Veteran Corpos of 1812 was held in the Star Hotel, Lispeard-street, last evening, Col. RAYMOND in the Chair. After the transaction of sure private business, the Secretary read a number of letters from gentlemen in Philadelphia and Washington, acknowledging the receipt of the complimentary resolutions passed by the Corps in reference to their recent visit to Philadelphia. The debate on Judge PHILLIPS', (of Vt.,) seat in the Senate is not yet closed, and may occupy that body for some days longer. It is feared it will somewhat interfere with the passage of the Nebraska bill.

A Committee of the Board of Aldermen has been directed to inquire why the rails of the Hudson River Railroad should not be removed below Sixtieth-street, because the Company has failed to change their present rail to a grooved rail, in accordance with the directions of the common Council.

The joint resolutions instructing our Senators, , in Congress to oppose any reduction of the duty on foreign salt, was called in the House of Representatives, and debated up to 1 o'clock the hour of adjournment. Mr. STRONG, a member from Philadelphia City, was opposed to action in the matter.

A FREEMAN IN BONDAGE! -- We have before us a letter written in the Louisville (Ky.) Jail, by EOWARD DERBY, a young man of color, aged about 22 years, who was born in this State, and some years since lived with Capt S. W. UPDIKE, of this city. He is the son of RUFUS DERBY, of Geneva, a colored preacher, who was also born in this State.

A BABY SHOW IN MASSACHUSETTS.--A baby show has literally transpired. It occurred at Palmer, on Wednesday evening last, in connection with a Ladies' Fair. Six of eight babies were exhibited, dressed "up to the pines." The committee that passed upon the merits of the little ones were childless, and they awarded the premium of $3, offered by Mr. FISK, of the Palmer Journal, to a boy baby of Mr. HARDAKER.

JOHN COCHRANE, Esq., in a letter given in another column, pays his respects to the editor of the Herald, in regard to the very important question whether Gen. FRANKLIN PIERCE did or did not write a letter to a Free, Soil meeting in 1848.

BOARD OF EDUCATION.--This monthly meeting of the Board of Education was held at the City Hill or Thursday evening, the President, Mr. DEMAREST, in the chair. The Committee on Appropriations submitted the following estimates of expenses for the ensuing year, and recommend that the Board of Finance make the required appropriations:

PROBATE COURT--Before Judge Warren--State of Ohio ex rel Walter Hinchman, by his next friend D. H. Taylor vs. Morgan Hichman.--The trial of this case was resumed this morning at 10 o'clock. Isaac shoemaker testified that he was brother of Mrs. Hinchman, and that as executor of his father's estate, he transferred to Mrs. H, before her marriage, her patrimony, amounting to $12,000--some of is was in stocks that were not at par value.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: If you correspondent "W. H. H." would wholly disregard "somebody's Theory of Storms," and acquaint himself with the known facts or law of their rotation and progress, he would not fail to understand why the George Law escaped the gale in which the San Francisco was wrecked.

We have been informed by Mr. P. S. FORBES of this City, a partner in the house of which the U. S. Consul at Shanghae, Mr. EDWARD CUNNINGHAM, is a member, that the report which we copied on Friday from the Hong Kong Register, concerning its business connections with SAMQUA, the Chinese Collector of Customs, at that port, is entirely without foundation.

On Saturday, Feb. 4, after a brief illness, PETER McLOUGHLIN. Esq., late Governor of the Aims-House, in the 60th year of his age. His friends are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Tuesday morning, 7th inst., at 10 o'clock, from his late residence, No. 232 Madison-st, near Jefferson st. His remains will be taken to St. Patrick's Cathedral for interment.

One is astonished as he calls to mind the published biographies of recent years, to note the number of mournful works among them. HAYDON'S Autobiography is the last publication of the class, and as it is now being generally read, it gives us a text for some remarks.

The Roman states are suffering greatly from scarcity of food, especially at Fenezza and Ravenna. A scarcity also prevails at Naples. The firm of G. G. BUONO had failed. The case of M. CARBONE, the American citizen, is still unsetiled, The American Minister had taken the matter up warmly, and the Neapolitan government was endeavoring to patch it up by bribing CARBONE to leave.

The 14th, 15th, and 16th sections of the bill for the suppression of intemperance were passed in the Committee of the Whole, at the afternoon session yesterday. On the 17th section differences of opinion were found to exist. It provides for the disposal of liquor after it has been forfeited under the act.
One week's later intelligence from Europe confirms previous statements of the successes of the Turkish and the losses and the discomfitures of the Russian armies.

Parliamentary preparations are beginning. Lord ABERDEEN was to road the Queen's speech to a private meeting of Government supporters on the 30th January, the speech being previously revised by the Privy Council.

Last night the "break" west of the depot across Sassafras street was guarded by sentinels to prevent a connection. Notwithstanding the declarations of the Marshal and the Railroad men that none was designed, it was still thought necessary for the protection of their "rights." A more perfect set of monomaniacs on the question of a "break," the world never saw.

Hon. FREDERICK P. STANTON, member of Congress from Tennessee, addressed the members of this political Association in the large room at the Stuyve?ant Institute, on last Saturday evening, L. M GLOVER, Esq , in the Chair. There were not more than 150 individuals present.
The following opinion was given on Saturday by Mr. BLUNT to Sheriff ORDER, upon the proper course to be pursued by that officer in relation to releasing Mr. STURTEVANT from custody.

THE LATE PRIZE-FIGHT IN CHESTER COUNTY.--The people at Westchester have vindicated the laws of the land and of common humanity, and have given bullies a wholesome hint of what they may expect in the event of their again making Choster County the scene of their brutal exhibitions.

DEATH OF MISSIONARIES.--Three female Missionaries of the American Baptist Missionary Union have recently deceased--Mrs. Rose, of the mission in Arracan, British Burmah, and Mrs. Shermer and Mrs Crocker, of the mission to the Bassas, West Africa--all within a year of their residence.

The advocates of the Nebraska bill had another caucus yesterday. It is understood that they will further modify the bill by substituting the repeal of the Missouri Compromise in express terms for the clause declaring that it is superseded by the principles of legislation of 1850. The Cabinet held another session yesterday over the Gadsden Treaty, which I have reason to believe will be sent to the Senate and ratified.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, Captain JUDKINS from Liverpool, at noon on Saturday, the 21st of January, arrived at this port this afternoon, bringing 79 passengers. The COLLINS steamship Pacific, from New-York on Saturday, the 7th ult., arrived at Liverpool at noon on Wednesday, the 18th ult.

FROM HAYTI.--BY the arrival of the brig Maria at this port, we have accounts from Cape Haytien to Jan. 14. The crews of many o' the vessels in port had suffered from yellow fever, but the sickness was abating. Coffee was coming in in large quantities, and was selling at $114@$112. Haytien currency, with a downward tendency.

The Assembly Committee to which the Dissection bill, as it passed the Senate, was referred, have reported it back to the House very much amended. The alterations principally tend to limit the bodies which shall be delivered up for dissection.
A singular petition is now before Congress. In 1846, Mrs. ELIZABETH C. SMITH of Missouri, under the assumed name of Ben Newman, enlisted as a soldier in the Mexican war.

This morning, this bright, beautiful November morning, I went forth to breathe the air before the millions of respirators were in motion, and I saw many a beautiful sight which made my heart glad, and filled me with hopeful, cheering thoughts.
The following is the weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 28th day of January to the 4th day of February, 1854. Men, 97; women, 68; boys, 197; girl, 199. Total, 491.

By the New-Orleans P?icayune of January 28, we have intelligence of the arrival of the steamship Texas at that port, with dates from Vera Cruz to the 24th inst., and from the city of Mexico to the 19th. She reports having left at Vera Cruz the Mexican ship of war Guadalupe, formerly the slaver Lady Suffolk, which was about to leave for Laguna Campeachy and the Pacific ocean.

Mr. FISH presented the proceedings of a meeting of citizens of New-York City, with resolutions against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise. He moved that they be read. Mr. DOUGLAS said he had no particular objection to the reading of the resolutions, but all had read them before. If every memorial was read at length, the whole time of the Senate would be so consumed.

EMILE DE GIRARDIN returns to the Presse after a long absence, in an article upon DROUYN DE L'HUYS' circular, announcing that the fleets were ordered to enter the Black Sea. This article has attracted much notice.

We are glad to see the effort made in the Legislature to separate the offices of Superintendent of Common Schools and Secretary of State. We hope a law will be enacted during the present session divorcing the parties to this union, which never was demanded, except for a temporary political purpose.

Erecting monuments is about the hardest work our people ever engage in. They will build a dozen cities and connect them with railroads and telegraph wires, while one monument is going up. Tunnelling mountains is child's play.

In the Legislature of Pennsylvania, the annual reports of the Treasurer and also of the Directors of the Franklin Canal Company were submitted to-day. It is somewhat remarkable that both were read, and without any snarling on the part of members, many of whom get alarmed at the mere mention of the name Franklin Canal.

We are glad to see that a bill is before the Legislature designating a newspaper at the Capital, in which legal and other official notices are to be published, and paid for at proper and remunerative rates.

The Bank of France has raised the rate of discount to five per cent. It was said the Bank would lend the Government from two to three hundred millions of francs on treasury bonds. Another important rumor prevailed, that arrangements were making to effect a fusion of the Bank of France with the Credit Mobillier, and by a bold expansion of currency to prevent the necessity of a loan.

The Nebraska and Kansas bill was again the dominant subject in the Senate on Saturday. Mr. DIXON, of Kentucky, made a speech in favor of the bill, with his amendment.
The Mail from New-Orleans, as late as due, is received. The Virginia House of Delegates rejected the bill appropriating $2,000,000 for the extension of the Ohio and Covington Railroad.

The signal of Admiral DUNDAS on entering the Black Sea, was: "Our duty is to protect, the Ottoman Marine and Territory from all aggressions in the Eaxine." A rumor was circulated on the Paris Bourse that the fleet had returned to the Bosphorus from stress of weather, but it proved to be untrue.

The Circular of M. DROUYN DE L'HUYS will, probably, have reached you at the same time with my last letter, in telegraphic outline, at least, and from it you will perceive that my appreciation of events now transpiring was correct.
