DARING BURGLARY.--Last night, between the hours of 12 and 1 o'clock, the residence of Mr. HENRY L. WALN, in Blockley Township, near the Falls of Schuylkill, was entered by three villains, masked and armed with revolvers and bowie knives. They effected an entrance through one of the kitchen windows, by prying off the shutters, in doing which they were heard by Mr. WALN. who arose, dressed himself, and went down stairs.

Since the exposure of the practices by which the pseudo-firm of B. B. MARS Co., (whose real name is McDONALD.) succeeded in ??indling various parties of their funds on lottery policies, the attention of the authorities has been sharply directed towards the remaining Latter, establishments.

BURTON'S THEATRE.--On Friday evening Mr. BURTON produced SHAKESPEARE'S immortal comedy of the "Midsummer Night's Dream." Not being able on that night to procure a seat in the ordinary way, and being stranger to the managerial courtesy of the Chambers-street Theatre, we were unable to record the entire success of this revival on the following morning.

In the last number of Blackwood's Magazine there is a very comforting article, under the above title. Comforting, we say, for it always comforts us to be told that whatever we love is good for us, and to have our tastes endorsed by the judgment of sound advisers.

There is a newspaper published in Kingston, Canada, called the British Whig. It is very savage upon THACKERAY for his note explaining the passage in his new novel which was supposed to indicate disrespect towards WASHINGTON.

By the Arabia, we have Halifax papers of the 4th inst. The bark Priscilla, form Philadelphia, bound for Liverpool, with a cargo of flour and grain, was fallen in with a sinking condition, and the officers and crew taken off and carried into St. John, Newfoundland.

Mr. Rusk appeared to-day. Mr. BRIGHT presented remonstrances from Georgetown against the construction of any bridges over the Potomac south of that place. MR. SUMNER presented the memorial of the New-York Geographical Society, setting forth the great inconvenience resulting from the variety and complexity of the standards of weights and measures.

The following Report of the Special Committee of the Board of Councilmen, who were appointed to proceed to Albany for the purpose of bringing before the State Legislature the important subject of the Encroachments upon the Harbor of New-York, was presented in the Board at its session of last evening.

TRAVELER !--LOOK TO YOUR INTEREST, SAFETY AND COMFORT.--CANANDAIGUA AND NIAGARA FALLS RAILROAD.--This road, connecting with the "Canandaigua and Elmira" and "New-York and Erie" Railroads, forms the most direct and expeditions route between New-York City and Niagara Falls, and being on the broad or six-foot gauge, the cars are more commodious and comfortable than on any other line of travel.

THE GREAT ITALIAN MEETING.--The Anti BEDINI demonstration held last evening, at the Stuyvosant Institute, was large, respectable, and enthusiastic. Every corner of the hall was occupied by Italians of both sexes, among whom we observed quite a considerable number of Americans.

The annual meeting of the Providence and Worcester Railroad Corporation was held to-day. A new Board of Directors, in the interest of Mr. FARNUM and the Norfolk County Railroad, were elected, and Mr. FARNUM was chosen President, and DANL. W. VAUGHN, Vice President.

On Monday, Feb. 6. MATILDA, widow of James Dorset, in the 61st year of her age. The friends and relatives of the deceased, also of her son-in law, John E. Earle, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, to-day, (Tuesday,) 7th inst., at 4 o'clock P. M., from the residence of the latter, No. 8 West Washington-place.

YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION.--The second of the semi-monthly Sunday Evening Sermeas, before the Young Men's Christian Association of this city, was delivered Sunday evening, at the Plymouth Church, by Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER.

A special meeting of the Board of Ten Governors was held in the Rotunda yesterday morning, to adopt suitable testimonials of respect to the memory of their late colleague, Governor PETER McLOUGHLIN, who died quite suddenly at his residence in this City on Saturday last.

The Court of Inquiry, convened by order of the President of the United States, to investigate the circumstances attending the loss of the U. S. transport steamer San Francisco, and such other matters as may relate to the embarkation of the troops and the conduct of the officers and men of the command, commenced its sessions yesterday morning at the headquarters of General SCOTT, the Commander-in-Chief, at No. 114 West Eleventh-street.

In the Senate yesterday Gen. SHIELDS from the Committee on the subject of the wreck of the steamship San Francisco, and measures of acknowledgement to those engaged in the rescue of her passengers, made a report which will meet the approval of the great majority of the people.

The spirit of intolerance which characterizes the movement marking by Mr. DOUGLAS and his friends to force the Nebraska bill through, without giving the opposition fair opportunity for discussion, displayed itself again on Saturday last.

(Before Hon. Recorder Tillon.) The calendar for this term presents a decrease of crime on a late months, but the cases are, many of them, of a serious character. Two are for murder, two for assault with intent to kill, four for robbery, and three for burglary.

Nothing of very special interest in railroad matters has transpired to-day. Gov. BIGLER and the Directors of the Western road are in consultation, detailing the arrangement for continuing its business, but up to this writing the result of their deliberations was not known to outsiders.

W. P. CHILTON and SAMUEL F. RICE, are elected Judges of the Supreme Court in Alabama. The Tennessee River at Chattanooga, on Saturday, had fallen to a good boating tide. The Tallahassee Sentinel, of the 31st ult., says the steamer James L. Teay broke in tow in the Spanish Hole, and had been towed into St Marks unfit for further service.

The Assembly was suddenly dissolved, while the reading of the journal was going on, this morning, by the announcement that the Franklin House was on fire. Some Members boarded there, and the interest in their chattels predominated over their sense of duty as legislators.

A large proportion of this morning's TIMES is devoted to the Annual Report of the City Comptroller, for the year ending Dec. 31, 1853. The Report exhibits the gratifying result of a surplus in the City Treasury, to the amount of $896,110 exclusive of the Sinking Funds.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--That "most epleasaunte comedie called a Midsummer Night's Dreame, wythe the freakes of the fayries"--as CHETWOOD has it--was produced here last evening. It is surely an event in the dramatic history of New York that this masterpiece of imagination should be produced in the best possible manner at two of our popular places of amusement within a week.

There has been less activity in the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets this week, and the excitement in CORN trade has been succeded by dullness; but large speculative operations have again taken place in Baltic produce, at considerably enhanced prices. MONEY is in demand, without change in the Bank rate of discount. The Bank of France has raised the rate to 5 ?? cent.

The debate in the Senate to-day on the Nebraska bill was rather exciting. Mr. WADE's speech was a rasping, effective effort, calculated to make a decided impression upon his section of the country. It was full of most excellent material, worked up in some points, however, hardly as judiciously as it might have been.

Pursuant to a notice published last Friday and Saturday, in the daily papers of our City, a very large and enthusiastic meeting of Italians assembled on Monday evening, at the Stuyvesant Institute. The hall was defusely crowded, every seat being occupied long before the hour fixed for the commencement of proceedings.

The afternoon session of the Assembly, yesterday was full of sound and fury, signifying nothing. The first motion was made by Mr. SESSIONS to refer the bill for the suppression of Intemperance to a Select Committee to report complete, it was supposed that any proposition which he might make, which would expedite the passage, would meet with a prompt support from the majority. Not so.

SECOND DAY. Gen. WINFIELD SCOTT, Presiding. The Court met pursuant to yesterday's adjournment. Present-all the members, the Judge Advocate and Col. W. GATES, being also in attendance. The proceedings of yesterday were first read to the Court by Major LEE, the Judge Advocate. -Col. GATES asked leave to introduce Captain SHIELDS, of the U. S. Army, to aid him in his business now before the Court, to which the Court assented.

INCENDIARY FIRE.--On Monday evening about 11 o' clock a fire broke out a row of cheap frame tenements owned by S. P. TOWNSEND, located in Court-Street between Mill-street and Hamilton-avenue, near Gowanus, which was entirely destroyed with the exception of one tenement.

THE STEAMER COMMODORE.--A meeting of passengers on board the steamer Commodore, of the Stoning-ton line, was held on the evening of the 4th instant, to remonstrate against the overcrowding of that vessel with freight and baggage. Mr. JOSEPH E. HOLMES, of this City, was selected as Chairman of the meeting, and Mr. THOS. B. BARNABY acted a Secretary.

The steamship Daniel Webster, from San Juan Nicaragua, arrived at the Balize at 4 o'clock this (Monday) morning. She brings dates from California to the 15th January,--120 passengers--and $13,000 specie on freight. The passage from San Francisco has occupied only 20 1/2 days.

Mr. JONES, of Iowa, moved to take up the hill granting alternate sections of public land, for twelve miles wide, to Minnesota, to aid that Territory in the construction of railroads therein. Agreed to.

On Tuesday afternoon. Feb 7, after a brief illness. ANNA CORA, daughter of John L. and Emeline Everitt, aged 3 years and 3 months. The friends of the family are requested to attend the funeral, without further invitation, from the residence of her parents, 10th-av. and 146th-st, on Thursday afternoon. at 3 o'clock.

In the House today, the amendment to the Constitution, by which the plurality system in elections is substituted for the majority system, was adopted by a vote of 226 Yeas to 46 Nays. The amendment had previously passed the Senate. The next Legislature must also pass it by a two-thirds vote, and the people accept it, before it becomes a law.

At 3 o'clock this morning, a fire broke out in this city, in a boarding-house occupied by some dozens of persons. When discovered, the flames had made such headway, as to cut off all chance to the inmates of escape by the doorway. An awful spectacle ensued. The frantic inmates were seen at the windows, surrounded, by flames, and shrieking for help. Four children were thrown into the streets,
HAVANA, Wednesday, Feb. 1, 1854.

NEW-YORK HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY.--A regular monthly meeting of the New-York Horticultural Society,was hell at No 600 Broadway, Monday evening--the Vice President, JOHN GROSHEN, in the Chair. The minites of the ]ast meeting were read and approved, after which Mr. ANDREW REED moved that the Society have an exhibition in the month of May.

The Duchess of ORLEANS, who married the son of LOUIS PHILIPPE, declines to join the league by which both the Bourbon and Orleans claimants to the throne have agreed to acknowledge the rights of the Count of CHAMBORD. She still claims that perquistle for her son--The grandson of LOUIS PHILIPPE; and she cannot, therefore, yield her acknowledgement to the doctrine of legitimacy.

The action of our Police authorities, in breaking up the Lottery swindling establishments recently exist ing in the business streets of this City, has been the means of doing good The suppression of this illegal business originated with the arrests of the brothers McDONALD (on the warrant of Justice WELSH,) while at their secret apartments iu John-street.

Dr. SOLGER commences the repetition of his series of lectures on European Politics, to morrow evening, at Hope Chapel. We speak only the unanimous opinion of all who have heard these lectures, in saying that they are altogether the most instructive and interesting discussions of this important subject yet brought within reach of our citizens. MYSTERIOUS AFFAIR.--Yesterday morning two Germans, named WILLIAM DUNKIRK and WEIDMISTER, pocketbook manufacturers, residing in Ross-street, near Wilson-street, East Brooklyn, were found in their bed, the former dead and the latter in a senseless state, from which it was impossible to remove him during the day, and it is supposed that the cannot recover.

BOARD OF TEN GOVERNERS.--The Board of Ten Governors held their regular weekly meeting in the Rotunda, yesterday afternoon at 4 P. M. Present, the President (DRAPER,) Governors TOWNSEND, PINCKNEY, HENRY, DUKE. The usual requisitions were read and the customary action taken in reference thereto.

Our city is now the centre of attraction for Agriculturists--The annual meeting of the State Agricultural Society, and the Poultry Exhibition. calling from all parts of the State, ?? in such matters. The Executive Board of the Agricultural Society most last evening for the transaction of business. Their proceedings have not transpired.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: We candldly believe that there is hardly a gentleman in France-nay, in Spain or Italy-who could restrain himself from challenging and slapping the face of any individual who would venture to compare that gentleman's wife or mother to MARGARET of Burgundy.

Mr. COEDEN has been setting forth the beauties of the secular system of education, at a large meeting at Manchester; preparatory to a fresh bill being brought in next session. The question is not likely to be burked, since Lord JOHN RUSSELL has promised to introduce. his scheme--a very fair one of its kind, if Parliament would only let him pass it;

At the meeting of the State Agricultural Society, belt this afternoon, the following officers were chosen: President--WILLIAM KELLY, Rainebeck. Datchest Co. vice presidents--1st District. John C Jackson New-York; 2d. A. B Conger Rockland; 3d George Ved, Renesseber; 4th, Lerey Mowre, Washington; 5h, Jan n land, 7th, Daniel H. Abell, Livingston; 8t, Silas M, Bunungas, Oileans.

We call upon the Chief of Police to send a detachment of his force to arrest Mr. GENIN and commit him to the Tombs. He was guilty of an offence yesterday which a week ago consigned some thirty or forty children to that dismal receptacle: and we take it for granted he will not he allowed to do with impunity acts for which they were so promptly punished.

Before Judge WILLIAMS, this morning, McCLOSKEY'S administrators obtained a verdict against the Prnns; Lvama Railroad for $4.500 McCLOSKEY was conveying berses from Pittsburg to Philadelphia, when he was killed, in March last, by a cellions near New on. The defence set up was that he was on the wrong car at the time of the accident.

The statements that the Cabinet have decided not to send the Gadsden Treaty to the Senate, is unfounded. There was another Cabinet meeting over it to-day, and it will probably be sent to the Sepate to-morrow. Dr. CHARLES EVANS, late of the Union, was confumed to-day to Venezuela.

The investigation in relation to the forged drafts of the Hamilton Exchange Bank, which has been pending before the Jefferson Mirket Police Court for several months past, was terminated yesterday by the decision of Justice STUART. We give the decision below, in full.

THOMAS, M. D. Philadelhpia: LIPPINCOTT, CRAMBO Co. This is the best Gazetter that has yet been published in this country.

A late number of the Westminster Review, under the head of "Political and Social Science," has the following significant paragraph: "Strange as it may appear, we are beginning to receive from America books which, admitting the insufficiency of asserting the errors of the principles on which the fathers of the Republic based their action, seek other foundations of political organization and power.

THE FISHERIES.--Mr. SABINE, of Framingham, who has been writing a long document on the subject of the fisheries, has sent an estimate to the Glouester Telegraph of the Cod, mackerl and hering fisheris of the Amreican seas. The number of American vessels engaged in the business is 3,160; British 3.775; French, 580.

On Wednesday, Feb. 1, 1854, by Rev. E. F. Hatfield, MANNING F. HATCHER to MARIAN, daughter of Wm T. Moore, of Rahway, New Jersey. At Hartford, Conn., on Tuesday, Feb. 7, by Rev. Mr. to HELEN, daughter of William C. Spark, of Glastenbury, Conn.

At an early hour yesterday morning, Mr, H. E. STEVENS, for many years Stage Manager of the Bowery. Theatre, died at his residence, from the effects of injuries received some days since, while wrestling in sport with a personal friend. An inquest was held on the body yesterday afternoon by Coroner HILTON. The following testimony was taken:

Music FOR THE BLIND.--We wish to introduce to the notice of those readers who may be interested in the information, a very ingenious Self Instructor for the Piano-forte, containing a new system of notation, for the use of the Blind. This system is the invention of Mr. C. MAHONY, a blind musician, residing at the NewYork Institution for the Blind.

We have received from Albany a copy of the Report of the Joint Committee on Commerce and Navigation of the Senate and Assemby, in reference to the Encioachments upon the Harbor of New-York. The Report was presented in the Senate on Tuesday, by Mr. ERASTUS BROOKS, of this City, Chairman of the Committee.

We publish in full, in this morning's TIMES the elaborate decision of Justice STUART in the long-pending case of VAN AERNUM and other who have been under examination for uttering forged checks of the Familton Bank, this State.

DAMAGES REFUSED FOR INJURIES FROM JUMPING UPON A TRAIN WHILE IN MOTION.--In the Supreme Court, in the case of Catharine Crosse us. the South Reading Branch Railroad Company, the Jury retired at about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and at 9 o'clock this morning, after being out all bight, they returned into Court with a verdict for the defendants.

THIRD DAY. Pursuant to adjournment this Courtof Inquiry assembled yesterday morning at 101/2 o'clock, at the Head Quarters of the United States Army, No. 114 Eleventhstreet. The proceedings were commenced by the Judge Advosate (Major LEE) reading the minutes of the last meeting. Lieutenant S. I.. FREMONT was then recalled, and forther examined by the Judge Advocate:

The Chair laid before the Senate a communication from the War Department, transmitting an abstract of the returns of the Militia of the United States. THE FRIENDS ON SLAVERY. Mr. BRODHEAD presented memorials from the Society of Friends in Pennsylvania, New-Jersey and Delaware, against the continuance of domestic slavery, and remonstrating against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise.

For seventeen good years the great Southern travel, with the United States mails, have passed from Wilmington to Charleston by sea steamers, the number employed in the regular mail service being four. There was no other Southern way of getting from New York, Philadelphia, and Baltimore to NewOileans, before the establishment of our present steamerlines to Charleston and Sa vannah.

During the entire history of the endeavors to obtain relief by the exteading of Aloany street to Broadway, all have ackno-ledged that relief must be had, but some have p inted to the widening of Fhames-street as a suffient relief. I have before said that this relief would have been accepted, and the Albany street extension abandoned, had not the authorities of Frinity Church refused to cooperate in that arrange eat.

There is a strong movement made at Albany to prevent the passage of the bill fixing some limit to the exactions which the Corporation Counsel of this City practices upon its inhabitants, under the name of fees for opening streets. The bill was for a long time in the hands of the Judiciary Committee,composed of lawyers and supposed not to sympathize very strongly with efforts to reduce the emoluments of any branch of their profession.

" CYMRUFU, CYMRU FYDD."--An adjourned meeting of Welshmen and descendants of Wales was held at the McChunts Institue, corner of Bowery and Division-street, last evening, for the purpose of making further arrangements a for celebrating the approaching Cambrian National Anniversay of the Birth St. David.

Before Judge Clerke. Ruckman agt. Pitcher.-This case, which is a little Jarndyce vs. Jarndyce in itself, reached its third trial on Tuesday It arose from the following facts: About thirteen years ago, we believe it was on the 21st October, 1841, a trotting match came off between the horses Lady Suffolk and Americus, on the Centreville Course, on Long Island.

BOYD, of Astoria, was finally closed on Monday evening, at the Jefferson Police Court, before Justise STUART. The case was fully recapitulated by counsel on both sides. The magistrate's decision is received Some additional testimony was taken, to the foil wing effect:

The work on the Lower Falls is progressing most satisfactorily and Messrs. MAILLEFERT RAASLOFF, the contractors, have, notwithstanding the extremely low state of the water, succeeded in opening a channel through a great portion of the ledge of rocks, and expect to complete a channel through the Lower Falls, 30 feet wide and 6 feet deep, within some few daya.
The friends of the Erie Canal, at Baffalo, have put forth an urgent address in favor of a full vote on Wednesday, 15th February, at the special election, to ratify the amendment to the Constitution.

The Finance Committee of the Board of Councilmen has been charged, by resolution of that bony, with the duty of inquiring into the expediency of purchasing the old Brick church property on Beekman.street. The terns of the resolution are concise.

In the last number of the Southern Medical Journal, Dr J. S. WILSON, of Alabama, urges the formation of classes of females in our Medical Colleges. Separate schools, he objects to as likely to increase the number of Medical Collges beyond our ability to support them.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the published account of the great meeting in favor of Religious Liberty, one of the speakers, Mr. HIRAM KETCHUM, is represented as having said: "There may be men coming from foreign countries, preaching to us that we do not know the doctrines of our WASHINGTON--that we have never understood them; but, my friends, they will go out of the country with disgrace."

LONG ISLAND RAILROAD.--At the last meeting of the Common Council, the Assessment Committee reported in relation to the regulation of the grades of the Long Island Railroad and Atlantic avenue, and recommended that a petition be forwarded to the Legislature to repeal the act passed April 13, 1853, entitled "An act relative to Railroats on Long Island ;" also in favor of applying to the Legislature to alter the Commistinners'

Many will wonder how it should happen that the burials in this City last week were 49 more than during the preceding seven days. The weather experienced several sudden changes, indeed, and a superficial observer might charge it to that. But few diseases are of such quick maturity that a change of weather should show its influence through them upon the mortality table witain a week's time.

The rioters were quiet during Saturday, and the Railroad Company busy repairing the depredations which had been committed on their depot ground some weeks since. The Governor and the Superintendent, Gen. PACKER, have made a contract with the Directors of the Cleveland, Painsville and Ashtabuia Railroad Companies, to ran the road of the Franklin Canal Company.

AUGUSTINE GROIIAN, the best soubrette on the French stage, is, at the age of 26, losing her eyesight. I write this paragraph with unmingled grief. The physicians have no hope-the shadow is settling over her, and in six months she will be irremediably blind. S She has retired to small country seat in the neighborhood of Paris, where she continues to receive the literary notabilities of the city.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Would the repeal, at this time, of the Missouri compromise place the politics of the country back in their original position, as suggested by J. W. the T. in your issue of the 27th? Would it deprive the great Northwest of the effects of the Slavery prohibition, as contained in the Ordinance of 1787, and successfully recnacted by Congress in each of their territorial organic laws,

On the 25th Dec. Dr. JAMES GILLKREST, Inspector General of Army Hospitals. This vetern medical officer entered the medical department of the A may in 1801, and served as furton to the Forty third throughout the Peninsular war, for which he received a medal with 12 clasps. After an arodus and eventful career of 41 years active service, he was promoted to the rank of Inspector General of Hospitals,

On Tuesday, Feb. 7, after a brief illness, ANNA CORA, daughter of John L. and Emeline Everitt, aged 3 years and 3 months The friends of the family are requested to attend the funeral, without further invitation, from the residence of her parents, 10th av. and 146th st. this (Thursday) after noon, at 3 o'clock.

As a prelude to the more important business of the day, an interesting little debate occurred on the propriety of admitting ladies to seats in the lobby, or, in other words of similar meaning, to constitute them lobby members problem. Senator HOUSTON couldn't see any particular harm in so doing, but Senators WELLER and PRATT saw a great deal.

In response to a very limited notice, the Park street Church, in this city, was densely packed this evening to hear an address from Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER on the present attitude of the Slavery question, as influenced by the pending Nebraska bill. Every seat, aisle, window and standing spot was occupied.

Scarcely a day elapses, but, either by letter or by personal application, we are asked what are the chances for teachers from the country to secure positions in our, public schools. We shall save a deal of postage and many an hour of time by answering them in the lump.

Our latest news from Italy confirms every rumor that has reached us respecting the fermentation occasioned in that country by the mere approach of war. Unless the Government of Austria openly and frankly declares against Russia, all Lombardy will rise, like one man, against her, at the first cannon shot.

Service of Plate to A. M. Cozzens, Esq. We have already mentioned the fact that a number of the friends of American Art, embracing same of the most distinguished of our citizens, have unused in presenting a service of Plate to A. M. COZZENS, Esq, late President of the Art-Union, as a mark of their appreciation of his services in the promotion of American Art.

BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. The Recorder in the Chair. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. EXPENSES OF THE CORONERS' OFFICE. The Committee reported in favor of paying the bills of the four Corners, amounting to $4,3105 87 1/2.

Tired of the everlasting noise about Nebraska,--weary with hearing again and again the reasons for heeding or neglecting the Missouri Compromise--to hear the old politicians at Washington talking of seeds and plants and agriculture, affects one as does a vision of trees, waving grain, and green pastures while closely confined in the city.

The Council Board, last evening, assumed possession of its new Chamber. The room is by far the handsomest in the City Hall. It is constituted from the old Superior Court Chambers, and is nearly twice the length of the Chamber of Allermen.

Democratic Republican General Committee. RESOLUTIONS ON THE CANAL LAW. The Democratic Republican General Commit tee held their regular meeting last evening, at the Stayvesant Institute, Broadway,--Mr. R. SCHELL in the Chair. On motion, Messrs MEAD, CARS0N and ALDEN were appointed to draft resolutions relative to the proposed amendments to the Canal law.

PROVISIONS--Bacon continues in good demand, but a decline of 1s Q2s, is yield to clear parcels PK ship. There is not much doing in Beet and Pork-buyers resist the high prices and supply themselves from day to day. Cheese searce and wanted Lard is steady at full rates. Tallow maintains extreme rates last advised.
The entire Afternoon Session has been passed in discussing the 17th section of the Temperance bill, and no progress made. The Committee of the Whole reported progress and asked leave to sit again.

The U. S. Mail steamship Pacific sailed from Liverpool, Wednesday, Jan. 25, about 2 o'clock in the afternoon, and arrived at this port at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The steamship Pacific sailed at 6 o'clock P. M., Jan. 25, and has had very heavy westerly gales the entire passage--the most severe the Pacific ever encountered.

MARINE COURT. Before Judge Thompson. Kurshadt against Ertiger.-- On the 10th of December, 1852, the defendant bought of Myers H. Cohn. a bill of tobacco amounting to $820 10, upon which payments have since been made, leaving a balance due, of $688,64, which, on the 28 h of October, 1853, was assigned by Cohn to the plaintiff.

PUBLIC SCHOOLS IN BROOKLYN.--The Annual Report of the Superintendent of the Common Schools of Brooklyn shows the following results: The number of Schools in the City is 15, including 2 for colored children; and the number of children taught is 20,527. This is an excess of 1,307 pupils over the number instructed during the previous year.

Feb. 9, at St. Clement's Church, by Rev. Theodore A. Eaton. WILLIAM B. ROBINSON, to HENRIETTA LOUISA PIERCE all of this City. On Feb. 8, in the order of the Society of Friends, ABEL ADAMS, of Marlborough, N. Y., to HANNAH y. BRUFF, of this City.

Mr. HAVENS, whose death we noticed yesterday, was from Shelter Island, Saff lk Co, in this State; whither his ancestors immigrated in 1699, from the Province of Rhode Island. His elder brother, JONATHAN NICOLL HAVENS, died while a member of Congress, during the Administration of THOMAS JEFFERSON.

The steamship Star of the West, Capt. E. L. TINKLEPAUGH, 8 1/2 days from San Joan, with 407 passengers and $749,620 in gold, to CHARLES MORGAN, arrived yesterday. We areindebted to Purser FOSTER, and to the Express agents of Messrs. WELLS, FARGO CO., ADAMS Co., and BERFORD Co., early attentions.

The matter of establishing a line of Mail steamers between the city of Brooklyn and various ports in continental Europe, was brought to the remembrance of the Senate yesterday, by the presentation of certain postal and commercial statistical tables having some bearing on that subject, which is deemed one of vast importance by the people of that city.

The nomination of ex-Governor VROOM, of New-Jersey, Minister to Prussia, was confirmed to-day, as was that of DANIEL E. SICKELS, of New-York, Secretary of Legation at London, and that of R. AUGUSTUS IRVING, of Connecticut, Secretary of Legation at St. Petersburg.

The amendment to the Nebraska bill which Mr. DOUGLAS presented to the Senate to-day, as the result of a caucus agreement, is a very ingenious device, and one that will probably accomplish its purpose--not because it expresses sentiments upon which those who vote for it can unite, but because it presents upon its face specious excuses and apologies which cover up the real purpose, just as the sugar does Dr SMITH'S coated pills.

The Alleged Murder Two Years Ago. INVESTIGATION BEFORE JUSTICE STEWART.-- Yesterday afternoon, the investigation respecting the alleged charge of murder pending against two men named PAUL RITTER and DAVID REED, was resumed before Judge STUART, at the Jefferson Police Court.

The Exhibition of Poultry now open at Van Vechten Hall, State-street, is certainly the most extensive and superb ever held in the Empire State. Over three hundred coops, and nearly fifteen hundred fowls, of every known variety, have been sent in, and such a cackling and crowing as rings from the hall the good people of the town have never heard before.

Mr. SEWARD presented certain postal and commercial statistical tables having some bearing upon the application for the establishment of a line of mail steamers between Brooklyn and various ports in Continental Europe. Referred. Numerous petitions were presented.

The Star of the West came in yesterday and poured her budget of news as usual into the DAILY TIMES, where upon our third page it may this morning be found, "How get on the Fillibusters?" will be the first question put, on seeing it.

The Herald has abandoned all attempts to obtain the Washington news from its own Correspondents. It copies regularly from other papers, and mainly from the Philadelphia North American. This certainly shows good judgment, as the Washington Correspondent of the DAILY TIMES writes the letters for that paper.

At Brooklyn, Feb. 9, Mrs. ELIZABETH GAULT, aged 93 years, relict of Mr. Robert Gaols. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from st. Ann's Church, Washington st., on Saturday afternoon, Feb. 11, at 2 o'clock.

SATURDAY MORNING, 3 o'clock--it falls to our lot his morning to chronicle the most destructive fire that has occurred in our city for many years. About 11 o'clock last night, the store of Messrs. MORRISONS MARABLE was discovered to be on fire.

The Annual Report of Mr. HENRY ARCULARIUS, Jr., Commissioner of Streets and Lamps, was presented to the Board of Councilmen last evening. The document is chiefly statistical, and we cannot publish voluminous tables this morning. The statements of the Commissioner exhibit a comfortable condition of affairs in his Department.

The Chair decided that no business was in order but private bills. Mr. PETTIT obtained unanimous consent to report private bills from the House. They were the bill extending the time for filing certain private land claims in California, and a bill confirming a private land claim in Wisconsin. Both were passed. The bill for the relief of the heirs of Lieut. WICKLIFFE was taken up.

Governor CROSBY delivered his Message to the Legislature on Wednesday. It is almost entirely local in its topics. Finances, Education, Internal Improvements, , of the State, are represented to be in a flourishing condition.

A man named JAMES PHILLIPS has abaconded from Winsborough, South Carolina, taking with him $10,000 belonging to Messrs. FISHER, AGNEW Co., Columbia. $5,000 reward is offered for his apprentension and the recovery of the money.

THE KNICKERBOCKER FOR FEBRUARY.--Our good friend, and everybody's friend, the genial, hearty Knickerbocker, is in full strength this month. The "Fudge Papers," by Ik Marvel, are continued. They barely sustain his reputation, but they are good and racy. An article on Sir JOHN SUCKLING affords the best criticism of that poet which we have ever met with.

Steamship George Law, JOHN McGOWAN, Esq., commanding, left Aspinwall at 7 1/4 A M., on the 1st inst., and arrived at Quarantine this morning, at 9 o'clock. After passing Cape San Antonio, she encountered heavy weather, with the exception of a single day, until she arrived at Sandy Honk.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times There appeared in your paper a few days since an editorial in relation to the controversy which has for some time existed between the Ladies' Home Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church and Mr. PEASE, of the House of Industry, accompanied by an article signed by JOHN STEPHENSON, copied from the New-York Courier and Enquirer.

1. A General Term of the Marine Court of the City of New-York shall be held on each Saturday, at 11 o'clock A. M., except during the months of July and August. 2. Trial and Special Terms will be held daily, (Saturdays excepted,) at 10 o'clock A. M. 3. The Calendar of "returned cases" will be called at 10 o'clock A. M., is the Clerk's office, where the pleadings will be entered.

Captain STURTEVANT, of bark Sarah Bridge, arrived at Havana on January 13, reports that on the 4th of January he fell in with the ship Constantine, from New-York for Liverpool, twenty-one days out. The Constantine had been struck by a heavy sea, which carried away a large portion of her spar-deck, shifted cargo, and nearly filled her with water.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. The question has been repeatedly asked, Does the Government still intend to send this shattered Regiment again to sea, en route for California? Can you give us any probable reply? It is well known that the officers and men lost everything. How are they to fit out?

We publish in another part of this morning's TIMES a letter from Mr. C. C. NORTH, in vindication of the Ladies' Five Points Mission, from the allegation said to have been brought against them, that they minister only to the spiritual wants of the degraded objects of their care, leaving their physical necessities unrelieved.

Hon. TRUMAN SMITH addressed the Senate today in continuance of this Nebraska discussion, presenting many excellent ideas, and making not a few strong points against the bill in his own plain, practical, common sense way. He had not concluded, however, when he gave way for a motion to go into Executive Session.

At the evening session yesterday, Mr. CROCHERON, of Richmond County, submitted an act to amend the act relating to the Commissioners of Emigration, and for the regulation of the Marine Hospital. It enacts: 1. The time allowed under the second section of the act of 1850, to the owner of any ship bringing emigrants to this port, to give the first bonds therein mentioned, shall be twenty-four hours instead of three days as at present.

Our American correspondence discloses some very remarkable facts respecting the condition of the United States fleet. It seems to have been recently discovered, or "realized," that the Navy of this great Naval Power has no substantial existence, and complaints are made upon the point in a style precisely ?? that sometimes adopted nearer home.

To the Hon Secretary of the Treasury: You propose to repeal the duty on linen fabrics, because the current revenue is more than is wanted for the current expenses of the Government. As before stated, you recognize the principle of protection by imposing high duties on articles produced or manufactured in the United States; admitting duty free articles which we do not produce or manufacture, and which are used in the arts or in manufactures.

A LOVE AFFAIR-ATTEMPTED SUICIDE OF A FORLORN SWAIN.-Quite an interesting case of attempted suicide, resulting from a disappointment in love, occurred in this City, a day or two since. A young gentleman, named HENRY STIMSON, employed in East Twenty-third street, suddenly left the establishment on Tuesday, and was not heard of for Forty-eight hours afterward.

Present-General SCOTT, President: General STANTON, Colonel SUMNER, Colonel GATES, and his counsel, Captain SHIELDS, with other officers, were in attendance. The record of the preceding day was read by Major LEE, the Judge Advocate.

It is a very good arrangement this by Which the Californian, Oregon, and Polynesian news comes to us by one steamer, and that from South America, the Isthmus and Australia, reaches us a day or two later. It is a great accommodation to editors who sometimes find it very inconvenient to make room for full details from all quarters of the globe, in one sheet, however ample.

On Saturday evening, Feb. 11, FRANKLIN PIERCE, infant son of John F. and Catharine Soloman, aged 7 months. The friends of the Nebraska bill contemplate making an effort to-morrow to get the subject before the House; and if they find themselves sufficiently strong, to rush it through under the "previous question."

The Registration Tables for the month of December, required by law to be ready by the third Monday of the succeeding month, have been delayed in consequence of the confusion attending the removal of the City Inspector's office from the New City Hall. The office is now permanently situated at No. 6 Centre street.

ANNUAL FESTIVAL OF THE HAMILTON LITERARY ASSOCIATION.--The twenty-fourth Annual Festival of this Society was held Friday evening at the Globe Hotel. This Society was organized in 1830, and many of its early and present members occupy the most responsible positions in society. About 50 members assembled last evening, among whom we noticed Judge GREENWOOD. H.B. DURYEA.

In the SENATE, on the 8th of February, the bill to establish a Territorial Government in Nebraska being under discussion. Mr. EVERETT said: Mr. PRESIDENT, I intimated to the Senate yesterday that, if time had been al lowed, I should have been glad to submit to the Senate my views at some length in relation to some of the grave constitutional and political principles and questions involved in the measure before us.

The first of May is moving-day in New-York, as all the world knows. The first of February is notice-day between landlord and tenant, as we have already told our readers. The house, or shop, or office, not secured at this time, passes into new hands at the close of the quarter, being in regular course the close of the lease year, unless accident or compromise wills it otherwise.

AFFAIRS AT THE NAVY-YARD.--The Navy Yard presents a dull appearance at the present time, compared with what it did a few months since. A few mechanics and laborers are to be seen, however, at the different works, making preparations for more extensive operations, as soon as the season will permit.

There has been more honest indignation wasted on the dirty condition of our streets, than on almost any other abuse which we are obliged to tolerate. Public sentiment has lifted up its voice like a trumpet, and done as much good as the tooting of the penny trumpet of a schoolboy. We are an independent people. We govern ourselves.

We publish this morning the closing letter of the series which has been for some months in course of publication in our columns, upon the Productions, Industry and Resources of the Southern States. Our correspondent, in the closing paragraph, gives so clear a statement of the circumstances of his engagement to write them, as to render needless any remarks of our own upon the same point.

The Royal Mail steamship Africa, Capt, HARRISON, from Liverpool on Saturday morning, Jan. 28, came inside the Hook about 7 o'clock this evening, and anchored at the Southwest Spit, owing to the prevalence of a thick fog. The screw steamship Alps, from New York, arrived out at Liverpool at noon, on Thursday, 26th ultimo.

We have to congratulate the public on the abdication of Mr. HENRY ARCULARIUS, the Street Commissioner. His resignation was sent in to the Board of Aldermen last night, to take effect on the 31st of March. No

Our citizens for some days past have been in much excitement in anticipation of the execution of DAVID JEWELL, which was fixed for to day. The singularity of his case, the great influence he brought to bear in his behalf in high places, and the many hopes and disappointments with which he has been agitated during the past year, have made him the object of much more than ordinary interest.
The Senate Chamber was yesterday inundated with petitions and remonstrances against the Nebraska bill; all of which, how ever, did not prevent a speech from Senator WELLER in its favor.

CONSOLIDATION--LAST MEETING OF THE COM MISSIONERS--The Commissioners on the Consolidation of the cities of Brooklyn and Williamsburg and town of Bush wick, under one municipal government, held a meeting at the Mayor's Office last evening to complete their business.

A Message of an important character was received in both branches of the Legislature to day. The law revoking the charter of the Franklin Canal Company, made it the duty of the Governor to take such measures as might be necessary to carry provisions into effect.

MASSACHUSETTS RESOLUTIONS ON THE NEBRASHA BILL.--On Saturday the Massachusetts Senate passed, by a unanimous vote, a series of resolutions against the Nebraska Bill, The resolutions use firm and decided but calm language. They propose no instructions to Senators or Representatives in Congress, but express what is unquestionably the almost universal sentiment of the people of that State upon the subject. Wednesday was marked in this locality by the third disastrous flood that has occurred in the Naugatuck Valley this season, and in which the Railroad, more particularly, has suffered interrupt on and damage to an extent hitherto unprecedented. Additional proceeding were had yesterday before Judge STUART, at the Jefferson Police Court, respecting the alleged seduction of a young girl named CORDELIA A. GRANT, by a person of wealth named GEORGE R. SHACKFORD, who resides at Fordham, Westchester County, N. Y. The complainant in the case is connected with a highly respectable family residing at Portland, Maine and when first brought to this City was not quite 16 years of age.

On Sunday morning, Feb 12, of scirlatina, CAROLINE ELIZABETH, youngest daughter of Townsend V. and Frances A. Roe, aged 2 years 8 months and 4 days. The friends of the family, Perry Chapter O. U. A., and Blooming Grove Lodge, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of her father, No. 274 West 36th st., to-day, (Tuesday,) at 1 o'clock, without further invitation.

Last evening was the occasion at the Astor House of the Annual Ball of the City Light Guard, of which Capt. EDWARD VINCENT is the honored Commander. This Corps is one of the oldest in date, as it is has always been one of the most distinguished and select of the City Military. Their festive occasions are uniformly

Mr. GADSDEN was confirmed to-day Minister to Mexico--Senator HOUSTON alone voting against him. To-morrow Senator HOUSTON will oppose the Nebraska bill-declaring that it is ruinous to the South and unjust to the North.

DISCOURSE TO DEA-MUTES.--Prof. CLERC, an instructor in the American Asylum for the Deaf and Dumb, at Hartford, Ct., addressed an audience of Deaf Mutep, in the University, last Saturday evening. The Professor, who is himself a deaf mute, is by birth a Frenchmen, and was a pupil of the celebrated Abbe LICARD. He came to this country with Dr. GALLAUDET,

The Dissection bill in the Council Board -- the question of the construction of the fourth section of the Amended Charter in the Board of Alder men, and the resignation of Mr. HENRY ARCULARIUS, the much beset Commissioner of Streets and Lamps--produced altogether a lively evening's session of the Corporation Boards yesterday.

PROJECT OF A WORKHOUSE.--A County Work house, for the employment of prisoners at labor, is in contemplation in Hudson County, such buildings having been erected with successful results in other counties in the State of New-Jersey. The Board of Chosen Free holders have designated the following Committee to select a site for such a building: Messrs Carpenter, Morgan, Soule, Youngs, Chamberlain, Banta, Knapp and Vreeland.

SUICIDE IN PLYMOUTH, VT.--The Brattleboro Statesman meations the suicide of O. K. FAREWELL, a young man who shot himself in a part of Plymouth called Frog City, on Sunday, the 13th ult. He married last Fall a girl seventeen years of age, whom he met at Wood stock Fair a week previous. His wife refused to live with

Notwithstanding the advices from America tending to improve the market, the critical state of European affairs has caused all descriptions to be freely offered, and, at times, pressed for sale; prices, therefore, were very irregular. American descriptions, of the better qualities down to low middling, are fully 1/6d. lb, lower.

From the Norfolk (Va.) Argus. We publish to-day the judgment of Hon. Judge BAKER in the case of Mrs. DOUGLASS, which has much excited our citizens. The first time within the passage of the act forbidding the teaching of slaves or free colored persons to read or write, has a case of this discription come under the jurisdiction of the Court, and it was singular that this case should be a woman. Licutenant Governor NESBITT opened the Babania Parliament--the Governor having died during the recess. In his opening address he alludes to this feelingly, congratulates the Colony on its considerable freedom from cholera but recognizes the warning offered by its close approach, and advises sanitary reforms. There was another numerous and brilliant gathering of spectators in the Senate Chamber yesterday, to hear Senator HOUSTON'S speech on the Nebraska bill. Previous to the calling up of the bill another formidable batch of petitions and remonstrances were presented against it.

Mr. O'SULLIVAN was confirmed in the Senate to-day, by a decided vote. The vote, however, was subsequently reconsidered, and the subject was laid over. Mr. GEORGE SAUNDERS' nomination for Consul to London, was rejected by a large vote.

AN INDIAN TREATY FORMED.--The St. Joseph Gazette. of the 1st inst., learns that Major GATEWOOD, Indian Agent, had concluded a treaty with the Omaha Indians, by which they cede all their lands lying on the Missouri River, from the mouth of the Platte River to the Iowa River, to the United States.

The GADSDEN Treaty has been sent to the Senate at last; and it now rests with that body to decide its fate. The President and Cabinet, after frequent consultations, and with the aid of the American negotiator's personal explanations, have decided upon such amendments as are deemed necessary, and submitted them, also, to the treaty-making power.

The hour for argument on the question of Canal Enlargement has passed. The time for the popular vote on the proposed Amendment to the Constitution of the State of New-York, which, if adopted, is to authorize the early consummation of this important measure, has come.

At 3 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon several hundreds of the leading business men of the City assembled at the Merchants' Exchange, in response to a call previously issued, to give an expression of the feeling of our citizens upon the question of a speedy enlargement of our State Canals.

THE ACTION OF THE GRAND JURY ON THE POLICE--THE BEDINI RIOTERS, SO CALLED.--The Grand Jury have reported concerning the late BEDINI trials in Cincinnati. They express their belief that the present system of the Police is inefficient and defective, and a radical change should be immediately made, and com mend the subject to the act on of the City Council and State Legislature.
The Cunard Mail steamship Africa, from Liverpool about 10 A. M. Saturday, the 28th ult., arrived in the Lower Bay, on Monday night, where she is still detained by the heavy fog.

The unsettled state of Foreign Politics continues to exercise an unfavorable influence on the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets, and only a moderate business has been transacted during the week, with the exception of Baltic produce, in which there has again been considerable speculation.

The Africa at a late hour last evening was still in the Lower Bay, having been prevented from coming up by the dense fog which prevailed in the harbor. We received our foreign packages, however, by our ship news collector, and present a full summary of the intelligence in another part of this morning's TIMES.

We beg to call the attention of the Administration, and of its peculiarly zealous champion, the Albany Argus, to the fact that a "three column Custom-House advertisement" makes its appearance again in this morning's TIMES. We hope the Argus will insist on knowing whether this is "by authority" or not.

Notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather, there was quite an assemblage of women present at the opening of the Convention this afternoon. SUSAN B. ANTHONY called the meeting to order, and made the following nominations.

The Ladies engaged in the Girls' Industrial School in Avenue D, held their first anniversary meeting last night at Hope Chapel. Although the night was stormy, the attendance was good and the proceedings were highly interesting.

BEFORE JUDGE STUART. The examination respecting the murder of an aged citizen named WM. FURLONG, in the month of March, 1852, was resumed yesterday before Justice STUART. The defendants, REED and RITTER, who stand charged with the perpetration of the awful crime, were arraigned, and WASHINGTON SECOR was further examined, as follows, by the Justice:

To the Newspaper Press. GENTLEMEN : Yesterday you published an ex parte statement of CORDELIA A. GRANT, implicating me in a criminal charge; may I not expect that you will do me the justice of publishing what I have to say as conspicuously? Yours, , CHAS. LOHMAN.

The galleries were crowded as early as 11 o'clock. On Mr. HOUSTON'S desk are piled up forty-eight large folio and quarto volumes, besides several packages of unbound documents, pamphlets, , , forming a barrier four feet above his desk, and behind which, when seated, Mr. Houston is invisible from the front.

A NEW CATHOLIC INSTITUTION AT EAST BOSTON--The 30,000 feet of land purchased a few days since at East Boston, by Rev. GEO. F. HASKINS, is adjacent to 60,000 feet previously purchased by him, and the whole is intended as a site for the eraction of large and substantial buildings for the "House of the Angel Guardian"--a Catholic charitable institution for boys, of which Mr. HASKINS is Rector.

In the House to-day the resolves in opposition to the Nebraska bill were passed to a third reading, by Yeas, 246; Nays, 13. The latter consisted of 11 Democrats and 2 Whigs. On the question of suspending the rules to pass the resolutions to be engrossed, a debate arose, in which Mr. WHITNEY, of Conway, Democrat, argued that no man has a right to legislate for Freedom or Slavery in other them his own State.

NATHAN C. ELY, Esq., in the Chair. POWER OF EXPENDING MONEY--DISPUTED CONSTRUCTION OF THE AMENDED CHARTER. Alderman WAKEMAN asked for a suspension of regular business to present the Report of Committee, appointed to inquire into the power of the Board of Aldermen under sec. 4 of the Amended Charter of 1853, to originate any measure involving an expenditure of money. Consent was granted.

In this City, on Tuesday, Feb. 14, BATHSHEBA ISAACS, the beloved wife of Moses Isaacs, aged 70 years. The friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No. 239 East 10th st., to-morrow, (Thursday,) at 10 1/2 o'clock A. M. In this City, Feb. 14, EDWARD H. MACY, aged 21 years, son of the late Edward H. and grandson of the late S. G Macy, of Hudson.

COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS. Before Hon. Escorder Tillon. At the sitting of the Court, yesterday morning, JAMES SAUNDERS, who, as marshal, directed the procession of the "Ancient Order of Hibernians" on the 5th of July last, was placed at the bar, under an indictment for riot in the Ninth Ward.

The right spirit pervades the commercial classes of this City on the Canal question, if all that was said and resolved yesterday at the Merchants' Exchange be a fair index of their purpose to act TO-DAY. The proceedings of the meeting will attract attention. Mr. GEORGE GRISWOLD presided; Mr. MOSES H. GRINNELL moved the resolutions.

RESOLUTIONS ON NEBRASKA AND SLAVERY. The Young Men's Democratic Republican Committee met last evening at Stuyvesant Institute. After the transaction of business, Mr. HART submitted the following resolutions, which were unanimously adopted without debate:

The Homeopathic Convention met here to-day--Dr. BALL, of New-York, presiding. Only twenty members were present. After the roll was called, several new members were elected. The order of business was suspended to receive reports of cases cured by a single remedy. Several cases were reported and discussed.

FOSTER BOSWORTH, late Postmaster of Troy, was arrested on Monday afternoon, in that city, by Marshal MOTT, charged with embezzlement of United States moneys, while in office, to the amount of more than $8,000. It appears that he made no returns to the Department for a portion of the last quarter he held the office, and he is represented to be several thousands of dollars behind on accounts rendered.

THE EXTENSION OF ALBANY STREET.--The Street Committee of Aldermen met in the room of the Board, at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, to discuss the objections of all parties to the proposed extension of Albany-street through the Trinity Church-yard to Broadway.

The Governors of the Almshouse held a regular meeting at the Rotunda, yesterday afternoon--present, Governors Draper, Smith, Duke, Townsend, Pinckney, Dagro, Henry, Herrick: the President, Governor DRAPER, in the Chair.

Mr. Councilman CLANCY appeared last evening in a new field of enterprise. Having defended the interests of the resurrectionists on Monday, he now turns, to an elaborate advocacy of Mr. Commissioner ARCULARIUS, whose resignation, by the way, has been laid upon the table by the Council until such time as an examination of his accounts can be obtained.

HARPER'S MAGAZINE.--The number for February is just issued. In its typographical appearance it is an improvement on the January number, but the publishers again solicit the indulgence of the public for some defects.

Corn rises, indeed, as wheat does, but -let us be thankful--not so rapidly nor so high. Families now have good reason to return to their primitive habits,--to eat Johnny-cakes at night, Indian cakes in the morning, and Indian puddings at noon.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: I Observe in a recent number of your paper, an article on the Tendency of American Politics, in which you quote from the Westminister Review, a criticism on a late treatise of mine, entitled "Theory of Politics."

Testimony for the Defence--Of Capt. Pendleton, Major C. S. Merchant, Lient. Van Voast and Dr. Wirtz. The inquiry was resumed yesterday morning, at 11 o'clock. Present, all members of the Court; also, Capt. SHIELDS, counsel for Col. GATES, and several witnesses, including Captain PENDLETON, of the Lucy Thompson.

THE AFRICA AGROUND--HER PASSENGERS AND MAILS LANDED.--Yesterday morning the Africa, after laying at anchor at the Southwest Spit for nearly forty hours, in the fog, weighed anchor and undertook to make her dock at Jersey City.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: On the 7th inst. I received a notice from the Croton Aqueduet Board that a fine of ten dollars had been incurred by me for a violation of the regulations of the Board, and a request that the same be settled immediately.

A meeting was held on Tuesday evening, in the First Reformed Dutch Church, Jersey City, which was largely attended by citizens, including most of the prominent property holders, at which Hon D. S. MANNERS, Mayor, presided, and Hon JAMES S. DAVENPORT acted as Secretary.

The Canal vote yesterday, though very light all over the State, was a triumphant vindication of the policy of the speedy en argement of the Erie Canal. We trust that the interests of this great work are now put beyond the reach of partisan malignity.

LECTURE I. We were much gratified to find the Chapel of the University filled on Saturday evening last, with an intelligent and distinguished audience, principally consisting of American ladies, attracted thither by the advertisements which have appeared in the City papers during the past week, announcing the delightful literary entertainments of M. PAUL ARPIN.
The following are the returns so far as received, of the vote yesterday upon the proposed Canal amendment to the State Constitution. They show largely in its favor.

IMPORTANT BILLS REPORTED AND PASSED. The Chair laid before the Senate Lieut. GIBBONS' report, being the second part of HERNDON'S Exploration of the Valley of the Amazon. Mr. EVERETT presented the memorial of the Massachusetts Humane Society, asking an appropriation to aid that Society in rescuing shipwrecked mariners.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: This question should at once be legally settled, for on the first of May next that officer is directed by law to select the Jurors for the ensuing year, and if they are not legally chosen, our Courts cannot proceed with their business.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have looked forward with considerable interest for the report published in to-day's paper, respecting encroachments on the harbor of New-York, and respectfully request the favor of making a few remarks on one particular subject connected with it, through your columns.

You have not forgotten Secretary MARCY'S Circular to the foreign officials of the U. S. Government, on the subject of their costume. You will remember that while consuls were expressly interdicted the wearing of embroidered garments, ambassadors were allowed to exercise their judgment, and make their choice.

A very remarkable civil suit for damages is now pending before the District Court of New-Orleans, involving, in the course of the testimony elicited upon the trial, the social history and habits of the Creoles or early settlers of Louisiana. for more than half a century before its accession by the United States. The Whig State Convention assembled in this city to-day. Hon. JAS. DIXON, of Hartford, was chosen President. The candidates for State Officers were nominated by ballot as follows: Governor--HENRY DUTTON, of New Haven.

Two weeks ago to-day, Mr. DOUGLAS said he would get the Nebraska bill through the Senate within a week. A fortnight has passed, and I see little reason to suppose the discussion will have closed another fortnight hence.

The Maryland Legislature, to-day, reelected JAMES A. PEARCE United States Senator, for six years, from the 4th of March, 1856. The vote stood: PEARCE, 58--Judge CONSTABLE, 39. All the Temperance delegates from Baltimore--Whigs and Democrats--voted for PEARCE. There were two scattering votes.

Postponement of the Investigation-Severe Illness of the Complainant--Cordella A. Grant--Incidents. Yesterday afternoon, at the hour appointed for the investigation of the charge of felony preferred against Madame RESTELL and GEORGE R. SHACKFORD, by CORDELLA A. GRANT, the Jefferson Market Court-room was crowded with persons, anxious to ascertain the particulars of the affair

We have received the undermentioned publications: From HORACE WATERS--The Bignores Polka, by M. G. S.-A lively and graceful composition, with a pleating melody and effective modulation. Likely to become popular. From FIRTH, POND Co.--Foster's Social Orchestra.

All the orders were signed to-day, and enveloped by the Perham Committee, at the Union Hotel, Georgetown, in the presence of many of the citizens of the District of Columbia. After the orders for the principal prizes were enveloped, the whole of them were thrown on the floor and thoroughly mixed in small parcels.

The proceedings in the extradition case of ALEX. HEILBRONN were resumed yesterday, in the Supreme Court, before Judges MITCHELL, MORRIS and ROOSEVELT. In the absence of Mr O'CONOR Mr. WHITING appeared on the part of the United States.
As there is some misapprehension in relation to our recently-established prohibitory postage, I beg to state that the law does not apply to matter going out of Cuba, in the shape of periodicals.
The bark Rainbow, from Rio Janeiro Jan. 7, arrived here this morning. She reports the market for Flour firm, and the stock high. Philadelphia brands were worth $21@$22, and Haxall and Gallego $24.

The meeting of captains of American vessels engaged in commerce with the Pacific coast, which was to have been held last evening at the Astor House, to take some steps to secure indemnity for the outrages sustained at the Chincha Islands, was postponed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times The amount of criticism with which the above named work has been honored during the week last past, is a gratifying proof of the taste extant for the great Bard's works, in like manner that the numbers who have witnessed its representation at two Theatres, evidence the desire of the public for productions of a high and poetic character.

We have files of Shanghai papers to the 19th of November. They give a variety of interesting details in regard to facts hitherto reported. A letter from our Chinese correspondent, published some days since, announced that the Imperialists had entirely destroyed the fleet of the insurgents at Shanghai.

PASSING COUNTERFEIT MONEY.--Assistant Captains BROWN and LATHAM, of the First District Police, succeeded about 9 o'clock last evening, in arresting two men named WM. H. WILSON and CHAS. C. LANSING, who were flooding the city with counterfeit one dollar bills on the Farmer's Bank of Bridgeport, Conn.

The Joint Committee of the two Houses of our State Legislature has made its report upon the encroachments on New-York harbor. With the exception of the Brooklyn members, the Committee was unanimous in concluding that the encroachments must be stopped, or a most serious injury will be done to our harbor.
The conclusion of Senator HOUSTON'S speech against the Nebraska bill in the Senate yesterday, does not occupy so much space in the Congressional reports as was generally anticipated.

Prudence is of no great account to a man who is stout and strong, rich and surrounded by interiors; but for puny people who have not enough of this world's goods to subsidize the strength of others, the possession of prudence is a fortune in itself.

The Nebraska bill does not seem to be making very rapid progress even in Congress. The fortnight of reflection already secured, has diminished the ardor even of its warmest friends, and greatly multiplied the chances of its defeat.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your correspondent from this city, under date of January 14, committed a serious mistake in stating the report of the Treasurer of the Executive Committee of the School.

WILLIAMSBURG FERRY COMPANY--INDIGNATION MEETING.--An immense number of the most respectable and influential citizens met at the Odeon, in Williamsburg, last evening, to consider the subject of the ferry communication with New-York. There were not less than two thousand present.

The Message of President PIERCE transmitting to the Senate the Treaty recently negociated with Mexico, published in the DAILY TIMES of yesterday morning, was received by Telegraph from Washington after midnight.

The following letters upon a matter which, last year, was the subject of remark in the public press, may serve to illustrate some of the anomalies arising under the ill-defined authority that exists in our Navy.

GRAHAM's MAGAZINE is a decided improvement on previous numbers. It contains some articles of real interest. HEADLEY'S Life of WASHINGTON, which is commenced, will extend the fame of that popular writer.

Below we publish a letter from Mr. DAVIDGE of the Broadway Theatre, concerning his rendition of " the character of Bottom in " M dsummer Night's Dream." It is temperate, and evinces an artistic amour propre that will be respected.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: My object in addressing you the, following lines, is solely the hope that the changes proposed in the mode of carrying steerage passengers, may contribute in some degree to the welfare of the poor people.

MRS. EUPHEMIA POLHAMUS--This lady died at Charlestown, Rockland Co., New-York, on Wednesday, Feb. 1. She was the widow of the late AARON POLHAMUS. She was born on the 20th day of October, 1750, and had consequently reached at the day of her death, the astonishing age of 103 years 3 months and 11 days.

In Brooklyn, on 4th day, Feb. 15, of consumption, VIRGINIA W., wife of S. Baldwin Chapman. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on 6th day morning, at 10 o'clock. from her late residence, Grand-av., between Fulton and Atlantic avs.
