Some of the Boston Reformers are moving to abolish the office of City Superintendent of Public Schools. The Schools get on so well, that they fancy there is no need of any officer with especial charge to watch them

On Monday. Feb. 13, by Rev. N. Lewis, Mr. WILLIAM HOLLELY to Miss BRIDGET SHERIDEN, both of this City. In Williamsburg, I. I., on Monday. Feb. 13, by Rev. Sylvester Malone, P P., WILLIAM E. JOYCE, of that city, to MARY ANN O'REILLY, only daughter of William O'Reilly, of New-York.

The letter of our Paris Correspondent, in another column, gives an interesting statement of the embarrassment and confusion which have been created by Secretary MARCY'S order concerning the costume of American Representatives at Foreign Courts.

Several brutal and outrageous assaults by biped monsters on women, have come before the authorities of London. One, a Mr. FRANCIS WEBB, of Clarence-street, ??lington, was charged with having violently assaulted his wife with a red hot poker. Another case is that of a woman as??med FLYNN, who lies in a very precarious state from the injuries received from her husband.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I was much gratified on finding that Mr. H. ARCULARIUS had resigned. It is a long-time since he performed any duty which would at all benefit the public, and it is gratifying to find him at last doing what he ought to have done long since, and the only thing he could do which would, in any way, benefit the City.

Our Havana letter this morning will be found to be of uncommon interest. The details which it furnishes may be relied upon as from undoubted sources, and they show that affairs in that island are hurrying to a crisis in the development of a policy which is pregnant with results affecting the existence of the white race there, and of vital importance to the United States.

Russia is almost devoid of an urban population. St. Petersburg, Moscow and Odessa are the only cities whose populations exceed a hundred thousand, indeed there is some doubt-whether that of Odessa even reaches this figure. There are only four towns containing more than fifty thousand in habitants each, and eighteen or twenty with populations exceeding twenty five thousand.

Your correspondent A. B. has an article in the TIMES with this singular caption "The Albany-street extension due to Trinity Church and to her only," and this from parties who admit that for forty years past, their aim has been to extend Albany-street through Trinity church yard, and have been invariably opposed in their project by every successive Board of the Vestry of that Church.

Public attention was first directed to the condition or vagrant children in this City, by the Police Re. ports of 1849, by which it appeared, that there were growing up here in the miles of us more than ton thousand. Children, nearly one half of whom were little girls, entirely without the pale of educational or religious influence, and who gained a precarious subsistence by beggary and theft.

The New-Jersey Medical Reporter, since we last noticed it, has grown immensely. Dr. PARRISH still edits it, and as well as ever. He has secured for his assistance a list of sturdy collaborators, and if they do not make a journal both read able and excellent, they will violate a flattering promise which the matter in the present number holds out.

The America, which reached Boston yesterday with three days' later intelligence, seems to have brought nothing but rumors, so. far as the Eastern War is concerned. There is a "rumor" of another great battle and Turkish victory at Kalafat ;--another that Persia has changed her policy and again become friendly with the Porte ;--and a third that Austria has renewed her demand for the extradition of foreigners in the service of Turkey.

The following conflicting Opinions on the operations of the Lien Law of this State, have been rendered in the Court of Common Pleas, by Judges WOODRUFF and INGRAHAM. Judge DALY concurs in the Opinion given by Judge WOODRUFF. The points involved relate to the construction of the "Act for the better security of Mechanics, ," passed July 11, 1851:

Rev. Dr. ADAMS will deliver the Lecture before the Mercantile Library Association, at Hope Chapel this evening. Subject: "The True Ideal of a Merchant." The Exhibition of the Students of the Free Academy takes place this evening.

The Herald's counsel in the Fry libel case, urged that the abuse of that paper had benefited the opera; and that Mr Fry, there fore, was not entitled to damages. The Jury thought differently ;but we are beginning to think that Mr. SANDFORD was right. The Herald's hostility is certainly serviceable to all its enemies.

The Court met at 10 1/2 o'clock, yesterday morning, and resumed the inquiry. Present, all the members, Col. GATES and his counsel, The record of the previous day's proceedings having been read and approved. Maj WYSE asked to make a statement or application to the Court.

Petitions and remonstrances against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise are still pouring into the Senate. Messrs. Chase and SUMNER presented a number yesterday, and soon afterwards Mr. BADGER proceeded to speak upon the Nebraska bill.

To the Editors of the National Intelligencer: It is my misfortune once again to find myself in a situation which obliges me to take part against many of my best personal and political friends, and upon a subject and under circumstances that, feeling and believing as I do, it would be criminal on my part to be silent; and, however

POEMS AND PARODIES By PHOERE CAREY. Boston: TICKNOR. REED FIELDS. NEW-York: EVANs DICKERSON. Miss PHOEBS CAREY, as our readers are aware, is the sister of Miss ALICE CAREY, through the pleasant places of whose "Clovernook" we have lately Been rambling, and whose merits as a writer, we have glanced at in another place.

The Free-Soilers of Massachusetts are holding a Convention in Faneuil Hall to-day, to remonstrate against the Nebraska bill. The meeting comprises most of the leaders of the party. Letters were read from Hon. S. P. CHASE, of Ohio, and J P HALE The Convention was numerously attended. Hon. J. W. ALVORD, Free-Soil Senator from Franklin County, presided, assisted by a large number of Vice Presidents.

The Convention of Cigar makers from different States, for the purpose of getting up an expression against increasing the importation of foreign cigars met this morning, and is largely attended. The following are the officers: President--JOSEPH BRADY, of Portland, Me. Vice Presidents--Robt. C. Campbell, of Suffield, Conn.; John Schnaber, of Syracuse, N. Y.; John Campbell, of Newark, N.J.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.-- There is a reproduction here to night. The drama of "Ernestine," with new secuery, costumes, and appointments, will be played -the character of Ernestine by Hrs. HOEY. LESTER and DYOTT sustain the principal male characters. "A Pretty Piece of Business" and "Love and Murder" are also in the bill.

The appearance of the GADSDEN Treaty, with the Amendments recommended by the Cabinet, and sent to the Senate confidently by the President, in the NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES, has caused considerable commotion here, from the fact that to secure a copy was supposed impossible.

On Thursday, Feb. 16, 1854, of brain fever, Sergeant JOHN O'SULLIVAN, of the Second Ward Police. His friends and relatives, also the members of the Police Department, and Hencock Lodge No 49 I. O of O. F., are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Saturday afternoon, at 1 o'clock P. M., from his late residence, No. 100 Beekman st , without further notice. Cork, Ireland, papers please copy.

Why should we love the heathen Turk And hate the Christian Czar- While Russia is, in wealth and work, " More civilized" by far? Her banner bears the Holy Cross Wherewith our creed is signed. While Turkey's Pachas only toss Their horsetails to the wind.

At an early hour this morning we received a telegraphic summary of the accounts from Europe, brought by the Canada, at Halifax, to Saturday, 4th February. These advices were preceded by the arrival of the America at Boston, with dates only to Tuesday, 31 st January.

VIENNA.-Count BUOL has drawn out a declaration of neutrality, with a strong leaning towards the views of the Western Powers, and has given this to Coun-ORLOFF as a final answer. ORLOFF'S mission has therefore failed.

The CHAIR presented a letter from the publishers of the Sentinel offering to take the contract for reporting the Senate proceedings and debates in place of the proprietors of the Union, who have given up their contract. Mr. HAMLIN presented a report made by M. ALEXANDRE VATTEMARE on the subject of international standard of weights and measures, which was referred to the Library Committee.

An arrival at this port brings us Rio dates to the 8:h January. Coffee was active and firmer; sales of the months 150,000 bags, including 55,000 for the United States. American lots were quoted 9 3/4c.@10c. on board. Madame SONTAO gave her first concert here last night, and met with a brilliant triumph. She goes to Mobile next week. The Eastern mail fails here daily.

Last evening Lieutenant MAURY delivered the Annual Address in the Chapel of the University before the Geographical and Statistical Society. There was a large assembly, notwithstanding the unfavorable state of the weather. Previous to the delivery of the lecture, Hon. GEORGE BANCROFT came forward and said that it gave him great pleasure to meet so large and respectable an audience on the second anniversary of the existence of their Society.

Messrs BROWN, SHIPLEY CO. say: In the early part of the week COTTON was much depressed, and forced sales were made to a considerable extent at irregular prices, varying from ?d @1/4d. lb. below the nominal rates of the day ; but the market having been relieved from a few anxious sellers, a little tone has been established--business closing more steadily but tamely at the quotations current at the departure of the last steamer.

In another part of this morning's Times will be found the Report of the Girl's Industrial School in Avenue D for the past year. It will not attract half the attention it deserves,--nor will one in ten of those who read it, realize the transcendent importance of the statements which it contains.

To The Editor of the New--York Daily Times. Mr. EDITOR: Permit me to say a few words, through your columns, to the mechanics of our State, and, incidentally, to all interested in the welfare of the industrial classes (and who is not?) in regard to the formation of an Industrial Institute.

The Cunard steamship America, with Liverpool dates of the 31st ult., arrived at this port at about 9 o'clock this morning. She brings the United States troops taken from the steamer San Francisco, by the ship Antarctic, and several letter bags, but not the regular mail.

On Thursday, Feb. 16, by Rev. William Baunad, JOHN OTTO, of Buffalo, and ELIZA SHIPMAS, daughter of Jasper Corning. At Paterson, N. J., on Wednesday, Feb 15, by Rev Mr. Hornblower, JULIA C. PIERSON, of Paterson, to WILLIAM J EMMET, of New-York. On Wednesday, Feb 15, by Rev. Samuel Cooke, THOMAS A. McCRERY, of Charleston, S C., to SARAHA, daughter of John Graydon, of this City.

In accordance with the appended call, published in the Free Democratic papers of Massachusetts, delegates from different parts of that State, together with other citizens, numbering about four thousand, assembled in Faneuil Hall, Boston, for the purpose of giving expression to the sentiments of their political organization in relation to the repeal of the Missouri Compromise, contemplated in the Nebraska bill, now pending before the United States Senate.

MR. PRESIDENT: The United States, at the close of the Revolution, rested southward on the St. Mary's and westward on the Mississippi, and possessed and broad, unoccupied domain, circumscribed by those rivers, the Alleghany Mountains, and the great Northern lakes.

The torch, composed of a nation's compacts, and fired by political ambition, to light of official preeminence the Little Giant of the West, burns brightly now, but like the bush the Moses saw, it burns without consuming. Neither does it illumine the path he would have trodden.

COURT OF GENERAL SESSIONS--Thursday. Before Recorder Tillou. TRAIL OF JAMES SAUNDERS FOR RIOT. The Court of General Sessions convened at the usual hour, on Thursday morning, and the trial of James Saunders, indicted for riot in Aeingdon square, on the 4th of July last, was resumed.

Mr. DEAN stated that he had received a letter from the Governor of New-York, transmitting the Joint Resolutions of the General Assembly, relative to the territorial question now pending before Congress. He asked that they be read, laid on the table, and printed. Mr. WALSH objected to the reading. Mr. CLINGMAN hoped there would be no objection to the printing.

From Athaya Co's Glasgoro Circular. GLASGOW, Feb 3.--BREADSTUFFS have been dull, but a better feeling in springing up. PROVISIONS in fair request. LARD quiet. A speculative business is doing in TALLOW, at 64s. 6d. @65s. ASHES is 6d, lower, and quiet. Sales of RESIN have been made at 12s. 3d. No transactions in TOBACCO.

The Council wasted one hour in debate whether to accept the offer of a clock for their Chamber from a manufacturing firm. The propriety of accepting the time-measurer was discussed by Councilmen FRYE, KENNEDY, MATHER, and others. bate was exceedingly desul-

The crowing of "the noble Cock BENEVENTANO" was nothing, absolutely nothing, in comparison with the "crows" and "clucks" and "quacks" that echo through "BARNUM's" Halls. The cocks that through that Hall diffuse a peculiar melody have a pleasant time of it. They crow in all keys. ey are worse than an eight keyed flute

The Street Committee of the Board of Aldermen met again at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, in the Chamber of the Board at the City Hall. There was quite a large attendance of the parties interested and counsel employed on both sides, and a crowd of citizens attracted thither by the importance of the discussion, filled the lobbies.

Lately it seems as if JOHN MITCHEL, every time he opens his mouth, like Mrs. Parting ton, puts his foot in it. But in to-day's Citizen he opens it to advantage, and puts his fist into the faces of some of his detractors very squarely. At Tarrytown, on Friday, Feb. 17, in the 85th year of his age, WILLIAM PAULDING. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral, without further invitation, at Christ Church, Tarrytown, on the arrival of the train, which leaves New. York at 10 o'clock Monday morning.

Senator SEWARD's speech to-day was a great effort, and admirably delivered. Many Northern and Southern Senators speak of it in terms of highest praise. One or more Southern Representatives will speak and vote against the Nebraska bill--mark this.
DEATH OF GENERAL PAULDING.--Information was received yesterday at the City. Hall, of the death of General PAULDING at Tarrytown. He was Mayor of this City in 1623 and '24, '26 and '27.

The managers of the Association for improving the condition of the Poor, have made an appeal to the public which ought to receive immediate attention. They state that in con sequence of the extreme inclemency of the season, the lack of employment, and the very great rise in the price of provisions, the number of destitute poor whose condition calls for immediate relief, is much greater than usual.

Testimony for the Defence Continued--Examination of, Lieut. Loeser, Lient, Fremont, Sergeant Horn, Lieut. Winder and Lient. Van Veast. ELEVENTH DAY. The Court met pursuant to adjournment, at 10 1/2 o'clock, but for some cause did not proceed to take termony until near 12 M.

THE POISONING CASE.--The examination of MICHAEL FABLEY, on the charge of poising Mrs. JOANNA DARBY, was concluded on Thursday. The Jury, after a few minutes' consultation, rendered the following verdict: "That the deceased, Mrs. JOANNA DARBY, came MICHAEL FARLEY, on Saturday, the 28th day of January, 1854; and, from the testimony, they do believe that his wife, MARGARET FARLEY, was knowing to and accessory to the same.

With public opinion in America the Editor of the "Citizen" now feels himself to be quit. When he landed on the shores of this Republic, all he sought, all he wanted in America was a shelter from his enemies; and this was quite sure to be accorded him. But this was not all.

The meeting held at the Tabernacle on Saturday night to protest against the nullification of the Missouri Compromise, of which a full report will be found in our columns this morning, was very large, enthusiastic and influential.

A large and enthusiastic meeting of citizens, chiefly from among the workingmen of New-York, assembled in the Tabernacle, on Saturday evening, to "after their stern protest against the threatened breach of faith, and their determined hostility to any encroachment by the Slave Power on the rights of free labor in the territories secured by the Missouri Compromise."

A meeting of the National Poultry Society was held on Friday morning in the Lecture-room of BARNUM'S Museum, for the purpose of considering the mode of rearing and the improvement of fowls. The President, Mr BARNUM made a few humerous remarks, and then introduced Mr. DAVID TAGGART, of Northumberland, Penn.

The Canada's mails reached us at an early hour yesterday morning. The summary of the intelligence by this arrival, which was received by Telegraph and published in the Times of Friday morning, was very full. We give below a variety of interesting extracts from our foreign files:

After a week's recess, both Houses of the Legislature should last night have returned to the discharge of their official duties. This morning brought back the lingering, and a working number in both branches--no, not in the Assembly, for still there were not enough there to pass any bills that required the presence of three-fifths--but enough for allthe other purposes of legislation.

BY SUBMARINE AND EUROPEAN TELEGRAPH M. De Kisseleff. BRUSSELS, Tuesday.--M. DE KISSELEFF arrived here this morning, at 6 o'clock. A. M. GERMANY. BERLIN, Tuesday.-The check experienced by Count ORLOFF in his mission is fully confirmed.

THE EXTRADITION CASE UNDER A NEW PHASE--EXCITING SCENE AT THE PARK SATURDAY MORNING--The case of ALEX. HEILBRONN claimed under the Extradition clause of the ASHBURTON Treaty, has been frequently before our readers. During the last six weeks he has been almost at liberty on his parole in the Marshal's office, Deputy Marshal PHILLIPS merely accompaning him to RABINESU'S to take his meals, auld placing him in a secure room at night.

The United States Mail steamship Baltic, from Liverpool, Feb. 8, arrived this morning at 3:20. We are under obligations to the Purser, Mr. JAS. G. MAGLAN, for the early delivery of our foreign papers. The Baltic left Liverpool on Wednesday, Feb. 8, at 5 P. M. The weather has been generally fine--full cargo--and 56 passengers.

BY ELECTRIC TELEGRAPH. EASTERN WAR. PARIS, Tuesday.--All the rumors of the ill succee??s of ORLOFF's mission are now confirmed. It is not likely that he will prolong his stay, but will, it is said, leave directly for St. Petersburg. Foreseeing the same rebuff at Berlin, he will refrain from visiting that capital.

From the New Orleans Picayane We have no intelligence from the city of Mexico to the 3d inst., and from Vera Cruz to the 8th. The intelligence contained in the papers presents no features of importance. The Walker expedition still occupied a large share of the attention of the press. A dispatch from Negrete is given, in which the account does not very materially differ from that obtained from the expedition. The Orden,

Arrival of the Crescent City. The steamer Crescent City, Capt. R. BAXTER, arrived last night from New-Orleans Feb. 11, and Havana Feb. 14. We are indebted to M. L. PULTZ, Esq., her Purser, for memoranda.

The tremendous rains of Monday night and yesterday morning, caused a must sudden rise in the Little and Big Miami rivers, and all the trioutaress to those streams within a distance of sixty miles from the mouth of each stream. The Ohio itself swelled rapidly, but a few hours makes less difference with that mighty river, even though melting snow and floods of rain should simultaneously feed it than with the two Miamis.

The details of the foreign intelligence, received by the Canada, which will be found in the TIMES this morning, are full of interest. The Eastern question has been debated at length in both Houses of Parliament, and although nothing absolutely new was disclosed in the discussion, much light is thrown upon the motives of the English Government in the course it has seen fit to pursue.

On Sunday, Feb. ID, GEORGE W. SUMMER. The friends of the family, and of his father-in-law, the late Chas. Porter, are invited to attend his funeral, without further notice, at his late residence. No. 170 East 19th st, on Tuesday, the 22d inst., a, 4 o'clock P. M. Funeral services at Calvary Church.

To-day, about 4 o'clock, P. M., the town of Harrison, (twenty miles northwest of Cincinnati) was visited by a fearful and destructive tornado, tearing down dwellings, stables, The course of the current of air was nearly from southwest to northeast, and the width of its track was about one hundred yards.

FUNERAL, OF THE LATE JUSTICE McGRATH.--The remains of the late JAMES McGRATH, Police Justice of the Second District Court, were interned yesterday in Calvary Cemetery, L 1. At the hour named for the funeral to leave, a number of military and citizens had assembled is White-treet, from Broadway to Orange-street.

We have no mail to-day beyond Mobile. A dispatch from St. Louis states that the Rev. Mr. GASSOWAY, formerly of Georgetown, D. C., one of the passengers on board the Kate Kearney, has died of his injuries.

Quite a fluttering was occasioned in the Senate this afternoon, after Mr. DOUGLAS' amendment had been adopted, by an amendment offered by Mr. CHASE. The DOUGLAS amendment, it will be remembered, declares that it is not the intention of the bill to legislate Slavery into the Territories or to prohibit it therefrom, but to leave this and all other domestic questions to the decision of the people of the Territories, subject only to the Constitution.

Our readers will find, in another column, the translation of an editorial article which appeared in last Saturday's issue of the Courrier des Etats Unis, the well-known French morning paper of this City. The article alluded to at once awakened general curiosity, as it communicated some information of much importance to the Government and people of this country.

The anti-Nebraska bill meeting in this city last night was very numerously attended. Mayor WILLIAMS presided. Citizens of all parties were present, and concurred in the proceedings. The resolutions thoroughly denounce the proposed repeal of the Missouri Compromise.

TWO HORRIBLE ACCIDENTS ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD, NEAR YONKERS!--One of these was reported in the Herald, as having occurred to the Express Train last Friday morning, to the serious injury of numerous persons. I was a passenger in the train referred to.

Mr. MARCY is represented to have said to a Soft member that the President expected his (MARCY'S) friends to support the Nebraska bill. The member replied that he was willing to go anywhere for MARCY, but to the devil; and that supporting the Nebraska bill would be equivalent to going to his Satanic Majesty.

A letter from Paris addressed to the Courrier des Etats Unis, by M. GALLIARDET, contains many just observations and some important news. It states that in the conferences had between the Russian Ambassadors to the courts of France and England, some very sharp words wore exchanged on the subject of the allied fleets having entered the Black Sea, adding that the Russian Ministers quitted London and Paris simultaneously.

We were enabled, though with some delay in the delivery of the TIMES to subscribers, to publish a very full summary of the important European news received by the Baltic, in our edition of yesterday morning. We append a variety of interesting details,--debates in Parliament, opinions of the Press, , , from our foreign files:

VISIT OF THE BALTIMORE "VIGILANT" FIRE COMPANY--PREPARATION FOR A GRAND TORCHLIGHT PROCESSION--The "Vigilant" Engine Company, of Baltimore, who have accepted an invitation from Columnbian Engine Company to spend a few days in his City as their guests, were expected last evening, but in consequence of the storm they did not arrive up to 11 o'clock.

We have received from Europe, by the Baltic, intelligence of the death of that remarkable tuan, SILVIO PELLICO, whose work, Le Mie Prigioni ("My Prisons") has been ran dated into every language in Europe, and made the name of the author almost a household word.

The state of the War in Europe grows exceedingly interesting. The Baltic brings the certain information that diplomatic intercourse has ceased, for the time, between Russia and the Western Powers. By some of the letter writers, a formal declaration is scarcely required to make the present attitude one of General War.

The Court assembled yesterday morning at 12 o'clock. Present, all the members of the Court, Colonel GATES, Capt. SHIELDS, his counsel, and others. Sergeant-Major Wm. Gorham, 3d Regiment of Artillery, was called on the part of Col. GATES, and examined as follows:

DETECTION AND ARREST OF BURGLAR.--Policeman FANAL, of the Fourteenth Ward, while patroling his beat at 4 o'clock on Sunday morning, observed a light in the store of JOHN RODENBERG, No. 2 Crosby-street, and on looking through the key hole, saw two young men engaged in packing up goods.

RUN OVER.--Mr. George B. Fellows, an elderly gentlemen, residing in Brooklyn, was run over in Broadway, near Wall street, at 10 o'clock on Saturday night, by stage No. 205, Murphy Smith's line, which at the time was racing and sustained a severe confusion on the back part of his head.

From a private communication to a gentleman in this City, we learn that the submarine operators, Messrs. MAILLEFERT and RAASLOFF, have made great progress of late in widening and deepening the channel of the Red River, through the Lower Rapids at Alexandria.

NAVAL INTELLIGENCE.--The brig Reindeer MOULTON, from Coast of Africa, reports the U. S. ship Marion was off the Congo, on a cruise. The U. S. ship Constitution, Commodore MAYO, sailed for St. Helena about Nov. 25. Most of the English squadron were upon the North Coast, in consequence of some disturbance among the natives.

THE NEBRASKA BILL. Numerous petitions against the Nebraska hill were presented from New-York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Ohio, Massachusetts, Illinois and Vermont. THREE INDIAN TERRITORIES. Mr JOHNSON introduced a bill to establish three Indian Territories west of Arkansas.

This morning about 11 o'clock, the steamer James Niles, from Cincinnati, with a heavy cargo and two barges in tow, sunk on the Falls in Big Eddy, and will prove a total loss. The boat capsized, and the cabin broke off and sent overboard.
Alea jacta est! There seems no longer room for doubt as to the certainty of War, between England and France as the allies of Turkey, on the one side, and Russia on the other.
PARIS, Wednesday, Feb. 8.-The Moniteur to day officially announces that the Russian Minister has left Paris. It has also begun the publication of the official documents on the Eastern question.

Nothing of interest has been done. BILLS REPORTED. To suppress the traffic in lotteries. To exempt plankroads from taxation. To incorporate the Ladies' Home Missionary Society. To incorporate the Albany Sixpenny Savings Bank. To incorporate the Atlantic and Pacific Transportation Company.

A heavy snow storm commenced here about 8 o'clock this morning, and still continues. It is now a foot deep on a level, and the railroads are all blocked up by the drift. No trains have arrived, and none gone out since 2 o'clock this afternoon HARRISBURG, Monday Feb. 20.

The general course of New-York legislation since the establishment of the Free Banking Law, in 1838, has uniformly been to the im provement of the currency, and the correction of the defects or weak places in the system as originally constituted.

In the Senate, the annual report of the Commission era of Emigration was presented by the President. You have a ready had its features. Mr. SPENCER endeavored to have the report referred to a special Committee, but was overruled by Mr. BROOKS and a vote of the Senate.

The Snow Storm of the season is still raging with a violence that causes those who encounter it to shiver beneath the most comfortable garments, and gasp for breath. It is not one of the old-fashioned, constitutional snow storms that occasionally come upon us in handsome, robust flakes--flakes which make phlegmatic noses shrink with fear, and which fiery beaks never fail to repel with an indignant "phist."

THE STORM--The Philadelphia Mail Train, which left at 5 P. M. on Monday, did not reach Jersey City until 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. When it reached a point one mile south of New-Brunswick, at 10 o'clock at night, it became fast in a snow-bank, and there remained until 10 o'clock yesterday morning.

The departure of the Russian Ambassadors from London and Paris closes the first act of that eventful drama, the end of which cannot be foretold. The second act opens with the mauceuvres to gain the cooperation of the so called German Powers. The most important question of the moment is, what position Austria will decide to take.

Mr. BAYARD presented five petitions in favor of establishing all Territorial Governments on the principle of non intervention by Congress. Mr. PEARCE offered a resolution that the Chair fill the vacancy in the Regents of the Smithsonian Institute, occasioned by the expiration of Mr. CHARLTON'S term Adopted.

The Northeast gale of Monday night was very severe. The schooner John R. Watson, of Perth Amboy, from North Carolina, while at anchor in the East River, lost both chains, and went into the South Ferry slip on Brooklyn side, carrying away her jibboom and slightly damaging her bulwarks.

Mr. WM. E. DUNSCOMB, Clerk and Comptroller, pro tem. of the Vestry of Trinity Church, has published in the TIMES of Friday last, an expose of their views in relation to the extension of Albany-street to Broadway. In the close of this article "Mr. BOORMAN" finds himself honored by the following notice:

BILLS REPORTED. To incorporate the Albany Sixpenny Savings Bank. To amend the charter of the Protestant Episcopal Missionary Society. NOTICES OF BILLS. To incorporate the Brooklyn Sixpenny Savings Bank. To incorporate the Methodist Home Missionary Society.

From the New Orleans Picayune. The Siglo XIX, of the 2d inst., publishes correspondence between Senior BONILLA, the Mexican Minister for Foreign Affairs, and Mr. CRIPPS, interim Charge d' Affaires for the United States at Mexico, on the subject of the expedition against Lower California and Senora.

The Nations long had groped their way Amid the shrines of sceptred Wrong, When twilight bursting into day, Proclaimed the birth of WASHINGTON, Then from our Western shores the night Of doomed Oppression fled away, And untold millions now unite To hail our Chieftain's Natal Day.

We published a day or two since an article from the Courrier des Etats Unis, noticing a report that Russian officers were in this City for the purpose of engaging privateers from American ports to cruise under the Russian flag, against the Commerce of those European Powers with which Russia may be at war.

The two Boards met last evening. The proceedings were quite interesting. The Councilmen commenced proceedings by a resolution requiring the Railroad Companies of the City to remove from the street the snow which they clear away from the tracks. Objection was entered against the blockade of the sides of narrow streets, such as Chatham, by the banks thrown up by the snow-plows.

REMOVAL OF THE POST OFFICE.--The large room in the Freeman's Building, Fulton-street, formerly used as an auction-room, is being fitted up for toe reception of the Post Office. The great increase of business at this office has rendered it necessary to have more accommodations than can be secured in the present location.

Among the petitions presented this morning in the Senate, was that of the Convention of the strong minded women in session at this place last week. Senators appeared at a loss to know what should be done with it. Some proposed a reference to the Judiciary, but objection was made; and then proposed an alteration of the rules, so as to provide for a Standing Committee on Woman's Rights.

The Committee on Railroads, of the Board of Councilmen, met yesterday afternoon. Present, E. H. KIMBARK, Chairman, and Councilman WILD. A petition was received, praying for the removal of one of the lines of rails of the Third avenue Railroad on Chatham street. Mr. VAN SCHAICK, counsel for the Rai road, appeared, asking for a postponement of any action in the matter for a short time, which was granted.

Mr. PRESIDENT: I approach this discussion with awe. The mighty question, with untold issues, which it involves; oppresses me. Like a portentous cloud, surcharged with irresistible storm and ruin, it seems to fill the whole heavens, making me painfully conscious how unequal I am to the occasion--how unequal, also, is all that I can say, to all that I feel.

ASSAULTING A POLICE OFFICER.--On Friday evening while officer CALHOUN was taking a man, named SIMMONDS, to the Station-house, for drunkenness, a companion of the inebriate, named JOHN BROWN. came behind him and attempted to strike him on the head with a heavy stick. He was observed in time to arrest the blow and stands committed for trial.

Senator SUMNER'S speech to-day was both brilliant and logical. The Senate chamber was crowded to excess, despite the storm and great depth of snow. The audience were delighted. Statesmen pronounce the effort masterly. The Whig papers in Mr. PRESCOTT'S district oppose the Nebraska bill, and letters received here say that Hon. JOHN J. CRITTENDEN will soon address the people against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise.

In Philadelphia on Sunday morning, Feb. 19, at the residence of her son-in-law, De Wilt O. Morris, Mrs. SARAH B JOHNSON, wife of Ebenezer Johnson, of New Haven, Conn., in the 69th year of her age. On Tuesday, Feb. 21, Mrs. RUTH C. LEWIS, in the 87th year of her age.

We hope our readers will take the trouble to read a little sketch, copied into another column of the Times, from Household Words, entitled " ANYBODY'S CHILD." It gives a graphic picture of one member of a very numerous class. It describes to the life the little, ragged, dirty, profane, thieving outcast, whom one may, nay must, meet daily in the streets of New-York.

In the Senate yesterday a number of petitions were presented in favor of establishing all Territorial Governments on the principle of non-intervention by Congress; but the most generally interesting part of the proceedings was the speech of Senator SUMNER against the Nebraska bill, which, for elegance of style and force of argument, was worthy of all the praise that distinguished Senators are said to have awarded to it.

On Tuesday evening, Mr. HENRY ARCULARIUS, Jr., the gentleman who wished to resign and couldn't, in consequence of the Board of Council. Men--sent to the Council his report for the year 1853 of the Bureau of Lamps and Gas. The results present some interesting features. The City pays a great deal of money for lighting the streets and avenues. The Almanac is the principal guide.

The Albany passengers, who left for New York on Monday afternoon at 5 o'clock, did not reach the lower depot until after 8 o'clock yesterday morning. The Hudson River train was within a few miles of the Thirty-first-street Depot at 9 o'clock Monday night. There was little or no snow at Albany when the train left.

The rumors concerning Prince ALBERT'S interference in political affairs, were elaborately refuted by Lord JOHN RUSSELL, in a speech which we copied yesterday. His Lordship gave a very interesting statement of the position of Prince ALBERT,--of his relations to the Government, and the high opinion entertained of him by Lord MELBOURNE.

The snow continued to fall here till 4 o'clock this morning, and lies two feet on a level, our streets almost blockaded by the drifts. No trains from any quarter have arrived since yesterday afternoon, and none have been sent out, all the railroads in the vicinity of the city being blocked up by immense drifts. This morning the weather is clear and warm.

Rev. THEODORE PARKER delivered last night at the Tabernacle a Lecture on the Conquests of Slavery in America, with special reference to the new conquest sought by the Nebraska bill of Senator DOUGLAS. It was an hour and three-quarters in length,--clear and impressive in language and style,--and unmeasured in its denunciation of Slavery, as well as of other predominant elements in American politics.

The Court assembled yesterday morning, at 12 M. Present--Major-General SCOTT, President; General STAUNTON AND Col SUMNER; Col. GATES, with his counsel; Capt SHIELDS and other military gentlemen, and citizens were present. Capt. James P. Watkins called and sworn.--Examined by Col GATES.

We publish in another column the report of the operations of the Children's Aid Society for the past year. To the people of this great City, it is a more important, and ought to be a more interesting, document than any President or Governor's Message for the last ten years.

Americans ought to be satisfied with their lot. No people have greater reasons for thankfulness, even if we omit that long list which passes in review on every fourth day of the Sixth month. Nowhere is the natural increase of population greater; nowhere is there more food to feed it.

The Anniversary of WASHINGTON'S Birth-day, was duly observed in Jersey City. During the early part of the day, the Continental Guard, Capt. POLLARD, paraded the streets, with music, is full force. They ma ched to Bergen Five Corners, where they were joined by the Washington Volunteers, Capt. SPEAR, and returned to Jersey City.

The funds have undergone a temporary rise, owing to the return of the Fleets to Beicos, and the apparent failure of the Count ORLOFF in his mission to Vienna. The Conference does not consider his propositions acceptable, and we expect to-day to learn of the dissolution of that body.

To-day is set apart, in very many of the churches of our land, for religious services having reference to the interests of our Colleges, Universities and Seminaries. In the City, prayer meetings are held in the morning; and in the evening, by appointment, Rev. G. B. CHEEVER preaches on the subject in the Lafayette-place Church.

On Wednesday, Feb. 22, after a short illness, Mrs. REBECCA CLARCK, aged 80 years. Her friends, the friends of her daughter, Mrs. Phebe Dupignac, and of grandsons William, George, James, and Andrew Dupienac, and E Harrison Reed, are requested to attend her funeral from the residence of her grandson, Wm. C. Dupignac No. 669 Water-st., on Friday, the 24th inst., at 2 o'clock, without further invitation.

A correspondent of the Lexington Gazette gives the particular of a fearful occurence on James River, at Balcony Falls, on Saturday the 21st of January. The Canal-boat Crinton, Capt. WOOD, with about fifty persons on board, principally negro bands, on their way to Central Railroad, ??pred to proceed up the river to Baehavan.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. THE RIVER AMUR, OR AMOUR, to which Lieut. MAURY alluded in his interesting lecture before the American Geographical and Statistical Society, at its late annual meeting, is a vast river of Chinese Tartary. It rises in north lat. 48[degrees] 52'; eastlong, of Greenwich 108[degrees] 27', in Mt. Kentey, or Kinhau. It is there called the Onon.

The following is a copy of the Opinion of the Counsel to the Corporation, presented in the Board of Aldermen on Tuesday evening, in relation to the powers of the two Boards to make appropriations of moneys for the expenditures of the City Government.

Sir FRANCIS HEAD, in his Faggot of French Sticks, speaks with interest of his visit, among the other curiosities of Paris, to one of the institution under the direction of the S etete des breches. These breches, or nurseries, (literally cribs,) are houses where women who go out to their work deposit their infants during their absence.

We publish in another part of this morning's TIMES a verbatim report of THEODORE PARKER'S extraordinary diatribe of Tuesday evening, on the Aggressions of Slavery. We think it ought to be read by those Southern supporters of the Nebraska scheme who retain any love for the Union, and who would not willingly see the country plunged into a civil contest which will be very likely to rend it asunder.

I have not communicated with you very recently, because the weather has been so inclement that we have received no news of any interest from the North, the Mountains or New Mexico. I received a letter from a friend last evening, who is now sojourning at Pembina, formerly known as Selkirk's Settlement, on the Red River of the North.

THE SNOW, AND HOW THEY GET THROUGH IT.--The passage of the streets yesterday was a feat to be accomplished through desperate effort, fixed determination, and hope. The ridges of ice, interspersed in agreeable variety by small ponds of water and miniature ravines, wherein sleighs stuck fast, and wheeled vehicles became nonentities, made an amusing, albeit, a disagreeable panorama.

The investigation of this case was commenced yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock, before Justice STUART, at the Jefferson Police Court. Mr Busteed appeared as counsel for Miss Grant. Mr. Jordan represented Caroline Lohman, (alias Madame Restell,) and George R. Shackford was defended by Ex Recorder Tallmadge. Miss Grant, Madame Restell, and Mr. Shackford were present.

A little incident which comes to light through the Police Department, affecting its relations to the public, deserves attention. Captain MAYNARD of the Nineteenth Ward Police, recently reported the Third-avenue Railroad Company as negligent in filling up certain gullies and ditches on the upper part of the road.

Rev. THEODORE PARKER delivered, last Tuesday evening, at the Tabernacle, a lecture on the Conquests of Slavery in America, with especial reference to the new conquest sought by the Nebraska bill of Senator DOUGLAS. The lecture was advertised to commence at 7 1/2 o'clock, and long previous to that hour the entire Tabernacle--body, gallery and aisles--was filled by a highly respectable audience, comprising both sexes

Poultry, which from time immemorial has been sold to market men at 15 cents apiece, or when plucked and in the stall at a dollar a pair, and thought to be well sold at that price, lately has experienced a rise, and become "an institution." It has its societies and its exhibitions, and now is assuming to be national.

A dull, heavy day, in both Houses, and little done. In the Senate, Mr. WHITNEY presented a petition asking for the passage of a law prohibiting the employment of Roman Catholic teachers in our common schools Mr. BROOKS introduced his bill for the incorporation of the Ladies' Home Missionary Society.

The Senate was not in the venerating mood today, so it did not adjourn over in consideration that it was the anniversary of WASHINGTON'S Birthday, but proceeded with business as usual. The regular proceedings up to the reports of Standing Committees were not of general interest.

DEAR SIR: If I am not misinformed, you are to record your vote in favor of the Nebraska bill. It is a matter of surprise to a vast majority of the people of the North that a bill portending more irremediable mischief than any one ever before offered to the National Legislature, could under any possible circumstances receive your approbation.

Private letters from Hon. JOH. J. CRITTENDEN express his intention, at a ?? entertainment to be given him at Frank or:, Ky., in a few days, to oppose the Nebraska bill. Senator SMITH, it is expected, will call for information relative to the retirement, of Mr. SANDFORD from Paris, which will, probably, bring up the whole subject of Ambassadorial dress.

WALLACK'S THEATRE--Reproduction appears to be the order of the day here. " "Erastins," dished up from the French, and "Temptation," dished up from nothing in particular, have been given to good houses. The first work possesses a certain amount of ingenuity, and affords ample opportunity for good acting, Mrs. STEPHENS, Mr. LESTER and Mr. DYOTT do all that can be done for it, and certainly make enough of it. But "Temptation" is another affair altogether.

Had GEORGE WASHINGTON witnessed the ceremonies in his honor which took place in this City yesterday, he would have been impressed with a befitting sense of the greatness of New-York and the esteem in which the services of the Revolutionary Heroes are held.

From the Courrier des E'ats Unis of yesterday. When we published on Saturday the secret designs pursued at this moment in some parts of the United States, our only object was to awaken public attention. In that point of view it has been reached. For the entire American Press, moved by the rumor of these facts, uninspected before, has reached the information we gave.

The annual meeting of this Association of ladies was held in the Lecture-room of the Broadway Tabernacle at 11 A.M., on Tuesday. Rev Dr PARKER presided. After singing and reading appropriate portions of the Scriptures, and player, Rev. Mr. EASTMAN read the Annual Report of the Association, containing Reports from each of the subordinate. Associations of which it is composed--showing that all had been well-sustained and attended through the year.

Your famous "Old Ironsides," the United States frigate Constitution, bearing the broad sennant of Commodore J. MAYO, Commander-in-Chief of the African Squadron, anchored in our bay on the 29th November, and having passed five most pleasant days with us, sailed again on the 4th Dec. for Monrovia.

The following facts with reference to the religious condition of several of the Colleges, are furnished from Ambers College: WATERVILLE COLLEGE, Maine, has 90 students, of whom 36 are professors of religion : 20 are preparing for the ministry, and 2 intend to be one missionaries to a foreign field. One case of conversion has occurred during the past year.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. "A Card" appears in the Express, Tribune, Commercial and Times, and probably in other papers of less circulation, purporting to be a defence of "Mr BOORMAN" against certain publications with which the writer supposes he has been "honored."

At a call of nearly four thousand citizens, (without distribution of party) of Oneida County, a mass meeting was held here to-day, to protest against the passage of DOUGLAS' Nebraska bill. A temporary organization was effected by the choice of JOHN D. MILLER, Esq , Chairman, and SIDNEY HENSHAW, and H. C. MATTESON, Secretaries.

On Monday, Feb. 20, RACHEL G., wife of William Gage, aged 56 years The friends of the family are requested to attend her funeral on Friday afternoon at 3 O'clock, P.M., from No. 271 3d St, without further invitation.

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times : In a critique contained in your paper of RED. FIELD'S reprint of COLLIER'S edition of SHAKSPEARE'S works, I find the following phrase: "Even the poor German, Dr. DELINS, who had got a translation of the former text nearly finished, on the basis of the well know edition of TIECK SCHELEGAL, must hasten to the work of usuals."

The Aldermen suffered an infraction of their dignity and of their privileges at the same moment last evening. A member of the Board expended much virtuous indignation upon the discovery of a "plagiarism."

An immense gathering of citizens of Boston and vicinity, of all shades of political opinion, took place in Faneuil Hall this afternoon and evening, to protest against the passage of the Nebraska bill. Hon. SAMUEL A. ELLIOT, was chosen President. Among the Vice Presidents were the Mayors of Boston, Raxbury, Cambridge, Charlestown, Lynn, Salem, and Lowell.

The Martha Washington conspirators, including KISSANE, CUMMINGS, COLE and CHAPING, were arrested this morning on a requisition from the Governor of Arkansas, and removed forthwith from the city-all being heavily ironed.

James Blydenburg, a young man of respectable appearance, was placed at the bar charged with grand larceny, in stealing four shawls, valued at $27, from Mr. Edward Phalon. tailor, of Broadway. Mr. Phalon deposed to the loss of fifteen shawls about the 26th of January last, four of which had been recovered from the prisoner. A clerk of Mr. Phalon's rectified that the first cost of the shawls was $27.

Ships--Michael Angela, Moore, San Francisco, John Ogden; George A. Phelps, Saermae, Liverpool, Cook ; Smith; Sea Serpent (clipper) Howland, San Francisco, Grinnell. Minturn Co.; Tropie, Smith, Havre, E D. Hurlout Co.; Enterprise, Davis, Liverpool, Taylor Rich.

The New-York TIMES was the only New-York paper received here yesterday which contained the Baltic's news. The Tribune and Herald had not a line of it. Competition for the earliest news is a feature in New-York newspapers. In this instance the TIMES has achieved a victory of which it may be proud.

We deeply regret to hear through the St. Thomas Times of Jan. 25th, of the death at that place on the 20th, of ISAAC B. HEADLEY, Esq., of this City, who had gone thither for his health. Mr. H. was formerly well known in Ohio, where he had been engaged in business until the failure of his health.

The steamship Northern Light, Capt. CHURCHILL from San Juan del Norte, arrived yesterday at 2 P. M., with 400 passengers and $800,000 in specie, on freight, to CHARLES MORGAN. We received early papers and letters through the politeness of Purser R LORD, ADAMS Co's, BEDFORD Co's, and WELLS, FARGO Co.'s Expresses
The following communication on this subject has been presented for the action of the Common Council. To the Honorable the Mayor and Common Council of the City of New York:

The bogus "Bank" gentry make their defence through the Herald. It appears in the money column as editorial. This does not conceal its origin. The unprincipled fellows who prepared it had as well signed their own names to the unblushing falsehoods.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I perceive in your issue of this date, an account of Colleges, the number of students, and number of professors of religion, But, strange to say, that you avoid making any mention of a Methodist College.

THE ROSS-STREET POISONING CASE.--Coroner BALL empanneled a Jury on Wednesday to investigate the causes of the death of the two Germans, DUNRISK and WEIDMASTER, who died suddenly a few weeks since at their boarding-house in Rosa-street, East Brooklyn, as in supposed from poisoning, as heretofore stated.

AN ADROIT ROGUE.--We learn from the Worcester Transcript that a man, named LABAN C. CANE, formerly an expounder of the science of Parenology in Worcester, was arrested several days since, in Hartford, for stealing a horse in Blackstone, and brought back to Blackstone, where he was lodged for the night in the fifth story of a house.

SIXTEENTH DAY--THURSDAY, Feb. 23. The Court assembled yesterday morning, at 11 o'clock. Present, Major General WINFIELD SCOTT, President; General STAUNTON and Colonel SUMNER, Col. GATES and his counsel. Capt. SHIELDS, was also in attendance, together with other officers.

BROOKLYN CITY RAILROAD COMPANY.--The books of this Company were opened on the 21st instant to receive subscriptions for stock, which was immediately taken up during that and the succeeding day, by about one hundred and fifty persons.

The Tribune says that it knows of some up-town subscribers to the TIMES who found not a word of the Baltic's news in that paper of Monday morning. We assure the Tribune that not a single copy of the TIMES was printed on Monday morning without the Baltic's news.

Owing to the tide not serving, the steamship America will not sail till 21/2 o'clock this afternoon. She takes out 14 passengers--no specie. It is snowing here, and is very cold. A strong northwest wind prevails.

NATHAN C. ECY, Esq, in the Chair. QUESTION OF PRIVILEGE--LITERARY TALENT OF THE BOARD INSULTED--GLARING PLAGIARISM Alderman HERRICK 1082 to a question of privilege. A great indignity had been offered to this Board to which be wished to call attention.

EDITORIALS--The War in Europe--Commercial Aspect at Home--The Repeal of the Missouri Compromise--Law and Romance--Austian Policy-Prince Albert--Privateering. POULTRY--The Cock Show-Pisciculture or Fish Breeding--Anybody's Child--Chinese intelligence--Recent Deaths--Silvio Pollico.

CANADIAN BALL.--The ladies of the Canadian Beneficial Society had a brilliant Ball, last night, in the Apollo Assembly Rooms. The evening passed very pleasantly with delightful music and a variety of beautiful dances.

General ARMSTRONG, of the Washington Union, died this evening, of congestion of the brain [For obituary notice, see fourth page.--ED. TIMES.] There was a large number of Postmasters confirmed by the Senate to-day, including the whole batch in Massachusetts.

FATAL ACCIDENT AT THE DIVISION STREET FERRY.--About 8 o'clock yesterday morning a young man named WILLIAM JOHNSON, residing in Grand street, near Third, was so seriously injured that he died about 10 o'clock, at the New-York Hospital.

A letter from the Breakwater, received at the Exchange, states that the storm of Monday night was the severest ever known, and was accompanied with terrific thunder and lightning. The beach is strewed with wrecks. Thirteen vease's are ashore within view of the Breakwater, among them the following schooners:

General ROBERT ARMSTRONG, of the Washington Union, whose death is announced by telegraph this morning, was a native of East Tennessee; his age was about 65 years. He removed at an early day to Nashville, where he lived as Merchant and Postmaster until 1845, when Mr. POLK, the President elect, gave him carte blanche to make choice of any post of honor or profit in the gift of the new Administration.

A long private letter has been received from our friend, Mr. MARTIN-no part of it ??, intended for publication, and in truth the writer know not that by the time it would come to hand, his correspondent would be an Editor.

The violent snow storm to-day detailed many of the trains with prominent politicians, who were expected to participate in the Anti-Nebraska meeting, announced to be holden in the Depot Hall. From this cause, Mr. BELL, the Whig candidate for Governor, who was expected to speak, was absent. But very few Democrats participated in the meeting, though many of them signed the call.
The Northern Light came up the Bay yesterday, and we received our papers by her at early evening. She has made a good trip, bringing in news from San Francisco only twenty-two days old.

Texas has not been favored with so delightful a Winter for many long years. The weather, for six weeks past, has borne a strong resemblance to Indian Summer. Rain is now really needed. Our interior navigation is closed for want of water. The Winter business of Houston continues unusually good. The city is fast improving.

M. PAUL ARPIN lectured on Saturday evening last, in the Chapel of the University, to a large and highly respectable audience. The attendance was even better than at his first entertainment. We remarked with pleasure that a large proportion of the audience were American ladies, who seemed to enjoy and appreciate M. ARPIN'S elegant and animated discourse, in a degree alike flattering to their own taste and the acknowledged ability of the lecturer.

Mr. HAMLIN presented the credentials of Mr. FESSENDEN, Senator from Maine, for six years from the 4th of March last. Mr. FESSENDEN appeared and was sworn. Mr. SHIELDS presented the credentials of Mr. DOUG LAS, Senator from Illinois, for six years from 4th March last. He was sworn last Spring without the presentation of his credentials.

During no other season of the year is the best possible arrangement of our ferries for the accommodation of the public, of greater necessity, than the present; and during none is the timetable so often disregarded.
We acknowledge the receipt of $25 from some one in Philadelphia, who desires us to appropriate it to the use of the "Girls' Industrial School, in Avenue D." He adds:
It may be some consolation to the stockholders of the Crystal Palace to know that theirs is not the only concern of this kind which has proved a dead loss.

THE WEATHER, Wednesday night, the wind shifted from W.S.W. to N.W., and during the whole of Thursday, has blown almost a gale, during which, about 4 o'clock P. M., the steamship Africa, for Liver pool, sailed, and no doubt made a fine run during the night.

The people of Boston held another mass meeting in Faneuil Hall, yesterday afternoon and evening, to protest against the passage of Senator DOUGLAS' Nebraska bill. Among the distinguished speakers on the occasion, were Hon. ABBOT LAWRENCE and Hon. ROBERT C. WINTHROP.

An important feature in the proceedings of the Senate, yesterday, was a petition presented through Senator CASS, asking the interposition of the Government with foreign powers, where such interposition is required, in order to secure to American citizens abroad, the enjoyment of religious worship, while living, and a place of sepulture and the rites of Christian burial when dead.

The resolutions introduced yesterday expressing Indignation at the attacks of the New York Tribune, were taken up to-day, and, after considerable discussion, were passed by 34 to 21. Those voting against the resolutions expressed themselves opposed to taking any action whatever in reference thereto.

The Pennsylvania Inquirer reckons that we of New-York "look on suicides and assassinations with wonderful indifference." The basis of the Inquirer's reckoning is the history of the LUTBNER tragedy, over which our citizens wondered quite intensely for a few days, and then, seeing the problem was too hard for them, gave it up, stopped marvelling, and forgot the case.

In the Senate, the Committee on Privileges and Elections, this morning, reported that ADAM STORING was the duly elected Representative from the Eighteenth Senatorial District, composed of the Counties of Otsege and Chenango, Instead of EBENEZER BLAKELEY, the present incumbent of the seat.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Some of our distinguished citizens will be indebted to the Map of the United States, as much, perhaps, as to the page of history, for preserving and handing down their names to posterity. They have their monuments, in the names given to places, in every section of the land.
The Richmond (Va) Whig, after some weeks of halting, gives in its adhesion to the bill of Senator DOUGLAS for repealing the Missouri Compromise, and establishing Slavery in Nebraska.

On Thursday, Feb. 23, by Rev J. B. Hagany, Mr. WILLIAM F. DUSENBURY to MRS SARAH A. ALBRO, all of this City. On Wednesday, Feb, 22, by Rev. Dr. Burcharl PROCTOR S. DUTCHINSON to Miss JULIA HOWELL HUNTINGTON, daughter of the late col. C. W. Huntington, of Norwich, Conn.

The heart upon which the memory of its early benefactor is engraven will glow with gratitude until its pulsations cease. We were indeed "wholly without means," and with a young family dependent upon our labor, when, thirty-two years ago, we applied to EVERARD PECK for employment. He did not really want a journey man, but his kindly nature prompted an effort in our behalf.

Pursuant to adjournment, this Court assembled Yesterday morning, at their accustomed place, at 11 o'clock. Present, General SCOTT, General STAUNTON, and Col. SUMNER, Col. GATES, with his Counsel, Capt. SHIELDS, together with other military officers, were present. The Judge Advocate having read the minutes of the last meeting.

The city that should lack hotels, would be quite an anomaly in this age. A house for the traveler is erected in every settlement, generally long enough before it is easy to discover why travelers should ever visit the neighborhood. The natural order of building, in a new village, is-first, a tavern, then a carpenter's shop, then the blue light in the window announces an apothecary;

It was in Edinburg last year that a doctor was called to see a lady who was prodigiously and very curiously sick. The doctor prescribed, but it did no good; indeed, every time the prescription was unusually long, or the medicine ordered very costly and long-named, she grew worse. At last, she died. The doctors called a consultation, and opened the body; and then and there-it is true:

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A communication in your paper this morning, and your habitual courtesy in matters of this kind, induces me to prefer my own complaint. I am the wife of a clergyman, and as my husband has no box in the General Post Office, I am wholly dependent upon the pennycarriers for the receipt and delivery of my letters.

The annual election of officers of the United States Agricultural Society, took place this morning. MARSHALL P. WILDER, of Massachusetts, was reelected President, with thirty-two Vice Presidents. Executive Committee-C. B. Calvert. J. A. King, J. D. Weston, A. L. Eliria, A. Watts, B. P. Poore, John Jones. Corresponding and Recording Secretary, WILLIAM S. KING, of Massachusetts; and Treasures, WILLIAM SHELDON.

Great pains are taken by Southern advocates of the Nebraska bill, to show that the Missouri Compromise was passed by Northern votes and against the wishes of the South. The following paragraph from the chapters of Col. BENTON'S reminiscences, recently given to the public, corrects this mistake:

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The advance in prices which has been going on for two or three years, is having pretty important bearings upon society. The main canse of this advance is supposed to be the immense gold discoveries in California and Australia. A short crop in Europe, and the prospect of a general war there, are no doubt operating just now upon the prices of breadstuffs and provisions.

The communication from the Representatives of the Fire Department of this City, in relation to the abuses alleged to exist in that Department, presented in the Board of Aldermen on Thursday evening, is given in full in our columns this morning. Appended to it are the resolutions adopted at Firemen's Hall in reference to the subject.

FATAL ACCIDENT IN HOLDEN.-We learn from the Worcester Transcript, that Mr MOSE BLACKMAR, on Monday last, was found dead in the pond below CHAFFIN's grist mill, in Helden. It is supposed that he entered the wheel pit for the purpose of starting the wheel, which was clogged by ice, and falling into the race-way, was unable to extricate himself Mr. B. was 78 years of age.

The ship Corneilus Grinnell, Capt. FLETCHER, from Liverpool, reports having had the roughest passage ever experienced by Capt. F., but has received no damage to hull, spars and sails. On Friday, 20th January, at noon, in latitude 48[degree], longitude 32[degree] saw it vessel with the American flag, union down, went to her assistance and found it to be the ship columbiana, of New-York, Capt. STAHL, from New-Orleans, bound to Liverpool.

The complaints uttered against the Gas Companies, 'or the Cimmerian darkness of the City on Tuesday night last, have some foundation in truth, and are likewise open to explanation. The truth that the Gas Companies are obliged, by the terms of their contract with the City Government, to furnish gas in certain quantities and under cortain conditions, is undoubted.

According to the programme published in the Republican and other City Papers, delegates from all the Republican Societies of New-York assembled at 41/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, in this club-room of the French Democratic Association, "Section de la Moniague," No 80 Leonard street, for the purpose of celebrating the anniversary of February 24, 1848, and the declaration of the French Republic. .

If our readers will hear with us one week longer, we will give them the DAILY TIMES in a much more legible and attractive typography than it has presented for a few weeks past. We ordered new type nearly two months since, but have been unable to procure it thus far.

THE STATEN ISLAND FERRIES.--Great complaint is made of the manner of conducting the Ferry from this City to New-Brighton, Staten Island. The irregularity and infrequency of the trips give plausible grounds for the remonstrances which the residents of that portion of the Island have laid before the Ferry Company.

We have received a copy of the New Zealander, of the 10th ult. The Governor, Sir GEORGE GREY, had returned from the Southern Settlements. 0n the 17th he was entertained at a public, dinner, on which occasion an address from the natives was presented to him, together with a song.

The excitement at the Court of St. James relative to the rumored exclusion of Mr. BUCHANAN from the opening of Parliament, because he was invited to appear there in court dress--which he could not wear, and, as an American, ought not to desire to wear--has extended itself to this metropolis.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Will you be kind enough to inform me, and many others interested, through the columns of the TIMES, to what parties letters should be addressed for the obtaining of the PERHAM Gift Prizes, and oblige,

The rumors to the effect that Mr. BUCHANAN intends to return, are unfounded. He designs shaming the British Government out of making his dress a question of international comity. Messrs. MARCY and CRAMPTON had an interview to-day relative to Lord CLARENDON'S declaration that the alliance between England and France on the Eastern question, was designed for the Western also. The result has not yet transpired.

HAPS AND MISHAPS OF A TOUR IN EUROPE. BY GRACE GREENWOOD. Boston: TICKNOR, REED FIELDS. New-York: EVANS DICKERSON. Of all recent tours in Europe with which we are acquainted, we consider GRACE GREENWOOD'S the best. Her Italy is far inferior to HILLARD'S,--but HILLARD confines himself to Italy.

The incredulity with which the rumor that the Russian Government contemplates raising armaments in American ports has been received by the Press of NewYork, presents a singular contrast to the unequivocal ap prehensions which have been, instinctively, awakened in Burope upon the same subject, and are visible enough in the columns of the newspapers brought hither by the last steamer, vague and reserved as they are,

It will be seen by a notice in another column, that a meeting of the Stockholders of the Crystal Palace is to be held at the Metropolitan Hotel this evening. The object of it is to nominate a Board of Directors to be supported at the coming election.

COSTS UNDER THE CODE--APPEALS IN SPECIAL PROCEEDINGS. Notwithstanding the limitation implied in the title "Of Civil Actions" prefixed to Part II. of the Code those provisions of that part of the Code which related to costs upon appeals, are applicable to appeals in special proceedings as well as to those "taken in civil actions, strictly so called.

INCENDIARY FIRES--LOSS OF LIFE.--No less than three incendiary fires occurred yesterday morning, and one was attended with the loss of life. The first broke out about 5 o'clock in a small liquor-store in Atlantic-street near Smith, kept by a man named WILSON. The Chair presented a communication from the Secretary of War, with a statement of contracts made by the War Department during 1853. CHILDREN'S AID SOCIETY.--The preliminary arrangements for the establishment of an Industrial School in this city, are new consummated. It is to be similar to the 'Children's Aid Society" of New-York, and is to be under the direction of an association of ladies, of which Mrs. C PEARCE, Mrs. F. DUNGAM and Mrs. E. N. COLT have been chosen Directresses.

During the past year there were 406 patients within the Pennsylvania Hospital for the Insane. 88 were cured, 16 much improved, 38 improved, and 15 died; yet there is room in the building for only 220. It seems that Penusylvania, having a population exceeding two and a half millions, has provision for only about nine hundred and thirty insane, while, at the end of 1840, with a population of less than two millions,

The Court of Inquiry into the causes and circumstances of the dreadful disaster to the San Francisco, which has been in session for some days past in this City, closed its proceedings yesterday and was adjourned sine die. Mr. SAUNDRRS, the Marshal of the pro cession of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, which was engaged in a riots in the Ninth Ward on the 4th of July last, having been convicted of riotous conduct, was sentenced on Saturday in the Court of Sessions to four months' imprisonment in the Penitentiary. We have received a copy of the Report of the Commissioner of Patents, and from it learn the following digested facts: The receipts of the Patent Office for the year 1853, on application for patents, , were $121,527, while the expenses have been $132,870. Among the items of expenses were $7,086 for seeds and agricultural statistics; $29,513 for salaries, offices, and $23,466 refunded money on withdrawals,

MERCANTILE LIBRARY LECTURES.--GOLD AND GILT OF YOUNG AMERICA.--GEOEGA W. CURTIS, Esq., delivered a lecture before the Mercantile Library Association, at Hope Chapel on Friday evening, on "The Gold and Gilt of Young America." There was a large and respectable attendance.

Mr. FESSENDEN presented numerous petitions from Maine, against, the nebraska bill. Mr. COOPER presented a memorial of the Society of Friends against the extension of Slavery. Mr. BRODHEAD presented petitions against the Nebraska bill.

A caricature entitled " The Modern Sword of Damocles at the Bourse," represents the trunk of M. DE KISSELEFF hung in mid-air over the heads of the gentlemen of the Stock Exchange. For a fortnight the rumors that this trunk was packed, that it was unpacked, that it was repacked and re. unpacked, kept the Board of Brokers in a state of perpetual fluctuation. last the trunk

By the Cunard steamer Europa, from Liverpool, about 10 o'clock morning of Saturday, Feb. 11, we have advices from Liverpool, and by telegraph from London to that date. The Cunard Company contradict the statement that the British Government has chartered their steamers for the conveyance of troops to Turkey.

The weather has been unusually severe of late. Nevertheless, only one wreck and two vessels in distress are reported. The brig Warren, BROWN, from Jamaica or New-York, arrived on the 11th in distress. She has been repaired, and will nail to day. On the 14th, the schooner George Manyham, from Philadelphia for New-Orleans, put in distress, with the carge damaged.

From the London Morning Post. ST. PETERSBURO, Wednesday, Feb. 1,1854. The excitement was very great. The war party was very enthusiastic, and the peace party very anxious. Nothing had transpired in official circles. The Emperor was suffering from an attack of bile, accompanied by fever. The presence of gout was also suspected.

Warlike preparations and diplomatic departures form the staple of the Europa's news, full details of which will be found in this morning's TIMES. KISSELEFF has left Paris, BRUNOW has left London, Count ORLOFF has left Vienna, and Baron BUDREIG has left Berlin.

In our report of the proceedings respecting an attempt of the pardoned policemen-Kennedy and Smith -to establish a charge of perjury against police-officer Kemp, as published in Saturday's TIMES, the compositor made a trifling error In the heading, to wit: '' Complaint against the pardoned policemen for perjury," instead of "complaint by them," as it was written by our reporter.

The steamship Isable has arrived here, bringing Havana end Key West dates to the 22d inst. From Havana we learn that the three American sailors, so long confined, had, through the exertions of Mr. Ron. ERTSON, the acting United States Consul, been liberated, and placed in his hands.

We publish this morning some highly interesting documents recently laid before the Senate, relating to negotiations with Switzerland, and embracing the text of a Convention agreed upon between the representatives of the two Republics. The negotiation was set

PROVISIONS--The demand for BACON has fallen off. BEEF and PORK are without buyers, except in merest retail. CHEESE scarce, and in moderate request. LARD remains steady; some sales for Spring delivery have been made at 558. TALLOW is rather dearer. LOVERSEED is neglected.

The protest of the English and French Ministers against American privateers, is the principal topic of conversation here. Mr. MARCY'S reply has not transpired. It is reported that J. J. CRITTENDEN has declared for the Nebraska Bill.

A "democratic conspiracy " was discovered at Madrid on 'the 6th-fourteen persons were arrested. Gen. Jose CONCHA is proclaimed a rebel, but has escaped into France. Count BUOL has notified the Turkish Ambassador that the concentration of troops on the frontier is intended only as a precautionary measure against Turkey. This notification was accompanied by friendly expressions.

We have New Orleans papers of last Monday by the Southern mail to day. A prohibitory Liquor law passed both branches of the Mississippi Legislature, but has to go back to the House for concurrence in amendments made in the Senate. The amount of United States stocks redeemed at the U. S. Treasury last week was $186,000

DUNECOMB, the Comptroller, pro tem., and Clerk of the Vesiry of Trinity Church. To the allusions thus made to him, Mr. B. submitted a respectful Card, in reply, on the 22d inst.

The management, or, rather, mismanagement, of the affairs of the Smithsonian Institute has been lately a subject of very general remark here. It is quite obvious that the purposes of the liberal-minded founder of this establishment have not been carried out in the conduct of its affairs. uest

THE RESIGNATION OF REV. DR. COX.--We have already mentioned the fact that Rev. Dr. Cox has applied for a release from his pastoral relations with the First Presbyterian Church in Henry street. Dr. Cox has presided over this congregation for the past seventeen years. Continued ill-health compel him to desist from ministerial labors, and he intends to retire to the country, having purchased a small farm near Owego. hurch

It is well that the Gadsden Treaty with Mexico has obtained the publicity which the absurd custom of secret sessions denied it. The instrument, without any authoritative knowledge of its provisions, had become the subject of very general public discussion, and considerable severe and unreasonable animadversion.

MUSEUM.--A drama in four acts, called the "Old Brewery," and adapted in some extraordinary way from the powerful work of that name recently published, was produced here last evening. It is from the pen of McCONWAY, and to that gentleman belongs much credit an unusual display of ingenuity in its composition; also for a tone more elevated and less conventional than we have been in the habit of hearing in other of his dramatic efferts.

By the bark Swan, at this port, we have Buenos Ayres dates to January 8. There is no news of interest. Exchange on the United States was at 3 per cent discount, and doublocks were quoted at 283@196 1/2. The latest advices from Montevideo represent that the advantage obtained by MORENO was but short-lived. His forces were completely routed and dispersed by Colonel FLORES,--MORENO and BENITES contriving to escape by water to Envre Rios.

We yesterday received a letter from "Captain D. S. GIBBS, of the Rocky Mountains," informing us that he would visit our city in a very few days, for the purpose of raising a company of young men to go immediately to the Territory of Nebraska, now holding so prominent a place in the public attention, for the purpose of settling and laying claim to some of the most valuable land in the West.
The strom of Saturday caused much damage in this vicinity. The Delaware rose 11 feet, and the Lehigh 6 feet, but both rivers are now falling. The Morris Canal is some what damaged.

The Peruvian Government have declined conforming to their agreement to settle with Capt. McCERREN for the injuries sustained by him at the Chincha Islands. Secretary MARCY is determined to compel them to stand by their own offer of settlement, and is inquiring concerning the best mode of bringing a ship of war argument to bear upon the case.

ARREST OF A POLICY DEALER -- Yesterday afternoon, officers SHERMAN and LARAMEE made a descent upon a Policy office at a private house in Eleventh-street, and arrested the occupant who is charged with dealing in Policies.

The Committee appointed to report in respect to a resolution for repealing the ordinance to open Albany street through Trinity Churchyard, held an adjourned meeting in the Chamber of the Board of Aldermen, at 3 o'clock P. M., yesterday. Present, Aldermen DRAKE, BROWN and BLUNT. There was a numerous attendance.

To Hon. Jacob Collumer, Postmaster General, Washington: MY DEAR JUDGE: As I suppose you will soon be thinking of a mail route to San Francisco, Cal, you will allow me to present a few suggestions for your consideration.

THE PATENT-SAFE GAME--ARREST OF A CONFIDENCE MAN.--Another patent-safe operation was perpetrated yesterday forenoon about 11 o'clock, by which a countryman named Oliver Smith, residing in Coshocton County, Ohio, was swindled out of $200. Mr. Smith arrived in New York on Monday morning, on his way to California, and stopped at the Girard House.

The bill to reverse and annul the judgment against THOMAS W. DORR was passed in the House this afternoon, with amendments, and goes back to the Senate tomorrow for concurrence. As amended in the House, the bill takes effect immediately. This is to prevent the Judges from interfering to prevent the execution of the act, if they should decide it to be unconstitutional. The debate was very excited.

A public meeting was held at the First Reformed Dutch Church last evening, to discuss the propriety of extending the Charter of the Camden and Amooy Railroad Company to the year 1889, as proposed by the bill now pending in the Legislature of the State, and which has passed the Senate.
Our reports of the two Boards of the Corporation were crowded out yesterday morning by the pressure of other matters. The leading proceedings were follows: GRANITE BLOCKS.

The steamship United States, from Aspinwall on the 22d inst., has arrived below. She reports that the steamship Empire City, from New-York vid Norfolk, arrived at Aspinwall on the morning of the 22d, and would leave the same afternoon for New York, with 200 passengers, and $600,000 in gold.

Since that time a call for a meeting to consider the subject was given in the various churches of the city, at which meeting quite a number of our most respectable citizens attended.
