The Senate wad deluged this morning with remonstrances against the repeal or abrogation of the Missouri prohibition, presented by Senators, BRODHEAD, SMITH, SEWARD, FISH, THOMPSON, of New-Jersey: EVERETT, WADE CHASE and SUMMER.

VETO.--Mayor LAMBERT has vetoed the report of the Assessment Committee relative to Atlantic-avenue grading from Gowanus-lane to Clason-avenue, on the ground that the proceedings had by the Commissioners are not in conformity with the law, and, if confirmed may subject the city to large expense.

Raritan Chapter, of the Order of United Americans, celebrated the Birthday of Washington, at Keyport N. J., with appropriate ceremonies. Senator CLAYTON speaks to-morrow against the Nebraska bill in its present shape. He will offer some amendments necessary to secure his vote, which the friends of the bill will not accept. Senator JOHN BELL intends to speak against the bill. Also Messrs. FOOTE and FESSENDEN are expected to oppose it. The interest and excitement here are increasing.

The receipts of the American Tract Society for the last month, were $60.056, including $29,525 in donations. The gratuitous circulation of publications since April 1, exceeds 46,000,000 of pages. The daily issue of books is about 5 000, and of other publications. including periodicals, nearly 50,000.

Governor DRAPER, President, in the Chair. The large lecture room of the New-York Medical College in Thirteenth street, was crowded at an early hour last evening, to attend the Commencement Exercises. The Chair was occupied by Judge EDWARDS. Dr. HENRY G. Cox, one of the Censors of the College, made a statement concerning the affairs of the institution.

There is much excitement here in relation to the murder of Mrs. FILER. Her husband was arrested and examined yesterday before Justice CUDDEBACK, of this city. MARY CUMINGS, the servant girl, testified that FILER attempted to poison his wife a week before the murder was committed.

A gentleman residing in this village has a dog of remarkable intelligence. Don--for that is the name given him by his master--has been taught to start off to the Colonel's as soon as the train arrives bringing the mail, to get the NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES. No sooner is the whistle of the approaching train new heard by him, than he "is on tip-toe for the news."

The Army Medical Board, which convened in the City of New-York on the 1st of December last, for the examination of Assistant Surgeons for promotion, and of applications for appointment in the Medical Staff of the Army, adjourned sin: die on the 4th inst., after a continuous session of more than two months.
A meeting of persons interested in the formation of the "American and Foreign Emigrant Protective and Employment Society," was held yesterday at the New Bible House.

In the Senate, yesterday, the chief subject of interest was the speech of Senator CLAYTON in favor of the Nebraska bill. He claimed, during his speech, that in favoring the bill, he was acting upon no newly adopted set of principles, and declared his belief that the Missouri Compromise was unconstitutional, and that he would vote for its repeal.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It is acknowledged that in our Commercial Marine may be found the most splendid ships which grace the ocean, the largest and finest sea steamers afloat; yet what would one of our "merchant princes" think, if on giving out his "specifications," the constructor required of him three years to build him a first-class steamer?

Island of St. Thomas--Terrific Ravages of the Cholera--The Neighboring Islands. British steamship Curlew, SAMPSON, from St. Thomas February 20 and Bermuda February 25, with merchandize and seven passengers to E. CUNARD, Jun.

Meeting of Army and Volunteer Officers. About twenty-five gentlemen who held commands in the regular and volunteer service during the Mexican War, assembled last evening, at FRENCH'S Hotel, to take into consideration a proposition, made in the West and Southwest, to give those officers additional rations to those allowed during that war.

PROFESSOR SHEDD.--The inaugural discourse of Professor SHEDD, on assuming the chair of Ecclesiastical History at Andover, two weeks ago, was on "The Historic Spirit, and its Influence upon the Taeolagian." We suppose Professor SHEDD will be more at home at Andover than at Auburn, and yet we are pained at losing him from this State.

We have received the undermentioned compositions: From S. C. JOLLIE, Broadway--Jullien's Music for the Million. This excellent collection of vocal and instrumental pieces is the Gift volume of Monsieur JULLIEN. A hundred thousand copies are to be printed, and the popularity of the composer justifies the belief that that immense edition will be sold.

Interesting News from a Private Letter. The news by the Andes, which has brought us no London papers, is very meagre. The most interesting part of it concerns the chartering of thirteen steamships, by the British Government, to convey troops to Malta.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It is known to most of our readers that this eminent missionary arrived in this City by the Africa from Liverpool, and that during the few days that he spent among us, he employed himself in visiting our principal educational institutions.

AN INHUMAN MOTHER--RUM'S DOINGS.--Coroner Hilton held an inquest on Tuesday morning at Bellevue Hospital, on the body of Catharine Reburg, aged 14 years. The testimony adduced went to show that the child had been horribly maltreated by its mother, forcing her to go around the streets bare-footed and poorly clad for the purpose of begging, in order to raise the means for the unnatural mother to purchase rum with.

THE READE-STREET MURDER.--Yesterday afternoon Coroner O'DONNELL proceeded to the Tombs and examined JOHN WILSON, the murderer who stabbed the German grocer in Reade-street on Tuesday:

A Lecture delivered before the American Anti-Slavery Society, by Wendell Phillips. On Tuesday evening, WENDELL PHILLIPS delivered an able and eloquent address on the above subject at the Broadway Tabernacle, in the presence of a large and highly respectable audience.

Judge NICHOLSON said this morning to Mr. DEAN and other anti-Nebraska Democracts, that he would not make fealty to the Nebraska bill, a test of Democracy--that there were no tests outside the "Baltimore Platform." This united the party and secured NICHOLSON's election.

THE SONS OF TEMPERANCE IN THE UNITED STATES.--From interesting statements lately made public, we gather some facts in relation to the origin and growth of the Order of Sons of Temperance in this country. The organization was commenced on Sept. 29, 1842. The party which first started the project numbered sixteen persons.

Meeting of Merchants at the Corn Exchange. A public meeting of merchants was held yesterday morning at the Corn Exchange, to take action in regard to a repeal or modification of the usury laws of this State.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: We understand that Capt. HUDSON, of the United States Navy, has just been ordered to report on the fitness of a certain vessel belonging to the mercantile marine for transporting the unfortunate 3d Regiment to California. There can be no doubt that sailing vessels are far better adapted for such service than steamers.

The popular English author, WILLIAM HOWITT, has just published an account of his experience at the gold diggings in Australia, which quite takes the romantic coloring from the picture, and leaves only very sombre tints behind.

On Saturday last we published in the TIMES the bill reported by the Assembly Committee on Commerce regulating Wharfage in New-York. On Monday the Albany Evening Journal copied the bill, very handsomely crediting the TIMES, and commenting upon it in a strain which we are happy to say is a little unusual for that generally sound and worthy paper.

Their Geographical Position and Extent, and their Geognostic Character and Scenery. The Sandwich, or, in official language, Hawaiian Islands, compose the most important group in Western Polynesia. No cluster of islands has so rapidly sprung into a world-wide notice, nor has any group in the Western Hemisphere elicited so many comments, oral and written, as that immediately before us.

NEW CHURCH ORGANIZED.--The Elm-place Congregational Church was organized on Monday evening with the usual ceremonies. The services were opened with a prayer by Rev. A large meeting of the citizens of Westchester County was held at the Village Hall in Peekskill, on Tuesday evening last, to protest against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise. The call was signed by one hundred and fifty citizens of Peekskill, without distinction of party.

The screw-steamship Andes, from Liverpool February 14, arrived at Boston about 8 o'clock yesterday morning. She brought no London papers or circulars, and the only paper that we have been able to procure is the London Times of the 14th.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE AT PORTLAND, KY.--About 7 o'clock last night a fire broke out in Portland, in the store of Messrs McCULLOUCH BUREN. The building was three or four stories high. The steamship Corwin, from Havana 1st inst., has arrived here with dispatches for Washington, detailing the seizure of the steamship Black Warrior, bound from Mobile to New-York, by the Cuban authorities for an alleged infringement of the revenue laws, she having some cotton on board for New-York not included in the manifest. The captain and crew of the Black Warrior abandoned the vessel.

From the Santa Fe Gazette. MORE DEPREDATIONS OF THE INDIANS--THE JICARILLAS AND OTHES, BECOMING TROUBLESOME.--It appears that about the the first of this month a party of Jicarilla Apaches made a descent upon the Rancho of Jesus Gallegos, and run off twenty head of beeves. .

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your article in this day's paper on "City Fires," you speak of the Cincinnati Steam Fire-engine. The success of the experiment in the Queen City of the West has determined its city authorities to supersede the old fashioned engines entirely. The steam-engine can be worked at a greater distance from the fire, is more effective, and every way superior to the ordinary fire-engine.

Important Case--Sub-Marine Telescope. BROOKLYN CITY COURT. Sarah P. Mather, against Willard Day.--This was an action upon a promissory note, made the defendant, for one hundred dollars, payable to The order of Mrs. Mather, five years after dare.

Sermon by Dr. Duff. Sunday evening Dr. DUFF, the distinguished Missionary of Calcutta, delivered a particularly able and instructive term n in the presence of a very large congregation, at the Presbyterian Church, corner of Crosby and Grand-streets.

The Senate rested from its labors yesterday, as was exceedingly proper. The House worked the more vigorously, seeing that the Nebraska bill was in their hands ready for action at any moment. It is understood, however, that action upon it will be postponed for a week.
The Atlantic, now fully due at this port, has not has not yet made her appearance. NANTASKET, Boston Harbor, March 6--11 P.M. There are yet no signs of the screw-steamer Alps, her seventeenth day.

In the Legislature of Pennsylvania, to-day, a most important bill was introduced by GIDEON J. BALL, of Erie, which has for its object nothing more nor less than transferring the late Franklin Canal and Railroad Company to the Sunbury and Erie Railroad Company.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: During the past Summer, when the public mind was agitated by projects for the construction Railroad in Broadway, the undersigned invited attention to his plans for an ELEVATED RAILWAY AND TERRACE PROMENDADE in that thoroughfare.

The Nebraska bill has passed the Senate, after having been emasculated in regard to what I deem one of its most essential provisions. Mr. CLAYTON, of Delaware, (a State not likely to increase in power and influence by foreign immigrants,) moved to strike out that portion of the fifth section of the bill, which allows foreigners, having filed their preliminary declaration to become citizens of the United States, the privilege of voting and holding office.

The London Examiner, in an article copied in another part of this morning's TIMES, contends that England may wage successful war against Russia without great expense or loss to herself, by simply shutting up her ports.

BOARD OF EDUCATION--CHILDREN.--An adjourned meeting of the Board was held on Saturday evening. The President, Mr. DEMAREST, in the Chair. Mr. BROACH, from the Committee, submitted the following report of the number of children in each Ward: First Ward.--Number of white children, 5,200; number of colored children, 81. Increase of white children, since last year. 264 ; do. of colored, 10.

From the Ballimore Sun. The origin, prosecution and detection of the GARDINER fraud abound with startling facts, and the mind is puzzled to determine, sometimes, where complicity end, and innocent participation with it begins. "The Senate Committee on Public Lands have decided against the appropriation for the construction of a Ship Canal around Niagara Falls."--Buffulo Express. The Committee on Public Lands has asked to be discharged from the further consideration of the memorials praying for grants to the Siate of New-York for the construction of the Ship Canal, indeed.

A Busy, exciting, evening was passed by the Councilmen, in discussing the provisions of the new Ordinance for Cleaning the Streets of the City. It was determined that the City be divided into small districts, for street-sweeping purposes, Dozens of amendments to the original recommendations were proposed, and nearly all were voted

Our Summer travel is not likely to be as open to the advantages and disadvantages of competition as it has been hitherto. We have already noticed the Railroad Convention held at Buffalo a few days since, to agree upon some uniform scale of charges for passengers and freight, as well as for other purposes.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : I have been asked several times, within a few days, why the "Sailor's Home" was to let. The fact is, several houses in the City have assumed the title of "Sailor's Homes," by which sailors are often deceived, and get into the wrong place. The "Home" to let is doubtless one of these.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your issue of this morning, in your paragraph on the recent fire, you say: "The Bostonians boast of their telegraph system, by which an alarm is given as quickly as electricity can covey it." That is strictly true. Dr. SMITH, the present Mayor of Boston, in his Inaugural Address, says:

We glean from the New-Orleans papers of the 27th and 26th ult., full particulars of the recent fatal accident at the Orleans Theatre in that city, of which we were apprised several days since by the Telegraph. The Theatre, during the last Winter, was remodeled and enlarged, and rendered much more airy and beautiful.

SINGULAR DEATH.--A singular death transpired in this village on Tuesday last. Miss ELIZABETH A. HAWYER, a young lady employed in the cotton mill of NATHAN WILD, while at work on Friday, the 27th ult., took in her mouth, as she had been in the habit of doing, the yarn which she was about placing in the shuttle for the loom.

The Gadsden Treaty is not reported from the Committee on Foreign Relations to-day, as was expected. The Committee have been engaged in discussing several amendments. The Navy Department has not received a single word from the Surveying Party, indicating the impracticability of the Darien Ship Canal route.

The Mississippi Free Trader of the 25th ult. contains a long article upon the story which recently appeared in the Tribune, of a slave having been burned alive at Union Point, on the banks of the Mississippi. In reply to the request of correspondents, the Editor of the. Free Trader gives the following as an authentic account of the transaction referred to:

THE MURDER CASE--THE BODY IDENTIFIED AS THAT OF AN ITALIAN REFUGEE.--At 10 o'clock yesterday morning, the investigation into the mysterious murder of Monday evening was resumed, before Coroner HANFORD. The body was recognized as that of an Italian refugee, named GIOVANNI FERDINANDA. The principal witness was GUIDAM MANCINI, of New-York, in whose employ deceased had been for sometime, in the capacity of barber.

Our City authorities have set themselves vigorously at work to clean the streets from the dirt and filth which have accumulated since the cowardly resignation of ARCULARIUS, and the refusal of the contractors to fulfil their stipulations.

The Charleston Courier gives various ex tracts from THEODORE PARKER'S discourse on Slavery and the Nebraska movement, and remarks that a true Southerner can well afford to forgive his denunciations, in consideration of his tribute to the fidelity with which the South stands up in defence of its own interests. It proceeds to say:

A Card from Senators SEWARD and others appears in another column, certifying that Mr. EVERETT, in spite of his failure to vote when the final question was taken on the passage of the Nebraska bill, was opposed to it; and that his position upon it is just as satisfactory as if he had voted against it.

SIR: Your zeal in the duties of your Committee, and the sort of difficulties you have already encountered in ascertaining what ought to be done, and how to get it done, may incline you to consider some suggestions, which arose on reading that part of the Annual Message of his Honor the Mayor, which refers to the topic pursued in this letter.

From the Washington Union of yesterday. From all the indications which come to us from the North and Northwest, we think it may be safely said that the principles involved in the Nebraska and Kansas bill, which has just passed the Senate by such a triumph ant majority, are marking a clear and unmistakable line of division there between Democrats and Whigs. This is as we anticipated.

INTERESTING LAW CASE.--CAN PERSONAL SERVICES BE ASSIGNED?--An interesting case, involving the law of contracts for services, and the question whether personal services are assignable, has been decided in the Supreme Court, (Special Term,) by Judge MITCHELL. The parties to the suit were N. K. ANTHONY against T. F. BEALE.

The following is a copy of a telegraphic dispatch, received by Messrs. LIVINGSTON, CROCHERON Co., the agents of the steamship Black Warrior, from Capt. J. D. BULLOCH, her commander, this morning, March 7: CHARLESTON, Monday, March 6, 1854. Messrs. LIVINGSTON, CROCHERON Co.: The Black Warrior has been detained by the authorities at Havana. Her cargo is declared confiscated, and is now being discharged by Spanish officers.

In the House little of importance was transacted, almost the entire session being passed in the consideration of the Medical bill. Speeches were made by six or seven opponents of the bill, which will probably bring out some of the strong men of the House in its support. With this understanding progress was reported.

KINGS COUNTY OYER AND TERMINER. Before Judges Rockwell and Moore, and Justices Stilwell and Stryker. The trial of WILLIAM BRENNAN for the murder of MICHAEL, HORAN in Williamsburg, on the night of December 30, 1853, was commenced yesterday before the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer. The murder was committed during a scuffle between the parties, in a porter-house kept by the prisoner.

MR. EVERETT WISHES TO RECORD HIS VOTE AGAINST THE NEBRASKA BILL. Mr. EVERETT said that he was absent on Saturday morning, when the final vote was taken on the Nebraska bill. He was severely indisposed at that time, and, as was well known, his health had not been good for some time. He was on that night over-fatigued, and was unable to remain till the hour when the vote was taken.

A terrific storm occurred here last night, doing much damage. No details are yet given. The letter of NAPOLEON to the Czar has been printed in the form of a placard, read publicly in all the barracks of France, and profusely distributed throughout all the communes in the Departments. It is also posted in large characters at the corners of every street in Paris.

The improved demand last noticed has continued, and the prices current for American are perhaps 1-16d. dearer-other qualities are unchanged. The week's sales foot up 69,600 bales, (of which 46,000 were American,) including 20,800 on speculation, and 3,440 for export. To-day (Friday) the sales were 8,000 bales with a firm market.

Texas has not been favored with so delightful a Winter for many long years. The weather for six weeks past has borne a strong resemblance to Indian Summer. Rain is now really needed. Our interior navigation is closed for want of water. The Winter business of Houston continues unusually good. The city is fast improving.

The market was flat and 1-16d. lower. The sales of the three days--the 18th, 20th and 21st--amounted to 19,000 bales, including for export 1,000, and on speculation, 2,000. Messrs. BROWN, SHIPLEY Co. quote the, following as rather extreme rates: Fair Orleans, 6 1/4d.; Middling, 6d.; Fair Mobile, 6 1/4d.; Fair Upland, 6 1/4d.; Middling, 5 7/8.; Ordinary, 4 3/4d.@5 1/4d.; Inferior, 3 1/4d.

On Tuesday, March 7, after a brief illness, Mrs. FRANCES BELL, relict of the late Nathaniel Bell, in the 77th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are requested to attend her funeral from the residence of her daughter, Mrs. E. M. Bunce, No. 19 Hubert-st., on Thursday afternoon, March 9, at 3 o'clock, without further invitation. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

The narrative of the GRINNELL Expedition in search of Sir JOHN FRANKLIN, has at length made its appearance. It is two years and a half since the Expedition returned from its adventurous voyage; but the story of the perils it underwent can never lose its interest.

It must be allowed that our paternal Government is not deluding itself with any illusions about the disposition of Hungary, The imprisonments and condemnations are as frequent as ever. War is at hand, but the dynasty has not yet come forward with any of those customary concessions, clemencies, and promises, which reckless and despotic sovereigns are generally in the habit of be stowing, whenever dreaded eventualities approach and the people's help is to be secured.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The following passage is from the speech of Senator DOUGLAS on introducing his Nebraska bill: But, Sir, these Abolition confederates, in their manifesto, have also referred to the wonderful results of their policy in the State or Iowa and the Territory of Minnesota. Here again they happened to be in fault as to the laws of the land.

Mr. EMERSON'S address before the Anti-Slavery Society, at the Tabernacle last evening, was in his usual vein, and there fore not very well adapted to the practical temper of his audience, or the practical objects for which they had assembled.

The Cunard steamer Asia arrived out at Liverpool at 2 o'clock, P. M., on the 20th Feb. The screw steamer City of Glasgow, from Philadelphia, also arrived out on the 20th. The terrific gale at Liverpool, reported by the Alps, had entailed no casualties on American shipping, excepting some of trivial importance.

By far the most important part of the last foreign news received by the Nashville and the Alps relates to NAPOLEON'S letter to the Czar, as published officially in the Moniteur. Some of our contemporaries have, strangely enough, regarded this letter as an opening to fresh negotiations, when it must be apparent to all who examine its bearings, carefully, that the way to further negotiations is effectually closed by that very document.

In this City, on Monday, March 6, by Rev. Dr. Spring, CHARLES F. CHESSMAN, of Milford, Mass., to Miss JULIA G. CASSITT, of La Grange, Tenn. In this City, on Tuesday, March 7, by Rev. James Beattic, Mr. LOUIS T. VALENTINE, to Miss CORDELIA, eldest daughter of the late George H, Hill, Esq., all of New-York.

From the Hartford Courant of Monday. Some time last October a stranger, calling him self HARRISON, hired a part of a house in Wethersfield lane, for himself and wife, of R. G. DRAKE, Esq., and soon after moved into it--other families occupying the other portions of the house. He soon left, and has seldom been seen since, only returning for a short visit once or twice.

The CUNARD Screw-Steamer Alps, with the European mails of the 18th ult., arrived at this port at about 9 o'clock this forenoon. The Alps brings twenty-nine passengers, and the mails of the 18th for the United States and Canada. On the 19th, the Alps passed the ship A. Z., round to Liverpool from New-York.

HARPER'S MAGAZINE.--The March number of this favorite periodical was issued yesterday. It is the last number which will be delayed beyond the regular Magazine day of publication. The April number will appear on the first of that month, with the other Magazines.

You must have become aware, through your exchanges, how universal is the dislike and condemnation of the Nebraska bill in the North west. The best index, of course, is to be found in the sentiments of Democratic journals, since they alone have any temptation to uphold it.

The Washington Union issues an official pronunciamento, which will be found in another column, substantially declaring that the Nebraska bill is to be made a party test. It gives, with an edifying minuteness, the view which the President proposes to take of the matter, and the extent to which he will permit members of the Democratic party to withold their support from the bill.

GEORGE E. PUGH was elected United States Senator by the two Houses of the Ohio Legislature, in joint session, on the 4th instant--receiving 80 votes out of 110 cast. The Cunard screw-steamer Alps, with the Liverpool mails of the 18th February, reached Boston at about 9 o'clock yesterday morning, and a full synopsis of her intelligence, received by telegraph, was published in last Evening's TIMES.
Three thousand troops embarked from Liverpool to-day. The Greek insurrection has gained a formidable headway--6,000 men being under arms in Epurus, Macedonia, and Thessaly.

In the House of Commons, on the 15th, the following conversation took place : Mr. DISRADLI--I wish to make an inquiry of her Majesty's Government respecting a very important diplomatic document which has appeared in a foreign journal. It affects to be a letter--an autograph letter--from the Emperor of the French to the Emperor of Russia, and is apparently written with the sanction of the Government of this country.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your paper of the 7th inst., I perceive a statement addressed "To the Public" by RICHARD BUSTEED, Esq., which unnecessarily and rather unfairly, as I think, introduces met to the public in connection with the late RESTELL case before Judge STUART.
Mr. FISH presented two memorials in favor of the grant of land to aid in the construction of a ship canal around the Falls of Niagara, and its reference to the Committee on Public Lands.

The regular monthly meeting of this Society was held in the small chapel, University, on Tuesday evening. Hon. LUTHER BRADISH presided. The Librarian, Mr. GEO. II. MOORE, reported the donations and additions to the Library since last meeting.

THE MYSTERIOUS MURDER.--CORONER'S INVESTIGATION CONTINUED.--The investigation relative to the mysterious murder on Sunday evening of GIOVANNI FERDINANDI, was resumed before Coroner HANFORD and the Jury, at 8 o'clock last evening, at the Mayor's office.

The certainly that this country is how at war has a depressing influence on business, and we have to report a dull, quiet COTTON market, with a shade less firmness in prices, the sales for the past two days being 11,000 bales, speculators and exporters taking 2,000 bales. The following quotations must be considered rather extreme: Fair Orleans.
BURTON'S THEATRE.-- A novelty--and a good one--called the "Lancers," was produced here last evening. It is adapted from the French, and was first produced in London at the end of last year.
The news by the Atlantic, of which very full details will be found in this morning's TIMES, is of very great interest and importance.

The Foreign accounts by the Atlantic this morning were unfavorably construed on the Stock Exchange, besides checking the good business which had been going on in Cotton for a week or two past. On the other hand, the rise in Grain and Flour, or rather the partial recovery of those staples in the English market, caused an advance here of 18?@25 cents the barrel, and 5@6 cents the bushel.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your issue of the 4th inst., your Albany Correspondent, in his report of the proceedings before the New-York Delegation does me great injustice. The facts, as they existed in regard to myself, are these:

In the Assembly this morning, the Judiciary Committee reported against the petition of the Turnverein Society of the City of New-York, asking for an act of incorporation. The motion to agree with the report of the Committee was laid upon the table.

The friends of Anatomical Science can rejoice in one triumph at least. The Dissection bill has not, indeed, passed the Assembly, but it has been repeatedly discussed there, and members have learned to face the ghost without childish shivering.

A regular meeting of this Board was held in the City Hall yesterday afternoon, C. P. SMITH, Esq., in the Chair. The Teacher's Committee made a report, which was accepted, of several appointments and doings of teachers in Schools Nos. 6, 9, 13 and 20.

Very summary action was taken last evening in regard to the streets of the City. The two Boards, in separate session, and afterwards in joint meeting as the Sanatory Committee of the Board of Health, pushed through promptly such measures as they deemed essential to the preservation of the public health.

VIENNA, Tuesday.-- The Chronicle's correspondent telegraphs that advices from St. Petersburg of 14th, state that another warlike manifesto had been issued levying 9 men per 1,000 till 15th April. The correspondent adds that this is authentic.

An interesting and somewhat graphic letter appears in the Freeman's Journal of yesterday, from an eye-witness of the cruise of the United States sloop-of-war Cyane, in pursuit of the Darien Ship Canal route, indicated by the English Engineers and Surveyors, FOX, GISBORNE and CULLEN.

The Annual Commencement of the Medical Department of the University of New-York, took place yesterday evening, in the University Chapel, which was crowded with a highly respectable and intelligent audience.

While there is a deal of unwritten woe felt underneath the surface of Society in the City, there are charities, too, that prefer to be veiled, and springs of mercy--the streams that flow from which are carefully shielded from the light.

The Royal Mail steamship Asia, Captain LOTT, from Liverpool on Saturday morning, the 25th of February, arrived at Halifax at 9 o'clock this evening. THE EASTERN WAR. No military or naval action had occurred, but political events of the highest importance are becoming developed.

A WILD WOMAN--SUSPECTED INFANTICIDE.--There was much excitement at the Railroad Depot on Saturday afternoon, by the sudden appearance of a female of some 35 years of age, in a state of entire nudity. She ran through the building from room to room, perfectly frantic.

The steamer Atlantic was got off yesterday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, having been aided by the steam-tugs Titan and Huntress, and reached her dock soon after, without having received any damage. Her mails were landed at an early hour in the morning.

FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT AT LIVERPOOL. A dispatch from Vienna on the 20th--not dated from Bucharest--says that the Russians have taken seven Turkish ships. (Doubtful.) The Russians are bombarding Rutschuck from Guirgevo. (This last is believed to be authentic.)

Liverpool Cotton Market. The COTTON market shows a trifling decline on the week, more particularly on middling qualities. It, how-ever, closed firm, and with all active speculative demand. The sales of the week were 40,000 bales, of which speculators took 5,500, and exporter ?? 3,000 bales.

The Crystal Palace, it seems positive, will be altogether inadequate to the demands which will be made upon it. Already the applications for places are treble its capacity. An architect has been called upon to devise plans for the construction of two "annexes," or supplementary wings.

Ruckman against The Merchants' Louisville Insurance Company.--This action was brought on a policy of marine insurance issued by the defendants on the vessel Margaret Hopping. The plaintiff claimed to recover as for a total loss. The defence was that the circumstances only authorized a recovery for a partial loss. We may say, in

The Committee on Foreign Relations of the Senate were not prepared to report the Gadsden. Treaty to-day, as it was understood they had intended to do. It is believed that numerous amendments have been proposed, the discussion of which has delayed the Committee's action. Every day the Treaty gained strength in the Senate as well as among the people.
From the London Times. Six short years ago it would have seemed absolutely incredible that such a state of Europe as now exists could ever occur.

Before Judges Rockwell and Moore, and Justices Still-well and Stryker. THURSDAY. This case was resumed at 101/2 o'clock this morning. The defence introduced ten or twelve respectable witnesses to prove previous good character of defendant. They all testified unreservedly to his industry, integrity, and good moral character.

An adjourned meeting of the American and Foreign Protective and Employment Society, was held yesterday, at No. 237 Broadway. The objects the Society have in view, are to procure suitable employment for moral and honest emigrants,--to give them assistance when necessary--to insure their transit to their different destinations, as cheaply and as speedily as possible, and to afford them good advice; and also, legal assistance when requisite.

The following interesting and important Official Correspondence in reference to the case of KOSZTA, has just been transmitted to the Senate by the President of the United States: To the Senate of the United States: I transmit to the Senate a report of the Secretary of State, with accompanying documents in compliance with their resolution of the 2d ultimo.

The London Weekly News says of the cholera in Eardle: "The mortality is four per cent. of the population in one month--one per cent, more than Newcastle. The small island of Eardle is badly supplied with water in Summer--the supplies then being dried up. In Winter they are dependent on the rain water that filters from the surface of a proverbially dirty site, composed of the debris from the slate quarries and other refuse.
The Young Lion of the West will get all the Public Lands. The struggle on the side of the ancient Thirteen is in vain. Neither threats nor entreaties will secure the smallest share of the spoil.

LINDSAY BLAKISTON, of Philadelphia have published in handsome octavo of 300 pages Dr. JAMES G. SIMPSON'S notable work on "Homeopathy--its tenets and tendencies." This is the first American from the third Edingburg edition of the most serious and successful exposition of the Homeopathic folly that has yet been published.
STREET COLLISION. Elijah P. Briggs against Jacob B. Van Houton.--This was an action to recover damages for running against and breaking the leg of the plaintiff's horse.

Our files of Chinese papers contain intelligence of a good deal of interest, connected with the progress and character of the Revolution. Through private sources we learn that rumors were current in Canton, during the latter part of December, that the insurgents had taken Teen-tsing, which is the port of Pekin, and distant from that city only forty or fifty miles.

In the Assembly, this morning, Mr. SAVAGE submitted a resolution directing the reference of the bill providing that the Police Justices of the City of New-York shall investigate the origin of fires, to a Special Committee, to report complete. .

FUNERAL OF GREGORY DILLON, Esq.--A solemn High Mass for the repose of the solemn of the late GREGORY DILLON, Esq., was offered up in the Cathedral, Mulberry-street, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. At 3 o'clock in the afternoon, the funeral rites were performed in the same church. The officiating clergymen on the occasion were the Very Reverend Mr. STARR, Vicar-General; Bishop BAILEY, and Rev. Mr. QUINN, pastor

The Asia reports, on Feb. 25, passed in the Mersey ship Pride of the Sea; same day at 10.10 o'clock A. M. passed the clipper ship Gauntlet, with loss of fore and mainmast and mainmast and bulwarks on the port side. Same day, at 11 A. M., passed the CUNARD steamship Arabia, from Boston on the 15th, going in to Liverpool, passage inside of ten days, mean time.

The Asia, at Halifax, brings news three days later from Europe, of which we gave a synopsis, received by Telegraph, yesterday. War is still carried on by official notes. The French Moniteur is the principal battery, and displays great activity.

The old proverb of the back-country should be changed--"independent as a top-sawyer;"--it should be "independent as a newsboy." Of all the classes of the great city, the newsboy is the very type of American independence. He has stood alone all his life.

Mr. SUMNER presented several remonstrances against the Nebraska bill. Mr. SEWARD presented a similar remonstrance from the students of Hamilton College, New-York. Also, a remonstrance 100 feet long, signed by 3,000 persons, with their places of residence, in Brooklyn. Also of the Philadelphia Female Anti-Slavery Society. Mr. CASS presented a similar remonstrance.

PER THE ASIA AT HALIFAX. Liverpool Markets. LIVERPOOL, Friday, Feb. 24. COTTON.--The market remains as advised per Atlantic--namely, quite inanimate--the closing rates to-day showing a reduction on the week of one-sixteenth to one-eighth of a penny, on middling and fair American, although the actual prices quoted in the published circulars, are scarcely reduced to that extent.

The numbers of the $250,000 fire in Spruce-street are still hot and blazing, when another great fire is announced. But what caused the Spruce-street fire? Was it the work of an incendiary? Was it the result of carelessness? or was it an unavoidable mishap, which no care could have averted, and for which nobody was blamable?

We publish this morning diplomatic correspondence of a good deal of interest concerning the KOSZTA case. It was sent in a few days since to the Senate, by the President, in reply to a resolution adopted by that body.

In the Senate, to-day, the Hoosac Tunnel Aid bill was passed, to be engrossed under a suspension of the rules. In the House the Liquor Law came up, the question being on the bill reported by the majority of the Committee to unconditionally repeal it. This was rejected--Yeas 80, Nays 183.

SALES OF STOCKS AT PHILADELPHIA.--Thursday--First Board--$ 100 Richmond District Coupon is 91 1/2 $4 660 City Railroad 6s, 81, 96 1/2, $150 Pennsylvania 5s, 53, 85 1/2; $450 Lehigh 6s, 70, 99__ Chesapeake and Delaware Canal 6s, '56, 903/4: $140 Camden and Amboy Railroad 6s, 7, 90; 1 Reading Railroad, 10 1/2; 905 do.. 403/4; 560 do., 403/4, 67 New-Orleans Gas, 122; a Camden and Amboy Railroad, 151/2 400 Morris Canal.

The investigation respecting the mysterious murder of LEOFOLD WRITH, at a German Ball in Forsyth-street, was resumed yesterday before corner WILRELM and a Jury. The perpetrator of the deed is yet unknown, and the Mayor has been requested by the Jury to offer a reward for his apprehension.

Remonstrances against the Nebraska bill continue to be placed in large numbers upon the table of the Senate. Among others yesterday, there was one from Brooklyn, signed by 3,000 persons, and 100 feet long. The Homestead bill was reported back, with a unanimous recommendation from the Committee, in its favor.

To the Editor of the North China Herald: DEAR SIR : As everything regarding the insurgents possesses a degree of interest at the present moment, I beg leave to send you the following account: Having obtained admission into the city of Shanghai this afternoon, I proceeded to one of the Chapels belonging to the London Missionary Society, where I commenced preaching to a large congregation, which had almost immediately gathered within the walls.

THE STREET-CLEANING MOVEMENT.--Unfavorable as was the weather yesterday for putting into execution the Street-cleaning ordinance, Alderman HOWARD had eighty men at work in the Sixth Ward, on Franklin and Leonard-streets, as early as 7 o'clock in the morning. The Alderman of the Third, also, had a force removing the sea of mud in Greenwich-street.

In Steamship Asia from Liverpool.-For Halifax-Messrs. G, King, Robertson, Crocker, Wm. Muirhead. Crevur. Capt. Welton and lady; J. James, Lassell, Capt. T. Murgans. For Boston--Messrs. F. Wood, F. Hostage. Robertson and lady; J. M. Slater and lady: Mime.

The Temperance bill has just passed the Senate by the following vote: AYES--Messrs. Bishop, Bradford, Butts, M. H. Clark, W. Clark, Z. Clark, Danforth, Dickinson, Dorrance, Field, Halsey, Hopkins, Lansing. Muaroe, Putnam, Richards, Robertson, Sherrill, Walker, Whitney, Williams--21.

Mr. DEAN'S resolution inquiring as to the propriety of suspending the nentrality laws with reference to Spain, in consequence of the seizure of the Black Warrior, was not introduced without authority. The Government is getting tired of submitting to the continued outrages of Cuba, and being subjected to protracted negotiations at Madrid.

For Particulars see our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Midsummer Night's Dream--Domnique the Possessed. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Love for Love--Curiosities of Literature. NATIONAL THEATRE.--Uncle Tom's Cabin--The Gambler. BARNUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.--The Old Browery.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It is very apparent that "K" in the article in your paper of the 4th instant, intends to reflect upon the Managers of the Hudson River Railroad, for not declaring dividends, while the Eric Company do so, without being better prepared for that event than the Hudson River. The Managers of the Hudson River put all such insinuations, and the authors of them, at defiance.

After closing my correspondence for the Black Warrier last evening, the community were surprised with the information that she would be detained by the Government. To-day we find that she hase been abandoned by Capt. BULLOCK, and is left upon the hand of his irresponsible Government, with which our troubles, according to present appearances, are never to have an end. It

The Government will make every proper exertion, we presume, to reclaim the large sum which was awarded by the Mexican Commission on the fraudulent claim of Dr. GARDINER. The subject is now before the Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives. The award was over $430,000.

We have received Galveston papers to the 22d, and a few exchanges from the interior. The steamer Jack Eays collapsed a flue, a short distance above Lynchburg, on the a Jacinto, on the 20th instant, killing a negro man and dangerously wounding the engineer, Mr. JAMES GRAY. No one else was injured, and the boat, which has returned to Galveston, is but slightly injured.

From the Citizen. In Parliament Lord PALMERSTON, in answer to a question, replied, that SMITH O'BRIEN, having acted as a gentleman in refusing to escape at the expense of breaking his parole, is to be pardoned.

Some commotion was occasioned yesterday, in the Hall of Records, in relation to an alleged financial trouble in the Office of the Register of the City. Various rumors were afloat, and messengers were dispatched to the residence of the Register, at Harlem, to learn the truth of the statements that had gained circulation.

The Journal of Commerce is very much disturbed because the clergy of all denominations, and in every part of the Northern States, are not unanimous in denouncing the Nebraska bill. In 1850 the Journal was still more violent in denouncing those clergymen who opposed the Compromise Measures, and was equally emphatic in praising those who approved them.

The regular train from Harrisburg, yesterday afternoon, met with an accident near Lancaster. An axle broke and tore away the bottom of one of the cars, causing some of the passengers to fall through, but none were seriously hurt.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Under the above heading, in your issue of to-day, a late article from the London Examiner is reproduced. In a brief editorial comment you inform us, "the article is worth reading." I agree with you. Probably there might be between us some difference of opinion, however, as to the grounds on which it deserves a perusal.

The steamer Asia, from Liverpool, Feb. 25, arrived at Boston at about 8 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning. From English papers received by her mails, we obtain the following details of European news, in addition to the telegraphic dispatch from Halifax, published on Thursday.

A resolution was unanimously adopted in the House of Representatives yesterday, calling on the President for information concerning the detention of the Black Warrior in the port of Havana, and the violation of our rights generally by the Spanish authorities in Cuba.

I have just heard narrated a little romance in real life, which results in great good fortune to the estimable and accomplished lady of Senator GWIN, of California. As the story is already cur rent in Washington society, I trust the relation of it in your columns will not be deemed obtrusive or officious by the parties most interested.

The very important subject of Street Cleaning is just now occupying the exclusive attention of the Corporation. The prompt and vigorous manner in which the two Boards, especially the Councilmen, have acted, reflects credit upon the Reform men who have put their shoulders to the wheel. It was idle to expect that much could be accomplished at the moment the new members assumed office. hey were cumbered by

To the Senate of the United States: In answer to the resolution of the Senate of the 7th of December last, requesting me to present to the Senate the plan referred to in my annual Message to Congress, and recommended therein for the enlargement and modification of the present judicial system of the United States, I transmit a report from the Attorney General to whom the resolution was referred.

The California returns, as indicated by the Mint report for the months of January and February, begin to excite remark, and fears are expressed that the product of 1854 will fall far short of that of the previous year. Hartford Times of yesterday,

Trial of William Breunan for the Killing of Michael Horan--Verdict of Manslaughter. In the Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday, this trial was brought to a close. Upon the assembling of the Court at 10 o'clock, the District Attorney, R. C. UNDERHILL, Esq., commenced summing up on behalf of the people. He spoke for about two hours, in a clear and able manner, presenting the features of the case to the Jury.

The river here is rising very fast, but the ice has not yet moved. Passengers for New-York go around by way of Troy. The Boston ferry boat crossed the river this morning, but will not go again for fear of being caught in the ice. P. M.--Thc ice has not yet moved, but the water is rising fast.

An invitation from the Trustees of the State Lunatic Asylum to visit that Institution was accepted, and the Senate agreed to adjourn over till Monday for that purpose. BILLS PASSED. In relation to the New-York Juvenile Asylum. To incorporate the Rose Hill and Bloomingdale Savings Bank. Making appropriations for Sing Sing Prison.

HARD FARE.--The schooner Water Rose, of Yarmouth, N. S., before reported abandoned, was from Shelburne, N.S., for West Indies, with fish, timber, In a tremendous gale and sea, Dec. 24, the same in which the steamer San Francisco was wrecked, the schooner was capsized and filled with water, in latitude 36 1/2, longitude 62. Two men were drowned.

Mr. SHIELDS moved to suspend the private calendar, and take up the bill to promote the efficiency of officers,--which bill was laid aside yesterday for want of a quorum. He said there was pressing necessity for the passage of the bill at this time. Mr. PETIT said he did not believe there would be any necessity for such a bill, and insisted on the consideration of the private calendar.

EISFELD's QUARTETTE SOIREE.-The fourth entertainment of the present season attracted a large audience last evening, notwithstanding the unfavorable state of the weather. This delightful work, overflowing with melody, and scientifically profound, but quiet, is calculated to please every possible variety of audience. Its

THE WILLIAMSBURG MURDER.--The testimony in this case was concluded yesterday. ANGELLO SEPARNI, who resides at No. 190 Twenty-first-street, New-York, identified the steel found near the murdered man as one carried by JAMES ANTONI, the prisoner. He further testified that, to his knowledge, a bad feeling had existed for some time between the prisoner and the deceased.

NEW-YORK LITERARY UNION.--The above Society held a special meeting last evening in the rooms of the Mercantile Library Association, for the purpose of discussing the propriety of publishing a general address to the Literary Societies of the United States.

At 7 3/4 o'clock yesterday morning, a special train of 27 carriages arrived at Southampton from Chichester, with a detachment of the Goldstream Guards. They were immediately merched from the terminus to the docks, precede by drums and fifes, and formed in a line four deep before the Orinoco steamer, and directly afterwards they marched on board in single file.

The following is the City Inspector's Weekly Report of Deaths, in the City and County of New-York, from the 4th day of March to the 11th day of March, 1854. Men, 73; Women, 84; Boys, 163; Girls, 133--Total, 453. DISEASES.

The boiler of the loeomotive attached to a freight train exploded at Hudson last evening, by which a fireman and brakeman, and probably others, were killed. The engineer's life is also despaired of. It was caused by insufficiency of water in the boiler. The upward passenger trains were delayed until 5 o'clock this morning.
FROM TEXAS.-- We have dates from Galveston to the 20th ult. The News of the 24th says: "The long expected announcement that navigation of the rivers is opened, has not yet been received."

FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT.--PATRICK TWO-MY, employed on a milk train on the New-York and Eric Railroad, was accidentally killed near Suffern's station, on Thursday night, between 9 and 10 o'clock. He was a milk agent of the company, receiving the cans of milk at the different milk stations. He also acted as a brakeman on the train. He lived in Railroad-avenue, Jersey City, where he has left a wife and child. His age was 32 years.

With shame and confusion of face, we found on our arrival in America lately, after five years' absence from the world, that the journals published on this side the Atlantic, and assuming to represent Irish feeling here, were all (save one,) devoted allies of European Monarchies, and determined enemies of European Republicanism--or, as they choose to call it, Red Republicanism.

FUNERAL OF ALDERMAN MORRIS.--The funeral of Alderman Morris took place yesterday afternoon, from the house of his son, F. II. Morris, Esq. The Aldermen and Supervisors both attended his funeral in a body. His remains were taken to Greenwood Cemetery in a hears drawn by four black horses appropriately draped. Sixty-three carriages followed, in procession, the remains to the grave.

In this City, on Saturday, March 11, MARGARET ANNE, third daughter of George and Eliza Jane Ross, after a severe illness, aged 7 years and 4 months. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood Cemetery for interment, from her late residence, No. 164 West 22d-st., this day, (Monday,) at the hour of 2 o'clock. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend, without further notice.

We are under many obligations to the London Examiner for having recently called our attention to a subject which, at the present moment, is of paramount importance, both in relation to the interests of American ship-owners, and to those of that enterprising and invaluable class of men whom it more immediately concerns.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The TIMES did me the honor to include in its columns, yesterday, a sketch of my lecture on American Poetry. As expressions are attributed to me in that sketch entirely opposite to the language I made use of, I beg leave to substitute what I did say in place of what your reporter says I said.

Open and above-board lotteries were put down by law in our State long since. Gambling is prohibited under severe penalties. But covert gambling and lottery tickets under another name are abundant in the City, as any who reads our Police news has not failed to discover.

The disasters on the Western waters are increasing at a fearful rate, and now we have to add the loss of the beautiful New-Orleans and Memphis packet Mary Agnes, which was destroyed by fire on the morning of Wednesday, the 1st of March, about daylight. She was on her way up from New-Orleans with about 400 tons of merchandise, groceries, , for Memphis.

The steamship North Star, of VANDERBILT'S Independent Line, arrived at this port on Saturday, from Aspinwall, with 300 passengers, bringing California news to the 16th February, two weeks later than the previous packet. The North Star brought no gold on freight. We are indebted to the Puiser, and also to the different Express Companies, for files of San Francisco and Panama papers.

From the Evening Post. Judge BRONSON, we are happy to say, has planted himself on the right side of the great issue between have had the pleasure of reading a letter addressed by him, sometime since, to JOHN COCHRANE and another gentleman of this City, from which we have been permitted to make an extract, which is creditable alike to head, heart, and pluck of the late Collector.

(By Steamer North Star.] The U. S. sloop-of-war Cyane arrived here from Calcdonia Bay, where the Darien Expedition has been located on the Atlantic, on the 28th--officers and men all well. When the Cyane left the Bay, the English war schooner Scorpion, and the French war steamer Chimere, were there. H. B. M. sloop-of-war brig Espiegle left for Carthagena the day previous.

The Land Claim difficulties between Messrs. FERMAN and CARTWRIGHT, which, less than a year ago, terminated in the murder of the former, had hardly passed from notice among the called upon to announce another similar one in that neighborhood, rendered more shocking, in that three men have been murdered in cold blood--two men shot, and one hung, strung up in regular California style till dead.
The Bourse took heart yesterday, and the Funds rose sensibly, under the impression that Austria and Prussia were virtually committed to sustain the Western Powers.

We desire to call the attention of the members of Grace Church congregation to the complimentary concert to Mrs. BODSTEIN announced for this evening. Mrs. BODSTEIN has for several years sustained tile choir of Grace Church in a manner so artistic and thoroughly undemonstrative, that we are persuaded the efforts of the ladies of the congregation to pay her a substantial compliment will be most cordially responded to.

Navy-Yard directing the war steamer Princeton to be got ready for sea, and to be prepared to leave at a moment's notice. She was hauled out yesterday, and now lies off the Battery.

MAIL RIDER TURNED ROBBER AND DECAMPED.--A late number of the Camden Republic chronicled the disappearance of J. D. GUNN, mail rider between that place and Cahawba, under suspicious circumstances. He was seen at Rehoboth on the 3d ult., and on the Monday following a package of letters, broken open, was found partly buried at the foot of a fallen tree.

The following members of the Committee were present: Messrs. CURRY, FORBES, and SEELEY, Mr. SEELEY presided.

We have been out ruralizing. Not we proper. For as all the world knows, we never go out of town, never ruralize, never breathe fresher air than invests the City and settles down into its high brick-walled streets. Here we have dropped anchor, here perpetually reside, and like the king, "never die."

PENNSYLVANIA INSTITUTION FOR THE BLIND.--The 21st annual report of this admirable establishment is before us, giving an account of its condition during the year 1853. The year has been most prosperous and encouraging to the friends of the Blind. In another column of this morning's Times will be found a description of one of the Russian faits d'armes during the late war in Hungary. The imperial proclamations and manifestos of the Czar, at the present moment, are so full of Christian indignation against the cruelties committed by the Turkish troops, that one might almost imagine that the Muscovite battalions kill their enemies without hurting their persons.

ANNIVERSARY OF A MEMORABLE EVENT.--Today is the anniversary of one of the most starting crimes that ever stained the records of Philadelphia. We refer to the murder of Mrs. SHAW and Mrs. LYNCH. On the night of the 10th of March, 1853, they fell victims to the ferecity and capidity of ARTHUR SPRING, and the next morning revealed a scene, at the house in Federal-street, which we would gladly shut out from our memory.

New-Orleans papers of Tuesday last are received. The news of the seizure of the Black Warrior had caused much excitement at New-Orleans and Mobile. In the Assembly, the Committee to whom was referred the petition for the incorporation of the Panama and Aspinwall Telegraph Company, this morning reported against granting the prayer of the petitioners. The Board of Councilmen last night made a donation to the Children's Aid Society of sundry desks, and other articles of furniture, no longer needed in the Public Schools.

Yesterday morning a five story brick block on South-street, corner of Paul, was destroyed by fire. It was used for manufacturing purposes, and contained a large steam engine, fixtures and a custom grist mill, owned by Messrs. GORDON Co., who lose $12,000; insured for $8,000. Mr. Ross, maker of grist mills, loses about $3,000, partly insured.

In this City, on Sunday, March 12, MARY McCREADY, relict of James McCready. The friends of the family, and those of her grandsons, John W. and Asher Morgan, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, on Tuesday, March 14, at 2 o'clock P. M., from her late residence, No. 156 Mott-st. The remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

SUPERIOR COURT--GENERAL TERM--Saturday. Davis, Palmer, and The Attorney General, against The Mayor, Aldermen, and Commonalty of the City of New-York, Jacob Shary, and others.--This was an appeal taken by the parties interested in the Broadway Railroad grant, from the previous decision in this Court, by which a perpetual injunction against the exercise of the powers attempted to be conferred was granted by the grant.

We conclude in this morning's TIMES, the publication of the important diplomatic correspondence in the case of KOSZTA. NEW MARKET.--A new market-house is being erected at the corner of Hamilton-avenue and Van Brunt-street, of the same dimensions as the Atlantic-street market. NEBRASKA.--An anti-Nebraska meeting will be held in this city next week. TALITY.-The Health Officer reports

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: At your convenience be pleased to mention who Lord RAGLAN is. His name does not appear on the Army List for 1848, which I have. I presume he is an officer who has been raised to the Peerage since that period. A CONSTANT READER. From the Commercial Advertiser.

Quiet settled down upon the Corporation last-night. Neither Board did anything remarkable. The only novelty was the introduction of a resolution in the Council Board, by Mr. KENNEDY, directing the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department to report upon the expediency of providing one or more steam fire-engines for use in the lower sections of the City, where the great warehouses are located. This is an important movement,

There was a powerful influence brought to bear upon the President to-day, to induce him not to recommend a suspension of the Neutrality Laws in relation to Spain. The probability, however, is that a message to that effect will be sent to Congress to-morrow. The majority of the Cabinet is

The Medical Department of the University of Vermont, after an interim of a few years, has again commenced operations under the supervision of a Board of six gentlemen of high standing and reputation in the profession.

Gen. PEZUELA has authorized the fire companies, composed of free negroes, to receive instruction in the "school of the soldiers," and, as they advance, arms will be placed in their hands for cultivation in the practice of the "manual". They will make a very good "Black Regiment," for emergency, being composed of all the assassins, burglars and ladrones of Havana;

The affairs of the Register's Office still remain in a deranged condition, and a considerable degree of excitement has been occasioned by the recent developments of alleged defalcation. Mr. FLEMING, formerly Auditor in the Custom-House, continues at his post in the Office, for the purpose of receiving the fees that are paid in, and to investigate such accounts as he is instructed to supervise.

Another large and enthusiastic meeting of citizens of New-York was held in the Broadway Tabernacle last evening, to protest against the passage of the Nebraska bill. The house was filled to its utmost capacity before 8 o'clock, and the greatest unanimity and enthusiasm of feeling prevailed throughout the proceedings.

There has been some dispute among strangers, whether the man garotted yesterday was the veritable VALDEZ, the murderer, or a soldier; but as my information comes from a reliable quarter, I cannot alter my report.

The road from Nachitoches on Red River to Texas, passes through a region of poor sandy ridges, bearing pine, with narrow swampy intervals of better soil. Some few small fields of cotton are to be seen in the latter, but the area of land which has once been in cultivation, and is now bearing pines of from one to fifteen years' growth, is considerably greater than all that which has been lately tilled.

The TIMES of yesterday placed among the viands of the morning's meal a tale of melancholy sadness; carried to thousands of eyes that which made them weep; to many a heart a cause of bitter anguish; to the Nicaragua Accessory Transit Company a terrible rebuke, and to the traveling community, a just cause of indignation.

The alarming frequency and destructiveness of fires in this City has created a feeling that some steps are indispensably necessary to give us greater security than we now enjoy. The alarm bell is scarcely silent for an hour, and whole blocks of buildings, and millions of property, are almost daily swept away. t away. There is no good

THE BEARD MOVEMENT IN ENGLAND.--The beard movement in England is one of the most rapid on record, even in these fast times. The Daily News strongly recommends the clergy to abandon smooth shaving, and return to the manly and majestic beard as worn by the glorious Reformers of the sixteenth century. It says nothing would be a surer preventive of clergymen's sore throat than for nature's covering to supersede cravats.

A mob at Erie tore up the Railroad track again yesterday afternoon, in consequence of the Company running their trains through on the connected tracks. The Sheriff made his appearance, and exhorted the people to desist, but they hustled him away. Several of the prominent leaders in the former riots also tried to dissuade the mob from violence, but were not heeded. .

The State Election to-day has been strongly contested in this city. The Sixth Ward elects two Coalition representatives; last year it elected two Democrats. This is indicative of a large gain in the State for the Whigs and Free-Soilers,

The loss of life at Virgin Bay, on Lake Nicaragua, a full account of which was published in yesterday's TIMES, has aroused the indignation of the community. Further inquiry has shown that the blame of the ca??astrophe must rest, not with the unfortunate persons whose lives were sacrificed, but with the Agents of the Transit Company and the Captain of the launch. . To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In reply to your correspondent M., I beg to say that on the question whether Slavery shall or shall not exist in Nebraska, the slave owner with twenty slaves can have but one vote, as has every other citizen.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It may be a matter of special interest to some of our good people to know that the City Missionaries, (of whom there is one in every Ward,) are frequently made the almoners of others.

The Memphis and White River steam packet Caroline was destroyed on Sunday, the 5th inst., on White River, about twenty miles above the mouth, and from forty to fifty lives were lost. The vessel took fire between 2 and 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and the flames spread so rapidly that it was with difficulty any person escaped. As soon as the fire

The President's Message to Congress has been delayed to-day by the dispatches from Havana, received last night. There is, however, little doubt that it will recommend a suspension of the neutrality laws. Orders have been issued to prepare the sloop-of war Falmouth, at Norfolk, for sea, as also the John Adams, at the earliest moment.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Lord PALMERSTON has announced in the English Parliament the cheering fact that SMITH O'BRIEN is about to be liberated; and from his Lordship's words we may assume that the "traitor" will be permitted to come to America. Perhaps Mr. MARTIN would receive the same grace, and also come to this country.

The meeting held last evening at the Tabernacle, to protest against the passage of the Nebraska bill, was very large, and of a character which should give it weight and influence at Washington and throughout the country.

A large anti-Nebraska meeting was held this evening in this city, Mayor GILPIN presiding. Speeches were delivered by Judge KELLY, General HUBBELL and others. Mayor GILPIN was assisted by upwards of one hundred Vice-Presidents from all parties, selected as active and distinguished citizens favorable to the Compromises of 1850.

As I telegraphed you this evening, it is by no means certain what course the President will pursue with reference to the outrage upon the Black Warrior. All of the Cabinet, except Messrs. GUTHRIE and McCLELLAND, were on Saturday, and are still in favor of suspending our neutrality laws, so far as Spain as is concerned.

SIR: The United States brig Dolphin, Lieutenant Commanding O. H. BERRYMAN, was employed last Summer upon special service connected with the researches that are carried on at this office concerning the winds and currents of the sea. Her observations were confined principally to that part of the ocean which the merchantmen, as they pass to and for upon the business of trade between Europe and the United States, use as their great thoroughfare.

From the Troy Daily Times. The NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES appeared in a beautiful new dress yesterday. We note the circumstance, not because such changes are of rare occurrence with the New-York papers of large circulation, but as a prefix to word with regard to the general character of that paper. As a general newspaper, the TIMES is not excelled by any journal in the country.

BILLS REPORTED. For an additional Clerk in King's County. The New-York School bill. The Free Church bill. The Senate concurred in the amendment to the bill to divide the Sixth Judicial District of New-York. The bill to authorize the consolidation of the Albany, Northern, Troy and Rutland, and the Rutland and Washington Railways was reported. s reported.

THE JOURNEYMEN PIANO-FORTE MEN.--An adjourned meeting of the Journeymen Piano-forte Makers Union was held in Mechanics' Hall, No. 160 Hester-street, last evening. It was very largely attended. Mr. E. S. TAYLOR, President of the Union, occupied the Chair.

We announced the fact yesterday that the Sailor Boarding-House Keepers were about striking, in behalf of their boarders, for higher wages. We are assured that the masters of vessels will not resist the movement. They say that the present wages are not by any means more than they are willing to pay, nor is the rate demanded at all exorbitant. t. They complain,

In this City, on Tuesday morning, March 14, THOMAS ASH, of Throg's Neck, Westchester Co., aged 67 years. Funeral from the Astor House this day, (Wednesday,) at 11 o'clock, where relatives and friends are invited to attend. His remains will be taken to Westchester for interment. In this City, on Tuesday, March 14, ISAAC C. FROST, in the 28th year of his age.

Beef and Poultry at this market have declined, the latter about lc. ?? lb., from the prices of last week. This reduction is partly attributed to the large quantities of cheap Philadelphia Veal which has arrived during the week. Vegetables and Butter, too, have varied in price from last week's quotations. Fish is abundant, and still continues in brisk demand. Potatoes, Apples, Cheese, and Eggs, are sold at last week's rates. annex the

DUANE, as delegates from the Colony of New-York to the Continental Congress of 1774. AAC Low loved his native land,

In consequence of a recent revolution, the in habitants of Acapulco, and all that portion of Mexico, are in a condition of intense excitement, but owing to the many conflicting rumors, it was difficult to form a correct opinion concerning their affairs, at the date of our reports from that country. To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: We notice that at last the clock that for so long a time has disgraced our noble City Hall, Is to be removed, to make way for one hope of steadier habits, and that will at least give us some approximation to the true time.

Mr. EVERETT presented the mammoth memorial from Massachusetts, signed by 3,000 clergymen, against the passage of the Nebraska bill. Messrs. PEARCE and PRATT both presented memorials praying for the improvement of the Harbor of Baltimore and the approaches to it.

The clipper-ship Comet, Capt. GARDNER, arrived at this port yesterday morning, in the unprecedented space of seventy-six days and seven hours from San Francisco. The Comet had from the wharf to the Equator, 13 1/2 days; thence to Cape Horn, 22 days; and thence to the Equator on this side, 26 days; and thence to within 220 miles of Sandy Hook, 12 1/2 days--from pilot to pilot, 76 days;

Mr. GWIN, from the Select Senate Committee, has made the plan heretofore moved by Mr. SEWARD the basis of the bill which he has reported for the Pacific Railway. The modifications relate to the details, rather than the principle of Mr. SEWARD's plan.

NEW MUSICAL WORK.--We have received the first number of a new periodical, called the Philharmonic Journal. Mr. HENRY C. WATSON, a gentleman well known in the critical world, is the editor, assisted by Mr. JAMES SIMMONDS, who is known favorably to the public as a writer of ballads, The editorial department will be efficiently attended to; and for correspondence and musical intelligence, arrangements have been completed on a satisfactory scale. So says the editor.

The business of the day was to be opened with the sale of the contributions of the HARPERS. The senior member of the firm, Mr. JAMES HARPER, being present, was called upon for a speech.

Was there no Southern man--no constitutionalist and patriot present, to hurl into his teeth the just indignation of the whole country !

In January, 1833, after repeated failures, Mr. FORD, of the Sun Fire insurance Office, persuaded seven other companies to join him in a general association of fire engines and firemen. Since that time all the offices keeping fire engines in London, (in number, 25,) except that of the West of England, have joined the brigade, and operate together.

In your paper of this date, I notice that you signalize Engine Company No. 46 as being engaged in a disgraceful fight with others. As Foreman of said Company, your statement in regard thereto is untrue, as said Company. was not out at the alarm of fire mentioned, the Engine having been laid up for the past two weeks.

FIRE.--Yesterday morning a fire occurred in the Hat Finishing establishment of A. M. Roberts, in the fifth story of No. 49 Cortland-street. The damage sustained was very trifling. The Board of Police Commissioners are to have their next session for trials of charges against members of the Department on the 25th inst.

A special dispatch from Washington, which we published yesterday, says: "The Western members, it is reported, are deter mined to kill the New-York Assay Office appropriation, in revenge for CUTTING'S vote against the Wisconsin Land bill, after it had been amended on his motion."

The Arabia's news, received by telegraph from Halifax, and published in his morning's TIMES, contains nothing of startling interest from the Seat of War. Neither does it exhibit any new features in the policy of the European Powers relative to the Eastern difficulties. They are, however, continuing to arm on a grand scale, and preparing, as well as possible, for the worst. the worst.

The House held a session yesterday afternoon, and heard speeches almost innumerable upon the bill permitting the Sackett's Harbor Railroad to change its route. The pending question was an amendment requiring the Road to relinquish grants of land made to it upon the supposition that the southern route would be adopted. No vote was taken upon the amendment, and the Committee of the Whole rose and reported progress.

The Message of President PIERCE In regard to the case of the Black Warrior, sent in to Congress yesterday, will be found in another column. It characterizes the affair as a flagrant and unjustifiable outrage, and informs Congress and the country that he has demanded satisfaction and compensation from the Spanish Government. If these shall be refused, he stands ready to take such action as Congress may direct. ct.

The Whig State Convention assembled this morning. A temporary organization was effected, and the several Committee appointed. The Committee on Permanent Officers have selected ex-Governor JOHNSTON for President, and will report at the afternoon session. JOHNSTON is talked of for Governor. ,

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, Captain JUDKINS, from Liverpool on Saturday, the 4th inst., reached her dock here at 2 1/2 o'clock, this afternoon. The Collins steamship Pacific, from New-York on the 18th February, arrived out at Liverpool at 4 o'clock, A.M., on Thursday, the 2d inst. The steamship Franklin, from New-York, arrived at Havre on the 28th ultimo.

The Councilmen had no quorum last evening, and were compelled to adjourn. The Aldermen held a fair-sized session, and passed upon a variety of business. The Alderman from the Twenty-first, Mr. MOTT, who was elected as a Reformer, has taken early ground against the Amended Charter, and proposed a resolution to urge upon the Legislature the propriety of repealing that instrument before the close of the present Session. All this is very foolish.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Well, the streets are being swept at last; the little hills rise on either side, and unless speedily removed, will again find a level where they so long remained undisturbed by hoe or broom. The difficulty seems now to be to get carts to carry away the dirt.

Great complaint has been made in reference to the management of the Ferries between this City and Williamsburg. The subject has been quite thoroughly examined by the Committee on Ferries of the Board of Aldermen, and we publish this morning the Report of that Committee in full. It presents the facts of the case very fairly. ly.
