Mr. RICHARDS reported that the charges preferred against DARIUS CLARK, the state Prison Inspector, were matters cognizable by the Governor. The Report was agreed to. Mr. HUTCHINS reported a bill to permit the Seventh Regiment of New-York Militia to erect a Regimental Armory. ASSEMBLY....ALBANY, Thursday, March 16. Mr. SESSIONS reported a bill to investigate the affairs of the State Prison.

The returns now hourly coming in, give a different complexion to the result of the election than was at first indicated. They show a Whig and Free-Soil gain of 91 in the House over last year, thus wiping out the Democratic majority, and leaving the opposition ahead; 157 Whigs and Free-Soilers, are elected 154 being a majority in the House. BAKER'S majority for Governor cannot exceed 1,500, while MARTIN'S majority last year, was 5,302.

In tile TIMES of the 4th inst. was pubshed a letter over the initials F. P., in reply to some strictures of mine upon the present management of the Smithsonian Institution, located in this city. I have not heretofore had time to spare from other duties to rejoin. Your correspondent, "F. P.," is quite mistaken if he supposes I designed to " comment severely" upon Prof. HENRY, for whom I certainly have great respect.

A communication was received from the Comptroller, in reply to a resolution calling for information concerning the lands between high and low water mark on the shore of Long Island. The communication, was as follows: DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE, COMPTROLLER'S OFFICE, NEW-YORK, Wednesday, March 15, 1854. To the Board of Councilmen: The Comptroller, in answer to following resolution, viz.:

The message from the President to-day, relative to the Black Warrior outrage, is the universal topic of conversation this evening. I have conversed with and heard expression of the sentiments of gentlemen this evening, but have not heard the first word in approbation of the Message. It is universally condemned, so far as I can learn, as a miserably inefficient, meaningless document, and such it certainly seems to me to be.

There is no mistaking the fact that a strong disposition exists in Congress to pursue ultra measures towards Spain, for the seizure of the Black Warrior. A suspension of tile neutrality laws seems to be the prominent feature with a majority of Members. Great excitement was apparent in the House, this morning, while the matter was under consideration. The clerks in the Post-office have resigned, in consequence of low salares.

The course of Senators BELL, of Tennessee, and HOUSTON, of Texas, against disturbing ,the Missouri Compromise, has very naturally attracted public attention to the firmness which they have evinced, and to the odds against which they have had to contend on this exciting question. A few words to call to mind the character and past career of one of these gentlemen, may not be out of place.

LAUNCHED.--Mr. A. Patterson launched from his yard, foot of North Eighth-street, at 11 o'clock yesterday, the ship Francis B. Cutting, owned by E. D. Hurlburt Co., and intended for their line of Antwerp Packets. She is 154 feet long, 36 feet beam, 23 feet deep, and 1,000 tons burden. She is to be commanded by Capt. Rockwell. KING'S COUNTY HOSPITAL.-Extract from the Resident Physician's report for the week ending March 14:

The steamer P. G. Coffin arrived here about 10 o'clock this morning from Catskill. The Oregon is advertised to leave here for New-York to-morrow evening. The sale of Mortgages on account of the Merchants' and Mechanics' Bank of Oswego, was stopped by an injunction obtained by a person named INNES, and the sale postponed till April 7.

The Senate has called for and received from the President all the diplomatic correspondence relating to the GADSDEN Treaty and Tehuantepee Grant. The indications are that there will not be much disposition to debate. The vote, however, will probably not be taken this week. The House Committee on Foreign Relations have not yet made any decision relative to the case of the Black Warrior. They meet again on Saturday.

It is not to be denied that, by some means or other, the people of the " States" have obtained and cherished very absurd notions respecting Oregon-its climate, its advancement and present condition. 1 believe that there are few parts of our country concerning which so much has been written, and so little is certainly known.

The following is the reply of the Secretary of the Navy to the resolution of Hon. Mr. WALKER, of New-York, asking information as to the fact whether the Ocean Mail steamers "accepted" by the Government are, or are not, in all respects, fit for service as war steamers, as the contractors stipulated to build them: NAVY DEPARTMENT, March 10, 1854.

A Parisian correspondent of the Medical Times (Dr. W. E. JOHNSTON,) narrates two extraordinary surgical operations. The first was a Dr. J., who, by carelessly holding in his mouth glass tubes charged with vaccine matter, contracted an " Epithelial Cancrord " induration, which, in spite of internal medication and external cauterization, rapidly so spread itself that it was deemed necessary to amputate.

Brooklyn has spoken. Last evening a large meeting of citizens, without distinction of party, was held in the Brooklyn Athenaeum, in obedience to a call made two days previous to the meeting, to express their indignation at the pro. posed passage of Senator DOUGLAS' Nebraska bill. The space occupied in our columns this morning by the proceedings of the Tammany Hall meeting precludes a full report of the Brooklyn gathering.

In this City, on Wednesday, March 15, Mrs. SARAH A. WAGSTAFF, relict of the late David Wagstaff, in the 85th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, at Calvary Church, 4th-av., on Friday, March 17, at 1 1/2 o'clock, P. M., without further invitation. In this City, on Tuesday morning, of disease of the heart, ISAAC JONES, in the 60th year of his age.

IMPORTANT LAW CASE--HEAVY DAMAGES.--A law case was decided yesterday, in the Supreme Court in this City, which is remarkable from the heavy amount of the verdict rendered. The Western Vermont Railroad Company was sued by BAYLEY, BROTHERS Co., an English house, to recover the value of some five thousand tons of Railroad iron.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the debate on the Nebraska bill, in the Senate, Hon. Mr. DOUGLAS stated a fact in regard to Slavery and involuntary servitude in the Terri ritory, and even in the State of Illinois, under the Ordinance of 1787, which may be new to many of your readers.

SERIOUS ACCIDENT ON THE RAILROAD,--AS the Philadelphia train was approaching the Jersey City depot, and within a mile of it, at 31- o'clock on Wednesday afternoon, an accident occurred under the following circumstances: A man named RICHARD CONOR stepped upon the track not more than 50 feet in front of the train, and started to walk in the same direction as the train was moving.

Col. ROWLAND G. TOMLINSON, of Philadelphia, has been appointed Mail Agent between New-York and California, and sails in the Illinois, on the 5th of April. As a girl named ELIZABETH CRAKAMER, aged 15 years, was carrying a loaded gun up stairs to-day, she got into a wrangle about the weapon with a younger brother, who caught hold of the gun while she retained her grasp of the muzzle.
The United States Mail steamer Washington, Capt. FITCH, arrived at this port at 11 o'clock last night. She left Bremen on 24th February, and Southampton on 1st March.

The greatest excitement was caused on Saturday morning, by the announcement that a fugitive slave had been arrested about four miles this side of Racine, by Deputy United States Marshal C. C. COTTON, and four other men, one of them named B. S. GARLAND, the alleged owner of the fugitive, and another, a constable of Racine--in all, five white men--and brought to this city and placed, handcuffed, in our jail.

A late number of the Edinburg Review had an article on "Quarantine," written in the Edingburg's best style, and which produced a good deal of sensation at the time. It took the ground that Quarantine Regulations were relies of an illy-informed age --urging that they should be entirely dispensed with, as unnecessary and grievous hindrances to commerce.

About a year ago the DAILY TIMES published a very interesting official letter from Hon. ROBT. C. SCHENCK--then Minister to Brazil--to the Department of State, in relation to the African Slave-Trade carried on under the American flag, between the Coast of Africa and Brazil.

We gave a very full report in the TIMES of yesterday morning, of the proceedings of the meeting held at Tammany Hall in Favor of the passage of the Nebraska bill. It was the first meeting on that side of the question held in this City,--in this State and so far as we know in any State of the Union.

London Markets. LONDON, Friday March 3, 1854. [Per Arabia.] A fair amount of business has been transacted in the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets this Week, without any material change in the value of the principal articles of consumption. Money continues easy, Consols leave off 91 1/8 @ ??.

Messrs. PUTNAM Co. announce the immediate sale of their valuable Stereotype plates, wood-cuts, and steel-plates, copyrights and contracts. Intending to devote themselves hereafter to the publication of their Magazine, and to the issue of the works of WASHINGTON IRVING and Miss WARNER, they have resolved to seize the opportunity of the present Trade-Sale by Messrs. BANGS BROTHERS, and dispose of their entire remaining stock.

LATER FROM THE RIO GRANDE.--We have Brownsville (Texas) papers to the 18th ult., but they contain nothing of importance. The Flag of the 11th has the following: A difficulty occurred at the rancho Carricitas on the 28th ult., which resulted in the death of a man called ELLIS.

GENTLEMEN: I shall detain you only a few moments, but I feel desirous of saying a word or two upon a subject which has been open to so many varying constructions, and has excised so deep a feeling in the bosom of this community.

The story of the frozen viper that stung the good man who warmed it in his own bosom, has abundant counterparts in our day. And none of them are more striking than the way in which railroads are treated by the villages and cities they have made on their routes as soon as they are grown.

From the Richmond Whig. JOHN MITCHEL'S views of Slavery, and the desire expressed by him to own a plantation in the South, well-stocked with "darkies," have brought down upon him the anathemas of the whole Abolition crew, whites and blacks. It has shocked their sensibilities excessively.

A special messenger for Madrid left here to-day. He takes the Arctic to-morrow with important dispatches to Mr. SOULE, relative to the case of the Black Warrior. The demands for redress, are decisive, and admit of no temporizing.
The Cunard steamship Arabia reached her wharf at East Boston about 1 o'clock this morning, making the ?un from Halifax in thirty hours. We glean some additional items of news from the English papers.

PETTIT said, if present yesterday, he would have voted in favor of Mr. PHELPS'S right to retain his seat. Mr. BRODHEAD reported a bill authorizing the Postmaster-General and Secretary of the Interior to provide suitable accommodations for the United States Courts and Post-Office in Philadelphia.

In this City, on Thursday, March 16. MARTHA ISABEL, infant daughter of Henry and Kale P. Dickinson. The friends and relatives of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, on Saturday morning, March 18, at 10 o'clock, from No. 183 West 26th-st. In this City, March 17, AUGUSTUS WILEY, in the 38th year of his age.

DEATH OF FRIEND HUMPHREY.--We are compelled to record the death of a well-know citizen. FRIEND HUMPHREY died last night, after a protracted and painful struggle with disease. He was a merchant of this city, whose long life of industry and devotion to business was crowned with ample wealth.

Mr. BROOKS reported a bill amending the Brooklyn Water Law. Mr. MONROE a bill making appropriations for the Brooklyn Orphan Asylum. Mr. SHERRILL reported against the bill to amend the charter of the New-York Sixpenny Savings Bank.

St. Patrick's Day, in the morning, was as bright and cheering as the most enthusiastic admirer of that renowned Saint could have desired. For once there was not a cloud in the sky. Nature seemed to be propitious to an occasion so full of pleasant associations to the sons of old Erin.

Meeting of the Board of Supervisors. The Board of Supervisors met at the City Hall yesterday afternoon. Alderman ELY was called to the Chair. The Chair announced that in the absence of the Mayor and Recorder, it was not competent to transact any business further than the reference of business to the proper Committees, which he understood it had been customary to do on such occasions.

CAPTAIN PENDLETON.--It was announced the other day that Captain PENDLETIN, of the ship New--England, from New-London for New-Zeland, had been accidentally shot dead during the passage. The New-London Chronicle contains the following particulars of this sad event, communicated to the owners.

The dust of yesterday, and the hot weather of the first of the week, for to call it simply warm would be grossly to misrepresent the enterprise of the mercury, which rose to Summer heat, and suggested ice-creams and mosquito-nets to everybody---while it comforted housekeepers who thought of the diminishing coal-heaps in their cellars--prompted sundry scores of those who are in no such habit, to spend a quarter and take a bath.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The recent attempts at burglary and arson in the Eighth Ward and elsewhere in this City--some of which have been successful--seem to call for further action on the part of the friends of order.

ACTION OF THE MISSIONARY AND TRACT SOCIETY.--The Jersey City Missionary and Tract Society was organized early in the Winter but circumstances have prevented the managers from getting it into successful operation, so that the Winter has passed without this Society having rendered aid to the poor, as is contemplated in its plan of operations.

In this City, on Friday evening, March 17, EURETTA, wife of Samuel F. Halsey, and daughter of George Youle, deceased. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, on Monday afternoon, March 20, at 1 o'clock from her late residence, No. 63 7th-st. In Williamsburg, L. I., Saturday, March 18, ANN ELIZABETH, wife of Wm. Adams, aged 20 years and 6 days.

THE BROOKLYN POOR.--A Society has been organized by the Indies of this city, under the title of the "Brooklyn Female Employment Society." Its objects are especially to furnish employment to poor sewing" girls at proper wages. It is proposed to establish a store for the sale of articles manufactured by those who come under their protection.

In the Assembly, this morning, Mr. SAVAGE presented a number of petitions asking that the size of the Central Fark, in the City of New-York, be reduced. He also resented a petition, numerously signed, asking that the 22d of February be declared a holiday. Mr. Woon, from the Committee on Colleges, this morning reported complete the bill to make the office of State Superintendent of Common Schools a separate department.

The amendments to the GADSDEN Treaty, now pending before the Executive session of the Senate, for the purchase of Lower California and Senora, will fail, because the Senate has decided that the amendments to a treaty require a two-thirds vote. The failure however may kill the Treaty.

The last Mail steamer from California brought no acknowledgment from the Governor or State Treasurer to the banking firm in this City, who advanced the January interest on their Public Debt, after the default of their own agents. In the Assembly yesterday afternoon, Mr. CUMMINGS presented a bill to regulate the powers of the Common Council of the City of New-York, in reference to Stage and Omnibus licenses.

Mr. ELY has returned. The cause of his going away and his whereabouts in his absence are thus explained by him:

We have received Galveston papers of the 6th inst. They contain very little news of interest. The Journal contains the following items: We learn that there is a rise of four feet on the Trinity, but from the upper river we have no favorable accounts.

The steamship Crescent City, H. WINDLE, Commander, from New-Orleans 11th, and Havana, 14th arrived at this port yesterday. She brings 65 passengers and a cargo of molasses, sugar and tobacco. Nothing whatever of importance has transpired at Havana, since the seizure of the Black Warrior.

AND MY HEART TOO.--A few years ago, when it was the custom for large girls and larger boys to attend district schools, and when flagellations were more common in school than at the present time, an incident took place in a neighboring town, which is worth recording as a reminiscence of school-boy days. One of the largest, plumpest, and fairest girls in school happened to violate one of the teacher's rules.
Weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 11th day of March to the 18th day of March, 1854. Men, 81; women, 68; boys 171; girls, 160. Total, 480.

The Newsboys' Lodging-House was opened on Saturday. The quarters provided for the boys are exceedingly comfortable and commodious. Neat wooden berths have been provided, each containing two good straw beds, with warm coverings; baths, warm water, and conveniences for washing and drinking, make up the boys' premises.
The following is the general report of the English Commissioners appointed to attend the Exhibition of Industry in New-York. It is addressed to the Earl of CLARENDON: LONDON, Dec. 1, 1853.

This afternoon, the reading of long speeches on the Maine Law is the special order in the Assembly. They are shrewd men who manage these matter. When a question comes up on which everbody has a speech to make, they agree upon afternoon sessions.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--A trifle called " A Good Fellow" was produced here on Friday evening. It is not much, dramatically ; but it is local, and aimed at a growing evil. Mr. Felix Umbraton, (WALCOT,) a good citizen, economical, honest, and content, is placed in juxtaposition with Mr. Rushton Sunnyside, (BROUGHAM,) a gentleman who lives in a splendid mansion, sports a handsome equipage, and has no earthly means of paying for either.

The telegraphic reports will doubtless indicate to you the results of the election in New-Hampshire, before this can reach your paper. The city has nobly vindicated her fame, and told the country that the home of MOSES NORRIS repudiates, by an over whelming majority, his infamous speech and vote. We send the entire delegation of fourteen--Whigs and Free-Soilers.

The Magyar exiles, about thirty in number, held a meeting, on last Wednesday evening, of quite a private character, at Newark, to commemorate the day on which the great Hungarian struggle for freedom, in 1848, commenced. The 15th of March is a day long to be remembered in the annals of Hungary.

The following correspondence with the State Department on a question of citizenship, has been handed to us for publication: NEW-YORK, Saturday, March 11, 1854. SIR: I take the liberty to address you, to solicit your opinion on the construction of facts presented to me, in the nature of the United States citizenship, and the issue by the State Department of passports consequent there-on.

THE U. S. STEAMER PRINCETON. The Steamer Fitting for Sea-Her Officers and Crew--Escape and the Capture of Seamen. In accordance with recent orders of Hon. J. G. DOBBIN, Secretary of the Navy, received by Commodore EOORMAN at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the Government steamer Princeton was last week removed from her mooring in the East River and anchored off the Battery.

ARCHBISHOP HUGHES FOR THE ANNEXATION OF CUBA.--We have seen a private letter from a gentleman, in whose representations we have ample reason t place implicit confidence. He says: "In regard to Cuba tell our friends that Archbishop HUGHES will probably do his best to direct the Catholic interest in the United States towards its acquisition.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : MY DEAR SIR : You have always evinced an interest in our Industrial School at Avenue D, and we are grateful to your for your kindly notices of it from time to time, as well as for your effective address on the evening of our Anniversary.

We have received files from Mexico to the 4th, and from Vera Cruz to the 8th inst., from which we extract the following news, which will be read with no small degree of interest: An insurrection, at the head of which is Gen. JUAN ALVAREZ, has broken out in the mountains bordering on the Pacific coast.

A tremendous northwest gale has prevailed here since 12 o'clock last night. An unknown bark is ashore on George's Island. A chimney on the corner of Court House-avenue was blown down, killing a man named DANIEL REGAN, and injuring another person.

THE LASALLE RIOTERS.--On Saturday afternoon, the jury who sat upon the trial of the four ringleaders in the riot which caused the death of Mr. STORY, last December, brought in a verdict against three for murder in the first degree, and of manslaughter against the fourth, assigning them worthy of punishment to the fullest extent of law.

The regular monthly meeting of this Society was held last evening at their rooms, No. 600 Broad way, Mr. SHEPHARD KNAPP in the Chair. Sixteen members were in attendance. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved.

The Chair laid before the Senate two communications from the War Department. One referring to Mr. WILLIAMSON'S report upon the Pacific Railroad project, which was referred to the Special Committee upon that subject. The Chair also presented the credentials of Mr. PEARCE, of Maryland, which were read.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I cut the following from the letter of your Washington correspondent, S., under date of March 13: I perceive that the press of New-York copy from the San Francisco Alta California, articles which seem to know that the Senatorial election in California will surely he brought about during the present session.

From the Washington Union of Saturday. The Arctic, which departs from New-York to day for Liverpool, will convey a special messenger from this Government with instructions to our Minister at Madrid to demand, in emphatic terms, immediate and ample reparation from Spain for the outrage committed by the authorities at Cuba in the instance of the Black Warrior.

A movement is to be made by persons connected with the Universalist denomination to raise funds for the purpose of erecting a suitable monument over the grave of the late HOSEA BALLOU, in Mount Auburn, The first Sunday in May has been named for simultaneous collections in the churches of the faith of the deceased, in aid of the object.

JANUARY AND FEBRUARY IN AMHERST, MASS.--Prof. SNELL, of Amherst College, says that the greatest cold indicated by the thermometer in January, was 91/2[degree] below zero; in February, 5[degree] below: The highest in the former month, was 45[degree] above zero, in the latter 450[degree]. The greatest mean range of the former was 54 1/2[degree]; of the latter, 50[degrees]. The mean temperature of January was 22 1/4; of February, 22[degree].

The wind of last week did great service in the City, although our columns show that it did great damage out of it. Let us be thankful that it was not the "ill wind" spoken of in the proverb, which "blows nobody any good."

In this City, on Monday, March 20, JOHN, youngest son of Edward and Margery A. F. Bookhout; aged 1 year 10 months and 1 day. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from No. 143 Suffolk-st., N. Y., this (Tuesday) afternoon, at 2 1/2 o'clock.
Wanted, to see a man of good sense, who believes that one half, one third, one tenth even of the fires which have lately proved so destructive to our City, were not the work of incendiaries.

On Saturday morning, died at Boston the distinguished Dr. GEORGE C. SHATTUCK. He was a native of Templeton of that State, a gradu, ate of Dartmouth College, a man of the highest personal and professional worth. He was in his 71st year.

NEW-YORK YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION.--A regular monthly meeting of this Society was held last evening, at its Rooms at the Stuyvesant Institute, Mr. CROSSNEY in the Chair. About fifty new members were received, and then a review of Hot Corn was read by Mr. C. S. HILL.

STRANGERS DUPED BY THE "SAFE" GAME, AND A NEW-YORK MERCHANT ARRESTED.--The "safe" game was Friday last performed on two uninitiated residents of the West, destined for California. The victims are JOHN HASSETT, of Chautauque Co., N. Y., and HUGH LAME, of Georgia Co., Ohio.

FIRE AND ARREST ON SUSPICION OF ARSON.--Officers De Valen and Fletcher discovered a fire in the clothing-store of Mr. A. C. Flanders, No. 85 South Seventh street, about 12 o'clock on Friday night. The door was forced open, and with a few buckets of water the fire was extinguished. The damage to the stock and fixtures amounts to about $300-fully insured in the Merchants' and Nassau Insurance Companies.

This Committee met yesterday at 3 o'clock, in the Council Chamber, for the purpose of considering the subject of establishing a Ferry from the foot of Desbrosses-street, New-York, to Pavonia-avenue, New-Jersey. The Chairman said that there had been some mistake in the advertisement calling this meeting.

Smokers of the "real Spanish" have some cause for alarm. There is an effort now making to force them to Americanize. And if it succeeds, " Windsor-brindles," and "Suffield-particulars," with Kentucky rappers, will be their portion, and their only solace for the future.

The Board of Supervisors met at the City Hall yesterday afternoon, Recorder TILLOU in the Chair. The troubles in the office of the Register of the County came up for consideration. HEARING ON CAPITAL PUNISHMENT.--The last hearing before the Committee on Capital Punishment took place yesterday. The speakers were Rev. DEXTER S. KING, Mr. GARRISON, Rev. Dr. LYMAN BEECHER, and JOHN A. ANDREW, Esq. Dr. BEECHER made an important proposition, which cannot fail to be generally satisfactory, if adopted.

The Senate Executive Committee was in session to-day. FLETCHER WEBSTER'S nomination as Surveyor of the Port of Boston was unananimously confirmed, without reference. The consideration of the Gadsden Treaty was resumed. Gen. SHIELDS made a speech against it.

The Board of Aldermen, last evening, put the finishing touch to Mr. MOTT'S scheme for repealing the Amended Charter. The discussion of his resolution being the special order of the evening, occupied the entire session.

Our exchanges from those sections of the country over which the gale of Friday and Saturday last passed with severity, come to us with long accounts of damages sustained. The following in addition to what we have already published, is gleaned from the Eastern papers: The storm took a very wide range. At Calais, Me., the roads were blocked up with snow-drifts, and the Western mail coach was compelled to return after starting on Saturday.

THE CUSTOM-HOUSE AT SAO HARBOR.--The owners of vessels employed in the coasting trade and owners fisheries, and otherwise engaged in commerce and navigation, residing at Sag Harbor, L. I., are circulating petitions praying for the erection of a new Custom-House at that port, the present building being inadequate for the purpose, in consequence of its dilapidated condition.

Few persons unacquainted with the agri cultural resources of this State have the remotest idea of its extent, and no person who has not seen, with his own eyes, the great advantages possessed here over other more populated portions of the Union, will believe how great these advantages are.

We are making our visits in the neighbor hood of one of the " Industrial Schools," and enter a large building, filled with poor families. They are mostly the poorest working-people,-wash-women, coal-shovelers, wood-sawyers, and the like. As we go from room to room, it seems as if scarcely any one was in employ. There has seldom been at harder Winter for the Poor.

Gentlemen of the forum think it better to give than receive a word of advice. But our turn has come. An old authority says, " Action is all." By" action" the authority doubtless meant behavior; from which it is discovered that the famous advice of the antique gentleman referred to, was but another version of the homely proverb, "Handsome is who handsome does."

Boys' ACADEMY.--The gentlemen engaged in getting up a Boys' Academy in this city have selected a site on the northerly side of Livingston, between Court and Bcerum-streets. The lot is 103 by 100 feet, and cost $16,000. The building, for which plans are already made, will cost about $28,000, making the total cost $17,000. Of this amount, $34,000 have alreary been subscribed for.

The Morris Canal will be opened for navigation to-morrow, (Wednesday.) All necessary repairs have been made and the Canal is in a first rate condition. It is anticipated that there will be a large Increase of business this year over last season. The canal was closed on the 17th of December last.

List of patents issued from the United States Patent Office, for the week ending March 7, 1854, dated March 7, 1654: William Burnett, of Boston-For improved arrangement of fusible plugs or disks for steam boilers. Isaac Hussey, of Harveysburg, Ohio--For improvement in machines for plastering.

CINCINNATI POOR.-The report of the Directors of the Cincinnati Infirmary holds out that that city is in better condition to meet a general epidemic than it has buyer been before. About the number of emigrants and their condition arriving there, it says: "The amount received in the City of New-York alone from this source (the Commissioners of Emigration) during the last fiscal year, was nearly $600,000.

AMERICAN TRACT SOCIETY.--A regular monthly meeting of the American Tract Society was held in the Tract House, yesterday. WILLIAM FORREST, Esq., occupied the Chair. A number of letters from foreign lands were read. The intelligence from France indicates that religious liberty is subject to new invasions, many Protestant Chapels being closed under cover of a decree originally aimed at political gatherings.

DEDICATION OF THE PARK CONGREGATIONAL CHURCH.--This new Church, located at the corner of De Kalband Carlton avenues, was dedicated to the service of God on Sunday afternoon, by the usual exercises. The dedication sermon was preached by Rev. Dr. CHEEVER, who took for his text, Actsi: 8, "But ye shall receive power, after that the Holy Ghost is came upto you."

Among your correspondents, so numerous, and from every known part of the globe, I have never noticed any communications from this southern extremity of American Independence. Nor is it entirely probable that you will care to open a correspondence with this lone town of the Union.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In an article in the TIMES this morning, headed "Wanted," I notice an allusion to the practicability of introducing something--and what that "something" is to be must be determined by the good sense of our citizens--to stop the alarming prevalence of incendiarism, as it is too evidently the cause of most, or many of the fires to which New-York seems recently to have been doomed.

The usual number of memorials and remonstrances against the Nebraska bill were presented in the Senate yesterday, but no additional explanations were made. The Universal Democratic Republicans memorialized the Senate, asking Congress to redress the wrongs and injuries of FREDERICK WIECHEL, and remedy the evil which they claim has been done to the cause of Republicanism, by the wavering policy of the Secretary of State.

After his admission to the Bar he was for many years successfully engaged in the practice of the law. n 1817 or '18 he was elected to the Senate

Under the above caption the Courrier des Etats Unis resumes a subject to which we have already devoted some paragraphs of extract from the Canadian papers. It quotes at some length from the Quebec journals, which treat the rumored scheme of Russia to invade the Canadas in the most serious manner.

The bill for the suppression of intemperance was the special order, in the Assembly, at the Afternoon Session yesterday. The time was occupied mainly by Messrs. ANGEL, of Monroe, and MALLORY, of Ontario. They were, both of them, strong friends of a prohibitory liquor law at the first of the Session, and are now; but they do not support the bill as it is at present before the House.

The Nebraska bill was passed by the Senate and sent to the House of Representatives on Saturday, March 4. Yesterday, the business on the Speaker's table being the order of the day in the House, this important bill was reached in regular course.

PROCEEDINGS OF THE COMMON COUNCIL.--There was a meeting of the Common Council of Jersey City at the Lyceum list evening, Alderman LYON presiding. After the adoption of the minutes of the previous meeting, various petitions were presented, among which was one from the licensed cartmen, presented by Alderman Low, asking for an amendment to the Ordinances, which will increase the rates of cartage.

LECTURE VI.--The French Dramatists. M. PAUL ARPIN delivered the sixth and last lecture of his delightful series on Saturday evening last, to a large and intelligent audience. The subject of this concluding entertainment was a review of the Dramatists of France, comprising the names of ALEXANDER DUMAS, VICTOR HUGO, ALFRED DE VIGNY, PONSARD, SCRIDE, and many others of elder date or less note.

It is in accordance not only with the spirit of Christianity, but with the genius of Republican institutions, that every possible means should be used to educate and elevate the masses. It is not the policy of a free Government to keep its subjects in ignorance ; the more enlightened they are, the more stable are its foundations.

The Sixth Ward was alive with excitement yesterday, growing out of the circulation of exaggerated reports of an affair which occurred in that part of the city, at the St. Charles Hotel, on Broadway, not far from the Sturgeon market, and in which Mr. HOFFMAN, a German citizen, extensively known, Mrs. BAKER and WILSON C. BAKER, her husband, and JOHN M. HAWLEY, JACOB B. BURROUGHS and MILO L. SMITH, friends of BAKER, were concerned.

In this City, on Tuesday morning, March 21, suddenly, JAMES SMITH, aged 51 years. His friends and acquaintances are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence, No. 251 3d-av., on Thursday afternoon, at 2 o'clock. His remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment. In this City, on Tuesday morning, March 21, SARAH MATILDA, infant daughter of Thomas G. and Sarah Bell Prichard, aged 9 months and 24 days.

I received a letter last evening from New-Mexico, of a later date than any news yet received in this city. The country generally is quiet, and has been so for some time past. Occasional broils of course occur, as they always will in these new regions, and more especially where two races whose characteristics are so much in contrast are mixed up. Governor MERRIWETHER is not very popular.

The law passed by Congress during the session of 1852 and '53, for the purpose of securing the greatest possible safety to the traveling public on board our steamboats, does not seem to answer the end desired to the extent anticipated. Certainly not, if it was not violated in the recent cases of terrible disaster we have had to record.

YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATIONS.--A special meeting of this Association was held last evening, at the Chapel of the Second Presbyterian Church. The Chairman stated that the special business of the meeting was to consider the moral wants of the destitute in the city, and the means for relief.

HENRY YATES, Esq., well known as the brother of the late Governor YATES, JOHN B. YATES, and Professor YATES of Union College, and as State Senator from the old Middle District from 1812 to 1820, expired at his residence in Albany on Monday morning, in the eighty-fourth year of his age.

An adjourned meeting of the Piano-forte Makers' Union took place last evening, at No. 160 Hetter-street. E. S. TAYLOR presided, and R. THOMPSON acted as Secretary. Several hundred members were present. The Committee appointed to consult with men in the employment of BACON RAVEN reported progress and asked to be discharged.

HORRID MURDER.--At Allegan, Mich., a dreadful case of parricide recently occurred. A man named CLEMENTS, about 35 years of age, killed his father, an old man of 70, by chopping his head to pieces with an axe. The murderer struck his victim 13 blows with the edge of that instrument, and when he had accomplished the dreadful deed, attempted to kills his brother also. The man was arrested.

We hear occasionally yet of the People's College. A very respectable, though not a large meeting, was held at Binghamton last Saturday, when the friends of the College talked over their plans and prospects, and encouraged each other with a comparison of views. Mr. H. HOWARD, who ad-

Alderman Mott and the Amended Charter. On motion of Alderman LORD, the report of Committee on Ordinances, on Alderman MOTT'S resolution for repealing the Amended Charter, (already published,) was taken from the table. Aldermant BLUNT moved that the report be accepted, and the resolution adopted.

The Senate furnished us to-day with a "protocol" to the Nebraska bill, in the way of two hours' explanations. As the Connecticut election succeeds the New-Hampshire in a fortnight, we shall probably have still another protocol at about that time. The sketch furnished by your Senate Reporter, has probably furnished you a general idea of the course of the debate to-day.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Not very long since, there was an article in the London Times, maintaining the necessity of international arrangements for securing greater care of emigrants, and of their necessary comforts during the transatlantic voyage.

Mr. FISH presented the memorial of the Chamber of Commerce of New-York, praying for the establishment of Naval Schools for the preparation of youth as seamen. Messrs. SEWARD and SUMMER presented petitions against the Nebraska bill.

A dispatch from Cincinnati more than confirms the worst reports relative to the loss of the steamer J. L. Avery. It says that her officers arrived there yesterday, and gave full particulars of the disaster of that vessel. The boat sank in two minutes after striking a snag. The cabin parted from the hull, and the latter went down in sixteen feet of water.

EXECUTION OF MOTLEY AND BLACKLEDGE.--The Charleston Standard learns from members of the party in charge of the prisoners--THOMAS MOTLEY and WM. BLACKLEDGE, from Charleston to Walterboro', the place of their execution--that these unhappy convicts suffered the extreme penalty of the law on Friday last, at 12 o'clock. tachment which started with the

The Legislative Session of 1854 was opened this morning, at 1 o'clock, by the Emperor, who received in the Salle des Marechaux the Senate, Deputies and Council of State. The only use of these bodies, the "Great Bodies of the State," as they are called, is to be addressed once a year and to receive a spoken message from his Majesty.

The Senate, in Executive Session to-day, received from the President GADSDEN'S instructions and correspondence, which were read--but they are of so confidential a nature that they refused to print them, lest they should leak out.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have frequently seen, in your valuable journal, some remarks upon the present condition of the Navy, but none of them seemed to me to point out any practical remedy. If you will allow me I will submit the following, which I think a very simple as well as practical method of remedying many of the evils at present existing in the service:

THE DISTINGUISHED MEN OF CALIFORNIA.--We have received from a correspondent in California a list of the members of the Executive and Legislative departments of the Government of California. JOHN BIGLER, the Governor of California, is a printer by trade, married, and 46 years of age. The Lieut. Governor is a merchant. A minor occupies the post of Comptroller. office of Treasurer is filled by a physician:

We would not speak disrespectfully of the Clerk of the Weather. We did once, and were rebuked for it by a weak-minded correspondent who wrote on both sides of the paper, and charged us with levity. But said Clerk never indicated to us his desire that we should insist that all weathers are equally pleasant.

The Board of Aldermen has inaugurated a new and somewhat important measure, intended to effect the sale of the Public Markets of the City, and their transfer to the hands of private parties. The proposal emanates from the Alderman of the Nineteenth Ward, (Mr. HERRICK,) who produces sundry statistics to confirm his position.

The Express train from Buffalo which arrived at Warsaw, 8 miles from this city, about 10 o'clock last night, was switched off the track through the carelessness of the switch-tender, and ran at full speed into some empty freight cars, smashing them up and instantly killing the engineer, Mr. COLEMAN, and an Indian who was sleeping in one of the freight cars.

MR. PRESIDENT: I am not surprised to see so large a number of the citizens of Rhode Island assembled on the present occasion. On this spot was formed the first Government on earth which proclaimed both civil and religious liberty to be the birthright of man. It is meet that on this soil, and in this city, a measure, which proposes to violate the most sacred rights of humanity, should receive its merited condemnation.

The Whig Convention at Sandwich to-day, nominated THOMAS D. ELLIOTT, of New-Bedford, for Congress, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Hon. ZENO SCUDDER. Strong anti-Nebraska resolutions were passed by the Convention.

The Ohio Anti-Nebraska Convention met at Columbus to-day, and was largely attended by all parties. J. R. SWAN, of Franklin County, was chosen President. Speeches were made by D. K. CARTER, Hon. J. BRINKERHOFF, S. P. CHASE, B. F. LEITER, and others.

Last evening, despite the driving storm of sleet, the rooms were well filled by the artists and their friends, for whom that time had been specially set apart. The Boston papers chronicle the death, on the 15th inst., in that city, of Rev. ALEXANDER YOUNG, D. D., widely known as an elegant writer and a laborious historical investigator. His disease was lung fever and dropsy on the chest. Dr. YOUNG was born in Boston, in 1806, and was the son of ALEXANDER YOUNG, a printer. graduated at Harvard College, in the class

Two suits for fees for medical services were tried last week in Boston. The first was preferred by a Mesmsrite. The Court ruled that though he was an irregular, yet, inasmuch as his professional character or the lack of it was well known, he was entitled to recover.

From the Bedford Yeoman. A most severe storm of wind and rain passed over a portion of this and Coffee county on Friday morning last, about 8 o'clock. A portion of the cloud passed over this place, but there was not wind enough to do any damage. The cloud was extremely dark, and came from the West and went a Northeast direction.

From the Galt (Canada West) Reporter. Since the period of the great fire in Main-street, in this village, no such calamity has befallen us as that which occurred yesterday in the destruction of both of the bridges over the Grand River, in this town, and a mass of other property, throughout the whole sweep of that river, from Bridgeport to its discharge into the lake.

Mr. B. TENBROCK bred Arrow. He is in Mr. DUNCAN F. KENNER'S stable, on the coast, and is trained by Mr. GRAVES. Highlander is at Mobile, and trained by Mr. STEWART, who has always trained him. Gen. FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE INDIGENT VETERANS.--A Grand Vocal and Instrumental Concert and Lecture took place at the Tabernacle last evening, for the benefit of the indigent members of the Veteran Corps of 1812. The music was by the New-York Harmonic Society, Dodworth's Cornet Band, and a number of distinguished artists, who kindly volunteered their services for the occasion.

In this City, on Wednesday, March 22, Miss EMILY E. H. S. MCCANCE. The friends of the family, and those of her brother-in-law, Mr. S. Campbell, are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from her late residence, No. 108 Monroe-St., on Friday, March 24, at 2 o'clock P.M., without further invitation.

Ex-President FILLMURE has met with kind and enthusiastic greetings from the people during his journey through the West, in which he has been accompanied by Hon. JOHN P. KENNEDY. At Lexington, Ky., he was greeted with the firing of cannon, the huzzas of a multitude of people, and a formal welcome from the local authorities.

The Santa Fe mail arrived at Independence last night, having met with no disturbance from the Indians. Business was dull at Santa Fe. CHARLES L. SPENCER had been appointed Treasurer of New-Mexico.

The liquor prohibition law--or, as it is likely to be called evermore, the "Maine Law"--has passed the Assembly by a vote of 78 of 42. It was amended, however, so as to make it go into operation on the first day of May, instead of the first of December, as the Senate left it.

The papers of this morning announce that Bavarice and Lubec having acceded to the United States and Bremen postal arrangements, the single rate to those States is reduced from 22 to 15 cents.

At the beginning there was great objection to it on grounds which an intelligent man would be ashamed to confess.

Mr. RANDALL moved to restore the amendment which had been adopted when the bill was in Committee of the Whole, but which had been cut out by the Select Committee to whom it was referred to report complete.

The tendency of that article is to create much mischief here ; for it contains statements entirely false, and, wherever read out of New-Haven will convey a very wrong impression.
PORT OF NEW-YORK..WEDNESDAY, MARCH 22

Since the defection of the counterfeit $10 notes on the Cranston Bank, Rhode Island, Judge STUART and two of his officers have succeeded in tracing a part of the gang engaged in putting the bills into circulation. Information was received that led to the capture of several old offenders.

CITY REFORM MEETING IN THE PARK.--The meeting, advertised to be held in the Park last evening, was attended by about fifty persons, who appointed Mr. GEO. MCALLISTER Chairman. Resolutions were about being read, when DANIEL MAHEN came forward and claimed to have been previously appointed Chairman of the meeting. He was ordered to leave the platform, when a general scuffle ensued.

Reasons for increased rates of wharfage and the immediate passage of a new law, or else the repeal of all law on the subject. 1. Because the present law has, by its operation greatly injured our harbor. 2. Because we have no such wharf accommodation as our business demands.

WHAT IS DIRT?--Old Dr. COOPER, of South Carolina, used to say to his students: Don't be afraid of a little dirt, gentlemen. What is dirt? Why, nothing at all offensive, when chemically viewed. Rub a little alkali upon that "dirty grease spot" upon your coat, and it undergoes a chemical change and becomes soap. Now rub it with a little water and it disappears; it is neither grease, soap, water, nor dirt.

AMBASSADORIAL PRIVILEGES.--The English Common Pleas have lately examined this subject, in connection with the case of M. DROUET, the secretary of Legation of Belgium. He was made a party to a suit with three others with whom he had been associated in some pecuniary enterprise, before his coming to England.

Dr. E. H. DAVIS, of the New-York Medical College, is lecturing in Boston on the Mounds of the Mississippi Valley. Large crowds attend the course, and the Boston papers sketch the lectures fully. The University of Louisville, Ky., graduated 79 M. D.'s on the 3d inst. Professor SILLIMAN delivered the Valedictory. Professor S. leaves his Chair to assume that vacated by his father in Old Yale.

The Jews are a peculiar peoples though their exercises at their " inauguration dinner," last evening, were not so peculiar but that Christians present thought it a very excellent and Christian-like entertainment. There are said to be some 17,000 of the Jewish faith in the United States.

Nobody drinks their health, nobody says, "God bless them." Singly,--one or two at a time,--those who have fought great battles, made good books, been promoted to high officers, are drunk with the honors.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: At the lowest estimate, our naval ve?sels should be furnished with Marine Guards as follows: For a ship-of-the-line, 100 privates; a frigate, 60 privates; a sloop-of-war, 30 privates; a, brig, 15 privates.

I am situated--as many of your readers are--in the country, and see no other daily paper but the TIMES; and have felt disappointed that you did not, at least, give us one speech or article from some friend of the bill.

THE WATER-WORKS.--The contractors have resumed their work with vigor, and efforts are making to complete these works in May or June. The work has been going on to some extent during the Winter.

The Richmond Enquirer says that the passenger train which left Staunton on Tuesday morning, for that city, with a number of passengers, met with an accident while crossing the Blue Ridge Mountain, over the temporary track.
The American Medical Monthly for March contains several valuable papers. Dr. CHAMBERLAIN, of Astoria, reports ten cases of Delirium Tremens treated with chloroform.

BURTON'S THEATRE.--Certainly one of the best comedies of its era is FARQUHAR'S "Beaux' Stratagem." It has some of the faults of its school, but they are not so palpably unpleasant as in other comedies belonging to it. More smartness and smut are not its only recommendations. There are touches of genius in the "Beaux' Stratagem" which cannot be surpassed. which will assuredly give it vitallty when CONGREVE'S fuss-and-fustian is properly forgotten.

In this City, on Thursday, March 23, MARGARET R., only daughter of Thomas U. and Mary R. Sutton, aged 2 years. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of her parents, No. 420 Grand-st., this (Friday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock. In this City, on Thursday, March 23, ALEXIS LOPEZ DIAS, native of Hordeaux, France, aged 58 years.

HOBBS'S LOCKS PICKED.--At the Institution of Civil Engineers, last Tuesday week, a paper was read by Mr. HOBBS, pointing out what he considered to be the defects of the English locks, and fully describing the peculiar excellency of his own locks, rendering them safe from the attempts of false keys and picklocks.

The great sale of Books, Stereotype Plates, Steel Plates and Wood-cuts, copyrights and contracts, forming nearly the whole of the vast publishing stock of Messrs. PUTNAM Co., took place yesterday, at the salesrooms of Messrs. BANGS BROTHERS, Park-row.

An anti-Nebraska meeting was held at the Capitol this evening, and was very largely attended. WILLIAM PARMALEE, Mayor of the city, presided. Resolutions in opposition to the Nebraska bill were reported by ISAAC EDWARDS, and were unanimously adopted. AMOS DEAN, BRADFORD R. WOOD and others, addressed the meeting.

NEW SHIP.--Mr. DONALD McKAY, of East Boston, has now on the stocks, nearly ready for launching, a beautiful clipper ship of 3,000 tons, having three decks, and being diagonally cross-braced with iron.

There are various rumors floating through the Press, this week, of the condition of affairs at the Capital. We take for granted they are not all reliable, but, as mere straws, they show the direction of the political winds at Washington.

The Legislature is as impatient to see the good results of their benevolence to us, as is the small boy who keeps lifting the settinghen from her nest to soe if any of the chickens begin to peep yet. If they would only let us alone, there is no doubt we could show them speedily a brood that would rejoice their eyes.

SPECIAL DISPATCH TO THE NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES. The Speech of Mr. HUNT, of Louisiana, in the House to-day, against the Nebraska bill, was most eloquent, able and thrilling. He took the highest ground, boldly declaring it a dishonorable violation of a compact.

The whole reduction of postage contemplated in this project, is exclusively confined to the single item of the ocean transit. It is proposed that this single service shall be performed invariably for one English penny, or two cents; leaving the different Governments to reduce or retain their present inland rates, just as they please.

This morning the first business in the House was the announcement of messages from the Senate. Among them was the bill for the suppression of intemperance, with a notice that the Senate refused to concur in the amendment of the House.

In sending these names, it is proper that I should not mislead you as to the opinion entertained of your paper here.

FIRE.--About one o'clock Wednesday morning, a fire broke out in a two-story frame house in Sullivan-street, near Van Brunt, which was entirely consumed, together with two three-story wooden houses adjoining. The fire originated on the second floor of the first house names, occupied by JOHN SULLIVAN. The second house was occupied by JOHN CASEY on the first floor; the other apartments were not occupied.

FROM NEW-MEXICO,--A later Santa Fe mail arrived at Independence, Mo., on Tuesday. The roads were good, and there had been no disturbance from the Indians. Business was dull in New-Mexico, and more Indian depredations were reported. CHARELS L. SPENCER has been appointed Treasurer of New-Mexico.

It appears to have been a one-sided affair, managed by and directed to the ends of a particular faction in the State, known as the BRODERICK wing of the Democracy.

THE NEW LOCOMOTIVE "Gov. SOUTHARD."--A new and splendid locomotive for the New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company came to Jersey City on Friday, from the shop of ROGERS, KETCHUM GROSVENOR, of Paterson. She was pronounced by competent judges to be one of the very best engines ever built. Her weight is 22 tons. She has a 14 1/2-inch cylinder 22-inch stroke, and 6-foot driving wheels.

DISTINGUISHED VISITOR.--Dr. HAMEL, of St. Petersburg, one of the most distinguished members of the Royal Academy, a Councillor of State in the Russian Empire, and a gentleman of great scientific attainments, has been deputed by the Emperor NICHOLAS to visit the various educational, scientific, and philanthropic institutions of the United States. Dr. HAMEL is now at the Revers House in this city.

After a session of several days the Coroner's Jury have rendered a verdict in the case of O'NEIL, who was killed in the riot of Friday night. A large number of witnesses were examined, among whom were several students; these however, generally declined to answer any questions, so that very little information touching the affair was elicited from them.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: For the past four or five years, Lieutenants and Passed Midshipmen of the Navy have been allowed to command steamships owned by private companies. These offices draw "leave-of-absence pay" from Government, receive between two and three thousand dollars each from the companies which employ them, are seldom at sea more than a fortnight at a time, while they lose none of their privileges in the Navy.

The steamship Empire City has arrived at this port from Havana. She reports that the Cuban authorities had offered to give up the steamship Black Warrior, upon condition that a fine of six thousand dollars be paid. Captain BULLOGH had accepted the proposition, and would take BULLOCH of the vessel on the 22nd inst., and immediately sail for New-York.

DECEASED NEWSPAPERS.--Two of our Georgia exchanges have within the last week gone the way of all the earth. The Oglethorpe Democrat and Athens Herald are no more. We regret their fate. Both have been welcome visitors to our office. It is but a little while since another Georgia weekly, the Vote Mecum., ceased to be. And not a year since the Southwestern Georgian, published at Oglethorpe, set the example of dying.
Weekly Report of Deaths in the City and County of New-York from the 18th day of March to the 25th day of March, 1854. Men, 105 ; Women, 71 ; Boys, 183 ; Girls, 154. Total, 513.

The Scientific Corps belonging to Capt. GUNNISON'S surveying party--reduced to three--have taken rooms with Mr. BLAIR, Attorney General of the Territory, and also the worthy proprietor of the "Salt Lake House." Mr. B. Is the relative of F. P. BLAIR, of Washington--very much the Virginian in his manners, and withal an accomplished and agreeable gentleman. The boarders, with the Squire and his SIX WIVES, pretty effectually occupy the house.

LETTER FROM MR. SANDERS. To my Countrymen at Home and Abroad: In the absence of any instructions from the Department, either for or against my addressing the public upon such matters as I might think of interest to the people, I selected the New-York Herald as the medium of communication.

Dr. JOHN S. SHULER died suddenly, in San Francisco, of apoplexy. Doctor SHULER arrived in Colifornia over three years ago. Soon after, he opened a private hospital for the sick. Many lives of invalid immigrants were saved under his nursing care. He commenced practice in Eastern New-York. About twnetysix years ago, he removed to Lower Lockport, in this State, and was one of the early pioneers of the town.

THE DARIEN EXPLORING PARTY.--The apprehensions for the safety of Lieut. STRAIN, of the Navy, and the party that went out in the Cyane to explore a route for a ship canal through the Isthmus of Darien, are increased by the report brought by the steamer United States, at New-Orleans.

Mr. HORATIO KING was nominated in the Senate to-day for Assistant Postmaster-General, vice Gen. HOBBIE deceased. There was no vote on his confirmation, but it will be unanimous.

CARMAN'S UNION ASSOCIATION.--This Association, composed of a larger portion of the Carman of our city, made their annual parade yesterday, under the charge of ex-Alderman JAMES McNEELY, as Marshal. The procession numbered about 150 stalwart men, all mounted and wearing their white sacks, making a very creditable appearance.

A great fire occurred yesterday afternoon in Birmingham, opposite this city. It originated in the packing house of IHMSEN'S glass works, and owing to a strong wind and no water being procurable, the fire raged until 6 0'clock, destroying upwards of 100 houses and stores, and rendering 200 families houseless.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: We are a great and thriving people. Either gold is cheaper, or everything else is dearer than 10 or 15 years ago. Rents are doubled, houses are going up, people are going up after them, and so the City is going up, both in altitude and latitude.

If his action is reported aright, Captain BULLOCK, of the Black Warrior, seems to have made a very decided, and not very creditable, retreat from the position he at first assumed. At the outset, he hauled down the American flag, and surrendered the vessel to the Spanish authorities, be cause they insisted on enforcing the penalty for violating the port regulations.

An intelligent gentleman residing at Eagle Pass, Texas, writes us that the Semiaole Indians are committing depredations on the frontier, headed by the famous WILD CAT. On the 8th inst., about sixty head of horses and mules were driven across the Rio Grande in broad daylight, and WILD CAT himself led the marauding party.

DESTRUCTIVE TORNADO--GREAT LOSS OF PROPERTY--BRIDGE DESTROYED.--We learn from the Florence (Ala.) Gazette, that a fearful tornado which destroyed much valuable property, visited the landing in that town on the morning of the 10th instant. The Florence Bridge, that magnificent superstructure which spanned the Tennessee River, was blown down, with the exception of two spans, and washed off.

The death of JONATHAN HARRINGTON, the last survivor of the battle of Lexington, who expired on Sunday, was announced in the House of Representatives today, and a Committee appointed to honor his obsequies which will take place on Thursday. About six weeks since, a bark belonging to New-York, from Mayumba, African coast, for Havana, put in here, pretending to be in distress. She had no cargo. The captain had a survey upon her, in hopes, it is presumed, that she would be condemned, that he might sell her, in which he was disappointed--the surveyors reporting but slight damages, and that very light repairs would put her in readiness for sea.

The Royal Mail steamer Africa arrived at about 8 o'clock yesterday morning. She sailed from Liverpool at an early hour on the morning of Saturday, the 11th, and thus brings intelligence three days later than had been received by the Pacific.

SLOOP-OF-WAR JOHN ADAMS FOR CUBA.--The Boston Chrenicle of Saturday says, that during the present week nearly one hundred men have been received into the Charlestown Navy Yard, their services being required to finish repairing the sloop-of-war John Adams.

The last of those heroes who participated in that memorable contest, at which the first blood of our Revolutionary struggle was shed, is no more! JONATHAN HARRINGTON died yesterday at his house, about half a mile east of the place from which I now write, which is within sight of the monument which marks the spot where, April 19, 1775, the Lexington flight occured. .

COUNTERFEITERS ARRESTED--GREAT HAUL OF COUNTERFEIT MONEY.--A man calling himself THOMPSON THORNTON, was arrested yesterday by Marshal WARD, on the affidavit of Mr. CETTO, and brought before Recorder CRISP, on a charge of passing a counterfeit $5 note on the Wareham Bank, Massachusetts.

FIRE AT SAG HARBOR--NASSAU HOUSE BURNT--ONE MAN BADLY INJURED.--The Nassau House, in this village, a three-story wooden building, took fire about 10 o'clock this forenoon, from the upper part of the building, and was partially destroyed.

The Board of Supervisors, Judges of superior Court and Court of Common Pleas, held a special meeting in the City Hall, at 3 o'clock P.M. yesterday, for the nomination of a Commissioner of Jurors, in place of Hon. Mr. Walker resigned. Judges Ingraham and Daly, of the Court of Common Pleas, were absent.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A communication in the Journal of Commerce, of Monday last, in relation to the extension of Albany-street to Broadway, in which I am referred to by name, says, "I am deeply solicitous that he may succeed in his laudable enterprise."

In this City, on Tuesday morning, March 28, suddenly, CHARITY C. CLARKE, daughter of the late Clement C. Clarke. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, without further notice, from her late residence, No. 17 University-place, on Thursday next, at 4 o'clock, P.M. The remains will be taken to Trinity Church.

Liverpool Markets. LIVERPOOL, Friday, March 10, 1854. COTTON MARKET.--The Cotton market continues dull, and prices are rather in favor of buyers. The decline in the week, however, does not exceed 1-16d. ?? lb. The dullness of trade increases, and we fear there is little hope of improvement in this respect.

In this City, on Wednesday, March 29, IDA LOUISA, daughter of Joseph and Ann Maria Clark, aged 8 months and 9 days. The relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral on Friday afternoon, March 31, at 3 ''clock, at the residence of her father. No. 43 Vandam-st.

The greatest excitement prevails. CUTTINO and BRECKINRIDGE fought this morning. Rumor states that BRECKINRIDGE was killed the first fire, the ball passing through a vital part of the neck. I will endeavor to verify the statement soon.

The Pittsburg Commercial Journal, of Monday, says: The largest and most disastrous fire we have been visited by since the 10th of April, 1815, occurred in Birmingham, opposite the eastern end of this city, yesterday, (Sunday,) by which upwards of one hundred houses and stores have been left in ruins, and at least two hundred families rendered houseless.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : SIR: With pleasure I respond to your request, and herewith enclose may name and address. While doing so, please permit me to add a remark or two in regard to the letters which appear in the DAILY TIMES of this morning, under the caption of "The Irish and the British Government."

The steamship Black Warrior, J. D. BULLOCK, Esq., Commander, arrived at this port last evening. She brings twenty-six passengers and nine hundred and sixty-one bales of Cotton. The Black Warrior was surrendered to Capt. BULLOCK on the 20th, when he again took possession.

GENTLEMEN OF THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS: When I accepted (and with the warmest appreciation of your partiality) the position of President of your Association, I tilt constrained to attach to that acceptance a peculiar condition, I reserved the right to resign the honor you had conferred upon me, if after a careful investigation I deemed it imprudent to assume the grave responsibilities involved in so gigantic and magnificent an enterprise.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: I regret to see in the editorial of this morning's TIMES, what might be construed into a reflection upon the judgement and firmness of Capt. BULLOCK of the Black Warrior. I do not think you make the allowances for his course that one might expect from the general independence of tone and practical view of things taken by you.

In the First District Court of New-Orleans, on the 20th inst., JAMES PATTON, a man who once occupied an enviable position in society, was put upon his trial for the murder of Colonel WALTER TURNBULL. The prisoner shot Col. T. in an omnibus on the 3d of December. The evidence went to show that PATTON was insane, but he refused to let his counsel put in that plea.

The steamship Ohio, which arrived at this port yesterday, from Panama, brings no tidings of the lost party of Lieut. STRAIN, except that five of the number were early separated from the main body, and after much privation and difficulty made their way back to the United States ship Cyane.

The City was kept in a state of high excitement during yesterday by the most contradictory rumors from Washington, concerning the personal difficulty between Messrs. CUTTING and BRECKINRIDGE. It was at first reported that a meeting had taken place, and that BRECKINRIDGE was killed.

The United States Circuit Court met on Tuesday, and again had before it the great India-rubber case of GOODYEAR versus DAY. Affidavits were introduced by the latter denying that he was in contempt, as charged by GOODYEAR. The Court referred the whole matter to the Master to report at the next term.

LOUIS NAPOLEON'S system of Government and of legislation is certainly the most prompt, efficient and infallible ever devised since the establishment of deliberative bodies. Listen to a succinct account of the manner in which the Emperor is a realize 250 millions of francs to carry on the war in the East.

The Chair laid before the Senate the Report of the War Department, under the last River and Harbore set, for the improvement of Western Rives and Harbore. Mr. FOOTE presented remonstrances from New-Hampshie against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise. MR. EVERETT presented the resolutions of three towns in Massachusetts against the Nebraska bill.

Between 3 and 4 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out in a small confectionery store, kept by a man named STRATTON, located on Hamilton-avenue, near the junction of that avenue with Union-street, and before the flames could be stayed, six three and four-story brick buildings--three on Union-street and three on Hamilton-avenue--were laid in ruins.

A memorial, worth of attention, was presented to the Senate yesterday, from the American Association for the Advancement of Science, praying for the establishment of a Geographical Department connected with the Congressional Library.

The town of Rye has elected JOHN S. PROVOST Supervisor, by 12 majority over JOHN GEDNEY, in a vote of 291. Mr. PROVOST was the regular Whig candidate, and the only Whig Supervisor elected from this town since 1849. Mr. GEDNEY was the regular Democratic and Temperance candidate.

The friends of Messrs. CUTTINGS and BRECKINRIDGE have been using every effort to-day to bring about a settlement without resort to arms. The prospect of peace brightens. Both the gentlemen are still out of this District. The excitement in the Senate about the GADSDEN Treaty continues.

We have often heard of meeting a murderer on the high seas, but seldom have to record such scenes of violence as occurred, on the steamer S. F. J. Trabue, on the Mississippi River, during her recent trip from New-Orleans. As is usual, at this season of the year, the boat was crowded with deck passengers, cheifly flat-boatmen, from the Wabash, and coal-boatmen from Pittsburg.

SINGULAR CASE.--Mr. HENRY MANTER, of Starks, had suffered from a disagreeable sensation in his stomach and a tickling in his throat, for a year or longer, and had occasionally raised blood. It was supposed that the sensations were deceptive, and in reality produced by worms, as various strange sensations are known to be. The cause, however, has turned out to be stranger still.

ANOTHER CANARSIE RIOTER CONVICTED.--MICHAEL McCONNELL, one of the parties engaged in the riot at Carnarsie, on the 5th of July last, was arraigned for trial in the Court of Sessions, before Judge MOORE, yesterday, on an indictment charging him with robbery, committed during the riot on that occassion, in stealing a gold watch from the person of JEREMIAH SCHENCK, who was so severely beaten on that occasion.

It would be doing tile German people great injustice for any one to suppose that a party exists among them really favorable in feeling to Russia. Indeed, public opinion and the voice of all political parties are so unanimous in their dislike, nay, in their heart-hatred to Russia, that it is idle to talk of anything like a Russian party among the various populations of the Teutonic family.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: In your paper of the 25th inst., you publish a communication over the signature of "S.," who thinks the number of members of Congress is by far too small. With your permission, Sir, I beg leave to say the number of our members of Congress is by far too large.

From the sunny German community in which I now write, it is not pleasant to revert to the cold prairies east of the Colorado, where my observations rested at the close of my last letter. Nor, until, after nearly a week's additional riding, we reached Austin were there any changes of importance in the general character of the country which I need report.

A careful perusal of our late exchanges from Mexico confirms, in our mind, the opinions we have hitherto held and expressed, that the existing Government there is one of a most ephemeral character, and that SANTA ANNA has nearly run his alloted course.

When the Nebraska question is settled, and a "finality" has been enacted on all the other important matters that agitate the United States to-day, one subject will remain as fruitful a topic of discussion and legislation as every,--to wit, the propriety or impropriety of continuing the office of Marine Hospital physician on Staten Island.

In this City, on Wednesday, March 29, MARGARET C., youngest daughter of James and Mary Eliza Harrison, aged 10 months. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral on Friday, March 31, at 2 o'clock, P.M., without further invitation, from No. 400 Hudson-st.

Gov. SEYMOUR will to-morrow return to the Senate the bill for the suppression of intemperance, with his objections to its becoming a law. While deeming it his duty to make public, at the earliest moment, the conclusion at which he has are rived, the Governor has not as yet made known the reasons which he will assign for his interposition of the veto.

The funeral solemnities of JONATHAN HARRINGTON, the last survivor of the battle of Lexington, were celebrated to-day and were very imposing. The Governor, Lieutenant-Governor, Executive Council, and many members of both branches of the Legislature, were present.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: An American has at length found favor in the eyes of the leviathan of the newspaper press, the London Times. A circumstance so unheard-of is cause for suspicion--suspicion that, unperceived by its, author, Colonel WEBB, the lauded letter bears a covert attack upon American interests.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--A translation--a pretty close one, we believe--from BAYARD'S Changement de Main, was produced here on Wednesday evening under the title of the "Prison and Palace." The alteration in the name is not felicitous, but sufficiently near.

MASONIC LODGE.--The officers of Varick Lodge, a newly organized lodge of Free and Accepted York Masons, were installed in office on Wednesday night, The officers are as follows: J. J. BURGERS, W. M.; D. S. SINCLAIR, S. W.; G. W. DEMPSEY, J. W.; J. WALSH, Secretary; J. MCLSEN, Treasurer; A. A. RICE S. D.; E. CAPRON, J. D.; A. QUACKENBOS, J. T. HEGEL, Stewards; A. McMULLEN, Tiler.

SHIP REPORTS.--Merchants, the friends of passengers, and even the agents of the CUNARD steamers, have often complained that the Press failed to get over the wires from Halifax, and publish, the ship reports of vessels spoken on the passage, the weather, and other incidents of the voyage, on the arrival of the Royal Mail steamer at that port.

There was tolerably numerous gathering of respectable mechanics and their families, in the Tabernacle last evening, to hear a discourse by Mr. BENJAMIN J. MORRILL on the "Wrights and Wrongs of Labor." Among those present were several wearing the badge of the "House Carpenters' Association."

The Court of General Sessions for the April term, commencing on Monday next, will be overwhelmed with important criminal affairs. Hon. Recorder TILLOU presides, and the calendar being unusually heavy, the trials of such cases as have long been delayed will probably be at once called on by the public prosecutor.

BANK ROBBERY, BY AN OLD OFFENDER.--Yesterday afternoon, a bold robbery was committed at the American Exchange Bank, in Wall-street, by an old offender, known as JACK HATFIELD. It seems the expert rogue followed a gentleman into the Bank, who had an account-book in his outside coat pocket containing $2,000 in notes, the ends of which were exposed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Tile Hon. Secretary of the Navy has recommended that at least six steam frigates shall, without delay, be constructed for the naval service, and all parties in Congress have promptly responded favorably in reference to tile recommendation,-very fortunately, for the importance of steam vessels for the service of the Government, methinks, cannot be overrated just at this crisis.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: The communications which yon have published since the appearance of some editorial remarks in your paper, on the subject of Ireland, have attracted my attention, as showing in themselves tile great misfortune of that land,--a want of anythling approaching unanimity in the feelings of Irishmen to the-to them-all-important subject of their country.

ELECTRIC TELEGRAPH TO STATEN ISLAND.--We understand that Mr. LEWIS, the manager of the Sandy Hook Telegraph Line, is about to construct a branch line to Staten Island, which, now that the island has become so populous, and is so intimately connected with the City, must prove of great convenience to the citizens residing there.

The policy of advertising has been pronounced good by all business men, but it costs prodigiously. In the City this has been reduced to an art, and it has many professors.

[From our Evening Edition of Saturday.] We published this morning a brief account of a railroad accident occurring to the down Express train from Albany last evening, about two miles above Tivoli. We are indebted to a gentleman from Waterbury who witnessed the scene, and who came to the City this morning, for the particulars. The cause of the accident was the falling of a large rock upon the track.

Sanitary science is of recent growth. It regards the health of localities and aims to obviate the sources of diseases. Its importance may be estimated from the fact that two-thirds, it has been calculated, of all prevalent diseases arise from causes theoretically removable, and practically so to a very large extent.

From the Richmond Examiner. Nothing is to the Southern arm more Indicrous than what be reads about the ferocious speeches which the hordes of this miserable faction have recently been making about their determination to "RESIST THE SOUTH BY FORCE." There are bold, courageous men in the Free States--Hundreds of thousands of them--but they are not Abolitionists. A hundred Southern gentleman, armed with riding whips, could chase an army of invading abolitionists into the Atlantic.

DREADFUL OCCURRENCE.--The Buffalo Republic learns that a few days since a house in the town of Northbush, in Erie County, was entirely destroyed by fire, and two children burned to death. The father and mother of the family, whose names were MUCK, went out in the evening to a neighbor's house to see a slok person, leaving at home a servant girl and three little children asleep.

LOUIS NAPOLEON has given a new proof of his cleverness. His financial measure to raise Fifty Million Dollars, by means of a national subscription, voluntary among the people, is an indisputable evidence of his thorough knowledge of his position and of the French character.

The letter of our Special Correspondent in the Southwest, which we publish this morning, opens an exceedingly interesting description of the German Colony recently settled in the Western part of Texas. We have already given a general statement of some of the remarkable political results which may grow out of this settlement, and our Correspondent's subsequent letters will throw additional light upon this subject.

The Albany Register is afraid the Whig party in this State will be very seriously damaged if the Legislature should pass a bill, to pay for the advertising which the State require. The Register's solicitude for the welfare of the Whig party is undoubtedly very sincere and very disinterested:--it has been too often shown in some such way as this, to be doubted.

Meeting of Journeymen Tailors. An adjourned mass meeting of the Journeymen Tailors' Trade Society was held in Warren Hall, corner of Henry and Oliver-streets, at 5 P. M. yesterday. THOMAS SPILLSBURY, President of the Society, occupied the Chair. The minutes of the previous meeting were read by JAMES GIBSON, the Secretary, and approved; after which a number of new members were admitted to the Society, and the monthly dues collected.
