This Court opened yesterday morning only to receive the Grand Jury, who brought in the following Bills of Indictment: The United States vs. John Dowling.--This was an indictment for smuggling on board the Cunard steamship Asia, in December last, a quantity of gold chains and lockets, valued at about $2,000. out $2,000.

STEAMBOAT LIBERTY ON FIRE. -- About 2 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning another fire was discovered on board of the steamboat Liberty, lying at the foot of Charlton-street, North River. The flames were first observed by officer Bryan, of the Ninth District. who called a private watchman, awoke the ship-keeper, and the three together extinguished the fire before it had made much headway.

CAUTION TO IDLERS AND VAGRANTS.--For more than a year last a gang of young men between the ages of sixteen and eighteen years, has been in the habit of loitering around the Bowery. St. Charles, and National Theatres, at night, watching opportunities to commit depredations.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN CLEVELAND--TWENTY FAMILIES BURNED OUT.--We learn from the Buffalo papers that on Sunday night, at near 12 o'clock, a fire broke out in Engine-house No. 2, situated in Seneca-street, Cleveland, Ohio. A strong wind was blowing from the lake, which caused the fire to sweep all the frame buildings on that side of the street off.

The Senate made but little progress yesterday. After the usual number of remonstrances against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise, the only subjects of material interest discussed were the joint resolution explanatory of the act regulating the manner of appointing Cadeis to West Point, on which no action was taken, and the question of the religious rights of American citizens a broad.

Archbishop HUGHES, in a letter which we publish in another column, makes a very tart denial of the report which attributed to him expressions favoring the annexation of Cuba to the United States. He bears witness to the good condition of the Creoles, to the capacity of the Colonial authorities and to the accomplished courtesy and urbanity of all the officials with whom he came in contact.

CHANGES IN THE CUSTOM-House.--The following list of new appointments and removals in the Custom-House has just been announced: Weigher--Albert Edgerton, vice Richard D. Little, removed. Gauger--Abraham S. Vosburgh, vice Albert Edgerton, appointed Weigher. Measurers--Germain Thompson, vice Aaron R. Thompson, Asahel Reed, to fill a vacancy. cy.

DEAR SIR : I told you in my first letter, that I did not consider the omission to extend the principle of the Missouri Compromise on the part of the Federal Legislature to other Territory since acquired, a violation of that plighted faith, in which it had its origin. This may require a little further illustration.

FIRE IN SOUTH WILLIAM-STREET.--Between 6 and 7 o'clock yesterday morning, fire was discovered in the five-story brick store, No 11 South William-street. The third, fourth and fifth floors were nearly destroyed. The first, third and fourth floors were occupied by MESSIS. CASAR PAULI, commission merchants.

OFFICIAL DECAPITATION.--The efficient Assistant Captain of the Second District police, RUFUE W. BELKNAP, was made to remove him when the present city authorities came into power, but the faithful manner in which he discharged his duties, and an opinion of the Counsellor to the Corporation, saved him for a time.

MEErINO OF THE FOURTH PRESBYTIRY.-A .meeting of the Presbytery of New-York was held in the Twenty-third-street Presbyterian Church at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. Rev. Mr. ST. JOHN was elected Moderator, and Rev. Mr. CLERKE was appointed :Secretary. A motion was made empowering the Moder :ator to inquire into the cause of the absence of the members who had not been present at the previous mseeting.

Two Whig Representatives have been elected in Hartford, one in Manchester, one in Meriden and two in East Hartford--all Whig gains upon last year. Second Dispatch.] HARTFORD, Monday, April 3. We have heard of the election of fourteen Representatives in this County, viz.: 10 Whigs, 3 Democrats and 1 Free-Soil, being a Whig gain of nine over last year.

Three fires occurred simultaneously in this city yesterday morning, one of which destroyed STURTEVANT'S large planing mills, including some immense piles of pine lumber, three dwelling-houses, STACY'S beer manufactory, DAVIS' carpenter shop, and several small buildings.

The Report of the Registry and returns of Births, Marriages and Deaths in the State of New-Jersey, during 1853, has been received. The value of the documents is very much impaired from the omission of forty-two townships and wards to make returns.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The item by telegraph from this city, published in the TIMES of yesterday, relative to the application of JOHN D. HAGER, of Poughkeepsie, against STEVENS, STOCKTON and others, made in the United States Circuit Court for this District, was not made sufficiently clear to a proper understanding of this important cause, and which is so closely connected with the management of the New-Jersey monopoly.

POLITICAL NOMINATION.--Last evening, the Democrats of the First Ward met and appointed Nominating Committees, and appointed as delegates to the City Convention Messrs. Joseph MoManus, John D. Nolan, Thos. Decker, Wm. Rodgers, Jr., and Joseph H. Fairbanks.

The nomination of Mr. ARMSTRONG, (Anti-Benton.) for the office of Postmaster of St. Louis, was confirmed to-day. The Trial of Capt. Schanumburg. WASHINGTON, Monday, April 3, brought in a verdict this morning of "Guilt, of assault, without intent to kill," the verdict creates some surprise.

The great post stake race comes off this afternoon at 3 o'clock. The stake is $20,000, and the greatest excitement prevails. Four horses have been entered, viz Lexington for Kentucky, Lecompte for Mississippi, High lander for Alabama, and Arrow for Louisiana A great crowd is now pouring into the racecourse, and thousands of strangers are present from other States Heavy bets are pending on the result.

NEW-YORK TYPOGRAPHICAL SOCIETY--MUNIFICENT OFFER OF GEORGE BRUCE.--An interesting meeting of the members of the New-York Typographical Society was held on Saturday evening, at the rooms of the Printers' Free Library, on the occasion of the semi-annual election for officers.

DEATH OF RUBINI.--Italy has lost one of her most popular artists. RUBINI died, in his rich palace at Remano, on March 2, 1854. Since 1815 he has retired to his natal place, and has enjoyed all he harms of repose--his fortune being upwards of four millions, or there-abouts. Never has a singer arrived as a similar result by the power and effect of his talent alone.

COLD BATHS.--Henry Austin was rescued from drowning on Saturday evening, at about 9 o'clock, by several citizens. He had either fallen or thrown himself into the water at the font of York-street. Jacob Loosey, on Saturday evening, walked into the slip on the New-York side of the ferry and was rescued by the ferry hands.

The schooner Lucy Watts, Capt. HALL, of Thomaston, Maine, from Philadelphia for Boston, spring a leak and sunk on the 26th ult., 30 miles from Cape Cod. The crew, after being three days and nights in the beats, were picked up the schooner John Pew, and landed at Gloucester yesterday, badly frost-bitten.

ROWDYISM.-On Sunday, about 5 o'clock, three young ruffians, the oldest not more than twenty-three years of age, were perambulating the sidewalk in Third street, near the Bowery, pretending to be tipsy, and jostling against all who passed, particularly if the person chanced to be unaccompanied. The ruffians then moved across the Bowery to Spring-street, and there commenced practicing the same conduct.

The additional returns of the Connection election received at this office during yesterday and last evening, put the complete overthrow of the Administration party beyond the shadow of doubt. Of the State Senators elected, fifteen are Whig and three are Democratic. There are yet three districts to be heard from.

The United States Mail steamship Empire City left New-Orleans March 26, for New-York ?? Havana, and arrived off Moro Castle at 10 P. M. on the 28th. Having landed her mails and passengers, and taken a supply of coal, she sailed at 7 P. M. of' the 29th tilt., for this port, special permission having been granted to leave the port after sunset.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A poor woman was a witness before the Grand Jury; she had a sick child, and no one to leave it with; she attended with it, before the Grand Jury.

A glance at the advertisements in the London news-papers will show that England is flooded with such books.

The GADSDEN Treaty has had a narrow escape from destruction; and as near as I can learn, Mr. MASON, the Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations, and others who have been the champions of the measure, have retired from the leadership.

Organization for Founding and Supporting Industrial Schools in Brooklyn. The Industrial School operations of Mr. PEASE and Mr. BRACE in New-York have excited a commendable spirit of emulation among the ladies of Brooklyn.

The entire vote for Governer is about 61,000, of which Dutton (Whig has about 10,500; Ingham,(Dem.,) about 28,000:' Chapman (Temperance) about 10,800, and Hooker about '2,7-making the majority against the Democratic candidate about 5,000. The Senate will stand-Whigs 17, Democrats 4. The Honse-Whigs and Free-Soilers 132, Democrats 94.,

In Washington County, Wm. W. Hoppin, Whig, for Governor, had 1,325 votes; Francis M. Dimond, Democract 562; scattering, 83. KENT COUNTY-Hoppin, 833; Diamond, 664. The whigs have carried this city by majorities varying from 200 to 1,000.

THE MERCHANTS' AND MECHANICS' BANK OF OSWEGO.--On the outside of to-day's TIMES is given a sketch of the case of the Merchants' and Mechanics, Bank of Oswego. In the Supreme Court, yesterday, Judge ROOSEVELT gave his decision in the matter.

Mr. BRIGHT appeared in his-seat for the first time in two months. The bill for the relief or WM. CLAUDE JONES was taken up and passed. Mr. PETTIT reported a bill supplementary to the act confirming private land claims in Missouri, and the same was taken up and passed.

From the Albany Evening Journal. Several hundred of the opponents of the Maine Law joined in a torch-light procession, last evening, in honor of the Veto. They were preceded by a full bank, and make a very imposing appearance.

We expressed the opinion, a day or two since, that "sober people" generally, on a fair consideration of the whole matter, would probably concede that Governor SEYMOUR'S objections to the details of the Temperance bill were substantially just.

SENSIBLE.--General JOHN A. DIX is said to have devoted a portion of his leisure, during the past Winter, in preparing for his family, who are now in Italy, a sort of classical Itinerary, in which he gives, in a pleasant, attractive style, the principal facts and events recorded in ancient literature, which are to special interest to the modern traveler in the ancient Empire of the C?ESARS.

Another hope has melted into thin air. The hope in HOHENZOLLERN, (or Hohenliden, spell the name,) has vanished like all its predecessors the hope in SAXE-COBOURG, the hope in ORLOFF, the hope in the autograph letter, the hope in numberless ultimatums.

Tile Academy of Medicine bad under consideration last night, among other things, the feasibility and necessity of establishing a new vaccine institution, with the purpose of insuring to all the -poor the benefits of vaccination, and to physicians a supply ofpure lymph at all seasons.

In the Assembly yesterday afternoon, the bill to provide for the appointment of Chief of Police in the City of New-York ? as taken from the table, and passed by a decided vote. Ages 79. You have had already a full copy of the bill, which it will be recollected give to the Mayor the power to remove at pleasure, o fill any vacancy that may occur.

Mr. BRECKINRIDGE possessesrare courage, talent, and eloquence but lacks the discretion and tact necessary for a political and parliamentary leader. He was not the man for managing the Nebraska bill in the Committee of the Whole, or lot repairing the damage it had received from Mr.CUTTING'S reprehensible pravious motion and course.

The races for the Spring Meeting over the Metairie Course commenced yesterday, with the spirit and brilliancy which should characterize the commencement of such glorious sport as will be offered during the continnance of the races. The course, with all its appurtenances, was in fine condition; the stands are exceedingly large, and substantially built, and have lately been inspected and declared perfectly safe.

We have papers from Galveston to the 26th ult., and from Indianola and San Antonio to the 20th. The principal intelligence contained in them is given in an extra of the San Antonio Ledger. From that we extract the following:

The prospects of the reopening of the Crystal Palace, under improved auspices, are growing more encouraging. It will be recollected that Mr. BARNUM, in his recent letter, addressed to the Directors of the Crystal Palace Association, declared his willingness to undertake the responsibilities of the Presidency, in case certain provisions were complied with.
ANOTHER FUGITIVE.--A negro man, belonging to Mr. RICHARD DOYLE, made his escape to the North a few days ago. He had been a corn-measurer for some time.

FIRE AND ACCIDENT.-About 12 1/2 o'clock this morning a fire broke out in a small stable, owned by Mr. JENNINGS, on Willow-street, near Atlantic-street. From this the fire spread to a wheelwright shop, owned by Mr. McGLINN, and from thence to a row of three two story buildings, owned by CHAS. SQUIRES, which were entirely destroyed.

The House yesterday requested the President to furnish all the correspondence between the United States Charge d'Affaires at Vienna and the State Department, relative to the arrest of Rev. Mr. RICHMOND ; and also concerning the rejection of the Exequatur of the Consulate at Trieste.

"The Czar refuses of treat," said all the papers yesterday. We are glad of it. We think better of the Czar for his refusal, and would commend his example to all the great men who take the TIMES, as well as to the little ones who do not.

In this City, on Wednesday, April 5, GEORGE M. WADSWORTH son of George B, and Matilda S. Wadsworth, aged Lycar 4 months and 9 days. Relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend to funeral, th's (Thursday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from the residence of his grandfather. G. Marsh Wadsworth. No. 45 3d.av., without further invitation.
We published yesterday morning the whole of the recent and confidential correspondence between the Emperor of Russia and the British Government, concerning the condition and the fate of Turkey.

CHURCH DEDICATION.--The Dutch Reformed Church, recently erected in North Brookly, is to be dedicated on Sunday afternoon next. The sermon on this occasion is to be preached by Dr. BETHUNE, of Brooklyn.

Whatever opinion may be formed as to the proceedings which took place last night in the House O Lords, we learn with the greatest satisfaction that the employed in the Foreign-office has been contradicted by him self in a manner which leaves no aspersion on his character, and that Lord ABERDEEN has withdrawn the accusation which he had, to say the least of it, injudiciously made.

THE COMET.--A correspondent, writing to the Boston Traveller, says the Comel, now so consipienous in the evening near the western horizon, as seen through the great Refractor at Cambridge, presents a blazing nuclues and a tall which may be traced to the extent of ten degress. The tail is curved towards the North,

Proceedings of the Last Meeting--Original Portrait of Washington. The regular monthly meeting of the Society held in University Chapel on Tuesday evening, was well attended. DON JOSE FRANCISCO RAMIREZ, of Mexico, and Hon. DAVID L. SWAIN, President of University, North Carolina, were elected corresponding members, and several gentlemen as resident members.

LETTER FROM EDWARD C. DELAVAN. To the Editor of the New-York Tribune: SIR: As an unwavering and uncompromising friend of a Prohibitory law, from its first inception to the present moment, permit me to address to you a few words in answer to your remarks as to one portion of my dispatch relative to the veto of Governor SEYMOUR, wherein you say:

WHIG PRIMARY MEETING.--On Monday evening, the Whigs of the Fourth Ward assembled at Well-wood Hall, and appointed as delegates to the city Convention, Messrs. H. M. Traphagen, James F. Fielder, Andrew Anderson, A. Van Riper, and H. M. Soule.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: GENTLEMEN: In your account of the burning of Messrs. Johnson Lazarus' distillery, yesterday morning, you state that it was caused by an explosion of a faucet connected with the still, which had (as annears) been neglected by those whose duty it was to replace it with a new one. Injustice to myself I ask you to correct the statement.

SHIPWRECK--SUFFERING AND RESCUE OF THE CREW.--GLOUCESTER, April 3.--The schooner John Pew, Capt. DAVID BOWEN, arrived yesterday (Sunday) from George's Shoals, having on board the captain and crew of the brig Lucy Watts, of Thomaston, Me., sunk at sea.

PROSPECT FOR THE NEW FERRY.--The prospects for the establishment of the South Tenth-street Ferry begin to look more favorable. We are informed from good authority that Mr. SHARLOCK has purchased two slips, one a the Roosevelt-street and one at the Catharine-street Ferry.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: I wish to call your attention to the general proposition of granting Government lands to the Western States, and content myself with a few observations, which your own good sense will amplify, in attempting to prove that the Eastern States, and particularly New-York City, should be the last to oppose them.

BEAN, Esq., clerk of the Vice-Chaucery Court, at Carrolton, and Mr. PATRICK HERRINGTON, which resulted in the death of the latter. It appears that HERRINGTON was, to a certain extent, laboring under the influence of liquor;

NEW TRAGEDY--A NEW SUCCESS OF MISS CUSHMAN.--A new five-act tragedy, entitled "Duchess Eleanor," has just been produced at the Hay-market Theatre in London. It is chiefly interesting to Americans from the fact that Miss CUSHMAN'S fine powers have received additional recognition, and that of the warmest kind, from the London press.

HISTORICAL SOCIETY OF PENNSYLVANIA.--Professor GEORGE TUCKER presided at the meeting of the Historical Society, on Monday night. Mr. THOMAS BUDDLE, Jr., read the proceedings of the previous meeting. The address, by Mr. JOHN C. DEVEREUX, of New-York, was then read, and will long be remembered with pleasure by the many members who listened to it.

SECOND DAY.--The weather was yesterday most unfavorable for field sports, as it rained heavily from 6 o'clock in the morning until noon, when the sky became clear, and the sun shone out warmly for the remainder of the day. The rain made the track very muddy and slippery, and what was worse, prevented many persons from going to the Course.

SHAMEFUL OUTRAGE. --The packet ship St Louis, Capt. DENNIS, from New-York, arrived alongside the wharf of the Second District on Tuesday afternoon, and was almost immediately boarded by a band of armed ruffians, said to be runners of the sailor boarding-houses, who attacked the Captain upon his own deck, knocking him down with a colt, and beating and bruising him in a most awful manner.

The steamship El Dorado, from Aspinwall, on the 30th ult., has arrived. She brings the California mails of March 16, 130 passengers and $40,000 in gold dust. The mail steamship George Law was to sail from Aspinwall, for New-York, on March 31, with 500 passengers, and nearly one million dollars in treasure.

The cruelties practiced by the man-stealers on the coast of Africa, and the horrors of the "middle passage," have been so frequently and so graphically described, that I am happily spared the necessity of attempting to dilate upon them.

It is the custom in some New-England Colleges, for the person matriculating as a student to have placed before him for his signature a copy of the laws of the institution. Of course he puts down his name, more careful whether his chirography is creditable than as to the contents of the document he thus pledges himself to be guided by.

A SCAMP--KEEP AN EYE ON HIM.-- The Huntsville (Texas) Item says: A man named JOHN M. DOWLING came here a few weeks ago, to work as a tailor, with B. M. CLOPTON, of our town. He is a native of Brooklyn, N.Y. , and went to Murfreesboro', Tenn., some years ago where he married a young lady of wealthy connections named MISS MARY SMITH.

The supporters of the GADSDEN Treaty had a conference this morning, and concluded to try again. The Administration has also taken hold. In Executive Session to-day, the subject was de bated with much warmth. A motion to table it was lost by a single vote. General CASS is considered doubtful, but its advocates look upon its ratification as not yet hopeless.

CONFLAGRATION AT EST SAGINAW.--At about 12 o'clock yesterday, fire was discovered issuing from the lumber pile of GARRISON BRISTOL adjacent to our office. It was soon apparent that it was impossible to extinguish or remove the large lumber piles in ? which the fire had entered, and part of the crowd commenced removing the goods from GARRISON BRISTOL'S store, our office, and buildings adjoining, while others retarded the progress of the fire.

The Democratic papers are a little puzzled to account for the recent elections in the Eastern States. The Union consoles itself with the reflection that Gen. JACKSON'S Administration was greatly obstructed by hostile majorities, and thinks that the Connecticut election may be of merely temporary influence.

On Thursday, April 6, MICHAEL, O'CONNOR, late organist of St. Bridget's Church; in the 29th year of his age. His friends, and those of his brother-in-law, James W. Walsh, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from St. Bridget's Church, opposite Tompkins-square, on Saturday, April 8, at 9 1/2 o'clock A.M., without further invitation.

The Captain of the bank Charles E. Lex, arrived here to-day from Port-to-Prince, states that on the 5th of March, a French frigate (brig) and a steamer anchored off the harbor, and the Admiral, DUQUESNE, demanded an audience of the Emperor, which was refused. A letter was then delivered, threatening that if certain demands were not complied with in forty-eight hours, the French would resort to the most severe measures.

Rowie knives and pistols were used by both parties, and both the young men were wounled -- Mr. GARTH, very seriously. Mr. CLARK, a gentlemen who by some means has become the owner of a quantity of Continental money, had a memorial presented to the Senate yesterday, asking for its redemption by the Government.

Mr. EVERETT presented resolutions of the town of Dedham, Mass., against the Missouri Compromise. Also, a petition from the citizens of Gettysburg, Penn., in favor of securing religious worship to Americans abroad. Mr. CLAYTON presented a memorial against the Homestead bill.

SELLING UNHEALTHY MEAT.--Inspector McLEER yesterday found a man named EUGENE BRENNAN, who keeps a small market on Hamilton-avenue, retailing out to his customers a veal carcase killed when only one day old. He was at once arrested and held for examination by justice BLACHLEY.

The Annual Fast in Massachusetts was observed to-day. The weather was warm and pleasant, and business was generally suspended in this city. The Churches were well filled. The Theatres also attracted large numbers, giving two or three performances. From the National Intelligencer. The subjoined communication from Gen. LESLIE COMES will be read with deep emotion by every Whig in the land. and with interest by every man, of every party, whose love of the Union has not been blunted by sectional or fanatical prejudice. In devotion to that Union, as our supreme national interest, next to public liberty, his patriotic soul was bound up, and for its preservation he was ever on guard.

Before Judge Roosevelt. At the sitting of the Court, yesterday morning, Archibald Murphy, 23 years of age, and born in Oswego, State of New-York, was placed at the bar, to take his trial for the murder of George W. Field. The prisoner was attired in a military jacket. He sat, during the whole of the trial, with his head drooping on his breast, and appeared either unconscious or indifferent to his awful position.

FIRES.--A fire broke out in an out house located in the rear of Gold-street, near Jay, about 4 o'clock yesterday morning, which at one time threatened an extensive conflagration, and one was only prevented through the almost superhuman exertions of the firemen--one company (No. 7) located a few blocks from the fire, dragged their machine on three wheels to it.

EXTRAORDINARY DISCOVERY--EXHUMING OF A HUMAN BODY IN A PETRIFIED STATE.--Yesterday ?? ?? as some workmen were excavating a cellar on Linten-street, a short distance below John-street, they came in contact with a hard substance, about nine feet below the grade of the street, which, after some trouble, was excavated and brought to light, and proved to be human body in a perfect state of petrifaction.

The Senate yesterday passed thirty-six Senate bills and twelve House bills, and postponed fifty, when, having impressed upon Mr. BADGER the idea that a glorious day's work had been done, they adjourned.

A political pamphlet, entitled "The Map of Europe," which has just been suppressed at Paris, continues to occupy the attention of political circles at the French capital. This brochure was published by M. PLON, and copies of in were actually sent to some of the leading journals of Europe, and even to some of the Paris journals.

The statement recently made public that Hon. EDWARD EVERETT is the author of the celebrated HULSEMANN letter, creates no excitement in this city whatever; neither has the disclosure of the fact caused any ill-feeling between the friends of the late Mr. WEBSTER and Senator EVERETT.

THE SHIP-VARDS--The ship-yards in this city pre? quite an active appearance. The following vessels are now in course of construction: At Mr. Patterson's yard. Foot of North Eighth-street, two ships, 215 feet on deck, 43 feet be ??, 2d feet deep, and 2,?00 tons burden.

FOURTH EVENING. The attendance at the Broadway Tabernacle last evening was large, as usual, since the commencement of this discussion. As it progresses, the feelings of the audience are becoming more strongly ealisted on both sides--not so much in the merits of the respective arguments as the success of the speakers.

The Lawyers near Cincinnati have struck for higher fees. The Judges of Pittsburg work as hard, says the Pittsburg Gazette, as the Judges of Philadelphia for $600 less per annum, want more money, and the legislators at Harrisburg have reported a bill increasing their wages.

THE FATAL SHOOTING CASE.--Yesterday morning, an in ?? wa held at the City Hospital by Coroner HILTON, on the body of the unfortunate man, named CARL ZER E K, who was recently shot by the accidental discharge of a pistol.

EXTENSION OF THE TELEGRAPH.--We understand that a Company has been formed in this City for the construction of a line of Telegraph from S. Johns, Newfoundland, to the States, and that a favorable grant has been obtained from the authorities of the Province.

Mr. SAVAGE, representing one of the Districts of this City in the State Assembly, moved on Wednesday an amendment to the School Law, rendering it imperative in every school of the State to read a portion of the English Bible daily, and forbidding the payment of any portion of the school money of the State to any school in which the Bible shall not thus be used.

The Board met pursuant to adjournment, his Honor Recorder TILLOU in the Chair. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. COMMUNICATIONS. From the Grand Jury, responding the unsuitable character of the room occupied by that tribunal.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Few railroads are so located as not to run over or by the side of deep water. Hence, whenever cars run off the track or into a draw, there is a liability on the part of passengers to be plunged into deep water or mud, shut up in the cars, with scarre a possibility of escape.

The subject of reducing the Tares on the Williamsburg Ferries was discussed last evening in the Board of Aldermen. The Committee which reported on a former occasion, made a supplementary Report, recommending that the fare be fixed at tarce cents.

The startling articles in the NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES of the 27th ult., announcing that preparations are on foot for an invasion of Canada by JOHN MITCHEL and his compatriots, has been the theme of much conversation and newspaper writing among us Provincials, during the last week.

To the Editor of the Union: My name has been mentioned in certain newspapers as authority for statements that Mr. LAW, of New-York, and my brother-in-law, Mr. GEORGE N. SANDERS, now in London, had disposed of their muskets to the Red Republicans of Europe, and acquired large sums of money thereby.

GIRLS' INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL.--We have been requested to state that the Girls' Industrial School, in the Fourth Wand, which has been kepigin the basement of the Mariter's Church. Roosevelt-street, will behornoved on Monday next, to a Hall, No. 64 East Broadway.

Rev. JOHN GOLDSMITH, D.D., died at Newtow. L.I., April 6. Dr. GOLDSMITH was a native of Southold Town, on Long Island. his father, Rev. BENJAMIN GOLDSMITH, was an eminent clergyman, who was for a long time settled in that place.

The friends of the Gadsden Treaty are making gigantic efforts to save it. Absent Senators have been telegraphed to return. It is, however, generally believed that it will be rejected, though some think otherwise.

FOREIGN GOSSIP.--A certain French engineer on a late visit to Sinope, upon examining some of the wrecks, gave as his opinion that the missiles used in the destruct ?? of the Turkish vess Is were of novel invention, and unlike anything hitherto used in warfare.
New-Orleans papers of Saturday are received. Ex-President FILLMORE was still receiving great attention in New-Orleans. He would go from there to Charleston by the land route.

"WORSE NOR BROADWAY."--Extract of a letter dated Melbourne, Australia, Dec. 19, 1853: 'I almost wish you could experience one such day as to-day, and you would know how to esteem a letter written in such weather.
FOURTH WARD POLICEMEN.--The Police Commissioners have rendered their decision in the case of the eight policemen of the Fourth Ward, who cruelly beat a prisoner when taking him down to a cell.
The anxiously looked for day has at last arrived, and to-day, at 3 o'clock, the great State Post Stake for $20,000, play or pay, will be run over the Metairie Course.

NO. VIII.--CHRISTIANS. The organized existence of the "Christian," sect or "Connection," dates about fifty years back From the best information to whcih we have access, and especially the perspicuous and pertinent narrative by Elder SHAW, of the interesting circumstance which gave rise to its formation, the movement was commenced by a number of Methodist Clergymen in Virginia and the Carolinas, who became disaffected toward the discipline of that Church, and finally withdrew.

It has embodied in the shape of two letters from an imaginary Boston correspondent, certain gossip that has been current for months in political circles, and had died out of the memory of those once familiar with it, until brought anew to life by the Post's exertions.

FIRES.--About 7 o'clock Saturday morning, a fire broke out in a porter-house, kept by JOHN GRADY, in Navy, near Tillary-street, which was entirely consumed. The upper floor was occupied as a place of residence by MICHAEL BROWN. Mr. GRADY'S loss is about $1,000. Injured for a small amount in the Brooklyn Insurance Company. Mr. BROWN'S loss is $1,000.

The Committee appointed to receive subscriptions and take other measures for securing this valuable collection to the City, held an adjourned meeting at the Stuyvesant Institute, on Saturday evening. Dr. FRANCIS occupied the Chair.

FUNERAL OF DR. JOHN GOLDSMITH.--Rev. Dr. JOHN GOLDSMITH, of whose death we made on Friday, was buried under the shadow of his own church at Newton, L. I., yesterday afternoon. A large concourse of people were in attendance, including most of the clergyman of the surrounding villages and from the Pre-bytery (O.S.) of New-York, with which he was connected. Rev. Dr. STRING preached the funeral sermon.

The United States Mail steamship George Law, Captain McGOWAN, arrived at this port yesterday morning, with the California mails of 16th March, a summary of which we had previously received by telegraph from New-Orleans, and also with later advices from the Isthmus of Panama, and the South Pacific and Australia. The George Law

Another fortnight has elapsed since the issue of our last steamer number, and our market has not experienced the slightest amelioration. Our readers will remember that we held out no hope of any change for the better, believing as we did that neither actual nor prospective circumstances would warrant us in so doing.

STRIKE AMONG THE OPERATIVES AT LEWISTON--SPEECH OF A FACTORY GIRL.--The further and Mechanic, published at Lewiston, Me., gives a long account of the proceedings of the operatives in the factories at Lewiston, who refused to work unless an arrangement could be made for eleven hours work for a day.

By far the most interesting new by the late packet from the Pacific is the safety of Lieut. STRAIN, U.S. Navy, and most of his party, who went out from the Darien Surveying Expedition, early in January.

The steamer Star of the West brings the following from our Jamaica correspondent: JAMAICA, Tuesday, March 28, 1854. The half-yearly meeting of the Bank of Jamaica, ending the 31st December last, shows a profit of [pound]2,520. A dividend of 6 per cent. per annum has been declared, hereby leaving a surplus profit of [pound]1,120 12s. 11d. on ??e half year's transactions.

After a season of non-productiveness comes one of plenty. For several weeks our managers have been falling back to take a spring, and this week they take it. Revivals and new pieces are announced at the principal Theatres, and a contest, in which excellence is the prize, begins to-day. Theatres have and it all to them.

Senators Jones of Tennessee, and BUTLER of South Carolina, have gone to the Southern Commercial Convention, to be held at Charleston. The Government is believed to have received news showing that the shedding of blood in Europe, on a large scale, is inevitable.

By the bark Pacz we have dates from Puerto Cabello to the 25th ultimo. Congress was in session, and considering the subject of the emancipation of the slaves at an early day. This project was a favorite measure of the President, who hoped by it to gain greater influence with the masses, so as to enable him to retain power, or confer it upon his brother, who was a candidate for the Presidency.

Poets are said to be an irritable tribe. Theologians enjoy pitched battles; when the battle rages hottest, their enjoyment is the keenest. They do not scruple to use poisoned bomb-shells--we are not sure but they would approve of spiritual vitriol even.

FIRE AT STATEN ISLAND.--About 3 o'clock on Sunday morning a fire broke out in the planning mill of GEORGE OSGOOD, at Vanderbilt Landing, entirely consuming the mill, together with a quantity of lumber in the yard. Loss, about $3,000. It is supposed to be the work of an incendiary, as the citizens in their endeavors to extinguish it were set upon by a parcel of rowdios, who pelted them with stones, thereby injuring one man.

SPECIAL DISPATCH TO NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES. The nomination of Dr. G. C. HEBBE was sent in to the Senate to-day for Consul to Aix-la-Chapelle, France. The GADSDEN Treaty was further debated. Its enemies, and some of its friends, united to-day, and inserted a clause fixing the boundary north of the lake, so that it does not strike the Gulf at all.

New-Orleans papers of Tuesday Last are received. The City Council of Savannah has extended an invitation to Ex-President FILLMORE to visit that city. Delegates to the Charleston Convention were already arriving in that city, preparatory to the meeting on the 10th inst.

AN AUSTRIAN AGENT UNDER ARREST.--On Saturday Officer FARLEY, of the detective force at the Crystal Palace, arrested FRANCIS RAFELSPERGER, an agent of several Austrian exhibitors, whose property on exhibition was under his supervision.

The City was a good deal shocked last Thursday morning, on discovering in the papers that a fatal case of yellow fever had occurred in the City, The Coroner's Jury pronounced it yellow fever ; the return to the City Inspector made it yellow fever;

ARCULARIUS, of unhappy memory urged this plea with tears in his eyes, and finally resigned his situation because he could get nobody to believe it.
"Remember," said Poor Richard, "that for six pounds you can have the use of an hundred pounds for a year." It was a wise saying of the garrulous old man, and should greatly console us in our poverty.

To the astonishment of many persons, a secret was divulged yesterday respecting the recent action of the Board of Police Commissioners in regard to the present Chief of the Police Department. It appears the Chief's term of office does not expire until the 1st of January next, yet he has been renominated and confirmed by the Commissioners, nine months in advance.

MARINE SOCIETY.--The regular quarterly meeting of the Marine Society of the Port of New-York, was held in the United States Hotel, at 6 o'clock last evening. Capt. FERRIEN presided. After the reading and approval of the minutes of the last meeting, the Secretary, Capt. RUSSELL, read his quarterly report, showing that during the past quarter the sum of $2,770 has been paid into the Treasury of the Society.

The following is a full report of the remarks of Senator GWIN, of California, made in the Senate yesterday, and referred to in our report of the debates in Congress: Mr. PRESIDENT: The history of the country presents no instance of a measure of great national importance in which there has been such unanimity of public sentiment in its favor as the project of connecting the Atlantic and Pacific by means of railway.

FREMONT and party had arrived there safe he day before, with the loss of one man.

Two new pieces were produced last night--one at Mr. BURTON'S, the other at Mr. WALLACK'S. Both were successful, and both were by modest men who declined favoring the public with their names. Probably the result will induce them to forego their heroic self-denial.

A short time since, a fire occurred in the eastern section of the city, and when the firemen entered the house, they found a young lady tied in the garret, and bearing the marks of improper chastisement. It is stated that she had been kept in that condition for some three or four weeks, and with searcely a sufficiency of food to sustain life.

A letter received here states the result of the late demand by the French Admiral upon the Emperor SOULOUQUE, somewhat differently to the report published last week. The demand was for payment of back indemnity money--about $160,000--with a threat of bombardment if not paid.

Rarely has a lovelier Spring day opened on more brilliant hopes and expectations than that which yesterday dawned upon the thousands who, to a greater or less degree, were rushing forward to the great event of the day, with the most pleasurable expectations.

Senator GWIN made a lengthy and an able speech in the Senate yesterday, on the Pacific Railroad bill, on which there is comment in another article. Remonstrances against the repeal of the Missouri Coin promise were presented in unusual numbers, and of more than usual interest.

FIFTH WARD.-- An election has been ordered in the Fifth Ward to fill the vacancy occasioned by the death of the late Alderman MORRIS--a member of the Common Council. the election takes place on the 25th of April.

The sensation produced by the publication of the Anglo-Russian private correspondence is extraordinary, and the indignation lively, though largely mixed with amused stupefaction at the vast projects of the Czar. The Editors of all shades have characterized them in a similar spirit of amazed hilarity, and half-comical wonderment.

PILOTS' LINES.--The Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts has lately decided an important question relative to this subject in the case of HUNT vs. CARLISLE. The defendant was master of the brig Hunter, and in bringing his ship into Boston Harbor had crossed in Pilot's line, on the boundary, upon the outside of which the Pilot is authorized to demand employment from incoming vessels.

On Saturday morning, April 8, of discase of the heart, MRS. MARY ANN REID, aged 66 years. Her remains were taken to Orange County for interment. In Brooklyn on Monday, April 10, very suddenly, JAMES FOSTER, aged 51 years. The friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from his late residence in Bridge-st., near Willoughby.

The remarks of Mr. DEAN which were published in the TIMES of yesterday, in connection with the resolutions offered by him in regard to the rights of Neutrals, are highly important to the Commerce of the United States.

New-Orleans and Mobile, and the whole Southern country have been deeply excited with the great Horse Race which came off in New-Orleans the 1st inst. Kentucky, Mississippi, Louisiana and Alabama had each entered their favorite, and Kentucky, gallant Kentucky, rich in great men, noble women and fleet, beautiful and enduring horses, with Lexington, of Boston stock, has gained the prize, a purse of $20,000.
The British Government has declared that the Anglo-French Alliance was not designed with any reference to Cuba or Mexican affairs, or any other on this hemisphere, except La Platte. s.

The Board of Ten Governors held its regular weekly meeting yesterday. Governor DRAPER, President, presided. The weekly requisitions give the following list of the inmates remaining in the various institutions under charge of the Board, for the week ending April 8, 1854.

The regular monthly meeting of the New-York Journeymen Tailors' Trade Society was held in the Mechanics' Hal, corner of Madison and Catharine-streets, Monday evening. THOMAS SPILLSBURY President of the Society, occurred the Chair.

RESULT OF THE ELECTION.--The Charter election in Jersey City took place yesterday. The vote was light, and we are only able to announce the probable result. Mayor MANNERS, Whig, is reelected by 300 majority;

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES: SIR: My hope is entirely in and from the South. I respect the supposed rights of the planter in his slave, however I may differ from him in opinion in regard to the legitimacy of those rights, and have even proposed the mode in which I believe the planter may, in the self-emancipation of his slave, be himself reimbursed.

A few private petitions were presented. The House bill for the relief of the legal representatives of ISAAC P. SIMONTON was taken up and passed. Mr. MORTON offered a resolution requesting the Postmaster General to inform the Senate whether the contract for carrying certain mails in Florida has been discontinued, and if so, for what reasons. Adopted.

For War, the first thing needful is money; the second,--money;--the third,--MONEY; and victory remains with him who has the last dollar in his pocket. In Europe we have seen thousands and thousands of cannon dragged out, a million of bayonets set in motion, for the pending war.

Coroner HILTON held an inquest on the body of a young child, yesterday, when the testimony of the mother elicited the following facts : That she arrived here on Monday last in the ship Amelia, from Havre, with 350 passengers ;

Trotting at Union Course--The Trotting Horse Tacony to be Sold at Auction. Yesterday afternoon a lively trotting match came off at SNEDICKER'S Union Course, Long Island. It was mile heats, best three in five, to harness, for a purse of $50. The following horses were entered for the contest:

SHOCKING SUICIDE.--About 5 o'clock yesterday morning, the body of a man with part of the head blown off and mangled in a most shocking manner, was found in a wagon owned by Alderman MORRELL, directly opposite his store, at the corner of market and James-streets. The body was first discovered by two boys belonging to the market.

From Dickens' Household Words. On Monday the 13th of March, this upright judge and good man died suddenly at Stafford in the discharge of his duties. Mercifully spared protracted pain and mental decay, he passed away in a moment, with words of Christian eloquence, of brotherly tenderness and kindness towards all men, yet unfinished on his lips.

The influx of passengers from the united States the first part of this month, consequent upon the extension of the railway towards the Pacific, the excellent state of the Cruces road, and especially upon the placing an opposition line upon this route, has changed materially for the better the business of the city.

No quorum of either House could be found in Albany last evening, so that notwithstanding the Speaker and I were peresent, there was no legislative action--or, at best, none that would be considered official. This morning, the regular order of business was gone through with.

SHOCKING ACCIDENT--RUM'S DOINGS.--A shocking accident occurred in this town yesterday afternoon. Two men, named AMOS WHEELOCK and HENRY CARR, were engaged blowing rocks; by some carelessness on their part, their power ignited, and they were blown, burnt and mangled, in a shocking manner. EELOCK'S face was literally blown to

HANGED WHILE DRUNK.--We read in the Gazette des Tribunaux: A young man about twenty-nine years of age arrived at Paris about a month ago, to seek a place, but as he was provided with a large sum of money, he resolved to indulge in debauchery until it. Should be spent. On Thursday evening he went to dine with some acquaintances, and remained drinking until 4 o'clock in the morning.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The Provisional Government of Montevideo, in carrying into effect a forced loan which it has imposed upon the inhabitants of that city, has reduced several foreigners, who have refused to pay the share assigned to them, to the alternative of paying it, or of leaving the country within half an hour.

The Secretary of State by the divorce of the duties of the Superintendent of Schools from his office, is relieved of an immense amount of business. Now that ho is a man of leisure, could lie not give a little attention to one department of his duties, as set down in the State Laws, to which late Secretaries have given very little heed?

The propeller New-England left here last night, being the first boat out; and the propellers Spaulding and Allegany left this morning. It is supposed they have got through without trouble, as there is no ice in sight except a strip at the mouth of the harbor. In the event of difficulty they would put into Gravelly Bay.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Your exemplary courtesy, in admitting to your columns objects of this nature, among the poor, induces me to send a few words on the Tract Meeting held last evening in the Presbyterian Church (Jay-Street) of this city.

Mr. WILSON, the Land Commissioner, has sent into Congress a statement that the whole surface of the Untied States embraces only 1, 391,480,320 acres, which is less by 220.704,599 than was reported in the annual statement from the Land Office.

From the New-Orleans Picayune, April 6. FIRST DAY.--Although the weather was delightful yesterday, and the track in good order, still the attendance at the race over the Metairie Course was meagre. The race was for a Jockey Club purse of $1,000, three-mile heats, and the entries were Little Flea and Blonde.

Cleared. Steamships Roanoke, Skinner, Norfolk, , Ludlam Pleasants; Empire City, McGowan, New-Orleans, M. O. Roberts. Ships Middlesex, Parmly, Liverpool, T. P. Stanton: Sameset, Chapman. Charleston, C. C. Duncan; Comet, Cardner, Liverpool. Buckley Co. Barks Marion, Telar, Terragona, S. M. Dow: Australia, (Br.,) Archer, Belize, master.

REVEREND GENTLEMEN: I acknowledge your kind consideration, in sending me the proceedings of the public meeting composed of twenty-five clergymen of the city of Chicago opposed to the Nebraska bill. These proceedings consist of a protest "in the name of Almighty God" against the passage of the Nebraska bill, and signed by yourselves "as citizens and as ministers of the Gospel of Jesus Christ;" t;"

The steamship Texas has arrived, bringing dates from Vera Cruz to the 8th, and the City of Mexico to the 4th instant. SANTA ANNA'S progress against ALVAREZ was received with great enthusiasm by the inhabitants. Several skirmishes had taken place with the troops of ALVAREZ, in which the latter were generally worsted. Prisoners were taken on both sides, and several of them were shot.

There is, very naturally, an increasing anxiety in reference to the non-arrival of the steamship City of Glasgow. Opinions concerning her safety appear almost daily in the newspapers of Philadelphia, which is her port. In the Bulletin of last evening we find that men experienced in nautical affairs are very far from giving her up.

TO THE PEOPLE OF CONNECTICUT : I respectfully announce to you that I have resigned my seat as your Representative in the Senate of the United Sates, to take effect from and after Monday, the 24th day of May next. I am impelled to take this step by the urgency of my private affairs, which have been too long neglected by reason of my engagements here.

I learn from good authority that England and France have agreed that they will issue no letters of marque to privateers during the pending war. Of all the Colleges in our State, there is not one so firmly fixed but it is willing to receive aid from the State Treasury,--none but has asked aid within three years. Their number is so great that they jostle each other. Like men in the Black Hole, or pigeons under a glass jar, the air that one breathes is so much less for the other, of its essential element.

Tile letter is long and declamatory: but it relates to an important topic and is of interest to a very large class of our readers. s. We

The Firemen and Coal-Passers. A Meeting of the Fireman and Coal-passers on steamship and steamboats plying to and from the port was held last night at KERREGEN'S Head-quarters, While-street. Considering that most of the persons engaged in this occupation must necessarily have been absent from the City, the meeting was a large one, there being nearly four hundred persons present.

New-Orleans paper of Thursday last are received. Captain HUGHES, of the ship Vicksburg, arrived at New-Orleans from New-York, reports seeing two ships ashore, on 28th ultimo, on Berry Island--apparently but recently gone on. Wreckers were around them.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Mrs. COWLEY'S Comedy of "A Bold Stroke for a Husband" is announced for to-morrow. The caste is very strong, including nearly all the principal artists of the establishment. New scenery has been prepared for the occasion, and the comedy will, without doubt, be presented to a New-York audience in a superior manner.

No Wonder rents are high. We have thousands to contest with us the "desirable houses in good neighborhoods, where none but small genteel families, without children, are admitted," who profess to live other-wheres, and do their voting, and are voted for, in other election districts.

Yesterday forenoon the Jefferson Police Courtroom was visited by a number of coal merchants and other business men, desirous of identifying another of the "confidence men," whose arrest we have noticed. It is proved that this fellow called at the house of Mr. JOSEPH W. GRIFFITH, No. 104 Jane-street, represented himself to be an extensive coal dealer,

THE CHARTER ELECTION.--The following in the full vote east at the Charter Elections, held on Tuesday in Jersey City, the results of which are entirely unexpected by the public, and show that some powerful influence has operated upon the great majority of the voters.

IN the House last evening a resolution was adopted to adjourn at 10 o'clock on Friday evening. the resolution requires the concurrence of the Senate before it becomes effective. The events of the past twelve hours make it possible for the Senate to concur, and to order an adjournment on the day proposed.

The letter from Col. FREMONT to Col. BENTON, which we publish this morning, corrects the rumors which reached this country a few days since. It was reported that he had lost seven of his party by cold and starvation, after having eaten seventeen of their mules; and that when found they were living on the remains of a dog.

On Wednesday morning, April 12, WILLIAM J. B. PELHAM, in the 22d year of his age. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, form the residence of his father, J. C. Pelham, No. 401 Atlantic-St., Brooklyn, on Friday, 14th inst., at 3 o'clock P. M., without further invitation.

A great crowd has arrived in this city to attend the Southern Convention, which commences its session to-morrow. Among those present are Messrs. DAWSON, of Georgia, LESLIE COMBS, of Kentucky, TROUSDALE, and JONES, of Tennessee. It is presumed that either of the last two named will be chosen President of the Convention. CHARLESTON, Monday Morning, April 10.

From the Savannah Republican. We had a long and very interesting interview yesterday, with captain JOHN OLIVER, of the bark Spermaceti, which arrived at this port some days since from Liverpool, consigned to Messrs. ANDREW Co. The Captain is a veteran English Tar, who has followed the sea since he was ten years of age.

The Chair presented a letter from the Hon. TRUMAN SMITH, of Connecticut, resigning his seat in the Senate, to take effect on the 24th of May next. Mr. FOOT submitted a resolution directing an inquiry, by the Committee on Commerce, into the expediency of making an appropriation for the purchase of a site, and the erection of a Custom House at Burlington, Vt. resolution was adopted.

TRUMAN SMITH resigns his seat in the United States Senate, his resignation to take effect from the 24th of May. His letter, which we publish elsewhere, is frank and manly in its tone, and expresses the feelings of an honest and a noble heart. elings of an henest and a noble heart.

The resignation of Hon. TRUMAN SMITH, of Connecticut, was received in the Senate yesterday, to take effect on the [Degrees]4th of May next. There was but little business done out of Executive Session. A bill introduced by Mr. RUSK, providing for the transportation of the United States mails, was considered a short time and referred.

An indignation meeting was held at the Museum to-night, composed of French and German Roman Catholics, to express condemnation of the course of Judge WOODWARD, of the Supreme Court, in a recent decision of the suit of the Roman Catholic Bishop of Philadelphia, against the Trustees of the Holy Trinity Church, to obtain possession of property.

The steamship Isabel has arrived at this port from Havana and Key West. She brings no political news of importance. In Havana vessels were abundant, and freights and declined 20 per cent. change on London was quoted at 8@9 premium.

The anniversary of HENRY CLAY's birthday was celebrated by the "Clay Festival Association" last evening, on a scale every way befitting the memory of the honored patriot and statesman. The United States steamship Princeton, Captain HENRY EAGLE Commander, arrived at this port yesterday morning, in six days from Havana. The United States frigate Columbia, bearing the broad ponnant of Commodore NEWTON, and sloop of war Albany, Capt. JAMES T. GERRY; also, United States steamer Fulton, Lieutenant. Commanding JAS. M. WATSON, Were at Havana when the Princeton left.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As your journal is becoming with each successive issue more popular with intelligent readers, and has always been the advocate of the moral and religious interests of the community, we desire to use a short space in your columns in calling attention to the "Young Men's Christian Association" of this city.

A few days after reaching San Antonio, we had occasion to return to Neu-Braunfels, and to obtain certain information were advised to call on the Superintendent of the Orphan Asylum, at New-Weit, a hamlet four miles from the town.

THE NEWARK FIRE DEPARTMENT AND THE COMMON COUNCIL.--The Newark Advertiser, of last evening, states that the Committee appointed by the Common Council to report a plan for organizing a paid Fire Department, are engaged in performing that duty, and some of their members have visited places where paid Departments exist.

In this City on Thursday, April 13, FRANCES LOUISA, daughter of James Y. and Catharine Watkins, aged 8 years, 3 months and 21 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral this afternoon, at 2 1/2 o'clock, from the residence of her parents, No. 20 Henry st. Her remains will be taken to Greenwood.

Mr. STUART reported back the House bill, establishing a new land district in the Lower Peninsula of Michigan, which was taken up and passed. Mr. CASS offered a resolution, directing inquiry, by the Committee on Public Lands, as to the expediency of granting land to aid in the construction of a railroad from Iron Bay, in Michigan, to Little Bay de Loquette. The resolution was adopted.

We give in another column a preliminary letter from a Special Correspondent of the TIMES, concerning the Southern Convention now in session at Charleston. The Telegraph has advised as very briefly of the general proceedings of the Convention thus far.

From the Times and Transcript, San Francisco. It will be seen from the document which we publish this morning, that C. A. DENMAN, United States Consul at Acapulco, has promptly responded to the call made upon him by Mr. A. JOUAN, who has been imprisoned at Tixtla, in the State of Guerrero, Mexico, at the suit of Mr. JOSE Y. LIMANTOUR.

U. S. DISTRICT COURT.--Nos. 23, 29, 31, 39, 47, 48, 50 to 53, 69. This being Good Friday, the Judges of the Supreme Court, the Superior Court, the Court of Common Pleas, and the Marine Court, will not be in attendance as on other days.

We have no particular attachment to landlords, though we certainly are much obliged to them for letting us live in their houses while we are too poor to have houses of our own to live in. We always mean to speak respectfully of them, for as the thoughtful boy said of the "play-actor man," we often think that we know not the hour nor the day when we may come to be landlords ourselves.

Our Correspondent at Washington states that England and France have signified their determination not to issue any letters-of-marque during the pending war with Russia. Whether Russia will be equally considerate we are not informed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I see by this morning's TIMES that my name is mentioned in connection with that of WESTERFIELD, the "Confidence Man," as having been fleeced, Allow me to correct the error. Day before yesterday this person called at our Coal-office, No. 104 Jane-street, and requested to see the senior partner of the concern, as he wished to borrow 78 cents to make change.

There have been about one thousand cases of cholera in Paris since its last return, of which one-half have died. GENDRIN commends bleeding, even in the state of collapse. The Tremont Medical School, (Boston,) founded in 1838, and of which the Instructers are, with one exception, Professors in the Medical Department of Harvard College, has 52 students.

"Do the Holy Scriptures Teach the Final Salvation of all Men?" SIXTH NIGHT. This discussion was continued on Wednesday evening at the Tabernacle, before a large audience. Rev. Dr. SAWYER, in opening in the affirmative, said he was afraid his learned friend was not quite or orthodox on the important doctrine of depravity.

American physicians have been duly excited by the announcement circulated in the papers, that a bequest of a hundred thousand francs has been made to the French Institute, as a premium for the discovery of means of curing the Asiatic Cholera, or of the cause of the pestilence; and until the cure be found, the interest of the money to be given each year to him who does most in combating the disease.

It appears that the treaty made by our Minister, Gen. GADSDEN, with the Government of Mexico, is not likely to receive the sanction of the Senate, at least without some important amendments,--but is destined to follow in the footsteps of its predecessors.

General JOSE VILLAMIL, Charge from Ecuador to-day took leave of the Secretary of State, preparatory to returning home. The President recognizes E. C. GOMEZ, Consul of the Republic of Nicaragua at New-Orleans, and Don ANTONIO MARIA SEGOVIA, Consul of Spain at New-Orleans.

Last evening a meeting, consisting of a number of Irishmen, was held at Captain KERRIGAN'S, No. 22 White-street, for the purpose of forming an Association having for its object ostensibly the benefit of Ireland and the Irish. Mr. P. G. COGHLAN was nominated Chairman, pro tem., and Dr. P. O'HANLON acted as Secretary.

When, about two months ago, we pointed out a secret and dangerous object which lay concealed under the ostensible mission of certain Muscovite officers recently arrived in the United States, some of our cotemporaries almost treated us as visionaries, while others accused us of calumniating the American people in admitting the possibility of armaments being fitted out in the ports of this country for the use of Russia.

MISSIONARY MEETING.--A missionary meeting, held Wednesday evening in the South Second-st. Methodist Episcopal Church, for the purpose of raising funds for the support of the missionaries among the Indians at the West.

MY DEAR SIR: I thank you for your kind favor, but find it out of my power to comply with your request and that of other friends. In a few days I hope to be on my way to see my family. Recently I learn that Mrs. HOUSTON'S health is quite feeble. Every hour of my time, until I can depart, will necessarily be employed in business, to enable me to get off.

A DESPERATE FIGHT.--A desperate affray occurred Wednesday night, in the Fourth Ward of Jersey City, which was caused by an animosity of feeling between Natives and Irishmen, and resulted in the representatives of the latter party being roughly treated. It appears that there were several persons in a party traveling about the Fourth Ward on an election spree.

The Senate were engaged in Executive Session during the greater portion of yesterday. From the early proceedings in the House it would appear that there is a coolness existing between the Postmaster General and the Post-Office Committee. e.- He

New-Brunswick papers speak of destructive freshets in that province, in consequence of heavy rains. Several bridges had been carried away, together with mills, fences, , and one man had thirteen head of cattle, one horse and thirty sheep drowned in his barn by the flood

From the Washington Union. We are indebted to S. C. HUMES, Esq., now is this city, for an extract of a letter received here last night by Mr. HUMES from Capt. J. H. STRAIN, sutler at Fort Arbuckle, which is as follows: FORT ARBUCKLE, C. N., March 18, 1854.

MURDER IN TROY.--A most cruel coldblooded murder was committed at West Troy this morning, between 2 and 3 o'clock. The facts are these: JOHN H. PHELPS, who resides in the Second Ward, near the Methodist Church, entered his house at about 2 o'clock, and entering the sleeping apartments of his wife, deliberately stabbed her twice with a huge butcher-knife, from the effects of which she died almost instantly.

There was a very fair attendance yesterday, at this course, to witness two good races. The weather was delightful, and the track was in excellent condition for fast time. The first stake was a sweepstake for two year olds, mile heats, to carry three year old weights. were

We mentioned in yesterday's TIMES the important fact that Messrs. HORATIO N. WILD, Councilman of the Seventeeenth Council District, had determined to average their mutual grievances by a resort to the "code of honor." The results of the trouble are still foggy.
The bill to reduce and graduate the price of the public lands was taken up again in tthe House yesterday, and passed.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--The most successful--probably the most deserving revival of the season, was made here last night. Mrs. COWLEY'S Comedy, "The Bold Stroke for a Husbank," is , perhaps, as good a working piece as any of the period, and open to less objection on the score of morality than the majority of them.

The belligerent Councilmen, WILD and SEELY, both appeared in their seats in the Council Board inst evening, unhurt; improved in pocket by their attempt at notoriety, and subject to manifold sharp hits from all their friends and enemies, who thought, alike, that they had made themselves ridiculous.

Of all men who work hard and get nearest to no pay at all, who get very few coppers and abundant curses for their labor, Country Postmasters deserve to be first named. The fees allowed by law would not pay a woman for her trouble of making up the quarterly transcripts.

An adjourned meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held on Thursday. R. C. BRAINARD, Esq., the President, tendered his resignation, stating as a reason, that since his election a number of new members had taken their seats in the Board who had no voice.

Although the event has long been foreseen, and takes no one, therefore, by surprise, the formal Declaration of War by the Western Powers against Russia is, nevertheless, the most important news brought by the Hermann.

The bill to reduce and graduate the price of the public lands was ordered to be engrossed for a third reading, by a vote of 72 to 68. Mr. Cox moved to lay the bill on the table. Negatived--69 against 80.

The R. M. steamship America, Capt. LANG, from Liverpool, on Saturday, April 1, arrived here at 3 o'clock this morning. The Collins steamship Arctic, from New-York on the 18th March, arrived out at 1 A. M. on Thursday, the 0th ult.

SCHOOL TEACHERS.--New teachers for the public schools have been appointed as follows: Miss WHITLEY, First Assistant of the Primary Department of Public School No. 1; Miss DUNCAN, Monitress in the same department; and Miss HODGES, Monitress of the Primary Department of Public School No. 2.

"Do the Holy Scriptures Teach the Final Salvation of all Men?" The discussion of this question between Rev. Messre. SAWYER and WESCOTT, brought to a conclusion last evening, had at least one merit--that of being condueted in a spirit of gentlemanly forbearance creditable to both parties--an instance which would have satisfied POPE that parties may widely differ on "points of faith," and yet not "like graccless zealots fight."

The Aldermen took up the REYNOLD's Offal Contract business last evening. The report of the Committee on Public Health of the Board of councilmen was taken up and discussed by Aldermen MOTT, HERRICK, LORD, HOARDMAN and President ELY. No Cerision was arrived at. The report (which has passed the other Board_ was referred.

In this City, off Thursday, April 13, ISABELLA JENKINS, aged 16 year and 17 days. The relatives and friends of the family are requested in attend her funeral, at No. 114 ?? st., this day, 15 2 1/2 o'clock. P. M.
THE EXECUTION OF CRIMINALS.--A bill, regulating the execution of criminals, passed the State Senate, on Friday, by an almast unanimous vote.

Cases of violent assault are becoming alarmingly frequent in the City. Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the hour when Broadway is most densely througed, a terrible affray occurred near the corner of that street and Canal, between a cab-driver named JAMES LYMAN and a young man residing in the Eighth Ward named GEORGE HILL.

New-Orleans papers of Tuesday last are received. They contain news from El Paso to the 30th altimo. A fight had occurred between a party from El Paso and a party of men under DONA ANA. The El Paso party was composed of 17 Americans, an Englishman, and a number of Mexicans. They were well armed and had 2 six-pounders. The fight lasted 26 minutes, when

The following official order for the surrender of DANIEL W. VAN AERNUM, under the Extradition Treaty with great Britain, has been received by the U.S. Marshal of this District. Mr. THOMAS MCGRATH is authorized to receive VAN AERNUM into custody, and the prisoner will be immediately removed to Canada to answer the charge of forgery: :

COLLISION ON THE HUDSON RIVER RAILROAD--A HAND-CAR AND SEVERAL PERSONS THROWN INTO THE RIVER.--The 3 o'clock Express train from Albany and a hand-car containing several persons, came into collision on the Hudson River Railroad, last evening, when a few miles from Poughkeepsie. The hand-car and all it contained were thrown into the river, but fortunately the persons in it received no serious injury.

The U. S. Mail steamer Arctic, from Liverpool about 1 P. M. on Wednesday, the 5th inst., arrived at this port early on Sunday morning. The Asia arrived out at 3 o'clock on the morning of Monday, the 3d instant. On Tuesday, the 4th, the Niagara sailed for Liverpool, with the 88th Regiment of infantry for the East.

The Anti-Nebraska meeting here last evening was large and enthusiastic. D. LODER was appointed Chairman, R. C. BELLEVILLE, Secretary, and ten Vice-Presidents. Resolutions were adopted, strong and emphatic in their tone, against the Nebraska bill, denouncing Senator DOUGLAS, and applauding CHARLES SKELTON, the representative from this district.

The New-York State Agricultural Society has appointed this City as the place for its next Annual Exhibition. The Fair will open early in September next. By a resolution of the Common Council, the Society is to be offered the free use of Hamilton-square for the purposes of its Exhibition, and for as long a period as may be desired.

On Sunday, April 16, of consumption, JENNET ELMENDORF, aged 46 years. Her friends and relatives are particularly invited to attend the funeral, on Tuesday, the 18th at 2 o'clock, from her late residence, No. 330 Hicks-st., near Degraw, South Brooklyn.

The Canal Board at Albany have announced that the Erie Canal will be opened for business on the first day of May. The prospects of a large trade with the West have seldom promised, on the opening of navigation, larger results to the revenues of the Canal.

Since yesterday afternoon both Houses have been almost constantly engaged in the third reading of bills. Among those passed, there were few of general interest to your city, in fact, the only one was the act for the consolidation of Brooklyn, Williamsburg and Bushwick.

PRESENTATION IN PUBLIC SCHOOL No. 1.--The male pupils of Public School No. 1 have presented to Mr. W. S. MACLAURIN, their writing-master, an elegantly prepared testimonial of their gratitude and respect for his unwearied attention in their behalf. It may not be generally known that during the last few months an important reform has been effected in the method of teaching the art of writing in our City Schools.

Both branches of the Nova Scotia Legislature, previous to its recent adjournment, adopted addresses to the Queen, expressive of their regret that the peace of Europe is likely to be disturbed by the unwarrantable aggression of Russia, and of their unwavering attachment to the British Crown.

A careful perusal of the great debate in Parliament on the Eastern War, of which a report is given in another part of this morning's TIMES; will make it evident that the transcendent importance of the struggle by which Europe is about to be convulsed, is thoroughly felt by the statement of England.

Some of our fellow-citizens have come forward, in this crisis, with a public spirit beyond mere eulogium. The freedom of the Press begins to be troublesome in England; and in that country as well as in France, though of course in a different fashion, measures are attempted for its restriction. This is scarcely to be wondered at;--for perfect freedom to canvass all public matters cannot fail to prove embarrassing in all countries where the people do not in fact constitute the Government. An aristocratic ministry, as well as

FATAL ACCIDENT ON THE ERIE RAILROAD. The Express Train which left New-York at 7 o'clock on Friday morning, met with a severe accident near Cochoeten. The engine ran off the track, on the sleep bank of the Delaware River, and was arrested with its fore wheels impending over the high embankment. The train partially doubled up; the tender was utterly demolished, and the baggage car badly broken.

We surrender a very large portion of our space this morning to the Arctic's advices, especially to the profoundly interesting debate in Parliament on the Declaration of War, and the revelations of the secret correspondence with Russia.

The America is below, but it is so dark that we do not expect her up before morning. The mails will not leave for New-York until Sunday afternoon, by the regular train. The reported failure of the Cochituate Bank, to-day, led to a great run upon it. Specie and current bills were paid out up to 1 o'clock, when the officers declined making further payments.

Some time ago the Senate ordered to be printed the mechanical portion of the Patent Office report. This fell to BEVERLY TUCKER, the Senate printer. Subsequently the agricultural portion of that report was sent to the House, who ordered one hundred thousand copies to be printed by the printer to the House, Mr. NICHOLSON.

The whole course of current politics in Europe shows how little the Progress of the age has made itself felt upon the governing classes. In every other department of action and of thought, advancement marks the age. d Science are spreading, ren-

THE STORM--ACCIDENTS.--In one instance, yesterday morning, an awning in front of LOSSEE'S Hotel, on Hamilton-avenue, fell, from the great weight of snow, while several persons were passing under it three of whom were seriously injured and a fourth slightly. A man named MICHAEL MCMULLEN, of Columbia-street, was one of the sufferers.

A severe snow storm, with a strong northeast gale, commenced here about 2 o'clock this morning, and still continues. Large lakes of snow fill the air, but partially melt on the ground. The gale off the coast since Saturday morning has been very severe, and it is feared serious marine disasters have occurred.

SICKNESS AMONG MORMONS.--Several hundred English, Welsh, and Danish Mormons have arrived in the city within the past two weeks. Not having wagons and outfits for continuing their journey to Utah Territory, they were compelled to stop here until such means were procured for them. Their agents, and in some instances the city authorities, obtained buildings for the occupancy of these emigrants while they remained in the city. asionally sickness has broken

The small note case against HAZEN, DAVIS, MORRIS and Lawson--a conspiracy case, for endeavoring to extort $110,000 from the Pennsylvania Railroad Company--was concluded to-day. WM. A. STOKES for the prosecution made an eloquent speech to the Jury. Judge McCLURE charged the Jury strongly for the prosecution, and after an absence of three hours the Jury returned a verdict of guilty. STOKES moved for sen-

Since my last letter, written upon the 28th ult., we have been greatly shocked by intelligence of the sad fate of one with whom we had formed a very pleasant acquaintance--Lieut. MATTHEWS, of the Plymouth. He was a very intelligent, serious young man.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Several years ago the residents of this City became entitled by the munificence of Mr. ASTOR to a large bequest, to be devoted to the foundation maintenance of a Public Library.

FOURTH DAY.-- The people were called together yesterday, to witness the race for the Club purse of two thousand dollars, at four mile heats, for which were entered Rube, of Alabama, Lexington, of Kentucky, and Lecompte, of Louisiana. Lexington, from his previous performances, was slightly the favorite, while others were willing to put up their money that Rube would win, at 2 to 3.

By the arrival of the mail from El Paso, the San Antonio Ledger has accounts from that place to the 9th of March. The Ledger says: We learn from a private letter, received by a gentleman in this city, dated El Paso, March 9, that business is very dull there, and but little prospect of speedy change.

The Common Council has authorized a loan of $8,500, for the purpose of completing the two Schoolhouses in course of construction in the First and Third Wards. A resolution has accordingly been adopted by the Board of Education, authorizing the President and Clerk of the Board to contract for the completion of the houses.

The grand Southern Pacific Railroad project was adopted after a warm debate between all the leading men in the Convention. The clause authorizing the Corporation to negotiate with Mexico was strongly opposed, and the resolutions in favor of the GADSDEN treaty and alternate sections of public land for Railroad purposes also caused bitter opposition. The Virginia delegates were withdrawn.

In this City, on Fourth Day, April 12, after a short illness, ADRIAN CORNELL, only son of Richard and Mary Annette Cornell aged nearly 12 years. In Chicago, Ill., on Sunday, April 9, of consumption, Mrs. MAHY LOUISA, wife of James D. Bonnor, and daughter of the late Robert Bogle, Esq., of Philadelphia.

The resolutions presented by General WALBRIDGE in the House, to-day, will be popular with the masses. He intends making a speech in due time. Mr. WALBRIDGE will doubtless be patriotic. The GADSDEN Treaty was defeated to-day, but it may be resuscitated. The vote for ratification was 27 against 18. The SLOO amendment was

The Committee on Markets of the Board of Councilmen, consisting of Messrs. CLIFTON, COOPER YOUNG, READ and WAINWRIGHT, met in the Council, Chamber at 2 o'clock P. M. yesterday, to hear argument, in favor of and opposed to the removal of Catharine Market. Councilman WAINWRIGHT aid he believed all the gentlemen present were opposed to the removal of the Market.

Those reports are to the close of the fourth day's session: and up to that time the action of the Convention had extended to only one or two points of general interest. Lieut.
The following is the weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 8th day of April to the 15th day of April, 1854: Men, 96; women, 68; boys, 108; girls, 128. Total, 460.
