Our State Legislature adjourned yesterday. The Session has been unusually laborious, though the acts passed have been mainly a local or private interest. Provision has been made for carrying into effect the recent amendment of the Constitution, authorizing the speedy completion of the State Canals.

We learn from Washington that the Treaty with Mexico recently negotiated by Mr. GADSDEN was rejected in the Senate Yesterday, by a very decisive vote, eighteen to twenty-seven. Another attempt will doubtless now be made to put our arrangements with the Mexican Government on a better footing than they are at present.
Mr. WADE presented petitions from Ohio the Nebraska bill. Mr. SEWARD presented remonstrances from County, Ind., and Spark, Mich., against the Nebraska bill. . SHMNER presented a like remonstrand

CONSOLIDATION.--The Star and Eagle, the former representing the Whig party and the latter the Democratic party in this city, both propose that a public demonstration be made to celebrate the passage of the act consolidating the cities of Brooklyn and Williamsburg and town of Bushwick, under one municipal form of government, passed on Friday last.

We have Austin papers of the 28th, and San Antonio of the 30th ult. Galveston to the 6th inst., and some other Texas papers. The Austin State Gazette, noticing the call by the Directors of the New-York Pacific Railroad Company, upon the stock holders, for the payment of a second installment upon the stock taken, remarks:

We cannot cease to feel surprise at the immense tide of travel flowing through our City. Every day some new fact is brought to our notice which exhibits the actual state of things, and we have no other means of relief than to chronicle it, and allow the wonder to be shared by the world at large-our readers.

In another part of this morning's TIMES, we publish some further documents, recently laid before Parliament, illustrating the history of the Eastern War. Those given to-day are especially important as throwing new light on the position of the German Powers, and the course which Austria will eventually take in the contest.

The Washington Correspondents of the Press have fallen into the habit of quoting Col. BENTON'S remarks on all current topics of general interest. Occasionally, some of them are sharp enough to bear repeating; but, as a general thing, types injure them.

The rights of neutrals, as defined by Mr. H. A. ADDINGTON, of the Foreign-Office, to the deputation of merchants connected with the trade with Russia, is anything buy satisfactory to some of the merchants of New-York and their representatives in this City. In regard to Russian property, Mr. ADDINGTON, in behalf of the Earl of CLARENDON, says:

THE STREETS--THE WEATHER.--GENIN is indefatigable. At nightfull yesterday, notwithstanding the severity of the storm during the three previous days, and the great accumulations of snow and rubbish in Broadway, it was quite possible to examine the granite formations with ease and comfort.

We publish elsewhere intelligence of interest concerning the progress of the revolution in Mexico. The Picayune states that just previous to the sailing of the Texas on the 8th from Vera Cruz, a telegraphic dispatch reached that city, announcing that an arrangement of existing difficulties had been made between SANTA ANNA and ALVAREZ, and that the revolution was thus at an end.

The Senate to-day reconsidered the vote rejecting the Gadsden treaty. Another effort is making for its ratification. Messrs. JONES, DAWSON and TOOMBS arrived in town to-day, making three affirmative votes. As the vote was under stood to stand yesterday, a change of two or three Negatives will ratify it. The friends of the treaty have strong hopes of accomplishing this.

In this City, on Tuesday, April 18, in St. George's Church by Rev. Dr. Tyng, BENJAMIN A. ONDERDONK and CAROLINE AUCUSTA, daughter of N W. Stuyvesant, Esq. In this City, on Tuesday, April 13. at St. George's Chapel, by Rev. Dr. Evans, JAMES REANEY, of Baltimore, to Miss ISABELLA McWHORTER, daughter of Alexander McWhorter, of this City.

The quarterly meeting of the Exempt Firemen of the City was held last evening at Firemen's Hall. P. W. ENOS, Esq., presided. There was a large attendance of members, and a very considerably amount of business was transacted. During the session, a French gentleman, named SAINT LANDEN, desired permission to say a few words relative to the recent decease of an old and brave member of the Fire Department, named H. PELETIER.

I learn from a gentleman just arrived from England, that Mr. BUCHANAN ant the gentlemen of his legation have been twice to the drawing-rooms of the Queen in black coats, but that the innovation was not at all relished, and that the Ambassador himself could not but be aware that his dress was thought out of character and in bad taste.

Lieut. MAURY has succeeded in directing the attention of the Southern States, as represented in the Charleston Convention, to the navigation of the Amazon, as a matter of special interest to that section of the country. The Business Committee has reported it as among the subjects to which the efforts of the Southern States ought to be directed.

ACCIDENT ON THE CENTRAL RAILROAD.-The Express train which left Buffalo at 11 o'clock on Saturday night, met with a sad disaster at Bergen, seventeen miles west of Rochester. From the best information we could obtain, it appears that the accident was caused by a cow lying near the rails on the track, which the loconiotive passed unmolested, as did also the baggage and and express cars. the agnearances. the first Das-

Late in the week Mr. ATTOMMAS, the celebrated harpist, gives an entertainment. The beautiful instrument on which he performs is not sufficiently known in this country. A few players like Mr. APTOMMAS, or a few more Concerts by that gentleman, would make it the rage--particularly with ladies have timely-rounded arms.

The preliminary measures have been taken by the Common Council for the purchase of the Brick Church property. A report from the Finance Committee of the Board of Councilmen, just printed, exhibits the whole subject in a clearer light than it has yet been favored with. The Committee recommend that arrangements be immediately consummated, whereby the premises may be transferred by the Trustees to the City.

A correspondent, dating from Nassau, N. P., April 2, says of that port: " It is supported almost entirely by the wrecking business. There are between 500 and 600 persons who have licenses to follow the business, belonging to the province, most of them sailing small schooners. The ringing of the bell that announces "a wreck ashore," diffuses over the place an atmosphere of hilarity and glee.

COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER--Monday. Before Judge Roosevelt. The Court met on Monday morning at 10 1/2 o'clock. The District Attorney stated that he should not be able to take up the case of William and Clara Hays, in consequence of the illness of Mrs. Lutener, wife of the deceased, and Mr. Shallow, who was just recovering from the typhoid fever.

Hon. ROBERT H. PRUYN, Speaker of the Assembly: I return to the Assembly, with my objections to its becoming a law, "An act to appoint Commissioners to investigate and examine into the pecuniary affairs and condition of the several State Prisons, and to report thereon, and also such laws as they may deem proper for the better regulation and discipline of said prisons, to the Legislature of this State."

The city is at this moment in the greatest excitement in consequence of the assassination of the Grand Euke, CHARLES III. He was stabbed in the bowels yesterday afternoon. about 6 o'clock by some unknown hand, while walking unattended through the spacious court-yard of the palace. A piercing cry attracted the guards at the doors. who instantly removed him to his chamber. but I cannot learn that the assassin was seen.

If a stranger should be suddenly set down anywhere in the quarter between Thirty-seventh-street and Fifty-fifth-street, on the side near the Hudson, he would hardly suspect he was in an American city. One's first thought is that he is in a collection of wigwams. On every hand little board or mud huts stretch away, with narrow lanes winding about among them.

In this City, on Tuesday, April 18, of consumption, in the 35th year of his age. THOMAS JEFFERSON, a native of Wigton, Cumberland. Eng. His friends are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, without further invitation, from his late residence, No. al Pike-st., this (Wednesday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock. In this City, on Monday, April 17, ELIZABETH, wife of Luis Sanchez, of Puerto Rico.

Mr. EVERETT presented the memorial of the American Statistical Association, praying that copies of all documents printed by Congress may be furnished them. Mr. SUMNER presented recomonstrances from Windsor, Vt., against the payment of the Amistad claim.

There was but little progress made by either House yesterday. Several petitions were presented, in the Senate, against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise; one against the payment of the Amistad claim, and one from Jewish citizens, asking that an effort be made to secure to American citizens religious toleration in foreign countries.

As everything which tends to throw light on the position likely to be assumed by the German Powers in the pending war, has decided interest, we translate the following from the Paris Republican correspondence of the Courrier des Etats Unis: PARIS, Thursday, March 30, 1854. The news which reaches us from vienna and Berlin is the forerunner of a notable change in the policy of the two great German Courts.

FEARFUL RAILROAD COLLISION--About 1 1/2 o'clock, a freight of twenty cars, with locomotive No. 21 attached, passed spencervillo, two miles from Broadway, at a furious rate, the engineer, owing to the snow, being unable to check the speed down the grade. It came in collision with locomotive No. 10, standing on the track. It damaged it badly, and started it off at a rapid rate.

A GOOD JOKE.--Two females escaped from the jail at Rome, a few nights since. In the morning a constable was dispatched after them. On the way he overlook two "young ladies." who asked him for a ride, and he gallently took them in his sleigh and carried them to Utica. It turned out that they were the "girls" he was after. But he don't know it.--Albany Eve. Jour.

Before Chief Justice Oakley. Ownes against Wooding.--In this case, an action of ejectment for dower, reported at length in the TIMES of Saturday, April 15, a verdict was rendered for the plaintiff. The case was tried once before, but the Jury could not agree.

REPORTED WRECKS AT BARNEGAT.--Rumors were current yesterday that one or more ships bound hither, were ashore and in imminent peril off Baruegat and Sguan Beach. NUMBER TWO. The House looks a little more lively today than it did on our last visit, and we are just in time to witness the close of that dreariest of periods in the Legislative day, known as "the morning hour," which is devoted to the calling of Committees for reports.

In this City, April 15, THOMAS CRICHARD, aged 46 years. His remains were interred in the Cemetery of Evergreens. In this City, April 19, MARTHA, infant child of Samuel and Helen Cooper, aged 3 months and 23 days. Friends and relatives are invited to attend the funeral on Thursday, at 12 M., from No. 127 East 35th-st., near 3d-av. In this city, April 19, Mrs. ISABELLA KEMP, in the 68th year of her age.
If the Board, of Councilmen had been organized as a Debating Club, there would be an excuse for the manner in which certain members waste the hours that should be devoted to the public interests.

SECOND DAY.--Another of those quick and closely contested races which have of late taken the sporting world by surprise, was run yesterday over the Metairie Course. The rain which was falling in town prevented the attendance from being good, but at the course it only sprinkled enough to lay the dust.

Congress takes matters easily. It gets over its business by easy stages, and doubtless has a good time of it. Yesterday, the Senate passed the bill, by a vote of 23 to 13, appropriating $100,000 to the discoverer of the popular anaesthetic agents. in-

Messrs. GALES SEATON: My attention has been attracted to the proceedings of the Senate, published in the Intelligencer of this morning, on the presentation of a memorial by General SHIELDS, signed by myself and thirteen thousand citizens of the United States, on the Subject of "spiritual manifestations."

We have Galveston papers of the 8th, and papers from the interior as late as due. The reports on the growing crops of Corn, Cotton and Sugar are unfavorable. The crops in Gonzales County, says the Inquirer, are in a most flourishing condition. Corn is knee high and growing rapidly, and the planters have commenced scraping Cotton.

PRESBYTERY OF BROOKLYN.--This body met last evening in the First Presbyterian Church, Henry-street. There was a very slim attendance. Rev. D. P. NOYES, A. M., Moderator, delivered the sormon. He took for his text, Isaiah xl., 1, 2: "Comfort ye, comfort ye my people, saith your God. Speak ye comfortably to Jerusalem, and cry unto her, that her warfare is accomplished, that her iniquity is pardoned:

Mr. WADE presented remonstrances against the Nebraska bill. Mr. SEWARD, from the Committee on Commerce, reported a bill to prevent unnecessary delay in discharging cargoes of vessels arriving from foreign ports. It was taken up and passed. Mr. COOPER presented twelve remonstrances against the Nebraska bill.

The London Times defends itself against the charge of publishing too much news. The attention of Parliament has been directed to that subject, Lord DERBY intimating that something ought to be done about it, and Mr. LAYARD making a very claborate argument to prove that the British Ministry must have furnished that journal with important information.

The Dry Goods trade of the past week has been very limited, owing to the disagreeable weather, which has prevented dealers from coming into the market. Yet, the stock of goods have not increased much; nor have prices of desirable articles varied essentially. Brown Sheetings and Shirtings are less active, but firm, as the supply is quite managable. Bleached goods, too, manifest less animation at old figures.

We have referred from time to time, to the strange course pursued by the American Consul at Shanghai, sustained by the United States Commissioner, in regard to the collection of duties levied upon American vessels by the Chinese authorities, after the fall of Shanghai. That event put an end to the imperial authority in that city.

From the Journal du Havre. There has lately been a great deal, nay, far too much talk, respecting the anticipated and alarming appearance of those letters of marque which, under assumed Russian colors, are to make good and lawful prizes of the French and English ships which they would unexpectedly capture on the seas that are now traversed by us with feelings of complete security.

Before Hoh. Recorder Tillon, CHARGE OF HAVING COUNTERFEIT BILLS, WITH INTENT TO PASS. John Masters Whiting was indicted for having in his possession, with intent to pass, counterfelt bills on the Bank of Cranston, R. I.

The Regatta in honor of the Commercial Convention, took place on Saturday afternoon, in presence of a large concourse of persons. The scene on East Battery was most animated, although the wind, blowing almost a gale, prevented the sport being so excellent as it would otherwise have been.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: The public attention having been called of late to this place of confinement, some have desired to know what kind of reception we met with from the inmates, at our weekly meetings, and what interest they feel in the establishment of a Library.

Hon. NEHEMIAH R. KNIGHT, formerly an esteemed Senator in Congress from the State of Rhode Island, died on Tuesday, April 18, at Providence. Mr. KNIGHT first entered the Senate in 1821, to till a vacancy, and was subsequently reelected for three successive terms--making the entire term of his service in that body twenty years.

The Board of Education met last evening. E. C. DENEDICT, Esq., presiding. A communication was received from the School Officers of the Thirteenth Ward, asking for transfer of Ward School No. 4 during erection of the school edifice on Rivington-street. The transfer was ordered.

The telegraph brings us intelligence of the death of Hon. JOHN DAVIS, of Massachusetts. He died at Worcester yesterday, after a very brief illness.

There is a thing for citizens to be ashamed of, and in which our Almshouse Governors are particularly guilty. It is, that when "distinguished strangers" visit our Institutions, they--the Ten Governors-should set out brandy and water for them at Bellevue, and champagne so profusely at Blackwell's Island, that it is not uncommon for one in ten of all the "distinguished strangers" making such visit to come back to the City "disguised."

There will be a treaty with Mexico, rely upon it. Senator JAMES has moved the re consideration of the GADSDEN Treaty. Colonel FORNEY is not yet impeached, but his congressional enemies declare that he will be. His enemies are the President's enemies.

The Emperor's innovation as regards a loan has succeeded brilliantly. 250,000,000 were called for, and 467,000,000 have been offered, and the books are now closed. 98,000 names have been inscribed upon the Grand Livre, and a very large portion of these names are new,-those of persons who were never before in the funds. COMMON COUNCIL.--At a regular meeting of the Common Council Tuesday evening, the principal proceedings were: The Finance Committee reported that the sum of $10,000 for the use of the city had been borrowed of the Hudson County Bank, at 6 per cent, interest. A requisition from the Board of Education for $2,683 59--of which sum $1,718 is to pay teachers' salaries--was directed to be paid.

From the Boston Traveller, 18th. The brig H. Kelloch, of St. George, Me., Capt. GARDNER MOSSMAN, sailed from the port of New-York, Nov. 15, for Norfolk, with a cargo of 78 hogsheads of sugar, and arrived at Norfolk Nov. 22, discharged her cargo, and took on board a cargo of staves, and Dec. 27 set sail for Barbodoes and arrived at that port Dec. 18.

ANOTHER NEST OF COUNTERFEITERS DISCOVERED.--In consequence of the arrest of BREWER and his accomplices, Deputy Marshals DE ANGELES and HORTON have been on the lookout for others of the same gang; and yesterday, at a house visited by the parties arrested last week, the officers discovered a valise which contained several counterfeit plates for printing bank notes, which they took possession of.
A Select Committee of the House of Commons, of which JOHN O'CONNELL is Chairman, is engaged in making inquiries into the existing laws regulating emigrants and emigrant vessels.

ARREST FOR ATTEMPTED THEFT ON BOARD OF THE EUROPA.--Just as the Europa was about to leave her wharf yesterday, a man was caught in the stateroom of a Hungarian, who was one of the passengers, in the act of opening his trunk.

THE VAN BRUNT-STREET AFFRAY.--The examination of PATRICK McAULIFF, private watchman, arrested on a charge of having killed BERNARD MANAHAN, during an affray in Van Brunt-street, on the night of the 30th of March last, was yesterday brought to a close, before Justice BLACHLEY.

FOREIGN ATTACHMENTS--WHEN A GOOD PLEA IN ABATEMENT. Bernard against Andrews--This is an action on a promissory note for $5,000. The defendant by his answer sets up a writ of attachment issued in a suit pending in Connecticut for the same claim, and the plaintiff now moves to set aside the answer as frivolous, and for judgment.

From the New-Orleans True Delta. The two weeks' Spring races of the Metairie Jockey Club are over, and now that the excitement connected with them is past, it is on looking back and reviewing the series of brilliant events which have taken place during their continuance, that we can truly say that they are unparalleled in the racing annuals of the country.

In the City, April 18, by Rev. Dr. Hawks, WILLIAM H. PARSONS, of Portsmouth, N. H., to ANNA PINE, daughter of the late John P. Decatur. In this City, on Friday evening, April 14, by Rev. Isaac Wescott, Mr. WILLIAM H. DELANO, to Miss PHEBE JANE BIRESALL, both of New-York.

PAUL JULIEN'S Concert last evening was by no means so well attended as it should have been. Probably the weather had something to may have been too many seats reserved. The vocalists for the occasion were Mrs. OSCAR COMETTANT and Mlle. HENRIETTE BEHREND. The former lady sang a cavalina from Semiramide, and a couple of characteristic ballads.

NEW WARD BOUNDARIES. -- The territory of Williamsburg will be divided into four Wards by the act consolidaring Brooklyn, Williamsburg and Bushwick. Their boundaries and numbers are as follows: Thirteenth Ward--Bounded by the Brooklyn line, East River Grand-street and Ninth-street.

In the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets a very moderate business has been transacted during the past week. SCGAR, COFFEE, COTTON, and TEA, all very quiet. BREADSTUFFS firm. HEMP and TALLOW have declined from the late highest point. MONEY is without change in value. CONSOLS leave off 67 1/2 _. Bar SILVER, 6S, 1 3/4, DOLLARS, 5S 3/4 d.

Active preparations are going on for the reinauguration of the Crystal Palace on the 4th of May. Judging from the alacrity displayed by the President and Directors of the Association, the Exhibition bids fair to be placed on an entirely improved basis.

GENTLEDMEN: You will, I dare say, recollect the six weeks' debate on the Loan bill in the House of Representatives In the Winter of 1814. The conflict of neutral rights with belligerent inflictions, which then presented the great public topics, has so long ceased that not many of our modern statesmen are familiar with doctrines then universally discussed.

The Senate of Pennsylvania has been engaged yesterday and to-day in the consideration of an important bill, so far as the interests of New-York and Ohio are concerned. Much discussion has taken place, and many hard things said by various Senators. The "unfortunate Franklin Canal Company," as it was termed, came in for an ample share of abuse, as did also the citizens of New-York and Ohio.

FROM THE BRITISH PROVINCES. -The Nova Scotia papers report a heavy rain storm as having occurred in the vicinity of Pictau, producing a freshet which washed away many bridges and destroyed a large amount of property. One man by the name of STEELE, a resident of Tatamagouche, lost thirteen head of horned cattle, one horse and thirty sheep, which were drowned in his barnin a single night, by the rising flood. THE ROBBERY ON THE EUROPA.--The person who was caught on Wednesday in the state-room of one of the passengers going out in the Europa, in the act of opening his trunk, has given his name as WM. MOORE. He was examined yesterday at 2 o'clock before Recorder CUTTER, and held for trial, if indicted by the Grand Jury. I. W. SCUDDER appeared as counsel for the prosecution, and WM. H. JELLIFF for the defence.

Although tile reports of the wrecks on the New-Jersey coast are somewhat modified by later advices received yesterday, the fact of the loss of the packet Powhattan, bound from Havre to this port, seems to be established. Telegraphic dispatches to the latest moment report that 120 bodies have been cast ashore, and successive tides bring in the sad remains of the wreck and its victims. FIRE--SEVEN HORSES BURNED.--At an early hour yesterday morning a fire was discovered in the stable owned by PATRICK MCINTEE, on Bergen-street, between Smith and Boerum. The flames spread rapidly owing to the combustible nature of the materials where the fire caught, and soon reached a two-story wooden dwelling-house adjoining, which, together with the stable where the fire originated and another stable occupied by JOHN DOYLE, was entirely consumed. THE ANESTHESIA BILL. The Senate bill to recompense the discovers of practical Anesthesia, was taken up. Mr. HAMILTON moved its reference to the Committee on Claims. Mr. LETCHER hoped it would not be sent there, considering it no claim at all.

The President recognizes REYNOLD WESTFELDT, as Vice Consul for Sweden and Norway at Mobile. The case of the Ohio Life and Trust Company against HENRY DEBOLT, the Treasurer, commenced to-day in the Supreme Court.

Commodore NEWTON arrived here to-day. He confirms the report of his refusal to salute the authorities of Cuba, and the Spanish flag. He remained in Havana ten days. He waited to-day on the President and the Secretary of the Navy, who received him cordially, and highly complimented his conduct.

The Board of Councilmen took preliminary measures last evening for purchasing the Brick church Property. A resolution was offered by Councilman KENNEDY to provide for the repeal of the restriction imposed upon the Trustees of the Church, so that they may proceed to sell the property for secular purposes.

Republics are not ungrateful. States are not indisposed to pay all their debts of honor, and even to bring into their debt their good children. A late evidence of the truth of our position we have in the noble conduct of the present Massachusetts Legislature.

In Jersey City. on Friday, April 21, HARRIET, wife of Samuel W. Dunscombe. The friends of the family will please attend her funeral, at the York-st. M. E. Church. on Sunday, the 23d inst.. at 9 o'clock. A. M., without further invitation. From thence her remains will be taken to West Bloomfield for interment.

New-Orleans papers of Friday and Saturday last are received: They contain dates from Belize, British Honduras to the 28th ultime. The new British Superintendent had arrived out. ?? was still prevailing there.

Dr. MANAHAN upon the subject of the connection between the Fine Arts and the Catholic Liturgy. The reverned lecturer said that the subject presented a vast field for the religious man as well as the man of letters.

Information has been received in this Department from JOHN F. BACON Esq., United States Consul at the Bahama Islands, that an a 't to consolidate the duties on imports into the colony has been passed, taking effect from the 1st instant. The principal difference between this law and the one recently in force is in the reduction of duties on all kinds of provisions, viv.: Fifty cents a barrel on flour:
A private dispatch received here states that Pernambuco dates to March 21 are to hand by an arrival at Baltimore. The Markets were unchanged, and there had been no arrivals from the United States.

The "Society Medico-Pratique de Paris" offers a prize, in the form of a gold medal, worth three hundred francs, for the best dissertation on the mode of action of the principal purgatives used in medicine, with the special indications for their use. The memoirs to be written in French or Latin, and sent before the 31st of December, 1854, to "M. MARTIN, de la Societe, a la Hotel de Ville."

The Baptist Church in Lambertville, N. J., has been reopened, after having undergone extensive alternations and improvements, at an expense of $2,000. An new Baptist Church has been dedicated in Westfield, N. Y.; another in Baltimore, and one in Mill Creek, Delaware County, Ohio.

REMOVAL OF MARKETS.--The Committee on Markets of the Board of Councilmen met at No. 4 Hall of Records yesterday, at 3 o'clock, GIDEON CLIFTON in the Chair, for the purpose of hearing arguments for and against the removal of Washington and Catharine Markets.

The Michigan papers contain accounts of a dreadful riot at Saginaw on the l7th inst. It originated In an attempt of some 300 armed men to burn the jail at that place and rescue the prisoners. The Sheriff and others interfered to put down the riot, and the Sheriff was killed. A large number of the rioters have been arrested and bound over to await an examination.

An adjourned meeting of the Alumni of Columbia College was held Saturday, at the Chapel of the College. The object of the meeting was to obtain the sense of the Alumni upon the subject of uniting in the Centennial Celebration of the founding of the Institution, in accordance with an invitation extended to them by its Trustees.

SHIP BUILDING.--This business has been carried on to an unusual extent during the past winter, and is still prosecuted with unabated vigor. In East Boston there are now in process of construction, in the various yards, twelve ships, of a total tonnage of 18,000 tens, besides a number of smaller vessels.

Mr. BENTON hopes to get the floor on Tuesday, for the purpose of giving the Senate Nebraska bill a broadside. His great speech will be against the appropriation in the Mexican Treaty, should it be ratified by the Senate. t is rumered that the new Nehraska bill will come up to-morrow, and the previous question move.

On the first Tuesday in May, at 10 o'clock, A. M., the Particular Synod of New-York will commence its session in the Wayne-street Reformed Dutch Church. The opening sermon will be preached by Rev. J. B. ALLIGER, President of the Synod at its last meeting.

The packet ship Blanche, which arrived at St. John, N. B., on 20th, from Liverpool, had Thirty-five deaths on board from cholera, during the passage. She had about 300 passengers. The Maine law bill has been defeated in the New Brunswick Legislature, and a bill passed very little different to the old license law.

An effort will be made to-morrow to introduce into the House another Nebraska bill. When the States are called for resolutions, the friends of the move will present the bill as a new measure, but it will be the old acquaintance with merely a new face, and essentially the same as the proposition of Mr. DOUGLAS.

A SENSIBLE PAYER.--The Chaplain of the Indiana Legislature recently opened the session with a general prayer, which closed with the following eloquent and sensible invocation. Parts of this invocation, it strikes us, are well suited to other meridians besides that of Indiana: "And, O Lord, have mercy upon legislators.

From the Cincinnati Enquirer, April 21. The trial of MATHEW F. WARD and ROBERT WARD for murder of Mr. H. G. BUTLER, is creating considerable excitement in Louisville. The case commenced on Tuesday morning at Elizabethtown, and a severance granted, MATHEW being first placed on trial.

The steamship North Star, Captain MINER, (VANDERBILT's Line,) arrived at this port yesterday. There being no ship of the Independent Line at Panama, she comes without passengers or later news from California. The Purser's politeness puts us in possession of Aspinwall papers.

It is now fifty-two days since the steamship City of Glasgow sailed from Liverpool for this port, during which time not a word has been heard of her, and the apprehensions for her safety have increased to a painful extent.

From the Detroit Advertiser of April 19. We were greatly pained to here it announced this morning that Captain AUGUSTUS CANFIELD. one of the Topographical Engineers, U. S. A., one of our most esteemed and respected citizens, was no more.

FIRE IN TERRE HAUTE.--A terrible fire occurred in our sister city, Terre Haute, on the night of the 11th inst., which destroyed almost an entire square. The Express says that twenty-one business firms were thrown out of shelter.

HORRIBLE MURDER.--One of the most brutal murders that it has ever been our duty to record was committed on Friday night last, about half a mile below Milton. In the afternoon of that day two Irishwomen, the youngest of which is said to have been quite handsome passed through Milton, as they said from an upper section of the Sunbury and Erie Railroad to a section on the Cattawissa road.

DARING HIGHWAY ROBBERY.--A bold robber was perpetrated between 8 and 9 o'clock on Saturday evening, in Union-avenue, near Skillman-street. A man named PATRICK BALYEN, residing on the Dutch Kiln Road, in Newton, was knocked down in Union-avenue by a man and woman, who robbed him of a wallet containing $250, (which he had drawn from the Bowery Bank that afternoon,) his hat, and a pair of new shoes.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Allow me to call your attention to that most excellent and ancient charity, the Eastern Dispensary in this City. It is, I believe, the parent institution of the kind, and is wholly supported by voluntary contributions.

From the New-Orleans Picayune, 16th inst. FOURTH DAY.--After an intermission of one day, on account of the rain, the sport was renewed yesterday. The track was heavy and slippery, the day cold and windy, and the attendance very poor. The race was spirited and well contested, but each horse appeared towards the end to have enough of it, and both were as glad as the spectators when it was over.

We have dates from Galveston to the 15th inst. The News of the 14th has the following items: Sales in town have been quite active, particularly in heavy groceries, which have become scarce in the country after so much delay in the navigation of the river.

Commencement of the Spring Races at Centreville Course--Six Horses Trotting for Sweepstakes of $150--A Trotting Match at Union Course. Yesterday, for the first time this season, Centreville Course, Long Island, was opened to the public. The track is in the finest order, and experienced turfmen say the soil is scarcely exceeded in the North or South, being perfectly free from stones or gravel.
We publish in another column an act passed by the Legislature at its recent session which governs the construction of Railroads in the City.

The bark Venezuela, DAVIS, from Puerto Cabello on the 9th inst., has arrived at this port, and reports that the Venezuclan Congress, on the 24th ult., abolished Slavery throughout the Republic, the bill receiving the President's signature and becoming a law the day it was passed. Indemnity to the planters is specified, but the funds for the purpose had not been created.

In this City, on Monday. April 24, EDWARD STRONG, son of Charles J. and the late Mrs. Elizabeth Strong Stedman, aged 1 year, 11 months and 14 days. The remains have been taken to Norwich, Conn., for interment.

Mr. FOOTE presented remonstrances against the Nebraska bill. Mr. HAMLIN similar remonstrances from Maine. Mr. SEWARD presented the memorial of the Jews of Rochester, praying that religious freedom be secured to all American citizens in European countries.

There has been a large export and speculative demand for Cotton to-day, and the sales reached 12,000 bales. Prices have advanced 1/4c., Middling being quoted at 8c. The sales of the week foot up 50,000 bales, and the stock on hand here is 317,000 bales.

Dates are to March 24. The revolutionists have taken Islay, and removed the custom-house archives, to Arequipa. The Callao Herald says that n body of the battallones nacionales, of Puno and Cuzen, when on their way to attack Gen. CASTILLA, revolted and returned to Lampa in great disorder, losing half their force.

This Court met yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. John Wilson was placed at the bar to take his trial for the murder of Henry Digkmeyer. N. B. ??, Esq., District Attorney, appeared for the prosecution, and the prisoner was defended by ex-Attorney General Chatfield, Gen. Nye and D.I. Baker, Esq.

The St. Paul Democrat of the 12th inst., has been received. We gather from it the following news: Shortly after their removal to Red Wood, Wabashaw's band of Sioux Indians, as well as that of Little Crow, returned to their former haunts to spend the Winter.

We beg to place before those who have the will and the means to be charitable, the following case of distress which has been brought under our notice. There is a lady at present in this City, the wife of a gentleman who was, some short time since, a highly respectable merchant in one of our principal cities. Unforseen circumstances caused him to fail in business.

The Steamer Illinois, arrived at this port last evening, left Aspinwall April 17, at 10 o'clock P. M., and has experienced strong head wind, and a heavy head sea, during the greater part of the voyage. She brings the mails and passengers from the San Francisco packet of 1st of April of Panama.

The Committee on Streets of the Board of Aldermen met yesterday, in order to give a further hearing to those interested in the extension of the Bowery through to Franklin-square. Present the Chairman, Alderman BLUNT and Alderman BROWN. There were a large number of property holders present, a majority of when appeared to be opposed to the proposed extension.

Both California packets arrived last evening; their dates the same from San Francisco. April 1. They bring some interesting accounts from the Pacific side, including the particulars of the entrance of the Russians into Japan.

The Jailor has received a package containing a large number of elegantly-bound books for the Jail Library, accompanied by a modest note to the following effect: "A donation of books, front some ladies, for the use of the prisoners."

We learn from Washington that the Gadsden Treaty was ratified by the Senate yesterday, after sundry modifications. It has been amended so that the extent of territory acquired is only about half as much as the original document ceded to the United States:--the portion ceded includes a Southern route for the Pacific Railroad. The atmosphere was balmy and, the roads being good, a fair attendance of turf sportsmen were present. About 3 o'clock, P. M., the Judges were selected, but all the horses entered for the contest did not appear. An

The defence then called their witnesses, and the greater part of the afternoon was accepted in receiving the testimony of various gentlemen, concerning the peaoefalness.

Colonel BENTON'S speech on the Nebraska bill, of which we publish an extended telegraphic report this morning, is a most earnest and forcible denunciation of that measure in every point of view from which it can be regarded.

RAILROAD ACCIDENT AND NARROW ESCAPE.--The express train from Philadelphia, due here at 6 o'clock on Saturday evening, was detained until 10 1/4 o'clock at night, in consequence of running over a cow at Hall's Cross Roads, by which the locomotive. Baggage car and smoking car were thrown from the track.

RUMOR OF THACKERAY.--The London correspondent of the Dublin Weekly Telegraph supplies that journal with the following piece of intelligence relative to Mr. THACKERAY, the celebrated lecturer and author of Pendennis and Vanity Fair:

Another large fire, involving a frightful less of life, and destroying property to the amount of $20,000, occurred in Broadway last evening. It originated about 8 o'clock, in the clothing and furnishing store of W. T. JENNINGS CO., No. 231 Broadway, a few doors above the Astor House.

A BOY KILLED IN A DRAWBRIDGE--On Sunday evening, Coroner HANFORD held an inquest at Green Point, on the body of FREDERICK, son of JAMES FITZGERALD, four years of age, whose death was caused by being crushed in the drawbridge at the mouth of Newtown Creek.

From the Savannah Morning News. In our evening edition of yesterday we announced the arrival in our city of MILLARD FILLMORE, ex-President of the United States. The lateness of the hour, however, necessarily prevented us from furnishing a full account of his reception. We will not give a more detailed description of the proceedings on that occasion.

SUDDEN DEATH OF A CLERGYMAN.--Rev. JOHN F. RUSSELL, a Baptist clergyman at Jackson, Miss., died in that city on the 6th. On the evening of his death, he was present at the meeting of the Jackson Bible Society, delivering a very cloquent and impassioned address.

Since the sailing of the last steamer, 16th instant, there has been a greater degree of activity in our general market than we have noticed for the past three months. The demand for nearly all leading articles has been very active. PROVISIONS, especially, have been much sought for, and large quantities have changed hands at advanced rates.

A paragraph appeared in several of the City newspapers some ten or twelve days ago, stating that Mr. Abel Chandler, a gentleman who is well known and much esteemed throughout the State, had been arrested on a charge of having sold or transferred a certain forged or fraudulent title to a tract of land, located somewhere in the State of Illinois.

JERSEY CITY PROPERTY.--Mr. DAVID SCOTT, auctioneer, sold, on Monday, real estate, in different parcels, to the amount of about $75,000. Of this, the block bounded by South Sixth, Erie, and South Fifth-streets and Jersey-avenue, known as block No. 175 of COLE'S Map, and comprising thirty-two lots, 25 by 100 feet in size. Lots on Erie-street sold for $1,100 and $1,120.

FOUND DEAD.--Coroner DERN held an inquest on the boil of MICHAEL GREIDER, who was found dead on Saturday morning last, in East Hempfield township. The deceased was addicted to internperance, and for several days had been wandering about, without sufficient clothing to protect him. His friends were in pursuit of, but were unsuccessful in finding him.

The declaration of Queen VICTORIA of 28th march. 1854, adopts the principle that free ships make free goods, unless they be contraband of war, and as the armed neutrality of 1780 did, without the previously associated maxim that enemy ships make enemy goods.

WILLIAM C. MICOU, of New-Orleans, died on the 16th inst., at his late residence, after a sickness of several weeks. The disease was of the brain, brought on by intense mental application. It made its first appearance in the loss of memory, and thence grew rapidly ?? total unconsciousness and bodily prostration, ending's death from exhaustion of the powers of nature.

The Senate, in Executive Session to-day, ratified the ?? ad den Treaty, by a close vote. The Supreme Court has reversed the decree of the Circuit Court of Ohio, which recently declared against giving the Methodist Episcopal Church South part of the assets of the Cincinnati Book Publishing Concern, which have been held exclusively by the Methodist Episcopal Church ??i??ce the separaties of tha?? denomination in 1844.

MARRIED. In Sonora, Feb. 20, by Justice T. S. Hall, Chas. Burt to Mrs. Mary Matilda McBride. At the house of George Michael, in Tholnmne County, on the 5th inst., by S. D. Abbott, Esq., George Michael to nancy, Jane Gates.

Messrs. WADE and BRODHEAD presented petitions against the Nebraska bill. Mr. HAMLIN presented a memorial from ROBERT B. FORBES in favor of schools for young men to be reared as seamen. Mr. BROADHEAD presented the memorial of the Franklin Institute, Pennsylvania, relative to the coinage.

The steamer Falcon, sent out from this port with part of the United States Third Artillery, for California, on 18th inst., after being a week at sea, put into Norfolk, disabled. The voyage is understood to be broken up. The troops go into quarters at Fortress Monroe, or Charleston. The result

SINGULAR DEVELOPMENTS--An organ-grinder has been arrested in Philadelphia, charged with robbing the dwelling of Mrs. J. B. SMITH, some time sineo, of $2,000 worth of jewelry. He alleges, in his defence, that at the time of the robbery a man asked him to go with him to carry some goods, stating that he had just been married to a pretty young lady.

TROUBLE ON BOARD A WHALESHIP.--Advices from Vasse, Western Australia, state that the whaler Iris, WEEKS, master, of this port. arrived at that port on the 26th of December, 1853. A boat from the ship landed the same evening. bringing ashore the mate, Mr. WARREN CRAPO, of Dartmouth, who had received a gun-shot wound from the hands of the captain, who had been observed to be very unsettled in his mind for several days previous.

The Royal Mail steamship Arabia, Capt. JUDKINS, from Liverpool on Saturday, the 15th instant, arrived here at 1 o'clock this morning. The Collins steamship Pacific, from New York on Sunday, the 2d instant, arrived at Liverpool at 9 o'clock A. M. on Friday, the 14th.

Dr. J. V. HUNTINGTON, Editor of the Catholic Metropolitan Magazine, of Baltimore, lectured on Monday evening at the Broadway Tabernacle, on "Authority and the Revolution," to an audience which was not very numerous, but seemed fully to agree with the speaker.

From the San Francisco sun. We have been favored by Lieut. A. W. WHIPPLE, of the Pacific Railroad Central Survey, and By Mr. CAMPBELL., his assistant, with the following notes relative to the Indian tribes met with on that route. We Believe that it will prove eminently interesting to many, particularly as it sets at rest the stories of the "golden bullets," reported by Mr. F. X. AUBREY, through the Santa Fe Papers.

From the Aspinwall Courier. From time to time we have given piecemeal statements snatched with eagerness from the mass of flying rumors (whenever they presented an appearance of probability) respecting the fate of STRAIN and his party.

The steamship Texas, from Vera Cruz, has arrived at this port, bringing dates from the City of Mexico to the 18th inst. A great engagement had taken place between SANTA ANNA and ALVAREZ, in which the latter was routed. The victory of SANTA ANNA was celebrated at the Capital with great rejoicing. A general illumination took place.

A memorial was in contemplation to he presented to the Governor for the purpose of suspending the functions of our local Legislature, and suggesting the necessity of Imperial intervention for the redress of grievances under which the Island labors from the apathy of the Assembly. In my last correspondence I clearly foresaw the consequences that were likely to have resulted.

The interest and excitement awakened in the minds of our citizens by the terrible disaster of Tuesday evening continued throughout yesterday. In the remoter parts of the City, conflicting reports were afloat, representing the loss of life as even more dreadful than the sad account it has become our duty to publish.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It is generally admitted that systematic and paid supervision, inspection, and examination of our Common Schools and their teachers are especially requisite in the City of New-York.

The regular meeting of the American Institute Farmers' Club was held in the Respository, Broadway, on Tuesday noon. CHESTER COLEMAN, Esq., was called to the Chair. The Secretary, HENRY MEIGS, Esq., announced the receipt of several agricultural publications from different sections of the Union, and read the following interesting extract from the Boston Journal of Agriculture:

ORIGIN OF THE TERM DOUGHFACE.--At an Anti-Nebraska Meeting held in Delhi, New-York, says the Gazette of that place, Judge HATHAWAY, who was one of the speakers, mentioned an anecdote showing the origin of the term "doughface," so commonly applied to Northern men with Southern principles.

MEETING OF THE COMMON COUNCIL.--On Tuesday evening there was a meeting of the Common Council at the Lyceum. Alderman LYON in the Chair. Among the items of business were the awarding of several street contracts.

About the time of the sailing of the last steamer for New-York, the American clipper Sea Witch arrived here from China, with over seven hundred Coolies for the Panama Railroad. Trade in black slaves having met the condemnation of the civilized world, the era of copper-colored traffic has been inaugurated. New-Orleans papers of Thursday last are received. The loss of the brig John Williams, on Aransas Bar, with a large cargo of Government supplies, is confirmed.

WARD, Jr., with shooting, with malice aforethought, W. H. G. BUTLER, in the city of Louisville, on the 2d of November last, causing his death on the 3d of said month.

The steamer Falcon which left New-York some days ago, with four companies of U. S. troops for California, put into Hampton Roads on Sunday last, with her machinery disabled, having encountered very severe weather.

Messrs. SEWARD and SUMNER presented remonstrances against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise. Mr. NORRIS, from the District of Columbia Committee, reported adversely on the petitions for paving Pennsylvania-avenue with the Russ pavement.

A ROOT DOCTOR.--A "herbalist." Mr. JOHNSON, was lately examined before the Coroner, in London, for the death of a child under suspicious circumstances. The following conversation took place: CORONER--I see from the certificate that has been produced that you have a diploma. Where did you get it from?

Before Judge Roosevelt. The People vs. Dennis O'Conor, and the other prisoners of the same name, one of them being his brother, were put to the bar jointly indic ed for the murder of MICHAEL CONROY by shooting him with a fowliag piece on the 17th December last.

FIRE DEPARTMENT ELECTION.--The election for chief and Assistant Engineers of the Fire Department, on Monday evening, resulted in the election of the following named gentlemen: For Chief Engineer--C. C. TALBOTT, by 160 majority.

To the Editors of the Louisville Journal: GENTLEMEN: The WARD case increases in interest as the trial progresses. From day to day, an immense crowd gathers in the Court-house, and all listen with eager attention to the protracted details of the evidence. Quite a large number of witnesses were examined to-day, and among them, the father and mother of the accused.

In this City, on Wednesday afternoon, April 26, after a short illness, MARGARETTA, wife of James Lucas, aged 24 years, 10 months and 2 days. The relatives and friends of the family, the members of the Norfolk-st. Baptist Church, and Suffolk-st. Christian Church;

The steamship Arabia reached her dock at East Boston, at 1 o'clock, this afternoon, making the run from Halifax in 29 hours. The Mail bags for the South were forwarded by the evening steamboat train due in New-York early to-morrow morning.

The United States Mail steamer Black Warrior arrived at her anchorage this evening at 4 3/4 o'clock, and the only annoyance she found from our authorities was an earnestness to get her out of port with the least possible delay practicable, and she will be under steam for Mobile at 6 o'clock to-morrow morning.

A MATE OF A WHALESHIP SHOT BY THE CAPTAIN.--The New-Bedford Standard says that a letter has been received in that city, from Vasse, Western Australia, which states that the whaleship Iris, of that port, WEEKS, master, arrived there on the 26th of December last.

The bill relative to the Sunbury and Erie, and Cleveland and Ashtabula Railroads, passed the Senate this morning--Yeas, 18; Nays, 11. It is similar to the bill defeated yesterday, provides for proper arrangements for running the cars on the Lake Shore Road, and protects the interests of Philadelphia and Erie.
Mr. JAMES C. VANDYKE was confirmed today, District Attorney for Philadelphia. GEORGE A. BRANDRETH, of New-York, confirmed as Consul to Plymouth, England. This is considered a Hard-Shell triumph.
GEORGE GRIFFIN, the sole survivor of the wreck of the schooner Manhattan, was in the city yesterday, and the following account of the disaster was gleaned from lists statements:

In this City, on Thursday, April 27, by Rev. Wm. S. Balch Mr. QUENTIN McADAM to MISS MARY BOOTH, all of this City. On Wednesday, April 26, by Rev. D. Henry Miller. of Youkers Mr. THOS. T. STONE to EMELINE, daughter of the late Gard not W. Kimball, of this City.

To the Editors of the Louisville Journal: ELIZBETHTOWN, Ky. Saturday night, April 22. GENTLEMEN: Nothing ever came off in this community that received hall the interest that is manifested in the WARD trial. Around the home fireside, in the streets, in court and out of court, by day and night, it is the subject of conversation, with both old and young.

DISTURBANCE AMONG THE FIREMEN.--Disgraceful scenes among members of the Brooklyn Fire Department are of so frequent occurrence that their acts are passed by, generally, unnoticed. There is scarcely an alarm of fire but a fight or some kind of disturbance between members of the Department takes place. The last of these disgraceful proceedings occurred on Tuesday evening, after an alarm of fire in the Sixth District.

There are German Powers great and small, German art and science, and German industry; there is a German people, and even a German Revolution; but unfortunately for the German race and for the world, There is no Germany as a political body.

The present Spring-time is passing its earliest days with a destruction to life and property even more serious than is usual. Already had one storm scattered death and ships in fragments along our coast, when, last evening, another sent to the bottom of the Hudson a vessel towards which the eyes of the civilized world have, for many months, been turned with eager expectation, and earnest hope for the success of her caloric motive power.

The Arabia's mails reached this City yesterday morning at an early hour. From our English files, which embrace London journals to the 14th, inclusive, we select the following extracts, which contain intelligence of a good deal of interest and importance: LATEST FROM THE SEAT OF WAR.

Mad dogs begin to abound again in the papers,--fortunately not in our streets. One was killed in the City on Saturday,--the first and last of the sort, so far as we have heard thus far in the season. Not so happy are they of Boston.

MEETING OF THE COMMITTEE ON RAILROADS.--The Committee on Railroads of the Board of Councilmen consisting of Messrs. KIMBARK, WILD, BEAKLEY, YOUNG and NORTH, was held in the Chamber of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, to take into consideration the propriety of prohibiting the use of steam on the Harlem Railroad below Forty-second-street.

USING DEADLY WEAPONS.--EDWARD and JOHN SCHNEIDER, two young Germans, were brought before Justice BOSWELL on Wednesday afternoon, on a charge of assaulting and striking EDWARD HARVEY, the afternoon previous, with a saw, which inflicted a serious scalp wound. They were discharged on the ground of having acted in self-defence. HARVEY was the transgressor, and struck them with a chain.

Public attention is still painfully directed to the recent lamentable catastrophe in Broadway. The meeting of Engineers and Foremen of the Fire Department, convened by order of the Chief Engineer, was held last evening, and energetic action was taken. The proceedings are fully reported below.

The Senate, as I anticipated, has concluded a treaty with Mexico, by a vote of 34 to 12--a very respectable majority surely for an instrument so confidently declared to be dead, used up, and so nefarious in its negotiation, object and aims.

We have already called public attention to the gross wrong practiced under Government sanction, in sending 300 United States troops, who had just escaped death from the San Francisco, to California by the old steamship Falcon, instead of the sound steamer George Law, which had been chartered for that special purpose.

The day before yesterday, M. SOULE, the American Minister here, received dispatches from his Government with instructions of a stringent nature with respect to the affair of the Black Warrior. To-day I learn that the matter was settled yesterday. Such businesslike promptitude is so unlike what we are accustomed to in affairs where Spaniards compose one of the parties concerned, that I can hardly bring myself to believe in the correctness of my intelligence.

WALLACK'S THEATRE--Prison and Palace-Hearts at Fault--Pretty Piece of Business. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Romco and Juliet--Faint Heart Never Won Fair Lady. NATIONAL THEATRE.--Uncle Tom's Cabin. BARNUM's AMERICAN MUSEUM.--Two Performances.

Mr. BALL, in the House of Representatives, from the Select Committee to whom was referred the resolutions of the General Assembly of the State of Ohio, "relative to the unlawful proceedings at Erie," has made a very eleborate report upon the subject.

In the Pennsylvania Senate yesterday, according to a telegraphic report in the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin, Mr. CRABB called up the bill relative to the Cleveland, Painesville, and Ashtabula Railroad, and submitted a new bill as a substitute. The amendment is substantially the bill voted down yesterday, requiring a subscription by the Ashtabula Company, of $500,O00, to the Sunbury and Erie Road.

THE FIRE DEPARTMENT--CHIEF'S REPORT. The Chief Engineer of the Jersey City Fire Department, Mr. S. A. FRENCH, has made his semi-annual report--in which he announces that the Department is in an efficient and harmonious condition, and will compare favorably with that of any other city. There are connected with it five fire engines, three hose carriages, two hook and ladder trucks, and three jumpers.

The well known prediction of Napoleon, that "Europe would become Cossack or Republican," briefly illustrates the two rival tendencies that oppose each other in all the European States. The Governments move toward Cossack-ism; the people aspire to the liberty of the Republic.

EXPLOSION OF THE GENESEE POWDER MILLS--On Thursday evening, at 9 o'clock, the powder mills of the Genesee Powder Co., (Messrs. FAIRBANKS CONOLLY CROMBIE,) at Allen's Creek, some five miles east of the city of Rochester, exploded, with a shock that sensibly affected all the buildings in the city, and was felt at a distance of over 12 miles.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--A new play in four acts, called "Isabel, or the Fatal Mask," was produced here last evening. It is from the pen of "a gentleman of this City," and has evidently been prepared as a stock piece for Miss JULIA DEAN. The incidents are avowedly taken from the French, but whether from novel or drama, we are unable to say.

A special meeting of the Board of Directors of the Society for the promotion of Collegiate and Theological Education at the West was held at 10 A.M. yesterday, in the Brick Church Chapel. Chief Justice HORNBLOWER, of New-Jersey, President of the Society, occupied the Chair, and Rev. Dr. EDDY, of do., acted as Secretary. Chair was made by Rev. Mr. PETERS, of Williamstown, Mass.
We make copious extracts from our files by the Arabia, because they embody intelligence of decided importance, which was, nevertheless, not given in the telegraphic dispatch from Halifax.
The Supervisors' Committee on Almshouse has reported in favor of paying, $3,400 88 to Messrs. BUMELL HOLMES--excess over their contract for work done at the county buildings.

In this City, suddenly, on Tuesday, April 25, JOHN AUBICK KEYSER, son of the late John Keyser, Esq., in the 23 year of his age. His relatives, the officers and members of City Hose No. 8, and other friends, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral on Friday, April 28, at 31 o'clock. P. M., from the Lutheral Church of St. James, in Mulberry-st., between Grand and Broome-sts.

Mr. WELLER presented a resolution of the Legislature of California, asking for increased mail facilities, and other local benefits. Mr. SUMNER presented a memorial signed by the Executive and Legislative officers of Massachusetts, in favor of cheap ocean postage.

A special meeting of the Board of Education was held on Wednesday evening--E. C. BENEDICT, Esq., President, in the Chair. A communication was received from the School officers of the Nineteenth Ward, nominating James Gallagher, Denis Tubridy, and Harmon Eldridge, for Trustees of Public Schools for that Ward, in accordance with the amended School law. The nominations were confirmed.

We have again but little of importance to report in our Colonial and Foreign Produce markets. Transactions generally have been on a limited scale, without any material alteration in the prices of the principal articles of consumption. MONEY is without change in value. CONSOLS, alter considerable fluctuations, close at 87 3/4. The Overland Mail has arrived, with advices to the following dates: Hong Kong, 25th February, Calcutta, 4th; Madras, 10th; and Bombay, 14th March.

Lord BEAUMONT--I avail myself of this opportunity to put some questions to my noble friend the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. I am unwilling--as I am sure he must be aware--either to pay much attention to the telegraphic messages which are constantly arriving in this metropolis from various parts of Europe, or to place too much confidence in rumors founded upon those messages.

From the N. O. Picayune, 19th inst. We understand Mr. BOYDEN has become owner of the famous horse Highlander, at a cost of something over $5,000. Mr. BOYDEN has bought of Judge HUNTER, of Alabama, the racing qualities for the Northern Summer campaign, of his fine filly Blonde, for $2,000.

The Madrid correspondent of the London Times states very positively that upon the demand of Mr. SOULE, the Spanish Government has decided that the Captain General of Cuba was entirely wrong in his action in the case of the Black Warrior, and that it has provided for indemnifying the owners.

It is no part of the proceedings of the Association, but it may be interesting, for all that, and highly important for you to know, that I am here, and that by paying board at Willard's Hotel, I am graciously permitted to sleep somewhere else, and get a glimpse cut of my window of that tavern. The public houses are all full.

To the Editors of the Journal of Commerce: GENTLEMEN: A passenger on board the schooner Canton, Captain JOHNSON, from Jamaica, reports having fallen in, near Castle Islands, (Bahamas,) with a large three-masted screw steamer, painted black outside, in side of bulwarks apparently yellow, yards square, and no appearance of any accident having happened.

FOUL AND ATROCIOUS MURDER.--We are Pained to learn that a most cold-blooded murder was committed in our city on Sunday night. The murderer is not yet known, though we understand that suspicions have fastened upon an individual now missing. The unfortunate victim is Mr. LAWRENCE RICHARDSON, a quiet, inoffensive person, formerly of St. Marys, now of this city.

Owing to the continuance of the storm, we are this morning without a report of the doings in the Senate yesterday. In the House, the bill granting lands to the several States for internal improvements was considered, and Mr. RODGERS spoke in its favor, claiming that heretofore, in this respect, gross injustice had been done to the old States. s. The House then went into Com-

The House resumed the consideration of the bill granting lands to the several States, for internal improvement and educational purposes. Mr. ROGERS spoke throughout the morning hour, in favour of the bill. In his judgment gross injustice has been done to the old States:

MATTHEW F. WARD, on trial for the murder of Professor BUTLER, has to-day been ACQUITTED. [In the TIMES of Thursday we gave a full report of the evidence in this case, up to that time. On the third page of this morning's paper will be found the conclusion of that report.]

Church Intelligence. Rev. BENTON SMITH has accepted the pastoral charge of the Universalist Church in South Reading, Mass. Rev. G. W. QUINBY has closed his labors with the Universalist Society in Cincinnati, O. Rev. Mr. SLADE has resigned the pastorship of the Universalist Church in Foxboro', Mass. Rev. G. V. MAXHAM was installed pastor of the Universalist Church in Medford, Mass., April 16.

DEATH or HUGH JAMESON, ESQ.--We regret to report the death of HUGH JAMESON, Esq., which event took place this morning, at his residence in this city. The deceased has long been known and respected in the mercantile community here. For many years he served as Deputy Surveyor of this port, the duties of which he discharged in a manner to secure the approval of all.

The Storm continued during yesterday, and rain was falling heavily at midnight. We hear of more disasters to property on the upper portion of the Island. Two frame cottages in One Hundred and Thirty-third-street were blown to the ground. The dwellings were constructed with all the modern improvements, and just approaching completion for the owners to remove into them on the 1st of May.

We went last week to Prince DEMIDOFF'S Villa, and were much surprised and delighted at the elegance and taste displayed. In one room he has five or six cases full of precious snuff-boxes, and other enriosities, and a beautiful portrait of NAPOLEON, by GROS; and another of PETER the Greater, by DE LAROCHELAROClLLLE.

The weather being fine and everything propitious, there was a large attendance this morning. The session opened at 10 1/2 A.M., and immediately went to work. The review in honor of the Duke of CAMBRIDGE, grandson of GEORGE III, of England, took place yesterday at the Champ de Mars. For forty-seven days not a drop of rain had fallen, and it really was curious to see the clouds gather, and just one hour before the time of meeting, burst and bespatter the city with a drenching discharge, which continued till the ceremony was over. e heavens

Arrangements have been made for the proper solemnization of the Obsequies of the deceased Firemen. A grand procession will form on Sunday morning at 11 o'clock, the right resting on Fourteenth-street, and will move through the principal streets of the City. The members of the Fire Department will all appear in citizens' dress, and no banners or music will be allowed in the line.
The funeral of the victims of the Broadway catastrophe is to take place tomorrow, and the ceremonies will undoubtedly be conducted with a solemnity suitable to so melancholy an occasion. on. The Fire

The following correspondence has taken place in consequence of the resignation of General A. CHANDLER, the late Corresponding Secretary and Agent of the Institute: To the Members of the American Institute: NEW-YORK, Wednesday, March 22, 1854.

THE CITY OF GLASGOW.--Capt. SAMPSON, of the British propeller Curlew, informs us that there were no tidings of the screw steamer City of Glasgour, either at Bermuda the 24th, or the West India Islands as late as the 19th. With the exception of a fall-rigged and hermaphredite brig seen yesterday, he has not seen a vessel during the passage. e.

NEWPAPER EXCERPTA.--There is some sport in picking up magnificent phrases. Witness the following. They are from a contemporary's glowing description of the strom and the sinking of the stcamer (!) Ericsson: "The earth trembling beneath the crash of ethereal war;" "clouds coiling up;" "in the teeth of atmospheric currents;" "rays of the sun heavily charged with heat;" "paraphernalia of a real, genuine, midsummer shower;"

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: MY DEAR SIR: What shall we do with the beggars? My oil cloth is worn out with running over it to the basement door to answer their knocks; the patience of my servants is exhausted, and so is mine. Scores of them visit us in a morning. They would knock the door down if we did not answer them. y tread down the

LA FONTAINE, in his own inimitable way, tells the story of the man who was greatly annoyed by the depredations of a hare in his cabbage-garden, and asked his lanblord to drive her out, who came with his grooms, horses and dogs and immediately began harrying the intruder right and left, and up and down, through the vegetables.

In this City, on Friday, April 28, ISAAC CARY, formerly of St. Louis, in the 34th year of his age. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, at No. 37 Barclay-st., this afternoon, at 2 o'clock, without further notice. In this City, at 9 1/2 A. M., on Friday, April 28, WILLIAM YOUNG, stone-cutter, native of Ayrshire, Scotland, aged 49 years.

A Kentucky Jury, acting under the presumed solemnity of an oath, has solemnly declared that WARD'S killing of BUTLER was not murder. A simple statement of the facts proved on the trial will show how impossible it is to acquit that Jury of perjury.

A violent gale has been raging here since 12 o'clock to-day. The schooner Rocky Mountain, loaded with lumber, was driven ashore, and immediately went to pieces. The hands were all saved. The schooner Richmond is on the breakwater, and is fast going to pieces. Crew saved.

The brig Glamorgan of New-York, arrived here to-day, under command of Licut. DOWNES, U. S. N. She was seized on the Coast of Africa by the U. S. brig Perry, on suspicion of being a slaver, and sent home for trial. CASPAR KEHRMANN, the Captain of Glantorgan, his mate, and two seament, will be examined before the United States Commissioner.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: When the spirit of '76 and of '87 opposes the Nebraska measure of Mr. DOUGLAS, the South, with virtuous indignation, exclaims: Have we not equal rights the North? May not we take our "property" to Nebraska, as well as the North theirs?

BEWARE OF DANGEROUS COUNTERFEITS ON THE RANDALL BANK.--During the past 24 hours new and dangerous counterfeit $10 notes on the Randall Bank, Cortlandt Co., N. Y., have been put into circulation in various parts of our City. HARD TIMES; by CHARLES DICKENS; chapeters 4 and 5. EDITORIALS.--The Sent of the Eastern War; Position and Prospects of the two Armies--England and Cubu--The Gadsden Treaty--The Emperor Napoleon--The Sloo Grant--Female Education--The Ward Case in Kentucky--Affairs in China.

FOR EUROPE.--We understand that among the passengers for Europe in the Arctic to-day, are E. C. BENEDICT, Esq., President of the Board of Education of this City, and Dr. BEDFORD of the New-York University. Both gentlemen will be accompanied by their families. Dr. BENEDICT will attend the Convention for th Promotion of Education, to be held in London the last of next month, as a delegate from the body of which he is President.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--A comedietta, or more properly a farce in two acts, called " Hears at Fault," was produced here on Thursday evening and repeated last evening. It is from the pen of Mr. WATSON, who; we believe, was also the author of "Penelope's Web, produced here some few weeks ago.

One of SOLON'S laws declared that any person who, in the midst of civil way should remain neutral, should be considered infamous. The principle of this law seems to have been adopted by the European belligerents, -- with the exception, that their interest, and not their honor, prescribe, the rule.

The falsity of the reports that constantly reach you from the "Seat of War," which is just now remarkably peaceful, cannot be better illustrated than by all you have heard about the presence of OMER PASHA at Kalafat. Some Weeks, or rather months, ago, the Vienna newspapers assured us that the Turkish General was often at "Widdin," and that he went over to Kalafat every four or five days.

In this City, on Saturday, April 29, ALBERT MILTON, youngest son of Edwin and Catharine Houghton, aged 8 months and 22 days. The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, at 2 'o clock. P. M. tins day, from the residence of his father. No. 121 Henry-st.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: In your paper of Saturday, April 29, complimentary notice is made of an eloquent passage in a discourse attributed to Rev. Dr. A. D. SMITH, on the death of Rev. Dr. C. HALL.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES: The number of the African race in the ranks of Slavery in the United States, at the present time, may be stated at three millions and a quarter or three millions and half; and the rate of their natural increase, in general terms, such as nearly to double their number in a quarter of a century.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your account of the disaster to the Ericsson, published last Friday, says that the firemen were throwing out cinders when the flaw struck her. Such was not the case.
The following is the weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from the 21st day of April to the 29th day of April, 1854: Men, 97; Women, 81; Boys, 173; Girls, 126. Total, 477.
DEDICATION OF A NEW CHURCH AT GREEN POINT, FLATBUSH.--A new church, called the "Methodist Episcopal Mission Church of Green Point," was dedicated yesterday morning with the usual exercises.

The Southern Mail, this evening, brings New-Orleans papers of Monday last. On Thursday, ex-President FILLMORE was publicly entertained at Charleston, by an excursion around the harbor, and by a grand dinner. On Friday, he left for Augusta, Ga., and from thence will proceed to Nashville, Tenn.

By the arrival of the Isabel, we are, in receipt of intelligence from Havana to the 21st of April. There is no news of importance. The authorities have resorted again to very stringent measures to prevent the circulation of incendiary matter through the Post-Office.

The Presbytery of Louisiana met in this city yesterday, to receive into their body Rev. Dr. RICHARDS, of the Presbytery of New-Brunswick, Rev. J. ACCIDENT ON THE PHILADELPHIA AND BALTIMORE RAILROAD.--The 9 o'clock A. M. express train, from New-York to Washington, encountered a serious accident on Saturday evening last, near the hamlet of Aberdeen, six miles from Havre de Grace.

INQUESTS.--On Saturday afternoon, Coroner Wilhelm held an inquest at the Liverpool House, No. 100 Cedar-street, upon the body of William Owens, who died on Friday evening. It was given in evidence that the deceased was an emigrant, and landed from the ship De Witt Clinton, from Liverpool, on Wednesday afternoon, and had been continually intoxicated, to the time of his death.

MESSRS. EDITORS: The drama judicial which we of this town have witnessed, is now drawing to a close. Yesterday morning, Mr. HARRIS, for the prosecution, addressed the Jury for the Common wealth. He was clear, plain, and convincing, if truth can have any effect.

FIRE IN A CHURCH.--Just previous to the commencement of Church services, yesterday forenoon, a fire was discovered in the Baptist Church, at the corner of Grand and Ewen-streets, which was extinguished with slight damage. The fire caught on the main floor, from the heater.

During yesterday forenoon, numerous citizens, without distinction of party, called on Mr. FILLMORE, at the Mills House, to pay their respects to him, and hail his Mills House, to pay their respects to him, and hail his welcome presence among us.

NAPOLEON BONAPARTE,--what a portentous name for so unimportant a personage,--NAPOLEON BONAPARTE, Jr., has left for the East. General of Division by favor, Commander of the Army of Reserve by brevet, and an incompetent lieutenant of artillery by grade, his Imperial Highness has started for Constantinople, in company with EMILE DE GIRARDIN and VELY-PACHA, the Turkish Ambassador.

Singular Discovery of Clothes, the property of Mr. Jennings, on the persons of some of, the deceased--Evidence of Mr. Richardson and the Attendant at the City Hospital. Pursuant to adjournment, the further investigation of this matter was pursued before Coroner HILTON, last Saturday morning, at the Astor House. The apartment was crowded to overflowing, by witnesses and other citizens. .

A New Race Course on Long Island--Purses of $8,000 to be contended for--Excitement among the Turfmen--Blooded Horses coming from the South. In addition to the "Union" and "centerville" race courses on Long Island, there is to be another one established on a very extensive scale, in the vicinity of Newtown and Flushing, by a company of Southern sporting gentlemen of the first water.

At no time do we remember having seen so large a number of Firemen in procession as yesterday, turned out from this and adjoining Cities, to attend the funeral of their comrades killed at the fire in Broadway--although from the absence of apparatus, music or banners, the procession did not cover so much ground.

About 2 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, a melanchely accident, occasioned by the heavy rain storm, occurred on Brooklyn Heights. The citizens were alarmed by a rumor that a building had been dislodged by the action of the rain, and carried into Furman-street, burying several of the occupants beneath the ruins. Upon repairing to the spot the rumor proved to be but too true.

BRITISH SEAMEN--IMPORTANT NOTIFICATION FROM THE BRITISH CONSUL.--We have great pleasure in laying the following sensonable notice, from H. B. M.'s Consul at this port, before our readers: H. B. M.'s CONSULATE, NEW-YORK, April 28, 1854.

MARINE DISASTERS, ETC. We have received files of the Nassau papers to the 19th inst., and find them replete with particulars of marine disasters. The Nassau Guardian, of the 12th inst., says that "within the last fortnight it is estimated that about $600,000 worth of wrecked property has been east on our shores, owing to bad weather." The American bark E. H. C. zpin, Captain BUCK, left Nassau on the 20th ult. for Baltimore.
The heavy rains of Saturday proved more or less disastrous in every direction. The dam of the Croton River was washed away and the City supply of water is likely to be very seriously curtailed. x-

Liverpool Markets. Per Pacific. LIVERPOOL, Tuesday, April 18, 1851. We have no new feature in our COTTON Market worthy of much notice, a slightly improved tone having been apparent the last two days, though with the increased business there is in some few quarters a determination to realize, and occasional low sales have been made.

By the United States Mail steamer Pacific, at this port yesterday morning, from Liverpool Wednesday, April 19, we have four days' later intelligence from all parts of Europe. The Africa arrived at Liverpool at midnight of Monday, 17th.

After the presentation of a number of petitions in the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SLIDELL offered a resolution directing the Committee on Foreign Relations to inquire into the expendieney of authorizing the President, at any time during the recess of Congress, to suspend the act preventing expeditions leaving the United State against foregin countries.

On Friday morning, April 14, after a short and severe illness, borne with true Christian patience, AMELIA ISABELLA, aged 17 years and 2 months, eldest daughter of Canfield Dorwin. Esq. Gentle, docile and affectionate, she was the delight of her friends, and the object of fond and tender hope to her parents.
