The Connecticut River is now nineteen inches above the great flood of 1891, and twenty-eight inches above that of 1843. The steamboat store-house here has been carried down the river.

The flood has caused great damage in this vicinity, the estimated loss on buildings, wharves and other property being about $40,000. In this town the following factories and mills have suffered more or less: LUDFORD'S Leather Mill, loss not very large; the Paper

The Northern Whigs seem much alarmed about Mr. SLIDELL'S resolution to-day, fearing its passage will involve us in war. The Senate to-day ratified the treaty of amity, commerce and navigation with Paraguay, negotiated by Mr. PENDLETON.

It is confirmed that the Russians have entered Servia. A force crossed on the 15th and occupied Turna. The important fortress of Tehaking (so spelled in the telegraph dispatch) in Lower Wallachia, was destroyed by accidental fire, together with all the Russian stores, c.

DAMAGE TO THE NEW-YORK AND ERIE RAIL-ROAD.--It has been ascertained that the damage to the New-York and Erie Railroad, although serious, is not so great as was feared. By transferring passengers and their baggage from one train to another, at the impassable points, all of the back passenger trains, except those due yesterday, arrived at 7 o'clock last evening.

ANTICIPATED RIOT.--A riot was anticipated during yesterday, at the yard of the Pennsylvania Coal Company, at the foot of North Eighth-street. The Irish laborers--about fifty in number--who had demanded an advance of two shillings per day, were discharged on Saturday night.

BOILER EXPLOSION.--At 1 3/4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the three boilers attached to the engine in the large foundry establishment of CAMERON, MUSTARD Co., at the east end of Hasell-street, exploded with a noise that alarmed and shocked the residents in that section of the city to a considerable distance.

We are in possession of papers from Vera Cruz to the 22d inst. The following communication with which we have been favored, gives the latest intelligence from Mexico, and will be found generally interesting:

We have received dates from Galveston to the 20th inst. A letter dated Cold Springs, Polk County, the 13th inst., says: "Our river is in fine order--cotton nearly all shipped--bad prospect for new crop--too much rain--our warehouses at Cedar Bluff are crowded with groceries--plenty to eat, and no sickness."

A MAN POISONED BY HIS SON.--On Monday morning, the 3rd inst., Mr. LEMUEL CURTICE, of Windsor, N. II., and Mrs. LYON, a window lady, and sister of Mr. CURTICE, (then acting as housekeeper for Mr. C.,) soon after eating their breakfast, were both attacked with violent hits of vomiting.

The Scientific Convention held its annual election to-day, with the following result: President, Dr. TORREY; Permanent Secretary, WALCOTT GIBBS; Treasurer, Mr. ELWYN; Recording Secretary, LAWRENCE SMITH. It was voted to meet in Providence on 16th August, 1855. An interesting discussion on the Dora Coal Fields took place to-day. The Association adjourns to-morrow.

FOUND DROWNED.--Mr. JOHN MURPHY, residing on Staten Island, and employed on the Government works at Fort Richmond, discovered on Friday last near the Narrows, drifting, the body of an unknown man drowned. Was about 5 feet 8 inches high, had long, black hair, no whiskers and no beard; was dressed in black cloth pants, (no suspenders,) alapaca coat, red flannel shirt, and calfskin boots.

Parliament was not in session. The Easter holidays had passed over much as usual. Advices from the seat of war were anxiously looked for. Lord JOHN RUSSELL, Lord PALMERSTON, and Sir HAMILTON SEYMOUR, were guests of the Lord Mayor of London, at a banquet given on Monday evening, the 17th. They each made a speech, but said little that we need repeat.

The arrangements had been made for an excursion to Mt. Vernon and Alexandria to-day, but on account of the threatening appearance of the sky, at an early hour the white flag was run up from the highest turret of the Smithsonian Institution, the concerted signal that we were to remain at peace at home, the excursion being postponed until Monday.

ANTICIPATED RIOT.--A riot was anticipated during yesterday, at the yard of the Pennsylvania Coal Company, at the foot of North Eighth-street. The Irish laborers--about fifty in number--who had demanded an advance of two shillings per day, were discharged on Saturday night. Yesterday morning, their places were filled by Germans belonging to New-York.

The end of this tragedy is not yet. The extraordinary acquittal of the murderer by the Court in Hardin County, is met with unqualified denunciation by a public meeting at Louisville, the scene of the murder, followed by a popular outbreak in the shape of effigy-burning in front of the elder WARD'S house.

COLONEL GATES.--The Government has not yet seen fit to make known the result of the Court of Inquiry held in this City some weeks since in the case of Colonel GATES, charged with unofficer-like conduct in connection with the wreck of the San Francisco.

The good citizens of Gotham, who retired last night wearily, besweated and bedusted, after the moving toils of yesterday, will rejoice to learn that the startling intelligence of a failure in the supply of Croton was greatly exaggerated in our contemporaries, and that they may indulge in the luxury of a bath without any fear of infringing on the rights of the tea-kettle.

Notwithstanding the large amount of space we have already alloted to accounts of disasters by the late storm, we are still in the hourly receipt of additional intelligence. In the City we have not much that is new to record. THE ERICSSON. Since the storm abated several men have been engaged in making preparations for raising the Ericsson, which they will probably accomplish in a few days.

The United States sloop-of-war Jamestown, DOWNING, arrived here this afternoon in 31 days from Pernambuac--all well. The steamship Guaker City, for the Charleston line, was launched this afternoon at Kensington.

The Pacific's news is of no peculiar importance. Fighting is going on, it seems, on the whole line of the Danube, but without decisive engagements, or at least without any solution of what may be termed the great mystery of the Dobrudseha occupation.

Messrs. THOMPSON, of N. J., DODGE and WADE presented memorials against the Nebraska bill. Mr. CHASE presented the remonstrance of the yearly meeting of Friends, of Indiana, against the Nebraska bill. Mr. SHIELDS, from the Committee of Conference on disagreeing votes on the Military Academy bill, reported that the Senate recede from its amendments increasing the salaries of Professors of French and Drawing Adopted.

CORPORATION SALE.--By order of the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund, the following docks, slips , belonging to the Corporation, not leased at the auction sale on the 23d ult., were put up to public auction at the City Hall, yesterday afternoon.

at Kalafat, and was saluted with a hundred salvos of artillery and three rounds of musketry. The news of the declaration of war created immense excitement at Bucharest, and in consequence Baron BUDBERG, the Russian Governor of the Danubian Provinces, had ordered all persons connected with the diplomatic agencies of the Western Powers, to quit the Principalities within eight days.

The Monitour publishes the law increasing the military contingent for 1854 from 80,000 to 140,000 men. Marshal ST. ARNAUD, Commander-in-chief of the French armies in the East, left Paris on the 15th for Marseilles. Messrs LEROY, CHALROL Co, Paris, whose suspension of payments we recently announced, have offered to pay all claims, with interest, within twelve months.

The Cortes were to remain open till the 16th May. Several meetings of a commission to promote legitimate commerce and suppress the Slave-trade on the east coast of Africa, by means of a Joint Stock Company, upon the plan of the English East India Company, had been held at Lisbon, with the sanction of the Portuguese Government.

A MAN POISONED BY HIS SON.--On Monday morning, the 3d inst., Mr. LEMCEL CURTICE, of Windsor, N. H., and Mrs. LYON, a widow lady, and sister of Mr. CURTICE, (then seting as housekeeper for Mr. C.,) soon violent fits of vomiting. Dr. WILKINS, of Antrito, was set for, and at once pronounced them poisoned. Both continued to vomit, and remained in great distress for several hours.

After the presentation of a number of petitions in the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SLIDELL offered a resolution directing the Committee on Foreign Relations to inquire into the expediency of authorizing the President, at any time during the recess of Congress, to suspend the acts preventing expeditions leaving the United States against foreign countries.

The semi-official Correspondenz announces that the objections made by Austria to the points introduced by Prussia into the draft of the new treaty of alliance, will not have the effect of breaking off negotiations. The ratification of the contract of marriage between the Emperor of Austria and ELIZABETH, Princess of Bavana, took place on the 7th.

THE NATIONAL MEDICAL ASSOCIATION.--The meeting of this association is to be held in this city on the 2d of May next, and promises to be the largest assemblage of professional gentlemen ever congregated in the West. The profession here have done everything in their power to render the reception and entertainment of the delegates worthy of our city and agreeable to them.

CORONER'S INQUEST.-The Circumstances of this affray, which occurred on the night of Saturday, April 22, (a full account being published in the TIMES of the Monday following,) and resulted in the death of WILLIAM HUGHES, was investigated before Coroner BALL, yesterday, and the following Jurors: DAVID MUNDELL, JOHN EALING, JOHN S. QUINBY, HENRY GERDINO, PATRICK DONOHUE, JOHN LITTLE.

At West Chester, on Wednesday, April 26, by Friends' ceremony, NATHANIEL B. STARBUCK, of Troy, N. Y., to AMELIA C., daughter of Israel H. Watson, of the former place. In this City, on Sunday, April 30, by Rev. Dr. Armitage' Mr. JOSEPH H. TOOKER to Miss WINNIE CONLIN, all of this City.

The phrase "Young America" has become one of frequent utterance among us. The wise will not regard it merely as a phrase, not merely as designating a certain number of ardent young men, or a certain number of persons, either old or young. It is a great deal more.

SARDINIA.--The Parlamento of Turin, of 10th, contains some particulars relative to the Duke of VALENTINOIS. The Prince was imprisoned, with his aide-decamp, in the Sardinian fortress of Villarfranca. Twentythree persons were arrested by the National Guard at Mentone. Eleven of the prisoners were held for trial, and the other 12 were liberated.

BOILER EXPLOSION.--At 1 3/4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the three boilers attached to the engine in the large foundry establishment of CAMERON, MUSTARD Co., at the east end of Hasell-street, exploded with a noise that alarmed and shocked the residents in that section of the city to a considerable distance.

The Board of Councilmen adopted a resolution last evening, which; if taken up and concurred in by the Aldermen, will entitle the Common Council to the thanks of their respectable constituents. They have taken decisive ground against granting licenses for the sale of intoxicating liquors to persons selling groceries.

Yesterday afternoon, about 1 o'clock, a fire broke out in the large warehouse of Messrs. EGAN COGHLAND, No. 19 Burling-slip. The store was filled with rags, cotton, and old junk. The engines were promptly on the spot-five before the bell rang-and hopes were entertained that the fire would be confined to the two upper stories.

We have no new feature in our COTTON Market worthy of much notice, a slightly improved tone having been apparent the last two days, though with the increased business there is in some few quarters a determination to realize, and occasional low sales have been made. The business of yesterday was 8,000 bales, and to-day 5,000 bales: Speculators and Exporters taking 3,000 bales, at the following quotations:

On Friday morning, April 14, after a short and severe illness, borne with true Christian patience, AMELIA ISABELLA, aged 17 years and 2 months, eldest daughter of Canfield Dorwin, Esp. Gentle, docile and tender hope to her parents.

In consequence of the recent abuse of the franking privilege, the Postmaster General has issued instructions to all officers in the Departments, Special Agents, C., to strictly enforce the provisions of the act of Congress in the matter.
The long-expected veto of the bill granting lands for the benefit of the indigent insane, was sent to the Senate yesterday, where it was read and commented upon at considerable length.

Brevet Major FRANCIS O. WYSE, of the Third Regiment of United States Artillery, was yesterday put upon his trial before a Court Martial, to answer to charges of insubordination, in refusing to embark with his command on board the steamship Falcon. The peculiar circumstances of the case rendered the occasion remarkably interesting.

Saturday was one of intense excitement in the Pennsylvania Legislature. In the Senate, the Erie and Pittsburg Railroad Company Transfer bill was again called up. It had been amended in the House, and in two instances amendments were offered and adopted in the Senate.

FIRE IN BUSHWICK.--Between 6 and 7 o'clock on Monday evening a fire broke out in a three-story brick building on Bushwick-avenue, owned and occupied by Messrs. LAWRENCE SONS, as a jenny house. The alarm was immediately given, and the firemen of this city succeeded in quelling the flames.

We have had another exciting day in our Legislature, particularly in the House, where a furious and stormy debate raged from 9 o'clock in the morning until 5 in the evening. The second reading and consideration of the bill relative to the Sunbury and Eric Railroad, and the Cleveland, Painesville and Ashtabula Railroad Companies, was resumed.

ST. ARNAUD, Madame ST. ARNAUD and their staff have let at last for Marseilles, on their way to the East. Lord RAGLAN starts to-day, the Duke of CAMBRIDGE of Wednesday or Thursday. Prince NAPOLEON has made a speech at Marseilles which created quite an excitement among the Municipal Councillors, and other gentlemen forming the claque.

We commence this morning the publication of the proceedings of a Court Martial instituted in the case of Major FRANCIS O. WYSE., for disobedience of orders. This trial possesses a peculiar interest, from the associations connected with the melancholy wreck of the steamship San Francisco.

The British schooner Mary and Jane has arrived here, with Nassau dates to the 20th ultimo. The Bremen ship Auguste, from New-Orleans, for Bremen, arrived at Nassau on the 20th. She went ashore on the 18th, on Memory Rocks, and was assisted off by wreckers. Salvage awarded, $20,000.

Some weeks before the time fixed for the trial of WARD for the murder of BUTLER, it was deemed advisable by his friends to at tempt the creation of a public sentiment in this section of the country, favorable to his acquittal. Letters ,were accordingly writ-

Mr. SLIDELL'S speech in the Senate yesterday continues to attract very general attention, and excites much remark. It is his purpose to press the subject involved in his resolution upon the attention of the Senate, and to get an expression of the sentiment of that body thereon.

The Particular Synod of New-York, in connection with the Reformed Dutch Church, met in Wayne-street, Jersey City, on Tuesday, May 2, at 10 A. M. A sermon was preached by Rev. WM. J. R. TAYLOR, of Jersey City. The following officers were elected: Rev. WM. W. HALLOWAY, of Williamsburg, President ; Rev. C. E. CRISPELL, Adsessor ; and Rev. Messrs. SCHENK and FERRIS, Clerks. Rev. Dr. STRONG acts as Stated Clerk.

On the 5th of March a conflict occurred between a detachment under the command of Lieul D. BELL, of the 2d Regiment of Dragoons, and a band of Jicarillas and Apaches, led on by the celebrated Chief, LOBOS.

On the 20th of March, the Russians crossed the Danube by means of a bridge of boats, formed at Hirchova, near Matchin. Here they succeeded in passing some 20,000 men, and on the next day about 15,000 crossed the Danube above Matchin. ks retired before them accord-

The Legislature of Connecticut was organized this morning. In the House, LAFAVETTE S. FOSTER, of Norwich, was chosen Speaker, and AMI GIDDINGS, of Plymouth, and F. E. HARRISON, of West Killingly, Clerks. Messrs. BABCOCK and WILDMAN, of the Palladium, were appointed State Printers.

Now here is a comfortable position of affairs! We are at WILLARD'S, taking the world as easy as if there were nothing to do, after a day most pleasantly spent, and in a fashion that no man may speak of as laborious. n of Gotham,

We have again to notice a tame and languid market for most descriptions of goods, the slight increase of country orders brought about by the approaching resumption of internal navigation, not having imparted much life or firmness to the business. Local jobbers are doing little, while commission merchants, in general, are idle.

The Crystal Palace is to be reopened for the season to-day, with appropriate and imposing ceremonies. Of course, the flush of public excitement which attended the completion of this magnificent structure, and which led to the great public demonstration of last Summer, has passed away, and cannot be renewed.

The steamer Black Warrior, Capt. J. D. BULLOCH, arrived at this port yesterday morning. She brings one hundred and one passengers, and a large amount of Cotton on freight. The B. W. left Mobile on the evening of the 25th, and arrived at Havana on the evening of the 27th. After coaling, she sailed on the 28th at 5 o'clock, P. M.
The trial of Mrs. HAYS, for the murder of Dr. LUTENER, is progressing before the Court of Oyer and Terminer.

Elliott, are invited to attend here funeral, on Thursday, at 4 o'clcok, P. M., at No. 41 Sidney-place, Brooklyn. The effects of the storm throughout Orange County have been unusually severe. The oldest residents of that region recollect no similar fall of rain. The fields in the vicinity of all the water-courses were completely overflowed, and water was standing on the surface as late as Tuesday morning. The injury to property will amount to a very considerable sum. dams,

Numerous petitions were presented. Mr. PETIT, from the Judiciary Committee, to which was referred the resolution directing inquiry as to the, propriety of having the United States Statutes revised corrected, and properly collated, reported that it was inexpedient to legislate on the subject.

The Committee on Markets of the Board of Councilmen met in the Council Chamber at 3 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of hearing parties for and against the removal of Washington Market to the foot of Gansevoort-street. Councilman CLIFTON was in the Chair. Upwards of one hundred persons were present.

By the arrival of the United States ship James-town, we have intelligence from the Rio de la Plata up to February 18. At Buenos Ayres business was very lively and the affairs of the Province were regarded as being in a hopeful condition.

Before His Honor Judge Betts. THE COLLIER CASE. The United States against James Collier.--Mr. Dickenson resumed his address yesterday morning, concluding about 12 1/2 o'clock, reviewing the points already alluded to, and presenting in a most forcible manner, his client's position.

Since then a brisk business has been done, sales amounting to upwards of 45,000 bags, of which only 12,000 bags for the States ; prices firm at 4||300 ?? ar., principally.

The General Meeting was of but a few minutes' duration. An invitation from the people of Georgetown to visit and dine with them was declined respectfully and with thanks. A letter from President WAYLAND was read, inviting the Association to meet next at Providence, R. I., which was referred to the proper Commit tee. It was also announced that the evening would be devoted to hearing the paper of Dr. HALL on Storms.

A very severe rain storm has prevailed here during the last 24 hours, and the lower portions of the Country in the vicinity of Boston are submerged. We hear as yet of no damage of importance. A land-slide occurred on the line of the Worcester Railroad about six miles from the city this morning, but the damage was promptly repaired with but little detention.

Before Hon. Judge Roosevelt. THIRD DAY. The Court met this morning at 10 A. M. Mrs. HAYS seemed slightly better than on the preceding day, al though not able to walk without assistance. The officers and her female attendants conducted her into Court, and she remained stretched on a couch during the day. n a couch during the day.

The sales of COTTON to-day were 4,500 bales. Middling is quoted at 8c.@8 1/4c. The stock on hand is now 311,000 unless, and the decrease in the receipts at all the Southern ports is 498,000 bales. FLOUR had advanced a tritle to-day. CORN is firm at 63c.@65c. FREIGHTS have advanced, and COTTON to Liverpool is quoted at id. EW-ORLEANS, Wednesday, May 3.

The grand Reopening of the New-York Crystal Palace took place yesterday. The occasion was all that could have been desired. The attendance was very large; the enthusiasm was undamped by fickle skies; and the speakers were numerous, pointed, brief, and happy. The exten-

St. John, New-Brunswick, papers of May 3 are received. In the New-Brunswick Legislature, a message had been received from the Lieut. Governor, containing the English declaration of was against Russia, and instructions from the Home Government to lay an embargo on Russian vessels.

It is understood that LANE of Indiana, and EDDY and one other Jersey member, and one from Connecticut, with some other from Northern States, who have pretended to be against the Nebraska bill, intend voting with RICHARDSON to take it up on Monday, under the pretext that they do so in order to kill it.

The Nebraska bill is still strongly, though covertly, pressed upon Congress as an Administration measure. Our advices from Washington state that a fresh attempt is to be made on Monday to take it up, and that great efforts are made to get votes in favor of so doing even from those who are opposed to the bill. gentlemen,

If popular favor, the tutular saint of the Crystal Palace, extends its smile of yesterday over its future, a glorious destiny awaits it. The Reinauguration, contrary to the anticipation of many who desire its success, was imposing; and gave good ground for cheerful expectation, in the presence of the mechanics and laboring men of this and other cities.

SECOND DAY. The Court reassembled at Governor's Island at 9 o'clock, Yesterday morning. All the members present on the first day, were in Court. The minutes of Wednesday's proceedings were read, as also the specifications and the testimony.

Our Cotton Market has been firm to-day, with sales of 7,000 bales. FLOUR is dull. CORN has advanced 2c., with sales of 50,000 bushels at 60c.@63c. The Pacific's news came to hand at 5 o'clock this evening. EW-ORLEANS, Tuesday, May 2--Noon.

In this City, on Thursday, May 4, at the residence of Henry W. Dunshee, by Rev. A. H. Wright, Rev. JOHN ERSKINE, of Delaware Co., N. Y., to MISS HARRIET PARKER, of this City. In this City, at the Reformed Dutch Church, Lafayette-place, on Thursday afternoon, May 4, by Rev. Dr. KNOX, JAMES JOURNEAY to SUSAN M., daughter of the late William Chardavoyne, all of this City.

The Jury empanneled to investigate the causes of the fire and loss of life at the building No. 231 Broadway, concluded their labors yesterday, by bringing in their Verdict. They exonerate Messrs. W. T. JENNINGS Co., the occupants of the building, but censure the architect and builders. Appended to the Verdict is a series of resolutions upon the imperfect state of our Fire Laws, with recommendations of improvement.

The United States Mail steamship Empire City, J. McGOWAN, Commander, arrived at this port last night, having left New-Orleans April 26, for New-York, via Havana, off which port she arrived on the night of the 28th. Having landed her mails and passengers and taken a supply of coal, she sailed for New- York at 1 P. M. on the 29th.

A correspondent of the Cincinnati Gazette, in speaking of the WARD trial, makes the following remarks: "Is this perversion of law and justice allowing to the weakness or corruption of Juries, or, is it not to be charged to the finesse of lawyers, the absurd technicalities and quibbles of the law and the veneration paid by the judge, to the antiquated decisions of English Courts? ever may be the cause,

J, McCarthy and Francis Leonard, Whose appointment was not confirmed by the Board.

The eighth volume of HARPER'S NEW MONTHLY is completed with the present number. This popular periodical will with the June issue commence the fifth year of its existence, having reached the unparalleled circulation of nearly 150,000 copies. The beginning of a new volume offers a favorable opportunity for new subscribers to give their orders to the agents.

From the N. O. Picayune, April 27. Since then we have also received one from the Western Texan, of the same date, and from the two we make up the following narration:

Mr. SEWARD presented remonstrances from 800 citizens of Otsego County, and also of citizens of New-York, against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise. Mr. CHASE presented it similar petition from citizens of New-York City. Mr. SUMNER presented a memorial, from citizens of Missouri and Wisconsin, on the subject of spiritual manisfestations.

The Herald feels uneasy in its solitary position, as the apologist and defender of MATT. WARD and the Kentucky jury which pronounced his deliberate, premeditated and unprovoked assassination of Prof. BUTLER to be no murder. It deprecates the odium and responsibility which belong to such an office.

LECTURES.--Mr. FARRENC is about to deliver a course of six lectures at the University, commencing on the 10th inst., on the "Rise and Progress of the Democratic Sentiment throughout Modern Times." The lectures will be delivered in the English language on Wednesdays, and be repeated on Fridays in French.

There is nothing new to-day as to the war, except rumors both from Paris and Vienna, of a new Prussian mediation. LIVERPOOL, Saturday, P. M. The sales of Cotton, to-day are estimated at 5,000 bales, the market closing tamely, but quite steady, at Friday's quotations. s.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The serious accident to the "Caloric Ship," last Thursday, has deprived me of the anticipated pleasure of inviting you to witness the performance of the new machinery of this ship.

The mail has failed this morning south of Augusta, Ca. The ship State Rights, from Liverpool, had arrived at Savannah, with loss of masts and spars, and had six seamen swept overboard during the passage. She reports seeing several vessels dismasted, and in distress.

From the Nashivlle Banner. The well-known coffee-house on Market-street, kept by JAS. LONGINETTE. was the theatre of a most distressing tragedy Thursday night. Between the hours of 12 and 1 o'clock, the building was found to be burning--the flamers had not. when discovered, made great progress, being confined pretty much within the closed house, which was densely filled with smoke.

SERIOUS ACCIDENTS--CARELESSNESS OF BUILDERS.--An elderly man, named JOSEPH FARMERMAN, some time during Wednesday night, fell into an excavation in front of a block of buildings erecting on Court-street, corner of President, a distance of fifteen to twenty feet, where he remained until 6 o'clock on Thursday morning, when he was discovered by the Police of the Third District.

The news from Madrid by the Africa, taken in connection with the speech of Mr. SLIDELL in Congress, and other movements having an official aspect, justify the suspicion that our Government has entered systematically upon the task of provoking a rupture with Spain, and that a war with that power, having for its object the acquisition of Cuba, is upon the programme, as an Administration measure.

Mr. BARNUM, the now President of the Crystal Palace Association, did not think it worth while to advertise its reopening in the columns of the Herald. In consequence of this omission on his part, that independent and high-toned journal gave the following full and accurate report of the proceeding on that occasion:

THE TRIAL OF MAJOR WYSE.--Our report of yesterday's proceedings of the Court Martial convened at Fort Columbus to investigate the charges against Major WYSE, of the 3d Artillery, is unavoidably crowded out this morning.
Tuesday's Proceedings Concluded. I stopped writing at the point when a recess was taken midday, to refresh with crackers and cheese in the Standing Committee Room.

Nebraska men are in good spirits. It is probably owing to the treachery of the Northern men, who will vote to take the Nebraska bill up out of the regular order, which will probably result in securing its passage by a small majority. Its opponents are rather desponding. General CASS returned to the city to-night.

The Chair said private bills was the order of the day. Mr. HUNTER, in accordance with a notice given, moved to suspend the rules, and take up the Indian Appropriation bill. Messrs. CHASE and SLIDELL objected, and the Chair ruled the motion out of order. Private bills, to which no objection were made, were taken up.

The steamphip Cleopatra, Capt. HENRY SALT, from Liverpool on the 11th of April for Quebec, arrived here to-day. She had very bad weather on the passage, deck swept and houses carried away. In going up the St. Lawrence, encountered an island of ice grounded, by which she was considerably damaged in her bows.

There are several important points in the Africa's news, the principal of which is the reply of the Russian Government to the Anglo-French declaration of war. This document was published on the 12th of April, in the official Journal of St. Petersburg, and will be found in this morning's TIMES. It is remarkable in more senses than one.

The eighth meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, whose sessions at Washington closed last. Wednesday, has been of a most interesting and important character. The records of its proceedings add liberally to the stock of positive facts in every department of Science of which it takes cognizance.

The royal mail steamer Africa arrived at this port yesterday morning, having left Liverpool on the morning of Saturday, April 22, bringing news three days later than had been received by the Pacific. The Franklin arrived off Cowes on the morning of the 20th, and, having communicated with the shore, continued her voyage to Havre. The news by this arrival is decidedly interesting.

The Board of Aldermen last evening took up the proposition to buy the Brick Church property, and adopted a resolution in favor of the measure. The Aldermen and Councilmen are of the same opinion, as regards the propriety of making this purchase. rst

Before Hon. Judge Roosevelt. FIFTH DAY. The Jury assembled at 10 o'clock. His Honor Judge ROOSEVELT, Mr. HAYS and his counsel, and the District Attorney were present, but Mrs. HAYS did not appear. The District Attorney said:

For several days past, no hope has been entertained, in any quarter, that the Governor would interpose prevent the execution of JOHN HENDRICKSON, Jr., for the murder of his wife. The result has been that the jailer has been overrun with applications for admission to the cell of the prisoner.

ATTEMPTED FRAUD UPON. THE NEW-YORK STATE BANK.--A young man presented to the teller of the New-York State Bank, this morning, a check for $1,000, upon a Bank in New-York, drawn by a firm in that City, and payable to the order of another firm.

We are given to understand that a fresh effort is to be made this week to bring up the Nebraska bill for action in the House of Representatives. Some fifteen or twenty bills stand before it on the Calendar, and the only way of reaching it is by taking up and laying each of these on the table in succession.

On the eighth page of this morning's TIMES will be found the decision of Judge CARROLL, of the United States Supreme Court, on an appeal from a decree of the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Ohio, in relation to the rights of the M. E. Church South and the M. E. Church North, in the fund of what is known as the Methodist Book Concern, at Cincinnati.

The evidence given on the trial of Major WYSE for refusing to order the troops under his command to go to sea on board the Falcon, shows conclusively that the steamer ought never to have been chartered by the Government for such a service. There are of course opinions given on both sides;- but the weight of disinterested testimony is clearly against her sea-worthiness.

Our Government has received from Mr. SOULE the very unexpected intelligence that the Spanish Government refuses compliance with his demands made in our behalf in the Black Warrior affair. Of this you may rest assured. As I informed you some time since, the Spanish Government was advised by Great Britain to settle the Black Warrior affair without hesitation, and at any cost.

The members of the House are estimated to stand as follows on taking up the Nebraska bill: For taking it up, one hundred and seventeen; against it, one hundred and seven; and seven doubtful. A majority can take the bill up in Committee of he Whole, by laying aside each preceding measuret

THE CIVIC AND MILITARY IRISH REPUBLICAN UNION.--The members of the Civic and Military Irish Republican Union held a meeting on Saturday night at KERRIGAN'S Head-Quarters, White-street. T. C. HOLLAND was called to the Chair. The minutes having been read and approved, Mr. MICHAEL MALLOY addressed the meeting, paying a tribute to the memory and worth of Mr. JOHN B. O'DONNELL, brother to their Secretary, who was killed at the late fire in Broadway.

There is abundant promise of an exciting Summer campaign in the theatrical and musical way, and this week opens it briskly enough. We have apparently passed the epoch of rumor, and begin realities from to-night. First on the list of actualities is NIBLO's, whose establishment, after a few months' alteration, opens to-night completely transformed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In yesterday's article upon the Kentucky murder, you reject the inference that you "wish WARD to be hung." Pardon me for thinking that this exhibits a morbid delicacy of feeling. For my part, I would walk ten miles barefoot, to see this cowardly assassin suffer the punishment due to his crime.

From the Louisville Courier. MATT. F. WARD, the acquitted murderer-that innocent and interesting young man, as WOLFE says--made his escape from this city by crossing the river at Jeffersonville, from thence to New Albany, where preparations were made to turn him out. but he decamped instanter on the first boat that came along--a stern wheeler, we are told--and when last seen, he was at Cannelton.

Another day of excitement in the Pennsylvania Legislature. This morning the House resumed the second reading and consideration of the bill relating to the Sunbury and Eric Railroad, and the Cleveland Painesville and Ashtabula Company. Numerous speeches were made, and the most grave charges of bribery and corruption were uttered. Mr. SMITH, of Crawford, said that the Pittsburg and Erie Railroad Company had been ruined by building their road to the Ohio State line.

THE NEWARK FIRE DEPARTMENT.--Majority and minority reports have been made by the Committee of the Newark Common Council, appointed to report on the probable cost of a paid Fire Department for the city. The majority report estimates the cost for ten companies, of four hundred men, exclusive of officers, at $14,459. The minority report estimates the expense of a paid Department at $35,000.

Reply of John Mitchel to C. Gavan Duffy. Mr. DUFFY, editor of the Dublin Nation, and member of the British Parliament for New-Ross, has written and printed a long letter to me; the text and the pretext being some passages in my "Jail Journal," commenting on his defence to a State prosecution. Those who know us both, know that this man has been a bitter enemy to me for many years.

Large Incendiary Fire in Gowanus--Accidents, A little before 2 o'clock yesterday morning, the inhabitants of that usually quiet locality Gowanus, in the Eighth Ward of Brooklyn, were aroused from their slumbers by the cry of fire. At this time, flames were to be seen issuing from the large Morocco Factory, in two different parts of the building, belonging to Messrs. MIRICK BROS., located on the west side of Third-avenue, between Twenty-first and Twenty-second-streets.

A remarkable murder trial has recently taken place in Rockbridge County, Virginia resulting in the disagreement and discharge of the Jury, and the case now goes to another county The prisoner is a member of the Virginia Military Institute, at Lexington; quite young, and without family or extensive family influence.

TRINITY CHURCHYARD.--Mr. Editor: A ridiculous report was made to the Board of Alderman on Friday evening, by Alderman DRAKE, of the Twenty-second Ward, on the subject of opening Albany-street through Trinity Churchyard. This dignitary, when the majority report of his associates.

SHOCKING CASE OF POISONING. Death of Rose Williams from Arsenic--Inquest--Her Husband held for the Murder. On Saturday, Coroner WILHELM held an inquest in the Ivy Green, Elm-street, upon the body of ROSE WILLIAMS, (Wife of ANDREW WILLIAMS,) whose death was caused by arsenic, supposed to have been given to her by her husband, on board the Golden State, where she went to see him.

The Religious Anniversaries have already commenced. No less than six of the institutions whose annual returns make the second week of May peculiar, had sermons preached in their behalf last evening. Today, at 3 o'clock, the Reformed Dutch Sabbath School Union is to celebrate in the Lafayette-place Church.

Pursuant to adjournment, the Court assembled yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. Mrs. Hays was sretched on a couch and covered with a shawl during the proceedings. She seemed better than yesterday, but is still in a very debilitated condition.

Another of those destructive fires which, of late, have been so frequent, occurred in this City yesterday. About fifteen buildings were either entirely consumed or badly damaged -- involving a loss of property estimated at $40,000.

The steamship George Law, Lieut. G. P. FORD, U. S. N., commanding, left Aspinwall at 11 o'clock, on the evening of the 30th ult., and arrived at Sandy Hook, at 11 1/2 o'clock on the 8th inst. She brings the California mails of April 15--$847,573 in treasure on freight, c., and 584 passengers.

From the St. Louis Intelligencer. The Seventh Annual Meeting of the American Medical Association convened at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, at the Verandah Hall, pursuant to adjournment. Dr. USHER PARSONS, of Providance, R. I., Senior Vice President of the Association, took the Chair, and called the Convention to order.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The solemn farce is ended! Kentucky, "free, glorious old Kentucky," has again vindicated her claim to her time-honored title of "the dark and bloody ground!" has gain asserted,

Judge KANE, to-day, delivered a long opinion of the Circuit Court in the case of the United States Marshals versus the Sheriff of Philadelphia. The hearing was on a habeas corpus taken out to prevent the relators being taken to Wilkesbarre for trial, under an indictment found against them for an assault while executing a writ in Wilkesbarre, issued by the Circuit Court.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A Communication, under the above head, in this morning's issue of your valuable journal, which derives its consequence solely from its place in your columns, contains cetain statements conserning lightning-rods, which, if uncontradicted, are liable to mislead those who, having paid no attention the subject, are not conversant with the facts.

In this City, on Tuesday, May 9. C. E. FRANCIS LANDRY, only son of Francis and Ruth Landry, aged 1 year and 10 months. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from No. 45 Anuty-st., on Thursday morning, 11th inst., at 10 o'clock. The remaine will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

Another trotting match took place yesterday at the Union Course, Long Island, for a sweepstake of $1,000, three miles and repeat, to harness, best two in three. HIRAM WOODRUFF named the gelding of Mr. SMITH, called Brimstone, and Mr. PFIEFER entered the handsome brown mare Lady Relief.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It is due to the public that they should be made aware of a recent change in the arrangements of the accommodation trains on the New-Haven Railroad. Here-??fore passengers from New-Haven could leave the cars at Harlem, if they desired to do so.

By the arrival of the brig Zeno, Captain GILCHRIST, from Montevideo, we are in receipt of news to the 25th of March, embracing intelligence of considerable interest. Gen. FLORES has been elected President, and on the 22d was installed in office.

BROOKLYN MECHANICS' EXCHANGE ASSOCIATION.--A society is being organized in this city under the above name. It is to be composed of Master Mechanics, Contractors, and others interested in the various trades. THE FEMALE INFANTRY--GREAT EXCITEMENT BUT NO SHOW.--On Monday all New-York was agog with the announcement that a corps of female infantry, a part on foot and a part mounted, was about to make its entrance into the City by way of Jersey City Ferry.

The second day's session (3d of May) was of usual interest. Dr. MENDENHALL, of Ohio, read an abstract of a report on the epidemics of Ohio, Indiana and Michigan, describing the geological features of those States, and the prevalent diseases during the years 1852 and 1853. Dr. HOLMES. of Missouri.

The Senate yesterday, after the presentation of a few memorials, talked a little while about the amendment to the Indian Appropriation bill, which proposes to pay $500.000 to the Creek Indians, for land taken from them during the War of 1812, and adjourned.

The Circuit Court has been occupied, up to Monday morning at 10 o'clock, with the case of ANN O'CONNOR vs. New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company. This is a suit for damages arising from the death of her husband, JAMES O'CONNER, on the 26th of March, 1852, by being run over by a train of cars on that Railroad, while he was crossing Railroad-avenue, in Jersey City.

So favorable a Spring as the present for agricultural operations has not been known in Texas for many years. The growing crop is in most flourishing condition. The George Law arrived yesterday morning, with dates no later than were brought the evening before from California by the Nicaragua steamer, but with interesting matter from the South Pacific Coast.
It is Anniversary Week. We are now in the midst of the Stir and bustle incident to six days of very crowded omnibuses, and very earnest efforts to make the visiting clergy as comfortable as possible.

THE LUTENER MURDER TRAIL.--The trail of Mrs. HAYES in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, for the murder of Dr. LUTENER, has now occupied one week, and is fast cating into another. Certain letters, of a very indelicate nature, which passed between Mr. HAYES and Mrs. HAYS, while the latter was in England, were yesterday produced in testimony.

It is pretty clear that the Nebraska bill is to pass. The decree has been registered, and the scenes of yesterday show conclusively that the conspirators have the power and the will to carry it into effect. No slave-driver was ever half so absolute on his own plantation, as was the President's Vice-gerent, Mr. RICHARDSON, in the House of the People's Representatives yesterday.

Yesterday afternoon, the work of raising the Calorie Ship Ericsson was successfully accomplished. Early in the day the men were busy at the pumps striving to free the ship of water, and the Boom-Derrick was brought alongside, to render the necessary aid. The vessel was nearly raised on Tuesday, when it was found that her anchors held her fast, having been cast out forward.

The modern Platform as an arena for speaking, is a valuable invention. Every man has sympathies with it. The only wonder is that it had to be invented. One would suppose, that it would have been co-existent with society. But this was not the fact. How the world ever managed to get on in its absence cannot be told, but that if did admits not a doubt.

The prospects of the friends of the Nebraska bill are not quite so bright to-day. The opponents declare they will not call for the Yeas and Nays until next Tuesday, when the Pacific Rail road bill must come up as a special order, except it be postponed by a two-thirds vote.

THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD.--The Albany Telegraph and Journal says the amount expended on behalf of the Vigilance Committee, by S. MYERS and H. TOPP, for passages and expenses of fugitive slaves, from Oct. 18 to Nov. 9, 1852, was $101 01. Late statements show that the emigration from Ireland for Australia and America is going on to a large extent. Some districts, it is said, are already nearly deserted.

CRYSTAL PALACE.--A marriage took place at the Crystal Palace yesterday afternoon. Rev. D. L. MARKS, of the M. E. Church in Bedford-streat. The groom was Mr. MERRIT SMITH of Mount Washington, Mass.; the bride, Miss ELIZABETH DIGNEAN, of Steyvesant Falls, N. Y. The ceremony took place in the picture gallery. AMERICAN INSTITUTE.--The annual election of oflicers of the Crystal Palace took place at the Institute building yesterday.

AMERICAN POETS.--The living American poets or the elder class are few in number. Within the past twelve years death has thinned their ranks by the removal of WOODWORTH, (1842.) ALLSTON, (1843,) WARE, (1843,) WILDE, (1847,) and NORTON, (1853) Of those born during the last century who survive, JAMES K. PAULDING is first in the order of age upon the list: he will be 75 years old next August.

The American Tract Society celebrated its Twenty-ninth Anniversary yesterday, at the Tabernacle. Chief Justice WILLIAMS, of Connecticut, presided. The services were opened at 10 o'clock A. M., with prayer, by Rev. Mr. SUNDERLAND, of Troy. MOSES ALLEN, Esq., read the Treasurer's report. The account of the Publishing department was read by Rev. Dr. HALLOCK, and the Colporteur department by Rev. Mr. COOK. The following are the statistical results of the year:

Dr. GROSS, of Louisville, offered the following resolution: Resolved, That a Committee of one, he appointed by the Chair, to inquire into the causes which obstruct the formation and establishment of our National Medical Literature and to report at the next regular meeting of this Association, or as soon thereafter as practicable. The President, under the resolution, appointed Dr. GROSS on said Committee.

On the 26th ultimo, a sharp combat took place before Kalafat. Twenty squadrons of Russians, with six guns, were making a reconnaissance of the Turkish lines, when the Turks sallied out with two regiments of regulars, and some bayouks and cannon, and after a combat of three hours' duration, obliged the Russians to retreat with a loss of 500 men. OMAR PASHA was at Shumla, concentrating his forces, apparently for defensive measures only.

Our village was yesterday the scene of a most disastrous fire. The Elbridge Manufacturing Company's large Knitting Factory caught fire, as is supposed from friction, at about 1 P. M., and is wholly destroyed. A strong breeze was blowing at the time, and at one time eleven buildings were on fire. We are blessed with an efficient body of firemen and good apparatus, otherwise a large part of the village must have burned.

NATIONAL ACADEMY OF DESIGN.--At the Annual Meeting of the academicians, (Wednesday evening,) after the reading of the reports of the Council, which exhibited the affairs of the Institution in a very happy and prosperous condition, the following elections of officers and new members were made: A. B. DURAND, President; T. S. CUMMINGS, Vice President; T. ADDISON RICHARDS. Corresponding Secretary; J. B. STEARNS, Recording Secretary, and F. W. EDMONDS, Treasurer.

Col. M. CANDLESS, counsel for Messrs. SHERWIN, JAQUES, KILPATRICK and KICPATRICK, the Erierioters, this morning moved that they be discharged upon the payment of the costs which have accrued since the commencement of the Erie difficulty. Judge SHALER, for the United States, opposed the discharge at present, as they were bound to answer for contempt and such other charges as might be preferred against them.

From the New-Haven Journal, of yesterday. U. S. COURT--BEFORE JUDGE INGERSOLL.--United States vs. Henry Comstock.--This was an action of debt, brought against the defendant, to recover a for feiture for breach of the revenue laws. This case grew out of the attempt made in September, 1853, to smuggle the cargo of the English schooner Mischief, which had arrived at the port of New-London in August of the same ear, loaded with wine, lead and raisins.

The Anti-Nebraska members are maintaining the struggle in the House with great firmness. The prospect is that they will sit all night, although the friends of the bill show some signs of caving in, and asking what terms would be acceptable to the minority. The minority answer: "A withdrawal of RICHARDSON'S resolution, or an adjournment until Tuesday.

The Anti-Nebraska meeting to be held in the Park this afternoon will be just in time to encourage the hearts, and renew the courage of the champions of Freedom and Public Faith in their unequal struggle against the Slaveholding interest, backed as it is by the whole power of the Federal Government.

From the Washington Union of Thursday. If the rumors which were current at Madrid at our latest dates be reliable, the Spanish Cabinet had declined to afford prompt reparation for the wrongs committed against the f1ag of the United States in the in stance of the Block Warrior. The intelligence, from the belief that it is true, is justly producing a mighty sensation throughout the Union.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Having been a "Worker" from my youth, I have heard much of the wrongs of labor, and seen not a little of the degradation of the mechanic, but I also have seen "self-culture" to be the "one thing needful;" and all reforms valuable in proportion to the aid they give to the individual.

Rev. Mr. DUNCASSON is still supplying the pulpit of the Congregational Church in Washington D. C.; and the Committee of the Church have published a card expressive of their sincere attachment to him, and. while acquiescing in the decision of the Council, they say that "the Divine blessing was resting on his labors, the audience was steadily increasing, the Church was satisfied and profited, and the prospect of ultimate success was strong, palpable and certain."

The band of Warriors among which WELLINGTON was the chief, is rapidly diminishing. After the death of "the Duke," came that of Marshal BERESFORD, who defeated SOULT at Albriera, and of Lord LONDONDERRY, one of the Peninsular commanders.

A great affair was the Congregationalist gathering of ministers, on Thursday evening, at the Mansion House, in Brooklyn. The long dining-room of that establishment was elegantly arranged with tables and seats for several hundred persons, and by 8 o'clock was crowded, not only with the clergymen-venerable and youthful--of this extensive and rapidly increasing denomination, but with an imposing force of ladies.

From the National Era of yesterday. We have received many private letters, asking why such papers as the Tribune and Era, and such. statesmen as Messrs. SEWARD and CHASE, cannot act together in one party for the defence and promotion of the cause of Freedom. The injury shows that the policy of Mr. SEWARD, and those who generally act with him, is not generally understood.

THEODORE PARKER last night gave his Anti-Slavery friends a good deal more than they bargained for, in the matter of his speech. The Tabernacle was densely crowded with a miscellaneous mass of people, of all parties, creeds, and colors, assembled to hear Messrs. PARKER, GARRISON, and PHILLIPS, who were announced to speak.

Mr. CHASE moved that when the Senate adjourn it be to Monday. Agreed. Mr. CHASE presented several petitions against the Nebraska bill. Mr. ALLEN--As there is no quorum present, I move that the Senate adjourn. Mr. WELLER--Let us have the Yeas and Nays. The list was called. during which many Senators came in. Motion lost--Yeas 10, Nays 15; no quorum.

The Nebraska excitement scarcely reaches Texas. The intelligent large planters are generally gratified and grateful to Senator DOUGLAS for his unexpected and gratuitous offer, but consider it of doubtful value to themselves in particular because the opening of Nebraska to slave-settlers would bring its lands in competition before immigrants with those in Texas, and most wealthy Texans are extensive land-owners and speculators as well as slave-owners.

KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--The Supervisors met Thursday. Supervisor DAYTON, Chair man of the Lunatic Asylum Committee, made a special report as to the condition of the finances of the Lunatic Asylum. from which it appears that on the 16th of May, 1854, the balance belonging to the Lunatic Asylum Fund was $20,962 90.

Intemperance has become so prevalent in Sweden that the Legislature is called upon from all quarters to interfere for its suppression. Even its victims, it is said, are themselves joining in the cry. The King of Sweden sympathizes with the temperance men, but hesitates in action. The temperance party there desire the entire prohibition, by rigorous statute regulations, of the manufacture of ardent spirits.

Everything that brings before us the social feelings and modes of our antecessors is read with pleasure; and that past with which we have nothing to do, and from which we look for nothing, has a curious sort of charm for our imaginations. Hence it is that old memories and family records always excite our interest.

The account is more minute, and differs somewhat from that previously published: On the night of the 28th of April the mail steamship John L. Stephens, arrived at Panama from San Francisco, with 550 passengers and $1,000,000 in treasure.

The steamer Isabel, from Havana and Key West, May 8, arrived at this port to-day. News had reached Havana from Spain, that the Spanish Government approves of the conduct of the Captain General in the Black Warrior affair. PEZUELA had published new regulations, making it lawful to search for negroes on estates.

The meeting held in the Park on Saturday, to protest against the passage of the Nebraska bill, was very respectable and influential. In point of numbers, it was not so large as it would have been, had anything like the usual preliminary efforts been made to call public attention to it.

Every precaution has been taken to prevent a riot to-morrow, on account of the street preaching O ORE. He will be allowed to preach and protected from assault by the autherities. The military will be under arms. If the Catholics make no overt act there will be no trouble.

The system of subscribing to a daily telegraph bulletin, as you would to a newspaper, is becoming quite general. The best agency of the sort is that managed by M. MONTDATAIONY. For 25 francs a month, the subscriber receives at noon each day the opening prices of the London Bourse of that morning, or the closing prices, at 8 o'clock in the evening; or, the closing prices at Vienna,

Sergeant McGuire, of the Fourth Ward, weat to clear the store, and found there a man named John Dillon, of No. 5 Oak-street, quarreling with the bar-keeper. The man, by the sergeant's orders,

In this City, on Thursday morning, May 11, after a lingering illness. Miss HANNAH WELLER, in the blissful hope of a ?? to eternal life.

We have no improvement to notice since our last circular in the Colonial and Foreign Produce Markets, which continue to be influenced by the state of Foreign Politics. SUGAR and COFFEE are steady. BREADSTUFFS firm. TEA, RICE and COTTON dull. MONEY, for short periods. continues easy. CONSOLS leave off 871/4@873/8. Bar SILVER, 5s. 1 3/8d.; DOLLARS, 5s. 1/2d; AMERICAN EAGLES 76s. 7 1/2d.

FIRES.--The alarm of fire in the Eighth District yesterday afternoon, was caused by the burning of some light goods at No. 125 Cedar-st. The firemen were early on the ground, and extinguished the frames before any material damage was sustained.....At a late hour on Friday night the slaughter house of GEORGE D. DAVIS and GEORGE JACOBS in the vi? of Ninth-avenue and Forty-third-street, caught fire.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The notice of the recent death of the Marquis of ANGLESEA, at the advanced age of 86, in the DAILY TIMES of Saturday, brings to recollection a very remarkable epitaph upon a portion of his mortal remains buried some thirty-nine years ago.

The Canada's mails bring no important additions to the summary of her news reported by Telegraph from Halifax. The English and French journals are still highly indignant against the King of Prussia, while their language towards the Emperor of Austria is much more moderate.

Editor of the Salt Lake News: ?? SIR-- I left Parowan Feb. 20, and arrived in this city on the first day or March, in company with President HENRY LUNT. Co. JAMES A. LITTLE. Major J. D. LEE, SAMUEL WEST JAMES H. MARTINEAU, SILAS and ?? SMITH, and others. We arrived in safety.

The New-Orleans mail, as late as due, has arrived, but we find no news of interest in the papers at hand. Ex-President FILLMORE and Mr. KENNEDY arrived here this morning, and were some hours in the city before their arrival was generally known. The Committee of Reception is in session this evening, making arrangements for a public reception, probably to-morrow.

Since last night the hall has been thoroughly cleansed of the two days' fifth. Members to-day are nearly all present. There was a general buzz of voices, and during the reading of the journal title knots of members gathered here and there, consulting as to future operations. Mr. HENDRICKS proposed to omit the reading of the journal, on account of its length;

ATLANTIC AND PACIFIC CANAL.--By the bark Restless, which sailed from this port for Car thagenia, New-Granada, on Thursday last, the Atlantic and Pacific Canal Company sent out a corps of Engineers, Mr. JAMES C. LANE, Chief, and WM. C. Fox, HENRY P. ADAMS, and S. LEE Perkins.

At the annual meeting of the shareholders of the New-York and New-Haven Railway Company, held at New-Haven a days since, it was stated by the President. Mr. SCHUYLER, that two hundred and fifty thousand dollars had already been paid and a further sum of fifty thousand dollar. remained to be paid by the Company, for damages to life and limb by the Norwalk disaster of May 7, 1853.

We have no mail to-night south of Petersburg, Va. A great race occurred at Petersburg on Friday, and was run in the fastest time ever made in Virginia. The heats were two miles, and the time was 3 min, 46 sec., and 3 min. 43 sec. The competitors were Fanny Fern, one Eye, Joe. Ellen Evans, and Margrave. The first named was the winner.

From the Troy Daily Times of Saturday Evening. A collision occurred on the Troy and Greenbush Railroad this morning, by the Hudson River 81/2 o'clock express train down. running into the Troy and Albany train at Bath. The latter train had started about live minute ahead of the Hudson River train, which is in accordance with the time tables.

A large and spirited meeting was held here last evening to express the public feeling in relation to the Nebraska bill. The talent and real worth of our city was largely represented. Such men as President WOOLSEY, Professors SILLIMAN and THATCHER, and Hon. R. S. BALDWIN took part in the proceedings, and the latter made a strong speech in opposition to the measure. n

ORGANIZATION OF THE BOARD OF CHOSEN FREEHOLDERS.--The new Board of Chosen Freeholders of Hudson County, numbering sixteen members, met on Wednesday, at the Court-House, for the purpose of organizing. The candidates for election as presiding officer, known by the titic of Director, were E. T. CARPENTER, of Hudson, Director of the last Board, and M. C. MORGAN, of Jersey City.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: You stated correctly in your notice of the operation of raising this ship, that "the derrick had too little lifting power to be of essential service except in raising the bow." It is somewhat surprising that Mr. BISHOP should take exception to a statement, the accuracy of which is so easily proved.

A California paper says, "for the benefit of those who have taken umbrage at recent articles in our paper, we will state that we have engaged a fighting editor, whose duties are exclusively confined to this particular branch of the editorial department. He stands seven feet in his stockings, his walking cane is a Miaie rifle, his shirt buttons are ounce balls, and he 'has killed his man.'"

To-morrow's proceedings in the House form a universal topic of conversation. There were separate caucusses last night of both Whig and Democratic opponents of the Nebraska bill. The spirit of both was firm and unyielding. They re solved that they would continue resistance to the attempted tyranny o, the majority, until the 4th of March, if necessary. hey are perfcctly willing to

Our readers will remember that during the late session of our State Legislature, there were two separate bills under its consideration which promised to relieve our City of the heavy tax inflicted on it by fires caused by design.

ATTEMPTED MURDER ON BOARD THE STEAM-SHIP WASHINGTON.--When the Southampton steamer Washington arrived at this port yesterday, one of the crew, named THOMAS DYER, was taken into custody by Capt. RACKLEWITZ, of the River Police, charged with attempting to commit murder on the high seas.

By the country papers we see that Spring has really come, and will stay a few days longer to fulfil her annual engagements. This vindicates the Almanac, which says the same thing. In town we have quite as indubitable evidences of Spring-time, as they have in the country, though of a different odor.

Mr. CRAIGE, of North Carolina, charged Mr. HUNT, of Louisiana, with being a Factionist. Mr. HUNT pronounced it a falsehood, which caused great excitement and disorder. Mr. HUNT was arrested by the Sergeant-at-Arms. It is believed that Mr. CRAIGE will send a challenge immediately. He has left the Hall.

The important event, by this arrival, is the bombardment of Odessa, the "Russian Florence," as a Muscovite writer, rather hyperbolically, calls it. This is the first serious step taken by the Allies, and one, which, should the town be captured, would have an immediate influence on the operations on the Danube, Odessa being the granary and principal depot of the Russian forces in the Dobrudscha.

The Constitution vests the war-making power in Congress; but Congress is not belligerent enough to suit the views of fillibusters and fillibustering politicians. Mr. SLIDELL, of Louisiana, has therefore introduced a resolution into the Senate of the United States which proposes to authorize the President to suspend the neutrality laws of the country whenever he shall deem it expedient--that is, to license fillibustering expeditions against Cuba, and bring on a conflict with Spain,

By the United States Mail steamer Atlantic, which arrived yesterday at 2 P. M., we have four days later news from all parts of Europe. The war news is interesting. The Atlantic has 82 passengers. The Cunard Mail steamer Europa arrived at Liverpool, midnight of Sunday, April 30. The screw-steamer Great Britain, from Liverpool, 29th April, for Australia, had returned to Liverpool having burst a flue off Holyhead.

This morning the Marquis PEZUELA, Captain General of Cuba. has issued his solemn proclamation, in the name and behoof of his Queen mistress, for the purpose of quieting public apprehension as to the eventual abolition of Slavery in the Island of Cuba "at a period more or less near, by a convention with a powerful nation,

The lost ship Winchester was chartered in ENOCH TRAIN'S Liverpool line. She was a line freighting-ship, of 1,500 tons, and was built in East Boston, three years since, by Messrs. JACKSON EWELL--Messrs. W. F. WELD Co., of this city, being her owners.

The Board of Aldermen met soon after 5 o'clock, and proceeded to business immediately. STREET CLEANING. The petitioner charged that while he had given in the lowest estimates for certain work,

Dates from El Paso to April 9, have been received at San Antonio. Gen. TRIAS has lately issued a proclamation denouncing the Lower Calfornia expedition, and calling upon his countrymen in earnest terms, to rally to the rescue of the country from a lawless band of pirates and highwaymen. The trial of Major WYSE, of the 3d Artillery, by Court Martial, for disobedience of orders, , was concluded yesterday. when the written argument for the defence was read. It is a long document, too long for publication this morning, and reviews with great thoroughness the evidence offered in the case.

The Nebraska force in the House of Representatives succeeded, yesterday, in passing a resolution to terminate debate on the bill on Saturday next at noon, and to postpone the Pacific Railroad bill until the 24th, by a vote of 114 to 59. The friends of Freedom and of Public Faith succeeded, therefore, in delaying the consummation of this iniquity only a week.

There was an interesting reunion at the Sandsstreet Methodist Episcopal Church, on Sunday evening, of the officers, teachers, and scholars connected with the Society. The house was filled at an early hour, notwithstanding the inclement state of the weather. The exercises were commenced by the choic and congregation singing the hymn:

A MAN MISSING.--A German named JOHN HENRY JOHNSON, who has for four years past been in the employment of Mr. ABRAM DURYEA, in Bergen Point, several miles south of Jersey City, started to come to Jersey City to deposit $101 80 of his earnings in the Savings Bank, on Friday last, since which, nothing has been heard of him.

The bark Springbok, arrived at this port, brings Cape Town (Cape of Good Hope) dates to the 26th March. The papers are filled with accounts of the gold discoveries, which are said to extend over the whole sovereignty. Many pure nuggets, 40 grains, had been received at Cape Town.

Rev. CHARLES L. BRACE delivered a discourse upon the "Children of the City Poor" on Sunday evening, at the Chelsea Presbyterian (Dr. SMITH's) Church, in Twenty-second-street, near Ninth-avenue. The reverend speaker selected his text from Lamentations it. 19 He stated, that notwithstanding the statistics and tales of poverty, few of us could have any conception of what it was to be a poor boy or girl.

Mr. WADE presented petitions against the Nebraska bill. Mr. SUMNER presented several series of resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts--among them one recommending the granting of pensions to :he survivors of the War of 1812, and against allowing the Amistad claim. Mr. WALKER presented the proceedings of a public meeting in Philadelphia, in favor of the Homestead bill.

A letter sent from the United States to any place in France is invariably charged with double postage when enclosed in an envelope. The fact should be remembered by those writing to their friends in that country. In order to save postage, letters should be written very close on good thin paper, and directed without an envelope. Letters without envelopes, weighing over 7 1/2 grains (1/2 of an ounce) are charged double postage in France.

We published yesterday morning a paragraph from the Washington Union, declaring in very distinct and unmistakable terms, that the accomplishment of the Nebraska scheme,--the repeal of the Missouri Compromise and the opening of all our Territories to the advent of Slavery, are necessary to the ulterior measures designed for the fortification and perpetuation of tile Slaveholding interest.

Yesterday afternoon another of the regular Spring races came off at the Union Course, Long Island, for a purse and stake of $250. This race was announced among those of the published programme, but it was the general opinion it would not take place, as many supposed Pony, (one of the horses entered,) had been sent away by his owner.

FIRE ALARMS.--The alarm of fire was at 9 o'clock, Saturday morning, was caused by the burning out of the chimney of a house in Suckett-street....At 9 o'clock on Sunday morning a false alarm was raised by some rowdies in Henry-street. Engine Company No. 4 started out and proceeded as far as Court-street, where a disturbance occurred....The liquor store kept by JOHN CAVANNAUGH, corner of Atlantic and Columbia-streets,

Our Havana correspondence this morning contains matter of a good deal of interest. The official denial of the Captain General of Cuba, of the statement that any steps are in progress, in alliance with England, for the ultimate abolition of Slavery, is given at length.

DISGRACEFUL RIOT AMONG FIREMEN.--Several disgraceful fights occurred about 1 o'clock, yesterday morning, among a number of fire companies, who were called out by a false alarm, rung for the Second District. Engine Companies No. 2 and No. 3 met at the corner of South Second and Eleventh-streets, where a disturbance was commenced. Capt. DONEVAN, and several of the First Ward officers made their appearance and put an end to the fight.

The Washington Union concludes a long article in reply to the National Intelligencer, on the Africanization of Cuba, as follows: Spain and England, and their faithful ally in the Federal city, cannot, with all their ingenuity, deceive the world into the belief that the Africanization of Cuba would be anything else but a gigantic evil, or that, once accomplished, it will ever be submitted to by the American people.

We have for some time past been in daily receipt of intelligence of wrecks and ships seen in a disabled condition out at sea. The late heavy gales have made terrible havoc among the shipping far and near. I am in a position to say to-day that the French Government, having recognized the in sufficiency of its preparations for the task it has undertaken, is silently making such additions to its armaments as circumstances will allow.

The United States Mail steamer Cahawba, R. W. SHUFELDT, Commander, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, from Mobile the 9th inst. and Havana the 12th, at 5 o'clock P. M.--making the run from the Moro to Sandy Hook in four days.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In reply to Mr. ERICSSON'S article in to-day' TIMES, I wish to say, that I distinctly stated that the ship was nearly raised when the derrick came to it, and that I made no claim to having raised her without other aid. I did all that remained to be done. Mr. ERICS

Mr. PETTIT introduced a bill to ascertain and settle a class of private land claims in Indiana. It was read and passed. He also introduced a bill for the relief of SYLVESTER M. GERAULT, of Indiana, and the same was passed.

MEETING OF THE BOARD OF GOVERNORS.--The regular weekly meeting of the Board of Ten Governors was held in the Rotunda yesterday afternoon. Present- Governors DRAPER, WEST, DUKE, TOWNSEND, SMITH PINCKNEY, HERRICK, DUGRO. Beyond the reading and examination into the requisitions from the various institutions, no business was transacted.

The defeat yesterday was brought about by DEAN, HUGHES, WENTWORTH, KITTREDGE, BANKS, SEYMOUR, EDGERTON, MACE and CHAMLAIN, who, after pledging their faith, deserted with out notice, and thus badly betrayed their trust. Had DEAN and HUGHES been true their votes were sufficient to defeat the scheme. They are responsible for the result and inexcusable.

We learn from privates sources at Havana that, at the solicitation of the United States Acting Consul at that port, the Captain General of Cuba has placed the Black Warrior and Cahawba on the same footing with the other United States Mail Steamers.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Is there not some fear that we may be in volved in a War with Great Britain? Our Government are seizing all the vessels that stow any cargo under the steerage passengers' berths, a practice permitted by our Custom-House for sometime without any objection.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: You have kindly indulged us in making our appeal to the public in behalf of the above object, will you now permit us, through the channel of your valuable pa per, to return our hearty thanks to all who have in anyway contributed to this object.

The regular weekly meeting of the American Institute Farmers' Club was held at 12 M., Tuesday. Between thirty and forty members were present. SOLON ROBINSON, Esq., occupied the Chair. The subject for the day was, " Summer Arrangement of Grave Vines and Small Fruit."

We are promised certainly a triangular, and possibly a quadrangular, contest for Governor this Fall. The Soft section of the Democratic party are to hold their nominating Convention, at Syracuse, on the 6th of September. They will undoubtedly renominate Gov. SEYMOUR, being, of course, committed to his political position, and their State Committee having formally approved of his veto of the Anti-Liquor bill.

The Third Session of the General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South assembled some days since, in Columbus, Georgia. It is the highest ecclesiastical body of this large and influential Church, and its proceedings attract great attention. About 130 members are in attendance.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Will you permit me, through the columns of you widely circulated paper, to express the sentiments gratitude I feel toward the " New-York Prison Association," and its humane and indefatigible Agent and Secretary, Mr. ADM. BEAL.

On the last day of April, 1854, a poet, who was a good, if not a great one, "shuffled off this earthy coil." To the recent necrology of distinguished men in England, we have now to add the name of JAMES MONTGOMERY, of Sheffield.

We have dates from Galveston to May 7. The telegraph wires on the line from Galveston to New-Orleans, work now to Palestine, and will be in operation through in a few weeks. The Trinity river had once more risen, but the rise was Flight. The Brazos river had risen, six feet at Washington, and steamers might go over the falls.

The Anniversary of the Young Men's Christian Association was held Monday evening, at Dr.CHEEVER'S Church in University-place, in the presence of a large and highly respectable audience. This Association was organized on the 30th of June, 1852, with a membership of about three hundred.

To the Edit of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Being intimately acquainted with the family of JOHN HENDRICKSON, Jr., and also the young man himself, I can safely say, never was there a greater bundle of false he?rds devised by the evil genius of man than by year special Albany reporter, respecting the incidents and tenor of his life, prior to his arrest on the charge of killing his wife.

FIREMEN'S RIOT--ONE MAN FATALLY IN JURED.--As before announced, Engine Company No. 12 on Sunday evening were driven from their machine in Myrtle-avenue, near Canton-street, by a well known gang of rewdies, but we have since learned that several persons were seriously injured. A young man named RANDALL was so severely injured that his life is despaired of.

A terrible explosion occurred at English Coal Pit fourteen miles from Richmond, Va., yesterday. Twenty men were in the pit at the time, all of whom were kille but one, who was taken up dreadfully injured. The pit was over 600 feet deep, and several explosions had occurred heretofore. The accident was caused by leaks from old damps. The bodies of the unfortunate men were terribly mutilated.

In Steamship Cahowba from Mobile and Havana--H. T. Livingston. lady, and servant: B. C. Lee, Rev. T. Clapp, lady and child; P. H. Foley, R. G. Darden, T. M. Jordan, T. A. Dwyer, C. A. Laird, A H. The hearing of this case was resumed yesterday morning. Mr. McKeon called attention to what he styled an extraordinary advertisement which appeared in the morning papers. He considered it his duty to do so, when anything out of the ordinary course of judicial proceedings transpired. Not only the private interests of his client, but the public interests were involved.

Debate on the Nebraska bill was resumed in the House of Representatives yesterday;--but it was conducted with but little spirit. The passage of the bill is a foregone conclusion.. As usual, the rights, interest and public sentiment of the Free States have been treacherously betrayed by some of their own representatives.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It having been stated in the published accounts of the wreck of the ship Winchester, that the life-boat sunk, and believing that great injustice may be done to Francis' Metallic Life Boats thereby, the undersigned would state, that after falling in with the wreck, P. W. KING, first officer, and four seamen, started in one of our Francis' Metallic Life-Boats, upon a most terrifie sea;

Yesterday afternoon an exciting match for $500, between two running horses, came off at the Union Course, Long Island, and was witnessed by a large number of persons. The horses entered for the contest were the imported gelding, called Emigrant Pat, by Mr. GALLAGHER, and a little brown mare called Dairy Maid, by CHARLEY HOOD.

The train on the Central Railroad, which left Albany at 10 1/2 o'clock last night, ran into a freight car on the track a mile and a half from this city, smashing the locomotive and some of the cars. Several persons were hurt, and one Irishman killed, both his legs being broken and terribly mangled.
