To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: Here is another evidence that business men do sometimes stop and think of others-even the Newsboys. The following note, and the goods, were duly received, and I esteem it a pleasant duty thus to acknowledge it. The note speaks for itself better than anything I can say.

The Anniversary of the New-York Conference Missionary Society was celebrated yesterday afternoon and evening, at the Jane-street M. E. Church. The Annual Missionary Sermon was preached by Rev. Dr. HOLDICH, at 11 o'clock. He took his text from Ezekiel, 47th chapter, 6th. 7th, 8th and 9th verses.

The London Times, in an article which we copied a day or two since, commenting on JOHN MITCHEL'S exhortations to his countrymen not to aid the English in their war against Russia, confidently asserted that the sympathies of the American people were with England and France in the pending struggle.

NIBLO'S GARDEN.-The attendance last night, we have much pleasure In stating, was literally over flowing--the occasion being Mrs. MOWATT'S farewell engagement. Half an hour before the time of performance we made an effort to procure standing room, but could not. Consequently we are prevented saying more at present. Probably on Thursday we may be more fortunate.

WARD, the murderer of BUTLER, in a card, published in another column, appeals to the public for a suspension of judgment in regard to his acquittal, until the publication of the full report of his trial shall appear.
AFFRAY AND MURDER AT A WEDDING.--On Tuesday night a wedding party assembled at the Brick maker's Hall, kept by J. KENSLER, on the plank-road about half a mile beyond the western boundary of the city.

Dr. GORDON HAKE, from London, who has recently lectured in Boston to the largest and best audiences, will deliver the first of two lectures upon the Vocal Music of England, this evening, at Dodworth's Rooms.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--The second performance of the "Merchant of Venice" attracted a crowded attendance last night. On its original production here we referred to the interpretation given to the character of the Jew by Mr. WALLACK, and indeed it is so well known to all theatre-goers, and varies so slightly on repetition, that it would be alike useless and unpalatable to refer to it continually at length.

The new American historical painting of WASHINGTON at the Battle of Monmouth, now on exhibition in this city, seems to excite much commendation as a work of art, and is certainly a production not deficient in many points of artistic merit.

THE FIRST FRUIT OF WAR.--A letter from Rev. WM. G. SHAUFFLER, of Constantinople, draws a melancholy picture of the distress which the Eastern War has already occasioned among the poorer classes of Constantinople.

From the New-Orleans Delta. To the Editors of the United States: GENTLEMEN--If I felt less confidence in the justice and magnanimity of the American people, I would not now intrude myself upon your notice. My position is one which may well be considered peculiar in the United States, where the laws have hitherto been respected, and where the verdict of a jury has been regarded as final in all criminal cases.

Messrs. GALES SEATON: The subjoined letter, taken from the Salt Lake News, and written by Mr. J. C. L. SMITH, of Paroan, is the latest account from Mr. FREMONT, although only one week later than his own letter, by Mr. BABBITT. It gives a special account of Mr. FREMONT's arrival in that valley, his departure from it, and states his full confidence in the central route.

The city of Brooklyn is blessed with many fine churches and a corresponding number of excellent divines. Her Young Men's Christian Association is reported as in a thriving condition; her Sunday schools are flourishing, and her meetings for prayer and exhortation favored, for, of a certainty, a portion of her inhabitants are in sore need of potent moral and religious influence.

In consequence of the storm of last evening, the telegraphic report for the Association, of the proceedings in Congress yesterday, is not as full as it would have been had the working of the lines been uninterrupted.

We must bespeak the indulgence of our subscribers who receive the DAILY TIMES by mail, along the line of the Erie Railroad, and in the section supplied from distributing offices on that road, for some probable delay in their receipt.

The general sentiment of the Southern Press, so far as our notice has extended, with the exception of the Richmond Examiner, which seems to be edited by a lunatic, and one or two other papers, is very earnest in its condemnation of the acquittal of WARD.

The Common Council did a thing, worthy of their name as reformers, when they passed, by handsome majorities, a resolution regulating the license of liquors. Sober men should rejoice in it, nor forget its provisions.

On the arrival of the Danville cars, yesterday afternoon, we learned of a terrible explosion and great loss of life at the "English Coal Pits," in Chesterfield County, about fourteen miles from this city, and, in order to become possessed of all the particulars, we at once repaired to the fatal scene.

By the arrival of the bark Springbok, at Boston, from Cape Town, the editors of the Traveller have received papers to the 27th of March. These papers contain additional particulars of the discovery of what mayprove to be extensive gold fields in Southern Africa.

* The country begins to look well, under the refreshing influence of frequent warm showers. Farmers have very generally commenced plowing, and in some instances, in Orange County, they are nearly through with the sowing.

The city has been comparatively quiet today, under the reaction of the excitement of the preceding week. Nebraska, by common consent, was laid aside as a topic out of doors, although speeches were upon it in the House.
A sketch of LAMENNAIS, in the May number of Putnam's Monthly, presents an animated view of the character and struggles of that distinguished man.
The Thirtieth Anniversary of the National Grays (Tenth Regiment,) was celebrated, yesterday, by a grand excursion to the village of Orange, New-Jersey. The Company looked exceedingly well.

The Minister of Public Works has made a report to the Emperor on the situation of the Pont d'Austerlitz. Several circumstances have contributed of late, to render this bridge the passage way for an immense number of vehicles, which it is not sufficiently strong to stand for any great length of time.

THE MASSACHUSETTS EMIGRANT AID COMPANY.--The corporators of the Massachusetts Emigrant Aid Company met at the Revere House. Mr. ELI THAYER. of Worcester, Chairman of a Committee appointed at the former meeting to prepare a plan of organization and also a specification of the objects of association made two reports.

The Dry Goods business remains without activity or buoyancy. The stocks on hand are ample, but they embrace but very little of ready desirable articles, which alone are in good demand at steady rates, operators thinking, and with justice, that it is a losing game to have anything to do with unpopular or inferior commodities.

SIR CHARLES NAPIER AND BALTIMORE CLIPPERS.--A letter attributed to Hon. Mr. BEDINGER, and copied into the Richmond Dispatch, describes an interview with Sir CHARLES NAPIER, who was, it will be remembered, at the capture of Washington City.

In a previous letter I have described to you the exceedingly honorable character supported by those German people of Texas who, in Europe, enjoyed the luxuries and advantages of education and wealth, and who have been driven to emigrate hither by persecutions of the police, and other misfortunes arising from their political views.

From the St. Louis Republican, of 13th. The packet Fashion arrived from Louisville last evening, bringing the first intelligence of the loss of the regular packet Pike. on the way from this port of Louisville.

It is impossible to over-estimate the importance of the Post-Office as an institution of our country. There is no one department of the public service which affects more universally the interests of the great body of the people.

The Veto of Miss Dix's "Insane bill" and the late meeting at Washington of Superintendents of Insane Asylums, brings in review before the public the whole subject of the treatment of the insane, and again suggests the query whether or not establishments for their cure are in reality of much service.

WASHINGTON NAVY-YARD.--More than usual activity prevails at the Washington Navy Yard. The great ship-house is to be extended one hundred feet, to facilitate the building of one of the six steamers recently ordered to be constructed by an act of Congress.

A MIRACLE OF THE PRESENT DAY.--Many readers may remember the appearance of Mr. Joseph BALCH, of Johnstown, N. Y., in the procession which met DANIEL WEBSTER, on his last public entrance into Boston. Mr. BALCH was born Feb. 16, 1960, and is now in the ninety-fifth year of his age.

GROWING CUCUMBERS.--The following has been tried and proved by the Scientific American: Take a large barred or hogshead; saw it in two in the middle, and bury each half in the ground, even with the top.

The bill fixing the salaries of Associate Judges in Pennsylvania, which has been hanging between the two Houses for some time, has been arranged through a Committee of Conference, and passed. The salaries are to be as follows: "For those whose attendance at Court exceeds six weeks per annum, and does not exceed twelve weeks, $150.

We have to record, beside several minor disasters, the total loss of two more packets--one, the Black Hawk, at sea; and another, the Harbeck, by burning in our harbor yesterday. In neither case were any lives lost.

A few petitions were presented. The bill for the relief of J. W. KELLY, Mail Contractor in Florida, was taken up, and after a debate as to the reason why KELLY'S contract was discontinued, the bill was passed. Mr. SHIELDS reported a bill granting the Fort Huron and Lake Michigan Railroad Company the right of way through the Military reservation at Fort Gratiot, which was taken up and passed.

In accordance with the resolution of the Common Council tendering an invitation to ex-President FILLMORE to visit this City, a Committee consisting of Messrs. FRYE, KIMBARK and BELDEN, left this City for Philadelphia on Tuesday evening to tender the invitation. Mr. FILLMORE'S engagements were so pressing that he could not comply with their request to remain in Philadelphia till to-day, so that they had but little time to make preparations.

CURIOUS.--The hours most fatal to life are thus determined by a writer in the London Quarterly Review from the examination of the facts in 2,880 cases: If the deaths of the 2,880 persons had occurred indifferently at any hour during the 24 hours, 120 would have occurred at each hour.
From the Albany Argus. Mr. HAWLEY, Postmaster at Canajoharie. Montgomery County. and a good and true Democrat, has been removed from office for "insubordination" alleged.
The same line of testimony was continued, and a number of witness were called who had voted for Cumming H. Tucker at the First District of the Twentieth Ward, in the late election.

From the Petersburg (Va.) Express. ACCOMAC C.H., Va., Thursday, May 11. Our community has again been thrown into a state of intense excitement by one of the most horrible murders that has ever come to my knowledge.

SUICIDE IN GENESEE.--A few days ago, a Mrs. SAMUEL SWIFT, of Genesee, Livingston County, committed suicide by hanging herself. It would seem, from a statement in the last Genesee Republican, that Mrs. S. first attempted suicide by bleeding herself to death and for this purpose cut a large gash in her left arm.

ESCAPE OF A PICKPOCKET--The Elmira Daily Republican states that as the night express train on the Erie road was coming west, from New-York, on Friday night, Hon. A. B. DICKINSON, of Steaban County, discovered a man picking the pockets of a lady passenger in the car.

If there was even a national anomaly, it was Ireland sixty years ago. Thronged with men eminent in every walk of life ; producing, simultaneously, the greatest orators, wits, lawyers, generals and scoundrels, of the time; preserving the highest tone of chivalric courtesy in its social circles, it yet seemed plunged into the most utter barbarism, and sustained customs that comported only with the habits of a savage nation.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Had Mr. HILTON glanced at the Albany papers issued on the afternoon of the 5th ultimo, the day of HENDERICKSON'S execution, he propably would not have used the very rude and mistaken language which disfigures his communication to the NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES of this morning.

When the English Government declared that it did not intend to issue letters of marque to privateers during the pending war, we took occasion to remark that its example would probably not be followed by Russia, inasmuch as the advantage of such a mutual surrender of what has hitherto been always deemed a lawful mode of war, would be wholly on the side of the Western Powers.

THE CONNECTICUT RIVER SHAD FISHERY. The shad-catching season is now at its height in the Connecticut river, and unprecedented fortune is attending the fisherman at the head of shad navigation under the dam at Holyoke.

New-York is getting close to every part of the South and the Southwest. About twelve hours takes us to Alexandria, Va. If the traveler is on the way to Southwestern Virginia, he can take the Alexandria and Orange Railroad any morning and proceed to Gordonsville.

At the opening of the Court yesterday the District Attorney rose and stated that, from the evidence in his possession, and given before the Coroner's Jury, it was apparent that Mr. Hays, at the time Dr. Lutener died, was in Harlem, and therefore that he should now move the Court for leave to enter a nolle prosequi in the case against Mr. Hays.

AMUSEMENTS THIS EVENING. For Particulars see our Advertising Columns. BROADWAY THEATRE.--Lady of Lyons--Box and Cox Married and Settled. WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Wild Oats--Who Speaks First NIBLO'S GARDEN--Genevieve la Sonnambula--Medina. NATIONAL THEATRE.--Steps to Crime--Blacksmith of Antwerp. BARNUM'S AMERICAN MUSEUM.--Two Performances. CASTLE GARDEN.--Jullien's Concerts. C

NIBLO'S GARDEN.--The second appearance of Mrs. MOWATT, last night, attracted another crowded attendance--quite equal to the first, and as large as the last can possibly be. One hour before the time of commencement, every available seat was occupied, and the patience of the audience until the rising of the curtain was exemplary in the highest degree.

We condense the following account of a violent storm in Indiana, from a description in the Indianopolis Sentinel of May 15th. About 7 o'clock on Saturday evening, the drizzling rain which had been falling at intervals during the day, gave way to a high wind, which between 8 and 9 o'clock swelled into a violent storm, accompanied with a heavy fall of rain, and continued with little intermission ill 11 o'clock.

An announcement of a severe shock of earthquake, felt in Vera Cruz on the morning of the 5th instant, which continued over fifty seconds, is the fitting introduction to a long account of the condition of Mexican affairs, published in the newspapers of New-Orleans, and republished in this morning's TIMES.

This is the time of year when men going into the country and seeing how green and fresh and tempting its fields look, are apt to exchange their loose money for homesteads, and straightway fall to studying the fashion of house they shall build. One in vests a dollar or two in a copy of Downing's Cottage Residences, and turns through its pages hopefully for a plan and specification to his mind.

EDITORIALS--The Nebraska Bill; Prospects and Results--THEODORE PARKER--Russia to France on the Dismemberment of Turkey--Why the Franking Privilege will not be Abolished Just Yet--The Canada's News- Females as Physicians--Personal Damages on Railways--Strides of Slavery--General Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church South--The State Elections Progress of the War--News by the Atlantic--The Nebraska Meeting--Russia and Privateering.

PRAIRIE FIRE.--The St. Anthony Express, a newspaper published at St. Pauls, Minnesota. says that the citizens of that place had for several days been "enjoying" the spectacle of a prairie on fire. When evening sets in the whole eastern horizon is belted with a wall of flame. now shooting heavenward in vivid streaks, and again bending like a low reed before the blast.

The U. S. sloop-of-war Cyane, Commander HOLLINS, arrived at this port yesterday, with Lieut. STRAIN and party on board. The Cyane left Aspinwall on the 25th of April, and Havana on the 8th. On leaving Havana the C. did not salute the Spanish authorities, owing to the belief that the Black Warrior difficulty was still in a state of abeyance.

ANOTHER OPERATION WITH THE PATENT SAFE.--Five young men from Vermont on their way to California, arrived in New-York safel, but were "sold" to the tune o. $77.--that being the extent of their pecuniary sufferings for falling into the agreeable society of three entertaining, very polite, well-deemed, gentlemanly-appearing sharpers.

It is a question among physiologists whether the heart or the capillary vessels do most toward supporting the "circulation of the blood. One would not suppose that here need be any such question. The heart does all the beating,--its thumps are recognized under the ribs every moment. If one's courage gives out, his heart fails him.

A great crowd of people assembled yesterday in the old Court of Sessions room at he Tombs, to hear the evidence in the case of burglary charged against Messrs. WILKINSON SLEIGHT, CHARLES B. ALLEN, and BENJAMIN P. MORRIS, who stood charged with burglariously entering the room of Mr. ELLIOT, No. 81 Nassau-street, and taking therefrom a trunk containing property belonging to Mr. ELLIOT.

A. resolution respecting the publication of the debates was discussed at consider able length in the the Senate yesterday, and resulted in a subscription for some five thousand additional copies of the Globe and Appendix.

Mr ETHERIDGE, of Tennessee, made a capital speech in the House to-day, on the Nebraska bill. devoting his attention mainly to an exposition of the folly and wickedness of abrogating the Missouri Compromise, and to showing that while the act is worth nothing to anybody, it is dangerous to the South, and to Southern interests. Mr. ETHERIDGE is a fluent speaker, and an able debater.

The National Intelligencer vindicates the opponents of the Nebraska bill in the House of Representatives, from the charge of "factious opposition" in having availed them selves of the rules of the House to resist and defeat the attempt to stop debate on the bill.

Mr. BRODHEAD presented the memorial of Senior ATOCHA, praying to be allowed a claim rejected by the late Board of Commissioners on Mexican Claims. The Select Committee on the subject had been equally divided on the merits of the claim. Mr. DOUGLAS laid on the table a substitute he intends offering for the bill reorganizing the Judiciary system of the United States. Ordered to be printed.

We publish this morning in full, Mr. CRITTENDEN'S argument in defence of MATT. F. WARD for the murder of Prof. BUTLER. We do this partly on account of its intrinsic interest, and partly because it presents WARD'S claim to an acquittal from the crime of murder in the strongest possible light.

This Conference assembled on Wednesday morning, in the Washington-st. Methodist Episcopal Church, and will probably continue in session from one to two weeks. At 10 o'clock a full representation was present and an organization was effected by electing the following as officers of the meeting: For President--Bishop AMES.

From the Burlington (Vt.) Free Press, of May 12. The steamboat Francis Saltus, which has run as a line boat upon Lake Champlain for some years past, was purchased last Summer by Messrs. PLATT VILAS, of Plattsburg, N. Y., for two companies who then owned and ran under one management the railroad from Plattsburg to Montreal.

RIOT AND BLOODSHED.--It could hardly have been expected, after the affair at the Third Precinct yesterday afternoon, that riot and bloodshed would not occur. When a number of men, in the exercise of their legitimate and undoubted rights, are assailed with brick bats and fired upon from the windows of an adjacent house, it is not strange that their resentment should lead to excesses and serious results.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church (Old School) met at the Central Church, in this city, this morning. About 300 delegates are present. Dr. YOUNG, of Kentucky, the Moderator, preaches the opening sermon. AFTERNOON SESSION. The Assembly organized in the afternoon. Dr. BOARDMAN, of Philadelphia, was chosen Moderator, and Professor WILSON, of Hampden Sydney College, Virginia, Temporary Clerk.

SUICIDE BY HANGING.--On Tuesday afternoon a laborer named PATRICK MURPHY, who was subject to fits of temporary insanity, committed suicide near Laurel Hill Cemetery, Queens County, by hanging himself with a cord suspended from the branch of a tree. He was in the employ of TERRENCE McGIVIGGIN, of this city, and destroyed his life while his fellow workmen were absent to dinner. Deceased was a native of Ireland, 30 years of age, and single.

AN ERRING FAIR ONE CAUGHT. - A few mornings since, some little excitement was created among the ladies attached to FRANCONI'S Hippodrome, stopping at the Merchants' Hotel, Cincinnati, by the sudden arrest of a young girl belonging to their troupe, who had arrived from New-York the evening previous.

THE FIREMEN'S RIOT IN MYRTLE-AVENUE. Seven firemen, charged with being concerned in this riot on Saturday night, were arrested on Wednesday, and were yesterday held in the sum of $500 each, to answer any indictment that may be brought against them. The boy RANDALL, injured in this disgraceful affair, was more comfortable yesterday, but small hopes are entertained of his recovery.

In this City, on Thursday morning. May 18, ALEXANDER A. POLLOCK, of the firm of Aitken Pollock aged 32 years. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to at tend his funeral, without further invitation, this (Friday) afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from his late residence, No. 231 West 16th-st.

Mr. FILLMORE meets with a high degree of attention during his sojourn among us. He was yesterday called upon by a number of personal friends and strangers, and in the afternoon sat down to a sumptuous dinner at the St. Nicholas, in company with a few friends, members of the Common Council and others. The dinner was entirely private.

The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, New School, met this morning in the First Presbyterian Church in this city. About 200 members were present, among whom were Rev. Doctors BARNES, BRAINARD and RIDDLE, of Pennsylvania; SKINNER, PARKER, SPEAR, BEMAN, SHAW and HAY, Of New York; EAGLETON, of Tennessee; and NEWTON, of Mississippi. Rev. Dr. ALLEN, of Lowe Seminary, preached the opening sermon.

The record of marine disasters has not yet reached its end. Intelligence was received in town, yesterday, of the wreck of the packet-ship Montezuma, Capt. DECOURCEY, on Rockaway Beach. The Montezuma left Liverpool on the 18th of April, just one month ago. She belongs to C. H. MARSHALL'S line, and had a large number of emigrants on board.

In this City on Wednesday Morning, May 17, at the Central Pres certain Church in by Rev. A. Aug. Wood, WILLIAM K. DIETRICH TO LOUISE VAN NOSTRAND, all of this City. In this City, on Thursday, May 18, at St. Stephen's Church, by Rev. Jos. II. Price, D. D., AUGUSTUS H. SANDS to CHARLOTTE E., daughter of George Haws, all of this City.

The eighth anniversary of the Society for the Relief of Destitute Children of Seamen took place on Wednesday at the Home for the Children of Seamen, near the Sailor's Snug Harbor, Staten island. A large number of the friends of the institution were present. The room in which the exercises were held was neatly fitted up for the occasion.

We learn that the 25th, 26th and 27th of October next have been fixed upon by the United States Agricultural Society for holding its first Cattle Convention in Springfield, Ohio. The amount of premium is $6,000, and competion to all without restriction. Twenty acres of ground have been enclosed, and more than 300 stalls will be prepared for the shelter of cattle and horses.

The Journal of Commerce, which enjoys the distinction of being the only reputable and influential paper in this City which favors the Nebraska bill, styles the TIMES an Abolition journal. The Journal professes to use language and apply epithets with some regard to accuracy; and it must be aware that in no sense of the word is the TIMES an Abolition paper.
One of the most stirring items brought by the Europa, yesterday, is the reported capture of a French merchantman by a clipper-built privateer, off Cardiff, Wales.
The new ship Commonwealth, Captain KNAPP, from Newburyport for New Orleans, went ashore at 5 o'clock this morning, in a fog, on Spit Sand, Newburyport Bar.

We are compelled to solicit the indulgence of our subscribers for a few days longer, in regard to the early delivery of the DAILY TIMES. We have been doing our best to remove all causes for complaint on this score, but the rapid increase in our circulation outstrips our utmost endeavors.

One sees many things to wonder at in riding a hundred or two miles from home in almost any direction. Suppose he rides from the greatest city on the Continent, to the capital of the greatest of countries on the globe.
OUR CUBAN CORRESPONDENCE. The U. S. Mail steamship Crescent City, H. WINDLE, Commander, arrived yesterday morning. She left New-Orleans the 11th and Havana the 14th inst.

About G o'clock yesterday afternoon, the Society of Cuban Exiles resident in this City assembled at No. 800 Broadway, and organized under their regular officers, to march in procession to the Apollo Rooms, where the evening was to be passed in celebrating the Fourth Anniversary of the landing at Cardenas, effected by Gen. NARCISSO LOPEZ and his little band, on the 19th of May, 1850.
FRANCIS GILLETTE, Free-Soil Whig, (for the short term,) and LAFAYEFTE S. FOSTER, Whig, for the long, were, this morning, elected United States Senators from Connecticut.
Events of the impending war thicken, like clouds before a gathering storm. Each is of little importance by itself :--but altogether they presage the tempest.
Yesterday, Mr. FILLMORE, in accordance with the arrangements of the Committee of Reception of the Common Council, visite 1 some of the public institutions in the City and on the Islands.

THE BELLIGERENTS.--The Washington correspondent of the Philadelphia Pennsylvanian. says: "BURTON CRAIGE, of North Carolina, I believe has no handle to his name. If he is a judge, general, colonel, doctor, or divine, I am not aware of the fact; but I do know that he is a gentleman of decided ability, of great energy of character, of unquestioned personal courage, and a soundly orthodox member of the Democratic Church.
The Herald gives notice that on and after Monday its price will be three cents per copy. As a financial operation the change will probably prove a good one. It

In this City, on Friday, May 19. JAMES HALL, (of the firm of Hall Bro.,) at his residence in Audubon Park, 157th-st. aged 44. The friends of the family, and the members of Excelsior Lodge, I. O. of 0. F., are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from Christ Church, Brooklyn, at 2 o'clock, P. M., on Sunday, 21st inst.
The Royal Mail steamer Europa, from Liverpool May 6, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock. She brings intelligence three days later from all parts of Europe.
In this City, on Thursday, May 18, by Rev. Isaac Ferris. D. D., ALFRED LOCK WOOD to MARIC LOUISE, daughter of Elias Wade. Jr., all of this City. In this City. on Wednesday. May 17. by Rev. Dr. Potts.

At the meeting of the Court yesterday, one of the jurors, Mr. DOSHER, was found to he absent, having been seized with sudden and serious illness After conversation between the opposing counsel, it was agreed that the case might go on without him.

A man called JOHN E. ELLIOTT has published me to the world as a burglar, for certain reasons which the public know nothing of, and for which I am in part left to guess. But the probable cause was that I was Chairman of a Committee to investigate certain grave charges brought against him on the part of a number of secret societies.

We have no disposition to become involved in the controversv between the Post-Office Department and the Erie Railroad Company. It is a matter of little importance to the public where the fault may be ;--the main thing desirable is to hare the evil remedied.

A letter appears in the Moniteur, of to-day, from the Baltic fleet. Sir CHARLES NAPIER was still at anchor about four miles from Stockholm. The ice was breaking up and it was expected the Cronstadt would be open by the end of April.

An adjourned meeting of the Georgraphical and Statistical Society was held on Thursday night at the University, for the purpose of hearing an exposition of the views of Mr. L. S. CHATFIELD, the late Attorney General of the State, on the Southern Railroad Route to the Pacific.

DEATH FROM HYDROPHOBIA.--GEORGE RIEHL, the young man bitten by a mad dog in the early part of April, at the tan-yard in which he was learning his trade, died at the residence of his parents, Fourth-street, below George, between 2 and 8 o'clock, yesterday morning.

The disaster to the Liverpool packet ship Montezuma, (before reported,) occurred on Jones's Beach, near the New Inlet, off Freeport--a village of the town of Hempstead, Queens County, L. I. and not on Rockaway Beach.

The House is still in session, as I write, (10 o'clock at night,) engaged in the debate on the Nebraska bill,--the best possible evidence that the time graciously allowed by the majority for the discussion, is far from being sufficient; else why would members sit until midnight to make speeches to empty halls, in order that they may get the de sired opportunity ere 12 o'clock on Saturday, when the debate is to be closed.

In the Morning Session of the Presbyterian General Assembly the Standing Committees were announced. Among the members of the Committee on Bills and Overtures are Drs. YOUNO, MUSGRAVE, McMASTIN, SILLIMAN, and Judge FINE.

The Court met at 3 o'clock, yesterday, to continue the examination of witnesses upon the charge of larceny pending against Messrs. J. W. Sleigh, C. P. Allon and B. T. Morse, for stealing moneys from .J. D. Elliot.

Mr. COOPER laid on the table, to have it printed, a substitute for the bill suspending the collection of duties on railroad iron. Mr. COOPER'S substitute proposes that, after its passage, a duty of $12 per ton shall be levied on all imported railroad iron, the price of which, at the place of manufacture, shall be $40 per ton.
The Spring Races--Trotting for Parse dan Stake of $250--The Great Pacing Match for $2,0000. Yesterday afternoon another of the Spring races came off at the Union Course, Long Island.

Thirty years ago Russia was at war with Turkey. As that event has again occurred, it is interesting to recur to the sentiments of two of the most cminent men that existed at that time, on the merils of the question and of war in general,

The Presbyterian General Assembly voted that any replies which might be made by Southern Presbyteries to the inquiries of the last Assembly as to their connection with Salvery, should be referred to the Committee on Hills and Overtures.

JULLUEN'S American campaign draws rapidly to a close. Five more entertainments only will be given, and then we lose the chef and his orchestra forever. We say forever, because we suspect the encouragement he has men with here is not of a kind to induce his return.

The Washington Union says that the DAILY TIMES "has advanced far enough in "the road to treason to propose WM. H. "SEWARD as the Northern candidate for the "Presidency." The readers of the TIMES are, of course, aware that the Union's statement is utterly untrue.
The propeller Kent, with a cargo of three hundred tons of goods, was entirely destroyed by fire last night on the Canadian shere of Lake Eric. The crew are supposed to have escaped in the boats.

We are compelled to solicit the mauigence of our subscribers for a few days longer, in regard to the early delivery of the early delivery of the DAILY TIMES. We have been doing our best to remove all causes for complaint on this score,
The Charleston Courier publishes a letter from Mexico, dated on the 5th inst., which states that SANTA ANNA had reached a village near the City, where Madame SANTA ANNA had gone to join him.
Twelve thousand four hundred emigranis landed at this port on Friday, before a late breakfast hour. Most of them go directly on to take possession of the rich lands that invite them to the West.

It is very seldom that we meet with a book of travel and adventure so deserving of an attentive perusal, as this volume of Mr. PECk's. It is one of the few works of its class which are really worth a prominent place on our bookshelves, not more for the novelty of their interest, than for the vivacity and attraction of their style. The opponents of the Nebraska bill held a caucus last night, and determined to fight it out to the last, using the usual " Parliamentary expedients," and, when the bill is reported to the House, calling the Ayes and Nays,

A new Daily made its appearance on Monday--La Civilization. This is the most serious attempt yet made in newspaper enterprise of late, for the new journal, besides being daily, is of full size, and presents a positive commercial and industrial interest.

UNDERGROUND RAILROAD AGENTS CAPTURES. --Some weeks ago we copied from the Sandwich (Mass.) Adrocale the announcement that a schooner had arrived at Watchman. from this port, with two slaves who succeeded in making their escape, and that it was supposed that the steward of the vessel assisted in getting them clear.

Since SANTA ANNA left for his army, there has been a suspension of new decrees he was in the habit of publishing daily, but they have issued one prohibiting the introduction into any port. except that of Vera Cruz., of books permited by law--the decree to go into effect four months after its date or publication, which was about the 20th ult.

Senator EVERETT has written the following letter to Governor WASHBURN: BOSTON, Wednesday, May 18, 1854. SIR: I regret to have to inform you that I am under the necessity of resigning my seat in the Senate of the United States.
The following is the Weekly Report of deaths in the City and County of New-York, from May 13 to May 20, 1854: Men, 75; Women, 68; Boys, 136; Girls, 115. Total, 394:
A story is going the rounds about a steamer on Lake Ontario, whose helm suddenly refused to answer to the wheel. The man at the wheel have lustily, but not an inch could he move it.
I telegraphed you, this morning, that etters from Havana had just been received here, indicating that the Island of Cuba is at the present time struggling amid the throes of Revolution.

BROOKLYN FEMALE HOME MISSIONARY SOCIETY--The Seventh Anniversary of this Society was celebrated on Friday evening at the Cemennary M. E. Church, in Johnson-street. Bishop AMES presided, and an able address was delivered by Rev. Dr. PECK.

The propeller Rent, with a cargo of 300 tons of goods, was entirely destroyed by fire last night, on the Canadian shore of Lake Erie. The crew are supposed to have escaped in the boats.

However preseveringly France and England have exerted themselves at Vienna, to counteract and overcome the influence of Russia there, they have not yet succeeded in obtaining anything but diplomatic replies to their propositions and queries.

Voting on the Nebraska bill Will De at tempted to-day. Appearances indicate that the opponents of the bill will make a firm and determined resistance to the vote being taken at present; and it is quite probable that the majority will be compelled to ride over all the rules and all Parliamentarylaw, in order to accomplish their object.

MESSRS. EDITORS: The Santa Fe and El Pasco mail, in charge of Capt. B. DAILEY, arrived here on the morning of the 26th. The news from Santa Fe is of a very exciting character. A desperate fight occurred at Taos, New-Mexico, between two companies of United States dragoons, under command of Capt. MAGRUDER and Lieut. DAVIDSON, and a large party of Apache and Utah Indians, (about 300 warriors).

From the Newark Mercury. It will be seen by the proceedings of the Common Council last evening, that the ordinance reported by the majority of the Special Committee on the Fire Department was adopted, and that, consequently, from this time forth, Newark may be ranked among those cities which, after full consideration, have adopted a paid Department.

MURDER IN SAVANNAH.--At about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, two men, named JAMES TUELL and CHARLES GRIFFITH, having had some previous misunderstanding, accidentally met in Liberty-street, when the old quarrel was renewed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. At the close of your very just remarks on RICHARDSON'S report of the WARD Trial Yesterday, You say: "While all the speeches for the defence are given at length. Only one is given at all for the prosecution, and that is Mr. ALLE'S.

From the Savannah Georgian. At the way things have been going on in our city for the past few months, Savannah bids fair soon to become quite as notorious in character for crime, from petty theft to bloody murder, as she has so long justly sustained as a city of good order and thrifty enterprise.

With feelings of unulterable sorrow, we announce that the noble and world renowned structure, the Wheeling Suspension Bridge, has been swept from its strong holds by a terrific storm, and now lies a mass of ruins.

THIRD DAY. Rev. Mr. WELLS, of the Dutch Reformed Church, stated that the Church had now 340 churche;, and 40,000 members. Communications were received from the Congregationalists of Boston, through Dr. ELDRIDGE: also, from the Association of New-hampshire, through Dr. SAVAGE; from the General Conference of Maine, through Dr. SHEPLEY, and from the General Conference of Rhode Island, through Dr. ALEXANDER.

[Friday's proceedings concluded.] After our report closed last night, Mr. PRINGLE indicated his opposition to the repeal of the Missiouri Compromise. Mr. HOME obtained permission to print a speech against the Nebraska bill. mr. GREENWOOD spoke in favor, and Mr. SEYMOUR aginst the measure.

The Hermann arrived off Cowes at midnight on the 6th inst. After coaling at Southampton, she proceeded to Bremen on the 8th.

The CHAIR presented a letter from Mr. EVERETT, notifying the Senate that he had sent to the Governor of Massachusetts his resignation as Senator, to take effect from 30th of June next. Mr. SMITH presented resolutions of the Legislature of Connecticut, on the subject of the Nebraska bill, the repeal of the Missouri Compromise, The resolutions were read.
The report of yesterday's proceedings in Congress is well worth reading. In the Senate TRUMAN SMITH gave Gen. CASS a fresh opportunity to define his position on the Wilmot Proviso.

PETERS, Esq: Dear Sir: I cannot submit the following observations upon the effect which a change in the political condition and relation of Cuba, would have upon the commercial interests of New-Orleans, and the agricultural interests of Louisiana, to anyone with greater propriety than to yourself.

This body assembled at 8 1/2 o'clock, A. M. The proceedings commenced with a prayer by Rev. Dr. BANGS. Bishop JANES presided. ELI BARRET, a local preacher, sent in an appeal, and his case was sent to the Quarterly Conference for a new trial. Rev. Dr. FLOY was selected to preach the Missionary Sermon on the first day of the next Annual Conference. Mr. NICHOLAS ORCHARD was admitted into full connection.

The following is a telegraphic dispatch per Franklin, from RICHARDSON BROS., of Liverpool, to SAMUEL SMITH, Liverpool and Philadelphia Steamship Company, Philadelphia. It was put on board by J. R. CROSKEY, U. S. Consul at Southampton, as we were leaving Cowes: J. C. KANE, Purser.

Probably your readers have been informed of the difficulties that have grown out of killing a few wild pigs on one of the Falkland Islands, by American whalemen, and as it is possible that a friendly correspondence will ensue between Great Britain and the United States, a more particular account of the affair may be acceptable and in the first place, of the Islands themselves.

SUNDAY SCHOOL CELEBRATION.--The twenty fourth anniversary of the Sunday School of this city, will be celebrated to-day in different churches, as follows: Central Baptist, Bridge-street; Sands-street; Methodist; First Baptist, Nassau-street; First Reformed Dutch, Jo.alem n-street; Pierre??t, Baptist; South Presbyterian, Clinton-street; First Presbyterian, Remsen-street; Second Presbyterian, Clinton-street; Plymouth Congregational, Carlton-avenue; Methodist, and Central Congregational.

At a meeting of the Stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, this morning, the Board of Directors submitted a report relative to the purchase of the Main line, stating that $3,000,000 would be required for the removal and repairs of the Road and Canal, and they estimate the total value at only $7,000,000.

A meeting of merchants was held in the Exchange Reading-Room to-day, in relation to the recent rescue of lives from disasters at sea. B. A. GOULD called the meeting to order. THOMAS B. CURTIS was chosen Chairman, and ALPHEUS HARDY Secretary.

ARRESTS.--PATRICK McGONICAN was arrested on a change of stealing from CASPER PAITZ, a newly-arrived German emigrant, the sum of $31 in gold and silver coin. PAITZ was about proceeding with his family by the Erie Railroad, and paying his fare, when the money was snatched from his hand by the accused. He was arrested by Officer SLATER, of the Third Ward.

EDWARD EVERETT is about to withdraw from the Senate and from public life. The country will feel his loss. With him will depart from the public councils more of high-toned, accomplished and disciplined statesmanship, than has been for many years embodied there in any other individual. He is not at home in the turmoil of political contention.

The fact is revealed by the late British Census (of 1851) that of 290,000 women under the age of 45, in one of the ten divisions, only 170,000 were wives--the 120,000 remaining being widows or spinsters; and from 1841 to 1851, only 10 children were born to every 58 women under 15 years.

THE WARD CASE.--The excitement in Kentucky, regarding the WARD case appears to be spreading and gaining strength. Public meetings are being held in various portions of the State, at which not only the WARDS and the jurors, but all who were at all prominent in their favor, seen to be indiscriminately condemned.

Three weeks of the month of May were ended Sunday night. During those three weeks, 429 vessels from foreign ports entered here, bringing to our midst 48,054 passengers. A very large proportion of these seek with us a home--a new home.

That such out-door preaching as assembled loafers and gentlemen of leisure generally are apt to get on Sundays from the City Hall steps, is a nuisance, and an offence against-good morals, we do not doubt. But, though it is the occasion of many rows, it is not so bad as it would be to put improper restraint upon Free Speech.

In this City, on Sunday, May 21, Mrs. MARY DOANE, widow of the late John Doane, in the 73d year of her age. The friends of the family and of her son, John J. Doane, are invited to attend the funeral at the house of her son-in law, Ezra Dennison. No. 135 West 24th-st., on Tuesday, May 23, at 2 o'clock P. M.

The deed accomplished! The Nebraska bill is passed--as I predicted, when the lamentable failure of last Wednesday occurred. The majority found no difficulty in passing it after getting the aid of its opponents to take it up.

ROWDYISM.--There was quite a turn-out of the rowdy portion of the community during Saturday night and Sunday morning, in the First and Second Wards. The police were so few in numbers (five on duty in each Ward.) that they were unable to prevent fights or unoffending citizens from being attacked and beaten.

The pilot boat George Steers, Cpt. LEWIS, from 'Omoa, Honduras, Central America, arrived in the lower bay yesterday, bringing the following passengers, who left on the steamer Wm. Jones Jr., in the evening, en route for Washington city: General JOSE BARREMDIA, Minister to Washington, wife and son; Don SOTERO LASSO, Secretary of Legation: AMONY EDWARDS, of New-York: HEIMAN SCHMIDT, of Brunswick, Germany; CHARLES FOLLEN and Miss FOLLEN, of Omoa.

The Board met pursuant to adjournment. In the absence of EDWIN J. BROWN, Esq., the President. Councilman F. E. MATHER was elected President Pro. tem. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. The Board received and referred the following PETITIONS. Of Jacob Sharp--To have Forty-second-street regulated and graded from Ninth to Eleventh-avenues.

ARRIVAL OF A BOSTON ICE-SHIP AT MADRAS.--STATE OF THE CARGO.--The American bark Piscataqua, from Boston, has arrived at Madras. She will already have attracted the notice of all whom business or pleasure has drawn to the beach, where she presents the curious appearance of a vessel on her beam ends and about to sink. She left Boston nearly five months ago in good trim, and filled with ice, for Madras.

The Assembly, after a warm debate, broke up the large Synod of Philadelphia, making a new Synod out of the Presbyteries of Baltimore, Carlisle and the Eastern Shore, to be called the Synod of Baltimore.

The New-York East Conference met again yesterday, Bishop AMES presided. The further consideration of the Slavery Resolutions was postponed. Dr. CURRY moved that the Conference proceed to the choice of a place for the next meeting. He recommended the city of Bridgeport, Ct.

From the Philadelphia Ledger. A DARING PROJECTOR.--The Southern Standard, published at Charleston, S. C., deserves the palm for having conceived the most gigantic of all the schemes of fillibusterism and "manifest destiny" yet projected. In a late article it holdly advecates the seizure of Cuba, the conquest of Hayti, and the entering into a close alliance with Brazil to control the Amazon, the West Indies, and the rest of the American tropical regions.

The proprietor of the New-York Herald proposes to raise the price of this journal to three cents per copy, beginning with Monday next. He has been induced to take this step in consequence of the great increase in the cost of paper, presses, type, materials and labor of all kinds, which has taken place during the last few years.

FIRE IN PACIFIC-STREET.--At 11 o'clock Monday evening, a fire, supposed to be the work of an incendiary, occurred in a stable on Pacific-street, near Hicks, occupied by Mr. PARKS, and owned by J. H. MILLER. The flames spread to an adjoining black smith's shop, occupied by MOORE MURPHY, and owned by GEORGE A. PATCHEM.

From the Albany Evening Journal. The crime is committed. The work of MONROE, and MADISON and JEFFERSON is undone. The wall they erected to guard the domain of Liberty, is flung down by the hands of an American Congress, and Slavery crawls, like a slimy reptile, over the ruins, to defile a second Eden. They tell us that the North will not submit. We hope it will not.

The special messenger from Minister SOULE brings nothing new in relation to the Black Warrior affair. Mr. SOULE is on excellent terms with the Court at Madrid, whatever may be the case with the Minister of Foreign Affairs. It is now quite certain that he will neither be recalled or voluntarily return. He will stay and finish the acquisition of Cuba.

Dr. Mellen's Lectures on the Colored Race. Dr. G. W. F. MELLEN, of. Boston, delivered the first of his Course of Lectures on the Colored Race, in Hore Chapel, last evening, in which he gave his theory of "the cause of color as it appears in the different races of men."

Mr. TOUCEY said that yesterday his colleague presented certain resolutions of the Legislature of Connecticut, which he regretted were presented in his absence. By the debate which sprung up on the resolutions, he perceived that his colleague had fallen into an error, as he naturally would in speaking of the action and sentiments of the Democratic party. His colleague was not very intimate with the wishes and sentiments of that portion of his constituents.

ASSOCIATE PRESBYTERIAN SYNOD.--The Supreme. Judicatory of the Associate Presbyterian Church of North America is to meet in Albany on the 24th day of May, at 4 o'clock P.M., and continue its sessions by adjournment, probably for a week or ten days. Several matters of very considerable importance will engage the attention of the Synod.

WHAT FALLS!--It is very surprising, says a late writer, that two of the greatest natural curiosities in the world are in the United States, and scareely known to the best informed of our geographers and naturalists; the one is a beautiful fall in Franklin, Habersham Co., Georgia; the other, a stupendous precipice in Pendleton district. South Carolina.

HENRY J. RAYMOND, Esq., Editor N. Y. Daily Times: SIR: Though unknown to you except in the most unfavorable light, I have taken the liberty not only of addressing you, but of asking of you a simple act of justice.

THE PAY OF DOCTORS AT THE STATION. HOUSES.--In the Marine Court, yesterday, before Judge PHILIPS, the question of the recompense of physicians who are called to attend patients at the station-houses, was called up. Dr. JOHN SIMONS sued the Corporation for remuneration for-services rendered at the Sixth Ward Police-station.

There Indians came to the camp of an emigrating, arts, and being somewhat intoxicated from spirits sold to them by the whiles, got into a squabble, and the Indians were expelled. The emigrants soon started a story that the Indians attempted to murder and reb them. The account continues:

A project of a treaty for the adjustment of the fishing question and the establishment of reciprocity of trade between the United States and the British North American Colonies was agreed upon, recently, by Mr. MARCY and the British Minister, Mr. CRAMPTON, and submitted to the British Government. The project was assented to by the British Government upon the condition of its acceptance by the Coionies whose interests are to be affected by it.

SANTA ANNA has been trying the late President WALKER'S game. It seems by our New-Orleans dispatch, that when he had led his men entirely within the trap set for him by his adversary, he summoned Acapulco to surrender. It reminds one strongly of the roving President, who, from the extreme northwestern corner of Lower California, ordered Sonora to be annexed to his baby Republic--and it was annexed.

JULLIEN ha! a splendid house Monday evening, perhaps the fullest of the season. Considering the time of year and the few visitors in the City, this is gratifying as it proves that the musical public of New-York is sufficiently strong to support JULLIEN, and willing to do so now that he is appreciated.

THE UTILITY OF FOREIGN MISSIONS. The Old School Assembly, in session at Buffalo, has discussed the subject of Foreign Missions with much earnestness. We quote from the Buffalo Commercial's report: Rev. Dr. LOWRIE drew the attention of the Assembly to the fact, that at almost all points there is an urgent call for more laborers in connection with the various missions.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: In the TIMES of this morning your correspondent "S.," writing from Washington under date of May 21, has something to say about the transportation of the mails over the Erie Railroad, and seems disposed to censure the course which the officers of that Company have seen fit to adopt in the transaction of their own business.

The New National Course--Public Meeting to Organize the National Jockey Club. Since the purchase of several acres of land on the Willett Farm, situated in the vicinity of Newtown, L. I., by Messrs. BOYDEN Co., who have commenced building a new track for turf sports, a lively interest has been manifested for the ultimate success of the great enterprise.

The following list consists of prominent Rouses in each line of Business: DRY GOODS. American and Foreign silks. BOWEN. McNAMEE CO..(Importers and Jobbers,) 112 Broadway. A. EDWARDS CO. (Imot's and Job.)9 and 11 park-place. French, Swiss and German Dry Goods.

A BLOODY DEED.--A one-armed desperado, named J. B. HORTON, came into the counting-room of the Picayune office yesterday morning and demanded a paper. SANDY, the well-known negro belonging to the office, informed him that there were no papers to spare, there were scarcely enough to make up the mail. HORTON immediately commenced cursing him, and sprang over the counter to get at him.

PARTICULARS OF THE BURNING OF THE SHIP HOPE GOODWIN--CREW IN IRONS.--On Friday night, says the Mobile Register, of the 15th, a calamity occurred in the lower anchorage that on Saturday morning created the deepest excitement in all our mercantile citizens. The mail boat reported that a ship was burning at her anchor, and close to the water edge.

The Texan papers teem with accounts of Indian outrages, and with loud calls on the Government to send more troops for the protection of our Southwestern frontier. We have no doubt that these savages commit frequent depredations on the property of the settlers, and that more effectual steps ought to be taken to check them.

A GREAT FEAT AND NARROW ESCAPE.--On Saturday, two young men, college students, about eighteen years of age, went out in a skiff over the bay on a shooting excursion. During the day they went round Lighthouse Point, and when they desired to return, were prevented by a strong head wind. All attempts to round the point being fruitless, they had to resign themselves to the control of the elements.

SIR: As you are aware a telegraphic message arrived in town Wednesday afternoon at about 3 o'clock, addressed to the Union Fire Company, asking their services to assist in extinguishing a most destructive fire which had broken out in St. Hyacinthe. Shortly after, another was addressed to the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, also praying assistance.

A MYSTERY SOLVED--Quite an excitement occurred during the past week at Altona, Pa., from strange noise having been heard in a graveyard, leading to the susposition that a lady who had recently been interred had come to life after burial. Several persons heard noises from the grave, and a crowd assembling. it was deemed preper to dismer the coffin.

A GENTEEL SWINDLER.--The Brandon (Miss.) Republican of the 11th inst. has an account of a "nice young man" who recently made his appearance in that quiet town, and who has, within a few days, honored this city with his presence.

THOMAS RITCHIE Jr., one of the editors of the Richmond Enquirer, died on Sunday evening last. The Washington Sentinel, speaking of the deceased, says: " For several years he has been in feeble health, and for many months his friends have been convinced that he could not long survive.

Our Postmaster General ought to have the sympathies of the country. The present mail system is behind the age, and that is a bad place to occupy. It allows the age to throw the Government, acting through this great machinery, into the shade, and even to direct a kick towards it in moments of irritation. The chief officer of the Department, whatever his merits, gets the blame, but things remain pretty much as they were.

Meeting of Workingmen at the Tabernacle. A demonstration of the Workingmen of New York, in favor of Union or Association of the graftsmen of all trades was held last evening at the Tabernacle. There were present upon the platform delegates from different Labor Associations, amounting in number to six: Plasterers, Carpenters, Plumbers, House Painters, Stone Cutters, and Bricklayers.

In the City, on Tuesday morning. May 23, by Rev. Dr. Potts. Hon. EDWIN J. BROWN to MARIETTA, daughter of the late David Strong, of Geneva. In this City, on Thursday evening, May 11, at the Carlton House, by Rev. Mr. Vandoren, Mr. CHARLES A. CORNELL, of New-York. to ROSALIA J., daughter of Almond Ticknor, Esq., of Massachusetts.

By way of New-Orleans and the telegraph we have a fortnight later news from California. The United States which brings it, brought also 100 passengers, and reports 400 others coming by the Illinois. Col. FREMONT had arrived weary with long wanderings and his party broken up.

Soon-after meridian yesterday, the people of this city and Georgetown were thrown into a state of painful excitement by a report that one of the bridges which connect the two cities had fallen in, carrying with it two passenger omnibuses, with their human freight. An apprehension that it was the high upper bridge was equivalent to a belief that all must have perished. But severe as was the accident, it was marked with wonderful preservation.

As has been seen, in the report of Mr. GLADSTONE'S speech in the British House of Commons, which we published yesterday, John Bull is already beginning to feel that what is called Glory is rather a costly thing. A surplus in the Treasury of $17,000,000 over the last year's expenditure, has melted away like a mountain snow-wreath under sunshine. A loan of $30,-

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I must respond to your notice of our markets in this morning's paper. I entertained a friend from Philadelphia a short time since, for whom I was glad to spread a very nice table. She praised my housekeeping, and expressed a desire to see our markets. You know it is a common thing for strangers to be taken through the Philadelphia markets.

STRANCE SUPERSTITION.--The Norwich (Ct.) Courier relates a strange and almost incredible tale of superstition recently enacted at Jewett City in that vicinity. About eight years ago, HORACE RAY, of Griswold, died of consumption. Since that time two of his children, grown up people, have died of the same discase, the last one dying some two years since.

We have already noticed that one line of omnibuses in the City has adopted a cheap fare, giving a ride hereafter at three cents instead of six; The latter has for many years been the settled, standard price for a ride of any respectable length in any carriage painted yellow, that lumbered along on four heavy wheels, and had its door in the stern. But this innovation is likely to produce a revolution.
From the Charleston Evening News. Among the expedients by which the Washington Union proposes to redress our wrongs, if Spain does not give us prompt reparation, is a blockade of the Cuban ports.

In San Francisco. April 13, Mrs. Charlotte M. Fisher, wife of Mr. Prince Fisher, aged 43 years, late of Nautucket, Mines. On the 15th ult., from injuries received from the explosion of the steamer Secretary, Cecelia, wife of J. B. Clark, Esq. late of Green Point, New-York, aged 40 years.

The North Star brings a plethoric budget. Our columns swell with a satiety of news from all quarters of her importation. The most engrossing matter-the one to which page after page of the San Francisco papers is surrendered-is the trial of the Mexican Consul, Senor DEL VALLE, at that port, for breach of the neutrality laws, in having enlisted a number of French and Germans to serve in the Mexican army.

List of Patents issued from the United States Patent Office for the week ending May 23, 1854--each bearing that date: Joseph Burch, of Cragg Hall, near, Macclesfield, England, for improvement in constructing ships for safety and escape.

Smaggling Liquors through the Custom House--Important Scizure of the Property at a Distillery--The Officer of a Bonded Warehouse Saspended from Duty. The Custom-House Officers of our City were in a state of great excitemen during yesterday, in consequence of the recent perpetration of a heavy frand on the United States Revenue, by the smuggling of Malag a wines and brandies, amounting to some forty easks.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: If it be true that the free population of Cuba are up in arms against the tyranny of Spain, it must be evident to all that whatever may be the result of the contest, the American Government cannot much longer avoid the consideration of the Cuban question, or forbear coming to a decision in regard to it.

The Royal Mail steamship America, Captain LANG, from Liverpool on Saturday the 13th instant, arrived here at 7 o'clock this morning, and sailed again at 8.15 for Boston, where she will be due at an early hour on Thursday evening.

In this City, on Wednesday, May 24, at the Astor-place Hotel, by Rev. Dr. Potts, Capt. G. B. WATERMAN, of ship Highflyer, to Miss SARAH T. BULKELEY, daughter of John T. Bulkeley, Esq., of Colchester, Conn. In this City, on Thursday morning, May 18, at the Church of the Holy Communion, by Rev. Dr. Muhlenberg, Mr. JOHN CAWOOD to Miss JANE AULT. all of this City.

MEETING OF LIBERAL SOCIETIES.--Another union meeting of Liberal Societies was held at Pythagoras Hall, in Walker-street, last evening. About fifteen native and foreign societies were represented, includig the Free Democratic Society of Universal Republicanism, Italian Democratic Society, Polish Democratic Society, German Democratic League, Union for Social Reform, German American workingmen's League, French society Le Montagne, Cuban athenaeum, and several others.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Can you explain the Herald's back and forward movements in regard to raising its price ? One day he announces his refusal to stand still. To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have just finished a close perusal of the APPLETON pamphlet upon the WARD trial. I had previously abstained from reading the telegraphic and newspaper reports, because I understood in advance, from a professional friend in Louisville, that a stenographic report would be published.

The subject of Romish baptism came up again in the afternoon, and drew forth a few strong speeches. Mr. DOBIE read extracts from the Romish Catechism, to show the radical differences between the baptism of that Church and baptism of the New Testament.

From the London Leader. The present moment seems favorable for a survey of the warlike operations which have been effected with-in the last six weeks. In this City, on Wednesday morning, May 24, Mrs. ADELINE G. BALCH, wife of Rev. Wm. S. Balch, aged 45 Years The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, which will take place this afternoon, at 3 o'clock, from the church corner of Bleecker and Downing-sts. The details of the California Mining and Market accounts to May 1 were received this evening by the North Star, of the Vanderbilt line, from Panama.

FLEET SAILING. -- The clipper ship Flying Cloud, it was reported by telegraph, had made the run out from New-York to San Francisco in 88 days! This is the quickest trip ever made between the two ports, beating even the same vessel's previous remarkable voyage, of 89 days and 16 hours duration, which, until the last trip noticed above, was the swiftest on record.

From the Washington Star. LIEUTENANT BONAPARTE.--We understand that this gentleman, who is attached to the Mounted Riflemen, (United States Army,) has obtained leave of absence from the War Department for the purpose of visiting Europe.

SHIP BUILDING AT GREEN POINT.--Mr. WM. PERRINE has just laid the keel of a clipper ship for Messrs. HARBECK Co., which is intended for the general freighting business. She will be 200 feet keel, 43 feet beam, 291 feet deep, and about 1,800 tons measurement.

REPORTED LOSS OF ANOTHER FINE CLIPPER SHIP.--A telegraph dispatch, dated at London, May 13, received in this City from one of the first houses in that city, states "that the ship Oriental, of New-York, was lost at Foo-chow-foo, China." The Oriental, Captain FLETCHER, was at Foo-chow-foo on the 15th of February, loading leas, , for New-York.

In For sign Bills to-day, owing not so much to the limited supply as to the rise in the rate of interest on the other side, and the advance, just announced, of 1/8 ?' cent. in the insurance upon specie, and a contemplated advance of 1/8 ? cent. on the freight charge on specie.

The following are the remarks of Senator SEWARD on Thursday night, during the debate in the Senate on the Ne-braska bill: Mr. PRESIDENT: I rise with no purpose of further resisting or even delaying the passage of the bill. Let its advocates have only a little patience, and they will soon reach the attainment of the object for which they have struggled so earnestly and so long.

The Crescent was in the ascendant yesterday. All that was not eclipsed on the sun's disk shone out as a luminous quarter, leaving the sky with the hue of twilight, while the thermometer fell ten or twelve degrees. The performance attracted a large audience. Indeed, we do not recollect seeing a larger concourse of people who evinced less enthusiasm.

SINGULAR ATTACHMENT.-Upon Col. KING's plantation, near this place, there is a certain old gander, so attached to one of the milch cows that he follows her wherever she goes. He has been seen plodding at her heels several miles from home, never permitting her to escape his sight. When caught and confined, he displays the greatest uneasiness, and never ceases his squalls until he finds the object of his devotion.

During the sitting of yesterday afternoon, a long and interesting report was read by Rev. Dr. EDDY. of Newark, from a Committee appointed last year, on Legal Rights, Claims and Liabilities of the General Assembly. It first gave a sketch of the early history of the Assembly; that it sprung originally from a single Presbytery. This Presbytery, in 1705, was divided into four, which were constituted into a Synod of New-York and Philadelphia in 1717.

MYSTERIOUS.--A gentleman came on the cars from the East, and put up at the Exchange Hotel in this city, on the 13th of April last, entering his name on the register as "H. M. BATES." He was unwell when he arrived, and continued to grow worse until the 13th inst., when he died. His disease was typhoid fever. His at tending physician was Prof. ALLEN, who counseled with other able physicians in the city.

In this City, on Friday morning. May 26, HENRY FRANKLIN FLAGG, only son of A. C. Flagg. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Sunday, 28th inst., at 1 1/2 o'clock, P. M., from the residence of his father, No. 3 London Terrace. (West 23d-st.,) without further invitation.

SILVER MINE IN HOOKSETT.--The Manchester Mirror states that quite an excitement has arisen in that vicinity, by the report that a silver mine is being worked in Hooksett, a town seven miles distant. The editor of the Mirror says the real circumstances of the case are these: On the west side of the river, at Hooksett, is Pinnacle mountain, a high elevation, whose summit is mostly covered with rocks and trees.

We crossed the Medina in returning from a trip to the Rio Grande, last Saturday morning, and hesitated whether we should not turn from our road and follow it up to the ranch of an Irish gentleman, who has one of the largest flocks of sheep in Texas, which he had invited us to look at. 'Preferring, however, to spend Sunday in town, we fortunately concluded to postpone our visit.

The remainder of the second day, as reported by the papers of Troy, was devoted to the examination of Mrs. LANNAGAN. Her testimony (that in addition to what we have already published,) was chiefly a description of the manner of her husband's death; the circumstances which immediately succeeded it, and how long she had known the prisoner at the bar.

I have just left the Senate chamber, where the Nebraska iniquity was consummated a few minutes since ; and, as I write, the roar of cannon from Capitol Hill s peaking the joy of those who have accomplished it. The work is finished.

She lives in handsome style at Grass Valley, where she has a pretty cottage.

THE GREAT SEA SERPENT--Capt. SEABURY, of the ship Mechanics' Own, which arrived here on the 17th inst., informs us that Feb. 1, in lat. 40? S., Ion. 39? 4? W., he saw something lying upon the water, with its head out, which very much resembled a serpent. When first seen, it was forward of the ocean of the ship, about fifteen yards distant.

One of our correspondents at Constantinople gives the following interesting items of information under date of April 20: The order of the Government, driving the Greeks from the country in fifteen days from the 1st of April, caused the utmost suffering among that class of the population.

The Ladies' City Missionary Society of the M. E. Church, in Newark, celebrated its anniversary on Wednesday. The Mission has had under its care during the past year 60 church members, 11 probationers, 4 Sabbath schools, 315 scholars, and 35 officers and teachers. The Warren-street Church is progressing and the Missionary has been liberally encouraged in his labors.

THE NEW-YORK DIRECTORY FOR 1851-55. --The New-York City Directory for the year 1851 55 was laid upon our table last evening. It is published by CHARLES R. RODE, (late of the firm of DOGGETT RODE,) and is issued with a degree of promptitude that is quite remarkable ; particularly in New-York, where things of importance are somewhat given to lagging.

To the Editor of the N. Y. Daily Times: DEAR SIR: The TIMES of Monday, the 22d inst., had an editorial article headed "Church and Statc--Clerical Abuses in England," wherein I find some misstatments--unintentional, no doubt,-- which, if you have no objection, I would like to correct; as the effect, though, [ trust, not the design,. of them can scarcely be other that injurious and offensive to Episcopalians.

One grumbler--well gifted in the way of a querulous temper and a garrulous tongue-can make more of a sensation than any fifty pleasant men. It is not to be wondered at, any more than that a small furnace should send smoke enough up a factory chimney to form a big cloud and hide a fourth of the sky, or that a kettle drum should be heard further than a Cathedral organ.

An accident of the most painful and alarming nature occurred between 5 and 6 o'clock last evening, at the Hoboken Ferry on the Jersey shore, by which the lives of some five hundred persons, men, women and children, were placed in peril.

The growth of Newark is commented upon by the Daily. It says the increase of population, business and improvement, has been so rapid that already the census of 1850 is getting obsolete. In the single item of manufactures, there has been an enlargement exceeding all general calculation. Scores of new factories have been erected, many of them for new branches of trade.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In a communication you published a few days since, copied from a Philadelphia paper, speaking of the causes of our recent heavy marine losses, one of the most important was omitted by the writer, which I conceive to have been the over-sparring of our modern built clippers.

We have: conversed with several persons acquainted with the circumstances attending the late explosion of the steamer Gazelle. which took place at Canemah on Saturday morning last. It seems to be the settled opinion of everybody that this melancholy accident, which caused the most intense anguish in the hearts of hundreds of our citizens, and spread a gloom over the entire community, was attributable to the reckless carelessness or total incompetency of the engineer.

Mr. OLDS is on the right track, at last. The bill reported from the House Commit tee on Post-Offices, proposing to return to former rates of postage, threatened us with a step backwards. Indeed, such a diminutive as a step does not equal the idea. It was a stride that would not disparage the best days of the illustrious " Seven-Leagued Boots."

SUSPENSION 0F REV. S. HOWLAND. The Conference reassembled at 8 1/2 o'clock on Friday morning, Bishop JANES in the Chair. After the usual religious exercises the cuse of Rev. S. HOWLAND, of the Heading Mission Church, was resumed. Rev. HART 1. PEASE addressed the Conference for the defence, commenting at length upon the evidence. His address occupied the entire morning session, and up to 5 o'clock in the afternoon.

Close upon the heels of the repeal of the Missouri Compromise come several attempts to reclaim fugitive slaves from Free States. One was seized at Boston on Thursday; three were taken from this City on Friday; --and rumor laid the scene of another at Syracuse.

Dogs have had their day. Mastiffs, pointers, hounds, and curs alike, are out of repute: A dog can't howl now-a-days, but he is suspected of being mad; he can't hold his peace, but his muteness marks him for suspicion.

The war now begun in Europe receives a practical interest-that has slumbered for near thirty years-in the principles of Pub lie Law, which define the mutual rights and duties of belligerents and neutrals. For our country, with its vast commerce floating on every sea, it is an immense interest.

As was anticipated, a very large number of persons gathered in front of the City Hall yesterday after noon, for the avowed purpose of listening to the discourse of one of the street-preachers. The discourse had scarcely commenced, when, although there were many present determined to defend the preacher, a few uttered words of disapprobation, and were almost immediately knocked down and badly bruised.
