In Brooklyn, on Saturday, May, 27, WILLIAM PRENTICE, only son of William M. Goodrich, of New-Orleans, aged 13vears and 14 days.

THE LOST STEAMER REPORTED BY THE BALDAUR NOT THE CITY OF GLASGOW.--Last evening's Philadelphia Bulletin says: We are indebted to Mr. SAMUEL SMITH, Agent of the Liverpool and Philadelphia Steamship Company. for the dispatch given below, sent by RICHARDSON, BROTHERS CO., per the steamship America, and telegraphed from Halifax to this city.

We are to have five more entertainments at Castle Garden with JULLIEN and his fine orchestra. They are devoted mostly to the popular performers; the first (to-night) being for the benefit of an artist who has no equal--Herr KCEING. This gentleman is so great a favorite with the public that it is unnecessary to add another word. To-morrow evening is set apart for Mile.

The following history of the Black Warrior outrage is abridged from a statement drawn up by a person fully conversant with the facts. The document was handed to us by a gentleman who has himself just arrived from Havana, and who assures us that its assertions may be depended on. It is headed--"The Case of the Steamship Black Warrior, and the Cuban Authorities--A Statement of Facts."

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : SIR: An article having appeared in your paper of yesterday, alleging or implying that I have smuggled goods into this port, and had defrauded the United States Revenue, , I beg to say that the charges and implications therein contained, affecting or implicating me, are wholly incorrect.

The Bellevilie (II.) Tribune publishes an account of a terrible storm which visited St. Clair County on the 16th inst. The first intimation of the approach of a storm was given by the leaves and twigs which filled the air, some of which had come from a considerable distance. The tornado, it is supposed originated in Missouri, several miles below St. Louis, and crossed over to the Illinois side.
The French Minister had an interview with Mr. MARMCY yesterday, when diplomatic notes were exchanged in relation to the recent arrest, at San Francisco, of Mr. DILLON, the French Consul at that port.

FIRE--NINE HORSES BURNT--ONE MAN STAB BED.--At an early hour Saturday morning a fire broke out in stable owned by CHARLES FROST, rear of Nos. 95, 97 and 99 Atlantic-street, and occupied by several parties. JOHN LOURY, butcher, lost two horses ; YOUNG WIL LIAMS, grocers, lost one horse; WICHETT WELSH, clothing, one horse; M. LUDWIG, pork dealer. In all, nine horses were burnt.

When the lovely poodle of Mrs. Upton has left the hands of the accomplished barber, who dresses his tail and clips the glossy wool from the sacred parts of his person, he disports himself in the window of Mrs. Upton's carriage, couchanl over the crest.

he regular weekly meeting of the Journeymen Tailors Trade Society, was held in Mechanics Hotel, corner of Catharine and Madison-streets, last evening. Mr. THOMAS SPILLSBURY, President of the Society, presided. The President said the special business before the meeting was the consideration of the bill of prices reported by the Executive Committee.

ARREST OF A NEGRO CHARGED WITH BURGLARY.--Information was communicated, by Telegraph from Elmira, to Deputy-Sheriffo LARD, of Jersey City, yesterday, stating that a barglary had been committed in Elmira, and a negro charged with he offence was on a train of cars on the New-York and Erie Railroad, on his way to New-York. When he arrived at Jersey City, Officer POLLARD arrested him.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The Czar NICHOLAS, after having provoked the present war, the aim of his ambition and the object of the plans so favored by PETER THE GREAT, beholding a fatality gathering around him, in the hostile alliance of France and England, now calls the conflict a Holy one, and appeals to his people in the name of the defence they owe to the Orthodox-Catholic religion.

In the Assembly this morning the protest against the action by the Assembly upon the Slavery question was presented and placed upon the minutes. The Committee on Bills and Overtures was instructed to reply. Rev. ALBERT BARNES having the floor resumed the discussion or the subject of Ecclesiastical Boards. He was heard with great attention.
From the Lexington Statesman. FIRST DAY.--Association Stake, mile heats, for three year olds, $100 entrance, $50 forfeit, $25 declaration--seventeen entries, seven of which started, viz.:

There is what is called a new plan for procuring an adequate supply of wholesome water, about to be submitted to the citizens of Brooklyn, for their acceptance or rejection. The subject is one of great importance, and, although the necessity for a better means of obtaining water than they now have is great, the plan proposed should not be carelessly favored.

The merchants of Elizabethtown have considered the question of adopting decimal currency, and doing away with the shilling and pence system. A Committee reported affirmatively, and the meeting resolved in favor of the reform. The New-Jersey Standard concludes, after an observation of years, that the arrival of the whip-poor will is a criterion for determining the advance of the season.

The Chair laid before the Senate a message from the President, communicating a copy of the Report by Mr. SANDFORD, late American Charge at Paris, upon the Penal Codes of France and other European countries, and also on the Administrative changes in Europe since 1848. Ordered to be printed. Mr. BADGER presented the Petition of 47 members of the Jewish persuasion, in favor of religious freedom.

In this City, on Monday, May 29, after a long illness, JAMES M. JAMES, in the 30th year of his age. His friends, and those of his brother, Pros. M. James, are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from his late residence. No. 284 Grand-st., on Wednesday next, at 2 o'clock, P.M. In this City, on Monday, May 29, after at short illness. WILLIAM, son of Johaana, McCauley, aged 2 years and 9 months.

The seizure of ANTONY BURNS, an alleged fugitive slave, under the pretence of a criminal charge, has excited in Boston the most intense feeling. Though you may have had the main facts through the papers here. yet a brief history of the case, up to the present time, may not be unacceptable. BURNS had been in the employment of a colored man named PITTS, deacon of a colored church in this city.

WHAT THEY ARE LOOKING AT.--The Second-street Cemetery at all hours of all pleasant days is shut out from the street--first by a heavy stone wall; second, by a stout iron railing; and third, by a cordon of neat little girls, shabby little boys, stout grown Irishmen, burly big Dutchmen, Yankees of all ages, and a sprinkling of butchers' boys with up-rolled sleeves.

On Sunday evening, about 8 o'clock, an affray occurred at Green Point, at a German porter-house, corner of L and Fourth--treats, between two Irishmen an the keeper of the house, named JOHN FOETZ, which resulted in FOETZ receiving injuries which it is feared will terminate fatally.

Historical Collections of Georgia--Progress of this Branch of Literature--New Works Expected. We have received a handsome volume of nearly seven hundred pages, with numerous wood cuts and fine engravings on the History of Georgia. It is the successor to the Statistics of Georgia, a work published in 1849. Both are from tile pen of Rev. GEORGE WHITE of that State.

In another part of this morning's TIMEs we publish at length the address of the Five members of the Hard-Shell branch of the Democratic party, who voted against the repeal of the Missouri Compromise. They justify their action by authority, as well as reasoning, which it will not be easy to impeach.

On the 19th we were gratified with the arrival of another war steamer from the Antilly squadron of "our sincere allies"--the Chimera, from Belize Honduras, Commander Mr. GUIMREY. The report still prevails that three more French vessels of war are ordered here for the protection of Cuba "from the clutches of the rapacious barbarians of the North."

We have received a private letter from a gentleman of high character, well known in the scientific world, stating that Mr. NOBLE BUTLER, brother of him whom MATT. WARD murdered, is likely to be obliged to sell his house to raise money to pay the necessary expenses of the prosecution.

Twelve months ago we directed attention to the insecure condition of the Ferry landings on the Jersey shore, and referred particularly to such of them as were largely frequented by Sunday holiday folk. At the time our remarks were offered it became sufficiently obvious that safety--to say nothing of accommodation-formed no part of the Ferry Companies' general scheme for the Summer campaign.

Some of your cotemporaries in various cities have a very unfortunate habit of pretending to copy from your Washington correspondence, while, instead of giving the text of my letters, they in reality furnish their readers with very careless statement of what they understand me to mean, upon a very hurried perusal.

In yesterday morning's TIMES, we published all of interest that had transpired in Boston relative to the proceedings, in and out of Court, in the case of the fugitive BURNS. This morning we continue the account as received through the newspaper, of Boston and by telegraph. Also, an interesting correspondence (on our second page) giving a condensed history of the case to date.

We have information through private and highly respectable sources in London, which indicate that the Emperor of Russia is seriously inclined to withdraw from the position into which he has been betrayed. Our informant states that the recent attempt of Austria to reopen negotiations with the Czar will afford the desired, if not indeed the concerted opportunity, for taking the first step in this direction.

The following is a list of the appointments of Cadets to the United States Military Academy at West Point. The appointments of those who pass the preliminary examinations take effect on the 1st of July, 1851, and those appointed are required to report at West Point between the 1st and 20th of June. The examination for admission takes place on the 20th of June.

DOUGLAS, TOOMBS and Company have no more serviceable and effective allies, in their base conspiracy against the rights and liberties of the land, than PARKER, PHILLIPS and the misguided mob whom they have stimulated to illegal and murderous violence.

BROADWAY THEATRE.-The world-renowned story of, "Faustus" was revived here la t evening, and seems likely to be as popular new as when it was first conceived before Shakspeare's time. The boldness and perspicuity of the main idea appeals to every taste, and when properly carried out seldom fails to elicit the approbation of an audience.

MORTALITY.--The Health Officer reports 52 deaths for the week ending Saturday last. Males, 29; females, 23; adults, 21; children, 31. THE SUNDAY RIOTERS.--Twelve of the per sons arrested for distributing the audience attending the preaching at the corner of Smith and Atlantic-streets, on Sunday evening, were arranged yesterday before Justice BLACKLEY and were held to bail to await an examination.

Resolved, That the Democratic party will resist tempts at renewing, in Congress, or out of it, the agitation of the Slavery question under whatever shape or color the attempt may be made.--Baltimore Dem. Platform. From the Hagerstown, Md. Whig Weekly Chronicle. When HORACE GREELEY, in the indulgence of his fanaitcism, "spit" upon the Whig platform, the blood hounds of locofocoism were unleashed, and set upon the track of the veteran SCOTT.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A correspondent in your paper of Tuesday asks if something cannot be done to arrest this rapidly increasing evil. He alleges that the "indignation of foreigners is already aroused--the fire kindled, ,--and that these meetings are productive of more harm than good."

The Elgin Palladium of the 18th, has the following account of some events which transpired at Naperville, after the execution there of DOYLE. on the 12th. Who are the Medical marauders from Chicago? "After his execution, a most disgraceful scene took place, between certain physicians and others in relation to the body of the murderer.

Senior Don JOSE FRANCISCO BARRUNDIA, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of the Republic of Honduras, presented his credentials to-day to the President, and the usual felicitations were exchanged. Mr. BARRUNDIA is a very sensible man, and will not press his annexation scheme till we are perfectly ready for it. We shall come down there in due time.

LECTURE ON DR. ABBOTT'S EGYPTIAN ANTIQUITIES.--Prof. SATILLA delivered a lecture before the School of Design for Women, last evening, at Dr. ABBOTT'S Museum of Egyptian Antiquities. The lecture was illustrative of ancient Egyptian art, and of the value of Dr. ABBOTT's collection.

INTERESTING STATISTICS.-The surplus of box rents in the Post-Office at San Francisco is such an extraordinary sum, and the yearly increase so great over anything on record in the General Post-Office, that we give it in the official figures as one of the remarkable facts in the progress of California--the political, financial and social miracle of the world.

The $1,000 Trotting Match Postponed--A Match for $500--The Horses Hero and Prince matched for $4,000--The National Jockey Club. It was anticipated yesterday that the trotting match for $1,000 between the two celebrated horses belonging of JAMES McMANN and HARRY JONES would take place.

In this City, on Monday evening, May 29, ELLA, daughter of Edward and Alida Van Volkenburgh, aged 1 year, 3 months and 17 days. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, this day, at 11 o'clock, A.M., at No. 216 West 22d-st.

It seems somewhat of a change to jump from Summer back again into Spring. To leave the apple blossoms falling through a still atmosphere in New-York, and find after two days' journey the larch tassels not yet unfolded. This has been my experience, and the rapid journey from the Chambers-street Station to SWORDS' Hotel, has accomplished this vegetable change.

In the Old School Assembly at Buffalo, on Monday, the special order was the election of Professors: The following nominations were made: For Professor of Pastoral Theology at Princeton--Rev. Dr. A. G. McGILL, Rev. Dr. HUGH N. WILSON Dr. McGILL was elected.
The Presbyterian General Assembly, (New School.) adjourned sine die this afternoon. The subject of Popish Baptism was indefinitely postponed.

A plump pamphlet vas sent us yesterday, purporting to be the Annual Report of the Board of Ten Governors. The contents present a very complete view of the condition of the Institutions placed under the supervision of the Governors.

A CATASTROPHE.--On Friday last, says the Saybrook Mirror, the wife of Mr. CHARLES PRATT, of this place. was very seriously injured by the family cat. Mrs. P. had sat down for a few moments to converse with a neighbor. when the cat came into an open window. and immediately jumped at her face, scratching her head. neck and arms in a most frightful manner.

The Assembly to-day took up the case of Dr. DAY and the Synod Ohio, and the Church of Worcester, which Church had struck DAY's name from the list of Ruling Elders because he would not suffer children to he baptized, and the Synod had replaced it. The Assembly decided against Dr. DAY and the Synod, and in favor of the action of the Worcester Church.

DERANGED.--Mr. IRELAND, of Irlenad's Corners, a few miles from the city, was attracted to a swamp near his house, late on Saturday night, by the cries of a man. On searching for the man he found him wandering about in great tribulation, saying he was pursued by several men from New-York, who wanted to arrest him and take him to that city, there to try him for killing his wife.

A strenuous and systematized effort is making here and in Alexandria, to raise a mob against Senator SUMNER, in retaliation for the Boston difficulty. The Union newspaper's article on Sunday last is said to have been written by Senator DOUGLAS. It looked directly that way. The Star of this evening has two articles, the incendiary purpose of which cannot be mistaken.

The intelligence from New-Mexico, which is published on the third page of this morning's TIMES, is full of interest to the general reader, and should incite Congress to, if possible, furnish more effective protection to our people in that region of country.

MAN KILLED ON THE CLOVE ROAD.--PATRICK BOYLE, an apprentice to JOHN COULTER, contractor for the Fulton-street sewer, was instantly killed on Sunday afternoon, on the Clove Road, near WILSON'S Hotel. by a blow given him on the side of his head, by some person as yet not arrested.

The Westminster Review, for April, contains an article on "Manners and Fashion," which has been noticed in the newspapers of this country more than is usual. A pretty fair interence from this act is, that the public are getting to be interested in this matter.

BOSTON ANNIVERSARIES.--Unusual interest will attend the various anniversary meetings in Boston, this week. Many distinguished speakers will be present from abroad. President ALLEN, of Girard College, will deliver the annual address before the American Peace Society, Professor PARK, of Andover.

Mr. BROUGH is well known to our musical public, in connection with Miss CATHERINE HAYS and Mme. ALBONI.

Passing lately through West Sixteenth-street, between Fifth and Sixth-avenues, our attention was arrested by the half-finished front of a dwelling-house, which appeared to be constructed of a stone differing from anything we had elsewhere noticed in the City. It had much the appearance of marble, but with more of a silvery gray or greenish tint, that lighted up finely in the sun.

From the New-Orleans Picayune, May 23. We are favored with intelligence from Corpus Christi to the 10th inst., from which we learn particulars of a fight that took place on the previous day between a small detachment of United States troops and a body of Indians four times their number.

All well-informed people know in how many respects we are behind England in the safety, promptness and regularity of our Post-Office system. The want of thorough organization in this branch of public service is now most deeply felt.

From the New-Orleans True Delta. ALABAMA AGAINST LOUISIANA--.LOUISIANA VICTORIOUS.--Our readers are aware that the Fire Department of our sister city of Mobile, some time since, challenged the South to meet them in a friendly contest, where the superiority of their respective machines, and the skill and muscle of the brave men that "man the brakes" might be fairly tested.

The recent struggle in the House of Representatives over the Nebraska bill will be memorable not only for the pertinacity with which the minority resisted its passage, but also for the extraordinary in ensures, to which the majority resorted at the last, to secure their triumph.

From the Mississippian. Two years ago a law was passed by the California Legislature granting one year to the owners of slaves carried into the territory previous to the adoption of the Constitution to remove them beyond the limits of the State. Last year the provisions of this law was extended twelve months longer.

The examination in the case of ANTHONY BURNS, the alleged fugitive slave, was resumed at 9- o'clock this morning. The Court room was less crowded, and there is far less excitement outside. He. ELLIS resumed his argument for the defence.

The excitement in and around the Court-House in Boston yesterday, while the Fugitive Slave Case was progressing, is reported to have been much less than on former days. principal feature in the

ASIATIC CHOLERA IN BROOKLYN.--That this fearful malady has made its appearance in this city, seems to be too true. At all events, several cases which occurred yesterday were pronounced such by Drs. COCHRANE and other medical gentlemen of distinction, who had them in charge. So far as we have ascertained, five cases have occurred--two of which resulted in death, two are not expected to recover, and a fifth is convalescent.

New-Orleans papers of Wednesday last are received. They contain Texas news to the 21st inst. The Court-Martial for the trial of Dr. STEINER had adjourned, on account of the non-appearance or the prisoner, who was still in the custody of the civil authorities.

An experiment was tried recently by the New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company, on the meadows west of Bergen Hill. Mail bags were changed while the trains were at a speed of fifty miles per hour--one bag was placed upon a post, and another was taken from it. If this plan proves practicable, mails may be transported by an express train for way stations.

The Fugitive Slave Law was one of the "Series of Compromise Measures." The "Compromise" is replaced. Does not the Fugitive Slave Law rightfully go with it? Has that Law now any morally binding force? Are we in justice, equity, or honor, bound to respect it? As a Law it imposes, we admit, an arbitrary obligation.

We selected our camping ground last night on a narrow slope of prairie between the foot of a rocky spur of the Guadalupe Mountains and a small creek of remarkably clear water. The stream ran parallel with the hill side, and at about two hundred yards distance.

THOMAS RITCHIE, Jr., whose death was announced a few days since, will be remembered from his connection with the horrible butchery in which JOHN H. PLEASANTS, at that time and for many years previous Editor of the Richmond Whig, lost his life.

The Nebraska bill having been enrolled, has gone to-day to the President. for his signature. The agitation which it produced already subsides in this quarter, and cannot be kept up. The cry of "repeal" is, according to Senator WADE, to be raised in all the Northern States, and the next House of Representatives, it is asserted, will embrace a large majority of Anti-Nebraskahill men.

Some months ago I informed you that a treaty for the annexation of the Sandwich Islands was expected to arrive in a short time. Unexpected obstacles in the way of the movement prevented its conclusion at that time.

OUTRAGE AND EXCITEMENT NEAR XENIA.-On Thursday of last week, a man named McLEOD, who had been stopping in and about Xenia for a few days, and who is represented as being a disreputable person, left that town in a buggy, and drove toward Selma. A few miles out he overtook a colored man, whom he suspected of being a fugitive slave, and asked him to get in and ride on to the next cross-roads.

Mr. JOHNSON, from the Committee on Printing, re ported adversely on printing 1,000 additional copies of SANDFORD'S Reports on the Penal Codes of Europe, and on the administrative changes in France since 1848.

Who is there that has not noticed in his metropolitan experience the man who is going down? From day to day you trace him in his mournful descent of the deelivity of life. He falls by inches, and his clothes are the barometer of his pocket. You do not know him.

The London Morning Post devotes over five columns to a list of guests at one of the Queen's drawing-rooms, and a description of the ladies' dresses. Each lady's name is given in capitals, at full length, and is followed by a minute technical description of her apparel.

The examination in the Fugitive Slave Case--if he is a slave, and if he is a fugitive--at Boston, was yesterday concluded. The decision will be rendered on Friday. Till that time, expectation, which has so long stood on tiptoe, will settle down to a cushioned seat and wait.

In this City, on Wednesday, May 31, Mr. SAMUEL W. OTIS. only son of Galen Otis, Esq., of Addison, N. Y., in the 27th year of his ago. His remains will be taken to Otisville, Orange County, for interment. Goshen and Addison papers will please copy. In Brooklyn, at his residence, oil Wednesday, May 31, Mr. SELAH SMITH, aged 74 years.

The match made some weeks ago for $1,000, mile heats, best 3 in 5, between two steeds belonging to gentlemen in this City, has been the theme of conversation in sporting circles. In consequence of the fact that the horses were never entered for a race before, their speed was not known to the old patrons of the turf, and parties were very cautious in making their bets.

The Washington Union and the Star are doing their utmost to stir up a mob against Senator SUMNER, on the false pretext that he has counselled forcible resistance to the execution of the Fugitive Slave law in Boston.

There bas been but very little done in Dry-Goods ,Since our last, and nothing essentially new is noticeable in the condition or prospects of the business; hence we dispense with all further reference to the market, than what is contained in the subjoined detailed report: Brown and Bleached Shirtings and Sheetings are inactive and languid, the poorest styles being, of course, the most depressed.

The Almanac makers must have a convention and set things straight again. The Seasons, like new performers in a dance, come in at the wrong time, and the days take the wrong partners by the hand. Monday was a Summer day; Tuesday was a legitimate rainy May day; Wednesday be longed to the October company, yet it came in as the usher of the first of June.

The old question whether or not alchohol should ever be used in medicine. is discussed again with great vigor. When it is settled, we hope the next greatest question will be disposed of-whether we should use fire in cooking, since our cook burned her hand dreadfully last week, and PLINY tells of a child that was burned to death.

The City Inspector's Report, lately published, is a pursy document of 264 pages and any quantity of elaborate tables. We do not make a long abstract of it, for the reason that at the opening of the year we abstracted the returns that had been made during the year preceding, at considerable length.

No one who enters the City to stay but a week should omit climbing to the top of Trinity. From the upper windows of its spire he will get a panorama of the City with its noble bay and rivers, its streets and Churches, parks and promenades, such as no other point affords.

The Seventy-First Annual Convention of the Episcopal Church of New-Jersey, met in Grace Church, Newark, yesterday, there being a very large attendance of members from all parts of the diocese. Bishop DOANE presided, and the proceedings were opened with the usual religious services. The eighth Triennial Charge was then delivered by the Bishop.

Drowned, in a pond, near Charlotteville, N. Y., on Monday evening, 29th inst., Mr. C. F. IZAREL, aged 21, of Fislerville, N. J.--a member of the Academy at Charlotteville. Mr. I. could swim but little, and in attempting to cross where the water was deep, became exhausted and sank. His eousin, a young man of 16, who was near him on the land, endeavored to save him, but could not reach him.

The improvement which has been effected in the outward appearance of the building formerly known as the Opera House, in Astor-place, but hereafter to be styled Clinton Hall, is highly creditable to the Trustees of that Association, under whose direction it has been accomplished.

About 10.45 o'clock this morning, three wagons loaded with five tons of gunpowder, belonging to Messrs. DUPONT Co., exploded at the corner of Fourteenth and Orange-streets, killing seven persons and fifteen horses.

The New-Orleans Bee comments on our remark, that the repeal of the Missouri Compromise had developed a popular sentiment in the North which would probably elect Gov. SEWARD to the Presidency in 1856 by the largest vote from the Free States ever cast for any candidate.

THE WATER ELECTION--ATTEMPTED POSTPONEMENT.--The friends of the " Water Plan" in the Brooklyn Common Council, finding there was but little prospect of the people adopting the plan, called a meeting of that body yesterday morning, when a resolution was adopted postponing the election to the 26th of June, by a vote of 8 to 5.

The long and interesting session of this General Assembly was terminated this afternoon-perhaps to the relief of your readers, and certainly to the relief of its members. The business transacted since my last sketch was quite equal in importance to any that pre ceded it. I will not detain you with any lengthened notice of it.

On another page, our readers will find a sketchy review of Dr. BACHMAN'S address before the second meeting of the Agricultural Convention of the Planting States, held in last December, at Columbia, S. C. It attracted a great deal of notice at the time, both on account of the merit of the Essay and the eminent talents of its author.

To the Editor of the N. Y. Daily Times: SIR: The Free Academy, as you are aware, has existed nearly six years. The general success that has crowned its efforts, reflects honor on its Board of Managers, and on those whose services are devoted to the Institution.

From the Frankfort, Ky., Commonwealth. We are informed that on Monday night, May 22, three daughters of Rev. Mr. PERRY, Methodist preacher, living at El Dorado, six or seven miles this side of Harrodsburg, were horribly burned by the explosion of a camphene lamp, and that the whole three are dead, and were buried in the same grave on Wednesday.

Meeting of the Senate Committee of Investigation. The Committee appointed under a resolution of the State Senate, dated April 13, 1851, charged with an investigation of the affairs of Columbia College, met yesterday morning at the Astor House.

THE WEALTH AND EXCLUSIVENESS OF THE DUBLIN UNIVERSITY.--Mr. FAGAN, M. P. for Cork, lately introduced a motion into Parliament for opening Trinity College,--in its honors and emoluments, for its has already been opened for imparting education,--to Roman Catholics and Dissenters; or, if that might not be, to institute and open one from its funds.

MINISTERS' SALARIES.--An interesting pamphlet has been published in Bo??lou, containing a statement of facts from each religious denomination in New England respecting Ministers' salaries. The facts have been collected and arranged by New CHARLES BROOKS, chairman of the committee of investigation appointed at the last meeting of the "Society for the Relief of Aged and Destitute Clergymen."

New-Orleans papers of Friday last are received. Intelligence from the ship Thomas Wright, ashore off O-alow Island, reports her going to pieces. A portion of her cargo, running rigging, and furniture, had been saved. Hen. ANGUS PATTERSON. President of the South Carolina Senate, died on Friday last.

MORAL SUASION ON A RAM.--When a friend of ours. Whom we call Agricula, was a boy, he lived on a farm in Berkshire County, the owner of which was troubled by his dog, Wolf. The cur killed his sheep, knowing, perhaps that his matter was conscientiously opposed to capital punishment and he could devise no means to prevent it.

The Quebec Chronicle says that nearly due north of Quebec, one hundred and eight miles as the bird sites, and probably one hundred and thirty by a constructed road, lies a magnificent lake, covering an area of 600 square miles, and abounding with a variety of fish. It is fed by numerous rivers, some of them navigable for a considerable distance to seasoners until batteaux.

GENTLEMEN: I have thought., for some time, I would write for your paper something in relation to the richest man in Virginia, and the largest slaveholder in the Union, and perhaps in the world, unless the serfs of Russia be considered slaves; and the wish you expressed in your paper, a few days ago, to know whom it was so wealthy in Virginia, includes me to write this now.

We learn from good authority that dispatches went out by the Europa on Wednesday to our Minister at Paris, in regard to the case of M. DILLON, the French Consul at San Francisco, concerning which the French Minister at Washington has made remonstrances with and exactions of our Government.

PROBABLE MURDER OF A WIFE.--Yesterday morning John Chesner, an Irishman, who resides in Newark-avenue near Brunswick-street, Jersey City, was brought before the Recorder on a charge of stabbing his wife. He has been on a drunken spree for six weeks past, and coming home at a late hour a Wednesday night he commanded his wife to get him some liquor, which she did, handling it to him in a tumbler.

HARD-SHELL GENERAL COMMITTEE. - The regular monthly meeting of the Hard-Shell General Committee took place last evening at the Stuyvesant institute. RICHARD SCHELL, Esq., presided. Mr. HART moved that a Committee be appointed to prepare a call for the Primary Elections, to be presented to the General Committee at its next meeting, on the 15th of this month.

TROUBLE AT COLUMBIA COLLEGE.--The entire Sophemore class at Columbia College were expelled from that institution yesterday. The class have been for some months past dissatisfied with certain arrangements of the Board respecting them, and have taken frequent opportunities of manifesting their discontent in the presence of the President.

ATTEMPT TO BURN A STORE--ARREST OF THE PROPRIETORS.--Yesterday morning, about 3 1/2 o'clock, a fire was discovered in the dry goods store of Messrs. SWARTZ WECHSLER, No. 190 Grand-street, Williamsburg. The alarm was given and the fire was soon extinguished.

My letter of yesterday from Bogoto left the triumph of MELO there in Bogota complete, and the palace converted into a prison. His plans had nothing to fear from any resistance that day, but everything to dread for the future. I could not believe that a revolution was mediated, because I knew that there was not a private man in all New-Granada who would willingly consent to a dictatorship.

The Star says that intelligence has been received by the European Embassies, of the complete and amicable settlement of the Black Warrior affair. Spain pays beck the $6,000,-rebukes the port authorities of Havana,-and promises to reform the regulations to meet the wants of American Commerce.

APPRENTICES NOT PROPERTY.-The Court-of Queen's Bench has lately decided that where a master has covenanted to instruct his apprentice in any trade, and by selling out his business, incapacitates himself from imparting the promised instruction, he, by that act of itself, violates his covenant, and that he could not justify himself by the fact that he had made arrangements by which his apprentice might be instructed by the party to whom the business was transferred.

PITCHING QUOITS.--A game of quoits for $100 a side, was played on Thursday, at GARRET DAY'S, on the Plank-road from Hoboken to Hackensack. JOHN B. RAE of Jersey City, and JOHN HAGUE of West Hoboken, played against HENRY BEATTY of Bergen Corners, and GARRETT DAY of New-Durham.

The United States Mail steamer Black Warrior, J. D. BULLOCK, Esq., commanding, arrived last evening from Havana, having sailed from that port on the evening of the 28th ult. She left Mobile on the 25th and reached Havana at 7 P. M. on the 27th.

Cast a bird's eye view on our city, gleaming with its thousand minarets and lofty towers beneath the mid-day sun, and you would sec nothing that betokened the internal discord and diverse excitements now raging Within its vast exterior: From the Ambassador to his menial, from the Sultan to his subject, each one has his theme, his own peculiar feelings and opinion.

At the present time when negotiations are understood to be pending at Washington, with probability of a favorable conclusion, for the settlement of the long-disputed Fishery question, and the establishment of a reciprocity of trade between the United States and Canada, the following diplomatic correspondence, communicated confidentially to the Senate more than a year since, but which has never before seen the light, will be of interest.

A letter from our Constantinople correspondent, dated May 6, contains the following paragraphs: "The English soldiery are arriving rapidly every day. There are at present in Scutari fourteen regiments, and most of them are encamped in tents on the large plain outside the barracks.

DROWNED IN A BARREL OF WATER.--Yesterday morning Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest in One Hundred and Forty-first-street, on the body of a female named RACHAEL HENRY, who was drowned by falling into a barrel of water, about 9 o'clock in the evening. Mr. HENRY came home, and finding his wife absent and the back door open, he became alarmed, and went among the neighbors to search for her.

THE CUTCHOGUE MURDER.--On our third page may be found the details of a horrid butchery, which took place in one of the most quiet villages of the East end of Long Island. A wretch, without provocation, entered the house of his late employer at Cutchogue, L. I., and with a post-axe murdered a gentleman, his wife and servant.

If any shrewd Futurist had told our grandmothers that two or three generations from their girlhood, women would become a Literary Power in America, he would have been set down as a fortune-teller. Our grandmothers could not but smile at such a vain prophesy.

There was a terrible riot in Brooklyn yesterday, during which some forty or fifty persons, either witnesses or parties causing it, were very seriously injured. The particulars, as near as our reporters could learn, are as follow: On the previous Sabbath, one of the street-preachers who have been the cause of many disturbances in New-York, went to Brooklyn, accompanied by a body guard, and preached in a vecant lot in Smith-street.

The Slavery propagandists, even in the hour of their victory, are disturbed by guilty fears. Before the roar of the cannon on Capitol Hill, indecently proclaiming their triumph, has died away, trembling seems to have seized upon them.

What a hero be must have been. If he only distinguishes himself

There is in the reopened Crystal Palace an extraordinary object of importance and interest, We mean the representation of M. Gulliver in Liliput. Every one of our readers may have seen it, laughed at it, and perhaps at the artist for having wasted his time on such useless work: but it may

The Freeman's Journal, in an article which has but just fallen under our notice, copies from the St. Louis Shepherd of the Valley an article designed to Correct the misapprehensions which led to the debate in the United States Senate upon a doctrine said to have been put forward in its columns.

FIRES AND ATTEMPTED RIOTS.--Yesterday afternoon a fire broke out in a carpenter's shop at No. 74 Broad-street, which, at one time, threatened to spread rapidly among the warehouses. The firemen soon came there in strong force and extinguished the flames before any heavy damage was done...... On Saturday morning, about 4 o'clock. a fire occurred in a carpenter's shop, in the rear of 192 Fourth-street. in the occupation of Messrs. KEYSER BERRIAN.

From the Richmond Enquirer. In any view it is a matter of very little consequence whether Commissioner LORING suffer the fugitive BURNS to escape, or remand him into the custody of his master. If the slave be given up, the less frantic portion of the Northern press will boast a signal triumph of law and order, and will claim the gratitude of the South as for some signal service.

The subject of national elementary education is now agitating Scotland. Heretofore the parish schools-so great a blessing, and to which Scotsmen owed so much of their superiority--were under the parish clergy, and the schoolmaster must be of the established Church. But the country has outgrown that. Only one-third of the population are now of that Church.

A SUSPIGIOUS SCHOONER.--Capt. BOWEN, of the bark Gem of the Sea, arrived at this port yesterday from New-Orleans. He reports that May 28, at 10 A. M., in lat. 35[degrees]-40[degrees], he saw a schooner on the weather beam. She kept off and run down across our bow ; she then hauled her wind and passed one-half mile to windward.

But few members of the House have re turned. There is no probability of a quorum to. morrow. Probably they will adjourn to Thursday. There is great excitement about the municipal election to-morrow. There is much betting upon the result. Representative MACE has returned from Indiana. He brings cheering intelligence in condemnation of the " iniquity " by all parties of that State.
The following is the weekly report of deaths in the City and County of New-York., from the 27th day of May to the 3d day of June, 1854: Men, 113; Women, 82; Boys, 123; Girls, 97. Total. 415.

Free man brought suit against Ellington for false imprisonment. When the case came on for trial, a few days

ARRIVAL OF THE EMPIRE CITY.--The United States Mail steamship Empire City, McGOWAN, Captain, left New-Orleans May 26, at 8 A. M. for New-York via Havana, at which port she arrived on the 29th. Having landed the mails and passengers, she sailed same day at 5 P. M. for this port.

JAMES GORDON BENNETT, Esq., Editor of the New-York Herald; Prince JEROME BONAPARTB, P. F. LAUDRE, French Consul at Belize, and J. VAN BUREN (not Prince John) and family, of this City, were: among the passengers in the Franklin for Havre, on Saturday.

In this City, on Saturday, June 3, JOHN F. DELAPLAINE, in the 68th year of his age. His friends and relatives and those of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral. from his late residence. No. 6 St. Marks-place, on Tuesday afternoon, at 4 o'clock. without further invitation.

From the Freeman's Journal of last week. Our bland-spoken neighbor of the TIMES has not rectified his erroneous statements respecting the sentiments repudiated by the Shepherd of the Valley. We are pleased to see in the daily St. Louis Intelligence the frankness of the following paragraph:

FIRST DAY OF THE JUNE TERM.--The next few weeks will be a busy time for the members of the Bar and the Judiciary. The calendars of the Supreme Court, Superior Court, and Common Pleas, contain the usual "infinite variety," and we may anticipate an effort on the part of the profession to dispose of a mass of unfinished business prior to the long vacation which commences at the close of the month.

In this City, on Sunday. June 4, by Rev. E. H. Chapin, Mr. WILLIAM JAMES to MISS MARY A. MAGOVERN, both of this City. In this City. on Thursday, June 1, by Rev. Charles Sommers WM. F. CONROY to MARTHA OLIVER, both of this City.

The Philadelphia papers seem to consider it a matter of conscience to abuse New-York and all things belonging thereto. The Crystal Palace just now comes in for their special attentions. One of them announces that it is sinking money very rapidly, and that "the whole concern is to be connected with a big gift enterprise, including the Palace itself."

Before City Judge Greenwood. Kelsey of Kelsey agt. Bradbury.--A man named Cox made a note, payable to Rouse, or order. He endorsed it to Elliot and Holden. The endorsees obtained a judgment upon it against the maker and endorser. The latter paid the judgment, received back the note, and transferred it to the defendant, who sets it up against a demand, upon which the plaintiffs sue as assignees of the maker.

THE AMERICAN CENSUS.--The Americans, who always go ahead in everything, have gone ahead of us in their census; for, instead of limiting it as we do to human beings, the United States have prepared a statistical account of all their cattle. We are rather surprised that the Great Re public should have officially recognized the animal kingdom, and admit it to the same tables with its own citizens. We should have hardly thought it

The Courts of the City, the two Boards of the Common Council, and the public offices generally, yesterday turned over a new leaf in their books, and commenced on the month of June. This is the last working month before the long Summer vacation. The Aldermen intend to improve it. They have resolved to sit every evening this week to finish the business of the session.

From the Columbia South Carolinian, June 2. The accomplishment of this measure appears to be the darling object of a portion of the people of the United States; but the only project for that purpose yet proposed, that of suspending the neutrality laws, is so revolting to every honorable idea of territorial acquisition in this age and country, that we do not think it could find supporters to the amount of a corporal's guard.
One of the Captains of Police in Boston sent to the Authorities on Saturday, the following letter: To the Honor the Mayor and Aldermen of the City of Boston:

We have intelligence from Galveston to the 27th inst., and corresponding later dates from other cities. The most important items of news are the following, which we condense from an extra of the San Antonio Western Texan, of the 22nd inst.:

A crowded and fashionable audience greeted W. V. WALLACE on the occasion of his Complimentary Benefit Concert, Saturday evening last. Considering the very short notice and the unusual attraction elsewhere, it was the more gratifying, as it showed, unmistakably, that Mr. WALLACE occupies, as he should, a position of high regard in our Musical community.

The publisher of the Southern Quarterly Review announces that with the July number, his vocation as publisher of that work must cease, unless he can succeed better than he has done hitherto in his endeavors to collect money from his delinquent subscribers. His appeals hitherto, to those indebted to him, have been received with "characteristic indifference," and his "applications to banks for relief have shared a like fate."

The Big Tent, which has been set up at the corner of Seventh-avenue and Thirteenth-street, was crowded on Sunday evening, the Alderman and Council-men of the Ninth Ward being upon the platform. There were at least 3,000 present.

A good deal of excitement pervaded Brooklyn yesterday, concerning the riots of Sunday, though no outbreaks took place. Many of the parties who had been injured were locked inside the cells during the night, and yesterday morning thousands gatherd in and around the Brooklyn City Hall, for the purpose of seeing them and hearing the result of their trail.

NICHOLAS BAIN, the party suspected of the murder of the family of Mr. WICKHAM, at Cutchogue, was arrested in the woods near Hermitage, L.I., at a very early hour yesterday morning. A strict watch had been kept up in the woods from the moment it was suspected that BAIN had taken refuge there, and, by strenuous exertions, the culprit was finally secured and safety lodged in jail at Riverhead.

An extra from the Baraboo (Wis.) Standard, informs us of stirring events at that place on Tuesday, May 23. It seems that the sale of liquor had grown into a monstrous nuisance, and led to frequent difficulties and abuse in families. At length the ladies called a secret meeting of their own number, and laid their plans for general destruction of the liquor in the village.

CHOLERA.--We regret to state that the Cholera has suddenly made its appearance in our city. We have taken pains to inquire into the number of deaths, and from authentic sources we have reports of sixteen since Saturday morning, previous to which time we hear of no cases.

We must confess the frequent occurrence of such disturbances as that in Brooklyn, has an ominous aspect to our mind. Scarcely a Sunday passes that our quiet streets are not disturbed by some collision, and that between natives and foreigners.
Upon assembling this morning, ten Senators were in attendance; and after the reading of the Journal, the Senate adjourned till Thursday next.

From Montreal to Quebec, one steams along the Saint Lawrence in a miserable boat known by the high-sounding title of the Lady Elgin. Human ingenuity could not have invented a more wretched conveyance. The state-rooms are mere chinks into which two people are squeezed, so limited in size that one of them has to get into bed while the other washes.

STRAWBERRY FESTIVALS.--One of the most novel and pleasing, and at the same time successful ways of raising funds for such church purposes as are usually committed to the stewardship of the ladies of the religious societies, are Strawberry Festivals--which institution is almost exclusively established in Jersey City.

In this City, on Monday, June 5, Mrs. ELIZABETH LOTT, aged 70 years, 3 months and 17 days. The relatives and friends of the family, and also the congregation of the Protestant Reformed Dutch Church, cor. of Bleecker and Amos-sts., are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, from her late residence, No. 50 Downing-st., this day, (Tuesday.) 6th inst., at 10 o'clock, A. M.

The Common Council of the city of Providence have voted to make no appropriation for the public celebration of the 4th of July, and have directed the bells of the Churches to be tolled for one hour in the morning, one hour at noon, and one hour at sundown, on account of the passage of the Nebraska bill and the recent proceedings under the Fugitive Slave act.

From the Tribune. SIR: When some years ago I had the honor of replying to an invitation of a portion of the members of the New-York Legislature to address them upon the Slavery question, I was thought by many a fanatic because I avowed that it was not a question about the African, but "whether we ourselves should be freemen or slave."

THE CROPS.-Grass and grain through-out New-England look well. The finest wheat crop of many years is promised in South Carolina. Louisiana prospects improve. The heavy rains have ceased, and the hoes and ploughs are busy in the cotton; while the tall corn would make a lover of hominy water at the mouth.

To the Stockholders of the Morris and Essex Railroad: In a few days an opportunity will be presented when, by your votes, a more efficient class of men can be selected in place of those constituting the present Board of Directors.

After a week's agitation--which showed a great deal larger in the newspapers than in the reality of the streets and the Court-House--the BURNS business ended to-day, as every dispassionate person in Boston knew it would end--that is, quietly--in a quiet surrender.

Darius Davidson, a celebrated naval architect of Boston, proposes to construct an immense steamship, S(C feet in length. She is to be driven by 16 seperate engines, having a total of 5,000 horse power, at the aver age speed of 25 miles per hour, and to have berths and state rooms for 3,000 passengers.

Senator DOUGLAS made a very small speech to Mr. JOHN COCHRANE, in one of the back rooms of the St. Nicholas Hotel, on Saturday evening last. His audience was of course select. Mr. COCHRANE was one of the most active of the VAN BUREN Free-Soilers of 1848, and ran for Congress, as the uncompromising opponent of extending Slavery into any territory of the United States, not long after.

The Bleachery at Scott's Pond, Smithfield, belonging to W.P. SAYLES, was destroyed by the fire about 3 o'clock this morning. The buildings were insured for $18.500 in this city, $1,000 at the People's Mutual Company, Worcester; $2,500 at the Metropolitan, Boston; $4,000 at the Western, Pittsfield; and $2,500 at the North-western, Oswego.

A correspondent sends us a communication concerning the WARD case, laying down the basis of his argument thus: "It has always been understood that the maxim of the English common law, that a prisoner was supposed to be innocent until proved guilty, was one of its most beautiful attributes.

That the New-Jersey Railroad is a profitable concern was abundantly evidenced by its annual exhibit, made at Newark yesterday, on the occasion of the Anniversary Dinner. The entertainment was handsomely set out in the City Hotel, and covers war laid for three hundred persons.

In steamship Illinois, for Aspinwall and California--Judge Henery (Postmaster of San Francisco) and lady. H. B. Hunt, lady and child. E Holfschaler, lady and child, M. Banerer. Mr. Eneland, J. Wormser and lady.

CASSIUS M. CLAY makes his appearance before the public again, in a letter on the duty of the Free States in regard to the repeal of the Missouri Compromise. It is characterized, like most of his productions, by zeal rather than discretion.

I no longer tread Granada soil. The unhappy land that has received me so kindly, and given me all the comforts within the reach of its boundless but undeveloped resources, lies far behind me. With distance, perhaps, I can speak more frankly of the situation and prospects of the land.

CONNECTICUT STATE TEACHER'S ASSOCIATION.--Very full, animated and enthusiastic educational meetings of the Connecticut State Teacher's Association, took place on Tuesday and Wednesday of last week, in the Medical College, New-Haven.

The Board of Aldermen held its first meeting of the June Session last evening. In the absence of President ELY, Alderman WAKEMAN of the Twelth Ward was elected pro tem. until his return. Petitions were received and referred: From members of Hose Co. No. 9 concerning the house now building for them.

ATTENDED SUICIDE.--A woman, about forty years of age, named EMALINDA COCKS, residing at No. 84 South Seventh-street, Williamsburg, attempted to destroy her life about 7 o'clock on Saturday evening by swallowing a dose of laudanum, which she procured at he drug-store No. 21 South Seventh-street.

A number of gentlemen from Great Salt Lake City, Utah Territory, were passengers in the Sam Cloon, on Tuesday night from the Missouri River. They arrived at Fort Leavenworth on the 26th ult., by the mail stage. Among them were the following gentlemen : W. C. DUNBAR, MILO ANDREWS, C. H. WHEELOCK, J. M. BARLOW, W. FROST, R. W. WOLCOTT, SETH M. BLAIR, Esq., U. S. District Attorney for Utah Territory, and Gen. JAMES FERGUSON.

The St Louis Intelligencer of June 2, announces the sudden death of one of its Editors, JAMES D. NOURSE, Esq. It says: On Wednesday morning Mr. NOURSE came to the office about the usual hour, say at 8 o'clock, and sat down and wrote an article in relation to Col. FREMONT'S late exploration of the Central Pacific route.

Hon. JAMES WADSWORTH, President of the Buffalo and Brantford Railroad, returned from England in the Asia, where he has been on business connected with the road. We understand he was eminently suesuccessful in the objects of his voyage-the negotiation of the bonds of the Company and the purchase of iron for the balance of the road-and that its completion to Goderich will be prosecuted with all practicable dispatch.--Buffalo Commercial Advertiser.

The Committee, appointed by the State Senate to investigate the affairs of Columbia College, met at 10 A.M. on Monday, in the College Library, where they were met by the following members of the Board of Trustees: Right Rev. Bishop Wainwright, Gerrit G. Van Wagenen, Treasurer, John Knox, D. D., Thos. L. Wells, Wm. Betts, LL. D., Clerk of the Board, Edward Jones, Wm. H. Hobart, M.D.;

It is stated that the journal-Les Mousquetaires--started by Dumas, (who, by-the-bye is writing a new novel in twelve volumes for the United States,) a month or two since, is very successful. Its motto at the head is literally thus: " M. Dumas has made the fortune of three papers." The authors of Paris are following Dumas's example, and publishing each his own organ.

Miss TERESA ESMONDE, a lady who had a short dramatic career at Mr. WALLACK'S Theatre, gave a second reading from the poets, at the Stuyvesant Institute last evening. We view with some apprehension the frequent recurrence of these entertainments, for if they are so successful as those of Miss ESMONDE are likely to prove, it is more than likely that the whole dramatic profession will be let loose on our unfortunate public.

Pursuant to an advertisement issued by the Nebraska Committee, calling a meeting of citizens in the Park, in order to proceed from thence to the St. Nicholas Hotel, and serenade Senator DOUGLAS, about 500 people assembled in that locality, and having formed a procession, proceeded along Broadway to the hotel.

The Whigs have carried the City of Washington! Under the very nose of the President,--directly in the teeth of the whole patronage of the Federal Government,--against the votes and influence of the whole crowd of office-holders, and, as it appears, in spite of threats to withhold appriations for City purposes, if the City vote went wrong,
The Nebraska procession passed our office twice last night. The first time it was scarcely visible. After visiting the Park and firing cannon for an hour, it marched back, considerably recruited.

The Democrats at their caucus this evening, nominated FRANCIS R. CHASE, of Conway, for the Speakership, and E. A. HIBBARD, of Meredith, and A. S. MARSHALL, of Concord, for Clerk and AssistantClerk. The votes in all instances were unanimous.

The Buffalo Republic relates a cow-hiding case in that city, in which a gentlemen temporarily residing there, but having a family at the Falls, was flogged in a restaurant by a "lady," who accompanied the chastisement with a "piece of her mind"--charging him with making disturbance in her family--promising to marry divers and sundry young ladies he being a married man all the while, and she would teach him better that.

In this City, on Tuesday evening, June 6, MARY B., wife of Robert McMurray, of this City, and daughter of Col. Richard C. Van Wyek, of Fishkill, Dutchess Co., N. Y., in the 26th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, on Thursday morning, June 8. at 10 1/2 o'clock, at the residence of Edward H. Seely, No. 72 West 26th-st., without further invitation.
People lately have been going down to the Five Points and expending their sympathy and labor on the children of depravity that swarm in those classic purlieus.

For three successive mornings we have given a large space to the details of one of the most horrible outrages yet entered in the annals of our criminal history. At Cutchogue, L. I.,. NICHOLAS BEHEEHAN, an Irishman, aged 21, entered the house of JAMES WICKHAM, Esq., a farmer, and retired merchant of this City, near midnight of Friday last, with the intention of ravishing a servant girl there residing.

THE CARSON LEAGUE.--The Carson League Committee, for the legal suppression of illegal liquor-selling, has opened an office in Appleton Buildings No. 9, No. 346 Broadway, in this City. The names of the Committee, as appears by their appeals, are HORACE GREELEY, M. HEWITT, THEODORE McNAMEE, C. C. NORTH, and W. D. MURPHY.

Vegetables and Spring fruits are abundant in market to-day, and in good demand. But little variation has taken place in the prices of meat since last week's quotations. We annex a list of the present standard retail prices:

Our municipal election is progressing quietly, with the probability of a heavy vote being polled. The general impression is that CONRAD, Whig, will be elected Mayor, and HAZLEHURST, Solicitor. The Know-Nothings, are at work and confidently predict the above result. It is currently reported that Democratic Know-Nothings are voting for CONRAD.

The Government of Sardinia is at this moment engaged in such a contest as might have agitated the mind of Northern Europe three centuries back, and is carrying it on in a manner which well merits the same success as our forefathers met with when fighting their way along the same path from darkness into light. The battle of religious liberty in Sardinia is not a name.

To-morrow, the 7th of June, at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, this accomplished lady and Mr. WM. FOUSHEE RITCHIE, son of the venerable THOMAS RITCHIE, of Richmond, Va., will be joined in the holy bonds of matrimony. The ceremony will take place at Ravenswood, the residence of Mr. SAMUEL G. OGDEN, the father of the bride, in the spacious mansion of the GIBBS family, which has been specially prepared for the occasion.

DEAR SIR: I cheerfully comply with the request contained in your letter of December 3, though necessarily in rather a brief manner. In carefully examining the history of the Church of Jesus Christ in the days of the Twelve Apostles, I find faith, repentance and baptism enjoined upon all desirous of salvation;...

The departure of the steamer Sicily for New-York has been delayed in consequence of her recent encounter with the Herculanleum, off Nice. The Captain and mate, in fact, were arrested on her arrival in this city, on a charge of carelessness in that distressing affair. Among the 50 passengers of tile H., which went down instantly, there was but one American, Mr. CHARLES GERSHOM, who is among the seventeen saved.
FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT IN SOUTH CAROLINA.--The Charleston Courier of the 1st, contains the particulars of the late accident on the Columbia Railroad.

WRECKS OF THE YEAR.--It is stated in the report of the British National Institution for Preservation of Life from Shipwreck, that nearly 800 wrecks, with the loss of 870lives, took place during the year 1853.

THE BROOKLYN RIOTS--EXAMINATION OF THE PRISONERS POSTPONED.---AII the parties arrested at the riot in Main-street, on Sunday evening, have been held to bail. The further examination was postponed to the 12th or 14th inst. A considerable degree of feeling continues to be manifested relative to the arrests, but through the energetic measures adopted by the Chief Magistrate, peace has been preserved.

About 3 1/2 o'clock I was awakened again by the whistle of the locomotive, answering I suppose, the horn of a stage-coach, which in a few minutes drove up, bringing a mail. A negro man and woman, sleeping near me, woke, replenished the fire ; two other passengers came in and we started.

The New-Orleans Picayune learns the following from gentlemen who came through on the steamship Pampero on her last trip from San Juan. It is curious: "The steamship brought up twelve or fifteen slaves, who, together with their master, were on their return from California to Georgia.

Whatever the intentions of the late Mr. HOLFORD might have been, his property has not been bequeathed to the Prince of Wales. His deceased brother's children inherit it, under a will made in l845. The rumor that the Prince of Wales had been nominated heir seems to have originated in Mr. HOLFORD'S having jestingly remarked, when improving his house and grounds, that they were intended for the heir apparent to the Throne.

Cholera is taking up its outposts, and looking in upon us from the frontiers. We hear of it along the Mississippi, and from Ohio. An editor at St. Louis died of it last week; no doubt his was preceded by that of many a less known man, though the reports mention none.

CULTURE OF THE SWEET POTATO.--This delicious and wholesome vegetable may be raised without difficulty in the New England States. It will not be quite so highly flavored, or dark colored as the Southern, but is well worthy a place in every kitchen garden. By placing a potato in a hot bed, or even on the grass covered with fine loam and horse manure, sprouts enough may be obtained to plant several hills ;

Alderman WAKEMAN in the Chair. The Board met, last evening, pursuant to resolution for holding consecutive meetings until the business be disposed of. Petitions were received and referred from J. McBrain and others, praying that all proceedings in the matter of paving Forty-eighth-street, between Fourth and Fifth-avenues, he stayed, until a hearing has been had before the Street Committee;

WONDERFUL GEOLOGICAL DISCOVERY.--A fossil frog has been discovered in the Wabash bottom several feet below the surface, with half a dozen strata of mud above him ; to the formation of which, according to well established geological principles, a period of 6,000 years, each, may be attributed.

IRISH AND NEGRO ROW.--There was a protracted and somewhat bloody fight yesterday afternoon, on the dock at the foot of Washington-street, between some negroes and Irishmen. The parties were about equal in point of numbers when the affair began, but the Irish soon collected in great force, and, considering it a free fight, counted themselves in, and poor Cuffee had not a ghost of a chance.
A MODEL SPEECH.-- We commend the following speech tb the careful study of all candidates before the people: "FELLOW-CITIZENS: I am no speech maker--but what I say, I'll do.

THE WORK OF A SESSION.--Last session the House of Commons sat on 160 days, and the sittings occupied 1,173 hours, and, we are sorry to say, 133 of the hours were after midnight. Tile House received 11,164 petitions, disposed of 200 public bills and 366 private, and divided 257 times, 61 times after midnight.

The quiet and seclusion of this romantic place is yearly disturbed by an examination of the Military, conducted under the inspection of a Board of Visitors, when all various departments of the Academy are in turn subjected to vigorous tests, and a report made of the progress and condition of the Institution.

LOCATION OF THE STATE IDIOT ASYLUM.--We are pleased to learn that the Commission to locate the site of the State Idiot Asylum building have selected the property of Hon. E. W. LEAVENWORTH, situated near the western terminus of Seymour-street, near the western line of the city boundaries, as such site. Fifteen acres thereof are required.
We have received a great number of communications concerning our comments on the Brooklyn Riot,--the Know-Nothings, the Roman Catholic influence and kindred topics.

The Telegraph yesterday afternoon announced the arrival of the Niagara at Halifax :--but very soon after the wires wore cut East of Boston, and all further communication suspended. They were repaired as speedily as possible, but were again severed, and up to a late hour last night they were not in working order.

FROM THE RIO GRANDE.--Details of news from the Rio Grande bring a few interesting items from Brownsville: The Flag states that the imported goods alone which passed through Brownsville during the past year amounted, according to the collector's statement, to the large sum of five millions of dollars in value, and that the domestic manufactures could not fall short of that amount.

We understand that the Court Martial in the case of Major WYSE, has found him guilty of disobedience of orders in refusing to embark on board the steamship Falcon; and that he has been sentenced to dismission from the service, as a punishment therefore.

Mr. AIKEN, from the Committee on Commerce, reported a bill making appropriations for light-houses, light buoys, , and for tile erection and establishment of the same. Referred to the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union.

FIRE IN FAIRIHAVEN.--A fire broke out on Saturday morning, in the boatbuilders' shop owned by NATHANIEL S. HIGGINS, and occupied by W. H. HURSELL, situated on Main-street, near the shore. This was consumed, with a barn adjoining, also owned by Mr. HIGGINS. In the shop, the stock and tools were destroyed. with one new boat, two partly finished, and four old ones belonging to T.KNOWLES CO. of this city. Mr.

THE SECOND EPISTLE OF PETER. THE EPISTLES OF JOHN AND JUDAS, AND THE REVELATION: translated from the Greek on the basis of the common English version. New-York: AMERICAN BIBLE UNION. The Corresponding Secretary of the American Bible Union announces that this revision is not final.

Our special reporter returned yesterday from the scene of the murder at Cutchogue; bringing very full and authentic details of the murder, and the Confession of NICHOLAS BEHEEHAN, the murderer, together with the testimony adduced before the Coroner's Jury, and accounts of the ceremories which took place yesterday at the funeral of the victims.

The express train going east this evening ran over a cow on the track, a few miles west of this place. The locomotive and first baggage car were not thrown off, but the next three cars, comprising a first and second passenger and one baggage car were thrown down an embankment twelve feet deep. The baggage car was entirely smashed to pieces.

Four of those who were engaged in it have been found guilty and sentenced to be hung on the 28th of July next. The following is the sentence pronounced by Judge J. G. CARS FOR THE NEW ROUTE TO BOSTON.--Six magnificent passenger cars have just been turned out from this city for the New-York and Boston day and night express lines, over the NewYork and New-Haven, Hartford and New-Haven, and Western Railroads. More beautiful, thoroughly built and commodious cars we have never seen.

The following is an abstract of the first annual report of the Ladies' Industrial School Association of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn: This School is the first enterprise of the kind undertaken in Brooklyn, and at the termination of this, its first year, we would gratefully report the success which has attended our labors.

We have just received through the medium of our friend, the Consul-General of the Roman States, a beautiful engraving of the Madonna of Rimini, executed by the order of Monsignor BEDINI, from a photograph which he had brought with him to this country, and dedicated by him to the Catholics of the United States and the Canadas.

The Royal Mail steamship Niagara, Capt. LEITCH, from Liverpool on Saturday, the 27th ult., arrived at this port, en route for Boston, at an early hour this afternoon. There is no news from the seat of war of a decisive character. Silistria was hard pressed by the Russians at the last accounts.

TURKS ISLAND.--The Turks Island Royal Standard of the 18th ult. says: " Notwithstanding tile quantity of rain which fell during the week preceding our last issue, owing to the salt in many of the pans being well covered with pickle and to better rakings at Salt Cay. our stock has been greatly increased during the present week. Our export has been 27,000 bushels.

Whoever attains to the position of Member of Congress, says the Washington Star, cannot be a mere "common man." Hear him: " His district has a population of some 70,000. Among that population there are lawyers, physicians, divines, and gentlemen of fortune, leisure, and education. There are orators, logicians, savans, philosophers, and men deeply learned in the abstract and exact sciences.

Heap the coal into the furnaces. Turn it into gas. Construe it into any form for fuel or for light. There is no danger that the race can exhaust it. The old folks used to fret for fear the woods would give out, and the world in its last days go chattering and shivering to bed with cold.

MELANCHOLY ACCIDENT.--We are pained to announce the occurrence of a melancholy accident, which occurred this morning, at the White's Corners Road, about seven miles from this city. It appears that a party ofgentlemen--Mr. GEO. PROVOST, Mr. LEVI JOSLYN, and Mr. E. G. BARROWS, with a son of Mr. PROVOST, about 14 years of age--went out on a shooting expediion.
THE ANCIENT AND HONORABLE ARTILLERY COMPANY.--The 216th anniversary of the incorporation of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company, was celebrated yesterday.

TOBACCO.--It is not everybody that is willing either to smoke, be smoked, or see others smoked with impunity. Tile cigar, that "tube of comfort " to such multitudes, is to others an offence, and even a sin. At the Convention of Congregational Ministers lately held at Boston, Rev. Mr. TRASK, from the Committee appointed last year on the subject of "Tobacco," read a lengthy report.

The steamship Danicl Webster, from San Juan, Nicaragua, and the El Dorado, from Aspinwall, have arrived at this port, bringing California dates to the 15th May. The passengers have arrived here in 19 days and 20 hours from San Francisco.

An invitation from the Order of United Americans to the Common Council to unite with them in the celebration of the Fourth of July was accepted. D. E. The New-York Correspondents of the Press abroad furnish many a pleasant item that cannot with exact propriety find its way into the City Press, many a criticism that would hardly be ventured into the ears of men on the spot, though true enough;

ACCIDENT AT THE GAS WORKS.--By the breaking of one of the ropes used in lowering the first section of the new manmoth boiler iron gasometer into the tank of the gas works on Thursday afternoon, it fell suddenly a few feet, and about one-third of it warped inwards, breaking out the rivers so generally, that part must be reconstructed. The damage is about $1,000, and about a week's delay will be occasioned.

EXTRAORDINARY AFFAIR IN THE GULF.--As Capt. DANIEL GORMAN, of the ship Jessy, from Limerick, was on his outward voyage, and when about forty-five miles southeast of the Island of Anticosti, during a thick fog, and surrounded by field ice, he beard the report of a gun. Supposing it to be a signal from another vessel near at hand, he caused the fog bell to be rung, to avoid a collision.

The annual meeting of the Protestant Foster Home Association was held at Newark on Mon day. During six years 90 children have been received. General SAM HOUSTON, (called by everybody in Texas, HUSETON,) has just visited this region, and what would have seemed strange in any other General, he has dined and taken "pot luck" with his old enemies, Col. MORGAN and Dr. ASHBEL SMITH, who live on this Bay, and are both will to do in the world.

In Brooklyn. on Tuesday night, June 6, of croup, GEORGE DEMPSTER, son of Charles W. and Mary A. Colburn, aged 5 years, 4 months and 8 days. The relatives and friends of the family are requested to attend the funeral, from the residence of his parents. No. 2 Wilson-st., Brooklyn, on Thursday, 8th inst., at 11 o'clock, A. M., without further invitation. The remains will be taken to Greenwood for interment.

From the Washington Star. Mr. JOHN T. TOWERS is a man of some forty-four years of age, who has made his own way in the world. He was educated for a physician, after learning the trade of a printer, for which calling he subsequently abandoned pills and blisters. He is entirely self-made ;

On motion of Mr. HENN, the Committee on Offices and Post Roads was instructed to inquire into the expediency of establishing certain post routes in Nebraska and Kansas. Mr. HOESTON made an ineffectual effort to change the daily hour of meeting to 11 o'clock. The House went into Committee of the Whole on the Pacifica Railroad bill.

We are now in receipt of our California papers to May 16th, brought here by the Daniel Webster and El Dorado. The amount of treasure on board the George Law, en route for New-York, is $1,140,000. The George Law was detained for some time at Aspinwall, by the way-bills of the treasure failing to arrive with the treasure, and an express had to be sent to Panama for them.

A MAN SHOT BY LIEUT. CULLEN, OF MOYAMENSING.--About 8 3/4 o'clock last evening, word was sent to the station-house in Moyamensing, that a man was flourishing a bloody knife in a yard attached to a house in Christian-street, below Ninth. Lieut. CULLEN and two officers proceeded to the spot, where they discovered a man raving with excitement, and swearing that he would kill anybody who dared to approach him.

YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION.--The formation of a Young, Men's Christian Association in Jersey City has been determined upon, and at a meeting held for the purpose of taking preliminary steps, it was determined to appoint a Committee, with power to call a meeting on the first Monday in October next, for the purpose of organizing the Association, and to report a Constitution at that time.

A SHOCKING CASE OF HYDROPHOBIA.--About three weeks since, Mr. JOHN CROOKSON, foreman of SEMPLE'S Foundry, was bitten by a mad dog. The wound was healed up, and nothing further thought of it, until Thursday evening last, when he complained of feeling unwell. Yesterday morning he was taken with convulsive spasms, which gradually increased towards noon, when he became so violent as to require the strength of six or seven people to hold him.

An old bachelor, by the name of LYMAN SUTLIFF, living some six miles from Jefferson, Ashtabula Co., and who was well off in the world, had a fine farm, well stocked, lived in his house alone, and carried on his farm himself. About four weeks age the old man was missing and his house closed up.

The trial of James Antoni, for the murder of John Ferdinandi, an Italian exile, was commenced in the Kings County Oyer and Terminer on Monday, before Judges Rockwell and Moore, and Justices Stilwell and Stryker. The prisoner having no counsel, Alexander Moore, Esq., was assigned to the Charge of his case.

From the Washington Star. A Territorial Judge appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, for the term of four years, was removed from office and his successor appointed before the expiration of said term.

Either of the intelligent Saxon or Celt--Protestant or Papist, will probably agree, so far as you went. The grand and essential point lies deeper than this, however.

The public were pretty generally aware that a railroad and steamboat excursion--perhaps the most magnificent ever projected--was to come off during the present week. Those who could get no tickets broke the tenth commandment, while, those who received them went incontinently into ecstasies.

The excursion trains over the Rock Island Railroad left the depot a little after 8 o'clock this morning for Rock Island. Long before the hour fixed upon for leaving, throngs were wending their way toward the depot. where two trains, with nine spacious passenger cars each. were speedily filled with ladies and gentlemen. The morning was fine, and the gay assemblage were in excellent spirits.

The steamship George Law, Lieut. G. V. Fox, U. S. N., commanding, left Aspinwall, at 9 o'clock on the morning of May 31, and arrived a Quarantine at 5 o'clock, P. M., June 8, having been detained five hours by the fog off Sandy Hook. She brings the California mails of May 16, $973,472 in treasure on freight, and 134 passengers.

The National Industrial Congress met again to-day. The Committee on Business reported a series of resolutions from among the number offered by members: 1. They deny the doctrine that individuals upon entering civil society must give up a portion of their natural rights.

The U. S. Mail steamsip Hermann, E. HIGGINS, Commander, arrived this forenoon, from Bremen and Southampton, having left the latter port on the 24th ult. The H. brings 260 passengers, and a full carge of freight. Has experienced fine weather on the passage.

A sad accident occurred here yesterday. The wife, son and daughter of Dr. BACON, who resides about a mile south of this village, had driven in their carriage to the house of B. MOORE, Esq., half a mile north of it. They had entered the lane which leads to his house when the coachman stopped to close the gate, carelessly throwing the reins upon the dash board.

FELLOW-CITIZENS : The Committee appointed at the great Metropolitan hall meeting of March 7, 1853, to take measures for reforming the abuses then universally conceded to exist in the conduct of our local affairs, and whose proceedings were subsequently ratified, almost unanimously, by the adoption of the amended Charter, respectfully invite public attention to some further suggestions touching the important subject of municipal reform.

We are again inundated with treaties, protocols, manifestoes, memorandums, conventions and stipulations, not to speak of new conferences of the great Powers at Vienna and of the little ones at Bamberg. The English and French have agreed about the division of prizes.

The State Convention of the Democratic party; known as the " Morrill men," assembled here to-day. The City Hall was well filled. CHARLES J. TALBOT, of Farmington, was chosen President, with a Vice-President from each County in the State. Speeches were made by Gen. PERRY, of Oxford, Mr. TALBOT and others.
