CHILDREN'S FESTIVAL.--A very interesting performance took place at Knickerbocker Hall on Wednesday evening, on the occasion of the performance of Mr. ROOT'S popular cantata, "The Flower Queen," under the direction of Mr. A. C. WILLIAMS. Evergreens, trees and flowers decked the stage in profusion.

In some of our cotemporaries we perceive statements appealing to the bounty of the charitable respecting the islands of Zante and Cephalonia, portions of England's Ionian Protcctorate. The currant crop, the staple product of these islands, has failed for the last four years in succession, and the people of all ranks, high and low, have been reduced to the greatest distress.

Captain Alvin Fox, of Perkins, has long been acknowledged the best shot with a ride in this section of the State. His prowess was put to a fearful test on Thursday afternoon. A piece of card, two inches by 1 1/2 inch wide, was stuck into the slip of a piece of shingle three inches in lenght.

We devote a large portion of our available space this morning, to the Letter of Archbishop HUGHES in reply to the Speech of Senator CASS, on Religious Liberty. It is very long, but in this respect it falls behind the interminable sereed of the Michigan Senator. Its best points are its personal hits, at which the Archbishop is always happy.

WALLACO'S THEATRE.--To-night is the benefit of the Assistant Doorkeeper, Mr. MOORE. Mr. WALLACK appears as Erasmus Bookworm, in BUCKSTONE'S play of the "Scholar," and Mr. LESTER as Sir Charles Goldstream, in the excellent comedy of "Used Up." It is announced that this is the last week but one of the season.

The Rochester Union of the 6th instant, says: A little boy, son of Christopher Abersold, who resides on North-street, came to his death yesterday afternoon in a singular manner; as follows: Mr. A., who is an officer in the Grenadiers, was with the military, and his wife left home to see the procession, leaving the child in charge of an aged parent.

Believing that the general custom which suffers the first day of Conventions to pass without doing anything beyond the preliminary business of organizations Would be improved upon by the practical time-valuing men who compose this Congress, your reporter arrived at the Temperance Hall, Trenton, at mid-day, expecting to find the Industrial hive in full session. But he was disappointed.

Both the California packets arrived last evening, the Gcorge Law from Aspinwall, and the Star of the West from San Juan. Together they deliver at this port over two millions dollars in Gold Dust and Bars, and the California mails of the 16th of May. Mr. GLADSTONE, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, is not a favorite with the gentlemen of the City, as the London bankers and money lenders are called His plans for conducting the finances of the Government through the war, are severely criticised on the Stock Exchange.

Plunkett against The Manhattan Gas Company.--Action to recover damages for injuries occasioned to the plaintiff by the falling of an iron roof which was in process of erection over the company's works, in Eighteenth-street, on the 11th of August, 1852.

Supposing that news from the extreme western border of the States and Territories, and from the Upper Missouri, might be interesting to your readers, I have concluded to give you some acccount of what I have seen and heard here. This town, or rather city, as all new places in the West are ambitious of being styled, was founded about the year 1840.

The Democrats have agreed to proceed to the election of United States Senators to-morrow at 11 o'clock, A. M. The Legislature met in Convention this morning and elected Democrats to fill the vacancies in the Senate and House. Governor BAKER was inaugurated this afternoon.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The examination on of NICHOLAS BEHAN (as his name is spelled on a recent letter from his father, in Ireland,) took place here yesterday before Justices COREY and CORWIN, The testimony of the witnesses was a repetition of the same facts which you have heretofore published. The prisonor himself asserted his innocence, and gave a detailed statement of his whereabouts on the night of the murder.

During the month of May, there arrived at Baltimore, 23 ships, 27 barks, 26 brings and 145 schooners. Total arrivals 221; of which 17 ships, 14 barks, 10 brigs, and 12 schooners, were from foreign ports; and 7 ships, 12 Larks, 16 brigs and 133 schooners were coastwise. There cleared during the same time, 17 ships, 25 banks, 33 brigs and 268 schooners.
The newsboys make a terrible commotion crying the " Wide Awake, one cent." Judging from the name, many people supposed the TIMES had lowered its price.

We learn from private sources that Gov. KOSSUTH had been invited to visit Sheffield, one of the most important manufacturing towns in England, and to address a large meeting to be held there, for the purpose of urging the English Government not to close the war with Russia until the rights of the nations she has oppressed shall be secured.

On motion it was agreed that when the Senate adjourn, it be till Monday. Several petitions were presented. Mr. CLAYTON moved that the Chair fill the vacancy in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, caused by Mr. EVERETT'S resignation. Agreed to, and the Chair appointed Mr. FISH.

WIDENING OF BROOME-STREET.--The following notice is issued by parties opposed to the widening of Broome-street: TO THE PUBLIC. You are hereby notified that there is a petition to have Broome-street widened, from Laurens-street, and cut through to the Hudson River, in a straight line from Broadway, which would come out about 100 feet below Charlton-street. The cross streets are interested, and will be assessed also.

Some persons imaging that a high honor has been conferred on me by the importance assigned o my name in the great speech which General CASS has thought proper to pronounce in the Senate of the United States. The providence of God has directed that General CASS should serve not only his country but his race in one order of life, and that it should be my humble privilege to serve both in another.

The Continent of Africa is like such a great potato as Irishmen are said to enjoy best--one with a bone in it. Geographers make easy work with the outside, but they cannot set their teeth into the bone in its centre. In old books they used to call Africa the dry nurse of lions.

FIRST CATCH YOUR HARE.--Somebody has been writing an elaborate work on the Human Hair. We have not seen it; but if the author has treated the subject fairly, he must have divided the Human Hair into several millions of distinct heads. We have some idea of writing a sort of companion treatise to that on Human Hair, under the title of Bald Facts.

Yesterday morning, between 9 and 10 o'clock, much excitement was created in the State Prison at Sing Sing, consequent upon the attempt of a desperate. convict, named-SAMUEL MURRAY, to murder one of the keepers, and make his escape from prison. s sentenced'in this City

Mr. JOHN WISE, the aeronaut, made his one hundred and sixty-third Ballon ascension yesterday. A great crowd of lookers-on assembled within the Palace to witness the performance. The result of the ascension was quite satisfactory, so far as the going up went. In descending, however, Mr. WISE had a narrow escape.

STORM ON THE SOUTHERN COAST--Loss OF MAILS.--The steamer Seminole, Capt. POSTELL, arrived yesterday from Florida, reports that on Friday evening, when twenty miles at seat, on her return trip from Florida to this port, she encountered a violent gale which lasted, several hours.

Our readers probably recollect a paragraph published in the TIMES a few days since, concerning the pecuniary embarrassments in which Mr. NOBLE BUTLER had become involved, in consequence of the expenses of the trial of his brother's murderer.

The Southern mail this morning brings us New-Orleans papers of Saturday last. Galveston dates to the 31st ultimo continue to mention numerous Indian outrages. Captain GRAINGER writes from Fort Merrill that within a week past the Indians had done more damage than in the previous three years.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The marriage ceremony between Mr. and Mrs. RITCHIE was performed not by Rev. Mr. KEENE, as you have it, but by Rev. THOS. WILKS, a gentleman of unaffected learning and piety, who considers the graces and flourishes of rhetoric as of less importance than the sincerity and truth of his doctrine.

The opening of the Covington and Lexington Railroad to Cynthiana was celebrated at the latter place yesterday. A dinner was given to Hon. J. S. HARRISON, Representative in Congress from this County, this evening, as a testimonial of approval of his course on the Nebraska bill.

The early members who strayed into Temperance Hall this morning before the hour of meeting, were more enlivened than edified by the sudden appearance of Mrs. FANNY LEE TOWNSEND, a strong-minded lady, who, eschewing all ceremony, elevated her right foot upon the seat in true masculine fashion, and addressed every one indiscriminately, with a volubility that left no room for reply.
The National Industrial Convention spent to day us considering resolutions. Mr. SHEDDEN introdueed a number of Land Reform, and other reform resoultions, which were adopted.

From Havana we have dates to the 31st of May. There is little news of especial importance from the Island of Cuba, excepting that the Captain General continues his preparations against local insurrection and the possibility of attack from the United States.

From the New-Orleans Crescent, 31st ult. We have had some experience in piscatory exercises, but an officer of the Customs, named CASEY, beat us all hollow a few nights ago. He understood a secret, known only to experienced fishermen, of using the right bait.

Mr. FAULKNER announced the Death of his colleague, JOHN F. SNODGRASS, which occurred suddenly at Parkersburg, Va., on Monday last,--being the fifth member who had died since the commencement of the present Congress.

At an Eccelsiastical council held at the call of the Tyrone and Jersey Baptist Church in Steuben County N. Y., Rev. FREDERICK KENT, pastor of that church, was deposed from the ministry and Church fellowship, on various charges of misconduct.

At a State Convention of the friends of a law prohibiting the sale of intoxicating liquor, held at Harrisburg, Pa., last week, letters were read from the Whig and Democratic candidates for Governor, in reply to inquiries as to their opinions and action on the subject.

We have already announced the decision of the Courts of Inquiry in the cases of Col. GATES and Major WYSE. The official report in both cases will be found on our second page this morning. Major WYSE is found guilty of disobedience of orders, in having refused to embark four companies of the regiment under his command on board the Falcon;--but he is acquitted on the charge of conduct unbecoming an officer and a gentleman.

I wrote you this morning before leaving Chicago, and I have now to announce our arrival at Rock Island. The weather before we started was cloudy, and threatened a stormy day; but fortunately the evil omen was averted, and the skies became propitious.

KEY WEST--A WRECK.--The. United States steamer Corwin, Lieutenant Commanding CRAVEN, from Key West, reports that, off Cape Hatteras, she passed the brig Charles Thompson, or Thomas, of Salem, lumber loaded, full of water, and 2 schooners were alongside wrecking her.

Mr. MILLSON said, as no quorum was present to take a vote on laying on the table Mr. GIDDINGS' resolution expelling the Editor and Reporters of the Union from the floor, he proposed that the House go into Committee, with a view of taking up the Pacific Railroad bill, and thus saving a day. Agreed to.

"JORDON AN 'EASY' ROAD TO TRAVEL."--STRANGE OCCURRENCE.--A queer accident happened on the Central Road on Wednesday night last. An old lady, a passenger on the night express train west, when near Buffalo, stepped out upon the platform and fell off the car. She was not seen going out, nor was she missed until sometime after the accident occurred.

MORE TEXAS CATTLE FOR CALIFORNIA.--The Victoria Advocate, of the 13th instant, informs us that Messrs. MCRAE and RANKIN recently passed through that town with a drove of seven hundred stock-cattle and beeves, on their way to California. This company consisted of fifteen hardy resolute men, beside Messrs. MCRAE and RANKIN.

The U. S. mail steamer Pacific, which left Liverpool at 1 P. M., on the afternoon of Wednesday, May 31, arrived last evening. In lat. 46[degrees], lon 49[degrees], she passed the bark Princeton, of Wales, bound in, June 7; on the same day, she passed the British bark Chas. Totten, bound west; on the 10th passed a ship bound west, supposed to be a Philadelphia packet, but could not distinguish signals.

Well, the long agony is over. Austria and Prussia have informed the world that they are to act in concert in the impending struggle, and that in certain given cases they will simultaneously repel any attack, and that in certain other specified conjunctures, they will combinedly take up the offensive against Russia.

OUTRAGEOUS INSULT AND ASSAULT.--A most outrageous insult was offered to, and committed upon, the person of Mr. J. W. LEWIS, at the National Theatre, on Wednesday evening last. Mr. LEWIS, at the solicitation of parties, prominent among which was Mr. HARRINGTON, the prompter of the Theatre, for whose benefit the performances were given, consented to appear and pronounce an oration on the Drama.

The dedication ceremonies of the new Roman Catholic church erected under the patronage of St. Lawrence, in Yorkviile, were performed yesterday by Arch bishop HUQHES, assisted by the very Rev. Dr. STARES is the celebrant priest, Rev. WALTER I. QUARTERS Pastor, and several other clergymen.

Foremost in the attractions of this week stands preeminently the Musical Congress. This great under taking comes off, our readers are aware, on Thursday next at the Crystal Palace. It cannot be too firmly borne in mind, not too much patronized when it occurs.

His Excellency Governor SEYMOUR paid a visit to this institution on Saturday, in company with B. R. WINTHROP, Esq., and several other members of the Board of Education. The school is temporarily held in Ward School House No. 40, in Twentieth-street, awaiting the completion of increased accommodations in the Hall of the Board of Education, its former place of meeting.

Something definite and important with regard to our relations with Spain is anticipated in the course of the current week. For several days past the State Department and the Spanish Legation have been discussing the questions at issue between the two countries, and it is certain that they are likely to be arranged in a manner satisfactory to both.

The "Know-Nothings" were in Court in Morris County last week. During the empanneling of a jury a gentleman was challenged as belonging to that order, and a number of witnesses were called, who perseveringly "knew nothing," and the ground of the challenge could not be maintained.

The Post of Boston says that Professor STOWE has lately used the following language: "I pretend to no great things, but I here say that this beard don't leave this chin until the repeal of the Fugitive Slave law is secured."

SHEEP SHEARING FESTIVAL IN WISCONSIN.- A sheep shearing festival was held at Whitehall, Wis., on the 31st ult. Pens for the sheep were prepared, so arranged as to form a circle--the inside of which was occupied by the shearers. There were from 1,000 to 1,500 persons present.

From the Boston Traveller. St. John papers to June 6 have been received here. They are filled with articles on the coming Legislative elections. The candidates proposed in St. John have addressed their constituents. None of them appear to be in favor of Protection.

As to the health of the City, all but those in authority have occasion to take comfort and be of good cheer. The Inspector reports for last week 408 deaths, less by 17 than the previous week. Sickness has not been general, and no epidemics are more than usually prevalent. More than half of those who died had not attained to the eleventh birth day.
PUBLIC MEETING. The Land Reformers assembled here, careful to lose no opportunity of spreading their principles, held a public meeting in front of the City Hall steps last evening.

We were the first to announce last week the negotiation of a treaty at Washington, for reciprocal trade between the United States and Canada. The details of the arrangement have not yet been made public. We find in the Montreal Herald what purports to be a general statement of its provisions.

The Synod met at 9 o'clock. The proceedings were opened with a prayer by the President, Rev. Dr. HUTTON. The Clerk called the roll, and over one hundred delegates responded to their names. The minutes of the meeting were read and approved.

In this City, on Sunday, June 11, OLIVE M., wife of Joel Sammis. The funeral will be attended at her late residence, No. 11 Pike-st., on Monday, 12th inst., at 2 o'clock, P. M. Her remains will be taken to Huntington, L. I.

We publish this morning a very interesting narrative of Commodore PERRY'S second visit to Japan, to receive the reply of the authorities to the invitation of the United States to enter into closer commercial relations.

YOUNG MEN's DEMOCRATIC REPUBLICAN GENERAL COMMITTEE.--A Regular Monthly Meeting of this body was held last evening at its rooms in the Stayvesent Institute-C. GOUFREY GUNTHER in the Chair, M. C. LONG, Secretary.

A message was received from the House communicating the proceedings of that body on the occasion of the death of Hon. J. F. SNODGRASS of Virginia. Mr. MASON delivered a eulogy upon the virtues of the deceased, and offered the customary resolutions-when the Senate adjourned.
We stated some time ago, that, in our opinion, the first movement of the Revolutionary party in Europe would be made in Italy.
I have been attending the negro exhibition at Belen, the old church property converted into barracks for Artillery, where the formalities of enrollment of our negro protection is going forward.

Much excitement was caused here yesterday and to-day, by a report that two persons from Virginia had arrived in Lowell in search of EDWIN MOORE, a colored barber, formerly resident in Lowell and now keeping shop here. MOORE is alleged to have escaped from Virginia, where he was a slave, twelve years since.
The following is the WEEKLY REPORT OF DEATHS in the City and County of New-York, from the 3d day of June to the 10th day of June, 1854. Men, 95; women, 91; boys, 132; girls, 90. Total, 408.

The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, on Tuesday afternoon June 13, at 3 1/2 o'clock, from her late residence. A WARNING STORY FOR LORD DERBY. Lord DERBY has avowed his chivalrous determination to run at the Press, when offended by the light cast abroad by it upon any subject that, as his Lord ship believes, ought to-remain in sacred obscurity. For the timely instruction and benefit of Lord DERBY, Mr. Punch humbly begs permission to relate to him a true story. (See Newspapers at PEELE's Coffee-house.)
When the Maine Law grounded on Governor SEYMOUR'S veto, some good people in our City were disposed to desert all projects of reform flat were based on the suppression of intemperance.
Crops in Orange County are looking well. In spite of a backward Spring, variable weather at the beginning of Summer, and untoward circumstances generally, the grains have come forward handsomely.

FROM PORTO RICO.--By the bark J. W. Dyer, (May 29,) we learn that heavy rains had set in, which greatly retarded the taking off the crop. American vessels were scarce throughout the island and St. Thomas. They were much wanted.

The environs of Quebec are well worth more than one-visit. Every year in the Summer time, hosts of our countrymen descend upon that devoted city and " do " it. They rush madly from he boat to SWORDS' Hotel, or RUSSLL's, frantically inscribe their names and whereabouts on the books, and after swallowing a sort of railway breakfast, proceed to "do" the lions.

The New-York Light Guard, with Dodworth's Band, command much attention from our military and citizens generally. They are the special guests of the Boston Light Infantry. Capt. ROGERS, and this afternoon both companies were reviewed on the Common by Major General EDMANDS and staff.

CITIZENS: Near thirty years ago, when I was young in the Senate, and the intercourse between Missouri and New-Mexico had just commenced, I procured the passage of an act of Congress to facilitate and promote that intercourse, and to make it permanent and profitable to the State.

The Synod met at 9 o'clock, agreeably to adjournment. Rev. MARCUS S. HUTTON, D. D., the President, in the Chair. The proceedings were opened with a prayer by the President. The roll of the Synod was called, and about sixty delegates answered to their names.

The statement is traveling overthe country that WARREN WINSLOW, who went to Madrid with dispatches to Mr. SOULE, in relation to the Black Warrior affair, is about to return to that Court with a specific offer for the purchase of Cuba. As much credence is given to the rumor, I may as well say it is unfounded.

From the New-Orleans Picayune. The revolutionary movements in Mexico are assuming an important aspect. Every steamer hereafter may be looked for with new interest. We have heretofore expressed a strong hope for the regeneration of Mexico; and welcome some of the signs that the national heart Is not dead, but may yet be quickened into renewed life.

The Susquehanna arrived at Hong Kong from Japan on the 2d (April), bringing the gratifying intelligence that Commodore PERRY had succeeded in the objects of his mission in a manner that will confer honor on his country and enduring fame on himself.

COPENHAGEN, May 18.--Owing to the politeness of the editors, I have now been able to see the new composing machine as in actual operation in the office of the Fadrelandet.

There is the greatest excitement at Lawrence, growing out of the late kidnapping of a girl about fir teen years old. The outrage was an exceedingly gross one, and has called forth the utmost indignation of the best citizens of that city.

The Richmond Enquirer is much disturbed at the dilatory diplomacy of the Administration in regard to Cuba, and takes the Executive tool of the Slaveholding power roundly to task because " so little has been achieved towards the solution of the Cuban problem."

Lord 'JOHN 'RUSSELL displays a consistency in connection with the Jewish Disabilities bill very unusual in so fickle. and procrastinating a Minister. On May the 25th, the second reading of the bill was moved, when a singular and unexpected debate took place.

COUNTERFEITING TRADE-MARKS, -- The rigid enforcement of the law against counterfeiting trade-marks is essential lot only to the pecuniary interests of merchants, but also to the sanitary interests of the public. In London there was recently seized a large quantity of spurious ale which whether pale in itself or not, was pretty likely to impart that hue to imbibers.

The bark Antelope arrived here to-day with advices from Rio de Janeiro to the 1st of May. BREAD-; STUFFS were exceedingly-dull with large receipts. -No; sales were reported, holders' views being above the, market rates.

A lamentable accident happened in this city this morning. A gravel train had stopped until some cattle were driven off the track, and two laborers on the cars were throwing stones to assist in driving them away, when the train suddenly started, and both the men were precipitated on the track.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: It is evident that there is great danger of a more serious riot in Brooklyn or here than has yet occurred, growing out of the Sunday harangues of ORR and others of his kind. A question therefore arises whether the means which are now being used, are the best that can be adopted to preserve the peace.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Having seen a letter from Mr. MICHAEL DOHENY concerning the superiority of the Irish Celtic race over the Anglo-Saxon, I was somewhat surprised at the language of the writer, and at the historical information he boasts of. He says that he for one will not shrink from the comparison, and appears to be much surprised at your indifference to the voice of history.

NEBRASKA AND KANZAS.--We understand that all the Indian tribes in these two new United States Territories have concluded treaties with the Commissioner of Indian Affairs, for the relinquishment of the lands at present occupied by them within the scope of country proposed to be included under the two new governments.

From the Delaware Republican. So far as can be ascertained there were only five persons killed by the late explosion in our city. An arm was found which was thought to belong to a female, but so far we have heard of no one being missed. The report that a carriage was near at the time, is certainly without foundation.

The steamship Isabel arrived here on Saturday evening, with Havana and Key West dates of the 8th inst. It was rumored in Havana (but not generally credited) that the Spanish steamer Guadalquiver had an action with two schooners of St. Jago de Cuba, which she captured and carried into that port.

FOR PUGET'S SOUND.--We see by the Cincinnati Commercial that Messrs. ISRAEL and LEWIS GARRARD, sons of Mrs. Judge McLEAN, are making preparations for an overland trip to Puget's Sound, the capital of Washington Territory. LEWIS, if we are not mistaken, when quite a boy spent some time among the Indians and trappers of New-Mexico, and published a very interesting account of his adventures.

We have the pleasure to lay before our readers a letter from Rev. Dr. DUFF, to his friend R. L. STUART, Esq. The Doctor, it will be recollected, went out in the steamer Arctic, and reached Edinburg in season to attend the meeting of the General Assembly.

From the Washington Star. We regret to have to state that this efficient officer is confined to his lodgings, in this city, by very severe indisposition. Col. MONEYPENNY, after being for years accustomed to a life wherein he was compelled to take much bodily exercise, has been very closely confined, indeed, ever since taking charge of the Indian Buicau.

The Nebraska bill was framed and introduced by a leading Democratic Senator, and a Democratic candidate for the Presidency. It was afterwards espoused by a Democratic President, sustained as an Administration measure, pushed by the whole weight and influence of the Democratic party, and made a test, in Congress and out, of fealty to Democratic principles.

A young man named A. G. Champ, formerly of Pittsburg, committed suicide by hanging, at the Sault, on Sunday night last. He had been employed to act an clerk to the National Mine, on Lake Superior, and went up the Lake to Ontonagon with the intention of landing at that port. but the state of the weather was such as to prevent the boat from touching there, and he returned to the Sault.

NEW-YORK OUTDONE--The PATENT SAFE GAME ECLIPSED.--As two verdant specimens, on Saturday last, were perambulating the classic grounds near Chepatchet, intent on seeing the country, they were gratified at a small cost with a view of the elephant. Being previously joined by a friendly individual, they were soon accosted by an apparent stranger who had a dog collar in his hand.

Major Gen. B. F. Edmands, Commander of the military force ordered out at Boston, by requisition of Mayor Smith, has put his name to a petition for the repeal of the Fugitive Slave law. The editor of the Gazette, an officer of the Boston Light Infantry, Says that nine-tenths of the men on duty sympathized with the slave.

Let the people get into a state of excitement;--let outsiders rage, and those who have an object to gain, make the most of the fact that we had fourteen fatal cases of Cholera reported last week, and that at Quarantine, Small-Pox abounds. Now, it is not to be denied that Cholera has visited our City this season.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: In your remarks of the 9th instant upon Mr. BARING and "the London Times," relative to the British Chancellor of the Exchequer's new mode of raising money, you say it "will be found quite readable on this side the water."

I request you to pile the Highlands on the Palisades, and very often the Palisades upon the Highlands, that you may get some idea of the scenery of the Upper Mississippi. You would, even then, fall short of any tolerable notion of its peculiar wild grandeur. Perhaps you have beheld such sublimity in dreams, but surely never in daylight walking elsewhere in this wonderful world.

We have dates from Havana to June 8. There is no news of importance, n?? contained in the letter of our regular correspondent. Correspondence from Spain to the Diario de la Marina dilates upon the proposed augmentation of the Spanish forces in Cuba, without stating any particular facts, although the promise of performance is large.

The following extract of a private letter to the Editor of this paper, is from an intelligent and reliable source: JACKSON, MISS., Sunday, June 4, 1854. My DEAR SIR: You will, no doubt, get any important information from this quarter earlier than I could give if you; but I may as well give you the current Cuba rumors.

The Cunard mail steamer Arabia, from Liverpool Saturday, June 3, at 1 P. M., arrived at this port last evening at 8 1/2 o'clock. The Pacific sailed from Liverpool Wednesday, May 31, at 1:30 P. M. The U. S. mail steamer Washington arrived off Cowes on Friday morning, and proceeded to destination.

From the Chicago Tribune. While the public are watching the vast tide of travel that sets backward on all of our Western railroad, and speculators in stocks calculate the extent of monthly receipts and dividends, very little appears to be known of the business of the great Underground Railroad.

LATER FROM TEXAS--We have papers from Galveston to the 4th inst., from Houston to the 3d, Santa Fe to the 29th of April, c. We find the following item in the Galveston Times of the 4th inst.: We were informed yesterday that the steamer Clifton had sunk in the Trinity River, five miles above Magnolia.

A distinguished Senator, for a quarter of a century in the public councils, is thoroughly convinced that the ultra-Southern party is determined to obtain possesion of Cuba and after that, to separate from the Northern States. He is not an alarmist, but an experienced, cool-headed, and sagacious statesman, of the conservative school, and a decided opponent of the fanatics of every section.

From the Washington Star. We learn Governor STEPHENS, of Washington Territory, has very recently made a report to the Secretary of the Interior Department, wherein he urges the necessity of holding a general council with the Indians of his Territory, in which the latter have already signified their willingness to take a part.

The appeal to the Supreme Court of New-York, taken just at this time by order in the Legislature of Virginia, against the decision of the LEMMON case rendered by Judge PAINE, of the Superior Court, is a significant fact--the importance of which in its policy and general reach should not be overlooked.

One of those "underground railroad" conductors, a citizen of Henderson, Ky., passed through our city night before last on his return from delivering, per contract, four female salves at the Canada depot in Petersburg, Ind. Information had been lodged with Marshal WARD that this man BROWN, who was well known here as a notion peddler, was suspected, and he directed the ferry to be watched, as he (BROWN) was expected to return about that time.

An immense crowd assembly in Independence-square to-day, to witness the inauguration of Mayor CONRAD. After taking the oath of office, the Mayor commenced delivering an inaugural speech, in the mid at of which he was interrupted by a tremendous shower. A great portion of the crowd fled to the vestibule of the Hall, and the Mayor took his position on the stair-way to finish his speech.

THE HOLLISTER CASE.--We find the following article in the Utica Herald of yesterday: "This case was brought to a close an Saturday. The forenoon was occupied by Mr. JENKINS, who made a very elaborate and very ingenious plea for the defence. He was followed in the afternoon by Judge GRIDLEY in a plea remarkable for the compactness of its arguments, the cogency of its logic and the eloquence of its appeals.

ANOTHER CARE OF HYDROPHOBIA.--About six weeks since a man named JOHN WELSH, residing on the Lexington Pike, near Ninth-Street, Was bitten by a ferocious dog, in the wrist and thigh. The would healed without his consulting any of the medical faculty, and the occurrence was almost forgotten.

The House refused to lay the Anti-Nebraska resolutions on the table, by 158 to 147, four Democrats and one Whig being absent. A motion to refer the resolutions to a Special Committees is now under discussion, and has opened up the whole question of Nebraska and the Compromise.

A decision which will excite no little interest and comment, has just been made in the Supreme Court of Wisconsin. S. M. BOOTH, citizen of Michigan, was in custody of the United States Marshall upon a charge of obstructing the execution of the Act of September, 1850, known as the Fugitive Slave Law. Upon application to the State Supreme Court, a writ of habeas corpus was granted.

CAPILLARY ATTRACTION ACCOUNTED FOR.--Nitrate of silver, they say, is coming to be quite an article of commerce for purposes not generally recognized. It used to be principally employed for marking linen. Then bronchitis came into repute, and nitrate of silver was in demand to cure it.

MARRIAGE OF CAPTAIN RYNDERS.--A BIT OF ROMANCE.--It is related by "Roderick," the Baltimore correspondent of the Washington Star, that Captain RYNDERS, well known as President of the "Empire Club," in New-York, and now an officer of the Custom-House, arrived in Baltimore on Friday evening, from the North, accompanied by a beautiful young lady.

Mr. WELLER presented the joint resolutions of the legislature of California, sustaining the principle of the Nebraska bill. He said the resolutions had passed the Legislature with but ten dissenting votes in the House and seven in the Senate. It was gratifying to the delegation in Congress from California to have their action approved by their constituents.

MEDICINE A. STATE INSTITUTION IN SPAIN.--The Gazette publishes a Royal degree to the following effect: ART. 2. Every town and locality in the kingdom are in future to be provided with physicians, surgeons, and apothecaries. whose duty it will be to dispense medical aid in the indigent classes, and any other persons who may require their attendance.

Rumors begin to prevail again about the intention of the Slave States to dissolve the Union. If their object is simply to alarm the North, and under cover of that panic to push their projects of aggrandizement, they have chosen their time badly, I because they will find it difficult to make anybody believe they are in earnest.

Both Houses of Congress are in tolerably good working order; consequently the transaction of a portion of the legitimate business which has long been waiting their pleasure may be looked for soon. The principal subject in the Senate yesterday was the vetoed Insane Land bill, on which Senator CASS spoke for more than an hour.

BROOKLYN BOARD OF HEALTH.--THE CHOLERA.--This Board assembled yesterday, Mayor LAMBERT in the Chair. The following notice was adopted: Whereas, It is rumored that the cholera exists in out city--Now, therefore, in order to allay any undue excitement, physicians are requested to report form with every case and locality to this office, so that our fellow citizens may have full and satisfactory information on the subject.

AN EXCITEMENT AND A FIGHT.--About 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, there was quite an excitement in the upper part of Main-street, and on Central-row. People were hurrying towards the latter point, and some said a mad dog had gone that way, and others that there had been a terrible fight, and others that a man had been shot, but what really was to pay it was difficult to tell.

The preparations for the forthcoming Musical Congress are going on with unusual rapidity. The mammoth Orchestra has already been erected, and yesterday morning it was occupied for the first time by a portion of the musical forces to assemble on Thursday. To-day there will be two rehearsals, and to-morrow morning a final cooperation of all the artistes.

King OTHO has become honest in spite of himself. He has dismissed his ministers and declared a strict neutrality,--in other words, he obeyed the ultimatum, presented at the point of 8,000 French bayonets, a force that had previously seized upon all the Greek men-of-war and occupied Athens.

The steamship Orizaba has arrived at this port with dates from the City of Mexico to the 5th inst. It is reported that the Gadsden Treaty had not been accepted by SANTA ANNA, but is returned to Washington with some unknown amendments. Great preparations were being made to celebrate SANTA ANNA'S birthday on the 13th inst, when, it was currently reported, he would declare himself Emperor.

This scientific body held its forty-third annual meeting in the city of Providence on Wednesday, June 7. The Regular annual discourse was delivered by Dr. S. CLAPP, of Pawtucket, North Providence, being a very complete and elaborate view of our knowledge of the disease called Diabetes mellitus, and of the recent physiological observations and experiments, by which its nature has been illustrated, and a way opened for the discovery of a successful treatment.

In this City, on Monday, June 12, NICHOLAS GOUVERNEUR, Esq., in the 62d year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, without further invitation. at the Church of the Ascension, of Thursday morning, 15th inst., at ?? o'clock. In Brooklyn, on Monday, June 12, JULIA C., daughter of Conrad C. Eliery, aged 14 years.

ANOTHER TRAGEDY.--The peaceful citizens of Carlisle were aroused from slumber a week ago, Sunday morning, with the fearful cry of "murder." In a brief affray between two parties of midnight strollers, one half-intoxicated youth inflicted a severe stab with a pocket bowie-knife, upon the right breast of another in a similar drunken condition, causing his death in about two hours after.

TESTIMONIAL TO JOSEPH McKEEN, ESQ., LATE COUNTY SUPERINTENDENT.--A meeting of the Teachers of the Common Schools of the City was held at Odd Fellows' Hall last evening, to take measures for presenting a testimonial of esteem to JOSEPH McKEEN, Esq. JOHN J. DOANE was appointed Chairman, and W. W. SMITH, Secretary.

Mr. CLAYTON said the Union charged him with in consistency in opposing that part of the Nebraska bill allowing aliens to vote, while he voted for the Compromise of 1848, which allowed the same thing. He then explained his action in 1848, and contended that, on the question of allowing aliens to vote, his course had been always uniform. Mr. GWIN gave notice of a bill amending the Judicial System, by establishing an additional Circuit.

You will, by this time, of course, have received news of the Austro-Prussian Treaty, which excites so much remark on this side of the water. More than three months ago, I expressed to you my belief that England and France would do everything in their power to win over Austria, in the heginning, at least, and that the latter would strive to keep up the illusion as long as possible.

In this City, on Wednesday, June 14, JOHN HENRY, son of George and Catharine R. Pratt in the 20th year of this age. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully requested to attend his funeral. this day, (Thursday) at 2 o'clock, P.M., from the residence of his parents. No. 359 Gth-av., without further notice. Interment in the Cematery of Evergreens.

THE CHOLERA.--No new cases of cholera were reported at the Health Office yesterday. Dr. CLARK was a called to attend a young man--a resident of this city--who was attacked on Monday night, at Quincy, and brought hither in a chaise. The unfortunate patient was in a state of collapse, and there was but little hope of recovery. He was taken to Deer Island.

ANTI-NEBRASKA IN IOWA.--The Whigs of the Second District in Iowa, in convention at Iowa City, have nominated JAMES THORINGTON, Esq., of Davenport, as a candidate for Congress, in the place of Hon. I. P. Cook, who declines a reelection.

The "Baxter Blues," of New-York, accompanied by Shelton's Hand, visited this place to-day as the guests of the Stanford Light Guard, who turned out with the Stamford Cornet Band, to escort them from the depot.

Mary Jane Jones, by her husband James Jones, vs. William Crowell et al, owners of the ship Jane D. Cooper.-- The libellant sues for wages due her as stewardess of the ship during a voyage from New-York to Liverpool and back between November 1852 and March 1853, at the rate of $10 a month, claiming a balance due her of $23.

If the information given by one of our correspondents in Mississippi yetserday be true-and we see no reason to doubt it the Richmond Enquirer must have been aware of the facts, and that puts a some what different face upon the admonition to the President of the United States, on which we offered some remarks day before yesterday.

The Washington Star had an article the other day,--designed doubtless to comfort some conscience-smitten members whose dull sense had been quickened by the resolutions of their constituents to see how small they really were--on the dignity of membership in Congress.

The synod met at 3 o'clock, Rev. Dr. HUTTON, the President, in the Chair. Over one hundred delegates were present. NEW-YORK COLONIZATION SOCIETY. Rev. HENRY CONNELLY, agent of the Colonization Society, was invited to address the Synod. He said that an aged slave in South Carolina had said to him that they were spiritually free, though still held in bondage.

Our Washington Correspondent sent us by Telegraph a brief notice of a clause in the Nebraska Bill, of which the effect would be to exclude all but citizens of the United States from the right of suffrage in the Territories of Nebraska and Kansas.

We have heard but little of late concerning the movements of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad Company, which was organized something like a year ago under the auspices of ROBERT J. WALKER, LEVI S. CHATFIELD and other distinguished political financiers.

The convention of both branches of the Legislature balloted for State officers to-day, with the following results: For Secretary of State--JOHN L. HADLEY of Concord, Democrat, had 168 votes; GEORGE S. TOWLE of Lebanon, Whig, 109; MOSES A. CARTLAND OF Lee, Free Soil 44; Blank I; HADLEY'S majority 15. Every member was present and voted, except one Democrat absent from sickness.

Lord JOHN RUSSELL and Mr. D'ISRAELI had a sharp personal debate in the House of Commons recently. Personalities in Parliament, however, mean something very different from what we understand by personalities in Congress,-inasmuch as neither party sings the gentleman in the combatant.

The great day of all musical days has arrived. At 4 o'clock this afternoon the Crystal Palace will open its gates for the reception of all who take interest in art; of all who are awake to true excellence ; of all who can appreciate the best works of the "divine art," rendered in the best and most perfect manner.

Were you ever a teacher, or the lover of a teacher? If so you will appreciate my feelings as I tell you that I was glad when I woke up on Thursday morning, and reflected that that day I was going off to attend the Suffolk County Teachers' Association.

The City Watchman for Jersey city, for the ensuing year, have been appointed by the Common Council, as follows: First Ward -- Daniel Calhoun, Jos. H. Fairbanks, Jonathan H. Baldwin, and J. S. McDonald. Two vacaneies in this Ward remain to be tilled.

Alderman WAKEMAN in the Chair. CATTLE DRIVING THROUGH THE STREETS. Alderman MOTT inquired if the Committee on Ordinances were prepared to report upon an ordinance referred to them some two months since, to prevent the driving of cattle through the streets ? Alderman LORD replied that the ordinance prepared by the gentleman from the Twenty-first and Submitted to the Committee was under consideration.

Las October I left Highland Park and its beautiful surroundings for the smoke of the city. I am now revisiting it, amidst the boom of the Spring. The scent of roses perfumes the air, and the songs of birds murmur on my ear. It is no wonder the heated and wearied citizen longs for the country, and sometimes indulges his taste at the expense of his pocket.

RAILROAD TRACK TORN UP BY THE PEOPLE. The railroad leading from this city to the gravel bank belonging to the Cleveland and Columbus Railroad Company, was torn up yesterday by a few individuals living in Franklinton, who claimed that the Company, in hauling the gravel, had injured Gift-street, in that ancient town, t??ereby cutting off the communication between the road and their slaughter-houses, upon the banks of the river.

LAUNCH.-- The new steam-tug Mercury will be launched from the yard of WM. COLLYER, at Green Point, to-day, at 11/2 P.M. The Mercury is a powerful beat, built with very heavy timber, with unusually thick planking, ceilings, , and is extra copper-fastened and coppered. She has a very powerful engine, built at the Allaire Works.

TERRIFIC EXPLOSION IN BRIGHTON-STREET. FIVE MEN BADLY SCALDED.--At 2 1/2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the boiler in the establishment of S. G. TAYLOR, Nos. 20 and 22 Brighton-street, collapsed a flue, seriously injuring five workmen, including the engineer.

The Annual Report of the Board of Education, long expected, has at length reached our hands. Nothing in this valuable record of our educational enterprise has interested us more than the account of the Evening Schools.

The following letter, from Mrs. SHIRLY, of Rahway, N. J., to her husband, at Forest Hall, gives a thrilling narrative of an adventure with a mad dog: MY DEAR JOHN: I had not sent your last letter much over an hour this morning, when we were all thrown into the utmost alarm and terror by a mad dog that got into our house.

Circumstances are gradually foreing upon me the belief, which I have been endeavoring for some time to resist, that old Referendary HAUTPOUL is to be made a Marshal of France. This individual has been an inefficient Minister of War, and an incompetent Governor-General of Algeria.

Documents emanating from the chief Engineer of the Fire Department have been sent us, treating at length of the subjects of insubordination in the Department and the facts relative to the action of firemen at the Broadway calamity. These representations have been laid before the Common Council, and are intended by Mr. CARSON to effect unfavorable impressions which have gone abroad.

The Councilmen last evening received and laid on the table a second communication from Mr. GENIN, in reference to the streets of the Sixteenth Ward. Mr. GENIN'S first communication was met by the earnest remonstrances of members of the Board, on the ground that it was not respectful intone.

The Senate yesterday considered the resolution adopted recently by the House, to adjourn on the 14th of August next. It was amended and adopted, reading that Congress adjourn from July 17 to October 16.

The Annual Excursion of the "City Guard" was concluded yesterday. The Company paraded on Wednesday, and went to Glen Cove, L. I., where they passed the day pleasantly. The City Guard is one of the oldest of our Military Companies. It forms a part of the Twelfth Regiment New-York State Militia, and when the command of captain McARDLE, obtained great celebrity.

The Chevalier J. C. GEVERS, formerly Charge 'd' Affaires of his Majesty the king of the Netherlands to the United States, has arrived at Washington to fill again the Administration journals that Mr. GEVERS, has come with full power to settle all clams against his Government, and to hear the charges and complaints of Captain GIBSON, who has made a demand for compensation for his imprisonment--National Intelligencer.

The Synod was opened with prayer by the President. Dr. CHAMBERS asked leave to postpone the order of the day, to hear a statement from Mr. EBAUGH, which was not granted. CORRESPONDENCE. The order of the day--which was the consideration of the Report of the Committee on Correspondence--was then taken up.

This celebrated preacher [Dr. CAHILL] is now in Ireland, and preached the opening sermon on Sunday. He will preach in a few other places previous to his departure for the Great Republic. whither he is to go in October, and has already made the necessary arrangements. All the companies whose vessels trade between Great Britain and America, have in the handsomest manner offered him free passage.

The New-York Light Guard are experiencing large-hearted hospitalities at the hands of the Boston Light Infantry. At their grand dinner, Lieutenant CLAPP, of the Light Infantry, was announced as the Toast Master for the evening, and gave the first regular sentiment.

Rumor after rumor has reached our ears from different quarters, and about the different movements of the Turkish armies; but we can substantiate nothing, and it is needless repeating false statements. There is an uproar in the camp. Brigadier Gen. BROWN has been ordered to embark to-day with one division of the British Army, consisting of 6,000 men, to some port of the Black Sea.

Yesterday afternoon, between 12 and 1 o'clock, a fire broke out on the southeast corner of the extensive block of brick buildings belonging to WILLIAM T. MERRIFIELD. The buildings were four stories in height, and if placed in a continuous line would measure 900 feet in length.

The Democratic State Convention met here to day. Ex-Governor HUBBARD presided. After the appointment of Committees, and the transaction of other preliminary business, this forenoon, the Convention adjourned. At 2 o'clock this afternoon the Convention reassembled, and the several Committees made their reports,--all of which were unanimously accepted.

The first musical Reunion--or Congress--as it is more properly named-came off last evening at the Crystal Palace, and met with the success such an undertaking deserves and will always receive, when, as in the present case, it is organized in an efficient and praiseworthy manner.

A large and enthusiastic Anti-Nebraska Meeting was held at Madison, Indiana, yesterday, composed chiefly of Democrats. Resolutions were passed, repudiating the Democratic Platform manufactured at Indianapolis recently, on the ground that it pledged the Democracy to the extension of whisky and Slavery. A Mass Convention was recommended to be held at Indianapolis on the 13th of July.

The Annual Examination of the U. S. Corps of Cadets will probably close on next Saturday, and the Corps will encamp the following week. The first or graduating class will leave on Friday, and will have a furlough of three months before being sent to duty with their regiments.

To the Editors of the National Intelligencer: GENTLEMEN: While the proceedings in Congress are occupying public attention more particularly with the subject of the Pacific Railway, I desire to offer to your paper for publication some general results of a recent Winter expedition across the Rocky Mountains, confining myself to mere results in anticipation of a fuller report, with maps and illustrations, which will necessarily take some months to prepare.

No preparations have been made for a riotous demonstration in Brooklyn tomorrow, so far as we are yet aware. The only precaution taken by the authorities to guard against a repetition of the scenes of the last two Sundays, is a standing order to the Military Companies of the city to assemble in their armories, at the signal of twelve strokes upon the fire-bells.

The U. S. Mail steamer Cahawba, R. W. SHUFELDT, Commander, arrived here at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, having left Mobile on the 9th, and Havana on the 12th. She brings 1,100 bales of cotton on freight, and 167 passengers.

She soon became notorious. Of a free and easy disposition, loose notions of morality and winning manners, she attracted hosts of admirers, and among them a Serjeant of the line, to whom she was afterwards married. It is really refreshing now and then to come across a bit of genuine human weakness. It is not that we have any peculiar sympathy with impostors. We regret, perhaps, that their acuteness has been turned to so poor an account as that of making capital out of the follies of their neighbors, but we echo--vehemently echo--the voice of public opinion, and denounce, as becomes indignant moralists, the wickedness of human beasts of prey.

At Hartford, Conn., on Wednesday, June 14, by Rev. Dr. Hawes, OLIVER ELLSWORTH, of Stonington. Conn., to CAROLINE C., daughter of Roswell C. Smith, Esq., of the former place. In this City, on Thursday, June 15, by Rev. Dr. George H. Fisher, Mr. J. C. C. REYNOLDS to Miss CATHARINE M., daughter of Stephen Keeler, all of this City.

DIABOLICAL ATTEMPT TO POISON CHILDREN IN BROOKLYN.--An attempt was made on Wednesday last, by some unknown person or persons, to poison several children of Mr. JOSEPH CARMER, residing at No. 381 Atlantic-street, a few doors above Bond.

It is announced that Mr. T. R. WESTBROOK Member of Congress from the Eleventh District in this State, is to be appointed District Attorney for this District, in place of CHARLES O'CONOR. Mr. WESTBROOK lives in Ulster County. His qualifications for the office consist in the fact, that he voted for the Nebraska bill.

A large concourse of people assembled yesterday afternoon, on Goat Island, to witness J. R. ROBINSON'S attempt to reach the canal-boat in the Rapids, mention of which we have heretofore made. The boat, which had been constructed on purpose for this attempt, first started from the head of the Hydraulic Canal, with a son of Mr. ROBINSON'S and two others.

From the Citizen of To-day. There have been tears for Poland. The good, the generous, the gallant of all climes have rapturously read her brilliant story, and, coming to the pages which record her downfall and dismemberment, have wept in anguish over the sorrows that have pierced the noble hear of old Sarmatia.

The Tariff Act, on which the House Committee of Ways and Means have agreed, adds the following articles to the free list: All books, maps, apparatus, and other articles imported for the use of the United States. Also, statuary, busts, paintings, drawings, etchings, cabinets of coins, collections of antiquities, , for the use of Colleges and Schools. .

Simultaneously with the good news from Japan of the successful mission of Commodore PERRY, we have from Washington the confirmation by the Senate of the South American treaties of trade and navigation, made by Mr. SCHENCK and Mr. PENDLETON, on behalf of the United States, In 1852-'3.

The Board met pursuant to adjournment, EDWIN J. BROWN, Esq., in the Chair. The Board received and referred the following PETITIONS. For a sewer in Twenty-sixth-street, from Tenth-avenue to the North River. Of John P. Dean, to be allowed to contract to supply marble for the New City Hall. Of J. E. Purser, for permission to exhibit his Fire Escape.

RESULT OF THE RIFLE MATCH--On the third page of this morning's TIMES we publish an account of the first day of the rifle match between Mr. LEWIS, of Troy, N. Y., and Mr. JAMES, of Utica. Since receiving that, we have received a later account, giving the proceedings of the last day, and the result, which is largely in favor of Mr. JAMES.

The rifle match between Mr. LEWIS, of Troy, and Mr. JAMES, of Utica, commenced Tuesday, will be completed to-day, at Fort Plain, Montgomery County. The contest between these two marksmen has attracted many "sporting" gentleman to that vicinity, and large bets have been made upon the result.

The Commissioners of Excise in the City of Brooklyn have had the tables turned upon them. The proceedings of yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer resulted in a verdict of guilty against JOHN CAVANAGH, the first of eight Commissioners placed upon trial for awarding liquor licenses in an illegal manner.

It is a comfort to know that nobody makes much money by keeping provisions, especially dead meats, up at their present prices. We, the consumers, are not alone out of pocket by the means. Butchers cannot afford to buy, because at the rates at which they must sell their meat, people will not touch it.

One of the leading points which the Archbishop attempts to sustain in his late Letter, is the distinction between the positive and negative offices of conscience. If the civil power, thinks the Archbishop, undortakes to compel a man to say or to do anything against his conscience, it violates its own trust, and outrages personal rights.

He felt much interest in the first bill on he calendar, yet, with a view to have the veto message disposed of to-day, he would waive all objections to postpone the private calendar.

Should I consult my own feelings, I certainly would not allow my name to be mixed up in the somewhat angry controversy between Archbishop HUGHES and Mr. CASS, published by you. A most heart-rending and distressing accident occurred here a few weeks since, of which, perhaps, you may have seen some partial account, as it excited a deep interest here with the public authorities and community generally.

A new edifice is in course of erection for the Reformed Dutch Church in Fairhaven, N. Y., and a new Reformed Dutch society, composed of the German residents, has been organized in Schenectady. A portion of the congregation of the M. E. Church in Thirtieth-street, have formed a new organization named Trinity M. E. Church ; Rev. C. MATTESON, formerly of John-street, is the pastor.

A novel and commendable method is pursued by the Emigrant Protection and Employment Society to prevent introducing domestics of bad character into good families. When a girl applies at the Office for a situation, a blank certificate is dispatched to her last employer, which she is invited to fill up.

The House this afternoon proceeded to ballot for United States Senators, with the following result: First ballot--whole number of votes, 308; necessary for a choice, 155. JOHN S. WELLS, Democrat, had 147. JOEL EASTMAN, Whig, 87. MASON W. TAPPAN, Free-Soil, 52. GEORGE W. MORRISON, 18. Two Democrats absent. No choice. Second Ballot--WELLS, 148;

This day, at 3 o'clock, P. M., His Excellency the Governor General proceeded in state to the Chamber of the Legislative Council in the Parliament building. The members of the Legislative Council being assembled, His Excellency was pleased to command the attendance of the Legislative Assembly, and that House being present, His Excellency opened the second session of the fourth Parliament of the Province of Canada with the following speech from the throne:

FIFTY-SEVEN deaths from Cholera are reported by the Inspector during the last week. None are surprised to hear it, and none are panie-stricken. At every step of the way this foe to our race has hung out his flag. He sent heralds to announce his coming. None were so blind as to deny that they saw evidences of the approach.

Everybody knows the symptoms of Cholern. A great many do not know that it has a marvelous counterpart in the Paine. But this latter is attended with the same deadly pain as the former, the same cold extremities, the same collapse, and--we speak advisedly--the same fatal issue.

Information having been given to United States Deputy Marshal Thayer, that a gang of fugitive slaves were secreted in the woods on Lick Run, he procured the services of Deputy City Marshals Lee and Worley and Sheriff Ward, of Covington, Ky., and on Wednesday night caught nine negroes in a stable about a mile beyond the asylum and brought them to the city.

The following is a synopsis of the Reciprocity Treaty, a copy of which was submitted yesterday to the Provincial Parliament by Lord ELGIN. Article first throws open the fisheries of British America, excepting those of Newfoundland, and the salmon, shad and shell fisheries, to American citizens.

The Union of this morning publishes the following dispatch, received by Hon. W. P. HARRIS from General QUITMAN, in relation to the statements connecting him with the filibusters: NEW-ORLEANS, Wednesday, June 14. Tell the Editor of the Union that no man is authorized to speak for me but myself.

They state that, for some years past, the students have adopted a mode--by lad outery--of giving each other notice when the officers are engaged in visiting the rooms.

In this City on Saturday morning, June 17, Capt. JOAN T. CAIRNS, in the 49th y year of his age. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend his funeral on Tuesday afternoon, June 20, at ? o'clock, from his late residence, No. 33 Rivington-st.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--This is an extra night, for the benefit of Mr. WALLACK, the indefatigable lessee. the regular season termianted on Saturday night, and this will consequently be the last opportunity but one--another benefit to which we shall refer when the occasion arrives--of witnessing the admirable company for some months.

The Senate has determined to pass the Homestead bill previous to the time fixed for the recess. It is quite certain the bill will be disposed of during the ensuing week. The debate on the Veto Message closes on Tuesday, and the Homestead measure will be the first business, subsequent to the disposal of that discussion.

We see it announced that the Shepherd of the Valley, the ultra Roman Catholic paper whose violent denunciations of religious toleration have done so much to arouse the distrust and indignation of the great mass of our people, has been discontinued.

We bespeak indulgence for any defects which the typographical appearance of the DAILY TIMES this morning may present, as it is worked for the first time upon the new Six-Cylinder "Lightning Press" which Messrs. IIOE Co. have just built for the TIMES establishment.

ELEVEN MEN CARRIED OVER A CATARACT.-- We imagine that our readers have heard of the narrow escape of eleven raftsmen, a few days ago, who passed over the Chats rapids in a fog, with several cribs of timber. It appears that they were directing the cribs to wards the head of the Victoria slide, but owing to the dense fog passed into the old timber channel, and so over the falls.

During the week, in addition to the cases of cholera which we have reported, several others have occurred. An Irishman named MICHAEL DREW, 34 years old, was reported to have died of cholera Thursday afternoon, at No. 136 Sea-street. EDWARD GROVER, 22 years of age, died at Deer Island, Thursday, of the same disease. MICHAEL MURRAY also died of cholera at No. 110 Sea-street.

In the Senate yesterday, the speech of Senator SEWARD on the vetoed Insane Land bill was the principal feature. The speech, which may be found in full in our report of the proceedings in Congress, is a clear, condensed argument the validity of the President's reasons for returning the bill.

I was an eye witness to the affray which occurred in Chambers-street on Friday evening last, by which JAMES CLORESY came to his death by a fall, occasioned by a blow given by JOHN McINTIRE. I was also present during the examination before the Coroner; and it appears passing strange that in view of the facts and evidence, the jury could have rendered such a verdict as they did.

This morning (Thursday) about 3 o'clock, a destructive fire broke out in the rear of Stanley-street, about half-way between Church and Victoria-streets, which has proved very destructive. Extending not only in both directions along Stanley-street, but back to Adelaide-street, a great many small houses have been burned, leaving between fifty and one hundred families houseless. The fire broke out about 2 1/2 o'clock,

From the New-Orleans Picayune, June 13. Dates from El Paso to the 7th ult., have been received at San Antonio. The Indians continue their depredations. Mr. HEDGES, who was en route for California with a drove of cattle, encountered a band of 110 Indians, between the Rio Limpia and Eagle Springs.

NAVAL.--Mr. THOMAS STACK launched from his yard, foot of North Second-street, Williamsburg, at 3 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, the bark Clara, owned by Messis. WAKEMAN, DIMOND Co., and intended for the general freighting business. She is 148 feet long, 33 feet beam, 19 feet deep, and 750 tons measurement.

The steamship Crescent City arrived yesterday from Havana, bringing our papers and letters to the 14th of June. The following form our regular correspondent gives all the intelligence of any interest:

RECORDER'S COURT.--In the temporary absence of Recorder CUTTER, Justice GARDINER presides in the Recorder's Court. On Saturday, Mrs. WILEY, arrested by officer TANNER for drunkenness and attempting the destruction of her own life, was arraigned. Her husband was also arraigned for interfering with the officer at the time of her arrest. Mr. WILEY was fined $3, and his wife was discharged.

NEW-ORLEANS, Friday 16. The sales of COTTON during the past week foot up 28,000 bales, Middling closing at 8c.@81/4e. The decrease in the receipts at all the Southern ports is now 395,000 bales. CHARLESTON, Saturday, June 17. The sales of COTTON to-day were only 200 bales. Prices are unchanged.

ATTACK UPON PEACEABLE CITIZENS--A LADY SERIOUSLY INJURED.--A young lady, wife of Mr. CHARLES B. DYER, who resides in Bedford-avenue, East Brooklyn, was seriously injured about 9 1/2 o'clock Sunday evening, by a ruffian throwing a paving-stone, which took effect on the left breast, knocking her insensible upon the sidewalk.

LATER FROM BRAZIL.--The bark Z. D., Captain BAXTER, arrived at this port to-day, brings advices from Montevideo to May 1. Affairs in the River La Plata were quiet. The Brazilian forces were positively to enter Montevideo on the day the Z. D. sailed;

We are often asked by young men who are about learning a trade, and by mechanics in the country, how wages are in the City, and what trade pays best. In most kinds of business, the prices paid differ about as much with the generosity or

In Executive Session to-day, the report of the Committee on Foreign Relations in favor of the withdrawal of the African Squadron was taken up, when Mr. SUMNER objecting, it was postponed until to-morrow. The proposition will meet serious opposition.

The Commissioner of Patents has renewed the Morse Telegraph Patent, of June 1840, for the term of seven years--Professor MORSE having disclaimed so much of his eighth specification as brings it within the decision of the Supreme Court in the recent case of Morse vs. O'Reilly.

The Montreal Herald says: "A citizen of Chicago has obtained from this Government the privilege of loading his vessel at Quebec. We presume a like privilege will be granted to all who apply for it--so that in reality the St. Lawrence is at last opened to the vessels of the United States, coming from the Upper Lakes.

On Saturday evening, ALEXANDER HEWITT, a resident of Blackstone, had a serious quarrel with his wife,--both of them being somewhat addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors--and finally the wife fled for refuge to the house of a neighbor named ORIN BROWN. She was followed by her infuriated husband, who upon being refused admittance at the door, proceeded to a window, where seing Mr. BROWN within, he drew a revolving pistol and shot him dead.

The Strike of Railroad Engineers. To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Sir: In Colonel DOHENY'S epistle with regard to the riot at Brooklyn, an insinuation is made that the True American and other American journals are edited by Welsh or Englishmen. I consider it due my position as editor of the first-named newspaper, to contradict any such malassertion, as being calculated to injure me in reputation and business.

HORRIBLE DEATH OF THREE MEN.--This morning, about 11 o'clock, a terrible accident occurred at the corner of Walnut and Preston-streets, by which three men were almost instantly killed. A privy pit was being dug by the side of an old pit, and preparations were being made to let the contents of the old one into the new one, when suddenly the earth caved in, pouring the entire contents of the privy into the new pit.

The New-Hampshire Whig State Convention convened at Concord yesterday, and was one of the largest ever held there. Judge PERLEY, who was chosen President, on taking the Chair made a speech strongly condemnatory of the late violation of public faith by the repeal of the Missouri Compromise.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times. Although a stranger, Sir, in this country, I take the liberty of sending you some corrections in regard to a letter published in your issue of today, (Wednesday), and signed by P. H., which purports to be a correction of Mr. DOHENY's remarks concerning the forces of England engaged in the battle of Waterloo.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: I ought to be ashamed again to trespass on your space. This, however, shall be the last time on the present subject. Whatever may be said or written of, or to, or about, me, I shall not again answer. This time, too, I shall be as brief as possible.

An Indian of the Mohegan tribe, by the name of HENRY COOPER, was drowned at Backus's wharf, in this city, about 10 o'clock Wednesday evening. cording to the statement made by COOPER's wife to those who arrived but a few moments after the occurence, both of them had left the store of Mr. RAWSON,

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Some two years since I proposed in one of the City papers to "lay the dust of the streets with salt, or by sprinkling with salt water." Some of the papers ridiculed, the thing; perhaps they will now. The workmen in the Park used a few bushels to pack the sand, then just carted in, (not half enough, however,) and there it ended.

Arrangements for the formation of this Church are nearly perfected. The society have extended a call to Rev. STEPHEN DOUGLASS, of Cloville, Oneida County, New-York, to become pastor. It is desired to locate the new Church in the Third Ward. At present services will be held at No. 1 Fink-row.

The Massachusetts State Temperance Convention assembled, this evening, in Huntington Hall. About 1,500 persons were present. S. S. MACK, Mayor of Lowell, was chosen President, pro tem., and on taking the Chair made a brief address. Prayer was offered by Rev. D. C. EDDY, of Lowell. v. A. A. MINOR,

MESSRS. EDITORS: I had the misfortune on Saturday afternoon, as I was passing along the road from Marion, Miss., to Mount Sterling, Ala., to witness the fighting of a duel between Gen. J. C. SAUNDERS of Alabama, and Judge EVANS of Mississippi. Five rounds were fired; the first round, General SAUNDERS received a ball in his left arm, but the bone was not injured nor any blood-vessel ruptured.

We conclude in this morning's TIMES the report of the trial of the nine persons claimed as fugitive Slaves from Boone County, Kentucky. The hearing before the Commissioner at Cincinnati was not lengthy, but the evidence was deemed by him sufficiently conclusive to warrant a decision that they be remanded to their owners.

The political action of New-Hampshire has assumed something of a national importance. It is a significant mater, when the best drilled State party in the Union hangs fire. To our credit you may say that HARRY HIBBARD can never be sent to the United States Senate. He must receive his thirty pieces of silver from the hand that employed him.

LAMENTABLE TERMINATION OF AN AFFRAY BETWEEN TWO IRISH LABORERS.--Charcoal-alley has furnished another victim to the combined influence of wicked passion and worse whisky. This famed locality last night alarmed the neighborhood by the cries of murder, which soon attracted the attention of constable BERRY, who repaired to the quarters occupied by a number of Irish families, in Charcoal-alley,

THE EXCISE COMMISSIONERS OF BROOKLYN--TRIAL OF ISAAC CRAMPTON.--ISAAC CRAMPTON was arraigned on an indictment charging him with misdemeanor in granting a tavern license, as one of the Board of Excise, to one WILLIAM GUBBINS, corner of Columbia and Amity streets, the said GUBBINS not having the accommodations required by law.

The Races at Centerville and Union Courses. On Monday a fine trolling match of two mile heats took place on at the Centerville Course, Long Island, between two celebrated horses, Whalebone and Dun. The trot was announced by Mr. JOEL CONKLIN, proprietor of the Course, as follows: Trotting, 4 o'clock P. M., match for $2,000, two mile heats to wagons. GEORGE SPICER NAMED s.h. Whalebone, and HARRY JONES named a bay horse, known as Don.

M. -The six fugitives claimed by Wm. Walton, were again brought in. Mr. Gitchel, after some efforts to converse with the fugitives, stated to the Court that he was not permitted by the officers in charge to converse with them in private. The MUSICAL, CONGRESS at the Crystal Palace should be attended by every one having the desire to hear good music performed in the best possible manner. All the additional bands (including DODWORTH'S and the Germania) are now incorporated with M. JULLIEN'S monstre orchestra, and the ensemble is now of a most perfect character.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In your daily issue of the 8th inst., I observe the following paragraph, under an editorial headed "College Rebellions:" "The Georgia University was thumping on the rocks when our last advices left them. Whether she gets off without damage, remains to be seen." Your "last advices" have not a shadow of foundation in truth.

THE OTTAWA RIOT.--It appears that first accounts of this affair were exaggerated as to the result, though correct in the other leading features. The Free-Trader of last Saturday says: "A serious riot occurred last Saturday evening, between ten or twelve Irishmen belonging to the State scow, (a boat for repairing the canal,) and seven boatmen. It took place between 6 and 7 o'clock, near the Collector's office, and resulted in four men being shot.

On the 15th the annual competition came off for the gold medal, valued at $100, by members of the Senior Class of Yale College. The competitors were STARR H. NICHOLS, YUNG WING, (Chinaman,) CARROLL CUTLER, WM. A. FENN, JAMES E. RAINS, WM. C. FLAGG and JAMES C. RICE. Only five subjects were given the class to be written on The following curd appears in the Palladium of Friday evening:

THE CHCLERA.--A disease, resembling cholera, has made its appearance in Milledgeville, Ga., causing much alarm. A gentleman residing in that place, returned some days ago with his wife and servant from a visit to Nashville, Tenn.

U. S. Commissioner CARPENTER, publishes a long communication in the Gazette denying the constitutionality of that portion of the Fugitive Slave law making it the duty of Commissioners to issue warrants and hear cases. He says he has refused and will continue to refuse to issue warrants.

Mr. SEWARD gave notice of a bill regulating Navigation to the coast of Africa in vessels owned by American citizens,--being a bill to break up the African Slave-trade in American vessels. Mr. JAMES reported a bill amending the Patent Office Laws. The Naval bill was taken up.

REPORTED DISCOVERY OF THE INCENDIARY OF JENNINGS' STORE.--Since the fire of W. T. JENNINGS Co.'s clothing store on Broadway, which was attended by such lamentable disasters, investigations have been set on foot to discover the incendiary by whom the building was fired. Circumstances have pointed to a young lad as the perpetrator.

UNION COLLEGE--A RICH TIME.--The following will be the arrangement of exercises as connected with the semi-centennial celebration at Union College: On Tuesday, July 25, the day preceding Commencement, a Historical discourse will be delivered by Hon. W. W. CAMPBELL, at 10 o'clock, A. M., in the Presbyterian Church, is Schenectady; and will be followed by an Address by Rev. Dr. WAYLAND.

The large Cotton and Woolen Mill, on Jefferson and Miffin-streets, Kensington, was totally destroyed by fire this afternoon, caused it is said by the friction of the machinery. About 300 persons were employed in the building,--mainly females,--and the means of escape by the stairways being cut off by the females, many had to be lowered by ropes, several were hurt by falling. Reports are afloat that several persons perished in the flames.

TERRIFIC STORM.--The Spartanburg Eupress of the 13th instant says: "On Saturday afternoon last, about 3 o'clock, a terrific storm accompanied with hail, visited the section of the country adjacent to the South Pacolet, (about fourteen miles northwest of Spartanburg,) ranging northwardly, about four miles in width, and extending some twelve miles towards Rutherfordton.

THE EXCISE COMMISSIONERS' TRIALS.-In the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday, a Jury was empannelled for the trial of ISAAC CRAMPTON, Excise Commissioner from the Sixth Ward, indicted for misdemeanor, after considerable difficulty. The empanneling of the Jury commenced on Monday, when only five of the regular pannel could be found who had not formed an opinion as to the guilt or innocence of the prisoner.

Eagle says: An IrisInnan by the name of DOBYNS, who was peddling on Irish Linans, was murdered on Friday night last, on the Sand Mountain, in this County, by a man named DUKES. To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: In reply to Mr. DOHENY'S reiterated misrepresentations, and in full corroboration of your correspondent who exposed the absurd statements which he put forth concerning a very distinguished regiment, the 88th, or Connaught Rangers, from whose well-merited repute it is far from the writer's intention to detract-it is enough to state that the 88th were in America, not in Belgium, on the day of Waterloo.

SINGULAR AFFAIR--A SON RUNNING AWAY WITH HIS FATHER'S WIFE.--On Sunday, a man about 30 years of age, accompanied by a woman aged 27, and two children--representing themselves as man and wife--made application to Mr. THOMPSON for relief. They stated that they were just from Canada--having come over by the boat--and were destitute of means ; hence the appeal for aid.

The Whig State Convention assembled here today, and was fully attended, embracing among its delegates many of the most prominent men in the State. Judge IRA PERLEY was chosen President. On taking the Chair, he made a speech strongly condemning the recent violation of the public faith in the repeal of the Missouri Compromise.

In the senate yesterday, Mr. SEWARD gave notice of a bill designed to break up the African Slave-trade in American vessels. The Naval bill was again considered, but no progress was made. In the House, another disgraceful scene was enacted.
