THE CHOLERA.--Dr. J. P. HOBBS, of Memphis, had addressed a letter to the Mayor of Nashville, Tenn., in which he states that by the use of cistern water entirely and exclusively, the cholera will disappear, and never return.

In a mclee in the House this morning, CHURCHWELL persisted in speaking when the House had refused him permission. He had come into the House armed, and when CULLOM went towards him he drew his pistol, cocked it, and waited CULLOM's approach.

In this City, on Tuesday, June 20, by Rev. Mr. Cuyler, JAMES MCKIBBIN to Miss MARY ELINOR VAIL, all of this City In this City, on Tuesday, June 20, at 12 o'clock, M.. in Calvary Church, by Rev. Dr. Hawks, Hon. JOHN B. WELLER of California, to Mrs. LIZZIE W. STANTON, youngest daughter of Levi Brockelbank, Esq., of Canada West.

CONDITION OF MINING BUSINESS.--So far as Lake Superior country is concerned, the past Winter has been a season of unusual interest, and of the most encouraging success in the copper and iron business. Every step in the progress of the mining business has been attended with the most satisfactory results.

CITY OF GALENA.--The first white settlers in Galena, here or hereabouts, are supposed to have been a Mr. BOUTHILLIER, JESSE W. SHULL, and Dr.SAMUEL MUIA, who were attracted hither by the Indian trade and the report of lead mines. This was in 1819, and in that year what is known as the "Buck Lead" was discovered, according to tradition.

PASH-EGGS.--During the fifteen days after Easter, which are the Russian Carnival, they have eggs dyed all manner of colors, which they send or give in presents to each other; and when they meet during this time they salute with these words, Christouos Chrest, Christ is risen; to which the other having answered Woistin wos Chrest, He is certainly risen, they kiss one another;

We are favored, from private sources, with a number of interesting items touching the movements at the South of the Cuban Junta and their affiliating friends among our own people. Some of these, in a different form, may have found currency already through the southern papers, but most of the particulars we believe are new.

FATAL RAILROAD ACCIDENT IN MAINE.-- At 8 1/2 o'clock, yesterday morning, near the gas works, Mr. ELIJAH GUILFORD was knocked down by a freight train and had both legs broken off near the ankles, two wheels passing directly over them, when the engineer succeeded in stopping the train.

From the National Intelligencer. The Smithsonian Institution has been put in communication with the French authorities in charge of all matters connected with the opening of the Universal Exhibition, which has been decreed to take place in Paris on the first day of May next. Thus, we presume,

The Erie Railroad Company experienced much trouble yesterday in the running of their trains, in consequence of the strike of the Engineers. The whole of the morning trains were detained at Jersey City until the afternoon, and ?? passengers who waited long and patiently, were compelled finally to retrace their steps, and hope for better times, when Engineers shall no longer upset a line of rails four hundred miles in length.

From the Norwich Courier. In the first place, it permits a man to make the apples of his own growth or gathering into eider, and his own grapes, currant or other fruit into wine. But it forbids him selling his neighbor it for mince pics or for any other purpose. He can sell him five gallons to be "actually taken at one time," and not a drop less.

It must be obvious to those who have lived in Europe since the great revolutionary period of 1848, that the Despotic Sovereigns having lost the affection of their people, would, more than ever, seek to govern with the bayonet, the spy and priestcraft.

Senator SEWARD, in accordance with instructions from the Committee on Commerce, informed the Senate yesterday, that while the Committee were unanimously impressed with the importance of the construction of a Ship canal around the Falls of Niagara, they were divided as to the expediency of aiding the work now, and for other reasons wished to be discharged from its further consideration, which was granted.

JOHN MITCHEL AT THE UNIVERSITY.--JOHN MITCHEL, as he is familiarly known to the American people, has accepted an invitation from the students of the University to deliver an address at the approaching anniversary celebration of the Commencement exercises. This is a distinction which has never been conferred upon any but the most eminent men of the country. It is a peculiarly appropriate tribute to the genius and worth of the Irish patriot.

There was some excitement in the City last evening, arising from the attention bestowed by passers by upon sundry placards posted through the streets. The purport of the document was an appeal in behalf of the people of Greece. Among other things, the Appeal says (after quoting the London Times on the affairs of Greece):

The decisive match between the New-York and St. George's Clubs was commenced yesterday on the ground of the New-York Cricket Club, Hoboken. The attendance was select, and seemed to comprise a number of admirers of the sport--the weather pleasantly cool for such exercise.

We have announced that WM. D. GALLAGHEE, formerly one of the editors of the Cincinnati Gazette, had retired from the conduct of the Louisville Courier. Mr. GALLAGHER has been one of the proprietors of the Courier since January last, and the principal editor for a somewhat longer period.

Two men, each with a brush-broom, have just been seen trying to make an impression on the filthy gutters of the Sixth-avenue. The strange sight has caused a tremendous excitement in the neighborhood. SECOND DISPATCH. Two o'clock.--The men have disappeared. The filth was well stirred, but not removed. The excitement is subsiding.

We publish this morning an important Report, laid before the Senate in Secret Session, on the proposal to terminate that provision of the Ashburton Treaty by which we stipulate to maintain a squadron on the Coast of Africa to aid Great Britain in the suppression of the Slave-trade.

A "Practical Farmer," in the last Mark Lane Express, closes a lengthy article on the subject of grain as follows: "Farmers may, for once, depend upon having the corn trade for the next year very much in their own hands. e never was a time when the world's stock of grain was so nearly exhausted ;

CHANGE READING NEVER COMES AMISS.--Dr. HAMMOND'S method was (which likewise he recommended to his friends,) after every sermon, to resolve upon the ensuring subject; that being done, to pursue the course of study which he was then in hand with, reserving the close of the week for the provision for the next Lord's Day.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE.--At about 11 o'clock last night, a fire broke out in the clothing store of E. L. ROBBINS BROTHER, No. 128 Genesee-street. The flames spread with rapidity, and in a few minutes the entire front part of the building was one fiory mass. It is of course, impossible now to ascertain the aggregate loss. The building was owned by ANSON THOMAS, and was insured to an amount nearly covering the damage.

In this City, on Wednesday, June 21, Mrs. CONNOLLY, aged 85 years. The friends and acquaintances are invited to attend her funeral, this day, at 3 o'clock, from her late residence, No. 467 Washington-st. In this City, on Wednesday, June 21. after a short illness, EDWARD T. LEE,of the firm of Leadbeater Lee.

The Convention of the Veterans of the War of 1812 met at the City Hall, yesterday morning. The attendance numbered about 900--among them a dozen oneidas, and two dozen Onondaga Indians. They adjourned, and forming a procession marched to Lafayette Park, where they were received by the military, and escorted to Corinthian Hall. At one o'clock General BENSON called the Convention to order.

SINGULAR DEATH.--The Galena (III.) Jeffersonian of the 15th, states that Mr. JOHN A. MOREHEAD, living near Paris, Mo., died last week under singular circumstances. He rose in the morning apparently in his usual health, and after walking about for a short time and partaking of his breakfast, he ordered his negro man to bring a long bench into the house, saying he expected to die soon, and wished to be laid out on the same.

THE SUNDAY RIOTERS AGAIN.-The following persons, arrested for being concerned in the Main-street riot on Sunday night, June 5, were bailed in the sum of $500 each, to appear before Justice BEACHLEY yesterday, in Brooklyn, for examination, but, failing to appear, forfeited their recognizances: Thomas Fitzpatrick, bailed by John McDermott; Christopher Burns, by Charles Collins; Edward Diver,

MAN SHOT IN FRANKLIN COUNTY.--On the evening of Tuesday, or on the morning of the following day, an altercation took place between a man named PATRICK SWEENY and another named AUSTIN, which terminated in AUSTIN'S killing SWEENY, by shooting him through the head. The origin of this affair was a misunderstanding, we have been informed, about a house and lot adjoining SWEENY'S farm, claimed by both parties.

A letter from Paris, in the Boston Atlas, says:- Young Mr. J. DELLUS, of Bremen, fell into the crater of Mount Vesuvias the 11th of May, and perished; his body was found. This unfortunate gentleman was the assistant professor of English literature at Berlin, who is so kindly remembered by all American students who have resided in Berlin, from his marked courtesy and hospitality to them.

The Board of Councilmen met last evening, the President, EDWIN J. BROWN, Esq. in the Chair. PETITIONS REFERRED. For a Hose Carriage for No. 18 Ninth-avenue. Of James B. Brady, to be allowed possession of Eighth-street to proceed with his contract for paving said street. Against a sewer on Thirteenth-street from the Tenth-avenue to the River.

The Anti-Nebraska resolutions were debated in the House at length to-day, and made the special order of the day for Thursday at 10 1/2 o'clock. The House laid the bill to increase the Capital Stock of the Indian Head Bank at Nashua on the table. This is significant of the fate of other bills.

The Royal Mail Steamship Canada, Capt. STONE, from Liverpool on Saturday, the 10th inst., arrived at this port, en route for Boston, at an early hour this morning. The Collins steamship Atlantic, from New-York on the 27th of May, arrived out at Liverpool at 10o'clock on Wednesday evening, the 7th inst.

The Supreme and Superior Courts adjourned yesterday, out of respect to the memory of Judge BARCULO, of the Second Judicial District, who died at his father's residence, in this City, on Tuesday morning last. Remarks eulogistic of the deceased were made in the various Courts, respectively, by Messrs. WHITING, ROBERTSON, SEDGEWICK and DAVIS.

The market for all articles in this line is tame and heavy. Buyers do not want much of even the choicest fabrics, which are the least abundant, and appear the firmest, though these also display a downward inclination. There is no considerable inquiry for inferior or unpopular productions; and it is almost impossible to sell such, except at ruinously low prices, which owners are not very willing to accept.

At a meeting of the Members of Congress, who opposed the passage of the bill to organize the Territories of Nebraska and Kansas, held, pursuant to previous notice, in the City of Washington, on the 20th day of June instant, Hon. SOLOMON FOOT, of Vermont, was elected Chairman, and Hon. DANIEL MACE, of Indiana, and Hon. REUBEN E. FENTON, of New-York, were appointed Secretaries.

SEVERE PHUNDER SHOWER IN MASSACHUSETTS.---The thunder shower yesterday afternoon, although of little violence in this vicinity, was very severe along the South Shore. At Kingston the shower is represented as the most severe ever experienced in that town. Little rain fell, but much damage was done by the lightning.

TASTE BEFORE EXTRAVAGANCE.--Somebody has said that a Parisian grisette, with a little tulle and ribbon, will conquer the world, while an Englishwomen, with all her shawls, damasks, and diamonds, looks only like an animated clotheshorse. There is some exaggeration in this statement, but more wit, and still more truth.

PATRICK HENRY'S SON--The youngest son of PATRICK HENRY died not long ago, poor and alone, in a public-house in Floyd County, va. Recently the tavern people applied to the Overseers of the Poor, for a special grant to indemnify him for boarding, funeral expenses, This was refused on the ground that retrospective appropriations are unauthorized, and that it would be establishing an improper precedent.

From the Albany Evening Journal. The Canal Board was engaged yesterday in the discussion of a question of great interest and importance. The Erie Canal, from its earliest period of navigation, has been dependent, at certain of the year, upon the ?? River for a supply of water.

CHOLERA IN TOLEDO.--We have had a few cases in town. They all seem to have been imported. The cases were isolated, and have created no alarm. We learn that in each of the cases that have transpired, a premonitory diarrhoea had been neglected for from one to three days, and that had even ordinary precautions been taken in time, the lives of the victims would have been saved.

It has long been a question which kind of cod liver is the most useful, and few know how to distinguish the genuine article from the adulterated. Dr. DE JOHGH, of the Hague, late Medical Officer of the Dutch army, was regarded by the late Dr. PEREIRA, as "the highest authority on this subject.

I suppose it was selected on account of the mild squabble which appears to exist between the two papers ;

THE COMMENCEMENT AT THE VIRGINIA UNIVERSITY.--The Commencement exercises of the University will be as follows: Oration on the night of the 27th by Mr. W. W. GORDON, of Tappahannock; Va., on the part of the Washington Society. Oration before the Literary Societies, on the morning of the-the 28th, by JOHN MITCHEL, Esq.

The democratic State Convention met here to-day. ERASMUS PLYMPTON, of Wardshoro', presided. Governor ROBINSON AND Lieut. Governor KIDDA both declined a renomination. MERRITT CLARK, of Poultney, was nominated for Governor, and WILLIAM MATTOCKS, of Beacham, for Lieut. Governor.

The Dobbs Ferry men had a pleasant time of it, yesterday, in laying the corner-stone of the Summer-field Methodist Episcopal Church,--The first church-building of this denomination with which that portion of Westchester County has been favored.

The statement that no Israelite in the United States is engaged in agriculture is contradicted. One of the largest plasters in Kentucky, Mr. Benjamin Gratz, an old personal friend of the late Henry Clay, is an Israelite, while in South Carolina, Georgia and Florida, and other States, there are many of that ancient faith extensively engaged in agriculture.

Henceforth the ivory paper-knife must be reckoned among the pocket instruments never to be omitted in packing up for a journey. CORPULENCE A CRIME.--Mr. BRUCE has written, in his Classic and Historic Portraits, that the ancient Spartan paid as much attention to the rearing of men as cattle dealers in modern England do to the breeding of cattle. They took charge of the firmness and looseness of men's flesh; and regulated the degree of fatness to which it was lawful, in a force State, for any citizen to extend his body.

ORIGINAL WORDS OF OLD SCOTCH AIRS.--Can any one tell me where the original words of many fine old Scotch airs are to be found? The wretched verses of ALLAN RAMSEY and others of the same school, are adapted to the "Yellow-haired Laddie," Etrick Banks," "The Bush aboon Traquair," "Mary Scott," and hundreds of others.

INTERESTING TO NATURALISTS.--At a late meeting of the Elliot Society of Natural History, the Secretary, Professor HOLMES, submitted for inspection, two embalmed or preserved heads of Mahue Indians, brought by Lieutenant HERNDON from the valley of the Amazon, South America, and presented by him to the Museum of Natural History of the College of Charleston.

A NEEDLE SWALLOWED AND EXTRACTED. --Sometime in December last a young lady of this city, who had indulged in the too common practice of holding pins and needles in her month, swallowed what at the time she supposed to be a pin. She soon after suffered severe pains in the region of the stomach, but did not then attribute the cause to the supposed pin.

The acquisition of Cuba is the only measure of policy in regard to which the people of the South feel any special and present interest. The traditional disputes of party are either settled or in suspension; in any event they are utterly incapable of awakening the least manifestation of popular enthusiasm.

We did not yesterday understand the precise nature of the question before the Canal Board. In September, 1850, the Canal Board decided upon a Canal 76 1/2 feet medium width at Lockport, and 62 feet at Rochester, with a declivity a little over half an inch to the mile, producing a descending current of about half a mile to the hour.

PATRICK HENRY'S SON.-- We published a notice yesterday, founded on a statement which appeared in several Virginia papers, in reference to the peculiar circumstances attending--what was given out to be--the recent death of the youngest son of the celebrated PATRICK HENRY.

To the Public. In the Fall of 1853 JOSIAH PERHAM exhibited in this City a Panorama called the "Seven Mile Mirror," of tickets to its exhibition. At the time designated the ticket-holders met to receive the property, and selected a Committee to have charge of it.

Treaty between the United States of America and the Mexican Republic, conclu ed at the City of Mexico, December 30, 1853. In the name of Almighty God! The Republic of Mexico and the United States of America, desiring to remove every cause of disagreement which might interfere in any manner with the better friendship and intercourse between the two countries.

"FOREFATHERS' ROCK."--The Trustees of the Pilgrim Society, after two or three meetings for consultation at Plymouth, have voted to purchase the wharf property on which "Forefathers' Rock" is situated, thus taking the first step towards the erection of a monument to the memory of the Pilgrims.

The Union is in danger again; but fortunately those who propose to dissolve it give us notice, as usual, of the precise contingency on which their procedure depends. The conditions always vary to meet the emergencies of the time.

The Territorial appointments were sent to the Senate to-day--Mr. REEDER, of Pennsylvania, as Governor of Kansas. Mr. BUTLER, of Kentucky, as Governor of Kansas. Mr. BUTLER, of Kentucky, as Governor of Nebraska. The latter will decline. It is contemplated to take up the Treaty Appropriation in the House to-morrow, and put it through before adjournment.

TWENTY YEARS IN THE PHILIPPINES. Translated from the French of PAUL P. Do LA GIRONIERE, Chevalier of the Legion of Honor. New-York: HARPER BROTHERS. Decidedly the most entertaining book of the season. A novel by the side of it is duller than a disquisition on the nature of the soul.

For the writings with which these papers are usually occupied, the Irish people have been held responsible. They have been held so by the American public generally, and by that portion of the European public which has the vitality to think otherwise than the police order them to do.

Somerset County was the first in the State of New-Jersey to establish Teachers' Institutes, and has maintained them for five successive years. It is largely owing to the efforts of the teachers and friends of education in that county, that the Legislature passed a law last Winter providing for their establishment in every county in the State, where desired by the teachers.

EDUCATION IN JERSEY CITY.--The Annual Report of the Board of Education of Jersey City shows the number of pupils and the average attendance at the Schools, as follows: School No. 1.--Male department, 211; average attendance, 148. Female department, 219; average attendance. 134.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the TIMES of yesterday morning, I find some good remarks under the head of "An Inflated Currency." Under the impression that "the causes of the present condition of the money market" are deeper seated and capable of being resolved into elements more simple than are there indicated, I venture to trouble you with a few observations.

The conflagration yesterday afternoon, in the Seventeenth Ward, presented for a time, a frightful scene, owing lo the rapid spread of the flames and the consternating among the panic-striken operatives, male and female. Like ao many similar establishments that have been burned in Philadelphiu of late years, the building had no proper means of escape provided in case of fire.

NARROW ESCAPE OF THE SARAH SANDS.--The Quebec Chronicle furnishes a detailed account of the narrow escape of the steamer Sarah Sands, from shipwreck. She was on her passage from Liverpool to Quebec, with a valuable cargo and a large number of passengers.

PUBLIC BUILDINGS IN JERSEY CITY.--Mayor MANNERS advertises for sealed proposals for $25,000 of the Six Per Cent. Bonds of the City Loan, intended as a portion of the Loan of $50,000, for the erection of public buildings. Propusals will be received until Thursday, June 29.

The Kings County Court of Oyer and Terminer re assembled on Wednesday morning to receive the verdict of the Jury in the case of ISAAC CRAMPTON, Excise Commissioner. The Jury came into Court soon after it assembled, and stated that they could not agree.
The anticipated change in the British Ministry has been made, and is by no means unimportant. There has been a trial of strength between the ABERDEEN and the PALMERSTON sections of the Cabinet.

We are sorry to see increasing indications of ill blood between our native and our foreign born citizens. It is particularly to be regretted at this time, in view of the issue which the repeal of the Missouri Compromise has forced upon the Free States, and upon which it is to be hoped they will go unitedly into the next elections.

Parliament was prorogued this afternoon amid great confusion. Members of the House insisted on speaking while the Governor was waiting in the Legislative Council Chamber. His Excellency's arrival being announced, cries of "Let him wait," were heard. The Speaker could not restore order, and the Governor General was kept waiting several minutes, during which the House was in the greatest confusion.

The steamship North Star, of the Vanderbilt Independent Line, from Aspinwall, June 16, arrived at this port yesterday afternoon, with the passengers and treasure brought to Panama by the Yankee Blade, from San Francisco, June 1. The gold, $355,000 in amount. is consinged--to ADAMS Co., $100,000: American Exchange Bank, $255,000--total, $355,000.

The CHAIR laid before the Senate a communication from the Treasury Department, transmitting, in reply to Mr. FISH'S resolution, copies of the accounts of the Director of the Mint, showing the charges collected of depositors and others. Referred, and ordered to be printed.

LOSS OF WHALING BRIG INGA.--A letter from B. F. ANGEL, United States Consul at the Sandwich Islands, to S.H. INGALLS, of this city, agent of the whaling brig Inga, confirms the report of her having been cut off at Pleasant Island, by the natives, in the Fall of 1852; and states that all the crew then on board were murdered or drowned, except one white man, J. T. BLAIR, and two natives from Byron's Island.

The following army order will be published to-morrow: GENERAL ORDERS--No. IX. WAR DEPARTMENT, ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE, WASHINGTON, Wednesday June 21, 1854. MURDER IN THE FIRST DEGREE.--On Sunday, the 11th inst., at Ridges, near Danville, Ky., two young men, JAMES HARLAN and THOMAS PITTMAN, Jr., got into a trifling dispute, which ended with the latter being shot by the former. Immediately after being shot. PITTMAN mounted his horse and rode home, (several miles,) at a desperate rate. It is said he fell from his horse several times before reaching home.

M. KOSSUTH was specially and warmly solicited to attend a popular demonstration at Sheffield, England, in favor of the restoration of the national rights of Poland. The principal meeting was held at noon, on Monday, 5th inst., when the distinguished guest delivered his views on the state of Europe in connection with the immediate subject of the meeting.

After the great assemblage at Sheffield, in Paradise-square, on Monday noon, there was a second meeting in the evening of that day at Music-hall, in furtherance of the same object as the previous one--" to consider the desirability of reconstituating Poland an independent nation." The audience on this occasion was by no means large. The Music-hall was far from being fill.

MURDER IN PEORIA, (ILL.)--The Peoria Reporter says AUGUST SONDERMAN was shot a few days since by HEINRICH BOLLMAN, the keeper of the "New Peoria House," in Lower Peoria, under the following circumstances: BOLLMAN threatened SONDERMAN, a few days since, (on account of jealousy,) that if he came to his house again he would shoot him.

There was not much done in Congress yesterday other than with private bills. In the Senate, a communication was received from the Treasury Department, transmitting copies of the accounts of the Director of the Mint.

CHOLERA HOSPITAL IN BROOKLYN.--A Committee from the Board of Health, yesterday took possession of the old Jackson Homestead, situated on Lafayette-avenue, between Raymond and Navy-streets, in the Eleventh Ward, to be occupied for the treatment of cholera patients, and it is now being furnished with cots, , for that purpose.

The new granite church just erected for the Unitarian Society in Jamaica Plain, Mass., was dedicated on the 15th inst. It is a beautiful edifice, furnished with a bell of over three thousand pounds weight, and an organ of unequalled tone and power.

This Society celebrated its Twenty-second Anniversary last evening in its Hall. There was a full attendance of the members and a large number of graduates, who met, as it were, in a Committee of the Whole on the State of the Society. Mr. OAKEY HALL, of the New-York bar, a graduate of 1844, made a short opening address.

Father KROEGER, a Roman Catholic priest in this city, was arrested yesterday for assault with attempt to commit a rape on a girl 14 years old. She testified that she went to confession to him; he asked her into a private room, and inquired if she had ever sinned with a man. She said "No," and he then undertook to make an indecent personal examination of her, which he did. He then whipped her severely.

KANSAS-Several professional gentlemen have signified their intention of joining the Kansas party, to leave here on the 17th of July, and to return in four weeks. Thus they will see the finest part of this country, besides going along the borders of Nebraska and Kansas.

THE JEFFERSON-STREET CONFLAGRATION.--The fear that human life was sacrificed at the frightful fire at Jefferson and Miftlin-streets, on Tuesday afternoon, has been realized. Yesterday the ghastly remains of a human being were found among the smouldering rains; they were so dreadfully burned that for a time it was not certain whether they were the remains of a human creature or those of a dumb animal.

The Colonial and Foregin Produce markets reopened on Wednesday with a moderate demand for most articles. The SUGAR market is quiet. BREADSTUFFS and COTTON firm. MONEY in much demand. Consols have fluctuated considerably, and leave off to-day 91 1/4@3/4. The price of Dollars has advanced, owing to the demand for China, to 5s. 1 1/2d. Bar Silver, 5S. 1 1/4d.

SUICIDE OF A STRANGER.--This morning about 3 o'clock, as Watchman MONTAGUE, of the Southern Station, was passing up Pratt-street, he discovered upon the pavement near Cypress alley, the body of a man with his throat cut from ear to ear. He immediately called for assistance, but before it arrived the unfortunate man was dead.

In Brooklyn, on Sunday, June 25, ANTHONY BOYER, aged 85 years. His friends and acquaintances are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, from the residence of his son. No. 234 State-st Brooklyn, at 4 o'clock, P. M., this day, 26th last., without further notice.

Full particulars respecting the opening of the great National Course, near Flushing, long Island, today, were given in Saturday morning's TIMES. Since then, the Jockey Club held a meeting at the Club House in Prince-street; and annexed we give a list of the races to-day, in numerical order.

The Musical Season proper commences with the present week. Unlike out trans-Atlantic brethren, our season commences when theirs end. A fact so significant argues much for future campaigns, for it is reasonable to expect that when the ferriage across the Atlantic has become familiarized to a few more leading artists,

Fourteen private bills were passed including the Senate bill to reimburse to the Common Council of NewYork City the expenditures made for the First Regiment of New-York Volunteers. Mr. HOUSTON moved that the House go into Commiteo on the General Appropriation bill, wishing to finish it to-day, so as to take up on Monday the bill appropriating $10,000,000 to carry the Gadsden Treaty into effect.

When the fox could not reach the grapes he turned philosopher-" they are sour things, and very apt to give a body the colic," said he. The fox was a wise fellow; we commend his shrewdness to all whose means are small, and who live in the City. Meat is still outrageously high.

Fort Leavenworth (though there is no fort here at all) is on land over five hundred feet above the river. In many respects it resembles an old village; and has scree very good and some very poor buildings. Its fine shade trees and fields give it a retired and pleasing aspect. As you look out from here into the territory, the land is uneven and picturesque. No prairies are in view.

The steamer Atlantic, of the Collins line, from Liverpool, Wednesday, June 14, arrived at her dock at an early hour yesterday morning. The accounts are thirteen days later than by the Canada. They are not of a decisive character touching the European War.

BRITISH,--Barracouta, str. 300 horse-power, 6 guns ; Bittern, brig, 12 guns; Comus, sloop, 14 guns; Encounter, sc. str. 360 horse-power, 14 guns; Grecian. sloop, 12 guns ; Lily, brig, 12 guns; Rapid, brig, 8 guns; Rattler, sc. str. 200 horse-power, 11 guns; Salamander, str. 200 horse-power, 6 guns ; Spartan, frigate. 26 guns; Styx, str. 280 horse-power, 6 guns; Winchester. 50-gun ship. 50 guns.

THE NEW-YORK AND ERIE RAILROAD-PROBA BLE ADJUSTMENT OF THE DIFFICULTIES.-The difficulties between the Engineers and the Superintendent on this road, which have resulted in nearly suspending the running of trains, it is believed will be amicably urranged, so that business will be resumed to-morrow or the next day.

The steamship Prometheus, Capt. E. W. TURNER, arrived last evening, from Puenta Arenas, Nicarauga, with 560 passengers, and $1,500,000 in specie on freight. The Prometheus arrived outward on the morning of the 16th, having touched at Kingston, Jam., for coals.

We are well enough provided with laws against throwing garbage in the streets,then why is the complaint about it so universal? One would suppose that the neighbors who suffer the nuisance would complain at once-that the police would arrest the offenders, and cause the instant removal of the objectionable matter.

In the column of Moral and Religious Itenis that about once a week posts up our readers in the minute of such matters, may have been noticed occasional movements on the part of Churches to provide for the use of the occupants of their parsonages a good miscellaneous and professional library.

AN AMERICAN SHIP BOARDED BY A BRITISH CAPTAIN,--Capt. ALLEN, of the ship Minnesota, arrived Saturday morning from Liverpool. He reports, on May 23, while in lat. 53 (degree), lon. 10(degree), was boarded by Her B. M. steamship Gladiator, who demanded the ship's papers for examination. Capt. ALLEN asked by "what authority" he boarded his ship. The officer refused to give any satisfactory answer.

The steamer Illinois sailed from Aspinwall on the 16th, having been detained awaiting the arrival of a portion of the mails, and arrived here early Saturday morning. Her news from California is, of course, to the same dates as brought by the North Star.

The Albany Atlas publishes the following letter, addressed to the officers of the State Temperance Alliance just previous to the election of 1852: To the Corresponding Secretary of the New-York State Temperance Society: SIR: Your letter of my absence from home, and of numerous pressing engagements which have prevented the from giving the questions you ask, the consideration their importance demands.

The U. S. Mail steamship Knoxville, Capt. LUDLOW, in fifty-five hours, from Savannah, arrived yesterday morning. She sailed in company with steamer Keystone State, for Philadelphia. On the 22d inst., at 4 P. M., when eighteen miles north of Lookout, exchanged signals with the steamship Tennessee, bound South.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the TIMES of yesterday we find a communication from G. R. HOLMES, of your City, respecting the late Rifle Match at Fort Plain. He makes the statement that may partner, "Mr. FERRIS, discovered the secret" of making large calibre rifles shoot well, and that "he made the guns that won these matches.

There is a general crude, indefinable idea prevalen in this country, that in agriculture almost entirely lies our wealth as a nation. Our cotton crop since 1821 has increased in annual export value from $20,157,484 in 1821 to $109,456,404 in 1853. This year it may fall back to $88,000,000.

We are in receipt of Rio Janeiro dates to the 16th May. Tke Coffee market showed a slight decline on inferio grades, and a slight advance upon selections Sales are reported of 30,000 bags at 4#@4#500. The new crop would be in the market about the Ist of July The Flour market evinced a better tone, and sales of Richmond had been made at an advance $1 per bbl.

We learn from a passenger by the North Star, which arrived in New-York yesterday afternoon, bringing passengers who left San Francisco on the 1st of June, the particulars of a tragedy which took place on the Isthmus. It will be recollected that SUSAN DENIN (Mrs. WOODWARD) and KATE DENIS (Mrs. Fox,) two actresses well known in this city, some time since went to California to fulfil professional engagements there.

The United States Mail steamship Atlantic, Captain WEST, from Liverpool, Wednesday, June 14, 10 o'clock A. M., arrived at this port yestcrday morning at 5 o'clock. The Canada sailed from Liverpool exactly at 10 o'clock, Saturday morning, 10th, for Halifax and Boston, with 160 passengers and a heavy mail. The Europa arrived at Liverpool on Sunday evening, 11th, at 10 o'clock.

A great nuisance is the very common custom of getting up processions, funeral or otherwise, headed by bands of music, to parade the streets on the Sabbath. Congregations of worshippers are disturbed, and the exercises within church are very often materially interrupted by the means.
The card of Mr. CRUTCHER, one of the Jury tat acquitted the murderer WARD, which we publish in another column, contributes some important facts to the history of that extraordinary affair.

SLAVES AT SOUTHAMTON.--There are now at Southampton, England, eighteen self-emancipated negroes, with five children belonging to them, from the Island of Cuba. The adults were kidnapped from Lagos, and are now about to return there. They were not all kidnapped at one time, but became acquainted with each other in slavery, and associated together from belonging to the same part of Africa.
The talented author of Reveries of a Bachelor, Mr. DONALD G. MITCHELL, more generally known as "Ik Marvel," finds the Consulate of Venice poorly suited to his taste or his pecuniary interest.

The mail which leaves here to-morrow, will convey to you the gratifying intelligence of the remarkable success of our squadron in Japan. The Susquehanna arrived here on the 2d inst., in guine days, from the Bay of Jeddo, bringing the news which you Nill receive and although this may not be entirely satisfactory, still sufficient is known, as you will see, to justify the conclusion that Japan is open to the Americans.

We publish on our third page this morning a statement from the General Superintendent of the Erie Railroad, in reply to the statement of the Engineers, which appeared in the DAILY TIMES of Friday morning last, and also to a communication from a correspondent.
The letter of our Correspondent from the Squadron of Commodore PERRY, gives a more detailed history of its second visit to Japan and of the negotiations had there, than has hitherto been published:

MUNICIPAL ELECTION.--STUBBS, Whig and Know-Nothing, elected Mayor, and whole Know-Nothing ticket. The President, Secretary DOBBIN and Senator CASS, arrived at Old Point to-day. BALTIMORE, Saturday, June 24. The New-Orleans papers of Monday received.

The inhabitants of Brooklyn enjoyed yesterday a Sabbath quiet to which they have been for some weeks strangers, owing to the late lawless excitements "Good citizens " once more were permitted quiety to take their seats in church, instead of parading the streets, as special constables, to protect the peace.

The very able opinion of Judge HOFFMAN, of the Superior Court, in the case of Hope against The Sixth and Eighth-avenue Railroads, will be found in another column. The case involves the legality of all our City Railroads, and the opinion will be found of equal interest to the public and the profession.

The Board of Health reports nine cases of Cholera during last week. One death from the same disease occurred to-day in the County Prison, where seven females, prisoners, have been attacked during the past week. No cases heard of to-day. Total mortality for the week in the city, 222.

Before Judge Ingraham and a Jury. SIXTH DAY. ATMARINE F. F. WALKER, BY CHRISTIAN S. SLOAN, HER NEXT FRIEND, VS. WILDES P. WALKER. As usual, in cases of this kind, the attraction appeared to increase as the trial draws towards a close, the Court-room being full of spectators long before the judge had taken his seat on the bench.

Judging from the fact that there were twelve fewer fatal cases of cholera last week than the week proceeding, and from the improved appearance of many streets, the Board of Health did good service to the City last week.

The cholera has broken out at Independence, Missouri. A letter, dated the 20th, to the St. Louis Intelligencer, states that the deaths in three days at Independence reached 25, and several fatal cases had occurred at Weston and St. Joseph; also, six or eight on the steamers Clara and San Cloon. The St. Louis Republican. of Thursday last, contains a month's later advices from New-Mexico.

This morning, at half-past 1 o'clock, the 10 1/2 o'clock evening train from Albany for Buffalo, (connecting with the 4 P. M. Hudson River Railroad train of Friday afternoon,) ran off the track three miles east of Little Falls, breaking the locomotive, (slightly,) the tender, two baggage and first passenger cars.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The stockholders and the public are not likely to be satisfied with the anonymous communications from the attorney of this Company, who, instead of answering the charges made against them, writes as follows: "But one person out of the Board of Directors has access to the documents he promulgates." That is certainly remarkable.

CRYSTAL PALACE.--There was a brilliant attendance last evening on the occasion of Mr. JULLIEN's farewell appearance, and the entertainments passed off with the greatest eclat. The selection, as we hinted in yesterday's paper, was made with proper discrimination for the acoustic capabilities of the building. The pieces were mostly loud, or given loud.

Day before yesterday, Capt. EXELMANS arrived in Paris with dispatches for-the Emperor, from ST. ARNAUD. The gist of them is understood to be that the Generalissimo asks for 50,000 more men immediately. They contain also a resume of the various circumstances which have prevented, hitherto, and promise still to prevent, an actual assumption of hostilities.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The address of the Anti-Kansas-and-Nebraskaites in Congress suggests a few thoughts in relation to what was the duty of Congress, after the acquisition of Louisiana from France. At that time all the Territory of the United States was free from Slavery, by the fundamentallaw of the land, as well as by act of Congress.

It turns out that though Lord PALMERSTON has unquestionably sustained tow defeats, (by not being appointed War Minister, and By Sir GEORGE GREY being made colonial Secretary,) he has been spared the third. His friend and adherent, the Earl of GRANVILLE, gives up the Presidency of the Council, it is true, but does not leave the Cabinet.

The steamship Isabel arrived here this morning with dates from Havana and Key West to the 22d inst. We have no political news of interest from Havana. The Sugar market had somewhat improved. The ship Northern Eagle, from Boston, had been ashore on the Bahamas, but was got off by the aid of wreckers, having thrown overboard 250 tons of ice. She sustained but little injury.

NYE, PARKIN Co., of Canton, for the following article from the North China Mail: The official papers, from the British Consulate at Shanghai, with which it is accompanied, confirm this statement of the affair, and gives the following list of killed and wounded: LIST OF KILLED AND WOUNDED IN ATTACK, C., ON 4TH APRIL.

Mr. BENTON'S speech is the theme of conversation and produced quite a sensation in the House. He does not stand alone in his opposition to the treaty appropriation, but it will pass notwithstanding. The Territorial appointments will sticks a little. The rumor that one of the nominees for Kansas is Free-Soilish, is gaining oradence among Southern Senators. Senator DOUGLAS urged the appointment of a particular friend and was denied.

In this City, on Monday, June 26, ANN COREY, age l 60 years and 6 months. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of Wm. H. Shay, No. 139 Amity-St., to-day, (Tuesday,) at 4 o'clock, without further invitation. In this City, on Monday, June 26, WM. H. VAN KLEECH, after a long illness.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I am glad that you have called public attention to the evils of the present system for the regulation of Prisons. Notwithstanding all that has been said in relation to this matter for the last ten years, the evils increase, and they will continue to increase until the Prisons under the care of the "Fen Governors" are thoroughly reorganized.

Before going into Committee of the Whole, Yesterday, on the Gadsden Treaty Appropriation, the House of representatives gave respectful attention to a question of privilege raised by Mr. BENTON in reference to the manner in which the negotiation was conducted by the President and Senate, without consulting the money-voting department of the Government.

The sales of COTTON to-day were 4,000 bales, al an advance of , middling being quoted 8 1/4c, @ 8 1\2c. NEW-ORLEANS, Thursday, June. 22. Our COTTON market has been firm to-day, but business was reatrieted in 2,000 bales. NEW-ORLEANS, Friday, June 23.

The Marquis DE LA PEZUELA, Captain General of Cuba, has issued a manifesto denying many facts, and promising many things. The people of Jamaica place no faith whatever in what he writes. Neither he nor his predecessors--with one or two honorable exceptions--can be relied on for sincerity of purpose, when half a dozen ounces--doubloons--pr capita of the slave, look so invitingly before their rapacious eyes.

I have just traveled through the cast portion of Kausas, and propose to tell you what I think of it. For the purpose of seeing the quality of its soil, face of the country, general appearance, , I determined to leave the river, and make the journey of between two and three hundred miles to this place by land.

By the steamer Orizaba, we have Vera Cruz dates of 22d inst. Madame SONTAG was attacked by Cholera, while on her way back to the United States, and died on the 16th inst., after a short illness. We have no important intelligence from the insurgents under ALVAREZ. A small engagement had taken place between the insurgents and the Government troope, in which the letter were victorious.

We have received a letter from Mr. EDMUND B. CHILDE, Editor of America's Own, replying to the recent letters of Mr. DOHENY, published in the TIMES. We would gladly give insertion to the communication of Mr. CHILDE, if we did not believe that the ground in controversy has been fully covered, and that we have already given so much space to writers upon both sides, that neither has any further just claim upon us.

The organization of the Territories of Kansas and Nebraska by Congress, has, I perceive, excited a good deal of interest in New-York and New-England. Much solicitude is expressed through the pubic press to learn what are their resources,--the character of their soil--their mineral products--their agricultural capabilities, and their manufacturing advantages.

To John Donahue, Wm. Schmer, John C. Megmnis, committee. Gentlemen:--I have explained Rule 6th, Supplementary Instructions of May 15, as follows:-- "The rule simply means this, that the engineer is responsible for the running off at a switch at a station where his train stops, whether he shall run off before or after receiving a signal to go forward from a switchman or any other person."

The building on Bridge-street, Brooklyn, formerly occupied by a Baptist society, between Myrtle-avenue and Johnson-street, has recently been purchased by the "African Methodist Wesleyan Episcopal Church," for the sum of $12,500, and was yesterday morning dedicated to the worship of God. The dedication sermon was preached by Rev. Dr. BANGS.

Y., was-sent to the barn for a horse, and on returning, led the horse by a rope halter, the noose piece having been removed, which allowed the halter to slip back to the horse's breast.

HYDROPHOBIA--FORCE OF IMAGINATION.--A young lad, son of Mr. WILLIAM BOOTH, a resident of Covington, was bitten in the leg about eight weeks since by a dog, The wound was but slight, and nothing more was thought of it until after the recent melancholy case of hydrophobia in that city.
From the Galveston Civilian we clip the following: Capt. WM. WOOD, a soldier at San Jacinto, died at Houston a few days since. He was an oceentric character, and his last hours were characteristic.

THE CHOLERA CASES IN PHILADELPHIA.--The weekly report of the Board of Health, of the interments during the past week, gives nine deaths from Cholera. Some excitable persons fancied that the city was about to be ravaged by disease, and no little alarm has been created among the timid.

On the 18th of the present month Lord RAGLAN embarked in the Caradoc steamer-for Varna, where he intended to plan the coming campaign with OMER PACHA. The Minister of War, RIZA PACHA, and the Minister of Marine accompanied him on board the Chef-fer, imperial steamer, and the French General, Marshal St. ARNAUD, departed at the same time in the Berthallet.
The steamship Orizabo, with advices from Vera Curz to the 22d inst., and the City of Mexico to the 19th, arrived at this port to-day. Her news is highly important.

INSURANCE LOSSES.-From a detailed statement which we find in the Jacksonville (Florida) Republican, the losses sustained by underwriters, by the late fire in that city, amount to considerably over one hundred and ten thousand dollars.

We published yesterday the correspondence between the General Superintendent and the "striking" Engineers of the Erie Railroad. The difficulty has been adjusted by the explanations of the Superintendent, although that officer withdraws nothing.

PAINFUL OCCURRENCE--DEATH OF JOSIAH HOLPROOK.--Yesterday afternoon the lifeless body of JOSIAH HOLBROOK, of Washington City, was found in Black Water Creek, near the mouth of the tunnel. Mr. H. had been staying in this city for several months, occupied in scientific, and especially geological pursuits, to which he was enthusiastically devoted.

In this City, on Monday, June 26, WM. H. VAN KLEECK, after a long illness. The relatives and friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral. from his late residence. No 77 Fast 23d-st on Wednesday. 28th inst., at 1 1/2 o'clock, P. M. without further notice.

The funeral of Mr. JOSEPH T. RICE, one of our oldest, and during the earlier part of his life, one of our most energetic and successful merchants, was largely attended yesterday.
A few petitions were presented. Sixteen private bills were received from the House and referred. The bill making Fronteras, in Texas, a port of entry was passed.

Our city was visited on Sunday morning by cholera, in its most malignant form. Up to the present time of writing, (Tuesday morning,) fifteen of our citizens have died. Almost every case reported proved fatal. Quite a number of our citizens have fled. Several new cases reported this morning. A number have died in the country.

Commencement Week in a Yankee village is the week of all the year. In our stirring City it produces not so much noise as to be appreciated above the din of commerce, the roar of rowdyism, and the usual amusements that serve to keep the excitable from perishing; and yet here it has its circle in which it is the most important event that the twelve months produce.

There was less excited discussion and more voting in Congress yesterday, than on the day previous. The Senate rejected the bill to alter the meeting of the sessions of Congress from the first of December to first October, by the decisive vote of yeas 15, Nays 33.

The thermometer now marks 95 1/2[degrees] in the shade. JOHN WELSH, a stevedore, died in the Hospital last night from the effects of a blow on the head by a colored laborer, in the hold of the schooner Lone Star, yesterday.

As many citizens of the United States have a claim against the British Government for the return of dues improperly levied, and as the grounds of the claim and the time when it originated, seem not to be understood in the United States, I beg to address the claimants through your paper, in order to save trouble to them and myself.

On Saturday last, the 24th inst., (St. John's Day,) the Free Masons of Watertown, and its vicinity, turned out in large numbers to celebrate the day. The elegant new Masonic Hall was solemnly dedicated by Hon. B. B. FRENCH of Washington, P. G. M. of the District of Columbia, acting as proxy for the M. W. J. D. EVANS, G. M. of Masons, of New-York.

The Alumni of Columbia College met in the Chapel, at 4 o'clock, P.M., yesterday, to consider the Report of the General Committee appointed on the 22d of April last. There were about fifty members present.

Lieut. W. D. SMITH, 2d United States Dragoons, arrived in this city last night from Fort Union, New-Mexico. He reached Independence on the 17, and left immediately for this city in advance of the until. Lieut. SMITH left Fort Union on the 3d inst.

Senator SLIDELL is very much troubled about the publication, the DAILY TIMES, of his report from the Committee on Foreign Relations, in favor of the withdrawal of the preventive squadron from the Coast of Africa.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Allow me, through the medium of your valuable journal, to call the attention of the proper authorities to the illegal practice of discharging guns and pistols, (to say nothing about fire-crackers, in the public streets before and during the entire day of the annual "Celebration of Independence."

The Government organ announces that the writs for a new election will be issued immediately, returnable by the 10th of August. The Ministry are determined to Prevent the people from exercising calm consideration upon the choce of candidates. We have no fear but the people will be ready ill tile; but it will be necessary to use all diligence. Doubtful points must be decided quickly, and the utmost exertion used to organize.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I notice in your paper of this morning a communication from "Knickerbocker," calling the "Ten governors" to an account for their bad management of the Penitentiary at Blackwell's Island.

You are not accustomed to receive letters from Saratoga in June, and doubtless many will think there is nothing here worth describing at this dull season. Well, I am not sure that there is. Most certainly those who only think of Saratoga as a place of fashion, gayety and dissipation, and wish only to hear of these things, may pass on, for my letter will be to them a very prosy affair.

NEW ARMORY IN HOBOKEN.--On Monday evening, the Highwood Guard, of Hoboken, opened its new Armory at the new Odd Fellows Hall, by giving an invitation Soiree. Some two hundred of the ladies and gentlemen of the village were present, and took a lively interest in the festivities of the evening. The Guard appeared in full uniform, and want through a short drill.

The usual exercises of the Annual Commencement of the New- York University took place yesterday, at Niblo's Garden. The first and second circles and parquette were densely crowded, while no inconsiderable number were compelled to take seats in the third circle.

It is very well known that the Earl of ELGIN, Governor General of Canada, is not likely to hold that high and lucrative office after this year. He was appointed by Lord JOHN RUSSELL in September, and eight years occupancy is an unusually extended term.

I have just returned from an excursion to Pennsylvania. Went by railroad from Philadelphia to the junction of the Juniata with the Susquehanna; thence by packet to Lockhave, and then in a wagon up the Sinnamahog, to Bennett's Branch, in Clearfield County, where I spent three or four days.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The impression prevails extensively that the judgment of the civilized would has already determined, that the Emperor NICHOLAS is unjust and arbitrary in his demands upon the Turkish Government; haughty and insolent in respect to the propositions of the Allied Powers to the established a peace; and hypocritical in his pretensions.

SIR: In your paper of the 17th inst. I find the following, viz: "The Representatives from the Free States, named below, voted. On Monday week, to take up the Kansas-Nebraska bill, with a view to urge its immediate passage," and among the number I find my name recorded.

CHOLERA--THE HOSPITAL IN BROOKLYN.--As nearly as can be ascertained, five cases of Cholera were reported yesterday to the Board of Health. Four of these, it is stated, terminated fatally. There are many complaints made about the reports of Cholera cases, but they are as correct as can be obtained, under the circumstances.

A correspondent at Malone, in Franklin County, informs us that on the evening of the 20th, the wife of GEORGE S. ADAMS, Esq., of that place, was instantly killed by the upsetting of a wagon in which she and her mother, an aged lady, were riding. Mrs. A. had been driving, but in turning a corner gave her mother the reins, as she had had the most experience.

THE FULL MISSION TO CENTRAL AMERICA.--We have reason to believe that the Government have determined not to fill this mission, on the ground that in the existing condition of Central America, it is not only useless, but a serious embarrassment to the proper care of our interests in that quarter.

From the Charleston Mercury. There is a cloud looming up in the West that is already a good deal larger than a man's hand, and that promises to grow apace. We have already noticed the project of the Abolitionists to get up a kind of fury of emigration to Kansas, and to seize at once upon the Territorial government, and stamp it with the character of Anti-Slavery form the outset.

From the Hartford Courant. An act has passed the Senate of the State Legislature, and we presume it will pass the House, entitled a bill for the Defence of Liberty in this State. Its de sign is to give to the Fugitive Slave the same privileges in his trial that are given to the common murderer.

TO MY CONSTITUENTS: My nomination to Congress alarmed me greatly, because I believed it would result in my election. To separate myself from my large private business for so long a time, and to war against the strong habits formed in my deeply secluded life, seemed to be well night impossible.

AN EXPERIENCED PICKPOCKET.--The police have just arrested the oldest and most experienced of Parisian female pickpockets--a woman nicknamed, from her dexterity, the Main d'Or. A few days ago they received intelligence that several pockets had been picked at railway stations, and that the Main d'Or had just arrived in Paris.

Mr. SUMNER in the Senate yesterday made a very effective vindication of his position in regard to the recapture of fugitive slaves. It is not easy to see what limit the slaveholding oligarchy which has possession of the Federal Government will place to their exactions, when they denounce as a trailer a Northern Senator who declares that he will not personally pursue, seize and return a fugitive from Slaver.

CONSTANTINOPLE, May.-A retailer of sundries, who has established himself here, and who has dignified himself with the title of "merchant," has made a rapid fortune, which he owes to the article talents of a captain of the French staff.

On the 15th, the celebration of "Corpus Christi" by procession, high mass , was the most brilliant that I have witnessed in Havana, for the last thirty years; and we had the pleasure of seeing the Viceroy and the Lord Bishop of the diocese in attendance, following the consecrated "bread and wind," which had become the veritable "body and blood" of the Saviour of the World.

A promise long since made to us, by the organs of French taste in this metropolis, at length seems to be upon the eve of its fulfilment. The French population of our City have long been striving to import the gayeties of their own brilliant capital into their places of public resort, and their private salons here, but have hitherto only partially succeeded.

At other fine day's sport on the turf was witnessed yesterday at the National Course, Long Island. It has now become a settled fact, that the enterprise has met with a degree of success unequalled in this section of the country since 1842-'3-'4-'5, when the first men of New-York took a deep interest in all matters connected With the Turf.

For more than two months now, that provision of the City Character which requires all the proceedings of the Common council and notices of City business to be published in one or more of the City papers, has been utterly disregarded by the existing City Government.

We learn from a correspondent that the Masonic Fraternity of this and the adjoining States and the Canadas, had a joyous festival at Auburn on the 24th inst. It was said to be the largest turn-out of Masons that has been witnessed, out of the New-York City, during the past 25 years. The procession was half a mile in length; and was accompanied by several bands of music.

DEAR SIR: We take leave to address you as friend to temperance, of humanity, as one interested in the welfare of the City, and us a taxpayer, directly or indirectly, and crave your attention for five minutes to the plan and working of the Carson League.

EXCITEMENT IN BEDFORD, KENTUCKY--ESCAPE OF DELIA WEBSTER.--Miss WEBSTER, as most of our readers know, was indicted some years ago, in Fayette County, Ky., for stealing or abducting a number of slaves. She was convicted and sentenced to the penitentiary for a term of years. And was pardoned out by Cov. CRITTENDEN after she had served the State but a small portion of the time she was sentenced for.

In Williamsburg on Tuesday, June 27. HORACE N. MARTIN, only son of Elharam Martin, aged 27 years. The friends of the family and his acquaintances generally are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on I Thursday, 29th inst., at 2 o'clock, P. M., from bis late residence. No. 133 South 8th St., Williamsburg.

We take pleasure in announcing that the efforts of Rev. Dr. PENNINGTON to recover for freedom the person of his brother STEPHEN PEMBROKE, have been entirely successful. Mr. PEMBROKE arrived here on Tuesday night at 11 o'clock, in Company with Mr. LORENZO DE ANGELIS, one of the Deputies of the United States Marshal for the Southern District of New-York, whose services the Doctor had procured for the purpose.

The debate on the anti-Nebraska resolutions was continued in the House to-day, but without final action. All the Banking bills were matured, and passed the House to-day. Balloting for United States Senators is fixed for tomorrow.

The Annual Celebration of the Association of the Alumni of the New-York University took place on Tuesday evening. The proceedings were opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. FERRIS, Chancellor of the University, after which Prof. BENJAMIN N. MARTIN, the orator on the occasion, addressed the members of the Alumni, and a numerous and select audience.

The Richmond Examiner is clamorous for the establishment of Southern Colleges, and for the education of the sons of Southerners in them. It denounces in unmeasured terms the habit, which seems to have become chronic with Southern men, of either sending their sons to the Free States for their education, or of employing Northern tutors at home.

RUN OVER AND KILLED.--A most singular, sad and fatal accident occurred at New-Boston village yesterday afternoon, 25th inst. Just as the people were coming home from church, which is situated on a high steep hill, the forward axeltree of Mr. SAMUEL MARDEN'S wagon broke, at the top of the hill, throwing him and his daughter out, hurting her badly.

DISTRESSING OCCURRENCE.--Last evening, about 6 o'clock, immediately after the steam ferry boat International had passed up the river, from the railroad terminus at Waterloo, some gentlemen who were fishing on Bird Island pier observed a man in the centre of the stream, swimming steadily and lustily for the American shore.

THE VETERANS OF 1812 IN CONVENTION.--The veterans of the war of 1812 have just concluded a pleasant Convention at Syracuse. Resolutions were adopted, instructing the officers of the corps in this State to memorialize Congress for relief; declaring it to be a sacred duty to shield and succor the helpless and indigent; and returning thanks to the Legislature, and members of Congress who have advanced the cause of the Veterans.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: In your journal of yesterday, under the head of "Washington Correspondence," I had an article pointed out to me, referring to Lieutenant FAUNTLEROY and myself, to which, in justice to ourselves, I feel it necessary to reply.
WASHINGTON NATIONAL MONUMENT.--The agent of the Washington National Monument has put forth an appeal to the public for aid on the fourth at the Palace. The appeal is published in another column.

THE SWINE ORDINANCE.--The Board of Health have extended the swine law so as to prevent the keeping of swine between the 3d of July and 1st of October in any portion of the Eighth and Ninth Wards. The swine in the city of Williamsburg are mostly owned by the Irish, and they threaten to resist the enforcement of the law.

London Markets. Per Europa.] LONDON, Friday, June 16-5 P. M. We have no material change to notice in the Colonial and Foreign Produce markets this week. SUGAR dull. COFFEE in good demand. and rather dearer. TEA, COTTON, and BREADSTUFFS firm. MONEY without change in value, but in less demand.

SUICIDE.--The Louisville Journal relates the facts concerning the suicide of a lad of 13 years, named HENRY MERRIMAN, ten miles from the city: This is one of the most mysterious as well as one of the most extraordinary cases of suicide ever committed in this country. HENRY was a devout Christian. He had lost a little sister who also belonged to the Church.

On Thursday last the Provincial Parliament was prorogued. Mr. HINCKS stated on be half of Government that this step was preliminary to dissolution. The Ministry had been previously defeated on the answer to the. Governor General's speech.

From the Missouri Republican. MANTENO, Kankakee Co., Saturday, June 24, 1854. A terrible hurricane blew over this place last evening from a north-easterly direction, extending some six or eight miles in width. In its course an immense deal of damage was done--houses blown down and torn from their foundations; roofs town off and carried from fifty to a hundred rods.

At no period since the organization of this Territory, has it been so sorely stricken, and so completely at the mercy of the Indians, as at this time. It appears as though all the Indians of the Great West had combined to overrun and destroy us. Within the last fortnight, the county of San Miguel has been sadly dealt with by a band of Cheyennes land Kiowas from the plains near the Arkansas river.

Don't trifle with the affections of young ladies. They ore institutions that never were established for any such purpose. If you don't contemplate marriage certificates and the parson, French bedsteads, a five hundred dollar house-rent, and a prospective home for the old folks, just take your hat and leave. You've no more right to go on trifling with confiding calico, than a holly hock has to pass itself off for a rose.

The managers of the Washington National Monument have issued an appeal to the nation for aid, saying that the funds are now nearly exhausted, and that, unless prompt and zealous efforts be made to raise money, the work must be discontinued. The monument is intended to reach a height of 517f feet, and It has al. ready been erected to an altitude of 154 feet, at a cost of$230,C00.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: We shall be happy to discuss with your correspondent, " A Constant Reader," the great subject Currency-which we deem the basis of all economic science. We have a theory to establish, yet we are not disposed to dogmatize, and desire only to ascertain the truth-to discover the law of the subject, which is obviously not understood.

A PRODIGY IN AVRSHIRE.--There is at present attending the Hastings school, Darvel, in Ayrshire, a girl, aged between 8 and 9 years, who commenced the study of arithmetic less than 'a twelvemonth ago. Such are the powers of her memory that she is now able to calculate mentally, in a very few moments, such questions as these: How many seconds in 20, 80, 90, or 900 years ?

The Frederick (Md.) Examiner announces the completion of the Artesian well in that place. Alt present it is found impossible to ascortain accurately the yield or winter, but all accounts agree that it will be at least 150 gallons per minute, and may be much more. The editor of the Harrisburg (Pa.) Union has just had the census of that town taken, showing the white population to be now 11,217, and the colored 605.

The Board of Aldermen held the first meeting of the July Session last evening. Little business was done, and they separated at an early hour. An invitation was had from Major General Sandford to receive the honors of a marching salute on the 4th of July. Accepted.

The trial of Col. SCHOULER for falling through the slats of his berth upon Rev. Dr. KENNEDY, while on the grand railroad excursion, appears to have been conducted with great solemnity. The Judge, on opening the court, laid a revolver and bowie knife on the table, and observed, "this court always tempers justice with mercy."

A terrible hurricane blew over this place last evening from a north-easterly direction, extending some six-or eight miles in width. In its course an immense deal of damage was done-houses blown down and torn from their foundations; roofs blown off and carried from fifty to a hundred rods. Much property was destroyed, but no lives were lost as I have been able to ascertain.

A horrible accident occurred on the Susquehanna Railroad last night, owing to a collision of trains. Twenty-four persons were instantly killed and thirty-three others injured, some fatally and all seriously. The regular train for York, (Penn.,) ran into the "Know Nothing" Excursion train--about 5,000 having proceeded in the morning to Rider's Grove to celebrate the day. The consisted of men, women and children.

WEEKLY REPORT OF DEATHS IN BROOKLYN. The Health Officer reports 79 deaths for the week ending Saturday last--Males, 51; Females, 28; Adults, 44; Children, 35; of the whole number there were 14 deaths by cholera; 8 by cholera infantum; 4 by cholera morbus; diarrhoca 3, and dysentery 2; 5 by consumption, and 6 drowned. There were but five cases of fevers.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: We shall be happy to discuss with your corre spondont, " A Constant Reader," the great subject Currency-which we deem the basis of all econom ic science. We have a theory to establish, yet we are not disposed to dogmatize, and desire only to ascertain the truth-to discover the law of the subiect. which is obviously not understood.

New-York was hot and orderly on the FOURTH. The sun came out very splendidty, very warmly, very clearly--and shone all day with undiminished fervor. No hotter Fourth certainly was ever seen. The City seethed and baked from early morning till late into the hour of evening.

The Frederick (Md.) Examiner announces the completion of the Artesian well in that place. At present it is found impossible to ascertain accurately the yield of water, but all accounts agree that it will be at least 150 gallons per minute, and may be much more.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE AT CITY POINT---Two HOTELS BURNT !--This morning about 4 o'clock as the steamer Belvidere started off from the wharf at City Point, a fire broke out in a stable or other out house belonging the Mr. BLITZ'S Hotel, ten-pin alley and other outbuildings.

The managers of the Washington National Monument have issued an appeal to the nation for aid, saying that the funds are now nearly exhausted, and that, unless prompt and zealous efforts be made to raise money, the work must be discontinued. The monument is intended to reach a height of 517 1/2 feet, and it has already been erected to an altitude of 154 feet, at a cost of $210,000.

Rows.-On Friday night, at a late hour, some Irishmen who were upon a drunken carousal in Newark-avenue, in Jersey City, were requested to go home. Refusing to do so, and offering defiance to the watchmen, an attempt was made to arrest some of them, and they resisted.

The Royal Mail steamship America, Captain LANG, from Liverpool on Saturday, June 24 arrived here at 10 o'clock this morning, en route for Boston. The Collins steamship Baltic, from New-York on the 10th of June, arrived out at Liverpool at 7 o'clock A. M., on Wednesday, June 21.

THE CHOLERA IN BROOKLYN.--A man named MORRIS, a German, residing on Court-street, between Mill and Church, was taken with the cholera immediately after eating his dinner yesterday, and died within three hours. Another person in the same house was taken with the disease about the same time, and was not expected to recover last evening. Several other cases of cholera were reported yesterday.

BUTCHERIES.--Amid all the very praise-worthy efforts of our City Authorities to prevent the further spread of the cholera, there is one class of nuisances which appears altogether to have escaped their attention. We allude to the slaughter-houses.

A horrible accident occurred on the Susquehanna Railroad last night, owing to a collision of trains. Twenty-four persons were instantly killed and thirty-three others injured, some fatally and all seriously. The regular train for York, (Penn.,) ran into the "Know Nothing" Excursion train--about 5,000 having proceeded in the morning to Rider's Grove to celebrate the day. They consisted of men, women and children.

ANOTHER REGATTA.--The New-York Yacht Club is organizing another regatta, prize, $500, to the sailed for at Newport, R. I., on the 10th of August. The lists are open to all vessels of over 15 tons, Custom-House measurement. The race is to be from Fort Adams out to sea and back, the stake boat being so placed as to make the distance, as nearly as possible, 40 miles. Entries close Aug. 1 in this City.

The Anniversary was observed in a very promisenous manner in Brooklyn. Young America was "wide awake" sometime before the day was ushered in; and when that event did occur, such a whizzing and shooting never was known before. The predictions of JOHN ADAMS were fully verified, so far as that city was concerned.

THE ENGLISH AT CONSTANTINOPLE.--NO small amount of sickness is likely to prevail among the inexperienced Europeans, unless they change their system of walking the streets at mid-day, and eating large meat dinners, accompanied by fiery liquids, as at home.

From the American Medical Monthly. Having, within a few days, had several friends relate their sudden illness after taking a single glass of soda water, and suspecting some poisonous impregnation to be the cause, I was induced to obtain several gallons of this favorite beverage from different parts of the City, and to submit them to a chemical examination.

To the Editors of the National Intelligencer: GENTLEMEN: In answer to a note from me, I have just received a letter from my friend, JAMES T. BRADY, Esq., a distinguished lawyer of New-York, and a widely-known and influential politician, always a National Democrat, giving his views upon the Nebraska bill.

On another page of the TIMES to-day we, publish an article from the Richmond Enquirer, to which we invite the particular attention of our readers. It is an edifying disclosure of the progress of Moral Science among the slaveholders. Their minds have now worked clear.

We publish on our second page to-day a long and very interesting letter from Professor FORESTI, who has been favorably known to our citizens for many years as a man of learning, and an estimable citizen.

CASTLE GARDEN. -- In consequence of the sudden indisposition of Madame BERTUCCA MARETZEK, the Opera last night ("Maria de Rohan") was postponed. There will be performance until Monday evening, when it is hoped the lady will be sufficiently recovered to resume her duties.

This world is full of sudden and oftentimes most fearful transitions--"We know not what an hour may bring forth"--and I have never felt so fully the correctness of this saying, or been more deeply impressed with the truthfulness of the declaration that "in the midst of life we are in death," than by the incidents of yesterday, the 79th Anniversary of our Independence.

BRUTAL OUTRAGE.--A well-known gang of rowdies, whose haunts are principally in the Eleventh Ward, Brooklyn, on Saturday morning made a serious and most unprovoked attack upon an unoffending citizen, at the corner of Myrtle-avenue and Raymond-street, knocking him down, kicking, and otherwise ill-using him.

THE CHOLERA HOSPITAL--Dr. J.C.HUTCHISON, attending physician at the Cholera Hospital, Brooklyn, makes the following report to the board of health, of the admissions, deaths and recoveries in said hospital, from the time it was open (June 26) to the present: Number admitted with cholera, 10; number admitted with after diseases, 2. Total, 12.

From the N. O. Picayune, June 28. Rumors of serious troubles in Mihoacan had been current for some time in Mexico, and it seems pretty clear that they were not altogether without foundation. Gen. ANASTASIO TORREJON has been nominated Commandant General of the Department.

CHOLERA AMONG RAILROAD MEN. -- The duties of the officers of railroad trains, yesterday, were arduous in the extreme, both from the effects of the weather and an unprecedented number of people using the cars.

A GROSS OUTRAGE--BLOWING UP OF A CHURCH.--The new stone Catholic Church, in the process of erection in Dorehester. Dear Milton, was blown up yesterday morning at 3 o'clock, by placing a keg of gunpowder on the floor of the building. The roof was entirely blown off, and the east and west walls demolished, making a complete wreck of the building.

The bill for the establishment of a line of mail steamers between San Francisco and Shanghai, in China, passed the Senate to-day by a vote of nearly two to one. There is good reason to hope this beneficent measure will promptly receive the sanction of the other House, and thus becomes a law.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Your correspondent B.'s notions of wealth, as expressed in your paper of the 4th instant, seem to me to be remarkable. He denies that money is wealth. He says that money is no more wealth than yard sticks. If so, he had better pay his landlord in yard sticks and not in money.

The inhabitants of the Key may be divided into two classes, which differ in a very marked degree in their character and habits of life: these are the Bahamians, and the emigrants from the States. Without wishing to consider intellectual and moral qualities as belonging to any particular class exclusively, we may notice as a fact, that the Bahamians are in both respects less improved than I the American portion.

The National Course Races Concluded--Sudden Death of a Virginia Trainer. The people were again disappointed yesterday, at the new National Race Course, in consequence of the races, as announced, not taking place. This was owing to the sudden death of Capt STEWART, the trainer of Mr. TEN BROECK's horses.

SINGULAR MATRIMONIAL MISTAKE.--There has been a good deal of gossip occasioned at Wortley and Helbeck during the past week by a curious marriage blunder. The bride and bridegroom, accompanied by an individual who was to act as the father and give away the bride, presented themselves for marriage at Wortley church, on Saturday morning last.

In this City, on Wednesday. July 5, Mrs. MARGARET JACKSON, wife of E. R Jackson, aged 38 years. The relatives and friends of the family, the brethren of Worth Lodge, No 210 F. A.M., and those of Marion Lodge, No 31, I. O. of O. F., are respectfully invited to attend the funeral, this (Friday) afternoon, at 3 O'clock, from her late residence, No. 100 Hester-st.

CASE OF SUN STROKE.--A German named JOHN FREDERICK SPEICKER, was found dead yesterday in a field at Sherwood, in Bergen. He had been but two weeks in this country, and was employed by Mr. YOUNG at Sherwood. He left Mr. YOUNG'S house on Monday, Complaining of being unwell. He had evidently died from the effects of the heat.

FIRE--HORSE BURNED.--At 2 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon, a fire broke out in Jersey City, in some out-buildings in the rear of the tenement-building Nos. 17 and 19 Sussex-Street. The Fire Department was soon on hand, and the fire was prevented from communicating with the dwellings.

One of the best celebrations of the anniversary of our National Independence has just closed in this place. It was emphatically a union celebration, and one of its most prominent features was the attendance of the six Sabbath Schools of the town, numbering in all about six hundred scholars.

The Museum and Theatre belonged to ISAAC B. PARKER, of Burlington, who, it is said, is insured. Their destruction is total. The fire raged till near daylight, burning off the roofs of seven buildings in Sansom-street. The museum walls have partly fallen in, and will have to be entirely demolished.
