By the way of St. Louis we have later intelligence from the Plains, the mail having reached Independence. Business at Santa Fe was dull, and there is but little news of interest. The various trains were proceeding slowly westward, on account of heavy rains rendering almost every stream impassable. The Pawnce Indians were very troublesome, robbing the trains.

The malignant efforts which are perseveringly made by a portion of the American press to turn aside the citizens of the United States from their natural sympathies, and we might almost say from their natural duties, give peculiar value and importance to the treaty which has just been concluded between the Federal Government and the British Crown.

It is an indisputable fact, that the people of the South have come to regard the institution of slavery with feelings and views very different from the traditional prejudices which they had been content to accept without investigation or inquiry. So radical and complete a change in public sentiment in respect to a subject of so much interest, could not occur without attracting the observation and exciting the curiosity of intelligent thinkers.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: DEAR SIR: The recent order from the War Department, approving the conduct of certain officers, and bestowing merited praise upon them for their gallantry, in contests with the Indians, was incorrectly printed in your paper.

ORIGIN OF THE WORD "TEETOTAL."--Mr. J.S. BUCHINGHAM, in his History and Progress of the Temperance Reformation, just published, says: "At Preston and Blackburn in England, at Paisley in Scotland, and at St, Johns in New-Brunswick, societies on the principle of total abstinence from all intoxicating drinks were founded in 1833.

The sorrowful occurrence noted Yesterday, of the explosion of the powder magazine, has been rendered still more sorrowful by the death of two of the sufferers. To ascertain the full particulars of the catastrophe, and the condition of the unfortunates, we went to Aurora Yesterday morning on the early train of the O. and M. Railroad, JESSE MOORE, Conductor.

OPERATIONS OF THE CITY MISSIONARY SO CIETY.-The report of the City Missionary Society a Jersey City for the past two months, showing the operations of the Society, has been made. Among the item of labor performed in that time, it is mentioned the 6,708 families have been visited, and 6,448 tracts have been distributed.

Issued from the United States Patent Office, for the week ending July 4, 1854--each bearing that date: Galusha J. Bundy, of Lyndon, Vt.--For improvement in potato diggers. Henry G. Bul?ley, of Kalamazoo--For improvement in the construction of salt evaporators. Aury G. Cons, of Worcester--For improvement in screw wrenches.

A very much be-raised book, with far loss merit than it ought to have to justify half the commendations bestowed upon it. The sketches contained in it were contributed to the NEW-YORK TIMES, and that acknowledged oracle of good taste and candor in literary judgment (!) pronounced them admirable. They were very well for the celumon of the TIMES, which is all the publicity they actually merited.

CHOLERA IN SHEPHERDSIVLLE-TOWN DESERTED, -We learn that the cholera broke out again in Shepherdsville last week, and up to Saturday evening nineteen deaths had occurred, making forty deaths in all since it first broke out. The disease was still raging when our informant left, and the town was almost entirely deserted.

The Moniteur publishes the report of M. DE SAINTE BEUVE, President of the Dramatic Commission, on the awards made by it of the Government prizes or the year 1853. It fills four columns, and is worth abridging. This is the second year that prizes have been given : the first, forty plays were sent by their authors to be examined by the Committee; the second, only 14 were submitted to it.

BRILLIANT METEOR.---Our city was visited on Thursday night last, about 10 o'clock, by one of those brilliant strangers of whom we are just permitted to see enough to long for them for ever after. Our visitor on this occasion was a meteor. Its course was, generally speaking, from south to north, inclining to the northeast.

The great trotting match for $10,000, which was announced by the Proprietor of the Centreville Course, L.I., as to take place yesterday between gr. g. Grey Eddy and Br. m. Highland Maid did not transpire. It appears the race had been drawn by consent of both parties, the night previous, but as no notice was given of it in the public prints, a large number went over and were disappointed.

SULEEN DEATH.--Mr. LYNES, driver of an ice-cart in South Brooklyn, and in the employ of Mr. IIOPKINS, was taken sick at 10 o'clock Thursday morning in Atlantic-street, while serving out ice, and was a corpse before noon. A few moments before he was taken sick was unusually happy and buoyant in spirits--so much so as to be made the subject of remark by those acquainted with him.

By the steamship Charles Morgan at New-Orleans, we are in receipt of papers to the 25th, from Galveston. The Galveston Times, of the 20th, says: The Indians who killed the FORESTER family have, it is supposed, been taken just below Fort Belknap, on the Brazos river--they, are of the Wacos. Major NEIGHBORS thinks the party arrested are the same who committed the murders.

Rev. J, R. R. INDRICK has resigned the pastorate of the First Baptist Church in Charleston, S. C., in order to accept that of the Fourth, in the same city. The Bishop of Pennsylvania has ordained Rev. AARON CHRISTUAN to the priesthood, and Messrs. C. H. ALDERT and J. W. ROBBINS to the diaconate.

Yesterday morning the trial was resumed at the usual hour, the Court-room being filled to its utmost capacity with an audience of respectable appearance. The Jurors having answered to their names, Mr. BUSTEED proceeded to sum up the case on the part of the defendant.

It is the "glorious Fourth," but patriot ism is not at so high an ebb here-that enjoyment is out of all question. Nothing more dangerous than crackers are heard in the streets, and though the atmosphere is at boiling heat, there are always cool breezes in the groves-and though the fountains look like boiling cauldrons, the water comes to your lips as refreshing as if it were a stream from the Northern Ocean;

A pane of glass was broken out immediately under the window-fastener, the catch removed and the window hoisted. The Sunday

The RECORDER in the Chair. The minutes of the last meeting were read and approved. REPORTS ADOPTED. From the Committee on Annual Taxes in relation to the tax levied on the Metropolitan Bank for the year 1851, referring the matter in dispute to the Common Council, the time for the action of the Board having expired. In favor of paying Wm. C. Havens for expenses incurred in going to Sing Sing.

In this City, on Thursday July 6, after a short and severe illness. GEORGE b. HUNT, aged 34 years His relatives and friends, also has family. are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, at 3 o'clock this day, from the residence of his father ,Wilson J. Hunt, No. 327 Washington St. In this City, on Friday morning. July 7, BRIDGET, wife of John K?efe. aged 29 years.

A meeting of this society was held last evening at the Vauxhall Garden, No 2 Fourth-avenue. Minues of the last meeting were read and approved. Mr. O'HANLON read a letter from Mr. J. C. DONOVAN, of Mobile, addressed to the Secretary, asking for a copy of their rules and constiution, calling upon all to organize, as now, England's difficulty was Ireland opportunity.

It was our fortune to ride down upon the Long Island Railroad a day or two since--the very day that the fare to Greenport was raised from two dollars to two and a quarter. There was a good deal of complaint that the charge had not been advertised near as extensively as the fact that excursion trains would be run through the week.

MESSRS. EDITORS: For two days past a dead horse-very dead-has been allowed to remain in the Tenth-avenue, between Twenty-first and Twenty-second streets; and the horrible odor, annoyance and alarm it has created among the respectable families of the neighborhood, seem to call forth some sort of public donouncement upon the officer who is duly authorized by law of attend to the immediate removal of so disgusting

In the Senate to-day Mr. ALLEN presented the resolutions of the Legislature of Rhode Island on the subject of slavery, against the Nebraska bill, against the Fugitive Slave Law, and against the acquisition of new territory. A bill confirming a private land claim in Louisiana was reported and passed.

The Duke of WELLINGTON died at a very proper time. In September, 1852, there was no outward appearance of the hurricane which has since struck dismay into the heart of Turkey. The Czar, it is true, was meditating on the condition of "the sick man," of whose effects he so speedily desired England to joint with him, as residuary legatees, in making a division.

The ceremony of laying the corner-stone of the Presbyterian Church in Fourth-avenue and Twenty second-street, took place on Thursday evening, at 6 o'clock P. M., in presence o a large assemblage. The exercises consisted of readings from the Sacred Scriptures by Rev. Dr. PRENTISS. Prayer by Rev. P. H. SKINNER.

For some reason, unknown to us, our dispatches from our regular Agent were not delivered at a late hour this morning. and our news is in con sequence not as various as it should have been. For the early delivery of a portion of our mails, we are indebted to two of the gentlemen connected with our Post-Office.

(Impt's and Job.) 9 and 11 Park place. French, Swiss and German Dry Goods. AUGUST WETTER (Importer)................19 Broad-St.

A regatta took place oil the 4th on Charles river, between BRAMAN s baths and the Brookline and Cambridgeport bridge. The first race was by dorys rowed by one man, and the six following boats. entered: the James Nesbit, J. A. Knowlton, John Brown, of Swamscott; Flash, Pirate, Topsy. The distance around the coast was called three miles, and the dorys were to row once round.

There was a large number of bills passed by the Senate yesterday. They received the resolutions, of the Legislature of Rhode Island, on the subject to Slavery, against the Nebraska bill, the Fugitive Slave Law, and the acquisition of new territory; passed a bill making appropriations for constructing military roads in Washington and Nebraska territories, and after giving some little attention to the private calendar, adjourned.

The great want of the age is practical scholarship. The men that the world most wants now are through-bred, well-education scholars, whose studies are on topics that concern its daily necessities. It is always painful to see poser wasted. We dislike to see "Ocean into tempest wrought to waft a feather or to drown a fly."

Thermometers at 100 degrees Farenheit. Far enough in heat, in all conscience. A relentless, blinding sun pouring vertically upon the streets, and converting the side-walks into a series of kitchen ranges, where innumerable soles are frying. A suffocating Simoon, or burning wind, sweeping heavily in through every open window.

NEW UNITARIAN CHURCHES.-The new Unitarian Society at Staten Island, Rev. JOHN PARKMAN, Minister, is in a very flourishing condition, having within the last year erected a beautiful church near Stapleton, which was soon so well filled that last Fall it became necessary to enlarge the building to accommodate all applicants for pews. The building is paid for in Full.

We publish, in another part of this morning's TIMES, an account of an intention to fire a building in Front-street, on Thursday night, which will be read with interest. A more fortunate mistake has seldom been made by a watchman, than that which led

TRIAL OF CAPTAIN SAMUEL W. DOWNING, U.S. N., For carrying to Rio ?? in the U S. ship James?? R. ?? of the Argentine Sqadron, during a Civil War in Buenos Ayres, and for other official misconduct. THUR-DAY, July 6, 1854.

The "Angel Gabriel" lectured here on Wednesday and Thursday evenings against Popery. On the last occasion the crowd was large, and a disturbance occurred. A mob of men and boys proceeded to the Old South Church, used by the Catholics as a place of worship, broke open the doors, rang the bell, and displayed the American ensign from the belfry.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: On Saturday morning last, two men, who had just arrived by the ship Cultivator from Liverpool, called early at my lodgings and requested me to help them to make arrangements for proceeding cheaply and expeditiously to St. Louis. Was $10 each.

Election of Assistant Superintendents--Per-hum Gift Tickets Refused--Grading and Salaries. A Stated Meeting of this Board was held on Wednesday evening, at the Hall of the Board of Education, corner of Grand and Elm-streets. Dr. A. V. WILLIAMS, President, in the Chair, and a quorum present.

NIBLO'S GARDEN GARDEN.-- We observe, with much satisfaction, that the name of Madame ANNA THILLON appears on the bills again to-night. The Opera had to be postponed on Thursday evening (English and talian fared alike from similar causes) in consequence of Madame THILLON's in. disposition. The epidemic appears to be fastidious in its choice of artists-selecting the best ones.

Up to the present time there have been thirty-two deaths from the late disaster on the Susquehanna Rail Railroad, and there are three or four more persons in a doubtful condition. A warrant has been issued for the arrest of Mr. PARKS WINCHESTER, the Superintendent of the Road.

From the Washington Intelligencer. Congress having agreed to close the present session this day four weeks, we have been looking over the calendar of business to see what bills, , are on the table of the House of Representatives waiting legislative action. The following list contains the more important subjects yet unacted on, and may possess interest enough for our readers to be worth a column's space:

FORGERY.--Forgeries have just been discovered at Amity Springs, (better known as Visseher's Ferry,) Schenectady Country, to the amount, as far as known, of $11,000 and it is supposed there are still others committed by DAVID BAKER. BAKER has been a resident of Visscher's Ferry for the last two years. He cane there as a school teacher. ingratiated himself into

1. Resolved, That the State of New-Hampshire re-affirms the principles promulgated by the House of Representatives in 1850, "that the people are bound by no compact, expressed or implied, to suffer the introduction of slavery into Territory now free, and that they are unalterably opposed to the erection of any Territory without its prohibition by positive law."

The steamship Cahawba, from New-York via Havana, arrived at Mobile yesterday. The American bark Grey Eagle succeeded in landing six hundred slaves near Havana, on the 25th of June. The Eagle was subsequently captured by the British brig of war L'Esperegle, but was finally surrendered to a Spanish man of war. Only a small number of the Negroes were rescued.

The whole mortality in this city for the past week, was three hundred and sixty-eight: under ten years of age, two hundred and fifteen; of cholera, twenty-two. The lightning train from Pittsburg over the Pennsylvania Railroad, arrived at the depot in this city, yesterday, in twelve and a half.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I should like to know what is the use of spending so much or even any money for public fireworks on the Fourth of July, when so few persons can see and enjoy them. Being in Madison-square on Tuesday evening, I could not but notice how foolish the whole affair was.

POLITICAL.--On Saturday evening the Ward Democratic Nominating Committee met organized by appointing T. B. DECKER, Chairman, a B. JAQUINS, Secretary, The Committee then nominated TIMOTHY L. SMITH, for Alderman, to fill the vacancy occasioned by the resignation of Alderman JAMES. The Whigs have called a meeting for this evening at the Hudson House to make a nomination.

Fifteenth Annual Commencement of Rutgors Female Institute. The Exercises of this Institution commenced on Friday at 2 1/2; the first having formed in Madison-street, in the following order: Junitor, President, Rev. Dr. FERRIS, Trustees, Members of Committees, Invited Guests.

PORTER, of the steamship Golden Gate, and Miss MATILDA HERON, the popular actress, who had just completed a long and progtable engagement at San Francisco.
AFFAIRS AT THE BROOKLYN NAVY-YARD -- FRIGATE INDEPENDENCE ORDERED TO BE FITTED have the ?? Independence ready for sea with all dispatch. She is destined for the pacific station.

FATAL ACCIDENT--DEATH OF PROFESSOR McFAIL--A party of the students belonging to the Carlisle (Schoharie County) Seminary, accompanied by Professor ALFRED McFAIL and others, proceeded, on Saturday last, to explore the celebrated cave, located a few miles from the Seminary. They bad closed their explorations, and were returning, when the accident occurred, which resulted in the death of the Professor.

About 8 o'clock this morning, a spark from the lapper in the Strong Mill, ignited the loose cotton lying around the machine, and the flames flashed through the combustible material with incredible capidity. The DAILY TIMES has been honored by a decree of interdiction from the French mails. For the "security general" of the Empire of NAPOLEON III., the circulation of our humble journal has been suppressed within and without the walls of Paris.

The Collins steamship Baltic, the previous victor in the list of the fine runs from Liverpool to New-York, has beaten her own famous passage of August, 1851. Her guns fired off the Battery on Friday night at 1:05 A.M. almost on the ninth day out from Liverpool. The apparent time, 9 days 12 hours.

The steamship Perseverance, Capt. LAWLESS, arrived yesterday from Brazos, vid Galveston, and we have received two numbers (17th and 24th ult.) of the Brownsville Flag. The Perseverance left the Brazos on the 28th, and Galveston on the 29th ult. The Flag of the 17th says there is a growing discontent among the citizens of Matamoros and throughout the State of Tamaulipas.

A TROCIOUS MURDER IN MACON.--On Saturday morning last, our citizens were startled by the news of a most atrocious and unnatural murder, committed in our midst. An Irishman, by the name of CONNELLY, boarding in the house of D. GARAUGHTY, on Bridgerow, killed his own wife in open day, and then affected his escape to the woods.

It seems that the New-York and Pacific Railroad Company is not quite so defunct its many have supposed, but is resolutely pressing forward in its object of securing the first trans-continental route to the western shore of our Republic.

Yesterday afternoon, Gen. JOHN A. QUITMAN, Mr. J. S THRASHER, and Dr. A. L. SAUNDERS appeared before G. W. GERLEY, U.S. Commissioner, and entered into recognizers pursuant to the order of Judge CAMPBELL, of the U.S. Circuit Court.

An abstract of the news by the George Law we gave in yesterday morning's paper; that steamer having arrived at her wharf at 3 o'clock A.M. Much further details, with items of interest from Japan, Australia and Polynesia, we publish this morning.

Steamship George Law, Lt. G. P. Fox, U.S. N., commanding, left Aspin wall at 7 1/4 on the evening of the 1st inst., and arrived at Sandy Hook at 9.30 on the evening of the 9th, having been detained several hours by the fog. She arrived at her dock at 3 o'clock yesterday morning.

From the Baltimore American. I joined the ship the evening before, having engaged a berth on her us a passenger to Baltimore. Was in bed, but not asleep, when the anchor was tripped, about 6 A.M. Shortly after, I was greatly startled by the report of the heavy cannon, apparently overhead.

A GREAT ROW--SHOOTING AFFAIR.--Yesterday three Irishmen, named EDWARD KENA, MICHAEL BOYLE, and JOHN HOWNE, Were brought before Recorder CUTTER, charged with riotous conduct of an outrageous nature.

The late occurrences in this city in connection with the SCHUYLER fraud are now attracting great and general attention. People look and speak as if they had been surprised into some sudden knowledge of human nature.
Quite a disturbance occurred here late on Saturday night between some Americans and Irish. Early in the evening a party of Irish raised the American flagon a pole surmounted by a cross.

Mr. BARNUM resigns the Presidency of the Crystal Palace. He has found its embarrassed finances and the up-hill work of popularizing a new the great Exhibition of 1853, two much for his physical man in this hot season.

Last evening "Sonnambula" was given by the Castle Garden troupe. It was, of course, a substitute for something else which would have been given if the Gods or the Doctors had been propitious. Although in no actual danger, there are at the present moment three of the principal artists "down" with cholera morbus.

COMMON PLEAS--GENERAL TERM--July 9. Before Hon, Judges Ingraham, Daly and Woodruff. Miller us, Eagle L. e Eastra ice Company--INGRAHAM, . J.--Our practice always has been where a judgment has been opened and a new trial ordered, be the judgment allowed to stand as security, to require a new judgment to be entered for the amount recovered on the second trial, without reference to the previous judgment.

In this City, on Monday morning, July 10, ELIZABETH HAGGART, widow of the late James Haggart, Sen., in the 68th year of her age. The relatives and friends of the family, and those of her sons. James and William S. Haggart, are invited to attend her funeral, from the residence of her son James, No. 251 Broome St., this (Tuesday) afternoon. at 21/2 o'clock.

Yesterday afternoon quite an excitement was created in the vicinity of the City Hall. in consequence of the investigation of the charges of official corruption in the Corporation Attorney's Office, under the administration of Mr. JOHN B. HASKIN, the present chief officer of that Bureau.

We have received dates from St. Helena to the 18th of May. The Russian ship Czarowitch, 10 guns, 70 men, anchored off St. Helena on the 16th of May, causing considerable excitement on the island. The 6. proved to be In the employment of the Russian and American Company, and was therefore not molested.

Incidents thicken here to make a New-Yorker Stare. In the first place, this town is farthest from "white" land, in fact, if not in distance, and nearer the famous identical jumping-off place to the pit than any other in Texas, though several be nearer thereto than any man East can imagine.

MYSTERIOUS REMAINS.--A few days ago, while a number of workmen were engaged in digging a vault at Baltimore, one of them struck his pick upon a "hard" substance several feet below the surface of the earth.

We have intelligence that the long contemplated movement for the separation from the New-Granadian Government, of the four Provinces comprising the Isthmus of Darien, (or Panama,) is likely to be made in the course of a few weeks from the present time.

Hon. JOHN MCKEON, was nominated and confirmed, to-day, United States District Attorney for New-York. Alas! poor Mr. WESTBROOK. CHALRES WELLER, a brother of Senator WELLER, was nominated and confirmed Postmaster at San Francisco.

[Reported for the New--York Daily Times.] Cooper against Renwick.--Decree of Chancellor modified, without costs in this Court. In the following cases, judgment reversed, new trial granted. costs to abide event of suit, viz.: Andrews and others against Durant and others.
Mr. SHIELDS presented a memorial from Icarian Society of Illinois praying for a grant of land in Iowa, of which to make a settlement, the same to be paid for after selection and settlement.

The only question of moment which agitates the public breast, is the rumored change of ministry in the Ottoman Government. It is well known that the Grand Vizier has been dismissed, and that MEHEMET KEBRKSLI PACHA, late Minister of Marine, has taken his place.
Unhappy citizens who are amenable to Jury duty will be in nowise unthankful for the gentle hint afforded by the mover of a resolution in the Board of Alderman last evening.

Although we really had no fear of the result of the balloting for senator on Thursday, we had certainly a little anxiety upon the matter. The ware pullers bad had another week to operate in, and Concord had been thronged with them.

THE ARREST OF SOLOMON NORTHROP'S ALLEGED KIDNAPPER.-- On Friday we announced the arrest of MERRILL, whom SOLOMON NORTHROP accuses of having kidnapped him in Washington, many years since, and said him into Slavery.

Exposition of the Carson League. An adjourned meeting of Tenth Ward inhabitants, who are favorable to Temperance. was held last evening in the lecture -room of the Allen-Street Church, for the purpose of considering the subject of the illegal liquor traffic. E. W. KETCHUM, Esq., was selected Chairman.

From the Manchester American and Messenger, July 8. On the night of the 3d inst. a very serious riot occurred in the Irish portion of this city. The facts we understand to be in substance these: Some Irishmen built a file on the west side of Elm-street near to what is called the Phoenix boarding house, and having collected around in considerable numbers.

COFFEE IS DETHRONED.--"LIEBIG, (the illustrious German chemist.) says that asparagus contains, in common with ten and coffee, a principle which be calls 'taurine.' and which he considers essential to the health of those who do not take strong exercise.

An itinerant spouter, whose name slips my memory, as were ??, has been this town haransung from the steps at the public place for several days, the principal topic of his Incoherent speeches being considered "down"--to use his own expression--an cambolies and foreigners generally.

WHAT A LOCAL BOARD OF HEATH CAN DO.--Through the efforts, during six months, of the local Board of Health for the parochial district of Regent-square Church, St. Pancras, 639 separate sources of infection have been or are about to be abolished, by the removal of cess-pools, the renewal of drains, the trapping of sinks, and the removal of refuse.

The following is a copy of a letter received yesterday morning by Mayor Snelbake, from Wm. P. Connolly, whom Allison accused of being his murder: PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Sunday, July 2, 1851. His HONOR THE MAYOR - Honured Sir : will you be so kind as to hear and read the pleadings and request of a perfect stranger to your honour! My name is W. P. CONNOLLY.

Yesterday at 3 o'clock P.M. was the time appointed for the great event in the history of the turf, respecting the match made several weeks ago, between the pacer Hero and the trotter Prince, five miles and repeat, for $4,000. During the past few weeks upwards of $10,000 has been staked on the result, and latterly the turf-men were betting $1,000 to $400 in favor of Prince.

The Administration, after having been long in-labor, during which all the regular political doctors of the Democratic party and a multitude of irregular quacks have been unremitting in their attentions, has been delivered of a United States District: Attorney for the Southern District of New-York-and his name is JOHN MCKEON.

CASTLE GARDEN.--Our readers will be glad to learn that "Maria de Rohan" will positively be produced to-night. In this Opera the new contralto, Signora MARTINI D'ORMY--of whom we hear enthusiastic accounts--will make her first appearance.

From the American Medical Monthly. It is fairly to be presumed that some of our citizens, not within the ranks of the profession, occasionally look over the pages of the Monthly; we therefore design the following remarks for their especial benefit.

MONTICELLO FEMALE SEMINARY.--The number of students at this Institution during the last year, was 128; of whom 48 were in the First Class, 24 in the Second Class, 16 in the Junior Class and 8 in the Senior Class.

WIVES WANTED.--Marriageable girls are quick in the Minnesota market. We quote from a letter in the Boston Daily Advertiser: "Several leading and wealthy citizens of Saint Paul have married Indian sqnaws--aboriginal ladies, perhaps I ought to say.

Miss ANTOINETTE BROWN filled the pulpit of Rev. LUTHER LEE, yesterday, according to arrangement, and had a crowded house morning and afternoon. She was neatly dressed, with rather a dashing watch establishment, and after throwing off her craps shawl, presented herself at the desk, made her prayer--a long one, after the Presbyterian usage--and spreading the Bible open before he took her test, and walked into her discourse.

WOMEN IN ARMS.--We learn that the old Jones Tavern in this city, situated on the Leicoster road, which for sometime past has been a nuisance to the neighborhood, by reason of the bad character of the inmates, was suddenly vacated on Thursday last, in consequence of an intimation that the police were about to pay a visit to the place. Since ?? it has been unoccupied;

BURNING OF RICHMONDVILLE SEMINARY--THREE STUDENTS MISSING.--The large and spacious Seminary at Richmondville, Schoharie County, was totally destroyed by fire, Friday evening. The fire originated in the belfry, and spread with great rapidity.

CHRISTIANITY IN NEW-ZEALAND.--The first night that the devoted missionary SAMUEL MARSDEN slept in New-Zealand, the spears of the warriors were planted around his head. In 1814 he carried missionaries there, and from that time till 1841, so effective had his labors been that Christianity was spread over the whole newly-visited land.

There was only one baby among the members of the late excursion party up the Mississippi to the Falls of St. Anthony. The baby was only six months old--a son of HENRY FARNAN, Esq., the engineer of the Chicago and Rock Island Railroad.

This afternoon the Golden Age starts for Panama, ?? open a new line of communication between Australia and England. This is an event not only of great importance to this Colony, but of no small historical interest, as the first attempt to span the Pacific by a regular line of steamers, and the partial accomplishment of a scheme of inter-oceanic communication which has been cherished for the last three hundred years.
Where's the use of toiling and sweating to make money, unless we are to enjoy our earnings as we go along? Depend upon it, it is all vexation of spirit,--vanity, and nothing else.

Mr. ROCKWELL presented a memorial of five hundred citizens of Massachusets for the repeal of the Fugitive Slave act. Mr. SUMNER presented a memorial from JOSSAH GODDARD, a merchant in New-York, declaring the Fugitive Slave law to be unconstitutional, according to the judgement of approved witnesses and common sense, and, therefore, that it ought to be repeated.

WHEAT AND WOOL--These two farm products can be well grown together. Probably the best rotation would be to sow all wheat land with clover and timothy seed mixed, and let that remain in sheep pasture three years, and then break up and saw again with a light dressing of lime and a renewal of grass-seed.

The practice of referring to a popular vote important questions of public policy is becoming far too general, and exhibits a lamentable want of courage and unwillingness to assume responsibility on the part of the representatives chosen to make the laws.

The gentleman of the name of URQUHART, who seems to adopt the Morning Advertiser as his organ, and unites in his own person the properties of author, orator, prophet, and public accuser. appears to be endeavoring to amuse himself and the public, with the idea that the ministry is a cabal of traitors, who would sell their country to the highest bidder, and that every man is a scoundrel except himself.

At 12 o'clock, yesterday, a sale of valuable horses took place at the "New-York Tattersall's," in Sixth-avenue. Nearly a thousand persons were in attendance, and the bidding was active. From twelve to fifteen horses were put up during the early part of the sale, and were bid off at prices varying from $200 to $550.

STRAY WIVES ABROAD.--A pair of them took their flight from this city a few days since, leaving their better halves to indulge in sorry reflections upon the fickleness and frailty of woman. After a fruitless pursuit to New - York, the deserted lords returned to test the experience of husbands without wives.

We have recentlyread a sermonon railroads, published in a North western news-paper. The discourse was delivered by a Minister of the Gospel to his congregation. It is a good exposition of the benefits of railroads, and especially of their moral bearings.

FROM ST. HELENA.--The New Bedford Mercury has a copy of the St. Helena herald of May 18, which states that the Russian ship Ceserevitch, of 528 tons, with 10 guns and 70 men, anchored in the roads at St. Helena May 16. The arrival occasioned considerable speculation. The Herald Says:

The arrival of the steamship Golden Age, a New-York built vessel, under New-York ownership, at Panama, from Sydney and Melbourne, is an event in the wonderful commercial progress of the times that deserves a special record.

THE JAY-STREET AFFRAY IN BROOKLYN.--JOHN MALLOY, charged with assault and battery, with intent to kill MICHAEL MCGRATH, in Bay-street, Brooklyn, two weeks since, by stabbing him with a shoe knife, was yesterday examined before Justice DANIEL K. SMITH, and committed in full to answer.

MICHAEL JENNINGS was executed at 10 1/4 o'clock this morning, for the murder of Mrs. BRADLEY, of North Haven. Two companies of military kept guard around the Jail. There was a large crowd, but they behaved very orderly.

An early dissolution of the present British Ministry appears more than probable.- It may not be unprofitable, on the near prospect of a change, to examine the personality of the existing rulers of England, and of their probable successors.

CHOLERA AND SUN STROKES.--ANN SULLIVAN was taken from No. 3 Hamilton-alley to the Hospital last evening, where she died at once of the cholera. MOSES SMITH, a deformed man, well known as a vender of newspapers, was struck down in State-street yesterday afternoon by a sun stroke. He will probably recover.

The Board of Health of Brooklyn met yesterday at the usual hour. Nuisances in vacant lots in Carroll-street near Van Brunt, gutters in Sands, Washington and Adams-street, were reported by the Health Wardens, and the same were directed to be abated.
If Mr. BENTON tells the truth--and who ever dared to doubt his veracity ?--there is need that our Mayor stick up one of his "Dog and Pound" bills in the Senate Chamber.

A disastrous conflagration occurred at Coxsackie last evening, consuming nearly the entire business portion of the village. For hours the flames spread with great rapidity, and so wildly did the fire rage that the light was distinctly visible from this City.

DUPUYTREN.--DUPUYTREN was the most celebrated French surgeon of his day; he was destitute of faith, and by his powerful mind and brusque, hardihood, overcame the individuality of almost every one who approached him.

From the Athenaeum. Natal papers record the death of Dr. STANGER, the Government Surveyor-General of the Por Natal District, on the 14th of March. Dr. STANGER was only in his forty-second year, and seems to have fallen a victim to an ill-judged application on the so-called hydropathic treatment.

THE SETTLING DAY AT TATTERSALLS.--On Tuesday, although vast sums of money were disbursed, numerous impediments to "smooth going" presented themselves. Unfavorable reports of absentees were life, and complaints of the "tightness" of money were heard on all sides.

Two or three days since an Irish gentle man, whose solicitor had vainly endeavored to serve a writ on an ex-M. P., for an Irish borough, hit upon the following mode: Having sealed a stone bottle with an imposing crest, and marked it "potheen," he forwarded it by an intelligent lad of thirteen, who was previously well instructed, as a present from a friend ill the West.-end, with instructions to be delivered only to himself.

CLOVER.--The Question Settled.--It has long been a subject of debate whether Red Clover would thrive in this region. After much doubt, its culture was finally attempted a few years since on some of the prairies and red-lands in Greene, Perry and Marengo counties, some hundred and sixty miles north of us.

REMARKABLE FEAT.--Some time since the point of the lighting rod on the steeple of the First Congregational Church in New-London, Conn., got unscrewed and fell to the ground. It was such a dangerous piece of work to replace it, that the Committee were unwilling to employ any one to perform the task.

TO KEEP FLIES OUT OF ROOMS.--BOHN'S Pictorial Calendar says: "It was on a subject of general interest that Mr. SPENCE wrote, when he communicated to the Entomological Society the account of a mode employed by a friend of his, in Florence, to remove this drawback to the comfort of existence.
J. WETHERBEE, Jr., Broker, is reported as having failed. At our Stock Market this morning, prices generally showed a material decline.
The death of Dr. BIBIGHAUS, of Cholera, was reported to the Board of Health to-day. It was only yesterday that he reported a case of that disease to the Board.

Mr. E. OSGOOD, Jr., the leading ticket-seller at the American Museum, died yesterday morning, after a brief illness. His age was forty. He leaves a wife and three children. Mr. OSGOOD was well known to frequenters of the Museum, and will be deeply regretted by the many friends who have clustered about him.

The British Mail steamer Asia, from Liverpool Saturday, July 1, 11 A.M., arrived at this port last evening at 7 P.M. The Liverpool Cotton Market is reported steady, closing, however, with rather less animation.

The treaty, about which the Government has gone to so much trouble and expense, is at last signed. It was accomplished to-day; the Commodore went ashore this morning, and returned a few moments ago, with the important document, encased in a handsome lacquered box, "signed, sealed, and delivered."

A Writer in the Paris Patrie discusses at some length the subject of the German emigration from Europe to the United States. At first, he says, the German States saw with indifference the departure of the peasantry and mechanics; are long, however, the municipal authorities and Governments became alarmed, and soon it was seen that labor and capital were moving off to an extent which must be seriously felt at home. 1848

The steamship Isabel arrived at Quarantine at 11 o'clock on Monday night, and reached her wharf at 6 o'clock this morning. Her dates are Havana, the morning of the 8th inst., and Key West the evening of the same day.

Scarcely a passenger vessel arriving at this port within the past six weeks has had any sickness on board, with the exception of a few cases of Small. Pox brought from Havre.

A Beacon Light has been established on the "Elbow Beacon,"Newark Bay, N J. It is a fixed light composed of a small Diptric Leas Lantern illuminated by a cross lamp with three burners elevated in feet above ordinary high water, and may be seen about three miles.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: A report has obtained circulation that the building recently set on fire and burned by lightning, at Harlem, was provided with QUIMBY's Improved Lightning Reds.

MARKED DOORS.-- There was considerable excitement about town last evening, upon the discovery that the doors of most of the houses in the city were marked just above the bell-pull, with figures and cabalistic characters in lead poncil.

WOMAN OVER THE FALLS.--A woman named ANN HALL, aged about 34, is supposed to have gone over the Fallson Monday. Her shawl was found in he race, below the Grist Mill, and her body was seen Boating in the race by an individual in the rear part of the Cataract House, but before be, with others, could reach the sport, she probably floated from the race into the river and over the cataract.

Another fine day's sport on the Long Island Turf was witnessed yesterday at the Union Course. The match, as announced, was a trot o two-mile heats in repeat, to come off between the celebrated horses Lad, Collins and Lady Franklin.

The Japan Treaty was sent into the Senate to-day. A motion to remove the injunction of secrecy forthwith was either rejected or laid over. The whole batch of nominations of New-York Postmasters, made by this Administration, and hitherto withheld, were sent in to-day and referred.

ASYLUM FOR THE BLIND.-The Annual Musical Entertainment given by the pupils of this Institute came off on Wednesday afternoon. The attendance was not so good as usual, owing perhaps to the simultaneous exercises at the Deaf and Dumb Institute, which, from their interesting charactor, never fail to attract a crowded audiance.

THE JERSEY CITY WATER WORKS.--It is now stated upon good authorty, that Passaic water will be introduced into Jersey City by the 1st day of August next. It was expected by the 1st instant, but the breakings of a valve of the steam pump at the Belleville Works, has caused the delay.

For a succession of four days the atmosphere has been made clear and cool by heavy thunder-showers, which have spring up from the watery regions of the northwest. The only unpleasant effect produced by these frequent showers is to leave the roads exceedingly muddy, and this effect is decidedly unpleasant, for the mud here is different in its cohesive qualities from any kind I over before saw.

The Indiana State Anti-Nebraska Convention assembled at Indianapolis to-day, and the attendance was very large. Judge THOMAS SMITH, an old line Democrat, was chosen President, with a large number of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries. A preamble and rezolutions were adopted by acclamation.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: Your journal of yesterday contained some severe strictures concerning the New-York Institution for the Blind, and its management under the present Superintendent.

M. M. HOWES, of New-Milford, who was sent to State Prison for ten years, on a charge of attempting to kill a school mistress in his neighborhood, died in the prison at Weathersfield on Sunday afternoon last. He had been confined about two years. HOWES was a mild inoffensive young man, about 21 years of age at the time of his sentence.

An indignation meeting of citizens of the Fifth Ward was held last evening. Earnest remonstrances were uttered against the occupation of the Emigration Office, in Franklin-street, for the purposes of the Cholera Hospital.
DEATH OF COMMANDER R. S. PINCKNEY, U. S. N:--We announce, with regret, the decease of Commander RICHARD SHUBRICK PINCKNEY, U. S. N., which occurred about 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

ORGANS.--The present organist at Breslan gives in a book just published, some curious facts respecting the external embellishment of the organs in the seventeenth and beginning of the eighteenth centuries. The whole case was ornamented with statues, heads of angels, vases, foliage, and even figures of animals.

ARREST OF THE ROBEER OF BELMONT'S BANKING HOUSE.--The robbery of Mr. BELMONT'S Banking House has been traced to Mr. WILLIAM PAUL, one of the sub agents to whom Mr. BELMONT delegated powers of attorney. The other two agents are Messrs. CHRISTMAS and MATSON, who are, of course, innocent of any participation in the deed.

At a late sitting of the Grand Council of Geneva, a member rose to propose a penalty against unfaithful reporters of the debates. In England, he said, such offenders can be sentenced to transportation!

A PITHY DISCOURSE.--We understand that on the last Sabbath, at Grace Episcopal Church in this city, after morning service, the rector, Rev. Mr. HOMER, made this startling announcement to his congregation: "I shall no longer preach in this house"--and after a short pause, amid the breathless silence of his hearers, he added, "so long as it is a house of merchandise and an oil shed."

The Dover Chronicle remarks in the course of an amusing account of a visit of an excursion party from that city, to Paris, that the principal drawback to the pleasure was the inconvenience which the majority experienced in making themselves understood. A few words of French were picked up by the dollest before the week had expired, but some of these were so fearfully distorted as to be quite unrecognizable by the French.

In the Senate yesterday, a bill was introduced by Mr. CHASE, to prohibit Slavery in the territories. The bill provides that there shall be neither Slavery nor involuntary servitude, otherwise than in the punishment of crime, in any territory of the United States.

The Ohio State Anti-Nebraska Convention met here to-day, nearly all the counties being represented by large numbers of delegates. HON. B. F. LESTER Was chosen President, with Vice Presidents from all the Congressional Districts.

GAS NOT UNHEALTHY.--An opinion is widely prevalent that gas is unfitted for the illumination of private dwellings, owing to the heat and noxious vapors it evolves. Nothing can be more erroneous.

The City is not bankrupt, in spite of such bargains as that which lost us the Gansevoort property at half its market value. We can afford to bury the dead yet,--and we had supposed that we had Hospitals enough, and beds enough in them, to accommodate the sick.

A NEW POLICE ORDINANCE.--It is in contemplation to increase the Police force of Jersey City by the adoption of an ordinance now pending in the Common Council, which will establish to a limited extent a Police system that may be hereafter extended, as the wants of the city require.

The citizens of the Fifth Ward held an indignation meeting last evening, at the Fifth Ward Hotel, to remonstrate against the occupation of the building No. 105 Franklin-street as a Cholera Hospital. The attendance was large and respectable. The meeting was organized by the selection of JAMES THOMPSON, Esq.; as President, and CHARLES TAPPEN, Secretary.

DEATH OF JAMES H. COLLINS, ESQ.--Our community was shocked on Saturday morning, by the announcement of the sudden and unexpected death of JAMES H. COLLINS, Esq. This distressing event occurred on Saturday morning at 6 o'-clock. Mr. COLLINS was in his usual good health and vigor, attending the Supreme Court now sitting at Ottowa.

E. C. DELAVAN, Esq., President New-York State Temperance Society: DEAR SIR: Having just completed the reading of your twelve temperance tracts, though the numbers differ in interest, I hasten to empress my general approbation of them, as a whole; and also my approbation of the enlightened and charitable design of placing a copy of the same in every family in the State.

The trial of ISAAC CRAMPTON, one of the indicted Excise Commissioners of Brooklyn, has resulted in a verdict of Guilty. Mr. CRAMPTON'S case is the second which has been tried under the law against the illegal issue of licenses for the sale of liquor.

ARMS FOR A STATUE--Everybody has seen or heard of the Venus of Milo--that wonderful creation, which of itself is worth a whole museum. It will be remembered the statue is destitute of arms, and academicians, antiquaries, and sculptors, have long been in dispute upon their true position and movement, while every artist has deplored their loss.

DEAD ANIMALS IN THE STREET.--Great complaint is made by the residents of the Sixteenth ward, respecting the repeated nuisance of dead animals left in the streets of that district until they become putrified.

SURVEYING OPERATIONS IN THE RAPIDS OF THE ST. LAWRENCE.--We are informed that these interesting operations are progressing satisfactorily, notwithstanding the delays and disappointments the engineers have experienced in the building and outfit of the numerous greater and smaller surveying crafts, with which they had to provide themselves.

DRESS.--A lady, writing to the Pennsylranian, says: "Speaking of beauty, I wish people would dress pleasantly, benevolently. I saw a lovely girl to-day looking unlovely and unlovable, because her muslin dress was stiffly starched, to keep clean longer. My laundress tries to persuade me into the barbarous custom.

THE COURTS--THE MASON WILL CASE.--This case, which was again before the Courts for a trial by Jury of certain issues of fact, on Saturday, the 15th presents a most curious history of the law's delay. The suit is now some fifteen years old. It is not yet settled. The suit is brought by the heirs at law of JOHN MASON, to set aside his will, and for a partition of the property among his heirs.

A MALE IN FEMALE ATTIRE.--On Wednesday evening a person richly attired in female wearing apparel arrived in this city by the cars, and put up at one of our hotels, under the name of "HARRIET DANIELS." On Thursday, as officer W. H. GOODWIN was passing through Hanover-street, he saw in a hair-dressing establishment this person, whose conduct and appearance excited his suspicions.

Great activity prevails among the publishlishers of sheet music and music books. Mr. LOWELL MASON, whom you Bostonians so well know, is engaged upon his crowning musical work. It is to be called The Hullciujah, and will contain the maturest flowerings of a mind of great natural strength and activity, enriched with half a century of assiduous and well-directed culture.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: In the valley of the Shenandoah, not far from the little village of Millwood, and within an hour's ride of that Greenway Court lately discoursed of, stands an old Revolutionary edifice, which attracts the attention of all who pass by it. A road winding pleasantly over little hillocks, and crossing a lucid stream which meanders through a grassy meadow, leads you to the old building.

TERRIBLE EXPLOSION AND FORTUNATE ESCAPE.--On the morning of the 5th of July, as the Waterville military company, with their field-piece, were returning from Hamilton, and within about three miles of home, two of their company, sitting upon the magazine of the gun, met with a most remarkable adventure.

There is scarcely anything in the affairs of the City that calls more urgently for reform than the matter of our markets. Our citizens complain of the enormous prices of the various articles of provisions--vegetables, fruits, c.--and they will continue to complain in vain so long as the present wretched system prevails.

SUGARS-Have been in steady demand since our last report of 26th ult., and we can hardly point out any change in prices. The demand, as already noted in our previous numbers, has principally been for Cucuruchos and Browns and for Florete Yellows, leaving other sorts almost neglected. Supplies from the interior are on the decrease and being exceeded by Exports, our Stock is gradually diminishing.

A PRACTICAL PREACHER.--A preacher, who came the other day to offliciate at a village in Lincolnshire, has been led to believe by his brethren that the inhabitants were very stingy towards their spiritual providers.

CONFESSION OF A MURDER.--The Galveston News understands that SHULTZ--now under sentence of death in that city for murder--has made a full confession; not only of the murder of BATEMAN and JETT, but also of a long catalogue of other murders and crimes during a period of many years. We have not as yet been put in possession of full details, though we hope soon to be.

CASTLE GARDEN.--"Sonnambula" was repeated here on Saturday evening to an indifferent house. The performance was excellent, and far superior to any preceding one. The troupe begin to work together, and have more confidence in themselves. To-night "Maria de Rohan" will be repeated with its admirable cast.

DEATH BY DROWNING.--SINGULAR DISAPPEARANCE OF A SCOW.--An inquest was held before Coroner HOBBY, at Snug Harbor, on Friday, on the body of a German gentleman named FIESJ, who was drowned on the 10th instant, near the Light-house. The deceased had gone out fishing in a small boat in company with some boys.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The deep interweavings of Education and Liberty are especially exemplified in the History of Poland, which is very little understood, especially in this country; whose opinion of that country seems to have been formed exclusively on HARPER'S reprint of FLETCHER'S History of Poland, published in their Family Library.

It may be considered probable, in reference to Ministerial changes in England, first, that the ABERDEEN Administration will soon go out, and next, that the DERBY-D'ISRAELI party will not come in; though, as Coalitions seem to be the order of the day, some of the leading members of that party may be included in a now Ministerial arrangement.

We are again forced to anticipate the ac??on of the Senate in regard to the propriety ??fgiving publicity to matters of great public interest and importance. The treaty between the United States and the Empire of Japan, about which so much has been said and written, is on the first page of this morning's DAILY TIMES, full and accurate.

THE ANCIENT GIANTS OF FINLAND.--Before the French--so runs the Legend--there were the Giants; a good while before, we should think, by the account the Fins give of their departure. The Finish tradition declares--A giant child came one day to her giantess mamma, and showed her a curious insect she held in her apron, and had picked up on the plain.

Don't be alarmed though you throw meat to the dogs during the ho; weather, you will find an ample supply of animal food for your table in the fish-market. Some of the varieties which were your favorites awhile ago are not now to be found. There are no flounders, which boarding-house keepers like, because they are cheap.

Last evening a crowd larger than on any former occasion assembled to hear the preaching opposite the American Hotel. A number of Irishmen, principally young men of the lower class, were on the ground and several attempts were made to interrupt the speaker. He was not, however, to be intimidated, and continued to launch out against priestcraft and Papacy in no very measured terms.

KINGS COUNTY COURT OF SESSIONS. Before Hen. Judge Moore and Justices Stilwell and Stryker. SECOND DAY. VERDICT OF THE JURY--CONDITION OF MR. CRAMPTON. The Court met on Friday morning at 10 o'clock, pursuant to adjournment. William Gubbins, the party to whom Crampton is alleged to have illegally granted a tavern license, was brought the Court upon as attachment.

It may not be uninteresting to the readers of the TIMES to know that the special friends and tools of DOUGLAS, in the Springfield Congressional District, dare not attempt to force the Democracy to swallow the Nebraska swindle.

Oh, how falsely we judge of the inmost recesses of the heart by what we can see on the surface--how little we know of what is going on within by the icy or dull exterior! How many would be ready to pronounce that dark, phlegmatic and very unsocial German one who never knew the heart-ache! "Will he marry?" says one.

THE FUGITIVE SLAVE DISTURBANCE CASES--INDICTMENTS FOR RIOT--THE CHARGE OF MURDER QUASHED.--In the Municipal Court, this morning, the Grand Jury came with various additional indictments, among others one containing four counts, charging SAMUEL PROUDMAN, WALTER PHOENIX, WALTER BISHOP, MARTIN STOWELL, JOHN WESLEY, T. W. HIGGINSON, THOMAS JACKSON and JOHN MORRISON with riot at the Court House on the evening of the 26th day of May last.

A CENTENNARIAN.--Captain WILLIAMSON, a free man of color, died in this city on Friday, July 7, at the extraordinary age of 113 years. He was a native of St. Paul's Parish, and came out of the estate of Mr. WILLIAMSON, out of which also came "Good Old Jacob," who died a few months since, at the age of 102 years, and whose death was noticed in our papers.

SIGNIFICATION OF IOWA AND OTHER INDIAN NAMES.--Mr. LECLAIRE of Davenport?? so long the Indian Interpreter of the Government?? of a late interview, gave the following interpretation of several Indian names: Iowa--means literally--"Here is the place." Driven, as were the ??was and Sacs from Wisconsin and Illinois, beyond?? the Mississippi, they exclaimed--"Here is the place" for us to live unmolested; and so it measurably proved for many years.

There are some people who maintain the Wandering Jew to be a myth--I believe the contrary--that he exists among us, and that he is known to men as Dr. WOLFF. I hope Hon. Mrs. NORTON will make a note of this. It is a fact of which she ought to be aware, as should Dr. CROLY, and especially DUMAS, otherwise his wondrous tale will be incomplete.

MEETING OF THE EXEMPT FIREMEN.--An adjourned mecting of the Exempt Firemen's Association of Brooklyn was held on Friday evening in the City Hall. DANIEL VOORHIES, Esq., presided, and THOMAS R. MERCEIN, Esq., acted as Secretary. The resignation of WM. A. WALKER, Corresponding Secretary of the Association, was received and accepted.

BRONZE STATUE OF CORWIN.--The friends of Gov. CORWIN in Southern Ohio have in contemplation the erection of his statue in bronze, to be placed in some appropriate position in one of the cities of this valley. A statue of the kind contemplated, say eight feet high, on a noble. pedestal, with panels representing striking events in his career, will cost about $15,000.

THOMAS WRIGHT and TAYLOR INGRAM were before Alderman HIBBERD yesterday, on the charge of kidnapping a colored boy belonging in this city. From the evidence elicited before the Magistrate, it appears that the defendants own a race-horse, which they have lately taken to different race-courses, for the purpose of running the annual.

CHEAPER PAPER--ANOTHER INVENTION.--The Long Island Vindicator of last week, says: Mr. SAMUEL NOLAN, late of the city of Dublin, Ireland, now resident in New-York, with the assistance of his brother-in-law, Dr. ANTISEL, has invented and patented at Washington, a paper-making machine and pulp that meets all the difficulty.
[CONFIDENTIAL.] Treaty between the United States of America and the Empire of Japan, done at Kanagawa, the 3d day of March, 1854, and of Kayei the seventh year, third month, and 3d day.

It is a peculiarity of modern times to overdo everything. Ideas, scanty enough always, are becoming more and more scarce--not your poetic ideas that have life, form, and beauty, in themselves, but the solid, substantial, tangible idea that innoculates not so much with admiration as envy.

Mr. SLIDELL said he voted yesterday under misapprehension against his colleague's amendment, giving the benefits of the homestead to Americans of the age o sixteen years and upwards. He desired to vote for it The Journal was corrected accordingly. Several Executive communications were presented and referred.

SUSPECTED MURDER NEAR THIS CITY.--ARREST.--Many who were on Genesee-street, Thursday evening, about 7 o'clock, remarked the desperate ate appearance of a man who passed down the west side to the river, and who carried an axe, in rest, and ready to strike. There were those who then suggested his arrest.

Captain INGRAHAM will in all probability receive a medal for his gallant conduct in protecting MARTIN KOSZTA. The Senate on Saturday agreed to that part of the House's resolution which provides for such a presentation, after having stricken out the vote of thanks.

From the St. Louis Republican. Extract of a letter from St. Joseph: "This certainly is a very remarkable place. Although the river has washed away its levee, and encroached far upon the town, taking away large warehouses, stores and dwellings, it is going ahead in business, prosperity and enterprise, and increasing in population, as if there had been no such calamity.

PERUSING OLD PAPERS.--How depressing is the overlooking old papers long locked up, and filed away, written many years ago, when the world was brighter and friends were more numerous than now, before misfortune had dimmed the one, or death had snatched away the other! Nor are one's spirits made more cheerful, when some old document or letter transports us backward to a season of bereavement or sad mischance.

HISTORY OF A VIOLIN.--The French Athenoeum relates the curious history of a precious violin whose tones were heard during the late fetes given in honor of the marriage of the young Emperor of Austria.

The Grand Jury of the Municipal Court this morning made a report of their action in relation to the riot and attempt to rescue the fugitive slave BURNS from the custody of the United States Marshal, on the night of the 26th May, when they were driven back, after killing JAMES BATCHELDER.

Several letters have been received in Paris from an American army officer, who was at their date with OMAR PACHA'S troops. He writes discouragingly, indeed hopelessly. I do not know what value his opinions may have, but they are nevertheless worth quoting.

The Japan Treaty was ratified yesterday. A motion to remove the injunction of secresy was warmly contested and finally lost. A motion to remove the injunction of secresy on the Canadian Fishery and Reciprocity Treaty--which, I observe, you published in full in the TIMES of Saturday--was carried, but was subsequently reconsidered and refused.

The United States mail steamer Cahawba, R. W. SHUFELDT, Commander, arrived on Saturday, from Mobile, vid Havana. Left the former port on the 8th inst., and the latter on the 11th. She has nothing of importance to report from Havana. Her letters and papers are to the day of sailing.

The Committee of the Board of Aldermen, appointed to investigate charges preferred by Dr. INGRAHAM against WM. B. HASKIN, Corporation Attorney, reassembled on Saturday at 2 P. M. Present--Aldermen BLUNT and KELLY. The Chairman (Alderman BLUNT) asked the parties whether they were willing to proceed in the absence of Alderman LORD.

The excitement relative to street-preaching on Sundays is rapidly dying out in this and adjoining cities, and the people are showing their good sense in keeping away from what they dislike. A report circulated that "opposition" preaching would be carried on in Williamsburg, failed of its object in creating a riot. The day there, as here and in Brooklyn, passed off without disturbance.

CHURCH, BROOKLYN.--The ceremony of baptizing a native of Canton, China, took place yesterday afternoon, at the Bethel Church, Main-street, Brooklyn. This convert recently arrived in this country on board of a vessel as steward to Captain ELLIS, the master, and intends studying so as to be able to return to his native land, and act as a missionary in Canton and its vicinity.

THE TRIUMPH OF A TRAVELING MESMERIST IN A DIFFICULTY.--The author of "Sam Slick," observes in the course of a work he has just published, that the trials to which traveling Mesmerists are put in America, are, at times, humiliating and painful enough, albeit they afford infinite sport to the unbelievers.

CASTLE GARDEN.--The third performance of "Maria di Rohan" attracted a good audience last evening. It was, perhaps; the best house of the season, and we are glad of it, for those who were present had a thorough opportunity of enjoying themselves.

According to the Washington Globe, this has at length been discovered by a Government naval inspector at the Gosport station, near Norfolk, Va. The Globe says:

JERSEY CITY PROVIDENT INSTITUTE DIVIDEND.-At a meeting of the Trustees of the Jersey City Provident Institution for savings, held on Saturday, a semi-annual dividend of 6 per cent. was declared on all sums over $5 and under $500; on all sums under $500, and over $1,000 5 per cent.; on all sums over $1,000 4 per cent. This takes effect from yesterday. /

The steamship Franklin left Cowes at 6 P. M., July 5, and went ashore on Long Island Beach, (just off Moriches, about forty miles to the westward of Montauk,) during the dense fog that prevailed, at 8 o'clock, yesterday morning.
To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: As the cause of Education is a matter that comes home to the business and bosom of every member of the community, I trust you will hear me patiently.
FOUR DEAD PERSONS AND A JUG.--On Tuesday last a gentleman from the Eighth Ward called upon the City Marshal, and requested him to make an examination of a house somewhere in that vicinity.
The regular conversational meeting of this Society was held last evening at their room, No. 600 Broadway. Some China specimens of black and red currants were exhibited by Mr. CRANSTOUN, of Hoboken.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: We see it currently reported by the Press that since the burning of our Seminary, our "College Buildings," in process of erection, have been fired several times. Such reports, we assure you, are entirely unfounded, and are the work of some malicious persons who wish to injure us.

HITTING THE PARTY.--A distinguished United States Senator told us, a few days since, that President PIERCE "has not the confidence and respect of a single member of the Senate," and he added, "if he could be hit without hitting the party, this sentiment would very quickly be made known."

In this City, on Monday, July 17. SAMUEL WHILEY LARKIN, son of Charles F. and Jemima C. Larkin, aged 4 years and 8 months. The relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, on Tuesday afternoon, July 18, at 3 o'clock, from No. 22 Avenue D.

DEATH OF DR. JOSEPH DENNIS.--Died at the State Emigrant's Refuge Hospital, Ward's Island, on Thursday last, JOSEPH DENNIS, M.D., aged 26 years, one of the house physicians of the Hospital, and son of Rev. R.G. DENNIS, of Grafton, Mass.

SHOCKING OUTRVGE.--A poor woman named MARGARET CAMERON, who has for sometime past been an inmate of the Blockley Almshouse, was recently discharged from the Institution.

The Senate met at 11 o'clock to-day. Mr. FISH presented several memorials for cheap ocean postage. Mr. SUMNER presented several memorials from Massachusetts against the Fugitive Slave law.

THE CHOLERA IN BROOKLYN--MORTALITY.--The Health Officer reports 221 deaths for the week ending Saturday last--116 males, 105 females--adults, 107; children, 114.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The village from which I write is the principal town in the County of Albomarle, and is situated in a country which, for the beauty of its landscape, is I presume, hardly any where surpassed. At this season, perhaps, this landscape appears to the greater advantage.

Yesterday afternoon a trotting match between two road horses came off at the Union Course. Long Island, which created great excitement and merriment among the audience. The contest was with the two celebrated drivers, HIRAM WOODRUFF and WILLIAM WHEELAN; and the horses entered for it were g. g. Mark Maguire.

In issue of the 9th, "Our Journal" gives us "the secret of our confidence and our strength." The national "honor, for which we ought to sacrifice the last stiver and the last man," is the hypothesis; showing the quality of our mettle "without concealment-with justice on our side-the opinion of Europe-the favor of the world of the world-our ancient alliances; who would not approach such a desperate struggle with terror?"

The last sentence of the law was to-day executed upon FRANK SMITH, convicted of the murder of his wife. The execution took place a few minutes past ten, within the walls of the Parish Prison, under the supervision of Sheriff MARIGUY and his Deputies.

MATTHEW MATTHEWS, JOHN GILL, WILLIAM L. MENTZER and C. SAXTON, hailing from Philadelphia, recently obtained $3,700 from the Rutland Bank, Vermont, by forget checks. MATTHEWS and GILL have been taken at Montreal and MENTZER at Rosse's Point, and $3,300 of the money was recovered.

To the Editors of the New-York Daily Times: GENTLEMEN: For a week after the 4th of July--you kept shady the day after--my paper was never delivered until ten or eleven o'clock Last week, for about half the time, the TIMES came betimes. It is now ten o'clock, this morning, and yet--no TIMES.

MENDELSSOHN.--There was this in expressible comfort, in all intercourse with MENDELSSOHN, that he made no secret of his likings and dislikings. Few men so distinguished have been so simple, so cordial, so considerate; but few have been so innocent of courtiership, positive or negitive. One might be sure that a welcome from him was a welcome indeed.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have noticed several communications in your journal, evidently from some of our Public School teachers, protesting against the passage of the By-Laws now before the Board of Education, providing for grading and classifying the teachers employed, and those to be hereafter employed, in our Common Schools, and to provide that the salaries paid shall, as far as practicable, be uniform.

THE NEW PARACHUTE.--On Tuesday evening a large number of persons assembled in Cremoinc Gardens, for the purpose of witnessing the ascent of M. LATOUR in his parachute flying machine, with which, a few days since, he made a successful and safe descent upon Blackheath.

We feel sure that our readers will share the surprise and pain with which we received yesterday the intelligence that Professor JEWETT, the accomplished Librarian of the Smithsonian Institution, has been peremptorily discharged from his office by Professor HENRY, the Secretary of the Institution. mor reached this city yester-

A SUNDAY MEAL IN GLASGOW.--A correspondent writes to the London Times, as follows: "To-day (Sunday,) having just arrived quite unexpectdly at Glasgow, I went to take up my abode with a friend. He is a bachelor, in lodgings, and had made no preparation for dinner for two. His castle being thus badly provisioned, we sallied forth at 5 o'clock in quest of a tavern or restaurant where we could obtain a moderate repast.

The Commencement will be held at Clinton, Wednesday, July 26. The addresses before the various societies will be delivered as follows: The address before the Society of Christian Research will be delivered by Prof. J. B. CONDIT, of Lane Seminary, on Sunday evening, July 23, at 7 1/2 o'clock.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As I am a constant reader of your prized paper, I am emboldened to ask you to urge it upon the City Authorities to do something for the immediate and thorough purifying of the streets. The Cholera seems impending over us, and the Ward in which I live is in a foul condition.

DEATH FROM EATING UNRIPE GOOSEBERRIES.--On Saturday last, a young girl about twelve or thirteen years of age, residing at the top of Leonard-street, after eating unripe gooseberries, became alarmingly ill, and gradually getting worse, her parents, procured medical aid.

MURDER IN CANADA.--We understand that on Tuesday night last, a murder was committed on the Cap-Rouge road, a few miles from this city. The alleged murderer is a young man named MARTEL, and his victim a girl called MOISAU, both residing near Lake Calvert.

A balloon race took place at Hartford, Conn., on the Fourth of July, which was witnessed by some 20,000 persons. The two balloons were occupied, the one by a Mr. Brooks, and the other by a Mr. Paulin, of Philadelphia.

By the arrival of the Niagara at Halifax we have three day's later news from Europe. The inteligence relative to the position of affairs at the East, done not differ materially from that received by the Franklin, and published in the TIMES of yesterday morning.

To the Editors of the New- York Daily Times: Your correspondent J. P. H. is disposed to treat our position, that "money is not wealth," with ridicule; at this we are not surprised, for the opposite theory is almost universal.

This Court reassembled this morning in the City Hall, Brooklyn. At the opening of the Court, the District Attorney, R.C. UNDERHILL, Esq., moved that sentence be pronounced upon CHARLES McGLONE, heretofore convicted of high way robbery.

FRIGHTFUL ACCIDENT ON THE DELAWARE.--Yesterday afternoon, about 4 o'clock, as the steamboat Napoleon was proceeding down the river to Red Bank, she was run into by a sloop, the howsprit of which struck the steamboat, tearing off the ralling and forcing its way through the side of the ladies' cabin.

A FASTIDIOUS EDITOR.--JOHN W. BOYD, Esq., formerly editor of the Chambersburg (Pa.) Repository and Whig, having been recommended for the Mayoralty of Hagerstown, declines the honor, for certain cogent reasons, which he states at length in the Hagerstown Chronicle.

THE WOUNDED AND THE RAILROAD COMPANY.--We learned yesterday that arrangements have been entered into by the Baltimore and Susquehanna Railroad Company, with several of those who were wounded by the late calamity on that road, by which the claims for damages are compromised. FORCE OF HABIT.--The Newark Daily Advertiser says that some thirty or forty years ago there lived on eccentric Englishman, who was so addicted to reading the London Times as to refuse to receive intelligence from any other source.

A Washington correspondent of the Express writes: There is something said summoning the proprietor of the NEW-YORK TIMES, before the Senate, to account for the manner in which he obtained a copy of the Reciprocity Treaty.

A ride through Long Island at this season, reveals a most gratifying spectacle to any who takes an interest in the prosperity to the farmer. Most of the hay has been got in,--a finer or larger crop has seldom been taken.
DESTRUCTIVE FIRE--BURNINGOF LAKE VIEW WATER CURE BUILDING.--About 3 o'clock this morning as Lake View Water Cure, was discovered to be on fire, and was speedily reduced to ashes and ruins.
Senator CLAYTON seems to be renewing his youth. Though the frosts of over sixty winters have whitened his head, the vices and follies of twenty seem to hold full possession of his heart.

Agreeably to a call previously issued, the members of the Bar of this City assembled at the room of the Court of Sessions yesterday, to give expression to their sentiments upon the death of NATHANIEL BOWDITCH BLUNT, late District Attorney of this City.

THE KIDNAPPING CASE.--A further hearing of the case of THOMAS WRIGHT and TAYLOR INGRAM, charged with kidnapping a colored boy named PURNELL JOHNSON, came off this afternoon before Alderman HIBBARD. A considerable number of colored persons and others, who took an interest in the matter, were present at the hearing.

DESTRUCTIVE FIRE IN SYRACUSE.--A fire broke out in a wood-pile belonging to the Central Railroad Company on Saturday evening, at Syracuse, by which not less than 1,200 cords of wood were burnt.
Afiray Between Thomas Francis Meagher and J. A. McMaster.: A personal rencontre took place yesterday between Mr. THOS. FRANCIS MEAGHER and J. A. McMASTER, editor of the Freeman's Journal.

SIOUX AND CHIPPEWAS.--Our readers recollect that some weeks since we gave an account of an attack made on the Chippewas at their agency by a war party of the Sioux, in which several scalps of the former were taken. Shortly af-

Mr. ADAMS moved to take up the bill granting a pension to the widow of BACHELDER, who was killed in Boston. Objected to. Mr. SUMNER presented a memorial of the Pennsylvania Society for the Abolition of Slavery, urging the repeal of the Fugitive Slave law, arguing that under the tenth section of the law a free colored person had already been sent back to slavery.

Our Neapolitan correspondent says: "As the season for excavating has in several spots drawn to a close, it will be well to give a glance at what has been done within the last few months, and at the altered position of the various scenes of anti-quarian interest in the kingdom of the Two Sicilies.

MAKING LOVE TO THE WRONG PERSON,--A Cincinnati paper is responsible for the following: A young gentleman who had been paying his addresses in propria persona to a young lady in this city, left a few months ago and went down the river on business.

BOARD OF ALDERMEN OF JERSEY CITY.--The Board of Aldermen met at the Lyceum on Tuesday evening. Alderman LYON, President of the Board, was in the Chair. Communications and bills were received as usual and referred to the appropriate committees. Mayor MANNERS sent in a veto of a resolution passed at a previous meeting of the Board giving the City Clerk an extra allowance of $200 for clerk hire.

DEATH OF A VETERAN POSTMASTER.--ABRAHAM NEWS, Esq., died at Weston, on Saturday last, the 15th, at the age of 88 years. This venerable citizen was at the time of his death, perhaps the oldest postmaster in the United States, having retained office through all the changes of administrations, from the time of his appointment under President MADISON, in the year 1812.

The Providence Journal says: Rev. Henry Wood, of Concord, N. H., the gentleman who certified to the temperate habits and personal piety of General Pierce, during the canvass which preceded the last Presidential Election, has been confirmed as consul at Beyrout, in Syria.

In our Mexican intelligence of yesterday we published the particulars of the death of this promising young tenor. Like Madame SON??, Signor POZZOLINI fell a victim to cholera. Their deaths were so similar and sudden that suspicions have been aroused, and a demand made for the exhumation of the remains of Signor POZZOLINI.
Of those changes shadowed forth, just now, in the war policy of the powers of Western Europe, that contemplated respecting the people of the Caucasus seems the most interesting.

The United States Mail steamship Charles Morgan arrived this morning from Indianala and Galveston, with dates from the latter place to the 8th inst. On the 8th inst., the brig Catharine Rogers bound for New-York, was towed to sea from Pas? Gavallo.

An additional number of memorials asking that the Fugitive Slave law be repealed were presented in the Senate yesterday, after which Mr. PETTIT, from the Judiciary Committee, stated that the Committee were of the opinion that legislation on the Fugitive Slave law, at present, was inexpedient, and requested to be excused from further considering the subject.

"Know-NORTHINGISM."--A municipal election in the borough of Chambersburg, Pa., for a member of the Local Council, in the place of one who had resigned, has resulted thus: WILLIAM HEYSER, regular Democratic candidate, 22; JACOB N. SNIDER, a Democrat, but not known as a candidate, 174!

The refusal of the Senate to go into an Executive Session to-day, was not a test of the strength of the Reciprocity Treaty, but of preference to dispose of the Homestead bill. The latter measure, I believe, is thoroughly defunct, after today's proceedings. Special Correspondence of the New-York Daily Times. WASHINGTON, Tuesday, July 18, 1854.

We are given to understand that the affair between Mr. MEAGHER and Mr. McMASTER is not to be considered precisely in the light in which it stood yesterday. Our statement that Mr. MEAGHER had an interview with the editor of the Journal previous to the assault, was, we are assured, incorrect.

"May 7, 1838.--Dined yesterday at E---'s :--a literary party of ten:--BELL (of the Atlas,) JERDAN, BLANCHARD, LEIGH HUNT, ROBERTSON (editor of the Westminster Review,) VILLIERS, WALLACE, a gentleman whose name I did not hear, and myself. Better talk than I have heard for some time,--chiefly, however, indeed almost entirely, from B--- himself and HUNT.

BLUNT was held by the community, it was filly proved yesterday by the numerous circle of personal friends and admirers from among all classes and parties who assembled at his residence in East Fourteenth street, to pay the last melancholy tribute of respect to his remains.
