The latest intelligence received from the steamship Franklin indicates that the vessel is a total wreck. It is supposed that most of the cargo will be saved. The passengers and their luggage, as we have already announced, are safe. The steam-tugs Hector and Achilles arrived here yesterday from the wreck, having loft the beach at 7 o'clock on Tuesday evening.

We have repeatedly called attention to the nuisance of Slaughter-Houses in the heart of the City. By their abominably disgusting odor, they are doing it now hourly for themselves. We defy any man blessed with the sense of smell to pass by one of them without experiencing one of the first symptoms of an attack of Cholera.

A Cholera-season always brings comfort to the soakers, though they are the ones that are really most likely to fall victims to it. There is a doctrine that pleases them preached high and low, by doctors and dunces, ex cathedra and out of the grogshop. It is the sentiment that men must not alter their habits however bad, in Cholera-times

Mr. SUMNER presented the memorial of CHAS. FRANCIS ADAMS and 300 others, of all parties, of Quincy, Mass., praying for the repeal of the Fugitive act. Mr. CHASE presented similar petitions from Ohio. All referred. Mr. GWIN introduced a bill granting the right of way to the Marysville and Benicia Railroad.

By the following royal order of the Queen of Spain, recently transmitted hither from the United Stales Legation in Madrid, it will be seen that a considerable reduction has been made in tonnage duties and port charges upon vessels of the United States in the Peninsula and adjacent Islands: [TRANSLATION.]

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Since the English army has proceeded to Turkey, the American papers, and especially the TIMES, have been filled with queries and answers to queries relative to the chief officers of the corps.

NEW TELEGRAPH COMPANY.--"The Long Branch and Sandy Hook Telegraph Company" was organized on Tuesday evening, at a meeting of the Stockholders, at the Pavilion Hotel, Long Branch. J. W. MORRIS was chosen President, We understand the line is to be leased to Mr. W. O. LEWIS, the lessee of the New-York and Sandy Hook line.

It is almost enough to give one a cholera cramp to enter one of our popular restaurants about the hour of neon of any of these hot days. The air is thick and hot, and the breath of many people mingling with the steam of smoking dishes suffices to drive back those who love to breath air, and to oat in cool and quiet places.

THE MASSACHUSETTS EMIGRANT AID SOCIETY.--We learn that the party which left this city yesterday, under the auspices of the Emigrant Aid Society, to become settlers in the new Territory of Kansas, numbered sixteen individuals.

ITALIAN OPERA,--VERDI'S "Louisa Muller" will be produced to-night for the first time in America. It has been some time in rehearsal, and will be given, we anticipate, in a perfect manner. All the artists of the establishment are in the cast, and that fact alone would insure its success;

In the Senate, on Thursday last, Mr. JONES, of Iowa, from the Committee on Pensions, reported a bill granting a pension to the widow of JAMES BATCHELDER, lately killed while aiding the Marshal to execute the laws of the United States in Boston. As the Committee was divided on the form of the report to accompany the bill, each division prepared a paper expressive of their opinions.

DEATH OF HON. GEORGE C. WASHINGTON, OF MARYLAND.--Hon. GEORGE C. WASHINGTON died at Washington City, on the 18th inst. Colonel WASHINGTON was one of the few remaining relatives of General GEORGE WASHINGTON, some of the family having settled in Maryland, Western Virginia and North Carolina.

A few weeks since, Mr. BENJ. F. PINCKNEY, member of No 22 Phenix Hose Company, and member of the City Council of New-York, introduced a resolution into the common Council, authorizing the appointment of a committee of five to inquire into the practicability of reorganizing the Fire Department and changing the present system.

SPAULDING, Esq., Sheriff of Kane Co, Ill.; DEAR SIR: During the last two weeks, I have received numerous petitions in favor of the commutation of the sentence of death upon KERN BRENNON, MICHAEL TEWEY, and JAMES TEWEY, convicted at the May term, A. D. 1854, in your County, to that of imprisonment in the penitentiary for life;

THE BROOKLYN BOARD OF EXCISE IN SECRET SESSION.--The Commissioners of Excise held a meeting at the City Hall, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. Their proceedings are a profound secret, as reporters and all others were locked out of the room, with the exception of N. F. WARING, Esq., Counsellor to the Corporation, who was instructed by Mayor LAMBERT to give them a whole some lecture on the subject of granting licenses.

We were able to inform our readers on Saturday last, that the Bishops of ?? and New-York were expected in this city, and on that any both these prelates arrived here from New-York, and became the guests of the Bishop of Montreal, at the Sec House. On Sunday they all look part in the different services of the Church. In the morning Bishop WAINWRIGHT attended at the Cathedral, where be preached.

The Squadron left the United States in June last, and passing over the Atlantic, visited Madeira for fuel, water, c. From the kindness shown the officers and men, one and all, at this place it was evident there was an abiding partiality for the Yankees.

The Washington Sentinel learns that two of the Ve??. Corps of that city are on the eve of dissolution. to be reorganized under new names and with new uniforms. the membership to be exclusively of native, without the admixture of any persons of foreign birth. The body of a man was found floating in the river two miles below Catskill last week.

The Annual Commencement at Harvard College takes place to-day. All the Banks in this city are closed as is usual on such occasions. A very large number of candidates have offered for admission to he College at the present Commencement. The festival of the Alumni takes place to-morrow, and promises to be numerously attended. THE BUSINESS OF LIFE.--We recollect walking with Mr. THOMAS CARLYLE down Regent-street, when he remarked that we poets had all of us mistaken the argument that we should treat. "The past," he said, "is all too old for this age of progress. Look at this throng of carriages, this multitude of men and horses, of women and children.

The Banffshire Journal gives a narrative of the sufferings endured by the crew of the Felix, sealer of that port, who, being obliged to abandon their vessel on account of its being stove by an iceberg, to the number of 26, were forced to take to the four boats without compass, and almost no stores of clothing food or drink.

A member of Governor STEVENS' northern route exploring party, writing from the head of Yellow Stone River, says of the "sights and incidents" thus far: On Sunday, after a march of some ten miles, the buffaloes were reached. They are before and on each side of the train. For miles ahead it seemed like one vast drove-yard.

The price of town land is almost beyond credit. There is no limit to the extravagant opinion that buyers and sellers entertain of its value. Innumerable instances might be quoted. In one case a house purchased for [pound]250, lately fetched [pound]12,000; another offered to Government for the use of the military officers for [pound]3,000, a month afterwards was valued at [pound]5,000;

The Cholera. DAILY REPORT OF THE FRANKLIN-STREET HOSPITAL. Date Received Died Disc'd. Remaining Wednesday, July 19.... 15 7 4 31 Decrease of deaths since Tuesday, 3. By means of a typographical error yesterday, the number of deaths in Hospital on Tuesday was stated at 16. Ten was the true number. Yesterday's return, published above, exhibits a decrease of three.

Lead-Works on Staten Island. Nearly half a century ago some favored points on Staten Island were selected as the theatre of manufacturing enterprise. Economy, no doubt, selected the location. A acre of land could then have been purchased at $30 to $40, which would now sell at one hundred fold. The chance was not to be lost.

Joseph Bounty vs. The schooner Thomas Cassidy and seventy tons of coal.--The libel is filed in this case to recover compensation for salvage services performed by the libellant in the Fall of 1853, in raising the schooner Thomas Cassidy, which was sunk with the coal on board, in October, 1853, in attempting to pass the draw across the Hudson River Railroad, at Spuytenduyvel Creek, for which, he alleges, he was to be paid $350.

We learn from Capt. WATCHTENDORF, of the Oldenburg bark Anna, which arrived here yesterday from New-York, that he saw a large steamship, supposed to have a double engine, in flames, on Monday night last. between Cape Henry and Cape Hatteras. He went near enough to see that there was no person on board, through he was unable to make out her name.

We have learned from several persons who have recently arrived from Laredo, that a most shocking affair occurred in that place about two weeks since. A CHILLES CENTRO, an balian, and DON PEDRO CARERA, a Mexican. were filed by a Dr. LINTON. The former was bank master of the 5th Regiment of Infantry, and the latter principal of the Mexican Maroma, and it was during P on PEDERO's exhibition that he was killed.

The U.S. Mail steamer Philadelphia, H. WENDLE, Commander, arrived in this port last evening. She left New-Orleans on the 11th, and reached Havana on the 14th. After landing mails and passengers, she left again on the same day. She brings 62 passengers and a cargo of pork and merchandise.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: As all well-authenticated information about this Territory will be useful and interesting to the numerous bodies of men who are about emigrating to it from the free States, I send you a letter written by a member of the Society of Friends, who was connected with a Friends Mission among the Shawnee Indians, who left Kansas last Fall, after a residence there of two years.

DEATH OF THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT ATTORNEY FOR MINNESOTA.--DANIEL H. DUSTIN, Esq., who was appointed by President PIERCE to the office of United States District Attorney for the Territory of Minnesota, died at Saint Paul, on the 10th inst.

AWFUL AND PROBABLY FATAL AFFRAY.--Last Saturday night, at about 11 1\2 o'clock, one of the most brutal affrays took place in a drinking establishment that ever disgraced our city. Mr. PETER McCORMICK and Mr. ALEXIS J. CHAMPLIN met in Mr. MENSING's bar-room, in Market between Meeting and King-streets.

THE LIE IN THE COUNCIL.--Yesterday afternoon, during tile exciting debate in the Board of Aldermen, on the important subject, who shall be scavengers of the city, a scene occurred between Dr. MAGRUDER and Rev. Mr. MARKS not usual, we should suppose, in that honorable body.

That London law which compels all manufacturers to burn their smoke ought to be better and more thought of than it is with us. Faugh! what intolerable stenches pollute the air that is stirring, and whom none stirs, how an atmosphere of evil odors covers Gotham as with a canopy! it need not be.

We hear, as we go to press, of the death of Adjutant-General TEMPLE. His disease, consumption. had, some weeks ago, made such ravages as to leave little hope of any other termination. That heart, now skilled in death, never beat but with pure, and manly, and noble pulsations. It was full of love to friends, loyalty to country, and soldierly courage.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: The quotations in your paper of to-day from VINCENT NOLTE'S work, fifty Years in both Hemispheres, , include a ridiculous and false account of an interview between that notorious "Merchant" (?) and J. J. AUDURON.

FLAX CULTURE.--The Earl of ALBEMARLE has addressed an important letter to the members of the Norfolk Agricultural Association respecting the cultivation of flax in this country. His lordship says, "The present high price of wheat cannot always continue; is it not, therefore, desirable to have a crop that will indemnify the farmer for the occasionally low price of grain?

The Homestead bill--or rather amendments and substitutes which even the authors do not seem very anxious to have adopted--are absorbing the time if not the attention of the Senate. They commence the morning by listening, or pretending to listen, to an amendment proposed by some one of their number.

We met the little apple-woman last night in the Bowery,--more bent and stooping than ever, and with as big a basket. She carried an old umbrella-handle for a walking stick, and trudged off as lightly as if advancing years rather strengthened than weakened her.

The Portuguese schooner Craveiro, consigned to Messrs. OSBORN Co., New-York, went ashore opposite Tenwick's Island, near Berlin, Md., on the 11th, and became total wreck. The crew were all saved The hull and materials were to be sold to-day-but of the cargo, consisting of salt and willow baskets, sufficient had not been saved to pay expenses.

Private advices received here by tne Franklin (the Niagara's mails of course have not arrived,) indicate that the insurrection in Spain is no child's play, but that it will be completely successful, especially as the Government is without money to carry on the struggle, and without credit.

We have had thousands of Conventions lately, of which it is charitable to presume that some scores did something beside elect officers, and pass resolutions that they never carried into practice. But there met a Convention at Warrenton, Virginia, last week, under the mirth-provoking name of the "Joint-Worm Convention," which did service to the Agricultural interest, and set. an example to all convening Christendom.

There is certainly " a refinement in names," and parents would do well to consider this matter with a little more attention than they appear. to do generally. Never give a child a name that he will probably dislike when he comes to years of maturity. There are some names that always seem to carry with them the joy and freshness of youth. though they may grace alike the silvery locks of deelining years.

YELLOW FEVER AT SEA.--The British brig Isabella and Dorothy, Capt. PERCIVAL, 12 days from Havana to Falmouth, (Eng.) put into this port in distress, having lost the captain (READ,) and 4 seamen on the passage by yellow fever.

Mrs. Martha Vernon, a resident of Richmond, who entered a compliant last Saturday before the Mayor, that a daughter had been abducted, made a further complaint yesterday morning, that she believed her daughter and this itinerant peddler, A. V. Spradling, were not married as had been asserted to her by one or both of the parties to this outrageous perpetration of villany.

Yesterday was commencement at the most ancient college in this country, and that remined the only college for more than half a century, when the college of William and Mary was founded at. Williamsburg. Virginia, in 1692. Eight years afterwards Yale College was founded. At a little past len o'clock, Gov. WASBURN and Lt. Gov. PLUNKETT reached Cambridge, under the escort of the Lancers.

The heat here, to-day, has been intense. Thermometers, in shady places, indicating 102 degrees. BOSTON, Thursday, July 20. The thermometer, to-day, stood at 91 degrees, hardly a breath of air was stirring, and it has been the most oppressive warm day of the season. CONCORD, Thursday July 20.

To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times: Although a good republican, I have read articles lately in the TIMES which made me hanker to be Dictator, because in that case I should have the power to bestow on its editor a civic crown of oak, for having deserved well of the State.

DEATH OF JAMES H. HICKS, ESQ.--Our city is called to mourn the loss of another of her valuable and upright citizens. Mrs. Hicks was one of our most enterprising and high-minded merchants, and a most useful and public spirited man. He was for a long time the senior member of the firm of HICKS, PALMER Co.,

To the Editor of the New York Daily Times: In an editorial of yesterday, the 20th, you advocate the removal of all "Slaughter-houses in the heart of the City." Germans, Irish, and others, are not seriously disturbed by the Board of Health and their officers. If notices have been served upon such to discontinue the keeping and slaughtering of hogs, it has no perceptible influence, as all continue to slaughter as usual.

It is an old saying that "Providence favors the lame and the lazy." Whether or not there is any indolence in SANTA ANNA, his wooden leg brings him within the lucky category. Providence certainly favors him. When he seemed o be standing on his last legs, the wooden one included, he receives sudden help from Previdence in the shape of $10,000,000 by virtue of the passage of the Gadsden Treaty.

THE DUEL WITH BROADSWORDS.--So much has been said about this affair, and so many contradictory accounts have been published, that we in common with the rest of the press of this city, concluded the whole matter a hoax, and so pronounced it. We yesterday learned that the report was true, and received from an eye-witness full particulars concerning the affair.

About 2 o'clock this morning a fire out in the Swan tavern on Main-street, and spread with great apidity in the adjoining buildings, all of which were two story frame dwellings. There being no engine in the face, the fire soread unchecked until 8 buildings were yestroyed, principally occupied by poor families, who are thus rendered homeless.

DEATH OF GEO. W. TOWNES, OF GEORGIA.--It is announced that this gentleman breathed his last on Saturday morning, the 15th, about 10 o'clock, at his residence in the town of Madison Ga. The Petersburg Express says Gov. TOWNES' was a gentleman of great intelligence, and almost unbounded popularity.

A LADY FREEMASON.--The Hon. ELIZABETH ST. LEGER was the only female ever initiated into the ancient mysteries of Freemasonry. How she obtained this honor we shall lay before our readers. Lord DONCRAILE, Miss ST. LEGER'S father, a very zealous Mason, held a warrant, and occasionally opened lodge at Doncraile House, his sons and intimate friends assisting, and it is said that never were that Masonic duties more rigidly performed than by them.

THE AMERICANS AS LINGUISTS.--In an article in the Electric Review, on American travelers in Europe, a writer speaks thus of the faculty of our countrymen for acquiring languages; "The Americans have pecular aptitude for foreign travel. They are excellent linguists. It is even said that they learn French more easily, and speak it better, than any foreigners in France.

The Governor's appointment of LORENZO B. SHEPARD, Esq., to be District Attorney, in place of the late N. B. BLUNT, does not give universal satisfaction by any means,--though for that matter no appointment would.

GENERAL W. O. BUTLER.--The Whig press of the North has been very free in charging that this distinguished gentlemen had declined the position of Governor of Nebraska, tendered to him by the President, in a letter of a most unfriendly character. As usual, the accusation turns out to be a gross fabrication.

On Monday forenoon, about 10 o'clock, a young man, who gave his name J. H. SUTLIFFE, and hailed from "the land of wooden-autmegs," was arrested by Officer REA, and brought before Mayor VOLZ, on a charge of attempting to force a young lady named M --- J ---- to accompany him against her wishes to Philadelphia!

PROBABLE MURDER IN POUGHKEEPSIE.--On Wednesday. a farmer named PHILLIPS, whilst ding in a team along Church-st., in Poughkeepsie, was accosted by three or four Irishmen, and from words they came to blows, when PHILLIPS suddenly clew a knife and stabbed one of the Irishmen twice, once in the stomach and again in the side.

Mr. STUART introduced a joint resolution confirming certain locations of military land warrants in Michigan. Considered and passed. Mr. BADGER'S resolution rescinding the rule fixing Friday for private bills was adopted. Mr. HUNTER moved to take up the Civil and Diplomatic bill.

We have several times adverted to the affairs of Columbia College. The subject still continues to attract a considerable share of public attention. This is in part no doubt due to circumstances connected with the action of the Trustees in some recent elections, but more, we should hope, to an awakening of the public mind generally to the importance of enlarging the sphere and exalting the standard of our Higher Public Instruction.

Dyer's Bank Note Plate Delineator No. 1, is the name of a new paper whose object is to assist the money-taker in detecting spurious and altered bank bills. This first number describes all he denominations of every bank in the Cities of New-York, Philadelphia, Boston, Baltimore, Brooklyn, Williamsburg, and Jersey City.

THE HEAT.-Still burning heat, and not a drop of rain. With the exception of two or three brief showers on the Fourth, a month or more has passed since the ground in this vicinity has been moistened from the clouds. Yegetation is suffering badly. The leaves of the corn are beginning to roll up, and oats are likely to provo a failure.

The Anti-Nebraska State Convention met in this city to-day, and was largely attended by men of all shades of politics from all parts of tile State. Mr. H. W. TART, of Worcester, was temporary President, with Mr. W.H. HARRIS and Mr. THOMAS DREW, also of Worcester, as Secretaries.

An exciting rumor was circulated very generally about town yesterday morning, to the effect that the steamer Commodore, which left this City for Stonington on Wednesday evening, crowded with passengers, was totally destroyed by fire on the Sound on Wednesday night. The annexed dispatch shows that the report was utterly unfounded:

Capt. MARSHALL, of the steaming Underwriter, reports the Franklin as having 12 feet water in her hold. There were five lighters and a steampump in readiness for use yesterday, as soon as the sea would permit. The cargo was being landed on the beach by means of a hawser from the mainmast-head to the shore.

Mr. JACOB RICHARDSON, late Collector at Oswego, is reported to have proved a defaulter to the amount of over $100,000. It is stated that proceedings have been commenced against him. Why they should have delayed until now we are not aware. During the Administration of President FILLMORE, by whom he was appointed, his delinquency was a matter of notoriety.
A correspondent at South Hadley, Mass., writes us how the girls of the Mt. Holyoke Seminary spent the gloriously hot Fourth of this hottest of Julys. .

HARVARD GRADUATES,--The triennial cataogue of Harvard, distributed at the College, contains the names of 8,369 persons who have been connected with the institution. Of all these, thee are living now only 3,566.

THE CHOLERA IN BROOKLYN.--Fourteen new cases of Cholera, and one death, were reported to the Board of Health yesterday morning. The summary of deaths by Cholera for the week, will show an entirely different state of affairs from what is represented by the reports made by the Board of Health.

Who ever thought of pitying a lawyer! he who shows no mercy--shall we have mercy on him? he who never pities suffering jurors or trembling witnesses, shall we stop to pity him? But let us consider whether they of the bar may not also have some wrongs, for the redressal of which they are too modest to ask.

They "have neglected the library," it says; "have refused to make any considerable appropriations for its enlargement--hardly as much in eight years as they were authorized to make in one year."

In my letter of yesterday I spoke of the promise the cricketers had of just such weather as they could ask for. It had been agreed on Tuesday afternoon between the two umpires that the wickets should be pitched at 9 1/2 o'clock A. M. on Wednesday, and that play should be called at 10 1/2 o'clock.

Mr. MAQUET, the Emperor's stationer, has set the fashion of a very luxurious and elegant mode of following the march of events in the East. He sells complete and intelligible maps of the seat of war, three feet by two, stiffly stretched upon pasteboard of irreproachable flatness--for there is no bore under heaven like a map that will roll.

MR. SLOW ON SYMPATHY.--The Boston Post reproduces the following moral reflections of Mr. Slow: "Bimelech," said Mr. Slow, solemnly extending his arm like a pump handle, "you are now old enough to understand the words of wisdom--being eleven and a half, in other words half-past eleven--and I wish to advise you never to interfere with nobody, nor to interfere with nothing that don't belong to you.
A NEW ENTERPRISE.--Mr. A. SWARZER, of Vienna, has undertaken the importation into this country of Hungarian wines, in their pure state, and without any admixture of alcohol.

In this City, on Friday, July 21, WESLEY F. BURGESS, of the firm of Burgess Day, in the 44th year of his age His friends and acquaintances are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, without further notice from his late residence No. 80 West 33d-st., at 9 o'clock, Sunday morning July 23.
At 2 o'clock to-day the thermometer stood here at 102. Commodore GREGORY adjourned the Court Martial being held at the Navy-Yard in consequence of the intensity of the heat.

The funeral of General ROBERT EMMETT TEMPLE took place this afternoon. The funeral procession comprised the military of this city and from West Troy and Schenectady.The turnout of the military and citizens was very large.

FASHIONABLE KNOWLEDGE OF ART.--The story of Miss Pettitoes' wondering how "Mr. Dusseldorf" could possibly find time to paint so many pictures, has been long since recorded by Mr. CURTIS, and also previously by another writer.

In consequence of various rumors concerning a large number of deaths by cholera at the Poor-House in this city, a large party of physicians and citizens visited the house to-day, and found everything connected with the establishment in the most horrible condition. Within 24 hours 15 insane persons and seven others had died of cholera, and four more were then in a collapsed state.

STREET-PREACHING.--There was street-preaching yesterday afternoon at Williamsburg, at the usual time and place. The largest number present at any time was about six or seven hundred, all of whom behaved in an orderly manner. Two men, who were arguing on religious matters, were about coming to blows, when they were arrested and taken to the lock-up.

Fuit Ilium ! Troy was, and so was Sleepy Hollow ! Troy is not, and Sleepy Hollow is no longer sleepy. That spot which IRVING'S genius has consecrated to memories of Katrina Van Tassol, Ichabod Crane and Brom Bones, is verily no mere myth or valley of Rasselas, but a granite based reality. We cannot vouch for the Headless Horse.

The Fourth of July was celebrated at Alexandria, in this State, with great eclat. There was a grand review of military, and an oration of a highly eloquent and impressive character was delivered by MERCER CANFIELD, Esq. Dinner was then announced, and this being finished, tile ladies retired, the company were reseated, toasts announced, and every thing was going on joyously, when a disturbance was heard, and very soon afterwards the report of a pistol.

The steamship North Star, Capt. R. A. WAMAEK, of the Independent Line, left New York on the 5th, at 3 P.M. From the 5th to the 9th she was favored with fine weather, the remainder of the passage was accompanied with a heavy sea and easterly winds. Arrived at Aspinwall on the 13th at 11 P.M., after a passage of 8 days and 8 hours.

DEATH OF MAJOR-GENERAL TOWSON.--We are pained to have to announce the death yesterday, from paralysis, of Gen. NATHAN TOWSON, Paymaster General of the Army. The name of this gallant and distinguished officer is intimately associated with almost every brilliant action upon the Niagara frontier from the commencement to the close of the war of 1812-'15.

DEATH OF GURDON WILLIAMS, ESQ.--Died, a his residence in this city, at 1 1/2 o'clock, yesterday morning, GURDON WILLIAMS, Esq. The deceased was born at Ledyard, in the County of New-London, and State of Connecticut, on the 28th day of March, 1791, and left his father's home at the age of 21 years.

The steamship Black Warrior arrived at Mobile yesterday, with Havana dates to the 16th inst. She confirms the loss or the steamer J. C. Lee, bound to Nicaragua, which vessel exploded her boiler off Cape Antonio on the 3d, and sunk. The captain and crew were saved.

The people of our Northern States are strongly inclined to reverence Books, and to lay very great stress on Book-culture. There is an idea among them that Books rule the world, and hence, if anything can be reduced to Logic and Philosophy, its victory over error and evil is certain.

CLOSE SAILING OF CLIPPER SHIPS.--Our morning and evening editions of yesterday report the arrival of the celebrated clipper ships Wild Pigeon, built by GEORGE RAYNES, of Portsmouth; the Sweepstakes, built by WESTERVELT, of New-York, and the Flying Fish, built by DONALD McKAY, of Boston.

Mr. PETIT made a personal explanation in reply to Mr. BENTON's letter, in which he (PETIT) was referred to as a "great liar" and a "dirty dog." He said that if he did not show Col. BENTON to be a wicked and malicious falsifyer of truth. an imbecile and a dotard, he would be content to deserve the epithets Mr. BENTON had applied to him.

The United States Mail steamer Illinois sailed from Aspinwall, at 10 o'clock on the 16th instant, eleven hours after the sailing of steamer North Star. Crossing the Carribbean Sea, experienced strong head winds, with heavy sea. DIED-July 17, THOMAS FLECK, a passenger from San Francisco, by steamer Uncle Sam; 18th, JOHN FAMOR, laborer on the Panama Railroad.

New-Orleans papers of Tuesday last are received. They contain late Texas dates; the news being mainly accounts of Indian forays along the frontiers. New-Orleans was quite healthy. The deaths during the week ending 16th, being only 129. The deaths in Baltimore during the past week were 174-none from cholera.

Richmond, which was made doubly interesting by the Queen sending from the Throne Room in the Palace full-length portraits of herself and Prince ALBERT to place by the side of that of WASSHINGTON; a compliment which I cannot too highly appreciate.

The Twenty-second Anniversary exercises of Burr Seminary have just drawn to a close, and although the weather has been excessively warm, a large number of the Alumni and friends of the Institution were present. The Secretary of War performs a painful duty in announcing to the army the death of Brevet Major-General NATHAN TOWSON, Paymaster General, who, after a protracted illness, has just closed his earthly career at his residence in this city. The character of this gallant soldier and pure-minded gentleman needs no labored enlogy.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: SIR: I have learned with pain that much dissatisfaction has been expressed by the friends of my father-in-law, the last Justice MERRITT, with the course of treatment pursued by his physician, Dr. JOHNS, during his last illness.

Reports having reached here on Saturday of the sudden outbreak of cholera at Niagara Falls, Drs. HAMILTON and HUNT repaired to the spot, and found it aging among the Irish laborers, on the Canal and the ? grounds at the Suspension Bridge.

The Washington Union asks: "In the illustrious roll of our patriot Presidents where, since the days of WASHINGTON, will history point to one more 'clear in his high office' the FRANKLIN PIERCE? 'In pace deuces, in dacas prasidium."

Conviction for Illegal Voting at the Late Water Election--Interesting Question as to the Legality of that Election. In the Kings County Court of Sessions, held in Brooklyn yesterday, Patrick Byrne, arrested by Constable Mundell, for illegally voting at the Water-election, held June 1, 1854, in the Third District of the Sixth Ward, Brooklyn, was placed at the bar for trial on an indictment for that offence.

CASTLE GARDEN.--"Louisa Miller," perhaps the most successful Opera ever produced in America, will be repeated to-night. The change in the atmosphere will, no doubt, influence the audience, which, to speak the truth, has been, for the last few nights, of the scantiest, A novelty like this late production of VERDI should not be neglected.

LETTER FROM ST. PETERSBURG.--An American gentleman, who is now on a visit to St. Petersburg, writes a letter to the editor of the New-Bedford Mercury, from which we take the following: The fortifications at Cronstadt are very strong, and NATIER will have a warm reception. English boasting produces considerable merriment here.

Yesterday morning, between 8 and 9 o'clock, a fire occurred on Second, between Almond and Popular streets, of consumed the composition rooting manufactory of Messrs. C. M. H. M. WARREN, No. 127 Second-street, with a number of other contiguous small buildings and out houses.

Some time since we alluded to the proposed erection of a large hotel at Niagara Falls, to be conducted by Mr. J. L. MITCHELL, of Congress Hall, Albany. The subscriptions to the capital stock have been so liberal as to justify the immediate erection of the buildings, the foundations of which will be laid this September.

The second Annual Commencement of the Free Academy of this City transpired yesterday at NIBLO's, commencing at 10 o'clock A. M. The entire spacious building was filled at an early hour' with hosts of interested and animated spectators.

Everybody in our county is interested more or less in the proceedings of Congress, and ordinarily, its debates attract a good share of public attention. But it is surprising, nevertheless, that so many evils should exist in it, and yet go uncorrected.

The Senate ratified the Russian Treaty immediately on receiving it. It guarantees the neutrality of the United States in the present war, and establishes as a principle of national law, that free ships make free goods, and that the property of neutrals, unless contraband of war, shall be respected, even when on board of enemy's vessels.

On Saturday and yesterday, exciting rumors were circulated respecting the sudden breaking out of cholera among the Irish laborers at the Suspension Bridge at the Fails, and the reports gathered confirmation when two of our leading medical men, Drs. HAMILTON and HUNT, were requested to repair to the spot to render assistance to the sick.
The celebration of the Anniversary of the Associate alumni was held on Monday evening, in the chapel of the Free Academy. The exercises of the evening were opened with prayer by Rev. THEODORE CUYLER.

WHAT IS THE MATTER?--Mr. ESTABROOK, the Brooklyn City Comptroller, says that he has advertised for sale the bonds of the city for erecting an Armory, to the amount of $50,000, but that he has only received bids at par for $5,500--for the balance no bids have been made at all.

The Chicago Tribune of Saturday states, that on Thursday last a fearful hurricane visited Davenport The steamer Ben Campbell had her pipes blown down. The steamers Golden Gate and Emma Harmon had their entire upper cabins blown off, and on the latter two persons were killed.
If a citizen go into the country now, almost the first question asked him is concerning the extent and fatality of the cholera here.

On our way across the Isthmus, at Obispo, the present termination of the Railroad, a disturbance occurred which resulted in the infliction of sundry severe wounds on these engaged. It originated in the robbery of a man whose name I have forgotten, and who died on his way across the Isthmus, just before reaching Obispo.

CASE OF NEGLECT.--An instance of cruel neglect transpired on Sunday and Monday last. A German laborer employed at Cochecton, on the New-York and Eric Railroad, while at work in a gravel hole had one of his legs broken or fractured, and badly, bruised, just below the knee.

The Commencement exercises of Hamilton College are now in progress. Last evening Prof. J. B. CONDIT, of Lane Seminary, addressed the Society of Christian Research. To-day, at 2 P. M., Rev. Dr. JOEL PARKER, of New-York, addressed the Anti-Secret Society.

The past week has been one of remarkably severe heat, standing out in this respect from the marked weeks of ordinary seasons. Thursday, Friday and Saturday last were the hottest days, and on each of these, thermometers went above 100 in the shade in this and most other of the exposed towns and cities of all this section of the Union.

MR. EDITOR: Noticing a communication in your paper of yesterday, (21st inst.,) animadverting rather severely, and I think very unjustly in some points, upon the "condition of the Erie County Poor-House," it is thought best to set the community right, as some of these charges are false and others grossly perverted.

Talmadge for the defendant, and Mr. Charles W. Sandford for the plaintiffs. We give a brief abstract of the points made on each side.

It rains. Schenectady is fully full. There is no telling how many houseless people are even now traveling the streets of this hospitable, wide-spread-out, and comfortable town--drenched, umbrellaless, and hungry.

The English journals are just now unusually full of eye-witnessed intelligence from the various seats of war, highly encouraging to the allies, and very dispiriting for the Russians. This is natural, and even necessary.

A large shoe firm in Pearl-street, in this city, was I forced to suspend payment to-day. Liabilities stated at $3G0,000, but the assets are much larger; and it is believed they will resume in a few days.

To the Pupils of the School of Design for Women: I beg to acknowledge your very gratifying letter in the public journals, to myself, Miss CHASE, and your talented instructor in wood-engraving, Mr. HERRICK, under whose direction many of your have produced excellent wood-engravings.

A Russian agent, said to be on his way to the United States, has made up a variety of statements and representations concerning the inclinations of the CZAR, the progress of the war, , , to be laid before the people of this country in advance of his arrival. They are contained in a letter from the Paris correspondent of the Tribune, to whom they were communicated for publication.

The Philomathean and Adelplin Literary Societies held their Anniversary this evening, in the Dutch Reformed Church, in Union-street. The house was very full. The Orator was WENDELL PHILLIPS, of Boston; the Poet, JOHN G. SAXE, of Burlington, Vt. A tolerably strong team, that.

THE BRAND OF CAIN.--The editor of the Philadelphia Courier says: While at the "Burning Spring," near Niagara, a few days ago, we were requested to enter the names of our party in the Visitor's Register, and while complying, we observed that the registry had been suspended at about two-thirds down on the left and page, and then continued at the top of he right.

Both Houses were busy yesterday, and both transacted a variety of important business. The bill creating a Collection District in this State making Dunkirk a port of entry, and other places in the District ports of delivery, was, in the Senate, reported back to the House, passed.
The Eagle has avenged itself upon the insect that dared to seek justice in spite of Jove's bird. The elephant has healed his honor that was wounded by a writhing worm, by crushing its life out.

The steamship Isabel has arrived here, having left Havana on the morning of the 22d, and Key West the same evening. On Sunday evening P. MERZER, a passenger, fell over board and was drowned. There is no political news from Havana.

Special Meeting of the Board of Aldermen. A Special Meeting of the Board, of Aldermen was called yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of acting upon certain assessment lists, for making sewers, flagging sidewalks, , and to consider a report and resolution from the Board of Councilmen, in favor of cancelling the contract for building a sewer in Forth-ninth-street, Second-avenue, Fifty-third-street, and Third-avenue, and re-letting the same.

THE RECENT HOMICIDE AT ROUNDOUT--VERDICT OF THE CORONER'S JURY.--An inquest was held yesterday upon the body of EDWARD WELSH who was shot at Roundout on Sunday right, by CONSTABLE ALBERT MALOY of that place. The inquest commenced at 7 o'clock in the morning, and lasted until 8 o'clock in the evening.

In this city, on Tuesday morning, at 81/2 o'clock, after a lingering illness, Mrs SARAH CHATTERTON, in the 54th year of her age. Her relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend her funeral from her late residence. No. 62 Wooster??t.. on Wednesday afternoon, at 1 o'clock. In this City, on Tuesday, July 25, ROBERT PORTER.

One of the most destructive hail-storms passed over the north part of the town of Addison, in this County, yesterday, ever known in this region. It commenced near the west line of the town, extending over a territory about two miles wide, proceeding thence east across the town, and going out of the County near the northeast corner.

MINNIE MYRTLE writes to the Courier and Enquirer, as follows: I have to-day, for the first time, read your criticism of "Myrtle Wreath," and was amused to see the exposition of the author's "Womanly fallacies," in the article on "Conversation as an Art." It did not give her a single pang, for she never spoke more truly than when she disclaimed all pretensions to logic and learning.

The Union of Wednesday has an article on the Cuba question. We are listening now attentively for a San Juan editorial. We are anxious to hear how the Administration carries itself on this glorious victory over a unarmed, undefended town.

THE RECENT ATTACK ON THE CLERK OF CENSUS BUREAU--FURTHER PARTICULARS.--Yesterday afternoon, about 2 o'clock, a young female entered the office of the Census Bureau, pistol in hand, threatening to shoot one of the clerks, talking furiously and vulgarly to all in hearing against the aforesaid gentleman, whom she accuses of dire injuries to her honor.

The Election in this Territory is over. The canvass was conducted with great vigor, though in general with good feeling. Two parties, and in some counties three, were fairly in the field. The chief issue was the State Government question. So far as the returns have been seen here, it is clear that the Whigs are greatly in the minority-although the Democrats have not so complete and undivided sway as they have hitherto claimed.

DEATH OF THE LAST OF THE SURVIVORS OF THE MASSACRE OF FORT GRISWOLD.--Dr. AVERY DOWNER died at his residence in Preston on Saturday night last, at the age of nearly ninety-two. He had been in the regular practice of his profession as a physician for full seventy years, and respected to the last for his professional character.

PRESENCE OF MIND.--On Wednesday morning, last week, Mr. JONATHAN T. REED, of Westchester, started in the cars of Paoli, intending there to take the Western line of Juniata county, on a visit to his friends. He had with him his son, as active, intelligent lad, of about 13 years of age.

From the Louisville Journal. A novel case cam up in the city Court yesterday. A bright mulatto woman had a son about 5 years old. She lived with a negro man named SANDY NELSON, who disliked the boy, and she gave him in charge of an old negro man and woman. The boy is now about 10 years old, has evidently been well cared for, and the old couple feel much attached to him.

Ill health drove me, a few months since, from your city, since which I have traveled over a very large portion of Iowa-indeed, nearly all of what is called Southern Iowa, comprising that part of the State included between the Mississippi and Missouri rivers on the East and West, the Missouri State line on the South, and the north line of the third tier of counties on the North.

Since I last wrote you we have been in the midst of war and bloodshed, with our lives not a little in peril. Sad, indeed, has been the state of things here since last September, and through the whole Winter human blood has been poured out without stint or measure.

We have before us a pamphlet giving a highly increasing and detailed account of experiments with the improved mode of using steam invented by Messrs. WETHERED BROTHER, of working "stam" or "stame," but in using a mixture of saturated and super-heated steam. The mode of obtaining this mixture was briefly stated y us yesterday, and is very simple.

A process for the arrest of Mr. BOOTH was issued on the 11th. Marshal ABLEMAN arrived in this city on Tuesday, and yesterday morning arrested the defendant in his office, and lock him to the office of the Clerk. Mr. BOOTH offered Dr. WENDERLY as bail, bat the Clerk doubted the propriety of accepting the Doctor, as he was bail before, and had surrendered the defendant and been discharged.

MESSRS. EDITORS: The Santa Fe and El Paso mail, in charge of Capt. B. DAILEY, a rivod here on last Monday morning, having performed the trip through in twenty-five days, and traveling very little at night. The Indians made an attack on the mail going up at Eagle Spring.

TO THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES OF THE UNITED STATES. The memorial of the Wheeling and Belmont Bridge Company respectfully showeth: That for five years your memorialists, and through them a large community, have been the objects of an unrelenting persecution, pursued under the forms of the judicial process of the United States.

STRANGE OCCURRENCE.--On Thursday, a large party, mostly Germans, went on a pic-nic excursion to the Miami Grove up the river, on the steamer Champion. They were accompanied by a band of music, and the principal amusement was dancing. During the day a German by the name of CHOLER was taken suddenly ill, and died on the boat while returning to the city.

From the Boston Courier. The death of the Secretary of the Prison Discipline Society will excite wide-spread regret. To him, this Society owed its origin and universal efficiency. From the time of its organization, in this city, in 1825, he has been its Secretary, and every year has appeared his annual report, with its accurate statistics, its warm, energetic, philanthropic and Christian remarks, its important suggestions and encouraging statements.

In this City, on Tuesday, July 25, at 7 o'clock P.M. NA. THANIEL C. PLATT, of consumption, aged 61 years, 1 month and 23 days. The funeral will take place from his late residence. No. 27 Hudson place, 34th-st., on Thursday, 27, inst., at 2 o'clock P.M.

MAN LOST IN THE WOODS.-A man named JOHN ROBINSON, residing in the village of Raw don, and who was employed in the survey conducted by Mr. QUINN, lost his way in the woods, and was missing for twelve days. By the praiseworthy exertions of Rev. CHAS. ROLLETT, an Episcopal minister, the man was found in a state of extreme exhaustion;

Yesterday, Hon, GEO. HASTINGS, of Mount Morris, addressed the Alumni of Hamilton College at Clinton. In the afternoon Hon, G. A. SCOFIELD of Pa. delivered an Address before the Annual Convention of the Alpha Delta Phi, and ALFRED B. STREET, of Albany, recited a Poem illustrating American themes for poetry.

The Phi Beta Kappa Society held its anniversary in the Presbyterian Church, at the con elusion of the Delta Phi celebration. The orator was JAMES S. THAYER, Esq., of New-York. His theme was of political bent, but conservative and constitutional. Mr. THAYER argued the want of new principles in society, or a contination of them that will tend to its improvement.

At noon yesterday the alarm of fire was given. The church bells rang long and loud--no ordinary fire raged. The day, exceedingly hot, above 90 Degree in the shade, resembled the 28th of May, 18.15. Arrived at the Church of St. Rochs, on which the fire engines were pouring a stream of water, the conflagration did seem to us to threaten with destruction the whole of St. Rochs.

The School Officers of the Thirteenth Ward, having deemed it necessary to tear down the old house, occupied by School District No. 4, and build a more commodious one, yesterday celebrated the laying of the corner-stone with proper observances. The new house occupies the same site as the old one, in Rivington-street.

From the Petersburg (Va.) Intelligencer. Mrs. MARTHA VERNON, the elderly lady who made complaint before the Mayor just one week since, returned to this city last Saturday for the purpose of entering suite against A. V. SPRALDING, who is now incarcerated on the charge of abducting and seducing her daughter under the promise of marriage.

It has become common for speakers and writers to characterize the whole country as running mad in the pursuit of wealth. According to their short and pithy creed, the entire community hold the Dollar in sacramental reverence, and, with a spice of profanity, it is capitalized as the "Almighty" Dollar.

The Omaha Arrow is the name of a new paper proposed to be published at Omaha City, in Nebraska Territory, nearly opposite Council Bluff City. A town has recently been laid off there. It is said to be a very eligible site, and preparations are going on for extensive improvements.

In the Senate to-day the reading of the Journal was dispensed with. Mr. BRODHEAD reported the bill for the relief of DAVID F. DOUGLASS, late Marshal for the Northern District of California. Passed. The numerous private bills passed by the House on Saturday and Monday were taken up, severally read twice and referred. A few of them passed.

BROADWAY THEATRE.--Notwithstanding the extreme heat of the weather, and the fact that the prices of admission were doubled to all parts of the house, the Roadway Theatre was last night filled with one of the largest audiences we have ever seen within its walls. The occasion was the Farewell Benefit tendered to Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS, previous to their departure for California.

NUMBER VIII. There is nothing more amusing in Saratoga life than the variety of consciences one meets. There is everything to tempt one from the straight and narrow path, and there are very few who continually walk within what they have been in the habit of considering or defining to be the limits of this path.

EXTENSIVE CONFLAGRATION.--The most extensive fire which has occurred in our city for the past five years took place at noon yesterday. Before its ravages were stayed, about fifteen stone and brick, and several wooden houses, were totally consumed. The fire broke out in an hay-loft in rear of Mr. GASPARD GARNEAU'S house.

A distinguished English gentleman, who has spent many years as a resident or in traveling in various Papal countries in Europe, in a recent speech in London, has presented some deeply interesting facts concerning vice and crime in Papal and Protestant countries. He possessed himself of the Government returns of every Romanist Government on the continent. We have condensed and will state its results.

By the way, we have made a discovery in the ratline, which we hasten to announce. It has been ? umphontly asked--"Of what use are rats?" and ? has answered--"Of what use?" But if any one will look at the window of Scott Bell's Sugar Brokerage No. 911 Wall-street, after they have closed for the ? be will see a rat inside of the window catching, fleas at an astonishing rate.

ATTEMPTED ABDUCTION AT BIRKENHEAD.--A few days age, a heard-headed sinner, who has numbered upwards of sixty years, and who is the father of a numerous family at Plymouth, after seducing a young woman, attempted to take her off to Canada, and had nearly succeeded in his disgraceful object.

NARROW ESCPE FROM DROWNING.--GILES W. HILTON, a gentleman from New-York, who is visiting in this city, with his lady, went out on a pleasure excursion yesterday, on the river in a skiff. When above Bath, by some mismanagement the boat cardened and threw the party, two gentlemen and three ladies, into the water, which was very deep.

The Late Mr. Lysander Thompson. The melancholy particulars which we published yesterday, of the pecuniary position of Mr. THOMPSON'S window and family, have elicited a response from a gentleman (signing himself "Cockney,") who encloses a dollar bill for their use.

A SAD SIGHT.--There are many of them now-a-days, no doubt, but not always as public as the one which has just. affected us-to tears. A German immigrant. with no mental development in proportion to his physical frame, sitting on the side walk, weeping over a dying child in his arms, with two others standing near him, and all in the hot burning sun.

A lecture way delivered in this Church, on the corner of Tillary and Lawrence-streets, Brooklyn, Tuesday evening, by Rev. Mr. WELSH, formerly a Roman Catholic Priest, and as he expressed himself, one of the most bigotted. The audience in attendance was not large, but very orderly.

THE "SAUSAGE ROW" MURDER,"--JOHN CASES was charged with the murder of MICHAEL MURPHY , in the Police Court yesterday. The entire of the case showed the following to be particulars of the affray: On Tuesday afternoon, a man named MICHAEL CONNOR asked CASEY to drink; a latter refused the first time, but a second request they drank together.

Thomas Conner, indicted, with Charles McGlone, (heretofore convicted,) and James O'Neil and Michael Ryan, for robbing Mr. John Nelson, at the corner of Court and Bergen-streets, on the night of the 30th of April last, was tried and convicted of simply assault and battery, in the Kings County Court of Sessions, held in the City Hall, Brooklyn Yesterday.

If a ghost ever appears to us, we hope it will be that of THOMAS W. SWEETZER, or we want good spirits, if any, to confront our startled visions. We don't know Mr. SWEETZER'S habits or creed. He may have taken a poor newspaper, been fond of Scotch snuff, and even approved of Abolitionism, for anything that at present recurs to us.

Yesterday afternoon the doors of the "Mountaineer," on Commercial-street, were crowded with persons anxious to see how HUGHES looked, as the hour approached at which the extraordinary pedestrian feat of walking for eighty consecutive hours without stopping, which he had undertaken, should be accomplished.

It is a breach of trust, certainly. If a man gives us a speech as if it were his own and wins our applause, when we discover that i. was "prigged," we feel that he has obtained our approbation under false pretences. So here is another sin to be laid at his door.

My allusion to the Postmaster Generals very singular curse of proceeding with reference to the California mail service, see us to have "stirred up the animals" consideady; and ?? day the stipendiary organ of the Administration ?? its allotted "duty" in endeavoring to avert from Mr. CAMPBELL'S head the effects of the blow aimed at him, and which for one I certainly believe was deserved

There was a wedding at Wiliwyk on the 4th, JOHN W. TYLER, of parts unknown, being married by Rev. Mr. FORT, of Wiltwyck Chapel, to Miss SARAH PERMELIA POST, of Esopus. The bridegroom is a real live Yankee, of some forty years, of intense activity, who has been prowling around this and neighboring counties for some yers, teaching juveniles to sing, and giving concerts of his pupils.

A correspondence at Rome writes as follows: One of the many robberies committed last Winter on the road from Civita Vecchia to this city was on the carriage of two English ladies, named IRELAND. The position who drove the horses from the station to Castel-Guidi pretended to arrange the harness, when the brigands appeared, and completely pillaged the carriage.

ALEXANDER got Poland by playing the liberal, and displaying a wonderful respect for nationality and constitutionalism. A true Russian, like NICHOLAS, could not go this length. The word constitution might not suit his mouth. But he might preach the independence of the Slavons, and far outbid even English, French and Austrian intentions for the independence of both Cis and Trans-Danubians.

At the Niagara Suspension Bridge yesterday, there were four deaths from Cholera on the American side, and eight on the Canadian. The disease is abating, and numerous cases were yesterday reported convalescent.

TO THE PEOPLE OF ST. LOUIS--Citizens; I feel it incumbent upon me to discharge a public duly in making known to you the conduct of one of our Members of Congress on a subject which concerns your interest, and on which your interest was attempted to be sacrificed from unworthy motives. I speak of Mr. JOHN S. PHELPS, and his secret opposition to the appropriation for the St. Louis Custom-House.

By the arrival at this port of the bark Venus from the above port, we have dates to 14th July. The island was perfectly healthy. There had not been any rain for some time past. Salt was very plenty, but there was no demand for it. It could be bought for 40 cen's per barrel.

THE GRAPE CROP.--The season has not been the most favorable for our vineyards. During the last week we have visited some vineyards and made diligent inquiry concerning all, with a view to ascertain the prospects of the coming crop. Among the vineyards on the hills and slopes in Slopes townships, the grapes are fine, and promise rather more than an average crop.

The London Medical Times and Gazette, for May, furnishes an interesting account of a man who had a bayonet forced through his body, and recovered without any unpleasant symptoms. It appears that foiled, when, to make his escape, he rushed across the barrack square towards a gate where a sentry was on duty.

If the "desperately hot" weather permit, I purpose to give you a few items of general interest respecting this ancient Dutch settlement. However, with the mercury ranging from 78[degree] on 98[degree] in the shade, during the sixteen hours of sunshine, you will not expect much exertion on my part. DANIEL COOPER (says GORDON,) was the first recorded inhabitant of "Prigmore's Swamp."

Several additional amendments to the Civil and Diplomatic bill were offered in the Senate, yesterday, increasing the appropriation; one for Custom-Houses and Hospitals, and another to purchase life boats for Lake Michigan were adopted.

Mayor WESTERVELT, acting for the sovereign people and entirely according to their behests, has awfully blundered. The Dog Law is a shameful error. The pound ought to be abolished, for dogs have come up in the social scale. They are not mad. Hydrophobia has ceased to prevail.

NEW-ORLEANS "SOLITARY AND ALONE. "--We referred on Saturday to the novel fact, that many of our citizens were deterred from leaving New-Orleans on account of the prevalence of the cholera in the West and North. We have since ascertained that many persons in the country are coming to this city to escape terrible pestilence.

NORDURFARI; OR, RAMBLES IN ICELAND. BY PLINY MILES. New-York: CHARLES B. NORTON. pp. 334. 12mo. The very title is refreshing. It is not less pleasant than to read of icebergs floating past the outlet of our harbor, or the presence of a cool breeze on the evening of such days as we boiled in last week.

"SCHUYLERISM."--The sentiment of the following paragraph from the Providence Journal (says the Boston Davy Advertiser) will command the Sympathy of all just and discriminating people. There have been many SCHUYLERS honest and but one a range:

The following precious piece of scandal is from the correspondent of the National Democrat: LONDON, Tuesday, July 11, 1851. Your old friend DICKENS, whom you recovered with such princely honor, and who assuredly repaid you with more than princely ingratitude, has again "gone to the Continent;" in other words, has been obliged to give the constable "leg-bail," in order to escape the penalty of his debts.

In this City, on Thursday, July 27, suddenly, in the 48th year of her age, ELIZABETH H., consort of Clarkson Crolius. His friends and those of her brothers, John M and Divia Seaman, are invited to attend the funeral, this afternoon, at 3 o'clock, without further invitation, from her late residence No. 50 2d-st. The remains will be interred in Greet wood Cemetery.

Kings County Board of Superviors. An adjuourned meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held last evening. Supervisor BERGEN presented a communication from the keeper of Kings County Penitentiary at Flatbush, in which it is stated that fourteen convicts escaped between June 10, 1853, to July 27, 1854. Only two of the whole number have been retaken.

Before the Phi Beta Kappa of Yale College, July 26, 1854. GENTLEMAN: A political discourse may seem out of time and out of place at a classic festival and in academic groves. Nevertheless, the office of instructor to a prince brought something more of dignity even to the learning and piety of FENELON.

In Brooklyn, on Wednesday evening, July 26. by Rev. Spencer L. Finney, Mr. J. B. MURDOCK., of St. Joseph, La, to Miss ANNA MURDOCK, of the farmer place. At Williamsburg, L I., on Wednesday. July 26. by Rev. Chas. Reynolds, THOMAS BURROUGHS ROACH, of the City of New-York, to ELLA, daughter of Mr. Heary Waterman, of Williamsburg.
